Africa News


January 10, 1994 / January 17, 1994


CURRENCY EXCHANGE RATES


LENGTH: 1490 words


 

Maxwell Stamp PLC

Economic Consultants

London * Nairobi * Riyadh * Mauritius

The table gives selected currencies valued against the major international trading currencies. Rates quoted are the middle rates between buying and selling, but currencies are in most cases not freely traded. These rates have been compiled by Maxwell Stamp PLC for information only. Maxwell Stamp accepts no responsibility for any transaction undertaken on the basis of these figures. For further information please contact John Morgan at Maxwell Stamp's Head Office in London; phone 44-71-251-0147; telex 914569 MAXAMP G; fax 44-71-251-0140. 

*CFA Franc = Benin, Burkina Faso, Cameroon, Central African Republic, Chad, Comoros, Congo, Cote d'Ivoire, Equatorial Guinea, Gabon, Mali, Niger, Senegal, Togo.

** commercial rate

$ L DM

Algeria Dinar (AD) 23.9993 35.7830 13.8564

BUSINESS


LENGTH: 1187 words


 

The following procurement opportunities in Egypt are available to U.S. companies through the U.S. Agency for International Development.

* Digital Equipment Corporation Computer Spare Parts. A.I.D. Project # 263-0132. A.I.D. Geographic Code 000 (U.S. only). RFQ # 200001-118. Purchaser: Geonex Corporation, International Operations/Egypt Project, 8950 Ninth St., North, St. Petersburg, FL 33702, Attn: Ionia Lyons; phone (813) 578-0100 or Frank Hanigan (Geonex Int'l); phone 20-2-716-364. BID DEADLINE: FEBRUARY 1, 1994. Write to the above address and send $20.00 non- refundable fee to obtain a copy of the solicitation. Estimated delivery date is April 1, 1994. Telephone and fax requests will not be honored. 

 

* IBM Compatible Personal Computers. A.I.D. Project # 263-0132. RFQ # 200001-119. A.I.D. Geographic Code 000 (U.S. only). Purchaser: Geonex Corporation, International Operations/Egypt Project, 8950 Ninth St., North, St. Petersburg, FL 33702, Attn: Ionia Lyons; phone (813) 578- 0100 or Frank Hanigan (Geonex Int'l); phone 20-2-716-364. BID DEADLINE: FEBRUARY 1, 1994. Write to the above address and send $20.00 non-refundable fee to obtain a copy of the solicitation. Estimated delivery date is April 1, 1994. Telephone and fax requests will not be honored.

*Three Ambulances. I.F.B. # ENR/4-94/ARE. A.I.D. Geographic Code 000 (U.S. only). Purchasing Agent: Egyptian National Railways. BID OPENING: February 21, 1994. Write to the Embassy of the Arab Republic of Egypt, 2232 Massachusetts Avenue, NW, Washington, DC 20008. Write to the above address and send $20.00 non-refundable fee to obtain a copy of the solicitation.

*Management Information Computer System. IFB #: CU/5- 94/ARE. A.I.D. Geographic Code 000 (U.S. only). Purchasing Agent: Cairo University, Kasr El-Eini Hospital. BID OPENING: February 28, 1994. Write to the Embassy of the Arab Republic of Egypt, 2232 Massachusetts Avenue, NW, Washington, DC 20008. Write to the above address and send $20.00 non-refundable fee to obtain a copy of the solicitation.

*Scientific Apparatus for the Chemistry, Botany, Physics, Mathematics, Geology, Zoology Depts. IFB #: ASUT-SOHAG/6-94/ARE. A.I.D. Geographic Code 000 (U.S.

only). Purchasing Agent: Assuit University, Sohag Branch. BID OPENING: March 1, 1994. Write to the Embassy of the Arab Republic of Egypt, 2232 Massachusetts Avenue, NW, Washington, DC 20008. Write to the above address and send $20.00 non-refundable fee to obtain a copy of the solicitation.

*Condenser and Heat Exchanger Tubes. IFB #: EEA/7- 94/ARE. A.I.D. Geographic Code 000 (U.S. only). Purchasing Agent: Egyptian Electricity Authority. BID OPENING: March 2, 1994. Write to the Embassy of the Arab Republic of Egypt, 2232 Massachusetts Avenue, NW, Washington, DC 20008. Write to the above address and send $20.00 non-refundable fee to obtain a copy of the solicitation.

*85 Lightening Arrestors. IFB #: EEA/8-94/ARE. A.I.D. Geographic Code 000 (U.S. only). Purchasing Agent: Egyptian Electricity Authority. BID OPENING: March 3, 1994. Write to the Embassy of the Arab Republic of Egypt, 2232 Massachusetts Avenue, NW, Washington, DC 20008. Write to the above address and send $20.00 non-refundable fee to obtain a copy of the solicitation.

The following procurement opportunity in Nairobi is available to U.S. companies through U.S.A.I.D.

* PVC and Steel Pipes and Fittings. A.I.D. Project # 612-0231. A.I.D. Geographic Code 935 (Selected Free World). RFP # REDSO/ESA RFP 623-94-P-006. Purchaser: REDSO/ESA/CM, Unit 64102, APO AE 09831-41021, Attn: Christine Lyons, RCMO, or Richard Webber, Contracting Officer; Fax: 011-254-2-219301/330945. BID DEADLINE: FEBRUARY 2, 1994. Write to the above address to obtain a copy of this RFQ. Telephone requests will not be honored.

The following procurement opportunity in Madagascar is available to U.S. companies through U.S.A.I.D.

*Notebook Computers, Desktop Computers, Computer Peripherals, Laser Printers, Ink Jet Printers, Color Scanner, Bar Code Reader, Overhead Projector, Color LCD Display Panel, Computer Software. A.I.D. Project: 687(Special Free World). BID OPENING: January 20, 1994. 0107. I.F.B. #: A0700/001. A.I.D. Geographic Code 935 Purchasing Agent: Management Science for Health, 400 Centre St., Newton Corner, MA 02158. Attn: Glen Davis. Tel:(617) 527-9202. Fax: (617) 965-2208.

3 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 10, 1994 / January 17, 1994


EDUCATION/TRAVEL


LENGTH: 3894 words


 

The International Bicycle Fund will sponsor a two-week, people-to-people, bicycle and train tours in Tunisia in March and April, 1994. Tour participants will meet craftsmen, educators, officials, and learn about day-to-day life in the villages. Contact: International Bicycle Fund, 4887 Columbia Dr. South. Seattle, WA 98108-1919.

Wells College will sponsor a course, "Senegalese" Society, Culture and Politics", which will introduce students to the complexity of Senegalese society, culture and politics. Most lectures will be held at the

Universite Cheikh Ahta Diop in Dakar. Contact: Tukumbi Lumumba-Kasongo, Political Science, P.O. Box 345, Wells College, Aurora, NY 13026; phone: (315) 463-3220. 

 

The Africa Fund continues to offer full- and part-time internships in its New York office. Activities often include research, data-base maintenance, filing, and information distribution. Contact: Adrene Ifill, The Africa Fund, 198 Broadway, New York, NY 10038; phone: (212) 962-1210.

The African Development Foundation offers Gray Senior Fellowships to African Academics and development professionals who have demonstrated a commitment to grass-roots development. Contact: African Development Foundation, 1400 Eye Street, N.W., 10th Floor, Washington, DC 20005; phone: (202) 673-3916.

The American Association of University Women Educational Foundation provides fellowships for graduate study in the U.S. to women who are not citizens or permanent residents of the U.S. Preference given to women demonstrating a prior commitment to improving the lives of women and girls, and applicants focusing their project on the advancement of women. Contact: AAUW Educational Foundation, 2401 Virginia Avenue, N.W., Washington, DC 20037.

The American University in Cairo is offering African Fellowships for two years of study toward an AUC Masters degree. Applicants from all disciplines are encouraged to apply. Contact: International Graduate Programs, Office of the Provost, American University in Cairo, P.O. Box 2511, 113 Kasr al Aini, Cairo, Egypt.

Boston University offers an opportunity to study in Niamey, Niger. Contact: Ned Quigley, Director, International Programs, Boston University, 232 Bay State Road, Boston, MA 02215; fax: (617) 353-5402.

The Center for Latin American Studies and the Center for African Studies invite junior and senior scholars to participate in an interdisciplinary program on Afro- American identity and cultural diversity in the Americas, including the Caribbean, Brazil, and the US, as well as areas of Africa. The program will enable visiting scholars to spend an year or a semester at the University of Florida to do research in this area. It will include studies of history, literature, religion, and popular culture. Each fellow will receive a maximum stipend of US$35,000 for the academic year, or half that for the semester. Applicants will be selected on a competitive basis related to their expertise and research in these areas. Candidates should submit a 100-word abstract, an essay of about 1,500 words detailing proposed research, a curriculum vitae, and two letters of recommendation. Send applications to Dr. Helen I. Safa, Center for Latin American Studies, University of Florida, P.O. Box 115530, Gainesville, FL 32611-5530; phone: (904) 392-0375; fax: (904) 392-7682.

The Council for Development of Social Science Research in Africa (CODESRIA) has a Small Grants Program for Thesis Writing to fund M.A. and Ph.D. candidates who are in the process of completing their theses. The funds will cover expenses in a country where research is conducted, but they will not cover the cost of travel to that country. For more information contact: Dr. Cyrus Reed, Office of African Studies, American University in Cairo, P.O. Box 2511, 113 Kasr al Aini, Cairo, Egypt.

The Frederick Douglass Institute for African and African-American Studies at the University of Rochester is calling for applications for its 1994-1995 Residential Fellowships. Available are one postdoctoral fellowship, one predoctoral dissertation fellowship, and two four- year fellowships for graduate study. Welcome projects include historical and contemporary topics on the economy, society, and culture of Africa and its diaspora, as well as projects on human and technological aspects of energy development and agriculture in Africa. DEADLINE: JANUARY 31, 1994. Contact: Associate Director for Research and Curriculum, Frederick Douglass Institute for African and African-American Studies, University of Rochester, 302 Morey Hall, Rochester, NY 14627; phone: (716) 275-7235.

The Fulbright Scholar Program offers a Fulbright Research Grant in conjunction with a ten-month position as Director of the West African Research Center in Dakar, Senegal. The WARC serves as a focal point of US-West African academic exchange. The grantee will manage the WARC as well as pursue independent research. Field experience in West Africa and/or experience administering overseas programs preferred. Fluent French and US citizenship required. The award will begin in October 1994. APPLICATION DEADLINE: JANUARY 15, 1994. Contact Christine Djondo, Council for International Exchange of Scholars, 3007 Tilden Street, N.W., Suite 5M, Washington, DC 20008-3009; phone: (202) 686-4028 or 686-4029; fax: (202) 362-3442.

Howard University's Center for the Study of Culture and Development in Africa offers a Resident Fellowship Program on Culture and Development. The theme of the program in 1994-1995 is "Gender, Cultural Production and Development in Africa." Two fellowships will be awarded, and fellows must be engaged in full-time research and be in residence at Howard University for the duration of the fellowship (August 1994-May 1995). Each full-year fellowship carries a stipend of US$30,000, plus $4,000 for relocation expenses, insurance, and other expenses. Limited funds are available for travel within the U.S. Candidates must have completed Ph.D. at the time of application. DEADLINE FOR RECEIPT OF APPLICATIONS AND ALL SUPPORTING DOCUMENTS: FEBRUARY 28, 1994. Contact: Director, Center for the Study of Culture and Development, Department of African Studies, Box 231, Howard University, Washington, DC 20059; phone: (202) 806-7115; fax: (202) 806-4425.

The International Bicycle Fund is sponsoring two two- week bicycle/train tours of Tunisia in March and April of 1994. The tours depart North America on March 29 and April 12. Land cost, including accommodations, meals, museum and monument fees and tour guide is US$1,090. Airfare is additional. IBF is also sponsoring bicycle tours of Uganda, February 1-17, 1994; and Zimbabwe, July 10-23, 1994 and July 24-August 6, 1994. Contact: IBF- Africa Program, 4887 Columbia Drive South, Seattle, WA 98108-1919; phone: (206) 628-9314; fax (manually activated): (206) 628-9314.

The International Foundation for Education and Self- Help's International Fellows Program encourages minority graduate students, as well as others, to participate in nine-month internships with self-help, economic development programs. Tuskegee University in Alabama implements the International Fellows Program through its office of International Programs. IFESH pays the cost of orientation, travel, health insurance and an overseas living allowance. APPLICATION DEADLINE: FEBRUARY 10, 1994. Contact: IFESH, 5040 East Shea Boulevard, Suite 260, Phoenix, AZ 85254-4610; phone: (602) 443-1800; fax: (602) 443-1824.

The IFESH is also recruiting teachers for its Teachers for Africa program designed to help improve education in Africa. This program sends educators to assist in African primary and secondary schools as well as African universities. Assignments are for one academic year. Seven years of teaching or administrative experience preferred. Must be U.S. citizens or permanent residents. IFESH is responsible for placement, orientation, round- trip transportation, insurance, and a living allowance while in Africa. DEADLINE: APRIL 4, 1994. Contact: IFESH, 5040 East Shea Boulevard, Suite 260, Phoenix, AZ 85254-4610; phone: (602) 443-1800; fax: (602) 443-1824.

The Johann Jacobs Foundation encourages African scholars to apply for support of doctoral research concerning youth in a changing world. Contact: The Johann Jacobs Foundation, Seefeldquai 17, P.O. Box 101, CH-8034, Zurich, Switzerland.

The William K. Kellogg Foundation offers international fellowships within its Initiatives in Leadership program. Study grants are available to southern Africans who are faculty or staff members of, and nominated by, an organization, institution or agency that has received funding or is being considered for funding by the Kellogg Foundation. Candidates should not already reside in the U.S. Contact: W.K. Kellogg Foundation, International Study Grant Office, One Michigan Avenue East, Battle Creek, MI 49017-4058; phone: (616) 968-1611.

The Margaret McNamara Memorial Fund invites applications for grants for women from developing countries who are studying in the United States and have a demonstrated interest in the problems and needs of women and children in their countries. DEADLINE: JANUARY 15, 1994. For application forms contact: Margaret McNamara Memorial Fund, 1818 H Street, N.W., Washington, D.C. 20433.

Michigan State University offers undergraduates the opportunity to spend a full academic year (March to December) at the University of Zimbabwe. Contact: John Metzler, 100 International Center, Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI 48824-1035; phone: (517) 353-1700.

Michigan State University Working Papers on Political Reform in Africa are designed to provide an outlet for the quick dissemination of research results and to promote an exchange of views on the process of political liberalization currently unfolding on the African continent. The editors, Michael Bratton and Nicolas van de Walle, welcome submissions focusing on political reform in Africa for possible publication in this series. Inquiries may be directed to: MSU Working Papers on Political Reform in Africa, Department of Political Science, MSU, East Lansing, MI 48824-1032. Phone: (517) 355-6590. Fax: (517) 336-1091.

The Modern Management Institute in Nairobi, Kenya offers a new home study method for learning Kiswahili, a language spoken in Kenya, Tanzania, Uganda, Malawi, Zambia, Zaire, Rwanda, Burundi, and the Sudan. The method includes a basic English/Kiswahili textbook for 24 lessons and audio cassettes to help with pronunciation. Contact: Geoffrey Njogu, Director of Studies, Modern Management Institute, P.O. Box 47390, Nairobi, Kenya; phone: (254.2) 33.17.02.

The Museum for African Art's "Discovering Africa" travel series continues this winter with trips to Cote d'Ivoire (January 17-28), Ghana/Benin (January 17-28), and Nigeria (February 15-March 2). Participants travel in small groups and focus intensely on the culture and people of Africa, meeting Africans who are leaders in the continent's art and politics. Contact: Jerry Vogel, The Museum for African Art, 593 Broadway, New York, NY 10012; phone: (212) 966-1313; fax: (212) 966-1432.

National Science Foundation Dissertation Improvement Grants support African graduate students who are enrolled in U.S. universities and are planning to undertake dissertation research related to a developing-country problem. Grants are intended to cover research expenses and travel costs, not tuition, fees, or living expenses. DEADLINES: IN SEPTEMBER AND MARCH. Contact: Dr. Francis Li; phone: (202) 653-5361.

The Population-Environment Fellows Program, sponsored by U.S. AID and administered at the University of Michigan, sponsors Fellows for two-year appointments with overseas agencies. Fellows provide assistance and technical support for developing country institutions to foster a comprehensive approach to development. Fellows must hold a graduate degree in a relevant area and demonstrate expertise in both population and environment. Applications are reviewed on a rolling basis, but the sooner a completed application is received, the greater the availability of sites for which it can be considered. Inquiries and application requests may be obtained from: The Population-Environment Fellows Program, SPH II, Room M2240, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109-2029; phone: (313) 747-0222; fax: (313) 747-4947.

The Rockefeller Foundation's Sub-Saharan African Dissertation Internship Awards 1993-1994 are open to citizens of sub-Saharan Africa studying in the U.S. or Canada. Priority will be given to research topics in the areas of agriculture, environment, health, sciences and schooling. Projects must involve field observations or use of primary sources only available in Africa. Students must have completed all course work and qualifying exams prior to receiving an award. DEADLINE: MARCH 1, 1994. To obtain applications and more information, contact: African Dissertation Internships, The Rockefeller Foundation, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, New York, NY 10036 or African Dissertation Internships, The Rockefeller Foundation, P.O. Box 47543, Nairobi, KENYA.

The Rockefeller Foundation Social Science Research Fellowships in Agriculture are designed to expand the number of social scientists who have had interdisciplinary research experience in international development. It is open to citizens of the United States, Canada, and Sub-Saharan African countries. The program supports a two-year appointment at international agricultural institutes based in developing countries. It is not the purpose of the program to permit a candidate to continue the same type of research in the same country in which he has worked previously. DEADLINE: DECEMBER 31, 1993 for candidates applying from North America and JANUARY 31, 1994 for candidates applying from overseas. Contact: Fellowship Office, Rockefeller Foundation, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, New York, NY 10036; phone: (212) 869-8500; fax: (212) 764-3468.

The Rockefeller Foundation offers Re-Entry Support for African Scholars Pursuing Education Research. Candidates must have completed their doctoral or post-doctoral programs and obtained employment in an African research or teaching institution. Contact: Scholars on Education Re-Entry Program, Rockefeller Foundation, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, New York, NY 10036; phone: (212) 869-8500; fax: (212) 764-3468.

The Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture of the New York Public Library announces its 1994-1995 Scholars-in-Residence Program. The program is designed to encourage research and writing in black history and culture, and encompasses projects in African, Afro- American, and Afro-Caribbean history and culture. DEADLINE: JANUARY 15, 1994. Contact: Scholars-in- Residence Program, Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, 515 Malcolm X Boulevard, New York, NY 10037-1801; phone: (212) 491-2203.

The University of Illinois-Egerton University Study Abroad Program allows undergraduates to spend eight weeks in Kenya this summer this summer. Participants will take courses at Egerton, tour various parts of the country, and live with Kenyan families in brief homestays. Contact: Center for African Studies, 210 International Studies Building, 910 South Fifth Street, Champaign, IL 61820; phone: (217) 333-6335.

The Washington Office on Africa seeks interns for Spring 1994. Interns will track legislation related to Africa, share information with congressional staff, be involved with the Southern African Working Group, and maintain the "Africa Hotline." Contact: Kristen Lee at Washington Office on Africa, phone: (202) 546-7961.

The Economic Development Institute of the World Bank announces the 1994 cycle of the Robert S. McNamara Fellowship Program which aims at producing the highest quality research results in the general area of economic development. The program also seeks to achieve wide geographical and cultural diversity among fellows. The 12-month fellowship does not support work toward an advanced degree, but innovate and imaginative post- graduate research in areas of economic development. Contact: Robert S. McNamara Fellowship Program, Room M- 4029, World Bank Headquarters, 1818 H. St., N.W., Washington, DC 20433.

The Centre for Refugee Studies at York University in Toronto offers an eight-week summer course on refugee affairs. The program will provide an overview of refugee issues, plus an opportunity to explore current topics with international experts. Participation is limited to 50 practitioners from inside and outside government who work with refugees or on refugee affairs and have a degree equivalent experience. Course dates are June 22-29, 1994. Contact: Dr. Tom Clark, Summer Course Coordinator, Centre for Refugee Studies, York University, Suite 322, York Lanes, 4700 Keele Street, North York, ON Canada M3J 1P3; phone: (416) 736-5837; fax: (416) 736- 5837.

The Los Angeles World Affairs Council 1994 Diplomatic Travel Program offers the following: "Untamed Africa - Kenya, Tanzania and Botswana". Trip will include Victoria Falls. From July 15 - August 8,1994. Contact: Los Angeles World Arrais Council, Diplomatic Tour Department at (310) 652-4675.


LOAD-DATE: January 17, 1994

Africa News


January 10, 1994 / January 17, 1994


EMPLOYMENT


LENGTH: 5427 words


 

Air Serv International, Inc. (ASI), a non-profit, humanitarian air transport company seeks an ACCOUNTANT for its Maputo, Mozambique office. Responsibilities cover financial management of operations, including establishment of systems to comply with reimbursable contract, bookkeeping, budget monitoring, cost projecting, producing financial reports for internal use and donor agencies, instruct, train and possibly supervise national staff. Requirements: Bachelor's degree in accounting, one year auditing experience, computer skills. Government accounting experience preferred, but not required. Send resume and salary requirements to: Personnel Department, Air Serv International, Box 3041, Redlands, CA, 92373; fax: (909) 793-0226.

The American Friends of the AICFA seeks a PROJECT MANAGER in Somalia for primary health care. Duties include procurement and logistics; project setup; maintenance of property; liaison with donors, other non- governmental organizations and authorities. QUALIFICATIONS: Three or more years in a similar position, strong negotiations, communications and management skills; ability to work in a difficult environment; knowledge of primary health care issues. Send resume and cover letter to: AFAICF, 815 15th Street NW, Suite 832, Washington, DC 20005; fax: (202) 783-5247. 

 

Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations has an opening for a SENIOR ECONOMIST (Marketing) in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia. This is a fixed term, 3-year position. QUALIFICATIONS: University degree in agricultural economics, preferably with postgraduate specialization in marketing, or a related field (such as agro-economy). Ten years of increasingly responsible professional experience in an international organization, government, private sector or research institution in agro-economic development. (An M.S. or equivalent advanced postgraduate degree in agricultural economics may be substituted for one year of the required experience, a Ph.D. or equivalent degree for two years of the required experience). Working knowledge of English (level C) or French or limited knowledge (level B) of the other. DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES: Under the supervision of the Director, Joint ECA (UN Economic Commission for Africa)/FAO Agriculture Division and the technical guidance of the Agricultural Services Division, to plan and coordinate the work of the Agricultural Marketing Section (ECA), and specifically, to: conduct analyses of the food and agricultural marketing situation in the region, including; developments in production, consumption, price policy, trade, distribution and demand, taking account of the Lagos Plan of Action, the Regional Food Plan for Africa and other regional programmes. Contact: Executive Officer, LNOR, Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, 1001 22nd Street, N.W., Suite 300, Washington, DC 20437

American Refugee Committee has the following positions available:

In Mozambique:

A PUBLIC HEALTH PROFESSIONAL to develop public health program in coordination with the water and sanitation projects. Rural setting. Requires: MPH; proven success in implementing new public health programs in developing countries; Portuguese, Spanish or French fluency. 1 year contract. ARC provides the transportation, health insurance, and group housing. JANUARY OPENING. A WATER/SANITATION ENGINEER to monitor water points to assess water quantity and quality; provide logistical support; assist in rehabilitation and construction of wells. QUALIFICATIONS: sanitation/civil/environmental engineering degree; experience working overseas; experience with water protection and sanitation projects; construction and supervisory experience preferred; Portuguese, French or Spanish fluency. US$1,500/mo. IMMEDIATE OPENING.

In Somalia:

MATERNITY SERVICES COORDINATOR, based in Afmadou, to select and train MCH Center maternity services staff; establish policies and procedures for the NCH Center maternity services; supervise the delivery of maternal services including prenatal care, labor and delivery

care, postpartum care. Qualifications: Certified Nurse midwife; experience in training and US supervision; strong primary health background. Six-month commitment, $1,500 a month.

CHW COORDINATOR, based in Afmadou, to implement CHW training programs for health workers; supervise and support community health workers in providing primary health care in their villages and provide primary health care in their villages and provide refresher courses when necessary; develop communications with village authorities and district and national health officials; interact with other agencies. Requires: RN, NP, PA, or MPH; proven success in curriculum development and training, flexibility, strong interpersonal skills. US$1,500 a month. Nine-month commitment.

COMPOUND MANAGER, based in Bardera, to act as liaison between ARC and other voluntary agencies; secure necessary supplies; coordinate ARC programs with those of other agencies; maintain close contact with Nairobi office. QUALIFICATIONS: previous experience as field coordinator or similar capacity in developing countries; strong communication skills; flexibility. US $1,200/mo. Minimum 6 month contract.

American Refugee Committee provides transportation,

health insurance, and group housing. Send resume to: ARC, Cathy Tilsen, 2344 Nicolett Avenue, Suite 350, Minneapolis, MN 55404; (612) 872-7060; fax: (612) 872- 4309.

The Center for International Development and Environment of the World Resources Institute seeks individual with experience in natural resources management, institutions, and/or natural resource and policy activities in Africa, particularly national plans and strategies for sustainable development. Africa experience and excellent language competence in French required. Will be responsible for the coordination and implementation of the Center's activities in sustainable development planning in Africa. Will coordinate the Natural Resource Management Policy Consultative Group for Africa, with priority on an on-going study of sustainable development planning in 8 African countries. Position includes field work, analytical report writing, some policy research, and preparing workplans and budgets. Send resume to: Africa Program, CIDE/WRI, 1709 New York Avenue NW, Suite 700, Washington, DC 20006.

OIC International seeks a SMALL ENTERPRISE MANAGEMENT/DEVELOPMENT AND APPROPRIATE TECHNOLOGY SPECIALIST to provide technical assistance and training in value-added transformation and raw produce with the purpose of creating employment and economic development opportunities for unemployed youths and disadvantaged communities in African and other countries. The person will identify cottage industry and appropriate technologies adaptable to the client countries; develop curricula to train related entrepreneurial and technical skills to develop and manage such businesses. REQUIREMENTS: First degree in engineering followed by an MBA or equivalent education in Business Management; experience in related development work, and working experience in Africa in particular, first hand experience managing business and/or in appropriate technology development; fluent in English and French; knowledge of Spanish is advantageous. Travel required. Send resume: President and CEO, OIC International, 240 W. Tulpehocken Street, Philadelphia, PA 19144.

The Center for Arabic Study Abroad seeks an Executive Director for the period June 1994 to June 1996. CASA offers intensive summer and full-year programs in spoken and advanced literary Arabic for American college and high-school students and faculty. It is operated at the American University in Cairo under the governance of 22 American universities. Contact: Gerald E. Lampe, Director, CASA, SAIS/Johns Hopkins University, 1619 Massachusetts Avenue, N.W., Washington, D.C. 20036; phone: (202) 663-5751.

Requires Master's degree in Public Health or social sciences or equivalent experience and three-plus years related work experience. The Ford Foundation is looking for a PROGRAM OFFICER or ASSISTANT PROGRAM OFFICER for its Africa and Middle Eastern Programs, to be based in Dakar, Senegal. Responsibilities include identifying priority areas; formulating appropriate strategies and monitoring grants aimed at building base of information on women's roles within contexts of culture and religion in francophone West Africa; raising public awareness of women's contributions to development; strengthening women's groups and organizations to empower women to improve their social and economic status. Requirements include: advanced training in social sciences, strong analytical and conceptual and writing skills, ability to work effectively with grass roots communities and university- based researchers, prior experience in programs to improve status of women, and fluency in French. Salary hiring guidelines for Program Officer: US$56,100-$71,100; Assistant Program Officer: US$38-700-$49,000. Send resume, brief writing sample for Position #206 to Joan Carroll, Manager of Employment, The Ford Foundation, 320 E. 43rd Street, New York, NY 10017.

The staff member will also oversee all Foundation activities in Zimbabwe and manage the Harare office. Graduate training in the social sciences is required. Salary starts at $54,000. If interested send c.v. and a brief writing sample for position #291 to Joan Carroll, Manager of Employment, The Ford Foundation, 320 East 43rd Street, New York, NY 10017.

Human Rights Watch/Africa Watch is accepting applications for a RESEARCH POSITION. The research will monitor human rights developments in several Sub-Saharan African countries through research, writing and advocacy efforts aimed at publicizing and curtailing human rights abuses. This will include conducting field investigations, writing reports and newspaper articles and devising strategies for addressing the abuses documented. QUALIFICATIONS: Applicants must have analytical skills, relevant work or research experience on a specific region (Horn of Africa expertise is a distinct advantage), fluency in spoken and written English and preferably a second language used in Africa. A demonstrated commitment to human rights is essential. US$30,000 - 40,000. 5 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 10, 1994 / January 17, 1994


VOLUNTEER OPPORTUNITIES


LENGTH: 1054 words


 

The Farmer-to-Farmer Volunteer Program, administered by Winrock International Institute for Agricultural Development and funded by the U.S. Agency for International Development, is currently recruiting agricultural specialists of varied backgrounds to provide technical assistance to female farmers in West Africa.

The countries targeted to receive this assistance are Burkina Faso, Cote d'Ivoire, the Gambia and Senegal. Volunteers posted to these countries will work closely with local farmers, small business people, and host country organizations to share their expertise on agricultural topics including distribution and marketing, women cooperatives, fruit and vegetable preservation and storage, rice and cassava marketing, sesame production and marketing, aqua culture, curriculum development and cooperative management.

Volunteer assignments range from three to six weeks and the ultimate goal of these assignments is to help host farmers improve family income and nutrition as well as to increase overall food production and distribution. 

The Farmer-to-Farmer Program pays for volunteer travel, meals and lodging. All travel logistics (i.e. visas, passports, medical exams) are arranged and paid for by Winrock International. The volunteer experts contribute their time and expertise.

For additional information and a volunteer application form contact Tom Bauer, Farmer-to-Farmer Program, Rt. 3, Box 376, Morrison, AR 72110; phone (501) 727-5435, ext. 253; Internet: tomb@winrock.org.

Health Volunteers Overseas has several openings for health care providers who wish to aid its programs in the following nations:

TRANSKEI (one-month assignments; April-December 1994): Participants needed in October and to teach anesthesia at Umtata General Hospital to physicians-in-training. Volunteers will also provide direct anesthesia care. Housing on hospital grounds is provided for the volunteer at no cost. Contact Dr. Kevin Speight, (919) 716- 4498/(919) 454-3956 or Spence Campbell (704) 696-9930.

UGANDA (one-month assignments; May-December 1994): Volunteers participate in the only anesthesia training program in Uganda. Most of the teaching takes place in Kampala's Mulago Hospital. Housing provided at the guest house at Makerere University. Contact Dr. Harry Zutz, (908) 381-4200/(201) 378-3323.

UGANDA (one-month assignments; March-November 1994): Program trains medical student, physicians, prosthetists, orthotists and physical therapists to improve the treatment of amputees and disabled people injured as a result of civil strife. Surgeons may also conduct orthopedic clinics an operating sessions with Ugandan doctors in upcountry regional hospitals in Tororo/Mbale, Mbarara and Fort Portal. Physical therapist volunteers will be needed to help the Ugandan tutors to develop courses in the three year diploma course are Mulago Hospital. Volunteers need to have a minimum of two years of clinical experience and some educational experience. Advanced degrees and lecture experience are big plus, but are not mandatory. Prosthetists are also being sought to teach. For a nominal fee, housing will be provided at the newly renovated Mulago Guest House. Contact: Dr. David Denzel, (716) 434-2697 or Elizabeth Kay, PT, (708) 897- 4814.

MALAWI (one-month assignments, longer considered; January-March 1994, May-June, 1994, September-December 1994): The Malawi Orthopedic Project trains classes of 10 full-time students in an 18 month course. Volunteers will participate in lectures, clinics, rounds and surgery. Operative cases include polio residents, tuberculosis, osteomyelitis, club feet and trauma. Volunteers will be located in Blantyre at the Queen Elizabeth Central Hospital. They will also travel to district hospitals, where they will supervise graduates of previous classes. Housing is available at a cost of $750 per month. A vehicle is furnished, but volunteers pay for gas. Contact Dr. Richard Kemme, (303) 352-0250.

For a more detailed description of each site as well as copies of trip reports from previous volunteers, contact Health Volunteers Overseas, c/o Washington Station, P.O. Box 65157, Washington, DC 20035-5157; phone: (202) 296-0928.

The American Medical Team for Africa (AMTA) promotes and executes educational exchange and medical training in African countries. The goal of the non-profit organization is to bring volunteer doctors, nurses and medical students together with donated supplies, and equipment to serve needs on the continent. Survey teams assess the most pressing needs in targeted countries, develop and publish training manuals in appropriate languages, hold workshops and refresher courses for doctors, nurses and specialists interested in maintenance of health care delivery systems in Africa; and distribute medical supplies and equipment donated by corporations, pharmaceutical companies, hospitals and doctors. The AMTA plans a second medical mission to Africa. For more information, contact Deman Rageh, Executive Director, The American Medical Team for Africa, 2245 Godby Road, Atlanta, GA 30349; phone (404) 766-8000; fax: (404) 767- 5264.


LOAD-DATE: January 17, 1994


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


January 10, 1994 / January 17, 1994


A PHALANX OF NEW FACES READY


BYLINE: Chris Louw, THE WEEKLY MAIL & GUARDIAN, Dec. 30, 1993 - Jan. 6, 1994


LENGTH: 920 words


 

When parliament reconvenes in Cape Town in May next year, the majority of faces will be several shades darker than those who debated the new constitution up until last week.

Where probably the last Afrikaner president sat to the right of the Speaker in the House of Assembly, the statesmanlike figure of Nelson Mandela will take his seat next year.

The African National Congress leader will be accompanied by a phalanx of new faces: Thabo Mbeki in Pik Botha's seat, Cyril Ramaphosa where Hernus Kriel used to sit, Mac Maharaj in Dawie de Villiers' place...

DeVilliers will also be there, as will FW de Klerk and Roelf Meyer. They will sit shoulder to shoulder with the Communist Party's Joe Slovo and Cosatu's ex-secretary general, Jay Naidoo. All of them will serve in a coalition cabinet in the government of national unity provided for by the transitional constitution. 

Chances are that few of the Conservative Party MPs who got to their feet in parliament last week to sing 'Die Stem' will be returned to the country's first non-racial government.

The singing of the national anthem ushered in a new

beginning in South African parliamentary politics: five years of enforced coalition government until the next elections in April 1999, during which period a new and "final" constitution will be written by our new rulers.

For every 20 representatives elected to the new parliament, all parties will be entitled to a cabinet member. Parties will nominate their own representatives, but the allocation of portfolios will rest with the president.

Parties with more than 80 seats will be allowed to appoint an executive vice-president to assist the president. If no party has more than 80 seats, the second biggest party will appoint a vice-president.

There is little doubt that Nelson Mandela, as the leader of the biggest party in the new government, will be elected president. FW de Klerk will probably lead the second biggest party, and will become one of his deputies.

The ANC is certain of more than 80 representatives in government. They will therefore also be entitled to appoint a vice-president. This could be either Thabo Mbeki or Cyril Ramaphosa. The choice largely depends on whether Mbeki becomes foreign minister.

In political circles strong voices were raised in favour of the present minister of foreign affairs, Pik Botha, retaining his portfolio. As the longest serving foreign minister in the world, the argument goes, he has the experience and the international contacts to ensure continuity and help bring investment to the country.

The ANC, however, might feel that a new appointee would symbolise to the outside world the end of the apartheid era. Mbeki will then, as deputy leader and head of the ANC's department of foreign affairs, be the obvious choice.

Another contender is Aziz Pahad, who heads the ANC's representation abroad.

If Mbeki gets the job, ANC secretary general Cyril Ramaphosa will become vice-president. If not, Ramaphosa will probably take over Roelf Meyer's portfolio of constitutional affairs. The new government will double as a constituent assembly writing the new constitution, and this portfolio is regarded as important.

The position of minister of law and order will be a difficult one to fill. Political analyst Dr. Frederick van Zyl Slabbert recently suggested that his portfolio, as well as those of agriculture and defence, be allocated to rightwingers in order to ensure their participation in the democratic process.

This is unlikely to happen, however. For the ANC it is equally important to show to its own constituency that there has been a genuine transfer of power.

University of Cape Town political scientist Hermann Giliomee has suggested that the law and order job had been offered to the NP's Leon Wessels, the current minister of manpower. This, he claimed, was part of the negotiations trade-offs, but it was hotly denied by the NP hierarchy.

Reprinted from WEEKLY MAIL & GUARDIAN, December 30, 1993 - January 6, 1994. WEEKLY MAIL & GUARDIAN is published by M&G Media

Contact: M&G Media, 139 Smit Street, Breamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025.


LOAD-DATE: January 17, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


11 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 10, 1994 / January 17, 1994


THE STRASSER GOVERNMENT'S PROGRAMME FOR CONSTITUTIONAL RULE


BYLINE: DAILY OBSERVER, December 28,1993


LENGTH: 1747 words


 

On 26 November, Captain Valentine E.M. Strasser, Chairman of the National Ruling Council and Head of State of Sierra Leone, issued a statement about his government's detailed plans to return the country to constitutional rule.

The following is the text of Captain Strasser's statement:

When the National Provisional Ruling Council took over the reins of government on 29 April 1992, it set itself a number of priority tasks. Among these were the speedy prosecution and conclusion of the rebel war, the revamping of the economy to restore stability and achieve sustainable growth and development, and the return of Sierra Leone to a democratic constitutional rule.

In pursuance of these objectives, and more particularly that of ending the rebel war, the government offered an amnesty to all patriotic Sierra Leoneans who were willing to lay down their arms and participate in the reconstruction of the shattered economy, so as to restore our dignity as a nation.

As is evident from recent reports, now that the rebel war is becoming a thing of the past, the National Provisional Ruling Council government as a further gesture of good will, and in the true spirit of reconciliation, has decided to renew the amnesty offer. In renewing this offer, the government wishes to assure all concerned that it has taken adequate steps to ensure that no one is brutalised or otherwise mistreated. All who take advantage of the amnesty offer will be humanely treated. 

To ensure that the information gets to all concerned, government has decided to use all possible media to disseminate the amnesty offer, including all FM stations throughout the country, the Sierra Leone Broadcasting Service and other international radio stations, the print media, as well as the air drop of leaflets in the affected areas.

To give credence to government's commitment, it will be observed that in the wake of the recent successes by the armed forces, numerous rebels have been surrendering to them on a daily basis. All who have surrendered so far have been granted amnesty instantly and are being humanely treated by the NPRC government. To make this offer more meaningful, government has agreed to designate certain areas as neutral zones and safe corridors. It is hoped that all concerned will avail themselves of this offer and take advantage of it by using the safe corridors. The areas so designated are Buedu, Nyandehun Mambabu and Koindu in the Eastern front and Sulima and Bumpe Perri in the Southern front.

Government realises that this offer can only be effective in a calm and peaceful atmosphere, and has therefore decided to declare a unilateral cease-fire effective midnight, 1 December 1993, for a period of four weeks.

Also, as another step in the direction of reconciliation and confidence building, the NPRC has released from detention all persons suspected to be rebels, to allow them to be reintegrated into the Sierra Leone society.

Logistic support, including transport, accommodation, food, medical and related assistance, will be made available in the neutral areas.

Fellow Sierra Leoneans, with the rehabilitation exercise already under way, my government is now afforded the opportunity of turning its attention more fully to the economic and social needs of the country with a view to enhancing the living standards of the average Sierra Leonean.

Let me point out that I do not intend in this statement to dwell at length on the strategy for achieving this objective. This will be the subject of another address to the nation. However, I want to give assurance to potential local and foreign investors that during the rest of this administration, we shall spare no effort in creating an enabling environment for private sector investment. We consider this of vital importance, because we realise that the resources of government are limited and cannot alone constitute the basis for a resurgence in economic activity. The enabling environment for private investment will encompass not only economic but also social and political dimensions.

In the budget statement delivered by the secretary of state finance, in the beginning of the current fiscal year, the rudiments of an incentive framework for private sector development were outlined. We intend to build on this to ensure the creation of a competitive and fair environment for all genuine business operators. The social and political aspects of the enabling environment for all private investors will include adequate protection of not only our national borders but also the lives and properties of all those who operate in this economy. We will carry this out through effective but unobtrusive policing activities consistent with an atmosphere of peace and stability.

In our view, this impetus to private sector activity will constitute the basis for increased employment, higher levels of income and poverty alleviation. It is our conviction that political plurality, freedom of association and the democratic values will be devoid of meaning if the economic well-being of the populace is neglected. Indeed, a sustainable path of economic growth and improved welfare is the best basis for a peaceful transition to constitutional rule. My government will continue to strengthen the economy and the capacity of the civil service to guide its sustained recovery in the coming years. I sincerely hope and believe that the legacy of my government to future governments in Sierra Leone will be a firm foothold for economic growth after many years of previous decline.

Fellow citizens, on the anniversary of our glorious revolution this year, my government gave a commitment on the imperative of returning the country to democratic constitutional rule. In fulfillment of this promise, we set up a National Advisory Council to work out the modalities for returning the country to a multi-party democracy, ensuring a broader and equitable participation of the citizenry in the democratic process and reflecting the views and aspirations of the people.

Since then, the Advisory Council has prepared a working document setting out the basis on which our new national constitution could be formulated. The process of constitution-building is never an easy one and in this instance it will require the contribution of all patriotic citizens. Our aim is to give this country a constitution that will endure the test of time and provide a framework and machinery on which individuals will conduct their affairs not only vis-a-vis each other but also between themselves and their rulers without fear or hindrance. It will also enshrine certain fundamental democratic values and principles designed to produce at all times a government of the people, by the people and for the people.

Determined to achieve this result, and following consultation with the Advisory Council, I am pleased to announce that the National Provisional Ruling Council is now in a position to declare a detailed transition programme that will guide my government's action in its bid to return this country to democratic rule.

The transition programme entails the following:

1. December 1993 (a): Advisory Council launches working document on the constitution to the nation.

(b) - Establishment of an Interim National Electoral Commission.

2. February 1994: National Commission for Democracy will be set up, which, on the constitution coming into force, becomes the National Commission for Civic Education.

3. March-June 1994: Registration of voters and delineation of constituency boundaries.

4. June 1994: A draft constitution to be produced jointly by the Advisory Council and a committee of legal experts.

5. November 1994: Non-Partisan District Council Elections to be wholly sponsored by Government: two-third members elected and one-third nominated by government.

6. May 1995: Referendum for adoption of constitution.

7. June 1995: (a) Constitution promulgated.

(b) Formation and registration of parties.

8. November 1995: Presidential election.

9. Early December 1995: General elections.

10. Early January 1996: Swearing-in of new president.

Reprinted from DAILY OBSERVER, December 28,1993. DAILY OBSERVER is published by THE OBSERVER COMPANY (GAMBIA) LTD.

CONTACT: DAILY OBSERVER, New Town-Sait Matty Junction, Bakau, P.M.B.131, Banjul, The Gambia. Telephone:(220)496608, Fax: (220)496878


LOAD-DATE: January 17, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


12 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 10, 1994 / January 17, 1994


WOMEN AND THE FUELWOOD CRISIS


BYLINE: Abdou Karim Sanneh, DAILY OBSERVER, December 6, 1993


LENGTH: 947 words


 

The growth of the population at a rate of 3.4 per cent is creating rapid deforestation at a rate of 290 hectares a year. This in turn is affecting the life of rural women who depend on the forest for energy and land for food and cash crop production. Fuelwood is the main source of energy for domestic use in both rural and urban Gambia, but the demand for it is causing environmental degradation, which has affected the lives of women.

The increasing need for fuelwood is speeding the disappearance of our priceless heritage, the natural woodlands. Deforestation has accelerated unfavourable climatic conditions, which in turn resulted in the death of trees because some species cannot adapt to a shift in climate change. 

Drought caused by deforestation has reduced the income of our farmers, resulting in widespread poverty within some farm families. According to the UNDP office in Banjul, about 50 per cent of our population, mostly women, are living in absolute poverty. Agriculture can improve the living conditions of rural farmers only if it is combined with forest resource management.

Let us give nature a change; she knows her business better than we do. Sustainable or environmentally sound agriculture involves a positive long-term trend in output (yield) and is achieved without damaging the environment and threatening the viability of the system. In the present trend in the demographic growth of The Gambia, sustainability has become one of the major objectives of agricultural research. This entails maintaining or increasing yield by using renewable resources, such as rainfall, more efficiently without degrading non- renewable resources, such as soil.

Planting more trees will influence rainfall and combat the threat of deforestation. Women in Jambajally in the Kombo South district have established a 2 km woodlot farm which can serve as a model for natural forest regeneration and conservation programme to combat the threat of desertification.

As the population grows, deforestation threatens traditional ways of life and the prospects for future generations. The Banjul Declaration of 1977, which is the government's commitment to environmental protection, warned of tragedy if the country's priceless natural heritage should be further endangered or lost. Our environment policy should be centered on comprehensive strategies such a agroforestry, gas and solar energy research, which is already in motion, household orchard development and the improvement of the human resource base (awareness and commitment) for sustainable management of the natural resources (land, water, air).

A great deal of the Gambia's wealth remains untapped as most of the productive land is not cultivated as well as it could be. Since agriculture is the mainstay of the Gambian economy, traditional farming systems, which depend most notably on rain-fed agriculture, should be improved drastically to meet the demands of the rapidly growing population.

For such a transition to be successful, the Gambian concept of farming will have to be thoroughly revised. For improvement in productivity depends on developing a farming system that will increase the biological productivity of the land, rather than reduce it.

In the southern part of MacCarthy Island Division around Mamud Fana, fragile soil is being eroded during the rainy season at an unacceptable rate because of the topography of the land. Every year, because of the wrong method of farming, the topsoil on which the farmers depend is fast disappearing. The farmers in Mamud Fana are highly knowledgeable and experienced, but they remain powerless to halt the growing levels of erosion.

Replacing The Gambia's traditional farming systems with advanced, sophisticated technology will not provide an easy solution. In The Gambia, farming systems must be robust so that if agricultural chemicals do not arrive or spare parts for tractors are not available, the system does not collapse. Consequently, it is the crops, livestock and techniques with which the farmers are familiar that should be exploited to the full. The solution will involve mixing farming land and knowledge together in the right blend, for the implementation of any new farming techniques will be dependent on an educated and receptive rural farming populace. At present the main problem is lack of know-how.

Agricultural problems in The Gambia can be reduced by innovative farming and innovative farmers, people who are receptive to new ideas and who can put the new ideas into effect.

Reprinted from DAILY OBSERVER, December 6,1993. DAILY OBSERVER is published by THE OBSERVER COMPANY (GAMBIA) LTD.

CONTACT: DAILY OBSERVER, New Town-Sait Matty Junction, Bakau, P.M.B.131, Banjul, The Gambia. Telephone:(220)496608, Fax: (220)496878


LOAD-DATE: January 17, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


13 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 10, 1994 / January 17, 1994


HOPE FOR STREET GIRLS


BYLINE: EDICESA NEWS, November 1993


LENGTH: 1614 words


 

Armed with an iron rod, Pauline Wangari, 11, menacingly demands money from a woman passer-by. Unfortunately, she is seen by the increasingly blood-thirsty Nairobi (Kenya) public who descend on her and beat her up leaving her for dead.

Although Wangari was dramatizing the life of a street girl in a concert, to her, every bit of it was the reality of her short life, as until recently, she had been living the life of a street kid since the age of six.

The drama was so heart-rending that many in the audience including Wangari's mother, Rose Wanjiku, a single parent of three children, wept openly.

The occasion was the official commissioning of the Peace House at Ngong on the outskirts of Nairobi by the Kenyan Minister of Culture and Social Service, Hussein Maalim. 

The House is part of the major global offensive against child labour by the International Labour Organisation (ILO) through the International Programme on the Elimination of Child Labour (IPEC). The programme provides advisory services to all ILO member states on request.

Kenya selected as a priority case

Kenya is among the first six countries to be selected as a priority case for action on child labour. The others are Brazil, India, Indonesia, Thailand, and Turkey.

The Peace House is not an institution but is a temporary shelter for girls whilst their immediate and long term needs are determined.

In Kenya, there are no statistics on child labour, however, the government acknowledges its existence. The chairman of the Child Welfare Society of Kenya (CWSK) Joseph Gichuru says child labourers are part of the new phenomenon of children in difficult circumstances.

"These children are forced to earn a living for themselves and/or their families as well, at the expense of valuable opportunities such as school or vocational training. Child labourers are denied not only their childhood, but most important their future as well. " They are mainly found in domestic work, especially in the case of female children; in the agricultural sector, where they are involved in picking farm produce such as coffee, tea or cotton; and in the industrial sector where they are employed in factories.

There are also street children who earn their living through hawking, begging, drug-trafficking or in some cases through outright prostitution.

Children exposed to abuse

Gichuru notes that all these children are exposed to all forms of abuse, notably child battering, sexual abuse and child defilement as well as exploitation. " The overall effect of the working conditions of children is therefore the dehumanization of the child and subsequent creation of a social deviant with a grudge against humanity and the world."

Gichuru calls for the development of an action-oriented national policy on child labour. He suggests that such a policy should address itself to improving the environment within which the child lives by empowering the family to be self-reliant, if only in subsistence so that the working child is free to continue with education. Working hours should be reduced so that the child does not have to forgo the attainment of his basic childhood rights such as education.

"Where work for the child is inevitable, attempts should be made to improve the health and nutritional status," says Gichuru. His organisation has chosen to tackle one aspect of child labour, namely the child who works on the streets.

About two decades ago, one could spot two or three boys in various corners of Nairobi streets who were conveniently baptized "parking boys." They directed vehicles to empty parking slots for a few coins and offered to look after the cars during the owners' absence.

The 1980's saw girls joining boys on the streets, a problem which caught the nation unawares. The deteriorating economic situation of the 1990's has led many children to turn the streets into homes in all urban areas. In Nairobi, they are called "street children"; in Mombasa "beach boys"; in Kisumu "basket boys"; in Nakuru "dust bins boys"; and in other smaller towns, they are "market boys".

Despite the ever-increasing problem of street kids, there are no reliable figures on these children. The last survey done in 1984 indicated that these children totalled about 30,000. The CWSK Project Officer on Street Children, Ms. Elizabeth Kamau, admitted that the lack of statistics was a major drawback "...and we have commissioned a private agency to do a national baseline survey on street children. We hope to have the results by the middle of next year."

Since the problem of street children started with boys well-articulated programmes to rehabilitate them have been in existence for a long time. For instance, the Undugu Society (Undugu means brotherhood in Swahili) was until recently concerned with street boys only in Nairobi. This Kenyan Non-Governmental Organisation (NGO) was established 20 years ago.

On the gender aspect of the problem, Kamau said street girls were vulnerable and suffered much more than boys through "unwanted pregnancies, sexually transmitted diseases including AIDS and are more open to all sorts of abuse."

Survey

As part of investigations to determine the needs of street children, five social workers undertook a survey of Nairobi to try and develop a relationship of trust with street girls in order to establish what sort of intervention was needed in each case.

Wangari was among the first to be interviewed. It was not difficult to talk to her as she confessed: "I have always wanted to get out. I was tired of begging, my mother always made me go out with the baby on my back. And then, there were street fights with rival gangs over earnings."

The social workers had to determine why the child went out into the streets and in the case of Wangari, it was abject poverty. Her mother did not have a job and could therefore not afford to rent a house for the family. They were always on the move with very little to ear. The mother had to serve a three-month jail sentence twice for brewing illicit alcohol, 'changa', leaving the children to fend for themselves.

Wangari's home was not conducive to proper rehabilitation, and she was referred to the Peace House. Her mother was asked what she could do and she narrated how she used to work as a vegetable vendor without a licence and that one day her goods were confiscated by the city authorities, after which she lost all her capital.

A loan has been made available to Wangari's mother, Wanjiku, to enable her to sell vegetables. This time she has a licence and has moved to Ngong where she rents a house for her family. Wangari is now a school girl. The project limits itself to children between six and fourteen years. Once they are identified, their homes are explored and those found in want like Wangari, are sent to the Peace House.

The school-age children who are interested in continuing with formal education are sponsored to do so while older children were allowed to choose their priorities and then taken to identified skilled artisans for vocational training.

The Peace House can accommodate up to 20 children but as many as 100 have been squeezed in for a night with the time limit of three months. The scheme has accommodated a total of 102 girls in various stages of rehabilitation.

The Child Welfare Society of Kenya has observed that this was a "drop in the ocean but that a good start has been made."

Reprinted from EDICESA NEWS, November 1993 EDICESA NEWS is published by EDICESA.

Contact: EDICESA, P.O. Box H94 Hatfield, Harare, Zimbabwe, phone:(011) 50311/2. Fax:(011) 52979.


LOAD-DATE: January 17, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


14 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 10, 1994 / January 17, 1994


WHERE THE SLAVES ARE REMEMBERED


BYLINE: Alle Badara Sheriff, DAILY OBSERVER, December 11, 1993


LENGTH: 747 words


 

The Slave House on Goree Island is a 30-minute ferry ride from the modern, thriving city of Dakar (Senegal). But when one steps onto the island and through the heavy wooden door of the Maison des Esclaves, one enters another, darker time.

The tragic history of the slave trade is not complete without a study of the role this little piece of land played in sending so many Africans to a lifetime of servitude, if not their death. One man who has devoted his life to preserving the memories of the slaves is Joseph Ndiaye, archivist of the Slave House. In an interview with Mr. Ndiaye last Saturday on the island, he made a passionate appeal to the Organisation of African Unity (OAU) to help rehabilitate the ageing Slave House, which was renovated by UNESCO, but is in need of repairs. Mr. Ndiaye is a walking encyclopedia of facts and figures on the slave trade and the key role Goree Island played between 1536 and 1848, first in promoting the trade and eventually in preventing it, when the island became a base for ships policing the waters against slave boats. The Portuguese were the first merchants to create a settlement there between 1536 and 1580, followed by the Dutch. Slaves were brought from various parts of Africa to Goree where they were sold to traders and kept in appalling conditions in the basements of the merchants' grand houses to await shipment abroad. Goree was ideally situated as a staging post for America and the West Indies, where the majority of the slaves were sent to work on the cotton, coffee and sugar plantations.

The Slave House that has been preserved today is just one of the many similar houses used to store humans as trade goods. On the first floor are large, airy rooms with tall windows and an open balcony overlooking the Atlantic. The wealthy slave trader and his family lived here, while down below in dark, unventilated and cramped chambers the recently captured slaves awaited an unknown fate across the seas.

Mr. Ndiaye is adept at bringing to life the horror of these conditions. One of the cells measures 2.6 metres in width. In this were kept 15 slaves. Around their waist they each wore a 10.3 kg metal weight linked to their ankle with a heavy lock to prevent escape. Anyone who tried to escape was shot.

The weighing room was a vital part of the Slave House. The minimum weight required for adult slaves was 60 kg and in this room the slaves were weighed to see if they matched up to the requirements. People from Nigeria and Niger were the most in demand as they were generally the strongest and heaviest. The slaves were transported in the hold of the ship, in a space usually no more than 30 metres long and 8 metres wide. At least 350 slaves were packed into this space -- the more slaves the ship could cram in, the more profit the traders could make. But the average mortality rate during the journey across the Atlantic was between 25 and 30 percent, and the bodies of the dead and the dying slaves were thrown overboard into the sea. During the 300 years of this inhuman trade, between 15 and 20 million Africans were sold and sent abroad as slaves, and it is estimated that six million died before they ever reached their final destination.

Many famous international figures have stood on the steps of the Slave House and listened to Joseph Ndiaye's eloquent and moving account of the world's most despicable trade, including Pope John Paul II, Nelson Mandela and President Mitterand of France. But will the OAU hear his call to help preserve one of Africa's greatest relics?

Reprinted from DAILY OBSERVER, December 11,1993. DAILY OBSERVER is published by THE OBSERVER COMPANY (GAMBIA) LTD.

CONTACT: DAILY OBSERVER, New Town-Sait Matty Junction, Bakau, P.M.B.131, Banjul, The Gambia. Telephone:(220)496608, Fax: (220)496878


LOAD-DATE: January 17, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


15 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 10, 1994 / January 17, 1994


IVORY COAST CFA


BYLINE: Cindy Shiner


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 1014 words


 

January 14, 1994

Consumers in francophone West Africa suffered their worst economic jolt in nearly 50 years this week when stores doubled their prices following a major regional currency devaluation that amounted to another break in the long standing, close relationship with their former colonial ruler.

The measure, taken by the 11 countries of the Central African Franc (CFA) zone on January 11, was designed to increase domestic production and investment. Prime Minister Daniel Kablan Duncan told reporters that the measure was aimed at creating "a future with better days, especially for our youth," adding that it would allow Ivory Coast to "rediscover the economic growth that had given it pride in the past."

But, for the time being people in many francophone countries are only seeing skyrocketing prices, primarily on imports. 

At one Abidjan supermarket, the price of a liter of French-made vanilla ice-cream soared to about $20. In a panic-buying spree consumers cleared store shelves of imported goods, keeping one step ahead of the price changers. Prices on most locally produced products remained the same.

That same supermarket, Nour-al-Hyat, was closed by the government on January 11 because it allegedly ignored price controls.

The exchange rate now is fixed at 100 CFA to 1 French franc, down from 50 to 1., but it will be some time before that stabilizes and people begin to see the promised benefits of devaluation.

"It will put off our coming into the CFA franc zone,: said Thomas Perko. regional representative for General Motors, which already has functioning outlets in anglophone Nigeria and Ghana, which have floating currencies.

Unlike most of their neighbors, CFA countries never had to worry about the fluctuation of their currency, which has had parity with the French franc for 45 years to promote stability and foster economic ties between France and its former colonies.

The French currency role in those countries -- Senegal, Equatorial Guinea, Central Africa Republic, Togo, Ivory Coast, Benin, Mali, Niger, Chad, Burkina Faso, Cameroon, Gabon, Congo and Comoros -- has been a major tool for French political influence.

The International Monetary Fund (IMF) had long pressured franc zone nations to devalue because it considered the CFA overvalued. The high rate of exchange made informal cross-border trade popular with countries with floating currencies; it also prompted capital flight.

France was urged by the IMF to support devaluation to help its former colonies recover from a decade-long economic slump largely brought on by a drop in commodities prices. France eventually conditioned additional development aid on economic reform and encouraged increased cooperation between its former colonies and the IMF. But France hasn't entirely cut its paternalistic ties. Paris announced post-devaluation bilateral debt relief for CFA countries of $4.2 billion. The IMF also says it will invest at least $1.5 billion to help ease the pain.

Importers and consumers dependent on foreign products most immediately will suffer the effects of devaluation.

Lebanese business Ali Hammoud said he lost thousands of dollars in less than 24 hours because he failed to convert his CFA before devaluation. "I never, never thought the CFA was going down," he said. "I have nothing left in my shop. What do I do? Go to Lebanon? I don't know Lebanon. I have two children to feed."

The average person who eats locally-produced food should not be adversely affected by the devaluation unless the price of fuel increases., which is likely. That will force people who bring produce into the city from the interior to raise their prices to cover transportation costs.

Burkina Faso, Mail, Chad and Niger, four of the world's poorest countries, could suffer more because the desert nations do not have sufficient agricultural and industrial capacity to offset a drop in imports or price hikes on those products.

Some franc zone countries have already taken their own measures to soften the blow of devaluation. Senegal announced a 10 percent pay hike for civil servants; last summer it lowered salaries by 15 percent as part of a structural adjustment program.

Ivory Coast and other nations have announced price controls. Duncan, the prime minister, increased the price of rice by 10 percent and gas by 15 percent. He also said civil servants would receive salary increases of between five and 15 percent.

The devaluation comes a month after the death of Africa's longest serving president, Felix Houphouet- Boigny of Ivory Coast, who helped lead the region to independence but had always urged maintaining close ties with France. The late president's funeral is to take place on February 7 in Yamasoukro, his birth place, which is the formal political capital of the country he ruled for three decades.


LOAD-DATE: January 17, 1994


LANGUAGE: English

Maxwell Stamp PLC

London * Nairobi * Riyadh * Mauritius

The table gives selected currencies valued against the major international trading currencies. Rates quoted are the middle rates between buying and selling, but currencies are in most cases not freely traded. These rates have been compiled by Maxwell Stamp PLC for information only. Maxwell Stamp accepts no responsibility for any transaction undertaken on the basis of these figures. For further information please contact John Morgan at Maxwell Stamp's Head Office in London; phone 44-71-251-0147; telex 914569 MAXAMP G; fax 44-71-251- 0140.
