Africa News


January 18, 1994 / January 31, 1994


EDUCATION/TRAVEL


LENGTH: 2347 words


 

The International Bicycle Fund will sponsor a two- week, people-to-people, bicycle and train tours in Tunisia in March and April, 1994. Tour participants will meet craftsmen, educators, officials, and learn about day-to-day life in the villages. Contact: International Bicycle Fund, 4887 Columbia Dr. South. Seattle, WA 98108- 1919.

The Frederick Douglass Institute for African and African-American Studies at the University of Rochester is calling for applications for its 1994-1995 Residential Fellowships. Available are one postdoctoral fellowship, one predoctoral dissertation fellowship, and two four- year fellowships for graduate study. Welcome projects include historical and contemporary topics on the economy, society, and culture of Africa and its diaspora, as well as projects on human and technological aspects of energy development and agriculture in Africa. DEADLINE: JANUARY 31, 1994. Contact: Associate Director for Research and Curriculum, Frederick Douglass Institute for African and African-American Studies, University of Rochester, 302 Morey Hall, Rochester, NY 14627; phone: (716) 275-7235. 

Howard University's Center for the Study of Culture and Development in Africa offers a Resident Fellowship Program on Culture and Development. The theme of the program in 1994-1995 is "Gender, Cultural Production and Development in Africa." Two fellowships will be awarded, and fellows must be engaged in full-time research and be in residence at Howard University for the duration of the fellowship (August 1994-May 1995). Each full-year fellowship carries a stipend of US$30,000, plus $4,000 for relocation expenses, insurance, and other expenses. Limited funds are available for travel within the U.S. Candidates must have completed Ph.D. at the time of application. DEADLINE FOR RECEIPT OF APPLICATIONS AND ALL SUPPORTING DOCUMENTS: FEBRUARY 28, 1994. Contact: Director, Center for the Study of Culture and Development, Department of African Studies, Box 231, Howard University, Washington, DC 20059; phone: (202) 806-7115; fax: (202) 806-4425.

The International Bicycle Fund is sponsoring two two-week bicycle/train tours of Tunisia in March and April of 1994. The tours depart North America on March 29 and April 12. Land cost, including accommodations, meals, museum and monument fees and tour guide is US$1,090. Airfare is additional. IBF is also sponsoring bicycle tours of Uganda, February 1-17, 1994; and Zimbabwe, July 10-23, 1994 and July 24-August 6, 1994. Contact: IBF- Africa Program, 4887 Columbia Drive South, Seattle, WA 98108-1919; phone: (206) 628-9314; fax (manually activated): (206) 628-9314.

The International Foundation for Education and Self-Help's International Fellows Program encourages minority graduate students, as well as others, to participate in nine-month internships with self-help, economic development programs. Tuskegee University in Alabama implements the International Fellows Program through its office of International Programs. IFESH pays the cost of orientation, travel, health insurance and an overseas living allowance. APPLICATION DEADLINE: FEBRUARY 10, 1994. Contact: IFESH, 5040 East Shea Boulevard, Suite 260, Phoenix, AZ 85254-4610; phone: (602) 443-1800; fax: (602) 443-1824.

The Museum for African Art's "Discovering Africa" travel series continues this winter with trips to Cote d'Ivoire (January 17-28), Ghana/Benin (January 17-28), and Nigeria (February 15-March 2). Participants travel in small groups and focus intensely on the culture and people of Africa, meeting Africans who are leaders in the continent's art and politics. Contact: Jerry Vogel, The Museum for African Art, 593 Broadway, New York, NY 10012; phone: (212) 966-1313; fax: (212) 966-1432.

The Rockefeller Foundation's Sub-Saharan African Dissertation Internship Awards 1993-1994 are open to citizens of sub-Saharan Africa studying in the U.S. or Canada. Priority will be given to research topics in the areas of agriculture, environment, health, sciences and schooling. Projects must involve field observations or use of primary sources only available in Africa. Students must have completed all course work and qualifying exams prior to receiving an award. DEADLINE: MARCH 1, 1994. To obtain applications and more information, contact: African Dissertation Internships, The Rockefeller Foundation, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, New York, NY 10036 or African Dissertation Internships, The Rockefeller Foundation, P.O. Box 47543, Nairobi, KENYA.

The Rockefeller Foundation Social Science Research Fellowships in Agriculture are designed to expand the number of social scientists who have had interdisciplinary research experience in international development. It is open to citizens of the United States, Canada, and Sub-Saharan African countries. The program supports a two-year appointment at international agricultural institutes based in developing countries. It is not the purpose of the program to permit a candidate to continue the same type of research in the same country in which he has worked previously. DEADLINE: DECEMBER 31, 1993 for candidates applying from North America and JANUARY 31, 1994 for candidates applying from overseas. Contact: Fellowship Office, Rockefeller Foundation, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, New York, NY 10036; phone: (212) 869-8500; fax: (212) 764-3468.

The Rockefeller Foundation offers Re-Entry Support for African Scholars Pursuing Education Research. Candidates must have completed their doctoral or post- doctoral programs and obtained employment in an African research or teaching institution. Contact: Scholars on Education Re-Entry Program, Rockefeller Foundation, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, New York, NY 10036; phone: (212) 869-8500; fax: (212) 764-3468.

The University of Illinois-Egerton University Study Abroad Program allows undergraduates to spend eight weeks in Kenya this summer this summer. Participants will take courses at Egerton, tour various parts of the country, and live with Kenyan families in brief homestays. Contact: Center for African Studies, 210 International Studies Building, 910 South Fifth Street, Champaign, IL 61820; phone: (217) 333-6335.

The Los Angeles World Affairs Council 1994 Diplomatic Travel Program offers the following: "Untamed Africa - Kenya, Tanzania and Botswana". Trip will include Victoria Falls. From July 15 - August 8,1994. Contact: Los Angeles World Arrais Council, Diplomatic Tour Department at (310) 652-4675.

Re-Entry Grants for African Scholars Pursuing Education Research are designed to assist in the professional re-establishment of talented African scholars who are returning from doctoral or post-doctoral studies abroad and wish to pursue research related to the revitalization and development of education in sub- Saharan Africa. All proposed projects must include and explicit and substantial focus on female school participation as part of the set of issues to be examined. The proposed budget, not to exceed $25,000, may request funding for items such as a microcomputer and software, books, office supplies, living expenses, personnel assistance, and local transportation. The budget may also include subsistence funds for one research team member of any nationality and a stipend to cover up to six months of transition costs for the returning African scholar. Applicants may submit research proposals prior to or within one year of returning to their Africa-based institutions. The proposal must be endorsed by the African institution where the applicant will be a full-time staff member. Also required are two letters of recommendation from doctoral or post-doctoral study; doctoral transcripts; and resume for the applicant and any professional research team member for whom funds are sought. There are no deadlines for submission of proposals. For a full description of the program, write to : Scholars on Education Re-Entry Program, The Rockefeller Foundation, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, New York, NY 10036, USA or to Scholars on Education Re-Entry Program, The Rockefellar Foundation, P.O. Box 47543, Nairobi, Kenya.

An African Studies Summer Program at Egerton University in Njoro, Kenya will run from June 6 to August 6, 1994. The program is sponsored jointly by the University of Illinois Center fro African Studies and Egerton University's Faculty of Arts and Social Sciences. The program is open to students from all participating Consortium for Inter-Institutional Cooperation (CIC) universities. Undergraduate and graduate students form all academic disciplines can apply, No background in KiSwahili is required. The program includes an orientation in Nairobi, classes taught at Egerton, homestays with Kenyan farm families, and a study-tour. Estimated cost $4,500 including airfare. To obtain applications and more information about this program, contact: Center for African Studies, University of Illinois, 210 International Studies Building, 910 South Fifth Street, Champaign, IL 61820. Phone: 217-333-6335.

Since 1973, the African Studies Outreach Program, University of Wisconsin, (NDEA/HEA Title VI African Resource Center) disseminates information about Africa to constituents in the Upper-Midwest. An Africanist-educator directs this program to provide speakers, workshops/institutes, resources, and consultation concerning Africa. Beginning in the late 1980s this service was expanded for national/international outreach through two computer services.

AFRICAN STUDIES BBS

The African Studies Program maintains an electronic bulletin board with a focus on African content only. The African Studies BBS began service in November, 1989. In addition to bulletins concerning activities in the Madison, Wisconsin area, the African Studies BBS offers files for scholars and educators (K-12) on various topics: grants, address lists, newsletters, conference programs, travel, publications, and so forth. The BBS holds over 2000 subscribers. This 24-hour service is available at telephone number: (608) 262-9689. Protocol = 3/12/24/9600 baud, 8 bits, 1 stop, n parity, n echo. Fidonet point = 1:121/25.3 (Madison, WI - The Off Line) or 1:109/151.42 (Washington, DC - The Baobab).

SWAHILI - L (internet)

The African Studies Outreach Program created this service at the request of post-secondary teachers of Swahili and returned Peace Corps Volunteers in July, 1992. This distribution list promotes Swahili literacy and allows for an exchange of ideas on various topics written in Swahili. Over 150 persons are subscribers from around the world. Persons interested in communicating in Swahili are welcome to subscribe (free) to the African Studies Outreach Program conversation board - Swahili-L. Write for subscription via the internet: To: listserver@relay.adp.wisc.edu Subject: subscribe swahili-l <name1> <name2>. For additional information contact: Outreach Director/ African Studies Program/ 1454 Van Hise Hall/ 1220 Linden Dr./ Madison, WI 53706-1557/USA. Phone (608) 263-2171 or 262-2380 Fax: (608)262-6998. afrst@macc.wisc.edu or afrst@wiscmacc.bitnet.

EMPLOYMENT


LENGTH: 4627 words


 

The American Friends of the AICFA seeks a PROJECT MANAGER in Somalia for primary health care. Duties include procurement and logistics; project setup; maintenance of property; liaison with donors, other non- governmental organizations and authorities. QUALIFICATIONS: Three or more years in a similar position, strong negotiations, communications and management skills; ability to work in a difficult environment; knowledge of primary health care issues. Send resume and cover letter to: AFAICF, 815 15th Street NW, Suite 832, Washington, DC 20005; fax: (202) 783-5247. 

Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations has an opening for a SENIOR ECONOMIST (Marketing) in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia. This is a fixed term, 3-year position. QUALIFICATIONS: University degree in agricultural economics, preferably with postgraduate specialization in marketing, or a related field (such as agro-economy). Ten years of increasingly responsible professional experience in an international organization, government, private sector or research institution in agro-economic development. (An M.S. or equivalent advanced postgraduate degree in agricultural economics may be substituted for one year of the required experience, a Ph.D. or equivalent degree for two years of the required experience). Working knowledge of English (level C) or French or limited knowledge (level B) of the other. DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES: Under the supervision of the Director, Joint ECA (UN Economic Commission for Africa)/FAO Agriculture Division and the technical guidance of the Agricultural Services Division, to plan and coordinate the work of the Agricultural Marketing Section (ECA), and specifically, to: conduct analyses of the food and agricultural marketing situation in the region, including; developments in production, consumption, price policy, trade, distribution and demand, taking account of the Lagos Plan of Action, the Regional Food Plan for Africa and other regional programmes. Contact: Executive Officer, LNOR, Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, 1001 22nd Street, N.W., Suite 300, Washington, DC 20437

American Refugee Committee has the following positions available:

In Mozambique:

A PUBLIC HEALTH PROFESSIONAL to develop public health program in coordination with the water and sanitation projects. Rural setting. Requires: MPH; proven success in implementing new public health programs in developing countries; Portuguese, Spanish or French fluency. 1 year contract. ARC provides the transportation, health insurance, and group housing. JANUARY OPENING.

A WATER/SANITATION ENGINEER to monitor water points to assess water quantity and quality; provide logistical support; assist in rehabilitation and construction of wells. QUALIFICATIONS: sanitation/civil/environmental engineering degree; experience working overseas; experience with water protection and sanitation projects; construction and supervisory experience preferred; Portuguese, French or Spanish fluency. US$1,500/mo. IMMEDIATE OPENING.

In Somalia:

MATERNITY SERVICES COORDINATOR, based in Afmadou, to select and train MCH Center maternity services staff; establish policies and procedures for the NCH Center maternity services; supervise the delivery of maternal services including prenatal care, labor and delivery care, postpartum care. Qualifications: Certified Nurse midwife; experience in training and US supervision; strong primary health background. Six-month commitment, $1,500 a month.

CHW COORDINATOR, based in Afmadou, to implement CHW training programs for health workers; supervise and support community health workers in providing primary health care in their villages and provide primary health care in their villages and provide refresher courses when necessary; develop communications with village authorities and district and national health officials; interact with other agencies. Requires: RN, NP, PA, or MPH; proven success in curriculum development and training, flexibility, strong interpersonal skills. US$1,500 a month. Nine-month commitment.

COMPOUND MANAGER, based in Bardera, to act as liaison between ARC and other voluntary agencies; secure necessary supplies; coordinate ARC programs with those of other agencies; maintain close contact with Nairobi office. QUALIFICATIONS: previous experience as field coordinator or similar capacity in developing countries; strong communication skills; flexibility. US $1,200/mo. Minimum 6 month contract.

American Refugee Committee provides transportation, health insurance, and group housing. Send resume to: ARC, Cathy Tilsen, 2344 Nicolett Avenue, Suite 350, Minneapolis, MN 55404; (612) 872-7060; fax: (612) 872- 4309.

OIC International seeks a SMALL ENTERPRISE MANAGEMENT/DEVELOPMENT AND APPROPRIATE TECHNOLOGY SPECIALIST to provide technical assistance and training in value-added transformation and raw produce with the purpose of creating employment and economic development opportunities for unemployed youths and disadvantaged communities in African and other countries. The person will identify cottage industry and appropriate technologies adaptable to the client countries; develop curricula to train related entrepreneurial and technical skills to develop and manage such businesses. REQUIREMENTS: First degree in engineering followed by an MBA or equivalent education in Business Management; experience in related development work, and working experience in Africa in particular, first hand experience managing business and/or in appropriate technology development; fluent in English and French; knowledge of Spanish is advantageous. Travel required. Send resume: President and CEO, OIC International, 240 W. Tulpehocken Street, Philadelphia, PA 19144.

The Center for Wildlife Management in Kenya seeks a WILDLIFE RESOURCE MANAGER for a permanent full-time position of Resident Faculty. Resident Faculty live on site, lecture in an interdisciplinary, non-traditional, field-based learning environment and oversee student- directed research projects. Send detailed letter explaining relevant skills and experience, CV, and three references to Kenya Wildlife Resource Manager Search, The School for Field Studies, 16 Broadway, Beverly, MA 01915; phone: (508) 927-7777; fax: (508) 927-5127.

Family Health International seeks a PROGRAM OFFICER to provide liaison, program, and administrative support required for a productive and efficient collaboration between FHI and UNICEF's AIDS unit; to facilitate FHI's provision of technical assistance to UNICEF's AIDS unit, Technical Support groups, and specified country programs. Requires Master's degree in Public Health or social sciences or equivalent experience and three-plus years related work experience. Experience in working with UN system of USAID-funded activities desirable. Fluency in French and/or Spanish desirable. To apply, send cover letter (with salary requirements) and resume to Linda Rodriguez, Family Health International, 2101 Wilson Blvd., Suite 700, Arlington, VA 22201.

FHI also seeks a RESEARCH OFFICER to assist in designing and managing the Behavioral Research program of the new global AIDS Control and Prevention Project (AIDSCAP) and to provide expertise in the planning, implementation, and evaluation of the Project's behavioral research program. Requires PhD in one of the social sciences or comparable combination of education and experience with AIDS epidemic and considerable experience in designing and implementing behavioral science research projects in the developing world. Ability to travel international, fluency in French or Spanish is preferred. To apply, send cover letter (with salary requirements) and resume to Linda Rodriguez, Family Health International, 2101 Wilson Blvd., Suite 700, Arlington, VA 22201.

FHI also seeks a CHIEF IN AIDS CONTROL AND PREVENTION PROJECT to manage the Behavior Changes Communications component, focusing on increasing condom demand and STD treatment-seeking behaviors and reducing numbers of sexual partners. Requires PhD or MA and equivalent experience and five years experience in the design of behavior change communications programs. Fluency in French or Spanish desirable. To apply, send cover letter (with salary requirements) and resume to Linda Rodriguez, Family Health International, 2101 Wilson Blvd., Suite 700, Arlington, VA 22201.

International Medical Corps has multiple openings. Mail or fax resume or letter of interest to International Medical Corps, Dept. 93-033, 12233 West Olympic Blvd., #280, Los Angeles, CA 90064; fax: (310) 442-6622.

PHYSICIAN with background in tropical medicine and immunization programs.

SITE MANAGERS: With administrative, finance, logistics, security exp. Three years in developing countries.

HEALTH WORKER TRAINERS with experience in community development and education in developing countries. MPH preferred.

VACCINATOR/TRAINERS with experience in EPI implementation. MPH preferred.

MATERNAL HEALTH PROGRAM COORDINATOR. 3 years experience in developing countries; community health, nurse practitioner with midwifery skills; traditional birthing (TBA) training experience. 1 year contract.

The following International Medical Corps position is available in Somalia:

MSN, RN or NP. OB/GYN skills; 2-3 years in developing countries. 1 year contract.

Round-trip transportation, room and board provided for each of these positions. Mail or fax resume or letter of interest to International Medical Corps, 12233 West Olympic Blvd., #2809, Los Angeles, CA 90064. Fax (310) 442-6622.

Four- to six-month positions in testing and evaluation; EMIS; Textbook Logistics; Teacher Education; Math/Science/Reading/English curriculum. Requirements: advanced degree, minimum three years experience; LDC living required. Send CV to The Mitchell Group, Box 73825, Washington, DC 20009; phone: (202) 745-1919; fax: (202) 234-1697.

The University of Cape Town invites applications for the newly established A.C. Jordan Chair in African Studies. Applicants should have an established research record, a commitment to multidisciplinary approaches, administrative experience, and strong ties to Africa. A complete announcement is on file at the Center. DEADLINE: FEBRUARY 15, 1994. The Ford Foundation is looking for a PROGRAM OFFICER or ASSISTANT PROGRAM OFFICER for its Africa and Middle Eastern Programs, to be based in Dakar, Senegal. Responsibilities include identifying priority areas; formulating appropriate strategies and monitoring grants aimed at building base of information on women's roles within contexts of culture and religion in francophone West Africa; raising public awareness of women's contributions to development; strengthening women's groups and organizations to empower women to improve their social and economic status. REQUIREMENTS include: advanced training in social sciences, strong analytical and conceptual and writing skills, ability to work effectively with grass roots communities and university- based researchers, prior experience in programs to improve status of women, and fluency in French. Salary hiring guidelines for Program Officer: US$56,100-$71,100; Assistant Program Officer: US$38-700-$49,000. Send resume, brief writing sample for Position #206 to Joan Carroll, Manager of Employment, The Ford Foundation, 320 E. 43rd Street, New York, NY 10017.

The Ford Foundation is seeking an ASSISTANT REPRESENTATIVE/PROGRAM OFFICER for African and Middle East programs to be based in Harare, Zimbabwe. The staff member will also oversee all Foundation activities in Zimbabwe and manage the Harare office. Graduate training in the social sciences is required. Salary starts at $54,000. If interested send c.v. and a brief writing sample for position #291 to Joan Carroll, Manager of Employment, The Ford Foundation, 320 East 43rd Street, New York, NY 10017.

The Washington Office on Africa seeks INTERNS for spring 1994. Interns will track legislation related to Africa, share information with congressional staff, be involved in the southern African Working Group, and maintain the "Africa Hotline." DEADLINE: MAY 1, 1994. Contact: Kristen Lee, Washington Office on Africa, 119 Maryland Avenue NE, Washington, DC 20002. tel: (202) 546-7961. fax: (202) 546-1545.

Human Rights Watch/Africa Watch is acceptingapplications for a RESEARCH POSITION. The research will monitor human rights developments in several Sub-Saharan African countries through research, writing and advocacy efforts aimed at publicizing and curtailing human rights abuses. This will include conducting field investigations, writing reports and newspaper articles and devising strategies for addressing the abuses documented. QUALIFICATIONS: Applicants must have analytical skills, relevant work or research experience on a specific region (Horn of Africa expertise is a distinct advantage), fluency in spoken and written English and preferably a second language used in Africa. A demonstrated commitment to human rights is essential. US$30,000 - 40,000. Send resume, one or two writing samples and the names, addresses, phone and fax numbers of two references to: Executive Director, Human Rights Watch/Africa Watch, 1522 K St. NW, Suite 910, Washington, DC 20005-1202. Fax: (202) 371-0124. DEADLINE: JANUARY 31, 1994.

Air Serv International seeks candidates for PRESIDENT/CEO. Air Serv is the leader in providing non- profit light air transport services to hundreds of international relief and development agencies within the crisis areas of Africa. Since its beginning in 1984, Air Serv's mission has been to provide safe, responsive, reliable and cost-effective air transport in remote areas isolated by war or geological barriers. It has a 9 year history nearly 100,000 flights without fatality or serious injury. Candidates must have experience leading a complex multi-million dollar enterprises and a background in relief and development. Aviation experience strongly preferred. Africa experience a plus. Send resume to Air Serv Search Committee, Box 3401, Redlands, CA 92373 or to confidential fax: 714-771-5199.

InterAction seeks a DIRECTOR OF FINANCE, PERSONNEL, ADMINISTRATION. Individual will oversee financial and contracts management, office administration, and personnel functions. Familiarity with AID contracting and grants management procedures essential. Excellent communication and organizational skills required. Prior experience with not-for-profit organizations would be helpful, but not essential. Applications due February 1. Candidates should send resume with cover letter, including salary history to: Office of the President, InterAction, 1717 Massachusetts Avenue NW, Suite 801, Washington, DC 20036. EOE.

The Refugee Data Center, a non-profit organization, seeks an ASSISTANT DEPUTY DIRECTOR to assist with management, staff supervision, quality control, budget preparation and project development. This position requires a college degree, excellent written and oral communication skills and interpersonal skills. Must have 3-5 years of solid management experience. Knowledge of computer systems helpful. Candidates should send a letter of interest with salary requirements and resume to: L. Farkas, Director, Refugee Data Center, 200 Park Avenue South, Room 911, New York, NY 10003. No phone calls.

The Hunger Project seeks an experienced ASSOCIATE PROGRAM DIRECTOR to plan and implement initiatives, particularly focused on mobilizing and supporting leadership for the sustainable end of hunger. Will have a track record in innovation and communications, and a firm understanding of international human development issues. Responsibilities: Will design and implement a broad range of strategic initiatives in partnership with small team, and individuals and organizations around the world. QUALIFICATIONS: 10+ years of relevant work experience; track record of accomplishments demonstrating vision, commitment, initiative and effective action; Masters or PhD or other demonstration of academic excellence preferred; outstanding verbal and written skills; computer proficiency; understanding of international human development issues; tenacity, a "can-do" attitude, and grace under pressure; ability to interact effectively with people from all levels of society; excellent organizational and analytical skills and self-management ability; team player; international experience and French fluency desirable. Resume and 3 professional references to: Dr. John Coonrod, :Director of Programs, The Hunger Project, 15 E. 26th Street, New York, NY 10010. Fax: 212- 532-9785. No phone calls.

The Trickle Up Program, an international nonprofit organization seeks a DEVELOPMENT OFFICER for its microenterprise development program. RESPONSIBILITIES: Write grant proposals, report to donors and Board of Directors, write and manage direct mailings, organize special events, serve as staff link to Business Council, supervise a Development Associate, write and produce development education publications such as the Annual Report, Fact Sheet, newsletter, Global Report. Starting date: January 1994. REQUIREMENTS: Minimum BA or BS, strong writing and interpersonal skills, proficiency in WordPerfect; 2+ years fund-raising experience and desktop publishing skills preferred. Fax resume and letter to Trickle Up at 212-877-7464. No phone calls.

World Learning, Inc., a US PVO working in international development, seeks a Finance Specialist/Deputy Project Director. Has primary responsibility for all financial and administrative aspects of project management. QUALIFICATIONS include: 5+ years experience in the area of financial management and administration of development programs in Africa; familiarity with US government funding instruments, including solid knowledge of disbursement, monitoring and reporting procedures including equipment procurement, required by USAID cooperative agreements; in-depth knowledge of, or experience in, PVOs/NGOs; proven ability to transfer skills to counterparts; strong computer skills. Previous experience with subgrantee management and A133 audit guidelines desirable. Send resume to Financial Manager, PIDT/DM, World Learning Inc., 1015 15th Street NW, Suite 750, Washington, DC 20005 by JANUARY 20, 1994.

CARE-USA, an international nonprofit relief and development agency, seeks an articulate, dynamic manager to direct recruitment, staff development, and employee relations programs for our national and international staff. QUALIFICATIONS: BA in appropriate discipline, 5 years of human resource experience, working knowledge of HRIS, outstanding management skills, thorough knowledge of EEO compliance and AA initiatives, the ability to design and monitor staff development and employee assistance programs, and the capacity to think and plan strategically. Overseas third world experience and/or background in community development is extremely helpful. Submit your resume and salary history to: Lee Moncaster, CARE-USA, 151 Ellis Street, NE, Atlanta, GA 30303. No phone calls. EOE.

The Department of History and the African Studies Center of Boston University seek a historian of West, Central or southern Africa with a strong background and interest in comparative history, either by region (e.g., Latin American/Caribbean or African-American) or by theme (e.g., slavery, immigration, aesthetics). Application at all ranks will be considered. Employment will begin September 1994. Send letter of application, c.v., and letters of recommendation by FEBRUARY 15, 1994 to Professor James C. McCann, Dept. of History, Boston University, 226 Bay State Road, Boston, MA 02215.

The National Democratic Institute for International Affairs is looking for a RESIDENT PROGRAM OFFICER. Position requires strong creative/design skills, organizational development background, innovative training skills and strong analytical abilities. The Resident Program Officer will reside in Mozambique for the duration of the program, will organize and manage the design and production of voter education materials, serve as a principle project spokesperson, write evaluations of completed programs and assess whether objectives were met. Officer will work closely with Mozambican NGOs, political parties, and election officials, as well as manintain contact with the United Nations and other donor officials. Applicants should have a minimuim of 5 years professional organizing experience and/or graphics/design & public relations experience. Design experience should include projection of videos, brochures, posters and/or training manuals. VOLUNTEER OPPORTUNITIES


LENGTH: 774 words


 

Health Volunteers Overseas has several openings for health care providers who wish to aid its programs in the following nations:

TRANSKEI (one-month assignments; April-December 1994): Participants needed in October and to teach anesthesia at Umtata General Hospital to physicians-in-training. Volunteers will also provide direct anesthesia care. Housing on hospital grounds is provided for the volunteer at no cost. Contact Dr. Kevin Speight, (919) 716- 4498/(919) 454-3956 or Spence Campbell (704) 696-9930. 

UGANDA (one-month assignments; May-December 1994): Volunteers participate in the only anesthesia training program in Uganda. Most of the teaching takes place in Kampala's Mulago Hospital. Housing provided at the guest house at Makerere University. Contact Dr. Harry Zutz, (908) 381-4200/(201) 378-3323.

UGANDA (one-month assignments; March-November 1994): Program trains medical student, physicians, prosthetists, orthotists and physical therapists to improve the treatment of amputees and disabled people injured as a result of civil strife. Surgeons may also conduct orthopedic clinics an operating sessions with Ugandan doctors in upcountry regional hospitals in Tororo/Mbale, Mbarara and Fort Portal. Physical therapist volunteers will be needed to help the Ugandan tutors to develop courses in the three year diploma course are Mulago Hospital. Volunteers need to have a minimum of two years of clinical experience and some educational experience. Advanced degrees and lecture experience are big plus, but are not mandatory. Prosthetists are also being sought to teach. For a nominal fee, housing will be provided at the newly renovated Mulago Guest House. Contact: Dr. David Denzel, (716) 434-2697 or Elizabeth Kay, PT, (708) 897- 4814.

MALAWI (one-month assignments, longer considered; January-March 1994, May-June, 1994, September-December 1994): The Malawi Orthopedic Project trains classes of 10 full-time students in an 18 month course. Volunteers will participate in lectures, clinics, rounds and surgery. Operative cases include polio residents, tuberculosis, osteomyelitis, club feet and trauma. Volunteers will be located in Blantyre at the Queen Elizabeth Central Hospital. They will also travel to district hospitals, where they will supervise graduates of previous classes. Housing is available at a cost of $750 per month. A vehicle is furnished, but volunteers pay for gas. Contact Dr. Richard Kemme, (303) 352-0250.

For a more detailed description of each site as well as copies of trip reports from previous volunteers, contact Health Volunteers Overseas, c/o Washington Station, P.O. Box 65157, Washington, DC 20035-5157; phone: (202) 296-0928.

The American Medical Team for Africa (AMTA) promotes and executes educational exchange and medical training in African countries. The goal of the non-profit organization is to bring volunteer doctors, nurses and medical students together with donated supplies, and equipment to serve needs on the continent. Survey teams assess the most pressing needs in targeted countries, develop and publish training manuals in appropriate languages, hold workshops and refresher courses for doctors, nurses and specialists interested in maintenance of health care delivery systems in Africa; and distribute medical supplies and equipment donated by corporations, pharmaceutical companies, hospitals and doctors. The AMTA plans a second medical mission to Africa. For more information, contact Deman Rageh, Executive Director, The American Medical Team for Africa, 2245 Godby Road, Atlanta, GA 30349; phone (404) 766-8000; fax: (404) 767- 5264.

Volunteer for African Nonprofits for 1 years as an URBAN DEVELOPMENT INTERN. Positions in Kenya, Uganda, Burkina Faso, Zimbabwe, South Africa. Call (202) 625-7403 for information.

PLANNING AHEAD

Washington, DC -- Conference

Africa News


January 18, 1994 / January 31, 1994


FREEING UP AFRICA'S AID FLOWS: ECA HEAD URGES ASSISTANCE TO IMPROVE ECONOMIC GOVERNANCE


BYLINE: Mr. Layashi Yaker, Executive Secretary of the UN Economic Commission for Africa


LENGTH: 1694 words


 

AFRICA RECOVERY, January 1994

Donors should ease their stringent conditions on aid to Africa, UN officials argue, in order to counter the communication of mounting economic and political turmoil and falling financial inflows now threatening to plunge the continent into further decline. Urging donors to show "greater understanding" of the difficult situation in which African governments find themselves and their limited room for maneuver, Mr. Layashi Yaker, Executive Secretary of the UN's Economic Commission for Africa (ECA) also said that the ability of African states to carry out their economic responsibilities must be enhanced. "The state must be strengthened," Mr. Yaker said, reflecting the growing feeling that market- dominated strategies must not negate the role of the public sector.

Mr. Yaker also called for "bold new measures" to lower the debt burden which continues to frustrate the continent's recovery efforts. He was presenting his annual review of African economies in a speech to diplomats in Addis Ababa last month.

So far during the 1990s, African economies have grown by a mere 1.5 per cent a year -- worse than during the "lost decade" of the 1980s. Prospects for this year are only a little improved. ECA estimates that, at best, African economies will grow by only 2.5 per cent this year, still well below the level of population increase. "The prevailing economic and political conditions in Africa do not allow for much optimism," Mr. Yaker warned. 

Just when increased help is needed, flows of official development assistance (ODA) to Africa have fallen a staggering 30 per cent in 1992, the ECA says. Yet, there is at the same time the paradoxical growth of undisbursed funds to the continent, averaging over $57 bn a year since 1990. This compares with actual disbursement of funds to Africa of some $21 bn a year, for the same period, leading Mr. Yaker to call for "greater flexibility" in setting aid conditions.

Mr. Edward Jaycox, the World Bank's Vice President for Africa, has already pointed out that undisbursed funds from the Bank to Africa were -- at over $16 bn -- equivalent to the entire three-year replenishment of the continent's single most important source of concessional money, the International Development Association (IDA). Nearly half-way through its 10-year life, the European Union's fourth Lome Convention with African, Caribbean and Pacific countries has disbursed only 13 per cent of its funds. Millions of dollars still wait to be disbursed from earlier Lome aid budgets.

Unutilized Funding

These unutilized pools of funding, Mr. Yaker concedes, largely reflect Africa's declining absorptive capacity, the result of "political restlessness and paralysis accompanying the democratization process," as well as "outright" armed conflicts, and weak administrative structures. But donors are deepening Africa's financial drought with conditions on aid precisely at the time when government are finding it more and more difficult, politically and financially, to implement the tough measures demanded in their adjustment programmes. "New conditionalities" on aid have been an important factor in the underfunding of most reform programmes, Mr. Yaker agrees.

UN Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali, in a 2 December address to the Panel of High-Level Personalities he has set up to advise him on implementation of the UN's New Agenda for the Development of Africa in the 1990s, argued that "greater care" must be taken to help governments address "the dire human consequences" of economic reform programmes, observing that "structural adjustment is not popular on the streets of Africa."

In his end of year survey of the African economy, Mr. Yaker said that the number of countries where political crises were impeding economic reforms was increasing. "Paradoxically, many such political crises were linked to the efforts at the democratization process," he observed. In this context, the combination of poor economic performance, tough conditionality and inadequate aid funding has often proved a combustible mix. "Given that the continent was already burdened with stringent austerity measures and growing social unease, further doses of economic retrenchments could only have proved, as they did in 1992, politically and socially burdensome," Mr. Yaker argued.

For every example of recovery from conflict, such as Ethiopia, where the economy grew an estimated 9.3 per cent, there were others such as Zaire where the economy continued to contract, last year by some 4 per cent after a 12 per cent decline in 1992.

Drought continued to frustrate African reform efforts as well. Agricultural production was well down in Morocco and other North African countries, with the sub- region barely growing at 0.1 per cent in 1993. Eastern and Southern African countries were also slow to recover from the impact of 1992's severe drought, growing some 1.5 per cent last year. The ECA also warns that recent crop failures in Eritrea and Ethiopia could be a "harbinger of another round of famine."

Adding to these internal problems was the continued sluggishness in the world economy generally. Poor demand in industrialized countries led to an estimated 6.4 per cent fall in prices for Africa's non-oil commodity exports, and could postpone hopes for the current year of a reversal in the 20-year downward spiral that has wreaked so much havoc on the continent's economies. With oil prices also well down, African export earnings declined an estimated 2.7 per cent in 1993, to $72bn.

Even the successful conclusion of the Uruguay Round of trade talks in December brings little hope for the immediate future. African food importers can expect higher prices, Mr. Yaker warns, while Lome Convention members face the erosion of their preferential access to the vital European market. With Africa's level of domestic investment continuing to stagnate, the continent will remain crucially dependent on high inflows of concessional funding to fuel its economic recovery.

Aid flows, however, not only have to be larger, but better coordinated and focused as well, Mr. Yaker argues. Aid should be increasingly directed towards building Africa's indigenous capacity to manage its own economic direction. While the essential role of the state is as facilitator and coordinator, recent development strategies have gone too far in dismantling the public sector, Mr. Yaker implies. "Countries have responded to the well-known failures of old approaches by abandoning planning altogether," Mr. Yaker observes. Instead, strategic planning involving all the principal economic actors, should replace the old model of central planning, be argues. With similar arguments confronting market- driven efforts at reform in the former Soviet Union and Eastern Europe, ECA will try to promote this new thinking further at its May Council of Ministers meeting in Addis Ababa. Goals will include the development of strategic national planning exercises, involving closer partnerships between the major institutional players.

While the state must be enabled to play a strengthened strategic role, African governments will also have to show "greater sensitivity" to the need for public support for reform measures, Mr. Yaker said. Endorsing African countries taking over the "ownership" of reform programmes, Mr. Yaker stressed their related need to boost the competence of their economic governance.

Lack of Domestic Investment

Already, lack of domestic investor confidence in economic management is inflicting the "dual damage" of restraining local capital formation and sending unfavourable signals to foreign investors, Mr. Yaker argued. This is compounded by Africa's debt burden, which continues to weigh heavily on the continent's economic prospects while official creditors discuss further relief. "Unless bold, new measures are taken in 1994 to reduce the debt stock and debt servicing requirements of African countries, economic growth will again be limited as more of ht a meager resources available are devoted to debt repayments," Mr. Yaker said. Actual debt servicing jumped to 35 per cent of exports in 1992 from 30 per cent in 1991. Debt reduction on a scale larger than the Trinidad terms -- which offer cancellation of two-thirds of eligible debt, but which have yet to be fully implemented -- is now required if investor confidence in African economies is to be boosted.

Reprinted from Africa Recovery, January 1994. Africa Recovery Press Features are produced by the United Nations Department of Public Information.

Contact: Africa Recovery, Room S-931, United Nations, NY 10017. Tel: (212) 963-6857, Fax: (212)963-4556.


LOAD-DATE: January 31, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


25 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 18, 1994 / January 31, 1994


AN EARTHQUAKE SHAKES THE UGANDA PRESS


BYLINE: Sarah Miremba and Staff Writer from The Monitor (Uganda)


LENGTH: 2480 words


 

THE MONITOR, January 7-January 11, 1994

Uganda's newspaper industry has become VERY competitive, and some have suffered the worst pinch of the current economic squeeze, and some papers have died or have one foot in the grave.

There is a variety of newspapers on the news-stands today and that is one of the reasons the going is tough. Papers are dying as fast as they are born.

Star's Last Breath

One of the influential dailies like The Star which had maintained a steady competition as the only privately-owned English daily recently closed. This left the government owned New Vision with a monopoly over the daily English market. 

The Star which used to be published by the Shield Publications Ltd. tried to go weekly on September 1, in an effort to stop its financial bleeding. General Manager Katende Luutu justified the move as a means of reducing the high costs of maintaining the two dailies, The Star in English and Ngabo in Luganda. Staff was cut from 74 to 54. Two months later The Star wound up.

Even Uganda Eyogera a Luganda daily founded mid- last year had its Editor-in-Chief Eng. J.B. Walusimbi suspended last month on allegations of "mismanagement and financial problems." The paper's financial woes are said to have led to its "temporary closure" on December 6, 1993.

The closure allegedly came after workers deserted their duties after prolonged non-payment of their salaries. Uganda Eyogera had been running on a daily basis since March 1993. Walusimbi's suspension say Robert Kiwanuka who had been editor "eating" chief editorship on the paper.

Just to make the paper's problems worse, thieves on December 22 are said to have broken into the offices and taken off with two typewriters and destroyed a radio cassette.

Other papers like the New Mirror, Express Post, News Magazine, Financial Times, The Banner, The News Desk and Mukwano which were born amidst lively competition, have either closed down forever, or indefinitely like the case with The Times. The Banner, the then only broadsheet on the market when it was founded in 1992, survived only two issues.

The New Vision's monopoly power over the daily English market is now facing a new entrant. Weekly Topic put out a Daily Topic beginning January 3, 1994.

In July of 1992 there was a dramatic change of faces at Weekly Topic when all but one of its senior journalists left the paper to found their own, The Monitor.

In one of the more remarkable footnotes of recent media history in Uganda, The Monitor became the largest circulating newspaper in less than a year, and became a bi-weekly in March last year.

Cheeye's Hand

The decision by Sseezi Cheeye's Uganda Confidential to rapidly from being a monthly, to a bi-monthly and a weekly changed the face of the weekly market. Its irreverent and crusading style put pressure on other weeklies to change. Weekly Topic's decision to go daily was seen partly as a response to that.

New Vision's reach in the market already eaten into by The Monitor may have to respond to the more blunt and aggressive reporting that one senses Daily Topic is bringing to that segment of the market.

The New Vision's unchallenged four-year reign as the highest circulating newspaper stumbled on Mondays when Uganda Confidential comes out, Tuesday when The Monitor hits the market and on Fridays when Weekly Topic (before it went daily) and the Monitor compete for the same audience.

Fighting Back

To counter the competition, New Vision decided to come up with pullouts like the 'Vision Weekend' on Fridays and 'Straight Talk' on Tuesdays to compete with The Monitor and Weekly Topic. The Vision Weekend was too much like the Weekly Topic's new Weekend Outlook section, many analysts could not help see it is a counter- offensive. New Vision cashing on the fact that it has the best printed pages and gets a lot of the official adverting has increased the number of its pages, and is doing brisk business in advertising which is the envy of every editor.

Going Modern

As part of the shake ups in the industry, most of the surviving newspapers in the country have embarked on a restructuring exercise to modernise their production mechanism and gain efficiency. Computers are edging out the old fashioned and labour intensive manual typewriters.

Cost reduction moves have seen publications laying off some of their staff.

Last October, the youthful Weekly Topic Editor John Baptist Wasswa sent five of its senior journalists on a forced leave in a restructuring move that began November 1. Though this was never said publicly, the move was seen as aimed at some "old guards".

Sources within the paper said at least one person in this group had passed his retirement age and most of them were largely non performers. The measure was reportedly to pave way for the young graduate journalists fresh from the University.

The affected staff, like the assistant Editor Henry Baguma (who has since been recalled) John J. Lule, Willy Kironde Mukasa and Emmanuel Okullu Opk were some of the longest serving staffers at the paper.

Munno Publications also recently sent all its workers on indefinite forced leave. Eight of their senior

staff, including three editors: Lawrence Kateregga, Henry Lumansi and Tamale Mirundi, were sacked. Reason? The cost of maintaining the publication was too high and a restructuring exercise was inevitable.

Munno's Woes

Munno Publications are the publishers of the oldest vernacular newspaper in the country and among the oldest surviving newspapers in Africa. The paper was started in 1911 by Catholic missionaries.

The paper's financial woes started eight years ago but became very bad three years ago.

Munno's woes distressed many senior journalists. At one time about 10 years ago, it was considered the "most reliable" newspaper in the country, and had very high circulations. But Munno was successful in the past because it relied on a network of priests to get its information from places where no one else would, and was broadly mindful of Catholic interests.

Recent years have seen it ignoring the interests of sections of the "Catholic interest" in parts of the country, and increasingly pushing the line for the radical faction of the Democratic Party, with which its Editor-in-Chief, Anthony Ssekwayama, is believed to be allied. It was courting disaster, and the further it has drifted from the safe center, the more it has sank into a grave.

The result of the Munno fiasco is that Tamale Mirundi, who was their best reporter, has teamed up with John Kakande, who was deputy editor of The Star, to bring out Lipoota Reporter with a Ligunda and English editions.

They will have to contend with Saba Saba, which was born last year and is now the highest circulating Luganda newspaper, and the Luganda version of Uganda Confidential, which is likely in the long run to change the tastes of the Luganda readers.

Cutting Losses

Another paper which is being closely watched is The Monitor. The July 14, 1993 government ban on its departments and parastatals advertising in the Monitor had also created a siege mentality in the newspaper, and on some days its offices look like a war room. While it has been perhaps the only newspaper to expand its circulation significantly since the ban in a bid to stem the drop in advertising revenues, its proprietors have nevertheless put a full stop on staff expansion and relapsed into fiscal conservatism.

The paper, unlike in its first year, has not recruited new staff since the advert ban. There is talk of a number of their staff who are currently teaching in the Mass Communications programme at Makerere University withdrawing from that service to go into the "trenches," as the expression at the paper goes.

The programme, which started five years ago, was the brain child of the late Dr. Francis Kidubukka (May his soul rest in eternal peace), Charles Onyango-Obbo, Editor of The Monitor, among others, and was run almost as a one-man show in 1992 by Mr. David Ouma the News Editor of The Monitor when Onyango-Obbo went off on study to the Harvard University, USA, and the programme did not have a Fulbright Fellow which now, fortunately, it has.

The Monitor has always been successful partly because it was able to put a new look in the paper by

coming up regularly with new features: District News, Regional Report, the currently much-read District Profile and the irreverent teaser--Snakes and Ladder of the CA Vote.

Next week it will start publishing a children's paper, Children's Voice, derived from its very successful child-participatory "Children's Voice."

But in this they do not have a monopoly. The Daily Topic, from how it has gone in the first week of being a daily, has a new feature for every day. All these innovations must be breaking for journalists. Only one group of people must be happy, the readers.

Watch-dogs

Besides money, the press has to contend with the politicians' rope around their necks.

Cases of criminal libel, and the highly political sedition cases, are not getting fewer.

While the courts have tended to lean on the side of the press, when court awarded former Amin minister Wanume Kibedi Shs.4.5 million in January, in a defamation case he brought against The Citizen newspaper, it was almost left on its knees.

Individual journalists are also still being threatened and intimidated with arrests.

The latest being the recent arrest of Uganda Confidential's editor, Teddy Sseezi-Cheeye, and Hussein Njuki and Haruna Kanabi, respectively editor and sub- editor of The Shariat.

They were arrested and held for four days, before being charged with sedition and publishing false news, and released at various dates on bail. For Seezi-Cheeye it was his fourth trip to jail in as many years. Even with the very best effort, Uganda Confidential reportedly cannot keep up with the criminal and civil cases being brought against it, but it remains undeterred--and very profitable.

New Faces

With the rat race and the risks, one would think new entrants would be faint-hearted. No. More and more papers are still being born. Apart from the papers like Lipoota, and the ever-growing New Vision family which recently added on th Luo paper Rupiny, and the Sunday Vision last year, other papers are still in the offing.

On Wednesday January 5, 1994, a new paper called The Statesman was born. A Swahili paper will soon hit the streets.

Uganda Today, a new paper, also came on the streets about four weeks ago. By the end of the month, an East African edition of the Nairobi-published will come on the news-stands. They have been advertising heavily in local papers for Ugandan journalists to run their Kampala operation.

Many good and senior journalists, frustrated or bored with their present jobs, are known to have applied.

There are about 25 publications in the country today, with 18 weeklies, six dailies and one bi-weekly. by mid-year, it will be interesting to see whether there will be more or less. No one can tell for sure.

Reprinted from THE MONITOR, January 7-January 11, 1994. THE MONITOR is published by The Monitor Publications Ltd. (Uganda)

CONTACT: THE MONITOR, P.O. Box 12141, Kampala. Phone: 251353; fax: 251352.


LOAD-DATE: January 31, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


26 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 18, 1994 / January 31, 1994


OUR MISSION: EXCERPTS FROM THE 1994 BUDGET SPEECH


BYLINE: General Sani Abacha, Nigerian Head of State


LENGTH: 1400 words


 

NEWSWATCH, January 24, 1994

The economy which this administration inherited was one characterised by grave debilities and great instabilities. On virtually all the indices, the outlook was rather sobering. Economic output as measured by gross national product has been on a steady decline in the past few years. Owing to the sluggish growth, employment has stagnated while the phenomenal growth in money supply fuelled by expansionary fiscal policies have piled pressure on the real sector.

Interbank and lending rates have risen to unprecedented levels, resulting in declines in investment and production. All these have been worsened by a collapse in the value of the naira, the attendant rapid increase of service charges on external debts and the worsening balance of payment profile. 

In short, it can be said that inadequate fiscal discipline complicated the already high incidence of budget deficits which, in turn, made efforts at economic reform more difficult to handle and led to a worsening of social conditions.

The federal budget of 1993 was formulated to address and redress the decline in economic activities. One of its advertised objectives was to promote accountability and transparency in the management of public finance. The budget also aimed at enhancing public sector activities and social programmes, while eliminating market distortions by giving freer rein to private enterprise.

For reasons which are not too difficult to discern, the 1993 budget performed rather poorly both in terms of attainment of set objectives and fidelity to the overall strategy. The budget deficit soared to N90 billion and this resulted in an excessive growth in money supply. The economy experienced high inflation, depreciation of the naira an continuing low capacity utilisation in the real sector. The political crisis which took up most of the second half of the year only served to further accentuate these already serious problems.

The three-year rolling plan was introduced to replace the five-year medium term programme as a development strategy. The twin-objectives of the 1994- 1996 rolling plan are to institute correct macro-economic policies and instill fiscal discipline in order to fashion a more conducive environment for economic growth. It is this imperative that provides the context for the 1994 federal budget.

The goals of the 1994 budget have been set to reverse the negative trend of the recent past. These

goals are: balanced budget firmly anchored in fiscal discipline and abolition of deficit financing; identification and mobilisation of new sources of collectible revenue; exchange rate stabilisation and reversal of the high incidence of capital flight; rationalisation of interest rates to stem the decline of the real sector; adoption of a comprehensive budgeting approach to bring all projects into the process; reduction in the level of subsidies and subventions to federal government-owned companies and parastatals, particularly those slated for partial or full commercialisation and outright privatisation; effective debt management strategies to reduce the debt service burdens on domestic commitments and obtain debt relief from the external creditors; rehabilitation of socio- economic infrastructure and strengthening of the law and order apparatus to provide a conducive environment for legitimate economic pursuits and private initiative; increase in the capacity utilisation of the industrial sector and effective sourcing of local raw materials; promotion of growth linkages in the rural economy; promotion of employment opportunities to reduce the currently high level of unemployment, especially among the youths; and policy fidelity and close monitoring of implementation to ensure the of these goals.

These goals, singularly and in concert, define an economic framework for budget plans and are, therefore, measures for ensuring overall discipline in our recovery effort. This administration will use these goals as standards for measuring the performance of sectors, institutions and officials. This administration wishes to serve notice that the monitoring and review of strategic institutions of public policy which we have commenced will continue and be intensified. This administration will neither tolerate the subversion of its programmes and policies nor will it allow its articulated goals and guidelines to be casually discarded or treated as mere suggestions.

We are now more aware of the relationship between the various aspects of reform programmes we have sought to implement and their overall effects on the quality of life of our citizens. We know that if we service debts, whose total legal character is yet to be ascertained, with our 30 kobo of every externally accrued naira, and if the percentage devoted to servicing of our debts continue to increase while the total income continue to decrease, that out people's welfare would also continue to be mortgaged.

We know that it we embarked on economic reform projects that tie the hands of government and disables government from putting in place programmes that will shelter the more vulnerable sectors of our society from the negative effects of these reforms, that we are actively increasing the ranks of the disaffected who will demand either protection from these effects of call for a change of the economic order and of government.

We know that we cannot embark on a ruinous debt service regime, mount an economic reform programme, and initiated difficult changes of our political system all at the same time. While investors' capital seek new arenas opened up by the ending of the cold war, it is apparent that the Nigerian managers of our economy would have to organise novel ways of undertaking reforms without increasing the volume of conflicts within our social order.

The international community must also come to understand the implications of these various programmes that have shaped the condition of life of our citizens. It is no longer enough to insist on reforms whose patterns of effects have now been catalogues country after country and yet for the international community not to appreciate what are the likely outcomes of changes that it advocates.

Nigeria, like other African countries similarly situated, have implemented structural adjustments of their economies. They are carrying the heavy burden that their debts place on their shoulders and they are saddled with the effect of painful and conflict-ridden democratisation of the policies. These three projects are all sources of conflicts that threaten social order and peace. There must be a way of spacing them and managing the conflicts they generate.

Reprinted from NEWSWATCH, January 24, 1994 NEWSWATCH is published by Newswatch Communications, Limited.

CONTACT: Newswatch Communications, Ltd., No. 3 Billings Way, Oregun Industrial Estate, Oregun, P.M.B. 24199, Ikeja, Lagos, Nigeria. Tel: 4960950. Fax: 962887.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


January 18, 1994 / January 31, 1994


MUSEVENI, MOI, MWINYI IN 'SECRET' PLAN FOR JOINT ARMY


BYLINE: THE MONITOR (Uganda)


LENGTH: 800 words


 

THE MONITOR, January 7-January 11, 1994

The idea sounded very attractive to the other leaders apparently because of the commonality of political problems facing the three leaders.

Tanzania's Ali Hassan Mwinyi is threatened with cracks in the union between mainland Tanzania and the Zanzibar island.

Kenya has been in the throes of ethnic violence for about a year now, and Moi, according to analysts in Nairobi sees part of the solution in an army under control, and a middle class which returns to its old relatively high standard of living. 

When Museveni was in Nairobi to attend the 30th Independence anniversary, Mwinyi was also in attendance and the three leaders reportedly met again and continued their Arusha conversations.

The push for a revival of the East African Community from Kenya's Moi has been remarkable since they initialed the November treaty in Arusha which started the process.

Yesterday a meeting of the Tripartite Commission which set up the treaty got underway and will go through the week.

The confederate authority would as a matter of priority put in place a joint military structure which sources say would be a design to crush any coup attempts by any of the national armies in the three states.

Besides the political benefits, Kenya has a lot more economic benefits to gain in the renewed regional cooperation. First because its previous position as an economic giant has suffered a severe blow from economic decline. Most investors in Kenya now view Uganda and Tanzania as more promising grounds for their money.

Secondly, the lifting of economic and political sanctions against South Africa has created economic panic among the Kenyan business class. South African goods have already started replacing Kenyan goods in both Uganda and Tanzania.

Uganda's interest in a joint airframe under the regional structure is understandable, if only because it lacks an airframe to speak of since its fleet was wiped out by the in the 1979 liberation war.

In the last seven years, Sudanese planes have impudently invaded Uganda's airspace and indiscriminately bombed areas near the border. The Sudanese government says rebels of the Sudanese People's Liberation Army (SPLA) have bases in northern Uganda, a claim the Kampala government has consistently denied.

Amidst all the euphoria however, The Monitor has learnt that Museveni remains th puzzling quantity in this scenario. First, he allegedly dominates meetings of the three heads of state by the sheer force of his intellect and plain speaking. Not many people believe that Uganda wants only safe passage to the sea and a cheap way to have an airframe capacity.

The unease about Museveni is not entirely unfounded. The Monitor's sub-editor was in Nairobi recently to sound out the new mood in Kenya in favour of regional co-operation and the comfortable relationship between Museveni and Moi, once arch enemies.

He reported that the level of public admiration for Museveni was tremendous. Museveni made bones when he kept a large crowd on its toes with his kick-them-in-the-pants speech during the December celebrations in Nairobi.

"If we were to elect an East African president, we would elect Museveni," he reported several Kenyans telling him (see story next week).

Since the Arusha meeting which put emphasis on expanding functional instituitions like railways, harbours, posts and telecommunications, Kenya has already extended its railway services up to Kampala, adding to the fleet of buses that now ply between the two capital cities.

Reprinted from THE MONITOR, January 7-January 11, 1994. THE MONITOR is published by The Monitor Publications Ltd. (Uganda)

CONTACT: THE MONITOR, P.O. Box 12141, Kampala. Phone: 251353; fax: 251352.


LOAD-DATE: January 31, 1994


LANGUAGE: English
