28 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 18, 1994 / January 31, 1994


NO PLACE LIKE HOME: MOZAMBICAN REFUGEES BEGIN AFRICA'S LARGEST REPATRIATION


BYLINE: Jeff Drumtra


LENGTH: 4254 words


 

U.S. COMMITTEE FOR REFUGEES ISSUE PAPER, December 1993

This report was written by Jeff Drumtra, Africa policy analyst for the U.S. Committee for Refugees (USCR). It is based, in part, on a USCR site visit to Zimbabwe, Mozambique, and South Africa in April/May 1993. It was edited by Virginia Hamilton and produced by Koula Papanicolas.

The following are conclusions and recommendations derived from this study. Conclusions and Recommendations

Mozambique is undergoing a transformation of historic proportions. One of the world's most brutal wars is over. The largest return of refugees and internally displaced persons in African history is taking place in the poorest country on earth. 

Some 5.5 million returnees will discover all too soon, however, that their beloved homeland is not yet ready to be a decent home. Too many devastating years of war, drought, and abandonment have brought the nation to its knees.

Although the fighting has stopped, permanent peace has not quite begun. Mozambique will not truly find peace until its uprooted people find their way home. The country cannot expect to piece itself back together until all its pieces--its people--are home again.

For millions of Mozambicans, most of them illiterate farmers who had no stake in the civil war other than bare survival, resettlement in their home districts involves dangerous risks--risks that war could resume, that political instability might drag on interminably, that food will be scarce and landmines abundant.

Mozambicans going home after years of upheaval deserve tranquillity and security, but they will instead find dangerous new tests awaiting them. Returnees will need help from many quarters if they are to integrate successfully.

The test for Mozambican government officials is whether they are equal to the task of rebuilding their country with political openness, economic reforms, and wise development decisions.

The test for Renamo is whether it is willing to lay down its arms and join the national political discourse with civil ideas instead of brutality and guns.

The test for neighboring countries of asylum is whether they will support repatriation with patience so that Mozambique can acquire permanent stability that would benefit the entire southern African region.

For the United States and the international community, the test is whether they will provide sufficient, well-targeted assistance in an age of shrinking budgets and competing international priorities to help tormented people rebuild their lives and their nation.

Massive repatriation and resettlement are underway in Mozambique, ready or not. This is a pivotal moment that could produce a new humanitarian crisis, or form the basis for a shattered nation's fresh beginning.

With these challenges in mind, the U.S. Committee

for Refugees makes the following recommendations:

To the Mozambican Government

1. Improve the government's cooperation with relief and development agencies. Specifically, the government should reduce import duties on relief supplies and equipment, encourage international NGOs in Malawi to establish cross-border operations in to Mozambique, and crack down on corruption by government workers engaged in relief distributions.

Top government officials have given repeated assurances that government policy includes full cooperation with relief and repatriation operations, but government personnel often fall short of those promises.

The government should expedite the import of NGO and UN supplies without exorbitant tariffs. Government officials should streamline procedures so that NGOs with long experience working in Malawi refugee camps can easily transfer their programs across the border into Mozambique.

Mozambican officials should ferret out corruption within government relief programs, particularly within the Office for Prevention and Combat of Natural Disasters (DPCCN), which assists in food distributions, and at the Quelimane port.

2. Decentralize decision-making by bestowing greater authority on government officials who work at district- and administrative-post levels.

The massive migration of Mozambicans back to their homes will create humanitarian emergencies to which local authorities must respond rapidly and with flexibility. Deciding which health clinics to build, which wells to repair, which small settlements to stock with food, or which tertiary roads to clear of landmines are decisions best handled at a grassroots level.

Overly centralized decision-making in Maputo would be cumbersome at best and potentially life-threatening at worst.

3. Allow traditional nongovernmental community leaders to clarify local land tenure issues at a local level.

Land disputes are inevitable as 5.5 million persons return home after years of displacement. Most returnees are subsistence farmers who possess virtually nothing but the ground beneath their feet. The land is their livelihood.

Renamo initially capitalized on farmers' alienation over the government's former land tenure rules, and land ownership remains the single most sensitive political issue in the country. Government officials in Maputo lack the administrative resources and the grassroots credibility needed to resolve most individual land tenure disputes.

4. Encourage political pluralism.

The government has pledged its commitment to an open multiparty political system, including the participation of Renamo as a political party. Government officials at all levels should maintain this commitment both before and after national elections.

5. Encourage reunification of families separated by the war, and establish foster family care programs for unaccompanied children instead of placing them in institutional orphanages.

An estimated quarter-million or more children have been separated from or lost their families as a result of the war. NGOs in refugee camps have established extensive foster-family programs to care for unaccompanied minors, but Mozambican government agencies have limited experience operating foster care programs, and historically have placed such children into orphanages.

The needs of unaccompanied minors may multiply as boy soldiers previously conscripted into Renamo ranks are suddenly free and alone without family, and many children currently supported by foster families in refugee camps will lose that support when they return to Mozambique.

To Renamo

1. Allow unrestricted access to territory under Renamo control and grant complete freedom of movement by all Mozambicans, UN agencies, NGOs, and government officials.

Renamo has granted improved access to relief officials since the ceasefire but continues to block or delay access in many instances. Evidence indicates that Renamo continues to impede free movement by many destitute families trying to exit Renamo-controlled regions in search of food.

2. Renamo political and military leaders should cooperate fully with relief and development efforts.

Renamo's distrust of outsiders and its own lack of knowledge about the requirements of relief operations have slowed relief efforts. In addition to granting humanitarian access, Renamo leaders should allow NGOs and UNHCR about arrivals of new returnees and other matters of humanitarian concern.

3. Renamo leader Afonso Dhlakama should meet regularly--perhaps monthly--with Mozambican President Joaquim Chissano.

The two leaders have met face-to-face only twice in the past year despite repeated offers by President Chissano to meet with Dhlakama virtually anywhere at any time. Infrequent contact between Dhlakama and Chissano after so many years of warfare feeds mistrust between the two sides and heightens public concerns that the peace is shallow and impermanent.

To the Government and Renamo

1. The government and Renamo should disarm and demobilize their troops without delay in accordance with written pledges made in last year's peace accord.

Renamo has consistently stalled troop demobilization, and the government has responded by keeping its troops armed. No meaningful disarmament had occurred by early November 1993, more than a full year after the signing of the accord, and seven months after the demobilization deadline originally agreed to by both sides.

UN peacekeepers are in place to provide protection, and demobilization sites have been identified, and programs to transport and resettle demobilized soldiers stand idle. Millions of Mozambicans cannot safely return to their homes until demobilization is completed.

2. Government officials and troops, and Renamo leaders and their soldiers in the field, should reveal the location of all landmines planted of discovered during the war.

The possible existence of one million or more landmines endangers all Mozambicans, particularly refugees and internally displaced families returning to former war zones.

Although government officials have generally cooperated with the United Nations' landmine clearance efforts, suspicions persist that some government military commanders have withheld information about the locations of minefields, in expectation that they will eventually receive financial compensation for divulging the information. Renamo's assertions that it did not lay landmines during the war are not believable.

The government and Renamo should immediately make public all information about landmines as part of their pledge in the peace accord to "undertake everything within their power for the achievement of genuine national reconciliation."

Withholding information about the location of landmines to extort financial or political gain is unconscionable.

To UNHCR

1. Adhere to the current strategy of providing egalitarian assistance to all Mozambicans--refugees and non-refugees alike--who are in need in returnee areas.

Mozambique is a devastated country. Many internally displaced Mozambicans find themselves in even worse condition than returning refugees. UNHCR has correctly decided to stretch its mandate--and its budget--by rendering assistance to all Mozambicans who need assistance in returnee areas.

2. Maintain adequate staffing and resources for UNHCR's operations in Mozambique, and grant wide authority to UNHCR staff in the field.

Returnees will be endangered if UNHCR fails to fulfill its repatriation duties. NGOs in the country are clamoring for better UNHCR coordination of repatriation and resettlement activities.

The agency should expedite its hiring process to maintain sufficient staffing, and should ensure that its field staff possess the authority and resources required to address rapidly changing conditions in isolated returnee areas.

3. Encourage and facilitate cross-border reconnaissance visits into Mozambique by refugees in asylum countries.

Refugees must obtain accurate information about conditions in their home areas of Mozambique so that they can determine when to repatriate. Information-gathering visits by refugee representatives are the single most credible source of information for many refugees.

UNHCR should provide transportation assistance and diplomatic support to these trips as necessary.

4. Provide transportation for refugees facing long journeys home.

UNHCR planners assume that the large majority of Mozambicans in Malawi will repatriate on foot or will purchase private transportation. This strategy is acceptable for short trips. Families facing journeys of several days, however, should qualify for more generous transportation assistance from UNHCR and the International Organization for Migration.

5. Press for earlier landmine clearance along secondary and tertiary roads that are likely to be key access routes for returnees.

UNHCR has identified key access routes, but UN mine clearance crews may fail to reach these routes before returnees arrive. UNHCR should urge the United Nations Operation in Mozambique (UNOMOZ) to give the highest possible priority to clearance of returnee routes, including remote footpaths.

To NGOs (International Nongovernmental Organizations)

1. Improve coordination of operations in the field and develop programs sufficiently flexible to meet the needs of Mozambique's massive population on the move.

There is no excuse for poor coordination in Mozambique, where many NGOs are just beginning new programs in previously inaccessible areas, and where "turf fights" over established programs should not exist. Poor coordination could result in refugees returning to areas unstocked with food, trucks laden with returnees traveling roads not yet cleared of landmines, and wasteful construction of buildings in unpopulated districts.

NGOs cannot "control" the movements or destinations of returnees. NGOs should instead establish operations capable of anticipating the country's population flows and responding quickly to emerging needs.

2. Road repairs and programs that increase local food production should be high priorities. NGOs should sustain their commitment beyond emergency relief.

Mozambique is the poorest country on earth and will require decades of development effort. NGOs should shift from short-term to longer-term reconstruction and development as local conditions permit.

3. Seek opportunities to collaborate with Mozambicans inside and outside of the government at local levels, who generally would benefit from closer association with professional relief and development workers.

International NGOs can help impart valuable professional skills to local government officials and volunteers working for nongovernmental Mozambican organizations at the provincial and district levels. This process would empower local workers so that the countries formerly centralized government structure becomes more decentralized and responsive.

To the United Nations and World Bank

1. Keep UN peacekeeping troops in Mozambique.

Mistrust between the government and Renamo remains a threat to permanent peace and hinders refugee repatriation. The UN should maintain its full peacekeeping contingent in Mozambique until full disarmament and demobilization are completed. The UN should keep a smaller peacekeeping force in place until the national election.

In November 1993, the United Nations voted to extend UN operations in Mozambique for six additional months. More extensions will probably be necessary.

2. Devote adequate UN resources to help ensure a fair, credible election with full popular participation.

The UN and other organizations should assist voter education, election planning and logistics, election monitoring, and other activities that encourage participatory democracy. The UN should enhance popular participation by exploring the feasibility of enabling refugees in asylum countries to cast absentee ballots during the election.

3. Sustain the United Nations' commitment beyond emergency relief.

Mozambicans will be rebuilding their country's destroyed infrastructure and social structure for decades. UNOHAC should play a leadership role in coordinating the world community's assistance efforts.

4. The World Bank should ease economic austerity measures so that Mozambique's government can hire teachers, doctors, and other humanitarian civil servants.

The World Bank should refrain from imposing artificial hardships on Mozambique and its people. Overdue reductions in the government's bloated payroll should not preclude hiring qualified teachers, doctors and other carefully selected personnel for closely monitored humanitarian endeavors. International donors should be encouraged to proved funds for hiring local teachers and medical personnel in Mozambique.

To the United States and other Governments

Provide generous, sustained financial support to repatriation, resettlement, relief, and rehabilitation in Mozambique.

Africa's largest refugee crisis can finally come to a satisfactory end if the United States and other major donors lend proper support. The United States should be commended for funding up to one-third of the early UNOMOZ budget and pledging $10.3 million to first-year repatriation expenses.

Sustained support will be essential, however. UNHCR's overall $203 million repatriation program for Mozambique remains 85 cents underfunded per dollar; a $12 million appeal by the International Federation of the Red Cross for repatriation and rehabilitation is 80 percent underfunded; other UN and NGO agencies will require hundreds of millions of additional dollars for the massive task of helping Mozambicans rebuild their country.

Inadequate donor support in the next few years would sow the seeds for intractable suffering at a time when regional stability finally has become a real possibility for Mozambique and its neighbors in southern Africa.

To Asylum Countries

1. Asylum countries should patiently allow Mozambican refugees to remain in asylum until they are prepared to repatriate voluntarily.

Malawi, Zimbabwe, Zambia, Swaziland, and Tanzania have--despite some justified criticisms--generally treated Mozambican refugees well in recent years and should be commended. The notable exception was South Africa, which for years refused to grant official asylum to Mozambicans and callously deported large numbers throughout the war. South African leaders finally signed agreements with UNHCR and Mozambique in late 1993 to provide better treatment of refugees.

The six asylum countries should refrain from pushing refugees to repatriate prematurely or involuntarily. Mozambique remains dangerous, and Mozambicans should be allowed to return at their own pace.

2. Asylum countries should allow and facilitate cross- border reconnaissance trips into Mozambique by refugee representatives so that refugees can gain crucial eyewitness information about conditions at their destination.

Refugees must have accurate information about conditions in their home areas of Mozambique so that they can determine when to repatriate. Reports about conditions deep inside the country may not reach refugee camps outside the country. Fact-finding visits are the most credible source of information for many refugees. Asylum countries should encourage these cross-border journeys.

3. Asylum countries should allow Mozambican refugees to cast absentee ballots if they are unable to repatriate voluntarily prior to the scheduled October 1994 election.

UNHCR predicts that as many as half of all Mozambican refugees will still be in asylum countries in October 1994 due to poor conditions in Mozambique. Enabling refugees to participate in the election by casting absentee ballots is logistically difficult but would enhance the credibility of the elections and contribute to national reconciliation.

4. Malawi should provide improved security for refugees traveling home to Mozambique.

Security in and around refugee camps in Malawi has deteriorated. Some refugees who have repatriated to Mozambique report that they have been victimized by bandits and by Malawi police. Mozambicans who have endured years of upheaval should not be subjected to the danger that their meager provisions will be stolen on the journey home.

5. South Africa should render assistance to refugees before and during repatriation.

After years of callous disregard for the well-being of Mozambican refugees, South African officials in September agreed for the first time to allow UNHCR protection and assistance for Mozambican refugees in South Africa. In October, South African authorities signed an agreement to help plan for the refugees' repatriation. South African officials have also indicated an interest in providing assistance inside Mozambique to agricultural projects, water supply programs, and skills training.

South African authorities should build on these welcome and long overdue steps.

Reprinted from U.S. COMMITTEE FOR REFUGEES ISSUE PAPER, "NO PLACE LIKE HOME: MOZAMBICAN REFUGEES BEGIN AFRICA'S LARGEST REPATRIATION," December 1993. Contact: U.S. Committee For Refugees, 1717 Massachusetts Ave., N.W., Suite 701, Washington, DC 20036. Phone: (202) 347-3507; fax: (202) 347-3418.


LOAD-DATE: January 31, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


29 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


January 18, 1994 / January 31, 1994


CONGO FINDS DEMOCRACY TOUGH GOING


BYLINE: Cindy Shiner


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 1854 words


 

AFRICA NEWS SERVICE, January 27, 1994

It's a worrisome thing when a president whose capital is fighting an undeclared urban war laments, "I have no army."

It is doubly troublesome when that president leads a democracy that has been considered a role model for the entire sub-Saharan region. President Pascal Lissouba, who became this Central African nation's first freely elected president in 1992 following 30 years of Marxist rule, actually does have an army; he just doesn't feel that he quite controls it.

And, by all accounts, he doesn't. But that is only one among several problems faced by him and other African leaders who head new democracies plagued with too many guns and too little experience with Western-style multi- party politics. The tension could spark a period of upheaval unseen since the battles for independence 40 years ago. 

Congo is experiencing its first ethnic-based fighting since 1958. To the east, Burundi's politically inspired ethnic battles left its first freely elected president and up to 100,000 other people dead last fall. In southern Africa, after fighting a 16-year was Angolans took up arms again 15 months ago when the opposition rejected its loss in the country's first democratic presidential election.

To too many politicians, said one Western diplomat who spoke on condition that he not be named, "democracy has just become another vehicle of ethnic domination through the ballot box."

Congo is inching dangerously close to a full-blown civil war. A political impasse has touched off ethnic fighting that has left up to 1,500 people dead in the capital Brazzaville in the past two months alone, diplomats and aid workers say. Another 400,000 people, half of the city's population, have been displaced as civilian militias split neighborhoods into opposition and pro-government strongholds, according to UNICEF, the U.N. Children's Fund. Arms flow freely into the country from South Africa and across the Congo River from anarchy- plagued Zaire.

The economy is suffering considerably. One of every 10 Brazzaville residents works for the bloated civil service and has gone without pay for nine months. Few people even bother to work more than a few hours a day. Congo's currency -- along with that of 13 other former French colonies -- was devalued this month by half, effectively cutting state salaries and raising food prices. Bread is scarce and the rail link between Brazzaville and the southern Pointe-Noire port was partially dismantled by opposition militants. Port workers are on strike.

It wasn't always like this. Only two years ago this oft-rich nation was euphoric over an end to authoritarian rule. Democratic elections followed a national conference which featured open debate that had been unthinkable under military ruler Denis Sassou-Nguesso. The conference stripped him of his powers and a transitional government wrote a new constitution.

Citizens of the newly democratic Congo tended to look with pity at their neighbors in Zaire, who are still struggling under the nearly quarter century-long dictatorship of President Mobutu Sese Seko. In recent years, economic despair has brought Zaireans in droves to seek wealth and refuge on Congolese shores.

Now, however, it could be Congolese who end up launching their pirogues to cross the river towards the relative calm of Zaire, a move akin to abandoning a burning house for a sinking ship.;

Congo's troubles began after legislative elections last May that the opposition, led by Bernard Kolelas, accused the government of rigging. The opposition boycotted the second round of voting in June, and armed clashes began between government and opposition supporters in Brazzaville's suburbs.

The fighting quickly took on ethnic overtones because political parties largely had coalesced around ethnic allegiance. Two southern groups, the Laris and Niboleks, are at the center of the conflict. Lari "ninjas" are fighting against both Nibolek militias and Lissouba's personally formed commandos known as the Aubevillois. No buses or taxis dare enter the capital's embattled neighborhoods. The U.S. ambassador's home, on the periphery of an affected area, was sprayed with machine-gun crossfire last week. No one was injured, but the incident has prompted the evacuation of 25 embassy dependents.

"We have fallen into fear and terror," said a young Lari man, a member of the opposition party's cabinet, who is in hiding in central Brazzaville because he fears being arrested or killed by government paramilitary forces. Aid workers say bodies lie in the streets of sealed-off neighborhoods, are buried in shallow graves or thrown into the Congo River.

"There are really, really awful ethnic atrocities going on here now," said the diplomat. Congolese now call the Bakongo neighborhood Serajevo.

Many of the killings are blamed on Lissouba's Aubevillois, a heavily armed militia of about 500 young men who are quickly gaining a reputation on par with the tonton macoutes of Haiti who carried out a campaign of terror to silence government opponents.

Lissouba created the Aubevillois, named after the place where they were trained, to deal with the problems that erupted in Bakongo. The regular army, which numbers about 14,000, had refused to intervene to stop the fighting between pro- and anti-government forces. Largely from the north, like their former leader Sassou-Nguesso, the military feared being drawn into bloody north-south conflict. Northerners, who had been favored by the French colonial rulers, continued to dominate the country after independence in 1960 until Lissouba came to power.

Lissouba, a 62-year old geneticist, denies that he stocked the Aubevillois with members of his own ethnic group for protection, saying it was simply a matter of convenience because they happened to live near the camp and the government didn't have enough money to recruit from the entire country.

He resents the loyalty Sassou-Npuesso still enjoys among armed forces and accuses him of helping arm opposition militias. "I have no army here. I just come from the outside and I have been absent from here during roughly 20 years," he said in an interview, referring to his time abroad when Sassou-Nguesso was busy recruiting.

The regular army refuses to let Lissouba's Aubevillois be integrated into their forces. Although the army outnumbers them, but the Aubevillois are said to be well-armed with weapons from South Africa and Lissouba said he plans to increase their numbers by 2,000 and to broaden their ethnic base.

"Today security is the priority," said Clement Mierassa, a former presidential candidate with the opposition Congolese Social Democratic Party. "If the ninjas weren't there we wouldn't be talking about democracy anymore. The opposition would have already been broken." Critics of the Social Democrats counter that it was the ninjas who began the ethnic purges last June by chasing non-Laris from their neighborhoods.

While security is now the chief preoccupation of both sides in the conflict, Congo has still managed to maintain democratic institutions, namely the Parliament, where opposition and government delegates meet regularly. In addition, a mediator has established contact between Lissouba, Kolelas and Sassou-Nguesso. A cease-fire went into effect last Sunday and the capital has been relatively quiet since.

However, the coming week is a crucial one and should indicate just how committed the government and the opposition are to the democratic process. The International College of Arbitrators, a body of European and African observers that was selected to help break the political impasse, is to decide by Feb. 5 whether the opposition or the presidential movement holds the parliamentary majority. Their ruling will be based on reviews of the disputed legislative elections. Under the constitution, the majority nominates the prime minister, who appoints the government.

"If they say the parliamentary majority rests in the hands of the presidential movement, we will accept it," said Kolelas in a telephone interview. "That is democracy. I'm not the president's enemy. He's my brother."

Lissouba has also suggested the possibility of creating a "government of national unity," but said he frowned on running ministries with members of different political parties unless he could choose the ministers from a broad selection.

A peaceful settlement of Congo's political problems could be an inspiration for pro-democracy advocates in other African countries. And Congo itself can look to Burundi for inspiration and hope. After the murder of its president, the east African nation has just selected a new president and is moving forward with the democratic process.

Lissouba is seeking a $1 billion bridge loan from the World Bank to implement social and economic reforms that he hopes will ease the strains that led to conflict.

"It is a challenge for us to start now and to have a democracy after one year" of transition, Lissouba said, "It is not possible. We have to give five years to 10 years" to move toward full democratic rule. The constitution, modeled on those of France and the United States, "cannot fit with our culture now. It is not what we're used to."


LOAD-DATE: January 31, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


30 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 1, 1994 / February 14, 1994


CURRENCY EXCHANGE RATES


LENGTH: 2420 words


 

Maxwell Stamp PLC

Economic Consultants

London * Nairobi * Riyadh * Mauritius

The table gives selected currencies valued against the major international trading currencies. Rates quoted are the middle rates between buying and selling, but currencies are in most cases not freely traded. These rates have been compiled by Maxwell Stamp PLC for information only. Maxwell Stamp accepts no responsibility for any transaction undertaken on the basis of these figures. For further information please contact John Morgan at Maxwell StampUs Head Office in London; phone 44- 71-251-0147; telex 914569 MAXAMP G; fax 44-71-251-0140. 

 

*CFA Franc = Benin, Burkina Faso, Cameroon, Central African Republic, Chad, Comoros, Congo, Cote d'Ivoire, Equatorial Guinea, Gabon, Mali, Niger, Senegal, Togo.

** commercial rate


                               $            L           DM

BUSINESS


LENGTH: 1120 words


 

The following procurement opportunities in Egypt are available to U.S. companies through the U.S. Agency for International Development.

*Three Ambulances. I.F.B. # ENR/4-94/ARE. A.I.D. Geographic Code 000 (U.S. only). Purchasing Agent: Egyptian National Railways. BID OPENING: FEBRUARY 21, 1994. Write to the Embassy of the Arab Republic of Egypt, 2232 Massachusetts Avenue, NW, Washington, DC 20008. Write to the above address and send $20.00 non-refundable fee to obtain a copy of the solicitation.

Write to the above address and send $20.00 non-refundable fee to obtain a copy of the solicitation.

32 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 1, 1994 / February 14, 1994


EDUCATION/TRAVEL


LENGTH: 3027 words


 

Education, Society and Learning in an African Context is a summer course in Zimbabwe from June 30 - August 7, 1994 sponsored by MSU's African Studies Center, Department of Teacher Education, and the Office of Overseas Study. For more information, contact: John Metzler at (517) 353-1700 or Anne Schneller at (517) 355-5522. Or write to the African Studies Center, 100 Center for International Studies and Programs, MSU, East Lansing, MI 48824-1035. E-mail: 21248JM@MSU.EDU.

The International Bicycle Fund will sponsor a two-week, people-to-people, bicycle and train tours in Tunisia in March and April, 1994. Tour participants will meet craftsmen, educators, officials, and learn about day-to-day life in the villages. Contact: International Bicycle Fund, 4887 Columbia Dr. South. Seattle, WA 98108-1919.

Wells College will sponsor a course, "Senegalese" Society, Culture and Politics", which will introduce students to the complexity of Senegalese society, culture and politics. Most lectures will be held at the Universite Cheikh Ahta Diop in Dakar. Contact: Tukumbi Lumumba-Kasongo, Political Science, P.O. Box 345, Wells College, Aurora, NY 13026; phone: (315) 463-3220. 

 

The Africa Fund continues to offer full- and part-time internships in its New York office. Activities often include research, data-base maintenance, filing, and information distribution. Contact: Adrene Ifill, The Africa Fund, 198 Broadway, New York, NY 10038; phone: (212) 962-1210.

The African Development Foundation offers Gray Senior Fellowships to African Academics and development professionals who have demonstrated a commitment to grass-roots development. Contact: African Development Foundation, 1400 Eye Street, N.W., 10th Floor, Washington, DC 20005; phone: (202) 673-3916.

The American Association of University Women Educational Foundation provides fellowships for graduate study in the U.S. to women who are not citizens or permanent residents of the U.S. Preference given to women demonstrating a prior commitment to improving the lives of women and girls, and applicants focusing their project on the advancement of women. Contact: AAUW Educational Foundation , 2401 Virginia Avenue, N.W., Washington, DC 20037.

The American University in Cairo is offering African Fellowships for two years of study toward an AUC Masters degree. Applicants from all disciplines are encouraged to apply. Contact: International Graduate Programs, Office of the Provost, American University in Cairo, P.O. Box 2511, 113 Kasr al Aini, Cairo, Egypt.

Boston University offers an opportunity to study in Niamey, Niger. Contact: Ned Quigley, Director, International Programs, Boston University, 232 Bay State Road, Boston, MA 02215; fax: (617) 353-5402.

The Center for Latin American Studies and the Center for African Studies invite junior and senior scholars to participate in an interdisciplinary program on Afro-American identity and cultural diversity in the Americas, including the Caribbean, Brazil, and the US, as well as areas of Africa. The program will enable visiting scholars to spend an year or a semester at the University of Florida to do research in this area. It will include studies of history, literature, religion, and popular culture. Each fellow will receive a maximum stipend of US$35,000 for the academic year, or half that for the semester. Applicants will be selected on a competitive basis related to their expertise and research in these areas. Candidates should submit a 100-word abstract, an essay of about 1,500 words detailing proposed research, a curriculum vitae, and two letters of recommendation. Send applications to Dr. Helen I. Safa, Center for Latin American Studies, University of Florida, P.O. Box 115530, Gainesville, FL 32611-5530; phone: (904) 392-0375; fax: (904) 392-7682.

The Council for Development of Social Science Research in Africa (CODESRIA) has a Small Grants Program for Thesis Writing to fund M.A. and Ph.D. candidates who are in the process of completing their theses. The funds will cover expenses in a country where research is conducted, but they will not cover the cost of travel to that country. For more information contact: Dr. Cyrus Reed, Office of African Studies, American University in Cairo, P.O. Box 2511, 113 Kasr al Aini, Cairo, Egypt.

Howard University's Center for the Study of Culture and Development in Africa offers a Resident Fellowship Program on Culture and Development. The theme of the program in 1994-1995 is "Gender, Cultural Production and Development in Africa." Two fellowships will be awarded, and fellows must be engaged in full -time research and be in residence at Howard University for the duration of the fellowship (August 1994-May 1995). Each full-year fellowship carries a stipend of US$30,000, plus $4,000 for relocation expenses, insurance, and other expenses. Limited funds are available for travel within the U.S. Candidates must have completed Ph.D. at the time of application. DEADLINE FOR RECEIPT OF APPLICATIONS AND ALL SUPPORTING DOCUMENTS: FEBRUARY 28, 1994. Contact: Director , Center for the Study of Culture and Development, Department of African Studies, Box 231, Howard University, Washington, DC 20059; phone: (202) 806 -7115; fax: (202) 806-4425.

The International Bicycle Fund is sponsoring two two-week bicycle/train tours of Tunisia in March and April of 1994. The tours depart North America on March 29 and April 12. Land cost, including accommodations, meals, museum and monument fees and tour guide is US$1,090. Airfare is additional. IBF is also sponsoring bicycle tours of Zimbabwe, July 10-23, 1994 and July 24-August 6, 1994. Contact: IBF-Africa Program, 4887 Columbia Drive South, Seattle, WA 98108-1919; phone: (206) 628-9314; fax (manually activated): (206) 628-9314.

The IFESH is also recruiting teachers for its Teachers for Africa program designed to help improve education in Africa. This program sends educators to assist in African primary and secondary schools as well as African universities. Assignments are for one academic year. Seven years of teaching or administrative experience preferred. Must be U.S. citizens or permanent residents. IFESH is responsible for placement, orientation, round-trip transportation, insurance, and a living allowance while in Africa. DEADLINE: APRIL 4, 1994. Contact: IFESH, 5040 East Shea Boulevard, Suite 260, Phoenix, AZ 85254-4610; phone: (602) 443-1800; fax: (602) 443-1824.

The William K. Kellogg Foundation offers international fellowships within its Initiatives in Leadership program. Study grants are available to southern Africans who are faculty or staff members of, and nominated by, an organization , institution or agency that has received funding or is being considered for funding by the Kellogg Foundation. Candidates should not already reside in the U.S. Contact: W.K. Kellogg Foundation, International Study Grant Office, One Michigan Avenue East, Battle The Modern Management Institute in Nairobi, Kenya offers a new home study method for learning Kiswahili, a language spoken in Kenya, Tanzania, Uganda, Malawi, Zambia, Zaire, Rwanda, Burundi, and the Sudan. The method includes a basic English/Kiswahili textbook for 24 lessons and audio cassettes to help with pronunciation. Contact: Geoffrey Njogu, Director of Studies, Modern Management Institute, P.O. Box 47390, Nairobi, Kenya; phone: (254.2) 33.17.02.

National Science Foundation Dissertation Improvement Grants support African graduate students who are enrolled in U.S. universities and are planning to undertake dissertation research related to a developing-country problem. Grants are intended to cover research expenses and travel costs, not tuition, fees, or living expenses. DEADLINES: IN SEPTEMBER AND MARCH. Contact: Dr. Francis Li; phone: (202) 653-5361.

The Population-Environment Fellows Program, sponsored by U.S. AID and administered at the University of Michigan, sponsors Fellows for two-year appointments with overseas agencies. Fellows provide assistance and technical support for developing country institutions to foster a comprehensive approach to development. Fellows must hold a graduate degree in a relevant area and demonstrate expertise in both population and environment. Applications are reviewed on a rolling basis, but the sooner a completed application is received , the greater the availability of sites for which it can be considered. Inquiries and application requests may be obtained from: The Population -Environment Fellows Program, SPH II, Room M2240, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109-2029; phone: (313) 747-0222; fax: (313) 747-4947.

The Rockefeller Foundation's Sub-Saharan African Dissertation Internship Awards 1993-1994 are open to citizens of sub-Saharan Africa studying in the U.S. or Canada. Priority will be given to research topics in the areas of agriculture, environment, health, sciences and schooling. Projects must involve field observations or use of primary sources only available in Africa. Students must have completed all course work and qualifying exams prior to receiving an award. DEADLINE: MARCH 1, 1994. To obtain applications and more information, contact: African Dissertation Internships, The Rockefeller Foundation, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, New York, NY 10036 or African Dissertation Internships, The Rockefeller Foundation, P.O. Box 47543, Nairobi, KENYA.

The Rockefeller Foundation offers Re-Entry Support for African Scholars Pursuing Education Research. Candidates must have completed their doctoral or post-doctoral programs and obtained employment in an African research or teaching institution. Contact: Scholars on Education Re-Entry Program, Rockefeller Foundation, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, New York, NY 10036; phone: (212) 869-8500; fax: (212) 764-3468.

The University of Illinois-Egerton University Study Abroad Program allows undergraduates to spend eight weeks in Kenya this summer this summer. Participants will take courses at Egerton, tour various parts of the country, and live with Kenyan families in brief homestays. Contact: Center for African Studies, 210 International Studies Building, 910 South Fifth Street, Champaign, IL 61820; phone: (217) 333-6335.

The Washington Office on Africa seeks interns for Spring 1994. Interns will track legislation related to Africa, share information with congressional staff , be involved with the Southern African Working Group, and maintain the "Africa Hotline." Contact: Kristen Lee at Washington Office on Africa, phone: (202) 546 -7961.

The Economic Development Institute of the World Bank announces the 1994 cycle of the Robert S. McNamara Fellowship Program which aims at producing the highest quality research results in the general area of economic development. The program also seeks to achieve wide geographical and cultural diversity among fellows. The 12-month fellowship does not support work toward an advanced degree, but innovate and imaginative post-graduate research in areas of economic development. Contact: Robert S. McNamara Fellowship Program, Room M -4029, World Bank Headquarters, 1818 H. St., N.W., Washington, DC 20433.

The Centre for Refugee Studies at York University in Toronto offers an eight -week summer course on refugee affairs. The program will provide an overview of refugee issues, plus an opportunity to explore current topics with international experts. Participation is limited to 50 practitioners from inside and outside government who work with refugees or on refugee affairs and have a degree equivalent experience. Course dates are June 22-29, 1994. Contact: Dr. Tom Clark, Summer Course Coordinator, Centre for Refugee Studies, York University, Suite 322, York Lanes, 4700 Keele Street, North York, ON Canada M3J 1P3; phone: (416) 736-5837; fax: (416) 736-5837.

The Los Angeles World Affairs Council 1994 Diplomatic Travel Program offers the following: "Untamed Africa - Kenya, Tanzania and Botswana". Trip will include Victoria Falls. From July 15 - August 8,1994. Contact: Los Angeles World Arrais Council, Diplomatic Tour Department at (310) 652-4675.

The SSRC-MacArthur Foundation Committee on International Peace and Security announces a program of small grants in 1994 allowing scholars and students of international relations to visit major universities and research centers outside their home region. Grants are intended for junior scholars who seek exposure to debates and scholarship on the changing international system and issues of international peace and security. Applications should be completed and returned to the Council, postmarked no later than JULY 15, 1994. Contact: Social Science Research Council, Visiting Scholar Fellowship Program on International Peace and Security, 605 Third Avenue, 17th Floor, New York, NY 10158.

Africa News


February 1, 1994 / February 14, 1994


EMPLOYMENT


LENGTH: 5694 words


 

Air Serv International, Inc. (ASI), a non-profit, humanitarian air transport company seeks an ACCOUNTANT for its Maputo, Mozambique office. Responsibilities cover financial management of operations, including establishment of systems to comply with reimbursable contract, bookkeeping, budget monitoring, cost projecting, producing financial reports for internal use and donor agencies, instruct, train and possibly supervise national staff. Requirements: Bachelor's degree in accounting, one year auditing experience, computer skills. Government accounting experience preferred, but not required. Send resume and salary requirements to: Personnel Department, Air Serv International, Box 3041, Redlands, CA, 92373; fax: (909) 793-0226.

The American Friends of the AICFA seeks a PROJECT MANAGER in Somalia for primary health care. Duties include procurement and logistics; project setup; maintenance of property; liaison with donors, other non-governmental

organizations and authorities. QUALIFICATIONS: Three or more years in a similar position, strong negotiations, communications and management skills; ability to work in a difficult environment; knowledge of primary health care issues. Send resume and cover letter to: AFAICF, 815 15th Street NW, Suite 832, Washington, DC 20005; fax: (202) 783-5247. 

 

Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations has an opening for a SENIOR ECONOMIST (Marketing) in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia. This is a fixed term, 3-year position. QUALIFICATIONS: University degree in agricultural economics, preferably with postgraduate specialization in marketing, or a related field (such as agro-economy). Ten years of increasingly responsible professional experience in an international organization, government, private sector or research institution in agro-economic development. (An M.S. or equivalent advanced postgraduate degree in agricultural economics may be substituted for one year of the required experience, a Ph.D. or equivalent degree for two years of the required experience). Working knowledge of English (level C) or French or limited knowledge (level B) of the other. DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES: Under the supervision of the Director, Joint ECA (UN Economic Commission for Africa)/FAO Agriculture Division and the technical guidance of the Agricultural Services Division, to plan and coordinate the work of the Agricultural Marketing Section (ECA), and specifically, to: conduct analyses of the food and agricultural marketing situation in the region, including; developments in production, consumption, price policy, trade, distribution and demand, taking account of the Lagos Plan of Action, the Regional Food Plan for Africa and other regional programmes. Contact: Executive Officer, LNOR, Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, 1001 22nd Street, N.W., Suite 300, Washington, DC 20437

American Refugee Committee has the following positions available:

In Somalia:

MATERNITY SERVICES COORDINATOR, based in Afmadou, to select and train MCH Center maternity services staff; establish policies and procedures for the NCH Center maternity services; supervise the delivery of maternal services including prenatal care, labor and delivery care, postpartum care. Qualifications: Certified Nurse midwife; experience in training and US supervision; strong primary health background. Six-month commitment, $1,500 a month.

TRADITIONAL BIRTH ATTENDANT COORDINATOR, based in Afmadou, to mobilize the communities to support and make use of the Traditional Birth Attendants; conduct training course to qualify participants to work as TBAs; and conduct

supervisory visits to observe TBA participants. QUALIFICATIONS: RN or midwife with previous experience in a developing country; previous training experience. US$1,500 a month. Six month commitment.

COMPOUND MANAGER, based in Bardera, to act as liaison between ARC and other voluntary agencies; secure necessary supplies; coordinate ARC programs with those of other agencies; maintain close contact with Nairobi office. QUALIFICATIONS: previous experience as field coordinator or similar capacity in developing countries; strong communication skills; flexibility. US $1,200/mo. Minimum 6 month contract.

In Sudan:

MEDICAL DOCTOR to provide emergency relief to displaced persons in Kajo Keji County. RESPONSIBILITIES: set up emergency/acute care clinic and coordinate all in-patient and out-patient activities. REQUIREMENTS: MD with emergency/acute care experience in developing countries and proven success in implementing new programs in relief situations. 6 month commitment. $1,200/month. NURSE to provide emergency relief/acute care to displaced persons; assist in setting up emergency/acute care clinic; and supervise local nursing staff. REQUIRES: RN with emergency/acute care experience in developing countries and proven success in implementing new programs in relief situations. 6 month commitment. $1,200/month.

HOME VISIT COORDINATOR to communicate with authorities to select health care workers; conduct an initial 1-month training course and provide continuing education for workers. QUALIFICATIONS: RN with primary health care background and training experience; previous experience in a developing country. 1 year commitment., $1,200/month.

American Refugee Committee provides transportation, health insurance, and group housing. Send resume to: ARC, Cathy Tilsen, 2344 Nicolett Avenue, Suite 350, Minneapolis, MN 55404; (612) 872-7060; fax: (612) 872-4309.

The Center for International Development and Environment of the World Resources Institute seeks individual with experience in natural resources management, institutions, and/or natural resource and policy activities in Africa, particularly national plans and strategies for sustainable development. Africa experience and excellent language competence in French required. Will be responsible for the coordination and implementation of the Center's activities in sustainable development planning in Africa. Will coordinate the Natural Resource Management Policy Consultative Group for Africa, with priority on an on-going study of sustainable development planning in 8 African countries. Position includes field work, analytical report writing, some policy research, and preparing workplans and budgets. Send resume to: Africa Program, CIDE/WRI, 1709 New York Avenue NW, Suite 700, Washington, DC 20006.

OIC International seeks a SMALL ENTERPRISE MANAGEMENT/DEVELOPMENT AND APPROPRIATE TECHNOLOGY SPECIALIST to provide technical assistance and training in value-added transformation and raw produce with the purpose of creating employment and economic development opportunities for unemployed youths and disadvantaged communities in African and other countries. The person will identify cottage industry and appropriate technologies adaptable to the client countries; develop curricula to train related entrepreneurial and technical skills to develop and manage such businesses. REQUIREMENTS: First degree in engineering followed by an MBA or equivalent education in Business Management; experience in related development work, and working experience in Africa in particular, first hand experience managing business and/or in appropriate technology development; fluent in English and French; knowledge of Spanish is advantageous. Travel required. Send resume: President and CEO, OIC International, 240 W. Tulpehocken Street, Philadelphia, PA 19144.

The Center for Arabic Study Abroad seeks an Executive Director for the period June 1994 to June 1996. CASA offers intensive summer and full-year programs in spoken and advanced literary Arabic for American college and high-school students and faculty. It is operated at the American University in Cairo under the governance of 22 American universities. Contact: Gerald E. Lampe, Director, CASA, SAIS/Johns Hopkins University, 1619 Massachusetts Avenue, N.W., Washington, D.C. 20036; phone: (202) 663-5751.

The Center for Wildlife Management in Kenya seeks a WILDLIFE RESOURCE MANAGER for a permanent full-time position of Resident Faculty. Resident Faculty live on site, lecture in an interdisciplinary, non-traditional, field-based learning environment and oversee student-directed research projects. Send detailed letter explaining relevant skills and experience, CV, and three references to Kenya Wildlife Resource Manager Search, The School for Field Studies, 16 Broadway, Beverly, MA 01915; phone: (508) 927-7777; fax: (508) 927-5127.

The program will strongly emphasize institutional building of indigenous NGOs. Requires Master's or doctoral level degree in public health or related field and seven-plus years experience in management of large public health/international development programs. Prior work with PVO/NGOs highly desirable. To apply, send cover letter (with salary requirements) and resume to Linda Rodriguez, Family Health International, 2101 Wilson Blvd., Suite 700, Arlington, VA 22201.

Requires Master's degree in Public Health or social sciences or equivalent experience and three-plus years related work experience. Experience in working with UN system of USAID-funded activities desirable. Fluency in French and/or Spanish desirable. To apply, send cover letter (with salary requirements) and resume to Linda Rodriguez, Family Health International , 2101 Wilson Blvd., Suite 700, Arlington, VA 22201.

Requires PhD in one of the social sciences or comparable combination of education and experience with AIDS epidemic and considerable experience in designing and implementing behavioral science research projects in the developing world. Ability to travel international, fluency in French or Spanish is preferred. To apply, send cover letter (with salary requirements) and resume to Linda Rodriguez, Family Health International, 2101 Wilson Blvd., Suite 700, Arlington, VA 22201.

FHI also seeks a CHIEF IN AIDS CONTROL AND PREVENTION PROJECT to manage the Behavior Changes Communications component, focusing on increasing condom demand and STD treatment-seeking behaviors and reducing numbers of sexual partners. Requires PhD or MA and equivalent experience and five years experience in the design of behavior change communications programs. Fluency in French or Spanish desirable. To apply, send cover letter (with salary requirements) and resume to Linda Rodriguez, Family Health International, 2101 Wilson Blvd., Suite 700, Arlington, VA 22201.

The International Development Group in Bethesda, Maryland seeks a BILINGUAL (ENGLISH/ARABIC) ADMINISTRATIVE ASSISTANT for a part-time (20-to-24-hour-a -week) position. The Administrative Assistant will report directly to the Administrative Coordinator and be responsible for the following: administrative support; and drafting correspondence and overheads in Arabic. Pay range: $10.50 to $12 an hour. Send resume to: University Research Corporation, 7200 Wisconsin Avenue, Suite 600, Bethesda, MD 20814; phone: (301) 654-8338.

NUTRITIONIST with masters degree in Public Health or PhD and extensive survey research experience. Demonstrated skills in epidemiology, biostatistics and nutritional anthroprometics required.

available:

Candidate must be a South African with relevant education, good communication skills, and a commitment to empowering blacks to establish successful SMEs. The Health and Nutrition Coordinator must have experience with nutrition surveys, data analysis and health planning. For the Relief Nurse position, experience in feeding and working at the government level are needed, as well as an ability to work in an isolated and difficult area. The Ford Foundation is looking for a PROGRAM OFFICER or ASSISTANT PROGRAM OFFICER for its Africa and Middle Eastern Programs, to be based in Dakar, Senegal. Responsibilities include identifying priority areas; formulating appropriate strategies and monitoring grants aimed at building base of information on women's roles within contexts of culture and religion in francophone West Africa; raising public awareness of women's contributions to development; strengthening women's groups and organizations to empower women to improve their social and economic status. Requirements include: advanced training in social sciences, strong analytical and conceptual and writing skills, ability to work effectively with grass roots communities and university -based researchers, prior experience in programs to improve status of women, and fluency in French. Salary hiring guidelines for Program Officer: US$56,100-$71,100; Assistant Program Officer: US$38-700-$49,000. Send resume, brief writing sample for Position #206 to Joan Carroll, Manager of Employment, The Ford Foundation, 320 E. 43rd Street, New York, NY 10017.

The Ford Foundation is seeking an assistant representative/program officer for African and Middle East programs to be based in Harare, Zimbabwe. The staff member will also oversee all Foundation activities in Zimbabwe and manage the Harare office. Graduate training in the social sciences is required. Salary starts at $54,000. If interested send c.v. and a brief writing sample for position #291 to Joan Carroll, Manager of Employment, The Ford Foundation, 320 East 43rd Street, New York, NY 10017.

DEADLINE: MAY 1, 1994. Contact: Kristen Lee, Washington Office on Africa, 119 Maryland Avenue NE, Washington, DC 20002. tel: (202) 546-7961. fax: (202) 546-1545.

CUSO, a Canadian international development organization, seeks:

MANAGER OF HYDROGEOLOGY AND CONSTRUCTION in Nigeria. This village borehole and sanitation project in Ondo State will provide clean water, public sanitation and public health training in disease endemic areas, as well as strengthen village and government institutions to enable rural communities to better manage their water and sanitation needs. Individual will act as chief advisor on rural water systems matters and supervise the principle contractor in hydrogeologic and related technical works, centered on borehole drilling. REQUIREMENTS: appropriate university degree; several years management experience in design, field implementation, computerized operations, and evaluation of water point improvement projects in developing countries, including community-based handpump maintenance and repair; experience in administration and supervision of field drilling contracts; leadership, communications and multicultural team work skills. Salary: CDN$40,000

REGIONAL DIRECTOR, South Africa. Individual will work on a well-integrated regional program with activities in Tanzania, Mozambique, Zambia, and South Africa. Working closely with the staff in the region, the Regional Director will be providing vision and leadership, as well as coordinating the development, implementation and evaluation of the regional program, ensuring effective program administration; managing human resources; representing the region and its programs and participating in organizational management. REQUIREMENTS: Experience in South/South, North/South interregional programming; excellent communication and representational skills; abilities in budgeting financial management and human resources management; knowledge of East Central and South Africa region; 50% travel; knowledge of Canadian realities and issues an asset. Salary: CDN$50,000. Send CV, names & addresses of 3 references, and a short statement on how you see yourself contributing to the work by FEBRUARY 28 to: CUSO, Human Resources Dept., 135 Rideau Street, Ottawa, Ontario, Canada K1N 9K7; fax: (613) 241-8068.

Africa News


February 1, 1994 / February 14, 1994


VOLUNTEER OPPORTUNITIES


LENGTH: 1134 words


 

The Farmer-to-Farmer Volunteer Program, administered by Winrock International Institute for Agricultural Development and funded by the U.S. Agency for International Development, is currently recruiting agricultural specialists of varied backgrounds to provide technical assistance to female farmers in West Africa. The countries targeted to receive this assistance are Burkina Faso, Cote d'Ivoire, the Gambia and Senegal. Volunteers posted to these countries will work closely with local farmers, small business people, and host country organizations to share their expertise on agricultural topics including distribution and marketing, women cooperatives, fruit and vegetable preservation and storage, rice and cassava marketing, sesame production and marketing, aqua culture, curriculum development and cooperative management. Volunteer assignments range from three to six weeks and the ultimate goal of these assignments is to help host farmers improve family income and nutrition as well as to increase overall food production and distribution. The Farmer-to -Farmer Program pays for volunteer travel, meals and lodging. All travel logistics (i.e. visas, passports, medical exams) are arranged and paid for by Winrock International. The volunteer experts contribute their time and expertise. For additional information and a volunteer application form contact Tom Bauer, Farmer-to-Farmer Program, Rt. 3, Box 376, Morrison, AR 72110; phone (501) 727-5435, ext. 253; Internet: tomb@winrock.org. 

 

Health Volunteers Overseas has several openings for health care providers who wish to aid its programs in the following nations:

TRANSKEI (one-month assignments; April-December 1994): Participants needed to teach anesthesia at Umtata General Hospital to physicians-in-training. Volunteers will also provide direct anesthesia care. Housing on hospital grounds is provided for the volunteer at no cost. Contact Dr. Kevin Speight, (919) 716-4498/(919) 454-3956 or Spence Campbell (704) 696-9930.

TRANSKEI: Volunteers are involved in the teaching of Orthopaedic Nurse Practitioners, who complete a one-year course, plus residents and medical students. Housing is provided at no cost. Accommodations for families can often be arranged. This program also seeks volunteers in Physical Therapy and General Surgery.

UGANDA (one-month assignments; May-December 1994): Volunteers participate in the only anesthesia training program in Uganda. Most of the teaching takes place in Kampala's Mulago Hospital. Housing provided at the guest house at Makerere University. Contact Dr. Harry Zutz, (908) 381-4200/(201) 378-3323.

UGANDA (one-month assignments; March-November 1994): Program trains medical student, physicians, prosthetists, orthotists and physical therapists to improve the treatment of amputees and disabled people injured as a result of civil strife. Surgeons may also conduct orthopedic clinics an operating sessions with Ugandan doctors in upcountry regional hospitals in Tororo/Mbale, Mbarara and Fort Portal. Physical therapist volunteers will be needed to help the Ugandan tutors to develop courses in the three year diploma course are Mulago Hospital. Volunteers need to have a minimum of two years of clinical experience and some educational experience. Advanced degrees and lecture experience are big plus, but are not mandatory. Prosthetists are also being sought to teach. For a nominal fee, housing will be provided at the newly renovated Mulago Guest House. Contact: Dr. David Denzel, (716) 434-2697 or Elizabeth Kay, PT, (708) 897-4814.

MALAWI (two-month assignments, one month considered; The School of Health Sciences in Lolongwe is the site for a program providing education support in the areas of diagnosing dental and oral pathoses, performing conservative dentistry, periodontics, uncomplicated dental extractions and preventive dentistry. This program is soliciting 3 volunteers a year with a one month hiatus between volunteers. Contact: Dr. Dick Nieusma, (402) 472-9846.

For a more detailed description of each site as well as copies of trip reports from previous volunteers, contact Health Volunteers Overseas, c/o Washington Station, P.O. Box 65157, Washington, DC 20035-5157; phone: (202) 296-0928.

The American Medical Team for Africa (AMTA) promotes and executes educational exchange and medical training in African countries. The goal of the non-profit organization is to bring volunteer doctors, nurses and medical students together with donated supplies, and equipment to serve needs on the continent. Survey teams assess the most pressing needs in targeted countries, develop and publish training manuals in appropriate languages, hold workshops and refresher courses for doctors, nurses and specialists interested in maintenance of health care delivery systems in Africa; and distribute medical supplies and equipment donated by corporations, pharmaceutical companies, hospitals and doctors. The AMTA plans a second medical mission to Africa. For more information, contact Deman Rageh, Executive Director, The American Medical Team for Africa, 2245 Godby Road, Atlanta, GA 30349; phone (404) 766-8000; fax: (404) 767-5264.


LOAD-DATE: February 17, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.

February 1, 1994 / February 14, 1994


AFRICAN VISITORS TO THE U.S.


LENGTH: 1120 words


 

Our list of African visitors to the United States is compiled from the "Arrival List of International Visitors," published by the United States Information Agency (phone 202-619-5219).

COTE D'IVOIRE...

Abdoulaye Sangare, Deputy News Editor and Secretary General of the Editorial Staff of "Notre Temps" (Ivorian Independent Weekly). Scheduled arrival date: February 28, 1994 for conference on "The Role and Responsibility of the Media". 

 

GUINEA...

Sarbour Keita, Head of Regional Office, Guinean Press Agency. Scheduled arrival date: February 28, 1994 for conference on "The Role and Responsibility of the Media".

Mamadou Savane, Head of Rural Radio Station, Kankan. Scheduled arrival date: February 28, 1994 for conference on "The Role and Responsibility of the Media".

LIBERIA...

Sam Van Kesselley, Managing Editor, "The News" newspaper; President, Press Union of Liberia. Scheduled arrival date: February 28, 1994 for conference on "The Role and Responsibility of the Media".

Philip Wesseh, Editor-in-Chief, "Inquirer" newspaper; Scheduled arrival date: February 28, 1994 for conference on "The Role and Responsibility of the Media".

MALI...

Ely Dicko, Journalist and Lay-out Person at "Le Republicain", private newspaper. Scheduled arrival date: February 28, 1994 for conference on "The Role and Responsibility of the Media".

MOZAMBIQUE...

Tomas Vieira Mario, Director of Information, Mozambican Television Station. Scheduled arrival date: February 28, 1994 for conference on "The Role and Responsibility of the Media".

NIGERIA...

Edwin Baiye, Features Editor, "Daily Times Newspaper". Scheduled arrival date: February 28, 1994 for conference on "The Role and Responsibility of the Media".

SOUTH AFRICA...

Michael Paul Van Graan; National Projects Officer, Congress of South African Writers; General Secretary National Arts in Review. Scheduled arrival date: February 28, 1994. Interests: Arts Policy; Relationship between Government and the Arts.

Josias Chale, Chief of Bureau, Sowetan Newspaper. Scheduled arrival date: February 28, 1994 for conference on "The Role and Responsibility of the Media".

Frederick Khumalo, Bureau Chief, Natal Edition of City Press. Scheduled arrival date: February 28, 1994 for conference on "The Role and Responsibility of the Media".

SUDAN...

Inshirah Ahmed Mukhtar. Scheduled arrival date: February 28, 1994 for conference on "U.S. Criminal Justice System".

SWAZILAND...

Vusi Sibisi, Editor-in-Chief, "The Swazi Observer", a government-affiliated newspaper. Scheduled arrival date: February 28, 1994 for conference on "The Role and Responsibility of the Media".

TANZANIA...

Soud Yussuf Mgeni; Member, Central Committee of Opposition Party Civic United Front. Scheduled arrival date: February 14, 1994. Interests: U.S. Elections.
