Africa News


February 1, 1994 / February 14, 1994


A VISIT WITH A DIFFERENCE: ARCHBISHOP CAREY IN SOUTHERN SUDAN


BYLINE: Bona Malwal


SECTION: VIEWPOINTS


LENGTH: 814 words


 

SUDAN DEMOCRATIC GAZETTE, February 1994

Last month the Archbishop of Canterbury, Dr. George Carey, and his wife Eileen spent probably the most difficult and dangerous four nights of their lives when they visited Southern Sudan. There were difficulties and dangers which they need not have exposed themselves to, yet millions of Southern Sudanese are very grateful that they did.

In successfully undertaking the visit to Southern Sudan, the Archbishop has focused the world's attention upon the plight of the people of Southern Sudan, Christian and non-Christian alike. In making the visit Dr. Carey has also carried out a biblical obligation to sympathise with the weak, the poor and the needy. He has fulfilled an important step in Christian solidarity with the Southern people, a step unmatched since the first Christian missionaries entered the South in the early years of this century. His visit is as significant for the Southern people as when the British colonial administration entered the South and made it a closed district within which they prohibited by law any act of slavery. 

For nearly forty years Southern Sudan has struggled against repression by the North. The modern variety of Islamic Fundamentalism just happens to be the worst ever seen. Forcible Islamicisation and Arabisation of the Southern people did not begin with the present regime, but new extremes of brutality have been reached as a result of its policies.

In Northern Sudan, the people of the Nuba Mountains have been singled out for particular repression, persecution and ethnic cleansing. These persecuted people have looked to the international community for help and salvation in the past with apparently little response. Dr. Carey has now demonstrated that the outside world can bypass Khartoum and help the people of the South and the Nuba Mountains directly.

An important aspect of the Archbishop's visit for the Christian community world-wide is that Christianity is alive and flourishing in Southern Sudan. In fact, it seems that the greater the attempts by Khartoum to forcibly convert Southerners to Islam, the more Southerners become Christians t demonstrate their defiance. This is a fact which ought to dissuade Christian communities and church leaders around the world from seemingly sacrificing Sudan's Christians in the process of achieving dialogue with the Islamic Fundamentalists.

During the period of the build-up to Dr. Carey's visit, Christians in both Northern and Southern Sudan feared that it would be taken over by the Khartoum regime and manipulated for political gain. Everyone remembers how the Pope's visit in February last year had been manipulated for propaganda purposes at the last minute. When the Archbishop of Canterbury refused to be bullied and intimidated by Khartoum's last minute demands, and instead cancelled his visit to Northern Sudan whilst going ahead with the visit to the South, this gave all Christians in Sudan renewed confidence that they are not on their own. Khartoum was so disturbed at its failure to manipulate Dr. Carey's visit, and ultimately its inability to prevent his visit to the South, that it was prepared to instigate a full-scale war with Britain.

All along the Archbishop of Canterbury had made it known that his visit was going to be a spiritual and pastoral one. He had no intention of allowing Khartoum to reduce the visit to a political contest. He saw no need to go out of his way to appease a regime which is actively repressing its own people. He opted for the way of Christ rather than the way of diplomatic nicety.

Khartoum's efforts to take over Dr. Carey's visit certainly rebounded upon its propaganda machine, largely because the controversy created gave the visit extended international media coverage that it might not have warranted had it gone ahead as originally planned. The decision by Khartoum to expel the British ambassador and to launch a full scale diplomatic row with the British government made Dr. Carey's visit even more newsworthy.

Reprinted from the SUDAN DEMOCRATIC GAZETTE, February 1994.

Contact: Sudan Democratic Gazette, P.O. Box 2295, London W14 0ND, U.K.


LOAD-DATE: February 17, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


40 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 1, 1994 / February 14, 1994


NEW DATE SET FOR 7TH PAC TO BE HELD IN KAMPALA, UGANDA APRIL 3-8, 1994


BYLINE: Dr. Tajudeen Abdul-Raheem, General Secretary, PAC


SECTION: DOSSIER


LENGTH: 1240 words


 

The IPC (International Preparatory Committee) Met In Kampala, Uganda on December 9th, 10th, and 11th (1993) and discussed the plans for the rescheduling of the 7th Pan African Congress. The new dates will be April 3-8, 1994.

Twenty years ago Africans around the globe convened for the purpose of holding the long awaited 6th Pan African Congress. The conference came about after the idea of Pan Africanism had taken its second dive since the 5th PAC was held in 1945. This was the last PAC attended and led by the founding father of Pan Africanism, the late Dr. W.E.B. Dubois. 

Dr. Dubois went to France in December 1918 to address the Peace Congress, being held at Versailles, about his idea of calling a "Pan African Congress." At the time he was without credentials or influence, but the idea took on. This led to the First Pan African Congress which assembled in Paris in February 1919. Of the fifty-seven delegates that attended, only nine countries and twelve delegates represented the African continent. Although Africa was partially represented (most of Africa was still colonized at the time), the main goals of the decolonization of Africa and African unity still prevailed.

The Pan African Congress continued to assemble periodically from 1919 to 1927, and was still mostly an American idea rather than African. By 1929 the Pan African Movement was losing ground and a desperate effort was made to hold the 5th PAC on the African continent. This attempt however was blocked by both the French government, who would not allow the Congress to meet in Tunis or in other of its colonies in Africa, and the Great Depression. Fifteen years later in 1945, the Word Trade Union Conference met in Paris, France. It was here that black laborers fro the Caribbean, America, and parts of Europe got together and called for a 5th PAC to be held in the Republic of Liberia. After reviewing the situation, the convening committee decided to hold the Congress in Manchester, England just days after the World Trade Union Conference. Despite the effort, difficulties of transportation and passport restriction made the attendance limited. However those who did participate in the conference, such Kwame Nkrumah, Jomo Kenyatta, Obafemi Awolowo, T.B. Makonnen, and others, were later to play a prominent role in the decolonization of Africa.

Almost thirty years would pass before the PAC would reconvene. During this time many African countries were slowly gaining independence from colonial rule. Ghana, formerly The Gold Coast, was the first to receive its independence in 1957. In April 1958, the incumbent President, Kwame Nkrumah, called a meeting of all independent African states at the time, and this meeting became known as the First Pan African Conference to be held on African soil. Later that year another conference was called, this time including both independent states and nationalist movements. Sixty-two Liberation Nationalist and Liberation Movements were represented. Patrice Lumumba, Abdul-Rahman Babu, Nelson Mandela, and Sekou Toure just to name a few. Similar conferences were held in Tunis and Cairo between 1961 and 1962.

In 1963, thirty-two independent states met in Addis Ababa and formed the Organization of African Unity, whose charter and purpose was a compromise of the radical and moderate nationalist leaders. The radicals wanted to see the immediate redemption of Africa by any means necessary, including armed struggle , while the moderates on the other hand wanted to take a slower approach in the unity of Africa. Militants and Pan Africanists were openly disappointed with the limitations of the OAU, because it did not advocate the participation or offer solidarity of Diasporic Africans.

This soon led to the revival of the Pan African Movement and the PAC series. The initiative for a 6th PAC came from a small group of African American and African Caribbeans who met in the United States and Bermuda in 1971 and '72. The committee organized and the 6th PAC took place in June 1974 at the University of Dar-es-Salaam, and was attended by fifty-two delegations from African and Caribbean states, liberation movements, two hundred and fifty African Americans, and communities of diasporans from South America, Britain, and the Pacific. Issues on the agenda were: independence through armed struggle , the question of imperialism and neo-colonialism, the underdevelopment of third world countries, education and culture, colonialism in the Caribbean, and the role of African women. Unfortunately there was the inability to make concrete resolutions so that they could be carried out, and there was no organizational structure for the Congress itself to serve as an institutional base. So once again the Pan African Congress would lie dormant for another twenty years.

After a series of meetings by the International Planning Committee, the date and place was set for the 7th Pan African Congress. The conference was to be held in Kampala, Uganda in December 1993. However, after some logistical problems, the 7th PAC was canceled and rescheduled for April 3-8, 1994. The broad theme of the Congress is: PAN AFRICANISM: Facing the Future in Unity, Social Progress and Democracy. Some main issues on the agenda are:

* A determination of the scope of the political and economic unity of Africa and Africans worldwide.

* Acceptance of the notion that Pan Africanism represents the basis of a viable and absolutely necessary project, to which all Africans must subscribe, and this should be the base for foreign policy formulation and projection.

The International Planning Committee aspires that the Congress not be just a forum for ideas, but an historic opportunity to formulate a plan of action. The IPC will also oversee the continuation of PAC conferences in the future. It would be a tragedy to let the Pan African Movement sleep for another twenty years. by the will of God, history will be made this April in Kampala, Uganda. We look forward to seeing you there.

For additional information, please call Adventure in Africa Tours in the U.S. (314) 962-2117 or write or fax to: 7th PAC Secretariat, Plot 3, Parliament Ave. , P.O. Box 7168, Kampala, Uganda. (256)(41) 257-986.


LOAD-DATE: February 17, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


41 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 1, 1994 / February 14, 1994


ANC CONTROVERSY OVER ABORTION PLAN


BYLINE: Pat Sidley and Reg Rumney


LENGTH: 694 words


 

THE WEEKLY MAIL & GUARDIAN, January 21-27, 1994

The ANC's tentative backing for abortion on demand in its draft health policy has already drawn criticism from pro-lifers. It is one of several highly contentious suggestions in the ANC's draft plan released this week, which emphasises public sector health at the expense of the private sector.

The support for women's choice on abortion is hedged with a note that "the issues around abortion remain contentious and need to be discussed and debated further." 

The move to support abortion is also likely to stir up feelings with in the ANC itself, where the issue of abortion is by no means settled. Another issue likely to cause controversy is the suggestion that medical graduates be forced to work for the state for a period -- or repay state loans.

The reaction of the Medical Association of South Africa to the plan has been muted, with the association saying it is "encouraged" by the policy proposals in general. Masa merely notes that "to discourage growth in the private sector is debatable". It also says ambitious time schedules could create unrealistic expectations.

Centre for Health Policy Studies' Max Price comments that there is a contradiction in the document which later talks about contracting the private sector to provide services for the public sector, which would entail growth.

Price believes that overall the document offers health care workers a rosy future, albeit in a regulated environment. The move to bar doctors dispensing medicines they themselves have prescribed will cause unhappiness among some members of Masa itself.

It is also unclear how the bar on medical practitioners buying shares in private clinics is to work. Dr. Gordon Cohen of Clinic Holdings notes the move could not be done retrospectively and he doubts its feasibility. "Our doctors are free to buy Clinic Holdings shares on the JES."

The plan proposes free basic medical care. Some proposals are also likely to send shivers up the spine of the pharmaceutical industry.

The ANC plan, which runs to 100 pages and was presented this week in Johannesburg by health and welfare supremo Cheryl Carolous, calls for a strengthening of the public health sector and the availability of basic medical care to the whole population. Free health care would be available to children under six, pregnancy and nursing mothers, the elderly, disabled and chronically ill.

Free medical services would include immunisation, regular screening procedures to detect cancer, ante-natal care and child delivery, contraceptives, feeding support and treatment for TB.

The national health service would be financed through current income tax levels, claims the ANC. Extra revenue would come from steep increases in the prices of tobacco and alcohol. Patients with health insurance or medical aids will face steep charges at public hospitals.

In an attempt to redirect resources towards the public sector, the plan would regulate private health care, which it says currently channels resources disproportionately to wealthier, healthier people.

Reprinted from WEEKLY MAIL & GUARDIAN, January 21-27, 1994.

WEEKLY MAIL & GUARDIAN is published by M&G Media Contact: M&G Media, 139 Smit Street, Breamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025.


LOAD-DATE: February 17, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


42 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 1, 1994 / February 14, 1994


WILL POTENTIAL VOTERS KNOW HOW TO MAKE THEIR X'S?


BYLINE: Enoch Sithole


LENGTH: 1147 words


 

SUNDAY NATION, January 9, 1994

The election date is now less than four months away. Most of the political work is fairly well advanced with last month's passing of the Electoral Act by parliament and the subsequent establishment of the Independent Electoral Commission (IEC).

But the most difficult work that lies ahead, it seems, is getting the voters to mark the ballot paper in the correct way to avoid spoiling their votes.

The Independence Forum for Electoral Education -- a coalition of about 60 organisations -- is now racing against time to ensure that on April 27 every voter knows what to do when he or she gets to the polling station. 

Work to educate the nation about elections started as long ago as December 1991, more than a year before the election date was agreed at the multiparty negotiations.

Spearheading the operation was the University of the Western Cape's Centre for Development Studies and the American-based National Democratic Institute for International Affairs.

These institutions arranged an election seminar which was attended by representatives from several mass-based organisations.

In May 1991, Matla Trust got together with the Democratic Party and the Damelin Management School to design a curriculum for the training of election managers, monitors and voter educators.

After this process, 300 trainees from eight regions of the country were recruited from political organisations, churches, trade unions, civic and other mass-based groups.

Training

The trainees attended a 10-day seminar entitled, "Training the Trainer" and they were later sent back to conduct training in their own areas and organisations.

To date, according to the Matla Trust's community and citizen education head, Terrence Tryon, 70,000 election trainers have been trained countrywide.

However, until now, the training has been broad, said Tryon. The passing of the Electoral Act will allow Matla Trust and other organisations within the coalition to sharpen the training, basing it on the provisions of the Act.

But a low of work, it seems, is still to be done. A large number of rural areas and farm communities have yet to learn what an election means and how it is conducted.

People living in rural areas do not have any means of getting information on the elections. Radio, television or newspapers are not an affordable commodity in these areas.

The only avenue to reach them is by getting someone to physically meet and talk to them.

Tribal chiefs and churches -- which seem to be the most credible structures in rural areas -- will be used to help voter educators reach the rural communities.

But when it comes to farms, where the owners may decide not to give access to voter educators, the coalition will have to resort to the provisions of the Electoral Act which ;makes it illegal for farm owners to stop anybody who seeks to reach voters living on their property.

In Delmas, the Catholic Church has found a way of getting around this problem. In co-operation with farm workers' activities, voting seminars are held with farm workers in nearby Botleng township.

Punish

However, this method cannot be applicable in all areas as some farm owners would punish their employees simply because they went to attend such workshops.

In Delmas, farm workers' activists complain about low turnouts as workers fear reprisals from their employers.

This is also a costly exercise because transport has to be provided to take the workers to and form the workshop venue.

Tryon says the provision of the Electoral Act stipulating that pictures of leaders of the various contending political parties will be printed on each ballot paper, will make voter education easier, because many people will identify the party they support through seeing its leader's pictures rather than its colours or logo.

Parties like Inkatha, according to a Matla Trust research, would suffer a major disadvantage if logos were to be used.

The research found that 50 percent of 800 respondents did not know what Inkatha's logo looks like.

However, leaders of parties such as Azapo and small parties whose leaders are rarely on television or pictured in newspapers will get very little benefit from this provision.

It is still a long way to go, Tryon says, but he is confident that on April 27 every voter will be able to correctly mark the party of his or her choice on the ballot paper.

Reprinted from SUNDAY NATION, January 9, 1994.

SUNDAY NATION is published by New Nation Publishing Co.

Contact: New Nation Publishing Co., P.O. Box 10674, Johannesburg 2000, South Africa, phone:(011) 333-2711. Fax:(011) 333-2733.


LOAD-DATE: February 17, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


43 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 1, 1994 / February 14, 1994


AIR GAMBIA CEASES OPERATION


BYLINE: S.B. Danso


LENGTH: 920 words


 

DAILY OBSERVER, Tuesday, January 18, 1994

Air Gambia is no more. The privately-owned air carrier, which has been transporting passengers and goods in large numbers to London and Freetown weekly, announced yesterday that it had ceased operation "with immediate effect."

A spokesman for the airline said although it had enjoyed satisfactory loads, the fares on its London/Banjul/Freetown route "had become so diluted as to make it impossible to operate viable scheduled services." He went on to state that very significant losses had been incurred by the airline since its inception, and not one flight had succeeded in making a contribution towards overheads or the full recovery of the airline's direct operating costs. 

According to the spokesman, the chequered history of the airline was well known to the public. And prior to being taken into administration, a euphemistic word for receivership, losses amounting to US$2 million had arisen, the bulk of which had been borne by the airline's minority shareholders, Omega, based in Ireland.

It may be recalled that Air Gambia was the subject of an interim administration order issued by the Supreme Court last June under the Insolvency Act of 1992. According to that order, Messrs. Raymond Davies and Peter Terry of KPMG Peat Marwick were appointed administrators of the company pending the outcome of a petition filed by Omega Air Limited of Ireland.

Liquidation

Following receipt of the unsigned message on its fax machine early yesterday afternoon, the Daily Observer contacted Mr. Raymond Davies, managing partner of Peat Marwick, who confirmed that Air Gambia was indeed ceasing operations.

"They are not going to fly any more. They're liquidating their operations," he added.

Mr. Davies went on to throw more light on the collapse of Air Gambia. He said after Peat Marwick had been called in as administrators of the airline, they sold it to the West African Trading and Mining Co. According to the press release, this company inherited a deficit of nearly US$500,000 and continued to accumulate losses of not less than US$20,000 on every service.

Gambia Airways Shares

Mr. Davies disclosed to this newspaper that it had been the intention of the new company to take over the 40 per cent equity in Gambia Airways, which was owned by British Airways. But in the Gambia Government's privatisation of Gambia Airways, the British Airways shares were sold to Mr. Alieu Conteh, a Gambian businessman based in Brussels. Failure to obtain these shares, which would have provided a much-needed boost to Air Gambia's viability, spelt doom for the beleaguered airline, according to Mr. Davies.

The only thing that might have saved it, he said, was if they had increased their fares by 50 per cent at least, in order to bring it up to the level set by the International Air Travel Association (IATA) .

But that was an unlikely prospect, in an environment flooded with charter flights carrying thousands of passengers, mainly tourists, into and out of The Gambia every week at rock-bottom prices.

The Air Gambia spokesman said the decision to cease trading by West African Mining and Trading was therefore inevitable, and had only been delayed by the advent of the festive season and the need to ensure that passengers who had previously booked were able to travel back to their homes and loved ones. Indeed this had only been possible because of the immense goodwill of Omega Air in continuing to provide the aircraft on a complimentary basis.

He praised the staff of the airline who, he said, "had performed magnificently but against impossible odds." "Their loyalty and dedication has, in the circumstances, been exemplary," he added.

He said the directors of the airline wish to express their sincere regret for the inconvenience that will be caused to passengers as the result of this unavoidable cessation of trading.

Reprinted from the DAILY OBSERVER, January 18, 1994.

DAILY OBSERVER published by The OBSERVER COMPANY (GAMBIA) LTD.

Contact: Daily Observer, New Town-Sait Matty Junction, Bakau. P.M.B. Banjul, The Gambia. Phone: (220) 496608. Fax: (220) 496878.


LOAD-DATE: February 17, 1994

Africa News


February 1, 1994 / February 14, 1994


ARMY TOP BRASS ANGER MUSEVENI


BYLINE: MONITOR Staff Writer


LENGTH: 894 words


 

THE MONITOR, January 21-January 25, 1994

President Museveni, incensed by the increasing inefficiency in army administration, this week, is reported to have released a volley of criticism and rebukes against some army top brass.

According to a highly placed military source, the president chairing the Army Council meeting in Kampala on Wednesday January 19, 1994 was particularly bitter with the army leadership for dragging him into "petty administration matters."

First to come under fire was the Chief of Logistics and Engineering, Lt. Col.. Dr. Kizza Besigye. He was held responsible for neglecting soldiers' welfare, a number of whom are now going almost naked. The situation was said to be particularly bad for those now serving in up-country stations. 

The president charged that efforts to supply the army with uniforms, boots and mattresses are often frustrated by some corrupt officers until he himself moves in to push and threaten the Military Tender Board and the Treasury in the Ministry of Finance and Economic Planning.

The tender board is accused among other crimes of dealing more with briefcase suppliers and concentrating more on kickbacks than establishing contacts with more reliable suppliers.

To cool the president's anger, Besigye reportedly took to the floor promising to secure more boots, uniforms and mattresses for the army "by the end of next month."

Every soldier is supposed to get a new uniform every six months, a pair of new boots every one year, and a new mattress every two years. But the situation has become so pathetic that it is said to have topped the agenda for the Wednesday Army Council meeting.

The president and some Division commanders were particularly dismayed by the fact that despite an emergency session which was called last year to discuss the problem of welfare and supplies, it was still topping the agenda.

The president reportedly spent some time quarreling about increasing corruption, inefficiency and non-performers in the army.

The directorate of construction was singled out as an example for non -performance. Some time back Museveni is said to have told the head of this unit to use money voted for construction to erect an armory in every barracks and Division headquarters but "the fellow did not put up any"

he lamented.

The president is also reported to be disturbed by the rate of drunkards in the army, more especially the commanders who go to the bars very early in the day before finding out what is happening in their units.

He informed the council that the conflict between the police and the army over Lt. Col. Nyanzi Drago's arrest had been resolved. In future, an army officer will be arrested only if caught in the act or after informing the most senior army officer in the locality or unit in which the officer comes from.

If the police has evidence implicating any army officer they have to contact the army which will then effect the arrest.

On the on-going CA exercise, the president is said to have reiterated army's promise to abide by any decisions reached by the masses democratically.

"The army will follow whatever avenue upholds the unity of the country," the source quoted Museveni.

The president also reportedly warned division and brigade commanders not to sway soldiers into voting for any particular candidate. "Do not sway soldiers, let them decide themselves on whom to vote for."

Some candidates near army barracks like in Mbarara have expressed fears that the large number of soldiers could be manipulated into voting for one particular candidate especially those seen as NRM (National Resistance Movement , the ruling party). The fears had prompted some of them to suggest that soldiers should not vote.

The voluntary retirement of soldiers in the second phase of the lay-off exercise due at the end of March or early April was also reportedly discussed. It was agreed that the army retains the prerogative to stay a soldier requesting for voluntary retirement.

Reprinted from THE MONITOR, January 21-January 25, 1994.

THE MONITOR is published by The Monitor Publications Ltd. (Uganda)

CONTACT: THE MONITOR, P.O. Box 12141, Kampala. Phone: 251353; fax: 251352.


LOAD-DATE: February 17, 1994


LANGUAGE: English

45 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 1, 1994 / February 14, 1994


QUITTING -- WHILE IT'LL STILL BE MISSED


BYLINE: Anton Harber


LENGTH: 1027 words


 

THE WEEKLY MAIL & GUARDIAN, January 7-13, 1994

You won't find Max Du Preez, the ever-ebullient founder and editor of "Vrye Weekblad", looking down in the mouth about this week's decision to close his five-year-old publication.

"We could have carried on for a few months and burnt up some more money. But when we discussed it, I thought about the British Anti-Apartheid Movement. They didn't know when to go. We don't want to make the same mistake. 

"We want to go while people still care. In a few more months, they would have stopped caring," he said in an interview this week.

"Many people have phoned me and said it's terrible and we can't possibly close now. Individuals have offered a total of R1,5-million to keep us going. I personally have taken calls from three people each offering R200,000.

"This shows us that our timing was right. Quit while people will still miss you.

"These people are kind, but it wouldn't change our basic situation. We have never had advertising support. We have a flood of legal costs. And we cater to a tine constituency.

"We outgrew that market because of the edge we had and because we offered quality. But I am not sure we have that edge any more. Now we're just bleeding ourselves dry," he said.

Du Preez also turned down an offer to merge with his competition, Nasionale Pers' "Insig" and "Die Suid Afrikaan." On the surface, the deal was good: the new publication would be independent, edited by Du Preez and would have a good shot at creating one viable product from three struggling magazines.

The idea broke down because Naspers said it should be monthly, and Du Preez said it was weekly or nothing. "We would be putting our masthead on something we didn't like," he said.

So nothing it is and after the final edition on February 2, Du Preez will dismantle the unconventional newsroom he had built from nothing over the past five years. He works from the Old Scout Hall in Brixton, a quaint building with the feeling of a small, rural church. The colourful posters and photographs on the walls seem to ridicule the quasi-religious building -- appropriately for a magazine that has build its name on mocking Afrikaans institutions.

On the wall, hovering over the room like a religious icon, is a painting by artist Braam Kruger showing a (coloured) Joan of Arc-like figure, bursting out of the burning ruins of the old South Africa wielding a copy of "Vrye Weekblad" in one hand and a sword in the other, a "wit wolf" snapping at her heels.

That's the original "Vrye Weekblad": battling for a cause against all the odds , never mincing its words, never backing away from a fight.

So what's changed? Partly, it is a sense that their fight is over. Mostly, it is that Du Preez himself is tired.

But ask him about the publication's achievements, and he is energetic again. "Our major achievement was inside the Afrikaans constituency. Afrikaners did not ask difficult questions, they respected their leaders...Our style was confrontational, we kicked arse, we loosened up the minds of Afrikaners and helped them break these attitudes. We showed them that their leaders were morally and financially corrupt.

"And we showed people that you could be part of the struggle "and" speak Afrikaans. You didn't have to become Anglicised.

"Before we came along, most blacks thought Afrikaners were dumb, thick-wristed "boers" who suppressed them. We made then see that we weren't all like that.

"With "The Weekly Mail" and "New Nation: and others, we helped push back the parameters of press freedom. When all the mainstream guys were complacent and accepted the limits, we had a role in challenging those limits.

"On a different level, we showed young Afrikaners that there was fun to be had. That there is life beyond the National Party, the NG Kerk, the Broederbond and Christian National Education."

And what will Du Preez himself do? "I have no plans and no firm job offers.

"I am burnt out in th print media. There are no hobs for me there. I need to earn a proper salary for 18 months, until I can afford to go and run the small farm I have bought. That's been my dream from boyhood."

He picked up his small farm near Ficksburg for very little when there was drought and a spate of racial murders. "Now there's plenty of rain and no Apla ," he said'

That provides ideal conditions for farming, not for alternative journalism.

Reprinted from WEEKLY MAIL & GUARDIAN, January 21-27, 1994.

WEEKLY MAIL & GUARDIAN is published by M&G Media

Contact: M&G Media, 139 Smit Street, Breamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025.


LOAD-DATE: February 17, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


46 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 1, 1994 / February 14, 1994


BOOM TIMES ARE BACK!


BYLINE: Mondi waka Makhanya


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 974 words


 

THE WEEKLY MAIL & GUARDIAN, January 7-13, 1994

The current boom on the Johannesburg Stock Exchange is a forerunner to stronger economic growth in 1994 than originally expected.

Economists are busy revising their growth projections upwards, following the JSE bull run which began in early December and continued unabated through the festive season.

Early January saw some of the most frenzied activity in the JSE's history. Share prices soared, pushing sectoral indices to record levels and catapulting market capitalisation (the amount of money invested in the market) to a record R740-billion. 

"It's been a mad time," said one broker.

Behind the rush is a steady increase in the gold price to nearly $400 as well as an influx of foreign money -- particularly American unit trusts and pensions funds. South African investors also expect falling inflation to force the Reserve Bank to lower interest rates, thereby rendering the share market an even better investment option.

A heavy foreign buyer of South African stocks has been the black-run Episcopal Church Pension Fund. Cash-flush American fund managers are looking at various foreign markets into which they can diversify. They are targeting emerging markets, of which South Africa is one. The JSE has been particularly attractive because of the relative cheapness of shares here as a result of the dual exchange rate system which makes local shares 20 percent cheaper for foreigners than for South Africans.

Furthermore, local companies have impressed foreigners by having withstood the brutal recession of the past four years and come out intact. Blue chip companies such as South African Breweries, Premier and Anglo American Industrial Corporation are also seen to be in an ideal position to expand into the rest of the continent and increase their exports in a post-General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade world.

"US funds fear they may lost out on great opportunities if they don't get into the South African market now," say Barlows economist Pieter Haasbroek.

South Africa has been helped by instability in Russia, which might create disruptions in new markets in central and eastern Europe. In comparison, the installation of the Transitional Executive Council has boosted confidence in this country.

"A lot of people outside are gaining confidence in South Africa. The fact that we reached a constitutional settlement without outside intervention was an indication to them that we can solve our problems, says Bank of Lisbon economist Paulo Fernandes.

Surprisingly, the high level of violence -- which is often touted as a deterrent to foreigners -- has been ignored.

Explains Econometrix's Tony Twine: "Foreign observers are becoming desensitised to violence. Perceptions of it having a destructive effect on the economy are being reduced."

But the effects of the bull run are unlikely to be felt on the real economy for quite some time. Economists say the money which local investors have poured into the JSE will start having an impact in the second quarter of the year.

According to the Bank of Lisbon's "Economic Focus", any advance in industrial shares usually precedes an upswing in the business cycle by between five and 12 months.

Haasbroek concurs, pointing out that local interest in shares comes from a belief among investors that reasonable growth is going to be experienced this year.

"Manufacturing production is on the increase and employment is going to pick up. Inflation is falling and this will probably lead to a decline in interest rates," says Haasbroek.

Market players are expecting the bull run to continue for quite some time. An increase in manufacturing production and the expectation of good performances by industrial concerns over the 12 months will keep industrial share strong.

The gold price is likely to remain stable, thereby boosting god shares.

The US fund managers have also only invested a tiny fraction of a percentage and many others are still waiting for the April 27 elections before they invest.

"Most people expect the bull ruin to be sustained," says Mathieson and Hollidge managing director Peter Redding.

Reprinted from WEEKLY MAIL & GUARDIAN, January 21-27, 1994.

WEEKLY MAIL & GUARDIAN is published by M&G Media

Contact: M&G Media, 139 Smit Street, Breamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025.


LOAD-DATE: February 17, 1994


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


February 15, 1994 / February 28, 1994


BUSINESS


LENGTH: 1507 words


 

The following procurement opportunities in Egypt are available to U.S. companies through the U.S. Agency for International Development.

49 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 15, 1994 / February 28, 1994


EDUCATION/TRAVEL


LENGTH: 2560 words


 

Education, Society and Learning in an African Context is a summer course in Zimbabwe from June 30 - August 7, 1994 sponsored by MSU's African Studies Center, Department of Teacher Education, and the Office of Overseas Study. For more information, contact: John Metzler at (517) 353-1700 or Anne Schneller at (517) 355-5522. Or write to the African Studies Center, 100 Center for International Studies and Programs, MSU,

East Lansing, MI 48824-1035. E-mail: 21248JM@MSU.EDU.

The Africa Fund continues to offer full- and part-time internships in its New York office. Activities often include research, data-base maintenance, filing, and information distribution. Contact: Adrene Ifill, The Africa Fund, 198 Broadway, New York, NY 10038; phone: (212) 962-1210. 

The African Development Foundation offers Gray Senior Fellowships to African Academics and development professionals who have demonstrated a commitment to grass-roots development. Contact: African Development Foundation, 1400 Eye Street, N.W., 10th Floor, Washington, DC 20005; phone: (202) 673-3916.

The American Association of University Women Educational Foundation provides fellowships for graduate study in the U.S. to women who are not citizens or permanent residents of the U.S. Preference given to women demonstrating a prior commitment to improving the lives of women and girls, and applicants focusing their project on the advancement of women. Contact: AAUW Educational Foundation, 2401 Virginia Avenue, N.W., Washington, DC 20037.

The American University in Cairo is offering African Fellowships for two years of study toward an AUC Masters degree. Applicants from all disciplines are encouraged to apply. Contact: International Graduate Programs, Office of the Provost, American University in Cairo, P.O. Box 2511, 113 Kasr al Aini, Cairo, Egypt.

Boston University offers an opportunity to study in Niamey, Niger. Contact: Ned Quigley, Director, International Programs, Boston University, 232 Bay State Road, Boston, MA 02215; fax: (617) 353-5402.

The Center for Latin American Studies and the Center for African Studies invite junior and senior scholars to participate in an interdisciplinary program on Afro-American identity and cultural diversity in the Americas, including the Caribbean, Brazil, and the US, as well as areas of Africa. The program will enable visiting scholars to spend an year or a semester at the University of Florida to do research in this area. It will include studies of history, literature, religion, and popular culture. Each fellow will receive a maximum stipend of US$35,000 for the academic year, or half that for the semester. Applicants will be selected on a competitive basis related to their expertise and research in these areas. Candidates should submit a 100- word abstract, an essay of about 1,500 words detailing proposed research, a curriculum vitae, and two letters of recommendation. Send applications to Dr. Helen I. Safa, Center for Latin American Studies, University of Florida, P.O. Box 115530, Gainesville, FL 32611-5530; phone: (904) 392-0375; fax: (904) 392-7682.

The Council for Development of Social Science Research in Africa (CODESRIA) has a Small Grants Program for Thesis Writing to fund M.A. and Ph.D. candidates who are in the process of completing their theses. The funds will cover expenses in a country where research is conducted, but they will not cover the cost of travel to that country. For more information contact: Dr. Cyrus Reed, Office of African Studies, American University in Cairo, P.O. Box 2511, 113 Kasr al Aini, Cairo, Egypt.

Howard University's Center for the Study of Culture and Development in Africa offers a Resident Fellowship Program on Culture and Development. The theme of the program in 1994-1995 is "Gender, Cultural Production and Development in Africa." Two fellowships will be awarded, and fellows must be engaged in full-time research and be in residence at Howard University for the duration of the fellowship (August 1994-May 1995). Each full-year fellowship carries a stipend of US$30,000, plus $4,000 for relocation expenses, insurance, and other expenses. Limited funds are available for travel within the U.S. Candidates must have completed Ph.D. at the time of application. DEADLINE FOR RECEIPT OF APPLICATIONS AND ALL SUPPORTING DOCUMENTS: FEBRUARY 28, 1994. Contact: Director, Center for the Study of Culture and Development, Department of African Studies, Box 231, Howard University, Washington, DC 20059; phone: (202) 806-7115; fax: (202) 806- 4425.

The International Foundation for Education and Self-Help is also recruiting teachers for its Teachers for Africa program designed to help improve education in Africa. This program sends educators to assist in African primary and secondary schools as well as African universities. Assignments are for one academic year. Seven years of teaching or administrative experience preferred. Must be U.S. citizens or permanent residents. IFESH is responsible for placement, orientation, round-trip transportation, insurance, and a living allowance while in Africa. DEADLINE: APRIL 4, 1994. Contact: IFESH, 5040 East Shea Boulevard, Suite 260, Phoenix, AZ 85254-4610; phone: (602) 443-1800; fax: (602) 443-1824.

The Modern Management Institute in Nairobi, Kenya offers a new home study method for learning Kiswahili, a language spoken in Kenya, Tanzania, Uganda, Malawi, Zambia, Zaire, Rwanda, Burundi, and the Sudan. The method includes a basic English/Kiswahili textbook for 24 lessons and audio cassettes to help with pronunciation. Contact: Geoffrey Njogu, Director of Studies, Modern Management Institute, P.O. Box 47390, Nairobi, Kenya; phone: (254.2) 33.17.02.

The Population-Environment Fellows Program, sponsored by U.S. AID and administered at the University of Michigan, sponsors Fellows for two-year appointments with overseas agencies. Fellows provide assistance and technical support for developing country institutions to foster a comprehensive approach to development. Fellows must hold a graduate degree in a relevant area and demonstrate expertise in both population and environment. Applications are reviewed on a rolling basis, but the sooner a completed application is received, the greater the availability of sites for which it can be considered. Inquiries and application requests may be obtained from: The Population-Environment Fellows Program, SPH II, Room M2240, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109-2029; phone: (313) 747-0222; fax: (313) 747-4947.

The Rockefeller Foundation's Sub-Saharan African Dissertation Internship Awards 1993-1994 are open to citizens of sub-Saharan Africa studying in the U.S. or Canada. Priority will be given to research topics in the areas of agriculture, environment, health, sciences and schooling. Projects must involve field observations or use of primary sources only available in Africa. Students must have completed all course work and qualifying exams prior to receiving an award. DEADLINE: MARCH 1, 1994. To obtain applications and more information, contact: African Dissertation Internships, The Rockefeller Foundation, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, New York, NY 10036 or African Dissertation Internships, The Rockefeller Foundation, P.O. Box 47543, Nairobi, KENYA.

The University of Illinois-Egerton University Study Abroad Program allows undergraduates to spend eight weeks in Kenya this summer this summer. Participants will take courses at Egerton, tour various parts of the country, and live with Kenyan families in brief homestays. Contact: Center for African Studies, 210 International Studies Building, 910 South Fifth Street, Champaign, IL 61820; phone: (217) 333-6335.

The Washington Office on Africa seeks interns for Spring 1994. Interns will track legislation related to Africa, share information with congressional staff, be involved with the Southern African Working Group, and maintain the "Africa Hotline." Contact: Kristen Lee at Washington Office on Africa, phone: (202) 546-7961.

The Economic Development Institute of the World Bank announces the 1994 cycle of the Robert S. McNamara Fellowship Program which aims at producing the highest quality research results in the general area of economic development. The program also seeks to achieve wide geographical and cultural diversity among fellows. The 12-month fellowship does not support work toward an advanced degree, but innovate and imaginative post-graduate research in areas of economic development. Contact: Robert S. McNamara Fellowship Program, Room M-4029, World Bank Headquarters, 1818 H. St., N.W., Washington, DC 20433.

The Centre for Refugee Studies at York University in Toronto offers an eight-week summer course on refugee affairs. The program will provide an overview of refugee issues, plus an opportunity to explore current topics with international experts. Participation is limited to 50 practitioners from inside and outside government who work with refugees or on refugee affairs and have a degree equivalent experience. Course dates are June 22-29, 1994. Contact: Dr. Tom Clark, Summer Course Coordinator, Centre for Refugee Studies, York University, Suite 322, York Lanes, 4700 Keele Street, North York, ON Canada M3J 1P3; phone: (416) 736-5837; fax: (416) 736-5837.

The Los Angeles World Affairs Council 1994 Diplomatic Travel Program offers the following: "Untamed Africa - Kenya, Tanzania and Botswana". Trip will include Victoria Falls. From July 15 - August 8, 1994. Contact: Los Angeles World Arrais Council, Diplomatic Tour Department at (310) 652-4675.

The SSRC-MacArthur Foundation Committee on International Peace and Security announces a program of small grants in 1994 allowing scholars and students of international relations to visit major universities and research centers outside their home region. Grants are intended for junior scholars who seek exposure to debates and scholarship on the changing international system and issues of international peace and security. Applications should be completed and returned to the Council, postmarked no later than JULY 15, 1994. Contact: Social Science Research Council, Visiting Scholar Fellowship Program on International Peace and Security, 605 Third Avenue, 17th Floor, New York, NY 10158.

National Science Foundation Dissertation Improvement Grants support African graduate students who are enrolled in US universities and are planning to undertake dissertation research relating to a developing country problem. Grants are intended to cover research expenses and travel costs, not tuition, fees, or living expenses. The deadline is in March. Contact: Dr. Francis Li at (202) 653-5361 for details.

The Library of Congress Junior Fellows Program: African and Middle Eastern Division offers academic fellowships for juniors, seniors, and graduate students in a program designed to fit the interests of the fellows while serving the mission of the Library. Projects in the collection should be of interest in library science and African studies. Contact the Acting Chief, African and Middle Eastern Division, Library of Congress, Washington, DC 20540 or call the Junior Fellows Program Coordinator at (202) 707-4353.

University Research Expeditions Program at Berkeley organizes research expeditions in Africa. Upcoming expeditions include: The Palace of Savi (Benin); Traditional Music of East Africa (southern Uganda); and The View from Eritrea. No experience necessary. Scholarships are available for teachers and students. For more information and a free catalog, contact: University Research Expeditions Program Department D05, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720. Tel: (510) 642-6586.

Visions in Action offers one-year volunteer internships in urban areas of Kenya, Uganda, South Africa, Zimbabwe and Burkina Faso. Program areas include: development journalism, writing, project management, youth group organizing, community development, health care education, clinical assistance, women's and environmental issues, low-income housing, human rights, and scientific research. Interns are required to cover their costs. Total fees (including airfare) are about $5,500 per year. Interns receive a monthly stipend. Deadlines range from April 15 to October 15, depending on the country. For more information, contact: Visions in Action, 3637 Fulton Street NW, Washington, DC 20007. Tel: (202) 625-7403.

The Community Law Center in Durban, South Africa offers internship opportunities for law students and some undergraduates from outside South Africa. CLC is affiliated with the University of Natal, and places emphasis on assisting the rural areas of South Africa. CLC publishes a quarterly newsletter, Izindaba. Contact: The Community Law Center, Berea Center, 7th Floor, 247 Berea Road, Durban 4001, South Africa.

February 15, 1994 / February 28, 1994


EMPLOYMENT


LENGTH: 5560 words


 

The American Friends of the AICFA seeks a PROJECT MANAGER in Somalia for primary health care. Duties include procurement and logistics; project setup; maintenance of property; liaison with donors, other non-governmental organizations and authorities. QUALIFICATIONS: Three or more years in a similar position, strong negotiations, communications and management skills; ability to work in a difficult environment; knowledge of primary health care issues. Send resume and cover letter to: AFAICF, 815 15th Street NW, Suite 832, Washington, DC 20005; fax: (202) 783-5247. 

Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations has an opening for a SENIOR ECONOMIST (Marketing) in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia. This is a fixed term, 3-year position. QUALIFICATIONS: University degree in agricultural economics, preferably with postgraduate specialization in marketing, or a related field (such as agro-economy). Ten years of increasingly responsible professional experience in an international organization, government, private sector or research institution in agro-economic development. (An M.S. or equivalent advanced postgraduate degree in agricultural economics may be substituted for one year of the required experience, a Ph.D. or equivalent degree for two years of the required experience). Working knowledge of English (level C) or French or limited knowledge (level B) of the other. DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES: Under the supervision of the Director, Joint ECA (UN Economic Commission for Africa)/FAO Agriculture Division and the technical guidance of the Agricultural Services Division, to plan and coordinate the work of the Agricultural Marketing Section (ECA), and specifically, to: conduct analyses of the food and agricultural marketing situation in the region, including; developments in production, consumption, price policy, trade, distribution and demand, taking account of the Lagos Plan of Action, the Regional Food Plan for Africa and other regional programmes. Contact: Executive Officer, LNOR, Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, 1001 22nd Street, N.W., Suite 300, Washington, DC 20437

American Refugee Committee has the following positions available:

In Somalia:

MATERNITY SERVICES COORDINATOR, based in Afmadou, to select and train MCH Center maternity services staff; establish policies and procedures for the NCH Center maternity services; supervise the delivery of maternal services including prenatal care, labor and delivery care, postpartum care. Qualifications: Certified Nurse midwife; experience in training and US supervision; strong primary health background. Six- month commitment, $1,500 a month.

TRADITIONAL BIRTH ATTENDANT COORDINATOR, based in Afmadou, to mobilize the communities to support and make use of the Traditional Birth Attendants; conduct training course to qualify participants to work as TBAs; and conduct supervisory visits to observe TBA participants. QUALIFICATIONS: RN or midwife with previous experience in a developing country; previous training experience. US$1,500 a month. Six month commitment.

COMPOUND MANAGER, based in Bardera, to act as liaison between ARC and other voluntary agencies; secure necessary supplies; coordinate ARC programs with those of other agencies; maintain close contact with Nairobi office. QUALIFICATIONS: previous experience as field coordinator or similar capacity in developing countries; strong communication skills; flexibility. US $1,200/mo. Minimum 6 month contract.

In Sudan:

MEDICAL DOCTOR to provide emergency relief to displaced persons in Kajo Keji County. RESPONSIBILITIES: set up emergency/acute care clinic and coordinate all in-patient and out-patient activities. REQUIREMENTS: MD with emergency/acute care experience in developing countries and proven success in implementing new programs in relief situations. 6 month commitment. $1,200/month.

NURSE to provide emergency relief/acute care to displaced persons; assist in setting up emergency/acute care clinic; and supervise local nursing staff. REQUIRES: RN with emergency/acute care experience in developing countries and proven success in implementing new programs in relief situations. 6 month commitment. $1,200/month.

HOME VISIT COORDINATOR to communicate with authorities to select health care workers; conduct an initial 1-month training course and provide continuing education for workers. QUALIFICATIONS: RN with primary health care background and training experience; previous experience in a developing country. 1 year commitment., $1,200/month.

American Refugee Committee provides transportation, health insurance, and group housing. Send resume to: ARC, Cathy Tilsen, 2344 Nicolett Avenue, Suite 350, Minneapolis, MN 55404; (612) 872-7060; fax: (612) 872-4309.

In Mozambique:

PUBLIC HEALTH PROFESSIONAL to develop health program in coordination with the water and sanitation projects. Rural setting. REQUIRES: MPH; proven success in design and implementation of new public health programs in developing countries. Portuguese, Spanish or French fluency. 1 year contract. Immediate opening. $1,500/month.

WATER/SANITATION ENGINEER to monitor water points to assess water quantity and quality; provide logistical support; assist in rehabilitation and construction of wells. QUALIFICATIONS: Sanitation/ civil/environmental engineering degree; experience working overseas; experience with water protection and sanitation projects; construction and supervisory experience preferred. Portuguese, French or Spanish fluency. $1,500/month. Spring opening.

The Center for International Development and Environment of the World Resources Institute seeks individual with experience in natural resources management, institutions, and/or natural resource and policy activities in Africa, particularly national plans and strategies for sustainable development. Africa experience and excellent language competence in French required. Will be responsible for the coordination and implementation of the Center's activities in sustainable development planning in Africa. Will coordinate the Natural Resource Management Policy Consultative Group for Africa, with priority on an on-going study of sustainable development planning in 8 African countries. Position includes field work, analytical report writing, some policy research, and preparing workplans and budgets. Send resume to: Africa Program, CIDE/WRI, 1709 New York Avenue NW, Suite 700, Washington, DC 20006.

OIC International seeks a SMALL ENTERPRISE MANAGEMENT/DEVELOPMENT AND APPROPRIATE TECHNOLOGY SPECIALIST to provide technical assistance and training in value-added transformation and raw produce with the purpose of creating employment and economic development opportunities for unemployed youths and disadvantaged communities in African and other countries. The person will identify cottage industry and appropriate technologies adaptable to the client countries; develop curricula to train related entrepreneurial and technical skills to develop and manage such businesses. REQUIREMENTS: First degree in engineering followed by an MBA or equivalent education in Business Management; experience in related development work, and working experience in Africa in particular, first hand experience managing business and/or in appropriate technology development; fluent in English and French; knowledge of Spanish is advantageous. Travel required. Send resume: President and CEO, OIC International, 240 W. Tulpehocken Street, Philadelphia, PA 19144.

The Center for Arabic Study Abroad seeks an Executive Director for the period June 1994 to June 1996. CASA offers intensive summer and full-year programs in spoken and advanced literary Arabic for American college and high-school students and faculty. It is operated at the American University in Cairo under the governance of 22 American universities. Contact: Gerald E. Lampe, Director, CASA, SAIS/Johns Hopkins University, 1619 Massachusetts Avenue, N.W., Washington, D.C. 20036; phone: (202) 663-5751.

The Center for Wildlife Management in Kenya seeks a WILDLIFE RESOURCE MANAGER for a permanent full-time position of Resident Faculty. Resident Faculty live on site, lecture in an interdisciplinary, non- traditional, field-based learning environment and oversee student- directed research projects. Send detailed letter explaining relevant skills and experience, CV, and three references to Kenya Wildlife Resource Manager Search, The School for Field Studies, 16 Broadway, Beverly, MA 01915; phone: (508) 927-7777; fax: (508) 927-5127.

Family Health International seeks a RESIDENT ADVISOR for Tanzania, to coordinate and manage implementation of an AIDS Control and Prevention Project and ensure that appropriate technical assistance is provided to programs and activities. The program will strongly emphasize institutional building of indigenous NGOs. Requires Master's or doctoral level degree in public health or related field and seven-plus years experience in management of large public health/international development programs. Prior work with PVO/NGOs highly desirable. To apply, send cover letter (with salary requirements) and resume to Linda Rodriguez, Family Health International, 2101 Wilson Blvd., Suite 700, Arlington, VA 22201.

FHI also seeks a PROGRAM OFFICER to provide liaison, program, and administrative support required for a productive and efficient collaboration between FHI and UNICEF's AIDS unit; to facilitate FHI's provision of technical assistance to UNICEF's AIDS unit, Technical Support groups, and specified country programs. Requires Master's degree in Public Health or social sciences or equivalent experience and three- plus years related work experience. Experience in working with UN system of USAID-funded activities desirable. Fluency in French and/or Spanish desirable. To apply, send cover letter (with salary requirements) and resume to Linda Rodriguez, Family Health International, 2101 Wilson Blvd., Suite 700, Arlington, VA 22201.

FHI also seeks a RESEARCH OFFICER to assist in designing and managing the Behavioral Research program of the new global AIDS Control and Prevention Project (AIDSCAP) and to provide expertise in the planning, implementation, and evaluation of the Project's behavioral research program. Requires PhD in one of the social sciences or comparable combination of education and experience with AIDS epidemic and considerable experience in designing and implementing behavioral science research projects in the developing world. Ability to travel international, fluency in French or Spanish is preferred. To apply, send cover letter (with salary requirements) and resume to Linda Rodriguez, Family Health International, 2101 Wilson Blvd., Suite 700, Arlington, VA 22201.

FHI also seeks a CHIEF IN AIDS CONTROL AND PREVENTION PROJECT to manage the Behavior Changes Communications component, focusing on increasing condom demand and STD treatment-seeking behaviors and reducing numbers of sexual partners. Requires PhD or MA and equivalent experience and five years experience in the design of behavior change communications programs. Fluency in French or Spanish desirable. To apply, send cover letter (with salary requirements) and resume to Linda Rodriguez, Family Health International, 2101 Wilson Blvd., Suite 700, Arlington, VA 22201.

The International Development Group in Bethesda, Maryland seeks a BILINGUAL (ENGLISH/ARABIC) ADMINISTRATIVE ASSISTANT for a part-time (20- to-24-hour-a-week) position. The Administrative Assistant will report directly to the Administrative Coordinator and be responsible for the following: administrative support; and drafting correspondence and overheads in Arabic. Required qualifications include: minimum 50 word- per-minute typing speed, word processing experience (WordPerfect 5.1 or Microsoft Word); three years of previous administrative/secretarial experience; occasional overtime required; proficiency in Arabic. Pay range: $10.50 to $12 an hour. Send resume to: University Research Corporation, 7200 Wisconsin Avenue, Suite 600, Bethesda, MD 20814; phone: (301) 654-8338.

International Medical Corps has multiple openings. Mail or fax resume or letter of interest to International Medical Corps, Dept. 93- 033, 12233 West Olympic Blvd., #280, Los Angeles, CA 90064; fax: (310) 442-6622.

The following International Medical Corps positions are available in Angola:

MATERNAL AND CHILD HEALTH TRAINERS Registered Nurse with certificate or advanced degree in midwifery or maternal-child health nursing. Training experience required.

REGISTERED NURSE with masters degree in Public Health or PhD and extensive survey research experience. Demonstrated skills in epidemiology, biostatistics and nutritional anthroprometics required.

NUTRITIONIST with masters degree in Public Health or PhD and extensive survey research experience. Demonstrated skills in epidemiology, biostatistics and nutritional anthroprometics required.

Round-trip transportation, room and board provided for each of these positions. Mail or fax resume or letter of interest to International Medical Corps, 12233 West Olympic Blvd., #2809, Los Angeles, CA 90064. Fax (310) 442-6622.

These advisers will provide technical advice and management capabilities to the AID Mission to Kenya. Fluency in French highly desirable. Contact: Helene Montell, ARC/OIS, 17th and D Streets, N.W., Washington, DC 20006.

HEALTH TECHNICAL TRAINERS-AFRICA REGION (several openings) -- U.S. Personal Services contract positions as Health Technical Coordinator for pre-service training in Africa. QUALIFICATIONS: prior Peace Corps experience in primary health care or maternal and child health education in West Africa; prior experience designing primary health care training curricula using practical and competency-based approaches; MPH or related post-graduate degree preferred; 2 years work experience in the field of primary health care, preferably in a developing country; some French language ability (FSI 2+); demonstrated success training American adults; interpersonal skills; maturity with demonstrated ability to work effectively and sensitively on an inter-cultural team of trainers; knowledgeable about integrated approaches to rural development would be helpful; proven flexibility and willingness to work long, irregular hours and under considerable stress; ability and willingness to assess and counsel trainees. Send SF-171 to: Jahleezah Eskew, program assistant, Office of Programming and Training/Africa Region, 1990 K Street N.W., Washington, DC 20526. DEADLINE: Open.

Private Agencies Collaborating Together (PACT), a US-based international development organization, seeks a DEPUTY DIRECTOR experience in the small and micro-enterprise (SME) field for its South Africa office. Candidate must be a South African with relevant education, good communication skills, and a commitment to empowering blacks to establish successful SMEs. Send letter with CV and contact address/telephone/fax to PACT, P.O. Box 32286, Braamfontein 2017, South Africa.

The Washington Office on Africa seeks INTERNS for spring 1994. Interns will track legislation related to Africa, share information with congressional staff, be involved in the southern African Working Group, and maintain the "Africa Hotline." DEADLINE: MAY 1, 1994. Contact: Kristen Lee, Washington Office on Africa, 119 Maryland Avenue NE, Washington, DC 20002. tel: (202) 546-7961. fax: (202) 546-1545.

CUSO, a Canadian international development organization, seeks: MANAGER OF HYDROGEOLOGY AND CONSTRUCTION in Nigeria. This village borehole and sanitation project in Ondo State will provide clean water, public sanitation and public health training in disease endemic areas, as well as strengthen village and government institutions to enable rural communities to better manage their water and sanitation needs. Individual will act as chief advisor on rural water systems matters and supervise the principle contractor in hydrogeologic and related technical works, centered on borehole drilling. REQUIREMENTS: appropriate university degree; several years management experience in design, field implementation, computerized operations, and evaluation of water point improvement projects in developing countries, including community-based handpump maintenance and repair; experience in administration and supervision of field drilling contracts; leadership, communications and multicultural team work skills. Salary: CDN$40,000 REGIONAL DIRECTOR, South Africa. Individual will work on a well- integrated regional program with activities in Tanzania, Mozambique, Zambia, and South Africa. Working closely with the staff in the region, the Regional Director will be providing vision and leadership, as well as coordinating the development, implementation and evaluation of the regional program, ensuring effective program administration; managing human resources; representing the region and its programs and participating in organizational management. REQUIREMENTS: Experience in South/South, North/South interregional programming; excellent communication and representational skills; abilities in budgeting financial management and human resources management; knowledge of East Central and South Africa region; 50% travel; knowledge of Canadian realities and issues an asset. Salary: CDN$50,000.

Send CV, names & addresses of 3 references, and a short statement on how you see yourself contributing to the work by FEBRUARY 28 to: CUSO, Human Resources Dept., 135 Rideau Street, Ottawa, Ontario, Canada K1N 9K7; fax: (613) 241-8068.

Yale University's Program in African and African-American Studies anticipates an opening for a LECTOR IN KISWAHILI. This is a position for one year with possible extension to three years, beginning in September 1994. Responsibilities will be to teach Kiswahili at any of four levels and to participate in related language programs in the US and abroad. REQUIREMENTS: An M.A. is required, PhD will be preferred. Candidates should have native or near-native fluency in Kiswahili and should have competence to teach at least one other African language. Candidates should also have experience in language teaching, expertise in an area of linguistics or in the field of African Literature, and an interest in developing language materials using videotapes and computer software. Send a letter of application, c.v., sample article or paper and the names and addresses of three references to: Sandra Sanneh, Chair, Kiswahili Search Committee, Program in African Languages, P.O. Box 206891, New Haven, CT 06520-6891. Application received by MARCH 4 will be assured of consideration.

Youngstown State University is looking for candidates for an African/African-American/Black Studies faculty position in their History Dept. For more information or to forward names of prospective candidates, contact: William D. Jenkins, Department of History, Youngstown State University, Youngstown, OH 44555-3452. Phone: (216) 742-3452.

Pembroke State University has a position for an Assistant Professor in History with a Third World specialty (Africa, Asia, Middle East or Latin America) and an ability to teach World Civilization surveys. A PhD is required for this tenure track position which will begin August 1994. Send letter of application, resume, copies of transcripts and three letters of recommendation to: Search Committee, Attention: David K. Eliades, Chair, Dept. of History, One University Dr., Pembroke State University, Pembroke, NC 28372-1510. Application DEADLINE: March 4, 1994.

JSI Research and Training Institute seeks an East African PROGRAM DIRECTOR for its Family Planning Private Sector (FPPS) Project. Responsibilities: Provide strategic direction, leadership and supervision to a team of 20; provide leadership and organizational development skills to create a fully functioning Kenyan NGO capable of soliciting donor resources, preparing, implementing, monitoring and accounting for comprehensive programs for delivery of family planning and HIV/AIDS prevention; ensure effective management of a diversified portfolio of donor-funded projects; provide technical oversight to program activities; expand program activities by securing donors funding for HIV/AIDS prevention and other health-related projects. QUALIFICATIONS: Post-graduate degree in public health, population, communications or social sciences; training in management or administration, with emphasis on organization development and team building. 5+ years experience in a senior management position of an NGO or international development program, preferably in health and family planning. Send letters of application with resume, photocopies of relevant certificates and names & addresses of 3 references to: JSI Research and Training Institute, Kenya Program Director, 210 Lincoln Street, Boston, MA 02111 by February 28.

Not-for-Profit international development assistance organization seeks operations officer for its Africa Region. Major duties include: DC based project financial monitoring, program and logistical support for projects overseas. Experience in program and budget preparation, contact/grant drafting and monitoring also required. Overseas experience a plus. Strong LOTUS/EXCEL and WordPerfect required as well as fluency in French. BA/BS degree and 2-3 years related work experience required. Send resume and salary requirements no later than March 1 to Joyce Franklin, 1828 L Street NW, Suite 1000, Washington, DC 20036.

AirServ International seeks experienced and committed individuals who are OPERATIONS MANAGERS, AIRCRAFT MECHANICS and PILOTS in operations where recip/turboprop singles and twins are used in disaster relief operations. Work is demanding. Pay is around $2000/month. Included are housing, transportation, plus benefits, but desire to serve/help people must be main motivation. If you seriously want to make a difference in the lives of suffering people and can commit a year or more now or in the future, send a resume and a cover letter to: Personnel Dept., Air Serv International, Box 3041, Redlands, CA 92373.

The International Rescue Committee operates refugee relief programs in over 20 countries worldwide and is seeking a PROCUREMENT ASSISTANT. Procurement for these programs involves complex communications and a vast network of international suppliers. Items procured range from vehicles and medical supplies to textbooks and tents. Based in New York, under the supervision of the Procurement Officer, individual will: develop and maintain a database of suppliers and resources; provide clerical support; purchase goods and prepare for shipment to overseas programs; maintain relations and communications with IRC's suppliers and agents; liaise between field offices and suppliers; assure that donor requirements are met. REQUIREMENTS: Undergraduate degree in a related field, excellent computer skills including database, WP51, spreadsheet and Lotus, previous work experience, strong organizational skills, and a team player. Send cover letter, resume and 3 references to: IRC, Recruitment Office, 386 Park Avenue South, New York, NY 10016. Tel: (212) 679-0010. Fax: (212) 689- 3459.

The African American Studies program at the University of Wyoming has been endowed to develop courses in sub-Saharan African languages. As employment would be seasonal, relocation would not be necessary. The program would be responsible for all travel expenses, plus a salary. Requirements: All language instructors must be indigenous Africans and must have the minimum of a Bachelor's degree in any field. Send all resumes and letters of interest to: Niyi Coker Jr., PhD, Director of African American Studies, University of Wyoming, Laramie, WY 82071. Email: niyi@uwyo.edu.

LANGUAGE: English
