51 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 15, 1994 / February 28, 1994


VOLUNTEER OPPORTUNITIES


LENGTH: 1147 words


 

The Farmer-to-Farmer Volunteer Program, administered by Winrock International Institute for Agricultural Development and funded by the U.S. Agency for International Development, is currently recruiting agricultural specialists of varied backgrounds to provide technical assistance to female farmers in West Africa. The countries targeted to receive this assistance are Burkina Faso, Cote d'Ivoire, the Gambia and Senegal. Volunteers posted to these countries will work closely with local farmers, small business people, and host country organizations to share their expertise on agricultural topics including distribution and marketing, women cooperatives, fruit and vegetable preservation and storage, rice and cassava marketing, sesame production and marketing, aqua culture, curriculum development and cooperative management. Volunteer assignments range from three to six weeks and the ultimate goal of these assignments is to help host farmers improve family income and nutrition as well as to increase overall food production and distribution. The Farmer-to-Farmer Program pays for volunteer travel, meals and lodging. All travel logistics (i.e. visas, passports, medical exams) are arranged and paid for by Winrock International. The volunteer experts contribute their time and expertise. For additional information and a volunteer application form contact Tom Bauer, Farmer-to-Farmer Program, Rt. 3, Box 376, Morrison, AR 72110; phone (501) 727-5435, ext. 253; Internet: tomb@winrock.org. 

Health Volunteers Overseas has several openings for health care providers who wish to aid its programs in the following nations:

TRANSKEI (one-month assignments; April-December 1994): Participants needed to teach anesthesia at Umtata General Hospital to physicians-in- training. Volunteers will also provide direct anesthesia care. Housing on hospital grounds is provided for the volunteer at no cost. Contact Dr. Kevin Speight, (919) 716-4498/(919) 454-3956 or Spence Campbell (704) 696-9930.

UGANDA (one-month assignments; May-December 1994): Volunteers participate in the only anesthesia training program in Uganda. Most of the teaching takes place in Kampala's Mulago Hospital. Housing provided at the guest house at Makerere University. Contact Dr. Harry Zutz, (908) 381-4200/(201) 378-3323.

UGANDA (one-month assignments; March-November 1994): Program trains medical student, physicians, prosthetists, orthotists and physical therapists to improve the treatment of amputees and disabled people injured as a result of civil strife. Surgeons may also conduct orthopedic clinics an operating sessions with Ugandan doctors in upcountry regional hospitals in Tororo/Mbale, Mbarara and Fort Portal. Physical therapist volunteers will be needed to help the Ugandan tutors to develop courses in the three year diploma course are Mulago Hospital. Volunteers need to have a minimum of two years of clinical experience and some educational experience. Advanced degrees and lecture experience are big plus, but are not mandatory. Prosthetists are also being sought to teach. For a nominal fee, housing will be provided at the newly renovated Mulago Guest House. Contact: Dr. David Denzel, (716) 434-2697 or Elizabeth Kay, PT, (708) 897-4814.

MALAWI (two-month assignments, one month considered; The School of Health Sciences in Lolongwe is the site for a program providing education support in the areas of diagnosing dental and oral pathoses, performing conservative dentistry, periodontics, uncomplicated dental extractions and preventive dentistry. This program is soliciting 3 volunteers a year with a one month hiatus between volunteers. Contact: Dr. Dick Nieusma, (402) 472-9846.

For a more detailed description of each site as well as copies of trip reports from previous volunteers, contact Health Volunteers Overseas, c/o Washington Station, P.O. Box 65157, Washington, DC 20035 5157; phone: (202) 296-0928.

The American Medical Team for Africa (AMTA) promotes and executes educational exchange and medical training in African countries. The goal of the non-profit organization is to bring volunteer doctors, nurses and medical students together with donated supplies, and equipment to serve needs on the continent. Survey teams assess the most pressing needs in targeted countries, develop and publish training manuals in appropriate languages, hold workshops and refresher courses for doctors, nurses and specialists interested in maintenance of health care delivery systems in Africa; and distribute medical supplies and equipment donated by corporations, pharmaceutical companies, hospitals and doctors. The AMTA plans a second medical mission to Africa. For more information, contact Deman Rageh, Executive Director, The American Medical Team for Africa, 2245 Godby Road, Atlanta, GA 30349; phone (404) 766-8000; fax: (404) 767-5264.

Private Voluntary Organization in Rosslyn needs an experienced Agribusiness/Marketing Specialist to fill a 3-year Chief of Party position in Mali. The candidate must have at least 10 years of proven experience in the field of Agribusiness, Marketing, Credit and Procurement (preferably of fruits & vegetables). Must have related job experience in developing country with hands-on experience and an MBA. Strong training skills in the areas of agribusiness and marketing required. Fluency in French/English (FSI , S-3, R03) a must. Interested candidates must submit a resume, a certification of foreign language capability, and a standard AID bio-data form. Please mail original copies to: Regina Wynn, VITA, 5th floor, Arlington, VA 22209. Tel: (703) 276-1800 or fax: (703) 2143-1865.

56 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 15, 1994 / February 28, 1994


WHY THE ANGER OVER MONITORING?


BYLINE: MONITOR Staff Writer


SECTION: VIEWPOINT


LENGTH: 760 words


 

THE MONITOR, Friday, January 28- February 1,1994

PRESIDENT Yoweri Museveni in his Kololo Airstrip speech to mark

the NRM's 8th anniversary attacked a new-found enemy: the National Organisation for Civic Education and Election Monitoring (NOCEM).

MUSEVENI got so angry, he asked what business NOCEM has monitoring the elections. "Who are they?" he asked. Museveni singled out Nathan Karema who was the UPC government's District Commissioner of Luwero during the NRA's brush war and had become Chief Monitor in Mbarara. Karema, according to the president, caused a lot of suffering in Luwero. 

TRUE, as Museveni said, people who monitor should have clean records. His argument that the monitoring should not be used for politicking and confusing the voters is well taken.

MONITORS are supposed to be neutral, otherwise the process loses meaning.

BUT the president's seeming blanket condemnation of NOCEM as an organisation is confusing. NOCEM is a collection of 12 law abiding nongovernmental organisations including journalists groups and the Uganda Law Society. If there is a "bad" person, that does not mean NOCEM has lost the moral legitimacy to monitor. It would be like saying that because there are a few criminals and corrupt people in NRM,. it has no business being in government.

WHAT right does NOCEM have to monitor elections? Well, it is their right as citizens. The same right they have to vote. As citizens they have a right to see that the process is fair.

AND we think the idea of people who were involved with the Amin or Obote governments not being able to monitor could be carried too far. It seems the NRM takes the view that "agents" of Obote and Amin who are "NRM agents" are okay; but those who are not pro-NRM are bad. Why this should be the case is not clear.

KAREMA'S case brings many of these issues into focus. When he appeared before the Human Rights Commission to give evidence about atrocities in Luwero, the Commission heard his testimony in camera. There are enough incredible rumours why that was the case. He has been arrested several times, but has not been convicted by a court of law. There are reports that he has made some money supplying to government.

ALL these tell us that we should guard against the political condemnation of people by the government of the day. A lot of innocent people were slaughtered because they were politically condemned as "Obote people" by Amin. Many people were killed during Obote II because they were "Museveni's guerrillas." Now we could see the NRM returning the compliments, by placing Amin and Obote "agents" under a political sentence.

WE hope NOCEM will not be scared into appointing only people who are approved by the government; and this is likely. The idea of local monitoring groups is relatively new in Africa. Many governments, not surprisingly, prefer the foreign to local monitors. This is because the local monitors have a longer presence and understand the local groups know the political terrain better. Foreign ones can be manipulated more easily by the government.

IT would be ABSOLUTELY wrong in future to seek to close citizens out of civic activities because they are "Museveni agents." As Museveni said, if these "agents" are criminals, let them be tried for their crimes. It would be a very sad day when Ugandans will have to trade in their political rights for forgiveness of their past "political" crimes by the government of the day.

Reprinted from THE MONITOR, Friday January 28- February 1, 1994.

THE MONITOR is published by THE MONITOR Publications Ltd.

Contact: THE MONITOR, P.O. Box 12141, Kampala, Uganda Phone: 236939. Fax: 251352.


LOAD-DATE: February 28, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


57 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 15, 1994 / February 28, 1994


WHEN SILENCE IS CRIMINAL


BYLINE: Olusegun Obasanjo


LENGTH: 3627 words


 

NEWSWATCH, February 14,1994

The following is excerpted from a keynote address at a conference organised by Arewa House, February 2, in Kaduna on the state of the nation.

General Babangida is the main architect of the state in which the nation finds itself today and General Abacha was his eminent disciple, faithful supporter and beneficiary. But when some of us saw the light, or is it darkness, if some half a dozen serious, responsible, principled and respected voices all over the country had joined to raise an alarm publicly, we would not be in the situation we are today. The alarm might have been heeded and harrowing experiences avoided.

Some of us here today cannot escape the charge of being accomplices and being guilty through silence. Speaking up and doing so early, objectively, seriously and concertedly might have prevented the destruction which occurred. While private urgings may be good, they are insufficient when a government is deaf and mischievous. Such a government sees private urgings and correspondence either as tacit approval or an invitation to be quietly settled. It would have been better for us to step on a couple of toes and some economic interests rather than allow the country to be bankrupted and destroyed almost to the point of irreparability. 

Let us attempt to draw a number of parallels between the present administration which must be part of the yard-stick of the measurement of the state of the nation, and its full military predecessor under whose tutelage it was for eight years. The moral underpinning of one was hollow through and through. The moral underpinning of the other is no better. General Sani Abacha reminds one of a man who, with other do- gooders, prepared a meal for a blind man. As soon as others turned their backs, this seeming good Samaritan, who was supposed to assist the blind man, went back to snatch the pot of soup and spoon from the blind man for himself. Again most of us Nigerians as spectators applauded. Under all sorts of excuses there was no shortage of partakers in the meal. And they were not troubled by the moral implications. The present government is challenged by overpowering issues of morality and ethics that it simply cannot wish away. Until it confronts these issues and deals with them, it will not be able to prepare the foundation and set the example that can move the nation forward. Few Nigerians are impressed by excuses being given for not doing what needs to be done. They see these excuses as self-serving, as grand deceit, and as cover-up. One man's own excuse was that "all Nigerians are corrupt." I challenged hi,. Not all Nigerians are corrupt. If, however, you are corrupt and you attain high public office, you either purge yourself or you put your authority in question. For, if you do not atone for it, corruption becomes debilitating and disabling. No society that treats public fund and property with utter disregard and cares only for personal accumulation on the principle of "steal and go" can make progress in the closing decade of the twentieth century. We cannot extol corruption and hope for the grace of God.

This present administration in an attempt to clothe itself with the garb of legitimacy and acceptance brought into its fold politicians of all shades of integrity most of whom were previously condemned and brought into disrepute by the same military men. One wonder whether these politicians have now been cleansed in the sea of Galilee.

Inconsistency and regular shifting of the goal post constituted the hallmarks of the Babangida's political chicanery of which Abacha was a part, we have now been told that the programme of this administration would last for an indefinite "brief period" which an insider told me could vary from one year to 10 years.

If a government out of lack of confidence in itself fails to repose confidence in us by telling us its programme and how long it requires to implement that programme, why should such a government ask for our confidence and understanding? And if it does, why should we give it? After all confidence begets confidence. And how seriously should anybody take the idea that the Constitutional Conference that has no hand in voting in the military government should determine its agenda. For us to take such idea seriously, the outcome or decision of the Constitutional Conference should be binding on the military government.

Corruption on any scale is bad; so is mismanagement on any scale. But given the events of the past eight years, it is clear that the civilian politicians of the Second Republic were far less rapacious in their corruption compared to the military who succeeded them, and far less degenerate in their social and economic management. But the greatest danger that military governance poses to our polity is not the perpetuation of economic and social mismanagement, bad as this is . The greatest danger lies in the failure of the military to break the vicious cycle of succeeding itself. Unless Nigerians stand up against this trend, it may continue indefinitely. Invariably, our leaders have failed because we have allowed them to fail us. Those leaders of erstwhile leaders sit down and enjoy and laugh waiting for another opportunity. What a tragedy for a nation! Since independence, Nigeria has not been able to unite behind one non-military leader, I believe we can unite behind one political issue. It is democracy.

In 1985 we were mesmerised with the debate on the IMF loan and later in 1986 with the Political Bureau debate. Most Nigerians, including those who set us on the IMF debate, understood little or nothing of the operations and policies of the IMF. In the end the two debates served the purpose they were meant to serve; to provide a diversion. Now, we are warming up to another diversion, and a more dangerous one called the Constitutional Conference. I will say more about this presently.

Meanwhile, I would like to draw another parallel between the present administration and its predecessor in the use and abuse of the press. It is common knowledge that the last full military administration hired hack writers to mislead the public, assassinate the character of innocent persons and to create the impression which the government wanted, however misleading. Editorials were sponsored and planted. These practices were acknowledge at the highest level of government. The present administration has embarked on the same method and the same practice, especially to justify and explain its inconsistencies as evidence that it is bowing to the wishes of the people. The culture of settlement and payment of praise singers and writers enthroned by the last full military administration continues with little or no abatement. The politics of prebendalism has been raised to a higher height.

For as long as our leaders and sponsor of leaders lead and sponsor for personal, ethnic, geographical, sectional, religious and purely economic interests, for so long will the problems remain with us, no mater the sophistication of our constitution or the frequency of change. How do we provide a stake in Nigeria for every Nigerian if Nigerians from one part of the country can be told that God has ordained people from another part of Nigeria for permanent political leadership of Nigeria and the others for followership? I would not have made reference to this unfortunate statement but for the fact that the person ;to whom it was attributed could jolly well have been voted in as the president of this country. There has never been a disclaimer. But more importantly, no responsible voice from up-country has publicly made a statement that leadership material is not limited to only one particular section of the country.

At this juncture, let me pay tribute to those who stood against the diabolical and destabilising role that Radio Kaduna played during the Babangida-created crisis of June/July/August last year. I do not listen to any Nigerian radio, let alone Radio Kaduna. But some of my northern friends who listened to Radio Kaduna alerted me and urged me to assist in giving hope, confidence and assurance of peace and security to Nigerians wherever they lived. It was the alert that partly made me call a press conference to urge Nigerians to remain calm in their places of abode and to assure them that the crisis would not lead to a civil war. Unfortunately some mass media in the south replied in king to Radio Kaduna. I say unfortunately because two wrongs don't make a right. But rather than Radio Kaduna which is paid from public funds being brought to order by the government, the media in the south that replied in kind were either banned or closed down. This was deliberately playing the north against the south for personal interest.

The settler/stranger syndrome aggravates the sense of belonging and stake in the country. It is pathetic and most lamentable that after forty years of residence in any part of Nigeria, a "non-indigene" is still regarded and still regards himself as an alien in that past of the country. Worse still ;are the institutional and procedural mechanisms that accentuate, amplify and reinforce such a feeling of alienation. I refer in particular to such instruments as discriminatory school fees, and appointments and promotions in the civil service, etc. It is important that we regard any Nigerian who has lived in a particular area for upwards of twenty years or who has been born into that area as qualified for all rights of an indigene of that area with all its obligations, responsibilities and duties. He should be free to participate fully and without discrimination in all political, economic and social activities of the area.

There is a grand falsification and misperception going around that the presidential system is expensive and therefore we should opt again

for the parliamentary system. The question is: expensive for what and for whom? The greatest advantage of the presidential system is that the country is the constituency of the president. He is obliged to know the country and to seek support across the country. Even if he is a tribal baron, his horizon and outlook will be broadened by the end of a nationwide campaign. In 1979, two of the presidential contestants confessed to me that the country-wide campaign tours provided a great education for them.

Most interesting to watch is the compromise of principles by public office holders in Nigeria and those angling for public office. The situation is so bad that it now seems an aberration for anyone to resign from public office on matters of principle. During my time in government, I recall two specific individuals who offered to resign on principle. I also recall the celebrated resignation of the editor of the "New Nigerian" at the height of the political crisis last year. There are two or three who refuse to join a particular government on principle. These examples represent our oasis of hope in a desert of unprincipled men and women. I believe there may be more men of honour and integrity whose actions and reactions are unheralded.

In the muddle and insincerity of deciding to probe or not to probe, it appears that some form of selective probes are going on at almost all levels. People are now wondering what is happening? Are there sacred cows or are we allowing camels to pass through the eye of the needle? Is this a case of nepotism, favouritism or is it enlightened self-interest? In a situation where fringe actors are being probed and principal actors are not probed, the public is bound to question the sincerity and the justice of the entire effort

It was the economic costs of non-democratic practice in Nigeria in the past eight years the group self-aggrandisement and the wens of patron-client relations and politics of distribution which led to the clamour for a National Conference s a means of redressing the past and preventing a re-occurrence. The government is offering a Constitutional Conference instead. Some expect to emerge from the National Conference new local governments while others expect new states and yet others expect to life oil for expected new Ogoni State. Ogoni is symbolic of most minorities' plight and thinking all over the country. No matter how we perceive their claim, it is an issue that must be put on the table.

There are many Ogonis, our dispensation must allow for the right of minorities including the enjoyment of part of the God-given resources in their area and there must be a delicate balance between the rights and interests of the minorities and the rights and common interests of all Nigerians. We must listen to them. I was told that the purpose of the conference is to satisfy the agitators, but should we address such a basic and vital issue as the constitution of a nation on the premise of satisfying a handful or agitators? The conference might get out of control. And if I may ask, "What is wrong with the 1979 Constitution and the 1989 Constitution?"

There is need for a general re-examination of all aspects of our national life; education, health, agricultural, industrialization, public administration, law and order and security, and judiciary etc. and what tier of government will be responsible and be involved for what ends and with what means. If, therefore, there is going to be a conference, it must be a conference to examine each and all of these issues. A Constitutional Conference to keep all agitators quiet, no matter how much it is dressed up, cannot achieve the objective of a genuine National Conference designed to examine critically the political and other essential areas of our lives on which there must be a consensus for effective government action.

With the atomisation of Nigeria by means of state creation almost to the point of rendering the constituent unites prostate, I find the concept of zones as the basis of our federation worth examining. At this stage of our development, we cannot abandon the federal system but perhaps the federating units should be enough to be viable, and made up of local governments. We may be able to save some costs on administration for development. The time has also come when as a mark of true federalism, revenue resources and responsibility of each constituent component, should determine wages and salary scales of each constituent.

I hereby declare once again that I cannot and will never be a party to the breaking up of Nigeria. Let me also reiterate what I have said before; I have had to fight a war to keep Nigeria together, I cannot and will not fight another war to tear Nigeria apart. However, I still believe that a major issue to be settled at the conference should be the issue of our living together -- the corporate existence of Nigeria. We must settle this matter once and for all and do away with constant threats to our corporate existence. After we have agreed to live together, we an settle the issue of how we will live together. I am convinced that when we are confronted with the reality of a break-up, our leaders will prefer living together on the basis of mutual respect and mutual benefit to breaking up. If our leaders cannot appreciate the need and the necessity, our people can and they will give the final verdict. These issues should be dealt with once and for all and most democratically.

The forum for dealing with this matter, as I see it, is a National Conference. A Constitutional Conference can deal with a number of relevant issues, but it will remain somewhat limiting. We have not had a Constitutional Conference since independence but since we have agreed that there is need for a Conference, let us make it one that will deal comprehensively with the fundamental issues of Nigerian existence. What our situation demands is a National Conference by elected representatives of the people in Nigeria to discuss all major issues, subject to one condition that whatever is agreed must be referred to a national referendum. If we opt for a genuine National Conference that will examine all aspects of our national life, it may last longer than one year. The time-table of the present military administration should, therefore, not be contingent on the result of the Conference since the final outcome will go before a referendum.

At this point let me report that on my way to Kaduna yesterday I was invited to Abuja. My discussion with the head of state centred essentially on the national constitutional conference. My feeling or should I say my deduction is that most of the points I have raised in his address on the conference are begin seriously considered.

The economy requires a big dose of discipline, reduction of corruption from the highest to the lowest, motivation, commitment, rationalisation and reduction of waste. No plea to our creditors for compassion, concession and relief will be heeded until some correctness is brought into our political and economic practice and management. We cannot maintain a high debt service ratio, decline in oil revenue, profligacy in spending, continuous capital flight and no foreign investment and then expect wonderful performance of the economy.

Manipulation of the judiciary in a way that undermined its credibility, independence and effectiveness is one of the greatest disservice of the last full ;military administration to the county. To destroy the judiciary must remain sacred. It is in the best interest of the people to ensure this, otherwise there will be no honest and credible arbiter between citizens ad between the citizens and the government especially a government that is full of mischief. The judiciary also needs to save itself and enhance its worth, by jealously guarding its independence.

Evil is not reformable, it must be removed. And that was what happened to the last full military administration. Although the present administration learned a lot from its teacher, it has not yet completely turned evil. But the trends and the tendencies are obvious. It is the responsibility of all Nigerians to prevent another government from becoming completely evil. We can embark on the process of democracy today with the establishment of a non-military national government that has the credibility and the moral strength to tackle the contending political, economic and social issues.

We must never be tired of demanding that any government should chasten itself and give us the foundation and the example to propel us forward. We must demand that any government should deal honestly with us and level up with us. We must have the programme ad the time-table of any government to be able to assess its performance. We must be accountability and transparency that we are not getting now. If any administration is turning evil we should spare no efforts or no sacrifice to remove it.

Nigeria has a responsibility to the whole black race to put its house in order and show that the race is not doomed. We cannot afford to fail because of our responsibility to ourselves, the rest of Africa and the black world.

Reprinted from Newswatch, February 14, 1994.

Newswatch is published by Newswatch Communications Limited, No. 3 Billings Way, Oregun Industrial Estate, Oregun, P.M.B. 21499, Ikeja, Lagos, Nigeria. Tel: 4960950. Fax: 962887.


LOAD-DATE: February 28, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


58 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 15, 1994 / February 28, 1994


TOO EARLY FOR GAMBIAN UNIVERSITY


BYLINE: Andrew Winter, U.S. Ambassador to The Gambia


LENGTH: 2040 words


 

DAILY OBSERVER, Thursday, February 3, 1994

The American Ambassador to The Gambia, Mr. Andrew Winter, says he feels "strongly" that the time has not yet come for the establishment of a university in this country.

Mr. Winter gave his views on education in The Gambia during an extensive interview with Daily Observer journalists yesterday, when he visited the Observer offices at the invitation of Mr. Kenneth Y. Best, the managing director.

"The costs of setting up and running a university are extraordinarily high. That same money could be better spent on improving basic education in this country, and technical education," Mr. Winter believes. He added that the money left over (which would be far less than a university would cost) could be sent on training Gambian students abroad. 

"I don't think the time has come; in an area where you have to pick and choose, I think the emphasis has to be on the basics," Mr. Winter stressed. He said that high schools should be improved, so that students could compete for overseas scholarships. He stated that the university in Sierra Leone was "half-empty," and he was sure The Gambia could "get a good deal" in making arrangements for some more of its students to obtain higher education there.

"Yes, you need education for development," he declared, " but for the initial stages of development you need a work force with basic technical skills. Lawyers can be trained outside this country -- doctors, too -- but it's a lot harder to train mechanics or offset press experts, or whatever it may be, outside the country."

Asked about the US government's provision for educational scholarships, he said he did not know the full amount involved, but he thought the US has been supporting Gambian students "fairly well." Enjoying Gambia

Mr. Winter said he has enjoyed his first four months here. He said coming to work in The Gambia is "the easiest adjustment I have ever made." He spoke approvingly of his own embassy staff, and of USAID and Peace Corps personnel here. The ambassador went on to say that in The Gambia "people are willing to talk," he can travel freely, and there are "very few frustrations." He said the greatest satisfaction in his job is that he feels he can make an impact. The Gambia, Mr. Winter said, has a government that listens, that does its best for the country, and that has the right kind of policies (for example, in encouraging private enterprise). He said his posting here "couldn't be better," because the Gambian and US governments enjoy shared values, especially a commitment to and respect foe human rights. 9M Aid Withheld

Talking about the D9m in US government aid that has been withheld,

Mr. Winter said: "The important thing to realise here is that the target of the sum was set jointly by the government of the United States and the government of The Gambia.

"The government of The Gambia agreed they would attempt to collect a certain amount of money under the AMRC's auspices by December 31, 1993. For a variety of reasons, the government has not been able to meet that target. We shall continue to work with the government and support the government in its efforts to meet the target." He added the government has made tremendous efforts to collect the money, but the rule of law must apply, and citizens have a right to pursue all legal means in their own defence. US Fund Not Misused

The ambassador said he was not aware that any US aid funds have been misused, in The Gambia or elsewhere. There are very stringent controls. Gambia's Future

Asked about what future he thought The Gambia could look forward to, Ambassador Winter said that on the positive side are the democracy and freedom this country enjoys, and its present emphasis on private enterprise. The less positive aspects include the country's small size and its lack of a natural resource base. Becoming an African "Singapore" is a long-term goal. Until the education provision has been enhanced, and until sub-regional, regional and all African trade and freedom movements are enlarged, the process will be long and slow. He praised The Gambia for making sacrifices "almost as no other country" in respect of realistic development policies.

He said the CFA zone has made its own adjustment much later, and therefore the pain of adjustment for them is greater. Russia, he added, seems to be backing away from essential economic reforms. The greatest hope for The Gambia is that its government and people have made the right decisions. Tourism

Ambassador Winter, turning to the tourist industry, said it is necessary to get tourists to spend more money here. This means considering going more "up scale," and encouraging eco-tourism. He had been impressed during his visit to Kiang West, and said there is scope for the type of tourist who likes bird-watching and nature generally.

USAID intends to help artisans sell their work. The Gambia could possibly very fruitfully liaise with Senegal in developing facilities that will attract more US citizens, including African-Americans, to make the long journey here. Visas

Replying to a question about the issuing if visas at the US embassy, the ambassador said there is absolutely no quota. If the applicant can satisfy the US consul that he is a bona fide tourist, businessman or student, he will be given a visa. He gave an assurance that there is no passing-on of information concerning visa applicants to other local embassies and high commissions. Press Freedom

On the press, the ambassador said he and his government are utterly committed to a free press as part of democracy.

He said sometimes governments are sensitive to press criticism, and they have the right to criticise the press themselves, provided they do not attack or threaten it. He added the press should be honest, and responsible, and not undermine confidence in a government that is doing its best. He added that he considers the Gambia press is, in general, very responsible. US Foreign Policy

On US foreign policy generally, Ambassador Winter admitted that during the cold war period, American governments had sometimes put their desire to combat communism above their wish to further the cause of democracy. This meant, for example, that at one time the US "saw advantage in backing people who did not share our democratic principles." But he said that, at the present time the US has made it clear that in Zaire, for example, Mobutu is part of the country's problem, and until he goes, the problem cannot be solved.

He agreed with his compatriot, Professor Harris, who gave a lecture here last week, that ultimately each country must take responsibility for its own destiny. South Africa

Ambassador Winter spoke very warmly of his optimism for the future of South Africa, in which he spent three and a half years. (He added that he has visited some 32 other African countries.) During his time there he felt genuinely "part of history." He had not understood before the basic lack of hatred between blacks and whites. He said that although the blacks, as symbolised by Mandela, have suffered every possible sort of deprivation and humiliation, they are now intent on working to introduce a multi-racial democracy. "There is no other alternative for South Africa," the ambassador stressed.

Mr. Winter said that following the inauguration of democratic rule, euphoria will gave way to realism, as the country experiences the realities of the economic situation. But he remained hopeful, given the inspirational leadership of de Klerk and the "even greater" inspirational role of Mandela, that South Africa's formidable problems will be solved. The US government has been "quietly talking to both sides" for seven or eight years, but South Africa will not benefit from outside interference. "Ultimately its problems must be worked out between its own peoples." Nigeria

Mr. Winter said the US is very concerned about Nigeria, and "strongly wants to see the return of democratic rule." He said he is not optimistic, in the short term; on the other hand, "democracy is the 'in- thing' everywhere, now, and democracy will come, sooner or later." Middle East

On US support for arms in the Middle East, the ambassador said ultimately every government looks after what it perceives to be its country's own self interest and the US seeks to create a balance of power by enabling its friends to defend themselves. But he said there has been very real progress in the relationships between Israel, the PLO, Syria, Jordan and Lebanon. Clinton's Priorities

Mr. Winter said President Clinton plans to concentrate on US domestic affairs, which he (like the ambassador himself) feels have been ignored for too long.

He said that as a "child of the sixties" in high school and university, he had experienced at first hand the struggles of African- Americans, and much has been accomplished, socially and in terms of legislation. But there is a great deal more to be done. Under President Clinton, the ambassador claimed, "some dreams have been revived." He went on that it would be insincere not to admit that black Americans are still disadvantaged in terms of their poverty, and limited access to education

"The odds are still against them." The US government is doing more to help, and such programmes as the effort to provide universal health care for all, and short-term welfare schemes are very promising.

Mr. Andrew Winter concluded that everyone strives to achieve "self worth," and that no-one can make a fortune on welfare handouts.

The ambassador visited all departments of The Observer Press Limited, and was introduced to staff by the managing director.

Reprinted from DAILY OBSERVER, Thursday, February 3,1994.

DAILY OBSERVER is published by THE OBSERVER COMPANY (GAMBIA) LTD., Contact: DAILY OBSERVER, New Town-Sait Matty Junction, Bakau P.M.B. 131, Banjul, The Gambia. Phone: (220) 496608. Fax: (220) 496878.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


February 15, 1994 / February 28, 1994


WILL NGOs BE DRAWN INTO A NEW GOVERNMENT?; Part 2 of Series


BYLINE: Rehana Rossouw


LENGTH: 1880 words


 

SOUTH, February 11-15, 1994

South Africa's real talent lies in the non-governmental organisation (NGO) sector and there should be more of it in the new bureaucracy, according to Prof Merlyn Mehl, education director of the Independent Development Trust (IDT).

Most NGOs have spent the past two years rethinking their positions and many have concluded that, to survive after the elections, they have to provide improved service and reach agreement with the government, Mehl said.

The state at present suffers not only from a lack of legitimacy, but also from a lack of effectiveness.

"Governments by and large are very inept," Mehl said.

"While the NGO sector responded to a lack on the part of the government, its existence demonstrates not only its viability to discuss social issues but also the need for such a sector. 

"Some of them are worth surviving, some will mercifully, disappear into oblivion."

Mehl said the NGO sector was already a surrogate bureaucracy, and had developed a high degree of innovativeness.

NGOs have had to find ways of doing things differently to the government. They could not be more of the same and this tended to be programme-centred, Mehl explained.

"For example, the Department of Education and Training;s Inset programme run by 600 subject advisors amounts to R600 million a year," he said.

"Governments respond to problems by appointing people. NGOs create a programme.

NGOs were also lean and thin, but the only reason was that they did not have any money. An analysis of major NGOs in education shows salaries are 50 percent of their annual budgets.

The state, on the other hand, spends 85 percent of its budget -- amounting to R23 billion -- on salaries and administration.

"There is no leeway for creativity among state employees, people are more concerned about their pensions," Mehl said.

"In the future, some people in NGOs will be absorbed into a future legitimate authority, as was done in Namibia. NGOs could also have a restructured relationship with the democratic state.

"Governments cannot and should no do everything for citizens. They have a tendency to do for and not with.

"The NGO sector must survive, because they really represent the variety and ability of th people."

Interfund, a major foreign funding organisation representing European and Canadian governments in South Africa, said it would co- operate in some way with a democratic government in South Africa.

Interfund director Mr. Barry Smith said he did not believe the future South African government was going to absorb all the NGOs.

"They might take up a lot of skilled people in organisations. And even if these people are committed to the NGO sector they may feel obliged to go to government because there are better opportunities for advancement in the new civil service," Smith said.

"This could drain the NGO and community-based organisation (CBO) sector. NGOs are less vulnerable because they have a bigger pool of trained people. CBOs will be affected insofar as their leadership could be drawn into local government structures.

"The sector will survive, but it will be a rocky road for a while."

Smith said organisations need to analyse honestly what their role in the future will be -- whether they will work outside of government structures until they are absorbed and run by government or whether they will remain independent.

Some -- like literacy organisations -- could work in integrated government programmes where there is a need for a strong government programme and use public money.

"Organisations need to ask whether there are really for remaining independent, whether their mission is to play a lobbying function, influencing policy," Smith said.

He warned that there were a lot more actors who would like to be involved in South Africa and could be in the future. There will be bilateral government-to-government projects.

The World Bank, western governments and the business community would also be involved at some level. This did not mean all would invest in the future.

Kagiso Trust director Mr. Eric Molobi said state intervention would not happen overnight as the transitional government would remain an area of contest for a long time.

"There will be a transitional period where NGO activity will become more intense as people who come into government realise that the bureaucracy blocks them and they will not be able to do anything because the bureaucracy is hostile," Molobi predicted.

"But when we say NGOs will do the work, we're not talking about the small projects activists work in, we're talking about bodies like the National Housing Forum, the National Electricity Forum. Although it is not a government body, the NHF can must R1,2 billion -- it can do development with impact."

Molobi also warned against South Africans allowing outside agencies to dictate development policy in the future.

"My limited experience of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund already shows me that if you allow them to come into your country with their own package, they nail you," he said.

"The only way we can circumvent that is if we draw up the package ourselves and go to them and say this is what we want to do.

"We may not reach that stage. The main players among political organisations' leadership today are concentrating their efforts on struggling for power and only that.

"And I know that after we enjoy the celebrations after the elections, the first thing on the agenda of the government will be development and we will have no real plans and will have to go to the World Bank on our knees."

Molobi said after elections, the European Community (EC), which channels funds into South Africa through Kagiso Trust, might change the emphasis of where it puts the money.

Some of it may go to a democratic government and a section may remain with NGOs.

"Whether this will happen is difficult to predict. One has to observe trends in African and other parts of the world," he said.

"We are hoping governments will not cut their money to South Africa after the elections, but merely the slice of the cake South Africa gets. The money can be deployed to other activities likes education and health.

"Kagiso Trust will be here for the long haul. We had discussions with the EC and secured this. The organisation will definitely not be

thrown out after there is a new government.":

A Johannesburg consultant who performs assessments of NGOs for foreign funders said a major short-coming in NGOs is skills training and the transfer of skills.

Affirmative action programmes are virtually non-existent. Black women in the leadership of NGOs and other funded structures are rare. Most are controlled by Indian and white men and a few white women.

If these people left the organisation to work for the new government, it could only strengthen the affirmative action programmes, she argued.

"They did not put enough effort into working out how to transfer skills and there are no signs that this vacuum is begin filled," she said.

"Funders are desperate for affirmative action programmes and this is not something that just happens, people have to plan for it.

"Many argue that they can either be professional or have affirmative action."

She said there were people in NGOs who want to make a difference.

"Many at top level don't want to touch government which they see as an under-resourced nightmare.

"It is much easier to be a watchdog than a civil servant.

"This could sharpen the problem of white-led NGOs and create conflict. People will perceive the watchdog organisation as racist which are opposed to the black-led government."

The consultant said many senior people in organisations assumed in the past that they would naturally form part of the new government but are rapidly changing their tune.

"Civics are a case in point. They are no longer local governments in waiting. The issues are not so simple any more. People are beginning to realise that local interests will conflict with national interest in the future."

Reprinted from South, February 11-15, 1994.

South is published by SOUTH Press Services (PTY) Ltd. Contact: SOUTH Newspaper, 76 Darling Street, Cape Town 8001. Tel: 021-462-2012. Fax: 021-461-5407.


LOAD-DATE: February 28, 1994


LANGUAGE: English

60 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 15, 1994 / February 28, 1994


"WE WANT TO SEE RESULTS"; Part 1 of Series


BYLINE: Rehana Rossouw


LENGTH: 1920 words


 

SOUTH, February 4-8, 1994

Non-governmental organisations (NGOs) tend to be much too dependent on external funds, funding organisations complain.

Many of them are also out of step with the new strategy of development work being promoted by funding agencies.

The government is setting up various bodies and structures to look into and deal with development. The business sector is investigating ways of radically widening its corporate social responsibility programmes to take account of development issues. But NGOs are still convinced they deserve support on the basis of "anti-apartheid" work. 

Within the democratic movement there are few people with the necessary skills and experience related to public and development management.

For the first time, funders are dictating the terms to organisations in South Africa, sometimes openly scathing of their ability to produce the goods the funds are earmarked for.

"We look at the process -- any project must be sellable and rooted in the community., They must have discussed it and be prepared to participate in it," explained Kagiso Trust director Mr. Eric Molobi.

Kagiso expects professional planning and reporting from the projects they fund today.

Molobi said the people complaining about this are those who ;used to get money very easily without necessarily reporting on how it was spent.

Many organisations complain that funders expect them to quantify and they are not able to do so. But the funders know exactly how to do this.

Kagiso conducted an exercise with literacy groups. They took the amount of money they got a year and divided it with the number of people they reached.

They found literacy groups spent more a head than the first year fees of a university student.

"And when we ask where are the people you trained, what are they doing with their skills, they can't supply the information," Molobi complained.

"We are no longer only doing financial audits, we are conducting performance audits as well, For the amount of Rands a project gets, they must be able to show how many people they have reached. "When we tell people we can no longer fund them because they aren't doing well enough, they get angry, we are labelled bureaucrats and accused of being co-opted by mainstream organisations.

"But these people forget one thing: when they send us their proposals, it is ratified by our board. We are accountable to our donors, in turn, and they keep reminding us that we are receiving taxpayers' money and they need proper reports.

"I am caught in-between. If I satisfy the old activist mentality then I am going to sacrifice my career and Kagiso will not be able to continue as a development agency. A number of proposals we receive are rubbish in development terms."

Mr. David Bonbright, executive director of the Development Resources Centre, said he believed the challenge for NGOs was to maintain their voluntary character while becoming increasingly effective in their work.

"They must avoid becoming aid bureaucracies while commanding greater resources and becoming more effective institutional players alongside other key actors such as government and companies," Bonbright said.

"They must be professional who remain completely answerable to the amateurs they are meant to serve, while simultaneously satisfying their donor paymasters."

Bonbright said the task of managing an NGO was much more difficult than either public sector or for-profit management. They must resist the temptation to import uncritically management lessons from those other sectors to the non-profit framework.

While NGO management was challenging, effective donor support for NGOs was equally so, he said.

Some grant funds that made a project possible often breed a crippling dependency into the NGO.

"It takes great skill and experience for donors to provide funding in ways that actually increase the capacities of the NGO partners to thrive without then," Bonbright said.

"In South Africa I find little evidence that these two propositions are heeded seriously be either NGOs or donors. If they were, we would see greater thought and resources begin applied to strengthening institutional capacities among NGOs and donors alike."

He said NGOs should give more attention to basic organisational skills like bookkeeping, filing systems and planning.

They should also use existing resource bases like their staff, governing board, funders, NGO partners, professional advisers and volunteers.

"With respect to the especially fraught issue of financial resources, NGOs must become much more creative in diversifying their sources of funding to the widest possible spectrum, including institutional donors, individual citizens, community fundraising events, in-kind support from companies and, where appropriate, income generation," Bonbright said.

"My experience with ordinary NGOs indicates a growing awareness among them of the need to strengthen institutional capacities in theses ways. There is even the beginning of the emergence of specialist NGOs dedicated to building institutional capacity of other NGOs.

"Here donors have an important role to play. I would like to suggest that at least five percent of the donor's budget should be spent on activities specifically designed to improve the effectiveness of the remaining 95 percent."

Bonbright said he was dismayed by the almost complete lack of organised efforts to improve the effectiveness and professionalism of donor institutions in South Africa.

"I cannot say why this is so, although it may have something to do with the simple fact that professional philanthropy in South Africa, including corporate social investment, is a young profession," he said.

"We could organise learning and exchange opportunities that allow donors to compare their experiences with each other and with international experts.

"Secondly, we can organise similar learning and exchange opportunities, but for donors and NGOs together. Through such sessions they may gain deeper understanding of their respective decision-making processes, become generally more transparent to each other, and give greater meaning to the notion of a "partnership" between donors and NGOs.

"Thirdly, and most controversially, we could work towards an open public discourse about the ways and means of financing development in South Africa."

Bonbright said the historical secrecy around funding, while understandable in an undemocratic era of political repression of NGOs, made it almost impossible to build strong, independent development organisations.

"And while one can sympathise with the reluctance of donors and NGOs to expose themselves to public criticism and debate about the appropriateness and quality of their humanitarian efforts, the wider public interest is best served by the rigorous and broad accountability of the humanitarians."

Mr. Barry Smith, of Interfund, argues funders have not really changed their demands on NGOs. They had always required clear information from projects about their performance and results.

"What has changed is that there is a larger profile of donor organisations in South Africa and many now engage in regular discussion with their partners," Smith said.

"When we were based outside South Africa, this relationship was very constrained. Now we have all had a healthy dose of reality about some organisations and are accused of being bureaucratic."

A few years ago, the environment in South Africa was very unfriendly to this kind of relationship, Smith said.

Although Interfund required proper accounting for funds in the past, they made allowances for the constraints people worked under -- the harassment and the atmosphere in the country.

Now their partners have changed from crisis-driven projects and overt political work to full-time socio-economic development, and Interfund believes private sector standards of policy, initiative and the provision of services can be replicated by organisations in the NGO sector.

The rhetoric and goals of an orgnisation laid out in funding proposals has to translate into reality for the people who count -- the target group identified as the beneficiaries.

"We understand that it is very difficult for organisations to make this shift quickly, particularly those who are deprived of access to training resources -- the kind of things that are readily available to NGOs in countries which are less politically troubled, Smith said.

"So we are not only making demands. In a limited way, we are trying to gind ways of supporting the development of structures and skills in organisations to allow them to be more productive and analytical about what goals and end products are."

Reprinted from South, February 4-8, 1994

South is published by SOUTH Press Services (PTY) Ltd. Contact: SOUTH Newspaper, 76 Darling Street, Cape Town 8001. Tel: 021-462-2012. Fax: 021-461-5407.

Africa News


February 15, 1994 / February 28, 1994


MORE TIME PLEASE...


BYLINE: Adebayo Idowu


LENGTH: 680 words


 

TELL, The Weekly Newsmagazine, No. 9, February 28, 1994

The hopes of some Nigerians eager to debate the nation's political future as soon as possible may once again have been dashed for now. In a repeat of ex-president Ibrahim Babangida's usual way of reneging on his promise whilst in power, the proposed National Constitutional Conference supposedly scheduled to kick off in the first quarter of this year may have been postponed "tacitly" by the Abacha government, through the coordinating body.

Last week, the National Constitutional Conference Commission, NCCC, which forwarded its recommendation on modalities for the proposed conference gave the indication. The commission's decision not to recommend any specific date for the commencement of the talks has heightened fears that it may even eventually be aborted. 

However, government has consistently assured Nigerians that the talks will not be delayed. The commission rested its argument on some excuses among which are time to "fine tune all kinds of logistics" for the conference. Those logistics according to Walter Ofonagoro, the commission's publicity and organising committee chairman, include accommodation, feeding and transport arrangements for participants. But political watchers who have been sceptical of this regime's sincerity to organise a Sovereign National Conference, may have been thinking that the government's plan on the talks is a bundle of contradictions and a ruse if the inconsistency in this government's statements is anything to go by.

Segun Jegede, administrative secretary of the Committee for the

Defence of Human Rights, CDHR, during an interview with TELL said that: "IBB and Abacha's regimes are the same." "What the human rights organisation will do is to present the catalogue of Abacha's treacheries to the whole world," he said.

The NCCC according to reports included in their recommendation that 75 per cent of conferees will be elected on the basis of senatorial representation while the remaining 25 per cent will be selected based on professional and interest groups. Such groups are traditional rulers, labour, students and human rights activists. The NCCC was set up mid- January to work out modalities for the national conference aimed at solving the recurring issue of national questions and usher in an enduring democracy. Those national questions are revenue allocation, oil exploitation and minority problem among others. The commission, also recommended the use of the celebrated Option A4 used for the annulled June 12 presidential election.

Ordinarily, there has been speculation of late that the northern power-brokers are putting pressure on the government to drop the idea of the national conference because of the gear of losing grip on the country's leadership. But the trend of events coupled with the inconsistent policy statements of th government, may have begun to prove sceptics rights. This is equally possible on the suspicion that the government may tinker with the NCCC recommendations and flood the conference with its lackeys just like when IBB doctored the Assembly's recommendations and draft. Perhaps.

Reprinted from TELL, The Weekly Newsmagazine, February 28, 1994.

TELL is published by TELL Communications Limited. Contact: TELL Communications Ltd., Textile Labour House, 10 Acme Road, P.M.B. 21759, Ikeja, Nigeria. Tel:" 01-824723.


LOAD-DATE: February 28, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


62 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


February 15, 1994 / February 28, 1994


WEST AFRICAN OPERATION IN LIBERIA UNDER STRAIN


BYLINE: Reed Kramer


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 1600 words


 

AFRICA NEWS SERVICE, Lagos, Nigeria

With world attention focused on Bosnia, an international effort to end an equally destructive conflict in Africa is threatened with collapse. West African governments, which have mounted an unprecedented regional peacemaking effort in Liberia, are warning that they can no longer afford to maintain their 19,000-strong multilateral force without increased international help.

Nigeria and its African neighbors have spent an estimated half billion dollars on the Liberian operation, which is one of the largest peacekeeping efforts in the world and the only major one not run by the United Nations.

More than four years of fighting in Liberia have claimed at least 150,000 lives and displaced over two million people. The conflict has created a refugee crisis throughout West Africa, and fighting has spilled into neighboring countries, particularly Sierra Leone. Renewed skirmishes in recent weeks have inflicted additional casualties and sent 10,000 more Liberians fleeing for safety. 

Last month, the World Food Program issued an appeal for stepped-up relief to Liberia, saying "there is still a large and desperate need for emergency assistance." A situation report issued on Thursday by the Office of U.S. Foreign Disaster Assistance says continuation of the conflict "has increased susceptibility to disease, caused rates of malnutrition to rise precipitously, and decreased the capacity of the rural population to participate in heavy agricultural labor."

In recent meetings with two visiting leaders from neighboring states, the Nigerian head of state, General Sani Abacha, declared that the financially strapped countries of this region cannot continue to use up their "vital resources" in Liberia when each is facing so many pressing domestic needs. Nigeria has the largest contingent in the peace force that was sent to Liberia in 1990 by the 16-member Economic Community of West African States, known as Ecowas.

Ghana, another principal participant in the peace force, has served notice that its troops may be withdrawn from Liberia in a month unless prospects for a lasting settlement improve. Ecowas leaders are planning an emergency summit within the next few weeks to reassess their Liberian involvement.

The 1990 West African intervention successfully separated warring Liberian factions and ended wholesale killing in the capital, Monrovia. But periodic outbursts of fighting in the countryside have blocked attempts to reunite the nation and rebuild its devastated infrastructure. Continuing disagreements have delayed the peace process and raised the costs of both peacekeeping and humanitarian aid. The U.S. outlay alone on humanitarian aid since 1990 has now risen beyond $320 million.

A new round of intense negotiations earlier this month broke the latest impasse among the three principal Liberian factions -- the interim government in Monrovia headed by Amos Sawyer, the rebel movement known as the Patriotic Front led by Charles Taylor, and a militia of former government soldiers called Ulimo.

The parties have set March 7 as the beginning of a six-month transition leading to elections in September. On that day, disarmament is to begin and a new interim administration is to take charge of the government.

The agreement was announced a week after the first visit to Liberia by a senior Clinton administration official, Assistant Secretary of State George Moose, who warned that any additional delays would result in reduced U.S. support for the peace process.

In a concession to Taylor, whose relationship with the West Africans has been rocky since the start, the peacekeeping force has added troops from African countries outside the region. As a further confidence builder, a small United Nations observer mission has been created to monitor the cease-fire and the elections. Some 800 soldiers from Tanzania and a slightly larger number from Uganda have joined the peace keepers in recent weeks, and about 360 UN military observers currently are taking up positions throughout the country.

Last month, after a lengthy interagency debate, the Clinton administration agreed to provide $30.8 million to underwrite the deployment of the new troops, including $19.8 million for the a trust fund established by the United Nations to pay for the troops and for the disarmament and election efforts.

But a number of obstacles remain. The scheduled dispatch of troops from Zimbabwe has been delayed indefinitely by a disagreement with the UN over how much Zimbabwe should be paid to offset its costs.

The entire UN effort in Liberia is seriously underfunded, Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali said in a report to the Security Council last week. While the U.S. contribution has made possible the deployment of the new troops, he said, there is no money to pay stipends for these soldiers and no money to offset the financial burden West African governments have carried alone for more than three years.

The West Africans are "facing difficulties in their own logistical support" for their troops, and the peace effort is "taxing the budgets of the contributing countries," the secretary general said. A similar warning was issued by the Nigerian commander of the West African force, Major-General John Inienger. The troops, which are expected to carry out a major disarmament operation, are working without such vital equipment as communications gear, and much of what they are using is obsolete, Inienger said in Monrovia last week.

Each of the West African participants in the peacekeeping force faces major problems at home. Ghana, for example, is struggling with an unexpected humanitarian disaster in the north of the country where competition for land suddenly erupted early this month into serious ethnic fighting. The government has dispatched troops to stop the killing, which left more than 1000 people dead, and is mobilizing food and housing for some 20,000 people forced to flee their homes.

For the military government in Nigeria, which is trying to weather its own political storms, the country's role in the Ecowas peace effort is becoming increasingly controversial. General Abacha took power in November, ousting an unelected transitional government that was installed after President Ibrahim Babangida annulled the June 12 elections his military government had organized and overseen.

Although a close Babangida associate, Abacha has tried to distance himself from his unpopular predecessor by appointing a largely civilian cabinet, many of whom are former anti-government activists, and by tilting his economic policies in a populist direction. But he has been unable to stop Nigeria's plunge into its worst economic slump in years.

The political and economic crisis has made Liberia a sensitive issue in Nigeria, which has borne most of the cost of the peacekeeping operation. Prior to the establishment of the UN mission late last year, the only significant outside assistance for the West African effort was a $29 million U.S. contribution to Ecowas.

There are no official figures on what Nigeria has spent to pay the troops, maintain a small air force and operate various other facilities, including a radio transmitter in Monrovia. Most of the outlay is believed to have come from a portion of government oil revenue that has remained off the official books and thus uncounted by the international financial institutions which hold Nigeria's mounting $30 billion foreign debt.

One newspaper columnist, writing in the National Concord last week, referred to Liberia as Nigeria's "Vietnam" and said the "consequences" of the peace effort for the country's "wobbling national economy" are too great any longer to bear. Another prominent editorialist, the Guardian's Cecilia Anthony-Williams, called for a "free debate on Nigeria's military adventures" and said it was time for Nigerians to stop allowing "military bosses to shed the blood of our soldiers in Liberia."


LOAD-DATE: February 28, 1994


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


March 1, 1994 / March 14, 1994


CURRENCY EXCHANGE RATES


LENGTH: 2501 words


 

Maxwell Stamp PLC

Economic Consultants

London * Nairobi * Riyadh * Mauritius

The table gives selected currencies valued against the major international trading currencies. Rates quoted are the middle rates between buying and selling, but currencies are in most cases not freely traded. These rates have been compiled by Maxwell Stamp PLC for information only. Maxwell Stamp accepts no responsibility for any transaction undertaken on the basis of these figures. BUSINESS


LENGTH: 1374 words


 

The following procurement opportunities in Egypt are available to U.S. companies through the U.S. Agency for International Development.

*Laboratory Equipment and Chemicals. A.I.D. Geographic Code 000 (U.S. only). I.F.B.#: SCRI/14-94/ARE. BID OPENING DATE: MARCH 14, 1994. Purchasing Agent: Sugar Crops Research Institute, Write to Embassy of the Arab Republic of Egypt, 2232 Massachusetts Avenue, NW, Washington, DC 20008; Send $20.00 non-refundable fee to obtain a copy of the solicitation. 

*Pediatric Medical Equipment. A.I.D. Geographic Code 000 (U.S. only). I.F.B.#: DEMPU/15-94/ARE. BID OPENING DATE: MARCH 21, 1994. Purchasing Agent: Abo El -Reesh New Children's Hospital, Write to Embassy of the Arab Republic of Egypt, 2232 Massachusetts Avenue, NW, Washington, DC 20008; Send $20.00 non-refundable fee to obtain a copy of the solicitation.

*Computerized Tomography (CT Scanner). A.I.D. Geographic Code 000 (U.S. only). I.F.B.#: AU/16-94/ARE. BID OPENING DATE: MARCH 21, 1994. Purchasing Agent: Alexandria University, Write to Embassy of the Arab Republic of Egypt, 2232 Massachusetts Avenue, NW, Washington, DC 20008; Send $20.00 non-refundable fee to obtain a copy of the solicitation.

*Network Maintenance Tools. A.I.D. Geographic Code 000 (U.S. only). I.F.B.#: EEA/17-94/ARE. BID OPENING DATE: APRIL 5, 1994. Purchasing Agent: Egyptian Electricity Authority, Write to Embassy of the Arab Republic of Egypt, 2232 Massachusetts Avenue, NW, Washington, DC 20008; Send $20.00 non-refundable fee to obtain a copy of the solicitation.

*Catheter Room Equipment. A.I.D. Geographic Code 000 (U.S. only). I.F.B.#: TUH/18-94/ARE. BID OPENING DATE: APRIL 5, 1994. Purchasing Agent: Tanta University Hospital, Write to Embassy of the Arab Republic of Egypt, 2232 Massachusetts Avenue, NW, Washington, DC 20008; Send $20.00 non-refundable fee to obtain a copy of the solicitation.

Purchasing Agent: Egyptian Electricity Authority, Write to Embassy of the Arab Republic of Egypt, 2232 Massachusetts Avenue, NW, Washington, DC 20008; Send $20.00 non -refundable fee to obtain a copy of the solicitation.

Purchasing Agent: Menoufia University, Facility of Engineering; Write to Embassy of the Arab Republic of Egypt, 2232 Massachusetts Avenue, NW, Washington, DC 20008; Send $20.00 non-refundable fee to obtain a copy of the solicitation.

LANGUAGE: English
