65 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 1, 1994 / March 14, 1994


EDUCATION/TRAVEL


LENGTH: 3094 words


 

Education, Society and Learning in an African Context is a summer course in Zimbabwe from June 30 - August 7, 1994 sponsored by MSU's African Studies Center, Department of Teacher Education, and the Office of Overseas Study. For more information, contact: John Metzler at (517) 353-1700 or Anne Schneller at (517) 355-5522. Or write to the African Studies Center, 100 Center for International Studies and Programs, MSU, East Lansing, MI 48824-1035. E-mail: 21248JM@MSU.EDU.

The Africa Fund continues to offer full- and part-time internships in its New York office. Activities often include research, data-base maintenance, filing, and information distribution. Contact: Adrene Ifill, The Africa Fund, 198 Broadway, New York, NY 10038; phone: (212) 962-1210.

The African Development Foundation offers Gray Senior Fellowships to African Academics and development professionals who have demonstrated a commitment to grass-roots development. Contact: African Development Foundation, 1400 Eye Street, N.W., 10th Floor, Washington, DC 20005; phone: (202) 673-3916. 

 

The American Association of University Women Educational Foundation provides fellowships for graduate study in the U.S. to women who are not citizens or permanent residents of the U.S. Preference given to women demonstrating a prior commitment to improving the lives of women and girls, and applicants focusing their project on the advancement of women. Contact: AAUW Educational Foundation , 2401 Virginia Avenue, N.W., Washington, DC 20037.

The American University in Cairo is offering African Fellowships for two years of study toward an AUC Masters degree. Applicants from all disciplines are encouraged to apply. Contact: International Graduate Programs, Office of the Provost, American University in Cairo, P.O. Box 2511, 113 Kasr al Aini, Cairo, Egypt.

Boston University offers an opportunity to study in Niamey, Niger. Contact: Ned Quigley, Director, International Programs, Boston University, 232 Bay State Road, Boston, MA 02215; fax: (617) 353-5402.

The Center for Latin American Studies and the Center for African Studies invite junior and senior scholars to participate in an interdisciplinary program on Afro-American identity and cultural diversity in the Americas, including the Caribbean, Brazil, and the US , as well as areas of Africa. The program will enable visiting scholars to spend an year or a semester at the University of Florida to do research in this area. It will include studies of history, literature, religion, and popular culture. Each fellow will receive a maximum stipend of US$35,000 for the academic year, or half that for the semester. Applicants will be selected on a competitive basis related to their expertise and research in these areas. Candidates should submit a 100-word abstract, an essay of about 1,500 words detailing proposed research, a curriculum vitae, and two letters of recommendation. Send applications to Dr. Helen I. Safa, Center for Latin American Studies, University of Florida, P.O. Box 115530, Gainesville, FL 32611 -5530; phone: (904) 392-0375; fax: (904) 392-7682.

The Council for Development of Social Science Research in Africa (CODESRIA) has a Small Grants Program for Thesis Writing to fund M.A. and Ph.D. candidates who are in the process of completing their theses. The funds will cover expenses in a country where research is conducted, but they will not cover the cost of travel to that country. For more information contact: Dr. Cyrus Reed, Office of African Studies, American University in Cairo, P.O. Box 2511, 113 Kasr al Aini, Cairo, Egypt.

The International Foundation for Education and Self -Help is also recruiting teachers for its Teachers for Africa program designed to help improve education in Africa. This program sends educators to assist in African primary and secondary schools as well as African universities. Assignments are for one academic year. Seven years of teaching or administrative experience preferred. Must be U.S. citizens or permanent residents. IFESH is responsible for placement, orientation, round-trip transportation, insurance, and a living allowance while in Africa. DEADLINE: APRIL 4, 1994. Contact: IFESH, 5040 East Shea Boulevard, Suite 260, Phoenix, AZ 85254-4610; phone: (602) 443-1800; fax: (602) 443-1824.

The Modern Management Institute in Nairobi, Kenya offers a new home study method for learning Kiswahili, a language spoken in Kenya, Tanzania, Uganda, Malawi, Zambia, Zaire, Rwanda, Burundi, and the Sudan. The method includes a basic English/Kiswahili textbook for 24 lessons and audio cassettes to help with pronunciation. Contact: Geoffrey Njogu, Director of Studies, Modern Management Institute, P.O. Box 47390, Nairobi, Kenya; phone: (254.2) 33.17.02.

The Population-Environment Fellows Program, sponsored by U.S. AID and administered at the University of Michigan, sponsors Fellows for two-year appointments with overseas agencies. Fellows provide assistance and technical support for developing country institutions to foster a comprehensive approach to development. Fellows must hold a graduate degree in a relevant area and demonstrate expertise in both population and environment. Applications are reviewed on a rolling basis, but the sooner a completed application is received , the greater the availability of sites for which it can be considered. Inquiries and application requests may be obtained from: The Population -Environment Fellows Program, SPH II, Room M2240, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109-2029; phone: (313) 747-0222; fax: (313) 747-4947.

The University of Illinois-Egerton University Study Abroad Program allows undergraduates to spend eight weeks in Kenya this summer this summer. Participants will take courses at Egerton, tour various parts of the country,

and live with Kenyan families in brief homestays. Contact: Center for African Studies, 210 International Studies Building, 910 South Fifth Street, Champaign, IL 61820; phone: (217) 333-6335.

The Economic Development Institute of the World Bank announces the 1994 cycle of the Robert S. McNamara Fellowship Program which aims at producing the highest quality research results in the general area of economic development. The program also seeks to achieve wide geographical and cultural diversity among fellows. The 12-month fellowship does not support work toward an advanced degree, but innovate and imaginative post-graduate research in areas of economic development. Contact: Robert S. McNamara Fellowship Program, Room M -4029, World Bank Headquarters, 1818 H. St., N.W., Washington, DC 20433.

The Centre for Refugee Studies at York University in Toronto offers an eight -week summer course on refugee affairs. The program will provide an overview of refugee issues, plus an opportunity to explore current topics with international experts. Participation is limited to 50 practitioners from inside and outside government who work with refugees or on refugee affairs and have a degree equivalent experience. Course dates are June 22-29, 1994. Contact: Dr. Tom Clark, Summer Course Coordinator, Centre for Refugee Studies, York University, Suite 322, York Lanes, 4700 Keele Street, North York, ON Canada M3J 1P3; phone: (416) 736-5837; fax: (416) 736-5837.

The Los Angeles World Affairs Council 1994 Diplomatic Travel Program offers the following: "Untamed Africa - Kenya, Tanzania and Botswana". Trip will include Victoria Falls. From July 15 - August 8, 1994. Contact: Los Angeles World Arrais Council, Diplomatic Tour Department at (310) 652-4675.

The SSRC-MacArthur Foundation Committee on International Peace and Security announces a program of small grants in 1994 allowing scholars and students of international relations to visit major universities and research centers outside their home region. Grants are intended for junior scholars who seek exposure to debates and scholarship on the changing international system and issues of international peace and security. Applications should be completed and returned to the Council, postmarked no later than JULY 15, 1994. Contact: Social Science Research Council, Visiting Scholar Fellowship Program on International Peace and Security, 605 Third Avenue, 17th Floor, New York, NY 10158.

The Library of Congress Junior Fellows Program: African and Middle Eastern Division offers academic fellowships for juniors, seniors, and graduate students in a program designed to fit the interests of the fellows while serving the mission of the Library. Projects in the collection should be of interest in library science and African studies. Contact the Acting Chief, African and Middle Eastern Division, Library of Congress, Washington, DC 20540 or call the Junior Fellows Program Coordinator at (202) 707-4353.

University Research Expeditions Program at Berkeley organizes research expeditions in Africa. Upcoming expeditions include: The Palace of Savi (Benin); Traditional Music of East Africa (southern Uganda); and The View from Eritrea. No experience necessary. Scholarships are available for teachers and students. For more information and a free catalog, contact: University Research Expeditions Program Department D05, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720. Tel: (510) 642-6586.

Visions in Action offers one-year volunteer internships in urban areas of Kenya, Uganda, South Africa, Zimbabwe and Burkina Faso. Program areas include: development journalism, writing, project management, youth group organizing, community development, health care education, clinical assistance, women's and environmental issues, low-income housing, human rights, and scientific research. Interns are required to cover their costs. Total fees (including airfare) are about $5,500 per year. Interns receive a monthly stipend. Deadlines range from April 15 to October 15, depending on the country. For more information, contact: Visions in Action, 3637 Fulton Street NW, Washington, DC 20007. Tel: (202) 625-7403.

The Community Law Center in Durban, South Africa offers internship opportunities for law students and some undergraduates from outside South Africa. CLC is affiliated with the University of Natal, and places emphasis on assisting the rural areas of South Africa. CLC publishes a quarterly newsletter , Izindaba. Contact: The Community Law Center, Berea Center, 7th Floor, 247 Berea Road, Durban 4001, South Africa.

The Council on International Education Exchange has a new academic program at the University of Ghana, Legon. Direct inquiries to Ellen Bahr, Administrator, University Programs, at (212) 661-1414 ext. 1230. Application DEADLINE for the 1994 fall semester and 1994-95 acadeimc year program is APRIL 1, 1994. Scholarships available.

The Visiting Scholar Fellowhsip Program of the Social Science Research Council and the MacArthur Foundation Committee on International Peace and Security offers fellowships for young faculty in African institutions as well as journalists, public servants and lawyers to pursue innovative research at universities and major research centers outisde their home areas. Contact Visiting Scholar Fellowship, International Peace and Security, 605 Third Avenue , New York, NY 10158. Tel: (212) 661-0280. Fax: (212) 370-7896. DEADLINE: JULY 15, 1994.

University of Minnesota, Minnesota Studies in International Development (MSID) offers academic year programs of internships and field study including 5 months in Senegal or Kenya. Financial aid is available. Details are available at the Center or through: MSID, The Global Campus, University of Minnesota, 106-M Nicholson Hall, 216 Pillsbury Drive, SE, Minneapolis, MN 55455-0138. Tel: (612) 625-3379.

The Center for Global Education announces a semester-long program in Namibia designed to introduce students to the central issues facing Southern Africa. Course credit may be earned. Applications and brochures are available from Center for Global Education, Augsburg College, 2211 Riverside Avenue, Minneapolis, MN 55454. Tel: (612) 330-1159.

Business Immigration Law Today. a fundamental course on how to prepare applications & supporting documentation to obtain business-related work visas and an analysis of the Immigration Act of 1990, will be presented by the Federal Publications Inc. and Interpreter Releases, the leading immigration & nationality newspaper. April 11-12 in San Francisco, CA; April 25-26 in Washington, DC. For further information, contact: iss J. K. VanWycks, Federal Publications Inc., 1120 20th Street NW, Washington, DC 20036. Tel: (800) 922 -4330 or (202) 337-7000. Fax: (202) 775-9304.

The Knight International Press Fellowship Program will sponsor up to 25 fellowsfrom the US each year to work with host institutions and news organizations that are seeking outside assistance. Specific criteria for fellowship applicants include: Outstanding personal and progessional achievement in the journalistic arena or in any of the related technical, management and business aspects of a free press; a stong commitment to assist colleagues in other countries and a demonstrated ability to do so; a willingness to undertake challenging projects overseas for a period of one to nine months. Application DEADLINES are March 15, July 15 and November 15. Fellowships generally begin within four months after selection. To obtain an application packet, please send a faxed or mailed request to: The Center for Foreign Journalists, 11690-A Sunrise Valley Drive, Reston, VA 22091.


LOAD-DATE: March 14, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


66 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 1, 1994 / March 14, 1994


EMPLOYMENT


LENGTH: 5120 words


 

The American Friends of the AICFA seeks a PROJECT MANAGER in Somalia for primary health care. Duties include procurement and logistics; project setup; maintenance of property; liaison with donors, other non-governmental organizations and authorities. QUALIFICATIONS: Three or more years in a similar position, strong negotiations, communications and management skills; ability to work in a difficult environment; knowledge of primary health care issues. Send resume and cover letter to: AFAICF, 815 15th Street NW, Suite 832, Washington, DC 20005; fax: (202) 783-5247. 

 

Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations has an opening for a SENIOR ECONOMIST (Marketing) in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia. This is a fixed term, 3-year position. QUALIFICATIONS: University degree in agricultural economics, preferably with postgraduate specialization in marketing, or a related field (such as agro-economy). Ten years of increasingly responsible professional experience in an international organization, government, private sector or research institution in agro-economic development. (An M.S. or equivalent advanced postgraduate degree in agricultural economics may be substituted for one year of the required experience, a Ph.D. or equivalent degree for two years of the required experience). Working knowledge of English (level C) or French or limited knowledge (level B) of the other. DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES: Under the supervision of the Director, Joint ECA (UN Economic Commission for Africa)/FAO Agriculture Division and the technical guidance of the Agricultural Services Division, to plan and coordinate the work of the Agricultural Marketing Section (ECA), and specifically, to: conduct analyses of the food and agricultural marketing situation in the region, including; developments in production, consumption, price policy, trade, distribution and demand, taking account of the Lagos Plan of Action, the Regional Food Plan for Africa and other regional programmes. Contact: Executive Officer, LNOR, Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, 1001 22nd Street, N.W., Suite 300, Washington, DC 20437

Christian Children's Fund (CCF) is solciting resumes for nurses/nutritionists to be based in Luanda, Angola for a period of 6 months beginning on or about APRIL 1, 1994 to work on a grant funded project working to reduce the invidence of malnutrition in childre, Interested individuals should belicensed nurses/nutritionists. Selected individuals will be engaged under contract. CCF will provide a package to include a monthly salary, post-differential, medical insurance and R&R. Communla housing, meals and other appropriate services will be provided. Fluency in written an doral Portuguese or Spanish required. Interested individuals should submit resumes to: Christian Children's Fund, Inc., Richmond, VA, Attn: Manager, Human Resources. fax: (804) 756-2718.

American Refugee Committee has the following positions available:

In Somalia:

MATERNITY SERVICES COORDINATOR, based in Afmadou, to select and train MCH Center maternity services staff; establish policies and procedures for the NCH Center maternity services; supervise the delivery of maternal services including prenatal care, labor and delivery care, postpartum care. Qualifications: Certified Nurse midwife; experience in training and US supervision; strong primary health background. Six-month commitment, $1,500 a month.

TRADITIONAL BIRTH ATTENDANT COORDINATOR, based in Afmadou, to mobilize the communities to support and make use of the Traditional Birth Attendants; conduct training course to qualify participants to work as TBAs; and conduct supervisory visits to observe TBA participants. QUALIFICATIONS: RN or midwife with previous experience in a developing country; previous training experience. US$1,500 a month. Six month commitment.

COMPOUND MANAGER, based in Bardera, to act as liaison between ARC and other voluntary agencies; secure necessary supplies; coordinate ARC programs with those of other agencies; maintain close contact with Nairobi office. QUALIFICATIONS: previous experience as field coordinator or similar capacity in developing countries; strong communication skills; flexibility. US $1,200/mo. Minimum 6 month contract.

In Sudan:

MEDICAL DOCTOR to provide emergency relief to displaced persons in Kajo Keji County. RESPONSIBILITIES: set up emergency/acute care clinic and coordinate all in-patient and out-patient activities. REQUIREMENTS: MD with emergency/acute care experience in developing countries and proven success in implementing new programs in relief situations. 6 month commitment. $1,200/month.

NURSE to provide emergency relief/acute care to displaced persons; assist in setting up emergency/acute care clinic; and supervise local nursing staff. REQUIRES: RN with emergency/acute care experience in developing countries and proven success in implementing new programs in relief situations. 6 month commitment. $1,200/month.

HOME VISIT COORDINATOR to communicate with authorities to select health care workers; conduct an initial 1-month training course and provide continuing education for workers. QUALIFICATIONS: RN with primary health care background and training experience; previous experience in a developing country. 1 year commitment., $1,200/month.

The Center for International Development and Environment of the World Resources Institute seeks individual with experience in natural resources management, institutions, and/or natural resource and policy activities in Africa, particularly national plans and strategies for sustainable development. Africa experience and excellent language competence in French required. Will be responsible for the coordination and implementation of the Center's activities in sustainable development planning in Africa. Will coordinate the Natural Resource Management Policy Consultative Group for Africa, with priority on an on-going study of sustainable development planning in 8 African countries. Position includes field work, analytical report writing, some policy research, and preparing workplans and budgets. Send resume to: Africa Program, CIDE/WRI, 1709 New York Avenue NW, Suite 700, Washington, DC 20006.

OIC International seeks a SMALL ENTERPRISE MANAGEMENT/DEVELOPMENT AND APPROPRIATE TECHNOLOGY SPECIALIST to provide technical assistance and training in value-added transformation and raw produce with the purpose of creating employment and economic development opportunities for unemployed youths and disadvantaged communities in African and other countries. The person will identify cottage industry and appropriate technologies adaptable to the client countries; develop curricula to train related entrepreneurial and technical skills to develop and manage such businesses. REQUIREMENTS: First degree in engineering followed by an MBA or equivalent education in Business Management; experience in related development work, and working experience in Africa in particular, first hand experience managing business and/or in appropriate technology development; fluent in English and French; knowledge of Spanish is advantageous. Travel required. Send resume: President and CEO, OIC International, 240 W. Tulpehocken Street, Philadelphia, PA 19144.

The Center for Wildlife Management in Kenya seeks a WILDLIFE RESOURCE MANAGER for a permanent full-time position of Resident Faculty. Resident Faculty live on site, lecture in an interdisciplinary, non-traditional, field-based learning environment and oversee student-directed research projects. Send detailed letter explaining relevant skills and experience, CV, and three references to Kenya Wildlife Resource Manager Search, The School for Field Studies, 16 Broadway, Beverly, MA 01915; phone: (508) 927-7777; fax: (508) 927-5127.

Family Health International seeks a RESIDENT ADVISOR for Tanzania, to coordinate and manage implementation of an AIDS Control and Prevention Project and ensure that appropriate technical assistance is provided to programs and activities. The program will strongly emphasize institutional building of indigenous NGOs. Requires Master's or doctoral level degree in public health or related field and seven-plus years experience in management of large public health/international development programs. Prior work with PVO/NGOs highly desirable. To apply, send cover letter (with salary requirements) and resume to Linda Rodriguez, Family Health International, 2101 Wilson Blvd., Suite 700, Arlington, VA 22201.

FHI also seeks a PROGRAM OFFICER to provide liaison, program, and administrative support required for a productive and efficient collaboration between FHI and UNICEF's AIDS unit; to facilitate FHI's provision of technical assistance to UNICEF's AIDS unit, Technical Support groups, and specified country programs. Requires Master's degree in Public Health or social sciences or equivalent experience and three-plus years related work experience. Experience in working with UN system of USAID-funded activities desirable. Fluency in French and/or Spanish desirable. To apply, send cover letter (with salary requirements) and resume to Linda Rodriguez, Family Health International , 2101 Wilson Blvd., Suite 700, Arlington, VA 22201.

FHI also seeks a RESEARCH OFFICER to assist in designing and managing the Behavioral Research program of the new global AIDS Control and Prevention Project (AIDSCAP) and to provide expertise in the planning, implementation, and evaluation of the Project's behavioral research program. Requires PhD in one of the social sciences or comparable combination of education and experience with AIDS epidemic and considerable experience in designing and implementing behavioral science research projects in the developing world. Ability to travel international, fluency in French or Spanish is preferred. To apply, send cover letter (with salary requirements) and resume to Linda Rodriguez, Family Health International, 2101 Wilson Blvd., Suite 700, Arlington, VA 22201.

FHI also seeks a CHIEF IN AIDS CONTROL AND PREVENTION PROJECT to manage the Behavior Changes Communications component, focusing on increasing condom demand and STD treatment-seeking behaviors and reducing numbers of sexual partners. Requires PhD or MA and equivalent experience and five years experience in the design of behavior change communications programs. Fluency in French or Spanish desirable. To apply, send cover letter (with salary requirements) and resume to Linda Rodriguez, Family Health International, 2101 Wilson Blvd., Suite 700, Arlington, VA 22201.

The International Rescue Committee operates refugee relief programs in over 20 countries worldwide and is seeking a PROCUREMENT ASSISTANT. Procurement for these programs involves complex communications and a vast network of international suppliers. Items procured range from vehicles and medical supplies to textbooks and tents. Based in New York, under the supervision of the Procurement Officer, individual will: develop and maintain a database of suppliers and resources; provide clerical support; purchase goods and prepare for shipment to overseas programs; maintain relations and communications with IRC's suppliers and agents; liaise between field offices and suppliers; assure that donor requirements are met. REQUIREMENTS: Undergraduate degree in a related field, excellent computer skills including database, WP51, spreadsheet and Lotus, previous work experience, strong organizational skills, and a team player. Send cover letter, resume and 3 references to: IRC, Recruitment Office, 386 Park Avenue South, New York, NY 10016. Tel: (212) 679-0010. Fax: (212) 689 -3459.

The African American Studies program at the University of Wyoming has been endowed to develop courses in sub-Saharan African languages. As employment would be seasonal, relocation would not be necessary. The program would be responsible for all travel expenses, plus a salary. Requirements: All language instructors must be indigenous Africans and must have the minimum of a Bachelor's degree in any field. Send all resumes and letters of interest to: Niyi Coker Jr., PhD, Director of African American Studies, University of Wyoming, Laramie, WY 82071. Email: niyi@uwyo.edu.

Africare has an immediate opening for a population and family planning project manager. Project manager will be a counterpart to the manager of a local NGO implementing a family planning program funded by USAID and other donors. Candidates should possess: advanced degree with 5-10 years of professional experience in a health-related field; background in project management, especially in health-related development projects in Africa; demonstrated understanding of clinical training, health services delivery, marketing activities and HIS; excellent French; working knowledge of such computer programs as WordPerfect, Lotus 123, DBase 3, SPSS, etc. Send resume and salary history to: Ms. Carolyn Gullatt, Africare House, 440 R Street NW, Washington, DC 20001.

CARE seeks PROJECT COORDINATOR to manage all aspects of 2 agroforestry/forestry projects in rural NE Rwanda. S/he will live and work in the field, approximately 2 hours drive from the capital. Each project has 3 components: forestry, agrforestry and energy conservation. Main responsibilities include personnel management, budget control, procurement and inventory control, monitoring and evaluation of project progress towards goals, reporting, technical assistance to staff and counterparts, and maintain good relations with local counterparts and donors. QUALIFICATIONS: prefer graduate degree in agriculture or agroforestry. 3+ years relevant experience management or playing a key role in agricultural development projects, preferably with peasant farmers in Africa. Very good spoken and written French and English.

RTA MONITOR (Rwanda) to provide technical assistance and advice in the area of monitoring and evaluation to country offices in the East African region. QUALIFICATIONS: Masters degree in a development related field or equivalent experience; 5 years overseas work experience (preferably in East Africa) with an emphasis on monitoring and evaluation. Proven consulting skills essential. French, Arabic or Swahili desired.

CONSULTANT (Rwanda) to assess project accomplishments of stated objectives, assess sustainability of project interventions, assess the role and effectiveness of participating institutions and project relationships to these institutions, asses pronect management and use of funds/materials, recommend actions for Phase III, and designate tasks and project relationship to these institutions. QUALIFICATIONS: French and English competencies; project management experience in Africa; forest managment expertise; excellent writing skills; leadership qualities; coordination and facilitation skills; knowledge of agroforestry interventions. Exeperience with NGOs; understanding of community participation and organization, agrofrestry and agriculture extension systems.

PROJECT MANAGER (Mali) to have overall responsibility for the planning implementation, monitoring and evaluyation of the Timbuktu Rural Development (TRD) Project. Individual will work closely with national staff technicians, government authorities, the CARE-Mali country office, and NGO partners working in Timbuktu region. QUALIFICATIONS: 5+ yrs overseas experience managing a development program; 2+ yrs with CARE; university degree in agriculture, natural resources, social sciences, management or international relations; excellent French and English; strong team building skills; self-starter, full of initiative.

For CARE positions, send resume to: Jeanette Nance Frett, International Recruiter, CARE, 151 Ellis St., Atlanta, GA 30303. Fax: (404) 577-9418.

March 1, 1994 / March 14, 1994


VOLUNTEER OPPORTUNITIES


LENGTH: 1347 words


 

The Farmer-to-Farmer Volunteer Program, administered by Winrock International Institute for Agricultural Development and funded by the U.S. Agency for International Development, is currently recruiting agricultural specialists of varied backgrounds to provide technical assistance to female farmers in West Africa. The countries targeted to receive this assistance are Burkina Faso, Cote d'Ivoire, the Gambia and Senegal. Volunteers posted to these countries will work closely with local farmers, small business people, and host country organizations to share their expertise on agricultural topics including distribution and marketing, women cooperatives, fruit and vegetable preservation and storage, rice and cassava marketing, sesame production and marketing, aqua culture, curriculum development and cooperative management. Volunteer assignments range from three to six weeks and the ultimate goal of these assignments is to help host farmers improve family income and nutrition as well as to increase overall food production and distribution. The Farmer-to -Farmer Program pays for volunteer travel, meals and lodging. All travel logistics (i.e. visas, passports, medical exams) are arranged and paid for by Winrock International. The volunteer experts contribute their time and expertise. For additional information and a volunteer application form contact Tom Bauer, Farmer-to-Farmer Program, Rt. 3, Box 376, Morrison, AR 72110; phone (501) 727-5435, ext. 253; Internet: tomb@winrock.org. 

 

Health Volunteers Overseas has several openings for health care providers who wish to aid its programs in the following nations: TRANSKEI (one-month assignments; April-December 1994): Participants needed to teach anesthesia at Umtata General Hospital to physicians-in-training. Volunteers will also provide direct anesthesia care. Housing on hospital grounds is provided for the volunteer at no cost. Contact Dr. Kevin Speight, (919) 716-4498/(919) 454-3956 or Spence Campbell (704) 696-9930.

UGANDA (one-month assignments; May-December 1994): Volunteers participate in the only anesthesia training program in Uganda. Most of the teaching takes place in Kampala's Mulago Hospital. Housing provided at the guest house at Makerere University. Contact Dr. Harry Zutz, (908) 381-4200/(201) 378-3323.

UGANDA (one-month assignments; March-November 1994): Program trains medical student, physicians, prosthetists, orthotists and physical therapists to improve the treatment of amputees and disabled people injured as a result of civil strife. Surgeons may also conduct orthopedic clinics an operating sessions with Ugandan doctors in upcountry regional hospitals in Tororo/Mbale, Mbarara and Fort Portal. Physical therapist volunteers will be needed to help the Ugandan tutors to develop courses in the three year diploma course are Mulago Hospital. Volunteers need to have a minimum of two years of clinical experience and some educational experience. Advanced degrees and lecture experience are big plus, but are not mandatory. Prosthetists are also being sought to teach. For a nominal fee, housing will be provided at the newly renovated Mulago Guest House. Contact: Dr. David Denzel, (716) 434-2697 or Elizabeth Kay, PT, (708) 897-4814.

MALAWI (two-month assignments, one month considered; The School of Health Sciences in Lolongwe is the site for a program providing education support in the areas of diagnosing dental and oral pathoses, performing conservative dentistry, periodontics, uncomplicated dental extractions and preventive dentistry. This program is soliciting 3 volunteers a year with a one month hiatus between volunteers. Contact: Dr. Dick Nieusma, (402) 472-9846.

For a more detailed description of each site as well as copies of trip reports from previous volunteers, contact Health Volunteers Overseas, c/o Washington Station, P.O. Box 65157, Washington, DC 20035-5157; phone: (202) 296 -0928.

The American Medical Team for Africa (AMTA) promotes and executes educational exchange and medical training in African countries. The goal of the non-profit organization is to bring volunteer doctors, nurses and medical students together with donated supplies, and equipment to serve needs on the continent. Survey teams assess the most pressing needs in targeted countries, develop and publish training manuals in appropriate languages, hold workshops and refresher courses for doctors, nurses and specialists interested in maintenance of health care delivery systems in Africa; and distribute medical supplies and equipment donated by corporations, pharmaceutical companies, hospitals and doctors. The AMTA plans a second medical mission to Africa. For more information, contact Deman Rageh, Executive Director, The American Medical Team for Africa, 2245 Godby Road, Atlanta, GA 30349; phone (404) 766-8000; fax: (404) 767-5264.

Private Voluntary Organization in Rosslyn needs an experienced Agribusiness/Marketing Specialist to fill a 3-year Chief of Party position in Mali. The candidate must have at least 10 years of proven experience in the field of Agribusiness, Marketing, Credit and Procurement (preferably of fruits & vegetables). Must have related job experience in developing country with hands-on experience and an MBA. Strong training skills in the areas of agribusiness and marketing required. Fluency in French/English (FSI , S-3, R03) a must. Interested candidates must submit a resume, a certification of foreign language capability, and a standard AID bio-data form. Please mail original copies to: Regina Wynn, VITA, 5th floor, Arlington, VA 22209. Tel: (703) 276 -1800 or fax: (703) 2143-1865.

The World Wildlife Fund (WWF) offers paid and unpaid internships for a 12-week duration beginning in June and ending in August. Internships are designed for college and graduate students with an academic background or work experience in the following areas: biology, environmental or conservation science, economics, environmental quality, natural resources management, public lands and resources , zoology or other areas of study related to WWF's work. DEADLINE for applications is APRIL 1, 1994. Interested candidates should forward cover letter describing areas of special interest and indicating compensation requirement, resume, two referencewith telephone numbers, and a writing sample of 3-5 pages to World Wildlife Fund, Internship Program, Humand Resources Department 94IM, 1250 24th Street, NW, Washington, DC 20037.

Africa News


March 1, 1994 / March 14, 1994


MORE TIME PLEASE


BYLINE: Nabusayi L. Wamboka


SECTION: REVIEW


LENGTH: 880 words


 

THE MONITOR, February 22-25, 1994

More Time is a new, and thrilling AIDS movie. It is a story about teenage love-mesh. It casts a real life situation of teenagers plunging in to the mysteries of love and relationships at the golden age of 15 to 17.

More Time, made in Zimbabwe with a Zimbabwean cast and crew revolves around 15 year old Thandi who is as adventurous as her age can allow. Thandi is not a village belle, but she is certainly striking and is a good netballer. 

She has dimples and a gap in her upper teeth.

She is ripe for any man to dare make passes, but she is also flirting with womanhood and township beckons. Thandi joins a group of rowdy school girls who lure her into the life of booze and sex.

Two girls have a match-make for Thandi. And guess who it is. The sexy athletics hero, David, who is the envy of all the beauties at school. He is fondly referred to as "Mr. Magic" -- which is why he swept Thandi off her feet.

It is not surprising therefore that Thandi is involved in fights with other girls over David. She is so infatuated that the sight of any other girl near David makes her raving mad.

But she has one problem. Thandi's kid brother is a pain in her neck. He monitors her moves and reports on her to her parents. They have started noticing the change in her and when reports of her fights reach them, they are more than broken hearted and mad.

But David's looks are also his un-making. His first girl Pamela with whom he has a baby has got AIDS. She got it from a certain 'uncle' who used to give her rides in his car. Her child died a few months later and David highly suspects he has got it.

So when he falls and bleeds during one of the school competitions, he cautions Thandi who had run to help him not to touch his blood. This however does not stop him from running Thandi. He wants to have sex with her. Thandi's two friends are also pushing them together and one of them even takes her to a drug shop for condoms.

Thandi is ready for everything and starts meeting David at night. Everything changed when they left with her family for a visit to the village during the holidays.

Thandi sees an AIDS patient and her grandmother tells her about it, a thing that her parents had feared to tell her. She is more careful when she comes back to the city life. When her mother finally finds the condoms in her bedside drawer, she picks the courage to tell her daughter about AIDS and marriage. Thandi is now more knowledgeable about AIDS than ever before and when she next meets David she tells him bluntly, "David I want to live my life, I want more time."

Despite his pleas that they will use condoms, Thandi sticks to her funs and because David was in love, he promises not to force her into anything. She agrees to a date for a dance and David says he also needs more time to know her.

More Time is a classic AIDS movie that will go a long way in educating the youths and parents about the deadly disease. It is not just about the don'ts that parents keep pushing down the throats of their children without explanations. It is about the self-realisation and discovery of the truth after both the dos and don'ts have been put before you at the table.

If you've watched Consequences, you will certainly love More Time by the same producers. It is a 90 minutes movie which has been donated to the AIDS Information Centre in Uganda to help fight AIDS among the teenagers and Youth. The Director of World Learning Inc. (Uganda), Mr. William Salmond, says the movie will be shown at the National Theatre beginning February 28 and will run for four weeks. Special concessions will be given to students but the official fee will be Shs 1,100.

The movie is ideal for both children and adults and will make parents discuss the subject more freely and frankly with their children.

It is produced by the Media For Development Trust in Zimbabwe with support from National AIDS Control Programmes of Zimbabwe and Botswana, DANIDA, CIDA, SIDA and NORAD.

Reprinted from The Monitor.

The Monitor is published by The Monitor Publications, Ltd., P.O. Box 12141, Kampala Uganda. Tel: 23-69-39. Fax: 25-13-52.


LOAD-DATE: March 14, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


73 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 1, 1994 / March 14, 1994


MUSEVENI AND KONY, MAKE PEACE


BYLINE: Monitor Staff


SECTION: VIEWPOINTS


LENGTH: 707 words


 

THE MONITOR, February 25 - March 1, 1994

Was has broken out again in northern Uganda. Rebel leader Joseph Kony with his Lord's Resistance Army has elected to bring another round of deaths and great suffering to the people of Acholi.

Kony started fighting the NRM government way back in 1987. Late last year, he was reported to have renounced war as a means of solving problems. He followed this up by accepting to hold direct peace talks with government. Mrs. Betty Bigombe, Minister of State in the Prime Minister's Office and in charge of the Pacification of the North, made several trips to the forests to talk peace with the s-called Lord's Army. 

The whole country was happy with Betty's courageous efforts and Kony's positive attitude. Ugandans were all looking forward to the D-day of Kony's coming out of the bush. Indeed when President Yoweri Museveni temporarily moved his headquarters to Gulu three weeks ago, many people thought he had gone there to welcome Kony and his group and to re-assure him of government's firm commitment to peace.

That was not to be. There was a sharp turn of events about ten days ago. Like a bolt out of the blue came Museveni's shocking ultimatum to Kony. Negotiations had collapsed because the rebels reportedly wanted a further five to six months before they could finally come out of the bush.

Museveni could not take it. So he issued the ultimatum giving them only seven days, from February 12 to surrender or face the might of the NRA. Kony threw back the challenge immediately. He resumed the war on February 18, a day before the expiry of the ultimatum.

What is disturbing is why the negotiations failed at the last minute. All peace loving Ugandans would be interested to know from both parties, but particularly from Government, why the peace talks collapsed so suddenly. This country has had enough war.

It is disheartening to hear that while the talks were going on, Kony's army was allegedly receiving military hardware from the Sudanese government. It is alleged that their biggest consignment came from the arms the Sudanese army captured from the SPLA-Garang (the faction of the Sudan Peoples Liberation Army led by John Garang) in Tollit. We hope Kony has not let himself to be used by foreign forces to destroy his own country. That would be treason, not just rebellion against a government one does not like which could be legitimate.

In response to all this, NRA is said to have sent more troops to Acholi-land, armed to the teeth and ready for total war. It is a pity that some Acholi politicians are not particularly bothered by this sad development.

Even if war has broken out again, Mrs. Bigombe should not give up. Both sides still appreciate the good work she has done to bring back peace in the north. This is important, especially as the rebels single her out as one of the few Acholi politicians who are not warmongers and whom they can still talk to.

Museveni should still allow the Minister to maintain contacts with the rebels. The war will not solve the problem. It has failed before, for seven good years, and it is bound to fail again. The only; sensible route to take is one of peace talks. Both parties should follow the route of give and take in the true spirit of tolerance and brotherhood.

Reprinted from The Monitor.

The Monitor is published by The Monitor Publications, Ltd., P.O. Box 12141, Kampala Uganda. Tel: 23-69-39. Fax: 25-13-52.


LOAD-DATE: March 14, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


74 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 1, 1994 / March 14, 1994


THE RISE, FALL, RISE OF UGANDA?


BYLINE: Charles Onyango-Obbo


LENGTH: 1894 words


 

THE MONITOR, February 1-4, 1994

The campaign to restore the kingdoms which saw the coronation of King Ronnie Mutebi as the 36th Kabaka of Buganda last July 31 was a major departure in Ugandan politics.

For the first time in nearly 24 years, what would six years ago have been pooh poohed as a tribal demand, became a respectable national issue. It was as if the gods were punishing the NRM. The political philosophy of the NRM, among that of all past governments, is the one which views such demands as "primitive and backward."

Yet it was to be the government to whom they duty would fall to persuade the country that the restoration of kingdoms (as cultural institutions) was a positive and unifying thing (see "Uganda's politics in a July twist," Ear to the Ground, last Tuesday). 

The restoration and the drama which surrounded the Mutebi coronation partly made "tribal" demands by other communities respectable.

The changes this has wrought in the last six months have been tremendous. Many NRM people, instead of championing "revolution" of the masses (peasant s and workers) "against the IMF and its neo-colonialist policies" are the spokespeople for these "tribal demands." And they are not preaching class struggle in their campaigns to be elected to the Constituent Assembly; they are bribing voters with booze, and turning out with their "supporters" in convoys of a thousand bicycles decorated with branches like chiefs of old.

How did all this come to pass, and is it good or bad?

In 1990, the Dag Hamarskjold Foundation organised a conference on governance at the Mweya Safari Lodge in Kasese District. The conference brought together some of Africa's leading social and political science scholars, and political practitioners -- like Kenyan politician Martin Shikuku.

President Yoweri Museveni was invited as a speaker to one of their sessions. Museveni repeated his now familiar criticism of parties. That in Africa they are not formed on a "scientific" basis; that political parties were and are organised around classes in the western world; classes which cut across tribe, religion and sex. (By the way this is not exactly true, and anyone who has read Seymour Lipset and Stein Rokkan's wonderful study of party systems and voter alignments know that too well.) Anyway, these parties supposedly unite people around broad interests.

Museveni at Mweya

Museveni argued that African, and for that matter Ugandan, politics had an inherent tendency towards tribalism. This because society is still "backward" (classes have not yet emerged) so parties are basically organised around tribe and religion. That they divide the people, and have been the cause of the turmoil of the last many years. Therefore, the NRMs' broadbased arrangement is superior in "backward societies where there are no classes" because it does not exclude one on the basis of one's tribe or religion.

This case was made partly to justify the NRM's suspension of open political parties activities.

Most of the chaps at the seminar were significant people in their own, and not being employees of Museveni's government, did not have to lick his boots. They told him frankly that there was merit in the NRM "no-party" or movement system, but that the one thing it had not solved was the question of tribalism.

They said if there was an inherent tendency toward tribalism....there was no reason why a movement cannot be tribalistic. That a movement would easily turn into rule by one tribe. The tribes who are NOT represented in its structures, would be very frustrated if because of the ban on non-movement politics, they had no alternative organisation where to make their demands.

Next week we shall revisit some aspects of this line. Nearly four years down the road, the scholars look like they are winning the bet. The NRM's broadbased politics has shown that it is very good at buying time for the wounds in a country which has been in civil war to heal. It was tailor made for a transition/interim period.

NRM's poor show

But it has done poorly as a means for resolving the conflicting interests of the various nationalities (tribes) and interest groups. This is partly because movement politics was based on the principle of suppression of certain political demands. If not voluntary suppression (sacrifice) through a gentleman's agreement, then through dictatorial law.

To use the popular jargon. It allowed for the rest of the people to look on peacefully and not disrupt as a few (NRM) people were eating. But it has failed to offer ways how those who are at the table eating can leave for the onlookers to take their place, while the first eaters become onlookers too.

For the NRM group to leave the table for the others would not have been necessary really, if the group had found a way of adding more chairs at the table for everyone to crowd around for the dinner. But they failed.

That is where the NRM got stuck in the mud. Their campaign is now stuck at the level of arguing that since everyone cannot fit at the table, the solution is not to leave it for those who have not eaten, but to allow those who have been eating to sit at it longer.

Buganda, was the first to find a quick way out of it. Like the recent meeting of the CA aspirants resolved, and the Deputy Katikiro Joseph Ssemogerere has hinted, they have said "Okay, we will support the movement system for five more years, but give us our own police force, give our king some power, etc."

In so doing, Buganda is paying the NRM government back in its own currency. When the NRM gave them back a cultural king without powers, it gave them food without salt. In promising to support the NRM's scheme for another five years of the movement system, in exchange for "Buganda's package", the impression one gets is that the NRM is not interested in what happens fifteen years to come (a long-term and definite constitution order), but only in ruling for another five years.

Going by the dinner table scenario, Buganda has told the NRM it can continue eating but Buganda will take over the kitchen. In the north, from what people like Adolo Nekyon are saying, the message seems to be that; "Okay, continue eating, and we will not fight for the kitchen with Buganda, but will take over the garden."

From what one hears, some parts of the country like West Nile are saying; "We will leave the NRM at the table, Buganda in the kitchen, the north in the garden, but we will take away all the seeds. The East has asked to take the hoes."

Dividing "Things"

If the NRM had proposed how to increase the size of the table and how to add chairs to it, the debating points would have been different. But because it wants to continue sitting and eating at the table, it now has to negotiate with Buganda about allowing the good to be cooked and to come out of the kitchen, With the North about allowing the food to be harvested from the garden and brought to the kitchen. With West Nile not to roast the seeds but allow them to be planted. With the East about letting out the hoes for the gardens to be tilled.

This is why CA aspirants have gone very local. A national all-tribal agenda sounds almost nonsensical in this situation.

Because in many parts of the country what they people want is pretty much settled, there isn't much candidates can do about that. In Buganda for example, whether one is DP, UPC, UPM or CP does not matter much. I cannot see how one would not support most, if not all, of "Buganda's package."

As to who gets to be chosen depends on who makes the people feel good most. And in many parts of the country this means the candidates who pay the voters most money. Nothing most captures this than the reports that in many areas voter registration certificates are called "dollars."

The NRM and its candidates are in double jeopardy. For many years they thought the "correctness of (their) line" and the wonders that their rule has brought self-evident. Realising that no one will listen to or vote for a candidate who only; talks about the correctness of a line, NRM candidates have had to "reintroduce" themselves -- as individuals -- to the people, and bring their campaign down to earth.

That is why its the NRM heavies like First Deputy Premier Eriya Kategaya in Rwampara, Transport Minister Dr. Ruhakana Rugunda in Kabale, Minister of State for Defence Amama Mbabazi with his helicopter arrival in Kinkizi who had convoys of tens of cars and hundreds of bicycles on their way to and from nomination. The stakes are higher for them.

Fortunately because they are the ones at the table, they have the food to pass around -- which looks good for their changes of winning at the polls. It waits to be seen whether it will be possible to fashion a clear "NRM agenda" on the CA floor.

If parties had been operational, I doubt that the regional and tribal agendas we are seeing would have come up. And this would have made it easier for the NRM to have its way.

Reprinted from The Monitor.

The Monitor is published by The Monitor Publications, Ltd., P.O. Box 12141, Kampala Uganda. Tel: 23-69-39. Fax: 25-13-52.


LOAD-DATE: March 14, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


75 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 1, 1994 / March 14, 1994


WE NEED A LITERATE POPULATION


BYLINE: Kebba Sallah


LENGTH: 920 words


 

DAILY OBSERVER, February 15, 1994

As a former president of the World Bank, Mr. Barber B. Conable, puts it:

"Investment in education contributes as much to economic progress as investment in roads, power plants, the tourist industry or any other physical capital; in fact, the economic returns to investment in education, as measured by productivity and income, are often higher."

This thesis can be demonstrated in down-to-earth ways in The Gambia. Many of our drivers are illiterate. They cannot read road signs and are ignorant of the principles of the internal combustion engine. The result is poor driving, bad road manners and misuse of cars and lorries. Although wages paid to our construction workers and labourers are some of the lowest in the world, the cost of their labour, increased by their low productivity, is relatively very high. 

Our largely illiterate farmers make a hard living by primitive methods. With about 75% of our population employed in farming, this industry adds only about 48% to our gross national product. In short, the social costs of our illiteracy are high.

The personal and private costs of illiteracy are high, also. This has been demonstrated clearly; in the case of girls and women. Women are the first educators of the nation's children. There is close positive correlation between the education of the mother and the health, nutritional status and life chances of her children and of her family as a whole.

In short, the progress of our nation in the complex modern world largely depends on our improving dramatically our literacy rate. Literacy might not be the sole factor, but it is definitely a major factor, in making progress.

The overall illiteracy statistics conceal serious inequalities in our society. This social handicap is not evenly distributed. There are great geographical disparities in its prevalence. Banjul and the Greater Banjul area have the highest number of literates.

There is also disparity between men and women, and between urban and rural dwellers, with many more literate men than women, and proportionately more town dwellers literate than villagers. And, of course, illiteracy being one of the syndromes of poverty, it follows that the lower socio-economic classes in this country are overwhelmingly illiterate. Divisions like this in any society are clearly unjust. One important task of our Government, therefore, is to find ways to expand the provision for education, especially basic education, and make it accessible to those who for historical, cultural and economic reasons are now deprived of it.

Implications of Introducing Basic Education

Such a programme needs heavy investment. It may be difficult for Government to find money from internal resources for any meaningful quantitative and qualitative improvement of our educational system. As a result, Government needs to secure external aid or grants to serve this purpose.

Another problem is the recruiting and retraining of the army of qualified teachers needed for these reforms. For a long time now we have had over 60% of our primary school teachers unqualified and untrained. Those of us who are in grassroots contact with schools know that "unqualified and untrained" in this context includes a great number of teachers who often barely keep one page ahead of the class they teach. Nowadays, Gambia College cannot attract entrants in sufficient numbers for their teacher-training courses. At high school level, there are more teachers leaving the school classroom, especially those in key subjects like sciences and mathematics, than there are graduates willing to go to the classroom.

Other problems are curricula that tend to alienate the child from his environment, and do not help him very much to fit into the world of work, leading to the prevalent attitude that schooling is not very beneficial to someone who wants to make his way successfully in an aggressive, materialistic world.

And of course, especially for non-formal and adult education, the use of English, which though the official language is foreign and difficult, does not make things easy for the educational planner and teacher.

Reprinted from the Daily Observer.

The Daily Observer is published by The Observer Company (Gambia) Ltd., New Town-Sait Matty Junction, Bakau, P.M.B. 131, Banjul, The Gambia. Tel: (220) 496608, 496877, 496878. Fax: (220) 496878.


LOAD-DATE: March 14, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


76 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 1, 1994 / March 14, 1994


HOW CAN WE COMBAT MALNUTRITION?


BYLINE: Abdou Karim Sanneh


LENGTH: 640 words


 

DAILY OBSERVER, February 14, 1994

Many households in urban and rural areas from season to season face food insecurity. According to United Nations office in Banjul, poverty is the root cause of food insecurity. Insufficient food and people suffering from dietary and cardiovascular diseases which are present in The Gambia are signs of malnutrition. 

In the Gambia, three pockets of malnutrition have been identified. Malnutrition in pregnant and breastfeeding women, malnutrition of infants and young children, and finally a food gap period of lean seasons are common in Africa. We need a positive approach to arresting the situation. I think a commitment to positive action to stem the tide of human suffering caused by hunger and malnutrition in The Gambia remains a challenge for us all today as in the past. There are cases of chronically undernourished people; people consuming too little food to meet minimal energy needs.

The people who are vulnerable to good insecurity are the "have-nots". What about the "haves"? They look strong and healthy! Food insecurity is higher in rural areas than the urban area. It is time to act! Freedom from hunger and malnutrition was recognised as a human rights with the adoption of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights in 1948. It was reaffirmed as recently as 1989 in the Convention of Rights of the Child. To these conventions, The Gambia is a signatory.

Hunger and malnutrition are no longer principally agricultural and health problems. Nutrition is a direct outcome and has an influence on national development. It belongs to the mainstream of economic and social development.

Deforestation in The Gambia is creating an "energy crisis" which has a direct bearing on nutrition and family care. The alarm rate of bush fires in The Gambia and the use of fire as the traditional method of land clearing is yearly reducing the fertility of our agroecology. Every year the burning of vegetation spreads the threat of desertification in the sahel regions. Modern agriculture like agroforestry, community forestry, fruit and vegetable farming have raised the hope that hunger would be eliminated with efficient management of land and water resources. Many farming practices like monoculture agriculture and shifting cultivation, which are unscientific, have resulted in environmental degradation. The productive potential of the land has consequently been reduced , creating insecurity in food production. Environmentally sound agriculture protects food security. Nutrition is a vital part of human ecology; the greatest impact of humanity on the environment stems from the need for food.

Government should support the efforts of the farming communities. These people in their struggle for immediate survival, are driven to practices that damage the environment and, in the process, undermine their own food security.

Reprinted from the Daily Observer.

The Daily Observer is published by The Observer Company (Gambia) Ltd., New Town-Sait Matty Junction, Bakau, P.M.B. 131, Banjul, The Gambia. Tel: (220) 496608, 496877, 496878. Fax: (220) 496878.


LOAD-DATE: March 14, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


77 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 1, 1994 / March 14, 1994


ZAIRE DIAMOND ENCLAVE A WORLD UNTO ITSELF


BYLINE: Cindy Shiner


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 1880 words


 

AFRICA NEWS SERVICE, Mbuji-Mayi, Zaire

A young man with a wry smile holds a stone up to the setting equatorial sun, the glint in his eye as strong as the one between his fingers. Two mud-stained boys wash the dirt away from their pebbles in a puddle marring one of Mbuji -Mayi's crumbling red roads.

Down the valley, the rusting Mobutu Sese Seko dredge, named after Zaire's president, clanks and sputters along to spit out the government's diamonds that have helped keep him in power for nearly 30 years.

If there is anywhere in this sprawling central African country that vividly reflects the dreams, wealth, corruption and self-sufficiency that have characterized Zaire for decades it is Mbuji-Mayi, a city of 1 million in East Kasai province that is as run-down as it is rich. There's no electricity, a few paved roads, no state hospitals and no telephones. Yet, about $15 million enters the city each week to feed the burgeoning diamond market, dealers say. 

"Since I've been here I've never seen a program by the government, neither from the (local) government or Kinshasa," says Kadiata Mukamba, president of the 32-year-old state-run diamond mining industry, known as Miba. "This city is constructed by the people themselves."

Indeed it is, much like the American Wild West had been. It's a city of traders, miners, heroes and villains, where diamonds and $100 bills cross tables on one side of the street and merchants sell chickens and peanuts on the other. Millionaires are made. Hearts and backs are broken. Marriages fail and families dissolve while young men work dusk-to-dawn picking through the earth looking for the big score. Students hand over school fees directly to their teachers who haven't been paid by the government for two years. Youngsters fill rain-gouged trenches in the roads with sandbags.

But the people's tolerance has its limits. Mbuji-Mayi has recently become a political symbol of resistance for pro-democracy advocates against the government's ineptitude and President Mobutu's prolonged rule, with people here expressing their dissatisfaction with him and his consorts where it hurts them most: the pocket.

Mbuji-Mayi's population and the entire regions of East and West Kasai have virtually created their won economy, based almost entirely on dollars and diamonds. "We are an enclave," says Mukamba.

They have refused to accept a new currency, the new zaire, introduced by the government of Prime Minister Faustin Birindwa -- widely labeled a Mobutu puppet -- last October as part of a disastrous effort at economic reform. One Western diplomat characterized the reform as something officials concocted as a "way of getting their hands into someone else's pocket."

Officials require exporters to receive payment from the Central Bank at the low official exchange rate, about 30 zaires to the dollar, while the government profits on the premium that the hard currency they deposit there brings on the black market where a dollar trades at 120 zaires. The loss suffered by exporters leads many to ignore legal channels altogether, breeding corruption and diminishing government revenue.

People in Mbuji-Mayi are ignoring the new currency, largely to demonstrate their support for Etienne Tshisekedi, a Kasaian, who Mobutu fired as prime minister last year. Many Zaireans consider Tshisekedi to be the only uncorruptible opponent to the president -- a view challenged by some Western diplomats and some of his former colleagues, including Birindwa. As part of their economic coup, people here have managed to keep their parallel exchange rate stable for four months. On the other hand, the capital, Kinshasa, is suffering the same economic woes that sent the inflation rate up to 8,000 percent last year -- one of the highest in the world.

The government's solution to Mbuji-Mayi's monetary rebellion was a standard one for Zaire. It sent in the troops, about 200 of them. They have tried to execute their mission by roughing up, and in some cases killing, money changers , seizing the old zaires and burning them in front of the Bank of Zaire.

It hasn't worked very well. Many of the poorly paid soldiers would rather keep the money for themselves. Two of Mobutu's sons have even ignored the decree to shun the money, visiting Mbuji-Mayi on business since the monetary reform went into effect, said one foreign diamond buyer, speaking on condition that he not be named.

Despite its wealth, Mbuji-Mayi isn't without its troubles. While Zaireans continue to strike it rich, along with British, Lebanese, Belgian and Israeli diamond dealers, Miba is near collapse.

Rats, snakes, and bats have infested the building where the diamonds are cleaned and sorted. Machinery constantly breaks down and spare parts are scarce. Safety precautions are often ignored. When about 50 illegal miners, or "clandestines" as they are known, were arrested on Miba's property recently they were jammed into a small, wet jail cell at the mine. A storm struck and knocked an electrical cable to the floor, instantly killing all of them.

Miba employs 6,400 people and is Zaire's second largest industry behind the state-run copper and cobalt producing plant, Gecamines, in southern Shaba province, whose production fell from about $500 million to a scant $20 million last year.

The costs to operate Miba far outweigh what it earns, Mukamba says. He says it can barely produce 400,000 karats per month, whereas it produced more than twice that much monthly only five years ago. It sells about $4 million in diamonds per month, compared to $5 million per week sold by Mbuji-Mayi's 30 or so private dealers.

Theft is also a big problem for the industry. Only 30 percent of the gem quality diamonds reach the end of the production line, said one well-placed employee.

"The current governor, he acquisitions what he wants of the merchandise," says Mukamba. "We buy a lot of fuel and food from Zambia, Zimbabwe or South Africa. These goods and fuel must pass by Shaba. Very often our products are stolen with the approval of the regional authorities. There are days and weeks when (the employees) don't work because of that."

And it doesn't stop there. Private dealers say the governor, Bashala Kantu wa Milandu, routinely takes 10 percent off the purchase of any diamond over 20 karats. In the past year alone, four stones over 100 karats have been found in the area.

Kantu wa Milandu vehemently denies any wrongdoing. "It is the people who try to corrupt us. It isn't the officials who are corrupt, above all, me."

Although 80 percent of the diamonds that are found in the region are industrial quality -- Zaire is the world's second largest producer of industrial diamonds behind Australia -- many high-quality large gemstones come from the Mbuji-Mayi area, says Greg Stephenson, the director of the De Beers Central Selling Organization's office in Mbuji-Mayi.

Zaireans are making a profit on that, and some of them are striking it rich. Last year, a small group of peasants sold a stone worth $8.5 million, nearly all of which they have already spent, Zairean dealers say.

Malika Ngandu is somewhat of a hero among the young miners who flock to Mbuji -Mayi. He is known around town as "the president," for his support of the local soccer team and his reputation as a wealthy and powerful man. Ngandu, 36, says he makes about $15,000 per month as a diamond buyer and seller. At least 100 people, he says, depend on his earnings, including his three wives and 15 children.

"If I had continued school I would have become jobless today," says Ngandu. "I have friends with whom I studied and they're on the street with frayed pants and they're out of work."

But the lure of wealth and the motivation simply to make a living in an area where there are few jobs and little infrastructure is damaging to more than just the land. It is eating away at the region's culture and traditions as well , aid workers and missionaries say.

Many children have left the villages for Mbuji-Mayi and have given up on education, which is traditionally received from a child's grandfather. In the melting pot of Mbuji-Mayi, people are losing touch with their native languages, mixing the French brought by the Belgian colonizers, and the traditional languages of Lingual from the west and the local Tshiluba tongue.

People have also discarded efforts at agriculture, farming almost entirely on a subsistence level in a region that missionaries say once produced corn for the entire country.

Even Zairean products are becoming more scarce, in part due to the lack of adequate roads to import goods. Many goods are brought in from abroad. The government has stopped direct flights from abroad to Mbuji-Mayi, requiring them to stop in Lubumbashi to the south, or Kinshasa, fearful that Kasains would no longer need the rest of the country for anything, raising the specter of secession. The southern Kasai region proclaimed itself the Independent Mining State of South Kasai in 1960, but it only lasted until 1961.

"I think the government is very wary of making the two Kasais (east and west) too independent," says Stephenson. "They've got all the wealth (here) already. The last thing they need is for Mbuji-Mayi to be completely self-sufficient."


LOAD-DATE: March 14, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


March 15, 1994 / March 28, 1994


BUSINESS


LENGTH: 1320 words


 

The following procurement opportunities in Egypt are available to U.S. companies through the U.S. Agency for International Development.

*Pediatric Medical Equipment. A.I.D. Geographic Code 000 (U.S. only). I.F.B.#: DEMPU/15-94/ARE. BID OPENING DATE: MARCH 21, 1994. Purchasing Agent: Abo El-Reesh New Children's Hospital, Write to Embassy of the Arab Republic of Egypt, 2232 Massachusetts Avenue, NW, Washington, DC 20008; Send $20.00 non-refundable fee to obtain a copy of the solicitation.

*Intensive Care Unit Medical Equipment. A.I.D. Geographic Code 000 (U.S. only). I.F.B.#: NHI/26-94/ARE. BID OPENING DATE: APRIL 19, 1994. Purchasing Agent: The National Heart Institute; Write to Embassy of the Arab Republic of Egypt, 2232 Massachusetts Avenue, NW, Washington, DC 20008; Send $20.00 non-refundable fee to obtain a copy of the solicitation.

Purchasing Agent: Menoufia University, Facility of Engineering; Write to Embassy of the Arab Republic of Egypt, 2232 Massachusetts Avenue, NW, Washington, DC 20008; Send $20.00 non-refundable fee to obtain a copy of the solicitation.
