Africa News


March 15, 1994 / March 28, 1994


EDUCATION/TRAVEL


LENGTH: 2974 words


 

Education, Society and Learning in an African Context is a summer course in Zimbabwe from June 30 - August 7, 1994 sponsored by MSU's African Studies Center, Department of Teacher Education, and the Office of Overseas Study. For more information, contact: John Metzler at (517) 353-1700 or Anne Schneller at (517) 355-5522. Or write to the African Studies Center, 100 Center for International Studies and Programs, MSU, East Lansing, MI 48824-1035. E-mail: 21248JM@MSU.EDU.

The Africa Fund continues to offer full- and part-time internships in its New York office. Activities often include research, data-base maintenance, filing, and information distribution. Contact: Adrene Ifill, The Africa Fund, 198 Broadway, New York, NY 10038; phone: (212) 962-1210.

The African Development Foundation offers Gray Senior Fellowships to African Academics and development professionals who have demonstrated a commitment to grass-roots development. Contact: African Development Foundation, 1400 Eye Street, N.W., 10th Floor, Washington, DC 20005; phone: (202) 673-3916. 

The American Association of University Women Educational Foundation provides fellowships for graduate study in the U.S. to women who are not citizens or permanent residents of the U.S. Preference given to women demonstrating a prior commitment to improving the lives of women and girls, and applicants focusing their project on the advancement of women. Contact: AAUW Educational Foundation, 2401 Virginia Avenue, N.W., Washington, DC 20037.

The American University in Cairo is offering African Fellowships for two years of study toward an AUC Masters degree. Applicants from all disciplines are encouraged to apply. Contact: International Graduate Programs, Office of the Provost, American University in Cairo, P.O. Box 2511, 113 Kasr al Aini, Cairo, Egypt.

Boston University offers an opportunity to study in Niamey, Niger. Contact: Ned Quigley, Director, International Programs, Boston University, 232 Bay State Road, Boston, MA 02215; fax: (617) 353-5402. The Center for Latin American Studies and the Center for African Studies invite junior and senior scholars to participate in an interdisciplinary program on Afro-American identity and cultural diversity in the Americas, including the Caribbean, Brazil, and the US, as well as areas of Africa. The program will enable visiting scholars to spend an year or a semester at the University of Florida to do research in this area. It will include studies of history, literature, religion, and popular culture. Each fellow will receive a maximum stipend of US$35,000 for the academic year, or half that for the semester. Applicants will be selected on a competitive basis related to their expertise and research in these areas. Candidates should submit a 100-word abstract, an essay of about 1,500 words detailing proposed research, a curriculum vitae, and two letters of recommendation. Send applications to Dr. Helen I. Safa, Center for Latin American Studies, University of Florida, P.O. Box 115530, Gainesville, FL 32611-5530; phone: (904) 392-0375; fax: (904) 392-7682.

The Council for Development of Social Science Research in Africa (CODESRIA) has a Small Grants Program for Thesis Writing to fund M.A. and Ph.D. candidates who are in the process of completing their theses. The funds will cover expenses in a country where research is conducted, but they will not cover the cost of travel to that country. For more information contact: Dr. Cyrus Reed, Office of African Studies, American University in Cairo, P.O. Box 2511, 113 Kasr al Aini, Cairo, Egypt.

The International Foundation for Education and Self-Help is also recruiting teachers for its Teachers for Africa program designed to help improve education in Africa. This program sends educators to assist in African primary and secondary schools as well as African universities. Assignments are for one academic year. Seven years of teaching or administrative experience preferred. Must be U.S. citizens or permanent residents. IFESH is responsible for placement, orientation, round-trip transportation, insurance, and a living allowance while in Africa. DEADLINE: APRIL 4, 1994. Contact: IFESH, 5040 East Shea Boulevard, Suite 260, Phoenix, AZ 85254-4610; phone: (602) 443-1800; fax: (602) 443-1824.

The Modern Management Institute in Nairobi, Kenya offers a new home study method for learning Kiswahili, a language spoken in Kenya, Tanzania, Uganda, Malawi, Zambia, Zaire, Rwanda, Burundi, and the Sudan. The method includes a basic English/Kiswahili textbook for 24 lessons and audio cassettes to help with pronunciation. Contact: Geoffrey Njogu, Director of Studies, Modern Management Institute, P.O. Box 47390, Nairobi, Kenya; phone: (254.2) 33.17.02.

The Population-Environment Fellows Program, sponsored by U.S. AID and administered at the University of Michigan, sponsors Fellows for two-year appointments with overseas agencies. Fellows provide assistance and technical support for developing country institutions to foster a comprehensive approach to development. Fellows must hold a graduate degree in a relevant area and demonstrate expertise in both population and environment. Applications are reviewed on a rolling basis, but the sooner a completed application is received, the greater the availability of sites for which it can be considered. Inquiries and application requests may be obtained from: The Population-Environment Fellows Program, SPH II, Room M2240, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109-2029; phone: (313) 747-0222; fax: (313) 747-4947.

The University of Illinois-Egerton University Study Abroad Program allows undergraduates to spend eight weeks in Kenya this summer this summer. Participants will take courses at Egerton, tour various parts of the country, and live with Kenyan families in brief homestays. Contact: Center for African Studies, 210 International Studies Building, 910 South Fifth Street, Champaign, IL 61820; phone: (217) 333-6335.

The Economic Development Institute of the World Bank announces the 1994 cycle of the Robert S. McNamara Fellowship Program which aims at producing the highest quality research results in the general area of economic development. The program also seeks to achieve wide geographical and cultural diversity among fellows. The 12-month fellowship does not support work toward an advanced degree, but innovate and imaginative post-graduate research in areas of economic development. Contact: Robert S. McNamara Fellowship Program, Room M-4029, World Bank Headquarters, 1818 H. St., N.W., Washington, DC 20433.

The Centre for Refugee Studies at York University in Toronto offers an eight-week summer course on refugee affairs. The program will provide an overview of refugee issues, plus an opportunity to explore current topics with international experts. Participation is limited to 50 practitioners from inside and outside government who work with refugees or on refugee affairs and have a degree equivalent experience. Course dates are June 22-29, 1994. Contact: Dr. Tom Clark, Summer Course Coordinator, Centre for Refugee Studies, York University, Suite 322, York Lanes, 4700 Keele Street, North York, ON Canada M3J 1P3; phone: (416) 736-5837; fax: (416) 736-5837.

The Los Angeles World Affairs Council 1994 Diplomatic Travel Program offers the following: "Untamed Africa - Kenya, Tanzania and Botswana". Trip will include Victoria Falls. From July 15 - August 8, 1994. Contact: Los Angeles World Arrais Council, Diplomatic Tour Department at (310) 652-4675.

The SSRC-MacArthur Foundation Committee on International Peace and Security announces a program of small grants in 1994 allowing scholars and students of international relations to visit major universities and research centers outside their home region. Grants are intended for junior scholars who seek exposure to debates and scholarship on the changing international system and issues of international peace and security. Applications should be completed and returned to the Council, postmarked no later than JULY 15, 1994. Contact: Social Science Research Council, Visiting Scholar Fellowship Program on International Peace and Security, 605 Third Avenue, 17th Floor, New York, NY 10158.

The Library of Congress Junior Fellows Program: African and Middle Eastern Division offers academic fellowships for juniors, seniors, and graduate students in a program designed to fit the interests of the fellows while serving the mission of the Library. Projects in the collection should be of interest in library science and African studies. Contact the Acting Chief, African and Middle Eastern Division, Library of Congress, Washington, DC 20540 or call the Junior Fellows Program Coordinator at (202) 707-4353.

University Research Expeditions Program at Berkeley organizes research expeditions in Africa. Upcoming expeditions include: The Palace of Savi (Benin); Traditional Music of East Africa (southern Uganda); and The View from Eritrea. No experience necessary. Scholarships are available for teachers and students. For more information and a free catalog, contact: University Research Expeditions Program Department D05, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720. Tel: (510) 642-6586. Visions in Action offers one-year volunteer internships in urban areas of Kenya, Uganda, South Africa, Zimbabwe and Burkina Faso. Program areas include: development journalism, writing, project management, youth group organizing, community development, health care education, clinical assistance, women's and environmental issues, low-income housing, human rights, and scientific research. Interns are required to cover their costs. Total fees (including airfare) are about $5,500 per year. Interns receive a monthly stipend. Deadlines range from April 15 to October 15, depending on the country. For more information, contact: Visions in Action, 3637 Fulton Street NW, Washington, DC 20007. Tel: (202) 625-7403.

The Community Law Center in Durban, South Africa offers internship opportunities for law students and some undergraduates from outside South Africa. CLC is affiliated with the University of Natal, and places emphasis on assisting the rural areas of South Africa. CLC publishes a quarterly newsletter, Izindaba. Contact: The Community Law Center, Berea Center, 7th Floor, 247 Berea Road, Durban 4001, South Africa.

The Council on International Education Exchange has a new academic program at the University of Ghana, Legon. Direct inquiries to Ellen Bahr, Administrator, University Programs, at (212) 661-1414 ext. 1230. Application DEADLINE for the 1994 fall semester and 1994-95 academic year program is APRIL 1, 1994. Scholarships available.

The Visiting Scholar Fellowship Program of the Social Science Research Council and the MacArthur Foundation Committee on International Peace and Security offers fellowships for young faculty in African institutions as well as journalists, public servants and lawyers to pursue innovative research at universities and major research centers outside their home areas. Contact Visiting Scholar Fellowship, International Peace and Security, 605 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10158. Tel: (212) 661-0280. Fax: (212) 370-7896. DEADLINE: JULY 15, 1994. University of Minnesota, Minnesota Studies in International Development (MSID) offers academic year programs of internships and field study including 5 months in Senegal or Kenya. Financial aid is available. Details are available at the Center or through: MSID, The Global Campus, University of Minnesota, 106-M Nicholson Hall, 216

Pillsbury Drive, SE, Minneapolis, MN 55455-0138. Tel: (612) 625-3379. The Center for Global Education announces a semester-long program in Namibia designed to introduce students to the central issues facing Southern Africa. Course credit may be earned. Applications and brochures are available from Center for Global Education, Augsburg College, 2211 Riverside Avenue, Minneapolis, MN 55454. Tel: (612) 330-1159.

Business Immigration Law Today. a fundamental course on how to prepare applications & supporting documentation to obtain business-related work visas and an analysis of the Immigration Act of 1990, will be presented by the Federal Publications Inc. and Interpreter Releases, the leading immigration & nationality newspaper. April 11-12 in San Francisco, CA; April 25-26 in Washington, DC. For further information, contact: Miss J. K. VanWycks, Federal Publications Inc., 1120 20th Street NW, Washington, DC 20036. Tel: (800) 922-4330 or (202) 337-7000. Fax: (202) 775-9304.

The Knight International Press Fellowship Program will sponsor up to 25 fellows from the US each year to work with host institutions and news organizations that are seeking outside assistance. Specific criteria for fellowship applicants include: Outstanding personal and professional achievement in the journalistic arena or in any of the related technical, management and business aspects of a free press; a strong commitment to assist colleagues in other countries and a demonstrated ability to do so; a willingness to undertake challenging projects overseas for a period of one to nine months. Application DEADLINES are March 15, July 15 and November 15. Fellowships generally begin within four months after selection. To obtain an application packet, please send a faxed or mailed request to: The Center for Foreign Journalists, 11690-A Sunrise Valley Drive, Reston, VA 22091.

A study tour of South Africa from June 29-July 16, 1994 will investigate South Africa following the April elections. This tour is sponsored by the Southern Africa Education Program at Stony Point Center in New York. There will be meetings with key actors in the new government, political parties, representatives of non-governmental organizations and rural development groups. George Hauser and William Palmer are the organizers and leaders of the tour. Participation is limited to 15 people. There is a small scholarship fund which they hope to increase. For more information contact: William Palmer, Southern Africa Education Program, Stony Point Center, 17 Crickettown Rd., Stony Point, NY 10980. Phone: (914) 786-5072 or (518) 398-6586.

The First Presbyterian Church in Ithaca, NY has created a mission fund to help in alleviating hunger in developing countries. The fund will provide supplemental financial support to an international graduate student at Cornell whose thesis deals with a hunger-related topic in his or her country. The student field support program is administered through the Director of International Agricultural Programs. Funds will be available beginning with the 1994 summer period. Applications should be received by MARCH 31, 1994. For application materials or further information, contact: Larry Zuidema, International Agricultural Program, Box 14 Kennedy Hall, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14853. Tel: (607) 255-3035.

A special edition of "Research in African Literature" will be devoted to African Cinema. Please submit entries dealing with African film or African film criticism to Kenneth W. Harrow, Dept. of English, Morrill Hall, Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI 48824-1036. DEADLINE for submissions is June 1, 1994.

A second volume of "Faces of Islam in African Literature" is going to appear. We are interested in papers that deal with Islam in African literature. Please send entries to Ken Harrow, Dept. of English, Morrill Hall, Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI 48824-1036 or to Rachid A. Hassani, Box 1257, Cambridge, MA 02238. DEADLINE for submissions is June 1, 1994.

EMPLOYMENT


LENGTH: 5494 words


 

Tiller's International offers a variety of workshops tailored to the needs of international rural innovators. Sessions feature hands-on activities, structured demonstrations, field trips and discussions. Workshops of particular interest include: Rural Development with Animal Power (May 24-28), Refining Animal Power Systems (June 20-July 29), and Low Cost Tools for Agriculture (August 16-20). A few scholarships are available for students of international development. Contact: Tiller's International, 5239 South 24th Street, Kalamazoo, MI 49008. Phone (616) 385-3233. Fax: (616) 385-2329. 

The American Friends Service Committee has two openings in its Human Resources Dept. and on in the Office of the Executive Director. HUMAN RESOURCES GENERALIST will handle recruitment and staffing, benefits counseling, staff relations, salary administration, training and affirmative action monitoring for an assigned area. Requires BA/BS, 5 years experience in Human Resources, and a demonstrated knowledge of all aspects of HRM. International recruitment experience preferred. ADMINISTRATIVE ASSISTANT will provide secretarial and administrative support for the Human Resources staff, including scheduling interviews and training activities, preparing reports, maintaining databases and files and other administrative tasks. Requires: high school diploma or equivalent, 3 years secretarial/administrative experience, proficiency on Word, Lotus or Quattro Pro. EXECUTIVE ASSISTANT TO THE EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR will assist the Executive Director in maintaining a wide range of relationships, managing the daily activities of the office, preparing and monitoring budgets, supporting the work of the Board and Corporation and providing general administrative support to the Executive Director. Requires: BA/BS or equivalent, 5-10 years administrative experience, proficiency in Word, Lotus or Quattro Pro, demonstrated ability to interact effectively at all levels of the organization and ability to handle multiple projects simultaneously.

TechnoServe, Inc. seeks Program Officer/Africa for its Norwalk, CT HQ. Responsibilities include: assisting the Regional Director with project management and evaluation, financial management, training and proposal development. Candidate should have 2+ years overseas experience in Africa in business and/or agricultural development, 3 years additional experience in Business Administration, Economics, Agriculture or relevant field experience. Excellent written and oral communication skills and French proficiency. Willingness to travel internationally (25-30%). Send resume and salary history to: Terri Scofield, Manager of Human Resources, TechnoServe, 49 Day Street, Norwalk, CT 06854 or Fax: (203) 838-6717.

Development/environment non-profit seeks a Communications Officer who will assist with evaluation of organizational communications needs' outreach to the federal government, Congress, the media, the international development community, and the public; preparation and dissemination of promotional materials. Candidates must have excellent writing skills and solid experience with Windows computer applications. Submit resume and writing samples to: Communications Director, ATI, 1828 L Street NW, Suite 1000, Washington, DC 20036.

The US Committee for Refugees seeks an energetic, professional person for #2 position in small development (fund-raising) office. Job encompasses direct mail, foundation fund-raising, and many other efforts. 2-3 years of fund-raising experience and computer skills required. Research, organization, writing and interpersonal skills essential. Send resumes by APRIL 6 to Development Associate Search, US Committee for Refugees, 1717 Massachusetts Avenue, NW, Suite 701, Washington, DC 20036.

International Services of the American Red Cross seeks an associate to coordinate and implement marketing plans for the department's programs and services. Duties include developing an outreach strategy to link the division's activities with private and governmental funding agencies, corporations, chapters and the general public for fund-raising and enhancing public awareness. Bachelors degree in marketing, social marketing, sociology or fund-raising is required. Must have strong fund-raising skills and a proven track record in identifying and capturing corporate and private resources. Send resume to Human Resources Administration, American Red Cross, 431 18th Street, NW, Washington, DC 20006, Attn: MR-Y188. DEADLINE: MARCH 31, 1994.

International Action Against Hunger seeks the following:

HEALTH COORDINATOR, Northeast Somalia: Individual to be responsible for developing a health education curriculum to be used in PHC facilities and communities in northeast Somalia, training in use of the curriculum and oversight of its implementation. Works closely with PHC and community organization teams. Requires MPH or related degree, demonstrated skill in development of community-responsive curricula, commitment to participatory techniques, 2+ years experience.

COMMUNITY ORGANIZER, Northeast Somalia: Individual to be responsible for facilitating the support by local community of community-based health systems; assist in identifying those needs; facilitate activities with local NGOs. Requires relevant degree with 2+ years overseas community-based experience. Strong communications skills and ability to live and thrive in a challenging environment are necessary.

HEALTH EDUCATION SPECIALIST, Northeast Somalia: Individual to be responsible for developing a health education curriculum to be used in PHC facilities and communities in northeast Somalia, training in use of the curriculum and oversight of its implementation. Works closely with PHC and community organization teams. Requires MPH or related degree, demonstrated skill in development of community-responsive curricula, commitment to participatory techniques, 2+ years experience. Assignments generally for 6-12 months, with opportunity for renewal. Competitive compensation package. Mail/fax cover letter, resume and salary requirements to: AICF/USA, 815 15th Street NW, Suite 832, Washington, DC 20005. Fax: (202) 783-5247.

Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations has an opening for a SENIOR ECONOMIST (Marketing) in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia. This is a fixed term, 3-year position. QUALIFICATIONS: University degree in agricultural economics, preferably with postgraduate specialization in marketing, or a related field (such as agro-economy). Ten years of increasingly responsible professional experience in an international organization, government, private sector or research institution in agro-economic development. (An M.S. or equivalent advanced postgraduate degree in agricultural economics may be substituted for one year of the required experience, a Ph.D. or equivalent degree for two years of the required experience). Working knowledge of English (level C) or French or limited knowledge (level B) of the other. DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES: Under the supervision of the Director, Joint ECA (UN Economic Commission for Africa)/FAO Agriculture Division and the technical guidance of the Agricultural Services Division, to plan and coordinate the work of the Agricultural Marketing Section (ECA), and specifically, to: conduct analyses of the food and agricultural marketing situation in the region, including; developments in production, consumption, price policy, trade, distribution and demand, taking account of the Lagos Plan of Action, the Regional Food Plan for Africa and other regional programmes. Contact: Executive Officer, LNOR, Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, 1001 22nd Street, N.W., Suite 300, Washington, DC 20437

Christian Children's Fund (CCF) is soliciting resumes for nurses/nutritionists to be based in Luanda, Angola for a period of 6 months beginning on or about APRIL 1, 1994 to work on a grant funded project working to reduce the incidence of malnutrition in children, Interested individuals should be licensed nurses/nutritionists. Selected individuals will be engaged under contract. CCF will provide a package to include a monthly salary, post-differential, medical insurance and R&R. Communal housing, meals and other appropriate services will be provided. Fluency in written and oral Portuguese or Spanish required. Interested individuals should submit resumes to: Christian Children's Fund, Inc., Richmond, VA, Attn: Manager, Human Resources. fax: (804) 756-2718.

American Refugee Committee has the following positions available:

In Mozambique:

PUBLIC HEALTH PROFESSIONAL, to develop health program in coordination with the water and sanitation projects. Rural setting. Requires: MPH or RN, NP, PA, MD with strong public health background; proven success in design and implementation of new public health programs in developing countries; Portuguese, Spanish or French fluency. 1 year contract. Immediate opening. $1,500 a month.

WATER/SANITATION ENGINEER to monitor water points to assess water quantity and quality; provide logistical support; assist in rehabilitation and construction of wells. Qualifications: sanitation/ civil/environmental engineering degree; experience working overseas; experience with water protection and sanitation projects; construction and supervisory experience preferred; Portuguese, French or Spanish fluency. $1,500/month.

In Sudan:

MEDICAL DOCTOR to provide emergency relief to displaced persons in Kajo Keji County. RESPONSIBILITIES: set up emergency/acute care clinic and coordinate all in-patient and out-patient activities. REQUIREMENTS: MD with emergency/acute care experience in developing countries and proven success in implementing new programs in relief situations. 6 month commitment. $1,200/month.

TRADITIONAL BIRTH COORDINATOR to mobilize the communities to support and make use of the Traditional Birth Attendants; conduct training course to qualify participants to work as TBAs; and conduct supervisory visits to observe TBA participants. QUALIFICATIONS: RN or midwife with previous experience in a developing country; previous training experience. 6 month commitment., $1,200/month.

The Center for International Development and Environment of the World Resources Institute seeks individual with experience in natural resources management, institutions, and/or natural resource and policy activities in Africa, particularly national plans and strategies for sustainable development. Africa experience and excellent language competence in French required. Will be responsible for the coordination and implementation of the Center's activities in sustainable development planning in Africa. Will coordinate the Natural Resource Management Policy Consultative Group for Africa, with priority on an on-going study of sustainable development planning in 8 African countries. Position includes field work, analytical report writing, some policy research, and preparing workplans and budgets. Send resume to: Africa Program, CIDE/WRI, 1709 New York Avenue NW, Suite 700, Washington, DC 20006.

OIC International seeks a SMALL ENTERPRISE MANAGEMENT/DEVELOPMENT AND APPROPRIATE TECHNOLOGY SPECIALIST to provide technical assistance and training in value-added transformation and raw produce with the purpose of creating employment and economic development opportunities for unemployed youths and disadvantaged communities in African and other countries. The person will identify cottage industry and appropriate technologies adaptable to the client countries; develop curricula to train related entrepreneurial and technical skills to develop and manage such businesses. REQUIREMENTS: First degree in engineering followed by an MBA or equivalent education in Business Management; experience in related development work, and working experience in Africa in particular, first hand experience managing business and/or in appropriate technology development; fluent in English and French; knowledge of Spanish is advantageous. Travel required. Send resume: President and CEO, OIC International, 240 W. Tulpehocken Street, Philadelphia, PA 19144.

The Center for Wildlife Management in Kenya seeks a WILDLIFE RESOURCE MANAGER for a permanent full-time position of Resident Faculty. Resident Faculty live on site, lecture in an interdisciplinary, non-traditional, field-based learning environment and oversee student-directed research projects. Send detailed letter explaining relevant skills and experience, CV, and three references to Kenya Wildlife Resource Manager Search, The School for Field Studies, 16 Broadway, Beverly, MA 01915; phone: (508) 927-7777; fax: (508) 927-5127.

Family Health International seeks a RESIDENT ADVISOR for Tanzania, to coordinate and manage implementation of an AIDS Control and Prevention Project and ensure that appropriate technical assistance is provided to programs and activities. The program will strongly emphasize institutional building of indigenous NGOs. Requires Master's or doctoral level degree in public health or related field and seven-plus years experience in management of large public health/international development programs. Prior work with PVO/NGOs highly desirable. To apply, send cover letter (with salary requirements) and resume to Linda Rodriguez, Family Health International, 2101 Wilson Blvd., Suite 700, Arlington, VA 22201.

FHI also seeks a PROGRAM OFFICER to provide liaison, program, and administrative support required for a productive and efficient collaboration between FHI and UNICEF's AIDS unit; to facilitate FHI's provision of technical assistance to UNICEF's AIDS unit, Technical Support groups, and specified country programs. Requires Master's degree in Public Health or social sciences or equivalent experience and three-plus years related work experience. Experience in working with UN system of USAID-funded activities desirable. Fluency in French and/or Spanish desirable. To apply, send cover letter (with salary requirements) and resume to Linda Rodriguez, Family Health International, 2101 Wilson Blvd., Suite 700, Arlington, VA 22201.

FHI also seeks a RESEARCH OFFICER to assist in designing and managing the Behavioral Research program of the new global AIDS Control and Prevention Project (AIDSCAP) and to provide expertise in the planning, implementation, and evaluation of the Project's behavioral research program. Requires PhD in one of the social sciences or comparable combination of education and experience with AIDS epidemic and considerable experience in designing and implementing behavioral science research projects in the developing world. Ability to travel international, fluency in French or Spanish is preferred. To apply, send cover letter (with salary requirements) and resume to Linda Rodriguez, Family Health International, 2101 Wilson Blvd., Suite 700, Arlington, VA 22201.

FHI also seeks a CHIEF IN AIDS CONTROL AND PREVENTION PROJECT to manage the Behavior Changes Communications component, focusing on increasing condom demand and STD treatment-seeking behaviors and reducing numbers of sexual partners. Requires PhD or MA and equivalent experience and five years experience in the design of behavior change communications programs. Fluency in French or Spanish desirable. To apply, send cover letter (with salary requirements) and resume to Linda Rodriguez, Family Health International, 2101 Wilson Blvd., Suite 700, Arlington, VA 22201.

International Services of the Red Cross seeks two (2) SENIOR TECHNICAL ADVISORS in AIDS and Child Survival which will be seconded to USAID. These advisers will provide technical advice and management capabilities to the AID Mission to Kenya. QUALIFICATIONS: MPH or equivalent in health field; experience with AIDS prevention and Child Survival activities of USAID; excellent communications and analytical skills; 5+ years experience in developing countries; data and word processing skills. Fluency in French highly desirable. Contact: Helene Montell, ARC/OIS, 17th and D Streets, N.W., Washington, DC 20006.

Khanya College, Cape Town, is accepting applications for a DIRECTOR. The candidate must have a minimum academic qualification at master's degree level and a demonstrable comprehension of the context in which Khanya College operates. The candidate will need to communicate effectively with a wide range of external players in the fields of funding, research, and policy formation. Send curriculum vitae and three references to S. Isaacs, Chairperson, Khanya Board of Trustees, c/o Peninsula Technikon, P.O. Box 1906, Bellville 7535, South Africa. The Mennonite Central Committee seeks a DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM OFFICER in South Africa. Contact: Mennonite Central Committee, 21 South 12th Street, P.O. Box 500, Akron, PA 17501-0500; phone: (717) 859-1151.

The Mitchell Group Inc. seeks INSTRUCTORS for its Africa Primary Education project. Four- to six-month positions in testing and evaluation; EMIS; Textbook Logistics; Teacher Education; Math/Science/Reading/English curriculum. Requirements: advanced degree, minimum three years experience; LDC living required. Send CV to The Mitchell Group, Box 73825, Washington, DC 20009; phone: (202) 745-1919; fax: (202) 234-1697.

HEALTH TECHNICAL TRAINERS-AFRICA REGION (several openings) -- U.S. Personal Services contract positions as Health Technical Coordinator for pre-service training in Africa. QUALIFICATIONS: prior Peace Corps experience in primary health care or maternal and child health education in West Africa; prior experience designing primary health care training curricula using practical and competency-based approaches; MPH or related post-graduate degree preferred; 2 years work experience in the field of primary health care, preferably in a developing country; some French language ability (FSI 2+); demonstrated success training American adults; interpersonal skills; maturity with demonstrated ability to work effectively and sensitively on an inter-cultural team of trainers; knowledgeable about integrated approaches to rural development would be helpful; proven flexibility and willingness to work long, irregular hours and under considerable stress; ability and willingness to assess and counsel trainees. Send SF-171 to: Jahleezah Eskew, program assistant, Office of Programming and Training/Africa Region, 1990 K Street N.W., Washington, DC 20526. DEADLINE: Open.

ASSOCIATE PEACE CORPS DIRECTOR/EDUCATION TECHNICAL COORDINATOR-AFRICA REGION (several openings) -- U.S. Personal Services contract positions as Education Technical Coordinator for pre-service training in Africa. QUALIFICATIONS: prior Peace Corps experience in education in Africa; prior experience designing teacher training curricula using practical and competency-based approaches; MD or related post-graduate degree preferred; 2 years work experience in the field of primary health care, preferably in a developing country; some French language ability (FSI 2+); demonstrated success training American adults; interpersonal skills; maturity with demonstrated ability to work effectively and sensitively on an inter-cultural team of trainers; knowledgeable about integrated approaches to rural development would be helpful; proven flexibility and willingness to work long, irregular hours and under considerable stress; ability and willingness to assess and counsel trainees. Send SF-171 to: Jahleezah Eskew, program assistant, Office of Programming and Training/Africa Region, 1990 K Street N.W., Washington, DC 20526. DEADLINE: Open.

LANGUAGE COORDINATOR - AFRICA REGION (several openings) -- U.S. Personal Services Contract positions. QUALIFICATIONS: Peace Corps training experience in competency-based language training; coordinating pre-service training activities; demonstrated success training American adults; interpersonal skills; knowledgeable about issues of international development; proven flexibility and leadership. Send SF-171 to: Jahleezah Eskew, program assistant, Office of Programming and Training/Africa Region, 1990 K Street N.W., Washington, DC 20526. DEADLINE: Open.

Private Agencies Collaborating Together (PACT), a US-based international development organization, seeks a DEPUTY DIRECTOR experience in the small and micro-enterprise (SME) field for its South Africa office. Candidate must be a South African with relevant education, good communication skills, and a commitment to empowering blacks to establish successful SMEs. Send letter with CV and contact address/telephone/fax to PACT, P.O. Box 32286, Braamfontein 2017, South Africa.

Youngstown State University is looking for candidates for an African/African-American/Black Studies faculty position in their History Dept. For more information or to forward names of prospective candidates, contact: William D. Jenkins, Department of History, Youngstown State University, Youngstown, OH 44555-3452. Phone: (216) 742-3452.

AirServ International seeks candidates fore President/CEO. Candidates must have experience leading a complex multi-million dollar enterprise and a background in relief and development. Aviation experience strongly preferred. Africa experience a plus. Send resume to: Personnel Dept., AirServ International, Box 3041, Redlands, CA 92373.

The International Rescue Committee operates refugee relief programs in over 20 countries worldwide and is seeking a PROCUREMENT ASSISTANT. Procurement for these programs involves complex communications and a vast network of international suppliers. Items procured range from vehicles and medical supplies to textbooks and tents. Based in New York, under the supervision of the Procurement Officer, individual will: develop and maintain a database of suppliers and resources; provide clerical support; purchase goods and prepare for shipment to overseas programs; maintain relations and communications with IRC's suppliers and agents; liaise between field offices and suppliers; assure that donor requirements are met. REQUIREMENTS: Undergraduate degree in a related field, excellent computer skills including database, WP51, spreadsheet and Lotus, previous work experience, strong organizational skills, and a team player. Send cover letter, resume and 3 references to: IRC, Recruitment Office, 386 Park Avenue South, New York, NY 10016. Tel: (212) 679-0010. Fax: (212) 689-3459.

The African American Studies program at the University of Wyoming has been endowed to develop courses in sub-Saharan African languages. As employment would be seasonal, relocation would not be necessary. The program would be responsible for all travel expenses, plus a salary. Requirements: All language instructors must be indigenous Africans and must have the minimum of a Bachelor's degree in any field. Send all resumes and letters of interest to: Niyi Coker Jr., PhD, Director of African American Studies, University of Wyoming, Laramie, WY 82071. Email: niyi@uwyo.edu.

Africare has an immediate opening for a population and family planning project manager. Project manager will be a counterpart to the manager of a local NGO implementing a family planning program funded by USAID and other donors. Candidates should possess: advanced degree with 5-10 years of professional experience in a health-related field; background in project management, especially in health-related development projects in Africa; demonstrated understanding of clinical training, health services delivery, marketing activities and HIS; excellent French; working knowledge of such computer programs as WordPerfect, Lotus 123, DBase 3, SPSS, etc. Send resume and salary history to: Ms. Carolyn Gullatt, Africare House, 440 R Street NW, Washington, DC 20001.

CARE seeks PROJECT COORDINATOR to manage all aspects of 2 agroforestry/forestry projects in rural NE Rwanda. S/he will live and work in the field, approximately 2 hours drive from the capital. Each project has 3 components: forestry, agroforestry and energy conservation. Main responsibilities include personnel management, budget control, procurement and inventory control, monitoring and evaluation of project progress towards goals, reporting, technical assistance to staff and counterparts, and maintain good relations with local counterparts and donors. QUALIFICATIONS: prefer graduate degree in agriculture or agroforestry. 3+ years relevant experience management or playing a key role in agricultural development projects, preferably with peasant farmers in Africa. Very good spoken and written French and English. RTA MONITOR (Rwanda) to provide technical assistance and advice in the area of monitoring and evaluation to country offices in the East African region. QUALIFICATIONS: Masters degree in a development related field or equivalent experience; 5 years overseas work experience (preferably in East Africa) with an emphasis on monitoring and evaluation. Proven consulting skills essential. French, Arabic or Swahili desired.

CONSULTANT (Rwanda) to assess project accomplishments of stated objectives, assess sustainability of project interventions, assess the role and effectiveness of participating institutions and project relationships to these institutions, asses project management and use of funds/materials, recommend actions for Phase III, and designate tasks and project relationship to these institutions. QUALIFICATIONS: French and English competencies; project management experience in Africa; forest management expertise; excellent writing skills; leadership qualities; coordination and facilitation skills; knowledge of agroforestry interventions. Experience with NGOs; understanding of community participation and organization, agroforestry and agriculture extension systems.

PROJECT MANAGER (Mali) to have overall responsibility for the planning implementation, monitoring and evaluation of the Timbuktu Rural Development (TRD) Project. Individual will work closely with national staff technicians, government authorities, the CARE-Mali country office, and NGO partners working in Timbuktu region. QUALIFICATIONS: 5+ yrs overseas experience managing a development program; 2+ yrs with CARE; university degree in agriculture, natural resources, social sciences, management or international relations; excellent French and English; strong team building skills; self-starter, full of initiative.

For CARE positions, send resume to: Jeanette Nance Frett, International Recruiter, CARE, 151 Ellis St., Atlanta, GA 30303. Fax: (404) 577-9418.

The University Research Corporation/The Center for Human Services is currently recruiting an Associate Director for Administration. Responsibilities will include work planning, activities coordination, monitoring work in progress, and financial and contract management. Minimum Qualifications: Master's degree or experiential equivalent in Business Administration, Management, Finance or related field; 5 years of exempt experience in project, financial or operations management; 3 years of experience supervising exempt personnel; fluency in French or Spanish; willingness to travel up to 1/3 time; A.I.D. contract experience preferred. To apply send resume to URC/CHS Attn. Human Resources Dept., 7200 Wisconsin Avenue, Bethesda, MD 20814 or fax to (301) 654-5976.

Africa News


March 15, 1994 / March 28, 1994


VOLUNTEER OPPORTUNITIES


LENGTH: 1267 words


 

Health Volunteers Overseas has several openings for health care providers who wish to aid its programs in the following nations:

TRANSKEI (one-month assignments; April-December 1994):

Participants needed to teach anesthesia at Umtata General Hospital to physicians-in-training. Volunteers will also provide direct anesthesia care. Housing on hospital grounds is provided for the volunteer at no cost. Contact Dr. Kevin Speight, (919) 716-4498/(919) 454-3956 or Spence Campbell (704) 696-9930.

UGANDA (one-month assignments; May-December 1994): Volunteers participate in the only anesthesia training program in Uganda. Most of the teaching takes place in Kampala's Mulago Hospital. Housing provided at the guest house at Makerere University. Contact Dr. Harry Zutz, (908) 381-4200/(201) 378-3323. 

UGANDA (one-month assignments; March-November 1994): Program trains medical student, physicians, prosthetists, orthotists and physical therapists to improve the treatment of amputees and disabled people injured as a result of civil strife. Surgeons may also conduct orthopedic clinics an operating sessions with Ugandan doctors in upcountry regional hospitals in Tororo/Mbale, Mbarara and Fort Portal. Physical therapist volunteers will be needed to help the Ugandan tutors to develop courses in the three year diploma course are Mulago Hospital. Volunteers need to have a minimum of two years of clinical experience and some educational experience. Advanced degrees and lecture experience are big plus, but are not mandatory. Prosthetists are also being sought to teach. For a nominal fee, housing will be provided at the newly renovated Mulago Guest House. Contact: Dr. David Denzel, (716) 434-2697 or Elizabeth Kay, PT, (708) 897-4814.

MALAWI (two-month assignments, one month considered; The School of Health Sciences in Lolongwe is the site for a program providing education support in the areas of diagnosing dental and oral pathoses, performing conservative dentistry, periodontics, uncomplicated dental extractions and preventive dentistry. This program is soliciting 3 volunteers a year with a one month hiatus between volunteers. Contact: Dr. Dick Nieusma, (402) 472-9846. For a more detailed description of each site as well as copies of trip reports from previous volunteers, contact Health Volunteers Overseas, c/o Washington Station, P.O. Box 65157, Washington, DC 20035-5157; phone: (202) 296-0928.

The American Medical Team for Africa (AMTA) promotes and executes educational exchange and medical training in African countries. The goal of the non-profit organization is to bring volunteer doctors, nurses and medical students together with donated supplies, and equipment to serve needs on the continent. Survey teams assess the most pressing needs in targeted countries, develop and publish training manuals in appropriate languages, hold workshops and refresher courses for doctors, nurses and specialists interested in maintenance of health care delivery systems in Africa; and distribute medical supplies and equipment donated by corporations, pharmaceutical companies, hospitals and doctors. The AMTA plans a second medical mission to Africa. For more information, contact Deman Rageh, Executive Director, The American Medical Team for Africa, 2245 Godby Road, Atlanta, GA 30349; phone (404) 766-8000; fax: (404) 767-5264.

Private Voluntary Organization in Rosslyn needs an experienced Agribusiness/Marketing Specialist to fill a 3-year Chief of Party position in Mali. The candidate must have at least 10 years of proven experience in the field of Agribusiness, Marketing, Credit and Procurement (preferably of fruits & vegetables). Must have related job experience in developing country with hands-on experience and an MBA. Strong training skills in the areas of agribusiness and marketing required. Fluency in French/English (FSI , S-3, R03) a must. Interested candidates must submit a resume, a certification of foreign language capability, and a standard AID bio-data form. Please mail original copies to: Regina Wynn, VITA, 5th floor, Arlington, VA 22209. Tel: (703) 276-1800 or fax: (703) 2143-1865.

The World Wildlife Fund (WWF) offers paid and unpaid internships for a 12-week duration beginning in June and ending in August. Internships are designed for college and graduate students with an academic background or work experience in the following areas: biology, environmental or conservation science, economics, environmental quality, natural resources management, public lands and resources, zoology or other areas of study related to WWF's work. DEADLINE for applications is APRIL 1, 1994. Interested candidates should forward cover letter describing areas of special interest and indicating compensation requirement, resume, two reference with telephone numbers, and a writing sample of 3-5 pages to World Wildlife Fund, Internship Program, Human Resources Department 94IM, 1250 24th Street, NW, Washington, DC 20037.

CUSO currently has the following openings:

NIGERIA and TOGO: Individual for each country to provide field support to cooperants and play a lead role in coordinating and developing alliances between Canada and West Africa, through the cooperant program. A degree in social sciences, adult education or community development; 3 yrs. experience in program development and management; and overseas living experience in a similar socio-political environment is required. Experience related specifically to West Africa is desired. SIERRA LEONE: CUSO and a variety of local partner organizations require the shared services of one fundraiser and a university degree and a minimum of 2 yrs. work experience in fundraising and administration with a nongovernmental organization. NIGERIA: The Cooperative Federation of Nigeria (CFN), a national non-governmental organization, requires a person with training in social sciences, adult education or community development, and 2 years experience with cooperatives, to contribute to the training of their members. MOZAMBIQUE: The national environmental division of the Government of Mozambique requires a person with a degree in social sciences/ environmental studies and 5 years experience in program management, training and gender analysis to coordinate the development of an environmental management program. TO APPLY: send resume to Cooperant Programming Unit, CUSO GE-19, 135 Rideau Street, Ottawa ON K1N 9K7. Postings are for two years. Salaries are modest, but cover overseas living costs. Transportation and benefits are provided.

AFRICAN VISITORS TO THE U.S.


LENGTH: 1214 words


 

Our list of African visitors to the United States is compiled from the "Arrival List of International Visitors," published by the United States Information Agency (phone 202-619-5219).

BOTSWANA:

Maphorisa, Joyce; Guidance Officer, Curriculum Development Unit, Ministry of Education; Arrives 3/7/94 for 28 days; To participate in the "Education for Careers" project.

CAMEROON:

Ntemfac, Aloysius Nkong; Editor-in-Chief, Private Newspaper "Cameroon Post"; Arrives 3/7/94 for 42 days; To participate in "The Fourth Estate: The Media" project.

Matateyou, Emmanual; Senior Lecturer, Advanced Teachers' Training College, Yaounde; Arrives 3/27/94; Project Interest: U.S. Higher Education System. 

EGYPT:

Abdel Wahid, Maher El-Sayed; Vice President, Egyptian Court of Cassation; First Assistant to Minister of Justice; 3/21/94 for 30 days to participate in the "Court Administration and Computerization" project.

Marei, Mamdouh Moheildin; Justice, Cairo Court of Appeals; Assistant to Minister of Justice for Judicial Inspection; 3/21/94 for 30 days to participate in the "Court Administration and Computerization" project.

Mohamed, Essam Ahmed; Chief Judge, Legislation Department; 3/21/94 for 30 days to participate in the "Court Administration and Computerization" project.

Shaker, Mokbel Shaker Mohamed Kamel; President of Judges' Club; 3/21/94 for 30 days to participate in the "Court Administration and Computerization" project.

El-Zahid, Mounir Abdel Wahab; Deputy General Manager, Commercial International Bank, Alexandria; 3/7/94 for 29 days to participate in the "Debt and U.S. Capital Market" project.

GABON:

Essaba, Simon-Clovis; English Teacher, National Teacher Training University; Arrives 3/7/94 for 28 days; To participate in the "Education for Careers" project.

KENYA:

Masia, Martin; Bureau Chief, Kenya Times, Nakurk; Arrives 3/7/94 for 42 days; To participate in "The Fourth Estate: The Media" project.

MALAWI:

Limbani, Moya; Senior Reporter, "The Nation"; Arrives 3/7/94 for 42 days; To participate in "The Fourth Estate: The Media" project.

MAURITIUS:

Bumma, Kreepanandsing Atma; Journalist, L'Express Newspaper; Arrives 3/7/94 for 42 days; To participate in "The Fourth Estate: The Media" project.

MOROCCO:

Houfaidi-Settar, Jamila; Professor, International Relations, Faculty of Legal, Economic and Social Studies, Hassan II University; 3/21/94 for 30 days to participate in the "Managing Regional Tensions" project.

MOZAMBIQUE:

Ivone, Pulqueria Estevao; Reporter, Radio Mozambique, Beira; Arrives 3/7/94 for 42 days; To participate in "The Fourth Estate: The Media" project.

Ramos, Jose Antonio; Editor-in-Chief, RTK Television Station; Arrives 3/7/94 for 42 days; To participate in "The Fourth Estate: The Media" project.

NIGERIA:

Mitu, Gideon; Editor, Sunday Standard Newspaper; Arrives 3/7/94 for 42 days; To participate in "The Fourth Estate: The Media" project.

SAO TOME:

Correia, Victor Manuel; Head of News Department at the National Radio; Arrives 3/7/94 for 42 days; To participate in "The Fourth Estate: The Media" project.

SIERRA LEONE:

Kuyateh, Davidson; Assistant Secretary General, Sierra Leone Teachers Union; Arrives 3/7/94 for 28 days; To participate in the "Education for Careers" project.

SOUTH AFRICA:

Albertyn, Catherine; WITS University Officer and Coordinator, Gender Research Project, Center for Applied Legal Studies, WITS University; Arrives 3/7/94; Project Interests: Human rights, Affirmative Action.

Lowry, Corinna; Co-Director, Johannesburg Dance Foundation; Arrives 3/21/94; Project Interest: Dance.

Bosilong, Tebogo; Journalist, Studio Manager, Peoples Express Newspaper; Arrives 3/7/94 for 42 days; To participate in "The Fourth Estate: The Media" project.

Dlamini, Edward; Course Facilitator, Nexus Community College; Arrives 3/7/94 for 28 days; To participate in the "Education for Careers" project.

UGANDA:

Tibarimbasa, Avitus; Institute Secretary, Institute of Teacher Education; Arrives 3/7/94 for 28 days; To participate in the "Education for Careers" project.

ZAIRE:

Nsapu, Paul; Founder and National President of "LZE", Zairian League of Electors; Arrives 3/27/94; Project Interest: U.S. Political, Cultural Institutions.

ZAMBIA:

Sianga, Mbambo; Registrar, Lecturer in Charge, Zambia Law Practice Institute; Arrives 3/7/94; Project Interest: Law Judiciary System.

Chilambwe, Peter; Production Editor, Zambian Weekly "Sun"; "Young African Leaders" project.

ZIMBABWE:

Mushava, Funny; Deputy News Editor, "The Herald"; "Young African Leaders" project.

PLANNING AHEAD

"How do we achieve sustainable development?"

Reading, Pennsylvania -- Conference

"Ngugi Wa Thiongo: Texts and Contexts"

Contact: Charles Cantalupo, Conference Director, Department of English, Penn State University, Schuylkill Haven, PA 17972; phone: (717) 385-6055; fax: (717) 385-3672; E-Mail: CXC8@PSUVM.PSU.EDU.

"The Advancement of African-Centered Knowledge for the 21st Century" is the theme of the 26th annual National Conference of the African Heritage Studies Association.

Africa News


March 15, 1994 / March 28, 1994


"I HAVE NOTHING AGAINST GOING TO AMERICA, BUT..."


BYLINE: Sheriff Bojang


LENGTH: 1000 words


 

WEEKEND OBSERVER, February 25-27, 1994

The matriarch of the Kunta Kinteh family of 'Roots' fame, 80-year-old Mrs. Binta Kinteh, has said she has nothing against going to the United States, provided certain conditions are met.

Mrs. Kinteh was commenting on plans by the U.S.-based tour operator, R.G. Gainey and Associates, to take her on speaking tours of American cities.

In a release faxed to this paper on Tuesday, the president and owner of the tour company, Miss Rosetta Gainey, said her organisation will sponsor Mrs. Kinteh's first visit in to the United States, scheduled for September to October this year.

According to the release, Mrs. Kinteh is to visit several cities and speak at colleges, universities, and various organisations on the Kinteh family story and her meeting with Alex Haley prior to the publication of the widely-acclaimed 'Roots.' 

The release added that funds raised fro the speaking engagements will be used to develop and preserve Juffure, Kunta Kinteh's ancestral village in The Gambia. It concluded by stating that, "the development and preservation of Juffure are activities that were never started or supported in the past; and activities greatly needed not only for the people of the village but for history".

Put to her, the old by firm Kinteh matriarch, surrounded buy three generations of family members, said that Mrs. Gainey visited the village twice in 1992, on July 30, and again in November, accompanied by a significant number of African-American tourists.

Mrs. Kinteh maintained that during her first visit Mrs. Gainey had promised to rebuild the Kinteh family home from its present derelict state. She said Mrs. Gainey reaffirmed her promise on her second trip, when she organised a cultural festival in the village, and during the celebrations proffered Mrs. Kinteh a $500 cheque towards the reconstruction of the family compound. This she said, was later taken from her by Mrs. Gainey, with the promise she would give her a heftier cheque. This, however, never came. Mrs. Kinteh stated that since then, they did not hear anything from Rosetta Gainey until November 29 last year, when her supposed agent, Mr. Modou Gassama of Brikama, visited the village bearing two signboards, one proclaiming "Housing Project for Mrs. Binta Kinteh", the other "Construction of a Multi-Purpose Youth Centre, Juffure-Albreada". Nothing transpired again, until mid December, when Mr. Gassama came once more, this time bringing a letter informing her of the proposed trip to the United States.

Mrs. Kinteh said she and her family deliberated on the issue, and collectively laid down conditions which must be fulfilled before she is willing to leave for the U.S.

She declined to go into detail, but disclosed that the Kinteh family have agreed that before she leaves Juffure, a binding contract must be drawn up with Rosetta Gainey in person. She said the services of a lawyer will be sought. She also disclosed that the family did not favour the "intervention of any middle-man" in their dealings with Mrs. Gainey. "We want to correspond with her directly," she stressed.

She said this was necessitated by unfortunate past experiences. "We have been taken for a ride many a time in the past. Now we are resolved not to allow such thing to happen again."

Alex Haley and 'Roots'

Commenting on Alex Haley, Mrs. Kinteh said she first met him in 1972. This was followed by visits to Juffure in 1979, 1982 and 1987. He came with his family during the third visit.

She recounted the blessing of the 'Roots' immortalisation of her village as resulting tin th provision of pipe-borne water, electricity and gravelled roads. The place has also become a tourist attraction. Nevertheless, Mrs. Kinteh recollected a series of promises, made to her by Alex Haley, that were never kept.

Among these, she particularly felt, were the promise of a trip to the holy shrine at Mecca, and the rebuilding of the dilapidated family home.

The construction of a mosque was begun, but it is still incomplete. Quizzed on whether Alex had bequeathed to her anything from his huge wealth, Mrs. Kinteh said they have not received a penny. She maintained that they have a natural claim to his bequests, as it was 'Roots' that made him a world celebrity and a millionaire.

The film version of 'Roots' was watched by a record 120 million television viewers. The book itself won a Pulitzer Prize. It has been translated into 37 languages.

Alex Haley died last year at the age of 72. His son, Bill Haley, visited Juffure last year.

Reprinted from the WEEKEND OBSERVER. The WEEKEND OBSERVER is published by The Observer Company (Gambia) Ltd. New Town-Sait Matty Junction, Bakau. PMB 131, Banjul, The Gambia. Tel: (220) 496608, 496877. Fax: (220) 496878.


LOAD-DATE: March 29, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


88 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 15, 1994 / March 28, 1994


FEMALE CIRCUMCISION NOT A RELIGIOUS RITE


BYLINE: Momodu Musa Secka


LENGTH: 854 words


 

DAILY OBSERVER, March 2, 1994

The Executive Secretary, Women's Bureau, Mrs. Isatou Njie-Saidy, has said that from an Islamic point of view, female genital mutilation or female circumcision is not a religious requirement.

In her address at the opening of the Regional Workshop on African Women and Tradition, Culture and Religion, held at the Atlantic Hotel yesterday, Mrs. Njie-Saidy pointed out that as a representative of a country where Islam is the predominant religion, she and others have been educated to the knowledge that circumcision is neither encouraged nor advised by Islamic scholars.

"That leaves culture and tradition as being squarely responsible for this practice, whose wisdom is increasingly being challenged in various quarters," she declared. She pointed out, however, that not all of our culture and traditions are anti-development and unprogressive. 

The Executive Secretary asserted that in an era when the drive towards greater social enlightenment has become all-embracing, the situation of a society divided between privileged and under-privileged based on sex, race or creed is an affront.

"In this workshop, we shall have the opportunity to exchange ideas on experiences and efforts being made, and progress attained in the struggle for the betterment of women in our various communities," she said.

Mrs. Njie-Saidy also briefly touched on what Gambian women have been engaged in during the last decade. She said that at the national level, there has been an increased awareness in the last decade or so about what really needs to be done, and how to go about it.

"About 14 years ago, the Government of The Gambia established the National Women's Council and Bureau by an Act of Parliament, to advise government on all matters affecting the welfare of Gambian women," she recalled. She pointed out that The Gambia's Women's Bureau, among other achievements, has been instrumental in creating greater awareness at all levels of women's problems and concerns.

"In all these development schemes and programmes, we are alive to the fact that, irrespective of what amount of legislation is put in place, the beneficiaries of the laws enacted, conventions signed, ratified and codified, can only be positively affected if they are part and parcel of the processes themselves, and people are convinced of their significance."

Knowing rights, duties and obligations enables women, as mothers, housewives and carers, to know what is convenient as a family size and what is possible to shoulder in terms of rearing children, she asserted.

"We must, as organisations, individuals and community groups from various countries, commit ourselves, as never before, to ensure that decisions taken and affecting the welfare of women are put into practice," she said.

In his address of welcome, the director, African Centre for Democracy and Human Rights Studies, Mr. Raymond Sock, said that the workshop is important because it gives African women scholars, activists and mothers, and indeed some men, a unique opportunity to explore some of the themes relevant to women's rights in Africa, prior to the regional meeting for the Fourth World Conference on women.

He described the workshop as timely, as it provides a touchstone for some of the issues of burning concern to African women.

"Although this workshop will concentrate on the effects of tradition, culture and religion on the realisation of women's rights in Africa, it is hoped that our discussions over the next five days will provide a catalyst for further investigation into other spheres of life militating against the advancement of women in Africa." Mr. Sock said.

The workshop, which ends on Friday, is being attended by 25 participants from Botswana, Burkina Faso, Cameroun, Cape Verde, Canada, Ghana, Kenya, Lesotho, Mali, Morocco, Nigeria, Senegal, Sierra Leone, South Africa, Sudan, Tanzania, Tunisia, the United Kingdom and The Gambia.

Reprinted from the DAILY OBSERVER. The DAILY OBSERVER is published by The Observer Company (Gambia) Ltd. New Town-Sait Matty Junction, Bakau. PMB 131, Banjul, The Gambia. Tel: (220) 496608, 496877. Fax: (220) 496878.


LOAD-DATE: March 29, 1994


LANGUAGE: English
