Africa News


March 15, 1994 / March 28, 1994


JOURNALISTS ON STRIKE!


BYLINE: Kassim Abdallah


LENGTH: 694 words


 

THE GHANAIAN CHRONICLE, March 7-9, 1994

Journalists in war-ravaged Northern Region have dumped their pens and notepads in protest against censorship and manipulation of news on the ethnic conflict in the area by the government and editors.

At an emergency meeting of the regional branch of the Ghana Journalists' Association (GJA) in Tamale last Thursday (March 3), the journalists resolved not to file any more reports on the four-week old conflict between Konkombas, and Nanumbas, Dagombas and Gonjas that has driven 2,000 people to their graves and 120,000 into refugee camps.

A resolution addressed to the GJA headquarters and the National Media Commission, protested the blackout of the news they had filed on the war by their Accra-based bosses, especially those in the state-owned media. 

They said: "The manner in which news on the current crisis and similar incidents in the region in the past has been treated by the editors has cast a slur on the competence and credibility of journalists on the ground."

Citing instances, the journalists said reports sent by local correspondents at the outbreak of the war on February 3, were not used. Much later, an official statement issued by the Number Two Brigade Commander in Accra was published as having been made in Tamale when nothing of the sort took place in Tamale.

"This was followed by the President's tour of the conflict areas which was also given wide coverage even though the news content was the same as that contained in earlier reports filed by local correspondents and which had not been used."

Recalling the latest incident in Tamale on Tuesday, March 1, in which security men shot and killed 15 people, the journalists complained that editors decided to use an official statement issued in Accra instead of oven-fresh reports from their correspondents on the spot.

They said while they were not averse to official statements issued to clarify or state the government's position, such statements should not be substituted with reports filed on the same issue by accredited reporters.

"Lives of reporters are put at risk as a result of confrontation with the public which thinks that we are unduly shelving reports on the situation, especially when incidents of lesser dimensions elsewhere are given prominence," they said.

As a result of that and the fact that they are not insured, the journalists resolved not to put their lives on the line, covering such dangerous events until their editors assured them of using their stories.

"We do not deny our editors their prerogative to edit our reports or even decide not to use them at all, but nobody can say it is not news when so many lives and property are destroyed," the resolution said.

The decision of the journalists could affect the national appreciation of the real situation in the conflict zone. The mobilisation of national and international moral support and resources to cushion the victims of the war could also be hampered by the black-out.

Government has been sensitive about the nature of news reports, fearing that the content could inflame the still-volatile situation in the war zone. Critics say that amounts to blaming the message on the messenger.

Reprinted from THE GHANAIAN CHRONICLE. THE GHANAIAN CHRONICLE is published by Ghanaian Chronicle, P.O. Box 6369, Airport-Accra. Tel: 22-77-89. Fax: 22-6573.


LOAD-DATE: March 29, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


90 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 15, 1994 / March 28, 1994


CHARTER REFLECTS WOMEN'S NEEDS


BYLINE: Ferial Haffajee


LENGTH: 600 words


 

THE WEEKLY MAIL & GUARDIAN, March 4-10, 1994

One of the first documents to be presented to the government of national unity in June will be a draft women's charter.

The Women's National Coalition last week brought two years' work to virtual completion when it presented the charter to a conference of over 300 delegates representing more than 80 women's organisations.

The Coalition is unlikely to demand the charter's inclusion in the Bill of Rights. Instead, it will be used as a political document to lobby parliament and organise women. 

The charter is detailed, offering something for all South African women. Flowing from Coalition research into women's needs, it includes sections on the economy, law, education, development, rape and battery.

It speaks as much to urban executives through calls for equal taxation as to rural woman by stating that "custom, culture and religion shall be subject to the equality clause in the Bill of Rights" and by promising them a say in development projects.

Women leaders will find comforting its promise that no tier of government will be without women representatives. Many ideas in the charter aim to improve the lot of women in the informal sector while other working women are catered for by a package of proposals which includes equal access to education and training, equal pay and improved childcare facilities.

The charter dodges the issue of polygamy, promotes freedom of choice on abortion and calls for the legalisation of prostitution. These nettles may take time to grasp but changes likely to occur soon after the installation of a government of national unity may see higher numbers f women judges and magistrates, gender balance in the human rights and gender commissions as well as in the constitutional court. The charter also calls for state-funded counseling centres for women who are battered and raped, but does not promise free health care.

In a move that took some by surprise, the ANC Women's League supported a National Party motion for the dissolution of the Coalition. "Most regions felt that because the charter is ready, there is no reason for the Coalition to continue," said Thandi Modise, deputy president of the League.

The conference instead decided to extend the life of the Coalition to the end of June when the charter will be presented to the first parliamentary session of a government of national unity.

New faces will lead the Coalition: some full-time staffers have left, while parliamentary candidates who also held leadership positions in the Coalition have had to step down,. The Coalition's steering committee is to meet soon to decide on replacements.

Reprinted from THE WEEKLY MAIL & GUARDIAN, March 4-10, 1994.

THE WEEKLY MAIL & GUARDIAN is published by M&G Media Contact: M&G Media, 139 Smit Street, Breamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025.


LOAD-DATE: March 29, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


91 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 15, 1994 / March 28, 1994


PROTEST AWAITS SHIPMENT OF DEADLY US TOXIC WASTE


BYLINE: Lena Slachmuiljder


LENGTH: 747 words


 

SUNDAY NATION, February 20, 1994

Efforts are underway to stop the shipment of 160 barrels of toxic mercury compound from the United States, destined for the Thor Chemicals plant in Cato Ridge in the Natal Midlands.

The shipment will arrive at the Durban harbour tomorrow and is expected to be greeted by a protest demonstration by South African environmentalists.

The shipment has been sent by US company, Borden Chemical and Plastics Inc., which has claimed that it is merely recycling "spent mercuric chloride catalyst" that it originally purchased from Thor. 

Part of the conditions of sale dictate that the product be sent back to Thor when much of the mercuric chloride is used up.

Thor then burns the catalyst in a high-temperature incinerator to extract any remaining mercury and use it to produce more catalyst, said Thor spokesperson John MacDonald.

But spokesperson for the Environmental Justice Networking Forum, Chris Albertyn, rejected Thor's claim, pointing out that the substance being shipped to Thor should be classified as toxic waste and banned from being imported in to South Africa.

Albertyn also said that because Thor has not yet received a permit to operate the incinerator from the Department of National Health, "Thor is sitting with two million kilograms of toxic waste on its premises that is not being recycled".

He said the waste poses a danger of seeping into the soil and groundwater.

He said that even when the substance is incinerated, there is no way of preventing toxic substances, including mercury and chloride, from being released into the air from the incinerator smokestack.

MacDonald said until a permit for the incinerator is granted, the catalyst from Borden is being kept in triple-lined ponds with alarm systems to detect if there are any leaks.

He said the United States' Environmental Protection Agency has declared that incinerating mercury-laden waste is the best known technology for dealing with the waste - which is banned in US landfills.

MacDonald also denied that toxic fumes would be emitted and said: "I am sure that there is more mercury emitted from an average South African braai than from Thor's incinerator smokestacks."

Although Thor has said it will stop mercury recycling by 1996, Albertyn said the amount of waste coming from Borden will be too much to handle by 1996.

This may run into problems with a future ANC environmental policy opposing the import of toxic waste.

And, if Thor is no longer reprocessing the waste, US laws will force Borden to stop exporting the substance.

Borden has currently been allowed to export the substance under the auspices that it will be recycled.

Thor Chemicals has been dogged by controversy for allegedly failing to ensure safety procedures for its workers at its plant. Three senior executives are facing charges of culpable homicide in connection with the death of one worker from mercury poisoning. The executives also face 46 counts of breaches of safety laws.

Reprinted from Sunday Nation.

SUNDAY NATION is published by New Nation Publishing Co.

Contact: New Nation Publishing Co., P.O. Box 10674, Johannesburg 2000, South Africa, phone:(011) 333-2711. Fax:(011) 333-2733.


LOAD-DATE: March 29, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


92 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 15, 1994 / March 28, 1994


ANC FAVOURS RENWICK AS DEADLOCK-BREAKER


BYLINE: Farouk Chothia


LENGTH: 907 words


 

THE WEEKLY MAIL & GUARDIAN, March 4-10, 1994

The ANC has suggested former British ambassador to South Africa Robin Renwick and former Nigerian military ruler General Olesegun Obasanjo as foreign mediators on South Africa's constitutional deadlock.

The sources said the ANC had also indicated strong support for a mediator from the US, but had not proposed a name.

Under local and international pressure, the ANC has grudgingly accepted foreign mediation in exchange for the Inkatha Freedom Party's provisional registration for the April election. The behind-the-scenes agreement was struck at a marathon eight-hour summit in Durban this week. 

The prime mover behind Tuesday's Royal Hotel summit is understood to have been Tongaat Hulett managing director Chris Saunders. Previously a staunch ally of Buthelezi, Saunders has forged ties with Mandela since his release from prison. In the international community, one of the strongest advocates of foreign mediation has been the Commonwealth.

Buthelezi has in the past proposed mediation under the Commonwealth or the Organisation of African Unity., Sources said he had also proposed an Italian-based body called the Council of Venice. Apparently rightwing and largely unknown, this is seen as a non-starter.

The ANC's acceptance of foreign mediation is a major victory of Buthelezi. It will return him to the international limelight, and he may use it to try and extract further concessions from the ANC, including a postponement of the April poll on grounds that the IFP needs time to gear up its election machinery.

Sources revealed that the kwaZulu caucus agreed at a meeting on Wednesday that the IFP should "provisionally" register for election. And IFP central committee meeting scheduled for this morning is expected to adopt a similar position. The deadline for the registration of political parties is today.

But a tough round of negotiations lies ahead. In his latest gambit, Buthelezi has told the kwaZulu caucus that Zulu king Goodwill Zwelithini is standing firm on his demand that a Zulu kingdom -- separate from the rest of South Africa -- be guaranteed in the interim constitution.

But once foreign mediators intervene, Buthelezi could find pressure on him mounting to adopt a pragmatic stance and agree to contest elections -- or risk being exposed as a spoiler.

In an interview, the Commonwealth's special representative in South Africa, Moses Anafu, said the body was "willing, able and ready": to send a mediation team to South Africa in a week's time.

Anafu said the Commonwealth could either engage in "shuttle diplomacy" or chair roundtable talks among the ANC, IFP, government and the Zulu monarchy.

He added that a mediation team could include a traditional leader -- such as the king of Malaysia of the Sultan of Sokoto -- to handle the thorny issue of Zwelithini's demand for a sovereign and independent kingdom in kwaZulu/Natal.

But other sources said the ANC has steadfastly rejected the Commonwealth offer, partly because it fears that Nigeria -- a strong proponent of federalism -- could wield enormous influence in the mediation team. Others countered that the ANC could rely on the support of countries like India and Zimbabwe to counter Nigerian influence and that the Commonwealth was bound to adopt and impartial stance.

Sources said that OAU, which also announced this week that it was willing to mediate, has also been rejected by the ANC, seeing it as a weak body which has failed to resolve conflicts in Africa.

Sources said the ANC preferred a mediator from Britain or the US, as having the clout to force the IFP to compromise and contest elections.

Obasanjo -- who heads the New York-based Africa Leadership Forum -- is also a favoured choice as he has developed "chemistry" with both Mandela and Buthelezi. Now seen in some circles and an "elder statesman" of Africa, he led the Commonwealth Emminent Person's Group to South Africa on a fact-finding mission in the 1980s in a failed bid to find common ground between the then-banned ANC and the PW Botha regime.

Reprinted from THE WEEKLY MAIL & GUARDIAN, March 4-10, 1994.

THE WEEKLY MAIL & GUARDIAN is published by M&G Media Contact: M&G Media, 139 Smit Street, Breamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025.


LOAD-DATE: March 29, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


93 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 15, 1994 / March 28, 1994


DOCTORS IN TANKS


BYLINE: Fernando Dias/Xangongo


LENGTH: 987 words


 

AFRICA SOUTH & EAST, February 1994

While the Angolan peace talks lurch through round after round, a radical German humanitarian organisation is hard at work rolling back the deadly debris of decades of war. As a form of radical preventive health care, the organisation destroys weaponry to avoid having to treat its effects in deaths and injuries.

Cap Anamur -- essentially, German Emergency Doctors -- arrived in Cunene Province a year ago to find it crippled by conflict, with thousands of landmines and tons of leftover high explosive ammunition posing a daily threat to the weary civilian population.

Working under the banner of "Radical Pacifism, Radical Neutrality, Radical Humanitarianism," they set to work clearing away the danger. Using converted high-tech East German military gear including white-painted tans and trucks originally designed to withstand the Siberian winter, Cap Anamur and their Angolan sappers have cleared 7,500 mine. From unguarded and precarious dumps, they have removed 50,000 high explosive missiles and shells, 200,000 smaller shells and over 49 tons of assorted explosives. 

All the munitions are destroyed in massive controlled blasts. "We are using the weapons of war to fight a war on war...a nice concept, don't you think?" We love destroying arms," says project manager Hendrik Ehlers.

By supporting recovery of the infrastructure and making the province safer for vulnerable local people, Cap Anamur enforce their commitment to disarmament. Fields abandoned for 15 years are again being cultivated as mines are removed and confidence that they will not be blown up returns to the farmers.

Roads in Cunene are generally so bad that the few functioning vehicles avoid them and health care collapsed long ago, leaving some areas with no child vaccination. Water remains a commodity some must walk 40km to draw from a dirty river. In towns and villages, once-splendid colonial buildings are now piles of rubble, while the roofless shells of post offices, schools and hospitals rot away.

In Namacunde, just short of the Namibian border, American food aid is one of the few items on sale at the local market, where the Angolan Kwanza trades at 7,000 to one against the US dollar. Care International and the UN World Food Programme truck tonnes of food aid into needy areas of the province, where war and drought have depleted grain stocks. Military hardware and burnt-out tanks are interspersed with civilian vehicles destroyed by land mines along the sides of the rutted toads, while huge areas of wasteland bear testimony to exploded ammunition dumps.

Although there is relative peace in Cunene, travellers on some roads are still hijacked by bandits using landmines as a somewhat indiscriminate weapon in their armed robberies.

"Mines don't have friends," says a military lieutenant in Cahama, an old site of battle between South Africa forces, the MPLA and Swapo. The deadly legacy of mines and ammunition dumps have cost scores of lives in the province, in a country with the world's highest amputee population.

But the enthusiasm of the Cap Anamur "desminagem" has made a real difference. The organisation also runs the only functioning workshop for 200km and use their former surplus military vehicles for bridge-building and the transportation of medical supplies in a region desperately short of transport.

"All they know here is famine, warm shitty weather and malaria," says Edith Fischnaller, a Cap Anamur nurse who rehabilitated an old hospital in Oncocua in the remote southwest which now serves 100,000 people over a 300km radius. She arrived a year ago to find the hospital a shell destroyed in 1981 by South African forces, while untreated diseases devastated the largely nomadic population.

The Government has since sent three nurses and eight assistants, but few medicines reach Oncocua in addition to those from German public donations. When Fischnaller arrived, hundreds were dying of a measles epidemic. None have died so far this year. She has learned basic surgical techniques, performing amputations where necessary and with the help of a new doctor from Germany she recently delivered a child by emergency caesarian section, proudly showing off a healthy mother and baby who would otherwise have died.

Cap Anamur don't pretend that volunteer efforts like theirs can clean up the whole country. That will require massive resources and an acceptance of responsibility from the militias who left behind their deadly weapons in th first place. And before that can happen, commitment has to be found to stop the fighting.

Reprinted from Africa South & East Africa South & East is published by ASE Publications, PO Box 260529, Excom 2023, South Africa. Phone (011) 487-1596/7. Fax (011) 648-0907.


LOAD-DATE: March 29, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


94 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 15, 1994 / March 28, 1994


COMMISSION UNDER FIRE


BYLINE: Enoch Sithole


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 800 words


 

SUNDAY NATION, February 20, 1994

The Independent Electoral Commission (IEC) is buying 20 American-made aircraft for election monitoring - but no one in the commission is prepared to discuss the deal.

The project is already under fire from politicians who argue that the IEC should either lease the planes or use the SA Air Force's surveillance aircraft.

The Democratic Party's (DP) Tony Leon said it was "shocking" to learn about such a deal while the ANC's Popo Molefe said he would have expected the IEC to lease airplanes "if they need them so desperately."

The criticism levelled against the deal is based on the fact that the 20 airplanes will cost the taxpayers approximately R77,8-million - yet they will only be used for about a month. 

The commission's chairperson, Judge Johann Kriegler, added to the controversy by denying the report. He refused to confirm the deal and could only say that a statement would be made "at an appropriate time".

The discussion with an irate Kriegler went this way: "We are not buying them," and when asked whether they were leasing them: "No!"

And when asked whether the IEC would use any aircraft during the monitoring of the election: "We will use them but we are not buying them." And when asked where they would get them from: "We will make an announcement at an appropriate time."

But Daniel Lewis, the marketing manager of Ayres Corporation - the manufacturing company - confirmed that the IEC had bought the aircraft. He also confirmed reports that 10 of them would arrive in South Africa on March 25.

The planes - known as Turbo Thrushes - are manufactured for use in the spraying of crops and fire-fighting. They have speeds of up to 200 kilometres an hour.

They only take two people on board and can fly up to 880 kilometres without stopping. Orange Free State farmers hire it for spraying and pay R2,700 per hour.

Speaking to Sunday Nation from the corporation's headquarters in Georgia, USA, Lewis said the planes would fly from the United States to Johannesburg.

"For such long flights, they use the tank which normally holds the chemicals...This tank is huge and the plane can fly for up to 12 hours," he said.

Surveillance equipment such as video cameras will be fitted by the buyer, Lewis said.

Asked to comment about Lewis' confirmation, Kriegler said: "I am telling you that is not true, you should wait until we make a statement." He would not say when exactly such a statement would be made.

But, according to Lewis, part of the amount involved has already been paid. He would not disclosed the exact figure or discuss the deal any further, saying that it was up to the customer - the IEC - to do so.

Reports from aviation experts suggest it would prove difficult for the IEC to sell all these aircraft after the election. They said the company had only been able to sell 19 of them in the 1984 to 1988 period.

Lewis said the company had sold about 800 since the planes went in to production in 1976. There were less than 10 of them in South Africa.

The buying of the planes was welcomed by the National Party's Daniel du Plessis, saying that "with the high level of intimidation for which members of the ANC, PAC, AWB and other radical organisations are responsible, any step will be welcomed by the National Party."

Reprinted from Sunday Nation.

SUNDAY NATION is published by New Nation Publishing Co. Contact: New Nation Publishing Co., P.O. Box 10674, Johannesburg 2000, South Africa, phone:(011) 333-2711. Fax:(011) 333-2733.


LOAD-DATE: March 29, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


95 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 15, 1994 / March 28, 1994


CORPORATE GROUP SEEKS TO 'PUT AFRICA BACK ON THE MAP';
Interview with Safi Quersehey, Chairman of The Corporate Council on Africa


SECTION: INTERVIEW


LENGTH: 814 words


 

The Corporate Council on Africa, launched late last year by a group of major American companies, was established to promote U.S. business investment in Africa. Founding members include Coca-Cola, General Motors, Mobil, Equator Bank and AST Research. Other leading members include a former assistant secretary of state for Africa, Chester Crocker; former U.S. ambassador to the United Nations Andrew Young; C. Payne Lucas, president of the Washington, D.C.-based development organization Africare; and David Miller, a senior White House official in the Bush administration. Chrysler joined the organization last month.

The council's board is chaired by Safi Qureshey, co-founder and chairman of AST Research, which has grown rapidly since its founding to 1980 to become currently the fourth largest computer company in the United States and the sixth in the world. Last year, the company took a big leap with the acquisition of Tandy's PC manufacturing operations. Qureshey, 42, is an engineer with degrees from both the University of Karachi in Pakistan and the University of Texas. 

Qureshey described the goals of the council in an interview, excerpted below:

AFRICANEWS: Is the Corporate Council on Africa primarily a grouping of companies already involved in Africa?

SQ: Some of our members have tremendous experience doing business in Africa. They have plants and operations in Africa. Then there are newer companies such as AST who are looking at Africa with an open mind. We're not just bringing in the companies that have interest in Africa.

This a group of companies looking at the 590 million people in Africa as a potential long-term market for American businesses. We want to expose Africa to other businesses, to educate the business community to the opportunities that exist there, despite all the negative news we read day in and day out. To be engaged over there and not get discouraged by the difficulties that any new market may represent. To put Africa back on the map.

People talk a lot about the former Soviet Union, but that market has not grown as well as expected, despite all the changes that have taken place. Africa has its own challenges, but its own potential. We believe the changes in South Africa can really turn around perceptions.

AN: And your company is taking a look at Africa for the first time?

SQ: We have been looking at Africa in the last couple of years. As the world is changing, Africa is changing, and we want to be engaged over there. Our involvement in the Corporate Council really is a way for finding out more, for playing a positive role in that part of the world also.

AST is a 14-year old company that has been in the fastest growing part of the computer industry. It has gone from three co-founders to 6,700 people around the globe. Besides looking at computers and their uses in North American market and European market, we are looking at some of the emerging markets such as China, where we do very well.

We are in the information tools business. A bank or a manufacturing company in Africa needs these tools to compete on a global basis. So as the world is changing, and economics is becoming more important, we believe we have something to offer to African businesses.

AN: What kind of reaction are you getting from the business community?

SQ: There is interest. It's a long-term process. It is a challenge to gain attention, because there's so much happening in other parts of the world. Africa has to compete for attention.

The reception from the current administration has been helpful -- Secretary (of Commerce, Ron) Brown coming to our inaugural event. He also took a trade delegation to South Africa, and I can imagine another trip to Africa. The Corporate Council will be active in hosting the business and political leaders coming from Africa and trying to introduce them to the business community over here.

The Corporate Council on Africa can be contacted at: 1666 Connecticut Avenue, NW Suite 510 Washington, DC 20009 Phone (202) 667-7330.

Africa News


March 29, 1994 / April 11, 1994


BUSINESS


LENGTH: 1054 words


 

The following procurement opportunities in Egypt are available to U.S. companies through the U.S. Agency for International Development.

The following procurement opportunities in Mozambique are available to U.S. companies through the U.S. Agency for International Development.

*Mogas, Diesel and other Petroleum Products. A.I.D. Geographic Code 935. Authority: CIP Number 656-0208. Purchasing Agent: Commercial Director, Petromoc, Praca D05, Trabalhadores, Caixa Postal 417, Maputo, Mozambique. Telex: 6-382 Petro Mo or 6-591 Petro Mo. Note: Petromoc, Maputo, Mozambique anticipates purchasing with USAID funds Gasoline, Diesel and other petroleum products over the next year in lots of 5,000 MT - 20,000 MT.

Africa News


March 29, 1994 / April 11, 1994


EDUCATION/TRAVEL


LENGTH: 2587 words


 

Education, Society and Learning in an African Context is a summer course in Zimbabwe from June 30 - August 7, 1994 sponsored by MSU's African Studies Center, Department of Teacher Education, and the Office of Overseas Study. For more information, contact: John Metzler at (517) 353-1700 or Anne Schneller at (517) 355-5522. Or write to the African Studies Center, 100 Center for International Studies and Programs, MSU, East Lansing, MI 48824-1035. E-mail: 21248JM@MSU.EDU.

The American University in Cairo is offering African Fellowships for two years of study toward an AUC Masters degree. Applicants from all disciplines are encouraged to apply. Contact: International Graduate Programs, Office of the Provost, American University in Cairo, P.O. Box 2511, 113 Kasr al Aini, Cairo, Egypt. 

The Center for Latin American Studies and the Center for African Studies invite junior and senior scholars to participate in an interdisciplinary program on Afro-American identity and cultural diversity in the Americas, including the Caribbean, Brazil, and the US, as well as areas of Africa. The program will enable visiting scholars to spend an year or a semester at the University of Florida to do research in this area. It will include studies of history, literature, religion, and popular culture. Each fellow will receive a maximum stipend of US$35,000 for the academic year, or half that for the semester. Applicants will be selected on a competitive basis related to their expertise and research in these areas. Candidates should submit a 100- word abstract, an essay of about 1,500 words detailing proposed research, a curriculum vitae, and two letters of recommendation. Send applications to Dr. Helen I. Safa, Center for Latin American Studies, University of Florida, P.O. Box 115530, Gainesville, FL 32611-5530; phone: (904) 392-0375; fax: (904) 392-7682.

The Council for Development of Social Science Research in Africa (CODESRIA) has a Small Grants Program for Thesis Writing to fund M.A. and Ph.D. candidates who are in the process of completing their theses. The funds will cover expenses in a country where research is conducted, but they will not cover the cost of travel to that country. For more information contact: Dr. Cyrus Reed, Office of African Studies, American University in Cairo, P.O. Box 2511, 113 Kasr al Aini, Cairo, Egypt.

The Modern Management Institute in Nairobi, Kenya offers a new home study method for learning Kiswahili, a language spoken in Kenya, Tanzania, Uganda, Malawi, Zambia, Zaire, Rwanda, Burundi, and the Sudan. The method includes a basic English/Kiswahili textbook for 24 lessons and audio cassettes to help with pronunciation. Contact: Geoffrey Njogu, Director of Studies, Modern Management Institute, P.O. Box 47390, Nairobi, Kenya; phone: (254.2) 33.17.02.

The Population-Environment Fellows Program, sponsored by U.S. AID and administered at the University of Michigan, sponsors Fellows for two-year appointments with overseas agencies. Fellows provide assistance and technical support for developing country institutions to foster a comprehensive approach to development. Fellows must hold a graduate degree in a relevant area and demonstrate expertise in both population and environment. Applications are reviewed on a rolling basis, but the sooner a completed application is received, the greater the availability of sites for which it can be considered. Inquiries and application requests may be obtained from: The Population-Environment Fellows Program, SPH II, Room M2240, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109-2029; phone: (313) 747-0222; fax: (313) 747-4947.

The University of Illinois-Egerton University Study Abroad Program allows undergraduates to spend eight weeks in Kenya this summer this summer. Participants will take courses at Egerton, tour various parts of the country, and live with Kenyan families in brief homestays. Contact: Center for African Studies, 210 International Studies Building, 910 South Fifth Street, Champaign, IL 61820; phone: (217) 333-6335.

The Economic Development Institute of the World Bank announces the 1994 cycle of the Robert S. McNamara Fellowship Program which aims at producing the highest quality research results in the general area of economic development. The program also seeks to achieve wide geographical and cultural diversity among fellows. The 12-month fellowship does not support work toward an advanced degree, but innovative and imaginative post-graduate research in areas of economic development. Contact: Robert S. McNamara Fellowship Program, Room M-4029, World Bank Headquarters, 1818 H. St., N.W., Washington, DC 20433.

The Centre for Refugee Studies at York University in Toronto offers an eight-week summer course on refugee affairs. The program will provide an overview of refugee issues, plus an opportunity to explore current topics with international experts. Participation is limited to 50 practitioners from inside and outside government who work with refugees or on refugee affairs and have a degree equivalent experience. Course dates are June 22-29, 1994. Contact: Dr. Tom Clark, Summer Course Coordinator, Centre for Refugee Studies, York University, Suite 322, York Lanes, 4700 Keele Street, North York, ON Canada M3J 1P3; phone: (416) 736-5837; fax: (416) 736-5837.

The SSRC-MacArthur Foundation Committee on International Peace and Security announces a program of small grants in 1994 allowing scholars and students of international relations to visit major universities and research centers outside their home region. Grants are intended for junior scholars who seek exposure to debates and scholarship on the changing international system and issues of international peace and security. Applications should be completed and returned to the Council, postmarked no later than JULY 15, 1994. Contact: Social Science Research Council, Visiting Scholar Fellowship Program on International Peace and Security, 605 Third Avenue, 17th Floor, New York, NY 10158.

The Library of Congess Junior Fellows Program:

African and Middle Eastern Division offers academic fellowships for juniors, seniors, and graduate students in a program designed to fit the interests of the fellows while serving the mission of the Library. Projects in the collection should be of interest in library science and African studies. Contact the Acting Chief, African and Middle Eastern Division, Library of Congress, Washington, DC 20540 or call the Junior Fellows Program Coordinator at (202) 707-4353.

University Research Expeditions Program at Berkeley organizes research expeditions in Africa. Upcoming expeditions include: The Palace of Savi (Benin); Traditional Music of East Africa (southern Uganda); and The View from Eritrea. No experience necessary. Scholarships are available for teachers and students. For more information and a free catalog, contact: University Research Expeditions Program Department D05, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720. Tel: (510) 642-6586.

Visions in Action offers one-year volunteer internships in urban areas of Kenya, Uganda, South Africa, Zimbabwe and Burkina Faso. Program areas include: development journalism, writing, project management, youth group organizing, community development, health care education, clinical assistance, women's and environmental issues, low-income housing, human rights, and scientific research. Interns are required to cover their costs. Total fees (including airfare) are about $5,500 per year. Interns receive a monthly stipend. Deadlines range from April 15 to October 15, depending on the country. For more information, contact: Visions in Action, 3637 Fulton Street NW, Washington, DC 20007. Tel: (202) 625-7403.

The Community Law Center in Durban, South Africa offers internship opportunities for law students and some undergraduates from outside South Africa. CLC is affiliated with the University of Natal, and places emphasis on assisting the rural areas of South Africa. CLC publishes a quarterly newsletter, Izindaba. Contact: The Community Law Center, Berea Center, 7th Floor, 247 Berea Road, Durban 4001, South Africa.

The Visiting Scholar Fellowship Program of the Social Science Research Council and the MacArthur Foundation Committee on International Peace and Security offers fellowships for young faculty in African institutions as well as journalists, public servants and lawyers to pursue innovative research at universities and major research centers outside their home areas. Contact Visiting Scholar Fellowship, International Peace and Security, 605 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10158. Tel: (212) 661-0280. Fax: (212) 370-7896. DEADLINE: JULY 15, 1994.

University of Minnesota, Minnesota Studies in International Development (MSID) offers academic year programs of internships and field study including 5 months in Senegal or Kenya. Financial aid is available. Details are available at the Center or through: MSID, The Global Campus, University of Minnesota, 106-M Nicholson Hall, 216 Pillsbury Drive, SE, Minneapolis, MN 55455-0138. Tel: (612) 625-3379.

The Center for Global Education announces a semester-long program in Namibia designed to introduce students to the central issues facing Southern Africa. Course credit may be earned. Applications and brochures are available from Center for Global Education, Augsburg College, 2211 Riverside Avenue, Minneapolis, MN 55454. Tel: (612) 330-1159.

The Knight International Press Fellowship Program will sponsor up to 25 fellows from the US each year to work with host institutions and news organizations that are seeking outside assistance. Specific criteria for fellowship applicants include: Outstanding personal and professional achievement in the journalistic arena or in any of the related technical, management and business aspects of a free press; a strong commitment to assist colleagues in other countries and a demonstrated ability to do so; a willingness to undertake challenging projects overseas for a period of one to nine months. Application DEADLINES are July 15 and November 15. Fellowships generally begin within four months after selection. To obtain an application packet, please send a faxed or mailed request to: The Center for Foreign Journalists, 11690-A Sunrise Valley Drive, Reston, VA 22091.

A study tour of South Africa from June 29-July 16, 1994 will investigate South Africa following the April elections. This tour is sponsored by the Southern Africa Education Program at Stony Point Center in New York. There will be meetings with key actors in the new government, political parties, representatives of non-governmental organizations and rural development groups. George Hauser and William Palmer are the organizers and leaders of the tour. Participation is limited to 15 people. There is a small scholarship fund which they hope to increase. For more information contact: William Palmer, Southern Africa Education Program, Stony Point Center, 17 Crickettown Rd., Stony Point, NY 10980. Phone: (914) 786-5072 or (518) 398-6586.

A special edition of "Research in African Literature" will be devoted to African Cinema. Please submit entries dealing with African film or African film criticism to Kenneth W. Harrow, Dept. of English, Morrill Hall, Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI 48824-1036. DEADLINE for submissions is JUNE 1, 1994.

A second volume of "Faces of Islam in African Literature" is going to appear. We are interested in papers that deal with Islam in African literature. Please send entries to Ken Harrow, Dept. of English, Morrill Hall, Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI 48824-1036 or to Rachid A. Hassani, Box 1257, Cambridge, MA 02238. DEADLINE for submissions is JUNE 1, 1994.

Gus J. Liebenow Fellowship at Indiana University is designed to recruit and provide assistance for an underrepresented minority student (U.S. citizen) who is interested in pursuing a Ph.D. at any school of Indiana University with a concentration in African Studies. Students in the program pursue degrees in their perspective major departments, with African Studies serving as an area specialization. For more information, contact Patrick O'Meara, Director, African Studies Program, Woodburn Hall 221, Indiana University, Bloomington, IN 47405. Phone: (812) 855-8284.

The United States Institute of Peace sponsors two all-expense paid summer seminars for educators. "International Peace, Security, and Conflict Management" is a summer institute for high school social studies teachers August 6-13, 1994 in Washington, DC. The DEADLINE for receipt of applications from social studies teachers is APRIL 15, 1994. For further information, contact: United States Institute of Peace, Education and Training Program, 1500 M Street, NW, Suite 700, Washington, DC 20005-1700. Phone: (202) 457-1700. Fax: (202) 429-6063. E-mail: msoley@usip.org.

EMPLOYMENT


LENGTH: 3920 words


 

Tiller's International offers a variety of workshops tailored to the needs of international rural innovators. Sessions feature hands-on activities, structured demonstrations, field trips and discussions. Workshops of particular interest include: Rural Development with Animal Power (May 24-28), Refining Animal Power Systems (June 20-July 29), and Low Cost Tools for Agriculture (August 16-20). A few scholarships are available for students of international development. Contact: Tiller's International, 5239 South 24th Street, Kalamazoo, MI 49008. Phone (616) 385-3233. Fax: (616) 385-2329.

The American Friends Service Committee has two openings in its Human Resources Dept. and on in the Office of the Executive Director.

HUMAN RESOURCES GENERALIST will handle recruitment and staffing, benefits counseling, staff relations, salary administration, training and affirmative action monitoring for an assigned area. Requires BA/BS, 5 years experience in Human Resources, and a demonstrated knowledge of all aspects of HRM. International recruitment experience preferred. 

ADMINISTRATIVE ASSISTANT will provide secretarial and administrative support for the Human Resources staff, including scheduling interviews and training activities, preparing reports, maintaining databases and files and other administrative tasks. Requires: high school diploma or equivalent, 3 years secretarial/administrative experience, proficiency on Word, Lotus or Quattro Pro. EXECUTIVE ASSISTANT TO THE EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR will assist the Executive Director in maintaining a wide range of relationships, managing the daily activities of the office, preparing and monitoring budgets, supporting the work of the Board and Corporation and providing general administrative support to the Executive Director. Requires: BA/BS or equivalent, 5-10 years administrative experience, proficiency in Word, Lotus or Quattro Pro, demonstrated ability to interact effectively at all levels of the organization and ability to handle multiple projects simultaneously.

TechnoServe, Inc. seeks Program Officer/Africa for its Norwalk, CT HQ. Responsibilities include: assisting the Regional Director with project management and evaluation, financial management, training and proposal development. Candidate should have 2+ years overseas experience in Africa in business and/or agricultural development, 3 years additional experience in Business Administration, Economics, Agriculture or relevant field experience. Excellent written and oral communication skills and French proficiency. Willingness to travel internationally (25-30%). Send resume and salary history to: Terri Scofield, Manager of Human Resources, TechnoServe, 49 Day Street, Norwalk, CT 06854 or Fax: (203) 838-6717.

Development/environment non-profit seeks a Communications Officer who will assist with evaluation of organizational communications needs' outreach to the federal government, Congress, the media, the international development community, and the public; preparation and dissemination of promotional materials. Candidates must have excellent writing skills and solid experience with Windows computer applications. Submit resume and writing samples to: Communications Director, ATI, 1828 L Street NW, Suite 1000, Washington, DC 20036.

International Action Against Hunger seeks the following:

HEALTH COORDINATOR, Northeast Somalia: Individual to be responsible for developing a health education curriculum to be used in PHC facilities and communities in northeast Somalia, training in use of the curriculum and oversight of its implementation. Works closely with PHC and community organization teams. Requires MPH or related degree, demonstrated skill in development of community-responsive curricula, commitment to participatory techniques, 2+ years experience.

COMMUNITY ORGANIZER, Northeast Somalia: Individual to be responsible for facilitating the support by local community of community-based health systems; assist in identifying those needs; facilitate activities with local NGOs. Requires relevant degree with 2+ years overseas community- based experience. Strong communications skills and ability to live and thrive in a challenging environment are necessary.

HEALTH EDUCATION SPECIALIST, Northeast Somalia: Individual to be responsible for developing a health education curriculum to be used in PHC facilities and communities in northeast Somalia, training in use of the curriculum and oversight of its implementation. Works closely with PHC and community organization teams. Requires MPH or related degree, demonstrated skill in development of community-responsive curricula, commitment to participatory techniques, 2+ years experience. Assignments generally for 6-12 months, with opportunity for renewal. Competitive compensation package. Mail/fax cover letter, resume and salary requirements to: AICF/USA, 815 15th Street NW, Suite 832, Washington, DC 20005. Fax: (202) 783-5247.

Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations has an opening for a SENIOR ECONOMIST (Marketing) in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia. This is a fixed term, 3-year position. QUALIFICATIONS: University degree in agricultural economics, preferably with postgraduate specialization in marketing, or a related field (such as agro-economy). Ten years of increasingly responsible professional experience in an international organization, government, private sector or research institution in agro-economic development. (An M.S. or equivalent advanced postgraduate degree in agricultural economics may be substituted for one year of the required experience, a Ph.D. or equivalent degree for two years of the required experience). Working knowledge of English (level C) or French or limited knowledge (level B) of the other. DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES: Under the supervision of the Director, Joint ECA (UN Economic Commission for Africa)/FAO Agriculture Division and the technical guidance of the Agricultural Services Division, to plan and coordinate the work of the Agricultural Marketing Section (ECA), and specifically, to: conduct analyses of the food and agricultural marketing situation in the region, including; developments in production, consumption, price policy, trade, distribution and demand, taking account of the Lagos Plan of Action, the Regional Food Plan for Africa and other regional programmes. Contact: Executive Officer, LNOR, Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, 1001 22nd Street, N.W., Suite 300, Washington, DC 20437

American Refugee Committee has the following positions available:

In Mozambique:

PUBLIC HEALTH PROFESSIONAL, to develop health program in coordination with the water and sanitation projects. Rural setting. Requires: MPH or RN, NP, PA, MD with strong public health background; proven success in design and implementation of new public health programs in developing countries; Portuguese, Spanish or French fluency. 1 year contract. Immediate opening. $1,500 a month.

WATER/SANITATION ENGINEER to monitor water points to assess water quantity and quality; provide logistical support; assist in rehabilitation and construction of wells. Qualifications: sanitation/ civil/environmental engineering degree; experience working overseas; experience with water protection and sanitation projects; construction and supervisory experience preferred; Portuguese, French or Spanish fluency. $1,500/month.

In Sudan:

MEDICAL DOCTOR to provide emergency relief to displaced persons in Kajo Keji County. RESPONSIBILITIES: set up emergency/acute care clinic and coordinate all in-patient and out-patient activities. REQUIREMENTS: MD with emergency/acute care experience in developing countries and proven success in implementing new programs in relief situations. 6 month commitment. $1,200/month.

TRADITIONAL BIRTH COORDINATOR to mobilize the communities to support and make use of the Traditional Birth Attendants; conduct training course to qualify participants to work as TBAs; and conduct supervisory visits to observe TBA participants. QUALIFICATIONS: RN or midwife with previous experience in a developing country; previous training experience. 6 month commitment., $1,200/month.

The Center for International Development and Environment of the World Resources Institute seeks individual with experience in natural resources management, institutions, and/or natural resource and policy activities in Africa, particularly national plans and strategies for sustainable development. Africa experience and excellent language competence in French required. Will be responsible for the coordination and implementation of the Center's activities in sustainable development planning in Africa. Will coordinate the Natural Resource Management Policy Consultative Group for Africa, with priority on an on-going study of sustainable development planning in 8 African countries. Position includes field work, analytical report writing, some policy research, and preparing workplans and budgets. Send resume to: Africa Program, CIDE/WRI, 1709 New York Avenue NW, Suite 700, Washington, DC 20006.

OIC International seeks a SMALL ENTERPRISE MANAGEMENT/DEVELOPMENT AND APPROPRIATE TECHNOLOGY SPECIALIST to provide technical assistance and training in value-added transformation and raw produce with the purpose of creating employment and economic development opportunities for unemployed youths and disadvantaged communities in African and other countries. The person will identify cottage industry and appropriate technologies adaptable to the client countries; develop curricula to train related entrepreneurial and technical skills to develop and manage such businesses. REQUIREMENTS: First degree in engineering followed by an MBA or equivalent education in Business Management; experience in related development work, and working experience in Africa in particular, first hand experience managing business and/or in appropriate technology development; fluent in English and French; knowledge of Spanish is advantageous. Travel required. Send resume: President and CEO, OIC International, 240 W. Tulpehocken Street, Philadelphia, PA 19144.

The Center for Wildlife Management in Kenya seeks a WILDLIFE RESOURCE MANAGER for a permanent full-time position of Resident Faculty. Resident Faculty live on site, lecture in an interdisciplinary, non- traditional, field-based learning environment and oversee student- directed research projects. Send detailed letter explaining relevant skills and experience, CV, and three references to Kenya Wildlife Resource Manager Search, The School for Field Studies, 16 Broadway, Beverly, MA 01915; phone: (508) 927-7777; fax: (508) 927-5127.

NURSE PRACTITIONER with experience in developing countries. To assist with EPI program.

These advisers will provide technical advice and management capabilities to the AID Mission to Kenya. Isaacs, Chairperson, Khanya Board of Trustees, c/o Peninsula Technikon, P.O. Box 1906, Bellville 7535, South Africa.

Aviation experience strongly preferred. Africa experience a plus. Send resume to: Personnel Dept., AirServ International, Box 3041, Redlands, CA 92373.

The International Rescue Committee operates refugee relief programs in over 20 countries worldwide and is seeking a PROCUREMENT ASSISTANT. Procurement for these programs involves complex communications and a vast network of international suppliers. Items procured range from vehicles and medical supplies to textbooks and tents. Based in New York, under the supervision of the Procurement Officer, individual will: develop and maintain a database of suppliers and resources; provide clerical support; purchase goods and prepare for shipment to overseas programs; maintain relations and communications with IRC's suppliers and agents; liaise between field offices and suppliers; assure that donor requirements are met. REQUIREMENTS: Undergraduate degree in a related field, excellent computer skills including database, WP51, spreadsheet and Lotus, previous work experience, strong organizational skills, and a team player. Send cover letter, resume and 3 references to: IRC, Recruitment Office, 386 Park Avenue South, New York, NY 10016. Tel: (212) 679-0010. Fax: (212) 689-3459.

Africare has an immediate opening for a population and family planning project manager. Project manager will be a counterpart to the manager of a local NGO implementing a family planning program funded by USAID and other donors. Candidates should possess: advanced degree with 5-10 years of professional experience in a health-related field; background in project management, especially in health-related development projects in Africa; demonstrated understanding of clinical training, health services delivery, marketing activities and HIS; excellent French; working knowledge of such computer programs as WordPerfect, Lotus 123, DBase 3, SPSS, etc. Send resume and salary history to: Ms. Carolyn Gullatt, Africare House, 440 R Street NW, Washington, DC 20001.

CARE seeks PROJECT COORDINATOR to manage all aspects of 2 agroforestry/forestry projects in rural NE Rwanda. S/he will live and work in the field, approximately 2 hours drive from the capital. Each project has 3 components: forestry, agroforestry and energy conservation. Main responsibilities include personnel management, budget control, procurement and inventory control, monitoring and evaluation of project progress towards goals, reporting, technical assistance to staff and counterparts, and maintain good relations with local counterparts and donors. QUALIFICATIONS: prefer graduate degree in agriculture or agroforestry. 3+ years relevant experience management or playing a key role in agricultural development projects, preferably with peasant farmers in Africa. Very good spoken and written French and English.

RTA MONITOR (Rwanda) to provide technical assistance and advice in the area of monitoring and evaluation to country offices in the East African region. QUALIFICATIONS: Masters degree in a development related field or equivalent experience; 5 years overseas work experience (preferably in East Africa) with an emphasis on monitoring and evaluation. Proven consulting skills essential. French, Arabic or Swahili desired.

CONSULTANT (Rwanda) to assess project accomplishments of stated objectives, assess sustainability of project interventions, assess the role and effectiveness of participating institutions and project relationships to these institutions, asses project management and use of funds/materials, recommend actions for Phase III, and designate tasks and project relationship to these institutions. QUALIFICATIONS: French and English competencies; project management experience in Africa; forest management expertise; excellent writing skills; leadership qualities; coordination and facilitation skills; knowledge of agroforestry interventions. Experience with NGOs; understanding of community participation and organization, agroforestry and agriculture extension systems.

PROJECT MANAGER (Mali) to have overall responsibility for the planning implementation, monitoring and evaluation of the Timbuktu Rural Development (TRD) Project. Individual will work closely with national staff technicians, government authorities, the CARE-Mali country office, and NGO partners working in Timbuktu region. QUALIFICATIONS: 5+ yrs overseas experience managing a development program; 2+ yrs with CARE; university degree in agriculture, natural resources, social sciences, management or international relations; excellent French and English; strong team building skills; self-starter, full of initiative.

For CARE positions, send resume to: Jeanette Nance Frett, International Recruiter, CARE, 151 Ellis St., Atlanta, GA 30303. Fax: (404) 577-9418.

The University Research Corporation/The Center for Human Services is currently recruiting an Associate Director for Administration. Responsibilities will include work planning, activities coordination, monitoring work in progress, and financial and contract management. VOLUNTEER OPPORTUNITIES


LENGTH: 974 words


 

Health Volunteers Overseas has several openings for

health care providers who wish to aid its programs in the following nations:

TRANSKEI (one-month assignments; April-December 1994): Participants needed to teach anesthesia at Umtata General Hospital to physicians-in-training. Volunteers will also provide direct anesthesia care. Housing on hospital grounds is provided for the volunteer at no cost. Contact Dr. Kevin Speight, (919) 716-4498/(919) 454-3956 or Spence Campbell (704) 696-9930. 

UGANDA (one-month assignments; May-December 1994):

Volunteers participate in the only anesthesia training program in Uganda. Most of the teaching takes place in Kampala's Mulago Hospital. Housing provided at the guest house at Makerere University. Contact Dr. Harry Zutz, (908) 381-4200/(201) 378-3323.

MALAWI (two-month assignments, one month considered; The School of Health Sciences in Lolongwe is the site for a program providing education support in the areas of diagnosing dental and oral pathoses, performing conservative dentistry, periodontics, uncomplicated dental extractions and preventive dentistry. This program is soliciting 3 volunteers a year with a one month hiatus between volunteers. Contact: Dr. Dick Nieusma, (402) 472-9846. For a more detailed description of each site as well as copies of trip reports from previous volunteers, contact Health Volunteers Overseas, c/o Washington Station, P.O. Box 65157, Washington, DC 20035-5157; phone: (202) 296-0928.

The American Medical Team for Africa (AMTA) promotes and executes educational exchange and medical training in African countries. The goal of the non-profit organization is to bring volunteer doctors, nurses and medical students together with donated supplies, and equipment to serve needs on the continent. Survey teams assess the most pressing needs in targeted countries, develop and publish training manuals in appropriate languages, hold workshops and refresher courses for doctors, nurses and specialists interested in maintenance of health care delivery systems in Africa; and distribute medical supplies and equipment donated by corporations, pharmaceutical companies, hospitals and doctors. The AMTA plans a second medical mission to Africa. For more information, contact Deman Rageh, Executive Director, The American Medical Team for Africa, 2245 Godby Road, Atlanta, GA 30349; phone (404) 766-8000; fax: (404) 767-5264.

Private Voluntary Organization in Rosslyn needs an experienced Agribusiness/Marketing Specialist to fill a 3-year Chief of Party position in Mali. The candidate must have at least 10 years of proven experience in the field of Agribusiness, Marketing, Credit and Procurement (preferably of fruits & vegetables). Must have related job experience in developing country with hands-on experience and an MBA. Strong training skills in the areas of agribusiness and marketing required. Fluency in French/English (FSI , S-3, R03) a must. Interested candidates must submit a resume, a certification of foreign language capability, and a standard AID bio-data form. Please mail original copies to: Regina Wynn, VITA, 5th floor, Arlington, VA 22209. Tel: (703) 276-1800 or fax: (703) 2143-1865.

CUSO currently has the following openings:

NIGERIA and TOGO: Individual for each country to provide field support to cooperants and play a lead role in coordinating and developing alliances between Canada and West Africa, through the cooperant program. A degree in social sciences, adult education or community development; 3 yrs. experience in program development and management; and overseas living experience in a similar socio-political environment is required. Experience related specifically to West Africa is desired. SIERRA LEONE: CUSO and a variety of local partner organizations require the shared services of one fund-raiser and a university degree and a minimum of 2 yrs. work experience in fundraising and administration with a nongovernmental organization.

NIGERIA: The Cooperative Federation of Nigeria (CFN), a national non- governmental organization, requires a person with training in social sciences, adult education or community development, and 2 years experience with cooperatives, to contribute to the training of their members.

MOZAMBIQUE: The national environmental division of the Government of Mozambique requires a person with a degree in social sciences/ environmental studies and 5 years experience in program management, training and gender analysis to coordinate the development of an environmental management program. TO APPLY: send resume to Cooperant Programming Unit, CUSO GE-19, 135 Rideau Street, Ottawa ON K1N 9K7. Postings are for two years. Salaries are modest, but cover overseas living costs. Transportation and benefits are provided.

SECTION: DIRECTORY


LENGTH: 1440 words


 

April

"Modern Days, Ancient Nights: the 2nd New York African Film Festival"

For more information, contact: Lincoln Center, 165 West 65th Street, New York, NY 10023-6595. Phone: (212) 875- 5600.

11

Ten-part series produced by Africa News and NPR

Mondays, starting April 11

Tune in to National Public Radio on Mondays through June for a special series of reports on Africa in the post- Cold War world.

Produced jointly by Africa News Service and NPR, the reports will air on the 90-minute afternoon news magazine, All Things Considered, during the second half hour, between 5:30 and 6:00 pm in most areas. 

Reporting teams from Africa News and NPR have traveled to East, West and southern Africa to explore the challenges facing the continent, including achieving food self- sufficiency, resettling refugees, demobilizing armies, and expanding the voice and participation of women.

Be sure to let NPR know your reaction to the series. Direct your comments to:

All Things Considered

635 Massachusetts Avenue

Washington, D.C. 20001-3753

and/or

NPR

(202) 414-2000

Underwriters for the project include: The Coca-Cola Company, the Ford Foundation, New Africa Advisers, Rodale Press, Pan Africa-U.S.A. International Track Meet, South African Airways, the CarEth Foundation and the Corporation for Public Broadcasting.
