105 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 29, 1994 / April 11, 1994


SUDANESE REFUGEES IN BATTLE WITH NGO


BYLINE: Lillian Nsubuga


LENGTH: 614 words


 

THE MONITOR, March 22-25, 1994

Sudanese refugees have accused officials of InterAid Uganda of sparking a riot in Kiryangongo Settlement Camp by withholding food for over three months.

Angry refugees visited 'The Monitor' last week and spoke of their months of hunger. They claim not to have received any of the tons of food which were ferried to the camp by InterAid, an NGO which deals with the refugees on behalf of the United Nations High Commission (UNHCR). To survive, they have had to do odd jobs for local villagers in return for one or two pieces of cassava. 

On February 19, the refugees rioted. "We broke into the food store because we were starving. Our food was in the store," the refugees told 'The Monitor'.

The refugees believe that the InterAid Programme Coordinator, Andrew Hatch, colluded with the Camp Commandant, Joseph Oketch, to deny them food, although they are unable to substantiate their claim.

The riot marked the beginning of war between the refugees and InterAid officials. The refugees claim that on February 20, Mr. Hatch threw out all the patients in the dispensary. A patient, Wengish Onena, died which fuelled anger against the officials.

The refugees said that Hatch also closed the feeding centre, the water system and the grinding mill.

Although the dispensary was later re-opened, it has no drugs or doctors. "The water system is the only facility we have left but InterAid have also threatened to stop it if we continue refusing to work with then," the refugees said.

The grinding mills have been closed since February 19 which means that camp residents can't make posho from the maize that they have recently received. "We now cook the maize and eat it just like that," a spokesperson said.

The refugees were also angered by the policemen who were sent in to quell the riot; "They went from house to house, recovering the good, beating up people and looting our property."

Twenty refugees were rounded up for spearheading the riot. According to the refugees who visited 'The Monitor,' Camp Commander Oketch has told them their friends will only be released if they accept InterAid back.

The InterAid Director, Suzan Wong, criticized the refugees fro making false accusations against Andrew Hatch: "They wanted to make the most out of the assistance given so they came up with lies".

Wong said that InterAid Uganda held discussions with government, UNHCR, and the refugees last week.

Reprinted from THE MONITOR, March 22-25, 1994. THE MONITOR is published by The Monitor Publications, Ltd., P.O. Box 12141, Kampala Uganda. Tel: 23-69-39. Fax: 25-13-52.


LOAD-DATE: April 19, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


106 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 29, 1994 / April 11, 1994


THE POOR GET EVEN POORER


BYLINE: Andrew Whiteford


LENGTH: 1094 words


 

THE WEEKLY MAIL & GUARDIAN, March 11-17, 1994

South Africa still has the most unequal distribution of income among countries for which national household income data is available, according to a recent study by the Human Sciences Research Council and the University of Natal.

This contradicts the conventional wisdom that the income gap between rich and poor households is diminishing.

The most common measure of income inequality is the "Gini coefficient". Simply put, in this measure perfect equality equals zero and perfect inequality equals one. South Africa, with a Gini coefficient of 0,68, heads the list of 36 developing countries. Jamaica, Bahamas and Brazil are next, while Taiwan is at the bottom of the list with a Gini of 0,28. 

In 1991 the poorest 40 percent of households in South Africa earned a mere four percent of the total income earned by South Africans: the richest 10 percent earned more than a half.

That South Africa's income gap has not changed between 1975 and 1991 seems to contradict intuitive observations of black advancement.

The answer to this apparent paradox lies in the changes in incomes among specific sectors within population groups. The richest 20 percent of black households have increased real average incomes by almost 40 percent over the period, making them the most upwardly mobile race group, as black professionals, skilled workers and entrepreneurs benefited from the erosion of apartheid.

At the same time rising unemployment and several seasons of severe drought have decreased the incomes of the poorest 40 percent of black households by around 40 percent.

The poorest 40 percent of the white population have also seen their incomes drop by a percentage similar to that of the poorest 40 percent of blacks. The incomes of the richest 20 percent of whites, however, have stayed the same.

This widening of the income gap among black s and whites has meant the overall gap between rich and poor is as wide as ever -- but the divide is no longer exclusively based on race. In 1975 less than 10 percent of the richest 20 percent of households were black. In 1991 this figure has risen to 26 percent.

The Gini coefficient of the black population group increased from 0,47 to 0,62 between 1975 and 1991, indicating an alarming increase in inequality within black society.

The Gini of the white population rose from 0,36 to 0,46 over the same period. This is in light of whites having a mean income and occupations similar to most first world societies, which have an average Gini of 0,39.

The Gini coefficients of the coloured and Asian communities remained fairly constant at 0,52 and 0,49 respectively.

The main reason for inequality in South Africa is inequality within population groups. Almost three quarters of total inequality can be ascribed to inequality within population groups. The remaining quarter is caused by inequality between groups.

Between 1975 and 1991 population growth outstripped income growth so that the average South African household income decreasing from about R30,000 to R26,000 in 1991 rands. Despite this, a quarter of households managed to increase their incomes over the period.

While the incomes of the richest 20 percent of black households increased, the incomes of almost all Asian households and 80 percent of coloured households rose.

The black share of total income has risen because of the big increase in the incomes of the richest black households. It is still comparatively small. The 1991 household census indicates blacks earned 28 percent of total income, through they constitute 75 percent of the population.

Whites, on the other had, comprise 13 percent of the population yet earn 61 percent of total income. Coloureds earn seven percent and Asians four percent of total income.

The disparity between whites and blacks is further illustrated by the average income of a white household being 12 times greater than the average income of a black household. In 1991 that figure had not changed from the figure in 1960, although it rose to 15 during the high growth years of the 1960s when whites enjoyed virtually all the benefits of economic growth

The 1960s saw a huge gap develop between the incomes of whites and blacks: the 1980s has seen a similar gap emerging within the black population group.

The gap between black and white incomes has certainly contributed to the social and political turmoil in South Africa over the past decade and more. The emerging income gap between rich and poor blacks may now threaten the survival of a democratically elected government, in the same way the reaction to the white- black income gap undermined apartheid

This is reason enough for reduction of income inequality to become, or remain, a priority in shaping South Africa's economic development policies.

Reprinted from THE WEEKLY MAIL & GUARDIAN, March 11-17, 1994. THE WEEKLY MAIL & GUARDIAN is published by M&G Media Contact: M&G Media, 139 Smit Street, Breamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025.


LOAD-DATE: April 19, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


107 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 29, 1994 / April 11, 1994


KINGIBE: WE CALLED IN THE ARMY


LENGTH: 1254 words


 

NEWSWATCH, April 4, 1994

Dear Member of Congress,

It has come to my attention that Chief M.K.O. Abiola has urged the US Congress to consider several actions concerning Nigeria including the adoption of H.R. Res 151. I regard the adoption of H.R. Res 151 as unfortunate and unnecessary. I am deeply concerned about the wisdom and appropriateness of the current restrictions against Nigeria and cannot begin to understand the basis for any further US actions whether the proposed actions are symbolic or otherwise.

As I am sure you are aware, prior to assuming the office of Minister of Foreign Affairs, I was the Vice Presidential candidate on the same ticket with Chief Abiola, the Presidential candidate election in convention by the Social Democratic Party. Chief Abiola and I contested and won the June 12, 1993 election. You probably are also aware that former Head of State, General Babangida annulled the June 12, 1993 election and stepped down on August 26, 1993. 

The events surrounding the June annulment of the election caused significant upheaval and chaos. An unelected Interim National Government was installed led by Chief E.A. Shonekan. Chief Shonekan did not command the support and the mandate of the people of Nigeria, and was unable to secure the endorsement of any section of Nigerian society and accordingly was clearly unable to govern. Besides the irretractable political deadlock, the national was paralysed by daily civil disturbances, threats of disintegration and ethnic clashes during October 1993. By the end of October 1993, it was obvious that there was a clear and present danger to the continued existence of a united Nigeria. This instability posed a very serious risk to our national security and the stability of the entire sub-region.

In view of these developments, the widest possible spectrum of Nigerians, increasingly concluded that direct intervention was the only way to stop the drift and create an enabling environment for the resumption of the democratisation process. Chief Abiola and myself were among those who endorsed and actively canvassed for this military crisis with various military caucuses, including General Sani Abacha and his present deputy, General Diya. We were never assured that such an intervention would have restored the annulled June 12 Presidential election.

Following the collapse of the Shonekan government, all of us who fought for democracy and the restoration of the June 12 election met with Chief Abiola on November 21 at his home to consider our reaction to the new development. There were a few vocally expressed dissenting views, including Chief Abiola's, but the overwhelming majority decided that we should cooperate with and participate in the new government if invited to join. At the conclusion of the meeting, Chief Abiola stated that anyone who wished to participate in the new government should feel free to serve if invited.

It was on this basis and after extensive consultation that I decided to accept the position of foreign minister. Dr. Onagoruwa, a frontline human fights activist, was also encouraged by his human rights organisation to accept the offer of Attorney-General. It should also be noted that other prominent members of the Abiola-Kingibe team have also offered their support of this government including Dr. Jonathan Zwingina, Chief Abiola's Presidential Campaign Coordinator, the party's staunch publicists and strategists such as Lateef Jakande, Ebenezer Babatope, Jim Nwobodo, Abubakar Rimi, Solomon Lar, and many other have joined this government.

I value my long service to the democratic renewal process in Nigeria. I was the executive secretary of the Constituent Assembly which reviewed the constitution of Nigeria in 1989 and was subsequently elected Chairman of the Social Democratic Party. While I had a personal interest in upholding of the election results, I like other democrats with impeccable credentials in General Abacha's government, accepted to serve because I felt that given the circumstances, the interest of the country takes precedence over everything else, including my personal ambition. We also believe that we should be in the best position to push the democratic agenda forward from within the government.

We are very pleased to say that the actions we have taken since November 1993 have nevertheless, succeeded in claiming passions and in actively working towards complete national unity. It has restored full freedom of the press and provided opportunity for serious national dialogue. We envision that through the Constitutional Conference, our people will design a clear direction for building a truly united nation as well as prepare the electoral calendar to end military rule. The inauguration of the National Commission on Constitutional Conference represents a concrete step in the democratic process. The Commission has already concluded its report on the modalities for convening the conference and public option supports these measures as lively debate on the political future of the nation is underway throughout the nation. Notwithstanding press reports to the contrary, the Constitutional Conference is going forward and will aid in the complete unification of our great nation.

I appreciate the keen interest in the democratic renewal in Nigeria demonstrated by the American people and their representatives in Congress and the Administration. Our government is doing all it can do to create a conducive atmosphere for dialogue and better understanding of our difficulties, hopes and aspirations. Once the programme of activities for the Constitutional Conference are announced, it should show sufficient commitment to the democratisation process.

Finally, I fully appreciate the support of the United States for the continued unity of the Federal Republic of Nigeria as an indivisible nation. Nigeria deserves the support of the American Congress, business community and other informed sectors of American society.

Signed:

Baba Gana Kingibe

21st March, 1994

Reprinted from Newswatch, April 4, 1994. Newswatch is published weekly by Newswatch Communications Limited, No. 3 Billings Way, Oregun Industrial Estate, Oregun, P.M.B. 21499, Lagos, Nigeria.


LOAD-DATE: April 19, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


108 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 29, 1994 / April 11, 1994


ABIOLA: ABACHA ENTICED MY SUPPORTERS


LENGTH: 880 words


 

NEWSWATCH, April 4, 1994

The President, The Secretary of State, Members of Congress

My Dear Fellow Statesmen and Stateswomen:

It gives me great pleasure to deliver this message to you to let you know that thanks to the Almighty God, I am alive and well. The struggle to actualise the Nigerian people's decision, taken at the election of June 12th, 1993, has been tough and fraught with danger. But in leading it, I am strengthened by the knowledge that we have the unflinching support of the political leadership of the democratic world, led by the United States. I thank you for the noble part you have played in this effort and humbly enjoin you not to relent in your efforts until the battle is won and the Nigerian people are allowed to install the government of their own choice. 

I would like you to know that the people of Nigeria have totally rejected General Abacha's military regime. All they want is to be given the opportunity to rule themselves like you do in the United States. On June 12, 1993, they voted as President, a man who presented them with a programme entitled "Farewell to poverty." They want this programme to be implemented so that they can move forward with confidence into the twenty first century. General Abacha thought he could confuse the people of Nigeria and let them forget their desire for democracy, by doing tow things as soon as he seized power on November 17, 1993.

First, instead of handing over the government to me, the elected president, he instead enticed some of my supporters into his government, including my vice- president-elect, Mr. Kingibe, who was made foreign minister. But the Nigerian people realised that what he had done was like someone ignoring president-elect Bill Clinton's victory, capriciously annulling the 1992 Presidential election and proceed to form a "government" with the then Chairman of joint chiefs of staff in charge of it as "Head of State," and inviting vice-president- elect Al Gore to become secretary of state in that government in an effort to achieve legitimacy and "acknowledgment."

This ludicrous act of staging "Hamlet Without the Prince" has been roundly condemned as an insult to the intelligence of all Nigerians. Accordingly, it must also be rejected in its entirety by all people who love democracy everywhere.

Secondly, General Abacha tried to throw dust into the eyes of Nigerians by proposing to hold a constitutional conference. (Nigeria has an excellent constitution, written in 1989, which has never been tried.) This proposal has been rejected as a waste of time by the intellectuals, human rights organisations, the trade unions, the students, the market women, and the masses of the Nigerian people. They see Abacha's constitutional conference proposal as nothing more than a dangerous ruse which could open a Pandora's Box that could lead Nigeria into untold bloodshed.

Even if a new constitution is promulgated, there can never be another election under it until the June 12 election is actualised. Many of the electors destroyed their registration cards in exasperation when the military annulled the June 12 election. And they have sworn to boycott any new registration, and to ensure that if their votes are regarded as of no consequence, they too will never allow anyone else's votes to count either.

World opinion must force Abacha to allow elected officials to return to their position without further delay. Otherwise, Nigeria is in for a long period of dictatorship, contrary to any claims by Abacha's highly paid public relations consultants and apologists at work in the United States.

Finally, we urge your continued support of House Concurrent Resolution 151, introduced by Congressman Payne (D-NJ) in the version recently passed by the House Foreign Affairs, Africa Subcommittee. This would be of tremendous help toward the transition of power to the people's choice as president, in order to begin the long and difficult journey to economic stability and true democracy for Nigeria.

Yours in the service of democracy,

Bashorun M.K.O. Abiola

President-elect, The Federal Republic of Nigeria

Reprinted from Newswatch, April 4, 1994. Newswatch is published weekly by Newswatch Communications Limited, No. 3 Billings Way, Oregun Industrial Estate, Oregun, P.M.B. 21499, Lagos, Nigeria.


LOAD-DATE: April 19, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


109 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 29, 1994 / April 11, 1994


PARTING OF WAYS


BYLINE: Nats Agbo


LENGTH: 1987 words


 

NEWSWATCH, April 4, 1994

At about 10 A.M. March 10, the office of the minister of foreign affairs, Baba Gana Kingibe, received an urgent message from the Nigerian embassy in Washington DC. It was brief: Switch on the fax machine for an important document. The document was faxed to the office at about 11.24 a.m. It was a one page letter, June 12 Must Stand, addressed to the president of the United States, his secretary of state and members of the US Congress. The letter was written buy Moshood Abiola and published also in "Roll Call", which is said to be a newspaper published in Capitol Hill and is widely read by members of Congress, for a wider public consumption. However it looks like a newsletter published by lobbyists.

Abiola, presidential candidate of the Social Democratic Party, SDP, in the June 12 presidential election last year, is canvassing American support to force the head of state, General Sani Abacha, to relinquish power to him. The letter, diplomatic sources in Abuja told "Newswatch" last week, was part of Abiola's campaign abroad to undermine the federal military government in his quest for power snatched from within his grasp when the presidential election which he is believed to have won, was annulled by the former president, General Ibrahim Babangida. 

Abiola urged the Americans not to waver in their support for his presidential ambition "until the battle is won and the Nigerian people are allowed to install the government of their own choice." He said that "the people of Nigeria have totally rejected General Abacha's regime," adding, that the head of state thought that "he could confuse the people of Nigeria and let them forget their desire for democracy," Abiola who referred to himself as president-elect told the Americans that contrary to expectations, when Abacha seized power November 17 last year and sacked the interim national government headed by Ernest Shonekan, he refused to hand over the government to him but instead "enticed" some of his supporters "into his government, including my vice- president elect" in order to "achieve legitimacy and acknowledgment."

Abiola has once again predicted bloodshed in the country, this time after the constitutional conference. The first time he predicted bloodshed for Nigeria was when he went abroad to campaign for sanctions against the country in the wake of the annulment of the presidential election. He had predicted then that if he was not sworn in as president on the departure of Babangida August 27, a combination of what was happening in Somalia and Bosnia would be a child's play compared to what would happen in Nigeria. He described the constitutional conference as an attempt by the government "to throw dust into the eyes of Nigerians." Abiola also claimed that the conference had "been rejected as a waste of time by the intellectuals, human rights organisations, the trade unions, the students, the market women and the masses of the Nigerian people." He said there was nothing wrong with the 1989 constitution which had not been tried. He went on: "Even if a new constitution is promulgated, there can never be another election under it until the June 12 election is actualised." There must be sustained pressure to force out Abacha, he said, otherwise, the military would institute "a long period of dictatorship" in Nigeria.

Abiola asked the president and the Congress men and women to continue to support the House of Concurrent Resolution 151 introduced by congressman Payne and passed by the house foreign affairs, Africa sub-committee. The resolution proposed stiffer economic and other sanctions against Nigeria. Abiola said their support for the resolution "would be a tremendous help toward the transition of power to the people's choice as president, in order to begin the long and difficult journey to economic stability and true democracy for Nigeria."

"Newswatch" spoke on phone with an American in Washington DC who identified himself as Randall Echols who said he had been working for "the president-elect Abiola" on the Hill for some time now. He confirmed that the letter was written by Abiola and that it was published in "Roll Call". "Newswatch" has learnt that Abiola has a number of lobbyists working for him on the Hill. They issue periodic newsletters to Congress on Abiola"s struggle for power.

"Newswatch" gathered that Abacha was shown the letter and he instructed Kingibe to prepare an appropriate response "to counter Abiola's propaganda." In his response dated March 21, Kingibe debunked Abiola's story. He described the letter to the Americans as "unfortunate and unnecessary." Kingibe went on to argue that it would be unwise for the US Congress to consider further sanctions against Nigeria because "the wisdom and appropriateness of the current restrictions" are questionable.

Kingibe, in what was obviously his first major public comment on the Abacha coup, confirmed it was staged with the support and connivance of the politicians. He admitted they invited the military to take-over the government once more because opposition to Shonekan had made it impossible for him to rule and the political crisis was deepening. He said when it became obvious that the Interim National Government, ING, no longer commanded the acceptance of Nigerians, most political leaders "concluded that direct military intervention was the only way to stop the drift and create an enabling environment for the resumption of the democratisation process." He said that he and Abiola canvassed for military intervention and discussed this with various military officers including Abacha and Oladipo Diya, the chief of general staff, CGS. Said he: "We were never assured that such an intervention would have restored the annulled June 12 presidential election." He explained that after the collapse of the ING, people "who fought for democracy and the restoration of the June 12 election met with Abiola on November 21 where it was decided that they "should cooperate with and participate in the new government to join if invited." He claimed also that Abiola stated during the meeting "that anyone who wished to participate in the new government should feel free to serve if invited."

Kingibe said it was on the basis of this agreement that he, along with Olu Onagoruwa, a human right activist, Jonathan Zwingina, who was Abiola"s campaign coordinator and other prominent supporters of the Abiola- Kingibe ticket including Jim Nwobodo, Abubakar Rimi, Ebenezer Babatope and Lateef Jakande joined the Abacha government. He said those who chose to serve did so because "the interest of the country takes precedence over everything else, including my personal ambition. We believe that we should be in the best position to push the democratic agenda forward from within the government."

On Abiola's opposition to the proposed constitutional conference, the minister said such opposition was unfounded. He said the expectation of Nigerians was that the conference would "design a clear direction for building of a truly united nation as well as prepare the electoral calendar to end military rule." Assuring that the military government is bent on creating the enabling environment for dialogue on Nigeria's problems and aspirations, Kingibe added: "Nigeria deserves the support of the American Congress, business community and other informed sectors of the American society."

In his reaction to Kingibe's letter, Abiola told "Newswatch" that he was surprised that a confidential letter between friends could find its way into the news media. He promised to give a detailed reply to it this week. He, however, denied that he approved of the military take-over or the appointments of Kingibe and other leading members of the SDP into Abacha"s cabinet. He admitted that he was with Abacha on the night of the coup but denied submitting a list of ministerial nominees to him. Said he: "When I was about to leave, Abacha asked me what I thought of his appointing Kingibe into his cabinet. I laughed. Kingibe never mentioned anything to me about his being considered for appointment until it was announced. He then came to my house to apologise to me. He told me that while waiting for June 12, some of them were finding it difficult to maintain their homes. I expected him to stand by me or resign. He didn't. Disbanding the political parties has nothing to do with the mandate given to me on June 12."

Abiola maintained that at the meeting of SDP leaders in his house after the coup, all of the agreed to stand by June 12. "I am a democrat. If they had said June 12 was dead, I would have abided by their decision. But nobody said so," Abiola said. He told "Newswatch" he believed Kingibe took up his appointment to maintain his family. "Democrats see him as a turncoat. In the politics of poverty that we have in this country, some people will rather rule in hell than serve in heaven" Abiola said.

He maintained his stand on June 12 and wondered how anyone would expect him to support Abacha. "It is rubbish. Abacha's government is not a legal government. It is another contraption like the interim national government. I abide by the mandate of my supporters. I am not part of the cabal that wants the military. Military government is a form of slavery for Nigeria. My position on this is clear. But if they call for a dialogue, I am prepared," Abiola concluded.

The letter was delivered to each member of Congress by the Nigerian embassy in Washington. "Newswatch" gathered that the federal government would intensify its lobby to prevent the Congress from "being taken in" by Abiola. Foreign ministry officials said last week that the letters would destroy whatever links existed between Abiola and Kingibe, his former running mate. Said the source: "It was never hidden, the animosity between the two men as a result of the presidential nomination which Abiola won. This will be the final break between them."

Reprinted from Newswatch, April 4, 1994. Newswatch is published weekly by Newswatch Communications Limited, No. 3 Billings Way, Oregun Industrial Estate, Oregun, P.M.B. 21499, Lagos, Nigeria.


LOAD-DATE: April 19, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


110 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


March 29, 1994 / April 11, 1994


LIBERIA: AFRICANS SHOW UN HOW TO PROMOTE PEACE


BYLINE: Cindy Shiner


LENGTH: 1094 words


 

AFRICA NEWS SERVICE

On a continent better known for famines and failures than for successes, Africans may finally have something to boast about.

A low-budget peacekeeping force composed of soldiers from eight other troubled African countries appears to be showing the United Nations a thing or two about stopping war. The success of the force that is bringing peace to this West African nation after four years of civil war could serve as an example for other trouble spots where U.N.-dominated operations have foundered, observers say.

"If you look at all the dismal flops in Somalia, Angola, Yugoslavia and elsewhere, it might be heartening to see some hope," said one diplomat, who asked not to be named. 

Russia has already looked at the African peacekeeping model for ways to settle the conflict in the former Soviet republic of Georgia, said Trevor Gordon- Somers, the Jamaican-born U.N. special envoy to Liberia who has been brokering the peace process with a stubborn determination that has won him few friends.

Although the U.N. is backing the operation, it was the 15,000 African peacekeepers who enforced the U.N. embargo against rebel leader Charles Taylor in November 1992 and defeated him on the battlefield under the leadership of a series of Nigerian generals.

The African peacekeeping force, backed by about 360 U.N. military observers, began disarming Liberia's fighters two weeks ago in line with a peace accord the factions signed last July to end the fighting that has claimed 150,000 lives. In addition, a new transitional ruling council representing a spectrum of political and ethnic groups was inaugurated and a transitional legislature installed.

However, problems remain. The factions have yet to agree on choices to head the government's four key ministries -- finance, foreign affairs, justice and defense -- and the political impasse is slowing disarmament. Two weeks after fighters began handing in their weapons, only about 1,500 soldiers out of an estimated 45,000 have been demobilized. Most belong to Taylor's National Patriotic Front.

In addition, splinter groups of fighters have emerged from each of the three factions that signed the peace accord. Taylor has manipulated the attacks, portraying himself as the innocent victim, a move that could win him support at the ballot box in presidential elections scheduled for September.

After an eight-month advance on the capital, Taylor had nearly tasted victory in 1990. The rebel leader sat for a month across the street from the presidential mansion, but was unable to deliver a final blow.

"This war was prolonged when the decision was taken that Charles Taylor had to be stopped by the West African community because taking power would mean instability in the West African region," Taylor complained to reporters recently. "I was...waiting to take Monrovia within hours when I was asked to cease fire."

Now recent positive developments have bolstered the nation's hope that the fighting -- which was marked by two particularly heinous massacres of groups of 600 and 700 civilians and the slaughter of five American nuns -- will soon end.

With the backing of the Economic Community of West African States, the peacekeepers installed an interim government. It ruled over a relatively calm but bullet- scarred Monrovia -- until Taylor attacked the capital in October 1992, reigniting the war and drawing the peacekeepers into battle.

The regional force was recently reinforced with troops from Tanzania and Uganda, largely to appease Taylor who has refused to give up his weapons to the Nigerians because of their country's longstanding ties to Doe.

But the peacekeepers have been able to step in where Western observers failed. For example, when a power struggle within the leadership of one of the factions appeared to threaten disarmament, the peacekeepers and local elders cam e together to resolve the dispute.

"It shows that we cannot continue to depend on the United Nations," said Nigerian Maj. Gen. John Inienger, the peacekeeping field commander. "There is more cohesiveness."

Observers, however, note that the peacekeeping effort is not entirely altruistic. Sierra Leone, for instance, was eager to stop the war that had spilled over its border. And many officers in the peacekeeping force are engaged in lucrative business ventures that exploit Liberia's resources of timber, diamonds, rubber and gold.

Regional troops also participated in the looting of Monrovia's suburbs in 1992. Refrigerators, air conditioners and other goods were later shipped back to their own countries. And Nigerian fighter planes bombed hospitals, aid convoys and food warehouses during the peak enforcement period of the embargo.

But it was that embargo which was the key to bringing about the recent peace, observers say, and its execution by the African peacekeepers is an example of how the U.N. can more effectively carry out its mandate without becoming too involved as it has in Somalia.

"We will stay here until elections," said Kenyan Maj., Gen. Daniel Opande, the chief U.N. military observer in Liberia. "But come elections, the day after the installation of the government, I don't think we will stay here even one day longer than that."


LOAD-DATE: April 19, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


111 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 11, 1994 / May 8, 1994


CURRENCY EXCHANGE RATES


LENGTH: 2165 words


 

Maxwell Stamp PLC

Economic Consultants

London * Nairobi * Riyadh * Mauritius

Rates quoted are the middle rates between buying and selling, but currencies are in most cases not freely traded. These rates have been compiled by Maxwell Stamp PLC for information only. Maxwell Stamp accepts no responsibility for any transaction undertaken on the basis of these figures. Africa News


April 11, 1994 / May 8, 1994


BUSINESS


LENGTH: 1640 words


 

American Information Technologies (AIT) can provide computer equipment, installation, maintenance, and training services for business or individuals starting up in Africa. Contact: AIT, P.O. Box 510, Tucker, GA. Phone (404) 723-9200.

Africa Centre for Resources and Environment (ACRE) was recently established to address the concerns highlighted in the Report of the World Commission on Environment and Development (1987). The principle purpose of ACRE, a non-profit organization with headquarters in Nairobi, is to contribute to sustainable environment and socioeconomic development through the coherent linkage between appropriate policies and feasible programs of actions. ACRE's programs focus on four areas: natural resource management, technology applications, environmental and development economies, and capacity-building in environmental and resource management. Contact: Bethual Kiplagat, P.O. Box 67504, Nairobi, Kenya. Fax: 254-2-226-506.

The following procurement opportunities in Egypt are available to U.S. companies through the U.S. Agency for International Development. 

*Library Books, Publications, Bulletins, Videos & Journals. A.I.D. Geographic Code 000 (U.S. only). RFQ#: CID93004. OFFER DEADLINE: MAY 25, 1994. LOAD-DATE: April 26, 1994


LANGUAGE: English

113 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 11, 1994 / May 8, 1994


EDUCATION/TRAVEL


LENGTH: 2067 words


 

The American University in Cairo is offering African Fellowships for two years of study toward an AUC Masters degree. Applicants from all disciplines are encouraged to apply. Contact: International Graduate Programs, Office of the Provost, American University in Cairo, P.O. Box 2511, 113 Kasr al Aini, Cairo, Egypt.

The Center for Latin American Studies and the Center for African Studies invite junior and senior scholars to participate in an interdisciplinary program on Afro-American identity and cultural diversity in the Americas, including the Caribbean, Brazil, and the US, as well as areas of Africa. The program will enable visiting scholars to spend an year or a semester at the University of Florida to do research in this area. It will include studies of history, literature, religion, and popular culture. Each fellow will receive a maximum stipend of US$35,000 for the academic year, or half that for the semester. Applicants will be selected on a competitive basis related to their expertise and research in these areas. Candidates should submit a 100- word abstract, an essay of about 1,500 words detailing proposed research, a curriculum vitae, and two letters of recommendation. Send applications to Dr. Helen I. Safa, Center for Latin American Studies, University of Florida, P.O. Box 115530, Gainesville, FL 32611-5530; phone: (904) 392-0375; fax: (904) 392-7682. 

The Council for Development of Social Science Research in Africa (CODESRIA) has a Small Grants Program for Thesis Writing to fund M.A. and Ph.D. candidates who are in the process of completing their theses. The funds will cover expenses in a country where research is conducted, but they will not cover the cost of travel to that country. For more information contact: Dr. Cyrus Reed, Office of African Studies, American University in Cairo, P.O. Box 2511, 113 Kasr al Aini, Cairo, Egypt. The Modern Management Institute in Nairobi, Kenya offers a new home study method for learning Kiswahili, a language spoken in Kenya, Tanzania, Uganda, Malawi, Zambia, Zaire, Rwanda, Burundi, and the Sudan. The method includes a basic English/Kiswahili textbook for 24 lessons and audio cassettes to help with pronunciation. Contact: Geoffrey Njogu, Director of Studies, Modern Management Institute, P.O. Box 47390, Nairobi, Kenya; phone: (254.2) 33.17.02.

The Population-Environment Fellows Program, sponsored by U.S. AID and administered at the University of Michigan, sponsors Fellows for two-year appointments with overseas agencies. Fellows provide assistance and technical support for developing country institutions to foster a comprehensive approach to development. Fellows must hold a graduate degree in a relevant area and demonstrate expertise in both population and environment. Applications are reviewed on a rolling basis, but the sooner a completed application is received, the greater the availability of sites for which it can be considered. Inquiries and application requests may be obtained from: The Population-Environment Fellows Program, SPH II, Room M2240, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109-2029; phone: (313) 747-0222; fax: (313) 747-4947.

The Economic Development Institute of the World Bank announces the 1994 cycle of the Robert S. McNamara Fellowship Program which aims at producing the highest quality research results in the general area of economic development. The program also seeks to achieve wide geographical and cultural diversity among fellows. The 12-month fellowship does not support work toward an advanced degree, but innovative and imaginative post-graduate research in areas of economic development. Contact: Robert S. McNamara Fellowship Program, Room M-4029, World Bank Headquarters, 1818 H. St., N.W., Washington, DC 20433.

The SSRC-MacArthur Foundation Committee on International Peace and Security announces a program of small grants in 1994 allowing scholars and students of international relations to visit major universities and research centers outside their home region. Grants are intended for junior scholars who seek exposure to debates and scholarship on the changing international system and issues of international peace and security. Applications should be completed and returned to the Council, postmarked no later than JULY 15, 1994. Contact: Social Science Research Council, Visiting Scholar Fellowship Program on International Peace and Security, 605 Third Avenue, 17th Floor, New York, NY 10158.

The Community Law Center in Durban, South Africa offers internship opportunities for law students and some undergraduates from outside South Africa. CLC is affiliated with the University of Natal, and places emphasis on assisting the rural areas of South Africa. CLC publishes a quarterly newsletter, Izindaba. Contact: The Community Law Center, Berea Center, 7th Floor, 247 Berea Road, Durban 4001, South Africa.

The Visiting Scholar Fellowship Program of the Social Science Research Council and the MacArthur Foundation Committee on International Peace and Security offers fellowships for young faculty in African institutions as well as journalists, public servants and lawyers to pursue innovative research at universities and major research centers outside their home areas. Contact Visiting Scholar Fellowship, International Peace and Security, 605 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10158. Tel: (212) 661-0280. Fax: (212) 370-7896. DEADLINE: JULY 15, 1994. University of Minnesota, Minnesota Studies in International Development (MSID) offers academic year programs of internships and field study including 5 months in Senegal or Kenya. Financial aid is available. Details are available at the Center or through: MSID, The Global Campus, University of Minnesota, 106-M Nicholson Hall, 216 Pillsbury Drive, SE, Minneapolis, MN 55455-0138. Tel: (612) 625-3379. A special edition of "Research in African Literature" will be devoted to African Cinema. Please submit entries dealing with African film or African film criticism to Kenneth W. Harrow, Dept. of English, Morrill Hall, Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI 48824-1036. DEADLINE for submissions is JUNE 1, 1994.

A second volume of "Faces of Islam in African Literature" is going to appear. We are interested in papers that deal with Islam in African literature. Please send entries to Ken Harrow, Dept. of English, Morrill Hall, Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI 48824-1036 or to Rachid A. Hassani, Box 1257, Cambridge, MA 02238. DEADLINE for submissions is JUNE 1, 1994.

Gus J. Liebenow Fellowship at Indiana University is designed to recruit and provide assistance for an underrepresented minority student (U.S. citizen) who is interested in pursuing a Ph.D. at any school of Indiana University with a concentration in African Studies. Students in the program pursue degrees in their perspective major departments, with African Studies serving as an area specialization. For more information, contact Patrick O'Meara, Director, African Studies Program, Woodburn Hall 221, Indiana University, Bloomington, IN 47405. Phone: (812) 855-8284.

The United States Institute of Peace sponsors two all-expense paid summer seminars for educators. "International Peace, Security, and Conflict Management" is a summer institute for high school social studies teachers August 6-13, 1994 in Washington, DC. The DEADLINE for receipt of applications from social studies teachers is APRIL 15, 1994. For further information, contact: United States Institute of Peace, Education and Training Program, 1500 M Street, NW, Suite 700, Washington, DC 20005-1700. Phone: (202) 457-1700. Fax: (202) 429-6063. E-mail: msoley@usip.org.

Fulbright Faculty Awards are available for university lecturing or advanced research in over 135 countries. Awards range from two months to a full academic year. Applications are encouraged from professional outside academe as well as from faculty at all types of institutions. For more information, contact: Council for International Exchange of Scholars, 3007 Tilden St., NW, Suite 5M, Box GBRO, Washington, DC 20008-3009. Phone: (202) 686-7877. Bitnet: CIES1@GWUVM.GWU.EDU.

The National Humanities Center awards approximately 35-40 residential fellowships each year for the advanced study of the arts and other fields in the liberal arts. Social scientists, natural scientists, or professionals whose work has a humanistic dimension are encouraged to apply. Applicants must hold a PhD or the equivalent degree. For more information, contact: Fellowship Program, National Humanities Center, Box 12256, Research Triangle Park, NC 27709.

The University of Cape Town's Centre for African Studies announces the Harry Oppenheimer Research Fellowship. Applicants are considered annually in December for the following year. The fellowship is for three to six months, depending on the recipient's program. Fellows receive R7500 and are expected to deliver and Africa Seminar and contribute to the cultural life of the Centre. For more information, contact: Harry Oppenheimer Institute, UCT Private Bag, 7700 Ronderbosch, University of Cape Town, South Africa. Phone: (021) 650-3273. Fax: (021) 650-3274. E-Mail: erasmus@socsci.uct.ac.za.

African Development Foundation (ADF) is a public enterprise set up in 1980 by the US Congress to support self-development initiatives by African populations. The major goal is to provide the resources needed by African grassroots populations to reach self-reliant development. ADF does not impose external development concepts on African communities. Instead, it encourages Africans to suggest innovative approaches to problem-solving, which will eventually lead to self-reliance and self-sufficiency in the local communities. Researchers are requested to explore problems directly related to grassroots development and to make concrete recommendations that can be of assistance to development project promoters in the community. ADF provides grants for research initiated and conducted by African academics, development specialists, students and community groups. Researchers are encouraged to be creative in selecting their theme and to focus their research on issues which are crucial to the development of their countries. In 1994, ADF will allocate approximately US $675,000 to research project funding. Four types of fellowships will be awarded: Gray postgraduate fellowships (deadline August 1, 1994); Be applied research fellowships (deadline August 1, 1994); Grants for transfer of knowledge (no deadline); Leland development fellowships (deadline January 1, 1995). For information contact: Office of Learning and Dissemination, African Development Foundation, 1400 Eye Street, NW, Tenth Floor, Washington, DC 20005.


LOAD-DATE: April 26, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


114 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 11, 1994 / May 8, 1994


EMPLOYMENT


LENGTH: 4734 words


 

Tiller's International offers a variety of workshops tailored to the needs of international rural innovators. Sessions feature hands-on activities, structured demonstrations, field trips and discussions. Workshops of particular interest include: Rural Development with Animal Power (May 24-28), Refining Animal Power Systems (June 20-July 29), and Low Cost Tools for Agriculture (August 16-20). A few scholarships are available for students of international development. Contact: Tiller's International, 5239 South 24th Street, Kalamazoo, MI 49008. Phone (616) 385-3233. Fax: (616) 385-2329. The American Friends Service Committee has the following openings:

NATIONAL REPRESENTATIVE FOR ECONOMIC JUSTICE (this position has been reopened): Carry major responsibility for forging AFSC understanding of economic changes affecting jobs, income and services for low income people and people of color; bring understandings to communities and policymakers; support and foster regional work on economic justice issues, focusing on housing and homelessness, welfare policy and jobs. Requires: demonstrated oral and written communication skills; experience in program development and/or community based work addressing needs of low income people; experience in fair housing/homelessness work or welfare rights work desirable; strong oral and written communication skills; experience in multicultural, multiracial work; skill in word processing, willingness to learn this skill; willingness and ability to carry out significant travel. (Address: Lydia Wilcox). 

ASSISTANT TO THE DIRECTOR, PLANNED GIVING: Responsible for processing new gifts and additions to existing gifts. Day-to-day oversight to assure compliance with existing agreements; respond to questions from prospects, fundraisers and planned giving participants. Maintain and update information on existing planned gifts. Maintain and update current information on donors, income beneficiaries and gift terminations. Requires: B.S. degree preferred; high school education accepted if experience is equivalent; experience with trusts as accountant or administrator; knowledge of securities; computer experience; ability to do detailed financial work, good communication, writing and telephone skills. (Address: Clara Wright).

ASSISTANT DIRECTOR (PROGRAM), INTERNATIONAL DIVISION: In consultation with the Division Director, work closely with program desk staff to support the development, project and disaster work especially, with some attention also to international affairs and reconciliation programs; work with the Development Department to assure timely submission of proposals and narrative reports to funding partners, especially in regard to grants that support work in more than one geographic area; supervise the Director of the Material Aids program and the Assistant for Publication; make occasional field visits. Requires: several years of experience in development work abroad and/or in the administration of development programs from a US base; demonstrated skill in program exploration and evaluation; experience in or knowledge of the field of conflict management very useful; demonstrated skill in writing in English, editing, layout; ability to attend some evening and weekend meetings and to travel abroad for periods up to 4 weeks; fluency in English essential, in Spanish and French highly desirable; experience in and enthusiasm for fundraising proposal and report writing. (Address: Lydia Wilcox).

For further information on all positions listed write AFSC Human Resources Office, 1501 Cherry Street, Philadelphia, PA 19102. Phone: (215) 241-7102 or 7114.

Development/environment non-profit seeks a Communications Officer who will assist with evaluation of organizational communications needs' outreach to the federal government, Congress, the media, the international development community, and the public; preparation and dissemination of promotional materials. Candidates must have excellent writing skills and solid experience with Windows computer applications. Submit resume and writing samples to: Communications Director, ATI, 1828 L Street NW, Suite 1000, Washington, DC 20036.

International Action Against Hunger seeks the following: HEALTH COORDINATOR, Northeast Somalia: Individual to be responsible for developing a health education curriculum to be used in PHC facilities and communities in northeast Somalia, training in use of the curriculum and oversight of its implementation. Works closely with PHC and community organization teams. Requires MPH or related degree, demonstrated skill in development of community-responsive curricula, commitment to participatory techniques, 2+ years experience. COMMUNITY ORGANIZER, Northeast Somalia: Individual to be responsible for facilitating the support by local community of community-based health systems; assist in identifying those needs; facilitate activities with local NGOs. Requires relevant degree with 2+ years overseas community- based experience. Strong communications skills and ability to live and thrive in a challenging environment are necessary. HEALTH EDUCATION SPECIALIST, Northeast Somalia: Individual to be responsible for developing a health education curriculum to be used in PHC facilities and communities in northeast Somalia, training in use of the curriculum and oversight of its implementation. Works closely with PHC and community organization teams. Requires MPH or related degree, demonstrated skill in development of community-responsive curricula, commitment to participatory techniques, 2+ years experience. Assignments generally for 6-12 months, with opportunity for renewal. Competitive compensation package. Mail/fax cover letter, resume and salary requirements to: AICF/USA, 815 15th Street NW, Suite 832, Washington, DC 20005. Fax: (202) 783-5247.

Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations has an opening for a SENIOR ECONOMIST (Marketing) in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia. This is a fixed term, 3-year position. QUALIFICATIONS: University degree in agricultural economics, preferably with postgraduate specialization in marketing, or a related field (such as agro-economy). Ten years of increasingly responsible professional experience in an international organization, government, private sector or research institution in agro-economic development. (An M.S. or equivalent advanced postgraduate degree in agricultural economics may be substituted for one year of the required experience, a Ph.D. or equivalent degree for two years of the required experience). Working knowledge of English (level C) or French or limited knowledge (level B) of the other. DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES: Under the supervision of the Director, Joint ECA (UN Economic Commission for Africa)/FAO Agriculture Division and the technical guidance of the Agricultural Services Division, to plan and coordinate the work of the Agricultural Marketing Section (ECA), and specifically, to: conduct analyses of the food and agricultural marketing situation in the region, including; developments in production, consumption, price policy, trade, distribution and demand, taking account of the Lagos Plan of Action, the Regional Food Plan for Africa and other regional programmes. Contact: Executive Officer, LNOR, Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, 1001 22nd Street, N.W., Suite 300, Washington, DC 20437 American Refugee Committee has the following positions available:

In Somalia:

MATERNITY SERVICES COORDINATOR: based in Afmadou, southern Somalia. Responsibilities: select and train MCH maternity services staff; establish policies and procedures for the MCH Center maternity services; supervise the delivery of maternity services. Qualifications: experienced Certified Nurse Midwife; experience in a developing country preferably in a rural setting; training and supervision background. Immediate opening; 6-month commitment. $1,500/month.

In Sudan:

MEDICAL DOCTOR to provide emergency relief to displaced persons in Kajo Keji County. RESPONSIBILITIES: set up emergency/acute care clinic and coordinate all in-patient and out-patient activities. REQUIREMENTS: MD with emergency/acute care experience in developing countries and proven success in implementing new programs in relief situations. 6 month commitment. $1,200-$1,600/month. Immediate opening.

FIELD COORDINATOR/LOGISITICIAN: 3 years experience in developing countries. Administration and logistical experience a must. 12 month commitment required. Salary, insurance, round-trip transportation and room and board provided.

NURSE PRACTITIONER: Experience in developing countries. To assist with EPI program. 12 month commitment required. Salary, insurance, round-trip transportation and room and board provided.

Resume or letter of interest to International Medical Corps, Dept. 94-008, 12233 Olympic Blvd., #280, Los Angeles, CA 90064. Fax: (310) 442-6622.

The Center for International Development and Environment of the World Resources Institute seeks individual with experience in natural resources management, institutions, and/or natural resource and policy activities in Africa, particularly national plans and strategies for sustainable development. Africa experience and excellent language competence in French required. Will be responsible for the coordination and implementation of the Center's activities in sustainable development planning in Africa. Will coordinate the Natural Resource Management Policy Consultative Group for Africa, with priority on an on-going study of sustainable development planning in 8 African countries. Position includes field work, analytical report writing, some policy research, and preparing workplans and budgets. Send resume to: Africa Program, CIDE/WRI, 1709 New York Avenue NW, Suite 700, Washington, DC 20006.

OIC International seeks a SMALL ENTERPRISE MANAGEMENT/DEVELOPMENT AND APPROPRIATE TECHNOLOGY SPECIALIST to provide technical assistance and training in value-added transformation and raw produce with the purpose of creating employment and economic development opportunities for unemployed youths and disadvantaged communities in African and other countries. The person will identify cottage industry and appropriate technologies adaptable to the client countries; develop curricula to train related entrepreneurial and technical skills to develop and manage such businesses. REQUIREMENTS: First degree in engineering followed by an MBA or equivalent education in Business Management; experience in related development work, and working experience in Africa in particular, first hand experience managing business and/or in appropriate technology development; fluent in English and French; knowledge of Spanish is advantageous. Travel required. Send resume: President and CEO, OIC International, 240 W. Tulpehocken Street, Philadelphia, PA 19144.

International Medical Corps has multiple openings. Mail or fax resume or letter of interest to International Medical Corps, Dept. 93- 033, 12233 West Olympic Blvd., #280, Los Angeles, CA 90064; fax: (310) 442-6622.

The following International Medical Corps positions are available in Angola: **EPIDEMIOLOGIST with masters degree in Public Health and extensive survey research experience in rural developing countries, survey design, implementation, analysis and report writing required. SITE MANAGER located in Luena. Logistics, bookkeeping, administrative skills and strong management skills. **SITE MANAGER located in Luena. Logistics, bookkeeping, administrative skills and strong management skills. **EPI TRAINER with strong teaching skills and implementation experience.

In Somalia: **HOSPITAL ADMINISTRATOR/EDUCATOR for its Emergency Medical Program. Requires prior international hospital administration experience in developing countries. Will train local medical personnel. Requires a minimum of a 6-month contract. Salary, room and board, medical insurance and round-trip transportation provided.

International Services of the Red Cross seeks two (2) SENIOR TECHNICAL ADVISORS in AIDS and Child Survival which will be seconded to USAID. These advisers will provide technical advice and management capabilities to the AID Mission to Kenya. QUALIFICATIONS: MPH or equivalent in health field; experience with AIDS prevention and Child Survival activities of USAID; excellent communications and analytical skills; 5+ years experience in developing countries; data and word processing skills. Fluency in French highly desirable. Contact: Helene Montell, ARC/OIS, 17th and D Streets, N.W., Washington, DC 20006.

Khanya College, Cape Town, is accepting applications for a DIRECTOR. The candidate must have a minimum academic qualification at master's degree level and a demonstrable comprehension of the context in which Khanya College operates. The candidate will need to communicate effectively with a wide range of external players in the fields of funding, research, and policy formation. Send curriculum vitae and three references to S. Isaacs, Chairperson, Khanya Board of Trustees, c/o Peninsula Technikon, P.O. Box 1906, Bellville 7535, South Africa. Box 500, Akron, PA 17501-0500; phone: (717) 859-1151.

Youngstown State University is looking for candidates for an African/African-American/Black Studies faculty position in their History Dept. For more information or to forward names of prospective candidates, contact: William D. Jenkins, Department of History, Youngstown State University, Youngstown, OH 44555-3452. Phone: (216) 742-3452.

AirServ International seeks candidates fore President/CEO. Candidates must have experience leading a complex multi-million dollar enterprise and a background in relief and development. Aviation experience strongly preferred. Africa experience a plus. Send resume to: Personnel Dept., AirServ International, Box 3041, Redlands, CA 92373.

The International Rescue Committee operates refugee relief programs in over 20 countries worldwide and is seeking: a CASE WORKER to assist in resettlement services for newly arrived refugees. Services include but are not limited to: housing, school enrollment, health screening, and job placement. Applicants must have a BSW or related degree/experience. Language skills (Arabic, Croatian, Somali) are preferred but not required. JOB DEVELOPER to network with area employers, source jobs, and create a hob back to assist in job placement for newly arriving refugees. Applicants must have previous related experience and be able to work with a variety of nationalities.

Send resumes to: IRC, Recruitment Office, 386 Park Avenue South, New York, NY 10016. Tel: (212) 679-0010. Fax: (212) 689-3459.

Africare has an immediate opening for a population and family planning project manager. Project manager will be a counterpart to the manager of a local NGO implementing a family planning program funded by USAID and other donors. Candidates should possess: advanced degree with 5-10 years of professional experience in a health-related field; background in project management, especially in health-related development projects in Africa; demonstrated understanding of clinical training, health services delivery, marketing activities and HIS; excellent French; working knowledge of such computer programs as WordPerfect, Lotus 123, DBase 3, SPSS, etc. Send resume and salary history to: Ms. Carolyn Gullatt, Africare House, 440 R Street NW, Washington, DC 20001. Resident Director in Ghana is needed for a new undergraduate program at the University of Ghana in Legon, offered by the Council on International Education Exchange. Candidates must have a PhD, university-level teaching experience, and experience in Africa. Contact: CIEE, 205 E. 42nd St., New York, NY 10017.

African Language Instructors for the University of Wyoming's African-American Studies program are needed to develop courses in sub-Saharan African languages. Employment would be seasonal, therefore relocation would not be necessary. The program would be responsible for all travel expenses and would also offer a salary. All instructors must be Africans and have at least a Bachelor's degree in any field. Send all resumes and letters of interest to: Niyi Coker, Jr., Director of African-American Studies, University of Wyoming, Laramie, WY 82071. E-mail: niyi@uwyo.edu.

Specialist in French Language and Francophone African Literature is needed at Bowling Green State University for a tenure-track assistant professorship starting fall 1994. Applicable foreign experience/ residence is highly desirable. A recent PhD in an appropriate literary field is required. Send application materials to: French Search Committee, Romance Languages, Bowling Green State University, Bowling Green, OH 43403.

Graduates in mechanical/electrical/ civil engineering, forestry, business, horticulture, chemistry or computer science who are under 25 are encouraged to apply. Duties: responsible for sourcing, recruiting, interviewing and relocating Christian third world experienced professionals for overseas service with World Vision. Qualifications: 3 years of professional recruitment experience, with significant experience in international recruiting; previous experience working overseas strongly preferred; committed Christian; strong sourcing, interviewing and organizational skills. Resume to World Vision US, 919 W. Huntington Dr., Monrovia, CA 91016. Attention: Richard Boulding. Fax: (818) 358-7615.

Helen Keller International seeks a Chief Financial Officer for its headquarters office in New York City. The CFO will be responsible for the organization's financial controls and reporting, and assist in strategic planning of program and development activities. Should have 5+ years experience in non-profit government financial management; a sound understanding of accounting/financial principles and excellent oral, written communication and interpersonal skills. CPA certification and an MBA in finance, accounting, or business administration is also required. Foreign travel may be necessary. Compensation includes salary, insurance and retirement benefits. Send cover letter with salary history and CV to Mr. John Palmer, Executive Director, FNC Division, HKI, 90 Washington St., New York, NY 10006.

The School for International Training (SIT) seeks individual for a Visiting Faculty position within the Department of Global Issues & Intercultural Management, with primary responsibility in the Master's Program in Intercultural Management (PIM). Seeking practitioner with years of distinguished experience in a managerial, training and/or consulting role in a "Southern" country. Primary responsibilities include a combination of teaching courses in human resource management, development program administration and strategic management, advising and evaluating students in their internships, and capstone papers and presentations. Depending on knowledge, interest and need, may also be asked to teach one of the following: project design, financial management of NGOs, or organizational behaviour. Minimum qualifications include distinguished experience in managerial positions in NGO, development organisations, and/or experience in teaching or training in nonformal, participant-centered education activities. Contract: 8/15/94 - 6/9/95. Salary dependent upon degree and experience. Position open until filled. Send resume and cover letter to HR, World Learning, PO Box 676, Brattleboro, VT 05302-0676.

The Unitarian Universalist Service Committee seeks skilled grants writer/manager to help secure foundation support for overseas projects in Central America and the Caribbean, Africa and Asia. Responsibilities: research and identify potential foundation funders on such issues as sustainable development, maternal and child health and related international development issues; help prepare diverse proposal-related materials; work on fund-raising activities and projects. Requires: 3+ years professional grant writing experience with emphasis on foundation proposal management; excellent writing and research skills; record of successful grant writing preferred, preferably related to international development; understanding of effective foundation relations necessary; strong organizational, administrative and record keeping skills; and familiarity with WordPerfect and database management. Position funded for 1 year. Send resume and short writing sample (e.g. funding proposal) to: Foundation Assistant Search, UUSC-MD, 130 Prospect Street, Cambridge, MA 02139.

The Center for International Private Enterprise (CIPE), an affiliate of the US Chamber of Commerce, seeks individual to assist with developing and implementing training/education programs focused on strengthening overseas business associations and their staffs' capabilities. Will conduct needs assessments; establish training objectives; select/develop courses; recruit instructors; and coordinate logistics. Will also assist with managing CIPE's grants programs for Africa. Requires related degree and 2 years of related training experience in an international setting; experience with Microsoft Word and Lotus; fluency in Russian; and the ability to travel, work with diverse constituencies and meet tight deadlines. Portuguese language skills preferred. Start $28K with excellent benefits. Send cover letter and benefits to: US Chamber of Commerce, Personnel Dept., 11615 H St., NW, Washington, DC 20062-2000.

Food for the Hungry International, a relief and development organization of Christian methodology and motivation, seeks individual to be based in headquarters in Arizona, to be responsible for all FHI accounting functions globally. Must be a CPA with 5-10 years experience, 3 years in the non-profit sector. Previous overseas experience is desired. Must understand basic management practices. Position will be filled by July 1994. Contact: Scott Allen, Director of Mobilization, Food for the Hungry International, 7807 E. Greenway Rd. #3, Scottsdale, AZ 85260. Phone (800) 248-6437. Fax (602) 951-9053.

Food for the Hungry International has the following positions available in Mozambique:

SOFALA PROVINCE EXTENSION AND REHABILITATION (SPEAR) PROJECT MANAGER. Responsible for overall planning and management of the SPEAR project. Requirements: MS or equivalent in agricultural discipline, 5 years of experience in international agriculture development projects, with progressively increasing responsibilities in project management. Strong experience in project planning, financial/personal management. Fluency in Portuguese or Spanish. Working knowledge of Lotus (or Quattro Pro or Excel) and WordPerfect. African experience desirable.

TRAINING UNIT COORDINATOR: Reports to the SPEAR project manager. Establish and manage an agricultural training center. Will train and develop agricultural extension agents and field researchers. Requirements: BS in Agricultural Extension/Education with hands-on international ag. development experience or BS in Agronomy/Horticulture/ Forestry with extensive international training experience. Good overall computer skills, excellent writing skills, and "training of trainers" experience is required. Must be fluent in Spanish or Portuguese.

PROVINCIAL CONSTRUCTION MANAGER: Responsibilities include the implementation and rehabilitation of rural infrastructure projects in all facets and phases. Requirements: BS Civil Engineering with 10 years of experience, including 2 years of international experience.. Fluency in Portuguese or Spanish is required.

The start date for all positions is July-August 1994. For more information contact Scott Allen, Director of Mobilization, Food for the Hungry International, 7807 E. Greenway Rd. #3, Scottsdale, AZ 85260. Phone (800) 248-6437. Fax (602) 951-9053.

115 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 11, 1994 / May 8, 1994


VOLUNTEER OPPORTUNITIES


LENGTH: 334 words


 

The American Medical Team for Africa (AMTA) promotes and executes educational exchange and medical training in African countries. The goal of the non-profit organization is to bring volunteer doctors, nurses and medical students together with donated supplies, and equipment to serve needs on the continent. Survey teams assess the most pressing needs in targeted countries, develop and publish training manuals in appropriate languages, hold workshops and refresher courses for doctors, nurses and specialists interested in maintenance of health care delivery systems in Africa; and distribute medical supplies and equipment donated by corporations, pharmaceutical companies, hospitals and doctors. The AMTA plans a second medical mission to Africa. For more information, contact Deman Rageh, Executive Director, The American Medical Team for Africa, 2245 Godby Road, Atlanta, GA 30349; phone (404) 766-8000; fax: (404) 767-5264.

Private Voluntary Organization in Rosslyn needs an experienced Agribusiness/Marketing Specialist to fill a 3-year Chief of Party position in Mali. The candidate must have at least 10 years of proven experience in the field of Agribusiness, Marketing, Credit and Procurement (preferably of fruits & vegetables). Must have related job experience in developing country with hands-on experience and an MBA. Strong training skills in the areas of agribusiness and marketing required. Fluency in French/English (FSI , S-3, R03) a must. Interested candidates must submit a resume, a certification of foreign language capability, and a standard AID bio-data form. Please mail original copies to: Regina Wynn, VITA, 5th floor, Arlington, VA 22209. Tel: (703) 276-1800 or fax: (703) 2143-1865.

Rockville, MD -- Workshop

Solar Energy International is sponsoring a meeting to show how development workers, as agents of change, can choose with confidence clean, reliable and cost-effective energy sources for overseas projects. Case studies will be presented and participants will see full working demonstrations of renewable energy systems. The workshop will be held on May 12, for 9-4 at the Holiday Inn Crowne Plaza in Rockville, MD.

April

Ten-part series produced by Africa News and NPR

Mondays, starting April 11

Tune in to National Public Radio on Mondays through June for a special series of reports on Africa in the post-Cold War world.

Produced jointly by Africa News Service and NPR, the reports will air on the 90-minute afternoon news magazine, All Things Considered, during the second half hour, between 5:30 and 6:00 pm in most areas.

Reporting teams from Africa News and NPR have traveled to East, West and southern Africa to explore the challenges facing the continent, including achieving food self-sufficiency, resettling refugees, demobilizing armies, and expanding the voice and participation of women. 

Be sure to let NPR know your reaction to the series. Direct your comments to:

All Things Considered

635 Massachusetts Avenue

Washington, D.C. 20001-3753

and/or

NPR

(202) 414-2000

Underwriters for the project include: The Coca-Cola Company, the Ford Foundation, New Africa Advisers, Rodale Press, Pan Africa-U.S.A. International Track Meet, South African Airways, the CarEth Foundation and the Corporation for Public Broadcasting.
