119 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 11, 1994 / May 8, 1994


SECTION: ANNOUNCEMENTS


LENGTH: 387 words


 

GOLDMAN ENVIRONMENTAL PRIZES AWARDED

Six environmental heroes from around the world received the fifth annual Goldman Environmental Prizes on April 18 at a ceremony in San Francisco. Each of the 1994 Goldman Environmental Prize winners receives a "no strings attached" award of $60,000 from the Goldman Environmental Foundation of San Francisco. The only 1994 winner from Africa was Laila Kamel (Cairo, Egypt)

As Volunteer Director of the Association for the Protection of the Environment (APE), Laila Kamel, 46, has worked tirelessly to improve the lives of Cairo's garbage collector population. Fleeing drought in the 1940's, whole villages migrated to Cairo from rural Southern Egypt. Unskilled and uneducated, they became garbage collectors of 'zabbaleen', eking out their livelihood collecting the household waste of the city's 16 million inhabitants and living amidst mountains of garbage on the outskirts of the city in the Mokattam Hills.

APE has pioneered several recycling projects in the garbage collector community with the goal of helping them turn "trash into cash." At the neighborhood composting plant, organic waste is refined into high-grade fertilizer and sold to agriculturalists. Metals are melted and reworked. And at Laila Kamel's Rug-Weaving Center, garbage collector girls turn "rags into riches." Using cotton remnants, girls learn to weave rugs on a hand-loom. The colorful rugs are later sold at handicraft fairs, and earnings are divided among the aspiring weavers. While learning to weave, the girls learn basic math and literacy skills. Each year 150 girls participate in this "learning and earning" project. Those who graduate from Kamel's program have the option of receiving a loom for their home to start their own cottage industry. Kamel's center has brought opportunity to young women, most of whom would otherwise spend their days sorting garbage.


LOAD-DATE: April 26, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


120 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 11, 1994 / May 8, 1994


VIEWPOINT: EGYPT REVEALS ITS HAND OVER SELF-DETERMINATION FOR SOUTHERN SUDAN


BYLINE: Bona Malwal, Editor and Publisher


LENGTH: 894 words


 

SUDAN DEMOCRATIC GAZETTE, April 1994

On 28 February the Egyptian foreign minister, Amero Musa, told the Arabic newspaper 'Al Hayat' of London that Egypt was totally against the right of the Southern Sudanese people to Self-determination and would never allow such a right to be exercised. He told the paper that Egyptian officials were in contact with the Khartoum regime to co-ordinate their efforts on how best to prevent such an eventuality. In addition, he revealed that Egypt was consulting other Arab countries in order to establish a common policy on the issue.

It has been clear for decades that Egypt does not act as an impartial neighbour when it comes to discussing the Sudanese conflict, in spite of the occasional overtures of goodwill towards the South, intended to fool the South into complacency. Ever since Sudan's independence in 1956, Egypt has sided with the Northern power elite in Khartoum against the South. Its interests have concerned the Nile waters rather than the people of Sudan, and so protection of those waters has been paramount in all its interactions with Khartoum. 

The worst intentions of Cairo have become clearer over the past four years as it has singularly failed to take any stance against the most repressive regime Sudan has ever suffered. This is despite the presence of millions of Sudanese refugees in Egypt. Now it appears that Cairo hopes it can win over Khartoum by adopting a strong anti-Southern Sudanese stance. Even if it succeeds, it will make little difference to the struggle of the Southerners because Egypt has never been one of their supporters. Most Southerners have always assumed that ultimately Egypt's power would be utilised by their oppressors in the North.

It is not too surprising to the people of Southern Sudan that Egypt has kept quiet and condoned all of the atrocities, killings and torture committed by Khartoum, only to speak out so strongly and so clearly today against the political interests of the South. Egypt may well be right that at present it will run no risks of repercussions for such a policy, in the face of a weak South bereft of external allies. However, it is definitely a serious political miscalculation as far as Egypt's long term prospects are concerned.

It is interesting that Cairo has chosen to deal with an African problem by referring it to Arab countries. This is in spite of President Mubarak being at this present moment the chairperson of the Organisation for African Unity (OAU). Other African states will note only too clearly where Egypt's real allegiance stands. Egypt is merely demonstrating the contempt with which it holds the rest of black Africa. The Egyptian authorities have not given a moment's thought to the peace initiative launched by the IGADD nations to find an African solution to an African problem.

While Egypt's intervention in the debate is intended to negatively influence the pro-Egyptian parties of Northern Sudan against Self-determination, it is the 'Gazette's' sincere hope that some of these parties will see through the Egyptian position and realise that it is based on pure self-interest and not even the interests of the North. Only a Sudanese solution will resolve the conflict and that has to be based upon the wishes of the people and the execution of a referendum on Self-determination in the South. One wonders how much the North now regrets today's problems should have been avoided, including the exodus of Northern Sudanese into Egypt who are now being used as a political lever by Cairo.

The call for Self-determination is both genuine and serious. It will not be sacrificed simply because the North now has the overt backing of Egypt. Self-determination for the South is now the only way open for the North to atone for its past crimes in the South. If that means the creation of a separate Southern Sudanese state, then so be it. The South will not be denied a free political choice. The 'Gazette' hopes that the representatives of the North will soon realize that Egyptian interference can only have a negative impact both upon themselves and the South. Whilst the Southern Sudanese accept external help in the mediation process, they will never accept the dictates of an external power concerning what is essentially a Sudanese problem.

Reprinted from the Sudan Democratic Gazette, April 1994.

The Sudan Democratic Gazette is published at P.O. Box 2295, London W14 0ND, U.K.


LOAD-DATE: April 26, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


April 11, 1994 / May 8, 1994


KAMPALA VISITORS CAME, BORED VILLAGE WOMEN STIFF


BYLINE: Judith Matovu


LENGTH: 1667 words


 

THE MONITOR, March 29-31, 1994

The venue is Lukolo village. The time is March 8, 1994. It is indeed a great day for the villagers who, for the first time have been honoured with the presence of big people from the city.

It came both as a surprise and like some sort of a joke when word started going round that in the whole of that district, Lukolo had been selected venue for the International Women's Day celebrations. Men were fast mobilised to oversee the preparations for this occasion. There were mixed feelings of anger, suspicion and anxiety among the males and minimal awareness among the females.

Some men were particularly excited and looked forward to hear for themselves about this international madness of women. 

Men like Kyasanku would not miss this opportunity to hear what these confused women from town had to say. He prepared to question them on why they thought, in this 21st century, water would start flowing uphill. However, if the worse came to the worst, these women might end up getting some disciplinary action from Lukolo men in their own husbands have stubbornly refused to dispense the same.

However, some of the more reactionary type went as far as sending a high powered delegation to their RC II Chairman for clarification on "activities threatening the stability of Lukolo homes". The RC man was cautioned that should anything go wrong he would be responsible and should therefore, expect a vote of no confidence and a probable banishment from Lukolo.

Anyway after long persuasion by the RC boss, tempers cooled down and for three complete weeks arrangements were amicably made for the 'great day'.

Kyasanku with four of his friends volunteered to put up a giant shed (ekidaala) and also took charge of the preparation of the local brew. Fro tarpaulins, banana leaves would do. The cutting and delivery of these materials to the ground was assigned to the women and children. This group would also cut grass and spread it in the shed when time came.

The issue of who would attend the function was seriously debated. One group of men felt that as usual it was the men and their adolescent sons. The other group felt that they would allow some unmarried women (old girls) and widows and school children for their entertainment role.

Others had heard that this was a women's function. Women's function? Whose wives were to be left to loiter just like that.

Well, at the end of it all it was agreed that all women be given permission to attend; but with strict instructions to stick to singing and dancing to entertain the visitors. They were not to ask any questions and they would leave the venue as and when their husbands felt it was time they went to attend to their domestic roles.

All drinking places were full of discussions about their 'day'. Men wondered what this Women's Day meant. Was it to instill town madness into their women? Was it an exchange of roles between men and women for that day? Was it a revolution against culture? Many wondered how their good government allowed these women who had nothing to do in town, do it in Lukolo.

The long awaited day came. The shed had been erected in the best way possible to reflect the excitement of the day. It was quite big. The men arrived in large numbers and much earlier than the women who had to attend to the family duties first. The men got comfortably seated in the chairs available. The atmosphere was general expectant.

When they finally arrived, women shyly got their places on the dry grass, behind the men. Theirs was a mixture of uncertainty and fear. They talked among themselves in murmurs and occasionally a suppressed laughter was head here and there.

The high table (on the side of the hosts) was mostly occupied by men apart from one RC lady who, from the look on her face, was far from comfortable. The school children and the women groups that were assigned to entertain the visitors were seated in one of the front corners, ready and waiting.

The awaited guests from town arrived. Formal welcome was done and immediately the day's programme started. The RC I Secretary for Women's welcome speech was short, simple and was just bare truth. The Lukolo women were happy to see their counterparts from town. They were still the women like their grandmothers had been, and they were all ears to hear what fellow women from town had to tell the. With those few remarks, she invited the chief lady guest to address the gathering.

The lady maximally used this opportunity to educate the gathering on the political economy, the economics of development of Uganda and the rate at which the Ugandan woman had lagged behind in as far as participation was concerned.

She laboured to bring it to her audience's notice that even the returns a woman in this land got for her contribution towards national development were so meagre. She elaborately discussed the women's marginal propensity to save and all that went with it. Finally, the guest of honour handled this question of the population explosion and its effects on the economy of the country, and therefore, the ordinary woman in Lukolo.

Anyway, most of her talk seemed too hard for the Lukolo women to comprehend. But, at the end of it all, the women felt they somehow had their own view on limiting the family sizes.

After the visitors had been treated to all sorts of entertainment in form of songs, plays, poems and 11 types of dances including the 'Runyege, Bwola' and 'Nankasa' they bid farewell with a promise to pay another visit in the near future.

Life went back to normal in Lukolo and as the women went to their gardens to collect food for supper, others to the wells, and the rest to collect firewood; the discussion in small groups of three nor four centred on this 'family limit'.

There were a number of questions that the Lukolo ladies asked themselves. "Has anyone ever realised that a village woman digs for the whole family, fetches water, looks for firewood, mends all the family clothes, attends to all the sick people in the home, plans for the family nutrition, nurses the baby and attends to her husband's endless needs?

Fair as it is to get fewer numbers, how does a village woman go about all the domestic chores without the help of her dear 'little ones'? At least if each child collects a sauce-panful of water, by the end of five rounds to the well, they will have filled a big drum.

When you send them to the forest, if each one comes back with a small dry branch, that is already enough firewood to make a meal. How then could a Lukolo woman afford to limit herself to only; one girl. Girls age very quickly. Who will help around the house if she got married?

The good ladies further examined the fact that in many homes, husbands are shared. The only way one proves to her co-wife that the husband still loves her is by getting a child after another. Otherwise, the co-wife may think you have been long abandoned.

Also, in this locality, a woman's company is only guaranteed among her children. Men here, quickly realise the necessity to search for better company. The only company these poor women are left with is their children who will never find 'another mom'.

Another point raised was that the children of theses days are very unreliable behaviour wise. They do not hesitate to become disobedient. The ladies feared limiting themselves to one to two, to avoid disappointment at the end of the day when these few proved nuisances. This would be very regrettable.

All in all, the Lukolo ladies only wish to wake up one morning and find that better technology has come nearer or even into their homes; food production and preparation has become less taxing on their time and energy; and they also feel that their scope is rather wide (mother-doctor-nurse-electrician-nutritionist-transporter-farmer...). A reduction in these roles, would allow them room to specialise, in some few.

Reprinted from THE MONITOR, March 29-31, 1994.

THE MONITOR is published by The Monitor Publications, Ltd., P.O. Box 12141, Kampala Uganda. Tel: 23-69-39. Fax: 25-13-52.


LOAD-DATE: April 26, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


122 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 11, 1994 / May 8, 1994


VIEWPOINT: NOW THAT WE HAVE THE EVIDENCE, WHAT NEXT FW?


BYLINE: Allister Sparks


LENGTH: 1134 words


 

SOUTH, April 1-5, 1994

The Goldstone Commission's revelation of prima facie evidence that top police officers have been behind the hideous violence that has soaked this country in blood is no surprise to reporters who have covered the carnage.

Newspapers such as "The Weekly Mail" and "Vrye Weekblad", and foreign correspondents such as John Carlin of "The Independent", have published mountains of evidence pointing to police collaboration with Inkatha in the violence.

They have disclosed details of Vlakplaas and the CCB, of hit squads and gun-running and secret training bases in Natal and Caprivi. The fact that no prosecutions resulted from any of this pointed ineluctably to high-level intervention. 

I have seen and heard enough to be in no doubt about police involvement in the violence. As long ago as August 29, 1990, after covering a series of attacks in the East Rand and the Vaal Triangle, I wrote in my column: "Ask any reporter who has been in the townships through the mayhem of the past few weeks and he will recount instances of police bias in favour of the Inkatha fighters that he has witnessed."

There was Inkathagate in July 1991, when it was revealed police had paid Inkatha R250 000 to help it counter the ANC; the Trust Feeds trial which exposed police action in carrying out a political massacre in Natal and Goldstone's raid in November, 1992, on a renegade Military Intelligence element carrying out anti-ANC operations.

The accumulation of evidence is formidable. Now we have to look at the political implications.

First, it is clear we cannot build a new South Africa without restructuring the police force. The authorities can't go on offering the excuse of "a few rotten apples" in a force that is basically sound. The rot is at the top. The police must be given a new command structure, starting with the commissioner who has himself been named as a major obstructionist.

That brings us to political responsibility. At the head of the queue of answerable figures is Minister of Law and Order Hernus Kriel. If he knew what was going on in the upper echelons of the police force for which he was responsible, then he is as culpable as his generals.

If he did not, he is incompetent.

Either way he should go. That is the principal of cabinet responsibility honoured in all democracies. It has never been heeded by the Nat government, but we keep hearing this is a new NP committed to democracy. Whether Kriel stays or goes is a litmus test of that claim.

Even more important than Kriel's resignation from an expiring cabinet is that he should be withdrawn as the NP's candidate for premier in the Western Cape.

That is the one region the NP could win in the election, and it is unthinkable that its leadership might go to someone who may bear responsibility, albeit vicariously, for the terrible violence that has ravaged the country. If the NP wants to play a constructive role in building the new South Africa, it cannot have that as its cornerstone.

Next in the responsibility queue is Chief Mangosuthu Buthelezi, a man who has long proclaimed himself to be the champion of non-violent methods of political struggle.

He said at the time of the Inkathagate scandal that he knew nothing about the payment of the security police money to his organisation. It happened without the knowledge of this man who is the dominant figure in his party and whom associates say has a personal hand in even its smallest decisions.

Now we are told the chief minister and Police Minister knew nothing about the gun-running to his own police force, through a Commissioner of Police seconded to him from the South African security police, at Judge Goldstone has revealed. A state of sublime ignorance pervades the entire IFP national executive.

As Goldstone carefully points out the case has not been proven in court. But the prima facie evidence is there. The wheels of justice move slowly, but the political pace is running much faster and the Zulu people are going to decide how they feel about the evidence and who may have been responsible for instigating the most terrible civil war in their history.

Then there is President de Klerk. It is hardly conceivable that he could have been involved in trying to destabilise the process he initiated and on which his whole reputation depends, yet at the very least he has been naive in failing to heed the warnings that there were malevolent forces at work in the security forces.

Time and time again his response was "bring me the evidence", as though the possibility of systematic covering up of evidence within the police force never occurred to him. With an innocence that belies his political experience, he expected the police to investigate themselves "to the bone".

Did he not know, or did he not want to know? That question remains unanswerable at this point. What is certain, though is that Goldstone's report blows to pieces the NP's claim to be the one party that has kept South Africa on a stable course through this transition period.

The scale of what has happened must not be forgotten. A total of 13 500 people have died in political violence since February, 1990.

Reprinted from South, April 1-5, 1994.

South is published by South Press Services (PTY) Ltd. at 76 Darling Street, Cape Town 8001, South Africa.


LOAD-DATE: April 26, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


123 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 11, 1994 / May 8, 1994


SOUTHERN AFRICA PROJECT January 14, 1994


LENGTH: 1134 words


 

HOW THE ELECTIONS WILL WORK

Unlike the U.S. electoral system where voters select individual candidates, the election in South Africa will be based on a system of proportional representation. Under a system of proportional representation, voters are required to select the part and not the individual or their choice. Voters leave it to the parties to select the individuals who will represent them in the legislature. In South Africa, the process will work as follows:

* The National Assembly will have 400 seats. Also at the national level, there will be a 90-member Senate composed of 10 representatives from each of the nine provinces. There will also be provincial legislatures which will vary in size according to the size of the electorate in each province.

* Parties will hold nomination conferences at which they compile nomination lists for national and regional legislatures. 

* In developing the national lists, parties will be required to submit a combination of one national and nine regional lists. In particular, a single list of 200 names would be submitted as the party's "national list" and nine lists, each containing names drawn from specific regions would be presented as "regional lists". Regional lists for the National Assembly are not to be confused with separate lists for the regional legislatures. So each party will submit a total of 19 lists - 1 "national list" (for the National Assembly); 9 "regional lists) (for the National Assembly) and 9 lists for the provincial legislatures.

* However, the voter's only concern will be which party he or she prefers. In particular, the ballot form will list the names of all parties taking part in the election. Next to each party name will be the symbol identified with that party and a photograph of the party leader. The voter will be asked to place and "X" next to the party of his or her choice.

* A single balloting system will be used to elect both the National Assembly and the Provincial legislatures. The Provincial legislatures, once composed, would elect the 90-member Senate. If a dual balloting system had been chosen, a voter could select one party for the "national" portion of the National Assembly and another party for the regional portion of the National Assembly and the provincial legislature. Many of the parties advocating for the dual balloting system have strong support in certain regions but do not have a strong national following.

* After the votes are tallied, parties will be awarded seats in the National Assembly and Provincial legislatures that are reflective of the share of votes they got in the elections. So if there are 400 seats in the National Assembly and a party receives half of all votes cast in the election, that party would be entitled to seat the first 100 nominees appearing on its "national list" and the first half of the nominees appearing on each of the "regional lists" in the National Assembly. Similarly, that party would receive half of the seats in the Provincial legislature.

* Nomination lists are required to be prepared in priority order. So if a party's share of votes translates into 3 seats in the National Assembly, the first three names appearing on the nomination list will be chosen to fill the seats. Because of this requirement, the women's lobby in South Africa has secured an agreement from the negotiating parties that not only must nomination lists include a minimum of one-third women, a female candidate will be required to appear in every third position on the nomination lists. Women advocates were concerned that parties would try to satisfy the one-third requirement by placing all of its female candidates at the bottom of their lists, thereby reducing female candidates' chances of gaining seats in the legislature.

* Once in place, the National Assembly will choose a Cabinet and President. The combination of the National Assembly and the Senate will form a "Constitutional Assembly" whose sole purpose will be to draft a permanent constitution for South Africa.

The following parties will participate in the elections in April:

Pan Africanist Congress of Azania (PAC)

Sports Organisation for Collective Contributions and Equal Rights (SOCCER)

The Keep it Straight and Simple Party (KISS)

Vryheidsfront - Freedom Front (VF-FF)

Women's Rights Peace Party (WRPP)

Workers' List Party (WLP)

Ximoko Progressive Party (XPP)

Africa Muslim Party (AMP)

African Christian Democratic Party (ACDP)

African Democratic Movement (ADM)

African Moderates Congress Party (AMCP)

African National Congress (ANC)

Democratic Party - Demokratiese Party (DP)

Dikwankwetla Party of South Africa (DPSA)

Federal Party (FP)

Luso - South African Party (LUSAP)

Minority Front (MF)

National Party - Nasionale Party (NP)

On April 20, Inkatha Freedom Party (IFP) decided to participate

Reprinted from the Southern Africa Project.

The Southern Africa Project is published by The Lawyers' Committee for Civil Rights Under Law, 1450 G Street, NW., Suite 400, Washington, DC 20005. Tel: (202) 662-8342.


LOAD-DATE: April 26, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


124 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 11, 1994 / May 8, 1994


PRESS GUIDELINES -- A HIDDEN AGENDA?


BYLINE: O.R. Awoonor-Gordon


LENGTH: 867 words


 

Reprinted by the DAILY OBSERVER from THE VISION, (Freetown, Sierra Leone), March 3-10, 1994

It is a contradiction for the NPRC to proclaim the slogan "Power to the People" while restricting ownership of the independent press to vested and monied interests.

The press is a source of information, a forum for discussion and circulation of ideas amongst the people. Who owns and controls the media should be of concern not just to journalists, but to the entire society. In a period of democratic transition it is a vital political question! 

Limiting ownership of newspapers to proprietors with at least Le6 million in assets is to deny access and control of the media to the vast majority of our people.

Journalists, teachers, workers, small business people, etc., do not have those kind of resources. The sectors which do are usually those people with vested financial interests or selfish political objectives to promote and protect.

Who will control the nation's papers after the new "guidelines" take effect? Mining companies which rape our environment but want to manipulate public relations? Lebanese businessmen with shady deals to defined? Ex-APC politicians seeking a new political lease of life?

Certainly most small papers owned and run by journalists and reflecting a wide diversity of social orientation and views will not survive the Le6 million hurdle posed by the new "guidelines".

Even papers which do find a sponsor will be at the mercy of the proprietors' interests.

The 'New Breed' for example lost its proprietor and its licence when its proprietor gained political office. The concept of editorial independence will certainly be sacrificed to political and financial ambition if the new "guidelines" are left in place.

If the NPRC slogan "Power to the People" is to be applied to information policy then it should translate itself into state support for the widest possible circulation of information and the broadest possible collective ownership of the media.

The NPRC could promote, through training and funding, co-operative ownership of papers by journalists, women's groups, trade unions and youth movements, for example. The neglected rural masses could be exposed to literacy campaigns and the outside world by local papers in our national languages, through co-cooperation between government, NGOs and the Sierra Leone Association of Journalists (SLAJ).

These and many other innovations can be achieved provided the NPRC regime is really committed to putting information in the hands of the people. A revolutionary and democratic information policy is desperately needed at this time in this country.

Let us understand, with out needless hypocrisy, that the present policy is neither revolutionary or democratic. Indeed the reactionary and backward nature of these "guidelines" is clearly apparent.

For many years now the so-called "elite" has been complaining about an "irresponsible" press. By that they meant a press which uncovered their crooked contracts, exposed their fake academic degrees and generally snooped and interfered while this APC "elite" ran the country into bankruptcy. Some people even present the case as if journalists are the one responsible for the massive looting of national resources, smuggling shameful neglect of the masses' interests and all the major ills of this country since independence.

To control the press, make it more "responsible" (i.e. prevent it exposing their terrible crimes to the masses) -- this reactionary cabal used political licensing of papers, the 1980 Newspaper Act, detention, bogus libel charges, bribery and ultimately violence during the period 1968 - 1992.

The Sierra Leone press today has been negatively affected by these measures. However, whatever ills afflict the press are the result not of too little, but too much government interference.

Reprinted from the Daily Observer, April 6, 1994.

The Daily Observer is published by The Observer Company (Gambia) Ltd., New Town-Sait Matty Junction, Bakau, P.M.B. 131. Banjul, The Gambia. Telephone: (220) 496608, 496877, 496878. Fax: (220) 496878.


LOAD-DATE: April 26, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


125 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 11, 1994 / May 8, 1994


NPRC REACTS


LENGTH: 827 words


 

Letter to the Editor

Mr. Editor,

The Government and people of Sierra Leone view with dismay your fabricated and is leading editorial of Thursday February 24, 1994.

It is true that the NPRC "promised to redeem the Sierra Leonean people from the corruption and oppression of the regime of President Momoh and his ruling All People's Congress (APC), which had dominated the country since 1968." This is well on course as the promise is steadily being made good.

What happened on December 29k, 1992 was an event in the Revolution that emancipated the people of this country and brought to a logical conclusion 24 years of APC misrule and depravity. The rest should be left to historians and posterity to judge and give a verdict within the context of our socio-economic and political achievements in due course. You should not adopt an inquisitorial attitude in this matter, offensively prying into what you are ill-informed about, and assuming the role of a prosecutor and judge at the same time. 

Your editorial failed woefully to give the true picture of the cordial relationship between the NPRC and the press in Sierra Leone. You may want to communicate your views directly to the press as they are keen to know your source of misinformation about the unrelated matters you raised in the editorial. The following is a resolution recently passed by the Sierra Leone Association of Journalists (SLAJ) on the issue of newspaper registration/re-registration and guidelines:

"The press is fully in support of the NPRC's anti-corruption and revolutionary objectives. SLAJ sees itself as a partner in progress, a contributor to national development and a key institution in this period of democratic transition."

We therefore deprecate any attempt to put a wedge between us by detractors. It is our nation that comes first.

Your assumption that newspapers were shut down and journalists jailed because they criticised the Chairman and Head of State was again fallacious and misleading. The truth of the matter is that when we had a mushrooming of newspapers and leaflets, there was a sudden emergence of cheque-book journalists everywhere, blackmailing law abiding and peaceful citizens. They were soon found out by heir own association -- SLAJ. One of these miscreant journalists was your Chernor Ojuku Sesay. His conduct was found to be inconsistent with the practices and ethics of the profession and he was consequently banned from practicing journalism for five years by his own association.

Mr. Sesay submitted a public apology for some false allegations he made in his paper against an innocent citizen, which caused this citizen considerable torment. It is government's responsibility to protect its citizens. It is in the light of this that guidelines are usually provided as safeguards for the protection of our citizens against unscrupulous journalists and reporters.

Paul Kamara simply did not apply for registration. No one arbitrarily closed his paper. It was his own decision not to print against. The 'New Citizen' was neither "closed" under decree 6 nor because of what your paper referred to as "irresponsible reporting". The editor was ordered to appear in court for publishing a newspaper without an imprint showing the name of the editor, proprietor and contact address. The implications for this act of omission you would agree would be far-reaching.

On the issue of press guidelines the purpose is not to muzzle the press as you conjectured. An objective analysis could have highlighted the advantages these guidelines would generate. Among other things, high standards of journalism and responsible practices would be enhanced. Most of the editors of the newspapers in question have accepted these guidelines as sensible and reasonable. Government is still encouraging dialogue on the matter. Meanwhile, registration of newspapers is well under way.

Captain Abdul Rahman, Kamara (Rtd), PRO - NPRC, Freetown

Reprinted from the Daily Observer, April 6, 1994.


LOAD-DATE: April 26, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


126 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 11, 1994 / May 8, 1994


THE TRUTH, NOT GUNS AND BAYONETS


LENGTH: 800 words


 

Editorial, DAILY OBSERVER

Captain Valentine Strasser and his National Provisional Ruling Council (NPRC) are typical aren't they?

When they seized power in a military coup in April 1992, they promised to redeem the Sierra Leonean people from the corruption and oppression of the regime of President Momoh and his ruling All People's Congress (APC), which had dominated the country since 1968.

But like all military leaders before him, and like so many civilian African leaders, Capt. Strasser and his group have, once tasting power, wasted no time in mobilising all the powers of the state -- and even the power which the state does not justly have -- against innocent and helpless people and institutions and, as a result, against the country as a whole.

This young soldier of only 28 years first shocked the world when he ordered the summary execution of 26 alleged coup plotters. Then he moved on the press, jailing and summarily shutting down the offices of any journalist who would dare to be critical of any of his brutal and ruthless acts. By mid 1993, barely a year after he seized power, most of the country's 31 newspapers had disappeared, leaving only 11, and these were also in a state of siege, thanks to the draconian laws instituted against the press. 

Under one of the laws, called Decree 6, the 'New Citizen' newspaper was closed in late 1993 for what the information ministry called "irresponsible reporting". Its only crime: an editorial critical of the government's human rights record. Paul Kamara, editor of 'For Di People', who was invited by UNESCO in 1991 to attend the Windhoek Seminar on an Independent and Pluralistic Press in Africa, was jailed and his newspaper was closed. Earlier, Chernor Ojuku Sesay, editor of 'The Pool' newspaper, had been summoned by Lt. Solomon Musa, the then vice chairman of the NPRC, and brutally beaten until he became unconscious.

Now the Strasser government has come up with a new set of measures to control journalists and newspapers. Publishers now wishing to re-register their newspapers have to deposit one million leones as collateral and must have assets valued at a minimum of five million leones. The Sierra Leonean Association of Journalists (SLAJ) has quite naturally, strongly criticised these measures, aptly describing them as 'primitive, illegal and repressive and an interference' in press matters.

In a country where less than 60 per cent of the population is literate, and whose economy, owing to over three decades of graft, corruption and mismanagement, has long been all but bankrupt, where in the world is a newspaper expected to raise that kind of money?

By attempting to muzzle the press, Strasser is employing the same old tactic that has led many African nations to chaos and destruction. For he seems not to realise that the media are the only link between himself and the people he claims to be serving. When he muzzles the press, he muzzles his people also, and creates a state of fear and trepidation in the country. But for how long?

How long does he think he can run away from truth -- that stubborn, indomitable, immovable originator and monitor of all human and natural substances and events in the universe? Can Strasser run away from God? He is Truth Personified.

We submit that Mr. Strasser is too young for that. If he really loves his people and wants them to love him in return, he should leave them alone to express their opinions about anything in the country, including the way their government is run. How else can he know how well -- or how badly -- he is doing?

In the end, the press would be his friend, not his enemy; for it is the one instrument in society which can tell him the truth -- the truth that can surely make him and the country free.

Nothing else can, certainly not his guns and bayonets.

Reprinted from the Daily Observer, February 24, 1994.


LOAD-DATE: April 26, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


127 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


April 11, 1994 / May 8, 1994


Nigeria;THE INTERVIEW THAT MADE THE GENERALS MAD


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 3827 words


 

NEWSWATCH, April 11, 1994

The following are excerpts from an interview in 'Newswatch' magazine with Brigadier-General David Mark, a former government minister under President Ibrahim Babangida. He is one of 17 senior officers who were forcibly retired in November after General Sani Abacha ousted the interim civilian-led administration that was appointed to run the country following Babangida's resignation in August.

When the interview was published earlier this month, the Abacha government reacted angrily. Ray Ekpu, founding editor of 'Newswatch', was detained, along with four other journalists from the magazine: names. Ekpu, who was on vacation when Agbese was arrested on April 8, was himself picked up at Calabar airport, in the east of the country, when he arrived to fly to Lagos to assist his colleagues. All were released on April 18 and charges were dropped. The magazine and the detainees have sued the government for damages.

Newswatch: It is said that you were involved with the military's return to power on November 17 with General Abacha as head of state. What do you say to that if indeed as you said you are for democracy? 

Mark: It is not yet time for me to say who was involved and who played what role but suffice to say for now that Abacha's regime qualifies for a space in the Guinness Book of Records as the greatest betrayal of the century. It is a betrayal of the military officers involved, it is a betrayal of the CD (Campaign for Democracy) and CLO (Civil Liberties Organisation) people and it is a betrayal of hope and aspirations for all Nigerians. It is a betrayal of democracy. It was not a coup against the ING but as it turned out it was a coup against democracy; supported and nourished by politicians who behave like chameleons. Surprisingly it was Abiola's close associates who were urging Abacha to take over. They dined with Abiola in the afternoon but in the night urged Abacha to seize power and forget June 12. I never believed that human beings could be so treacherous, unprincipled, and shameless.

Newswatch: Can you elaborate?

Mark: It is a betrayal because what the administration is doing now is the exact opposite of what we agreed and what we set out to do. It is a complete turn around. I am so disappointed that I had to write a letter to General Diya on it.

Newswatch: What happened?

Mark: When we saw that things were getting out of control in the country and it had become obvious that the interim government could not hold an election and the ship of state was drifting precariously, we reluctantly decided that the military should again intervene. When we met we considered three possible options. The first option was to give Shonekan and his team the teeth to be able to bite and conduct the presidential election successfully as was in the transition programme. The second option was to go for a short but full military regime for six months and conduct only; th presidential election thereafter. And the third option was a mixed grill, a diluted military regime for no more than one year, culminating again in a presidential election.

Most of us favoured option one for obvious reason. We believed that Nigeria at that time, was not in the mood for a military regime. People were no longer prepared to tolerate the military. In addition, most of us were acutely aware that the entire world was moving toward democracy. The dramatic effects of the last few years -- the collapse of the Soviet Union, and the rise of democratic movements are around the world clearly galvanised that point. Besides we had covered considerable distance in out tortuous march towards democracy; to do otherwise would amount to reversing the hand of the clock. The CD and CLO had gained so much popularity that it would be difficult for the military to rule effectively without bloodshed. The military had been seriously fragmented, disgraced and politicised so much so that Nigerians no longer trusted its impartiality nor respected its air of authority. The military needed to return to the barracks to put its house in order, and address the much neglected welfare problems of the troops. Sadly, our soldiers live in slums. They are totally ill equipped and untrained, in spite of all the money gulped buy the Ministry of Defence. The reasons for these were no far fetched. It was an open secret among soldiers and soldiers' wives, unfortunately, to the embarrassment of the officers, whose conditions were not nay better. These, amongst other, informed our decision in favour of option one.

Newswatch: How were you to accomplish this?

Mark: We were to accomplish option one by openly telling the nation that the military was strongly behind Shonekan and his team in their effort to complete the transition programme successfully. General Abacha was to make the announcement and warn the State Governments that were not cooperating that they risked being removed and state of emergency being declared in their states. We were to be emphatic and unequivocal in our support for Shonekan and his team. But surprisingly the Governors did not want Shonekan to succeed. They made Abacha's home their pilgrimage point and urged Abacha to take over power.

The second option was a short full fledged military regime for six months -- we discarded this for obvious reasons, some of which I have already told you. This option presented more problems than we could handle at that time. The problems included possible economic sanctions from the western world, head on collision with the international monetary and financial institutions; if at that late stage in our march towards democracy we returned to military government attain, it would completely undermine our leadership role in the African continent. And more importantly there was the possibility of being disgraced out of office by a civilian uprising. We were not even sure that the soldiers in the barracks who had also witnessed the move toward democracy around the world, would be supportive. Why should they anyway when their condition is worse off in a military regime? And we realised sadly too that the solution to our economic and political problem could not be solved by simple military decree.

The third option, which was a longer one, was a diluted military arrangement for no more than one year. Within this one year we were to conduct al the elections from local government chairmanship to the presidential. After all, Obasanjo and Yar'Adua did their elections in one year therefore there was no reason why we could not have done the same.

In all the three options, there were a few constants. The two political parties were to remain, although they could be renamed it the politicians so desired, government was to stop funding the political parties. Parties were to fund themselves, the parties were not to be treated as government parastatals. The parties were to refund N100 million each back to the government. Independent candidacy was to be allowed in all the elections and as much as possible each of the two political parties was to nominate a southern presidential candidate for obvious reasons.

Newswatch: By southern Presidential candidate do you mean a Yoruba?

Mark: No not necessarily, I mean a candidate from the southern part of Nigeria. He could be Igbo or any southern minority.

Newswatch: You did not appear to have settled on any of the three options. What we now have bears no resemblance to all the careful calculations. What happened?

Mark: Yes we did settle on an option. At the end of a stormy debate, we favoured option one while General Abacha and Diya favoured option three with modification in the duration. Abacha and Diya wanted the regime to remain in power for a minimum of five years and a maximum of eight years. The younger officers in the group objected vehemently because they maintained, and rightly so, that it would be impossible to sell Abacha to the nation or the international community for one day let along five years. They maintained that it was impossible to separate Abacha from Babangida. This marked the beginning of a major disagreement within the group. Eventually, General Abacha and Diya reluctantly agreed but with the proviso that Diya "would sound out the CD, CLO, Yoruba leaders of thought, the elders, and the Obas to see if option three would be acceptable." Diya confirmed that he sent Onagoruwa to meet the Ala'afin and to tell him that the Ooni was opposed to a military regime in hope thereby to vet his support, since Diya knew the two traditional rulers rarely agreed on any one issue. He also added that he had discussed with Jakande who was prepared to abandon Abiola if he was offered the position of Minister of External Affairs or Finance. Diya maintained that most Yoruba leaders would settle on any other Yoruba man, apart from an Egba man, as a presidential candidate. He eventually assured us that after an extensive consultation with Gani, Beko, Falana, Onagoruwa, the CLO, CD the elders, the Obas, and the leaders of through they agreed to support a total military regime for no less than five years to put the economy right. He then arranged for Onagoruwa to go and thank all those involved as well as seek the support of other eminent Yorubas...

...Newswatch: Did you have a programme for option three?

Mark: We had but they do not want to implement it because they are spending all their time and energy trying to find how they will remain in power for five years. Their whole effort is geared towards that direction.

The government was to undertake some specific programmes. The priority programme was education. The federal government was to concentrate heavily on improving the universities and other tertiary institutions all over the country. The federal government was to takeover the payment of teachers' salaries form primary schools to universities. Voluntary organisations were to be allowed to run schools up to university level.

The second priority was road networks. The federal government was to dualise the roads form the north to the south through the west and from north to south through the east. It would also complete the dualisation of the west-eat southern roads through Patani to Port Harcourt and Calabar. The federal government was also to take immediate steps to signpost all federal roads. It is indeed amazing that we spent so much money to build dual carriage roads but we cannot signpost the roads. All federal government interstate roads were to be centre paved with reflectors. The idea was to concentrate on projects that have immediate had direct impact on the ordinary Nigerian. In any case there is a limit to what could be done in one year. There was no point in biting more than we could chew.

At the swearing in ceremony of the administrators they were to be given specific tasks which were to cover the following areas: construction of roads within the states, erecting standard secondary schools buildings (not ramshackle structures), providing science equipment for al the science subjects and the provisions of potable drinking water to every community within the states. They were to concentrate on repairing all potholes, constructing covered drainage and walk paths an all roads in the state capitals. They were to ensure that the roads were usable all the year round not like Awolowo Road that is passable only; in the dry season and becomes a swimming pool with the first rain. It was to be compulsory for state governments to provide a twenty-four hour ambulance service in all the state capitals. The were also to fun to a limited extent general hospitals as efficiently as it was possible. They were to provide drugs for only common diseases such as malaria and snakebites etc. They were not to undertake the building of prestigious and white elephant project like stadia, government guest houses, or theatres of any kind. The essence of these was that government would make impact on the lives of the ordinary Nigerian on the streets. It was designed to bring government closer to the people.

Local governments were to concentrate on constructing proper buildings for primary schools and equip them with chairs, tables, blackboards, and chalk. They were to run rural health clinics, provide potable drinking water to every community in the LGA, and where possible construct rural roads. Above all it was to educate the grassroots on their civic responsibilities so that they don't sell their votes when the politicians eventually come.

The Nigerian police, the judiciary and the military were to receive special attention. The police force was to be reorganised to be more efficient and responsive, to become friends instead to goes. Every policeman on patrol was to carry a walkie-talkie. We were also to increase police foot patrol, purchase as many motor cycles as we could to increase police area patrol in the major cities. We were to change their vehicles from Land Rovers particularly for those in urban areas to faster vehicles like the Peugeot cars. We believe that the police are very poorly paid at the moment and we were to increase their allowances and improve on their accommodation. Only the police and the ambulance were to be allowed to use sirens.

We were also to improve the judiciary. We were to increase the salary of every supreme court judge from whatever it is presently to N500,0000 per annum. We were convinced that the number of supreme court judges was small enough for the government to accommodate that level of annual salary easily. This was to stop the accusation rightly or wrongly of corruption in the judiciary. We were to graduate the salaries down with the least in the judiciary hierarchy receiving N350,000 per annum. We were also to provide all the courts and judges with state of the art court reporting equipment. We were also to improve the standards of the courts, upgrade the building s and facilities such as air conditioners.

Like the police we were to do a total surgical operation on the military. At the moment for lack of words to adequately describe the situation in the military it is a "group of disorganised cowboys." Our soldiers don't have boots. Where they have boots, they don't have socks. Where they have socks they don't have a complete uniform. You could go on endlessly. They don't have the equipment and where they do have the equipment they don't function. You can go on endlessly. The military was to be our main focus. We were to ensure that they are properly accommodated and their welfare is given top priority. Their pay was to be reviewed upwards immediately. That our soldiers have not revolted like the Zaireans is a demonstration of their high discipline indeed they remain the most disciplined soldiers of the African soil.

Also as a part of the programme the minister of education was to be tasked within the first one week to draw what would constitute our national values. These values were to be taught in primary and secondary schools as well as in higher institutions. Indeed it was to be a deliberate policy of indoctrination. We believe that education is a primary vehicle in democratisation, technological development, and fundamental human rights in the world today. We had to place a lot of emphasis on education to lay a solid foundation for the future.

Newswatch: Your plan did not seem to include on of the cardinal programmes of the Abacha administration, the constitutional conference. Did it ever feature in your discussion?

Mark: There was no mention of a constitutional conference on l;y a national conference and even that was a controversial point. When Diya first introduced it, he said it was the only basis on which CD/CLO and the Yorubas would support the military government and that the very first announcement must emphatically state that there would be "a national conference." We accepted it because on the face value of it, we didn't see nay problem with a national conference, but when we wanted further explanation, in fairness to him, he confessed that it was to be used as a smoke screen for the government to buy time for five years. He circulated a paper in which he said the national conference would take nine months to a year to set up, the committee would then be given one year to complete its task and the government would take six months to study their submissions and recommendations before producing a white paper. The government would take six months after accepting the white paper to register the political parties. The conference was to be teleguided to recommend that the elections be spread over two years. That would be a total of four years and nine months or five years but it would be approximated to six years. The hidden design is for the regime to end on a historic note on the 31st December, 1999. At every stage of the discussion he tried desperately to convince us to accept 31st December, 19999 as the handover date but we remained adamant that if we didn't take option one then one year was the maximum time acceptable for option three. We became more resistant when we discovered that all issues to be discussed by the national conference were either already covered in the Political Bureau report or were contained in the constitution, unless, of course, we were going to allow room for secession.

Unfortunately, what has come out is a constitutional conference instead of a national conference. From the original national conference, it is now a constitutional conference. What is the constitutional conference going to address? Nothing. Diya wanted the conference to determine the duration of the stay of government. How can the conference that does not know what the government agenda is, decide how long the government should stay? It is ridiculous and unbelievable. It is a delay tactic and a ploy., And that is what Diya wanted it to be.

Newswatch: If you objected to the conference, how did Diya have his way?

Mark: We did no object to the conference per se but we objected to the fact that the conference was to be used by some perpetualists as delay tactics. This is the reason why nobody appears to know what the conference is to over. It is an open ended conference.

Diya had his way because we are note there now. That is the more reason why they wanted us out of the way. So that they could have their way and take the nation for a ride on a directionless roller coaster. Whether it is a national or constitutional conference it is not going to address any new issues. As long as the conference is on, Abacha and Diya will remain in power and that is what they wanted...

...Newswatch: What is the way forward?

Mark: I have already sent a note to the Head of State on the way forward. You can get a copy from him. The summary is that he must find a way to have by 31 December 1994 to a nominated national government to speedily conduct an election or come out with his political programme immediately which must end within one calendar year. We cannot decree democracy overnight; we must allow it to grow as a part of our culture. In the course of growth we are bound to miss steps on the way. That should not become an excuse for any overtly ambitious military man to stop the process. We must be allowed to get up after every fall and try again.

Reprinted from NEWSWATCH, April 11, 1994.

NEWSWATCH is published Newswatch Communication Limited, No. 3 Billings Way, Oregun Industrial Estate, Oregun, P.M.B. 21499, Ikeja, Lagos, Nigeria. Tel: 4960950.

* A Debate about Press Freedom

The following editorial, letter to the editor and article have appeared in the Daily Observer in Banjul, Gambia, over the course of the last few months.

February 24, 1994


LOAD-DATE: April 26, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


May 9, 1994 / May 23, 1994


CURRENCY EXCHANGE RATES


LENGTH: 2447 words


 

Maxwell Stamp PLC

Economic Consultants

London * Nairobi * Riyadh * Mauritius

The table gives selected currencies valued against the major international trading currencies. Rates quoted are the middle rates between buying and selling, but currencies are in most cases not freely traded. These rates have been compiled by Maxwell Stamp PLC for information only. Maxwell Stamp accepts no responsibility for any transaction undertaken on the basis of these figures. For further information please contact John Morgan at Maxwell Stamp's Head Office in London; phone 44-71-251-0147; telex 914569 MAXAMP G; fax 44-71-251-0140.

                          SDR1=$           L1=$        $1=DM
                             1.42138       1.519       1.650


                             Y              FF          SF
Algeria Dinar (AD)          0.3521         6.3417      25.5516

Africa News


May 9, 1994 / May 23, 1994


BUSINESS


LENGTH: 1187 words


 

American Information Technologies (AIT) can provide computer equipment, installation, maintenance, and training services for business or individuals starting up in Africa. Contact: AIT, P.O. Box 510, Tucker, GA. Phone (404) 723-9200.

Africa Centre for Resources and Environment (ACRE) was recently established to address the concerns highlighted in the Report of the World Commission on Environment and Development (1987). The principle purpose of ACRE, a non-profit organization with headquarters in Nairobi, is to contribute to sustainable environment and socioeconomic development through the coherent linkage between appropriate policies and feasible programs of actions. ACRE's programs focus on four areas: natural resource management, technology applications, environmental and development economies, and capacity-building in environmental and resource management. Contact: Bethual Kiplagat, P.O. Box 67504, Nairobi, Kenya. Fax: 254-2-226-506. 

The following procurement opportunities in Egypt are available to U.S. companies through the U.S. Agency for International Development.

*Inductively Coupled Plasma - Optical Emission Spectrometer (ICP-OES). A.I.D. Geographic Code 000 (U.S. only). IFB No: CID93017. OFFER DEADLINE: JUNE 3, 1994. Purchasing Agent: Consortium for International Development, Write to Embassy of the Arab Republic of Egypt, 2232 Massachusetts Avenue, NW, Washington, DC 20008; Send $20.00 non-refundable fee to obtain a copy of the solicitation.

*Well Drilling Rig and Associated Equipment. A.I.D. Geographic Code 000 (U.S. only). IFB No.: CID93007. OFFER DEADLINE: JUNE 6, 1994. Purchasing Agent: Consortium for International Development, Write to Embassy of the Arab Republic of Egypt, 2232 Massachusetts Avenue, NW, Washington, DC 20008; Send $20.00 non-refundable fee to obtain a copy of the solicitation.
