LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


130 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 9, 1994 / May 23, 1994


EDUCATION/TRAVEL


LENGTH: 4120 words


 

The Center for Latin American Studies and the Center for African Studies invite junior and senior scholars to participate in an interdisciplinary program on Afro-American identity and cultural diversity in the Americas, including the Caribbean, Brazil, and the US, as well as areas of Africa. The program will enable visiting scholars to spend an year or a semester at the University of Florida to do research in this area. It will include studies of history, literature, religion, and popular culture. Each fellow will receive a maximum stipend of US$35,000 for the academic year, or half that for the semester. Applicants will be selected on a competitive basis related to their expertise and research in these areas. Candidates should submit a 100- word abstract, an essay of about 1,500 words detailing proposed research, a curriculum vitae, and two letters of recommendation. Send applications to Dr. Helen I. Safa, Center for Latin American Studies, University of Florida, P.O. Box 115530, Gainesville, FL 32611-5530; phone: (904) 392-0375; fax: (904) 392-7682. 

The Council for Development of Social Science Research in Africa (CODESRIA) has a Small Grants Program for Thesis Writing to fund M.A. and Ph.D. candidates who are in the process of completing their theses. The funds will cover expenses in a country where research is conducted, but they will not cover the cost of travel to that country. For more information contact: Dr. Cyrus Reed, Office of African Studies, American University in Cairo, P.O. Box 2511, 113 Kasr al Aini, Cairo, Egypt. The Modern Management Institute in Nairobi, Kenya offers a new home study method for learning Kiswahili, a language spoken in Kenya, Tanzania, Uganda, Malawi, Zambia, Zaire, Rwanda, Burundi, and the Sudan. The method includes a basic English/Kiswahili textbook for 24 lessons and audio cassettes to help with pronunciation. Contact: Geoffrey Njogu, Director of Studies, Modern Management Institute, P.O. Box 47390, Nairobi, Kenya; phone: (254.2) 33.17.02.

The Economic Development Institute of the World Bank announces the 1994 cycle of the Robert S. McNamara Fellowship Program which aims at producing the highest quality research results in the general area of economic development. The program also seeks to achieve wide geographical and cultural diversity among fellows. The 12-month fellowship does not support work toward an advanced degree, but innovative and imaginative post-graduate research in areas of economic development. Contact: Robert S. McNamara Fellowship Program, Room M-4029, World Bank Headquarters, 1818 H. St., N.W., Washington, DC 20433.

The Community Law Center in Durban, South Africa offers internship opportunities for law students and some undergraduates from outside South Africa. CLC is affiliated with the University of Natal, and places emphasis on assisting the rural areas of South Africa. CLC publishes a quarterly newsletter, Izindaba. Contact: The Community Law Center, Berea Center, 7th Floor, 247 Berea Road, Durban 4001, South Africa.

The United States Institute of Peace sponsors two all-expense paid summer seminars for educators. "International Peace, Security, and Conflict Management" is a summer institute for high school social studies teachers August 6-13, 1994 in Washington, DC. The DEADLINE for receipt of applications from social studies teachers is APRIL 15, 1994. For further information, contact: United States Institute of Peace, Education and Training Program, 1500 M Street, NW, Suite 700, Washington, DC 20005-1700. Phone: (202) 457-1700. Fax: (202) 429-6063. E-mail: msoley@usip.org.

Fulbright Faculty Awards are available for university lecturing or advanced research in over 135 countries. Awards range from two months to a full academic year. Applications are encouraged from professional outside academe as well as from faculty at all types of institutions. For more information, contact: Council for International Exchange of Scholars, 3007 Tilden St., NW, Suite 5M, Box GBRO, Washington, DC 20008-3009. Phone: (202) 686-7877. Bitnet: CIES1@GWUVM.GWU.EDU.

The National Humanities Center awards approximately 35-40 residential fellowships each year for the advanced study of the arts and other fields in the liberal arts. Social scientists, natural scientists, or professionals whose work has a humanistic dimension are encouraged to apply. Applicants must hold a PhD or the equivalent degree. For more information, contact: Fellowship Program, National Humanities Center, Box 12256, Research Triangle Park, NC 27709.

The University of Cape Town's Centre for African Studies announces the Harry Oppenheimer Research Fellowship. Applicants are considered annually in December for the following year. The fellowship is for three to six months, depending on the recipient's program. Fellows receive R7500 and are expected to deliver and Africa Seminar and contribute to the cultural life of the Centre. For more information, contact: Harry Oppenheimer Institute, UCT Private Bag, 7700 Ronderbosch, University of Cape Town, South Africa. Phone: (021) 650-3273. Fax: (021) 650-3274. E-Mail: erasmus@socsci.uct.ac.za.

African Development Foundation (ADF) is a public enterprise set up in 1980 by the US Congress to support self-development initiatives by African populations. The major goal is to provide the resources needed by African grassroots populations to reach self-reliant development. ADF does not impose external development concepts on African communities. Instead, it encourages Africans to suggest innovative approaches to problem-solving, which will eventually lead to self-reliance and self-sufficiency in the local communities. Researchers are requested to explore problems directly related to grassroots development and to make concrete recommendations that can be of assistance to development project promoters in the community. ADF provides grants for research initiated and conducted by African academics, development specialists, students and community groups. Researchers are encouraged to be creative in selecting their theme and to focus their research on issues which are crucial to the development of their countries. In 1994, ADF will allocate approximately US $675,000 to research project funding. Four types of fellowships will be awarded: Gray postgraduate fellowships (deadline August 1, 1994); Be applied research fellowships (deadline August 1, 1994); Grants for transfer of knowledge (no deadline); Leland development fellowships (deadline January 1, 1995). For information contact: Office of Learning and Dissemination, African Development Foundation, 1400 Eye Street, NW, Tenth Floor, Washington, DC 20005.

First Run/Icarus Films offer a collection of over 450 films and videos on South Africa. Some of the most recently released titles are "Ordinary People", "Mama Awethu!", "The Peacemakers", "The Lawyer, the Farmer and the Clerk", "Sebokeng by Night", "The Penalty Area", "City of Dreams", "The Tooth of the Times", "Make Believe", "Enthombe", "South African Chronicles", "The Two Rivers", and "The Ribbon". For a comprehensive catalog describing available titles, write or call: First Run/Icarus Films, 153 Waverly Place, Sixth Floor, New York, NY 10014. Tel: (212) 72701711 or (800) 876-1710. Fax: (212) 989-7649.

The Translations Program of the National Endowment for the Humanities supports individuals or collaborations among scholars to translate into English works that are germane to the history, literature, philosophy, and artistic achievements of other cultures, thereby making the thought and learning of those civilizations available to scholars, teachers, students and the public. The next application deadline is JUNE 1, 1994 for projects beginning after April 1, 1995. For more information call (202) 606-8207 or write to Translations, Room 318, National Endowment for the Humanities, 1100 Pennsylvania Ave., NW, Washington, DC 20506. Fax (202) 606-8204. E-mail nehres@gwuvm.gwu.edu.

The National Research Council announces the 1994 Resident, Cooperative, and Postdoctoral Research Associateship Programs to be conducted on behalf of federal agencies or research institutions whose 140 participating research laboratories are located throughout the United States. The program provides opportunities for PhD scientists and engineers of unusual promise and ability to perform research on problems largely of their own choosing yet compatible with the research interests of the sponsoring laboratory. Areas of interest include chemistry, earth and atmospheric sciences, engineering and applied sciences, biological, health, and behavioral science and biotechnology, mathematics, space and planetary sciences, and physics. Applications submitted directly to the National Research Council are accepted on a continuous basis throughout the year. Those postmarked no later than 15 August will be reviewed in October. Initial awards will be announced in July and November. Information on specific research opportunities and participating federal laboratories, as well as application materials, may be obtained from the Associateship Programs.

The National Endowment for the Humanities (NEH) seeks applications from the nation's precollegiate humanities teachers who wish to undertake an academic year of full-time independent study in history, literature, the classics, foreign languages, or other disciplines of the humanities. Annually, on 1 May, NEH accepts applications for Teacher-Scholar awards. For guidelines and further information about the NEH Teacher-Scholar award, contact the National Endowment for the Humanities, Division of Education Programs, Room 302, 1100 Pennsylvania Ave., NW, Washington, DC 20506. Tel (202) 606-8377.

A new $10,000 book award will recognize the best work received in Continuum's principal publishing areas: religious studies, literature and the arts, psychology and social thought, and women's studies. Manuscripts that are interdisciplinary in nature and that offer innovative and theoretical perspectives of wide-ranging cultural importance are the primary focus of the award. Continuum will consider manuscripts for the award twice yearly: deadlines for receipts of completed manuscripts are 1 FEBRUARY and 1 SEPTEMBER; awards (if granted) will be announced 1 MAY and 1 DECEMBER. Monies awarded represent an advance against royalties, and will be granted as often as a book is found to merit the award, nut no more than once a year. Manuscripts should be sent to Continuum Book Award at 370 Lexington Avenue, New York, NY 10017. Continuum catalog available upon request.

The SSRC-MacArthur Foundation Committee on International Peace and Security announces a 1994 program of small grants allowing scholars and students of international relations to visit major universities and research centers outside their home region. Grants are intended for junior scholars who seek exposure to debates and scholarship on the changing international system and issues of international peace and security. These grants will be awarded to well-qualified applicants for study at major research centers selected in consultation with Council staff. Post-graduate applicants should have received their doctorate within the past seven years. Applications should be complete and returned to the Council, post-marked no later than 15 JULY 1994. For information or materials, contact Social Science Research Council, Visiting Scholar Fellowship, Program on International Peace and Security, 605 Third Avenue, 17th Floor, New York, NY 10158. Tel: (212) 661-0280, fax: (212) 370-7896.

The Collaborative Projects Program of the National Endowment for the Humanities welcomes applications for projects of broad scholarly and public significance in the humanities that entail the collaboration of two or more scholars for periods 1-3 years. All topics in the humanities are eligible. Awards usually range from $10,000 to about $150,000. The deadline is OCTOBER 15, 1994 for projects beginning no earlier than July of the next year. For application materials and further information write or call: Collaborative, Projects/Interpretive Research, Division of Research Programs, Room 318, 1100 Pennsylvania Ave., NW, Washington, DC 20506. Tel: (202) 606-8210.

The National Endowment for the Humanities Reference Materials Program supports projects to prepare reference works that will improve access to information and resources. Support is available for the creation of dictionaries, historical or linguistic atlases, encyclopedias, concordances, reference grammars, databases, textbooks, and other projects that will provide essential scholarly tools for the advancement of research or for general reference purposes. Support is also available for projects that address important issues related to the design or accessibility of reference works. The application deadline of 15 SEPTEMBER 1994 for projects beginning after 1 JULY 1995. For more information write to Reference Materials, Room 318, NEH, Washington, DC 20506.

The Re-entry Grants for African Scholars Pursuing Education Research program is designed to assist in the professional re-establishment of talented African scholars who are returning from doctoral studies abroad and have a research interest in issues related to the revitalisation and development of education in sub-Saharan Africa. All proposed projects must include and explicitly and substantial focus on female school participation as part of the set of educational issues to be examined. The proposed budget, not to exceed $25,000, any request funding for items such as a microcomputer and software, books, office supplied, living expenses, personnel assistance and local transportation. The budget may also include subsistence for on research team member of any nationality and a stipend to cover up to 6 month's transition costs for the returning African scholar. Applicants may submit research proposals prior to or within one year of returning to their Africa-based institutions. Grants are made to the scholar, but the proposal must be endorsed by the African institution where the application will be a full-time staff member. Also required are two letters of recommendation from academic supervisors at the institution where the candidate carried out doctoral study, postgraduate transcripts, and a resume. There are no deadlines for submission of proposals. For a full description of the program, write to Scholars on Education Re-Entry Program, The Rockefellar Foundation, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, New York, NY 10036 or Scholars on Education Re-Entry Program, The Rockefellar Foundation, P.O. Box 47543, Nairobi, Kenya.

The Social Science Research Council/American Council of Learned Societies is calling for proposals for their African Archives and Museums Project (AAMP). The AAMP is designed to help museums and archives in their efforts to overcome problems of funding and materials. AAMP awards two types of grants: seed grants and implementation grants. Seed grants up to $5,000 are intended to advance the conceptual and logistical development of conservation, documentation or exhibition/outreach/education projects. Implementation grants from $5,000 up to $15,000 are intended to support conservation, documentation, and exhibition/outreach/education activities. AAMP is especially receptive to projects that draw on local expertise and community resources and bring together different institutions in cooperative ventures. For more information and for a list of 1993 awards, address inquiries to the African Archives and Museums Projects, Social Science Research Council, 605 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10158. Tel: (212) 661-0280. Fax: (212) 370-7896.

Environmental Briefs Corp. is a non-profit organization that publishes a newsletter updating African environmental scientists on recent findings published in academic literature. The students intern would serve as an editorial assistant. Duties would include: reading and summarizing articles in the academic literature; going to university libraries to photocopy articles; writing letters to journal editors and article authors; and updating mailing lists. Knowledge of or familiarity with calculus, mathematical models, the earth sciences and Africa would be helpful. Computer experience (preferably in a Macintosh environment) is also a plus. While this is an unpaid internship, it will provide invaluable experience to anyone interested in a career in either international development of the environment. Please contact Catherine Camp Boyle, Environmental Briefs Corp., 22 Willowdale Road, Winchester, MA 01890.

The Population-Environment Fellows Program, sponsored by USAID and administered at the University of Michigan, sponsors fellow for two-year appointments with overseas agencies. Fellows, who must hold a graduate degree in a relevant area and demonstrated expertise a both population and environment, provide assistance and technical support for developing country institutions to foster a comprehensive approach to development. Applications are reviewed on a rolling basis, but the sooner a completed application is received, the greater the availability of sites for which it can be considered. Inquiries and application requests may be obtained by contacting: The Population-Environment Fellows Program, SPH II, Room M2240, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109-2029. Tel: (313) 747-0222. Fax: (313) 747-4947.

The University of Florida sponsors academic year abroad programs in Tanzania and Nigeria and summer programs in Uganda and Morocco. At the University of Dar es Salaam in Tanzania, students spend an academic year studying Swahili. A summer field course in tropical rain forest ecology and conservation will be offered in the Kibale Forest of Western Uganda at the Makere University Biological Field Station. A Summer Arabic Language, Conversation and Translation Program is located in Fez, Morocco. Contact: Overseas Studies, Office of International Studies and Programs, 123 Tigert Hall, University of Florida, Gainesville, FL 32611. Tel: (904) 392-5206. Fax: (904) 392-5575.

Research grants in African Rural Development Issues are offered by the Winrock International Institute for Agricultural Development. Although the fourth round of grants had a deadline of February 1, 1994, interested social scientists may contact Winrock for further information on future funding opportunities. Contact: Dirk Perthel, Winrock International, 08 B.P. 1603, Abidjan 08, Cote d'Ivoire. Phone: (225) 44-94-14. Fax: (225) 44-94-11. Their U.S. office is at 1611 N. Kent St., #600, Arlington, VA 22209. Tel: (703) 525-9430. Fax: (703) 525-1744.

The Federal Court Interpreter Certification Project will offer examinations for several languages, including Arabic, on August 27, 1994. Successful completion of these examinations does not constitute an offer of employment by the United States Courts, but this written examination constitutes the first step in achieving certification or otherwise qualified status. The fee for the written exam is $80 for each language requested. All applications for the exam must be postmarked no later than July 1, 1994. Contact: Federal Court Interpreter Project, Modern Languages Building, Room 445, University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721. Tel: (602) 621-3687. Fax: (602) 624-8130.

WorldTeach provides opportunities for graduating seniors and others to spend one year teaching English, math or science in Namibia or South Africa. For details contact WorldTeach Inc., Harvard Institute for International Development, One Eliot Street, Cambridge, MA 02138-5705. Tel: (617) 495-5527.

The Washington Office on Africa (WOA) seeks interns for Spring and Summer semesters 1994. For more information and an application form contact The Washington Office on Africa, 110 Maryland Avenue, NE, Washington, DC 20002. Tel: (202) 546-7961. Fax: (202) 546-1545.

The American Committee on Africa/The Africa Fund seeks interns for its New York office. For further information contact Adrena Ifill, The Africa Fund, 198 Broadway, New York, NY 10038.

The UIUC-Egerton University Study Abroad Program allows undergraduates to spend eight weeks (June 6-August 7) in Kenya this summer. Interested students should contact the Study Abroad Office, University of Illinois, immediately. Tel: (217) 333-6322.

University of Minnesota, Minnesota Studies in International Development (MSID) offers an academic year program of internships and field study including 5 months in Senegal or Kenya. Financial aid is available. Details are available at the Center of through: MSID, The Global Campus, University of Minnesota, 106-M Nicholson Hall, 216 Pillsbury Drive SE, Minneapolis, MN 55455-0138. Tel: (216) 625-3379.

The Center for Global Education announces a semester-long program in Namibia designed to introduce students to the central issues facing Southern Africa. Course credit may be earned. Applications and brochures are available from Center for Global Education, Augsburg College, 2211 Riverside Avenue, Minneapolis, MN 55454. Tel: (612) 330-1159.

The Southern Africa Education Program at Stony Point Center is planning a tour of South Africa June 29-July 16. Interested persons should contact William Palmer, SAEP, Stony Point Center, 17 Crickettown Road, Stony Point, NY 10980. Tel: (914) 786-5072. Deadline is MAY 15, 1995.

Baylor in Africa is a five-week study program headquartered near Nairobi, Kenya. The program will run May 27-July 1. For details contact Blake Burleson, Director, Baylor in Africa '94, Box 97313, Baylor University, Waco, TX 76798-7313. Tel: (817) 755-3505.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1994


LANGUAGE: English

131 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 9, 1994 / May 23, 1994


EMPLOYMENT


LENGTH: 5267 words


 

The American Friends Service Committee has the following openings:

NATIONAL REPRESENTATIVE FOR ECONOMIC JUSTICE (this position has been reopened): Carry major responsibility for forging AFSC understanding of economic changes affecting jobs, income and services for low income people and people of color; bring understandings to communities and policymakers; support and foster regional work on economic justice issues, focusing on housing and homelessness, welfare policy and jobs. Requires: demonstrated oral and written communication skills; experience in program development and/or community based work addressing needs of low income people; experience in fair housing/homelessness work or welfare rights work desirable; strong oral and written communication skills; experience in multicultural, multiracial work; skill in word processing, willingness to learn this skill; willingness and ability to carry out significant travel. (Address: Lydia Wilcox).

ASSISTANT TO THE DIRECTOR, PLANNED GIVING: Responsible for processing new gifts and additions to existing gifts. Day-to-day oversight to assure compliance with existing agreements; respond to questions from prospects, fundraisers and planned giving participants. Maintain and update information on existing planned gifts. Maintain and update current information on donors, income beneficiaries and gift terminations. Requires: B.S. degree preferred; high school education accepted if experience is equivalent; experience with trusts as accountant or administrator; knowledge of securities; computer experience; ability to do detailed financial work, good communication, writing and telephone skills. (Address: Clara Wright). 

ASSISTANT DIRECTOR (PROGRAM), INTERNATIONAL DIVISION: In consultation with the Division Director, work closely with program desk staff to support the development, project and disaster work especially, with some attention also to international affairs and reconciliation programs; work with the Development Department to assure timely submission of proposals and narrative reports to funding partners, especially in regard to grants that support work in more than one geographic area; supervise the Director of the Material Aids program and the Assistant for Publication; make occasional field visits. Requires: several years of experience in development work abroad and/or in the administration of development programs from a US base; demonstrated skill in program exploration and evaluation; experience in or knowledge of the field of conflict management very useful; demonstrated skill in writing in English, editing, layout; ability to attend some evening and weekend meetings and to travel abroad for periods up to 4 weeks; fluency in English essential, in Spanish and French highly desirable; experience in and enthusiasm for fundraising proposal and report writing. (Address: Lydia Wilcox). For further information on all positions listed write AFSC Human Resources Office, 1501 Cherry Street, Philadelphia, PA 19102. Phone: (215) 241-7102 or 7114.

Development/environment non-profit seeks a Communications Officer who will assist with evaluation of organizational communications needs' outreach to the federal government, Congress, the media, the international development community, and the public; preparation and dissemination of promotional materials. Candidates must have excellent writing skills and solid experience with Windows computer applications. Submit resume and writing samples to: Communications Director, ATI, 1828 L Street NW, Suite 1000, Washington, DC 20036.

International Action Against Hunger seeks the following: HEALTH COORDINATOR, Northeast Somalia: Individual to be responsible for developing a health education curriculum to be used in PHC facilities and communities in northeast Somalia, training in use of the curriculum and oversight of its implementation. Works closely with PHC and community organization teams. Requires MPH or related degree, demonstrated skill in development of community-responsive curricula, commitment to participatory techniques, 2+ years experience. COMMUNITY ORGANIZER, Northeast Somalia: Individual to be responsible for facilitating the support by local community of community-based health systems; assist in identifying those needs; facilitate activities with local NGOs. Requires relevant degree with 2+ years overseas community- based experience. Strong communications skills and ability to live and thrive in a challenging environment are necessary. HEALTH EDUCATION SPECIALIST, Northeast Somalia: Individual to be responsible for developing a health education curriculum to be used in PHC facilities and communities in northeast Somalia, training in use of the curriculum and oversight of its implementation. Works closely with PHC and community organization teams. Requires MPH or related degree, demonstrated skill in development of community-responsive curricula, commitment to participatory techniques, 2+ years experience. Assignments generally for 6-12 months, with opportunity for renewal. Competitive compensation package. Mail/fax cover letter, resume and salary requirements to: AICF/USA, 815 15th Street NW, Suite 832, Washington, DC 20005. Fax: (202) 783-5247.

American Refugee Committee has the following positions available:

In Somalia: MATERNITY SERVICES COORDINATOR: based in Afmadou, southern Somalia. Responsibilities: select and train MCH maternity services staff; establish policies and procedures for the MCH Center maternity services; supervise the delivery of maternity services. Qualifications: experienced Certified Nurse Midwife; experience in a developing country preferably in a rural setting; training and supervision background. Immediate opening; 6-month commitment. $1,500/month.

In Sudan: MEDICAL DOCTOR to provide emergency relief to displaced persons in Kajo Keji County. RESPONSIBILITIES: set up emergency/acute care clinic and coordinate all in-patient and out-patient activities. REQUIREMENTS: MD with emergency/acute care experience in developing countries and proven success in implementing new programs in relief situations. 6 month commitment. $1,200-$1,600/month. Immediate opening.

FIELD COORDINATOR/LOGISTICIAN: 3 years experience in developing countries. Administration and logistical experience a must. 12 month commitment required. Salary, insurance, round-trip transportation and room and board provided.

NURSE PRACTITIONER: Experience in developing countries. To assist with EPI program. 12 month commitment required. Salary, insurance, round-trip transportation and room and board provided.

Resume or letter of interest to International Medical Corps, Dept. 94-008, 12233 Olympic Blvd., #280, Los Angeles, CA 90064. Fax: (310) 442-6622.

The Center for International Development and Environment of the World Resources Institute seeks individual with experience in natural resources management, institutions, and/or natural resource and policy activities in Africa, particularly national plans and strategies for sustainable development. Africa experience and excellent language competence in French required. Will be responsible for the coordination and implementation of the Center's activities in sustainable development planning in Africa. Will coordinate the Natural Resource Management Policy Consultative Group for Africa, with priority on an on-going study of sustainable development planning in 8 African countries. Position includes field work, analytical report writing, some policy research, and preparing workplans and budgets. Send resume to: Africa Program, CIDE/WRI, 1709 New York Avenue NW, Suite 700, Washington, DC 20006.

OIC International seeks a SMALL ENTERPRISE MANAGEMENT/DEVELOPMENT AND APPROPRIATE TECHNOLOGY SPECIALIST to provide technical assistance and training in value-added transformation and raw produce with the purpose of creating employment and economic development opportunities for unemployed youths and disadvantaged communities in African and other countries. The person will identify cottage industry and appropriate technologies adaptable to the client countries; develop curricula to train related entrepreneurial and technical skills to develop and manage such businesses. REQUIREMENTS: First degree in engineering followed by an MBA or equivalent education in Business Management; experience in related development work, and working experience in Africa in particular, first hand experience managing business and/or in appropriate technology development; fluent in English and French; knowledge of Spanish is advantageous. Travel required. Send resume: President and CEO, OIC International, 240 W. Tulpehocken Street, Philadelphia, PA 19144.

International Medical Corps has multiple openings. Mail or fax resume or letter of interest to International Medical Corps, Dept. 93- 033, 12233 West Olympic Blvd., #280, Los Angeles, CA 90064; fax: (310) 442-6622. Logistics, bookkeeping, administrative skills and strong management skills. **DEPUTY DIRECTOR. Strong management, logistics, administrative and financial skills. **EPI TRAINER with strong teaching skills and implementation experience. IMC is seeking a **HOSPITAL ADMINISTRATOR/EDUCATOR for its Emergency Medical Program in Somalia. Requires prior international hospital administration experience in developing countries. Will train local medical personnel. Requires a minimum of a 6 month contract.

These advisers will provide technical advice and management capabilities to the AID Mission to Kenya. QUALIFICATIONS: MPH or equivalent in health field; experience with AIDS prevention and Child Survival activities of USAID; excellent communications and analytical skills; 5+ years experience in developing countries; data and word processing skills. Aviation experience strongly preferred. Africa experience a plus. Send resume to: Personnel Dept., AirServ International, Box 3041, Redlands, CA 92373.

The International Rescue Committee operates refugee relief programs in over 20 countries worldwide and is seeking: a CASE WORKER to assist in resettlement services for newly arrived refugees. Services include but are not limited to: housing, school enrollment, health screening, and job placement. Applicants must have a BSW or related degree/experience. Language skills (Arabic, Croatian, Somali) are preferred but not required. JOB DEVELOPER to network with area employers, source jobs, and create a hob back to assist in job placement for newly arriving refugees. Applicants must have previous related experience and be able to work with a variety of nationalities. Send resumes to: IRC, Recruitment Office, 386 Park Avenue South, New York, NY 10016. Tel: (212) 679-0010. Fax: (212) 689-3459.

Africare has an immediate opening for a population and family planning project manager. Project manager will be a counterpart to the manager of a local NGO implementing a family planning program funded by USAID and other donors. Candidates should possess: advanced degree with 5-10 years of professional experience in a health-related field; background in project management, especially in health-related development projects in Africa; demonstrated understanding of clinical training, health services delivery, marketing activities and HIS; excellent French; working knowledge of such computer programs as WordPerfect, Lotus 123, DBase 3, SPSS, etc. Send resume and salary history to: Ms. Carolyn Gullatt, Africare House, 440 R Street NW, Washington, DC 20001. Resident Director in Ghana is needed for a new undergraduate program at the University of Ghana in Legon, offered by the Council on International Education Exchange. Candidates must have a PhD, university-level teaching experience, and experience in Africa. Contact: CIEE, 205 E. 42nd St., New York, NY 10017.

African Language Instructors for the University of Wyoming's African-American Studies program are needed to develop courses in sub-Saharan African languages. Employment would be seasonal, therefore relocation would not be necessary. The program would be responsible for all travel expenses and would also offer a salary. All instructors must be Africans and have at least a Bachelor's degree in any field. Send all resumes and letters of interest to: Niyi Coker, Jr., Director of African-American Studies, University of Wyoming, Laramie, WY 82071. E-mail: niyi@uwyo.edu.

Specialist in French Language and Francophone African Literature is needed at Bowling Green State University for a tenure-track assistant professorship starting fall 1994. Applicable foreign experience/ residence is highly desirable. A recent PhD in an appropriate literary field is required. Send application materials to: French Search Committee, Romance Languages, Bowling Green State University, Bowling Green, OH 43403.

Graduates in mechanical/electrical/ civil engineering, forestry, business, horticulture, chemistry or computer science who are under 25 are encouraged to apply. Duties: responsible for sourcing, recruiting, interviewing and relocating Christian third world experienced professionals for overseas service with World Vision. Qualifications: 3 years of professional recruitment experience, with significant experience in international recruiting; previous experience working overseas strongly preferred; committed Christian; strong sourcing, interviewing and organizational skills. Helen Keller International seeks a Chief Financial Officer for its headquarters office in New York City. The CFO will be responsible for the organization's financial controls and reporting, and assist in strategic planning of program and development activities. Should have 5+ years experience in non-profit government financial management; a sound understanding of accounting/financial principles and excellent oral, written communication and interpersonal skills. CPA certification and an MBA in finance, accounting, or business administration is also required. Foreign travel may be necessary. Compensation includes salary, insurance and retirement benefits. The School for International Training (SIT) seeks individual for a Visiting Faculty position within the Department of Global Issues & Intercultural Management, with primary responsibility in the Master's Program in Intercultural Management (PIM). Seeking practitioner with years of distinguished experience in a managerial, training and/or consulting role in a "Southern" country. Primary responsibilities include a combination of teaching courses in human resource management, development program administration and strategic management, advising and evaluating students in their internships, and capstone papers and presentations. Depending on knowledge, interest and need, may also be asked to teach one of the following: project design, financial management of NGOs, or organizational behaviour. Minimum qualifications include distinguished experience in managerial positions in NGO, development organisations, and/or experience in teaching or training in nonformal, participant-centered education activities. Contract: 8/15/94 - 6/9/95. Salary dependent upon degree and experience. Position open until filled. Send resume and cover letter to HR, World Learning, PO Box 676, Brattleboro, VT 05302-0676.

The Unitarian Universalist Service Committee seeks skilled grants writer/manager to help secure foundation support for overseas projects in Central America and the Caribbean, Africa and Asia. Responsibilities: research and identify potential foundation funders on such issues as sustainable development, maternal and child health and related international development issues; help prepare diverse proposal-related materials; work on fund-raising activities and projects. Requires: 3+ years professional grant writing experience with emphasis on foundation proposal management; excellent writing and research skills; record of successful grant writing preferred, preferably related to international development; understanding of effective foundation relations necessary; strong organizational, administrative and record keeping skills; and familiarity with WordPerfect and database management. Position funded for 1 year. Send resume and short writing sample (e.g. funding proposal) to: Foundation Assistant Search, UUSC-MD, 130 Prospect Street, Cambridge, MA 02139.

The Center for International Private Enterprise (CIPE), an affiliate of the US Chamber of Commerce, seeks individual to assist with developing and implementing training/education programs focused on strengthening overseas business associations and their staffs' capabilities. Will conduct needs assessments; establish training objectives; select/develop courses; recruit instructors; and coordinate logistics. Will also assist with managing CIPE's grants programs for Africa. Requires related degree and 2 years of related training experience in an international setting; experience with Microsoft Word and Lotus; fluency in Russian; and the ability to travel, work with diverse constituencies and meet tight deadlines. Portuguese language skills preferred. Start $28K with excellent benefits. Send cover letter and benefits to: US Chamber of Commerce, Personnel Dept., 11615 H St., NW, Washington, DC 20062-2000.

Food for the Hungry International, a relief and development organization of Christian methodology and motivation, seeks individual to be based in headquarters in Arizona, to be responsible for all FHI accounting functions globally. Must be a CPA with 5-10 years experience, 3 years in the non-profit sector. Previous overseas experience is desired. Must understand basic management practices. Position will be filled by July 1994. Contact: Scott Allen, Director of Mobilization, Food for the Hungry International, 7807 E. Greenway Rd. #3, Scottsdale, AZ 85260. Phone (800) 248-6437. Fax (602) 951-9053.

Food for the Hungry International has the following positions available in Mozambique: SOFALA PROVINCE EXTENSION AND REHABILITATION (SPEAR) PROJECT MANAGER. Responsible for overall planning and management of the SPEAR project. Requirements: MS or equivalent in agricultural discipline, 5 years of experience in international agriculture development projects, with progressively increasing responsibilities in project management. Strong experience in project planning, financial/personal management. Fluency in Portuguese or Spanish. Working knowledge of Lotus (or Quattro Pro or Excel) and WordPerfect. African experience desirable. TRAINING UNIT COORDINATOR: Reports to the SPEAR project manager. Establish and manage an agricultural training center. Will train and develop agricultural extension agents and field researchers. Requirements: BS in Agricultural Extension/Education with hands-on international ag. development experience or BS in Agronomy/Horticulture/ Forestry with extensive international training experience. PROVINCIAL CONSTRUCTION MANAGER: Responsibilities include the implementation and rehabilitation of rural infrastructure projects in all facets and phases. Requirements: BS Civil Engineering with 10 years of experience, including 2 years of international experience.. Fluency in Portuguese or Spanish is required. The start date for all positions is July-August 1994. For more information contact Scott Allen, Director of Mobilization, Food for the Hungry International, 7807 E. Greenway Rd. #3, Scottsdale, AZ 85260. Phone (800) 248-6437. Fax (602) 951-9053.

The Social Science Research Council anticipates an opening for a Program Officer in its research and training programs focused on Africa. Working primarily through the Joint Committee on African Studies, which the Council sponsors with the American Council of Learned Societies, the program seeks to bring together scholars principally in the social sciences and humanities, from different areas of the world to support doctoral and post-doctoral training in Africa, and to stimulate new research on this region and on comparative and transnational themes involving Africa. Applicants should already hold a PhD, or be close to completing all requirements for a PhD in asocial science. Applicants from anthropology, history, political science or sociology, with expertise in Central or Southern Africa will be especially favored. Applicants with MA degrees will be considered if they bring other skills and experience to the job. The Council would strongly favor candidates with expertise in fundraising or prior foundation employment and program management experience. Program Officer responsibilities include: organizing scholarly meetings, workshops and conference; providing professional support for research programs; overseeing fellowship competitions; helping to develop, prepare and present funding applications to private foundations and government agencies; and liaison with researchers and academic institutions working on and in Africa. This position may become available as early as October 1994. Candidates should submit a letter of application, curriculum vitae, and 3 letters of reference to Ms. Dorie Sinocchi, Human Resources Director, Social Science, Research Council, 605 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10158.

The Ford Foundation is seeking a Program Officer or Assistant Program Officer for Africa and Middle East Programs, to work with the representative in Nairobi and other Foundation staff, to develop, monitor and evaluate program activities in East Africa aimed at alleviating rural poverty and promoting improved rural livelihoods and resource use. The program focuses on small holder farmers, and particularly women farmers, living in medium potential areas and emphasizes better land and water management and small enterprise development. The assignment involved work with public and private organisations, to link relevant applied research and social action and support community-based solutions. An advanced degree in the social agricultural science and experience in applied economic development, along with sound judgment and demonstrated interpersonal, analytical and writing abilities, are required. For further information, contact Joan C. Carroll, The Ford Foundation, 320 East 43rd St., New York, NY 10017. Tel: (212) 573-5144.

The Department of History and the Africana Studies Program at Bryn Mawr College seek to make a joint visiting appointment in African History; candidates with research and teaching interests in any region of sub-Saharan Africa except southern Africa are invited to apply. Send a c.v., a description of research and teaching interests, a sample syllabus and three letters of recommendation to Jane Caplan, Department of History, Bryn Mawr College, 12091 N. Merion Avenue, Bryn Mawr, PA 19010-2899. Tel: (610) 526-5331.

The South End Press collective is a non-profit, multi-cultural publisher of non-fiction books that help people understand and change our world. They are currently seeking an activist/editor to join them as a full-time collective member. This position involves all aspects of manuscript solicitation and editing, computerized book production, and business management. Members make a two-year commitment. Knowledge of and commitment to progressive ideas and activism is essential. Editing, some business experience, and the ability to work in a collective setting is also required. All collective members currently earn $27,500 per year with an additional $6,000 dependent allowance for parents. To apply, contact South End Press, 116 St. Botolph Street, Boston, MA 02115. Tel: (617) 266-0629.

CUSO is seeking candidates for the following positions:

** COMMUNICATIONS OFFICER in Ottawa. Deadline MAY 10, 1994. Under the direction of the Executive Director and working in collaboration with Canadian, Overseas regions and the different units in the secretariat, the Communications Officer has organizational responsibility for the coordination and implementation of a consistent and coherent communications plan designed to meet CUSO's mission and strategic directions and to promote CUSO's image to its various constituencies. The Communications Officer is responsible for the preparation and production of materials for use in CUSO's communications activities with the media, government and the public and is also responsible for supporting the Executive Director and the members of the Board of Directors in their external relations. QUALIFICATIONS: Experience working in and with the media; excellent understanding of the workings of the federal government, especially Canadian International Development Agency; excellent communication skills in both official languages of Canada; Proven ability to write in styles appropriate to the information media; Comprehensive knowledge of editing and print production; Good understanding of international development; Excellent inter-personal skills and the ability to work to strict deadlines.

**REGIONAL PROGRAMME COORDINATOR, in Accra, Ghana. Deadline MAY 10, 1994. Under the direction of the Regional Director and working in close collaboration with the Programmer Coordinators and the Ottawa-based Programme team and other teams and units collaborating with the Region, the Regional Programme Coordinator will provide leadership in program development for the region. The Regional Program Coordinator plays a key role in coordinating, supporting and promoting the programme work within the region. QUALIFICATIONS: University degree or advanced degree in social sciences/community development/program-project management/ international development or administration degree or equivalent; Minimum 5 years experience in development/programming work; Good knowledge of social, political and economic issues of the region; Proven programme management skills; Excellent analytical skills; Effective communication and representational skills; Capacity to work in both English and French; Ability to travel extensively within the country and the region; Computer literacy; NGO experience; Ability to work as part of a team in as participatory management environment. ***Interested applicants should support their application with a current resume, the names and addresses of 3 references and short statement on how they see themselves contributing to CUSO's work in the particular position. Forward the above to CUSO Human Resources Department, 135 Rideau Street, Ottawa, Ont., K1N 9K7. Fax: (613) 241-8068.

Africa News


May 9, 1994 / May 23, 1994


VOLUNTEER OPPORTUNITIES


LENGTH: 334 words


 

The American Medical Team for Africa (AMTA) promotes and executes educational exchange and medical training in African countries. The goal of the non-profit organization is to bring volunteer doctors, nurses and medical students together with donated supplies, and equipment to serve needs on the continent. Survey teams assess the most pressing needs in targeted countries, develop and publish training manuals in appropriate languages, hold workshops and refresher courses for doctors, nurses and specialists interested in maintenance of health care delivery systems in Africa; and distribute medical supplies and equipment donated by corporations, pharmaceutical companies, hospitals and doctors. The AMTA plans a second medical mission to Africa. For more information, contact Deman Rageh, Executive Director, The American Medical Team for Africa, 2245 Godby Road, Atlanta, GA 30349; phone (404) 766-8000; fax: (404) 767-5264.

Private Voluntary Organization in Rosslyn needs an experienced Agribusiness/Marketing Specialist to fill a 3-year Chief of Party position in Mali. The candidate must have at least 10 years of proven experience in the field of Agribusiness, Marketing, Credit and Procurement (preferably of fruits & vegetables). Must have related job experience in developing country with hands-on experience and an MBA. Strong training skills in the areas of agribusiness and marketing required. Fluency in French/English (FSI, S-3, R03) a must. Interested candidates must submit a resume, a certification of foreign language capability, and a standard AID bio-data form. Please mail original copies to: Regina Wynn, VITA, 5th floor, Arlington, VA 22209. Tel: (703) 276-1800 or fax: (703) 2143-1865.

PUBLICATIONS


LENGTH: 800 words


 

Philip Bonner, Peter Delius, and Deborah Posel, Editors, Apartheid's Genesis 1935-1962. Braamfontein: Ravan Press, 1993. $24.95 (Paper). 455 pp.

John English, Mary Tiffen, and Michael Mortimore, Land Resource Management in Machakos District, Kenya 1930-1990. Philadelphia: World Bank, 1994. $7.95 (Paper). 86 

Cecil Foster, No Man in the House. New York: Ballantine Books, 1994. $10.00 (Paper). $13.50 (Canada). 281 pp.

Alan Gelb & Associates, Oil Windfalls: Blessing or Curse?. Cary: Oxford University Press, 1988. $32.50 (Cloth). 357 pp.

Nicholas Gordon, Murders in the Mist: Who Killed Dian Fossey?. Kent: Hodder & Stoughton, 1994. $29.95 (Cloth). 254 pp.

Marilyn Heldman, African Zion: The Sacred Art of Ethiopia. New Haven: Yale University Press, 1993. $50.00 (Cloth). 272 pp.

Paul Kishindo, Elizabeth Eldredge, and Marc Epprecht, ISAS Working Paper Series. : Institute of Southern African Studies, 1993. 89 pp.

Helen Elaine Lee, The Serpent's Gift. New York: Atheneum A Division of MacMillan Pubs., 1994. $21.00 (Cloth). $27.50 (Canada). 374 pp.

Peter Limb, The ANC and Black Workers in South Afirca, 1912-1992: An Annotated Bibliography. London: Hans Zell Publishers, 1993. $95.00 (Cloth). 380 pp.

Marcia D. Lowe, Back on Track: The Global Rail Revival. Washington: Worldwatch Institute, 1994. $5.00 (Paper). 55 pp.

L.B.B.J. Machobane, Christianization and African Response Among the Barolong & Basotho, 1820-1890. : Institute of Southern African Studies, 1993. 32 pp.

Nicholas Maddock, Editors and Frank Wilson, Project Design for Agricultural Development. Brookfield: Ashgate Publishing Company, 1994. $54.95 (Cloth). 224 pp.

Edwin Mansfield, Intellectual Property Protection, Foreign Direct Investment, & Technology Transfer. Philadelphia: World Bank, 1994. 43 pp.

Fred Marte, Political Cycles in International Relations: The Cold War and Africa 1945-1990. New York: Paul & Company Publishers Consortium, Inc., 1994. $57.00 (Cloth). 496 pp.

Ann McKinstry Micou, Foreign Assistance to South Africa: A Directory. New York: Institute of International Education, 1994. 99 pp.

Clement Nwankwo, Basil Ugochukwu, and Dulue Mbachu, Nigeria: The Limits of Justice. Surulere: Constitutional Rights Project, 1993. 74 pp.

Don C. Ohadike, Anioma: A Social History of the Western Igbo People. Athens: Ohio University Press/ Swallow Press, 1994. $39.95 (Cloth). $17.95 (Paper). 249 pp.

J.D. Omer-Cooper, History of Southern Africa, 2nd Edition. Portsmouth: Heinemann, 1994. $22.50 (Paper). 300 pp.

David Ottaway, Chained Together Mandela, de Klerk & the Struggle to Remake South Africa. New York: Times Books, 1993. $25.00 (Cloth). 292 pp.

Helen C. Price, Editors, Cloin Hewson, and David Blake, Theses on Africa, 1976-1988 (Accepted by the Univerisites of The United Kingdom & Ireland). London: Han

Staff of the International Monetary Fund, World Economic Outlook October 1992. Washington: International Monetary Fund External Relations Office, 1992. $30.00 (Paper). 179 pp.

James B. Stewart, Editor, The Review of Black Political Economy. New Brunswick: Transaction Publishers, 1994. 166 pp.

Michael Twaddle, Kakungulu & the Creation of Uganda. Athens: Ohio University Press/ Swallow Press, 1993. $19.95 (Paper). 310 pp.

UNICEF, Day of the African Child Commemoration 16 June 1993. New York: United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF), 1994. 40 pp.

US Dept. of Agriculture, Foreign gricultural Trade of the United States (FATUS) 11/12 1993. Washington: United States Department of Agriculture, 1994. 100 pp.

Africa News


May 9, 1994 / May 23, 1994


PLANNING AHEAD


LENGTH: 3894 words


 

May 27-29, 1994

Ontario, Canada -- Conference

"Pan Africanism: Agenda for Unity".

Africa News


May 9, 1994 / May 23, 1994


ANNOUNCEMENTS


SECTION: DIRECTORY


LENGTH: 534 words


 

Ten-part series produced by Africa News and NPR

Tune in to National Public Radio on Mondays through June for a special series of reports on Africa in the post-Cold War world.

Produced jointly by Africa News Service and NPR, the reports will air on the 90-minute afternoon news magazine, All Things Considered, during the second half hour, between 5:30 and 6:00 pm in most areas.

Reporting teams from Africa News and NPR have traveled to East, West and southern Africa to explore the challenges facing the continent, including achieving food self-sufficiency, resettling refugees, demobilizing armies, and expanding the voice and participation of women. 

Be sure to let NPR know your reaction to the series. Direct your comments to:

All Things Considered

635 Massachusetts Avenue

Washington, D.C. 20001-3753

and/or

NPR

(202) 414-2000

Underwriters for the project include: The Coca-Cola Company, the Ford Foundation, New Africa Advisers, Rodale Press, Pan Africa-U.S.A. International Track Meet, South African Airways, the CarEth Foundation and the Corporation for Public Broadcasting.

E-Mail information on South Africa is available free from SAFRICA.WATCH, which is updated every Thursday. The service is provided and produced by Oxfam-Canada, with funding from the Canadian International Development Agency and elections communications support from Web. To receive SAFRICA.WATCH, send a message to africadesk@web.apc.org.

An electronic bulletin board now serves the African health informatics community. Interested subscribers should send their name, E-mail address, and postal address to: Mikko Korpela, HELINA 93 Overseas Bureau, University of Kuopio, Computing Centre, PL 1627, FIN-70211 Kuopio, Finland. Fax: 358-71-282-5566. E-mail: korpela@uku.fi.

The Africa News and Information Service (AFRICA-N) is an electronic mailing list (listserv) that provides news, information, analysis, and articles about Africa. It is produced by Faraz Rabbani at the University of Toronto. To subscribe send an e-mail message to: listserv@utoronto.bitnet. Leave the subject blank and type "subscribe AFRICA-N" followed by your full name. You will get a notification that you are on the list and begin to receive messages.

138 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 9, 1994 / May 23, 1994


BEWARE SUGAR DADDIES


BYLINE: PANOS/WorldAIDS


LENGTH: 840 words


 

Zimbabwe's Ministry of Education has just launched what is believed to be the most comprehensive Aids education programme in Africa. Its aim is to inform young people of the dangers of Aids before they become sexually active, as HIV is spreading rapidly among Zimbabwean teenagers.

Between 600,000 and 1.5 million people in Zimbabwe are believed to be infected with HIV. In March, the National Public Health Laboratory reported that over 400 teenagers had been diagnosed with Aids, 90 percent of them girls. 

The first step in the new schools programme was the publication of a book, 'Let's Talk', aimed at 11-12 year olds in their final year of primary school. Books for older schoolchildren are planned from 1994. Unicef and other donors provided funding for educational materials. At the book's launch, education secretary Isiah Sibanda said the aim of the new course was to help teenagers "resist exploitative sexual relationships."

Health Minister Dr. Timothy Staps told provincial head teachers that the blame for the prevalence of HIV among schoolgirls lay with "sugar daddies" -- older men who seduce young girls. Describing them as "lethal weapons," he accused them of taking advantage of the accelerating economic crisis by offering to pay school fees in return for sexual favours.

'Let's Talk' does not refer directly to sugar daddies, but covers the theme in a chapter about "Tanya," a nine-year-old schoolgirl. Coming home from school, she meets one of her uncles at the bore hole, but runs away when he attempts to molest her. Children are encouraged to discuss how they would have reacted in a similar situation.

The book tackles Aids through direct and indirect messages and also touches on other issues of importance to young people -- including smoking, alcohol, and bullying. Poems and songs are used to get the message across.

Helen Jackson, author of the prevention manual 'Aids: Action Now,' things the government is right to prioritise Aids education. She approves of the book's approach to condoms, which are mentioned but not stressed since the target audience is children. "I don't want anything that encourages early sexual experiment," she says. Condom use is dealt with more explicitly in Jackson's book which is aimed at adults.

Condoms have proved to be a difficult area for Zimbabwe's Aids educators. After adverse comment from Vice-President Joshua Nkomo, a television condom commercial was dropped recently. Church circles oppose any mention of condoms -- but since many schools are church-funded, their support is essential fro any successful education campaign. Sibanda expressed a government hope that churches and educators would "work together." And the country's Scripture Union has for some time been running its own schools Aids programme using visiting teams of young people -- an approach which allows for much greater frankness than is normal in the classroom.

Another problem is the strong cultural aversion to talking about sex. Traditionally, instruction in Zimbabwe was given to girls buy their aunts, and in some remote areas girls were subjected to virginity tests. The tests were still being conducted as recently as 1976 at one mission in Mutoko, where a quarter of all girls said their aunts had tested them.

Jackson wonders whether school teachers can cope with the huge task of adjusting to the post-Aids era. "There is a need to demystify a great many sexual issues," she says.

An earlier attempt at a schools Aids books in Zimbabwe stressed the possibility that Aids could be spread by sharing a -- giving the false impression of a highly infectious illness and possibly contributing towards people with Aids. This time the emphasis is on sexual transmission and convincing teachers that the virus is not spread by, for example, mosquitoes.

To back up the book, a series of workshops is being organised throughout Zimbabwe. Three-day courses are being run for the 150,000 teachers involved in the first phase of the programme.

Reprinted from AFRICA SOUTH & EAST, January 1994.

AFRICA SOUTH & EAST is published by ASE Publications, 1 Mayo Centre, Fortesque Road, Yeoville and printed by Caxton Limited, cnr. Commando Rd/Blumberg St, Industria, SA.


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


139 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 9, 1994 / May 23, 1994


MAKING CONDOMS A COOL PRODUCT


BYLINE: Annabel Dunn/Gaborone


LENGTH: 907 words


 

US-based company Population Services International is attempting to Influence sexual behaviour through innovative social marketing programmes designed to make condom use attractive.

PSI launched its first programme in Zaire in 1988, at a time when many countries were reluctant to acknowledge the existence of the Aids pandemic. Before the programme began, 300,000 condoms were being sold annually in the country. By 1991, PSI had sold 18.3 million of its Prudence condoms, at an affordable price to citizens. 

As the only international non-governmental organisation marketing condoms for Aids prevention, PSI works through the private sector, relying on donors to help fund marketing programmes which deliver essential health products to low-income families.

Vice-president Judith Timyan says PSI always sells condoms, rather than giving them away. "Giving them away creates a stigma," says Timyan. "It tells people to use them because they have no choice. The brilliance of our marketing effort lies in treating people as consumers rather than beneficiaries. You give them choices, take away the stigma and make it a cool product."

PSI's programme in Zambia was launched a year ago on World Aids Day. Since that time, sales of "Maximum" condoms have exceeded 4.4 million -- the highest per capita sales in Africa.

PSI has been helped in its efforts by community groups in Zambia who have rallied behind Aids prevention programmes at a time when some feel the government has been slow to act. The involvement of churches has also been significant. The church-supported Kara Counselling Programme on Aids in Zambia is recognised as the most successful in the region. Now money has been set aside for a mass media condom marketing campaign.

By contrast in Botswana, where PSI launched the "Lovers' Plus" brand in June 1993, government involvement has been substantial. But PSI Botswana director Renee Romanowski said some of the government efforts trod a find line between persuasion and dictation.

"By putting up billboards saying: Aids is your problem too -- use a condom, they are presenting a rather dour message. PSI brands the product and creates an attractive image for it so that people will actually choose to use a Lovers' Plus condom," she said.

"We have a limited budget in Botswana, but we are aiming to make good use of the mass media. We conduct condom training sessions at events around the country to teach the correct way to use a condom. In our first three months of operation, we've reached out to a whole range of sales outlets."

Botswana and Zambia share an open approach to the discussion of Aids/HIV in public fora. But a lack of openness about the problem, coupled with the reluctance of foreign donors to provide funds before constitutional change, have been major obstacles for PSI in South Africa.

Although the pandemics not as advanced in South Africa as further north, the incidence of HIV is doubling rapidly. By the year 2000,m it is estimated that 20-30 percent of the population will be HIV positive. PSI director in Durban, Mitchell Warren said people in South Africa had not recognised Aids as a problem yet.

"In Zambia, almost everyone has buried a friend or family member who has died of Aids. The disease hasn't had that impact here yet," says Warren.

Racially-divided communities labelled Aids as a "black" or "white" disease and therefore not their problem. Advocacy of condom use was linked in the minds of the black community to long-standing attempts by the apartheid regime to control black population growth. And in a highly repressive society, attempts to regulate sexual behaviour were seen as an encroachment on one small remaining area of personal autonomy.

But Warren believes the perception of condoms is now changing fairly rapidly. Despite an awareness that any new South African government will face a massive agenda of problems.

Warren is cautiously optimistic. PSI South Africa has recently secured funding from the Anglo-American Corporation, and pledges of support from two other corporations.

"We are selling a fair number of condoms, but not as many as in Botswana and Zambia. The sad fact is that it won't be until we have seen more Aids deaths that behaviour will begin to change significantly. Getting the message into the townships is also difficult, when people there are facing a daily battle just to get basic foods."


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


140 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 9, 1994 / May 23, 1994


SHIFTING A MILLION A MONTH


BYLINE: Annabel Dunn & Mary Roberts/Gaborone


LENGTH: 840 words


 

Botswana has launched a campaign to change national attitudes towards people with Aids. The "A friend with Aids is still my friend" theme will run in tandem with the World Health Organisation's 1993 slogan "Time to act" as part of the Botswana Aids/STD Unit's aim to address the discrimination faced in the country by people with HIV/Aids.

Up to an estimated 92,000 people in the country (around 7 percent of the total population) may be HIV-positive, but awareness of the pandemic has lagged behind that of other African countries and the majority are unaware that they are affected. And the majority of those who do know won't tell friends or family for fear of discrimination at home or at work. 

National Aids Control Programme (NACP) head Dr. Matshidiso Moeti says these fears are justified -- people have lost jobs, friends and families as a result of disclosing that they are HIV-positive. "Such reactions, and the stress they cause, can actually make a person with HIV more ill, and could possibly hasten death," said Moeti.

"By preventing people from coming out, the best Aids educators -- those who have the virus -- are prevented from getting involved in the campaign against the disease. Botswana is one of the few countries in the region to have no person with HIV/Aids publicly involved in Aids prevention."

Because the general perception of people with Aids is negative at all levels of Botswana society, there is a fear of testing, and misconceptions about how the virus is contracted and the ability of HIV-positive people to continue working are widespread. A 1993 study suggests that although 90 percent of the population have some knowledge about the disease, the attitude towards people with Aids is predominantly ambivalent or negative.

In Botswana, infection is concentrated in the 20 - 40 age group, with a much more even spread between urban and rural areas than in Central Africa, where the problem is predominantly urban. 34 percent of HIV-positive people are in the northern town of Francistown. According to Dr. Karl-Olaf Wathne, a WHO epidemiologist, the weekend movement from towns to rural areas and vice-versa is responsible for this spread pattern. But Wathne is optimistic about one thing: "The attitude towards condoms is much more positive than two years ago, and the change has happened so quickly. The Botswana central medical stores distributes six times as many condoms per month as two years ago...around one million a month compared to two million a year. This is a positive sign that people are changing their sexual behaviour."

Since June, Botswana has been implementing the social marketing of the "Lovers Plus" brand of condoms, under the auspices of Population Services International (PSI) funded by USAID. PSI country director Renee Romanowski describes social marketing as selling the condoms at normal retail outlets at a subsidised and hence affordable price -- in Botswana 50 thebe for a packet of three. "But wholesalers and retailers will still make a profit and therefore be motivated to distribute the product widely."

Botswana has identified three Ministries (education, labour and home affairs and local government, lands and housing) as key sectors in planning to respond to the epidemic, and is also involving non-governmental organisations in the campaign. President Ketumile Masire told a September (1993) briefing: "The only weapons available to fight this deadly disease are education and behavioural change."

The country's Ministry of Health has drafted a national policy to ensure that HIV-positive people who come out do not suffer such negative consequences as being dismissed from work or expelled from school.

The proposed legislation will prevent employers from sacking HIV-positive workers simply on the grounds that they have the virus. Doctors cannot reveal that their patients have Aids -- although people in the more advanced stages of the disease and suffering from an Aids-related complex of illnesses (ARC) still risk dismissal on medical grounds through repeated absenteeism.

"There are groups of people with HIV who are considering coming out ," says Moeti, "and we hope this campaign to change public attitudes will help them to come forward. It will help communities appreciate the problem and show that people with HIV are ordinary people."


LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


141 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 9, 1994 / May 23, 1994


IS ANYBODY OUT THERE LISTENING?: GIVE WOMEN MORE POWER;
The AIDS pandemic is spreading through the region...In response, AIDS educators are trying to spread the safe-sex message. (Africa South & East's) correspondents suggest they are having varying degrees of success.


BYLINE: Violet Byvanck/Bujumbura


SECTION: AIDS


LENGTH: 1107 words


 

AFRICA SOUTH & EAST, January 1994

All over the world, Aids educators are trying to convince people that they should think before they act. Sexual behaviour -- the use of condoms, varieties of sexual activity, celibacy, fidelity -- has become the focus of attention, and depending on the cultural traditions, lifestyle, religion and age of their constituents, educators have chosen three major messages: stick to one partner, have safer sex (use condoms, non-penetrative sex) or abstinence.

But despite increasing levels of information about HIV/Aids, behaviour change is happening more slowly. Researchers are beginning to isolate the reasons for this. 

* Male dominance. In most societies, it is difficult, if not impossible for a woman to refuse her partner sex. And men are often reluctant to use condoms.

* Poverty. Many women in the developing world are forced into prostitution simply to support themselves and their families. "You tell me I might die of Aids in some years. But if I do not work on the streets, my children will stave this week," one Zimbabwean sex worker told a newspaper.

* Fatalism. People with strong traditional beliefs (or those who have bought the negative message of some early Aids propaganda) believe there is little that can be done to avert death.

* Availability of condoms. In some countries, condoms are hard to obtain, or expensive. There may be misconceptions about their effectiveness or a reluctance to use them.

* Lack of information on Aids/HIV.

As it becomes increasingly clear that women are more and more the main victims of Aids, research is focusing on the empowerment of women within relationships as a vital factor in stemming the spread of the disease. Medical workers are also trying to develop a non-contraceptive virucide for HIV, which women could use without having to seek male permission.

In Burundi, the HIV-infection rate is about 15 percent in urban and peri-urban areas, and at least 1 percent in the rural areas where the bulk of the population lives. Research in 1987, 1990 and 1992 suggests that there have been behaviour changes. While most respondents said they were choosing fidelity, condom use has risen from 27.5 percent in Bujumbura in 1990 t almost 50 percent in 1992.

In Uganda, where infection rates range between 5-29 percent, a 1992 survey of 4,500 young people between 15 and 24 suggested that there was good knowledge of the basic information about HIV. However, knowledge was not yet affecting actions. Although most respondents knew condoms prevented sexually-transmitted diseases (STDs) including Aids, most also had a negative attitude towards condoms. 21 percent of mend and 8 percent of women reported having had an STD.

In Malawi, Dr. George Liomba, Head of the Malawi Aids Control programme estimated and adult HIV infection rate of at least 10 percent, probably much higher in the urban areas. A survey done in rural Thyolo district by Deborah Helitzer-Allen and Mercy Makhembera revealed that young women know Aids ca kill, but most think it will not kill them. They have heard -- through radio, church, or word of mouth -- that Aids is only spread by "easy" partners such as bar girls and truck drivers and that people with Aids are easily identified because they look ill. They did not identify their own partners as "easy." The young women have a hard time changing their own behaviour. More than half of those interviewed said they were "often" forced to have sex; 66 percent had accepted money or gifts for sex. And in Thyolo, condoms are distributed through the district hospital, a round trip of 25 miles for many or sold in very limited numbers through a few commercial outlets.

In Tanzania, 40 women were interviewed about negotiating sex with their partners as the first phase of a WID/Aids in the Workplace project. Almost all of them claimed to be ore careful about sex because of Aids. Half of them had used a condom for some sexual encounters, but only 24 percent used condoms regularly. Although 72 percent of the women said they could say "No" to a partner wanting sex, only 39 percent had ever refused to have sex if a partner would not use a condom.

In Ethiopia, surveys are now revealing alarmingly high HIV-infection rates, 17-18 percent among pregnant women in some areas and up to 75 percent among sex workers in the capital. Ethiopia's Organisation for Social Services for Aids (OSSA) believes earlier under-reporting related to the country's extreme poverty. "If people who are malnourished become infected with this virus, they will not live long enough to develop Aids. They will die earlier, their lowered resistance falling prey to opportunistic diseases...This makes our statistics misleading," says OSSA's Abba Tsegaye Kenneni.

Aids education targeted at sex workers has become a priority. "Our work is starting to have an effect," says Negussie Yitbareq, Head of Aids Information in the Ministry of Health. "The number of clients for bar-ladies is decreasing and women are refusing to work in bars to the extent that some bars report they cannot get enough staff." Hotels in Addis are also starting to provide condoms in their rooms and souvenir shops. Ana Aids information hotline, training for counsellors and teachers and home-based care for people with Aids are also planned, as well as Aids education for the country's large refugee population. But poverty, overstretched health services and inadequate condom supply pose huge problems for Aids educators.

LANGUAGE: English
