156 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 23, 1994 / June 6, 1994


AFRICA GROWLED AT CONGRESS; WILL IT BITE?


BYLINE: Vukoni Lupa-Lasaga


LENGTH: 1720 words


 

THE MONITOR, April 15 - 19, 1994

It was an unusual week for Kampala. The city buzzed with talk of overthrowing the imperialist order policed by the United States of America.

After a slumber of twenty years the Pan African movement was flexing its muscles, to do battle for its own place in the sun. The Pan African Congress last met in Dar es Salaam in 1974. Then the world was being ruled from Moscow and Washington. 

Now only the voice of America matters. Metaphorically, the just-ended 8th Pan African Congress is the puny David swinging the sling against Goliath. But whether it fells the giant o not, the congress was an event worth remembering.

OF SURPRISES

First the surprise. Kabaka Ronald Mutebi hosted the delegates to the congress a sumptuous cocktail party on Wednesday. As they toured the Bulange, many of those from the diaspora were moved to the point of tears to discover an ancient dynasty still ruling in the heart of Africa. "Ebyaffe" serves a progressive Pan African purpose, after all.

General Mohammad Farah Aideed stole the limelight from day one, Monday April 4. These days even Museveni does not get a two-minute's standing ovation on merely showing his face.

"As you may know, I and my people are engaged in a struggle against a new imperialism," Aideed begun his diatribe against the Yankees. And the crowd loved it all. Seeing the frail middle-aged man in the flesh, it was hard to believe he was the "demon" on whose head the Americans had put a price in their hour of despair.

Aideed made big waves when he called for a Pan African parliament in the next five years and demanded for compensation from the Americans for destroying over $1 bn of Somali property, 18,000 lives and 45,000 limbs.

For Col. Dr. John Garang and Dr. Riak Machar, the commanders of the two feuding SPLA factions, the congress meant a lot. The "Arabs" in northern Sudan knew this and they fielded over forty pro-Khartoum delegations to "outgun" the southern Sudanese bushmen.

For both parties, it was a bitter war of words. Eritrean foreign minister Gebre Yemane poked the first stick in the Sudanese beehive. On Monday he read his president's analysis of the Sudanese civil strife and laid the blame squarely on the shoulders of the militant muslims of Northern Sudan.

Up to the very last, the Sudanese question threatened to rend the congress apart. Everytime a pro-Bashir delegate opened his mouth to speak, SPLA Young Turks unfurled banners condemning the Khartoum government. The hostilities often broke into shouting matches.

Thursday, the northern most; the secession of Southern Sudan, their footstool.

For once, Garang and Machar sat side by side, and joined forces against their common enemy.

Happy Otafiire

One man who must have regretted ever inviting the querulous Sudanese was Col. Kahinda Otafiire, the convener and chairman of the international preparatory committee of the 7th PAC. He had a tough time keeping the Sudanese from flying at each others' throats. And satisfied.

On Friday, a smile almost split the colonel's face in two when the Sudanese warriors embraced and shook hands.

But, the IGGAD initiative has yet to hammer back into place the weakest link in the chain of the Pan Africanist ideal. The relationship between Arab and Black Africa. Another trying moment came on the issue of reparations for slavery. Dr. Chinweizu who represented the Lagos branch of the International Committee on Reparations stabbed a finger at Arab slavery which is still going on in Sudan and Mauritania.

So by implication, Arabs had to also pay for enslaving Africans. That sent a northern Sudanese mad.

"You are even whiter than myself and you have the nerve to call us Arabs!" the indignant man with a heavy Arab accent told off Chinweizu who was actually lighter. The Libyan foreign affairs minister Abdul Moussa turned read when the issue came again in a plenary session. Which told volumes about this Pan Africanism "katogo".

Prof. Ali Mazrui saved the congress from a split on this question, when he suggested that Arab slavery was a household affair. For the time being Arab and black Africans had to stick together to take on imperialism.

When the congress was wrapping things up, a bomb shell came from an unexpected quarter -- Ghana. Taata Ofosu of the Democratic Alliance of Ghana (DAG) put forward a resolution condemning Jerry Rawlings' government for humiliating and harassing the late Kwame Nkrumah's family.

DEVIL'S ADVOCATE

Dr. Esiu Sutherland, an eloquent spokeswoman of the Ghanaian official delegation acted the consummate devil's advocate. She denied that the Ghana government had impounded the passport of Madame Fatiah, Nkrumah's widow, or confiscated her house. Till Gorkah Nkrumah, the son of the late Ghanaian president, spoke.

"This government (Rawlings') has been the only government since the coup (which overthrew Nkrumah) that has withdrawn the passport of my mother.

"You cannot claim that you are rehabilitating the image of Nkrumah while at the same time withdrawing the passport of his widow."

You could have heard a pin drop. Then the outrage. The three Ghanaian government representatives sat dumbstruck as their regime was "whipped" for cruelty to the family of a pan Africanist. Gender sensitive speakers also gave a bashing to the trio for defending the wrong done to an African widow.

Col. Otafiire had to step in to patch up things.

Wearing an embarrassed expression on his face, the ESO chief said that he was at a loss because the controversy had exploded when the Ugandan government was already "whispering" to the Ghanaian government. Though at the end, it was Gamal Nkrumah who saved the face of the Ghana government by pleading to the garrulous Ofosu to withdraw his resolution. As a compromise, the congress delegated Kwesi Pratt and Mohamed bin Abdallah, also Ghanaians, to ensure that Fatiah and her family got better treatment.

UNCLE SAM WORRIES

American State Department officials, must have sensed that their government was going to come under heavily under fire.

George Moose, the US Assistant Secretary of State for Africa is quoted by local media sources to have admitted that his presence in Kampala at the time of the congress was not a coincidence.

There should be many more Pan African congresses, outside Uganda. That seemed to be the prayer on the lips of Ken Lukyamuzi, the vocal multi-partyist who was viciously attacked by Maj. Ondoga ori Amaza for criticizing the military.

It was a congress of African opposition groups. They found a safe platform for damning their own governments. It was better than the OAU where only diplomatic niceties are exchanged between ruling parties and military juntas.

Ngugi wa 0Thiongo, the celebrated Kenyan author spat at Moi's regime on behalf of the clandestine "Mwakenya." Malawian and Ghanaian dissidents also took the chance to rubbish their home governments. Be sure the next congress will attract all the briefcase opposition to Museveni if convened outside Uganda.

The 7th PAC was a rebirth of third world radicalism. The buzzwords were liberation, revolution, workers' rights, south-south networking, a new economic and communications order, and the overthrow of despots.

But Yoweri Museveni's two speeches to the congress were a syncretic mix or revolutionary rhetoric and World Bank/IMF adjustment economics. The president rode his old hobby horse -- Africa's need for homegrown democracy, and his views on science and technology. No new thought has re-emerged on post-cold economics and politics.

Over a hundred resolutions were passed. But the congress needs more than tough talk to see it through resolutions such as the demand on the US to life the Cuban and Libyan blockades.

A tall order. But great revolutions begin as the dreams of a few mad men, don't they?

Reprinted from THE MONITOR, April 15-19, 1994.

The Monitor is published by The Monitor Publications Ltd., P.O. Box 12141, Kampala. Tel: 23-69-39.


LOAD-DATE: May 23, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


157 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 23, 1994 / June 6, 1994


RAWLINGS ATTACKED OVER FATHIA


BYLINE: Audrey Gadzekpo


SECTION: PAN-AFRICANIST CONGRESS


LENGTH: 880 words


 

THE GHANAIAN CHRONICLE, April 11-13, 1994

Already high temperatures at the just-ended 7th Pan-Africanist Congress in Kampala threatened to erupt after a group of Ghanaian delegates and participants at the Congress circulated a petition on the PNDC treatment of Madame Fathia Nkrumah, wife of Ghana's first president, Osagyefo Dr. Kwame Nkrumah.

Spearheaded by Kwesi Pratt, Jnr., leader of the non-governmental delegation to the 7th PAC and chairman of Nkrumahist party, PPDD, in conjunction with several Ghanaian exiles attending the conference, the petition asked that the passport of Madame Fathia Nkrumah be restored to her; that the Nkrumah family house at Labone, currently occupied by the Speaker of Parliament, Justice D. F. Annan be given back to Madame Nkrumah and her offsprings; and that the Kotoka International Airport be renamed after Osagyefo Dr. Kwame Nkrumah.

The withdrawal of Madame Fathia's passport and residence by the PNDC government, which claims to be strongly Pan-Africanist and which erected a multi-million-cedi mausoleum in honour of the Great Osagyefo in 1989, according to the petition, has resulted in Madam Fathia living in "a one room bed-sit in Cairo, Egypt." 

Hundreds of Pan-Africanists attending the Congress, which owed much of its early beginnings to the likes of Dr. Kwame Nkrumah, were outraged when the petition hit the floor. A lady delegate from Nigeria, Ms. Abiola, immediately took to the podium after reading the petition and demanded that the petition be addressed as part of the larger issue of the oppression of women and widows.

Despite the fact that the petition was signed by more than 400 people attending the Congress, (P)NDC government loyalists still attempted to defend the shabby treatment of the Nkrumah family. Mrs. Esi Sutherland Addy, a former Deputy Minister for Education under the PNDC regime, asked delegates and participants to appraise themselves of the true facts of the case before jumping to conclusions. Briefly, the situation threatened to get out of hand when Taafa Ofosu, a victim of the PNDC government who now lives in exile in London, shot up to reiterate the position of the petition and called Mrs. Sutherland Addy a liar. Mrs. Sutherland-Addy who together with ex-Culture Minister Dr. Mohammed Ben Abdallah, were part of a three-member government delegation to the Congress, is fairly respected by many Pan-Africanist women partly because she has the reputation of being an advocate for women's issues and because she happens to be the daughter of a respected veteran Pan-Africanist Bill Sutherland. Mr. Bill Sutherland also attended the Congress.

In a related development, seven Ghanaian participants to the Congress, including Zaya Yebo, ex-Minister of Youth and Sports under the PNDC government who now lives in exile in the Gambia; Kwesi Pratt, Jnr.: Akyaaba Addai-Sebo, who was shot by government functionaries and spirited outside the country in the early days of the revolution, circulated a statement condemning the Rawlings regime on several issues, including extra-judicious killings and the negative impact of structural adjustment on Ghanaians.

Structural Adjustment was a big issue at the Congress with delegates and participants condemning IMF/World Bank stipulations in very strong terms.

The Congress was hosted by President Yoweri Museveni of Uganda and attended by Pan-Africanists and freedom fighters from across the Continent and in the diaspora. Notable among attendees were Somali faction leader General Mohammed Farah Aideed who was given a standing ovation when he addressed the Congress; Colonel John Garang of the Sudanese People's Liberation Army (SPLA); Kwame Ture, formerly called Stockley Carmichael of the Black Panthers; Mrs. Betty Shabazz, widow of Malcolm X; Mrs. Graca Machel, widow of Mozambique's first President Samora Machel; author Ngugi Wa Thiongo and Ali Mazrui.

Such interesting characters as President Jerry John Rawlings, Winnie Mandela, Col. Muammar Gaddafi, Nigeria's Alhaji Mashood Abiola, Mwalimu Julius Nyerere, who would have undoubtedly added more fireworks to the already volatile Congress, were expected to attend but did not show up.

Reprinted from The Ghanaian Chronicle, April 11-13, 1994.

The Ghanaian Chronicle is published at P.O. Box 16369, Airport-Accra. Tel: 22-77-89. Telex: 2694. Fax: 22-65-73.


LOAD-DATE: May 23, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


158 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 23, 1994 / June 6, 1994


MANDELA'S CABINET JUGGLING ACT


LENGTH: 1654 words


 

THE WEEKLY MAIL & GUARDIAN, May 13, 1994

The ANC's national working committee, the Nats and Inkatha, all put pressure on Nelson Mandela in his choice of cabinet. Farouk Chothia, Stephen Laufer, Chris Louw, Paul Stober report

UNMISTAKEABLY bearing Nelson Mandela's personal stamp, the national unity cabinet announced this week emerged after days of juggling during which the president was forced to keep his eye on a number of balls tossed to him by the coalition parties.

Perhaps most influential among the juggler's assistants was Mandela's own organisation, with the ANC's highest body, the national working committee, insisting on retaining control over several key portfolios despite massive pressure from the National Party and Inkatha for him to relinquish them.

Among the cabinet positions the ANC was determined to hang on to were those related to security, including the defence, police, and justice ministries, and land, key to the party's reconstruction and development programme.

ANC members have also been named as deputies in key ministries the party relinquished to their coalition partners. Said one cabinet insider: "We have a watchman in any ministry with relevance to the future." 

"Watchmen" include trade union heavyweight Alec Erwin as deputy finance minister to the Nat's Derek Keys, ANC legal advisor Penuell Maduna as deputy to Home Affairs Minister Mangosuthu Buthelezi, Valli Moosa at Provincial Affairs under Roelf Meyer, which will be key in the development of the federal system, and Thoko Msane at Agriculture, which is headed by the Nat's Kraai van Niekerk.

The ANC can expect to instal a second level of "watchmen" when the directors general are appointed. These could include Cheryl Carolus at welfare, and John Samuel at education. Lawyer Nicholas "Fink" Haysom was reportedly offered the top South African Police position, but turned it down in favour of a counsellor's post in the President's office.

The appointments of Winnie Mandela and Bantu Holomisa as deputies in the education and environment ministries respectively relates directly to their standing in the ANC. Mandela appears to have found it impossible to ignore their popular followings.

Buthelezi's appointment to the Home Affairs ministry -- formerly Interior -- was criticised by Inkatha spokesman Ziba Jiyane as "the only substantial ministry we got". He said Buthelezi "was very hesitant right up to the last moment", but had told colleagues they could take cabinet positions if they wanted to.

Buthelezi had argued in Inkatha for an opposition role, saying the ANC would use the cabinet as a "rubber stamp" for its own policies, "messing up the country" and then holding everyone responsible. But the opposite view, that it was "important to have a foothold in decision making on things that affect people on the ground" prevailed, said Jiyane.

Although the home affairs ministry is regarded as a very senior portfolio and Buthelezi's appointment is a clear sign that Mandela intends to continue with his policy of national reconciliation, ANC insiders insisted the Inkatha chief would not be allowed to run future elections. Although this function has traditionally resided within the interior ministry, several senior sources said a permanent independent electoral commission would be established.

The NP argued strongly for the defence, correctional services, justice, and police portfolios, saying the appointment of one or more senior Nats who enjoyed the trust of the security forces would smooth the transition.

But the ANC's top committee was unwilling to relinquish the ministries, arguing that the NP's human rights record made it impossible to give them the justice portfolio. Similarly, reservations surfaced on the Nats' willingness to root out the "third force" inside the security forces. "They want the security forces to know right away who is boss," said one Nat source.

Added to the equation was the ANC's intention of leaving General Johan van der Merwe in charge of the police and General George Meiring at the head of the military for the time being. They are seen as powerful leadership figures, particularly for white members of the security forces who need to be led gently to integration and transformation.

Balance required ANC people to head these ministries as long as the old guard stayed in uniform, argued the NWC. While Sydney Mufamadi's appointment to head the law and order ministry -- renamed "safety and security" -- was almost universally welcomed within the SAP and the ANC, former MK commander Joe Modise's nomination to the defence portfolio was more controversial.

Senior SANDF officers made their preference for Modise clear, but ANC members have criticised his endorsement of the generals' demands for an end to defence cuts. He has also not fully lived down criticism of his failure to prevent human rights abuses in MK camps in Angola in the 1980s.

But Modise enjoys the loyalty of the MK hierarchy, many of whom can expect to take senior uniformed and defence ministry positions in the near future. His conduct of the integration negotiations and TEC defence subcouncil have been positively received.

The appointment of Inkatha's Joe Matthews as deputy minister of safety and security is both a concession to Buthelezi and a calculated strategy by Mandela, who is keen to show the kwaZulu police that their long-term interests are best served by integration into South Africa's future security establishment. A former ANC member, Matthews is seen as intelligent and flexible, and ANC security experts believe it will be possible to establish a good working relationship with him.

The ANC's insistence on retaining the main security portfolios -- correctional services ultimately went to Inkatha's Sipho Mzimela -- cost constitutional affairs expert Kader Asmal a key position as provincial affairs minister. The portfolio, vital to shaping the federal relationship between central and regional government, went to the NP's Roelf Meyer in return for Nat aquiescence on the security ministries.

The land portfolio was almost lost to the ANC when the NP insisted on heading the agriculture ministry, which has traditionally included land matters. Mandela was reportedly preparing to withdraw his nomination of Derek Hanekom last Friday when the NWC stepped in.

Saying the ANC was the only party with a coherent policy on land, and pointing to its central importance for the party's reconstruction and development programme, several NWC members insisted on splitting land and agriculture.

Hanekom's nomination to the portfolio was also contentious, with some arguing that a ministry responsible for the emotive issues of resettlement, land redistribution and compensation should go to a black. Former ANC Women's League general secretary Baleka Kgositsile was mentioned as a possible minister.

Although regarded as a political heavyweight, Kgositsile was felt to lack experience in land issues. Hanekom, whose expertise and struggle credentials are unquestioned, was championed by several NWC members. "Competence won out over political correctness," said one participant.

Inkatha is understood to have had its eye on at least one senior security position as well as health and housing. The two departments are key to improving basic living conditions, and represent areas in which there is potentially much political hay to be made in the runup to the 1999 election.

Recognising their importance, Mandela stuck to his original choices of Joe Slovo for housing and Dr Nkosazana Dlamini Zuma for health.

Reprinted from The Weekly Mail & Guardian, May 13, 1994.

THE WEEKLY MAIL & GUARDIAN is published by M&G Media Contact: M&G Media, 139 Smit Street, Breamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025.

The Weekly Mail & Guardian is now available via the Internet. Subscription enquiries should be directed to wmail-info@wmail.misanet.org. Telephone 27-11-403-7113; fax 27-11-403-1025 attn. Bruce Cohen.

LANGUAGE: English

159 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 23, 1994 / June 6, 1994


LAND DEAL: THE KING'S RANSOM


BYLINE: Estelle Randall and Farouk Chothia


LENGTH: 1147 words


 

THE WEEKLY MAIL & GUARDIAN, May 20, 1994

FORMER state president FW de Klerk ceded control of a third of the land in kwaZulu/Natal to Zulu King Goodwill Zwelithini in a highly secretive deal the day before he was voted out of office last month.

The transfer of three million hectares scattered throughout the province was effected in terms of the kwaZulu Ingonyama Trust Act, passed by the kwaZulu Legislative Assembly and assented to by De Klerk on April 25 this year.

In terms of the legislation, King Goodwill Zwelithini, the sole trustee, will administer all tribal land in the province -- with the cost of administration being borne by the new regional government. It covers all the land for which the kwaZulu Legislative Assembly was established in 1971 and land acquired by the kwaZulu government under various proclamations and laws since then. 

It appears that under pressure from the kwaZulu government, De Klerk moved to prevent kwaZulu- administered tribal land from falling under state control -- the automatic effect of the new constitution, which kicked in on April 27 -- in an apparent sop to the Inkatha Freedom Party in exchange for its participation in the April poll.

A source close to Andre Fourie, the former minister of regional and land affairs, said the land transfer had been part of negotiations between the National Party government, the ANC and the IFP.

But ANC secretary-general Cyril Ramaphosa, who played a key role in the negotiations leading to the IFP's participation in the elections, denied this: "The Ingonyama Trust doesn't mean a thing to me; I'm hearing about it for the first time. I doubt very much that Nelson Mandela would have known about it. You are drawing a blank from me."

President Nelson Mandela's office was yesterday unable to comment, as was the office of Zwelithini.

ANC leaders in kwaZulu/Natal also appeared dumbfounded when approached this week. Regional supremo Jacob Zuma said he knew nothing of the transfer, and knew of no one else in the ANC who was aware of it. "It is surprising that this happened just before the election."

And in a furious reaction, ANC Midlands spokesman Blade Nzimane said: "The fact that this was done behind the backs of people and through an illegitimate bantustan structure seems to indicate that was aimed at undermining any constitutional accommodation of the king by the ANC.

"It seems to have been aimed at ensuring that kwaZulu retained actual control of the land even if it was disbanded."

Also unaware of the transfer was Roelf Meyer, the NP's central constitutional negotiator; Coenie de Villiers, director-general of land affairs -- who said "nobody consulted me about this Act" -- and the new Minister of Land Affairs, Derek Hanekom, who said he was "shocked" by the move.

"Effectively the land that was kwaZulu is no longer state land," Hanekom said. "It's in private ownership, held in trust by the king."

He added: "My ministry will be raising the issue politically and will be carrying out a full investigation to find out on whose ultimate authority the transfer was effected.

"We have consistently tried to get a moratorium on the transfer and sale of state land, but we never thought bantustan land would be transferred.

"There are potentially grave political implications and we're deeply concerned." He hinted that the National Assembly might overturn the legislation.

Some IFP sources described the formation of the Ingonyama Trust as a "house-keeping arrangement" between Chief Mangosuthu Buthelezi and De Klerk's governments before their demise -- and an attempt to protect the monarch from possible ANC rule in kwaZulu/Natal.

"The chances of the land ever being alienated (from the king) are now remote in the extreme," said an IFP source.

Zuma insisted the formation of the Ingonyama Trust was not part of the agreement that brought the IFP into elections. "We made an elaborate proposal for the monarchy so far as kwaZulu/Natal is concerned which we still have to iron out in the provincial constitution."

Observers believe the legislation has far-reaching implications: it means that future governments in the province will have to gain Zwelethini's permission -- or the permission of his chiefs or any other representative he charges with decision-making responsibility over the trust land -- before engaging in any development on the land in question. It means that land earmarked for redistribution in terms of the ANC's land reform plans is no longer available to the central state.

Barely 300 000ha of state land is now available for redistribution.

The formation of the trust also consolidates the relationship between Zwelethini and chiefs, as they will now be reliant on him for development in their areas -- and will reduce the prospect of an ANC-led government in kwaZulu/Natal winning major support among IFP-aligned traditional rulers.

Lawyers contacted yesterday stressed the land deal had not gone before the Transitional Executive Council which had overthrown other land decisions.

They also said that a challenge to the land transfer could be mounted. In terms of court precedents, changes to the ownership status of state land could not be made without consultation with the affected parties.

Reprinted from The Weekly Mail & Guardian, May 20, 1994.

THE WEEKLY MAIL & GUARDIAN is published by M&G Media Contact: M&G Media, 139 Smit Street, Breamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025.


LOAD-DATE: May 23, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


160 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 23, 1994 / June 6, 1994


IN THE NAME OF ALLAH, PLEASE!


BYLINE: Daily Observer Editorial


LENGTH: 960 words


 

DAILY OBSERVER, April 11, 1994

Africa seems to be overpowered by the evil spirit of destruction and death. Throughout the continent, a never-ending spiral of destruction, and death by the tens of thousands, is taking place.

The tragic plane crash in Kigali, Rwanda, last week demonstrated that we have become so good at mass destruction and fratricide that we are now killing two presidents at a time. Nothing, absolutely nothing on the entire continent seems to be good enough to let be, to encourage, to help along, to improve upon. No. Nothing. Everything must be destroyed. 

Take the relations between the two sister republics of Senegal and The Gambia -- two countries comprising blood relatives on either side of the border, of the same languages, culture and religions. The Senegalese government and the Senegalese media seem to be engaged in a war of nerves will little Gambia, accusing her of all kinds of things. All of this was sparked off first by the arbitrary closure of the border, denying Gambian businessmen the opportunity to transship their goods through Senegalese territory to landlock Mali and other neighbouring countries.

The Senegalese have said they took the action to prevent smuggling of goods from The Gambia into Senegal, which Dakar claims was "undermining" the Senegalese economy. Talks have been going on between the two nations, at ministerial level, but until now the problem persists. But, of course, the Senegalese border is wide open to allow Gambian groundnuts into Senegalese factories. The transshipment trade has traditionally been one of the main sources of revenue for The Gambia; so quite naturally, the Gambian economy has been hard hit by the border closure. And Senegal seems to be enjoying every minute of it. Two months ago a Senegalese newspaper said social unrest was brewing in The Gambia because the country had fallen on hard economic times, due to the border closure.

Now the Senegalese media is harping on an extraordinary new theme: that The Gambia is arming Cassamance rebels! The Senegalese ambassador in The Gambia has, of course, denied any knowledge whatsoever of these allegations and insisted that they did not come from his government, but from a private newspaper. But clearly, some segments of that country's media are nursing Dakar's anger with Banjul and are bent on taking it to jingoistic proportions. But to what end? Do they want to see the Gambian economy come to a complete standstill? Do they want to see The Gambia de-stabilised? How can trouble in The Gambia help Senegal?

We urge The Gambia Government to invite the Senegalese government and the Senegalese media to send a fact-finding mission here to investigate theses allegations and report their findings to the world.

The Gambia is a peace-loving country, trying its utmost to live at peace with all her neighbours, especially Senegal, whose friendship and co-operation she has always cherished and cultivated. At the same time, The Gambia is striving very hard to cope with the consequences of the border closure and all the other economic, political and social difficulties that afflict the sub-region and the entire African continent. Meanwhile, the country is endeavouring to maintain the democracy, peace and stability that have earned her, small and weak though the country is, the respect and admiration of the world. But this seems not to be good enough. Here is our big sister across the border hitting persistently at us, throwing stones she knows we cannot bear, for reasons known only to herself.

Yet The Gambia can never be a threat to Senegal., After all, she "is" our big sister, 8.8 times bigger in population, 18.4 times bigger in land size, and 23.9 times bigger than The Gambia in Gross National Product (GNP). It is like Germany, Europe's most powerful nation, with 80.6 million people and a GNP of US$1.8 trillion, hitting at Luxemburg, a tiny country with 350,000 people and a GNP of a meagre US$9.6 billion. No! Far from it, Germany sits at the same round table with Luxemburg, both as equal and sovereign member states of the European Union, helping each other in every possible way. Why on earth can't Africa learn that it is through hate and wickedness toward on another that we have robbed ourselves of what was billed as "the African century", and flushed out, for the foreseeable future, our own liberation, self-reliance and development.

In the name of Allah, we call n Senegal to stop kicking her little sister who is trying to remain a good and friendly neighbour. Let her remember, too, that Allah is a God of justice, and has His own way of protecting the weak from the strong.

Reprinted from DAILY OBSERVER, April 11, 1994..

DAILY OBSERVER is published by THE OBSERVER COMPANY (GAMBIA) LTD.

CONTACT: DAILY OBSERVER, New Town-Sait Matty Junction, Bakau, P.M.B.131, Banjul, The Gambia. Telephone:(220)496608, Fax: (220)496878


LOAD-DATE: May 23, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


161 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 23, 1994 / June 6, 1994


JANET MUSEVENI WEEPS OVER RWANDESE KIDS


BYLINE: Dismas Nkunda


LENGTH: 480 words


 

THE MONITOR, April 29 - May 3, 1994

A funeral air hung over Entebbe International Airport, Wednesday, when 54 children -- all orphans of Rwanda's genocide, arrived en route to Italy.

The First Lady, Mrs. Janet Museveni, broke down and wept on seeing the sickly looking kids, maimed and with the look of horror in their eyes. Many of the kids were themselves crying. 

Mrs. Museveni even gave up her earlier plans to talk to journalists. She left the airport still in tears.

The kids had arrived in a convoy of mini buses from Rwanda's Gahini Hospital and Muhura orphanage in Byumba.

Captain Mike Mukula of Speedbird Aviation, who coordinated the operation, was himself in a sombre mood as he paced up and down to see off the kids.

The children were between two months and eight years old. The children who arrived in Uganda by road were picked up from Entebbe by an Italian Boeing 737. They were headed for an orphanage in Italy.

The kids were a most pitiful sight. Even onlookers brave enough not to shed a tear, could not help muttering in anger under their breath.

One kid, Budeyi, told "The Monitor" that he had been picked from a heap of decomposing human flesh where he had been for four days. He said when the "Interahamwe" (MNRD's youth-wingers) struck at dawn, his parents were dragged out and hacked to death. His mother was killed first. Then the baby on her back. The his father...

It was all chaos as people tried to run for their lives. A bullet his Budeyi in the arm and he fell. Other bodies mowed down by gunfire or machetes fell over him. The children were escorted from Rwanda by RFP's prime minister designate, Jack Bihozagara. He said more orphans will be picked and taken to the Italian orphan NGO "Together For Peace Foundation."

The kids were received by Mrs. Mariapia Fanfani, the Foundation's director and wife of former Italian premier, Fanfani.

The next time round Mrs. Fanfani shall pick 30 of the remaining 80 children also maimed, but still in Byumba.

Reprinted from THE MONITOR, April 15-19, 1994.

The Monitor is published by The Monitor Publications Ltd., P.O. Box 12141, Kampala. Tel: 23-69-39.


LOAD-DATE: May 23, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


162 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 23, 1994 / June 6, 1994


STILL BEATING THE WAR DRUMS


BYLINE: Chukwujama Eze


LENGTH: 1120 words


 

TELL, April 18, 1994

If wishes were horses, Cameroun would have probably caused the month of March to last for more than "only" 31 days. March was the month when France, its colonial master, took its turn to occupy the Presidency of the United Nations Security Council.

And Cameroun's design was to take advantage of the French Presidency at the council to press its quest for global intervention in its festering border stand-off with Nigeria, over the oil-rich Bakassi Peninsula.

But, Cameroun's two letters persuading the security council to convene an urgent meeting on the border row could not draw any responses from the UN body before the expiration of French Presidency March 31. 

In a last ditch effort, Paschal Bilo Tang, the country's permanent representative at the UN, transmitted to the Security Council, the full text of a communique issued by the conflict resolution organ of the Organisation of African Unity, OAU, which met in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia on March 24, this year, with a view to getting the matter listed by council an urgent crisis while France held the body's presidency.

In the communique, the OAU central organ on the mechanism for conflict prevention, management and resolution expressed grave concern about the implication of the escalating border crisis and noted with satisfaction, the willingness of the two parties to engage in a negotiated truce.

"This strategy (of pressurising the UN) may not achieve much as the Nigeria-Cameroun conflict is currently not on the agenda of the Security Council as a threat to International Peace and Security a diplomatic source in the Nigerian Mission at the UN assured the News Agency of Nigeria, NAN, last week.

But Cameroun has remained relentless in its efforts to snatch the oil-rich island from Nigeria. For now, the battle ground has shifted to the International Court of Justice at the Hague, where it has filed a suit against the Federal Republic of Nigeria.

Cameroun is praying the World Court to rule that it has sovereignty over Bakassi Peninsula and that Nigeria has violated International Law by using force against Cameroun to take full possession of the island.

Cameroun further asked the court to order Nigeria to withdraw its troops stationed at the Peninsula and pay reparations to Cameroun.

Although no date has been fixed for hearing, the two countries have signed written declarations to accept the verdict of the legal arm of the UN.

Their undertaking to accept the court's jurisdiction came in the wake of apparent failure of the directive from the OAU conflict resolution committee, that both parties pull out their troops from the border to pave the way for a truce.

President Paul Biya is scheduled to embark on a string of diplomatic shuttles to Britain, France, USA and China, in order to drum up what he considers necessary diplomatic support capable of swaying world court opinion in favour of his country.

Although details of the global tour and itinerary were yet to be released at the time of going to press last week, the game plan, according to foreign affairs analysts, is to exploit to Cameroun's advantage, current cold relations between Nigeria and Western democracies following the annulment of June 12 presidential election.

In spite of its diplomatic posturing, security sources further say that Cameroun is secretly consolidating its military position as a last resort in the border feud.

Just as France was stepping out the presidency of the Security Council, the Nigerian army alerted the global community that it had uncovered the clandestine motive behind the joint Franco-Beninois military manoveures between March 6 and 11 this year.

Okon Edet Okon, a colonel and army spokesman, said in a statement, that the five-day joint military exercise was in fact, an operational rehearsal to prepare ground of eventual French involvement in support of Cameroun in the event of an outbreak of war with Nigeria.

According to the army spokesman, French participants in the exercise, drawn from the highly motivated Rapid Deployment Force, RAR, came with sophisticated weapons and armaments, few of which were left behind in Benin and majority of which have been diverted to Cameroun for possible attack on Nigeria.

"Of great significance is the fact that the defence adviser to Benin republic including that of Nigeria were invited merely to the closing ceremonies, rather than the actual scenes where French forces and equipment were used.

But exactly how innocent is Paris of these scorching charges? The French ambassador to Nigeria, Mr. Garrique Guyonnaud was said to have travelled home when TELL called for his comments at the French Embassy last week. The embassy's information officer said over the telephone that only the ambassador can comment on the allegations.

Meanwhile, speculation is rife in security circles that a significant percentage of the 304 millions US dollars or about 1.75 billion CFA Francs recently allocated by France to finance education, health and job creation projects in Cameroun will, indeed, be channelled to fund joint Franco-Cameroun military adventure in the volatile Bakassi Peninsula.

Reprinted from TELL The Weekly Newsmagazine, No. 16 April 18, 1994.

TELL is published weekly by Tell Communications Limited, Textile Labour House, 10 Acme Road, P.M.B. 21749, Ikeja, Nigeria. Tel: 01-824723.


LOAD-DATE: May 23, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


163 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 23, 1994 / June 6, 1994


OUR ORDEAL: WHEN THE SWORD HOLDS SWAY


BYLINE: Mercy Ette


LENGTH: 2160 words


 

NEWSWATCH, May 2, 1994

It was a warm and moving scene for staff of Newswatch Communications, Ltd., NCL, and its subsidiaries April 18 when their three directors returned from Ikoyi prison where they had spent six long days. Recollecting the reception, Dan Agbese, the editor-in-chief of "Newswatch" said: "I was overwhelmed. I felt really encouraged."

For the trio, Ray Ekpu, the chief executive officer, CEO, of NCL, Yakubu Mohammed, the deputy CEO, and Agbese, their prison experience will remain indelible in their memory, not so much for what they suffered but for what they saw. The injustice and lawlessness in the country shocked them.

Although the three had all been detained before, their six-day stay in Ikoyi prison was their first stint in jail. It was like a rite of passage and as Agbese put it "it opened the biggest unknown in my life, which is jail and which everybody is afraid of. Having been in there an out, the last wall of fear has been broken down." The prison is no longer an unknown world to them. 

If the directive of Sani Abacha, the head of state, had been obeyed, the three editors would have spent just two nights in jail. On Thursday, April 14, Abacha had ordered that they be released but the prison authorities would not let them go. They had no written order from the government to effect the release. It seemed Olu Onagoruwa, the minister of justice, who should have taken the necessary steps for their release was not in a hurry to do so.

Gani Fawehinmi, their lawyer, anticipating that government will resort to unnecessary bureaucracy in releasing them, had issued a statement April 15 outlining how the presidential fiat could be effected. Four days later, he, along with a team of lawyers, trooped to the federal high court in Lagos and prayed the judge to grant them an order restraining the government from further detaining the editors. They also made an application for the immediate release of the editors. At exactly 2.10 pm, April 18, the three directors became free men again. Less than an hour later, they reunited with their staff and later with their families.

The road to prison started from the Calabar international airport for Ekpu as he was waiting to board a flight to Lagos. He was whisked away by the state security service, SSS, agents at about 6.35 pm. April 18 on the excuse that the SSS director wanted to see him. But when he arrived the office, the director was not there. He was put in a small room furnished with a chair and serviced by a stinking toilet that had no water and no tissue paper.

In the room, Ekpu had to struggle with mosquitoes. The mosquitoes won and chased him out. "They were rather big," Ekpu chuckled last week when he talked about his room-mates. Nobody thought of giving him food and when he requested for something to eat, somebody went to town in search of food but returned two hours later with nothing. According to the security officer, he could not find food to buy in Calabar, a town noted for its delicacies. The following day, after a brief meeting with the SSS director, Ekpu was sandwiched in a station-wagon to Lagos, straight to the Awolowo Road detention camp.

Compared to his cell in Calabar, what he got in Ikoyi was a palace. There were three chairs, a table and an airconditioner that generated heat and noise rather than cold air. The mosquitoes had already colonised the room and he had to wage a war against them with mosquito coils. Unlike in Calabar, he was also provided with food. At meal time, somebody would "bring N15 and ask me what I wanted." The first day, he asked for bread and groundnut. In subsequent days, he ate "mama put" (food sold by roadside food vendors).

Apart from a glimpse he caught of Agbese on Sunday, April 10, Ekpu was not allowed to see his colleagues until Wednesday, April 13. The reunion was brief but barely an hour later, the three became inmates at Ikoyi prison. Ordinarily, only Agbese should have been arrested since the issue that led to their arrest was an editorial matter, but Ekpu and Mohammed were hurled along as well although they had stepped aside from the editorial department of NCL. "They apparently wanted to make it look bigger than it was," Ekpu observed.

Prison life reminded the chief executive that "all military regimes have the same complexion. None is humane." It also sensitised him to the need to fight for democracy that will make all freedom possible. He is convinced that outside a civilised system, there can be no free press and "that is why the press must join human rights groups and other people to fight against military rule." Would he allow the kind of interview that got him and his colleague into trouble to be published again? "Sure," he said. "It was a good interview. It gave chapters and verses and the government has not contradicted anything David Mark said."

That the federal government reacted to the interview which laid bare the secret agenda of the Abacha government was not a surprise. Mohammed, former managing editor of "Newswatch" and how deputy CEO of NCL, expected government in 1994 couldn't do better." The best way to handle the matter, he said, would have been for government to address the fundamental issues raised and to allay the fears of the public. Instead, it resorted to trading abuses and the usual clamped-down on journalists.

For Mohammed, his troubles with security men started on Friday, April 8. He had just left the office of the Kogi State administrator in Lokoja when Chris Okolie, a lawyer and magazine publisher, told him about the arrest of Agbese. As Mohammed was about to follow Olusola Akanmode, secretary to Kogi State government and his friend and school mate at government secondary school, Okene, to his office, a security agent stopped him. The agent said the SSS state director wanted to see him. Mohammed was then accompanied by four security agents to see the security boss. He was detained by the security operative in Lokoja. The following day, he was driven to Lagos to join Agbese.

As traumatic as the experience was, Mohammed says he holds nothing against the security agents. "They were nice, they were human beings," he insists. Although he was confined to a room where mosquitoes held sway, he says it was not the fault of the security operatives.

Unlike Ekpu who was isolated, Mohammed later shored a room with Agbese, but they still had to content with boredom. "It is difficult to handle boredom if you have been busy all your life," he realised during their detention. He describes the nights they spent in detention as "our longest nights." They were nights when they could not sleep because of mosquitoes, heat and dysentery.

Ikoyi prison gave him a reprieve. There he could go to a mosque built by Umaru Shinkafi to pray, play games and interact with other prisoners. Although he lost a game of table tennis, he was able to defeat Agbese in the game of Ludo.

Looking back two days after he walked into freedom, Mohammed said his faith in God kept his spirit up. "I remembered that they (Abacha and his junta) were not God although they could pretend to be. They were not God. "He has already put his experience behind him and is not regretting it.

Agbese too does not regret having his name on the list of those who have been hosted by Ikoyi prison. After seven difficult days in SSS detention camp, the five days at Ikoyi prison were not so bad. From the first night at "Hollywood" detention centre somewhere in Ikoyi to the last day at the Awolowo Road cell, he had to sleep on the floor. "It was rough, very rough," he recollected.

By the time he was moved from the security cell, he had blotches all over his body from mosquito bites. He was not surprised when he had malaria in prison. A daily bath which he used to take for granted, was a luxury while he was in detention. In seven days, he bathed only twice because there was no bathroom and no water. The two times he bathed he had to beg for water and had to do it openly, in the dark.

The move from detention camp to the prison yard was swift. The three editors were simply whisked to the Igbosere magistrate court on April 13, and within 10 minutes the magistrate had ordered that they be remanded in prison custody for two weeks to give him time to decide whether he should grant them bail or not. Agbese thinks the high-handedness displayed was to teach them "who is the boss, who is stronger and to prove that even if the pen is mightier than the sword, the sword can still hold sway."

There were many things to show that the sword was momentarily mightier. He had no access to paper or pen. He could not write and often he could not sleep because of the heat. For three days, he was alone and was denied visitors. Two books, "The Prize", which he describes as an interesting story of oil, and a Bible were his only companions until Mohammed joined him. In prison, the three directors were put in one cell which made their five-day stay bearable. Apart from reading and playing games with other prison inmates, they also had unlimited time to chat. Ekpu was in charge of mosquito control, Mohammed was responsible for supply of water while Agbese took care of brewing tea and keeping the cell tidy.

Unlike their detention days, the editors slept on proper beds, Ekpu and Mohammed were assigned to a double decker. When Ekpu tried to climb on the bunk, the bed threatened to fall apart, so he had to relinquish the top to his deputy. He slept under. In prison, they also had access to water which was a luxury while they were in detention. After days of going without a bath, they were able to bathe regularly again.

For Agbese, the 12 days he was locked up helped him to appreciate a few things including water. He was reminded that the hazard of journalism is real, that "you don't have to be a criminal to be treated like one" and that the level of injustice and lawlessness in Nigeria is more serious than he ever thought.

When the editors recollect their days of imprisonment, what will stand out may not be their ordeal but the ordeal of the inmates they met and left behind. Agbese said what he saw in prison was a shame to Nigeria. In a prison meant for 800 people, there are 1,600 people crammed together. Three quarters of them are awaiting trial and some have been there for 10 years and their cases have not even been mentioned let alone tried. The editors were shocked by the large number of juvenile offenders, some as young as 13 years who were arrested for hawking and charge for attempting to commit felony. The three editors left prison with the determination to fight for prison reforms. "I hope to be able to sue both my personal resources and the magazine to fight for reforms," Agbese promised. The other directors are behind him.

If they succeed then their detention would have served a useful purpose.

Reprinted from Newswatch, May 2, 1994.

Newswatch is published weekly by Newswatch Communications Limited, No. 3 Billings Way, Oregun Industrial Estate, Oregun, P.M.B. 21499, Lagos, Nigeria.


LOAD-DATE: May 23, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


164 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


May 23, 1994 / June 6, 1994


NEW SOUTH AFRICAN CABINET


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 680 words


 

South African President Nelson Mandela announced his Cabinet on Wednesday 11 May 1994.


Full cabinet ministers are:

Mr Dullah Omar            -- Justice

Mr Joe Modise             -- Defence

Mr Sidney Mufamadi        -- Safety and Security

Mr Sibusiso Bengu         -- Education

Mr Trevor Manuel          -- Trade, Industry and Tourism

Mr Alfred Nzo             -- Foreign Affairs

Mr Tito Mboweni           -- Labour

Dr Pallo Jordan           -- Posts, Telecommunications and  Broadcasting

Dr Nkosazana Dlamini Zuma -- Health

Mr Mac Maharaj            -- Transport

Mr Roelf Meyer            -- Provincial Affairs and  Constitutional Development

Mr Derek Hanekom          -- Land Affairs

Ms Stella Sigcau          -- Public Enterprises

Dr Zola Skweyiya          -- Public Service and  Administration

Mr Joe Slovo              -- Housing

Mr Jeff Radebe            -- Public Works

CURRENCY EXCHANGE RATES


LENGTH: 2405 words


 

Maxwell Stamp PLC

Economic Consultants

London * Nairobi * Riyadh * Mauritius

The table gives selected currencies valued against the major international trading currencies. Rates quoted are the middle rates between buying and selling, but currencies are in most cases not freely traded. These rates have been compiled by Maxwell Stamp PLC for information only. Maxwell Stamp accepts no responsibility for any transaction undertaken on the basis of these figures. For further information please contact John Morgan at Maxwell Stamp0s Head Office in London; phone 44-71-251-0147; telex 914569 MAXAMP G; fax 44-71-251-0140. 

*CFA Franc = Benin, Burkina Faso, Cameroon, Central African Republic, Chad, Comoros, Congo, Cote d'Ivoire, Equatorial Guinea, Gabon, Mali, Niger, Senegal, Togo.

** commercial rate


                               $             L          DM

BUSINESS


LENGTH: 734 words


 

American Information Technologies (AIT) can provide computer equipment, installation, maintenance, and training services for business or individuals starting up in Africa. For additional information, contact: AIT, PO Box i510, Tucker, GA Tel: (404) 723-9200.

The following procurement opportunities in Egypt are available to U.S. companies through the U.S. Agency for International Development. 

*Medical Laboratory Equipment, consisting of medical equipment and supplies. A.I.D. Geographic Code 000 (U.S. only). IFB No: 263-0203-06. BID CLOSING DATE: JUNE 14, 1994. Purchasing Agent: TransCentury Associates, Inc., 12110 Sunset Hills Rd., Suite 450, Reston, VA 22090, Attn: Mr. George Scott, Tel: (703) 715-3047.

Purchasing Agent: Consortium for International Development, Write to Embassy of the Arab Republic of Egypt, 2232 Massachusetts Avenue, NW, Washington, DC 20008; Send $20.00 non-refundable fee to obtain a copy of the solicitation.

Purchasing Agent: Consortium for International Development, Write to Embassy of the Arab Republic of Egypt, 2232 Massachusetts Avenue, NW, Washington, DC 20008; Send $20.00 non-refundable fee to obtain a copy of the solicitation.

Purchasing Agent: Consortium for International Development, Write to Embassy of the Arab Republic of Egypt, 2232 Massachusetts Avenue, NW, Washington, DC 20008; Send $20.00 non- refundable fee to obtain a copy of the solicitation.
