174 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 6, 1994 / July 3, 1994


WEED THE CRIMINALS OUT OF THE SDUS


LENGTH: 1107 words


 

SUNDAY NATION, MAY 22, 1994

Self-Defense Units have played a sterling role in the protection of our communities in the past three to four years. They succeeded where the formal law enforcement agencies failed.

In fact, their very existence was made necessary by the gross incompetence on the part of the police to protect communities against the bloodletting pursued by political retards who were determined to stall the inevitable democratic victory we scored so recently.

The role of these SDUs was indeed noble. 

But when noble imperatives such as the defense of our communities are shoved aside in pursuit of narrow group and even personal objectives, society needs to step back and take serious stock of itself.

And when the pursuit of these narrow selfish objectives result in senseless carnage of the type we saw in Thokoza last Friday, society needs to step in and bring the full weight of its moral being to bear on the guilty. What is amply apparent is that the SDUs have, in some cases, decayed into bands of criminals masquerading as defenders of our communities.

But it has until now been difficult, if not impossible, to rip off the mask from the criminal elements in the SDUs and expose them to the communities they have begun terrorizing.

Conditions have, however, changed dramatically in the past few weeks and we can no longer tolerate explanations and excuses that in the past justified the secrecy behind which these criminals thrived.

Two priorities must therefore be pursued with great vigor if we are to deny these criminals the space to further terrorize our communities.

First and unquestionably the most important is the need to introduce the element of transparency. To achieve this objective we must move with all haste to begin building a culture of community policing in which the authority of victims of past excesses will reign supreme. In the process, the SDUs must be brought above ground.

Secondly, we must disarm the SDUs.

Neither of this will be easy. There is still a great deal of suspicion, and justifiably so.

Members of SDUs have in the past been forced to operate clandestinely mainly because of the threat they faced from the formal police units themselves.

It is no secret that an open war raged between the Internal Stability Division of the police and the SDUs.

Identifying an SDU member under these circumstances was tantamount to passing the death penalty on such a person.

Removing these fears will take a long time.

And this will impact on the willingness of SDU members to surrender their weapons and subject themselves to the authority of the communities they serve in.

Be this as it may, we can no longer delay the process of immobilizing the criminals festering in the SDUs.

Transparency and accountability to the community is the only guarantee against criminals pursuing narrow selfish objectives at the expense of township residents; if we fail, a repeat of the Thokoza executions is a certainty.

However, the responsibility of ensuring transparency is, in great part, also a responsibility of the new government, which must ensure that the police are kept on a short leash.

Only this will help erode the suspicion that will otherwise continue to provide the justification for the continued existence of clandestine defense units.

Disregard for the law, whatever quarter it emanates form -- the police or the SDUs -- must therefore be dealt with firmly and without compassion. However, in advocating the disarming and disbanding of the SDUs, we must also stress that they have an important contribution to make towards developing a new policing culture.

More than anyone else, the SDUs have developed an understanding of the needs of their communities and their preferences when it comes to policing. This is an experience that must be incorporated into cultivating the culture of community policing.

The possibility, therefore, of incorporating members of the SDUs into a new police force must not be rejected out of hand.

The temptation to do so will, however, be great given the Thokoza experience. But if we discarded the SDUs altogether, we would have also failed in our desire to weed out and isolate the criminal factor.

The jackboot culture of the SAP alone will not help a great deal in developing a new set of law enforcement imperatives.

We must also warn that if we fail to rein in the police and the SDUs, safety and security will remain empty slogans.

The consequent instability will not help mend the social fabric that has been all but destroyed by apartheid violence.

And this in turn will render all our efforts at reconstruction and development sterile.

Reprinted from Sunday Nation, May 22, 1994.

SUNDAY NATION is published by New Nation Publishing Co.

Contact: New Nation Publishing Co., P.O. Box 10674, Johannesburg 2000, South Africa, phone:(011) 333-2711. Fax:(011) 333-2733.


LOAD-DATE: June 9, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


175 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 6, 1994 / July 3, 1994


THE 40,000 RWANDESE BODIES ARE NOT IN VAIN


SECTION: VIEWPOINTS


LENGTH: 707 words


 

THE MONITOR, May 24-27, 1994

The problem at the heart of Rwanda's tragedy was captured by a subscript at last weekend's mass burials of some of the thousands of bodies from the carnage in the country which have been washed over Lake Victoria into Rakai and Masaka districts.

British High Commissioner to Uganda, Mr. Edward Clay, said the Rwanda massacres, in which up to 500,000 non-combatant civilians are estimated to have been killed, was a shame to the people of Africa and an indication of backwardness and underdevelopment.

Yes, the last 30 years have been dog years. Democracy has all but disappeared from the continent. The more common form of government are one-party, or military dictatorships. 

Nearly all the African governments have turned into rule by a single tribe, and made corruption a model of government. The results are everywhere; bankrupt treasuries, famine, abject poverty, disease, ignorance and bloody fights over the national cake.

But you would never have guessed that the savagery in African politics is created by fights over the dwindling national cake, if Col. Kahinda Otafire -- CA delegate, Chairman of the Pan-African Movement and Chief of the External Security Organisation had also not spoken at the same occasion where Clay unveiled the shame of Africa.

Otafire said the madness in Rwanda was an African tragedy with "historical roots in world politics." In other words colonial policy of countries like Britain, which thrived by institutionalising division among the African people, must also shore the blame. It sounds like an old-fashioned Pan-Africanist argument, but it is still valid nevertheless.

Otafire also warned that the Rwanda tragedy is also born of governments adopting policies of "identifying a section of its population as a national enemy." There are a few Ugandans who can now sleep soundly after hearing a top NRM man say that.

We think that the genocide in Rwanda was the result of extreme prejudice, fear and too much anger. This happens when the rulers try to justify and cling on their privileges by invoking the superiority of their tribe, clan or ideology -- and by demonising those who hold a different opinion from theirs.

Or when the oppressed revolt, driven by a sense that everything the oppressors touched, the women they married, the children they bore are an evil to be wiped off the face of the earth -- and that it's their historical destiny to execute that task.

None of these grave shortcomings cannot be cured by

democracy: Allow the people to profess their faith, to proclaim their political beliefs without undue obstruction, to work and to make a profit without the government stealing it from them, to enjoy access to national resources irrespective of their tribe, race, religion or political party. In case anyone had forgotten the consequences of the failure to do this from our recent history, there is now the macabre reminder from Rwanda. It could have chosen no better a time than when we are discussing the new constitution to come.

Reprinted from The Monitor, May 24-27, 1994.

THE MONITOR is published by The Monitor Publications Ltd. (Uganda)

CONTACT: THE MONITOR, P.O. Box 12141, Kampala. Phone: 251353; fax: 251352.


LOAD-DATE: June 9, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


176 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 6, 1994 / July 3, 1994


AFRICA: CONFLICT PREVENTION AND NEW DEVELOPMENT INITIATIVES


BYLINE: James G. Speth, Administrator, United Nations Development Program


SECTION: SPEECH


LENGTH: 4400 words


 

The following speech was delivered to The African-American Institute in New York, NY on May 24, 1994.

Friends,

UN Officials,

Your Excellencies,

Ladies and Gentlemen,

Thank you very very much for this opportunity to speak today with you about Africa and its future. There is simply no subject on earth that is more important. As Ms. Derryck so correctly mentioned, it is a continent of contrasts today. In South Africa, after decades of racial separation, vast inequities, inequalities, conflict, there is a reaching out of hands in the spirit of unity and reconciliation. We join in applauding these historic accomplishments. Then, there is Rwanda, where we witness with horror the degeneration of ethnic conflict into barbaric acts of destruction and mayhem. We must condemn these atrocities in the strongest possible terms. I fear that the international community has merely watched as this horror has unfolded into genocidal proportions. 

Whatever is done there, it will almost certainly be too little, I fear, and it is already too late. Three days before the place crash that killed the Presidents of Rwanda and Burundi, Oxfam reported that more than 850,000 people -- one eighth of the population of that country -- urgently needed food to prevent starvation due to the drought. Six months before this occurrence, UNDP had met with the country's main donors and urged them to relax conditions that would have enabled us to proceed with a program of demilitarization and resettlement. This agreement was not achieved. Virulent ethnicity and virulent fundamentalism flourish under conditions of rapidly declining opportunity. Where the State is the primary and sometimes the only source of social power, prestige, and comfortable lives, it will be fought for fiercely, often to the death. Where true power resides with military authorities, we can expect that on occasion they will use the means at their disposal. And the means have been increasing unfortunately. One diplomat on the scene in Rwanda was quoted as saying, "Blood has been in the air for months". But, still, the arms kept flowing in. Since the end of the cold war, affluent nations' arms merchants have compensated by dumping arms into the developing world, including Rwanda.

The events in South Africa and Rwanda epitomize the contrasting situations across Africa today -- hope and despair, progress and destruction, decency and depravity.

One might say that history has not been fair to Africa, and that is, indeed, true. Two externally imposed experiences -- the slave trade and colonialism -- interrupted the process of indigenous state formation and the development of the several great empires of the region and introduced artificially imposed systems of administration and production.

We conveniently forget Africa's history. We forget the transatlantic slave trade that robbed Africa of about 12 million of its able bodied men and women. We forget the colonialism which followed the slave trade introduced a system of exploitation of Africa's natural resources to feed the industries of the West. We forget that the Colonial Conferences of Berlin which crudely balkanized and divided Africa into geographic areas of control by the West, with scant regard to the ethnic boudaries and groupings. We even forget that during the period of the cold war's geopolitical fight for spheres of influence, Africa became a focal point for the ideology and the arms that today contribute to the havoc we find in Rwanda and Burundi, in Zaire, Angola and Somalia.

Even independence, which restored self-rule and self-determination to Africa, was unable to counter these long-term effects of history. It could not reverse the character of Africa's state systems that resulted from an arbitrary forging of nations from disparate tribes and ethnic groups. This set the stage for the many conflicts that we see today.

Yet for two decades, improvements in Africa were in fact impressive. Particularly for a region that for the most part became independent states only thirty five years ago.

Gains in education and health, in communication and roads, and in housing and water supply were no less than those achieved by other regions at similar stages of their development. From 1960 to 1980 average Gross National Product growth rates exceeded those of population growth rates. And the period 1967-1974 was a particularly successful one for African growth, with average GDP growth rates of 6 percent. Even greater improvement occurred with regard to social indicators. Primary school enrollment nearly doubled from 41 per cent to 79 per cent during this period. Under five mortality rates dropped from 300 to 200 per 1,000 between 1960 and 1980.

Even in the area of democracy and political pluralism, progress has occurred. In the last three years, twenty-four African countries have embarked upon programmes to improve the national climate of politics and governance. This year alone, twelve countries are scheduled to hold elections in Africa.

Yet, despite the gains, the challenges Africans face today are truly unprecedented by any standard. Today the total wealth of Africa, which has twice the population of the United States, is little more than that of Belgium. At the World Bank's projected growth rates for Africa, Africans will have to wait two generations to reach even the standard of living they had in 1975.

In too many countries, poor governance continues to impede reform and development, thereby reducing domestic savings and discouraging domestic and foreign investment. Too many Africans remain marginalized in their own countries. Too many face repression and deprivation and torture.

The economic performance of the region in the sixties and seventies was not sustained, and, in fact, real per capita incomes fell during 1981-93 at over 1 per cent a year. It is estimated that half the people in Africa south of the Sahara will be living in absolute poverty by 2000. Despite its capacity to feed itself, Africa is the only region to produce less food per capita today than at the beginning of the 1980s.

The developing world received about 32% of direct foreign investment in 1992. Africa received 2%. Evidence of the brain drain out of Africa is equally alarming. In Ghana, for example, it's estimated that 60% of the doctors trained in the early 1980s have left the country.

Then there's the social challenge -- the need to bring under control the rapid population and urbanization growth, which contribute to the grave social conditions that give rise to the many jobless unemployed who are ready participants in civil unrest. The statistics are telling. The maternal mortality rate in Sub-Saharan Africa at 700 per 100,000 live births is the highest in the world. Average years of schooling at 1.6 in 1992 was the lowest in the world. Life expectancy at birth at 51 years in 1992, is still the lowest in the world. The number of chronically undernourished in Africa continues to increase, from 100 million in 1969-71 to 168 million in 1990. And this figure is projected to double by 2010 when perhaps a third of the African people will suffer chronic undernutrition, according to FAO estimates.

Therefore, at this critical juncture in the continent's history, we should ask ourselves what steps should Africa be considering, and what can the international community do to encourage African initiatives.

It is a given that the primary responsibility for the development of Africa rests with Africa itself. As Professor (Adebayo) Adedeji has written, "Africa must grapple with the reality of developing itself primarily through reliance on its own resources, no matter how difficult that might be." In this regard, Africa's tenacity in staying the course of appropriate economic reforms, thereby laying the foundation for growth or expansion in production, should provide the base for an increase in the jobs and incomes that are necessary for development. But economic reforms alone will never be enough; nor will a myopic fixation on aggregate indicators of national economic growth and performance. Governments must not worship at the altar of GNP. It's the quality of life for people and the quality of the environment on which the people depend that truly matters.

Africa can therefore move a step further, I believe, adopting those policies and programmes that center on people and on sustaining the resource base. In UNDP, we call this goal sustainable human development. It's development that doesn't merely generate growth, but distributes its benefits equitably. It's development that regenerates the environment rather than destroying it. It's development that empowers people rather than marginalizing them. It's development that enlarges people's choices, enlarges their opportunities, providing for the participation in the decisions that affect their lives. In short, it's development that's pro-poor, pro- jobs, pro-nature, and central to all of that, pro-women.

To achieve sustainable human development, economic reforms, economic adjustments must be complemented by equally powerful initiatives to ensure that economic growth benefits the poor more than the rich, that it is job-led growth, and that the environment is protected. We at UNDP are committed to working with African countries in an urgent search for this package of complementary initiatives -- not a one-sided macro-economics-only agenda -- but a balanced agenda for the people. We will work with Africa to try to ensure that this more complete agenda receives as much international support as economic reforms and ajustments have received.

The good news is that Africans are insisting on political liberalism and better governance in their societies. Many have already begun to take the hard measures to mobilize and efficiently allocate domestic resources. I believe this new approach is consistent with Africa's own prescriptions and initiatives as called for in the Lagos Plan of Action, The African Charter for Popular Participation in Development, the Treaty Establishing the African Economic Community, all of which point in the right direction. They need now to be transformed into living programmes of action, with the full support and the unstinting backing of the international community.

And now to the international community -- what should we do?

Let me suggest that as great as it seems, the needs of Africa are moderate and well within the means of the international community. Helping Africa to succeed is a do-able proposition! For example, the $30 billion in annual flows called for by the New Agenda for African Development (UN-NADAF) represent less that 1 per cent of the GDP of the smallest economy of the G-7 member states. We have yet to achieve this since the New Agenda for African Development was launched in 1991. In fact, the trend suggests a slight decline. After a peak of $25.7 billion in 1990, ODA flows fell to $25.1 billion in 1991 and $24.8 billion in 1992. Enhanced and assured flows are needed to consolidate African development gains. And it would be unfortunate in the extreme if, in the push for the legitimate needs of other regions, Africa's urgent call for development assistance is crowded out.

The quality of assistance, and not merely the quantity, to Africa has also got to improve. In the May 1994 issue of "The Economist", in noting the transfer since 1960 of some $1.4 trillion (in 1988 dollars) of aid from the rich countries to the poor, "The Economist"

asked: Has this aid been properly used? Has it relieved poverty? Has it stimulated growth? And our "Human Development Report" at UNDP has raised similar questions. And the data are not encouraging. In sub-Sahara Africa in the 1980s, only $1 of development assistance went to primary school pupils compared with $575 to each university student. And I might add, at UNDP, we know we must do a better job in our capacity building work in Africa and elsewhere, and address our own shortcomings.

I must, therefore, take this occasion to issue an urgent plea to the OECD donor countries to review their priorities, with the goal of elevating dramatically the support given to international development cooperation in general and the support given to Africa in particular.

Together we've got to tackle the very, very difficult job of rekindling public support for development assistance. Logically, it shouldn't be that hard a job, for non of the goals that the world community is addressing today -- not peace, not human rights or democratization, not environmental protection, not reduced population pressures, not disease control, -- none of these can be achieved except in the context of development.

Yet, despite the centrality of development to the concerns that capture the political energies today, international support for development is under attack and is threatened, perhaps as never before. The threat comes from many sources, including aid fatigue, competing domestic priorities, sluggish economies; perhaps above all from a lack of public understanding in the donor countries. The resources being devoted to peacekeeping, to humanitarian relief, and to support for political and economic reforms in the former Soviet Bloc are all increasing; the support for development assistance in the poorer countries is hardly increasing at all. If you adjust for inflation it's about about holding constant.

Armed conflicts and humanitarian emergencies fill the daily headlines and attract resources, and for good reason. Yet, underlying many of these tragic events are the silent crises of underdevelopment, of chronic and growing poverty, of mounting populations pressures and widespread environmental deterioration. And as efforts to respond to acute crisis through peacekeeping, humanitarian relief, assisting refugees grow larger, so must our efforts to respond to the silent crisis through the promotion of sustainable human development. It is far cheaper, more humane, more effective to act preventively, to address the root causes rather than the tragic symptoms.

Which brings me to the urgent requirement for the international community to assist African in the area of peace building and conflict prevention. Civil war and strife have been major constraints for the development of many African countries. Already one third, or sixteen, African countries are involved in one form or another of civil conflict. There are over six million refugees in areas beyond their own borders. An additional 17 million are internally displaced. There is simply no way that development can proceed under these conditions.

Conflict and wars claim resources that would otherwise be spent on education and health and housing and other areas of development. An estimated per capita public expenditure on the military in Sub-Saharan Africa averaged $11 in 1990, compared with $13 in education. In one African country, the military budget was five times that of the budget for health and education.

A large part of the blame for this trading in death rests with the industrial countries who, while giving aid on the order of some $60 billion a year, earn an estimated $125 billion per year from the military expenditures of the developing world.

For the poor countries in Africa, for the poor people in Africa, this madness should be brought to an end. Therefore, I would like to propose the phasing out of all arms trade and military assistance to Africa, over the next three years. This call might form the basis for UN-sponsored talks on how this phasing might be achieved. We should start with a focus on the countries that risk being on the verge of conflict, perhaps Burundi, Zaire, Cameroon, Algeria. Reversely, those states that promote peace, security and development within their borders should be rewarded by the international community with substantially higher levels of development assistance.

In Africa, action to change the situation, to address the potential and the emerging conflicts within countries, is, fortunately, already underway. At the June 1993 Annual Summit of the Organization of the African Unity, African Heads of State established a management mechanism in the OAU Secretariat to address such internal conflicts. The mechanism underscores regional ways of preventing political tensions from escalating into armed conflict. Specifically, the mechanism provides for the anticipation and prevention of conflicts, the undertaking of peace-keeping and peace-building activities, including the deployment of civilian and military missions of observation and monitoring in identified crisis-prone countries.

But the OAU lacks both the resources and the capacity to act on these intentions and this good plan. The international community must therefore help, and this means urgent contribution to the OAU Peace Fund which was established for this purpose. Already, the international community has spent $3-4 billion on conflict resolution in the region, and the tab is rising. I believe that a mere 10% of this amount, or $300 to $400 million, provided to the OAU for its Peace Fund would do much more, would get better mileage than the international community has been able to get thus far. I therefore propose and recommend to the international community a $400 million African Peace Fund. The key in this regard is to provide the resources up front -- now -- to enable the OAU to effectively mount pre-emptive responses to potential conflicts. It's not enough to scramble when a conflict is full swing as we have found tragically in the case of Rwanda. We should act preventively.

UNDP, which is already assisting the OAU with the implementation of the African Economic Community, and assisting several African countries in various governance interventions, would be prepared to help the OAU develop this programme and the terms and conditions to enable them to discharge the responsibilities related to the operation of this important Fund.

More importantly, although facing financial constraints ourselves at UNDP, we are prepared to contribute to this preemptive Peace Fund by providing three million dollars to be used as seed money to strengthen OAU's capacity for the development of the programmes to operationalize the activities envisioned for the Fund.

I would also like to propose that the international community do more to address the issue of African debt. One cannot address the African crisis without addressing the debt issue.

The question of debt relief for Africa has been under consideration for several years, and there have been significant responses on the part of the international community. Some creditor nations have unilaterally canceled a significant portion of the debt to the poorer African countries; and others have provided relief through Paris Club arrangements.

Yet, more is required to remove this major constraint on African development. According to the latest report of the OECD, the ratio of sub-Saharan Africa debt stock to GNP was on average 109 per cent, compared with the average of 37 per cent for the developing world as a whole.

At the least, therefore, the international community, as a first step, should urgently endorse the G-7 Trinidad Terms, which represents the most far- reaching debt relief mechanisms, for application to all African countries, big or small, poor or not so poor. Essentially, these terms would imply a cancellation of two-thirds of all official bilateral debt and a rescheduling of the balance over a longer period of 25 years including a five-year grace period.

Such an across-the-board approach would provide the necessary breathing space for Africa to launch its sustainable human development strategy and to halt dangerously declining living standards. Moreover, UNDP is considering a mechanism, referred to as the Poverty Dividend Account (PDA), which would require recipient countries undergoing debt relief to commit at least 25 percent of the value of debt relieved towards poverty reduction programmes, aimed at the poorest segments of their population. This proposal would result in a longer term and more comprehensive debt reduction strategy than the ad hoc approach now being used, and importantly, would link debt relief to performance criteria for improving the living standards of the people.

My final word has to do with South Africa. While rejoicing in the political changes that have taken place there, the international community must move quickly to help South Africa succeed in its economic transformation by providing the means to address development needs of the vast number of its citizens who were by-passed by the apartheid system. In doing so, we will not only help South Africa and the people of that nation, but we give impetus to the development of an important growth pole for the entire African subregion.

The Secretary General recently indicated that UNDP, along with other UN agencies, would be gearing up to respond to South Africa's needs and priorities. We are reviewing our ongoing programmes there, with the Government of South Africa and we expect to present a country programme in South Africa which is directed to meeting the needs of the majority population, whose per capita income is roughly estimated to be no more than $100 compared with the $2,300 officially listed by the World Bank as the national per capita income figure. UNDP will also within six months be co-sponsoring with other donors an international donors' conference that will focus on and mobilize resources for South Africa's human resources development.

In closing, let me say that Africa remains for UNDP a region of the utmost importance. Nearly half of our resources are directed towards the region's development and, to a large extent, UNDP's own success will depend on Africa's success.

Helping Africa is a doable proposition. Providing annual official flows of assistance of $30 billion is doable. Mobilizing $400 million to support programs aimed at preventing conflict is doable. Implementing a more comprehensive debt relief program is doable. Curbing the arms trade to African nations is doable. Helping South Africa to consolidate its political program, its development goals is doable.

I hope that these suggestions will find a positive reception in UNDP's program countries and our donor countries, and I stand ready with my colleagues at UNDP, led by Ms. Johnson-Sirleaf, to work even more assiduously with African governments and African institutions and with the African people in the realization of their development aspirations.

Thank you very much for this opportunity.


LOAD-DATE: June 9, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.

June 6, 1994 / July 3, 1994


CHALLENGE TO THE CENSORS


BYLINE: Stefaans BrUmmer


LENGTH: 587 words


 

THE WEEKLY MAIL & GUARDIAN, June 3, 1994

The first court challenge to a Publications Appeal Board ruling since 1987 -- by the producers of two safer sex education videos banned 18 months ago -- has raised the curtain on renewed debate about censorship in the new South Africa.

The Pretoria Supreme Court on Wednesday reserved judgment after stormy argument, mostly technical, about the process by which the Publications Appeal Board (PAB) last year decided to uphold an earlier decision by a Committee on Publications to ban the videos Safer Sex, a Lovers' Guide and Safer Sex for Gay Men and Men who have Sex with Men.

The Publications Act allows the supreme court only to review the process by which the board reached its ruling, and not the merits of the videos themselves -- whether they are in fact too explicit and transgress the freedom of expression guarantee in the new constitution. 

Said Jeff van Reenen of Reel Communications: "What makes this case important is that it centres on a ruling made by the Directorate of Publications in the old South Africa. Today the censor board and the Publications Act are in violation of the new constitution. Ironically, the supreme court may have to uphold this violation."

Advocate Gilbert Marcus, representing the producers, said there could be strong grounds for a hearing in the constitutional court if the supreme court challenge fails.

Legal argument on Wednesday centred on whether the PAB had given sufficient consideration to the likely audience, and on its treatment of expert evidence submitted to it by Professor Reuben Sher of the South African Institute for Medical Research and Mary Crewe, chief Aids educator of the Johannesburg City Council.

Sher and Crewe endorsed the videos as a step in the right direction by treating Aids education in the context of eroticism and emphasising the pleasures of safer sex rather than staid lecturing.

It was common cause that the board had accepted the expert evidence on the videos' educational value. Marcus argued that the board had not sufficiently considered the

evidence. Advocate H de Wet, for the board, retorted: "At the end of the day (the board) still has to judge the vehicle in the light of the morals of society."

Reprinted from The Weekly Mail & Guardian, June 3, 1994.

THE WEEKLY MAIL & GUARDIAN is published by M&G Media

Contact: M&G Media, 139 Smit Street, Breamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025.

The Weekly Mail & Guardian is now available via the Internet. Subscription enquiries should be directed to wmail-info@wmail.misanet.org. Telephone 27-11-403-7113; fax 27-11-403-1025 attn. Bruce Cohen.

Africa News


June 6, 1994 / July 3, 1994


MINISTER LINKED TO GUN-RUNNING


BYLINE: Paul Stober and Farouk Chothia


LENGTH: 1200 words


 

THE WEEKLY MAIL & GUARDIAN, June 3, 1994

The Goldstone Commission has information linking the new minister of police in kwaZulu/Natal, Celani Mtetwa, to illegal gun-running for Inkatha.

Sources inside and outside the commission confirmed this week that they have information tying Mtetwa to the receipt of weapons from the network alleged to have been set up by renegade South African Police members.

The police portfolio in the Natal cabinet has been at the centre of this week's battle between the ANC and the Inkatha Freedom Party in Natal over regional executive positions.

It has also emerged that the government of national unity is keeping new details of the involvement of key former South African Police and IFP officials in political violence under close wraps for fear of the political repercussions. 

The Mail & Guardian has been leaked the second report of the Transitional Executive Council task group on hit squads in the kwaZulu Police, which names IFP PWV leader Themba Khoza, IFP PWV parliamentarian Humphrey Ndlovu, and 16 senior kwaZulu (KZP) policemen who are said to have taken part in hit squad activity. No action has been taken on this, although it is dated March 29. And a new Goldstone report, which was expected to have been made public, has been sent to the international team investigating the involvement of IFP and SAP officials in "third force" activity.

This report, dealing with covert operations against anti-apartheid activists, corruption and other criminal activities by policemen, was expected to be released three weeks ago, according to sources in the ANC.

Sources in the commission have confirmed that such a report was drawn up. "There was going to be a report but it was decided it was inappropriate for Goldstone to have his own report now that the international team was investigating," said a source close to the minister of safety and security. Goldstone is understood to have discussed the report with the minister, Sidney Mufamadi.

Judge Richard Goldstone confirmed his commission had handed over the relevant information to the international team. "All information has been submitted to the international team," he said. Asked if his commission would produce further reports on the matter,

he said: "It depends very much on what comes out of the international investigation. There may or may not be, I really can't say."

The second report by the TEC task group investigating hitsquads in the kwaZulu Police recommends the immediate suspension of the deputy commissioner of the KZP, Major General Sipho Mathe, on grounds that he aided and concealed the activities of hit men in the KZP. Among other things, he is accused of "disgraceful conduct" by failing to investigate hit squad claims against three senior Inkatha members.

The report paints a frightening picture of the systematic concealment, failure to investigate and conniving at hit squad activity in the KZP by senior officers. It recommends the suspension of two KZP brigadiers, CP Mzimela and BL Ndlovu, and a district commander, Lieutenant Colonel Sipho Mdluli. It also calls for charges of defeating the ends of justice to be investigated against LA Hlengwa, a former policeman and currently an IFP head office official in Ulundi. Also recommended is the suspension of two majors, two captains and a lieutenant and the investigation of a brigadier, a major and two captains.

The TEC report says an investigation into a massacre at Nqutu, Natal, by a kwaZulu policeman, Lieutenant Mbatha, "revealed that the rest of the suspects were members of a hit squad that operated from hostels in East Rand and that Themba Khoza and Humphrey Ndlovu were involved in the planning of the massacre".

The reluctance to take firm action against "third force" suspects reflects differences in both the ANC and the government about how to deal with criminal rightwing elements in the security forces.

In the ANC, there are those who are urging a "softly-softly" approach, in an attempt to win these elements over. They appear to have the backing of State President Nelson Mandela.

Others feel the quick removal of those who were involved in orchestrating violence is the only way to finally stop those involved in political destabilisation and get to the bottom of the political violence which has rocked South Africa since 1990.

The debate around indemnity is also crucial. The authors of the TEC report urge the TEC to grant selective indemnity to witnesses who are prepared to give further details of "third force" activity. They warn that without being able to offer potential witnesses indemnity, there is "little or no prospect of rooting out those orchestrating this significant cause of political violence".

The government has made no substantial moves towards addressing this particular indemnity issue. Senior former South African Police officers are pushing for a blanket indemnity for all political crimes after a cut off date, without disclosure of the crime. They apparently hope this will prevent lower ranking officers from testifying against their seniors.

The ANC and human rights activists have been pushing for the full disclosure by those involved in political violence to help them with their investigations At the moment, the government is taking the view that they cannot defy the generals without destabilising the security forces -- something they are not prepared to risk.

Meanwhile, all Judge Goldstone's witnesses -- the mystery "Qs" who were sent to Denmark for safety in the wake of the release of the "third force" report -- were brought back to South Africa three weeks ago.

Reprinted from The Weekly Mail & Guardian, June 3, 1994.

THE WEEKLY MAIL & GUARDIAN is published by M&G Media

Contact: M&G Media, 139 Smit Street, Breamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025.


LOAD-DATE: June 9, 1994


LANGUAGE: English

179 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 6, 1994 / July 3, 1994


WHAT ABOUT THE DEFENSE UNITS?


BYLINE: Amrit Manga


LENGTH: 2107 words


 

SUNDAY NATION, May 22, 1994

Jessie Duarte, MEC in charge of safety and security in the PWV region, which includes the volatile East Rand, says addressing the SDU issue is not an easy matter.

But she says that, before anyone begins to address the debate, they should examine the background against which the SDUs emerged.

"One must understand that the SDUs were set up in a situation in which there was no protection. Communities could not rely on the formal protection units, the South African Police, at the time.

"The only protection communities could rely on was that from the SDUs and the South African Defense Force." Duarte concedes that some of the SDUs now pose a threat to communities. But she hastens to add that rogue defense units -- those infiltrated or set up in the mold of vigilante groups -- are in a minority. 

The challenge now is to take all SDUs along in the creation of a new policing culture. Changed conditions now allow for communities to be empowered in the area of policing.

One entry point for SDUs into the new culture, says Duarte, is through the constitutional provision which provides for the creation of Community Police Liaison Forums.

"This is an opening to bring about a closer link between professional police and the desires of the communities.

"We see the SDUs playing an important role in fostering that kind of community-police liaison," Duarte says.

But she is also mindful of the resistance her department will experience from some SDUs. "I think there are individuals in some of the SDUs who are not going to want to cooperate."

This resistance could come from people who are aware that the power of the SDUs will be severely curtailed once they are above ground.

But Duarte is not unduly concerned about such individuals, saying that they will marginalize themselves through their resistance to the new order.

Another entry point is to formally join the police service, says Duarte. This will give SDU members who are genuinely committed to the protection of their communities the opportunity to ensure, from within, that residents get the kind of policing service they desire.

Duarte does not believe that the SDU members -- even those genuinely committed to serving the community -- will make such a transition easily. There would need to be some indication that the police themselves have shed the baggage of the "old South Africa."

But there may be some in the police services who feel they cannot share the ideals of the new government and might want to leave.

"It is only if they commit themselves (SDUs and the police) to a common goal, that they will be able to work together," Duarte says. She adds that it will be a big loss if either the police or the SDUs decide to remain outside the structures of the new South Africa.

"It would be a great pity of we lost the professional experiences of the police and the SDUs' informal, but real, experience in community policing." Defense units have a very real operational understanding of the communities they have been protecting, says Duarte. And this understanding is necessary in building the culture of community policing. "It would be disastrous if we lost that experience," she adds.

"And I think the formal police accept that they (the police) lack that experience."

If these two areas of experience are combined, Duarte believes the region could emerge with a formidable public safety and security network.

"But the ISU (Internal Stability unit) has to change its orientation if we are to succeed. You have 8000 highly skilled police people. But their orientation has to change, and we are say ing that to them quite openly.

"It is very true that the communities saw the ISU as negative, and that goes for the whole fashion of policing -- the knocking down of doors, the breaking of windows, the assaulting of people suspected of crimes.

"We have the assurances of the generals in the police that they are continuing with their work to reorientate their force, taking in the view that community policing is community protection, rather than instilling fear into the communities."

While bridging the gap between police and SDUs could see Duarte's vision of a new police force being realized, the challenge of resolving tensions within the defense units remains.

Past attempts, such as the January Daveyton Accord, have failed. This makes the challenge more difficult. but Duarte is not perturbed by this failure. She says it is important to recognize the circumstances in which the Daveyton attempts failed. And much of that had to do with the tensions between political organizations.

While conditions have changed, says Duarte, it would be naive to assume that these tensions have disappeared.

"But there is now a recognition among most political organizations that the arena in which to fight their political battles is in fact the parliament and the provincial legislatures. Very few still believe that these battles have to be resolved by getting people on the ground to kill each other."

Duarte says it will take a great deal of effort to ensure this recognition that the new terrain of struggle has shifted away from violence. And much of the responsibility for this rests with the newly elected MECs and parliamentarians.

"ANC people at a regional level will soon be meeting with the SDUs to discuss this new reality and the new role that the defense units can play.

"For my part, I am going to meet every person employed by the police service in this province to ensure that they understand that there is a new perspective."

While skeptical of the scale of the success of these efforts, Duarte acknowledges that there is no other option.

She nevertheless draws some confidence from conversations she has had with SDU members, who have told her that they are ready for the change. Police people she has spoken to have expressed the same sentiments.

"The practical thing to do is to bring them together so that they can talk to each other -- its already happening in some places."

This week, Duarte met with a group from Vosloorus on the East Rand, representing the police, civic association and the SDUs, and listened to their proposals about how they could help realize the new vision of community-oriented policing.

Duarte says a similar meeting was also convened in Soweto, where representatives of the church, the civics and all the police stations in the township met to discuss the community police liaison committees. According to Duarte, the issues being discussed include ways to translate the theoretical vision of community policing into practical reality. "One of the things they are saying is that the first thing to do is to get all people who belong to SDUs together."

But, given the tensions within and between SDUs, convening such a meeting is not easy. One immediate question, says Duarte, is who should get such a meeting together?

Duarte says there are SDUs from a range of different political affiliations. She says there are not only ANC SDUs, but also PAC and Inkatha defense units.

"I have suggested that the civic assume the responsibility of convening the meeting of SDUs. Civics are not political.

"At the same time, political organizations will also have to urge SDUs to accept the new political order," says Duarte. This will be important, especially in areas like the East Rand, which was characterized by intense territorial battles.

"If there is this territorial battle, we have to unite our communities before any meaningful progress can be made towards establishing a community police service committed to the singular purpose of protecting the community." And, once again, the civic must be the engine to drive this process, says Duarte.

But this in itself could ignite conflict, as was the case in the Vaal region, where SDUs went to war against each other on the question of who should ultimately take charge of the defense units. Some leaders were violently opposed to the SDUs coming under the command of the civic and were killed as a result.

Duarte, however, says the focus of the debate has now shifted.

In the past 30 weeks before the elections, for example, "we had a situation where people felt they needed to won particular areas of our communities, or particular structures." Political hegemony was so important that it gave relevance to the debates around who the SDUs should be accountable to.

"I don't think the se debates are relevant any longer."

Duarte is also mindful of the fact that debates on the future of the SDUs become irrelevant if police do not take the responsibility for protection of the communities. "That is the bottom line -- who takes this responsibility. "People in the SDUs were protecting communities as volunteers. Communities now need to push the paid public servants to take that responsibility and treat it seriously."

Another critical factor on which the success or failure of Duarte's efforts hinge is disarming the communities.

The importance of this comes into sharp relief given estimates of over a million firearms on the East Rand Alone, says Duarte. "This means there is an average of one firearm in every home." At the core of the entire debate, however, is the need to accept the principle that the country can only have one formal police force, whose sole purpose must be to protect the community.

An acceptance of this principle presupposes agreement by the SDUs that they give up their arms and join the formal police force if they still have a commitment to the protection of their communities. Once again, this will not be easy.

Rerpinted from Sunday Nation, May 22, 1994.

SUNDAY NATION is published by New Nation Publishing Co.

Contact: New Nation Publishing Co., P.O. Box 10674, Johannesburg 2000, South Africa, phone:(011) 333-2711. Fax:(011) 333-2733.


LOAD-DATE: June 9, 1994


LANGUAGE: English
