Africa News


June 6, 1994 / July 3, 1994


WFP LAUNCHES EMERGENCY AIRLIFT TO BUJUMBURA


LENGTH: 654 words


 

Bujumbura, June 2, 1994

WORLD FOOD PROGRAMME

THE FOOD AID ORGANIZATION OF THE UNITED NATIONS SYSTEM

The World Food Programme, with considerable support from the Burundi government, today embarked upon an airlift operation between Dar-Es-Salaam and Bujumbura. The operation has been launched to ensure a continuous supply of relief food to the ever growing refugees and displaced population in Burundi, Rwanda and Eastern Zaire. Over the next three weeks, WFP plans to fly in a total of 1500 metric tons of various food commodities, destined to some one million people in the region. 

Today's deliveries of 37 tonnes of beans, arrived on a DC 8 aircraft chartered by the US Government on behalf of WFP. Starting this weekend, two Hercules L 100s will also make rotations between the two cities every day, increasing the daily food arrivals to 160 tonnes. Much of this food will be directly off-loaded by trucks and sent immediately to the refugee and displaced in Northern Burundi.

Significant quantities of relief food for the Burundi emergency are available in Dar-Es-Salaam port, from where it is usually sent via truck, rail and barge to Bujumbura. For weeks, however, both slow off-take from Bujumbura port as well as limited trucking capacity in the region, created bottlenecks which constrained the flow of relief food. Although the port has improved its handling capacity to 500-600 tonnes a day, an airlift is required to temporarily boost the food supply.

"With was still waging in Rwanda, we can expect a wave of refugees arriving in Burundi and/or Eastern Zaire at any moment," says WFP Country Director for Burundi, Genimo Lodesani. "Furthermore, food aid deliveries to Southern Rwanda are most easily conducted from here. A sufficient food stock in Burundi is therefore absolutely crucial." Already there are scattered reports of Rwandan refugees dispersed in the swamp areas along the border between Butare and Kirundo province.

Since the outbreak of civil war in Rwanda, the population in the region in need of food aid has exploded: 75,000 Rwandan refugees and 175,000 Burundis, formerly refugees in Rwanda, have trekked across the borders into the northern provinces of Burundi; 5000 Rwandans along with 18,000 Zairians, who had lived in Rwanda for generations, have fled into Eastern Zaire - 60,000 Burundi refugees and 104,000 displaced are currently living under critical conditions in camps in Southern Rwanda; 600,000 people displaced since the 1993 October massacre in Burundi are still not self- sufficient.

For more information contact:
Gemino Lodesani, Country Director
Cecilia Ljungman, Information Officer
WFP Bujumbura
Tel: 225621, 223072, 213332

Brenda Barton
Regional Information Officer
Tel: (254-2) 230807 (w)
(254-2) 645044 (h)


LOAD-DATE: June 9, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


181 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 6, 1994 / July 3, 1994


TWO SIDES OF ONE COIN


BYLINE: Mike Akpan


LENGTH: 1400 words


 

NEWSWATCH, May 16, 1994

From Nzeogwu to Abacha, the battle cry is down with corruption, yet the cankerworm grows even fatter.

For twenty-four years, the military has arrogated to itself the messianic task of stamping out corruption in Nigeria. But this self-appointed mission has continued to be a mere wish. This wish dates back to January 15, 1966, when Chukwuma Kaduna Nzeogwu, a major, took the nation by surprise in his dawn broadcast from Kaduna announcing the first military take-over in the country. Said he in the broadcast: "...the country's enemies are the political profiteers, the swindlers, the men in high and low places that seek bribes and demand 10 percent, those that seek to keep the country divided permanently so that they can remain in office as ministers or VIPs at least; the tribalists, the nepotists, those that make the country look big for nothing before international circles, those that have corrupted our society and put the Nigerian political calendar back by their words and deeds." 

According to Nzeogwu, it was the with of the military to establish a strong, united and prosperous nation, free from corruption and internal strife. "Our method of achieving this is strictly military," he warned. Since Nzeogwu's coup did not record nation-wide success, it was, therefore, difficult to hold him to his words. But Johnson T. Aguiyi-Ironsi, a major-general, who took over the reins of power as the most senior military officer around, never mentioned eradication of corruption as part of his agenda. But in the former Western Region, the military administration seized the property of some former public officers which were said to have been acquired corruptly.

Six months into his administration, Aguiyi-Ironsi was toppled in a counter-coup of July 29, 1966, which paved way for the emergence of Yakubu Gowon, then a lieutenant-colonel, as head of state. Said Gowon on assumption of office: "As soldiers, my colleagues and I are ready to go back to the barracks any day. But the work of national reconstruction must be completed; public confidence in our institutions must be restored; and civilian leaders demonstrate to the nation that they are ready to take over and project a better image of the country than it had just before January 1966. There are five main issues which the federal military government will deal with in the course of national reconstruction. The first is the reorganization and long-term re-integration of the Nigerian army... The fourth is to continue the fight against corruption in public life and the fith is the preparation of a new constitution for the country.

Gowon gave his game plan to fight corruption. Said he: "Regarding the eradication of corruption from our public life, the federal military government will take appropriate action in the reports of the inquiries recently held into the Nigerian Railway Corporation, the Electricity Corporation of Nigeria and the Lagos City Council. Similar inquiries will be held into other federal corporations. The decree on the declaration of assets will be implemented and the investigations into the assets and liabilities of those who held public offices from 1960 to 1966 will be continued. Those involved will include former ministers, chairmen of statutory corporations, board members, permanent secretaries and other senior civil servants, general managers and the executives of public corporations. The government has been handling these investigations in a quiet way because it does not want to give the impression of witch-hunting. Those found guilty of ill-gotten gains will be appropriately dealt with."

Gowon could not implement his wish because of the civil war which broke out a year later after what was then known as Eastern Nigeria attempted to secede from the rest of the country. But after the war ended January 15, 1970, he renewed the intention of his administration to prosecute the war on corruption. He drew up a five-year development plan which had a nine-point program. One of the programs was the eradication of corruption from national life. But Gowon did not prosecute the anti-corruption war. Consequently, many of his lieutenants, both military and civilians, took advantage of this to enrich themselves at public expense. Thereafter, Muhammed set up a commission of inquiry to probe the administration of the eleven governors and the administrator guilty of corrupt practices. They were made to forfeit to the state the property they corruptly acquired. In addition, the military governors were summarily dismissed from the services of the armed forces and the police. Beyond the governors, many top public officers were probed and those found guilty were appropriately punished.

Olusegun Obasanjo, then a lieutenant-general, who succeeded Muhammed after the February 13, 1976 abortive coup, pursued the policy of low profile and discipline in public life started by the administration.Like in January 1966, the military under Mohammed Buhari, a major-general, sacked the civilian government of President Shehu Shagari December 31, 1983. In his maiden broadcast to the nation January 1, 1984, Buhari explained what informed the military take over and listed the goals of his administration. One of the goals was a war on corruption and indiscipline. Said he: "While corruption and indiscipline have been associated with our state of underdevelopment, these twin evils in our body politic have attained unprecedented heights in the past four years... We deplore corruption in all its facets."

His riot act was clear and blunt. "This government will not tolerate kick-backs, inflation of contracts and over-invoicing of imports, etc, nor will it condone forgery, fraud, embezzlement, misuse and abuse of office and illegal dealings in foreign exchange and smuggling." Like Muhammed, Buhari showed the commitment and political will to prosecute the war, but Ibrahim Babangida threw spanners into his works and overthrew his administration August 27, 1985. He also threw away the war against indiscipline launched by Buhari. Said Babangida: "The war against indiscipline will continue, but this time, in the minds and conduct of Nigerians and not by way of symbolism or money-spending campaigns. This government, on its part, will ensure that the leadership exhibits proper examples."

Babangida never lived up to his words. His eight-year rule has been characterized as a period when corruption became institutionalized in Nigeria.Like Babangida, Sani Abacha, whose government relaunched the War Against Indiscipline and Corruption, WAI-C, May 4, has promised to lead by examples. So far, there are only precepts. In fact, successive military administrations in the country have proved to be no less corrupt than the civilians they overthrew on allegations of corruption. Will Abacha make the difference?

Reprinted from Newswatch, May 16, 1994.

NEWSWATCH is published by Newswatch Communications, Limited.

CONTACT: Newswatch Communications, Ltd., No. 3 Billings Way, Oregun Industrial Estate, Oregun, P.M.B. 24199, Ikeja, Lagos, Nigeria. Tel: 4960950. Fax: 962887.


LOAD-DATE: June 9, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


182 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 6, 1994 / July 3, 1994


THE GATHERING STORM


BYLINE: Nats Agbo


LENGTH: 6600 words


 

NEWSWATCH, May 30, 1994

For the second time in five weeks, the government of Sani Abacha, a general, is facing a major crisis. The first crisis was over an interview with David Mark, a retired brigadier-general, which was published in the April 11 edition of "Newswatch" in which he said Abacha and Oladapo Diya, the chief of general staff, had no plan for democracy until 1999. Now, the government is in a quandary over the political programme which it hurriedly drew up as a response to that interview. Notable politicians are boycotting the ward election planned for this week. Instead they are asking Abacha to release the result of the June 12, 1993, presidential election and swear in the winner as president. 

Last Thursday, the demand led to open confrontation between traditional rulers from the South-West and security agents. The traditional rulers had converged on Ijebu-Ode, in Ogun State, to discuss the boycott of the election. But by 7 a.m. on the day, the whole town had been taken over by armed policemen. Even the toll-gate was blocked by anti-riot policemen who searched every vehicle and everybody who was passing through. A senior police officer who led the operation told "Newswatch" that they had instructions from "very high quarters" to stop people from entering Ijebu-Ode. Festus Adesanoye, Osemawe of Ondo, Adebobayo Adesida, Deji of Akure and three other traditional rulers were refused entry into the town. When Adesanoye insisted on knowing why he and his colleagues were barred from entering the town, he was shown a letter titled "Attempts to disrupt the Constitutional Conference Election." Signed by Tunji Sokoya, the secretary to the Ogun State government, the letter order the police to halt the meeting of the traditional rulers and other Yoruba leaders.

Some other personalities, however, managed to beat the trap and reached the palace of Sikiru Adetona, the Awujale of Ijebuland, venue of the meeting. There they met another shocker. The gate to the palace was blocked by another detachment of policemen led by Abiodun Asabi, an assistant superintendent of police. There, some of the traditional rulers who reached the gate were not allowed to enter the palace. Only those who were with Adetona by 8:30 a.m. entered the palace with him. Adeyinka Adebayo, a retired general and chairman of Egbe Ilosiwaju Yoruba, was the first person to break the rules. He drove in straight into the palace ignoring police signals that he should stop. Shortly after him came Salawu Adekoya, the Ayangburen of Ikorodu. When his driver was disallowed from entering the palace, he was visibly angry.

Adekoya: Why are you preventing me from entering?

Asabi: We are under instruction not to allow anybody into the palace.

Adekoya: You are not serious. You cannot prevent me from entering the palace which is still in my territory. We will hold this meeting today. If you want to arrest us come and arrest us here. Go and call your commissioner of police to come and arrest us.

In annoyance, Adekoya forced his way into the palace. The policemen trailed him into the palace. He turned round and said: "If you follow me again, I will slap you." Knowing that the traditional ruler was serious, the policeman allowed him in.

Other notable leaders like Olu Falae, Segun Osoba, Bola Tinubu, Adesuyi Haastrup, former deputy governor of Osun State, were not allowed to enter the palace through the main gate. But they later found an unmanned one through which they entered the palace. Each pretended he was driving off but would drive to the back of the palace, park his car, and enter through the gate into the palace. By 11:00 a.m., the meeting had commenced, catching the police unawares.

Expectedly, the traditional rulers threw their weight behind calls for total boycott of the proposed constitutional conference. Said the traditional rulers: "The proposed conference can be for no other reason than to delay giving respect to the will of the people as manifested in the June 12 election." The traditional rulers quarrelled with the absence of a decree covering the conference, the choice of a constitutional conference instead of a sovereign national conference and the decision to nominate 96 of the expected delegates. "This is not only undemocratic but unacceptable," they said, adding, "the consultative committee agreed at the meeting to call on all Yoruba to reject participation in the election."

The danger signal for the May 23 ward election emerged on Sunday, May 15. After a two-day meeting at a private residence in Ikeja, Lagos, a new political group, the National Democratic Coalition, NADECO, issued a statement asking Abacha to invite Moshood Abiola, believed to have won the June 12, 1993, presidential election to form a government of national unity. Made up of such big names as Adekunle Ajasin, former governor of Ondo State, Anthony Enahoro, a former minister, Yohanna Madaki, former governor of Benue and Gongola states, Ralph Obioha, a prominent Igbo politician, Osoba, former governor of Ogun State, and Bolaji Akinyemi, former external affairs minister, NADECO gave the head of state until May 31 to effect its order. Although, the group did not specify what it would do if the deadline is not met, NADECO described the proposed constitutional conference as a "ruse" planted to ensure continued "military dictatorship, aided by the greed and opportunism of a political clique." The statement further added: "The military government should stop forthwith all preparations and call off the ill-conceived constitutional conference that will be futile and prove a colossal waste of public funds at this time of untold economic hardship being experienced by the people of Nigeria, including a vast majority of armed forces personnel and the police who are not in government."

NADECO also called for the formation of a national government which will restructure the Nigerian polity in order to establish a true federalism, introduce a more justifiable manner of power-sharing and revenue allocation, as well as encourage respect for the fundamental human rights of all Nigerians.

The initial reaction of the government was to ignore NADECO's ultimatum. According to political experts in government, NADECO's formation and ultimatum may have been influenced by events in South Africa. Their argument, which pleased Abacha and his close aides, was the NADECO was composed of just a faction of the banned Social Democratic Party, SDP. NADECO members from the South-West are all members of the Afenifere, a political group which has its roots in the Egbe Omo Oduduwa. Among such men are Ajasin, Olabiyi Durojaiye, Akin Aduwo, Olufemi Olutoye, Osoba and Akinyemi. Members of the New Dimension like Layi Balogun, Omololu Olunloyo and Bamidele Olumilua, former Ondo State governor, who are said to be favourably disposed towards Musa Shehu Yar'Adua, are not in NADECO.

From the Middle Belt, NADECO members are mostly made up of members of the Middle Belt Forum, MBF. They include Dan Suleiman, Jonah Jang, Steven Achema, Madaki and Moses Adasu. Members of the Middle Belt Congress, MBC, a break-away faction of the MBF which is led by Paul Unongo, a former minister of steel, are not members of NADECO. Also absent from NADECO's membership list are members of the Eastern Mandate Union, EMU, which is led by Dele-Cole. Also, no member of the defunct National Republican Convention, NRC, is a member of NADECO.

This government was, however, jolted because from then onwards, events began to happen very fast, indicating that the government was losing control of the nation. Abiodun Adetiloye, archbishop of the Anglican Church in Nigeria, fired the first salvo in support of NADECO;s position. He wrote Abacha, asking him to "bow out honorably," warning that "if you cannot see the handwriting on the wall and bow out, the end may be inglorious." He said from all indications, Abacha's life-long ambition had been to rule Nigeria, adding, "now that that ambition has been fulfilled, I hope you will not lack sufficient courage to take the right decision."

Government was equally troubled by the decision of traditional rulers from the South-West to advise a boycott of this week's ward election. It was said to have been further alarmed by the formation of National Unity Promoters, NUP, which also has Yar'Adua as a member. The NUP, like the Association for Democracy and Good Governance, ADGG, is made up of friends who are unhappy with the trend of things in Nigeria, especially the acceptance of political appointments in governments by erstwhile proponents of the June 12 election. The NUP is led by Olusegun Obasanjo, Nigeria's former head of state. A member of the group which will meet on June 4 sees the call for a boycott of the election as "rubbish." Whatever is the stand of NUP, government is alarmed because "each time Obasanjo leads such a group, the government collapses in a matter of weeks" Government officials were said to have used the last days of the government of former President Ibrahim Babangida as example, saying, "government will either match its words on the ban of political groupings with action or be ready to be rushed out of office."

While government was still contemplating how it should react to NADECO's ultimatum, security reports said politicians were gathering in Port Harcourt, Rivers State, for a conference. The two-day conference was to have been addressed by Obasanjo, Theophilus Danjuma, a lieutenant-general and former chief of army staff, Dele-Cole and many other prominent Nigerians.

The Port Harcourt meeting, it was learnt, was halted because of the political implications. According to Aso Rock sources, "the government had been pushed into announcing a political programme because Mark had exposed their plans to stay indefinitely. That is why there is so much vagueness with plans for elections for the constitutional conference." The fear also was that the Port Harcourt meeting could be sued to further embarrass the government. Said a government source: "In view of the type of people who were to attend that Port Harcourt conference and the call for a boycott of the ward and subsequent elections, then this government would collapse." But according to Dele-Cole, one of the conveners of the meeting, the conference would have allowed prospective participants at the constitutional conference to discuss serious national issues, especially problems associated with oil revenue, which could emerge at the conference. He asked: "How can you have a system where you are going to discuss how to elect candidates into a forum to discuss the country's constitution and seven days from the election, you still have not discussed oil?"

Government's reaction to the botched Port Harcourt conference convinced some politicians that, as Mark claimed in his interview, government had no genuine intentions about its political programmes. Very many prominent politicians who had earlier collected nomination forms either refused to submit them or failed to appear before the Constitutional Conference Electoral Commission, CCEC, for screening. Initially, some of them said they would contest buy they would withdraw from the conference if it became obvious that Nigerians did not want it. Olusola Saraki, former senate leader in the Second Republic, who had said he would contest the election, did not present himself for screening. Other notable politicians also announced their boycott of the election. Falae, who was a presidential aspirant of the SDP, announced that he was no more interested in the election. He hinged his withdrawal from the election on two points: the opposition of NADECO to the election and the constitutional conference.

By Wednesday, last week, opposition to the conference had grown beyond the control of the government. Students of the University of Benin threatened to beat any electoral officer found at the university during the week's election. Their opposition, through, was against government's decision that only Nigerians 35 years of age or above were qualified to contest the delegates election. Five youths, Bola Aguda, 29, Akinboyede Akinola, 31, Bola Aidi, 30, and two others also went to a Kaduna high court challenging the age limit, saying it was a travesty of justice. Tinubu, T.O. Abuede, Rasheed Shitta-Bay, Femi Lanlehin and Busurua Alebiosu, all Lagos politicians, issued a statement supporting "a boycott of the proposed conference" and appealing to "all Lagosians to do the same."

Support for the boycott also came from a strange quarter, the Catholic Church. Usually conservative in its approach and reactions to political matters in Nigeria, the Catholic Church stepped out of such passiveness last week. Albert Obiefuna, president of the Conference of Catholic Bishops of Nigeria, told pressmen in Lagos that the Catholic Church was in support of a release of the June 12 presidential election. Said he: "The church must speak out when injustice is perpetuated. All we are concerned about is declaring whosoever that won (the election) and that is the stand of the church." Nigerians in the United States of America also lent their support to the restoration of democracy in the country. A group which calls itself the Nigerian Democratic Awareness Coalition said it was prepared to help in actualising the intentions of those crusading for democracy. In a statement signed by Oye Fasakin and Edward Oparaoji, the group said: "We received with utmost excitement and encouragement statements on the current political impasse in our dear fatherland."

At press time, various interest groups were holding series of meetings to adopt their respective line of action. The Afenifere, a political group in the South-West, met in Owo last Wednesday and restated its stand on the boycott of the conference, saying that what it wanted was a sovereign national conference. The Annang, the second largest ethnic group in Akwa Ibom State, as well as the Izon (Ijaw) also announced their withdrawal from the conference. The Annang are unhappy that only two of the nine seats allocated the state went to the group. The Ijaw National Congress, in a communique signed by F.T. Williams, secretary, and J.B. Fumudoh, president, said its members should boycott the proposed conference "as it will not serve the Ijaws any useful purpose." Last week, Abacha sent Lateef Jakande, works and housing minister, and Ebenezer Babatope, transport and aviation minister, to the west to persuade Yoruba leaders not to boycott the constitutional conference.

"Newswatch" learnt that the renewed political showdown with the Abacha regime has its roots in the installation of Nelson Mandela as South African president. Al Gore, the US vice-president, and other leaders who attended the ceremony shunned Abacha, preferring instead to hold parlays with Abiola. Most of these world leaders were said to have encouraged Abiola to seize the initiative and chase the military out of power. When he returned from South Africa, Abiola was again pressured by difference groups to form a cabinet and be ready to stake his life, as Mandela did on Roben Island for 27 years, in order to wrest power from the military.

On May 12, verbal messages were sent to some of the interest groups for a meeting in Lagos. To test public reaction to Abiola's plans, his aides leaked to the press information that he had, indeed, formed a cabinet. The reaction, according to an Abiola aide, "was very encouraging. We were even surprised by the number of inquiries we received from Nigerians." Somehow, the first meetings of NADECO were infiltrated by security agents. But the final meeting which led to the issuance of a communique was held at a secret location. Some NADECO members who were to attend the meeting could not even find the venue. Abiola made a brief appearance at the meeting, assuring those present of renewed commitment to democracy. Abiola had said that he was happy that he was not sworn in as president on August 26 last year. His reason was the he "would have run the worst government Nigeria ever had" because most of the people he wanted to appoint ministers "had a separate personal agenda." He lamented that those who advised him to write to former President Ibrahim Babangida were those who leaked the letter to the press.

He added: "They were only waiting for me to appoint them and they would have come with their own plans which would have torpedoed my government." "Newswatch" also learnt that most of the people who attended the meeting from the Middle Belt claimed they did so on observer basis. Said one of them: "Our instruction was to attend the meeting, go back home and discuss the issues raised before a joint communique has been issued, what shall we tell them when we return? Supposing most of them are not keen on boycotting the election as enunciated in this communique?" Some leaders of the South-West listed as having participated in drafting the communique claimed that they were not at the meeting. While Akinyemi said he attended only one of the meetings of NADECO but supported the boycott of the election, Balogun said he could not append his signature to a document he did not help draft.

A member of NADECO who participated in drafting the communique, however, dispelled rumours of any division in their rank. He accepted the stand of the Middle Belt group that further discussions at the regional levels would have been welcome. "We were, however, mindful of the time factor. If you allow too much time to pass, many people will change their positions, so we had to act fast," the source said.

For the government, the on-going crisis is not a total surprise. In South Africa, Abacha himself had said he was embarrassed by the cold reception he received from world leaders. "He felt lonely and sad," said a government official who was also in South Africa. "He was only consoled by his public relations men who promised to present him to the international community as "a sincere leader whose intentions have been grossly misunderstood."

The first suggestion was for the head of state to grant interview to international magazines and journals. This was abandoned when the head of state showed very little enthusiasm for it. It was then decided that he should react to international issues through paid advertisements. Last week, "Time" magazine published a statement by Abacha congratulating Mandela for his electoral victory. Targetted at the American audience, the one-page statement advocated "peaceful change" in South Africa. To assuage the feelings of many world leaders who reportedly told him during his South African trip to embrace democracy, Abacha also spoke of the need for "the rest of us in Africa" to "move speedily to enthrone freedom and home-grown democracy." Although he did not elaborate on what his home-grown democracy means, the head of state said: "This process is taking root in Nigeria with the Constitutional Conference which will define our march to full democracy."

The statement, which cost Nigerian tax payers more than N1 million, came during what an Aso Rock source described as "Abacha's season of anomy." In the economic and political sectors, nothing appears to be working. Government officials were even working at cross-purposes. Take Don Etiebet, the minister of petroleum resources. He had addressed the press and hinted of an imminent increase in the price of fuel. But Jerry Gana, the information minister, who sat with Etiebet during his encounter with the press, quickly denied the story, saying there was no plan to increase the price of petroleum products. Another statement was issued by Diya's office denying any imminent fuel price increase.

For politicians, the call for a boycott of the elections was an anti-climax. Unsure of whether Abiola would stand up to the calls for him to form a cabinet or not, the politicians who had formed various political groups had made elaborate arrangements for the election. In the South-West zone, for instance, the election would have been a showdown between Afenifere and the New Dimension. Afenifere's position on the constitutional conference and other national issues were hazy until last week when it finally called for the installation of Abiola as president. Ajasin could not talk to "Newswatch" last week because he was observing a bedrest. Ige would not talk except by appointment. Adeleke said he would indeed to get clearance from all the group leaders to be able to talk on it. Initial indications were that although the group was maintaining its stance on the sanctity of June 12 and Abiola's mandate in public, it was ready to settle for a rotational presidency starting with the Yorubas. The group, using the old structures of former Action Group, AG, and Unity Party of Nigeria, UPN, seems to be very popular among the older generation in the states.

The New Dimension is the brain-child of people who disagree with the approach and style of the west in former political dispensations. They claim to resent the politics of exclusion and secrecy of the AG and UPN days which they believed did not open up the west to national politics. The group is led by Oladosu Oladipo, former SDP governorship aspirant in Osun State. Other prominent members of the group include Bamidele Olumilua, former governor of Ondo State, and former chairmen of SDP in the western states, Tade Ipadeola, Oyo; Kareem Ajayi, Osun; Kayode Blessing, Ondo; Gbolade Oshimowo, Ogun; and Nuru Baruwa, Lagos. It has also been enlarged to include some notable former NRC stalwarts like Yekini Adeojo, Femi Coker, and Ayo Ogunlade, all former NRC governorship candidates in the 1992 governorship elections in Oyo, Ogun, and Ondo states. Other notable members are: Sunday Afolabi, former deputy governor of Oyo State, Adisa Akinloye, former NPN national chairman who is the "father" of the group, Yomi Akintola, son of late premier of the Western Region, S.L. Akintola, and the Wole Awolowo, son of Obafemi Awolowo.

The group's major achievement is the reconciliation of both the Akintola and Awolowo families, whose fathers fell apart during the AG crisis in 1962. The presence of former NPN and NRC chieftains makes it difficult to attach any ideological leanings to the group. Oladipo, however, insists it is made up of progressives since the core founders were former SDP members. "That there are members of former NPN and NRC among us shows that we have converted those people into the progressive fold," he told "Newswatch."

The presence of Oladipo. Afolabi, Haruna Elewi and others who worked for Yar'Adua during the 1992 presidential election primaries has earned the group the tag Yar'Adua boys." They are said to be consolidating their political hold on the south-west so that the group can win th presidency for a Yar'Adua man. But Oladipo denies this allegation. Of course, any election in the south-west zone now will be a test of strength between Afenifere and the New Dimension.

The situation in Oyo State is very interesting. The struggle is between Lamidi Adedibu and members of both Afenifere and New Dimension. In the state, leaders of the two groups like Kolapo Ishola, Afenifere, Rasheed Ladoja, a former senator, Afenifere, Yekini Adeojo, New Dimension, Olunloye, New Dimension, and others are challenging the political leadership of Adedibu in Ibadan politics. Acting under the umbrella of Ibadan/Ibarapa Movement, they have denounced Adedibu as their leader. The group is led by Balogun who incidentally does not belong to either Afenifere or New Dimension. Balogun told "Newswatch" that the group is to create a common leadership front that will have a kind of control on the state's indigenes no matter their political leanings. He said the group wants to ensure that credible people come out to contest elections rather than the usual handpicking of candidates for elections.

For the constitutional conference, the Ibadan/Ibarapa Movement had lined up its candidates. For the two seats given to Ibadan, they picked Ladoja and Adeojo. The group has been campaigning for these candidates against those nominated by Adedibu. The boycott order may have now thrown a spanner in the works.

In the eastern states, it was not clear at press time if the boycott order would be effective. Eastern leaders did not speak with one voice on the boycott. Lulu Briggs, former deputy chairman of the NPN, has a few words for advocates of a boycott of the conference. Says he: "People should send forth their first eleven because anything could happen at the conference. Decisions will be taken and they will be imposed on even those who were not keen on the conference." Okon Amana, a spokesman for the Akwa Ibom Forum on National Issues, AKFON, also advised people to embrace the conference so that vital issues of national integration could be tackled. Only the Ijaw, the Annang and the Ogoni had said they were boycotting the elections. Eric Aso, a former governorship aspirant in Rivers State, is against the conference "because the basis of representation marginalises the people of Rivers State. So what are we going there to say?"

The conference itself, for the minority groups of the east, presents an opportunity to seek justice and fair play. According to political leaders from the area, the annulment of the June 12 election raised fundamental questions about the role of each ethnic group in Nigeria. An unanswered question, according to Asikpo Essien-Ibok, a political scientist and a member of the SDP, is: "If the big one cannot get its way, what future is there for the smaller ones?"

This thinking, he said, has resulted in the formation of various political associations in the minority states. At the respective mini-national conferences which took place a month ago, each southern minority state called for the sovereignty of each nationality. Said Essien-Ibok: "Of all the many associations that emerged in the minority states, the most potent that has clarity of purpose and intellectual vision of the new Nigeria is the Movement of National Redemption, MNR. Its membership cuts across all nationalities of every state. Its philosophy is universal and its ideology is the ideology of redemption from oppression, exploitation, corruption and mismanagement. Since it is national in scope, it assures a new form of progressive movement." The MNR is led by Enahoro, a former federal commissioner for information.

There are also the Oron Study Group and the Akwa Ibom State Centre for New Nigeria, AKSCNN. The two groups have made their positions known in their separate papers to the National Constitutional Conference Committee. Before submitting its memorandum, the Oron Study Group, comprising only the four local governments of former Oron Local Government, mandated O.O. Bassey, a professor and surgeon and his group, to work out a position for the people of Oron. Of course, the Oron people seem to favour federalism and are opposed to creating new zones as federal units. It favours a readjustment of boundaries of existing states based on rational criteria.

But the AKSCNN also wants the sovereignty of Nigeria discussed freely at the national conference. It insists that such debate must be based on the principle of equality of various nationalities or ethnic groups in Nigeria. AKSCNN favours an arrangement whereby the southern minorities are allowed to exercise sovereign rights over their people, culture, tradition and mineral resources which fall within their territory. In other words, AKSCNN wants a loose federation.

The Movement for the Survival of Ogoni People, MOSOP, seems to share the feelings of the AKSCNN although it goes a step further to demand independence for the minorities. Ken Saro-Wiwa, president of MOSOP, is very resolute in his pursuit of this goal.

Beyond the groupings of various nationalities, there is also a resurgence of former political associations. The Eastern Mandate Union, for instance, is a grouping of the defunct Peoples Front of Nigeria, PFN. Its members in the east and southern zone are proteges of Yar'Adua. They include Dele-Cole, Chuba Okadigbo, a senator, and Arthur Nwankwo, among others. At the moment, it is more academic than real. As Essien-Ibok puts it: "As far as the politics of the east is concerned, the main attraction will be the volume of resources pumped into it rather than the idea or the personality involved."

The National Unity Club is supposed to be a rebirth of the non-registered Peoples Solidarity Party, PSP. The name was coined and stamped in Owerri by a member of the group described by his colleagues as "young and over-ambitious." It exists more in Imo State and on the pages of newspapers than anywhere else in the east.

The Eastern Forum is derived from Eastern Solidarity founded by the late R.B.K. Okafor and Essien-Ibok. It later matured into Oriental Club. The club was later reorganised by Steven Shekari, retired air vice-marshal and national caretaker chairman of the SDP. The Forum was a serious political proposition with a major defect. There was no centre of gravity; no material basis for unity; no new theoretical constructs to invoke a sense of belonging. Unlike Kaduna and Ibadan which were and still are the political centres for the former north and west respectively, Enugu is not the political centre for the former east, not even for the four Igbo states carved out of former East Central State, Enugu is now for Enugu State. Enugu does not prescribe and protect the interest of Akwa Ibom, Rivers and Cross River states.

Politically, there is a yawning gap between the east and southern zone comprising Akwa Ibom, Cross River and Rivers states. The gap is based on distrust, and a defeated Domino theory. For instance, in May 1987, Tanko Yakasai, Okafor, Tunji Otegbeye, Essien-Ibok, Balarabe Musa, Ibrahim Gusau, Guy Ikoku, Lateef Jakande met in Okafor's residence for the first time after the demise of the Second Republic to formulate ideas which could lead to the re-awakening of the Progressive Movement. Those ideas led to the formation of the PSP. Claude Ake, a professor of political economy and Essien-Ibok, were the main ideologues of the party.

When it came to power sharing, the post of national secretary of the party was zoned to the east. The eastern minorities sought the cooperation and support of the Igbos for the office. They received none. Rather, the Igbos grabbed it and advised the eastern minorities to wait for another opportunity. That position went to Ezekiel Izuogu. When the PSP transformed into the SDP, the post was once again zoned to the east. It was now the opportunity of the CAR states to produce one. Again, the eastern minorities were outmaneuvered.

Times are also changing in the Middle Belt states of Benue, Kogi, Kwara, Plateau, Niger and Taraba. Until three weeks ago, only the Middle Belt Forum, an amalgam of various progressive elements in the area, was in existence. Its origin stretched to 1992 when it sought to present a presidential candidate from the area. Adebayo, Madaki, Jang, Suleiman, Adasu and Achema are some of the forum's prominent members. Their obsession and common linkage is their distaste for domination by the Hausa-Fulani group. In the past four weeks, the group's target shifted to only Yar'Adua. With the backing of Danjuma, members of the group have vowed to whittle down Yar'Adua's political influence in the Middle Belt area. Unable to change the course of events within the MBF, some Yar'Adua faithfuls in the Middle Belt thought of a bright idea - split the MBF. This has now led to the formation of the Middle Belt Congress, MBC, led by Unongo.

Whether politicians in the Middle Belt will boycott this week's election will depend on personal decisions of contestants. So far, the Middle Belt as a group has not come up with any joint decision on the conference. Although Achema and a few other members of the MBF attended NADECO's meetings, their mission was not to commit the group to any communique.

So far, the far northern states have been silent on all the political maneuvers going on in Nigeria. No prominent politician from the northern states has said he is boycotting the national constitutional conference. The little effort made towards the constitutional conference was by Umaru Shinkafi, former presidential aspirant of the NRC, and Bashir Tofa, presidential candidate of the NRC in the annulled June 12, 1993, presidential election. Jointly, they had organised a conference: "Nigeria for Our Generation." The group also tried to woo southern politicians like Sam Mbakwe, former governor of Imo State, Akinloye, president of Nigeria, and Ola Vincent, former governor of Central Bank of Nigeria, CBN.

Yar'Adua appears to be the only star around which political events in the northern states, as in most other states, revolve. He is still maintaining all his old political structures and is said to be working ahead of the constitutional conference. "Newswatch" learnt that Yar'Adua has also established strong links with notable northern politicians like Adamu Ciroma, minister of agriculture, Bamanga Tukur, minister for industries, Tofa, Shinkafi and Lawal Keita. The aim, according to a source, is to ensure his return to the northern fold. In the last experiment with democracy, Yar'Adua's support base was strong in the south-west than it was in the northern state.

But if NADECO's wishes are upheld, these political maneuvers may all come to naught. The question, however, is whether Abacha and his men would go ahead with the elections. Olisa Agbakoba, president of the Civil Liberties Organisation, CLO, told "Newswatch" last week that although his organisation was not consulted on the boycott order, it will be effective with "A mass-based organisation." He said there had been a lot of noise-making on the issue of June 12, adding: "The time has come for a pro-democracy movement that can deliver."

Indications at press time were that government may postpone this week's election. As one government source said: "How can we go ahead with this election when many people are boycotting it? The lessons of the 1964 boycott of election are clear enough. Going ahead with it would be a disaster for the government." Indeed the Abacha government seems to be riding a tiger's back.

Reprinted from Newswatch, May 30, 1994.

NEWSWATCH is published by Newswatch Communications, Limited.

CONTACT: Newswatch Communications, Ltd., No. 3 Billings Way, Oregun Industrial Estate, Oregun, P.M.B. 24199, Ikeja, Lagos, Nigeria. Tel: 4960950. Fax: 962887.


LOAD-DATE: June 9, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


183 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 6, 1994 / July 3, 1994


A BREAKTHROUGH FOR AFRICAN CHILDREN


BYLINE: Djibril Diallo


LENGTH: 1534 words


 

Special Assistant to the Executive Director of UNICEF

"Tostan" means "the hatching of an egg" in Wolof, one of the languages of my country, Senegal. "Tostan" has been used to name a successful literacy project in Senegal, as it carries the idea of "breakthrough," that moment of discovery when a chick cracks open the eggshell or when a human being makes the connection between letters and ideas. Africa is waiting for an even bigger breakthrough, when the world discovers that Africa is not, as commonly considered, a continent of despair, but a continent where a better future is within reach.

The challenge has never been greater External debts of crippling proportions, falling commodity earnings, war, drought, high population growth, environmental degradation, and an epidemic of AIDS have reversed the advances made in Africa in the 1960s and 1970s. Governments try to ensure that the basic needs of their populations are met, but in times of trouble the first cutbacks are usually in health and education sectors. The victims? Those whose need for support is the greatest -- children. 

Africa has only 10 percent of the world's child population, but one third of the almost 13 million children who die every year are Africa. Over 30 million children in African are suffering from malnutrition. At least one African in three of primary school age is not in school.

Yet two facts stand out that give cause for hope and optimism. We have the capability to succeed in creating a better life for all our children, as well as the conditions favorable to do so.

Success is possible because we have the tools to counter disease, malnutrition, and illiteracy. Effective, sustainable, and low-cost interventions will improve the health and lives of the disadvantaged. The cost of providing clean water in Africa has been halved since the mid-1980s and now averages about $20 per person per year. Trials in all regions of the world, including Africa, have demonstrated that the incidence of child malnutrition can be halved for less than $10 per child per year. Basic education can be provided at a cost of approximately $20 per child per year.

Many factors are helping to push the needs of children to the top of agendas for action and attention. The movement towards democracy is gaining ground. The breakthrough of past political ideologies has left a vacuum that can be filled by humanitarian guiding principles. Already, African governments have surpassed other regions in their commitment to the protection of child rights through their ratification of the "Convention on the Rights of the Child".

There have been concrete successes, but many were not considered "newsworthy," despite the often extraordinary efforts made to achieve them. By 1990 two thirds of African countries achieved the goal of immunizing 75 percent of their children against the six major diseases of tuberculoses, measles, diphtheria, whooping cough, tetanus, and polio. The challenges were many, including overcoming the logistics of keeping vaccines chilled between modern medical centers and remote, traditional communities. (Methods including strapping iceboxes on to the back of bicycles; traditional four-legged modes of transportation were also used.)

Under the Bamako Initiative, launched in 1987 in the capital of Mali, communities in rural, underserved areas have worked in collaboration with their national ministries of health to establish affordable and sustainable basic health services that, to the extent possible, are locally financed and managed. The value of community-based health care is better understood when one learns that in sub-Saharan Africa, there is an average of one doctor for every 24,500 people.

Wars have been halted for African children. In the Sudan in 1989, after bloody strife and associated famine had claimed the lives of some 250,000 civilians, mostly children and women, warring parties granted safe passage for the delivery of food and assistance to more than 2 million people. This practice of "corridors of peace" acknowledges that the future of a nation ultimately depends on the survival and healthy development of its children.

Concrete expressions of support and commitment to improving the well-being of African children have been made at international gatherings with players at the highest levels. In November 1992, a major conference held in Dakar, Senegal, united heads of state, government ministers, local government leaders, and non-governmental organizations from Africa, developing, and industrialized nations to focus on issues concerning African children. Convened by the Organization of African Unity with assistance from UNICEF, the countries of Africa represented at the International Conference on Assistance to African Children pledged to attain a set of intermediate targets by the end of 1995.

This commitment shows to what extent African social leaders, experts, and humanitarians believe in the ability of Africa to reverse the recent trend of decline. For they pledged to further raise immunization coverage levels, increase use of oral rehydration therapy to combat dehydration caused by diarrhea, virtually eliminate iodine and vitamin A deficiency disorders, and encourage breastfeeding, all by 1995. This represents tremendous mobilization in a relatively short period of time -- three years -- that could spell generations of life at higher levels of health and well-being.

The importance of international support and commitment was underlined at the Dakar Conference. In 1990, world leaders at the World Summit for Children adopted goals ensuring the survival, protection, and development of children by the year 2000. The cost of achieving those goals in Africa, including the intermediate targets adopted at the Dakar Conference, is estimated to total US$12.7 billion.

This may seem like a lot. Yet it is actually less than what Africa already receives in the form of official development assistance (ODA) -- the continent annually receives US$18 billion. However, only US$2 billion of ODA currently goes towards meeting priority human needs. A reorientation of social values and priorities is clearly necessary. Actions taken to reach the intermediate targets would save the lives of some 3,000 children every day -- 1 million a year -- and significantly reduce malnutrition and disabilities as well.

Recent events have shown that care does not need to be confined within national borders. The children of Somalia are the concern of the global community, in spite of economic recessions and plunging profits. In addition, the growing interdependence among nations not only brings social responsibility for one another, but also an increase in cultural wealth and understanding. This is why I urge all Americans, especially Africa-Americans, to join in the 1993 Commemoration of the Day of the African Child on June 16.

The June 16 date was selected because it was on that date in 1976 that school-children were massacred in Soweto, South Africa. The Day of the African Child can have many meanings. For some, it will be a cause for celebration, an opportunity to report progress on promises that were made to Africa's children. For others, it will be a time for reflection on hardships experienced by the youngest and most vulnerable citizens of the continent. This year, many African nations will focus on reaching the intermediate targets and the World Summit goals.

The commemoration of the Day can help generate the breakthrough that Africa is waiting for, when the world community cracks the wall of misperception and discovers a continent where a better life for children is within reach and there is a strong will to attain it. Children receive only one chance to grow normally in mind and body. That chance should be protected, in good ties as well as in bad. It must be a priority for all.


LOAD-DATE: June 9, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


184 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


June 6, 1994 / July 3, 1994


CLINTON ADOPTING A "CRISIS-PREVENTION" APPROACH TO AFRICA


BYLINE: Reed Kramer


LENGTH: 1267 words


 

AFRICA NEWS SERVICE

Addis Ababa

When Brian Atwood, the U.S. government's coordinator for international disaster assistance, went to the White House last month to report on his upcoming visit to this famine-plagued quadrant in Africa, his mission was "enthusiastically endorsed" by the president.

"We talked about the importance of crisis prevention as the foundation of his foreign policy," Atwood said enroute to deliver the message that East Africa could be facing yet another massive humanitarian disaster.

The trip, which the White House designated a "presidential mission" to give it greater visibility, is the first of a planned new series of initiatives to make Africa a higher foreign policy priority. Africa policy has lacked identity of shape, senior officials concede. But they say there is a new determination to avoid costly Somalia and Rwanda-type fiascoes. 

To highlight the new policy direction, the White House will has a day-long conference on Africa at the end of the month with participation by members of Congress, academic experts and the leaders of key private organizations. The president and vice president will speak and take part in what officials are calling an "extraordinary" event.

Planning is underway for a state visit in the fall by South African President Nelson Mandela, and President Clinton is planning a trip early next year to South Africa and several other newly democratic African countries.

The president also has appointed a special envoy for Sudan, Melissa Wells, a senior career diplomat with extensive African experience, who will arrive in the region next week to bolster current efforts by East African governments to end that seemingly intractable civil war. Already, another special envoy, Paul Hare, is working alongside a United Nationals negotiator on Angola.

Atwood, who visited three African countries and three European capitals last week, is accompanied by Rep. Tony Hall (D-OH), the prominent Congressional anti-hunger campaigner, and the heads of three major private relief organizations -- CARE, Catholic Relief Services, and the International Rescue Committee.

More than 20 million people face starvation if the annual rains don't arrive in the 10-nation region extending from Sudan and Somalia southward through Burundi, Rwanda and Tanzania, according to a detailed U.S. government analysis compiled from satellite photos and other data. Weather patterns so far this year suggest a repeat of the devastating droughts that hit the area in 1984-85 and 1972-73. The suffering this time could be on a far larger scale because of a rapid population increase and the devastation of war throughout the area.

"If we don't have a bad drought this year, we will next year or the year after," said Fred Fischer, director of AID's regional office in Nairobi, told the Atwood delegation in a briefing here.

With United States currently providing 60% of the food aid in the region, both Atwood and Hall asked during the European stopovers for other donors to take a larger share if additional food is needed this year.

During the group's visit to Eritrea, which became independent from Ethiopia a year ago, President Isayas Afewerki criticized what he said was an imbalance in U.S. foreign aid that he said discourages self-sufficiency.

Eritrea this year is receiving about $24 million in emergency food from the United States, but only $6.9 million in development assistance. More long-term development funding is required, he said, to enable countries like Eritrea to escape dependency on outside help. Eritrea has drawn up a detailed economic redevelopment plan, but disappointingly little of the assistance needed to implement it has been pledged, he said.

The Eritreans are trying to jump-start their economy with projects designed to give two major population groups that now live on hand-outs the means for self support. In the town of Tessenai, in western Eritrea, the delegation visited a refugee reception center, which is nearly ready to begin processing the fist of some 500,000 Eritreans living in camps a few miles across the border in Sudan.

With health and nutrition deteriorating in the camps and Sudan's military regime aggressively pedaling fundamentalist Islam to the refugees, the Eritrean government decided not to delay their repatriation effort while awaiting outside help.

At the nearby Ali Gidir agricultural project, Atwood's group saw what this month will become home to several thousand former guerrilla soldiers who are begin demobilized as Eritrea reduces its army to 35,000, about a third of the size when the 30-year independence war ended in 1991. Modern farm machines are parked on three large plots marked off for planting by the first group of 2500 ex-fighters scheduled to arrive next week.

With over 60 percent of its 2.6 million people currently dependent on food aid and the country already suffering from prolonged drought, the government has not wanted to set up new camps inside its borders where money spent on their upkeep would drain funds from economic development. Instead, the authorities turned to the Central Bank for financing when sufficient donor assistance could not be found so that refugees can begin returning home and on arrival receive the tools and seeds needed to immediately start growing their food.

"We've got to get this region beyond the disaster level and onto the path of economic growth," said Atwood, who heads the U.S. Agency for International Development (AID). "Scarcity clearly produces conflict," he said. "That was a big problem in Rwanda -- population growth that outdistanced food output." The Clinton administration when it took office promised to do more to help Africa. But the continent has not received the kind of high-level attention policymakers say they had intended. Atwood says that is changing. The administration is "very pro-active with respect to Africa," Atwood said, citing th recently announced $600 million aid package for South Africa and the White House conference. Beginning with a dinner on June 26 addressed by Anthony Lake, the president's national security advisor, the conference will continue throughout the next day with top officials outlining administration policy and participants taking part in discussion groups. Clinton will speak at lunch on June 27.


LOAD-DATE: June 9, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.

Maxwell Stamp PLC

Economic Consultants

Maxwell Stamp accepts no responsibility for any transaction undertaken on the basis of these figures. Ghana Cedi (c)              9.2037       171.30       695.03
Guinea Franc (GF)           9.4726       176.31       715.34
Guinea-Bissau 
   Peso (GBP)              119.9575      2232.71      9058.74
Kenya Shilling (KSh)        0.5516        10.2673      41.6572
Lesotho Maloti (LM)       350.2681      6519.3778  26450.9303         
Liberia Dollar (L]         0.1498         2.7875      11.3097
Libya Dinar (LD)            0.0030         0.0578       0.2344

SECTION: BUSINESS

American Information Technologies (AIT) can provide computer equipment, installation, maintenance, and training services for business or individuals starting up in Africa. For additional information, contact: AIT, PO Box i510, Tucker, GA Tel: (404) 723-9200.

* 29 Two-wheel drive vans. IFB No.: 263-0203-07. A.I.D. Geographic Code 000 (U.S. only). Purchasing Agent: TransCentury Associates, Inc., 12110 Sunset Hills Rd., Suite 450, Reston, VA 22090. Tel: (703) 715-3047. Bid Deadline: August 4, 1994.

LOAD-DATE: July 11, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


188 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 4, 1994 / July 18, 1994


SECTION: EDUCATION/TRAVEL


LENGTH: 2934 words


 

Fulbright Faculty Awards are available for university lecturing or advanced research in over 135 countries. Awards range from two months to a full academic year. Applications are encouraged from professional outside academe as well as from faculty at all types of institutions. For more information, contact: Council for International Exchange of Scholars, 3007 Tilden St., NW, Suite 5M, Box GBRO, Washington, DC 20008-3009. Phone: (202) 686-7877. Bitnet: CIES1@GWUVM.GWU.EDU.

The National Humanities Center awards approximately 35-40 residential fellowships each year for the advanced study of the arts and other fields in the liberal arts. Social scientists, natural scientists, or professionals whose work has a humanistic dimension are encouraged to apply. Applicants must hold a PhD or the equivalent degree. For more information, contact: Fellowship Program, National Humanities Center, Box 12256, Research Triangle Park, NC 27709.

The University of Cape Town's Centre for African Studies announces the Harry Oppenheimer Research Fellowship. Applicants are considered annually in December for the following year. The fellowship is for three to six months, depending on the recipient's program. Fellows receive R7500 and are expected to deliver and Africa Seminar and contribute to the cultural life of the Centre. For more information, contact: Harry Oppenheimer Institute, UCT Private Bag, 7700 Ronderbosch, University of Cape Town, South Africa. Phone: (021) 650-3273. Fax: (021) 650-3274. E-Mail: erasmus@socsci.uct.ac.za. 

African Development Foundation (ADF) is a public enterprise set up in 1980 by the US Congress to support self-development initiatives by African populations. The major goal is to provide the resources needed by African grassroots populations to reach self-reliant development. ADF does not impose external development concepts on African communities. Instead, it encourages Africans to suggest innovative approaches to problem-solving, which will eventually lead to self-reliance and self-sufficiency in the local communities. Researchers are requested to explore problems directly related to grassroots development and to make concrete recommendations that can be of assistance to development project promoters in the community. ADF provides grants for research initiated and conducted by African academics, development specialists, students and community groups. Researchers are encouraged to be creative in selecting their theme and to focus their research on issues which are crucial to the development of their countries. In 1994, ADF will allocate approximately US $675,000 to research project funding. Four types of fellowships will be awarded: Gray postgraduate fellowships (deadline August 1, 1994); Be applied research fellowships (deadline August 1, 1994); Grants for transfer of knowledge (no deadline); Leland development fellowships (deadline January 1, 1995). For information contact: Office of Learning and Dissemination, African Development Foundation, 1400 Eye Street, NW, Tenth Floor, Washington, DC 20005.

The National Research Council announces the 1994 Resident, Cooperative, and Postdoctoral Research Associateship Programs to be conducted on behalf of federal agencies or research institutions whose 140 participating research laboratories are located throughout the United States. The program provides opportunities for PhD scientists and engineers of unusual promise and ability to perform research on problems largely of their own choosing yet compatible with the research interests of the sponsoring laboratory. Areas of interest include chemistry, earth and atmospheric sciences, engineering and applied sciences, biological, health, and behavioral science and biotechnology, mathematics, space and planetary sciences, and physics. Applications submitted directly to the National Research Council are accepted on a continuous basis throughout the year. Those postmarked no later than 15 August will be reviewed in October. Initial awards will be announced in July and November. Information on specific research opportunities and participating federal laboratories, as well as application materials, may be obtained from the Associateship Programs.

The SSRC-MacArthur Foundation Committee on International Peace and Security announces a 1994 program of small grants allowing scholars and students of international relations to visit major universities and research centers outside their home region. Grants are intended for junior scholars who seek exposure to debates and scholarship on the changing international system and issues of international peace and security. These grants will be awarded to well-qualified applicants for study at major research centers selected in consultation with Council staff. Post-graduate applicants should have received their doctorate within the past seven years. Applications should be complete and returned to the Council, post-marked no later than 15 JULY 1994. For information or materials, contact Social Science Research Council, Visiting Scholar Fellowship, Program on International Peace and Security, 605 Third Avenue, 17th Floor, New York, NY 10158. Tel: (212) 661-0280, fax: (212) 370-7896.

The Collaborative Projects Program of the National Endowment for the Humanities welcomes applications for projects of broad scholarly and public significance in the humanities that entail the collaboration of two or more scholars for periods 1-3 years. All topics in the humanities are eligible. Awards usually range from $10,000 to about $150,000. The deadline is OCTOBER 15, 1994 for projects beginning no earlier than July of the next year. For application materials and further information write or call: Collaborative, Projects/Interpretive Research, Division of Research Programs, Room 318, 1100 Pennsylvania Ave., NW, Washington, DC 20506. Tel: (202) 606-8210.

The National Endowment for the Humanities Reference Materials Program supports projects to prepare reference works that will improve access to information and resources. Support is available for the creation of dictionaries, historical or linguistic atlases, encyclopedias, concordances, reference grammars, databases, textbooks, and other projects that will provide essential scholarly tools for the advancement of research or for general reference purposes. Support is also available for projects that address important issues related to the design or accessibility of reference works. The application deadline of 15 SEPTEMBER 1994 for projects beginning after 1 JULY 1995. For more information write to Reference Materials, Room 318, NEH, Washington, DC 20506.

The Re-entry Grants for African Scholars Pursuing Education Research program is designed to assist in the professional re-establishment of talented African scholars who are returning from doctoral studies abroad and have a research interest in issues related to the revitalisation and development of education in sub-Saharan Africa. All proposed projects must include and explicitly and substantial focus on female school participation as part of the set of educational issues to be examined. The proposed budget, not to exceed $25,000, any request funding for items such as a microcomputer and software, books, office supplied, living expenses, personnel assistance and local transportation. The budget may also include subsistence for on research team member of any nationality and a stipend to cover up to 6 month's transition costs for the returning African scholar. Applicants may submit research proposals prior to or within one year of returning to their Africa-based institutions. Grants are made to the scholar, but the proposal must be endorsed by the African institution where the application will be a full-time staff member. Also required are two letters of recommendation from academic supervisors at the institution where the candidate carried out doctoral study, postgraduate transcripts, and a resume. There are no deadlines for submission of proposals. For a full description of the program, write to Scholars on Education Re-Entry Program, The Rockefeller Foundation, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, New York, NY 10036 or Scholars on Education Re-Entry Program, The Rockefeller Foundation, P.O. Box 47543, Nairobi, Kenya.

The Social Science Research Council/American Council of Learned Societies is calling for proposals for their African Archives and Museums Project (AAMP). The AAMP is designed to help museums and archives in their efforts to overcome problems of funding and materials. AAMP awards two types of grants: seed grants and implementation grants. Seed grants up to $5,000 are intended to advance the conceptual and logistical development of conservation, documentation or exhibition/outreach/education projects. Implementation grants from $5,000 up to $15,000 are intended to support conservation, documentation, and exhibition/outreach/education activities. AAMP is especially receptive to projects that draw on local expertise and community resources and bring together different institutions in cooperative ventures. For more information and for a list of 1993 awards, address inquiries to the African Archives and Museums Projects, Social Science Research Council, 605 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10158. Tel: (212) 661-0280. Fax: (212) 370-7896.

Environmental Briefs Corp. is a non-profit organization that publishes a newsletter updating African environmental scientists on recent findings published in academic literature. The students intern would serve as an editorial assistant. Duties would include: reading and summarizing articles in the academic literature; going to university libraries to photocopy articles; writing letters to journal editors and article authors; and updating mailing lists. Knowledge of or familiarity with calculus, mathematical models, the earth sciences and Africa would be helpful. Computer experience (preferably in a Macintosh environment) is also a plus. While this is an unpaid internship, it will provide invaluable experience to anyone interested in a career in either international development of the environment. Please contact Catherine Camp Boyle, Environmental Briefs Corp., 22 Willowdale Road, Winchester, MA 01890.

The Population-Environment Fellows Program, sponsored by USAID and administered at the University of Michigan, sponsors fellow for two-year appointments with overseas agencies. Fellows, who must hold a graduate degree in a relevant area and demonstrated expertise a both population and environment, provide assistance and technical support for developing country institutions to foster a comprehensive approach to development. Applications are reviewed on a rolling basis, but the sooner a completed application is received, the greater the availability of sites for which it can be considered. Inquiries and application requests may be obtained by contacting: The Population-Environment Fellows Program, SPH II, Room M2240, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109-2029. Tel: (313) 747-0222. Fax: (313) 747-4947.

The University of Florida sponsors academic year abroad programs in Tanzania and Nigeria and summer programs in Uganda and Morocco. At the University of Dar es Salaam in Tanzania, students spend an academic year studying Swahili. A summer field course in tropical rain forest ecology and conservation will be offered in the Kibale Forest of Western Uganda at the Makere University Biological Field Station. A Summer Arabic Language, Conversation and Translation Program is located in Fez, Morocco. Contact: Overseas Studies, Office of International Studies and Programs, 123 Tigert Hall, University of Florida, Gainesville, FL 32611. Tel: (904) 392-5206. Fax: (904) 392-5575.

Research grants in African Rural Development Issues are offered by the Winrock International Institute for Agricultural Development. Although the fourth round of grants had a deadline of February 1, 1994, interested social scientists may contact Winrock for further information on future funding opportunities. Contact: Dirk Perthel, Winrock International, 08 B.P. 1603, Abidjan 08, Cote d'Ivoire. Phone: (225) 44-94-14. Fax: (225) 44-94-11. Their U.S. office is at 1611 N. Kent St., #600, Arlington, VA 22209. Tel: (703) 525-9430. Fax: (703) 525-1744.

The Federal Court Interpreter Certification Project will offer examinations for several languages, including Arabic, on August 27, 1994. Successful completion of these examinations does not constitute an offer of employment by the United States Courts, but this written examination constitutes the first step in achieving certification or otherwise qualified status. The fee for the written exam is $80 for each language requested. All applications for the exam must be postmarked no later than July 1, 1994. Contact: Federal Court Interpreter Project, Modern Languages Building, Room 445, University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721. Tel: (602) 621-3687. Fax: (602) 624-8130.

The American Committee on Africa/The Africa Fund seeks interns for its New York office. For further information contact Adrena Ifill, The Africa Fund, 198 Broadway, New York, NY 10038.

The UIUC-Egerton University Study Abroad Program allows undergraduates to spend eight weeks (June 6-August 7) in Kenya this summer. Interested students should contact the Study Abroad Office, University of Illinois, immediately. Tel: (217) 333-6322.

University of Minnesota, Minnesota Studies in International Development (MSID) offers an academic year program of internships and field study including 5 months in Senegal or Kenya. Financial aid is available. Details are available at the Center of through: MSID, The Global Campus, University of Minnesota, 106-M Nicholson Hall, 216 Pillsbury Drive SE, Minneapolis, MN 55455-0138. Tel: (216) 625-3379.

The Center for Global Education announces a semester-long program in Namibia designed to introduce students to the central issues facing Southern Africa. Course credit may be earned. Applications and brochures are available from Center for Global Education, Augsburg College, 2211 Riverside Avenue, Minneapolis, MN 55454. Tel: (612) 330-1159.

The Southern Africa Education Program at Stony Point Center is planning a tour of South Africa June 29-July 16. Interested persons should contact William Palmer, SAEP, Stony Point Center, 17 Crickettown Road, Stony Point, NY 10980. Tel: (914) 786-5072. Deadline is MAY 15, 1995.

The National Science Foundation grants Dissertation Improvement awards to support the work of African graduate students enrolled in US universities who plan to conduct dissertation research on a topic relating to a developing country problem. The grants cover only research expenses and travel costs (no tuition, fees, or living expenses). For further information, contact: Francis Li, National Science Foundation, 4201 Wilson Blvd., Room 935, Arlington, CA 22230. Tel: (703) 306-1234.

The University of Westminster offers MA/Postgraduate diplomas in Francophone African Studies. The MA in Francophone African Studies provides students with the framework within which they can study aspects of Francophone Africa, including literature, political and socio-economic issues, in the context of the relevant major debates raised by the discourses of post-colonialism. For further information and application form, please contact: Nikki Roberts, School of Languages, University of Westminster, 9-18, Euston Centre, London NW1 3ET.
