SECTION: EMPLOYMENT


LENGTH: 1680 words


 

American Refugee Committee has the following positions available:

In Somalia: MATERNITY SERVICES COORDINATOR: based in Afmadou, southern Somalia. Responsibilities: select and train MCH maternity services staff; establish policies and procedures for the MCH Center maternity services; supervise the delivery of maternity services. Qualifications: experienced Certified Nurse Midwife; experience in a developing country preferably in a rural setting; training and supervision background. Immediate opening; 6-month commitment. $1,500/month.

In Sudan: MEDICAL DOCTOR to provide emergency relief to displaced persons in Kajo Keji County. RESPONSIBILITIES: set up emergency/acute care clinic and coordinate all in-patient and out-patient activities. REQUIREMENTS: MD with emergency/acute care experience in developing countries and proven success in implementing new programs in relief situations. 6 month commitment. $1,200-$1,600/month. Immediate opening. 

FIELD COORDINATOR/LOGISTICIAN: 3 years experience in developing countries. Administration and logistical experience a must. 12 month commitment required. Salary, insurance, round-trip transportation and room and board provided.

NURSE PRACTITIONER: Experience in developing countries. To assist with EPI program. 12 month commitment required. Salary, insurance, round-trip transportation and room and board provided.

Resume or letter of interest to International Medical Corps, Dept. 94-008, 12233 Olympic Blvd., #280, Los Angeles, CA 90064. Fax: (310) 442-6622.

INTERNATIONAL MEDICAL CORPS has multiple openings. Mail or fax resume or letter of interest to International Medical Corps, Dept. 93- 033, 12233 West Olympic Blvd., #280, Los Angeles, CA 90064; fax: (310) 442-6622. The following International Medical Corps positions are available in ANGOLA: **COUNTRY DIRECTOR: October 1994 start date. Prior overseas experience managing emergency/relief program with increasing levels of reponsibility required. Strong management, interpersonal and donor-relations skills required.

The INTERNATIONAL MEDICAL CORPS is seeking a SITE MANAGER for its emergency medical program in Belet Weyne, SOMALIA. Requirements include: Prior international experience, accounting, management, administrative and security experience. Assignment is for a minium of 6 months. Salary, insurance, round-trip transportation, room and board provided.

The INTERNATIONAL MEDICAL CORPS is seeking an EPI COORDINATOR for its Emergency Helath Care Program in SUDAN. Requirements include: Prior international experience, strong teaching skills and immunization campaign implementation experience. Salary, insurance, round-trip transportation, room and board provided.

The INTERNATIONAL MEDICAL CORPS is seeking the following for its start-up emergency hospital program in RWANDA: FIELD COORDINATOR - Setting up security, accounting ability, site manager experience, 3 years in developing country experience. This position will be responsible for financial and administrative management. LOGISTICS SPECIALIST - 2 years experience in developing country logistics management. EMERGENCY ROOM NURSE - Strong trauma background, critical care casualty, emergency and triage preferred. TRAUMA and/or GENERAL SURGEON - Strong trauma background, critical care casualty, emergency and triage preferred. PUBLIC HEALTH NURSE - For outreach program. 2 years experience in developing countries. OUT PATIENT DEPARTMENT NURSE - Strong trauma background. 2 years experience in developing countries.

The School for International Training (SIT) seeks individual for a Visiting Faculty position within the Department of Global Issues & Intercultural Management, with primary responsibility in the Master's Program in Intercultural Management (PIM). Seeking practitioner with years of distinguished experience in a managerial, training and/or consulting role in a "Southern" country. Primary responsibilities include a combination of teaching courses in human resource management, development program administration and strategic management, advising and evaluating students in their internships, and capstone papers and presentations. Depending on knowledge, interest and need, may also be asked to teach one of the following: project design, financial management of NGOs, or organizational behaviour. Minimum qualifications include distinguished experience in managerial positions in NGO, development organisations, and/or experience in teaching or training in nonformal, participant-centered education activities. Contract: 8/15/94 - 6/9/95. Salary dependent upon degree and experience. Position open until filled. Send resume and cover letter to HR, World Learning, PO Box 676, Brattleboro, VT 05302-0676.

The Center for International Private Enterprise (CIPE), an affiliate of the US Chamber of Commerce, seeks individual to assist with developing and implementing training/education programs focused on strengthening overseas business associations and their staffs' capabilities. Will conduct needs assessments; establish training objectives; select/develop courses; recruit instructors; and coordinate logistics. Will also assist with managing CIPE's grants programs for Africa. Requires related degree and 2 years of related training experience in an international setting; experience with Microsoft Word and Lotus; fluency in Russian; and the ability to travel, work with diverse constituencies and meet tight deadlines. Portuguese language skills preferred. Start $28K with excellent benefits. Send cover letter and benefits to: US Chamber of Commerce, Personnel Dept., 11615 H St., NW, Washington, DC 20062-2000.

The Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) of the United Nations has the following openings:

In Ghana:

REGIONAL PLANT PRODUCTION AND PROTECTION OFFICER in Accra. Qualifications: University degree in agricultural sciences and postgraduate specialization in plant production and protection or crop science. Ten years of progressively responsible professional experience in plant production including field work in tropical or subtropical agriculture in developing countries, especially in Africa. Duties and Responsibilities: Under the direction of the Assistant Director-General, Regional Representative for Africa, and with the technical guidance of the Plant Production and Protection Division, to be responsible for promoting plant production and protection activities in the region. More specifically, to: advise the Assistant Director-General, Regional Representative for Africa on the short- medium- and long-term policy and programme formulation with regard to plant production and protection activities in the region; assist in formulating policies with regard to plant production and protection at regional/subregional level. Languages: Working knowledge level (C) of English or French and limited knowledge (B) of the other. Salary: Level P-5 carries a net salary per year from US$53,941 to US$63,683 (without dependents) and US$58,210 to US$69,514 (with dependents).

REGIONAL AGRICULTURAL PLANNING ECONOMIST in Accra. Qualifications: University degree (Ph.D. or equivalent) in economics or agricultural economics with postgraduate studies related to economic planning and/or agricultural economics. Ten years of progressively responsible professional experience including experience in the analysis of agricultural and economic development programmes and problems with reference to African countries. Duties and Responsibilities: Under the direction of the Director, Office of Internal Audit, Inspection and Management Control, the incumbent will: plan, supervise, review and report in a managerial capacity on the work of the audit team in any of the four audit groups of AUD and present verbally and in writing to the Director, AUD and senior management the results and the related recommendations for improvements. This may also involve audit quality review of work performed by other senior audit staff on behalf of the Director, AUD. In relation to the Office as a whole and to each audit group, duties performed require the senior auditor to: provide input to the overall policy and strategies for AUD at programme and programme element levels; participate in definition of AUD programme elements objectives for Headquarters' financial and operational audits, field audits of FAOR and projects; management and advisory assignments. Languages: Working knowledge level (C) of English, French or Spanish. Salary: Level P-5 carries a net salary per year from US$62,686 to US$73,978 (without dependents) and US$67,636 to US$80,351 (with dependents).


LOAD-DATE: July 11, 1994


LANGUAGE: English

190 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 4, 1994 / July 18, 1994


SECTION: VOLUNTEER OPPORTUNITIES


LENGTH: 454 words


 

The American Medical Team for Africa (AMTA) promotes and executes educational exchange and medical training in African countries. The goal of the non-profit organization is to bring volunteer doctors, nurses and medical students together with donated supplies, and equipment to serve needs on the continent. Survey teams assess the most pressing needs in targeted countries, develop and publish training manuals in appropriate languages, hold workshops and refresher courses for doctors, nurses and specialists interested in maintenance of health care delivery systems in Africa; and distribute medical supplies and equipment donated by corporations, pharmaceutical companies, hospitals and doctors. The AMTA plans a second medical mission to Africa. For more information, contact Deman Rageh, Executive Director, The American Medical Team for Africa, 2245 Godby Road, Atlanta, GA 30349; phone (404) 766-8000; fax: (404) 767-5264. 

Private Voluntary Organization in Rosslyn needs an experienced Agribusiness/Marketing Specialist to fill a 3-year Chief of Party position in Mali. The candidate must have at least 10 years of proven experience in the field of Agribusiness, Marketing, Credit and Procurement (preferably of fruits & vegetables). Must have related job experience in developing country with hands-on experience and an MBA. Strong training skills in the areas of agribusiness and marketing required. Fluency in French/English (FSI, S-3, R03) a must. Interested candidates must submit a resume, a certification of foreign language capability, and a standard AID bio-data form. Please mail original copies to: Regina Wynn, VITA, 5th floor, Arlington, VA 22209. Tel: (703) 276-1800 or fax: (703) 2143-1865.

Global Service Corps' "Project Kenya" is a 23-day volunteer experience from August 19-September 11. The tour cost (excluding airfare) is $1600, depending on fluctuation in the Kenya shilling. Project participants will have an opportunity to learn about Kenya small-village culture and development while helping initiate biointensive garden plots and other small enterprises. The trip will include time in Nairobi, a 4-day small-village development training session at Manor House Agricultural Centre in Western Kenya, home stays with village families and side trips to nature reserves. For further information contact Global Service Corps at 415-922-5538.

SECTION: PUBLICATIONS

Wade in the Water: African American Sacred Music Traditions An Educators' Guide. Washington: NPR Outreach, 1994. $75.00 (Kit).

Report on the First Nigerian Economic Summit. Los Angeles: South African Tourism Board, 1993. 128 pp.

Report on the First Nigerian Economic Summit. PMB 5612: Spectrum Books Limited Sunshine House, 1993. 128 pp. 

Anton Andereggen, France's Relationship with Subsaharan Africa. Westport: Greenwood Publishing Group, 1994. $55.00 (Cloth). 216 pp.

David A. Anderson/SANKOFA and Illustrated by Claude Joachim, The Rebellion of Humans. Mount Airy: Sights Productions, 1994. $18.95 (Paper). 35 pp.

Kathy Austin, Author and William Minter, Editor, Invisible Crimes: U.S. Private Intervention in the War in Mozambique. Washington: Africa Policy Information Center, 1994. $5.50 (Paper). 50 pp.

Lester R. Brown, Hal Kane, and David Malin Roodman, Vital Signs 1994. Washington: Worldwatch Institute, 1994. $10.95 (Paper). 13.99 in Canada 160 pp.

Richard W. Bulliet, Islam: The View from the Edge. New York: Columbia University Press, 1994. $29.95 (Cloth). 236 pp.

Steve Chimombo, Napolo and the Python. Portsmouth: Heinemann, 1994. $15.95 (Paper). 7.99 UK 182 pp.

Jacklyn Cock, Colonels & Cadres: War & Gender in South Africa. Cape Town: Oxford University Press, South Africa, 1994. $12.95 (Paper). 253 pp.

Mia Couto, Everyman Is a Race. Portsmouth: Heinemann, 1994. $9.00 (PAPER). 118 pp.

Basil Davidson, The Search for Africa: History, Culture, Politics. New York: Times Books, 1994. $25.00 (Cloth). 32.50 in Canada 373 pp.

Zeki Ergas, The Catharsis and the Healing South Africa in the 1990s. New York: Paul & Company Publishers Consortium, Inc., 1994. $25.00 (Cloth). 339 pp.

Essays by Assorted Authors, Sudan: The Forgotten Tragedy. Washington: United States Institute of Peace, 1994. 89 pp.

Joe R. Feagin and Melvin P. Sikes, Living with Racism: The Black Middle-Class Experience. Boston: Beacon Press, 1994. $25.00 (Cloth). 398 pp.

Christopher Flavin and Nicholas Lenssen, Powering the Future: Blueprint for a Sustainable Electricity Industry. Washington: Worldwatch Institute, 1994. $5.00 (Paper). 74 pp.

SECTION: DIRECTORY


LENGTH: 360 words


 

ANNOUNCEMENTS

June 9, 1994

In recognition of the debut of the World Cup in the United States, MasterCard, and Official Sponsor and the Official Card of World Cup USA 1994, announced at a press conference the selection of 24 foreign-born U.S. residents as "MasterCard's Ambassadors of Soccer" for the outstanding contributions to the growth of soccer in the United States. These Ambassadors of Soccer were selected by a national media panel and Pele in a two-phase process. MasterCard will donate $1,000 to the charity of each ambassador's choice, and provide two tickets to one of their native country's World Cup matches.

The following Africans were chosen:

Jean-Pierre Tokoto, Rockford, IL (Cameroon)

Staff Coach/Supervisor - Rockford United Soccer Club 1991-present

Coach Instructor - Rockford United Soccer Club 1991-present

Coach/Director/Instructor - Star Soccer Academy 1983-91.

Abdullah Mokhriby, Erie, PA (Morocco)

Head Coach - Villa Maria Academy 1980-present

Head Coach - Erie County Special Olympics Team 1988-1992

Head Coach - Erie Metro Soccer League/Northwest Penn. Soccer League 1981-91

Assistant Coach - West PA Olympic Development Program 1981-84

Tony Igwe, Belmont, CA (Nigeria)

Head Coach - Menlo Atherton High School and College 1985-present

Women's Head Coach - Stanford University 1979-85

Director - World Ambassador Soccer Academy 1984-present

Africa News


July 4, 1994 / July 18, 1994


THE CLEANSING OF SOUTH AFRICA


BYLINE: Allister Sparks


LENGTH: 1227 words


 

SOUTHEASTER NEWSPAPER, June 10-14, 1994

The recent Goniwe verdict presents the new Government of National Unity with an early challenge on dealing with the evils of our past.

By finding unequivocally that Matthew Goniwe and his three colleagues were murdered by security forces in 1985, and that Major-General Joffel van der Westhuizen's signal to the State Security Council was indeed a request for permission to assassinate, Judge-President Mr. Justice Neville Zietsman has opened the way not only; for the full truth about this grisly hit-squad operation to be revealed, but, together with it, much about the military-security underworld and its Third Force operatives that have ravaged our society for so long.

The pressures will be great not to rock the boat at this moment when the focus of the new government is to bring about national reconciliation, especially not to alarm and estrange the security forces just when they are being brought on side.

But disclosing the truth is an essential part of reconciliation. As President Mandela said in his first state-of-the-nation address to parliament last week, the past may be forgiven but cannot be swept under the carpet. 

All the great religions teach there must be confession and atonement before there can be absolution and reconciliation. It is a truth as fundamental to human psychology as it is to theology from Ireland to Bosnia, the lesson of history is that unrequited grievances poison the future.

There does not have to be retribution. As Nyameka Goniwe says, all she needs is to know who and why. She does not required revenge in order to be requited.

What should happen now is clear. On the basis of the judge's findings, there is a prima facie case of incitement to murder against Van der Westhuizen, both in regard to the death of Goniwe and his colleagues and in regard to a plot to assassinate Lennox Sebe, the former president of the former Ciskei bantustan.

It would appear that Van der Westhuizen could also be charged with perjury, since on the basis of the judge's findings he must have lied under oath in his evidence to the inquest court.

Major-General Johannes van Rensburg, who received the death signal from Van der Westhuizen after discussing the matter with him on the telephone, would also appear to be vulnerable to charges of incitement to murder and perjury.

The Attorney-General of the Eastern Cape division of the Supreme Court should press these charges without delay. This would confront both men with the choice of either facing trial, or of seeking indemnity under a new amnesty law now being drafted which will almost certainly require applicants to give details of the acts for which they wish to be indemnified.

Either way, we would then stand to learn more about what happened and who else may have been involved. For example, Van der Westhuizen refused to answer questions at the inquest about Operation Katzen -- a plot named after himself and the former Chief of the Defence Force General Kat Liebenberg, to assassinate Lennox Sebe and install his brother, Charles Sebe, as head of a new party modelled on Inkatha to rule an amalgamated Transkei-Ciskei bantustan -- on the grounds that he might incriminate himself.

If he were to stand trial on a charge related to that operation, Van der Westhuizen would have to answer those questions. We might then get some disclosure of the extent of the military-security underworld's activities in the Border-Kei region, for years a prime target area for the forces of repression.

What is even more important is that there is now a powerful onus on the military and police to clear their names by identifying the murderers in their midst. They cannot be respected and effective arms of the new South Africa if they continue to cover for guilty members in their ranks.

The police especially have an obligation to bring the Goniwe investigation to a satisfactory conclusion -- and it is up to the new Minster of Safety and Security, Sidney Mufamadi, to ensure this is done.

The police have to find what lawyers call the missing "nexus" in this case -- the missing link that prevented Mr. Justice Zietsman from making a definitive finding in the inquest.

It is known, according to the verdict, that Van der Westhuizen, then a brigadier in charge of Eastern Cape Command, sent a signal message to Van Rensburg, then secretary to the State Security Council, requesting permission for Goniwe to be murdered. It is also known that he was indeed murdered by the security forces. But what cannot be proved on the evidence now available is whether the killing was a direct result of the message.

That is the missing link. If it is found, the charge against one or more people will be murder.

In other words, the police have to establish what happened to the message after Van Rensburg received it. Who did it go to? Did someone authorize the murder? If so, who? And who carried out the order that must have been given?

This is ascertainable information. There must be people who were in powerful positions in and around the State Security Council at the time who know what happened. They, too, now face a choice -- either run the risk of successful police detection which could lead to them being charged with complicity in the murder, or seek indemnity and disclose what they did and what they know.

Thus can the truth come out at last. And as these chips in the granite wall of secrecy are prized out, an avalanche of disclosure will follow -- until at last not only Nyameka Goniwe, but the whole South Africa will know who and why, from Steve Biko to the Third Force, and our society will be cleansed of its ugly past.

Reprinted from Southeaster Newspaper, June 10-14, 1994.

Southeaster Newspaper is published by South Press Services (PTY) Limited. 76 Darling Street, Cape Town 8001. South Africa. Tel: 462-2012. Fax: 461-5407.


LOAD-DATE: July 11, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


197 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 4, 1994 / July 18, 1994


THE AFRICAN DEVELOPMENT BANK AT A CROSSROADS: CHANGE OR SELF-DESTRUCT?


BYLINE: Korinna Horta


SECTION: VIEWPOINT


LENGTH: 2054 words


 

ENVIRONMENTAL DEFENSE FUND, May 26, 1994

The Knox Report

There was not much cause for celebrating the 30th anniversary of African Development Bank at the Bank's annual meeting in Nairobi in May 1994. The majority of Africans are poorer now than they were thirty years ago with famine and civil strife a reality in many countries. In addition, the continent's premier development institution had received a devastating report card, which for several months had been kept under strict secrecy but could no longer remain confidential at the Nairobi meeting. Analogous to the Wapenhans report at the World Bank, the African Development Bank underwent a review of its portfolio which is known as the Knox report. The central conclusion of the Knox report is that the Bank may end up destroying itself unless it is strengthened through fundamental reforms in its governance and management. 

The Knox report states that it was unable to assess the Bank portfolio's contribution to development in Africa, because the Bank does not have "reliable and sufficient data on completed and active projects" (p.4). The Knox report found that there is no systematic monitoring, supervision and reporting of Bank projects. Neither does the Bank know how its staff time is being used nor had it established a relationship between its planning and budget. Other findings were that the Bank's own rules and procedures are often ignored and that the Bank suffers from a general absence of responsibility. All the emphasis is placed on the volume of money lent with little consideration for the development impact: "At presents, too much attention is paid to the quantity of lending and tool little, perhaps even none, to its quality" (p. iv).

Many of the same Bank executives and managers, who have presided over the chaos at the Bank in the past, will now be in charge of introducing fundamental reforms. This will doubtlessly be challenging.

Over the years the Bank has lent billions of dollars for development project yet it has paid little or no attention to the impact of these projects on people and the environment. African non-governmental organizations have gathered increasing evidence that projects by the Bank often aggravate the already precarious situation of poor populations living in the project areas and contribute to environmental degradation.

The Bank must be restructured to ensure that the impact of its policies and projects on people and the environment become its top consideration in future lending decisions. Responsibilities as well as an internal system of incentives must be clearly spelled out to ensure adherence to the new priorities. Any "strengthening" of the Bank short of this goal will be short-term and ineffective. Member countries are still deliberating replenishment of the African Development Fund and should consider phasing their three-year contribution to make it contingent upon the efficacy of the reform efforts.

What Concept of Environment?

Until now the African Development Bank Group has largely dealt with the environment as a public relations issue to "please the non-regional member countries." The prevailing attitude continues to be that concern about the environment is a luxury that may be appropriate for the rich developed countries, but that African countries can ill-afford. Western conservation organizations active in Africa, with their traditional focus on the protection of wildlife and lack of attention to the needs of local people, may have helped shape this attitude.

But environment is first and foremost clean water, air and healthy soils, which are the basis for all economic activity and on which human well-being and survival ultimately depends. In Africa, concern about the environment is directly related to the continent's ability to produce food. Protection of the environment is essential to good production especially on a continent where millions of people are threatened by malnutrition, if not famine and starvation. The production of staple foods for local consumption and, where possible, of tradable surpluses is the most effective means of alleviating poverty. There is a clear chain linking a healthy environment with food production and poverty reduction and subsequently with the health of women and children as well as population growth.

The livelihoods of a vast majority of Africans depend directly on the productivity of the land, forests and oceans, rivers and lakes. Soil erosion, degraded forests and polluted waters, which often result form misguided development efforts, mean stunted growth for children and a life of ill health and ultimately the tightening of the vicious cycle between environmental degradation and increasing poverty.

The Know report states that Africa needs a Bank that is "fired with imagination, ideas and flexible and innovative approaches to development." A fundamental reorientation of the current development model is needed toward addressing the priorities of local people and protecting the natural resource base that sustains their livelihoods. Increased social well-being and political stability will be the likely spin-offs of such a reorientation. So will global benefits such as a more humane world to bequeath to future generations and much improved chances for the protection of the earth's biodiversity and atmosphere.

Concrete Steps to Strengthening the Bank's Environment and Social Policy Division

Access to information on Bank projects and the opportunity for participation of affected people and NGOs in projects from the early project design stages to it implementation and evaluation continue to be unfulfilled promises.

The Bank has now committed itself to develop an information policy and a model for an independent appeals mechanism, analogous to the one created at the World Bank. NGOs hope to have the opportunity to provide input in both these important initiatives.

In the meantime, the Bank's Environment and Social Policy Division clearly needs to be elevated within the Bank and be considerably strengthened before -- at a very minimum -- it ca help ensure that Bank policies and operations do not contribute to the impoverishment of Africa's people and environment.

The Division is woefully understaffed and lacks resources. Despite the competence and dedication of the ca. ten staff members of the division, they have neither the access nor the resources to carry out the tasks at hand: Overseeing policies, programs and operations relating to all social, environmental and public health issues of the Bank's entire portfolio. At present, a considerable amount of staff time has to be used to raise funds from bilateral donors for environmental impact assessments that are mandatory under the Bank's policy. In addition the staff is to categorize all project proposals, monitor and supervise the ca. 180 projects in the lending program, as well as raise the funds and identify the consultants for the Bank's policy work. This is clearly an untenable situation and some immediate steps should be taken:

-- Elevate the Bank's Environment and Social Policy Division to be put directly under the Bank's Vice President for Central Operations. This would confer to the Environment and Social Policy Division at a minimum the same status currently enjoyed by the Bank's Private Sector Development Unit;

-- Provide the Division with the resources and expertise it needs. At present the environmental work of the Division has no social scientists, biologists, expertise in water resources management (since departure of Norwegian technical assistant) and hazardous and toxic waste, etc.;

-- Integrate the Bank's NGO unit, which is currently marginalized within the Bank, into the Environment and Social Policy Division to help ensure access to and dissemination of information on Bank projects;

-- Provide free-standing funds for the Bank's policy and program work and make EIA expenses an integral part of project preparation costs. At present most of the bilateral aid which finances EIAs is "tied aid," which means that all or much of the financing has to be used for consultants from the country providing the funds;

-- Ensure participation of in-country national expertise in all EIA work to help support national capacity-building and in-country monitoring of project related activities. So far EIA missions consist frequently entirely of foreign consultant on short-term assignments;

-- Report on consultation with affected groups. At the previous replenishment negotiations the Bank committed itself to ongoing consultations with affected people and NGOs throughout the EIA process. Management was to report to the Board that meaningful consultations had taken place and would describe these. There seems to have been little -- if any -- action on the commitment. In the future no EIAs should be presented to the Board for approval without detailed description of the consultative processes that have taken place.

-- Ensure Bank "ownership" of the Bank's policies and guidelines. At present these are mostly financed through bilateral aid and produced by consultants from the country providing the "tied aid." For example, the Bank's recent poverty alleviation paper was funded by Norway, so are the country studies and the Bank's population paper, It is not enough for the Bank to say that poverty alleviation is its top priority. This needs to be reflected in the budgets, including funding for the Bank's basic policies and guidelines to help ensure that they become an integral part of the Bank's culture and operation;

-- Resettlement guidelines. The Bank to date has no policy or guidelines when its projects involved involuntary resettlement. Again bilateral funding has been sought to put these guidelines together and Denmark has committed to provide the funds. Denmark agreed to include African consultants aside from Danish consultants s that will be hired for the job. While preparations may be too advanced to insist on "untied" aid in this particular case, the Bank now has an excellent opportunity of demonstrating its seriousness about consulting with NGOs. The draft resettlement policy should be widely circulated and African NGOs should be consulted on the draft before it is presented to the Bank's Board for adoption.


LOAD-DATE: July 11, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


198 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 4, 1994 / July 18, 1994


A STATEMENT TO THE WHITE HOUSE CONFERENCE ON AFRICA


LENGTH: 4574 words


 

By Wangari Maathai, June 27, 1994

Vice President Gore; Distinguished Participants,

I wish to record my deep appreciation for the honour and the warm invitation to participate at this meeting and particularly, at this setting. I believe that it represents a genuine concern for Africa and her peoples and I am sure that many will welcome the hope this initiative represents. They will also follow whatever tangible commitments it will generate.

Some three decades ago, the political leaders of modern Africa had three major objectives in their minds as they became the first post-colonial African rulers: to decolonize the continent, to promote unity and to effect economic development. With the recent political freedom of Namibia and South Africa that generation of African leaders may consider their first agenda complete. But I think that de-colonizing territories is only the first step. A more difficult form of is the mental and the cultural decolonization and these two have been ignored to the detriment of the people Africa. 

This and the agendas for economic development and unity (national and regional) are the challenges of the new generation of African leaders who are expected to free their people from fear and want and give them dignity. Five hundred years is a long time to struggle against oppression. The task ahead is enormous because the battles of five centuries have left Africans weakened culturally, economically, and politically. But above all it has left us without visionary leaders. The crisis we face in Africa is a crisis of leadership. So how do we go bout facing our current challenges and playing our role?

In trying to answer this question, I draw upon some of my experiences. I came to this country during the Kennedy Student Lift of 1960 and was among the first Graduate Fellows of the African American Institute. I therefore testify to the importance of education, especially for women. Apart from my academic pursuits at the University of Nairobi, I have worked for the Green Belt Movement of Kenya, a national, indigenous, grassroots and environmental organization, run mostly by women. This organization plants trees. It also informs, educates, empowers women in particular and the society in general. It addresses issues such as wood energy, soil loss, bio-diversity, food security at family level, poverty, land use capacity, population, and mechanisms of governance.

The Green Belt Movement is a bottom-up approach to development. It has no blue print, preferring to rely on a trial and error method using their expertise, knowledge and the capability of the local people. It addresses both the symptoms and the causes of environmental degradation. It adapts what seems to work and quickly drops what doesn't. It prioritizes on meeting the felt needs of communities: creating jobs, improving the economic status of women, transferring farming techniques and tools, providing wood-fuel for rural populations and the urban poor, fighting malnutrition especially by the planting of fruit trees and indigenous food crops, providing fencing and building materials, protecting forests, water catchment areas and open spaces in urban centers. While addressing these and other environmental issues the Green Belt Movement also identifies and subsequently works on economic and political issues which form important linkages with environmental concerns which are likely to have a negative impact on the environment.

But this is not what I was trained to do. This is what the socio-political realities of my country forced me to choose to do. For our work the Green Belt Movement has been threatened, abused and ridiculed. We have continued to work partly because of the support of many friends, some of them right here, who have stood with us in our times of danger. For that we shall be eternally grateful.

While doing this environmental work we have identified many bottlenecks which frustrate development efforts and continue to keep the majority of the African people in the back stage of their development and political agenda. Perhaps none of the bottlenecks mentioned below are new, but I believe they have to be addressed if we genuinely want to help Africa.

The concern over these bottlenecks has been raised in other fora. But never at a setting where those with the economic and political power to assist Africa have expressed interest in ideas o how best to go about it. Like me, many who will learn about this conference will be full of faith and hope because their confidence in the ability and capacity of the United States of America is not misplaced.

And now to some examples of the bottlenecks:

1. The absence of peace and security in Africa.

Peace and security are a prerequisite for development and all human beings aspire and deserve peace and security. They also aspire for happiness and a quality of life devoid of poverty. For the last three decades many African states have hardly enjoyed internal peace and security. Oppression and a prevalent culture of fear and silence gave a semblance of peace which was used to minimize the outcry of citizens in many countries which some sectors of the world portrayed as peaceful, secure and prosperous. But those were the days of the Cold War and misrepresentation was part of the War.

The Cold War though, was hot in Africa. It precipitated some of the most devastating internal wars as African friends and foes of the superpowers fought for economic and political control. It also justified political and economic oppression and violation of human rights in many countries. A trend which did not end with the end of the end of the Cold War. Human and material resources were diverted towards these wars and internal security of states rather than towards human development. The African peoples took a back stage.

2. Style of Leadership.

The other reason why human-centered development was ignored was the style of leadership. During this period dictatorial leaders who were unpopular with their citizens received huge military aid and they built up massive armies, police forces and an equally huge network of secret service whose main preoccupation was, and still is, to spy on their own citizens. In many African states, including the one I know best, Kenya, citizens have become prisoners within their own borders. The preoccupation with internal security and political survival by leaders misdirected scarce resources and sacrificed the agenda for human development for decades. It also encouraged leaders to make changes in national constitutions to give themselves absolute powers and control over all national resources and mechanisms of governance (radio, television, the judicial system, the civil service, the armed forces and periodic elections) originally intended to provide checks and balances and prevent dictatorial tendencies.

All these mechanisms are heavily controlled, manipulated, misused and censored by Heads of States. So poised, many of the current African leaders enjoy immense power and control and indeed run states as if they were their personal property. They have invented divisive and manipulative tactics such as the on-going politically-motivated tribal clashes in Kenya in order to stay in power. The tribal clashes are also presented as age-old tribal animosities which are coming to the fore because of political liberalization.

However, in countries where the freedom of the press and information is curtailed, where citizens may not assemble, associate or move freely without being harassed by armed policemen, it is difficult to know the honest opinion of ordinary men and women. At least in Kenya, I know for certain that tribes would live together peacefully as they have done for generations.

The possibility of a more open political system has disquieted President Moi, enough to allow the brewing tribal tensions in Kenya which could easily erupt into the type of violence now ravaging Rwanda. It is important to emphasize that it is not the tribes who want to fight, rather, it is the leaders who are using tribes to arouse ethnic nationalism. The President of Kenya, as was the case with the late President of Rwanda, speaks peace and blames the Opposition for the tribal clashes. One should give him the benefit of the doubt. But, it would be impossible for the Kalenjin community (which is President Moi's community) to train militia, arm them, kill some 2000 of the targeted tribes (in full view of the police force) without the personal sanctioning of the President.

This is not to say that ethnicity is non-existent or that Africa will not have to address the problems of identity and nationalism especially with respect to the very unnatural nature of African Nations. But the tribal agenda today has to do less with problems of identity and more with the issue of political and economic control of national resources. Those opting for the old one-party rule want to continue their monopoly of control. Of course we cannot over-rule external forces. A weak, disunited and war-ravaged African is easier to control and exploit. Not to mention that it becomes a big market for small firearms from nations whose economy needs to sell them to make money and save jobs.

Dictators will continue to argue that democracy is a western value which cannot work in Africa. But at the same time they deny citizens the right to have constitutional conventions to decide for themselves what type of democracy they want. In Kenya, for example, the Opposition and the religious leaders have been denied the right to meet and discuss the Constitution. Yet the Opposition represents 65% of the electorate.

3. A frustrated democratization process.

The truth is that Africans, like all other human beings want justice, equity, transparency, responsibility and accountability. They want respect and human dignity. They want a decent life and an opportunity to feed, shelter and clothe their families. They are not seeking to dominate or marginalize each other. They want to create a strong civil society which can hold its leaders accountable and responsible, as well as, sustain mechanisms of governance which ensure the security of the people rather than the security of Heads of States and a small group of supporters and opportunists who surround them.

That is the type of democracy millions of Africans are striving for. And that is what they would like the leadership in their country to help facilitate morally, economically, and politically.

In his day, Kwame Nkrumah of Ghana is said to have urged Africans to seek first the political freedom and all else would be added unto them. Today Africans are seeking for a more democratic, just and fair form of governance so that all else may be added unto them. As we look at the bottlenecks it would appear that Kwame Nkrumah was right. Only he did not say that it is political freedom which must be grounded on liberty, justice and equity.

Incidentally, the recent power sharing in South Africa offers an interesting alternative for Africa. The political culture of "the winner takes all" was forfeited for national unity. The traditional acquisition of absolute power and the control of national resources by "the winner" is one major motivation for dictatorship. Those who "win", even with a minority vote, inherit the land and all its wealth...literally!

4. International cooperation for human development.

Africa is being marginalized by the lack of genuine support and cooperation from the rich international community. There is more rhetoric than action. For we know what the problems are. They are discussed in a myriad of words in books, magazines, evaluation reports and development plans, many of which are written by experts. Most foreign aid comes in the form of curative social welfare programmes such as famine relief, food aid, population control programmes, refugee camps, peace-keeping forces and humanitarian mission. Resources should be concentrated in preventive and sustainable human development programmes such as functional education and training, building of infrastructure, in institution and capacity building, in food production, promotion of entrepreneuership, development of cultural and social programmes which empower people so that they can tap their creative energy.

5. Corruption in Africa.

It is suggested that funds which were advanced to Africa for development are stolen and stashed away in secret bank accounts in developed countries. Much secrecy surrounds these financial transactions but it is suggested that if these funds were made available to Africa she would need no more aid. One way to assist Africa and to end "donor fatigue" is to locate these funds and return them to the World Bank and IMF or whoever had advanced them. This would not be a matter of forgiving debts but a case of retrieving stolen capital and returning to the original owner! It is a matter of ethics. A matter of being just and fair to ordinary Africans on whose behalf the funds were borrowed and from whom the World Bank and IMF is demanding repayment. Many future generations of Africans will be born already deeply in debt.

So is anybody interested in justice? What is the truth about Africa's international debt? Perhaps when the truth around these financial transaction, which have economically crippled Africa, is finally exposed we shall be as shocked as the world was when we comprehended the atrocities of the Slave Trade or the Holocaust. And we shall again wonder aloud, "How can there be so much cruelty in the hears of men?"

For if it is a crime to kill half a million people in Rwanda, it should be a crime to steal millions of dollars, thereby causing the death to millions of innocent people through hunger, malnutrition, lack of adequate health care, and inflationary pries which make it impossible to provide the basic needs. Why is this not a crime?

Africa is more than its leaders and more than the political and economic interests which influence decision about her. Concern for Africa ought to be concern for the African people and for the future generations of Africans. Those who are cooperating and protecting such stolen wealth should not be protected by global public opinion which wishes to pretend that this is the way Africa does business. Perhaps there should be an international code of moral responsibility to make these cases a threat to peace and security in about the same way ethnic wars threaten peace and security of people in Somalia, Rwanda, Liberia, Kenya, and the former Yugoslavia. Retrieving these funds and returning them to the creditors would be a great economic humanitarian intervention!

Sometimes it appears like these ills are tolerated because they happen in Africa. Would the US have tolerated such financial and economic mismanagement during the re-construction of Europe after the World War II? Would US have ignored a mismanaged Europe and call it the European burden? Marginalizing and ignoring Africa in her times of crisis raises these questions because it is contrary to the ideals and the principles which the United States of America is founded upon. Various forces which shape human history and destiny have placed other regions in similar predicaments. The US reaction was not to marginalize or ignore them. They were genuinely assisted with the necessary financial requirements and the technology. And it was not just technology transfer for consumerism.

6. Developing a market which benefits Africa.

Despite many countries having achieved political independence the economic market is still designed to supply mainly stimulants like coffee, tea, cocoa and luxury delicacies like nuts, beans, tropical fruits and flowers. But again this is a case which can only improve if the governance is improved and the African people assume control of their resources and their economies. International investments are important and an open market is desired but unless once has a government which cares about its people it is difficult to see how any development model designed and carried out by an international community which comes to make profits would generate wealth for the African people. The continent is wealthy but the wealth is mined by and for the benefit of others outside the region. Of course it is her leaders who facilitate this mining of the wealth from the continent to other regions but that does not make it fair and just.

7. Poverty, poor health and sustained hunger.

Good health is essential for sustained, creative and productive work and life. Healthy individuals are resourceful and creative and have the urge to fulfill their full potential. If millions of people never have enough to eat, are undernourished and are suffering from parasitic infestations and diseases associated with mal-nutrition and poor sanitation development is bound to stagnate. Poverty, poor health and sustained hunger become a vicious endless circle of misery and want.

Notwithstanding statements at international conferences and roundtables of development agencies about agriculture, food security, farming techniques and preventive medicine, the only farming sector which receives adequate attention is that which brings in foreign exchange (coffee, tea, flowers and horticultural crops for export).

Food has of course even become a political weapon with the leaders in power keeping the key to the national granaries, disposing of the food even when their own people need it, and subsequently appealing for food from the international community. The national agricultural policies discourage local farmers and opt for cheap food in the international community.

Most of the available food is produced by women who also carry much of the burden for work done in the rural areas and at family level. But women's work is still rated low, is given low priority, prestige and compensation. Agriculture and food production in Africa is still a low priority, political statements, again notwithstanding. But again only a government that cares about its people will protect its citizens from the politics of food. And only an informed strong civil society will persuade its government not to sacrifice the local farmers at the altar of international food politics.

8. Illiteracy.

Yet another obstacle to development is illiteracy. The older generation of Illiterate people tend to overvalue education and the ability to read and write. They over trust those who can and tend to undervalue and underestimate themselves. This disadvantage puts citizens at the mercy of literate members of the community. and the state controlled media! In many countries the national radio and television are the main means of communication and are intended for public education. Unfortunately, many leaders use the national radio and television for political propaganda and personal aggrandizement. Using the radio and television to educate members of the public can only; be effected it here is a democratic and accountable government with effective check s and balances to prevent misuse of political power, privileges and the mass media.

9. Foreign languages form a communication barrier.

At independence many African States adopted foreign languages as their official languages and all official communication is conducted in those languages. Education is often equated with the ability to speak and write these languages and entry into the job market is virtually impossible without the ability to read and write in them. But only a small number of people speak and write these languages fluently and competently.

In a continent where illiteracy is very high, communication technology sparse, transport slow and inadequate, use of foreign languages marginalizes a majority of the indigenous populations and greatly reduces their capacity to pay a meaningful role.

The inability of a country to communicate effectively with itself ought to be recognized as a major obstacle to development especially at this time of communication revolution. Also the inability to communicate effectively disempowers people, kills their self-confidence and destroys creative energy. It minimizes indigenous knowledge and expertise. We should have the courage to admit that languages so highly valued in the world may not be essential for all the 1/2 billion Africans and may in fact be a bottleneck to their development. The few elites and vestiges of former colonial powers may be excused for believing that development is impossible without these languages. But so did those who believed in Greek, Latin, French, the former language of diplomats and royalty. Insisting on foreign languages for universal functional literacy marginalizes the majority of the people. At the same time, literacy, language and culture are very important in human development.

10. Traditional wisdom and culture have been ignored and even destroyed.

All human beings have their traditional culture, knowledge, wisdom, and values. These have been accumulated for thousands of years and are older than the Dead Sea Scrolls, many scriptures, masterpieces of literature and music, libraries, and modern media. They have been passed from one generation to another. This accumulated heritage directs communities in times of peace, insecurities, and in times of birth, life and death. It is their antennae into the unknown future and their reference point into their past. While some peoples have invented the art of reading and writing and have been able to record their accumulated knowledge and wisdom, others pass it through oral instructions, stories, ceremonies and customs.

People who are robbed of their heritage during occupation, enslavement and political and religious colonization, become disoriented and disempowered. They may lose self-respect and self-confidence as well as the capacity for self guidance, leadership and independent decision-making. Thus beginning a vicious cycle that may be difficult to break.

The world cannot ignore centuries of cultural adulteration of the African people through religions and mental indoctrination against their heritage. Neither can they minimize the accompanying political and economic domination and exploitation. It is important to recognize the processes through which African people have become disengaged and disempowered. Lest we perpetuate the legacy of blaming the victim.

But this must not be an excuse for the perpetual litany of woes about colonialism, slavery, and other injustices against the African people. These gross violations of the rights of the African peoples should be living examples of the many battles which we have fought and won. These are valiant examples where the power of evil was overcome by the power of good. Like the Wailing Wall of Jerusalem these processes should be symbols of the power of the human spirit. They should be a source of pride, inspiration and hope. A people less endowed would have become extinct and forgotten. When this rich heritage is used to disempower the African people it becomes a bottleneck of development when it should be the source of our empowerment.

Indeed it is empowerment for me!

I draw strength from these past triumphs. They give me reasons to fight modern injustices. They remind me of the victorious road which we have travelled and they give me strength for the journey ahead. I am always aware that I am not alone. For I am in the company of men and women whose moral strength has changed the course of history. You are such men and women. You have the ability and the capacity to change the history of Africa. And the words of Presdient Kenedy ring in my ears. "Why not?"

Thank you.


LOAD-DATE: July 11, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


199 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 4, 1994 / July 18, 1994


REMARKS TO THE WHITE HOUSE CONFERENCE ON AFRICA


LENGTH: 2854 words


 

By President Clinton, June 27, 1994

The President: Thank you very much, Mr. Vice President. Ladies and gentlemen and distinguished guests, thank you so much for participating, and thank you for your understanding of our tardiness here today and for waiting so that I could at least share a few of my thoughts on this subject.

When I became President, it seemed to me that our country really didn't have a policy toward Africa, that we had policies toward specific countries and very often we tried to do the right thing. We did have a policy toward South Africa that had been the subject of much division and then was the subject of a lot of unity after the election. But it occurred to me that we were really suffering from having paid insufficient attention to the entire continent as well as to various regions and specific countries and specific problems and certain great promise. 

And it became crystallized for me in a way in our involvement in Somalia, which I will always believe was a well-motivated and good thing to do that saved hundreds of thousand of lives, but which was presented, I think quite honestly but wrongly, to the American people as something that could be done on a purely humanitarian enterprise.

And as we dealt with that and dealt with the complexities of trying to hand over power to the United Nations mission and the question of how long was long enough; and what the U.N. could do; and what our responsibilities were as a police force, in effect, after the Pakistani comrades in arms were killed there; and dealing with all the various interpretations which could be given to those roles -- it struck me again how we needed good intentions in Africa. We needed attention to Africa. But we also needed to bring the best minds in our country and around the world together to try to learn and to grow and to develop a policy that would make some sense and really had a chance to unleash the human potential of the people of the African continent in ways that would lead to a safer and more prosperous world, a better life for them and a better life for us.

I wish very much that I had had the chance to just sit here for the last couple of days and listen to all of you. I never learn anything when I'm talking. And I know I need to learn a lot. I was so jealous when the Vice President told me he actually got to come and sit in on one of the seminar sessions and to listen to your wonderful speech, madam (Wangari Maathai), and we thank you for coming. But I assure you that I will follow the results of this conference very closely.

Africa matters to the United States. It has to matter to us. And the things we want to do, they sound so good, but we know they're hard to do -- to have sustainable development; to have reasonable population growth; stop the environmental decline; to stop the spread of AIDS; to preempt ethnic tensions before they explode into bloodbaths; to protect human rights; to integrate the spiritual -- the rich and wonderful spiritual heritage of Islam with the demands of modern states and the conflicts that must be reconciled in peaceful ways. These are not just conceptual, these are practical problems, not just for Africans but also for Americans.

For decades we viewed Africa through a Cold War prism and through the fights against apartheid. We often, I think, cared in past years more about how African nations voted in the United Nations than whether their own people had the right to vote. We supported leaders on the basis of the anti-communist or anti-apartheid rhetoric perhaps more than their actions. And often the United States, because it was a long way away and we had a lot of other problems, just simply ignored the realities of Africa.

But now the prism through which we viewed African has been shattered. In the post-Cold War and post-apartheid world, our guideposts have disappeared and it may be a very good thing if we respond in the proper way. We have a new freedom and a new responsibility to see Africa -- to see it whole, to see it in specific nations and specific problems and specific promise.

It seems to me that a lot of what we would like to see occur in Africa is what we would like to have happen everywhere. We'd like to see more prosperity and more well-functioning economies and more democracy and genuine security for people in their own borders. We'd like to see sustainable development that promotes the long-term interest of our common environment on this increasingly shrinking globe.

Africa illustrates also a central security challenge of the post-Cold War era -- not so much conflicts across national borders, but conflicts within them which can then spill over. It's not confined to Africa as you see in Europe and the effort we have made to try to contain the conflict in Bosnia even as we worked to resolve it.

The United States is presently supporting seven peacekeeping efforts in Africa. And I have issued new guidelines to help us do this work more effectively. I've already discussed Somalia, but we've had special envoys to the Sudan and Angola. We supported the Organization of African Unity's attempts to find new ways to resolve conflicts there and elsewhere.

The daily reports from Rwanda, of course, remind us of the obstacles we face. There we have provided material, financial and statistical support for the U.N. peacekeeping mission, more than $100 million in humanitarian relief. We've insisted that those who are committing genocide be brought to justice. And we supported the French decision to protect Rwandans at risk.

This action will end as soon as the United Nations is ready to deploy peacekeepers. And we will redouble our efforts to make sure we're providing all the support we can for that and to make sure it happens as soon as possible.

I'm not sure that we can fairly view what has happened in Rwanda as an aberration, but simply as the most extreme example of tensions that can destroy generations and disrupt progress and delay democracy. It seems to me that in the face of all of the tensions that are now gripping the continent, we need a new American policy based on the idea that we should help the nations of Africa identify and solve problems before they erupt. Reacting is not enough, we must examine these underlying problems.

I know one of the underlying problems, and I've been following this on the television, your meeting, is the enormity of outstanding debt. Last year we announced a policy at the G-7 meeting of writing off 50 percent or more of the debt of selected African nations that carry the heaviest debt burdens, and we will continue that. But we are actively searching for new solutions to that problem as well.

And let me just, among others, challenge all of you here who have to work within the existing federal guidelines -- and I just named our Budget Director the new Chief of Staff, and I don't want to criticize tough budget guidelines, because they help us to get the deficit down -- but one of the difficulties the United States has that a lot of our partners don't have in writing off debt is that debt, even if it is not worth very much, is required under our budget rules to be scored with a certain value. And we have to really work on that because we often find ourselves because of the mechanics of this in a position that can be quite counterproductive.

This is a problem not just in Africa but elsewhere as well. We are actively searching for new solutions to this problem. And I believe that we have to do something about it. Even though we know lightening the debt load won't solve all the problems, we can't solve a lot of the other problems unless we do it.

The long-term goal has to be sustainable development. And the statistics are pretty grim. Look at what is happening to natural resources, to population, to the gap between rich and poor. Look at what has happened to per capita income in so many countries in the decade of the 1980s.

Africans have a daunting set of challenges before them. And yet we know that they can't do what people are always urging me to do -- just pick out one thing and do it; forget about all the rest. (Laughter.) Right? You hear that before? (Laughter.) The problem is, it gives you something to say you did, but it may not solve the problem.

I was very impressed by the writings of Professor Homer Dixon, who argued that all of these fronts must be moved on at once. There is no silver bullet; there is no magic cure. It would be nice if we could just work on one or two issues, but it, unfortunately, it's not possible.

When the representatives from 170 nations meet in Cairo at the population conference in September, they will approve a plan of action that attacks this problem at its heart -- one which will eventually bolster families, improve the social and economic status of women, and provide the kinds of family planning and health services that sustainable development requires.

The United States is a proud partner in embracing this strategy, which will eventually raise living standards and enable us to raise children better throughout the globe. I hope all of you will be supportive of that endeavor.

As Africans turn away from the failed experiments of the past, they're also embracing new political freedoms. Yes, I know there are too many nations in Africa where tyranny still drowns out opposition in human rights. But as we meet today, more than a dozen Africa nations are preparing for elections. Opposition voices grow louder. Someday they'll be like me and they'll wish it weren't happening. (Laughter.) But it's a good sign. And the lights of freedom shine brighter. It's all part of it, right? (Laughter.)

I think South Africa has given a great cause for hope, not only on the African continent, but throughout the world. President Mandela spoke to you, I know, by videotape, and I thank him for that. I thank Reverend Jackson and others who worked so hard to make those elections work well there. And I think the $35 million we spent there last year in trying to prepare for and help make sure the elections came off all right was about the best expenditure of a modest amount of tax dollars that I have seen in many a year. (Laughter.)

But now the hard work begins. Governor Cuomo of New York used to have a wonderful phrase that he toted all the time. He says, you know, we campaign in poetry, but alas we must govern in prose. (Laughter.) And Nelson Mandela's long travail in prison, for the rest of us who did not have to suffer personally was an exercise in agonizingly beautiful poetry.

But now that those decades of struggle have come to fruition, they must govern in prose, and we must find prosaic, practical, meaningful ways of helping them.

We have launched a three-year, $600 million trade investment and development program, which is a beginning of that, but not be the end. And we have to do a number of other things as well. I want to ask all of you who are Americans at least when you leave here to help us to develop an American constituency for Africa that creates lasting links between our people and their peoples, and that will help to drive not only the continent ahead but will help to drive a meaningful, sustained agenda here at home.

We can do this. And maybe the most important thing I can do to work with you in the aftermath of this conference is to do whatever the President can do to develop that constituency, to explain to the American people of whatever race, region or background, why Africa matters to all of us and to our common future.

But all members here of the Congress who have participated in this, including many who have tried to have more attention drawn to Africa for years and years and years know that that is the first thing we must do in our democracy.

Let me just say one or two other things. I think it's important as we kind of wrap this up to remember that with all the problems and all the terrible things that are happening and all the economic backsliding which has occurred, there is a lot of hope in Africa, even though, for example, there are problems in Sudan, where division delays development; there is Senegal; there is Mali; there is Namibia; there is Botswana. For every Rwanda, there is Benin, Malawi, Eritrea, Ethiopia, where people are trying to draw together as a society. In spite of our continuing frustrations with Angola, we look at Mozambique reaching out for national reconciliation, looking forward to new elections.

I say this because one of the problems I always find in trying to discuss this with people who are not otherwise engaged is that they read about all these terrible problems and they think, look, we've got all we can say grace over and then some. We're trying to get you to do less, and here you try to get me to think about this. This is a conversation I have now in the White House and around in town here.

And I think it is very important, as American s have to choose whether to engage in the future of Africa, that all the things that are happening which are good and positive be known, because we can never develop a constituency for change in this country until people imagine that it will make a difference. And the level of knowledge, frankly, is pretty low, except when something really horrible happens, then it just cuts through our heart and it seems so overwhelming that we can't do anything about it.

And so that also gives you an excuse to walk away. You get the best of all worlds -- I really care about this, but lamentably there's nothing I can do.

And so I say to all of you, I will do what I can. I will never know as much as those of you who have committed your professional lives to the development of Africa; those of you who have friends and family members there; those of you who have ties of passion and history there. But I do know we need a new policy. I do know we need a policy. I do believe Africa matters to America.

I do know there are a lot of good people there leading and making good things happen. I do know there are a lot of visionaries there. And I do know my child and my grandchildren's future depends upon reconstructing the environmental and social fabric of that continent. I know that.

And so I say to you, let's build a constituency. Let's remind people there are things to hope about as well as things to fear. And let's go to work and make this the beginning, just the beginning, of a new American commitment to a better future for all our peoples.

Thank you very much. (Applause.)


LOAD-DATE: July 11, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


200 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 4, 1994 / July 18, 1994


STATEMENT AT THE OAU MEETING OF HEADS OF STATE AND GOVERNMENT


SECTION: DOSSIER


LENGTH: 2574 words


 

BY PRESIDENT NELSON MANDELA, Tunis, Tunisia, June 13, 1994

Mr. Chairman, Distinguished Heads of State and Government, Heads of Delegations, Your Excellencies, Ministers, Ambassadors and High Commissioner, Comrades, Ladies and Gentlemen.

In the distant days of antiquity, a Roman sentenced this African city to death: "Carthage must by destroyed! Carthage delenda est!"

And Carthage was destroyed. Today we wander among its ruins, only our imagination and historical records enable us to experience its magnificence. Only our African being makes it possible for us to hear the piteous cries of the victims of the vengeance of the Roman Empire.

And yet we can say this, that all human civilisation rests on foundations such as the ruins of the African city of Carthage. These architectural remains, like the pyramids of Egypt, the sculptures of the ancient kingdoms of Ghana and Mali and Benin, like the temples of Ethiopia, the Zimbabwe ruins and the rock painting s of the Kgalagadi and Namib deserts, all speak of Africa's contribution to the formation of the condition of civilisation. 

But in the end, Carthage was destroyed. During the long iterregnum, the children of Africa were carted away as slaves. Our lands became the property of other nations, our resources a source of enrichment for other peoples and our kings and queens mere servants of foreign powers.

In the end, we were held out as the outstanding example of the beneficiaries of charity, because we became the permanent victims of famine, of destructive conflicts and of the pestilences of the natural world. On our knees because history, society and nature had defeated us, we could be nothing but beggars. What the Romans had sought with the destruction of Carthage, had been achieved.

But the ancient pride of the peoples of our continent asserted itself and gave us hope in the form of giants such as Queen Regent Labotsibeni of Swaziland, Mohamed V of Morocco, Abdul Gamal Nasser of Egypt, Kwame Nkrumah of Ghana, Murtala Mohamed of Nigeria, Patrice Lumumba of Zaire, Amilcar Cabral of Guinea Bissau, Aghostino Neto of Angola, Eduardo Mondlane and Samora Machel of Mozambique, Seretse Khama of Botswana, W.E.B. Du Bois and Martin Luther King of America, Marcus Garvey of Jamaica, Albert Luthuli and Oliver Thambo of South Africa.

By their deeds, by the struggles they led, these and many other patriots said to us that neither Carthage nor Africa had been destroyed. They conveyed the message that the long interregnum of humiliation was over. It is in their honour that we stand here today. It is a tribute to their heroism that, today, we are able to address this august gathering.

The titanic effort that has brought liberation to South Africa, and ensured the total liberation of Africa, constitutes an act of redemption for the black people of the world. It is a gift of emancipation also to those who, because they were white, imposed on themselves the heavy burden of assuming the mantle of rulers of all humanity. It says to all who will listen and understand that, by ending the apartheid barbarity that was the offspring of European colonisation, Africa has, once more, contributed to the advance of human civilisation and further expanded the frontiers of liberty everywhere.

We are here today not to thank you, dear brothers and sisters, because such thanks would be misplaced among fellow-combatants -- we are here to salute and congratulate you for a most magnificent and historical victory over an inhuman system whose very name was tyranny, injustice and bigotry.

When the history of our struggle is written, it will tell a glorious tale of African solidarity, of Africans' adherence to principle. It will tell a moving story of the sacrifices that the peoples of our continent made, to ensure that that intolerable insult to human dignity, the apartheid crime against humanity, became a thing of the past. It will speak of the contributions of freedom -- whose value is as measureless as the gold beneath the soil of our country -- the contribution which all of Africa made, from the shores of the Mediterranean Sea in the north, to the confluence of the Indian and Atlantic Oceans in the north.

Africa shed her blood and surrendered the lives of her children so that all her children could be free. She gave of her limited wealth and resources so that all of Africa should be liberated. She opened her heart of hospitality and her head so full of wise counsel, so that we should emerge victorious. A million times, she put her hand to the plough that has now dug up the encrusted burden of oppression accumulated for centuries.

The total liberation of Africa from foreign and white minority rule has now been achieved. Our colleagues who have served with distinction on the OAU liberation committee have already carried out the historical task of winding up this institution, which we shall always remember as a frontline fighter for the emancipation of the people of our continent.

Finally, at this summit meeting in Tunis, we shall remove from our agenda the consideration of the question of Apartheid South Africa.

Where South Africa appears on the agenda again, let it be because we want to discuss what its contribution shall be to the making of the new African renaissance. Let it be because we want to discuss what materials it will supply for the rebuilding of the African city of Carthage.

One epoch with its historic tasks has come to an end. Surely, another must commence with its own challenges. Africa cries out for a new birth, Carthage awaits the restoration of its glory.

If freedom was the crown which the fighters of liberation sought to place on the head of mother Africa, let the upliftment, the happiness, prosperity and comfort of her children be the jewel of the crown.

There can be no dispute among us that we must bend every effort to rebuild the African economies. You, your excellencies, have discussed this matter many times and elaborated the ideas whose implementation would lead us to success.

The fundamental so what needs to be done are known to all of us. Not least among these are the need to address the reality that Africa continues to be a net exporter of capital and suffers from deteriorating terms of trade. Our capacity to be self-reliant, to find the internal resources to generate sustained development, remains very limited.

Quite correctly, we have also spent time discussing the equally complex questions that bear on the nature and quality of governance. These, too, are central to our capacity to produce the better life which our people demand and deserve. In this regard, we surely must face the matter squarely that where there is something wrong in the manner in which we govern ourselves, it must be said that the fault is not in our stars, but in ourselves that we are ill-governed.

Tribute is due to the great thinkers of our continent who have been and are trying to move all of us to understand the intimate inter-connection between the great issues of our day of peace, stability, democracy, human rights, cooperation and development.

Even as we speak, Rwanda stands out as a stern and severe rebuke that she will never know stability and peace, that she will never experience development and growth, that her children will forever be condemned to poverty and dehumanisation and that we shall for ever be knocking on somebody's door pleading for a slice of bread.

We know it is a matter of fact that we have it in ourselves as Africans to change all this. We must, in action, assert out will to do so. We must, in action, say that there is no obstacle big enough to stop us from bringing about a new African renaissance.

We are happy, Mr. Chairman, to commit South Africa to the achievement of these goals. We have entered this eminent African organisation and rejoined the African community of nations inspired by the desire to join hands with all the countries of our continent as equal partners.

It will never happen again that our country should seek to dominate another through force of arms, economic might or subversion. We are determined to remain true to the vision which you held out for South Africa as you joined the offensive to destroy the system of apartheid.

The vision you shared whit us was one of a non-racial society, whose very being would assert the ancient African values of respect for every person and commitment to the elevation of human dignity, regardless of colour or race.

What we all aimed for was a South Africa which would succeed in banishing the ethnic and national conflicts which continue to plague our continent. What we, together, hoped to see, was a new South Africa free d of conflict among its people and the violence that has taken such a heavy toll, freed of the threat of the civil strife that has turned million of people into refugees both inside and outside our countries.

We all prayed and sacrificed to bring about a South Africa that we could hold out as a true example of the democracy, equality and justice for all, which the apartheid system was constructed and intended to deny.

The vision you shared whit us was one in which we would use the resources of our country to create a society in which all our people would be emancipated from the scourges of poverty, disease, ignorance and backwardness.

The objective we all pursued was the creation of a South Africa that wool be a good neighbour and an equal partner whit all the countries of our continent, one which would use its abilities and potentialities to help advance the common struggle to secure Africa's rightful place within the world economic and political system.
