Thus must we build on the common victory of the total emancipation of Africa to obtain new successes for our continent as a whole.

Mr. Chairman: We are ready to contribute what we can to help end the genocide that is taking place in Rwanda and bring peace to that troubled sister country.

We also join the distinguished Heads of State and Government and Leaders of Delegation sin urging a speedy implementation of the OAU and UN decisions aimed at resolving the question of Western Sahara.

We extend our best wishes to the leaders and people of Angola in the fervent hope that the process of negotiations in which they are engaged will, as a matter of urgency, bring about the permanent and just peace which the people of that country so richly deserve.

Equally, we would like to express our deep-felt wish that the necessary measure will be taken by all concerned to guarantee the success of the peace processes in Mozambique and Liberia, to end the war in the Sudan and protect democracy and stability in Lesotho.

We also appeal to the world community to respond in a sensitive and generous manner to the famine that threatens the peoples of East Africa.

Mr. Chairman, our delegation is also happy to announce that we have had the honour to pay the subscription that the OAU has levied for South Africa. In addition, and as a token of the commitment of the people of our country to support Africa's peace efforts, we are glad to inform the Assembly that we have also made an additional contribution of R1 million to the OAU fund for peace.

We congratulate you, Mr. Chairman, on your election as the current chairman of the OAU and thank you, your government and people for the extraordinary welcome you have extended to us. We are indeed glad to be here because Tunisia was among the first countries on our continent to respond to our appeal for help, when we were obliged to take up arms to fight for our liberation.

We thank our brother, President Hosni Mubarak, for the outstanding work he did during his chairpersonship, including the direction of the efforts of the OAU as it helped us to deal with political violence in our country and ensure the holding of free ad fair elections.

We salute too, our Secretary-General, H.E. Salim Ahmed Salim, the OAU Secretariat, the OAU Head of Mission to South Africa, Ambassador Joe Legwaila, the Heads of State and Government and the people of our continent who helped us successfully to walk our last mile of the difficult road to freedom.

To you all, we would like to say that your sacrifices and your efforts have not been in vain. Freedom for Africa is your reward. Your actions entitled you to be saluted as the heroes and heroines of our time. On you shoulders rests the responsibility to restore to our continent its dignity.

We are certain that you will prevail over the currents that originate from the past, and ensure that the interregnum of humiliation symbolised by, among others, the destruction of Carthage, is indeed consigned to the past, never to return.

God bless Africa.

Thank you.


LOAD-DATE: July 11, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


201 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 4, 1994 / July 18, 1994


SCIENCE AND ENVIRONMENT; "THE TROUBLE WITH KARAMOJA"


BYLINE: Kyazze Simwogerere


LENGTH: 2800 words


 

THE MONITOR, June 3-7, 1994

Over 90 percent of Uganda's population lives in the rural areas, with all its negative drawbacks. Extremely low incomes, subsistence food production, disease and poverty forming a vicious cycle. In that cycle, wood fuel comes to play a very important role.

According to a 1992 study by the Forestry Department at Uganda's Ministry of Natural Resources, the estimated per capita consumption of dry wood is one tonne per year.

The effect on vegetation cover is obvious here. 

Coupled with that, is the overwhelming demand for wood fuel by the urbanites, too.

Although Uganda has a relatively small urban population (about 10 percent of total population), most of them are either civil servants or petty traders, and would never afford electricity. The Uganda Electricity Board (UEB) doubles its rates almost every six months (a unit costs about US 50 cents today)

"I know it's bad to use charcoal because it is finishing our forests," said Kyambade Coach, who works with a local consultancy firm.

"But I also know I have to cook my food on something, and I sure cannot afford electricity."

Kyambade earns Shs 36,000 per month (US $ 34) which is hardly enough to feed him. So electric powered cookers are out for him, as they are for hundreds of thousands of other town dwellers.

Their demand is met by a charcoal burning industry which is one of the fastest growing and therefore, one of the most dangerous in Uganda.

This is courting disaster, according to Otia Otim, the top government representative in Moroto.

"Maybe far off into the interior, but near the town (Moroto), the people have finished all the trees," he said. In this town, one could look 20 km across flat plains with nothing but patchy brown growth in the place of grass. And no trees at all.

This writer actually beheld a long stream of people, especially old men and women, carrying bundles of firewood to sell to towns like Masindi, Moroto and Ntungamo, in different parts of the country. These towns lie in the cattle corridor.

Karamoja equation

To Karamoja then, and its special status as the ultimate problem case in Uganda's fragile areas.

The vast plains of Karamoja, in the North East of Uganda, and its towering inhabitants cover 24,000 sq 300km from north to south, and 80 km from east to west.

With average rainfall less then 15 inches (380mm) per annum, Karamoja is the most arid region in Uganda. Yet it supports about 500,000 people and twice that, the heads of cattle.

Similar drylands, but a little more fertile, are to be found in Ankole, further down, the cattle corridor, where most of the Bantu pastoralists live.

There are some more marginal lands in the rift valley region near the border with Zaire up to near Sudan. There are also some isolated pockets in Kasese.

But Karamoja is in a class of its own.

"Our problem is water," , said an elderly man in Iriiri, Moroto District. Iriiri, where I heard this lamentations, is ironically the most fertile part of Karamoja.

At Katakwi, in neighboring Teso, I met an elderly man who tried to sell me the ekicolong (a small traditional stool favored by every Karimojong male).

He said he had sought refuge among the Itesots because his village in Nupe sub-country, had been hit by drought since June 1992.

He had a suuka (polyester cloth) draped around his shoulders and absolutely nothing else.

When they were excited (as this Mzee was when I gave him some money and he enthused Ejoku-hello), the clothes often slips and falls to the ground. No Karimojong will be in a hurry to pick it up.

This incidentally, is the distinct way of dress (or undress) among the Karimojong, and it was a rude cultural shock to me. And to know that these are also Ugandan citizens like me!.

Water is the one thing that is in extremely short supply in Karamoja. While the southern part of Uganda's cattle corridor gets some rain, and has some pretty fertile areas, Karamoja defies words to describe its harsh constitution.

The Karamoja plain is driest in the eastern part, where average rainfall dips to 380mm to form shallow, coarse, sandy soils with low humus content.

But it is lack of vegetation that really wreaks havoc on these plains.

Manyattas, no forests?

I asked Debbie, a Karimojong girl who runs a St. Phillips Christian Hostel in Moroto, why there is so little vegetation.

"Why? Look, they use it to build their Manyattas, which have a fence, huts and the roofing," she said. Manyattas are the semi-permanent enclosures where, women, children and the old stay, living fairly sedentary lives.

Debbie said her people also use a lot of wood for cooking, for warming themselves, making these stools and burning for charcoal, which they sell to townspeople.

"Here, we use a thermal generator, which works only six hours a day between 6:00 pm and midnight," she said. She added that the people must have alternative fuel, and those who provide it most have some form of income.

Because the Karimojong have an almost ritualistic reverences for cattle, everything revolves around them.

"There is nothing us the Karimojong can do without cattle, because this place is very dry, and the crops do not do well." said Andrew Kehem, a political mobiliser in Moroto.

It is not difficult to see why this is so. Cattle provide food (blood mixed with milk) skins for dress and sale, dowry and as sacrifice when the rains fail.

And the warriors, as the Karimojong are called, will fight to the death, anyone who stands between them and their herds. At least those who have cattle.

"This untenable weather forces us to move with our cattle for very long distances looking for grass and waters," Kehem said. It is not uncommon for them to move 50 km away from their Manyattas in search of water. And during droughts, they move five or six those distances to other districts, notably in Teso, Acholi and Lango, Bugisu.

Violent flare-ups are common, especially because the Karimojong's neighbours grow some crops as well as keep cattle, and the warriors dubious claim, that all the cattle they see are theirs. The Karimojong who have been to school, bitterly dispute this and claim it is a fabrication of their enemies.

The competition for grass and water has translated itself into bloody episodes which have made some parts of northern Uganda ungovernable.

In early April, for instance, Mzee Acuma, was shot dead by Karimojong warriors whom he caught stealing his cassava in Olilim, Lira district, are very far away from Karamoja. This Karimojong family fled to Lira to survive the drought.

The father of one of the warriors was fines 33 heads of cattle, but they had to be driven away from the village because of fears that the Karimojong would come and rustle them back in the still of the night.

It is after all for cattle rustling the warriors are most known around the world.

Charles Ocan, a research fellow with Centre for Basic Research, a local concern, wrote that "Cattle raids have become a serious political crisis in Uganda, affecting a population of over three million in (nine districts)."

The bulk of cattle raiding has tended to centre around...Karimojong politics," said Ocan in his paper: "Pastoral Crisis in North Eastern Uganda -- The Changing Significance of Cattle Raids."

History of Raids

Cattle raiding is not a new phenomenon in Karamoja, but the dramatic form it has taken in the last few years, has everything to do with declining fortunes of the whole of Northern Uganda.

The Karimojong have distinguished themselves as the ultimate and enduring rebels of our times because of this raiding.

Cattle raiding, the elders argue, were a form of survival response by a clan to disasters resulting from cattle diseases, famine and hazards propelled by social disruptions.

Marriage in Karamoja is one way of getting cattle and according to Kehem, "the in-laws can demand anything from 10 to 100 heads for their girl." He got nine of his 46 animals from men who married his two sisters.

Then in 1979, at the fall of dictator Idi Amin's regime, the Karimojong descended on Moroto Barracks which had the second biggest armoury of the regime. The barracks is right in the heart of Karamoja, and the huge cache of automatic rifles, explosive and tonnes of ammunition, changes cattle raiding forever.

They have over the years become the most feared gunmen in Uganda. They make up for their perennial lack of ammunition with deadly accuracy.

"The Karimojong do not waste bullets," said Debbie. "One man, one bullet is their motto."

Today, you cannot find any Karimojong rearing cattle without a gun and woe betide anyone who might want to take away the weapon.

They for instance, defied President Museveni's February 1994 ultimatum to hand over their guns or face arrest. They told him to go and make a grab for the guns -- at the peril of his soldiers. And the government backed down.

I saw hundreds of gun-toting warriors (including naked 10-year olds), all through Karamoja.

They do not shy away from using the guns to raid, either. Veterinary records in the districts of Soroti, Kumi, Mbale, Tororo and Kapchorwa indicate approximately 950,000 heads of cattle to have been raided since 1986. While the raiders could be any of many players, the Karimojong stand out more than the rest.

Sure, at the height of the insurgency in northern Uganda, both the government troops and rebels, looted and roasted hundreds of cattle.

That the Karimojong have been involved in most of these raids and this, according to an elder in Bugisu, the southern most "neighbour" has only worked to "worsen relations with neighbours. Nationality conflicts are now sharper than ever before in this region."

This has even jeopardised the safety of those Karimojong who have migrated from their region because of the persistent droughts in Moroto and Kotido.

Most of those who have settled in other areas, did because they lost their cattle to raiders, and cannot stay on a land which sustains only cattle.

The Central Government Representative of Moroto, Atia Otim, said he saw Karimojong who had settled in Amuria and Kapelebyong sub-counties, in neighbouring Teso.

"This is bound to happen more often as people look for more comfortable areas," he told me.

It is sure hard to stay in Karamoja, and live.

At the turn of 1993, the drought was so severe that many people starved to death. Moroto (one of Karamoja';s two districts) district officials showed me figures f 130 dead in Rupa sub-county, 106 more in Nudunget, and another 103 in Katikekile sub-county, high up in the mountains.

"Death from starvation is not uncommon in Karamoja," said Kehem.

"But this drought is no where near the one of 1980, or that of 1992." He is right. In 1980, it was a real catastrophic famine which hit the region, just after the 1979 devastating "war of liberation", when Tanzania invaded Uganda and toppled Idi Amin.

An estimated 50,000 died of starvation.

The Karimojong call that year "Lobulubolu" (year of empty and running stomachs). Elders told me of the famines of 1938, 1945, 1949, 1956, 1965, 1969 and 1975, but said 1980 was the ultimate test. Their worst this century, when they ate rats and residues of the local brew, "malwa".

But as Ben Okudi who did extensive research on this subject shortages in July 1978, caused by crop failures, drought and plant disease, the government made no effort to alleviate the suffering." Then Ugandan President, Godfrey Binaisa, denied knowledge of the famine until Nick Worral, a reporter for "The Observer" in London forced the Uganda leader to own up to the catastrophe.

And sadly, the same culture of silence still prevails in government, when it comes to reports of famine. While people were dying in Karamoja for instance, the Minister of Agriculture, Mrs. Victoria told Parliament in April, that there was no famine.

A local newspaper had reported a few days earlier, that people were starving in 16 of Uganda's 39 districts.

"Nobody is dying in those districts," the minister said. She said there was just some localised droughts in the areas, but ironically, she announced that government was going to aid the areas with some foodstuffs to alleviate the serious disruptions of the drought.

Reprinted from The Monitor, June 3-7, 1994.

THE MONITOR is published by The Monitor Publications Ltd. (Uganda) CONTACT: THE MONITOR, P.O. Box 12141, Kampala. Phone: 251353; fax: 251352.


LOAD-DATE: July 11, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


202 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 4, 1994 / July 18, 1994


A HILL DIES, A VOLCANO GROWS IN ITS PLACE.


BYLINE: Charles Onyango-Obbo


LENGTH: 3200 words


 

THE MONITOR, May 27-31, 1994

I graduated from Makerere University thirteen years. Since that time I have been to some of the most distinguished universities on the face of this earth in search of knowledge (though that may not always be obvious from my scribblings).

The point here being that I feel old enough and respectably knowledgeable to say what I am going to say about Makerere,

As universities come and go, present day Makerere (where by the way I also teach journalism) both amazes and depresses me. It amazes me because of in spite of nearly everything going wrong with it in the past twenty years, it has not yet collapsed in disgrace- some of its academic programmes are very well run and very brilliant students still come to us from there.

It depresses me because some of the actions of the students remind me of scenes from William Golding's Lord Of the Flies. A virtuous friend also told me the last time he visited a women's hall of residence there, he felt like he had strayed into a back street brothel. I winced, because I thought it was a bit to extreme. 

Last Tuesday the Monitor run a front page story, "Makerere Hit By Bloody Weekend Clashes." According to the story, last Saturday Lumumba (men's) Hall was celebrating Lumbox day. They took their party on a walk around the campus. In the process they trampled the Elder's platform, a "sacred" piece of the courtyard in Nkrumah Hall, and a jolly good bloody fight broke out. Injuries of various degrees were reported.

The brave Lumumbists had earlier taken their celebration to Mitchell and University halls, leaving broken pieces of glass in both places to attest to their visits.

That same Saturday students from Northcote, the most ancient and honorable hall where I resided when I was at Makerere, attacked Africa Hall which was having a ball. In a very interesting choice of weapon they sprayed pepper in the dancing hall, ruining the ball. That was the most uncivil, the Northcoters plea of justified retaliation for disparaging remarks made by the Africa hall chairperson about themselves on Capital notwithstanding. This violent and anarchic behavior has been the order of the day at Makerere in recent years.

I do not want to spend myself denouncing this violent behavior, but rather to understand it. Significantly, on the Saturday of the Northcote pepper attack on Africa, the guest of honor at the ball was Brig. Jim Muhwezi, Director General of Internal Security Organisation. About a week earlier, his counterpart, Col. Kahinda Otafiire, Director General of the External Security Organisation, once a Nkrumist, stood on the "sacred" ground on which the Nkrumah-Lumumba had been fought and spoke to the students as a guest of honor at their annual party.

Times have really changed. When I was at the university (the first two years of which were during dictator Idi Amin's fall), it was inconceivable that a soldier, let alone a head of a security organisation (however benign) would have been invited as a guest of honor to a university event.

In our time, any female who dated a solider or an intelligence officer was stigmatised as an abominable wrench. In recent years, such a female would be envied by others. Two things have drastically changed at Makerere. The students live in what in out times would have been decried as primitive conditions.

Last year I sneaked into Northcote and went to one of the rooms which I shared with another student and later lived in alone. The curtain was torn, there were two double deckers in the room- for four students. The same is true for other halls of residence, including women's. I can not imagine that you can live in a room four people and not be, at worst, mildly mentally imbalanced. I imagine one must forego certain luxuries, like entertaining visitors of the opposite sex in one's room.

Needless to say in the past years when the rooms were not crowded, if you had a room to yourself it was fairly easy to entertain. If you shared a room, it was easy to "dustpan" your roommate if you had a "visitor" because there was always some space in some other single room for him to place his or her mattress. These days it would be next to impossible to arrange alternative boarding for three roommates. I can only imagine two things happening. One, that prospective "importers" forego any "serious" entertainment of the opposite sex, or if you are "dry", to use popular jargon, you camp with your guest overnight on your portion of the decker- oblivious to what must be the profound discomfort of your roommates. This must be very dehumanising.

Even after the university took action to encourage students to eat in the dining halls recently, students still carry their breakfast, lunch and dinner out of the dining and eat it in their rooms or in the courtyard. In our time, this practice had already started, but it was limited to people who had guests in their rooms and did not want to bring them to eat in the dining.

In those days, the business of raising standards in the room- by jazzing up the food from the university kitchen over a coil in the room- had started. But I remember in Northcote, only a few rooms were known to do it. I, for one, would never understand how a university student could cook in the same tiny room he lived (and kept the electricity coil, saucepan, tomatoes and onions under the bed). Anyway, in Makerere until the latest crackdown, there were more coils and saucepans in students' rooms than books.

The effect of this has been disastrous: It means students' socialisation at the lunch and dinner tables virtually dwindling. Therefore the civilising influence of eating at the table: buttoning up your shirt or blouse, not chomping your food, not shouting and gesticulating, and asking permission before you leave others at the table, were foregone.

These are just a few examples. The net result is that the students are very tensed up, frustrated, ill-mannered, and basically have not been subject to many civilising influences.

Unfortunately, there is nothing that Makerere offers today to channel these frustrations into a creative outlet. The gymnasium is cramped and hardly functioning, the swimming pool is dry most of the time, the library is dinghy, the books have been vandalised- and the easy browsing section where one could have gone to read a "Newsweek" or "Time" magazine are not functional. And unlike in our times, students cannot escape to town to see movies on the big screen, because the cinema houses are no more. And even if they were functional, the students of today are on average poorer then ten or fifteen years ago, There is no BOOM, yet, in addition to everything else they have to buy their own toilet paper and lightbulbs!

This frustration and anger has not transformed itself into traditional student militancy and radicalism. It has degenerated into militarism.

There are historical reasons for this. It started with the fall of Idi Amin in 1979. Idi Amin's regime was very hated on campus. The army and intelligence services were considered demons.

The most fierce competition and passionate thing at the University used to be the clash between the army's and the University's basketball and boxing teams. We would go there charged, lose our head in excitement when we won, and weep when we lost. I have never, since that time, witnessed and basketball or boxing matched more charged. I remember the last basketball match in the main hall in 1079. There was a middle heavy weight fighting out between Peter Baingana, who later joined the NRA and defected as one of the Rwandese Patriotic Front attack on Rwanda on October 1990

Baingana went up against a huge soldier. The soldier hammered him hard, and he was drenched all over in blood. He refused to quit the fight as the coach implored. Wobbling, with cuts all over and a blood-drenched vest, Peter came into the third round. The soldier hit him. He remained standing. Then he attacked. He stunned the enemy with a blow. The adversary bucked into a corner. We sniffed an opportunity, jumped to our feet and bellowed "Peter go get him." And he did. At the end Peter collapsed in a heap. We won by a whisker. (Peter died in combat inside Rwanda in 1990, may his soul rest in peace).

Now, in our times, that was how we saw our relationship with the state. That we had to put up a fight against, it, and that when they allowed to come to a field, to play, we would go the extra mile to win.

Not any more, because students (and the country at large) were fed up with Amin and his brutes, the Tanzanian and Ugandan liberators who ousted him in 1979 became heroes on campus. Many politicians of the Uganda National Liberation and officers of the Uganda National Liberation Army were adored by university students.

The cause of the progressive politicians in the UNLF, like Prof. Dan Nabudere, Omwony Ojwok, Paul Wangoola, Yoweri Museveni, Ruhakana Rugunda's etc., became the cause of the student leftists. The late Brig. Oyite Ojok, became a legendary figure. It became a badge of honour to have a friend in the UNLF, or for women to date some dashing soldier.

In the article, "The UPC-nisation of the NRM" ("The Monitor, May 6-10, 1994), Makerere don Joe Oloka-Onyango wrote of his view of student politics; "student politics should be anti-institution, anti-establishment and radically student-centred and independent; ...neither the political parties, nor government, nor anybody external to the campus context had any business getting involved in student politics." If over the years this tradition had been declining, it went into a coma with the UNLF period.

With Obote II, it was clear it would not come out of the coma. The university -- students and teachers -- became split into a pro-UPC camp versus the rest. Student and university issues were no longer settled in their own right, but from the point of view of whether they were pro-UPC and anti-UPC. At that time, the most popular figure on campus (a period when UNLA and the NRA were embroiled in a war in Luwero in which UNLA was being accused of committing atrocities) was the populist late 2nd Lt. Kagata Namiti.

Last Generation

At about the time UNLF took power, the last generation of students who had passed through primary school in the period before Amin graduation. Thereafter, all the students who came to university had gone to primary school at a time when militarism, brutal military repression, and armed resistance to it, were the only form of politics. These students did not know anything else. When I was at Makerere, the most "subversive" thing was an independent-minded group of students calling themselves the "Society of Free Thinkers." Today, their equivalent are the Northcote "soldiers" in genuine military uniform. The idea and allure of intellectualism, debate, reasoned arguments has been buried.

This student-militancy-degenerated-into-militarism had its greatest moment of triumph when the NRA took power. Many NRA officers were only recently university graduates. Some of them had abandoned their studies to go to the bush to fight and returned to find their classmates still at the university. They were seen as the White knights in armour. They were romanticised, and idolised. Because scholarly rigour at the university was in decay, the intellectualism of the soldiers tempered with down-to-earth realism from the bush war, was over-powering for the students -- and most of the lecturers.

The new heroes on campus continued to be soldiers; Col. Kahinda Otafiire for one remains a favourite. Between 1986 to 1990, the now much-hated Education minister Maj. Amanya Mushega was all the rage. In many ways the collective intellectual community at the university succumbed to the intellectual might of the NRM/NRA cadres. The few truly independent-minded people, especially among the lecturers, were hounded or unnerved by constant harassment.

The one form of protest that captured the student imagination was the one that was being romanticised by the NRM/NRA and had been in vogue (and continues to be) -- a military form of confrontation. To appreciate why Otafiire is a perpetual guest of honour at student events at Makerere, and why Muhwezi was the guest of honour at the Afrostone (Africa and Livingstone) event last Saturday, one needs to see that the political norm that is entrenched at the university of the NRA variety -- of the heroic soldier riding to the rescue of beleaguered civilians.

So it was that on May 7, 1994, I returned to the great Hall, Northcote, for a Bull Roasting event.

The students were dressed mostly in NRA uniform or imitation military uniforms. It was no longer the "great Spirit Hall", but the "State of Northcote", with its gallant army.

The University authorities have banned military uniforms on campus, and the NRA Chief of Staff also announced that there should be no military uniforms worn on campus, but the Northcoters have said NO.

There is a lot of anger and militarism in Northcote. The Bull Roasting was like a break at a war front.

I could hardly comprehend the things that were being said. The speeches from the students were like military communiques.

To start with, they commissioned several officers and men for "specials studies." And the titles were very statist or military. Thus there was State Dustbinee, Attache Makerere Police Post, Commander State Brewery, State Assassin, State Conman, Chief Prisoner, Importer Scandalous Goods, Director Ballistics, Defiled Last State Virgin, Bodyguard to D.C., Director of Training. The list was about 75 titles long. Some of them are extremely funny and the product of creative minds; but of a creative military mind.

Kamuntu's Show

When the Warden, Joe Pacuto, was making a point in favour of respecting the ruling against wearing military uniforms, he had to adopt military language. Thus he told them that is a neighboring enemy state's soldiers had the same uniform as yours, it was wise to change your uniform because the enemy could infiltrate your army. You could see they understood that.

And, remarkably, guest of honour Mile Bank MD Ephraim Kamuntu, himself a Northcoter (and now Ancestor) had done his homework and really got the students very excited and enthusiastic. Warning them of the dangers of AIDS, he told of how the forces of the Great Hall fought major wars in the past and won all of them:

"We would lay ambushes in Bwaise and defeat the enemy,: he said. They roared in appreciation.

"We would attack Katanga (a slum full of prostitutes opposite Makerere) and score victory." More wild cheers. "If there were nurses from Mulago hanging about, we would capture those too." More wild cheers.

Then the clincher. "But those wars we won without either helmets or boots. In these modern wars, without helmets and boots (both references to condoms) you can't win wars." A deafening and near-hysterical applause went up.

I looked at Kamuntu, and was hopelessly impressed by his understanding of how the university student's mind had changed.

It was then that I understood what had happened; that the university had become more like a holding camp for politically dissenting military officers, than a battlefield of ideas.

I imagine the clashes with the police we saw on May 10 when students of Makerere and other higher institutions of learning who were protesting the cost-sharing proposals in the White Paper on education, must have been the skirmish before the big battle.

Thus the supreme irony; the student militants at Makerere are the ideological children of the NRM. Will it be the parent who rues the day be bore such children, or the children who will forsake the parent first? Only time will tell.

Reprinted from THE MONITOR, May 27-31, 1994.

THE MONITOR is published by The Monitor Publications Ltd. (Uganda) CONTACT: THE MONITOR, P.O. Box 12141, Kampala. Phone: 251353; fax: 251352.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


July 4, 1994 / July 18, 1994


VOLTA DAM IN DANGER


BYLINE: Kwaku Sakyi-Addo and Kofi Opare-Addo.


LENGTH: 787 words


 

THE GHANAIAN CHRONICLE, May 23-25 1994

The slow but sure dip of the operating level of the Akosombo Hydro-electric Dam may be due to more then just an erratic rainfall pattern, or overzealous consumption of electric power by rural folk newly connected to the national grid.

"Chronicle" investigators have come upon two new hydro-electric dams built and commissioned in 1993 by the not-so-friendly government of neighboring Burkina Faso, on the white Volta as one of the key reasons (Uganda)he lake. One of the main sources for the Volta river is the White Volta, called Nazimon by the predominant Mossi of Burkina Faso. 

Experts say the two dams, known as the Bagre and the Kompienga, built by financial support by France have, in effect, stalled the flow of the White Volta downstream. The Burkinabe government of Blaise Compaore had a third dam on the drawing boards to be situated on the Black Volta, or the Mouhoun, but they are yet to construct to due to lack of funds.

"Chronicle" sources in Ouagadougou and Bobo Diouallasso say the construction of the dams are not entirely without political motives. The Akosombo Dam was constructed in 1965 with a few of supplying electric power to several West African countries, including the then Upper Volta. Ghana exports electricity to Cote d'Ivoire, Togo and Benin; but the Burkina Faso waited fruitlessly for almost three decades and went ahead with its own plants when Ghana's overhead did not show up.

Analysts contend that the soured relations between Ghana and Burkina Faso following the murder of Rawlings revolutionary comrade Thomas Sankara allegedly by Compaore, prevented the development of bilateral co-operation had a common programme in hydro-electricity generation and supply.

However, not all of Volta Dam's woes can be traced to Ghana's northern neighbors. Volta River Authority (VRA) insiders say a scandalous blunder some two years ago was committed by engineers who kept the spillways open longer then required when the dam reached the maximum operating level of 278 feet (84.73 metres).

In the process, the level of the dam reportedly went down farther then it should have.

The Volta Dam is currently running at about 244.50 feet (74.52 metres), three and a half feet (1.07 metres) below its minimum operating level, leaving at risk the much-touted rural electrification programme of the Rawlings administration.

VRA officials have blamed the decline on the world's largest artificial lake to environmental and climatic factors, and to unfriendly farming practices of peasants along the river.

The lowering of the lake's level has forced Volta Aluminum Company (Valco) to shut down one of its four potlines, prompting the loss of more the 230 jobs. Valco, a smelting subsidiary of the giant Kaiser Aluminum Corporation of the United States is the largest single user of Ghana's hydro-electricity.

The Electricity Corporation of Ghana (ECG) has begun rationing power to domestic and other industrial consumers, Besides, Ghana, otherwise a net exporter of power, now imports from la Cote d'Ivoire's Compagnie Ivoirien d'Electricite (CIE).

The Akosombo Da, Africa's biggest after Egypt's Aswan Dam, pumps out more than 900 megawatts of electricity.

Given that Burkinabe are now lighting up their country and providing energy from the same water source, and there is not telling when Heaven plans to improve the climate, the future of the Volta Dam and one of Rawling's electoral aces- rural electrification- all hang in the balance.

Reprinted from The Ghanaian Chronicle, May 23-25, 1994.

The Ghanaian Chronicle is published at P.O. Box 16369, Airport-Accra. Tel: 22-77-89. Telex: 2694. Fax: 22-65-73.


LOAD-DATE: July 11, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


July 4, 1994 / July 18, 1994


AFRICAN MANATEE NOT EXTINCT IN GHANA


BYLINE: Staff Writer


LENGTH: 640 words


 

GHANAIAN CHRONICLE, May 9-11, 1994

The African Manatee, a fresh water mammal long thought to be extinct in Ghana, has been sighted at a number of locations in the Afram Plains wing of the Volta lake.

Dr. Martin A. Odei, Deputy Director-General of the centre for Scientific and Industrial Research (CSIR) said in Accra that new evidence of the existence of the Manatee, popularly known as "the sea cow", implies that the mammal; still has a home in the country although it may be a highly endangered species.

The Institute of Aquatic Biology (IAB) took delivery last month of a 260-centimeter long female Manatee captured at Gadokope in the Afram arm of the Volta lake. 

Experts at IAB have not been able to determine the exact weight of the Manatee which died only a few days after its capture and has since been embalmed for studies. They, however, think that the creature could weigh almost twice the size of a normal cow.

"We have been searching all our fresh waters for the Manatee and other mammals. What we thought was extinct all these times turned out to exist in our ecosystem" ,Dr. Odei said of the manatee.

The United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP) has been assisting the IAB with research work on marine and fresh water mammals.

It is also instrumental in the institute's survey programme on turtles, dolphins and lizards in Ghana.

Mr. Patrick Ofori-Danson, a project co-ordinator for IAB's programme, said the Manatee's natural habitat is the brackish environments around the estuaries.

"In Ghana, the Manatee's natural home should normally be within the Lower Volta area around Ada. But the recent sightings up country could be the result of the entrapment of the species in the Volta lake when the Akosombo dam was built" ,he said.

Mr. Ofori-Danson said the species is obviously endangered because it has a very rigid sexual character, reproducing only one baby once in between three and five years.

"This means that any mature Manatee we sight today is very old and may have completed this long reproductive cycle. If you shoot it, you are simply breaking the cycle" ,he added.

Using spears and traditional harpoons, local people living along the Volta in the Afram Plains are alleged to have been hunting the sea cow for domestic consumption.

Aquatic Biologists contend however, that the Manatee, a herbivore, is important for its ability to control aquatic weeds by feeding on them.

Mr. Ofori-Danson appealed to the people who come into contact with the Manatee and other rare mammals to protect rather than kill since most of them "are of greater value to us and our environment".

Reprinted from THE GHANAIAN CHRONICLE, May 9-11, 1994.

THE GHANAIAN CHRONICLE is published at P.O. Box 16369, Airport-Accra. Tel: 22-77-89. Telex: 2694. Fax: 22-65-73.


LOAD-DATE: July 11, 1994


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


July 4, 1994 / July 18, 1994


OUR AGENDA: TEXT OF THE HEAD OF STATE'S BROADCAST JUNE 12, 1994


BYLINE: General Sani Abacha


LENGTH: 1094 words


 

NEWSWATCH, June 27, 1994

On Thursday, 18th November, 1993, in my maiden national broadcast, I referred to what had become obvious to every concerned Nigerian. Our beloved country was adrift, threatened with imminent anarchy and disintegration. Some component parts of the nation threatened secession. Critical elements within the society openly invited the Armed Forces to intervene to secure the territorial integrity and sovereignty of the Nigerian state and to stem the tide of dangerous national descent into chaos and disorder.

As a result of this nation-wide concern about the state of our country and following intensive consultations with a wide range of interests, including the principal actors of the June 12th crisis, the Armed Forces, along with other patriotic Nigerians, took the initiative of devising a way forward, by forming a government of a grand national coalition. To facilitate reconciliation, this coalition comprised eminent and tested leaders from all shades of political opinion. It is therefore clear that this administration came in to perform a mission of national salvation. Fellow Nigerians, we have undertaken to lay a solid foundation for the growth of genuine democracy in our country. this is the agenda of our administration, we are determined to accomplish this historic task, firmly, objectively, decisively and with sincerity of purpose. 

Guided by mature advice from the best political insights available in the country, we considered all options that could move the nation forward. Some of the options were practical but undemocratic. Others were emotional among a vocal few but not practicable. After exhaustive appraisal of all the options. we recognized as our best choice the convention of a constitutional conference.

The Constitutional Conference is an opportunity for the duly elected representatives of all Nigerians to come together for unfettered national dialogue and discussions on a wide spectrum of issues confronting us as a nation. I have already signed into law the Decree establishing the conference. On 27th June, I shall inaugurate the Constitutional Conference. The Conference Agenda has been derived from more than one thousand memoranda received from individuals and groups from all strata of our society, across the length and breadth of this country.

Let me state categorically our firm determination to see to the successful implementation of the program towards democratization. We must warn that our pursuit of this noble objective is unequivocal and cannot be compromised. Therefore, those elements in our society engaged in acts of confrontation, sabotage, rumor-mongering, false alarms and distortion of facts must bear in mind the full consequences of their acts of disservice to the nation. They must also be prepared to face the full force of the law of the land.

This country is greater than any individual or group. No individual or group would be permitted to hold this country to ransom. We have had enough and we have seen enough. All well meaning Nigerians condemn the attempts of some individuals and groups seeking to translate their personal ambition into a national trauma. It is clear that the Constitutional Conference would afford any group or individual with genuine grievances, ample opportunity to discuss them. choosing the path of confrontation and subversion at this time of our national history would not be tolerated. Such acts would be sternly punished.

We acknowledge the interest demonstrated by the international community concerning our great nation. We know most of you are doing so with very good intentions. We urge you to continue to appreciate fully the magnitude of our problems and give support to our determination and courage to grapple with them. We indeed hope that in the true spirit of our mutual interests, you should do nothing to encourage the idle dreams of self-seeking individuals or the parochial interests of small opportunistic groups within our society who are bent on acts of destabilization under various covers.

This administration appreciates the political and economic crisis confronting us today. But, we are determined to contain and control their painful effects on our people. Indeed, the economic policies of this administration have been realistic in appraising both the depth of the crisis as well as in offering genuine short and long term solutions.

Fellow Nigerians, this Administration has a solemn responsibility to maintain the corporate existence of Nigeria. We have a responsibility to achieve this objective through the enthronement of the principle of justice, equity and fair-play. Our mission is to ensure that we establish a very enduring democratic base that will form the bed-rock for a sustainable, nationally acceptable government for our nation. We enjoin all patriotic Nigerians to participate in this great national endeavor.

Government wishes to thank all our citizens for their patience and show of understanding at this critical moment of our history. We ask all members of our society to continue to be peaceful and law abiding. This administration wishes to reassure everybody of our commitment and determination to protect all lives and properties. Long live the Federal Republic of Nigeria.

Reprinted from Newswatch, June 27, 1994.

Newswatch is published by Newswatch Communications Limited, No. 3 Billings Way, Oregun Industrial Estate, Oregun, P.M.B. 21499, Ikeja, Lagos, Nigeria.


LOAD-DATE: July 11, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


206 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 4, 1994 / July 18, 1994


THE ABIOLA SAGA


BYLINE: Wale Akin-Aina


LENGTH: 2654 words


 

NEWSWATCH, June 27, 1994

The Eleganza Sports Centre in the coarse inner city area of Epetedo, Lagos Island, had no claim to fame, until Saturday, June 11. At about 7 p.m., Moshood Abiola, unofficial winner of the annulled presidential election of June 12 last year, arrived at the decrepit premises of the centre which also houses a Lagos State Health Clinic and the Palace Club, a social club of Epetedo indigenes. His mission: to declare himself President of the Federal Republic of Nigeria and Commander-in-Chief of the Armed Forces. Abiola's action was to be the climax of the revived campaign, which started mid-last month, to claim his mandate.

In the mini-sports hall, chairs and tables, obviously borrowed from the club house, had been set up. Minutes after his arrival, word had been passed around and a crowd had formed in the sports hall, even spilling into the streets. Shouts of "M.K.O., M.K.O.," rent the air. Efforts to keep the crowd quiet so Abiola could speak repeatedly failed. Abiola himself kept appealing: "Let me talk, let me talk," but the crowd had been worked into a frenzy. In the end, Wahab Dosunmu, former minister of works and housing, and Ralph Obioha, former presidential aspirant, both close aides of Abiola, had to distribute Abiola's speech to the crowd. 

According to Dapo Adebowale, a resident of Epetedo and a school teacher: "Abiola only spoke for about five minutes. Those who were not near enough did not hear him. The public address system was not clear and the crowd did not allow him to speak, they kept shouting M.K.O., M.K.O." "Newswatch" gathered that no one actually heard Abiola declare himself president. But in his eight-page speech, Abiola declared that "from this moment, a new government of national unity is in power throughout the length and breadth of the Federal Republic of Nigeria, led by me, Bashorun M.K.O. Abiola, as president and Commander-in-Chief." He also ordered the reconvening of the National Assembly and reinstated all governors. In addition, he reinstated states assemblies and local government councils dissolved last November when Sani Abacha, a general, became head of state.

Abiola stated: "I hereby invoke the mandate bestowed upon me by my victory in the said election to call on all members of the Armed Forces and the police, the civil and public services throughout the Federal Republic of Nigeria to obey only the government of National Unity headed by me...My government of National Unity is the only legitimate constituted authority in the Federal Republic of Nigeria, as of now."

The new development was an anti-climax to the build up to June 12. Abiola had said he would be sworn in that day, "let heavens fall." "Newswatch" learnt that his declaration was actually to be followed by a swearing-in ceremony conducted by a retired judge. This did not happen. Also there were no representatives of the local and foreign news media at his purported declaration. The first time Nigerians heard the news was late Saturday night through the BBC. Both the BBC and CNN broadcast the news several times the next day. The BBC also broadcast an interview with Abiola. The venue and circumstances of the declaration were not clear. Also no copes of Abiola's declaration was made available to the press. Abiola's choice of a mini sports centre in the back streets of Lagos for his declaration remains a big puzzle. But "Newswatch" gathered that Dosunmu, a member of the Palace Club, the social club and night spot which is located inside the Eleganza Sports Centre, might perhaps have convinced Abiola to make his declaration there to escape arrest.

Throughout the week preceding Abiola's declaration, there was an immense build-up to June 12 that had raised anxiety and excitement to a critical level. Threats and counter-threats were traded between Abiola and the National Democratic Coalition, NADECO, on the one hand and government on the other. For instance, at a conference on "change and challenge on South Africa" June 8, Abiola had challenged government to arrest him. promising that he will be "sworn-in" as president by the first anniversary of the annulled election. In a press conference by the police, June 10, Nuhu Aliyu, a deputy inspector-general of police in charge of operations, warned Abiola not to form a parallel government or he would be charged for treason. The police also sealed off Moshood Abiola Crescent, where Abiola's residence is located and his campaign office, Hope '93, on Opebi Road, both in Ikeja.

By the morning of June 11, the anxiety that gripped the nation took a dip when Abiola announced that he had postponed his plans to form a parallel government by June 12. His decision, he said, was informed by letters from Reverend Abiodun Adetiloye, the Anglican archbishop, to NADECO urging them to delay for a few days. Abiola was quoted by newspapers as saying; "As a man who respect the religious beliefs of our people and based on the unanimous advice of our leaders of the NADECO, I confirm to you the postponement of the swearing-in ceremony." He promised a later date would be fixed for the ceremony.

By Saturday afternoon, however, the police had moved against Abiola. They sealed up the premises of his newspapers, the "Concord" group and "The Punch." The police claimed that arms and ammunitions were being stored in the premises of the newspaper houses.

Bola Kolawole, editor of "The Punch," who was in his office when the police moved in, was not allowed out the "The Punch" premises. Last week, Kolawole regained freedom following a suit at the Federal High Court filed by Gani Fawehinmi. The court ordered the police to vacate the premises of both newspaper houses. But the police are yet to respond to the order.

Demola Osinubi, general manager of "The Punch," told "Newswatch" last week that he did not know why government linked his paper with Abiola. Said Osinubi: Abiola has no kobo in "Punch."" According to him, former President Ibrahim Babangida also proscribed "The Punch" last year along with the "Concord," claiming that Abiola gave the paper money and newsprint. "It is a campaign of mischief," he added.

The police declared Abiola wanted also on Saturday evening. In a statement, the police said that they had uncovered "laid down plans to cause public disorder, breakdown of law and order and a plot to forcefully overthrow the federal government." They had established that Abiola's activities "enjoyed tacit support of certain foreign missions in Lagos." The police offered a N50,000 reward to anyone who helps them to arrest Abiola. Many people saw this level of price on the head of such a wealthy man as a way of ridiculing him by the police.

In reaction to the police allegation, the American embassy denied that Abiola had take refuge at the embassy in Lagos. Arlene Jacquette, information officer at the United States Information Service, the USIS, said that although the United States supports democratic process, it does not support individuals, we recognise countries." She said that the US had been consistent in this policy, adding: "A year ago, we were calling for the release of the result of the election and the installation of the winner. That is still our policy."

Jacquette said the US would not relax "sanctions (against Nigeria) unless concrete steps towards the installation of a civilian government are taken." Such steps must be broad-based and widely acceptable.

Another diplomat said that the meeting Abiola had with Congressmen in the US was purely to get Congress educated on the goings-on in Nigeria. He said that although Abiola had declared himself president, he would not get US government support because the government does not support individuals. The diplomat said that although Abiola may have his reasons for going into hiding, "it is not a good move to get support."

"Newswatch" gathered that although the police action against Abiola was approved by Aso Rock, government decided to later stop the action. Dependable "Newswatch" sources said some government officials felt that by sealing up Abiola's residence and arresting him, government might unwittingly play into the hands of Abiola who might over-dramatise his arrest to win public sympathy. Following this new line of reasoning, frantic efforts were made to get in touch with Ibrahim Coomasie, the inspector-general, to stop action. He could not be reached, so the police went ahead.

But Abiola appeared to be one step ahead of the police. Shortly after making his declaration, Abiola disappeared into the night and has not been seen since, except to be heard talking to the BBC by phone. An evidently embarrassed police force was at pains to explain how Abiola slipped through a tight security cordon. Tunji Alapini, an assistant commissioner and Lagos State police spokesman, said Abiola sneaked out of his house disguised as a woman wearing a veil in the midst of women similarly dressed. "The question of beating police security does not arise under such circumstance," Alapini said.

Aliyu dismissed Abiola's declaration, saying there was no event at the Eleganza Sports Centre in which Abiola declared himself president. According to him, the venue of declaration was close enough to the detachment of policemen at Idumota (a kilometre away), the Lion Buildings (about 500 metres) and the Force Headquarters (700 metres). Aliyu said no such ceremony with a gathering of 3,000 could have taken place without the knowledge of the police. "Newswatch" confirmed that the Sandgross police barracks is about 70 metres away from where the ceremony took place and the Adeniji Adele police station is about the same distance. Yet the police, which had been on security alert since a fortnight ago, was not at the venue of Abiola's declaration. However, the mode of Abiola's declaration and his prompt disappearance may not have attracted the attention of the police.

Abiola's Saturday night action change government plan too. "Newswatch" learnt that Abacha was, in event of a public declaration by Abiola, to declare a state of emergency and impose martial law.

Aso Rock found Abiola's action so laughable that Abacha no longer found it necessary to take that line of action. After his broadcast Sunday morning, Abacha flew to Tunis for the 30th Summit of Organisation of Africa Unity, OAU, heads of state and government, an indication that the declaration was given little importance by the government.

But last week, government alleged that large sums of money had been disbursed to thugs and miscreants by disgruntled elements in the west with instructions to attack innocent people. The statement, issued by the office of the chief of general staff, CGS, said the aim was to provoke retaliation and cause public disorder.

In his nation-wide broadcast June 12, Abacha promised that his government would keep the pledge to institute a viable democracy. He said all those with grievances should go to the constitutional conferences to iron them out. The head of state warned, however, that his government, which he maintained was invited to take over power buy the politicians themselves, would deal decisively with anyone who challenged it.

Abiola's disappearance has had a dampening effect on the renewed struggle for June 12. On Monday, June 13, there were sporadic riots in parts of Lagos and Ondo states which were promptly put under control by security forces. In Lagos, banks were not opened and shops closed down in the morning in what was initially thought to be in response to the one week protest called by the Campaign for Democracy, CD. But by Tuesday, Lagos had come alive again, which showed that people had stayed indoors out of fear rather than obedience to the call buy the CD. Pockets of protest were also reported in Ilorin, the Kwara State, and Ile-Ife, Osun State, where students f the Obafemi Awolowo University clashed with the police.

Fawehinmi told "Newswatch" last week that he does not agree with Abiola's going into hiding. Said he: "There was no cause of it. What is worth fighting for is worth dying for." Fawehinmi added that since Abiola had declared himself president, which should have been done earlier than now, he should "stick to it and fight it to the end. That is my advice to him."

Abiola's close associates are also in hiding. "Newswatch" gathered that Abiola and his advisers have been holding meetings on how to sustain the campaign. By Wednesday, it was agreed that Abiola should come out of hiding. It was also agreed that Abiola must meet the local press either last Friday or early this week. But events did not appear to have been firmed up. Bola Tinubu, a former senator and close associate of Abiola who is himself out of circulation, told "Newswatch": "We are still working on the logistics."

Last week, Kudirat, Abiola's wife, added a new twist to this new plan. She told the BBC that her husband was ill and would come out soon to speak to the press and also give himself up to the police as soon as he was well. She denied he was in hiding.

Close aides of Abiola told "Newswatch" that he is suffering from sore throat and exhaustion. "We have to wait for medical advice before he goes for the press conference, otherwise he would not be able to talk," they said.

The spate of arrests, which began the week preceding Abiola's declaration, tapered off although last week, there were reports that Sam Mbakwe, former governor of Imo State, and Ezekiel Izuogu, a key member of the defunct Social Democratic Part, SDP, were arrested.

Reprinted from Newswatch, June 27, 1994.

Newswatch is published by Newswatch Communications Limited, No. 3 Billings Way, Oregun Industrial Estate, Oregun, P.M.B. 21499, Ikeja, Lagos, Nigeria.


LOAD-DATE: July 11, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


207 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 4, 1994 / July 18, 1994


THE FORBIDDEN FRUIT


BYLINE: Dan Agbese


LENGTH: 1454 words


 

NEWSWATCH, June 13, 1994

The Nigerian soldier, the Nigerian civilian

The good Lord made them both.

The one to wear starched uniform,

The other to wear whatever catches his fancy.

The one not to be bloody,

The other to be bloody.

To the civilian, the good Lord said;

You are the political head of this territory given to your ancestors. 

You shall look after the land

You shall take care of my people who shall be your people.

Thou shalt see to the care of their welfare

Thou shalt give them water and light and roads

For their health, thou shalt give them hospitals

Their general happiness and welfare shall be thine own concern and responsibility.

Thou shalt protect those who abide by the laws from those who break the laws

Thou shalt look after my people through the instrumentality of the covenant with the people which shall be known as the constitution

By no other covenant shalt thou govern my people.

The civilian said to the good Lord:

Thy commands, Lord, shall I obey,

Even my children and my children's children.

By the book shall I abide

And by the book shall I rule my people.

To the soldier the good Lord said:

The civilian shall equip thee with starched uniform, guns, bombs and grenades and all the instruments of death

With these, thou shalt keep safe the territorial integrity of the land of your father and your forefathers and of generations to come

Thou shalt prevent the acquisition thereof of the land

By those hungry for more land

With thy weapons, thou shalt prevent from acquiring power those who shall seek the short cut to rule my people

Thou shalt take orders for the use of thy weapons from the civilian whom I have put in charge of the welfare of my people.

Then the soldier said to the Lord:

Thy order, Lord, I obey.

Then the serpent came to the soldier and the serpent asked the soldier:

Hast thou tasted the fruits of political power?

The soldier said to the serpent: No,

The good Lord hath said the fruit shalt be eaten only by the civilian who he hath put in charge of the welfare of his people

My duty is to guard the fruit not eat it

For it is forbidden that I eat the fruit thereof

Then the serpent said to the soldier:

You fool

Wilt thou allow thyself to guard the fruit and not taste it?

Wilt thou condemn thyself to carrying the gun and the bullet and the bomb waiting for an enemy?

Must thou allow thyself to guard the room when the master eateth his fill and throws thee the crumbs?

See thou not his mansions

And his expensive cars?

See thou not his privileges in every corner of the land?

See thou not his healthy bank account

Or the records waxed in his name and the chieftaincy titles bestowed on him

Or his praises sung in the press?

Must thou be denied these things

Because of thine starched uniform?

Then the serpent said to the soldier:

The civilian giveth thee the gun and the bullets and the bomb and the bayonet

Use, I sayeth to thee, what thou hast to get what thou needeth.

The soldier thought hard and remembered the story of Adam and Eve

Through Eve and the serpent man was driven out of the Garden of Eden.

The soldier said to himself:

Nigeria is not a Garden of Eden;

It is excusable for a woman to fail but for a soldier to fail, it is abomination.

Then the soldier said to himself:

With the gun how can I be wrong?

Thus it came to pass

That the soldier turned the gun and the bullets on the civilian.

Thus it came to pass that the soldier ate the fruit of political power and, finding it sweet, said to the civilian, "You cheat!"

So the civilian reminded the soldier of the good Lord's division of labor but the soldier said to the civilian:

The civilian and the soldier, the good Lord made them both and both shall eat the fruit of political power

And the civilian said to the soldier:

You desecrate your oath

And the soldier said to the civilian:

You desecrate the book.

The common-sense said to both,

Let there be compromise,

Let the soldier rule

and let the civilian rule

Let the fruit go round.

The civilian says no but yes.

So, the soldier and the civilian came to this problem:

how long shall each rule?

And which, pray, is the aberration?

Pox on the serpent?

Curse not God's creature

For the good Lord

Never intended

that the fruit shall be forbidden to some

And free to others.

And thereby hangs this tale

of the khaki and the agbada and other clothes in between and the nth constitutional conference.

Reprinted from NEWSWATCH, June 13, 1994.

NEWSWATCH is published by Newswatch Communications Ltd., No. 3 Billings Way, Oregun Industrial Estate, Oregun, P.M.B. 21499, Ikeja, Lagos, Nigeria.


LOAD-DATE: July 11, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


208 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 4, 1994 / July 18, 1994


HER VENGEFUL "MA-JUSTICE"


BYLINE: Dayo Ajigbotosho


LENGTH: 1440 words


 

TELL, June 13, 1994

Any moment from now, Newswatch Communications Limited will be locking horns with Funmilayo Oni-Okpaku, high court judge and chairman of the Miscellaneous Offences Tribunal, on a neutral ground -- the civil court. Following the four-day detention of six of its journalists by Oni-Okpaku without any formal charge about two weeks ago, Newswatch has given the go-ahead for its lawyers to commence a civil action against the tribunal chairman. Despite begin the accuser, the judge had summoned the journalists to appear before her on Friday, 27, and without much qualms ordered them to be kept in custody.

It is the second detention the magazine will be contesting in less than two months. The first which is now subject of a N15 million suit was ordered by the military government over the magazine's publication of an interview with David Mark, a retired brigadier-general. Oni-Okpaku who wielded the big stick this time had summoned Ray Ekpu, Soji Akinrinade, Mike Akpan, Wale Akin-Aina, Sam Olukoya, Tunde Asaju, Godwin Agbroko, Olu Ojewale and Abdulrazaq Mogaji. Three of the Ojewale, Agbroko, now editor of "The Week" and Mogaji were absent and so escaped detention. All nine were involved in writing the cover story of the March 7 edition of "Newswatch" titled "Exclusive Drug Scandal: The inside story." 

"Newswatch" had seized the opportunity of the celebrated case of Joe Brown Akubueze, an alleged drug baron tried by Oni-Okpaku to generally look at the happenings in the Nigeria Drug Law Enforcement Agency, NDLEA, the Miscellaneous Tribunal and the Ministry of Justice. The story reflects an allegation that the tribunal chairman had bought a Mercedez Benz 230 saloon, LA 3865 DC, impounded from a drug suspect, as well as her response when confronted with the allegation. Nevertheless, Oni-Okpaku said the story contains a false, malicious and libelous report about her as chairman of the tribunal. Beside the alleged libel, she claimed the report amounted to contempt of court since Akubueze's appeal was still pending. Oni-Okpaku who said she had notified the Nigeria Press Council, NPC, believed the publication was a calculated attempt to lower her integrity and prejudice the appeal hearing. Hence, she was unsparing in pouring her venom on them. To her, they are "men of small minds" who practice journalism fit only for the trash can. "You are not to be trusted in upholding the truth. You have behaved not like a newspaper of repute, but like an enemy of the nation out to discredit my integrity..." She railed at them on end. Exasperated by her action, Gani Fawehinmi, leading counsel for "Newswatch" took up the cudgels for his clients. He described the judge's procedure that day as most unprecedented and unusual. Apart from producing a letter by Bappah Muhammed Jama'are, former Director-General and Chief Executive of NDLEA, claiming she bought the mercedez benz car in question, Fawehinmi said the judge had only complained instead of reading out a charge. "You are the accuser and the judge this morning ," he said, adding that her conduct was a negation of section 33 (i) of the 1979 constitution restored by Decree 107 of 1993. Pointing out the impropriety of bringing the case before her, Fawehinmi said she could have allowed the justice ministry or the police to raise a charge. He claimed that everything she had done so far was "a legal nullity" and that she had allowed her personal interest to becloud her judicial oath. Since, having spoken from the bench, she could not be sued by the journalists, Fawehinmi said she should apologise to them for her tirade. Rather than an apology, Oni-Okpaku gave an order for their detention. Their counsel's application for bail was deferred.

Monday May 30, however the chairman released the journalists. In her ruling, the judge said she was in possession of a report of Federal Investigations and Intelligence Bureau, FIIB, countering Jama'are's written allegation and exonerating her. According to her, the FIIB findings say the car was disposed of the Messrs. A. O. Emoni Enterprises, by the secretary to her tribunal without her authority or that of Fulani Kwajafa, Jama'are's predecessor. No punishment, from any court, she believed, would be adequate for the journalists. So, she said, she was discharging them, "leaving you to your conscience and to the Nigeria Press Council."

But the session that day was to end in confusion as the table was turned against the judge who had sought to pillory the journalists and their counsel. In response to her ruling, Fawehinmi had complained about lack of formal charge against his clients whereupon Oni-Okpaku threatened to walk him out. Fawehinmi stood his ground, saying there was no justification for punishing his clients for four days when they had not committed any offence. And she ordered the police to walk him out. But the people overruled her. To her amazement, the spectators at the tribunal surged forward to prevent the order from being carried out. In the ensuing confusion, she fled the tribunal room.

This, in no way, placated the editors. Soji Akinrinade, Deputy Editor-in-Chief of "Newswatch", said he was baffled at Oni-Okpaku's action. In the course of investigating the story, he said, she was given the opportunity of giving her won version which was reflected in the publication. Besides, after the edition came out, she was given audience by Ekpu and Akin-Aina when she requested a meeting. Her complaint then was the fact that "Newswatch" gave more than once page to Akubueze's profile when her own judgment came after the magazine had gone to bed. And, in the following edition, the judgment was reported.

Oni-Okpaku's summons might have surprised the "Newswatch" team, but the detention did not catch them unawares. They had been put on their guard by the unusualness of fixing Friday for such summons and the fact that no formal charge was preferred. So, they prepared their minds for the worst. The Friday coincided with the sending of their response to NPC's demand for explanation based on Oni-Okpaku's complaint. However, the judge apparently did not care much about the involvement of the council to which interestingly she said she was leaving the journalists after discharging them.

If she felt any pain as a result of the experience, Akinrinade said it was form the fact that it was not the military government detaining them in such a manner now, but someone from the judiciary which is supposed to be the last hope of the common man. He wondered what would have happened to anybody of less social standing. His disillusionment was however mitigated by the behaviour of the policemen he encountered during their detention. "Now, I know some policemen can be absolutely decent and human," he said.

Reacting to the detention, Sylvester Odion-Akhaine, General Secretary of Campaign for Democracy, CD, said it was a reflection of the general decadence in the judiciary which CD hopes to tackle in a sovereign national conference. Alfred Ilenre, secretary of Ethnic Minority Rights Organisation of Africa, EMIROAD was of the same opinion. Oni-Okpaku's behaviour, he said, "was a display of emotionalism. Her tirade at the tribunal, he continued, is not expected of a high court judge no matter the provocation, because any careless statement from that sacred body (judiciary) can upset it."

Reprinted from TELL, June 13, 1994.

TELL Magazine is published by Tell Communications Limited, Textile Labour House, 10 Acme Road, P.M.B. 21749, Ikeja, Nigeria.


LOAD-DATE: July 11, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


209 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 4, 1994 / July 18, 1994


RENT BOYCOTT THREATENS THE IMPLEMENTATION OF RDP


BYLINE: Klaas Skosana


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 627 words


 

SUNDAY NATION, May 29, 1994;

The rent boycott could take another three to six months to resolve and this could place a tremendous strain on the implementation of the Reconstruction and Development Programme(RDP).

But there are as yet no immediate plans to crackdown on rent defaulters with leading community representatives, consultants and politicians arguing that any campaign to end the boycott will only succeed once legitimate local authorities are in place.

Khehla Shubane for the Wits University Centre for Policy studies told Sunday Nation this week that township residents would remain reluctant to end the boycott unless local authorities, who enjoy the necessary political legitimacy, are put into office. 

That could, however, take another six months, with local authority elections only scheduled for November this year.

According to the head of the ANC's delegation in the central Witwatersrand Metropolitan Chamber, Mathole Motshekga, the transition to democratically elected local authorities will take place in three stages- with each phase lasting at least three months.

And it is possible that rent defaulters could be convinced to begin paying once the second stage in the process, represented by the coming into existence of transitional metropolitan councils, is reached in about June.

Shubane says legislation compelling residents to pay will only be enforceable if such laws enjoy the necessary legitimacy in communities affected by the rent boycott. The capacity to act against people for defaulting on rents must be underpinned by the legitimacy of the authorities which take such action, Shubane said.

This week Housing Minister Joe Slovo warned that the RDP would be in jeopardy unless the rent boycott was ended.

The Pretoria-Witwatersrand Vereeniging (PWV) provincial legislature's ministry of housing and local government is flexing its muscles to tackle the daunting task of breaking the culture of non-payment of rents and services.

PWV Minister of Housing and Local Government Daniel Mofokeng will address the National Civic Organization (Sanco) branch meeting in Tembisa on Sunday.

This will mark the beginning of a major campaign to improve communication between local councils and residents.

People will be constantly reminded of the services and finance agreement which was signed by President Nelson Mandela and then President FW de Klerk.

The agreement provides for the writing-off of all arrears up to December 31, 1993, and the resumption of payment for rent and services.

The rent issue will receive special attention during Sanco's meeting in Tembisa today.

Reprinted from SUNDAY NATION, May 29, 1994.

SUNDAY NATION is published by New Nation Publishing Co., P.O. Box 10674, Johannesburg 2000, South Africa.


LOAD-DATE: July 11, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.

Maxwell Stamp PLC

Economic Consultants

London * Nairobi * Riyadh * Mauritius

211 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 19, 1994 / July 31, 1994


BUSINESS


LENGTH: 480 words


 

American Information Technologies (AIT) can provide computer equipment, installation, maintenance, and training services for business or individuals starting up in Africa. For additional information, contact: AIT, PO Box i510, Tucker, GA Tel: (404) 723-9200.

The following procurement opportunities in EGYPT are available to U.S. companies through the U.S. Agency for International Development. 

* Printers and Plotters for PCs. RFQ No.: 200001-124. A.I.D. Geographic Code 000 (U.S. only). Purchasing Agent: Geonex Corporation, International Operations, 8950 Ninth St., North, St. Petersburg, FL 33702. Attn: Ionia. Tel: (813) 578-0100. Bid Deadline: August 15, 1994.

LANGUAGE: English
