212 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 19, 1994 / July 31, 1994


EDUCATION/TRAVEL


LENGTH: 2187 words


 

The National Research Council announces the 1994 Resident, Cooperative, and Postdoctoral Research Associateship Programs to be conducted on behalf of federal agencies or research institutions whose 140 participating research laboratories are located throughout the United States. The program provides opportunities for PhD scientists and engineers of unusual promise and ability to perform research on problems largely of their own choosing yet compatible with the research interests of the sponsoring laboratory. Areas of interest include chemistry, earth and atmospheric sciences, engineering and applied sciences, biological, health, and behavioral science and biotechnology, mathematics, space and planetary sciences, and physics. Applications submitted directly to the National Research Council are accepted on a continuous basis throughout the year. Those postmarked no later than 15 August will be reviewed in October. Initial awards will be announced in July and November. Information on specific research opportunities and participating federal laboratories, as well as application materials, may be obtained from the Associateship Programs. 

The Collaborative Projects Program of the National Endowment for the Humanities welcomes applications for projects of broad scholarly and public significance in the humanities that entail the collaboration of two or more scholars for periods 1-3 years. All topics in the humanities are eligible. Awards usually range from $10,000 to about $150,000. The deadline is OCTOBER 15, 1994 for projects beginning no earlier than July of the next year. For application materials and further information write or call: Collaborative, Projects/Interpretive Research, Division of Research Programs, Room 318, 1100 Pennsylvania Ave., NW, Washington, DC 20506. Tel: (202) 606-8210.

The National Endowment for the Humanities Reference Materials Program supports projects to prepare reference works that will improve access to information and resources. Support is available for the creation of dictionaries, historical or linguistic atlases, encyclopedias, concordances, reference grammars, databases, textbooks, and other projects that will provide essential scholarly tools for the advancement of research or for general reference purposes. Support is also available for projects that address important issues related to the design or accessibility of reference works. The application deadline of 15 SEPTEMBER 1994 for projects beginning after 1 JULY 1995. For more information write to Reference Materials, Room 318, NEH, Washington, DC 20506.

The Re-entry Grants for African Scholars Pursuing Education Research program is designed to assist in the professional re-establishment of talented African scholars who are returning from doctoral studies abroad and have a research interest in issues related to the revitalisation and development of education in sub-Saharan Africa. All proposed projects must include and explicitly and substantial focus on female school participation as part of the set of educational issues to be examined. The proposed budget, not to exceed $25,000, any request funding for items such as a microcomputer and software, books, office supplied, living expenses, personnel assistance and local transportation. The budget may also include subsistence for on research team member of any nationality and a stipend to cover up to 6 month's transition costs for the returning African scholar. Applicants may submit research proposals prior to or within one year of returning to their Africa-based institutions. Grants are made to the scholar, but the proposal must be endorsed by the African institution where the application will be a full-time staff member. Also required are two letters of recommendation from academic supervisors at the institution where the candidate carried out doctoral study, postgraduate transcripts, and a resume. There are no deadlines for submission of proposals. For a full description of the program, write to Scholars on Education Re-Entry Program, The Rockefeller Foundation, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, New York, NY 10036 or Scholars on Education Re-Entry Program, The Rockefeller Foundation, P.O. Box 47543, Nairobi, Kenya.

The Social Science Research Council/American Council of Learned Societies is calling for proposals for their African Archives and Museums Project (AAMP). The AAMP is designed to help museums and archives in their efforts to overcome problems of funding and materials. AAMP awards two types of grants: seed grants and implementation grants. Seed grants up to $5,000 are intended to advance the conceptual and logistical development of conservation, documentation or exhibition/outreach/education projects. Implementation grants from $5,000 up to $15,000 are intended to support conservation, documentation, and exhibition/outreach/education activities. AAMP is especially receptive to projects that draw on local expertise and community resources and bring together different institutions in cooperative ventures. For more information and for a list of 1993 awards, address inquiries to the African Archives and Museums Projects, Social Science Research Council, 605 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10158. Tel: (212) 661-0280. Fax: (212) 370-7896.

Environmental Briefs Corp. is a non-profit organization that publishes a newsletter updating African environmental scientists on recent findings published in academic literature. The student intern would serve as an editorial assistant. Duties would include: reading and summarizing articles in the academic literature; going to university libraries to photocopy articles; writing letters to journal editors and article authors; and updating mailing lists. Knowledge of or familiarity with calculus, mathematical models, the earth sciences and Africa would be helpful. Computer experience (preferably in a Macintosh environment) is also a plus. While this is an unpaid internship, it will provide invaluable experience to anyone interested in a career in either international development of the environment. Please contact Catherine Camp Boyle, Environmental Briefs Corp., 22 Willowdale Road, Winchester, MA 01890.

The Population-Environment Fellows Program, sponsored by USAID and administered at the University of Michigan, sponsors fellow for two-year appointments with overseas agencies. Fellows, who must hold a graduate degree in a relevant area and demonstrated expertise a both population and environment, provide assistance and technical support for developing country institutions to foster a comprehensive approach to development. Applications are reviewed on a rolling basis, but the sooner a completed application is received, the greater the availability of sites for which it can be considered. Inquiries and application requests may be obtained by contacting: The Population-Environment Fellows Program, SPH II, Room M2240, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109-2029. Tel: (313) 747-0222. Fax: (313) 747-4947.

The University of Florida sponsors academic year abroad programs in Tanzania and Nigeria and summer programs in Uganda and Morocco. At the University of Dar es Salaam in Tanzania, students spend an academic year studying Swahili. A summer field course in tropical rain forest ecology and conservation will be offered in the Kibale Forest of Western Uganda at the Makere University Biological Field Station. A Summer Arabic Language, Conversation and Translation Program is located in Fez, Morocco. Contact: Overseas Studies, Office of International Studies and Programs, 123 Tigert Hall, University of Florida, Gainesville, FL 32611. Tel: (904) 392-5206. Fax: (904) 392-5575.

Research grants in African Rural Development Issues are offered by the Winrock International Institute for Agricultural Development. Although the fourth round of grants had a deadline of February 1, 1994, interested social scientists may contact Winrock for further information on future funding opportunities. Contact: Dirk Perthel, Winrock International, 08 B.P. 1603, Abidjan 08, Cote d'Ivoire. Phone: (225) 44-94-14. Fax: (225) 44-94-11. Their U.S. office is at 1611 N. Kent St., #600, Arlington, VA 22209. Tel: (703) 525-9430. Fax: (703) 525-1744.

University of Minnesota, Minnesota Studies in International Development (MSID) offers an academic year program of internships and field study including 5 months in Senegal or Kenya. Financial aid is available. Details are available at the Center of through: MSID, The Global Campus, University of Minnesota, 106-M Nicholson Hall, 216 Pillsbury Drive SE, Minneapolis, MN 55455-0138. Tel: (216) 625-3379.

The Center for Global Education announces a semester-long program in Namibia designed to introduce students to the central issues facing Southern Africa. Course credit may be earned. Applications and brochures are available from Center for Global Education, Augsburg College, 2211 Riverside Avenue, Minneapolis, MN 55454. Tel: (612) 330-1159.

The National Science Foundation grants Dissertation Improvement awards to support the work of African graduate students enrolled in US universities who plan to conduct dissertation research on a topic relating to a developing country problem. The grants cover only research expenses and travel costs (no tuition, fees, or living expenses). For further information, contact: Francis Li, National Science Foundation, 4201 Wilson Blvd., Room 935, Arlington, CA 22230. Tel: (703) 306-1234.

The University of Westminster offers MA/Postgraduate diplomas in Francophone African Studies. The MA in Francophone African Studies provides students with the framework within which they can study aspects of Francophone Africa, including literature, political and socio-economic issues, in the context of the relevant major debates raised by the discourses of post-colonialism. For further information and application form, please contact: Nikki Roberts, School of Languages, University of Westminster, 9-18, Euston Centre, London NW1 3ET.

The African Development Foundation (ADF) is a public enterprise established by the U.S. Congress in 1980 to support self-development initiatives by Africans. The ADF provides postgraduate and doctoral research fellowships. The deadline is August 1, 1994. Contact: The Office of Learning Dissemination, African Development Foundation, 1400 I Street, NW, Washington, DC 20005.

The Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture has a Scholars in Residence program, designed to encourage research and writing in black history and culture, to facilitate interaction among the participants and to provide for widespread dissemination of findings through lectures, publications, and the Schomburg Center Seminars. For information and application forms, write to: Scholars in Residence Program, Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, The New York Public Library, 515 Malcolm X Boulevard, New York, NY 10037-1801. Tel: 212-491-2203.

The University of Cape Town's Centre for African Studies announces the Harry Oppenheimer Research Fellowship. Applicants are considered annually in December for the following year. The fellowship is for three to six months, depending on the recipients program. Fellows receive R7500 and are expected deliver an Africa Seminar and contribute to the cultural life of the Centre. Contact: Harry Oppenheimer Institute, UCT Private Bag, 7700 Ronderbosch, University of Cape Town, South Africa. Phone: (021) 650-3273. Fax: (021) 650-3274. email: erasmus@socsci.uct.ac.za.

EMPLOYMENT


LENGTH: 4667 words


 

American Refugee Committee has the following positions available:

In Somalia: MATERNITY SERVICES COORDINATOR: based in Afmadou, southern Somalia. Responsibilities: select and train MCH maternity services staff; establish policies and procedures for the MCH Center maternity services; supervise the delivery of maternity services. Qualifications: experienced Certified Nurse Midwife; experience in a developing country preferably in a rural setting; training and supervision background. Immediate opening; 6-month commitment. $1,500/month.

In Sudan: MEDICAL DOCTOR to provide emergency relief to displaced persons in Kajo Keji County. RESPONSIBILITIES: set up emergency/acute care clinic and coordinate all in-patient and out-patient activities. REQUIREMENTS: MD with emergency/acute care experience in developing countries and proven success in implementing new programs in relief situations. 6 month commitment. $1,200-$1,600/month. Immediate opening.

FIELD COORDINATOR/LOGISTICIAN: 3 years experience in developing countries. Administration and logistical experience a must. 12 month commitment required. Salary, insurance, round-trip transportation and room and board provided. NURSE PRACTITIONER: Experience in developing countries. To assist with EPI program. 12 month commitment required. Salary, insurance, round-trip transportation and room and board provided. Resume or letter of interest to International Medical Corps, Dept. 94-008, 12233 Olympic Blvd., #280, Los Angeles, CA 90064. Fax: (310) 442-6622. 

INTERNATIONAL MEDICAL CORPS has multiple openings. Mail or fax resume or letter of interest to International Medical Corps, Dept. 93- 033, 12233 West Olympic Blvd., #280, Los Angeles, CA 90064; fax: (310) 442-6622. The following International Medical Corps positions are available in ANGOLA: **COUNTRY DIRECTOR: October 1994 start date. Prior overseas experience managing emergency/relief program with increasing levels of reponsibility required. Strong management, interpersonal and donor-relations skills required.

The INTERNATIONAL MEDICAL CORPS is seeking a SITE MANAGER for its emergency medical program in Belet Weyne, SOMALIA. Requirements include: Prior international experience, accounting, management, administrative and security experience. Assignment is for a minium of 6 months. Salary, insurance, round-trip transportation, room and board provided.

Requirements include: Prior international experience, strong teaching skills and immunization campaign implementation experience. Salary, insurance, round-trip transportation, room and board provided.

TRAUMA and/or GENERAL SURGEON - Strong trauma background, critical care casualty, emergency and triage preferred. PUBLIC HEALTH NURSE - For outreach program. 2 years experience in developing countries. OUT PATIENT DEPARTMENT NURSES - Strong trauma background. 2 years experience in developing countries.

The Center for International Private Enterprise (CIPE), an affiliate of the US Chamber of Commerce, seeks individual to assist with developing and implementing training/education programs focused on strengthening overseas business associations and their staffs' capabilities. Will conduct needs assessments; establish training objectives; select/develop courses; recruit instructors; and coordinate logistics. Will also assist with managing CIPE's grants programs for Africa. Requires related degree and 2 years of related training experience in an international setting; experience with Microsoft Word and Lotus; fluency in Russian; and the ability to travel, work with diverse constituencies and meet tight deadlines. Portuguese language skills preferred. Start $28K with excellent benefits. Send cover letter and benefits to: US Chamber of Commerce, Personnel Dept., 11615 H St., NW, Washington, DC 20062-2000.

El Taller seeks Secretary General. Experience and qualifications: Profound interest in and comprehensive knowledge of the current debate on the identity, philosophy and the (future) role of NGOs in the development process and the strategies to be followed; capable strategic thinking and planning; extensive experience in (development) education, training and curriculum development; excellent financial management and organizational skills; working experience in a multi-cultural environment; capable of combing differences to harmonious working relations: experience in fund-raising; creative personality and good team-builder; excellent communication abilities, and fluency in English, French and Spanish. For more information, contact: Sandra Kabir, El Taller, BP 137, 1002 Tunis-Belvedere, Tunisia; fax (261/1) 751.570. Deadline for applications: AUGUST 1.

Doctors of the World, a New York-based volunteer organization that provides medical and humanitarian relief to desperate populations around the world, is seeking a dynamic Executive Director to manage and develop this young and growing non-profit. As the Executive Director, you will be responsible for creating and implementing fund-raising strategies, writing proposals, and overseeing day-to-day operations including managing personnel, finances and material resources. In addition, you will recruit field staff, respond to field programs' needs and handle legal (and other) matters pertaining to overseas programs and headquarters office. Required qualifications: Master's degree in a relevant field (or equivalent work experience) and 3-5 years of solid foundation fund-raising and/or management experience. Excellent representational, public relations, communication and proposal writing skills as well as supervisory and budget monitoring experience and a commitment to the goals and development of this organization are essential. Experience working overseas, or a background in a health/medical field and a working knowledge of French and/or Spanish are desired. We offer a salary range of $50,000-$55,000 plus benefits. Qualified women and minorities are encouraged to apply. Please submit resume and cover letter to: Dr. Victoria Sharp, Executive Search Committee, DOW, 415 West 51st Street, New York, NY 10019.

InterAid International seeks a Country Director for its Kenya programs. Responsibilities include overall management and administration of country operations. individual should have international management experience preferably in East Africa; be capable of administering financial controls and budget implementation and possess excellent communication and proposal writing skills. We offer a competitive salary and benefits package. Mail or fax resume to InterAid International, 360 Mobil Avenue, Suite C210, Camarillo, CA 93010; fax 805-484-8829.

The AIDS Control and Prevention (AIDSCAP) division of Family Health International seeks a Policy/Modeling Officer to develop strategies and tools for use by policy makers, including the application of computer modeling projections to suggest the course of the epidemic. Requires PhD or MA in Public Health, Epidemiology or social sciences or equivalent years of experience and 5+ years experience working in international development programs, including field experience; ability to present information clearly in oral and written from; sensitivity to cultural differences and understanding of the political and ethical issues surround HIV infections; ability to travel internationally; French or Spanish fluency desirable. Competitive salary and excellent benefits package. Please state salary requirement in cover letter with resume to: Human Resources (MD/PMO), FHI, 2101 Wilson Blvd., Suite 700, Arlington, CA 22201.

Food for the Hungry International seeks Director of Finance to be based and FHI headquarters in Scottsdale, AZ. Will be responsible for all FHI accounting functions globally. Must be a CPA with 5-10 years experience. Previous overseas experience is desired. Must have non-profit and government accounting experience. Position will be filled by July 1994. Send resume to: Scott Allen, Director of Mobilization, Food for the Hungry International, 7807 East Greenway Road, Suite 3, Scottsdale, AZ 85260; 800-248-6437. Fax: 602-951-9035.

TechnoServe Inc. seeks a Regional Director/East Africa for Norfolk, CT headquarters. Regional Director will be responsible for: supervising and ensuring the overall quality of assigned overseas country programs; the identification and start-up of new country programs, backstopping and support services to field operations, participating on a Program Management Team to contribute to the overall management of the Program Division (goals, objectives, strategic plants). Required qualifications: 5+ years of management experience in international development, 3+ years overseas management experience. Master's degree in finance, business administration, economics or related fields/experience. Excellent oral and written communication skills in English, French desirable. Willingness to travel international (25-30%). TechnoServe Inc. seeks a qualified fund-raiser. Responsibilities; conceive, develop and implement strategy for fund-raising from foundations, corporations and religious and community organizations. Requirements: 3+ years experience in successful fund-raising from foundations, willing to travel, international background; computer literacy. Spanish desirable. EEO Employer. Send resume and salary history to: Ms. Terri Scofield, Manager of Human Resources, TechnoServe, Inc., 49 Day Street, Norfolk, CT 06854. fax: 203-838-6717.

International Action Against Hunger seeks Health Coordinator for oversight of Community Health Workers, Traditional Birth Attendants and MCH workers; oversight of EPI activities; participation in the design and implementation of training programs; contribute to the development of a community health education curriculum; surveys, monitoring and evaluation; and set-up and supervise the use of an HIS. Send resume and cover letter including date of availability and salary requirements to: Personnel Recruiter, AICF/USA, 815-15th Street NW, Suite 832, Washington, DC 20005. fax: 202-783-5247.

USAID/Mozambique seeks Project Manager. PVO Support Project makes grants to private voluntary and non-governmental organizations involved in humanitarian development assistance in Mozambique. Principal duties include responsibility for coordinating project implementation team, reviewing grant proposals, drafting grant agreements, tracking grantee financial information, and filed activity monitoring. Duties also include representing Mission on project matters to PVO/NGO community, other donors and Government of Mozambique. Position requires excellent management and administrative skills. Knowledge of USAID grant procedures would be advantageous. Portuguese language is desirable. University degree, computer skills and relevant experience required. Position open August 1994 for 2 years renewable. Competitive salary and international benefits packages. Resume to: PVO Support Project Officer, Maputo, Dept. of State, Washington, DC 20521-2330.

International public health management firm seeks an Assistant Database Manger with an interest in international development to assist with the administration and operations of a complex database. Duties include: tracking and managing shipments of AID-donated commodities; acting as liaison between JSI staff and the shipping contractor, coordinating activities among AID, the shipping contractor and JSI staff; managing all electronic data import form the shipper, and supervising other staff. Applications should be self-directed, detail-oriented, and have strong interpersonal/communication skills. Must have 2+ years professional experience. USAID knowledge a plus. We offer a flexible working environment, excellent benefits and a salary commensurate with experience. Send resumes to Magda Ruesch, John Snow, Inc., 11th Floor, 1616 N. Fort Meyer Drive, Arlington, VA 22209. NO PHONE CALLS.

CARE seeks individual to support the development of health projects around the world. Reviews and provides technical assistance to health project. Will support development of design and evaluation criteria, handle external networking of Child Survival programs and manage the portfolio management system. Qualifications: MA in public health, nutrition or related field. Lesser-developed country experience in community-based primary health care projects (3+ years). Experience in project design, implementation and evaluation. Analytical, writing and public speaking skills. Ability to work without direct supervision. Willingness to travel (33-50%) to remote areas of developing countries. Resume: Ann Magoffin, CARE, 151 Ellis Street, Atlanta, GA 30303-2439. Fax: 404-577-9418.

CARE seeks individual to supervise and coordinate the implementation of infrastructure development projects and Urban Food for Work (UFFW) activities in Mogadishu. Will plan, administer, monitor and evaluate the Mogadishu Emergency Employment Creation (MEEC)/UFFW in accordance with the program's focus. Planning responsibilities include finalizing criteria and selection of participating communities and individual infrastructure projects. Prepare quarterly schedules; develop commodity/material distribution, monitoring and reporting system to control stocks and for the disbursement of UFFW rations; direct and supervise CARE Community Extension Workers; provide direction to various personnel; handle donor funding negotiations and project reporting. Qualifications: previous experience in a Food for Work (FFW) project, good negotiating skills, demonstrated organizational capabilities, and patience. Resume: Jeannett Nance Frett, CARE, 151 Ellis Street, Atlanta, GA 30303-2439. Fax: 404-577-9418.

CARE seeks individual to provide technical assistance to CARE's SEAD projects, focusing on the areas of institutional development, management of large credit funds, rural SEAD programming, and management information systems (computer skills). Provide and/or coordinate technical training for CARE's overseas staff or counterparts in response to SEAD Unit initiative related to specific areas mentioned above. Focus on technical assistance needs which are implementation and systems oriented. Assist in evaluation programs. Improve skills of other Regional Technical Advisors. Qualifications: Graduate degree in Business, Economics or International Development with a strong emphasis on economics preferred. 5+ years experience in Small Enterprise Development work, a portion of which must have been spend in direct program management. The Biodiversity Support Program (BSP), a consortium of World Wildlife Fund (WWF), The Nature Conservancy, and the World Resources Institute, seeks individual to join WWF's office in Washington, DC. Individual will contribute to BSP's conservation of biodiversity through analysis of existing field programs in Africa, Asia/Pacific and Latin America, and will be responsible for defining, distilling and synthesizing lessons learned from selected conservation approaches, developing activities, and overseeing the effective dissemination of results. Requires: 8+ years experience in biological conservation, natural resources management, international development or related field; and demonstrated success developing and managing complex analytical projects. Master's in biological sciences, natural resources management, social sciences or related field required. PhD preferred. 2+ years work experience in developing countries. Experience with USAID desirable. Cover letter and resume to: WWF, Human Resources, Dept. 935MD, 1250 24th Street NW, Washington, DC 20037. Fax: 202-293-9211.

The Law Group works on-site and from DC to empower locally-based rights advocates and promote human rights. The SPO will develop, design, raise funds for and supervise programs to support the rule of law in developing countries, particularly the work of local human rights NGOs. Fax: 310-442-6622.

International Medical Corps seeks the following for its emergency medical program in Belet Weyne, SOMALIA: Requires: prior international experience, accounting, management, administrative and security experience. Assignment is for 6+ months. Salary, insurance, round-trip transportation, room and board provided. Submit resume or letter of interest to: IMC, Dept. 94-019, 12233 W. Olympic Blvd., #280, Los Angeles, CA 90064. Fax: 310-442-6622.

Social Sciences/Africa/African-American Studies: Assistant/Associate Professor: Full-time, tenure track position beginning Fall, 1994. PhD preferred. Send letter of application, vita, course syllabi, sample research papers of publications, and the addresses and phone numbers of three references to:: Search Committee Chair, African/African-American studies program, Anthropology,/Sociology Department, 256 AuSable Hall, Grand Valley State University, Allendale, MI 49401.

Oxfam America has employment information available. Phone the job line by dialing 617-482-1211. Follow the recorded menu prompts to dial 3 then 1, 1, and 2 for current employment opportunities. Information about previously opened jobs is available by dialing 3,3 and 2.


LOAD-DATE: July 18, 1994


LANGUAGE: English

214 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 19, 1994 / July 31, 1994


VOLUNTEER OPPORTUNITIES


LENGTH: 454 words


 

The American Medical Team for Africa (AMTA) promotes and executes educational exchange and medical training in African countries. The goal of the non-profit organization is to bring volunteer doctors, nurses and medical students together with donated supplies, and equipment to serve needs on the continent. Survey teams assess the most pressing needs in targeted countries, develop and publish training manuals in appropriate languages, hold workshops and refresher courses for doctors, nurses and specialists interested in maintenance of health care delivery systems in Africa; and distribute medical supplies and equipment donated by corporations, pharmaceutical companies, hospitals and doctors. The AMTA plans a second medical mission to Africa. For more information, contact Deman Rageh, Executive Director, The American Medical Team for Africa, 2245 Godby Road, Atlanta, GA 30349; phone (404) 766-8000; fax: (404) 767-5264. 

Private Voluntary Organization in Rosslyn needs an experienced Agribusiness/Marketing Specialist to fill a 3-year Chief of Party position in Mali. The candidate must have at least 10 years of proven experience in the field of Agribusiness, Marketing, Credit and Procurement (preferably of fruits & vegetables). Must have related job experience in developing country with hands-on experience and an MBA. Strong training skills in the areas of agribusiness and marketing required. Fluency in French/English (FSI, S-3, R03) a must. Interested candidates must submit a resume, a certification of foreign language capability, and a standard AID bio-data form. Please mail original copies to: Regina Wynn, VITA, 5th floor, Arlington, VA 22209. Tel: (703) 276-1800 or fax: (703) 2143-1865.

Global Service Corps' "Project Kenya" is a 23-day volunteer experience from August 19-September 11. The tour cost (excluding airfare) is $1600, depending on fluctuation in the Kenya shilling. Project participants will have an opportunity to learn about Kenya small-village culture and development while helping initiate biointensive garden plots and other small enterprises. The trip will include time in Nairobi, a 4-day small-village development training session at Manor House Agricultural Centre in Western Kenya, home stays with village families and side trips to nature reserves. For further information contact Global Service Corps at 415-922-5538.


LOAD-DATE: July 18, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


215 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 19, 1994 / July 31, 1994


PUBLICATIONS, MUSIC AND VIDEOS


LENGTH: 2280 words


 

Publications

Berhanu Abegaz, Essays on Ethiopian Economic Development The Making of Modern Africa. New York: Atheneum A Division of MacMillan Pubs., 1994. $76.95 (Cloth). 341 pp.

This volume of original essays provides a sober assessment of the economic consequences of the Ethiopian Revolution, 1974-91. And as such, it fills important gaps in the literature on the Ethiopian economy. Three types of papers were solicited: those dealing with the structural features of late development (modeling a peasant economy, the theoretical underpinnings of state-led and market-led development), those melding current debates in development economics with sectoral surveys (agricultural development, industrialization), and those providing microeconomic analyses of selected issues.

Aderanti Adepoju and Christine Oppong, Gender, Work and Population in Sub-Saharan Africa. Portsmouth: Heinemann, 1994. $45.00 (Cloth). 245 pp. 

Addresses gender issues and raises questions including:

* What use are manpower and agricultural surveys when women have been labeled as housewives, unpaid family workers or farmers' wives?

* How often are women invisible in official labor force statistics, when in fact their hours of economically valuable activity, maintaining family dependents, are frequently greater than those of their male counterparts.?

* How are the bearing, nursing and socializing of the next generation being combined with women's heavy work schedules?

* How do models of family relations and domestic organization need to be built in order to reflect African realities more effectively?

Ken Cole, Sustainable Development for a Democratic South Africa. East Haven: Earthscan Publications, Ltd. Inland Book Company, 1994. 247 pp.

Analyses the changes which are needed and which might result from the new political culture in post-apartheid South Africa. It discusses the policy requirements necessary for sustainabnle development and looks at how the economy, regional integration, land reform, the law, local government, NGOs, health care and AIDs prevention, education and the media will all be affected, drawing on the experience of other countries in Africa which have witnessed the transition to black majority rule.

United Nations Publications Economic Commission for Africa, Foreign Trade Statistics for Africa Direction of Trade Series A. New York: United Nations Publications, 1992. $35.00 (Paper). 165 pp.

Contains trade by country data in thousand US dollars for African countries for which data were available to the secretariat of the Commissison on tape from the UN office in Geneva and in country publications.

Europa Publications, The Middle East and Africa, 1993 39'th Edition. London: Europa Publications, Inc., 1993. $280.00 (Cloth). 988 pp.

The most comprehensive reference survey available on all of the countries in the region.

Europa Publications, Africa South of the Sahara 1994 , 23'rd Edition Regional Surveys of the World. London: Europa Publications, Inc., 1994. $310.00 (Cloth). 1012 pp.

The definitive survey and reference guide to all fothe countries of the African continent wyhich lie south of the Sahra Desert.

Monica M. Hubbard and Beverly Baer, Cities of the World: Fourth Edition/ Volume One: Africa Cumulative Indexes Volumes 1-4. Detroit: Gale Research Corporation, 1993. $79.00 (Cloth). 1066 pp.

A comilation of current information on cultural, geographical, and political conditions in the countries and cities of six continents, based on the Department of State's "Post Reports."

Human Rights Watch / Africa, Civilian Devastation: Abuses By All Parties in the War in Southern Sudan. New York: Human Rights Watch, 1994. 279 pp.

Since 1983, the civil war in southern Sudan has claimed the lives of some 1.3 million civilians as a result of targeted killings, indiscriminate fire, or starvation and disease. Both government and rebel forces are culpable as they wage war in total disregard for the welfare of civilians, violating almost every rule of war applicable in an internal armed conflict. Government forces have engaged in indiscriminate aerial bombardments, scorched earth tactics, torture, disappearance and summary executions. The two factions of the rebel Sudan People's Liberation Army have engaged in indiscriminate attacks, destruction of property, looting, and long-term sieges that starve civilians. The cumulative effect has been to turn Sudan's southern region into a permanent emergency situation where war, flood, drought, and disease have torn apart ordinary survival strategies and made millions dependent in whole or in part on international assistance.

Human Rights Watch/ Africa, Mauritania's Campaign of Terror: State Sponsored Repression of Black Africans. New York: Human Rights Watch, 1994. 156 pp.

Documents the range of human rights abuses that the black Africans have suffered in Mauritania. It shows that the most egregious violations -- such as massacres, torture, and slavery -- have been accompanied by more insidious forms of de facto discrimination against the black Africans, aimed at ensuring their marginalization from the rest of sociey and depriving them of their fundamental human rights.

Shawn McCormick, The Angolan Economy Prospects for Growth in a Postwar Environment. Washington: Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS), 1994. $8.95 (Paperback). 88 pp.

Despite the signing of an international peace accord in May 1991 and the holding of multiparty elections the following September, hopes that the Angolan economy could be rapidly rebuilt were dashed by the country's return to full-scale war. There is guarded optimism that a lasting peace for this resource-rich nation may be achievable soon. The author provides a sector-by-sector summary assessment of the historical context, present status, and future potential of Angola's oil and other resource and infrastructure.

United Nations Publication, AIDS and the Demography of Africa. New York: United Nations Publications, 1994. $37.50 (Paperback). 71 pp.

Expands upon the analyses made in the 1992 Revision of the United Nations world population estimates and projections. In considering the demographic impact of the AIDS epidemic, a more detailed evaluation of changes in the age distribution of both the population and deaths is presented. It also reviews the epidemiology of the HIV/AIDS epidemic and considers its likely social and economic impacts in sub-Saharan Africa.

Amanda Wheeler, Arms of the Magnolia. New York: Ballantine Books, 1994. 5.99, Canada 264 pp.

Joachim von Braun, Raymond F. Hopkins, and Detlev Puetz, Rajul Pandya-Lorch, IFPRI, Aid to Agriculture: Reversing the Decline. Washington: International Food Policy Research Inst., 1993.

Addresses the downward trend in agricultural development assistance and indicates why the promotion of agricultural growth remains critical for many developing countries. Identifies what needs to be done to reverse these trends.

Music

Africando Volume 2: Tierra Tradicional. Stern's Africa.

Africando is three of the finest singers from Senegal (Pape Seck, Medoune Diallo and Nicolas Menheim), first-class Latin musicians from Cuba, Puerto Rico and the Dominican Republic, the acclaimed Malian arranger Boncana Maiga get together again to produce rhythms that leap off the disc!

Francis Bebey: Mwana O. Sonodisc.

I.K.Dairo M.B.E. & His Blue Spots: Ashiko. Green Linnet Records, Inc.;

I.K. Dairo, the undisputed father of modern juju, Nigeria's exuberant folk music, returns to the world music stage with an upbeat album of percolating drums, loping guitars, deep-voiced choruses and the unexpectedly bright, warm sound of accordion.

Busi Mhlongo & Twasa: Babhemu. Stern's Africa.

Babhemu (which means "friends" in Zulu) is the debut album by the South African singer, Busi Mhlongo and her band Twasa. The songs vary in style from percolating mbaqanga-like dances to cosmopolitan soul-inflected pop. In her lyrics (in Zulu and English) as well as in her singing style, Busi expresses the hard-earned wisdom, emotional strength and hopes of her life as a South African and peripatetic emigre.

Vieux Diop: Deesso. Stern's Africa.

Etoile de Dakar Volume 2: Thiapathioly. Stern's Africa.

The music is called mbalax, from the Wolof word for rhythm, and was at its height of popularity a decade ago. Its components include the Latin dance music that was popular in West Africa for years, the contemporary rock and soul music that emanated from America, and the ancient rhythms and song-forms of the Wolof, Mandinka, Jola and Fula peoples of Senegal and Gambia.

Sam Mangwana: Rumba Music. Stern's Africa.

Sam Mangwana has been a major star of African music for 30 years, starting with the Orchestre African Fiesta in Kinshasa. This new release is a celebration of Sam's musical roots -- according to Jim Hori (The Beat, Jan. 1994), "one of the most significant releases in this veteran singer's career."

Madilu System: Sans Commentaire. Stern's Africa.

The Wassaulou Sound: Volume 2 Women of Mali. Stern's Africa.

This is lively dance music echoes the dailectic between the modern (interests such as love, marriage, keeping families together despite the disruptions of the changing world) and the traditional (in which men re-enact heroirc hunting exploits while women perform the accompaniment). The music balances electric guitars and keyboards with instruments such as the kamal ngoni (a six-string relative of the guitar), the soku (a single-string fiddle), the bolon (a small harp) and the djembe (a drum).

Thomas Mapfumo & The Blacks Unlimited: Vanhu Vatema. Stern's Africa.

Arthur Jones, Tenor & Ingrid Hansen Thompson, Pianist: Wade in the Water: Spirituals. Orbis Books.

The music listed above can be ordered from these distributors:

Green Linnet Records, Inc.

43 Beaver Brook Road

Danbury, CT 06810 USA

Orbis Books

P.O. Box 301

Maryknoll, NY 10545-0301

(914) 941-7636 x 2477

(800) 258-5838

Sonodisc

85, Rue Rondary

75015 Paris France

45-77-30-34

Stern's Africa

c/o Stern's Music

598 Broadway

New York, NY 10012 USA

(212) 925-1648

219 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 19, 1994 / July 31, 1994


ANNOUNCEMENTS


SECTION: DIRECTORY


LENGTH: 227 words


 

If you are engaged in environmental research, policy making, planning or management INTERAISE (International Environmental and Natural Information Service) may be able to help you locate and acquire environmental information about your country.

The INTERAISE documentation collection contains natural resource assessments and environmental profiles, including TFAP Reviews, UNCED National Reports, and biodiversity profiles. 

The INTERAISE Information Service, located at IIED, provides copies of these documents FREE wherever possible to bona fide requests from developing countries.

The Directory of Country Environmental Studies details the documents held by INTERAISE for each country or region of the world. For a FREE copy, or for a listing of the information held on your country, please contact the INTERAISE Information Service at: IIED, 3, Endsleigh Street, London WC1H 0DD, United Kingdom. Tel: +44 71 388 2117. Fax: +44 71 388 2117. E-mail: iiedepg@gn.apc.org.


LOAD-DATE: July 18, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


220 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 19, 1994 / July 31, 1994


TOWARD A NEW US-AFRICA RELATIONSHIP; DAILY OBSERVER


SECTION: VIEWPOINT


LENGTH: 854 words


 

June 29, 1994

It would be asking too much to expect the White House Conference on Africa, the first in recent memory, to develop the recipe for the solution to all of Africa's problems. The African continent is much too vast, diverse and complex, too far from the American mainland; and the United States is saddled with its own problems, in addition to the global problems besetting her as the world's only remaining super power.

The opportunity should nonetheless not be missed to note the particular significance of this historic conference, coming as it does at a time when the African continent is bleeding, to an extent perhaps without parallel since the Atlantic Slave Trade. From Algeria to Angola, from Liberia to Rwanda and Somalia, the continent is gripped with fear, desperation, destruction and death. All of this is in addition to the normal problems of economic decline, poverty, stagnation and backwardness that attend regimes, found throughout the continent, which persist in corruption, mismanagement and widespread human rights abuse. 

The situation is so bad that African leaders themselves seem to have no clue as to what to do about these problems; and the inertia of the international community in the face of the mounting post-Cold Ward problems makes a distinct mockery of a world which should have, since Gorbachev, been made "safe for democracy."

Even in this state of despair and pessimism, however, it is to the credit of the Economic Community of West African States (Ecowas) that their timely intervention in Liberia in August 1990 prevented, to some extent, the terrors that have consumed Rwanda. Yet, unfortunately, intransigence on the part of the warring factions persists, resulting in a stalemate in the Liberian peace process, continued sporadic killings and a delay of the elections that should usher the country into democratic civilian rule.

The capacity for reason and peace seems still to be eluding, also, warlords and leaders in Somalia, Sudan, Angola, Zaire and other places; while in other parts of the continent, AIDS, TB, etc., as well as the general economic, social and political malaise are sapping the energies, even the existence, of our people.

Anthony Lake, President Clinton's national security advisor, is right that the present and future generation of African leaders cannot go on blaming other people for Africa's problems. They must make conscientious and persistent efforts to deal with those problems, as only they can. The trouble is, all too many of our leaders and people don't want to face the reality of their problems; but rather bask in the illusion that the problems are of external origin or stem from internal "trouble makers". This is one of the reasons many in the international community throw up their hands in the face of Africa's mounting crises.

It is praiseworthy that the Clinton administration, while it could be taking much more concrete action to help us, has at least decided to discuss the problems at the highest level of government. We pray that the panelists will take their task very seriously and approach it from the broadest possible perspective. It is easy for intellectuals in the USA, who have either read much about, or visited Africa a few times, to assume that they know all the answers to all the problems. That has, unfortunately, been the failing of many a State Department, World Bank or IMF regime, resulting in a foreign policy that has made many costly, even tragic mistakes.

We hope that the White House conference will achieve some tangible results which would, among other things, help lead to a decisive end to the wars in Angola and Liberia and the resolutions of the crises in Somalia, Rwanda and Zaire. The issues of economic reform, debt and the improvement in the quality of life of the African people are also critical to the future.

It is hoped that policy proposals submitted will engender a new and enduring US-Africa relationship that will contribute substantively and wholesomely to world peace and human development.

Reprinted from the Daily Observer, June 29, 1994.

Daily Observer is published by The Observer Company (Gambia) Ltd. Contact: Daily Observer, New Town-Sait Matty Junction, Bakau, P.M.B.131, Banjul, The Gambia. Telephone:(220)496608, Fax: (220)496878


LOAD-DATE: July 18, 1994


LANGUAGE: English
