Africa News


July 19, 1994 / July 31, 1994


STATEMENT ON RWANDA CRISIS


BYLINE: Julia Taft, President of Interaction


LENGTH: 920 words


 

June 30, 1994

As members of Interaction, the nation's largest coalition of private humanitarian agencies, we are distressed by the appalling lack of action by the international community to take concerted and deliberate action to stop the killing in Rwanda; to provide expanded humanitarian assistance to the displaced, and to pursue a reconciliation process that would provide greater stability throughout Central Africa.

We call upon President Clinton to take immediate steps to provide U.S. resources and initiatives to address these concerns.

We commend the President for his stated commitment on June 27th to make Africa a major priority of his foreign policy, but we recognize, as we are sure the President does, that such a commitment has little value unless it is matched with concurrent action. 

We believe the most pressing issue facing the United States today regarding Africa is the apparent lack of policy toward the on-going genocide in Rwanda. We strongly recommend that the President exercise the moral leadership of his office in addressing the issue of genocide and in explaining to the American people why the United States must respond in the face of this enormous tragedy. Specifically, we urge the President to do the following:

* provide immediate logistical and financial support for an African peacekeeping force whose mission is to protect civilians and to stop the killing. One example of our concern: dozens of U.S. armored vehicles, which could have been operational weeks ago, have not been deployed to the region. These vehicles are vital if the international community is to succeed in replacing French peacekeepers with an African peacekeeping force.

* expand humanitarian assistance to hundreds of thousands of civilians now living in camps inside Rwanda and in neighboring countries. We call on the President to join leaders of U.S. humanitarian aid groups in urging the American people to support efforts to provide food and medical supplies to Rwandan refugees. The refugee crisis is not over. The United States should play an active role in making contingency plans to address the potential needs of as many as 700,000 additional displacements in the near future.

* recommend to the U.N. Security Council that radio broadcasts encouraging the slaughter of civilians be stopped. Radio transmissions controlled by supporters of genocide continue to incite violence in Central Africa. Reports in recent days indicate that a new radio station is broadcasting into Burundi and Tanzania seeking to inflame ethnic tensions. The United States and the United Nations should take immediate action to shut down such broadcasts.

* acknowledge that the killing of several hundred thousand Rwandans is the result of a planned, systematic genocide. As a signatory to the Genocide Convention, the United States is obligated to work with other nations to identify and bring to justice those who have planned and carried out these plans. The President should support efforts in the United Nations calling on the U.N. Commission on Human Rights to fulfill its mandate in investigating these crimes.

* support reconciliation efforts throughout Central Africa. The President should lend his political and diplomatic support for regional negotiations among Central African leaders to prevent additional ethnic conflicts and to provide greater stability in the region.

The following Interaction agencies urge the President to take these steps:

Africare

Baptist World Alliance

Catholic Relief Services

Center of Concern

International Rescue Committee

Lutheran World Relief

Mercy Corps International

Operation USA

Refugees International

U.S. Catholic Conference

U.S. Committee for Refugees

Women's Commission for Refugee Women and Children

World Concern

World Vision For more information about how Interaction agencies are responding to the crisis, contact Mike Kiernan at Interaction at 202-667-8227.


LOAD-DATE: July 18, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


222 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 19, 1994 / July 31, 1994


STATEMENT ON RWANDA


BYLINE: Congressman Donald M. Payne


LENGTH: 547 words


 

JUNE 30, 1994

As the Chair of the Congressional Black Caucus Task Force on Foreign Affairs I am pleased to join InterAction in urging greater Administration support for stopping the genocide in Rwanda.

Like the Congressional Black Caucus, the voluntary humanitarian organizations that belong to InterAction make up the conscience of America.

Rene Degni-Segui, UN Human Rights Investigator, just returned from Rwanda and in his preliminary report said, "hundreds of thousands of Tutsis and moderate Hutus have been killed in Rwanda." I repeat, he "hundreds of thousands." 

The UN Human Rights Investigator, the distinguished Dean of the Law School in Abidjan has confirmed what the world feared, that genocide had happened. For all those disbelievers who thought this could "never happen again," it did, and right under our eyes. There is no excuse for our country or the international community to be late in responding.

Two days ago I met with the Secretary General of the OAU, Mr. Salim Admed Salim, who expressed great frustration in successfully enlisting eight African countries to volunteer troops, only to not be supported by the US and other Western countries in guaranteeing the necessary funds and logistical support to immediately send them into Rwanda.

The United States did promise 50 armored personnel carriers to be in place weeks ago, but as of this date only 30 have arrived in Uganda and they still are not in use.

United Nations Assistance Mission for Rwanda (UNAMIR) Officers are exasperated at how little response there has been to calls for reinforcements when the French Operation Turquoise was able to take place so rapidly,.

On May 4th the Congressional Black Caucus sent a letter to President Clinton urging him to see that the United States gives aggressive and positive leadership through the UN Security Council to immediately address the problems in Rwanda. Much to our dismay our UN Representative, Madeleine Albright, has done the opposite; participating in one stalling maneuver after another.

The respected OXFAM/UK has actually accused the United States of being responsible for much of the slaughter due to our "stalling" actions. After a series of setbacks on US policy for Africa, this was the major reason for the lack of meaningful participation in the recent White House Conference on Africa. These concerns were conveyed to President Clinton in a second letter of June 16, 1994. We are still waiting for a written reply to both letters.

However, we are encouraged by this show of support for our position demonstrated by the presence of the many US humanitarian agencies today.


LOAD-DATE: July 18, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


223 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 19, 1994 / July 31, 1994


STATEMENT BY MOST REV. DESMOND TUTU, ARCHBISHOP OF CAPE TOWN AND PRESIDENT OF THE ALL AFRICA CONFERENCE OF CHURCHES (AACC) FOLLOWING HIS VISIT TO LIBERIA JULY 4-6, 1994.


LENGTH: 934 words


 

July 6, 1994

We came to this beautiful, but tragic country at the invitation of the Liberian Council of Churches (LCC) and the Carter Centre. Our visit was not intended to offer an infallible blueprint for peace and reconciliation, but to hear from a wide range of people and to be sensitive to what has happened and what might occur in the future.

We also commend all those Liberians and others who have made contributions to efforts for peace and reconciliation, especially our brother Rev. Canaan Danana of Zimbabwe and the Organization of African Unity (OAU) and Mr. Trevor Gordon-Somers, the special representative of the UN Secretary General.

We commend the work of the Economic Community of West African States (Ecowas) and the United Nations Observer Mission in Liberia (UNOMIL) within their respective mandates. 

We commend our brothers and sisters in Liberia's religious communities for their tireless attempts to bring about the peace Liberians yearn for, especially the LCC and the Interfaith Mediation Committee of Liberia. We thank the Carter Centre for its support and assistance.

We were graciously received by his excellency David D. Kpomakpor, Chairman of the Council of State of the Liberian National Transitional Government (LNTG) and the four other members of the council of state. We also met with the following leaders of carious factions:

-- Armed Forces of Liberia (AFL), General Hezekiah Bowen;

-- Liberia Peace Council (LPC), Dr. George Boley;

-- LOFA Defense Force (LDF), Mr. Francois Massaquoi;

-- National Patriotic Front of Liberia (NPFL), Mr. Charles Taylor;

-- United Liberation Movement for Democracy in Liberia (ULIMO),

General Roosevelt Johnson.

We also met with a wide range of diplomatic, political, government, church, non-governmental and peace and reconciliation representatives.

We are grateful for the frank exchange of views and information and wish to commend all Liberians for their resilience and fortitude in the face of the on-going nightmare that their country has become.

We are heartened by the desire of everyone we met for immediate peace and an end to violence. Without exception all people we spoke with expressed a commitment to peace and we are deeply impressed by those words and the willingness to allow Liberians the right to choose freely who will govern them.

We received, in the presence of the Chairman of the Council of State who accompanied us to Gbarnga, a special commitment from Mr. Taylor for an immediate ceasefire, a person-to-person meeting with Mr. Kpomakpor as soon as possible to discuss urgent matters of state and a commitment to a "summit" meeting in the near future with all factional leaders.

We are gratified that, after speaking with all the key persons in the Liberian conflict, a consensus exists on the need for an immediate ceasefire and full disarmament.

We drew heavily; on our South African experience as an important example for Liberia:

-- An apparently intractable situation can be resolved when people have the will and the hope that Liberians seem to have;

-- When a country like South Africa, which could be splintering for many reasons can come together into one nation, then peace and reconciliation can be achieved in Liberia.

We call on all nations supplying arms to warring factions to desist. Without arms, the war is more difficult to prosecute.

We have assured the LCC, the religious community, the Carter Centre and the various groups with whom we spoke that the AACC stands ready to continue this process and, if desired, the AACC's General Secretary, Rev. Jose Chipenda, will contact the LCC about the most useful way to follow up on our visit.

We reiterate today the message we have given several times at very moving and crowded worship services in various parts of the country and in all our meetings:

-- There is hope, there is an end to the nightmare;

-- God has not forgotten Liberia: God will use human hands to

bring peace, reconciliation, justice and prosperity to your

land.

Be assured of our constant prayers for Liberia and our fervent belief that peace will come to this beloved land.


LOAD-DATE: July 18, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


224 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 19, 1994 / July 31, 1994


REMARKS AT THE WHITE HOUSE CONFERENCE ON AFRICA


BYLINE: Tony Lake, National Security Advisor


LENGTH: 2427 words


 

A very warm welcome to the White House conference on Africa. I can't tell you what pleasure it gives me to say those words. (Laughter.) I think this is the first such gathering of regional experts ever sponsored by the White House. And I am particularly pleased and excited that our focus is on Africa. In fact, I've heard an ugly rumor around that the choice of topics might have something to do with my own personal prejudices. And I want to tell you that ugly rumor is absolutely true.

As I said, this is our first effort in drawing together a group like this in seeking a very wide range of views. So I hope you won't hesitate to tall us at the end of the conference where we went right and where we went wrong, and that you won't keep your opinions to yourselves. And somehow I'm not worried on either score, looking out on you. 

All of us are reminded that we live in exciting and very uncertain times. The Cold War is history; democracy is on the march around the world; technology and commerce are drawing us closer together. And this exciting new world challenges us to think and act anew. And that's why it's so important that you are here. As I was saying to Jim Grant just now, none of us in such a new world which does so challenge our thinking should let slip any opportunity to plagiarize. And I look forward to our plagiarizing your ideas in the coming weeks and months and even years ahead of us.

Africa, like the rest of the world, captures our attention and emotions as rarely ever before. Nations consumes by conflict live side by side with those struggling quietly for success. Headlines speak one day of ethnic massacres and the next day of democracy's advances. The terrible problems of African nations and the pessimism they can breed are matched only in scope by the Continent's huge potential. In recent months, events in South Africa and Rwanda have starkly illustrated those contradictions, and offered sharply different pictures of Africa's future.

Had anyone of us come before a group like this half a decade ago and predicted what would happen in South Africa, we would've laughed him or her right off of the podium. But Nelson Mandela is the elected leader of a free South Africa, and we live in a post-apartheid world. And whenever we feel overwhelmed by the troubles that face Africa, we should remind ourselves of those wonderful pictures of South Africans standing in line, waiting for hours and days to cast their votes in free and fair elections. And then we should repeat to ourselves that magic phrase, "President Mandela." Just think about it.

While south Africa's citizens have proved that political courage and personal will can triumph over the habits of history, recent evidence from Rwanda tells a much different story. It's a story of ethnic hatred transformed into genocide, the story of unspeakable physical horror, of generations and families lost to rifles and machetes. It's a test case of one of the great security challenges of the post- Cold War era. Conflicts within rather then among nations. And it's a warning of what can happen if African nations and all of us do too little to stop simmering conflicts before they boil over.

The examples of South African Rwanda illustrates why our administration cares so deeply about African affairs and why we have committed ourselves to stronger ties with Africa. We care about Africa because of the great potential of its people., its traditions and its resources. And we care because of the historical ties that bind our two people together. And we care because of the great global challenges of tomorrow are reflected in Africa today

So for most Americans, Africa is a place of which we care. Who would not? When we read the newspaper account a few days ago of a Rwandan women, separated from her husband and children, waiting in a church for either the next visit of the murderers who were coming from time to time to pluck their next victims from the group she was in, or for her deliverance.

But caring is not enough. Care must be translated into conceptual charity, about the nature of the problems that Africa faces, and then care must be translated into practical action.

And that begins, unhappily, with the sober appreciation of the limitations that we face and must overcome. Shrinking budgets that will prevent large new infusions of funds. An American people unsure of when or where on earth they want their nation to get involved. A United Nations that is stretched to its capacities.

In a sometimes overwhelming feeling of pessimism, borne of a decade of African economic decline in African per capita income of about two percent per year. But we are engaged in Africa and we will move forward.

In support of security on the Continent, we have engaged in active diplomacy to help reserve internal conflicts, including sending presidential special envoys to work on the crises in Angola and in Sudan and in Somalia. We've supported seven peacekeeping efforts in Africa,, from Mozambique to Liberia, from Angola to Rwanda, giving the people of those nations the breathing space they need to try to rebuild their societies.

In Somalia, the efforts of the American soldiers and of our relief agencies helped save hundreds of thousands of Somali lives. We're supporting the OAU's conflict resolution mechanism which will identify and address potential conflicts before they explode. We've launched new programs to support the flourishing of democracy on a continent which has seen half its nation's take bold or tentative steps in that direction in the past few years.

Throughout Africa also, we have left no doubt in the minds of autocratic leaders that we insist on a rapid transition to democracy, return to civilian rule and respect for human rights. To pursue the goal of sustainable development, we're maintaining current levels of development assistance, despite serious cuts in foreign aid budgets elsewhere. We're providing broad relief to African nations burdened by crushing debt, and we intend to do more. We have been steadfast in our support for the wonderful historic change in South Africa through election support and through a post-election package of trade and investment and development policies.

These efforts are a beginning. But there are opportunities to do more to assist sustainable development, conflict resolution and the promotion of democracy and human rights. We hope that your efforts over the next few days will provide fresh thinking and a deepening public-private partnership that will allow us to seize those opportunities.

For their part, the next generation of African leaders faces limitations and challenges that dwarf, of course, our own. But they, too, must look forward beyond the tendency to blame all their problems on the very real legacy of colonial domination. Instead, they must take responsibility for the tough steps that sustainable development and democracy require.

So over the next two days, we will be discussing a wide range of the challenges that African nations are facing and the decisions that the United States faces in conducting its relations with the continent. We will hear from President Clinton, from Vice President Gore and from Secretary Christopher. But most of the hard work, of course, will be done in the conference's six working groups into which you have been divided. And let me take a few minutes, if I may now, to describe those groups.

The first working group will address the issue of sustainable development, and will be chaired by C. Payne Lucas of Africare and Elliott Berg of Developmental Alternatives. The nexus of economic and political and social and environmental challenges facing African can lead on e to a sense of "Afro-pessimism," as Robert Kaplan has observed in his article, pessimistic enough, "The Coming Anarchy." This group will consider how we can simultaneously address these challenges and create a synergy that can stimulate development, resurrect societies and build hope.

A second group, chaired by Richard Joseph of the Carter Center and Pauline Baker of the Aspen Institute, will address the challenge of supporting democracy and promoting human rights. The group will address how the United States can support the revolution of democracy sweeping the Continent on center stage in South Africa, but in quieter and no less dramatic, present also in countries like Malawi and Benin and Niger and Mali. It will also explore how we can best support the creation of a culture of tolerance, a flowering of civil society and the protection of human dignity throughout the Continent.

The phenomenon of societies ripping themselves apart from Rwanda and Sudan to Somalia and Liberia is neither new nor unique to Africa. But it has taken on a new urgency in recent years. A third group chaired by Francis Deng of the Brookings Institution and Hank Cohen of the Global Coalition for Africa will consider the proper international response to these crises, including diplomacy, conflict resolution, humanitarian assistance, and peacekeeping. It'll address the roles for the United Nations, for the OAU, for European nations and for our own efforts, and consider ways of the often slow and tortuous, cumbersome international response to these crises.

A fourth group will address a wide range of global issues facing Africa along, of course, with the rest of the world. These issues range from refugee flows to capacity building for education, from combating crime and corruption to the fight against AIDS. From insuring the full participation of women in society to incorporating modern technology into the life of the Continent.

Vivian Lowery Derryck of the African American Institute and Don McHenry from Georgetown will chair this group, which certainly has its work cut out for it.

Too often, we think of Africa only in terms of the problems to be overcome rather than the mutual benefits that can be derived. A fifth panel addresses business relationships with Africa, chaired by Percy Wilson of the Corporate Council on Africa, and Stephen Lewis of Carleton College. It will consider how we can expand trade and investment links to Africa, how these links can support African development, and the relationship between our government and the private sector.

Central to all of these efforts will be the strengthening of the American constituency for Africa. At a time of renewed interest in Africa, where the exhilaration in South Africa and the horrors in Rwanda I spoke about earlier have produced more front-page stories about Africa than at any time in my memory, it"s incumbent on all of us who care deeply about the Continent to translate this caring and this interest into a tangible commitment. The chairs for this panel will be Charlayne Hunter-Gault of PBS, Ben Chavis of the NAACP, and Michael Clough of the Council on Foreign Relations.

These are all difficult and long-term challenges. And it would be foolish to expect or even to seek consensus from this conference on all of these issues. But the tremendous experience and commitment and intellect of the people in this room, applied exclusively to the African issues for the next two days, is an important milepost in our efforts.

I thank you for your willingness to take time from your very busy schedules to participate in this stage of our national dialogue on the future of Africa and our policies towards Africa.

As we proceed, none of us, I'm sure, will underestimate the magnitude of the problems that confront so many African nations. But again, I urge you not to let the recitation of these problems blind you to Africa's potential.

Anyone who knows the peoples of Africa as well as you knows the particular combination of greatness and power that dwells across their continent. It's the greatness and power that dwells across their continent. It's the greatness of natural beauty and the power of untapped resources. It's the greatness of diverse and rich cultures and the power of talented peoples striving for a better future. That greatness, that power, is reflected in Africa's future. That greatness, that power, is reflected in Africa's progress towards democracy and reform, and offers a solid evidence that a brighter African future is much more than a dream.

I'm now very honored to introduce a message to the conference participants from a man who embodies that brighter future -- the President of South Africa, Nelson Mandela. Thank you. End


LOAD-DATE: July 18, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


225 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 19, 1994 / July 31, 1994


REMARKS AT THE WHITE HOUSE CONFERENCE ON AFRICA


BYLINE: Vice President Al Gore


LENGTH: 2734 words


 

June 27, 1994

Those of us who were lucky enough to be in South Africa on the morning after Nelson Mandela's inauguration could pick up the "Star" and relive the triumphant moments of that stunning day. The great crowds cheering outside Pretoria's Union Buildings. Mandela and F.W. deKlerk raising their hands together. The delta wing jets that swept over the crowd, with contrails in all the colors of the African flag.

"A day of music, flags, colour and joy," a headline read.

And so it was.

But if you read past the front page and on through the paper, you saw hints of the reality that lies ahead. A story about South Africa's growing number of street children. Little ads from American immigration lawyers promising help to those who want to migrate here or to New Zealand. Letters to the editor complaining about how Zimbabwe treated whites after its independence. Articles about the devastating possibilities of drought for the sugar crop, of when to sell gold stocks -- an sober discussion of the dismal GDP for subSaharan Africa. 

It was the morning after. We had celebrated a triumph. Now the hard work of building a nation began.

And in many ways, what is true of South Africa is true of the entire continent.

Sweeping through Africa in this last decade of the 20th Century is a wave of optimism. Is it generated by the Mandela inauguration? Not entirely.

After all, I saw other African success stories first hand during my recent trip: Namibia, Benin, and Cape Verde. To meet with the leaders of the Southern African Development Community is to realize that Africa now has eight established democracies -- Senegal, for example, and Botswana. It has 12 new ones, some admittedly fragile. And we see real progress towards democracy in 17 others. The optimism we see is based on far more than the events in Pretoria last month.

On the other hand, I remember a conversation with Gwanda Chakuambaphiri, Malawi's Minister of Home Affairs, where he rightly pointed out that support for democracy evaporates if a representative government fails to deliver the goods.

Democracy is only the beginning. Election achievements are meaningless if people continue to suffer under corruption, poor leadership, ethnic hatred and economic failure. And while there are examples of peace, progress and stability -- Botswana, or Namibia -- Africa is worse off now than it was at the beginning of the 1980s.

Per capita income has dropped drastically. Debt has ballooned. Country after country has sunk into civil was; seven of the 17 U.N. peacekeeping operations are deployed in Africa.

Much of Africa is plagued by disease, whether AIDS for which no country has a cure, or schistomyosis, which can be cured in the industrialized countries for pennies. Nigeria has already lost more than 60% of its forests, savannah and wetlands. Only 15% of Uganda has access to safe water.

And in Niger, the terrible deforestation means women must walk three times as far through the hot sun for wood to prepare the midday meal.

How do we help Africa fulfill the promise held out by the events in South Africa last month?

This Administration wants to help.

In part, our interest in Africa arises out of a vision of foreign policy enunciated by the President during the campaign and much of this year. It is a three-pronged vision: one that seeks to promote democracy, promote prosperity, and promote our own national security in an age when the Berlin Wall has been dismantled and people are casting ballots in the Kremlin.

Our interest in Africa arises as well, from our passionate belief in the common bond of humanity and from the fact that both this President and Vice President speak for 25 million Americans whose roots are in Africa.

Early in this Administration, National Security Advisor Tony Lake emphasized our commitment to support Africa in three key areas, reiterating the President's priorities.

We want to promote trade and investment. We want to leverage capital for basic development and infrastructure. We want to support effective government and democracy.

There are those who argue that democracy or free market economies -- or, for that matter, attention to the environment -- are luxuries Africa cannot afford. What patronizing nonsense.

Democracy is not a cure-all. But if ever there was doubt that Africa is not ready for democracy it was surely dispelled when we saw ordinary men and women waiting in line at the polling places for hours and hours in small townships, rural reserves and great cities along the length and breadth of South Africa.

And as for those who argue that free-trade will only trample Africa's small companies and smother its entrepreneurs -- well, history shows that when countries choose economic isolation over international economic engagement, their standard of living falls.

Democracy ... free markets ... attention to the environment. All three conditions, like a kind of economic Petri dish can create conditions allowing environmentally sustainable economic development.

Our policy has achieved some notable successes. We have eased the debt burdens of Africa's poorest countries. We have supported democratic transitions. We have influenced the growth of accountable government by conditioning our economic assistance in countries like Zambia and Kenya.

We expanded the Africa Regional Electoral Assistance Fund to strengthen democratic institutions.

We've continued our support for South Africa's transition to democracy with a $600 million multi-year program designed to meet the urgent needs of South Africans for jobs, housing, health care, basic education and black private sector development.

We will continue to work closely in partnership with South Africa to ensure that this historic transition succeeds. In the coming weeks, I expect to announce the establishment of a concrete mechanism to focus our dialogue with Nelson Mandela's government and to maintain high level involvement in helping the South African people realize their dream of a democratic, non-racial, prosperous and free nation.

American involvement elsewhere in Africa includes leading the international community's humanitarian effort to end the starvation that ravaged Somalia, and supporting its reconciliation process.

We have worked to strengthen the OAU's abilities to resolve conflicts; helped expand the Ecowas peacekeeping presence in Liberia; worked with the international community to advance to OAU-brokered peace accord in Rwanda; provided $94 million in humanitarian aid to Rwanda, Burundi and neighboring states; leased peacekeeping equipment to the U.N., and encouraged regional leaders to revive the Arusha process.

Our Agency for International Development has undertaken extensive consultations to develop a new approach for doing business in southern Africa.

AID has reached agreement on regional initiative in four areas -- two of them unlike anything it has done before; a Southern African Enterprise Fund to encourage indigenous private sector development; and a Southern Africa Democracy Fund to strengthen participatory democracy.

Usually, in speeches like these, we try to make news. But this year we have also worked very hard to prevent some headlines from appearing.

This Spring it looked very likely that there would be famine in parts of the Horn region by the end of the growing season.

It is one of the most pressing problems on the African continent. Who here does not have emblazoned in our mind's eye the images of starving families in Ethiopia in 1984?

This time we did not wait. President Clinton despatched Brian Atwood to the region as his special envoy to coordinate emergency relief efforts and to lead the way focusing development activities on the root causes of famine. Buy targeting our efforts, along with other donors, on the underlying causes of recurrent famine, we can help break the cycle of despair that now grips much of the Horn region. I'm pleased to state that our efforts have produced results already. We consulted with and gained commitments from the European Union to augment and coordinate food delivery to the region; we energized the United Nations and the PVO community to the crisis.

We do not claim to have solved the problem of famine in Africa. Right now there are over 20 million people needing emergency aid in Eastern Africa alone. But this fall, at least, we expect one of those rare times when no news is good news. The real news, of course, is that the world community is reacting quickly to forestall what could have been starvation and death for whole villages.

I do not run through this list to argue that we have solved problems. I mention them only to demonstrate the depth of our commitment.

For in the end, American aid ca only be a catalyst. Those who create real change in Africa will be the African people themselves.

But that is what we have seen.

Uganda has emerged from years of chaos and a fairly elected constituent assembly will soon ratify a democratic constitution for that country. Outsiders didn't do that. Ugandans did.

Malawi prepares for the first genuine elections in three decades. Outsiders didn't create those elections. The people of Malawi did.

Both Madagascar and the Seychelles recently abandoned socialist rule and have run free and fair elections. Tanzania has legalized opposition parties.

This wasn't the work of outsiders. It came from the aspirations and persistence and courage of the people of Madagascar, Seychelles and Tanzania.

The world-wide telecommunications revolution also holds great promise for Africa. It will spark trade and investment throughout Africa, accelerate the spread of ideas and information.

Right now there are 55 phones for every 100 Americans -- and less than 1 for every 100 Africans. Private sector projects such as AT&T's proposed fiber optic seabed cable and the LEOS (Low Earth Orbiting Satellite systems) promise to enrich the lives of all Africans. Meanwhile, Africa can increase its access to information through projects like the GLOBE initiative, which allows school children throughout Africa and the world to work together measuring environmental phenomena.

This is not to argue that Africa is in the homestretch. Democracy has made some progress. But there is so much more to be done.

Many African countries need reform in both civil service and in education. In too many African countries, disenfranchised, illiterate populations have been -- and sometimes still are -- the victims of those who won power often through the barrel of a gun and ruthlessly maintained that power. The United States will be frank in its condemnations of those who call themselves leaders, but who continue to prosecute wars in which they risk the lives of hundreds of thousands of their own people -- people who have no voice in their own destinies -- or who, as in Rwanda, butcher those with whom they must live in peace.

But if we in the United States cannot solve Africa's future, we can work with those who have that ability. In fact, we already have. And for evidence, we need look no further than those who are in this room.

For looking around, I see Wangari Maathai, the founder of the Greenbelt movement and a champion of rural Kenyan women. I see members of the Congressional Black Caucus which, now under the leadership of Kweisi Mfume, which has made so many Americans aware of African problems and opportunities.

I also see Maya Angelou.

The night of Nelson Mandela's inauguration, we celebrated in the Market Theatre in Johannesburg, a theatre that was in itself a symbol of hope with its willingness to defy apartheid by the plays it produced. And at one point, Maya Angelou cam to the stage to read her poetry.

As I listened -- I was next, and believe me, I didn't relish the idea -- I though of the other time I had stood on a stage and listened to her.

It was also an inauguration -- President Clinton's, And I remember her poem, which contained these lines:

Lift up your eyes

Upon this day breaking for you

Give birth again

To the dream...

Lift up your hearts

Each new hour holds new chances

For a new beginning

A new day is breaking not only in South Africa but for the entire continent. And what we do in the months and years ahead will help determine how bright a day it is.

Decades from now, when we look back on what we will accomplish, let it be said that this was the generation that helped Africa achieve the peace and prosperity that has eluded it for so long.

Let it be said that inspired by those who tore down apartheid we helped Africa use its strength to build a new life.

Give us your ideas. Give us your insights. Give us your commitment. Africa is the continent where human beings began. Help Africa become testament to the best human beings can achieve.


LOAD-DATE: July 18, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


226 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 19, 1994 / July 31, 1994


STATEMENT BY THE SECRETARY GENERAL AT THE WHITE HOUSE CONFERENCE ON AFRICA


BYLINE: H.E. SALIM AHMED SALIM


SECTION: DOSSIER


LENGTH: 5227 words


 

26 JUNE 1994

Your Excellency the Secretary of State,

Your Excellency the National Security Adviser,

Distinguished Members of Congress,

Your Excellencies, Ladies and Gentlemen,

I wish to begin by thanking the Administration for extending an invitation to me to attend the White House Conference on Africa and to share with key policy makers of this country our views on the situation in the Continent.

You will appreciate that, given the magnitude of things in Africa -- its size, diversity, its problems and its potential, I cannot venture to speak in any conclusive terms, about all that is happening in it. We shall have the opportunity during the Conference to discuss these issues further. What I propose therefore, is briefly to tell you some of the principal problems Africa is facing, what our countries are doing about them and in which areas the United States can assist. In particular, I intend to tell you how far Africa has gone, and what efforts are being expended to deal with the triple challenge of democratization, economic reform and bringing about peace and stability through conflict resolution and the kind of support we think America can bring to these efforts. 

Of course, one cannot speak of developments in Africa now without beginning with the happy events of South Africa, where a people separated by centuries of racism and bigotry rose to the challenge of peace and have now found common ground in a new democratic country. We celebrate the triumph of reason and justice and of human will as we do the global human solidarity that was forged to oppose the evil of racism. We celebrate the will and determination of people like President Nelson Mandela, whose vision of a society free from racism and in which South Africans of all races and gender can find common belonging. We celebrate the vision of people like Frederick de Klerk, who was willing to initiate the process of change and fought with determination to keep it on course and has now joined efforts in building the new South Africa. We salute them as we urge all South Africans to persist along the course of peace, national reconciliation and unity.

With the dismantling of apartheid and the installation of an elected Government of National Unity in South Africa, the OAU has closed the chapter on decolonization in the continent. Of course, the struggle for decolonization, and especially that against racism in South Africa, enjoyed the support of millions around the world and especially in this country. It was the sustained massive public demonstrations and protests, sit-ins and campaigns of disinvestment in the legislatures and campuses around the United States which pushed the sometimes reluctant administrations to take a definite stand against institutionalized racism in South Africa. Africa is infinitely grateful to those millions, who in selfless commitment to the cause of justice, stood in solidarity with the people of South Africa and kept the faith that ultimately delivered a new and democratic society we now celebrate.

The people of America and successive administrations of this country were able to support the struggle for justice and against oppression and racism in South Africa because it was simply wrong and constituted an affront to what the United States stands for. And even when political expediency seemed sometimes to weaken American resolve, the collective pressure of the conscience of the people of this country eventually redirected America to the path of justice.

Africa won in its battle for political freedom and against racism, partly because it had the support of the greater part of the world. We now need the same kind of solidarity if we are to extend the reaches of our freedom to the economic domain to liberate the people of the continent of Africa from the oppression of grinding poverty and economic under-development. The Continent also needs to re-focus its attention to matters of governance, of human rights and of conflicts, which stand to undermine all the efforts at development and peace.

Africa is now engaged in the monumental task of democratization. It is not easy. And given the constraints of the socio-economic circumstances in which our countries have to operate, that task is made infinitely difficult. Yet our countries have not resigned to these difficulties and have instead faced the challenge of bringing greater democracy with courage and determination.

Increasingly we see governments responding to the demands of the people for accountability and good governance. Governments are likewise converting to popular participation, giving greater political dispensations by which they yield more ground to popular views. The regard to human rights is getting stronger, as governments are being challenged by an increasingly assertive and growing independent media. The regard to the rule of law, accountability and transparency in government are issues which are now taken seriously as agenda for governments. This transition to a new political way of doing business is bringing along with it prospects for a good future, hopes, as well as challenges. And, for all the difficulties this political transition poses, our governments are willing to move with fortitude in the strong conviction that the future of the Continent depends on it.

Africa has taken the challenge of democratization seriously even in the face of the myriad of problems it faces. Today in the Continent, more and more countries are converting to political pluralism as multi-party elections have become a frequent occurrence. Five years ago we could count how many African countries had multi-party elections. Today we can count how many do not. This tremendous change has come about in part because of popular demand, but also because governments are increasingly becoming responsive to these demands. It has not been an easy or smooth transition from overwhelmingly single-party political systems and military rules to multi-party politics. This transition has in some cases brought the political fabric of countries under severe strain, as contrasting and sometimes contradicting interests in society have had to be balanced.

The overriding objective in the Continent has been to ensure that even as we undergo transition, we should do so taking into account the material conditions -- especially those of its history, traditions and culture. Additionally, accent has been placed on the need to safeguard the many social gains which have been achieved over the years, and to ensure that the unity and cohesion in our countries,which have been built at great cost, are not compromised or undermined by that process of transition. To lack care or take this fundamental consideration for granted would in fact undermine the very process of political transition we want to sustain in the Continent.

One of the unintended effects of the new political liberalization has been the rise of the ugly spectres of tribalism, ethnicity, religious intolerance and other tendencies of separatism and division. These have equally brought great strain to the social fabric in our countries. The challenge which Africa faces is how to ensure that the genuine identities of religion, ethnicity and tribe are accommodated without allowing the forces of bigotry and all forms of intolerance to exploit that accommodation.

You will all appreciate that in a continent as vast and diverse in terms of race, ethnicities, tribes, languages, religions and cultures, tolerance is key to social harmony and stability. Likewise, the challenge we have is to build a culture of tolerance and to use our diversity creatively as a source of strength rather than of division. Naturally, we see the American experience in social accommodation as the most readily adaptable to the African situation.

We in the Organization of Africa Unity who have had the privilege to be closely associated with this process of political transition through observing elections in many countries, are keenly aware of the problems which the Continent faces. We therefore see strong need to moderate that transition so that the corresponding and necessary adjustments in society which will ultimately sustain that process, are made. When I speak of adjustments, I mean the measures to assure all segments of society, which invariably enjoyed different degrees of political power and influence under the old order, that the change is for the good of all. Principal among these measures is building awareness and instilling in our nations a sense of a new beginning, based on equal rights as well as obligations for everyone.

We need also to impress upon those who may triumph in elections that electoral majority on themselves are not always sufficient to ensure smooth transition to democratic rule. The electoral process and its results, too, need to be measured against the need to create the conditions in which true and effective national leadership can be exercised. Equally, those who lose elections also need to understand that defeat is part of the democratic process and that they can still contribute constructively to the governance of the country, as a responsible opposition. In fact, we need to know how to lose and how to win elections.

While the full internalization of this new outlook will require time and effort as more experience is gathered, there is need to educate for a new political awareness in the Continent. This is an area to which, I believe, the experience and resources of this country can be targeted. Education to build awareness among the electorate on the processes of elections and those of building and consolidating democratic institutions and governments.

But beyond this process of educating for a new political awareness in the Continent, there is great need for the newly democratizing countries to be supported politically and economically. Invariably most new governments have replaced others which had been in place for decades. These inordinately long periods of rule were at times accompanied by political rigidities and excesses, as well as economic difficulties. All these created a ready opposition which swung to the new political dispensation and supported the new political parties. But now that the new parties have come into power on the ticket of reform, they have to deal with the realities of governance -- of meeting the economic needs of the people, balancing the conflicting political interests in society and maintaining law and order. This is a gigantic task which these new governments have to face without adequate resources. This is all the more compounded by the institution of the needed economic reforms. To democratize at a time when you are carrying out an adjustment program means that you have to find ways by which order can be maintained without resorting to coercion. At the same time, the people who voted these new governments into office are genuinely entitled to expect quick results and a positive change in their livelihood.

This is why I believe these democratizing countries need to be assisted, particularly in the economic field, so as to sustain and strengthen the process of political transition. Otherwise the strain of poverty will undermine the cause of democracy in the Continent.

I speak of economic assistance because I am aware of the Herculean efforts being undertaken by the Continent at instituting measures which are designed to halt economic decline and restore productivity growth and development. These have been done, with and sometimes without the support of the international financial and monetary institutions. Africa now realizes that it must take responsibility for the economic mistakes of the past and that to deserve international assistance it must demonstrate that it is doing its best first.

For this, African governments are willing to take great political risk and institute unpopular austerity and economic reform measures. These measures have meant less public spending in key social sectors such as health, education, and housing, as well as rolling back the development of much needed infrastructure. The consequences of these reforms, particularly to the very vulnerable segments of society, women and children, have been excruciating. In the spirit of the reforms they have to share cost of health care and education when they literally have no income.

Above the squeeze in public spending, the countries have opened up for the private sector, liberalized markets, interest rates and currency regulations. Foreign Investment Promotion programmes have been instituted.

All these measures were initiated because they are necessary. At the same time, Africa hoped that the urgings and encouragement it was receiving from the western world to speed up these reforms would have been supplemented by increased resource commitment to support that reform process in the Continent. But neither the western world nor the international monetary and financial institutions have made available the requisite financial support. Africa is forced to look to the commercial capital market, where it lacks certification and collateral, to raise resources to support the reforms at home. Emphasis in the West and by the financial and monetary institutions seem to be on debt repayment rather on the mobilization of the needed resources to help Africa undertake the reforms which will anchor the continent on sound economic footing.

I believe that the United States should look at the great efforts that the Continent is deploying. People are suffering and governments know. But they also know that they have to persist in these reforms and look to the long term for the benefits. They also know that unless they can mitigate their extreme effects on the people, these reforms are not sustainable and they cannot benefit from indefinite public tolerance. There is, therefore, a symbiotic relationship between the sustenance of both economic and political reforms. And that symbiosis is in resource availability.

This is why I see the American role in the economic field falling in two broad categories.

Firstly, I see a national effort at bilateral level to support the efforts in individual African countries. Through increased resources commitment to the adjustment and restructuring programmes, the United States can help ensure that those programmes are sustained and strengthened. Equally, I see a role of the United States, especially through its Development Agency, to invest in society targeting, in particular, the rural poor in those sectors vacated by governments as a result of structural adjustment programmes. Investment in clinics and health centres, primary schools and drinking water for example, will help meet society needs at a grass roots level and would be in keeping with the noble mission of the United States Development Agency.

Secondly, I see the United States providing leadership at the international level, with the industrialized countries and the monetary and financial institutions in mobilizing support for reforms and development generally in the continent. Apart from the additionality of resources, I see as a clear priority the issue of Africa's indebtedness. I know that many complex monetary and economic arguments and pleas have been put forward to deal with the question of debt. The Toronto Plan, the Trinidad and Tobago Terms and others. But I also know the beyond legal arguments and economic considerations the issue of Africa's external indebtedness is a political one. For the total of Africa's debt is not an amount of any consequence to the debtor countries. All it needs is political will, and experience has shown that in cases where that will exists, economic arguments are set aside. I therefore hope that the United States will take the necessary political decision to provide leadership and to urge for debt forgiveness in the case of Africa, as a means of liberating the Continent from this albatross as well as of supporting the political and economic transition there.

The social problems of the Continent -- high birth rates, low life expectancy, high maternal mortality, the high infection rates of the HIV virus and other killer diseases, chronic malnutrition, the high rate of unemployment, rapid urbanization growth, environmental degradation and many others -- are directly linked to poverty. We cannot, therefore, hope to address any of these comprehensively unless we first aim at poverty elimination.

Likewise, we cannot hope to promote human rights or pursue matters of good governance unless we address the key issue of poverty which militates against our efforts.

Perhaps the most topical of all the problems of Africa are its conflicts. We are witnessing the horror of organized carnage in Rwanda. Conflicts in Somalia, Angola and Liberia still persist and tensions in Burundi and in other countries present Africa with a formidable challenge.

We know the extent of death, destruction of property and infrastructure, as well as of the damage to social fabric these conflicts have brought about in the Continent. The phenomenon of seven million refugees and fifteen million displaced persons has partly been brought about by these wars and conflicts.

In 1990, in a declaration of the Assembly of the Heads of State and Government of the OAU, Africa renewed its commitment to the objective of bringing peace, through the resolution of its conflicts. What was significant about that resolution, was that for the first time Africa said that all conflicts, including those within states, were the concern of every African and that the OAU had a central role to play in the resolution of those conflicts. This new outlook by which Africa freed itself from the limiting interpretations of sovereignty, has been the driving force behind our efforts in the Continent. Since 1990, the OAU has dealt with almost all the conflicts on the continent. The main objective has been to place the instrumentality of the Organization at the service of those in conflicts, and I must add, we have had success in inspiring the confidence of many.

In order to give this new perspective and the efforts of the OAU an operational framework, the leaders of Africa decided last year in Cairo, to set up a Mechanism for conflict prevention, management and resolution. That Mechanism is built around the Bureau of the Assembly of Heads of State and Government, with the Secretary General and his Secretariat as its operational arm. The Mechanism has a Peace Fund to finance its operational activities.

In the course of the last year, our efforts have been directed at making the Mechanism operational and at applying it to the conflict situations in the Continent. While it is still early to pass full judgment on it, I can confidently say that Africa is on the right course. The Mechanism is an African creation and tailored to the needs and circumstances of the Continent.

The Mechanism is an institutional framework for peace and stability, but above all, it is a political statement. It is a manifestation of Africa's new resolve to take the mantle of leadership by situating itself, through the OAU, at the centre of efforts at conflict resolution on the Continent. Africa is saying that charity begins at home, that to get assistance, one must deserve it through example of effort. The countries of Africa are now prepared to get out of the limiting traditional political considerations, such as those of sovereignty and misplaced notions of non-interference, and to embrace each other in a partnership to bring peace and stability on the Continent.

We in the Organization of African Unity see this as a fundamental transformation, which will prove key to the process of ushering in and consolidating peace.

It is now one year since the establishment of the Mechanism. Of course, during these formative stages we are bound to experience problems, basically those of growing up. Even with the political disposition we see on the part of African countries, there is still some slowness in embracing a new thing. Change of habits built overtime is bound to take time, and we appreciate the difficulties of conversion. With time, and as the Mechanism is applied and internalized, we are bound to overcome the natural fear of the unknown.

Already the Mechanism has dealt with a number of conflicts with success. The timely intervention in Congo, for example, helped diffuse the political crisis there.

What we may however find difficult, at least in the short run, to overcome, is the central question of resources which are necessary to cover the operations of the Mechanism. We have made budgetary outlay for the OAU Peace Fund, and we hope that African countries will, in some other way share the cost of the operations undertaken within the Mechanism. But even with our efforts, it will still be necessary to mobilize resources from outside the Continent. In this respect, I wish to thank your government for the financial support you have extended to the OAU in our efforts earlier in Rwanda and currently in Burundi and at resolving conflicts generally. As we proved, I hope it will be possible to expand on the cooperation we have had so far in to bring added American support to the Mechanism.

Apart from this financial support, experience over the last one year, especially with regard to our operations in Burundi and Rwanda, has taught us some lessons. Principal among those lessons, is that Africa needs to wean itself from the dependence syndrome and the mistaken belief that the rest of the world will always be there with its compassion and resources to serve the Continent. The ambivalence of the world, including the United Nations, to take swift and decisive action as hundreds of thousands of people were slaughtered and millions fled into exiles as refugees and displaced persons in Rwanda was an indictment to us all. It was a failure for Africa, the United Nations and humanity at large. But if we put this failure in context, you will appreciate that Africa made the efforts which culminated in agreement to contribute troops to join the United Nations humanitarian effort in Rwanda.

I wish to recall that when President Mwinyi of Tanzania, Dr. Boutros Boutros Ghali, the Secretary General of the United Nations and I met with Vice President Al Gore in Pretoria on May 10, just before President Mandela's inauguration, I did point out that several African leaders had on that very day responded to my appeal to contribute troops to UNAMIR's operations. By the time the OAU Summit in Tunis was over ten days ago, more than 4,500 African troops had been committed, ready for deployment.

To date it has not been possible for the United Nations to deploy these forces because of lack of logistical means. Even at this late hour, I wish to fervently appeal to countries like the United States, to provide without delay, all necessary logistical support to enable the UN to deploy the African troops to Rwanda.

Another lesson we have learnt is that Africa needs to be prepared sufficiently to respond swiftly in situations of conflicts. I believe that if Africa had ready forces to draw from, it could have made a difference in terms of troop mobilization for service in Rwanda. This is why I have urged the earmarking of contingents in African national armies, trained in peace observations and peacekeeping, which could be made available for service with the UN or OAU, where circumstances necessitate. I intend to follow up this idea which I had again raised at the Tunis Summit with member states.

In all these, I see the American role being two-fold. Firstly we want America to support our efforts in political terms. As a world leader, America can make a major difference if it supports the OAU politically. A firm endorsement by America in the UN and elsewhere of our efforts would give us the necessary momentum to go ahead. Secondly, provision of added resources, logistically and financially through the Peace Fund, would equally give us the means to operate.

What we see in Africa is a continent ready to reseize the initiative particularly at finding solutions to its problems. We see in the Continent greater realism and preparedness to depart from established habits of blaming others for its ills and of looking at outsiders for their resolution. Now we take responsibility in the realization that it is Africa which can resolve its own problems even if we shall continue to require outside help. It is this realism and preparedness to assume responsibility that is at the root of the new outlook in the Continent and which holds promise.

Our countries have taken on the challenge of political and economic reforms and of bringing peace to the Continent. Of course we have difficulties, some of them quite serious. Many are man-made but we have to deal with natural disasters such as desertification as well. Of course, when we look at what is happening in Rwanda it is easy to fall prey to the usual stereotyped view that Africa is a continent where suffering and conflicts are endemic and which is condemned to misery and backwardness. But unfortunate as the Rwanda conflict is, it should not be allowed to overshadow the many achievements which Africa has had or the sustained efforts which have been deployed in the area of conflict resolution. Today we celebrate victory in South Africa, we note the peaceful resolution of the Chad-Libya conflict as we do the stabilization of the situation in Congo, and the progress made in Mozambique, Liberia, Somalia and Burundi.

Also, we should not lose sight of the great efforts in the Continent at democratization and economic reform and the positive effects these are beginning to have. What the outside world needs to do is to look at Africa objectively and appreciate the great and determined efforts being expended. It is only if the world sees and knows what Africa is doing that it can render constructive assistance.

Why should the United States care about Africa? Because I believe it is in your interest as well. Africa and this country share common bonds of history and culture. In this rapidly shrinking global village, we need global solidarity to sustain cooperation and our interdependence. The problems of Africa concern this country just as Africa is affected by practically every major development in this country. Helping Africa to emerge from its present difficulties is therefore in the long term interest of this country. You need a strong Africa which can be a strong partner in global development and not a subject of your constant compassion and unending charity.

Africa is not a continent resigned to fate but one which is determined to emerge from its present difficulties. I hope the Conference will provide opportunity for the participants to look at African closely and beyond the unfortunate negatives which are so often picked on by the detractors of the Continent, to explain away the case of its people. I look forward to being part of that dialogue.

I thank you.


LOAD-DATE: July 18, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.
