Africa News


July 19, 1994 / July 31, 1994


GRANT SOUGHT FOR RADIO GAMBIA


BYLINE: Daily Observer Staff Reporter


LENGTH: 1214 words


 

DAILY OBSERVER, June 28, 1994

The Gambia Government, in consultation with its development partners, notably the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, decided to table Gamtel's take-over of Radio Gambia on July 1, while "alternative options" are sought for the transformation of the nation's number one radio station.

Finance Minister Bakary B. Dabo, in his Budget Speech last Friday, hinted that there would be a delay in the July 1 hand-over of the radio station to Gamtel, in accordance with the recommendations of the Task Force appointed by the President on the matter. Without going into detail, he stressed Government's commitment to the upgrading and modernisation of Radio Gambia, and added: "alternative institutional and other arrangement are being examined by a Task Force whose recommendations will allow Government to take a definitive decision fairly soon."

Contacted by this newspaper yesterday for clarification, Mr. Dabo said the role of the IMF had been "exaggerated." "They have indeed expressed an opinion," he noted, "but the decision is Gambian." 

The Minister was probably reacting to an article in a local newspaper which last week quoted sources at the Ministry of Information as saying that Radio Gambia's move to Gamtel had been "cancelled at the intervention of the IMF."

"These people are our development partners," explained Minister Dabo, "and in a development like this we consult with them and when they give us their opinion, we study it. But the final decision is The Gambia Government's to make."

The Minister assured this newspaper that Government considered the matter "super urgent and important. We know that Radio Gambia is desperate and something needs to be done; but there are too many ways of killing a cat."

He was asked to confirm information reaching this newspaper that Government had been advised to seek a grant from a friendly nation or nations that would take care of the expenses for the rehabilitation and modernisation of Radio Gambia. All he would say is that "It's not as simple as that."

However, Abdoulie Touray, chief executive of the National Investment Board and chairman of the Task Force whose recommendations the Cabinet approved over tow weeks ago, said that Government had indeed been advised to seek a grant from a friendly nation.

"If the grant comes through, it would not be necessary for Gamtel to use its internal resources to fund some of the capital investment for Radio Gambia," he said. But the telecommunications company would still be called upon to render technical and managerial services toward modernisation of the radio station, he added.

Mr. Touray said that based on the Budget Speech, the Task Force would re-convene and look at the alternatives and make further recommendations to Government.

This newspaper, in an editorial on the subject several months ago, wondered why, if it were simply a question of money, hadn't a grant been obtained long ago. Now it seems that President Jawara, having grown weary of an inefficient national radio, makes a decisive move to do something about the problem -- and more studies are being requested.

Information Minister James A. Gaye, under whose Ministry Radio Gambia falls, told this newspaper he had nothing to add to what the Finance Minister had stated in his Budget Speech.

Japanese Grant Approved

Meanwhile, the managing director of Gamtel, Bakary Njie, whose corporation received very high marks in the Budget Speech for excellent parastatal performance, told this newspaper that he and Gamtel had been honoured by the invitation of the President to help Radio Gambia out of its crisis.

"The challenge at Radio Gambia is not difficult at all," Mr. Njie told the "Daily Observer" yesterday. "It can be very easily done. With our technical base, which includes an all-Gambian work force and 10 years of experience, we believe Gamtel can offer substantial complementary services to Radio Gambia."

Mr. Njie welcomed the idea of a grant to help modernise Radio Gambia, and indicated that, in fact, a grant had already been approved.

He told this newspaper that the Japanese government had already expressed its willingness to provide a grant for this purpose, and that it was only a matter of time. "Perhaps the recent changes in the Japanese government have contributed to the delay," he suggested; but expressed certainty that if the Gambia Government pursued the matter seriously, the Japanese would come through without delay.

The Japanese grant, he said, would cover the cost of a new transmitter, repair of the studio facilities and the development of FM broadcasting.

Gamtel, he explained, would do the initial rehabilitation in anticipation of the Japanese grant. Mr. Njie then gave an outline of the immediate line of action Gamtel would take, if given the opportunity. First, he would re-locate the Radio Gambia transmitter at Bonto, which lies between Yundum and Brikama. "The transmitter is situated at a spot where there is no public electricity," said Mr. Njie. "They have to depend on a stand-by generator, and the cost of fuel alone is well over three quarters of a million dalasis per year. They have exhausted all their fuel quote," he added, so they had to switch off the medium wave and use FM.

Second, Gamtel would extend the FM coverage area by increasing the tower height at Mile 7 and link it to the main transmitter. Third, Gamtel would rehabilitate the second transmitter at Bonto, and this would extend medium wave coverage further into the interior.

Reprinted from the Daily Observer, June 28, 1994.

The Daily Observer is published by The Observer Company (Gambia) Ltd., New Town-Sait Matty Junction, Bakau, P.M.B. 131. Banjul, The Gambia. Telephone: (220) 496608, 496877, 496878. Fax: (220) 496878.


LOAD-DATE: July 18, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


228 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 19, 1994 / July 31, 1994


NIF REGIME FINALLY MOVES AGAINST EL MAHDI


BYLINE: Bona Malwal


LENGTH: 1560 words


 

SUDAN DEMOCRATIC GAZETTE, July 1994

Finally last month, the Islamic Fundamentalist military regime of the National Islamic Front (NIF) moved to arrest the former prime minister and leader of the Umma Party, Sadiq El Mahdi. He and three of his lieutenants were charged with plotting to overthrow the regime by force. The three aides, Professor Hamad Baghadi; the former security advisor to the former prime minister, Abdel Rahman Farah, a retired army officer who was an elected member of Mr. El Mahdi's party in the parliament which the present regime dissolved in 1989; and one Said, were detained several months ago without charge. The charge of a plot involving Sadiq El Mahdi seems to have been developed by the regime during the long months of detention of these aides to the former prime minister.

Professor Baghadi and Mr. Abdel Rahman Farah were said to have been heavily tortured and the confessions of plotting against the regime, for which the former prime minister has now also been arrested, were obtained under the duress of torture. Their videotaped confessions were relayed on the regime's controlled television just as the security forces moved in to detain El Mahdi. 

Falsehood

The latest arrest of Sadiq El Mahdi, which links him to a plot against the regime, must be weighed against the regime's repeated efforts, over the last year in particular, to find faults with which to charge him. This arrest must also be viewed with grave concern for the safety of Sadiq El Mahdi.

For at least two years, rumours have circulated within Sudanese circles which indicate that the regime has been seeking a way of legally ending the life of the former prime minister and not just putting him away in prison. The present charge of plotting to overthrow the regime carries with it a maximum sentence of death. Sudanese generally are taking this trumped up charge against the leader of the Umma Party seriously and there are appeals to the international community to do something to save El Mahdi's life.

It would appear that the arrest of the former prime minister, who has recently shown that he had the nerve and the guts to stand up to the regime, shows how desperate the situation has come in Sudan. Sudanese fear that the regime may have finally decided to falsely accuse Mr. El Mahdi because they intend to either kill him while in detention or to put him through one of their Islamic kangaroo courts and then execute him. Such fears cannot be taken lightly.

The arrest of Sadiq El Mahdi and his being charged with a serious criminal offence which carries the death penalty, come hardly two months after an ominous comment made by the regime's figurehead military leader. General Omer Hassan El Beshir was quoted as saying the Sadiq El Mahdi should know that we could get rid of him in a similar way to that used by the former Sudanese dictator, General Jaafar Nimeiri, who got rid of El Sadiq's uncle. The late Imam El Hadi Abdel Rahman El Mahdi was killed by General Nimeiri's security agents in 1970. The public explanation put out tat the time was that he was shot fleeing the country across the border with Ethiopia.

Predicted Arrest

Apparently predicting his arrest, Sadiq El Mahdi made a public statement only hours before the security collected him, refuting all allegations of involvement with any violent plot against the regime. The statement was successfully smuggled out of Sudan as the former prime minister was being arrested and given wide circulation abroad by his party on 21 June, the day following his arrest.

In his statement, Sadiq El Mahdi recounts the continuous efforts made by the regime to connect him personally and his party with acts of violence, all of which he denies. He said that the Umma Party has what he called "a solemn commitment" to non-violent resistance to the regime. He concluded that even if the Umma Party were to decide to resist the regime and to attain the legitimate democratic objectives of the people of Sudan by other means, these other means would not be as crude and as criminal as the regime wants to accuse him and his party of.

On 22 June, two days after the former prime minister was arrested, the leadership of the Umma Party abroad held a press conference in London in which they decried the arrest of their leader, called for international public attention to the threat to the life of Sadiq El Mahdi and for an international campaign to free him. Both the secretary general of the Umma Party, Dr. Omer Nur El Daim, and the party's external affairs spokesman, Mubarak El Fadil El Mahdi, recounted the history of their party's relations with the NIF regime and how the regime has tried to implicate their party in each and every plot it says was aimed at overthrowing it.

Turbulent Times

Relations between the Umma Party and the regime, which had never been good since the regime overthrew in 1989 the democratically elected government led by the Umma Party, has been particularly bad in 1994. Things were especially tense between the regime and Sadiq El Mahdi personally, because the former prime minister has strongly and openly challenged the legitimacy and the moral and constitutional authority of the regime. On two or three different occasions this year, before they finally locked him up, the former prime minister had engaged the regime in a contest for popular support on the streets of the capital, Khartoum. He won all with flying colours and by many miles ahead. The regime always detained and questioned him briefly after these popular events, but he would be quickly released.

There is every indication that his arrest this time was premeditated and the pretext deliberately fabricated. Which is why the risk to hi life this time must betaken extremely seriously.

Two of his aides, who are being reported by the regime to have confessed to a plot involving the former prime minister, were arrested several months ago. That it took this long for these confessions to be made public by the regime and to have the events around these confessions take such a dramatic turn, attests only too clearly to the regime's own plot against the former prime minister.

Regime's Plot

The true story of the confessions is, of course, the story of the regime managing over time to extract from the two men false evidence fed to them while under torture. Eventually Professor Hamad Baghadi and Abdel Rahman Farah "admitted" that they and the former prime minister had plotted the assassination of the leaders of the NIF, Dr. Hassan Abdalla El Turabi, Ali Osman Mohamed Taha and others, and the violent overthrow of the regime. When the two accepted to co-operate and made the false confessions, a conversation between the two of them and a security agent, a certain Said, was taped to make the plot seem legitimate. Said, and Umma Party member turned security agent, is supposed to have produced an earlier tape recorded conversation between himself, Professor Baghadi and Abdel Rahman Farah, in which the regime's agent told th tow Umma leaders that he would work with them to assassinate the NIF leaders. Professor Baghadi and Mr. Farah are said to have confessed to having had this conversation on the video tape, which was played on the regime's television the night the former prime minister was arrested.

It is a story which even the supporters of the regime themselves find difficult to believe. For one thing, if a plot like that had existed, and the regime and the evidence which it now says it has, why did they not arrest Sadiq El Mahdi with the other two? The nature and the extent of the regime's own plot against Sadiq El Mahdi indicates that the threat to his life is real and serious.

Reprinted from the Sudan Democratic Gazette, July 1994.

Sudan Democratic Gazette is published at P.O. Box 2295, London W14 0ND, U.K.


LOAD-DATE: July 18, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


229 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 19, 1994 / July 31, 1994


PRICE OF NEGLECT


BYLINE: Moffat Ekoriko


LENGTH: 2867 words


 

NEWSWATCH, July 4, 1994

For 18 days last April, official of Shell Petroleum Development Company Limited had some serious problems to contend with. The company was losing 158,000 barrels of oil daily as a result of communal disturbances in its operational base in Rivers and Delta states. Crude oil deliveries too were behind schedule because production in 10 communities was halted. And more communities were rising up in protest against the firm.

The company hurriedly commenced negotiations with the aggrieved communities and by May 2 succeeded in restoring production of 100,000 barrels in five oil fields in Delta State. Production in five other fields in Rivers State resume late last month. Still, Shell is losing 28,000 barrels of oil daily form the closure of its five flow stations in the three local government areas that make up Ogoni in Rivers State. The company was forced to abandon production in the area at the peak of hostilities against its operations.

Peace is yet to return to the area and there is no hope production will resume before the end of this year. Emeka Achebe, Shell's general manager, business development, says the company's workers cannot go back to the area unless there is peace and absolute guarantee of their safety. 

Shell and other oil firms are now paying the price of the years of neglect, marginalisation and environmental degradation of the oil producing communities. Last February, Shell was forced to close down its operation s at Etelebou, Adibawa, Ubie and Enwhe fields and some wells In Kolo creek fields losing 30,000 barrels of oil daily. Production stopped for almost three months. In neighbouring Delta, a wave of demonstrations from April 14 to May 6 brought production in any communities to a halt. It first started in Uzere, April 14 when more than 5,000 demonstrators took over a glow station and two oil fields which had 39 oil wells. April 20, Escravos Beach, Afremo, Saghara and Otumara communities followed by shutting down Shell facilities and holding some staff hostage. The face off cost Shell 100,000 barrels of oil daily of 12 days. The company was forced to notify crude oil lifters of anticipated delays in loading of tankers at the Forcados Terminal, an announcement that pushed up the price of crude oil from $14.65 to $15.25 per barrel in the international market. Oleh and Olomoro communities in Isoko local government also rose up against Shell in May shutting down a flow stations and 25 oil wells. They also seized 18 vehicles belonging to Seismograph Services Limited, a seismic contractor to Shell.

The demands of the protesting communities are legion. They include access roads, electricity, potable water, contracts, scholarships, employments and compensation for degradation of their environment. But the cost of the disturbances has been enormous.

Last year, Shell lost 141 man-days from 51 incidents in its western division covering Delta, Edo and Ondo states. Losses sustained on the non-utilisation of facilities or down time cost came to $850,000. Besides, its oil production losses were put at 15,17 million barrels. In the eastern division covering Rivers, Akwa Ibom, Imo and Abia states, Shell lost 1,269 man-days and incurred a down-time cost of N250.4 million from 108 incidents. It could not produce 12 million barrels of oil as a result of communal disturbances. For now, it has increased the number of its security staff from 1,480 in 1990 to 2,470. In effect, security staff constituted 50 percent of its work force in 1993. Still as at April this year, deferred crude oil production in the east alone stood at 6.6 million barrels from 19 incidents.

Like Shell, Elf Petroleum Nigeria Limited has been operating in difficult circumstances in Obagi, Ahoada local government area of Rivers State since February. Trouble for the company actually started on October 4 last year when youths from the community ransacked its operational location damaging equipment and disrupting activities for some days. They accused the company of insensitivity to their demands for employment, contract awards and constant water supply. The Oil Mineral Producing Areas Development Commission, OMPADEC, had to step in to resolve the conflict. Peace reigned until February 12 when armed policemen attacked the community ostensibly to recover equipment stolen during the October 4 riot. The attack left a police sergeant dead and many members of the community injured. Elf was forced to shut down its productions of 60,000 barrels of oil daily from the Obagi field.

Chevron Nigeria Limited, another oil producing firm, also has its own problems. On May 2, indigenes of Opuama in Delta State demonstrated against Shell and Chevron to press for N3.7 billion reparation for damages arising from oil exploration in the area by the two oil companies. After shutting down Shell's on-shore flow station, they headed for Chevron's off-shore oil installations. With 16 boats strung together with cables, they blockaded the installations at Opuekebo. Faced with the threat of a shut down of its facilities, Chevron called in the police to break the blockade. The villagers told "Newswatch" that the police sent in a self-propelled barge which rammed into the blockade sinking all the 16 boats. Three person, Godspower Niki, 27; Hebite Opuba, 48; and Sarah Omoko, 24 drowned while several others were injured.

Chevron has a different account of the incident. Bill Edma, Chevron"s managing director, issued a statement claiming that the policemen were sent to tell the people to get out of the way. He claimed the people had complied with the police order without any incident. Tension is still high in the area although Chevron operations are going on with security cover from the police.

Nigerian Agip Oil Company Limited is not left out. Late last year, it suffered disruption of its operations in Brass local government are of Rivers State. The demand of the protesting communities centred on provision of social amenities.

Apart from the losses which the oil companies bear as a result of the disturbances, the federation account is also worse off. Oil proceeds form 67.1 percent of the account. At the current oil prices of $17.08 per barrel, Shell lost $48.57 million for the 18 days it could not produce 158,000 barrels of oil daily in April. The federation account which gets 68 percent of oil revenue lost $33.04 million, an equivalent of N727 million.

Apart from this, some key oil related projects are being held up by the disturbances. Among them is the $500 million gas pipeline meant to supply natural gas to the N30 billion Aluminum Smelter Project at Ikot Abasi in Akwa Ibom State. Disturbances in Ogoniland have prevented the take-off of the project forcing the government to consider tapping gas from other locations since the aluminum plant cannot be commissioned without the gas supply line.

Because of the losses, some of the oil companies are raising the community development budgets. Shell says it is spending $16 million on community development this year in its western division. The package according to Christopher Akinro, the public affairs manager, west, is 2.7 percent of the division's $350 million budget for 1994. The expenditure last year was $10 million. In the eastern division, Stephen Lawson Jack, public affairs manager, east, says the company would spend $22 million on direct community assistance. In addition, a minimum of two percent of production project cost is to be set aside for community development. Last year, the company built six cottage hospitals at N13 million each for oil producing communities in Rivers Sate.

On its part, Mobil Producing Nigeria has constructed a link-road between Ibeno and Eket in Akwa Ibom State, provided a hospital and electrified Mkpanak where its tank farm and processing facilities are located. Similarly, Agip built a bridge to link the two sections of Brass community in Rivers State last year.

Some other companies have no recent community development projects to show. Elf which is embattled at Obagi, its main oil field, could not present any project for 1993. For three weeks, the company's public affairs officials in Lagos kept dodging "Newswatch" enquiries on their community development expenditure in 1992 and 1993.

If most oil companies are paying greater attention to the development of local communities, why are they still experiencing communal disturbances in their areas of operation? Thompson Okorotie, a one time legislator and secretary of the Association of Oil Producing Communities of Nigeria, ASOPCON, says it is the expression of resentment of years of neglect of oil producing areas. This position is shared by many Nigerians, including Chidi Amuta, a former university lecturer. Amuta told a national seminar on "Oil Production and Sustainable Economic Development" in Lagos June 15 that a study conducted by the University of Port Harcourt, UNIPORT, has shown that oil communities have the worst poverty level in the country. The areas do not have amenities like roads, water and electricity, a problem compounded by the difficult riverine terrain of the Niger Delta where oil is produced, he explained. With very few schools especially in the interior areas and lack of infrastructure, indigenes of the areas a re disadvantaged educationally and economically.

Achebe admits that the fundamental cause of the disturbances is the perception of inequity in the distribution of the nation's wealth especially towards the oil producing areas. "While oil money is used to develop other areas, the people from whose land the oil is take see no development," an official of another oil company lamented last week.

Even the government acknowledges this fact. Umaru Baba, minister of state for petroleum resources, said in Lagos June 14 that the communities have genuine grievances having waited for so long to derive lasting benefits from the resources being exploited from their areas. Under Nigeria's petroleum laws, the federal government appropriates the rights over oil and gets all revenue from its production without adequate attention to the oil areas in terms of development.

The oil companies have also contributed to the problem by being insensitive to the plight of their host communities. Before now, they perceived their responsibility as ending with the payment of taxes to the government. That perception only changed in the last three years when disturbances threatened oil production. Paul Asiemo, spokesman for Olomoro community in Delta State, said Shell failed to provide anything beyond a 3-classroom block in the 34 years it had operated in the community. "It was only last year that the company awarded contracts for a six-classroom block and boreholes for the community," he added. Where the facilities were provided, the companies did not bother about their maintenance. For example, in Obagi, a water scheme built by Elf has stopped working for lack of maintenance.

In 1933, the total expenditure on community development projects by all the oil companies was not up to $40 million, less than two percent of their estimated $2.5 billion budget for the year. Don Etiebet, petroleum resources minister, said last March that the extreme disparity in the standard of living in oil workers camp and the host communities equally created tension. This was compounded by the refusal of the companies to extend electricity and potable water enjoyed in such camps to the community. In Oleh, Lucky Ogba, president of the community, complained that the villagers are not allowed to fetch water provided by Shell and SSL for their workers "even though they pollute our own source of water supply without an alternative provision."

Oil companies also delay the payment of compensation for damages to communal and individual property, a problem Shell says it wants to solve by setting a target or 35 days as maximum period for the settlement of claims. Under the Land Uses Act, the land belongs to the state government and not the individual or the community. This makes it possible for oil firms to pay the communities for only structure and crops already on the ground while rent goes to the state government. According to the rates worked out by government, an hectare of farmland would attract a compensation of less than N10,000 and the farmer loses his rights over the land forever. Although, some of the oil companies like Shell have abandoned the government rates to pay at least N100,000 per hectare according to Lawson Jack, others are still hiding under the law to pay the ridiculous rates. The complex procedures for getting the compensation has compelled some of the communities to hire claim agents who take away up to a third of the amount. Lawson Jack said the agents are unnecessary in the case of Shell. For most other companies, the communities complain that they make little headway without the agents who can "settle" officials.

Apart from these problems most of the oil companies have refused to employ indigenes of the oil areas. Unemployed youths are now responsible for most of the disturbances. "They have hijacked leadership from the elders who have failed to deliver over the years," an oil company official said last week. The change in leadership is now making community relations management difficult for the companies. "The elders were easier to deal with," the official added.

At the root of the current spate of disturbances is the question of responsibility for developing the oil areas. To Achebe, the primary responsibility is that of the government. He said, "Our role should be secondary. If Shell takes over the provision of social services, it would end up running a parallel government which is not healthy." Marshal Harry, managing director of Harrison Oil, argues that "whosoever is collecting the oil money should be the person with responsibility to develop the areas. All of them, government and the oil companies have a collective responsibility." Okorotie shares his position saying "the oil companies have something at stake too."

By last week, the oil companies were exploring options for handling the crisis before it gets out of hand. "Newswatch" learnt that a joint submission by all the companies to the Emmanuel Abisoye panel probing the Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation warned of the dangers of continued neglect of the oil areas. They called for quick action by the government on issues fueling the disturbances. As Paul Ogboman, an indigence of Ogbia in Rivers State, said last week, if the neglect and degradation are not promptly addressed, the current spate of disturbances may be "a mere dress rehearsal."

Reprinted from Newswatch, July 4, 1994.

NEWSWATCH is published by Newswatch Communications Ltd., No. 3 Billings Way, Oregun Industrial Estate, Oregun, P.M.B. 21499, Ikeja, Lagos, Nigeria.


LOAD-DATE: July 18, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


230 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 19, 1994 / July 31, 1994


MY OWN COUP


BYLINE: Kayode Soyinka


LENGTH: 1734 words


 

NEWSWATCH,July 11, 1994

Umaru Dikko, Nigeria's most celebrated political exile and transport minister in the Shehu Shagari administration, returned to Nigeria June 26. He has spent ten-and-a-half years in self-exile in Britain, where, in 1984, he was kidnapped, drugged, chained, and crated to be forcibly flown to Nigeria in a Nigerian Airways cargo plane. The kidnap was foiled by British anti-terrorist police at Stansted Airport in the outskirts of London. He is now a nominated member in the Constitutional Conference.

Newswatch: You are returning to Nigeria after more the ten years of self-exile in London. How do you feel now that you are going back home freely? 

Dikko: Well I have always felt that in the end God will ensure that justice is done. I have never lost hope that one day I will again participate in the affairs of my country. Maybe you recall in one of my several interviews with you, I said even though I cannot have access to God's own computer but I believe I have still some programmes in it. Because if the program was finished I would have perished in that crate. I feel thankful to God that He has given me another opportunity. If I had been bad in His sight, He wouldn't give me another opportunity. So, to me, this is my vindication. And I am ready- I have always said it- I am happy, I am ready, whenever my country requires my services, I will offer those services in the best way that I can.

Newswatch: Emotionally, how are you feeling?

Dikko: I don't feel very much emotional. I just feel it is something that has to come. As I said, it did not take me by surprise, because I knew that there is still a programme in God's computer as far as I am concerned. So, all I can say is that I am glad that His will be done.

Newswatch: How did your nomination to the constitutional conference come about?

Dikko: It must have been by the design of the chief designer- that is God. So, to me, it has come the way it has come, it is what I hoped would come. Not that I have been expecting to be included as a member of the constitutional conference. What I am saying is that I have all along expected that one day, God will make it possible for me to show up again in Nigeria, and to carry on with the work that I have been doing, which, even though condemned by some, it has now been proved it has not been condemned by God.

Newswatch: Have you noticed the irony? The same people who declared you wanted, sponsored your kidnap, crated you, and sought your extradition, are the ones now giving you a hero's welcome back to Nigeria as a member of the constitutional conference.

Dikko: Yes. It is now all hands on deck. They say, "when the going becomes tough, it's then the tough gets going."

Newswatch: Many people are still surprised that you are included in the constitutional conference. Who initiated the move to include your name.

Dikko: It is a pleasant surprise. From the day I was told in conversation by some friends locally here (London) that Nigeria would be looking for their best to participate in the conference; I said, "well, if I am not the best, I cannot be the worst." So, therefore, there is a chance, right? So, I thought that somehow, somewhere, at a certain level, one may feature.

Newswatch: What is your own opinion on the constitutional conference? Haven't we had enough constitution-making conferences in Nigeria?

Dikko: I think it is a good thing in the sense that so much water has passed under the bridge, and there is so much more controversy over the last eight, nine years. There have been so many changes, I think it is time we look into the fundamentals and discuss issues openly, frankly, fairly, boldly, courageously, so that once we've found a solution, it would be a stable solution. I don't want any make-shift solutions. As you know I have been out of Nigerian politics within the boundaries of Nigeria over the last ten years. Now that I am going back; we'll pick up where we left.

Newswatch: What are these fundamentals and issues which you think the conference must seriously discuss?

Dikko: Well, in my view, the first and the most important is for the conference to diagnose what has been wrong with Nigeria. Why is that problems always crop up? Why is it we are unable so far, from the day we got independence to this day, to find a permanent solution to our problems? Why do we walk and fall walk and fall, walk and fall? The conference must find out why we don't have stability, politically. We must find out why. Is it due to the selfishness of the elites? Or do the masses have any role to play in it? We must find out. We must really go deep and identify, because if their is a disease and you don't identify the causes then it becomes difficult.

Newswatch: From your experience, what really is the problem with those who lead us in Nigeria?

Dikko: Not many people are willing to work for the country. Most people look at public life in terms of personal benefit, a way of earning a living. This, I think, is one of the real problems facing us. We don't have people with vision, people that lay claim to leadership, they are of very limited vision, and also, of very limited exposure internationally, that is our problem. Therefore, the world is moving on very easy, and if you don't move with the correct speed, you are bound to be left behind, and if you are left behind, all the mess that is thrown out by the fast moving planet will fall on you. I believe it is high time we try to identify those with the correct vision, so our country can be led into a future that is bright. We have got a country with tremendous potentials but because of our political technicians do not see far we always have problems. We say we want democracy and yet we don't even want to except the rules of democracy. If there is an election, as soon as I am the winner, we will shout it is rigging. As soon as you are the winner it is rigging. If you've got two opposing parties, or, two rivals in an competition, if one is victorious, the other has to accept it, and vice-versa; but we don't seem to do that. That is one of the areas where I think there is something fundamentally wrong. That is why I said regard this conference as more then discussing the legal terminologies such as there shall be one president, there shall be this and that; this is more then that, the way I see it. And I want to face it from that angle.

Newswatch: Can the country still remain one?

Dikko: I believe it can, but we have got to work out the modus operandi, because to remain one, it must be to remain sensibly one, and to remain usefully one, and to be determined that by remaining as one, we are going to make progress. This is important. All along we have not sat down to discuss what should be what and who should be where. I think this time we should do so. All these cries of domination, political domination, economic domination, religious domination, all these things we must not fear to discuss them and to negotiate how the country should be run.

Newswatch: Who should decide whether the country should remain one or not, is it a handful of people in the constitutional conference, or, the people of Nigeria themselves in a national referendum which some have called for?

Dikko: First of all I am only saying my own views, I don't know what is on the agenda. Maybe what I am saying may not be on the agenda, but at least that would be my view. Now, left to me, I will say put it to a referendum. Once it is put into a referendum and the country decides, then no local politician can come out with different views. That's the point. Put it to a referendum, let the ordinary man say which way he wants, and then whoever you are, whether you are a delegate, elected or nominated, you know you have to operate within the framework.

Newswatch: But how do we get out of the June 12 albatross that is hanging over the nation?

Dikko: Well, June 12 of 19- what? Of 1994 or 1993? If you are talking of June 12, 1993 dilemma, I think those who are prolonging the dilemma are doing so in an exercise to be heard. They wish to remain in the limelight and that is why they carry on. If you have got only one topic, you keep on talking about it so people can hear your voice. I think that we have got so many topics in Nigeria and people should just forget about June 12.

Reprinted from Newswatch, July 11, 1994

Newswatch is published by Newswatch Communications Ltd., No. 3 Billings Way, Oregun Industrial Estate, Oregun, P.M.B. 21499, Ikeja, Lagos, Nigeria.


LOAD-DATE: July 18, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


231 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 19, 1994 / July 31, 1994


KISEKKA ACCUSES UNDP OF THEFT


BYLINE: Henry Muwanga-Bayego


LENGTH: 1547 words


 

THE MONITOR, June 28 - July 1, 1994

In another public tongue-lashing similar to the recent Uganda Airlines Corporation and Gulf Air affair, President Museveni may again not have been told the whole truth in the controversy surrounding the management of a US$3.1 million UNDP-funded Tree Seed Project.

At a press conference on June 6 after his return from a European tour, Museveni criticised the way the project was being handled. "They have removed the money from the ministry (Natural Resources) to a non-existent unit in a corner...", he said. He promised to investigate.

In an interview with "The Monitor" at his office last Thursday, the Vice President, Dr. Sam Kisekka admitted advising the President on National Execution Unit's (NEX) controversial role in the seed project. 

Without mincing words, the VP said NEX was formed to tap money from government project, employing people who wanted to net a lot of money after resigning from government. He said he briefed the President after detecting a lot of loopholes in the operation of NEX.

The two year long controversy of the stalled project in which the Vice President was drawn, began with complaints by the Natural Resource Minister, Henry Kajura seeking management of the project without the involvement of the Ministry of Finance and Economic Planning.

Henry Kajura had written to the Minister of Finance and Economic Planning complaining that the project had stalled due to NEX's interference.

The Vice President intervened in June last year by writing to the Minister of Finance & Economic Planning expressing his concern over the interference of NEX which he called an "illegal" unit in the Ministry of Finance. He said its activities had never been discussed in cabinet, especially whether its formation and modalities were acceptable to all ministers.

But the VP's intervention instead fuelled bickerings over the project. The Ministry of Finance insists that on May 3, 1990, the Minister of State for Finance & Economic Planning, Matthew Rukikaire, communicated to all ministers and copied the letter to all permanent secretaries, the three Deputy Premiers about the formation of NEX. The functions of NEX were explicitly outlined to include monitoring, executing and overseeing on behalf of government all United Nations supported projects. And to streamline accountability of UNDP funds.

The Unit's organisational chart falls under External Aid Coordination Department. Under the agreement of the Tree Seed Project a national and three regional centres would be set up.

This explanation however was not bought by those opposed to any interference in the project. The first scathing attack came from the Assistant Commissioner Forestry who is also Seed Project Manager, (also said to be wife to the then Personal Assistant to the Vice-President Nyanja Musoke) Mrs. Racheal Musoke.

In her correspondences, she alleged that NEX was a one man organisation formed by the Permanent Secretary in the Ministry of Finance & Economic Planning, Tumusime Mutebile, which had ignored Desk Officers in the implementing line of the Ministry of Natural Resources.

To this Mutebile agrees that an error of omission in the letters of agreement had been made. Because under the agreement, the Department of Forestry was erroneously accorded the executing status when by virtue of its technical nature it is supposed to be merely implementing. Mutebile wrote to the UNDP indicating that there was need to amend the letters of agreement for the Tree Seed Project.

In an interview last week, the UNDP Resident Representative and Co-ordinator of all UN operational activities in Uganda, Tedla Teshome, said NEX is legal and operating under procedures accepted by both government and UNDP.

He said the controversy which surrounds the Tree Seed Project is an internal problem brought about by officials in the department of Forestry.

He said that UNDP was happy with the performance of NEX because it controls and makes assessments on projects' progress. UNDP represents the project donor, United Nations Sudano Sahelian Office (UNSO) in New York.

But the Vice-President would not buy any of that. On May 16, 1994 he wrote to the Director of OPS (Office for Project) in New York requesting the head office's intervention. He protested the ways in which UNDP Kampala and NEX were handling the affairs of the Project.

Kisekka accused the Kampala UNDP office of conniving with NEX to terminate the services of the project's Chief Technical Adviser, James Kilpatrick

He warned that government was taking a very serious view of the attempt by the UNDP office in Kampala to "run a government within government." He also asked them to rectify the situation "for future smooth running of various programmes."

He rubbished the argument that NEX was formed in May, 1990 and known to all ministers. He reasoned that if the Unit had been operating at that time (1990), then the letters of agreement which were signed in 1991, would have stated NEX as the executing agent but not the Forestry Department which is fighting to control the project funds.

"I cannot rule out the fact that UNDP Kampala colluded with NEX to misappropriate the project money. Well they would like to exonerate themselves through the press but have not done the right thing," he said. He said the decent desert was advancing but that the expatriate (James Kilpatrick) who was working on the project had been laid off.

"The Monitor" has learnt that Teshome, disturbed by the CP's harsh language over the matter and believing that both the president and the CP have been insufficiently informed, has been trying to get the facts to the two. But going by the CP's response last week, the conflict seems to be still far from being resolved.

Responding to accusations levelled against NEX, its head Wesles Nyabongo, in an interview last Thursday decried the poor level of concern the Minister of Natural Resources and the Vice President had over the Unit. He said by an Act of Parliament, the Ministry of Finance and Economic Planning is empowered to enter in any contract on behalf of government but not any ministry.

He said it was absurd that the Vice President and Minister Kajura were the only officials who claimed not knowing about the existence of NEX, when over 80 UN Projects are executed by the Unit on behalf of government. He said that the calibre of manpower at the Unit equalled the expatriates level.

"NEX has a long term strategy of eliminating the expatriate component on UN funded projects. In fact government should be proud of our performance instead of calling us an illegal Unit," he said.

Reacting to the termination of Kilpatrick"s services, Nyabongo said he performed below expectation and that was the reason why UNDP which handles all OPS and UNSO projects declined to renew his contract which expires in May this year. Kilpatrick failed to submit a project plan after working on the project for a year. And that it was the DANIDA Seed Centre staff who assisted him prepare one.

The NEX boss said he had a problem of receiving accounts of the project from the Project Manager, Racheal Musoke, because for two years nothing was going on. "Except of course she was making budgetary revisions and requesting more money for no work done," he alleged.

Reprinted from The Monitor, June 28 - July 1, 1994.

The Monitor is published by The Monitor Publications Ltd. (Uganda) Contact: The Monitor, P.O. Box 12141, Kampala. Phone: 251353; fax: 251352.


LOAD-DATE: July 18, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


232 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 19, 1994 / July 31, 1994


KAIJUKA DENIES "EATING" FROM MARLBORO DEAL


BYLINE: Lillian Nsubuga


LENGTH: 1120 words


 

THE MONITOR, June 14-17 1994

The arrival of Marlboro on the Ugandan tobacco scene is stirring up controversy with allegations the Trade and Industry minister, Richard Kaijuka, is personally "eating" from the palms of Philip Morris -- the American multinational making Marlboros.

The arrival of Philip Morris broke a decade-long monopoly by British American Tobacco (BAT) Uganda Ltd.

A BAT mid-May press statement said they did not object to competition from any company joining the Uganda market, as long as it was fair and honest.

There are however those who claim there is something fishy about this Marlboro affair. There are claims that Kaijuka, who signed the agreement that gave Marlboro a slot on the Ugandan scene and NRM Vice Chairman, Haji Moses Kigongo have a vested interest -- considering their assumed links with Translink (U) Ltd., the marketing agents of Marlboro. It is said that Kaijuka and Kigongo pushed for Marlboro only, as opposed to a general opening of the market to all cigarette makers because they hoped to make money out of the deal which only allows for a duopoly. 

And that is not all. There are those who will swear that Kaijuka has a grudge against BAT and is determined to kill it using his positions Minister of Trade and Industry.

But Mr. Phakrar Makesh, Translink (U) Ltd. boos, refuted the allegations. So did Kaijuka.

Kaijuka says that the government has "liberalised the entire tobacco industry" from the production and marketing of the tobacco leaf to importation of cigarettes.

He explained that the government has started having problems with the tobacco industry. "That is why we liberalised it. BAT was, allegedly, not buying all the tobacco grown by the farmers causing a surplus menace in many tobacco growing areas."

That was mainly because of the glut on the international market for the leaf. "BAT was therefore buying from only the contract farmers, while other farmers were left out," he explained.

He said that farmers had also began having doubts about BAT being the only buyer of their crop. "Some felt they were not getting a fair price for their crop, and that if there were other buyers, it would perhaps improve their opportunities."

He said that there were also problems with classification, so tobacco farmers with grades BAT didn't want were left in the cold.

Kaijuka says government will now allow in any company as long as it has the capacity to buy the surplus tobacco that BAT may not have purchased; and as long as it has the capacity to help Uganda grow appropriate varieties of tobacco and can assist in marketing it.

"Even today any company can come in as long as it can help us to solve those problems," Kaijuka said.

He said that government has still protected BAT by imposing an import duty for all the new companies in addition to all the other taxes paid by BAT.

According to Kaijuka any newcomers must first deal with the surplus of tobacco before they can start growing, and they must go to new areas and new farmers, not those already developed by BAT.

He said that this was a cabinet decision, and not his alone. In any case, he said, he has never done business with Kigongo.

Kaijuka also said that a number of other companies have asked to be allowed into the Uganda market but some are not willing to undertake those conditions. "Philip Morris have promised to undertake these responsibilities, that's why we let them in," Kaijuka said.

Makesh said that whichever conditions have been imposed on Philip Morris will be honoured, although this can't be done overnight.

"The infrastructure in Uganda has been developed by BAT, so we have to put parallel infrastructure before we can begin growing," he said.

Makesh added, "BAT has been producing its own tobacco. So Philip Morris can't just buy BAT tobacco unless it is clear it has failed to buy,"

But BAT Assistant Public Relations Manager, Jimmy Kiberu, said that BAT buys all the usable tobacco and it is very unlikely for any other company to buy tobacco rejected by BAT because it is usually of poor quality.

Another BAT official said that tobacco growing is a very expensive and cumbersome affair only a committed company would undertake.

He said the Philip Morris is essentially a manufacturing company which buys tobacco leaf from tobacco merchants like Universal Leaf (an American Company), and Standard Commercial.

"Uganda would be a rare exception if Philip Morris suddenly decided to go into growing," the official mused.

He said BAT has 300 extension workers upcountry, and spends about Shs. 3bn every season on extension services (which includes planting techniques and advice on how to use fertilisers).

Worse still, prices for the tobacco leaf have registered a 20 percent drop in the last two years, which makes growing tobacco very risky and unprofitable. For instance. a BAT mid-May press statement said that Zimbabwe had reduced its tobacco crop from 230 million Kgs last season to 165 million this season. The statement said the BAT made a loss on the export side of its business last year.

Reprinted from The Monitor, June 14-17, 1994

The Monitor is published by The Monitor Publications Ltd. (Uganda) Contact: The Monitor, P.O. Box 12141, Kampala. Phone: 251353; fax: 251352.


LOAD-DATE: July 18, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


233 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


July 19, 1994 / July 31, 1994


CA IN SECRET PLAN TO MAKE NEW GOVERNMENT?


BYLINE: Peter G. Mwesige & Kyazze Simwogerere


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 2307 words


 

THE MONITOR, July 1-5, 1994

Behind the noisy scenes in the Constituent Assembly, there is a plan which is brewing to turn it into a transitional parliament -- and government under President Yoweri Museveni -- after the NRM's extension expires January 26, 1995.

According to information available to "The Monitor", a power-sharing deal for a transitional government is being brokered behind the CA curtains as a compromise for both multi-partyists and movement advocates. This would come into effect when the NRM's five year extension expires January 1995.

The behind the scene manoeuvers, are producing strange bed fellows, and deals are being cut around some critical issues over which the delegates are sharply divided.

The type of government is obviously the biggest bone of contention, and "Movement" politicians argue -- as they have done for the last eight years -- that the political parties need time to "re-organise." 

Outnumbered and outplayed, several multi-party delegates are said to be arguing that a snap election in 1995 would give NRM as easy election win, something everyone fears might brew trouble. But in making that argument, they will be able to eat their cake and have it at the same time. They could "eat" something from supporting an extension of NRM rule in more respectable form in the transitional government, and yet appear to their electorate to have supported multi-partyism in principle.

That the Movement system -- or the NRM -- be given five more years in its present form, which has until now seemed a credible idea, is withering.

Most critics say in NRM got another lease of power through any kind of arrangement other than a REAL general election, they would appear like political crooks who have stayed longer than their welcome.

Besides, many delegates towing this line argue that due to logistical mountains, it is impossible to hold an election in January 1995 when the NRM's mandate expires

CA Commissioner Stephen Akabway's Election Evaluation Workshop held in Mbarara in May seemed to work in favour of this view when it recommended that given the many hurdles conservative estimates of the time required to adequately prepare general elections is ten to twelve months from the.

The cheap alternative.

The idea of transforming the CA into a "transitional parliament" and President Museveni into a transitional leader.

That the President be directed to transform the National Resistance Army (NRA) into a NATIONAL ARMY, and change the widespread view that it is his "army." The proposed national army be recruited through a quota system for each of Uganda's 39 districts.

The political parties would also sort out their houses and together with CA delegates, nominate ministers who would then form a transitional government.

In fact some members of UPC, though they scorned the CA elections and officially say they will not recognise whatever comes out of it, are said to be already negotiating for some slots in the transitional government!

It is this government that would steer the country into general elections. All in the magical year 2000.

Very convenient.

Museveni gets the best part of the beef in this scheme. He is looked at as the man who should lead the transitional government, since he is the one who "initiated the democratisation process."

The group pushing for the transitional arrangement is said to be vehemently opposed to a power-sharing deal with the National Resistance Council (NRC) which they accuse of having botched up the 1989 extension. They say the CA is more credible if transformed into a legislature because it was largely elected on universal adult suffrage.

They also believe that even if it comes to push and shove, they would still manage to push a vote through the NRC to amend the Law and accommodate any new arrangement. Not surprisingly, the NRC is struggling to gain credibility. In an unprecedented move which was seen as a vote of no-confidence in government, it trashed President Museveni's Communication from the Chair statement to parliament, which was full of rosy claims on the economy but had no new ideas to help the growing army of the poor. The CMs always knew that these claims about the wonders of the economy were a world apart from reality, but had never had the guts to say so.

The only problems for this transitional scheme seems to stem form the kind of trade-offs that have to come into play.

Federalism is one issue which will simply not die, for instance; the line which was mooted by the Buganda Lukiiko was that all the nationalities (tribes) in Uganda should go their separate ways in administration.

The Lukiiko argues that federalism is the only way Ugandans can live together without pointing tribalistic fingers at each other, and is the only way to end the robbery of the rest of the country to fill the stomachs of the tribe in power.

The Baganda delegates believe they have a good chance of getting their way on this, and are also reported to have changed tactics.

CA delegates from Buganda have told "The Monitor" of talks about giving the platform to delegates from areas other than Buganda to push for "federo" so that it is not seen as merely a local Buganda issue.

Many NRM politicians loathe federalism because they think it is shorthand for the rest of Ugandans being chased out of Buganda.

But if the buoyant mood that existed during the coronation of King Ronald Mutebi last July is anything to go by, the Buganda are not going to let this thing go without one hell of a fight.

It would be suicidal for government to forget that it was party to whipping up expectations which must be met at least half way. "The Monitor" has learnt that the NRM is trying to find a solution to this question in "federo" based on regions. This arrangement is aimed at mostly benefiting and appeasing Buganda.

The raw nerves over federalism were exposed just days ago, when Minister of Justice and Attorney General Abu Mayanja, CA delegate for Busujju made an outrageous remark regarding kingship.

After the children's CA mock debate two weeks ago decided that monarchies be banned, Abu rather recklessly (though some people say he was only joking) said that "those who do not want kingdoms should leave the country."

The Wednesday Abu was reported in a "New Vision" lead story to have cautioned non-Baganda living in Buganda to desist from any attempt to oppose full restoration of monarchism in the region. He is reported to have said that monarchism would be fully resorted whether the "aliens" like it or not.

He drew a lot of flak for the remarks and even had to call a press conference Wednesday to clear the air. "There are differences (in the Ugandan communities) and it is a mistake to pretend that they are not there," he said, though he conceded that the statement after the kinds" debate was unguarded. A source who was tat the occasion in Njeru where Abu spoke claims that "The New Vision" only reported the tip of the iceberg.

Mayanja's pleas that his remark was unguarded was not known in the CA where he was attacked viciously.

Prof. Apollo Nsibambi, who also got carried away after the children's mock debate, on his part told "The Monitor" Wednesday that the issue of federalism is falsely equated with monarchism yet the two are different.

"Bugandanising the issue is a way of dismarketing it," he said.

"Federalism is a national issue not a Buganda issue."

About the trade-offs in the house, the professor admitted there was a lot of bargaining in the CA corridors.

"But there is no war in the CA. We have a more informal and detailed form of bargaining where people are much more amicable," he said.

He dismissed the alleged trade-off between pluralists and "Buganda federo" saying the two are separate.

Nsibambi also dismissed the idea of a transitional government.

"I don't think a transitional government is necessary because after the CA we shall have elections. We are now ready to have a fully elected government.

Omara Atubo however told "The Monitor" the same day that a participatory position would be the moderate position.

"Parties don't think they are participating in terms of policy," he said.

On federalism, Atubo said it is complicated by the tendency to equate federalism with the supremacy of the Kabaka in Buganda, which may be seen to threaten the unity of Uganda.

He said a short term alliance will not help the country.

"If we believe Uganda is ready for federalism let's go for it. If we believe it needs pluralism let's go for it," Atubo argued.

In fact the spirit of consensus that many delegates like referring to platitudinously, is also threatened by a reported split between delegates who are also NRC members -- now called veterans and the fresh delegates -- called virgins.

The virgins have already started charging that the veterans are trying to marginalise them.

An unhappy virgin delegate who talked on condition of anonymity to "The Monitor" complained that even the four committees that have just been instituted are all led by veterans.

The Rules and Orders Committee Chairmanship went to Omara Atubo with Brigadier Jim Muhwezi acting as deputy.

The Privileges, Discipline & Welfare Committee went to Brig. (Retired) Moses Ali who emerged man of the week after clinching FUFA chairmanship. Hajati Janet Mukwaya is his deputy, while the Business Committee, the biggest of them all, will be chaired by Stephen Kavuma.

The sharp-tongued George Kanyeihamba ate Chairmanship for Legal & Drafting Committee with Ben Wacha being his deputy. This especially is reported to have witnessed a big battle with the virgins pushing for Dani Nabudere. It is only an alleged deal between the NRM and UPC that Kanyeihamba cam in on the NRM ticket, while Wacha on the UPC ticket.

Most delegates from Northern Uganda, especially the pluralists, are also said to be bidding their time and not talking, to "avoid being sized up."

But the NRM is said to be playing their cards tight. Many CA delegates believe that already cars for the delegates have entered the country but will only be given out "when Museveni thinks the time is ripe!"

And of course, everyone wants to eat, whether a car, ministry or some parastatal job.

In an assembly which in public is said to be split over everything from petty details like whether delegates need cars, how much they should earn, whether to be called Distinguished of Honourable Delegate or something else, to big issue of land, citizenship and the big one -- the Movement, buying them might be the best way to go.

It is a divided House that one. But that is not say there is no "glue" which will bring them together. The question is, what will that glue be?

Reprinted from The Monitor, July 1-5, 1994.

The Monitor is published by The Monitor Publications Ltd. (Uganda) Contact: The Monitor, P.O. Box 12141, Kampala. Phone: 251353; fax: 251352.


LOAD-DATE: July 18, 1994


LANGUAGE: English

August 1, 1994 / August 14, 1994


BUSINESS


LENGTH: 520 words


 

American Information Technologies (AIT) can provide computer equipment, installation, maintenance, and training services for business or individuals starting up in Africa. For additional information,

contact: AIT, PO Box i510, Tucker, GA Tel: (404) 723- 9200. 

The following procurement opportunities in EGYPT are available to U.S. companies through the U.S. Agency for International Development.

* Color Plotters, color scanners, optical drives and digitizers for geographic information system. IFB No.: CID94018. A.I.D. Geographic Code 000 (U.S. only). Africa News


August 1, 1994 / August 14, 1994


EDUCATION/TRAVEL


LENGTH: 2294 words


 

The National Research Council announces the 1994 Resident, Cooperative, and Postdoctoral Research Associateship Programs to be conducted on behalf of federal agencies or research institutions whose 140 participating research laboratories are located throughout the United States. The program provides opportunities for PhD scientists and engineers of unusual promise and ability to perform research on problems largely of their own choosing yet compatible with the research interests of the sponsoring laboratory. Areas of interest include chemistry, earth and atmospheric sciences, engineering and applied sciences, biological, health, and behavioral science and biotechnology, mathematics, space and planetary sciences, and physics. Applications submitted directly to the National Research Council are accepted on a continuous basis throughout the year. Those postmarked no later than 15 August will be reviewed in October. Initial awards will be announced in July and November. Information on specific research opportunities and participating federal laboratories, as well as application materials, may be obtained from the Associateship Programs. 

The Collaborative Projects Program of the National Endowment for the Humanities welcomes applications for projects of broad scholarly and public significance in the humanities that entail the collaboration of two or more scholars for periods 1-3 years. All topics in the humanities are eligible. Awards usually range from $10,000 to about $150,000. The deadline is OCTOBER 15, 1994 for projects beginning no earlier than July of the next year. For application materials and further information write or call: Collaborative, Projects/Interpretive Research, Division of Research Programs, Room 318, 1100 Pennsylvania Ave., NW, Washington, DC 20506. Tel: (202) 606-8210.

The National Endowment for the Humanities Reference Materials Program supports projects to prepare reference works that will improve access to information and resources. Support is available for the creation of dictionaries, historical or linguistic atlases, encyclopedias, concordances, reference grammars, databases, textbooks, and other projects that will provide essential scholarly tools for the advancement of research or for general reference purposes. Support is also available for projects that address important issues related to the design or accessibility of reference works. The application deadline of 15 SEPTEMBER 1994 for projects beginning after 1 JULY 1995. For more information write to Reference Materials, Room 318, NEH, Washington, DC 20506.

The Re-entry Grants for African Scholars Pursuing Education Research program is designed to assist in the professional re-establishment of talented African scholars who are returning from doctoral studies abroad and have a research interest in issues related to the revitalisation and development of education in sub-Saharan Africa. All proposed projects must include and explicitly and substantial focus on female school participation as part of the set of educational issues to be examined. The proposed budget, not to exceed $25,000, any request funding for items such as a microcomputer and software, books, office supplied, living expenses, personnel assistance and local transportation. The budget may also include subsistence for on research team member of any nationality and a stipend to cover up to 6 month's transition costs for the returning African scholar. Applicants may submit research proposals prior to or within one year of returning to their Africa-based institutions. Grants are made to the scholar, but the proposal must be endorsed by the African institution where the application will be a full-time staff member. Also required are two letters of recommendation from academic supervisors at the institution where the candidate carried out doctoral study, postgraduate transcripts, and a resume. There are no deadlines for submission of proposals. For a full description of the program, write to Scholars on Education Re-Entry Program, The Rockefeller Foundation, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, New York, NY 10036 or Scholars on Education Re-Entry Program, The Rockefeller Foundation, P.O. Box 47543, Nairobi, Kenya.

The Social Science Research Council/American Council of Learned Societies is calling for proposals for their African Archives and Museums Project (AAMP). The AAMP is designed to help museums and archives in their efforts to overcome problems of funding and materials. AAMP awards two types of grants: seed grants and implementation grants. Seed grants up to $5,000 are intended to advance the conceptual and logistical development of conservation, documentation or exhibition/outreach/education projects. Implementation grants from $5,000 up to $15,000 are intended to support conservation, documentation, and exhibition/outreach/education activities. AAMP is especially receptive to projects that draw on local expertise and community resources and bring together different institutions in cooperative ventures. For more information and for a list of 1993 awards, address inquiries to the African Archives and Museums Projects, Social Science Research Council, 605 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10158. Tel: (212) 661-0280. Fax: (212) 370-7896.

Environmental Briefs Corp. is a non-profit organization that publishes a newsletter updating African environmental scientists on recent findings published in academic literature. The student intern would serve as an editorial assistant. Duties would include: reading and summarizing articles in the academic literature; going to university libraries to photocopy articles; writing letters to journal editors and article authors; and updating mailing lists. Knowledge of or familiarity with calculus, mathematical models, the earth sciences and Africa would be helpful. Computer experience (preferably in a Macintosh environment) is also a plus. While this is an unpaid internship, it will provide invaluable experience to anyone interested in a career in either international development of the environment. Please contact Catherine Camp Boyle, Environmental Briefs Corp., 22 Willowdale Road, Winchester, MA 01890.

The Population-Environment Fellows Program, sponsored by USAID and administered at the University of Michigan, sponsors fellow for two-year appointments with overseas agencies. Fellows, who must hold a graduate degree in a relevant area and demonstrated expertise a both population and environment, provide assistance and technical support for developing country institutions to foster a comprehensive approach to development. Applications are reviewed on a rolling basis, but the sooner a completed application is received, the greater the availability of sites for which it can be considered. Inquiries and application requests may be obtained by contacting: The Population-Environment Fellows Program, SPH II, Room M2240, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109-2029. Tel: (313) 747-0222. Fax: (313) 747-4947.

The University of Florida sponsors academic yearabroad programs in Tanzania and Nigeria and summer programs in Uganda and Morocco. At the University of Dar es Salaam in Tanzania, students spend an academic year studying Swahili. A summer field course in tropical rain forest ecology and conservation will be offered in the Kibale Forest of Western Uganda at the Makere University Biological Field Station. A Summer Arabic Language, Conversation and Translation Program is located in Fez, Morocco. Contact: Overseas Studies, Office of International Studies and Programs, 123 Tigert Hall, University of Florida, Gainesville, FL 32611. Tel: (904) 392-5206. Fax: (904) 392-5575.

Research grants in African Rural Development Issues are offered by the Winrock International Institute for Agricultural Development. Although the fourth round of grants had a deadline of February 1, 1994, interested social scientists may contact Winrock for further information on future funding opportunities. Contact: Dirk Perthel, Winrock International, 08 B.P. 1603, Abidjan 08, Cote d'Ivoire. Phone: (225) 44-94-14. Fax: (225) 44-94-11. Their U.S. office is at 1611 N. Kent St., #600, Arlington, VA 22209. Tel: (703) 525-9430. Fax: (703) 525-1744.

University of Minnesota, Minnesota Studies in International Development (MSID) offers an academic year program of internships and field study including 5 months in Senegal or Kenya. Financial aid is available. Details are available at the Center of through: MSID, The Global Campus, University of Minnesota, 106-M Nicholson Hall, 216 Pillsbury Drive SE, Minneapolis, MN 55455-0138. Tel: (216) 625-3379.

The Center for Global Education announces a semester-long program in Namibia designed to introduce students to the central issues facing Southern Africa. Course credit may be earned. Applications and brochures are available from Center for Global Education, Augsburg College, 2211 Riverside Avenue, Minneapolis, MN 55454. Tel: (612) 330-1159.

The National Science Foundation grants Dissertation Improvement awards to support the work of African graduate students enrolled in US universities who plan to conduct dissertation research on a topic relating to a developing country problem. The grants cover only research expenses and travel costs (no tuition, fees, or living expenses). For further information, contact: Francis Li, National Science Foundation, 4201 Wilson Blvd., Room 935, Arlington, CA 22230. Tel: (703) 306-1234.

The University of Westminster offers MA/Postgraduate diplomas in Francophone African Studies. The MA in Francophone African Studies provides students with the framework within which they can study aspects of Francophone Africa, including literature, political and socio-economic issues, in the context of the relevant major debates raised by the discourses of post-colonialism. For further information and application form, please contact: Nikki Roberts, School of Languages, University of Westminster, 9-18, Euston Centre, London NW1 3ET.

The African Development Foundation (ADF) is a public enterprise established by the U.S. Congress in 1980 to support self-development initiatives by Africans. The ADF provides postgraduate and doctoral research fellowships. The deadline is August 1, 1994. Contact: The Office of Learning Dissemination, African Development Foundation, 1400 I Street, NW, Washington, DC 20005.

The Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture has a Scholars in Residence program, designed to encourage research and writing in black history and culture, to facilitate interaction among the participants and to provide for widespread dissemination of findings through lectures, publications, and the Schomburg Center Seminars. For information and application forms, write to: Scholars in Residence Program, Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, The New York Public Library, 515 Malcolm X Boulevard, New York, NY 10037-1801. Tel: 212-491-2203.

The University of Cape Town's Centre for African Studies announces the Harry Oppenheimer Research Fellowship. Applicants are considered annually in December for the following year. The fellowship is for three to six months, depending on the recipients program. Fellows receive R7500 and are expected deliver an Africa Seminar and contribute to the cultural life of the Centre. Contact: Harry Oppenheimer Institute, UCT Private Bag, 7700 Ronderbosch, University of Cape Town, South Africa. Phone: (021) 650-3273. Fax: (021) 650-3274. email: erasmus@socsci.uct.ac.za.
