August 1, 1994 / August 14, 1994


EMPLOYMENT


LENGTH: 7374 words


 

Washington-based international development firm interested in receiving resumes from experienced project management professionals. Interested individuals must have at least ten years experience working with private voluntary organizzations and/or USAID in the area of development and humanitarian assitance. They should be experienced in program evaluation, project design and implementation, and the management of USAID/PVO grant portfolios. Experience in any of the follwing very userul: samll enterprisee credit development, agriculture/farming systems, natural resources management/environmental protection, cooperative/international trade, and development education. Fax CV to Mendez England & Assoc,. 202-965- 4053.

Washington-based international development firm is seeking individuals with 3+ years experience in the administration of USAID/PVO grant portfolio. Knowledge and working experience iwth proposal reviews, project monitoring and evaluation, preparation of grant documents and overall grant management and adminstration. Qualified candidates should be able to pick up on complex subject matter and procedures quickly and be able to handle routine work conscientiously. Must posses excellent writing and communications skills. Undergraduate degree required. Fax CA to Mendez England & Assoc,. 202-965-4053.

Mendez England & Associates is seeking experienced consultants in the following areas for upcoming projects: project evaluation, project design and implementation; management and technical training; small enterprise credit development; agriculture/farming systems; natural resources mangement/enviornmental protection; cooperative/international trade; development education; local government; communications; journalism; and television production. Fax CV to Mendez England & Assoc,. 202-965-4053. 

The School of International and Public Affairs at Columbia University is expanding its Executive-in- Residence and Diplomat-in-Residence programs to include the field of economic and political development. The School seeks individual for the Economic and Political concentration of the Master of International Affairs program. This 1-year appointment, beginning no later than September 1, may be renewed annually for up to 5 years. Stipend of $25,000/academic year. Individual will teach one course on project management and lead one semester- long workshop in economic and political development designed to enable students to apply theories and skills learned in the classroom to specific development problems.Candidate will participate in student advising and career counseling. These responsibilities will involve 2-3 days/week during the academic year. Qualifications: extensive field-level project management experience; understanding of management functions such as options analysis, organizational analysis, human resources management, information management, financial management, performance management and quality and production line management; broad knowledge of development, and its economic, political, administrative, and cultural dimensions. Resumes by August 1 to: Dean Steven Cohen, 1417 International Affairs Building, 420 West 118th Street, New York, NY 10027.

DIRECTOR OF INTERNATIONAL OPERATIONS - Candidate should have strong knowledge of international development agencies and development issues related to macro-economic policies, private sector development, privatization, training and management and institutional development; familiarity with foreign direct investment and capital financing; good organizational, analytical, communication and interpersonal skills; strong knowledge of computer databases and electronic information management; working knowledge of 1+ foreign languages, preferably French or Spanish; minimum BA; MA in relevant field preferred; prior work experience in a developing country. Responsibilities: Supervise and backstop all international activities including helping set priorities, communicating these to staff, and overseeing implementation; manage all research requests for ongoing activities and marketing, including supervision of research staff; work on specific projects on an ad hoc basis and undertake assignments to prepare feasibility studies, proposals and reports; market the firm's capabilities to private corporations, government agencies, foreign governments and non-profit organizations. Fax resume to the attention of G. Walker at 703-684-9489.

The AIDS Control and Prevention (AIDSCAP) Division of Family Health International seeks a DEPUTY DIRECTOR, AFRICA to assist the Regional Director in providing technical and managerial expertise in planning, implementing and evaluating country programs and to provide direct supervision of office staff. Requires doctoral or masters level degree in social science, publich health and 7+ years of program management experience; considerable knowledge and expertise in public health, infectious disease transmission, and behaviour change related to health issues. Please state salary requirements in cover letter with resume to: Human Resources (MD/DDA), FHI, 2101 Wilson Blvd., Suite 700, Arlington, VA 22201.

Refugees International is seeking a senior advocate to become a key player in our advocacy on behalf of refugees and other humanitarian victims. The senior advocate is expected to travel on short notice to sites of humanitarian emergencies to assess needs and give early warning using written and verbal reports of governments, UN officials, the media, etc. Ideal applicant would have: excellent written and verbal advocacy skills and name recognition; extensive experience in conducting humanitarian emergency field assessments; strong background in Africa; and good working knowledge of UN humanitarian operations with relevant contacts. Send resume, salary history, and 2 writing samples to: Refugees International, 21 Dupont Cicle NW, Washington, DC 20036. Fax: 202-828-0819.

PACT, Inc. seeks outstanding, broad-gauged individaul with 3-5 years media experience to: conceive, shape and impart the public image of PACT targets to US and overseas audiences through media, publications and videos; work with PACT overseas and US staffs and others to document program experiences, and to articulate and share lessons learned; write speeches, op-ed pieces and other PACT-focused literature including annual report; and sevre as PACT spokesperson. Send letter of interest, resume, salary history and writing samples to: Fannie Sedgwick, Executive Search, PACT, Inc., 1901 Pennsylvania Ave., NW #510, Washington, DC 20006.

Heifer Project International, an international non-profit organization, seeks writer/editor. Experienced person to research, write and edit publications. College degree or equivalent experience required. Salary $20-23K DOE. Job description available upon request. Send resume by August 1 to Personnel Office, Heifer Project International, PO Box 808, Little Rock, AR 72203.

Bread for the World, a nation-wide, faith-based, anti-hunger advocacy orgnaization is looking for a Writer/Editor/Coordinator with the ability to take complex hunger-related policy issues and write for a general membership audience. Five years of experience, rewriting, editing, proofreading and publication coordination skills are essential. Good people skills necessary. Send resume, availability, salary needs and references to: Carole Zimmerman, BFW, 1100 Wayne Ave., Suite 1000, Silver Springs, MD 20910. No phone calls please. BFW is an equal opportunity employer.

CURRICULUM DEVELOPER/TRAINER - Develop advocacy training materials for womens' NGOs in preparation for the 1995 World Women's Conference, with a focus on Africa. Broad background in women's issues and development and proven training capabilities required. French required. OPD SUPERVISOR, Uganda. Responsibilities: train and supervise local nursing staff; set-up emergency/acute care clinic; collaborate with local health authorities, NGOs and UN agnecies; oversee patient and clinic activities and prepare monthly reports. Qualifications: RN or MD with emergency/acute care experience in developing coutnries; proven success in implementing new programs in relief situtaions; excellent communication and interpersonal skills; self-starter; training experience desirable. $1,200/month, 6 month contract. Call or send resume to American Refugees Committte, Cathy Tilsen, 2344 Nicollet Avenue, #350, Minneapolis, MN 55404. Phone: 612-872-7060. Fax: 612-872-4309.

MENTAL HEALTH COORDINATOR, Uganda. Position will work with Rwandan refugees in two camps in southern Uganda. Responsibilities: prepare and conduct needs assessment; prepare and conduct training course for Rwanda counterparts; develop, with counterparts, therapeutic activities; provide accessible mental health services to refugees in both camps.

Qualifications: Masters degree in counseling and mental health services; minimum of 2 years developing country experience; previous experience with post traumatic stress disorder, preferably among refugees; ability to work well with refugees and host country nationals in program planning and implementation. French proficiency desired. 6 month contract, $1,200/month, immediate opening. Transportation, health insurance and group housing provided. Contact American Refugees Committte, Cathy Tilsen, 2344 Nicollet Avenue, #350, Minneapolis, MN 55404. Phone: 612-872-7060. Fax: 612-872-4309.

HOME VISIT COORDINATOR, Uganda.

Responsibilities: Coordinate with Ugandan Red Cross to select participants to be trained as home visitors; prepare and implement training course to enable participants to provide primary health outreach to all families in the refugee camps; supervise and support local staff in daily primary health care activities; provide continuing education to the home visitor participants; prepare and submit reports and attend meetings as needed. Qualifications: RN or MPH with minimum 2 years experience in health prevention/promotion activities; previous developing country experience; ability to work effectively with host country nationals and refugees in program planning and implementation; and proficiency in French. 6 month contract. Immediate opening. $1,200/month. Call or send resume to American Refugees Committte, Cathy Tilsen, 2344 Nicollet Avenue, #350, Minneapolis, MN 55404. Phone: 612-872-7060. Fax: 612- 872-4309.

International Rescue Committee seeks fund- raising professional to manage major gift program. Applications must possess 3 years of fund-raising experience (preferably with a non-profit major gift program), BA/BS, strong analytical and organizational skills, excellent communication skills, both verbal and written; some field experience with refugees desirable; some international travel. Must be willing team player. Position offers excellent salary/benefits and pleasant work environment. Send cover letter, salary history and resume to: Louise Shea, IRC, 122 East 42nd Street, New York, NY 10168.

DEVELOPMENT OFFICER. The International Women's Health Coalition seeks seasoned development professional to manage annual and project funddevelopment of annual fund-raising goals, design and raising. Newly-created position. Responsibilities: management of campaigns and events; writing proposals, solicitations, reports; coordination of prospect and donor research and contacts. Emphasis on expanding individual donor base. Qualifications: 5-10 years significant development experienece; strong writing and oral communication skills; computer literate. Requirements: detail-oriented, highly organized.

World Vision US seeks individuals to handle the following responsibilities in DC office: financial management of government contracts, budgeting for grant proposals, compliance reporting, and providing technical support to field offices. Must have good communication skills and the ability to manage multiple tasks under very tight deadlines. Degree in accounting or finance and at least 5 years experience required. CPA or advanced degree desired. Requires extensive international travel. Resume to World Vision US, Employment Dept., 919 W. Huntington Dr., Monrovia, CA 91016.

ACCION International seeks Program Assistant tot work with Director of US Operations in all aspects of management and development of ACCION's network of associated microenterprise organizsations throughout the US> Recommeneded qualifications invlude knowledge of community economic development (in the US and/or in the field of microenterprise development), relevant masters degree andor experience in the field, strong Spanish speaking and reading skills, and basic computer skills. Fax: 202-393-5115.

Refugees International is seeking an executive assistant for its President to: provide administrative support, liasison with staff and Board; draft correspondence, memos, faxes, reports and testimony; schedule meetings and travel arragements; contact press, politicians and government officials, and maintain and update files. The ideal candidate would have: 5 years administrative/secretarial experience in a fast-paced, quick turn-around environment; WordPerfect 5.1 proficiency; experience with e-mail and Internet; excellent oral and written communications skills; and strong organizationsal and problem-solving skills. Located in the Georgetown section of Washington, DC. Small, very busy, international consulting firm has an immediate need for a bright, energetic individual to handle a wide variety of office duties. Must know WordPerfect and Lotus. Database experience helpful. Salary $18,000 to $20,000. Send resume to SK, 3250 Prospect Street NW, Washington, DC 20007. Fax: 202-965-4053.

InterAction seeks a part-time intern to assist the Program Officer for Foreign Disaster Response. Duties will include gathering and editing information on member agency activities in crisis areas throughout the world, reporting on meetings and briefings related to disaster assistance efforts, and liaison with member organizations, USAID's Office of Foreign Disaster Assistance, and UN agencies. The position is unpaid and requires 18 to 21 hours per week. Applicants should have strong writing and computer (Windows, Internet, etc.) skills. Overseas humanitarian experience preferred. Please fax cover letter and resume to George Devendorf at 202-667-8236.

The Center for International Private Enterprise (CIPE), an affiliate of the US Chamber of Commerce, seeks individual to assist with developing and implementing training/education programs focused on strengthening overseas business associations and their staffs' capabilities. Will conduct needs assessments; establish training objectives; select/develop courses; recruit instructors; and coordinate logistics. Will also assist with managing CIPE's grants programs for Africa. Requires related degree and 2 years of related training experience in an international setting; experience with Microsoft Word and Lotus; fluency in Russian; and the ability to travel, work with diverse constituencies and meet tight deadlines. Portuguese language skills preferred. Start $28K with excellent benefits. Send cover letter and benefits to: US Chamber of Commerce, Personnel Dept., 11615 H St., NW, Washington, DC 20062-2000.

El Taller seeks Secretary General. Experience and qualifications: Profound interest in and comprehensive knowledge of the current debate on the identity, philosophy and the (future) role of NGOs in the development process and the strategies to be followed; capable strategic thinking and planning; extensive experience in (development) education, training and curriculum development; excellent financial management and organizational skills; working experience in a multi-cultural environment; capable of combing differences to harmonious working relations: experience in fund-raising; creative personality and good team-builder; excellent communication abilities, and fluency in English, French and Spanish. For more information, contact: Sandra Kabir, El Taller, BP 137, 1002 Tunis-Belvedere, Tunisia; fax (261/1) 751.570. Deadline for applications: AUGUST 1.

Doctors of the World, a New York-based volunteer organization that provides medical and humanitarian relief to desperate populations around the world, is seeking a dynamic Executive Director to manage and develop this young and growing non-profit. As the Executive Director, you will be responsible for creating and implementing fund-raising strategies, writing proposals, and overseeing day-to-day operations including managing personnel, finances and material resources. In addition, you will recruit field staff, respond to field programs' needs and handle legal (and other) matters pertaining to overseas programs and headquarters office. Required qualifications: Masters degree in a relevant field (or equivalent work experience) and 3-5 years of solid foundation fund-raising and/or management experience. Excellent representational, public relations, communication and proposal writing skills as well as supervisory and budget monitoring experience and a commitment to the goals and development of this organization are essential. Experience working overseas, or a background in a health/medical field and a working knowledge of French and/or Spanish are desired. We offer a salary range of $50,000-$55,000 plus benefits. Qualified women and minorities are encouraged to apply. Please submit resume and cover letter to: Dr. Victoria Sharp, Executive Search Committee, DOW, 415 West 51st Street, New York, NY 10019.

InterAid International seeks a Country Director for its Kenya programs. Responsibilities include overall management and administration of country operations. individual should have international management experience preferably in East Africa; be capable of administering financial controls and budget implementation and possess excellent communication and proposal writing skills. We offer a competitive salary and benefits package. Mail or fax resume to InterAid International, 360 Mobil Avenue, Suite C210, Camarillo, CA 93010; fax 805-484-8829.

Food for the Hungry International seeks Director of Finance to be based and FHI headquarters in Scottsdale, AZ. Will be responsible for all FHI accounting functions globally. Must be a CPA with 5-10 years experience. Previous overseas experience is desired. Must have non-profit and government accounting experience. Position will be filled by July 1994. Send resume to: Scott Allen, Director of Mobilization, Food for the Hungry International, 7807 East Greenway Road, Suite 3, Scottsdale, AZ 85260; 800-248-6437. Fax: 602-951-9035.

TechnoServe Inc. seeks a Regional Director/East Africa for Norfolk, CT headquarters. Regional Director will be responsible for: supervising and ensuring the overall quality of assigned overseas country programs; the identification and start-up of new country programs, backstopping and support services to field operations, participating on a Program Management Team to contribute to the overall management of the Program Division (goals, objectives, strategic plants). Required qualifications: 5+ years of management experience in international development, 3+ years overseas management experience. Masters degree in finance, business administration, economics or related fields/experience. Excellent oral and written communication skills in English, French desirable. Willingness to travel international (25-30%). International Action Against Hunger seeks Health Coordinator for oversight of Community Health Workers, Traditional Birth Attendants and MCH workers; oversight of EPI activities; participation in the design and implementation of training programs; contribute to the development of a community health education curriculum; surveys, monitoring and evaluation; and set-up and supervise the use of an HIS. Send resume and cover letter including date of availability and salary requirements to: Personnel Recruiter, AICF/USA, 815-15th Street NW, Suite 832, Washington, DC 20005. fax: 202-783-5247.

International public health management firm seeks an Assistant Database Manger with an interest in international development to assist with the administration and operations of a complex database. Duties include: tracking and managing shipments of AID-donated commodities; acting as liaison between JSI staff and the shipping contractor, coordinating activities among AID, the shipping contractor and JSI staff; managing all electronic data import form the shipper, and supervising other staff. We offer a flexible working environment, excellent benefits and a salary commensurate with experience. Send resumes to Magda Ruesch, John Snow, Inc., 11th Floor, 1616 N. Fort Meyer Drive, Arlington, VA 22209. NO PHONE CALLS.

CARE seeks individual to support the development of health projects around the world. Reviews and provides technical assistance to health project. Will support development of design and evaluation criteria, handle external networking of Child Survival programs and manage the portfolio management system.

Qualifications: MA in public health, nutrition or related field. Lesser-developed country experience in community-based primary health care projects (3+ years). Experience in project design, implementation and evaluation. Analytical, writing and public speaking skills. Ability to work without direct supervision. Willingness to travel (33-50%) to remote areas of developing countries. Resume: Ann Magoffin, CARE, 151 Ellis Street, Atlanta, GA 30303-2439. Fax: 404-577-9418.

CARE seeks individual to supervise and coordinate the implementation of infrastructure development projects and Urban Food for Work (UFFW) activities in Mogadishu. Will plan, administer, monitor and evaluate the Mogadishu Emergency Employment Creation (MEEC)/UFFW in accordance with the program's focus. Planning responsibilities include finalizing criteria and selection of participating communities and individual infrastructure projects. Prepare quarterly schedules; develop commodity/material distribution, monitoring and reporting system to control stocks and for the disbursement of UFFW rations; direct and supervise CARE Community Extension Workers; provide direction to various personnel; handle donor funding negotiations and project reporting. Qualifications: previous experience in a Food for Work (FFW) project, good negotiating skills, demonstrated organizational capabilities, and patience. Resume: Jeannett Nance Frett, CARE, 151 Ellis Street, Atlanta, GA 30303-2439. Fax: 404-577-9418.

CARE seeks individual to provide technical assistance to CARE's SEAD projects, focusing on the areas of institutional development, management of large credit funds, rural SEAD programming, and management information systems (computer skills). Provide and/or coordinate technical training for CARE's overseas staff or counterparts in response to SEAD Unit initiative related to specific areas mentioned above. Focus on technical assistance needs which are implementation and systems oriented. Assist in evaluation programs. Improve skills of other Regional Technical Advisors. Qualifications: Graduate degree in Business, Economics or International Development with a strong emphasis on economics preferred. 5+ years experience in Small Enterprise Development work, a portion of which must have been spend in direct program management. Fluent French or Spanish. Resume: Ann Magoffin, CARE, 151 Ellis Street, Atlanta, GA 30303-2439. Fax: 404-577-9418.

The Biodiversity Support Program (BSP), a consortium of World Wildlife Fund (WWF), The Nature Conservancy, and the World Resources Institute, seeks individual to join WWF's office in Washington, DC. Individual will contribute to BSP's conservation of biodiversity through analysis of existing field programs in Africa, Asia/Pacific and Latin America, and will be responsible for defining, distilling and synthesizing lessons learned from selected conservation approaches, developing activities, and overseeing the effective dissemination of results. Requires: 8+ years experience in biological conservation, natural resources management, international development or related field; and demonstrated success developing and managing complex analytical projects. Masters in biological sciences, natural resources management, social sciences or related field required. PhD preferred. 2+ years work experience in developing countries. Experience with USAID desirable. Cover letter and resume to: WWF, Human Resources, Dept. 935MD, 1250 24th Street NW, Washington, DC 20037. Fax: 202-293-9211.

MAP International seeks a representative to obtain donated medicines and supplies from pharmaceutical companies of the commodity distribution program of MAP. Responsibilities include researching and developing current, potential new, and lapsed donor companies with special focus on the generic industry. Qualifications: 3-5 years experience in sales or public relations, preferable background in pharmaceutical or medical field, good communications skills and ability to travel. Position location: Brunswick, GA. If interested, submit resume and cover letter to: Personnel Director, MAP International, P.O. Box 215000, Brunswick, GA 31521-5000.

Lutheran Immigration and Refugee Services seeks Director for Finance and Administration. This individual is responsible for management of all fiscal activities of organization including accounting, financial reporting, budgeting, insurance and supervision of management information services and office support services. MBA and/or CPA helpful. Mail or fax resume and salary requirements to: LIRS, c/o Ann Fries, Manager, Human Resources, 390 Park Avenue South, New York, NY 10016; fax: 212-213-6081.

The International Human Rights Law Group seeks a senior program offices (SPO) for its Washington headquarters. The Law Group works on-site and from DC to empower locally-based rights advocates and promote human rights. The SPO will develop, design, raise funds for and supervise programs to support the rule of law in developing countries, particularly the work of local human rights NGOs. Individual needs practical experience in development or human rights, familiarity with donor-supported rule of law programs or advocacy NGOs and knowledge of fund-raising. Languages, substantial travel. Interviews early August. Contact: Karin Edlund, International Human Rights Law Group, 1601 Connecticut Avenue, #700, Washington, DC 20009. 202-232-8500. Fax: 202-232 6731.

OIC International seeks individual to provide technical and training assistance in value added transformation of raw produce with the purpose of creating employment for unemployed youths and disadvantaged communities in third world countries. Will be responsible for identifying cottage industries and appropriate technologies adaptable to the client countries; develop curricula to train related entrepreneurial and technical skills to develop and manage businesses. Applicant should possess degree or have experience in development work, and working experience in Africa; first-had experience in managing a business and/or appropriate technology development. Must be fluent in written and spoken English and French, Spanish a plus. Post located in Philadelphia with extensive travel. Resume and salary requirements to: OIC International, Inc., 240 W. Tulpehocken Street, Philadelphia, PA 19144, Attn: Human Resources Administrator.

International Medical Corps seeks a dynamic Development Director to direct its fund raising activities. Individual will be responsible for the implementation of a comprehensive development plan. Individual will research and write foundation proposals, develop grassroots support, act as a liaison with board members, oversee the direct mail campaigns, plan special events, supervise maintenance of donor data base and coordinate corporate and major gifts programs. Qualifications: superior writing skills, established contacts with major donors and foundations, BA/BS degree, 5-7 years of proven fund- raising experience, excellent interpersonal skills and supervisory skills. Competitive salary and full benefits. Salary, insurance, round-trip transportation, room and board provided. Submit resume or letter of interest to: IMC, Dept. 94-017, 12233 W. Olympic Blvd., #280, Los Angeles, CA 90064. Fax: 310- 442-6622.

International Medical Corps seeks staff for its Emergency Intervention Program in ANGOLA: EPI TRAINERS, Luene, Menongue, Huambo -- Strong teaching skills and immunization campaign implementation experience required. DEPUTY DIRECTOR (Luanda-based) -- Strong management, logistics, administrative and financial skills required. COUNTRY DIRECTOR (Luanda- based) -- Oct. 1994 start date. Prior overseas experience managing emergency/relief program with increasing levels of responsibility required. Strong management, interpersonal and donor-relations skills required. Portuguese a must. Assignments for 1 year. Salary, insurance, round-trip transportation, room and board provided. Submit resume or letter of interest to: IMC, Dept. 94-003, 12233 W. Olympic Blvd., #280, Los Angeles, CA 90064. Fax: 310-442-6622.

International Medical Corps seeks the following for its start-up emergency hospital program in RWANDA: FIELD COORDINATOR -- Setting up security, accounting ability, site manager experience, 3 years in developing country experience. This position will be responsible for financial and administrative management. LOGISTICS SPECIALIST -- 2 years experience in developing country logistics management. EMERGENCY ROOM NURSE -- Strong trauma background, critical care casualty, emergency and triage preferred. TRAUMA and/or GENERAL SURGEON -- Strong trauma background, critical care casualty, emergency and triage preferred. MUST speak French. 6-month commitment required. Salary, insurance, round-trip transportation, room and board provided. Submit resume or letter of interest to: IMC, Dept. 94-014, 12233 W. Olympic Blvd., #280, Los Angeles, CA 90064. Fax: 310- 442-6622. International Medical Corps seeks the following for its emergency medical program in Belet Weyne, SOMALIA: Requires: prior international experience, accounting, management, administrative and security experience. Assignment is for 6+ months. Salary, insurance, round- trip transportation, room and board provided. Submit resume or letter of interest to: IMC, Dept. 94-019, 12233 W. Olympic Blvd., #280, Los Angeles, CA 90064. Fax: 310-442-6622.

Social Sciences/Africa/African-American Studies: Assistant/ Associate Professor: Full-time, tenure track position beginning Fall, 1994. PhD preferred. Send letter of application, vita, course syllabi, sample research papers of publications, and the addresses and phone numbers of three references to:: Search Committee Chair, African/African-American studies program, Anthropology,/Sociology Department, 256 AuSable Hall, Grand Valley State University, Allendale, MI 49401.

Oxfam America has employment information available. Phone the job line by dialing 617-482-1211. Follow the recorded menu prompts to dial 3 then 1, 1, and 2 for current employment opportunities. Information about previously opened jobs is available by dialing 3,3 and 2.

Africa News


August 1, 1994 / August 14, 1994


VOLUNTEER OPPORTUNITIES


LENGTH: 1520 words


 

HEALTH VOLUNTEERS OVERSEAS is pleased to announce the opening of their newest division, Internal Medicine Overseas (IMO). The first training site has been established at the Moi University Faculty of Health Sciences (MUFHS) in Eldoret, Kenya, in conjunction with an Indiana University training program started in 1990. This IMO site will begin seeking volunteers by August of this year for two- month long training assignments. For more information, please contact Kate Skillman, Program Coordinator at (202) 296-0928.

HEALTH VOLUNTEERS OVERSEAS has the following 

programs and volunteer opportunities:

ANESTHESIA OVERSEAS (AO) & NURSE ANESTHESIA

OVERSEAS (NAO): **ERITREA: This new program will train two groups of students: nurse anesthetists and soldiers who provided anesthesia care during the recent war. A suitable curriculum is being developed and volunteers will be needed beginning in March 1995. Anesthesiologists and nurse anesthetists with teaching backgrounds, not necessarily in an academic setting, are being solicited. Interested volunteers are required to provide a CV six months prior to their assignment. Assignments are for one month. Contact: Dr. Hugh Westgate, 612-938-1474.

**MALAWI: This program provides assistance in the training and supervision of Medical Assistants undergoing a one year training program to produce Anesthetic Clinical Officers. Volunteers are solicited for one month assignments. Contact: Dr. Howard Chait, 310-470-6291.

**TRANSKEI: Transkei, SA is in need of program participants to teach anesthesia at Umtata General Hospital to physicians-in-training (medical students and medical officers) who will be providing anesthesia services in the outlying hospitals upon completion of their training. Volunteers will also provide direct anesthesia care. Housing on the hospital grounds is provided for the volunteer at no cost. Contact: Dr. Kevin Speight, 919-716-4498 (w), 919-454-3956 (h).

**UGANDA: Anesthesiologists and CRNA volunteers participate in the only anesthesia training program in Uganda. Most of the teaching takes place in Kampala's Mulago Hospital. Three groups of students are in need of additional training: those in the "masters" program (equivalent to our residency), anesthesia asistants who work without supervision and administer most of the anesthesia throughout Uganda, and the medical students. A guest house is available for volunteers.

Volunteers serve a minimum of one month. Contact: Dr. Harry Zutz at 908-381-4200 (w), 201-378-3323 (h) or Mattilou Catchpoe, PhD, CRNA at 217-786-7425 (w), 217- 525-0183 (h).

DENTISTRY OVERSEAS (DO):

** MALAWI: The School of Health Sciences in Lilongwe is the training site for a program providing education support in the areas of diagnosing dental and oral pathoses, performing conservative dentistry, periodontics, uncomplicated dental extractions and precentive dentistry. Volunteers are solicited for two month assignments with one month assignments also considered. This program is soliciting at least three volunteers a year with a one month hiatus between volunteers. Contact Dr. Dick Nieusma 402-472-1367.

ORTHOPAEDICS OVERSEAS (OO):

**MALAWI: The Malawi Orthopaedic Project trains classes of 10 full-time students in an 18 month course. Volunteers will participate in lectures, clinics, rounds and surgery. Operative cases include polio residuals, tuberculosis, osteomyelitis, club feet and trauma. Volunteers are needed for a minimum period of one month and for additional periods in increments of one month. Volunteers will be located in Blantyre at the Queen Elizabeth Central Hospital. They will also travel to District Hospitals where they will supervise graduates of previous classes. Housing is available at a cost of $750 per month. A vehicle is furnished but volunteers pay for gas. Contact: Dr. Richard Kemme at 303-352-0250.

**TRANSKEI: Volunteers are involved in teaching and providing for orthopaedic care needs at the Umtata General Hospital and the Transkei Medical School. The students include residents and medical students as well as Orthopaedic Nurse Practitioners who complete a one-year course. Housing is provided at no cost. Accommodations for families can often be arranged. This program also seeks volunteers in physical therapy and general surgery. Contact: Dr. Robert Eaton at 704- 692-5781.

**UGANDA: This program trains Ugandan medical students and physicians to improve the treatment of amputees and disabled people injured as a result of civil strife. Orthopaedic surgeons are needed to teach orthopaedic assistants, medical students and physicians at the national teaching hospital in Kampala and its newly renovated orthopaedic operating theatre which provides orthopaedic surgical care for Uganda's 18 million people. Surgeons will also conduct orthopaedic clinics and operating sessions with Ugandan doctors in upcountry regional hospitals. Volunteers are asked to serve for a minimum of one month. For a nominal fee, housing will be provided at the newly renovated Mulago Guest House. Contact: Dr. David Denzel at 716-434-2697.

The American Medical Team for Africa (AMTA) promotes and executes educational exchange and medical training in African countries. The goal of the non-profit organization is to bring volunteer doctors, nurses and medical students together with donated supplies, and equipment to serve needs on the continent. Survey teams assess the most pressing needs in targeted countries, develop and publish training manuals in appropriate languages, hold workshops and refresher courses for doctors, nurses and specialists interested in maintenance of health care delivery systems in Africa; and distribute medical supplies and equipment donated by corporations, pharmaceutical companies, hospitals and doctors. The AMTA plans a second medical mission to Africa. For more information, contact Deman Rageh, Executive Director, The American Medical Team for Africa, 2245 Godby Road, Atlanta, GA 30349; phone (404) 766-8000; fax: (404) 767-5264.

Private Voluntary Organization in Rosslyn needs an experienced Agribusiness/Marketing Specialist to fill a 3-year Chief of Party position in Mali. The candidate must have at least 10 years of proven experience in the field of Agribusiness, Marketing, Credit and Procurement (preferably of fruits & vegetables). Must have related job experience in developing country with hands-on experience and an MBA. Strong training skills in the areas of agribusiness and marketing required. Fluency in French/English (FSI, S-3, R03) a must. Interested candidates must submit a resume, a certification of foreign language capability, and a standard AID bioWynn, VITA, 5th floor, Arlington, VA 22209. Tel: (703) data form. Please mail original copies to: Regina 276-1800 or fax: (703) 2143-1865.

Global Service Corps' "Project Kenya" is a 23- day volunteer experience from August 19-September 11. The tour cost (excluding airfare) is $1600, depending on fluctuation in the Kenya shilling. Project participants will have an opportunity to learn about Kenya small-village culture and development while helping initiate biointensive garden plots and other small enterprises. The trip will include time in Nairobi, a 4-day small-village development training session at Manor House Agricultural Centre in Western Kenya, home stays with village families and side trips to nature reserves. For further information contact Global Service Corps at 415-922-5538.

This event will commemorate the arrival of the first African people to English America in 1619.

Call (804) 253-4175 for more information.

"Agricultural Competitiveness, Market Forces, and Policy Choice" is the theme of the 22nd International Conference of Agricultural Economists.

Contact: Walter Armbruster, Farm Foundation, 1211 W. 22nd St., Suite 216, Oak Brook, IL 60521-2197.

August 25-27, 1994

Chicago, IL -- Conference

The African American Museums Association (AAMA) will hold its 1994 conference at the Swissotel, Chicago, IL. The conference will be hosted by the DuSable Museum of African American History of Chicago. 

For conference registration or membership information, contact Jocelyn Robinson-Hubbuch, executive director, at 513-376-4611. Fax: (513) 376-2007 or write AAMA, P.O. Box 548, Wilberforce, OH 45384.

September 1994

Johannesburg, South Africa -- Conference

"Texts and Images of People, Politics and Power: Representing the Bushman People of Southern Africa."

Deadline for papers is June 1994.

Contact: T.A. Dawson or J.D. Lewis Williams, Rock Art Research Institute, Department of Archaeology, University of Witwatersrand, Johannesburg 2050, Republic of South Africa.

AMARC 6, The Sixth World Conference of Community Radio Broadcasters. Africa News


August 1, 1994 / August 14, 1994


DIRECTORY


LENGTH: 1347 words


 

ANNOUNCEMENTS

The following books are needed for the Malawi Orthopaedic Project sponsored by Health Volunteers

Overseas:

"Fractures and Joint Injuries" by R. Watson Jones
"Fractures in Children" by W. Blount
"Campbell's Operative Orthopaedics" any edition.

If you have any of these volumes, please contact Dr. Richard H. Kemme, Chairman of the Orthopaedic Overseas Malawi Program, 4254 West 14th Street Drive, Greeley, CO 80634. Tel: 303-352-0250 or Fax: 303-352-0256. 

HOW TO HELP RELIEF EFFORTS IN RWANDA

InterAction, a Washington, D.C.-based coalition of more than 150 U.S. non-profit humanitarian aid groups, has issued the following list of accredited relief agencies accepting cash contributions for relief efforts to assist victims of the current violence in Rwanda. For more information call 202-667-8227.

Africa News


August 1, 1994 / August 14, 1994


ABIOLA TO RECEIVE HONORARY DEGREE FROM UCONN


LENGTH: 1147 words


 

Storrs, Connecticut

July 21, 1994

Chief Moshood Abiola of Nigeria -- businessman, philanthropist, and pro-democracy leader -- will receive the degree of honorary doctor of letters from the University of Connecticut for his commitment to democracy and his outstanding philanthropy.

Chief Abiola, one of Africa's leading businessmen and philanthropists, won a majority of votes in the June 12, 1994 democratic election in Nigeria. However, the results were annulled by the military government and Abiola is presently under arrest. Nigeria's oil workers, civil servants, teachers, physicians, and association of lawyers are now on strike in an effort to persuade the military government to respect last year's election results. 

The University will award the honorary degree to Abiola at its Convocation ceremony August 31 or at Commencement in May 1995.

"In a continent plagued by crises, Chief Abiola has become a powerful symbol of the hopes and aspirations of African peoples around the world," says Amii Omara-Otunnu, director of the University's Center for Contemporary African Studies, who nominated Abiola for the honorary degree.

Nigeria, an oil-producing country, is more than twice the size of California and has the largest population of any African nation. It is the historical homeland of many African-Americans.

Abiola was born in 1937 in Ogun State, Nigeria. Now a millionaire, from age nine he got up before dawn to collect firewood which he sold to pay his school fees. Later he supported himself through performing as a musician at weddings and funeral ceremonies.

Trained as an accountant at the University of Glasgow, Scotland, he was graduated in 1966 with highest distinction.

He quickly worked his way up from head of finance and accounts at Lagos University Teaching Hospital and the University of Lagos Medical School, to regional controller of Pfizer Products of Nigeria and Ghana, to managing director and chief executive officer of ITT for Africa and the Middle East. He was the first Nigerian to head a multinational corporation in Africa.

In 1991, he served as president of the Nigerian Stock Exchange.

His business enterprises include founding and managing the Concord Press of Nigeria, which publishes the "African Concord" a weekly which covers socio- political news from the Cape to Cairo and is distributed in 81 countries across six continents, and the "Africa Economic Digest," a round-up of business and economic news from all over Africa.

A staunch champion of the freedom of the press, Abiola was arrested on several occasions during the 1980s for the independent stance of the Concord Press, says Omara-Otunnu.

"Chief Abiola has a record of standing firm for his principles, even at risk to his personal safety," says Omara-Otunnu.

When devaluation of the Nigerian currency during the 1980s put textbooks out of reach for many Nigerians, Abiola formed Abiola Bookshops to provide educational textbooks and supplies, and initiated a National Commercial Printing Association to enhance local production of books, Omara-Otunnu says. In 1989 Chief Abiola, a practicing Muslim, gained permission to produce both the Koran and the Bible in Nigeria, making nearly 12 million copies available, he adds.

Concerned about the food crisis in Africa after a visit to drought-stricken Ethiopia, in 1984 he founded Abiola Farms Ltd., which produces more than 4,000 tons of grain and 1,400 tons of soy beans annually and serves as a national model for agricultural production. He also established a bakery which produces more than 500,000 loaves of bread a day.

"Chief Abiola's career is distinguished and inspiring," says Omara-Otunnu. "Through sheer hard work in the academic and business worlds, he overcame abject poverty to become a millionaire."

"He has committed his wealth to endow philanthropic causes across ethnic, religious, and national lines," adds Omara-Otunnu.

A patron of both the U.S. Congressional Black Caucus and the Black Parliamentary Caucus of Great Britain, Abiola's distinctions include the 1990 Congressional Black Caucus Chairman's Award for Exemplary Service to the International Community and the African Diaspora and the 1987 National Association for the Advancement of Colored Persons (NAACP) Black Heritage Award.

In the U.S., he has endowed Alabama's Tuskegee University with 25 scholarships in honor of 25 African and African-American leaders of the Pan-African movement, and he has awarded fellowships in African studies and applied sciences at both Tuskegee and Howard Universities.

In Africa, Abiola is the principal patron of the W.E.B. Debois Foundation and the Kwame Nkrumah Foundation, public research foundations named after two champions of the common interests of black people worldwide.

He is a patron of several projects of the African Studies program in Nairobi in which 29 African countries participate and he regularly donates books on African affairs to African university, including those in French and Portuguese-speaking countries.

Abiola has established a six-year high school for 2,000 students in his home state of Ogun, made substantial personal contributions to more than 200 community grammar schools throughout Nigeria, and established 194 Islamic centers to provide free Koranic education to Muslim children.

Holder of many African honorific tittles, Abiola was awarded the title of Bashorun, or chief, buy the Ooni, or king, of Ife in Yorubaland, a distinction equivalent in Nigeria to being knighted in Britain. End


LOAD-DATE: August 1, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


245 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 1, 1994 / August 14, 1994


LETTER FROM MOZAMBIQUE


BYLINE: Carol C. Gilley


SECTION: DOSSIER


LENGTH: 1040 words


 

Maxixe, Mozambique

July 1994

Carol Gilley, an American working in Mozambique, is supported by the United Church of Christ.

Dear friends,

Veronica Mazive is a special friend of mine. Her husband Chadreque is the pastor of the Congregational Church at Morrumbene, a small town north of Maxixe. In 1992 Chadreque and Veronica came every week for English lessons and stayed overnight with us. In 1993 Veronica came to the Bible school in order to become better equipped to lead women's groups in the church. In March, 1994 we traveled to Zimbabwe together to see work begin done for and by women in our churches there. 

Veronica goes home to Morrumbene each weekend, and one weekend she invited me to accompany her. We left Balaza Friday noon, walking the two kilometers to the National Road #1. Both of us had a small bag of personal belongings, but in addition Veronica carried a 25 kilogram bag of maize on her head. We waited by the road for about an hour before a "taxi" -- in this instance a small pickup truck -- stopped to pick us up. It was already quite loaded with people and their

things: a bookshelf, and bags of maize, onions, and coconuts. We passed small villages and markets. We saw many people walking along the road. We passed groves of coconut and cashew trees with cassava planted between them. We crossed three rivers and occasionally caught glimpses of Inhambane Bay in the distance.

The Mazives live in a densely populated settlement of dislocated families about one kilometer from the center of Morrumbene. Their home consists of four small reed houses, with roofs of palm fronds. The houses are well built and attractive. The yard is swept clean, and there are well-tended flower beds. The household consists of Chadreque, Veronica, and four of their six children. Laura (22) manages the household while Veronica is away at school. Herminio (18) is apprenticed to a carpenter. Quinita (11), a 5th grader, is a slim attractive girl who cheerfully helps her mother and older sister with tasks like fetching water from the well nearly a kilometer from home. Almeida (8) is a 2nd grader.

I was warmly welcomed. Almeida, who had visited me at Balaza several times, was especially happy to see me and quickly brought a chair for me to sit in a shady spot in the yard. Herminio told me that I would use his house and he showed me the chairs and stool that he had made. The neighbors were surprised to see a white stranger but came to greet me. Laura put a bucket of hot water, a new bar of soap, and the family's best towel in the reed bathhouse and invited me to bathe. After that treat, Laura served tea with bread and hot crisp fried fish.

Veronica took me for a walk to see their church building. The Morrumbene Church, like most of our churches, is built of poles, reeds, and palm branches. It is attractive but not very durable. As we walked along we greeted dozens of people. We passed empty houses, and Veronica explained that people are returning to the places from which they fled during the war. The Mazives will move to a bettor place, as soon as Chadreque has completed the houses he is building for the. We called on several people who were ill and prayed with them. At one home I was given a welcoming gift of eggs.

Saturday morning I woke to the sound of the sweep, sweep, sweep of the yard being swept clean and the chop, chop, chop of firewood being cut for the day's cooking. Having visited me many times, Veronica knows that I like an early morning cup of coffee, so, at 5 a.m., with a gentle knock on the door, she brought me a steaming cup of coffee.

We left Morrumbene and went to Tinga Tinga on foot and by rowboat. We were poled through the mangroves and we saw flocks of flamingoes. Veronica met with some of the women of the Tinga Tinga Congregational Church. She helped them to prepare for their participation in the annual regional meeting of Xirilo (the uniformed women's organization). We stayed the night in the home of Agostinho and Amelia Muriane. Agostinho is a lay leader of the Tinga Tinga church, a student at the Zakewu Likumbe Bible School, a skilled mason, and the owner of two small fishing boats. Amelia served fresh shrimp for supper caught from Agostinho's boats in Morrumbene Bay.

Sunday morning, Veronica led the service in the Tinga Tinga Church. She admitted some new members of Xirilo. They were dressed in their uniforms and acknowledged by the congregation. I preached the

sermon on the theme of the Xirilo conference: "Whoever is thirsty should come to me and drink." Sunday afternoon we returned to Morrumbene by boat landing to the Mazive's home, stopping to admire Veronica's cassava field along the way. Chadreque said how much it meant to them to have me visit and I tried to tell him what a privilege it was for me to do so. I remembered the saying that you shouldn't judge a person until you have walked a distance in her moccasins. I didn't walk in Veronica's moccasins nor did I carry her 25 kilogram bag of maize on my head. But I understand her better and value her more for having walked beside her for a few days. Yours faithfully, Carol C. Gilley


LOAD-DATE: August 1, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


246 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 1, 1994 / August 14, 1994


FOOD AID MOVING TO REFUGEES IN ZAIRE: PLANS MADE TO ENCOURAGE REFUGEES BACK INTO RWANDA


LENGTH: 1000 words


 

Rome, Italy

July 26, 1994

The World Food Programme today said it is quickly mobilizing and delivering the food needed for the current influx of Rwandan refugees into Zaire and was increasing efforts to distribute food inside Rwanda to attract refugees back into the country.

'At a news briefing in Rome today Ms Catherine Bertini, WFP's Executive Director, said the Programme is actively looking at ways to encourage refugees back into Rwanda. Today, the Programme will meet with the International Committee of the Red Cross to discuss the mechanics of how this will be done. The Programme plans to set up a logistics base in Gisenyi inside Rwanda to store food and will set up drop off points and distribution points for food for the refugees in addition to it's regular distribution programme inside Rwanda. The first truck convoy to transit Rwanda from Kampala to Goma will leave tomorrow. 

"We hope that when the refugees in Goma see that WFP is moving food through Rwanda and know that food is available inside the country they will have the confidence to return home" said Ms Bertini. "The best way to end this almost apocalyptic crisis is for the people to go back to Rwanda and it is up to us to ensure that we have the food and distribution systems set up in the country that will allow this to happen.," she added.

The Programme has also been delivering food inside southern Rwanda and to the refugees in Bukavu and Uvira.

WFP - The food organization of the United Nations - has also appealed for U.S. $76 million in new funding to cover the costs of 82,246 MT of food and related transportation costs for the 1.7 million refugees in Zaire for the next three months. To date about U.S. $23 million of this amount has been contributed by donors.

At a meeting with international donors yesterday, Ms Bertini pointed out that it was critical for them to provide the cash and food necessary for the Programme to fill it's food pipeline to feed all the affected people in the region.

"While we received about U.S.$9 million in new contributions yesterday and donors have started to respond positively to our pleas for assistance, there is still a along way to go to meet our needs and donors must now begin to give us the money needed to fill this gap" she said. The Programme in total, is supplying emergency food aid to almost 4 million people affected by the crisis in Rwanda and surrounding countries. The Programmes shortfall for this caseload for the remainder of the year is about 184,000 MT of food or about U.S.$132 million including non-food items and transportation costs. (further assistance will be needed for the refugees in Zaire for the last three months of 1994.)

The Programme has quickly mobilized food aid for the new refugees in Zaire through borrowing food from it's other operations and purchases in the region. It has available about 44,000 MT of emergency food for the Zaire emergency.

WFP started airlifting food to the camps in Goma July 16, 48 hours after the bulk of the refugees arrived there and now has five Iluysin 76's in operation, each capable of carrying about 35 MT on each flight. These planes are based in Nairobi , Kenya and Entebbe, Uganda. While the Programme is capable of providing at least 10 flights per day into Goma, only half that number of landing slots are available to it. To date the Programme has airlifted about 700 MT of food into Goma.

The Programme is also quickly moving to provide the trucks needed to deliver the 600 MT of food per day necessary for the refugees in Goma. The Programme has already delivered more than 1,000 MT of food by road into Goma primarily using the 54 trucks mostly from the former WFP truck fleets in Eritrea and Ethiopia which are now based in Uganda. A further 15 trucks from a commercial fleet operate in Burundi, Zaire and southern Rwanda. A further 20 trucks are available to the Programme.

However there is a severe shortage of trucking capacity in the region which is why the Programme found it necessary to bring in trucks from other areas. WFP is also completing arrangements to bring a further 50 trucks into the emergency operations from a commercial fleet in Jordan which the Programme had previously used for relief operations in the Horn of Africa. The first 15 of these trucks will start to be flown into Kampala on Friday through a United States military airlift. The remaining 35 trucks will go to Mombasa to load food for Zaire. With all these trucks the Programme will be in a position to deliver the complete daily food needs of refugees in Zaire in about 10 days.

For further information contact:

Paul Mitchell (39) (6) 5228-2602

Francis Mwanza (39) (6) 5228-2623

Penny Lewis (254) (2) 230-807


LOAD-DATE: August 1, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.
