Africa News


August 1, 1994 / August 14, 1994


RWANDA- CIVIL STRIFE/DISPLACED PERSONS OVERVIEW


LENGTH: 2174 words


 

U.S. Agency for International Development Situation Report #3

July 13, 1994

Conflict erupted in October 1990 when the Rwandan Patriotic Front (RPF), consisting largely of exiled Rwandan Tutsis living in Uganda, invaded Rwanda. A guerrilla war was waged primarily in the north until the two sides agreed to cease fire in July 1992 and began negotiations toward a political settlement. The conflict came to an official end when the government of Rwanda and the RPF signed the Arusha Peace Accord in Tanzania on August 4, 1993. 

On April 6, 1994, President Habyarimana of Rwanda, President Ntaryamira of Burundi, and a number of government officials were killed when their plane crashed approaching the airport in Kigali, Rwanda's capital. The presidents death ruptured the fragile peace signed in August, 1993. Since the crash, the government forces and the RPF have been fighting for control of the country. In addition, government forces and bands of armed guerrillas have been massacring large numbers of unarmed civilians. Foreign nationals and 258 Americans were safely evacuated from the country in the early stages of the conflict, and U.S. ambassador David Rawson closed the U.S. Embassy on April 10. Most international relief staff were also evacuated but are conducting cross-border humanitarian assistance operations to displaced persons because security within Rwanda continues to be tenuous. The United Nations Assistance Mission to Rwanda (UNAMIR) peacekeeping forces drew down their numbers in accordance with a U.N. security council Resolution. On May 17, the U.N. Security Council passed a new resolution approving the deployment of 5,500 UNAMIR troops to assist the humanitarian operations, and efforts are underway to deploy these forces. On June 22, the Security Council approved the French proposal to dispatch troops to Rwanda to act as an interim force to protect civilians and humanitarian relief efforts until UNAMIR forces arrive. The French-led deployment into Rwanda began on June 24.

Rwanda is the most densely populated country in Africa. It is the size of the state of Maryland and has a population of 8.1 million people. The population is comprised of 14% Tutsi and 85% Hutu. Since it gained independence from Belgium in 1962, Rwanda has been fraught with problems of ethnic violence that has claimed the lives of thousands of people, however, the current violence and death toll are unprecedented. Numbers Affected

Unconfirmed press reports indicate that from 200,000 to 500,000 persons may have been killed throughout the country since the fighting began and the death toll mounts daily. As of July 11, United Nations Commissioner for Refugees reports that approximately 541,000 refugees have fled to the

following countries since April 6: 436,500 to Tanzania; 85.000 to Burundi; 10,000 to Uganda; and 9,720 to Zaire. Approximately 40,000 Burundian refugees remain in Rwanda out of the 300,000 who fled after the October 1993 coup attempt in Burundi. It is estimated that 50,000 people remain in Kigali out of it's original population of 300,000; 25,000 of these are displaced. As many as 2 million persons could be internally displaced, some of whom are being prevented from leaving Rwanda. General Situation

The violence that erupted throughout Rwanda following the April 6 plane crash has resulted in a devastating humanitarian crisis of almost unprecedented proportions. Hundreds of thousands of Rwandans have been killed in indiscriminate massacres waged against the civilian population. The extreme violence has sparked the largest and swiftest mass exodus of people ever witnessed by the UNHCR. In late April, approximately a quarter of a million people streamed across the Rwandan border into Tanzania to seek refuge in a period of less than 48 hours. The magnitude of such massive population movements has created one of the most challenging humanitarian crises in history.

In early May, USAID/BHR/OFDA responded to the humanitarian crisis by deploying a two person assessment team to evaluate the needs of over 400,000 persons seeking refuge in neighboring countries. Based on the assessment teams recommendations, OFDA dispatched a Disaster Assistance Response Team (DART) to the affected region on May 25, 1994. Political/Military Situation

The April 6 plane crash and subsequent deaths of Rwandan President Juvenal Habyarimana and President Cyprien Ntaryamira of Burundi sparked immediate massive violence throughout Rwanda. Members of the Hutu-dominated Rwandan military, well armed militia forces, and extremist civilian gangs began a large scale massacre of Hutu opposition politicians, Tutsi leaders, and civilians. The violence originated in the capital city of Kigali, but soon spread throughout the country. After the plane crash, fighting quickly erupted between the government forces and the RPF. There are also unconfirmed reports from observers in northern Tanzania that the RPF is committing atrocities against civilians as well as the government forces. The RPF now holds the eastern two-thirds of the country. In mid-June, RPF forces took Kabgayi and then pushed north to take Gitarama, forcing the interim government to flee Gisenyi. The RPF's attack on Kigali intensified the following announcement of the French intervention. On July 4, the RPF gained control of Kigali and the southern town of Butare. At the organization of African Unity (OAU) conference in mid-June, representatives of the RPF and the interim government forces verbally agreed to a cease-fire, but it was never realized. The brutal violence that erupted in Rwanda on April ¬ prompted the evacuation of foreign nationals and the withdrawal of approximately 2,000 U.N. peacekeeping troops. Less than 450 U.N. troops remain in Kigali at present, although 5,500 have been approved for deployment with an expanded mandate to assist the humanitarian operations by providing security to relief workers, supplies, and beneficiaries. Several African countries, including Ghana, Ethiopia, Senegal, Zimbabwe, and Nigeria have committed to providing troops to the U.N. effort.

On June 17, France introduced a proposal in the U.N. Security Council to deploy 2,500 troops to Rwanda to act as an interim peacekeeping force until the UNAMIR force is assembled. On June 22, the U.N. Security Council voted in favor of the French-led operation, and on June 23-24 French troops were dispatched into western Rwanda through Zaire to operate under a U.N. peacekeeping mandate. The French have stated that their mission is to protect civilians and humanitarian relief efforts, and that they will remain in the country only until UNAMIR forces have been assembled and deployed. The troops have established a "safe zone" defined by the prefectures of Gikongoro, Kibuye, and Cyangugu to protect vulnerable populations. French involvement in Rwanda has received support from both the U.N. and the U.S., although the RPF remains skeptical of Frances motives.

On June 10, the U.N. Human Rights Commission's special envoy began a week long mission in Rwanda to investigate human rights abuses throughout the country. At the end of June, the report of the envoys findings was made to the Commission, stating that the massacres were a systematic campaign of genocide and preplanned. Field officers remain in Nairobi, Kenya, to continue the Commissions' investigation. Relief Efforts

The violence initially forced almost all relief organisations to suspend their work in Rwanda. NGOs have begun to reinstate their humanitarian relief efforts to displaced persons and refugee camps where security permits. The U.N.'s response to the crisis is coordinate by the U.N. Rwanda Emergency Office (UNREO), which was created on April 14 when the U.N. Department of Humanitarian Affairs (DHA), U.N. Development Program (UNDP), and other U.N. agencies decided to coordinate their efforts to provide a comprehensive relief response in Rwanda. UNREO is based in Nairobi, and the coordinating offices have been established in Kabale, Uganda ; Bujumbura, Burundi; Goma, Zaire; and Kigali. The organizations efforts have been fundamental in encouraging the coordination of NGOs and their activities, as well as in developing relationships with the RPF to formulate and implement relief efforts in RPF territories.

OFDA's DART continues to coordinate and facilitate the USG's response to the humanitarian crisis in the field. The operational base of the team is located in Nairobi, Kenya, and staff have made assessment trips to Uganda, Tanzania, Burundi, Zaire, and Rwanda. The team, led by OFDA regional advisor Kate Farnsworth, now includes a contracts officer, and field officers in Kabale and Bujumbura. The team performs assessments of the region, reports information from the field to Washington, and provides an immediate funding mechanism to U.N. agencies, International Organizations (IOs), and NGOs for projects that address the needs of displaced persons within Rwanda.

Two IOs have continued to maintain an active presence in Kigali since the crisis began. International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) and Medecines Sans Frontieres (MSF) retain medical staff in the city to provide emergency treatment and relief items to victims. Their efforts, however, are unable to meet the massive needs of the affected population.

Recent reports indicate that crop production appears to be better than previously expected throughout Rwanda . However insecurity and the displacement of the population are preventing people from harvesting their crops, thereby disrupting the next agricultural season which commences in August/September. ICRC projects that if Rwandans are not able to return to their land by the end of July, significant food aid could be required until at least 1995 for an estimated one million persons. Logistical difficulties continue to hamper relief efforts, both within Rwanda and in surrounding countries.

The nature of the crisis in Rwanda has caused health related issues to be a primary concern for the relief community. World Health Organization (WHO) issued a report stating that the disruption of basic health services in Kigali has increased the likelihood and outbreak and transmission of diseases such as cholera, dysentery, louse borne typhus, and even plague. Efforts are being undertaken to build latrines ; vaccinate populations; build adequate water purification systems; and dispose of dead bodies.

On April 25, Peter Hansen, Under Secretary General of DHA, launched the U.N. interagency flash appeal for Rwanda to the international community. The appeal totals $11.6 million for resources required by the U.N. and intergovernmental organizations to set up programs of assistance for the internally displaced and for refugees. In early May, UNCHR issued and appeal of $56.7 million in funding to provide assistance for Burundian and Rwandan refugees in the region through July 15. ICRC revised it's emergency program for Rwanda from $28.3 million to $41 million. The International Federation of the Red Cross (IFRC) also revised it's appeals from $2.4 million to $9.9 million and WFP has appealed for cash and food contributions. In late June, the U.N. issued a contingency appeal to address the needs of 500,000 people over a six week period . This current appeal is intended to bridge the gap between current funding, which is nearly exhausted, and the funds that will be raised from the consolidated appeal due for release sometime in late July. the total amount requested is $22.5 million.


LOAD-DATE: August 1, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


248 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 1, 1994 / August 14, 1994


WESTERN "TRIBALISM" OBSCURES REAL ISSUE


BYLINE: Peter Rosenblum


LENGTH: 1000 words


 

DOCKET, June 1994

Late in March, the Law Group received a call from Monique Mujawamaliya, Rwanda's leading human

rights activist. Her tone was tense: President Juvenal Habyarimana had again violated the Arusha peace accords and she was being threatened by the presidential militia. The international community refused to respond. She and other human rights activists -- Hutus and Tutsis alike who had spent years struggling for human rights and democracy -- were convinced that a crackdown was imminent. 

When it came, one week later, only the catalyst -- a plane shot down while carrying Habyarimana and the president of Burundi -- was unexpected. But the media, caught far away and unprepared, treated the ensuing tragedy as an "ancient tribal conflict" between Hutus and Tutsis. Readers were battered with references to "tall, thin Tutsis" and "short, squat Hutus." Rare indeed was any other explanation for the bloodletting.

Reporting from Africa is reduced to simplistic caricatures and Rwanda is no exception. Tribal conflicts, particularly "ancient ones, " have replaced political analysis. "The seeds of strife can be found in ancient ethnic rivalries," wrote the "New York Times," in connection with the Congo, implying that the end of single party dictatorship unleashed aggressions pent-up since a few families first strolled out of the Olduvai gorge. But labeling African struggles as tribal disputes obscures the responsibility of those dictators still clinging to power and excuses the Western states who supported their regimes.

Many of the tribal explanations are simply wrong. The "ethnic" conflict in Natal Province of

South Africa concerns only one ethnic group: Zulus. And last spring, two tribes -- the "Kasais" and "Katangans" used by the "New York Times" to explain an

"ethnic conflict" in southern Zaire didn't exist: Katanga and Kasai are regions, not ethnic groups.

In Rwanda, Hutus and Tutsis, whose supposed differences became the staple of nightly news, speak the same language and share religious and many cultural traditions. Locals say they can distinguish one from the other only about 60% of the time. There was even a great deal of intermarriage until German and then Belgian colonizers elevated the minority Tutsis as a class, entrenching a social distinction.

The violence in Rwanda is not an "ancient tribal conflict" but a modern power struggle. At a time when the Hutu and Tutsi opposition was increasingly well organized, and the regime of President Habyarimana reduced to the support of a small minority from one region, a deliberately staged bout of "ancient tribal warfare" was the only recourse of a military eager to stave off democratic transition.

If Africa were truly wracked by age-old tribal strife, then there would be no need to search for culprits and little point in seeking solutions. But there are culprits; threatened leaders across Africa have an incentive to incite ethnic conflict. In Zaire, Mobutu Sese Seko has all but promised to repeat the violent Congo crisis of the 1960s if he is forced from office. In Kenya, Daniel arap Moi continually cries ethnic division while allowing his own Kalenjin people to attack other ethnic groups.

Permitting these despots to disguise their megalomania as "ancient tribal conflicts" is an abdication of our international responsibilities. The journalist is spared the burden of explaining a complex political process, the former colonial power is no longer accountable, and the West can shrug its shoulders and justify paying even less attention to Africa.

In fact, the West is already blaming itself for doing too much. Former Deputy Secretary of State Clifton R. Wharton, Jr. used the tragedy of Rwanda to claim that "we cannot push democracy faster than it can be assimilated." But the United States is hardly pushing democracy in Africa. The Clinton Administration is doing even less than its predecessors to support the forces for democratic change in Africa.

Activist Ambassadors in Zaire, Kenya and Cameroon, among others, gave vigor to the later years of the Bush Administration. Their departure, followed by the hasty abandonment of Somalia and the shameful delay of action on Rwanda, have sent the clearest possible signal to Africa's dictators, old and new. From Ethiopia to Zaire, militant intransigence is being met with nothing stronger than prolonged policy reviews followed by acquiescence.

There is a long list of countries in Africa which face risks equal to Rwanda's. In most of those, the conflict is about democratic reform, not tribal violence. When violence erupts, we should look behind the mask of "ancient tribal warfare." There we will see dying dictators and generals unwilling to submit to the ballot.

Reprinted from DOCKET: A Journal of the International Human Rights Law Group, Volume 9 Number 1, June 1994


LOAD-DATE: August 1, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


249 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 1, 1994 / August 14, 1994


STATEMENT BY THE PRESS SECRETARY


LENGTH: 547 words


 

THE WHITE HOUSE, Office of the Press Secretary

July 15, 1994

In an effort to bring an end to the fighting and growing humanitarian disaster in Rwanda, the Clinton Administration has closed the Embassy of Rwanda and ordered all personnel to leave the country. Representatives of the so-called interim government of Rwanda must depart within five working days.

The White House also announced that it will begin consultations with other United Nations Security Council members to remove representatives of the interim government from Rwanda's seat on the council. The State Department declared that representatives of the Interim Government will be denied access to any Rwandan government financial holdings in the United States. 

"The United States cannot allow representatives of a regime that supports genocidal massacre to remain on our soil," President Clinton said.

Noting that the ongoing fighting is creating an even more perilous humanitarian disaster in Rwanda and along its borders, the White House appealed to all forces to agree to an immediate cease-fire. It called on all responsible parties to begin serious talks on forming a transitional government that will lead to genuine power sharing.

The White House applauded the French effort to protect Rwandans at risk, and said the United States would continue to press for rapid deployment of the UN peacekeeping force (UNAMIR) to replace the French. It appealed to the international community to redouble its efforts to deploy those U.N. forces.

The White House again insisted that those Rwandans responsible for genocidal killings and other crimes against humanity be brought to justice. It said it hoped that the United Nations would act swiftly -- under the Security Council Resolution that established a U.N. Commission of Experts -- to create a War Crimes Tribunal.

As the crisis in Rwanda has unfolded, the United States has taken a leading role in efforts to protect the Rwandan people and ensure humanitarian assistance.

It has:

Provided more than $95 million in relief, including food, medicine and supplies for international organizations and private relief agencies.

Flown about 100 Defense Department missions into the region to airlift relief supplies.

Strongly supported an expanded UNAMIR; airlifted 50 armored personnel carriers to Kampala to support the UN peacekeepers; and committed to equipping the U.N.'s Ghanaian peacekeeping battalion. # # #


LOAD-DATE: August 1, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


250 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 1, 1994 / August 14, 1994


THE ADMINISTRATION'S RESPONSE TO THE CRISIS IN RWANDA STATEMENT BY THE PRESS SECRETARY


SECTION: DOSSIER, RWANDA


LENGTH: 387 words


 

THE WHITE HOUSE, Office of the Press Secretary, (Miami, Florida)

July 18, 1994

In a further response to the urgent humanitarian crisis in Rwanda and the Zaire border region, the President has authorized the use of an additional $19 million in emergency relief funds to provide food, medicine, other relief supplies and airlift to the victims of this crisis. These funds, authorized under the Emergency Refugee and Migration Assistance Fund, will assist the efforts of the international community, including the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and the World Food Program, to address the needs of refugees and displaced persons in the region.

These additional funds bring the total U.S. humanitarian assistance to Rwanda-Burundi this fiscal year to $139 million, including $118 million since the start of the current crisis in April. This assistance has included support for 100 airlift missions. Another 80 missions will be undertaken in response to the immediate crisis. # # # THE WHITE HOUSE Office of the Press Secretary July 16, 1994 Statement by the Press Secretary The White House announced today that the President has asked U.S. Agency for International Development Administrator Brian J. Atwood to travel to the Rwandan border regions in his capacity as Special Coordinator for International Disaster Assistance. Mr. Atwood will assess relief efforts for the victims of the crisis in Rwanda and the need for enhanced assistance caused by the recent wave of new refugees across the border from Rwanda to Zaire and the increased numbers of displaced persons within Rwanda itself. Mr. Atwood will arrive in Goma, Zaire, on Monday. The White House reaffirmed its commitment to assist the humanitarian relief effort with food, medicine and other supplies. Since the start of the current crisis in Rwanda in April, the United States has provided a total of about $100 million, including support for 100 airlift missions. Another 80 missions will be undertaken in the short-term. # # #


LOAD-DATE: August 1, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


251 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 1, 1994 / August 14, 1994


THEIR REAL INTENTION


BYLINE: Sam Olukoya


LENGTH: 1107 words


 

NEWSWATCH, July 25, 1994

Shehu Yar'Adua, a retired general, has been on the go since the constitutional conference reconvened in Abuja last Monday. He has been meeting with members of his newly formed political group, tentatively called "The Patriots," to work out a strategy which will enhance the group's chances of forming a political party when the ban on politics is lifted. "The Patriots" will use the conference as a shopping ground for political associations.

So far, it has been able to enter into a working alliance with Olusola Saraki, senate leader in the Second Republic. With a determination to make himself a powerful figure at the conference, Saraki's choice as an ally of the Yar'Adua group is understandable. Saraki first made himself visible by sponsoring the motion that states be paired for the purpose of nomination into the standing order and business committees of the conference. He followed this up by emerging the representative of Kwara/Kogi states. Saraki even moved a notch higher when he became chairman of the business committee. Members of the standing order and business committees, both of which constitute the selection committee of the whole house, will be responsible for assigning the members into the various committees. 

The Yar'Adua group will, however, have to contend with another group from the north. This is made up of conservative elements like Bamanga Tukur, a former presidential aspirant, Umaru Dikko and Uba Ahmed, both of them key politicians in the Second Republic. Both groups hold diametrical views on a number of issues, including the arrest of Moshood Abiola, the undeclared winner of the June 12, 1993 presidential selection. While the Yar'Adua group believes Abiola should be released, the conservative group insists the detention is proper.

Dikko, who was in exile for more than 10 years, is believed to have been nominated to the conference as a counter weight to those supporting June 12. However, he has had no impact on the conference so far. Last Wednesday, when deliberation strayed into the contentious June 12 issue, Dikko, contrary to expectations, kept mum.

Even though the Yar'Adua group and the conservative elements are strongly opposed to each other, both groups want to use the conference to prepare the ground for national political parties when the ban on political activities is eventually lifted.

For delegates from the south-west, however, the conference is an avenue to canvass the sanctity of June 12. Last Wednesday, a number of delegates from the area expressed their displeasure at the annulment of the election and Abiola's detention. Dayo Abatan, a delegate from Ogun State, wondered why the man who won an election was in jail and was being conveyed to and from court in a Black Maria, while those who created the problems facing the country were enjoying government's patronage. Another delegate, Tele Olukoya, called on other delegates to examine the annulment so as to alleviate fears that other elections may suffer the same fate wondering whether the result of another presidential election would be accepted. He also called on the government to release all political detainees.

Not all the delegates from the south-west share that sentiment over June 12. Reuben Famuyibo is one of those opposed to the agitation for its restoration. Famuyibo, who is said to be a surrogate of Oladipo Diya, the chief of general staff, told "Newswatch" that the strong sentiment on June 12 would make the south-west lose sympathy of the other parts of the country.

Some delegates from the east too believe the Yoruba and the Hausa-Fulani should show more sympathy for their cause. "We have come to persuade the Yorubas and the northerners to let us also taste power," says one of the eastern delegates. Indeed, having a fair share of the national cake is what the delegates will push for as soon as the eastern conference gets fully under way. "Newswatch" gathered in Abuja last week that the eastern agenda will unfold when the house debates marginalisation.

A clue to what is to be expected was given when Jossiah Odunnah from Imo State repeated the Igbo refrain on marginalisation. According to him, the Igbos have been marginalised in each succeeding regime. Another delegate from Rivers State also sang the familiar tune of his people. He expressed hard feelings that no attention has been paid to his people despite the role of oil from the place in the nation's economy and the attendant menace of its exploration.

With the accommodation problem that stalled the conference when it was inaugurated June 28 now over, the delegates are now prepared to settle down for business. Some 19 committee have been formed to tackle various issues. But even as that was being done, it was glaring that some delegates nurse deep suspicion about the military. They have requested that their resolutions be regarded as final. Famuyibo suggested that a resolution be passed before the debate commences that the military should not tinker with the outcome of the deliberations. Chris Abashiya, another delegate from Kaduna State, and Paul Unongo, a delegate from Benue State, also share the distrust about the military. Unongo particularly spoke with a touch of humour. According to him, there are two political parties -- the military and the political

class. He warned: "We should not play into their hands again."

Reprinted from Newswatch, July 25, 1994

Newswatch is published by Newswatch Communications Ltd., No. 3 Billings Way, Oregun Industrial Estate, Oregun, P.M.B. 21499, Ikeja, Lagos, Nigeria.


LOAD-DATE: August 1, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


252 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 1, 1994 / August 14, 1994


ALL FOR ABIOLA


BYLINE: Mike Akpan


LENGTH: 5734 words


 

NEWSWATCH, July 25, 1994

Trade unions take up the fight to secure Abiola's release from detention and have him sworn in as president.

The buzz word in labor circles in Nigeria last week was "confrontation." The unions adopted that posture to compel the federal military government to address the political and economic problems of the country. Pascal Bafyau, president of the Nigerian Labor Congress, NLC, said the inability of the government to resolve the political crisis which resulted from the annulment of the presidential election of June 12 last year, had aggravated the economic problems of the country and worsened the plight of workers. It also led to "uncontrollable inflation which has further reduced the living and working conditions to a situation which had made life unbearable for the common man."

Bafyau cited the sharp decline in the purchasing power and value of the naira, collapse of social services even while the costs are increasing, low capacity utilization of industries, job insecurity and retrenchment, social decay in values and the drift from poverty to pauperization as the consequences of 

the political crisis. Said he: "For the economy to recover and be put on the path of growth and vibrancy, the political crisis and instability must be brought to an end. The Central Working Committee, CWC, (of the Congress) is convinced that the on-going strategies in resolving the political and economic crisis in the country are not producing desired results. Instead, they had worsened the situation and the misery of all Nigerians."

Bafyau said the CWC discussed the political crisis at its meeting in Lagos July 7 and came to the conclusion that the federal government must ease what he referred to as an unnecessary tension in the country. The Congress made a six-point demand which the NLC wanted the government to implement within 10 days. These were an immediate end to all political arrests, detention and trials, unconditional release of Moshood Abiola, undeclared winner of the annulled presidential election, and Frank Kokori, general secretary of the national Union of Petroleum and Natural Gas Workers, NUPENG. But the police have denied that they are holding Kokori. The confusion over Kokori's whereabouts was compounded last week when Jerry Gana, the minister of information, told reporters in Abuja that the NUPENG secretary-general is actually with the police. According to him, Kokori is chatting with the police, but he is not under arrest.

Other demands were that the government should drop all charges against all political detainees, stop further arrests and harassment of labor leaders as well as re-open all shut media houses. The NLC communique was silent on actualization of Abiola's June 12 presidential mandate and re-instatement of all dissolved political structures by the Abacha regime. In the pre-amble to the six-point demand, Bafyau had specifically said the annulment was not justified. He

argued: "The annulment of the election and subsequent developments since then have combined to portray our country as an object of ridicule, dented our image and diminished the confidence of the international community in our country.

Newswatch gathered the omission of the two demands in the communique was influenced by pressure on some labor leaders by the government as well as some influential politicians. But John Gimbason, president of the National Union of Banks, Insurance and Financial Institutions, NUBIFIE, told Newswatch that the various unions were still discussing endorsing Abiola as president and disregarding the restoration of state administrations and other dissolved political structures. "There is no argument whether June 12 is a reality or not. But the big

question is: Can we actualize June 12 without taking a look at other democratic structures? That is what we are still looking at," he said.

He doubted the practicability of that demand because, according to him, some former state governors and local government chairmen were a disgrace to their states and local governments. The said in Kaduna State, the people would not accept the r-instatement of Dabo Lere, the former governor. "Dabo Lere can never go near the state house. we will stone him." He said the case of Kaduna State could be replicated in Lagos, Benue, Plateau, Kano, Akwa Ibom, Cross River and Rivers. According to him, the problem was whether Abiola could become president without reinstating the old political structures.

The federal government saw the confrontation coming but took no steps to stop it because government officials dismissed it as a joke. For such ac confrontation to succeed in forcing the government out of office, they reasoned, the NLC must support it. At the moment, they believe the NLC is inclined towards the government and would not show partisan commitment to agitation for the revalidation of the annulled presidential election. To be sure the NLC was not dragged into the political agitation, government officials advised that Bafyau be sponsored on a trip to Geneva so that he could be free from he pressures of pro-democracy activists.

That strategy backfired. Bafyau's absence created an opportunity for members of the National Democratic Coalition, NADECO, to not only penetrate the NLC but other unions. For instance, NADECO influenced the choice of an acting president of the NLC while Bafyau was away. NADECO also infiltrated strategic unions whose strike actions could cripple economic and social activities in the country. Of the 44 industrial unions, NADECO strategists picked only those in the oil and finance sectors. They held a series of meetings with leaders of NUPENG, NUBIFIE, Petroleum and Natural Gas Senior Staff Association of Nigeria, PENGASSAN, and the Lagos Council of the NLC. Newswatch stumbled on one of such meetings between NADECO strategists and Kokori at the Jabita Hotels, Ikeja, in May. NADECO's strategy was to break up unions whose leadership supported the government.

The strategy paid off. NADECO succeeded in convincing the leadership of NUPENG and PENGASSAN to plan for a political strike to force out the military government and pave way for the actualization of June 12. NADECO strategists had no problem in convincing the two unions to carry out the strike because of the collapsing state of the oil industry and its effects on the workers. For example, the union leaders were made to understand that the unending political transition program and the resultant crisis were responsible for the collapse of the oil industry because the money that should have been used to revamp it was channeled into politics. asked one NADECO

leader at one of the meetings: "Is it right for this country to embark on another transition program that is bound to fail after wasting more than N40 billion to set up political structures that Abacha single- handedly pulled down?" That question worked up that union leaders and toughened their resolve to confront the military government once and for all.

First, the two unions made several demands on the government in June and wanted them fulfilled before the first week of July, failing which they would call out their members on strike. NUPENG, for example, wanted the government to fulfill 11 demands. One of the demands was that the government quit the political "stage in Nigeria permanently, restore the dismantled democratic structures,. call on the acclaimed winner of the last presidential election to negotiate a peaceful hand-over of the reins of government to satisfy the yearnings of the teeming millions of Nigerians who voluntarily gave him that historic mandate."

PENGASSAN made 10 demands which also included the actualization of the June 12 mandate given to Abiola, restoration of all dismantled democratic structures and the convening of a sovereign national conference. The government was not bothered by the ultimatums of the two unions because it still relied on the NLC to stall the strike threats.

But when the NUPENG strike started July 4, the NLC could not help. Instead,, the NLC leadership sensed that it would become irrelevant if the NUPENG strike succeeded. In desperation, Bafyau was recalled from his Geneva trip. Government also allegedly offered N¬ million to the NLC but the money was rejected after the leadership realized that the oil workers' strike would succeed.

The NLC leadership compelled Bafyau to summon an emergency meeting of the CWC Thursday July 7 to take a firm stand on the economic and political situation in the country. At that meeting most of the members told Bafyau that they felt uncomfortable with his close relationship with the government. They accused him of taking certain decisions on behalf of the congress without consulting them. They cited his nomination as a member of the constitutional conference and his acceptance without reference to the congress. Bafyau was told that he must either go along with the popular will of the congress to lead out the workers on strike or resign. But if he failed to act, the congress was determined to pass a vote of no confidence on him and remove him. Newswatch learnt that the communique he read a t a world press conference on July 9 was drafted for him to sign.

Government guessed the possible outcome of the July 7 CWC meeting and made desperate moves to influence it. Oladipo Diya, chief of general staff, made overtures to the NLC leaders through Bafyau to address the CWC meeting. The request was turned down and Bafyau was advised to inform him that if government had anything to say, it should address the nation.

The strike by NUPENG got off to a shaky start but by last Monday its effect on the commercial life in Lagos and some other major cities had become serious. The participation of senior workers in the oil industry, worsened the situation. The oil companies were forced to close down their operations.

By last Wednesday, oil production had dropped from 1.89 million barrels a day to only 900,000 barrels. Industry sources said last week the quantity could drop to 150,000 barrels by the weekend.

Chevron shut down its Escravos oil terminal. Mobil Producing Nigeria Unlimited also closed down its Qua Iboe terminal the following day. Shell Petroleum Development Company Limited, the biggest oil producer in Nigeria, also cut down the operational level of its Bonny and Forcados terminals by half.

With crude oil production disrupted, the strike spread to the refineries. Workers at the War Refinery and Petro-chemical Company joined the strike on Monday. The refinery, with a capacity of 110,000 barrels per day, had just undergone a turn-around maintenance and was expected to commence full production last week. That left only the Port Harcourt and Kaduna refineries running.

However, by last Wednesday, the oil pipeline taking crude oil from the Niger Delta to the Kaduna refinery ruptured near Auchi in Edo State causing a serious oil spillage. That development prompted a shutting down of the pipeline. With no crude oil supply, the Kaduna refinery operating currently at only 50 percent of its installed capacity since last year, is expected to close down this week after exhausting its crude oil stock. Newswatch learnt that the Port Harcourt refinery with a capacity for 210,000 barrels per day was also shut down last Wednesday. It was unable to confirm that report by press time.

The strike action has received a near-total support among senior oil workers. Investigations last week confirmed that all the senior workers in the oil companies had withdrawn their services on Monday. In the Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation, NNPC, the staff of the Products and Pipeline Marketing Company, PPMC, National Petroleum Investment Management Services, NAPIMS, Warri Refinery and Petrochemical Company, WRPC and the PHRC also joined the strike. As a result, soldiers deployed to lift fuel from Ejigbo oil depot in Lagos could not do so because they could not operate the equipment.

But cracks developed in the ranks of the oil workers last week. Workers at the Kaduna refinery said they were not part of the strike action. The Kaduna Zonal council of PENGASSAN said after its meeting last Wednesday that its members should continue to work. Newswatch later learnt its position on the strike was influenced by northern traditional rulers who are opposed to the political demands of the striking oil workers.

Workers at the corporate headquarters of the NNPC also pulled out of the strike. As at last Wednesday, most of them had reported in their offices in Victoria Island and Ikoyi. A week earlier, junior workers in the corporation had also opted out of the NUPENG strike. Workers at the Warri refinery called off their strike too by Wednesday.

But so far, government attempts to break the strike have been unsuccessful for two reasons. Firstly, 80 percent of the workers in the oil industry are from the southern parts of the country. Government's usual tactics in breaking politically- motivated strikes is to play on the ethnic sentiments of workers. That explains the position of the Kaduna zone of NUPENG, PENGASSAN and state councils of the NLC in the northern states. But in the case of both NUPENG and PENGASSAN, the number of workers from the north is very negligible and therefore their decision to stay out of the strike cannot register the desired impact. Moreover, all the key facilities except the Kaduna refinery employed to make the strike effective are located in the Warri-Port Harcourt-Eket axis in the south.

Secondly, it was easy to mobilize oil workers on a political strike because of the state of the oil industry. Once regarded as a blue chip, the industry is collapsing, leading to mass retrenchment by oil service companies. Government which owns 60 percent equity shares in all joint venture companies in the industry except Shell where it owns 55 percent has defaulted in its financial contributions to the companies in the past one year.

At the beginning of this year, it was owing the joint venture companies $1.043 billion according to Don Etibet, petroleum resources minister. By the end of last month, $791 million of the accumulated debts was paid leaving a balance of $252 million or N5.54 billion. Arthur Onoviran, national publicity secretary of PENGASSAN, explained that the debts were accumulated because government which gets 68 percent of the net proceeds from the industry is diverting resources to an endless transition program. As a result of the non-funding of the joint venture commitments, all the oil companies are forced to cut down on their operations.

In the past one year, no oil company undertook any drilling operations. Oil production still depends on existing fields with no new discoveries to shore up the fast depleting resources. The industry is currently operating only 19 drilling rigs against 50 last year. Seismic operations have also been cut by 50 percent according to PENGASSAN. Most of the oil service companies have folded up. The service companies employ about 60 percent of the workforce in the oil industry.

Even the oil producing companies are threatening to reduce their staff by as much as 30 percent. Onoviran told Newswatch that workers in the oil sector believe corruption institutionalized by the military was responsible for their woes. He said NNPC resources had been plundered through spurious contracts forced on the management by the military officers in government. for instance, he claimed that 22 coastal tankers were currently on hire by the NNPC at an annual cost of $96 million or N2.1 billion. Foreigners are now recruited as "technical back-ups" for jobs hitherto performed by Nigerians. The recruitments are handled by racket companies owned by government officials, he alleged.

Besides, proceeds from oil sales are no longer accounted for. The use of Lebanese firms and front companies owned by influential Nigerians to sell crude oil has resulted in delayed remittance of sales proceeds. In some cases, returns for crude oil sales are not paid to the federation account. Such proceeds are usually passed on to dedicated accounts which are not subject to official audit.

Allocation to dedicated accounts currently stand at 220,000 barrels per day. Hitherto, proceeds from crude oil sales were controlled by the NNPC which also had an allocation of about 200,000 barrels per day to fund the joint venture commitments. The cash call allocation to NNPC was abolished early this year. Consequently, NNPC now queues for disbursement of funds like every other government establishment at the treasury.

The financial crunch has also affected the maintenance of NNPC refineries and plants resulting in low capacity utilization, scarcity of fuel and allied oil products. The workers are also angry that their jobs are being taken over by soldiers. The unions are accusing the government of starving the department of petroleum resources, the monitoring agency for the industry of operational resources to perpetrate fraud by its officials. Military task forces are said to have taken over the monitoring of the agency. Onoviran's grouse is that members of the task forces are not trained for the jobs they are now asked to perform and therefore cannot detect lapses and sharp practices in the industry. One of the demands of the striking oil workers is that the DPR be upgraded to an inspectorate commission.

The absence of an effective monitoring agency in the oil industry explains why there is a boom in oil bunkering and cross-border smuggling of fuel -- illegal activities for which PENGASSAN has accused influential Nigerians and government officials of perpetrating.

Apart from the complaints of the oil workers, the strike has also succeeded because of the tacit support of the oil companies which have been engaged in a running battle with the government to pay up their debts. For some time now, oil producing companies have witnessed declining business fortunes wing to shortage of funds for their joint venture operations. The strike by the oil workers is seen as desirable to force the hands of the government to pay up the debts.. For the oil marketing companies, the strike is also a welcome development because it will enable the government to pay them a debt of N500 million owed for products bridging to the north.

Even within the NNPC, there is an unofficial support for the strike as the only way of checking the plundering of the corporation and interference by government officials. The convergence of the interests of the oil companies, workers and other players in the industry has provided the enabling environment for the success of the strike.

The strike has led to a rise in the prices of crude oil. By close of business last Thursday the London Brent, equivalent to Nigeria's Bonny Light, traded for $18.66 per barrel as against $17.75 on Monday. The price was expected to hit $19 per barrel by last weekend.

As at last Thursday, the country's daily loss from crude oil export was $28.2 million or N619 million. Nigeria exports 1.55 million barrels of crude oil per day out of its OPEC quota of 1.89 million barrels. For local consumption, it sets aside 330,000 barrels daily for the refineries. NNPC losses from inability to sell refined products was put at N70 million daily by oil experts last week. Besides, down time losses to oil companies were estimated at $6.1 million or N132 million a day. The losses excluded the costs suffered by most public establishments that depend on the oil industry.

For example, the National Electric Power Authority, NEPA, could not generate electricity from its four gas turbine power plants at Afam, Ughelli, Sapele and Egbin. NEPA was forced to rely on its two hydro-electric stations at Jebba and Shiroro. The two stations have a combined output of 1,400 megawatts. The national demand is 2,362 megawatts. Industrial plants such as the National Fertilizer Company of Nigeria, NAFCON, Onne, and some factories in Lagos and Aba which rely on gas like NEPA were forced to either switch on to diesel or shut down. Even most companies which also rely on parallel power generation through private generating plants were also forced to close down because of fuel shortage.

The strike severely affected air and land transportation in many parts of the country. Many motorists who had no fuel were forced off the road. The few commercial transport operators who managed to buy fuel at exorbitant prices jacked up transport fares by as much as 500 percent. As at last Wednesday, a 50-litter jerry can of fuel sold for between N2,500 and N3,000 in Lagos. That also affected transport fares in the city.

Air transportation was similarly affected by shortage of aviation fuel. For one week, aircraft operating domestic services were refueling at the international wing of the Murtala Muhammed International Airport, Ikeja. Femi Asun, station manager of Aviation Development Corporation, ADC

Airlines, said: "We now spend up to four hours at the queue to refuel one aircraft, a situation that has resulted in flight delays." By 3 p.m. last Wednesday, that system had collapsed. "When we went there, there was nobody to attend to us. This is making it impossible for us to operate," Asun said. On July 13, none of the airline's nine scheduled flights took off. The ADC, according to the station manager, was losing an average income of N2 million daily from flight cancellations.

Harco Air Services Limited could not operate any of its 10 scheduled daily flights last week. That leaves it with a daily loss of N2 million from flight cancellations. Only the Nigeria Airways and Okada Airlines were able to operate skeletal services. Although Chris Aligbe, head of corporate information, said the Airways was getting its normal fuel supply from National Oil, two of its flights were canceled last Wednesday. One of the flights to Yola via Jos was canceled even after passengers had boarded. Other victims of flight cancellations were Emeka Anyaoku, secretary-general of the Commonwealth, and Olu Onagoruwa, federal attorney-general and minister of justice. They could not travel to Abuja for scheduled meetings last Wednesday for lack of flights. Newswatch learnt that as of Wednesday, only Kano airport had aviation fuel; but most airlines did not have fuel to take their planes there for refueling.

The strike also dislocated commercial and industrial activities in many parts of the country. MicCom, an indigenous electric cables manufacturer in Lagos, said the fuel shortage had caused it a daily loss of N3 million. It said the loss would continue as long as the strike lasted.

The situation will get worse this week if the July 19 deadline by the NLC for a nation-wide strike holds. Lagos and Kwara state councils of the NLC and the Senior Staff Association of Universities, Teaching Hospitals, Research Institutes and Associated Institutions, SSAUTHRIAI, joined the strike action last week. NUBIFIE and the National Union of Road Transport Workers' Union, NURTW, were warming up for action this week.

There was no indication late last week that the federal government would accede to the political demands of the striking workers. Jerry Gana, the information minister, was quoted last Wednesday as saying the release of Abiola as demanded by the striking workers was the responsibility of the Abuja federal high court currently trying him. The court refused Abiola bail last Thursday. Justice Mohammed Mustapha, the presiding judge, said that there was no formal application with an accompanying affidavit to support it. Besides, he said, Abiola's lawyers had not shown enough evidence that their client would not jump bail.

Despite the legal brick wall, efforts to get him released from detention were in top gear, leading to newspaper speculations last week that Abacha had ordered he be freed. Kudirat, Abiola's wife, and Kola, his eldest son, were in Abuja all of last week for this purpose.

Although Kudirat and Kola are working to achieve the same objective, they differ in their strategies. Kola wants his father to renounce his claim to the June 12 presidential mandate but Kudirat wants him to stick to it. She wants her husband to be set free on his own terms. Both of them were said to have avoided Diya. Instead, they were dealing with Aminu Saleh, the secretary to the federal government.

Dapo Tejuosho, the Ohile of Okeona and a nominated member to the constitutional conference, was also exploring other contacts to get Abiola released. He is a member of the conference's business committee. In his new position, Tejuosho has taken over the campaign to secure Abiola's release. Although he could not convince Okunade Sijuwade, the Ooni of Ife, to come to Abuja to persuade Abiola to drop his claim to the presidency, he succeeded in reaching out to other Yoruba leaders, including the Alafin of Oyo, the Ewi of Ado Ekiti and Michael Adekunle Ajasin, former civilian governor of Ondo State.

Newswatch learnt the government was prepared as early as last Monday to release Abiola if he agreed to renounce his claim to the presidency. A source at the presidency said government's condition for Abiola's release agreed with the standpoint of Kola that his father should forget about politics and face his business. Kola's position is already causing problems not only with his father's wives who are opposed to it but also with NADECO. Kola is reportedly fighting Kudirat, saying she is pushing his father into a struggle that would finally destroy him. He believes June 12 is dead and should be laid to rest. Abiola was said to have rejected Kola's position.

But Kola has not given up. He now wants influential Yoruba leaders to persuade his father to reason with him. Already, he has visited Olusegun Obasanjo, former head of state, to speak to his father on the futility of trying to actualize the annulled mandate.

In response to Kola's request, Obasanjo led a team of some Yoruba leaders made up of Richard Akinjide, a former justice minister, A.M.A. Akinloye, former national chairman of the National Party of Nigeria, NPN, Layi Balogun, a former presidential aspirant, among others to meet Ajasin at his Owo residence July 10 to brainstorm on how the political crisis could be resolved. Unfortunately, Obasanjo's visit to Owo created a deep suspicion among pro-June 12 supporters who feel increasingly worried about his role in the political crisis in view of a campaign going on for the formation of another interim government as a way out of the current crisis. Canvassers of the interim government idea want Obasanjo to head it.

The idea is said to have been sold to Walter Carrington, the United States ambassador in Nigeria, as well as to Jesse Jackson and Andrew Young, both prominent black Americans. In turn, they are selling the idea to the State Department. But Edward C. Oparaoji, chairman on the Nigerian Democratic Awareness Committee based in the U.S., has already petitioned the State Department disagreeing with the idea of an interim government.

This, perhaps, accounted for the initial rebuff of Obasanjo and his team by Ajasin and the pro-June 12 supporters who insisted on the presence of key progressives like Olu Falae and Remi Okunrinboye before Ajasin could listen to them. At the meeting, Ajasin told Obasanjo that there was no going back on June 12 as far as the Yoruba were concerned and that the Yoruba were not prepared to trade the mandate for his release. Newswatch sources said Obasanjo met Abacha in Aso Rock last Wednesday.

NADECO said last week that it was prepared for a long drawn out war with the government to secure Abiola's freedom and the actualization of his mandate. It said it would intensify grassroots mobilization of opposition to the present regime. Apart from the trade unions, it said it had reached out to various groups like students market women and professionals to

support the struggle. Said a NADECO leader: "Our role is to act as a catalyst. We will gather all pro- democracy forces together, fine--tune their individual strategies, advise them on the mode and appropriateness of their action and give them moral and material support." That strategy has started to show some results. The group itself has adjourned its general house sine die because it believes it has been infiltrated by government. A group of its elders will now coordinate all NADECO's activities. In Lagos, market women and lawyers have organized a series of protests in the last three weeks to press for Abiola's freedom. Newswatch learnt that the students, under the auspices of the National Association of Nigerian Students, NANS, were also planning a big showdown with the regime.

Pressure for release of Abiola is also coming from Shehu Musa Yar'Adua, a retired major-general and a constitutional conference delegate. With pressures coming from various directions, it is very likely government will set him free soon. But if it does not and its planned talks with labor leaders fail, then there might be tougher days ahead.

The government appears to have made up its mind to face the showdown as security reports have indicated. It has handed over the management of security in Abuja for the next six months to MOSAD, an Israeli secret service. Already, 28 MOSAD agents, made up of four officers and 24 other ranks, are in Abuja. Their services will cost Nigeria $2 million a month. End Reported by Soji Akinrade, Nats Agbo, Wale Akin-Aina, Utibe Ukim, Joseph Ode, Moffat Ekoriko, Jonah Achema and Tunde Asaju.

Reprinted from Newswatch, July 25, 1994

Newswatch is published by Newswatch Communications Ltd., No. 3 Billings Way, Oregun Industrial Estate, Oregun, P.M.B. 21499, Ikeja, Lagos, Nigeria.

Africa News


August 1, 1994 / August 14, 1994


FREEDOM OF EXPRESSION IN MALAWI: THE ELECTIONS AND THE NEED FOR MEDIA REFORM


LENGTH: 1920 words


 

ARTICLE 19: THE INTERNATIONAL CENTRE AGAINST CENSORSHIP

July 21, 1994

Malawi will be seen by many as an example of a successful transition forced upon an undemocratic government from outside and below. It moved from 30 years of autocratic rule, through a relatively open and peaceful campaign period, with elections recognized by international observers as expressing the will of the people, in to a new era of multi-party democracy.

In many ways this is a faithful representation of events. Compared to the transition process in some other states, the campaign and election were peaceful and orderly, and, when the results were known, the old order calmly gave way to the new with grace and dignity. Nevertheless, most Malawians would agree that their nation has a long way to go before its transition is complete. Indeed, the new United Democratic Front (UDF) government, led by President Bakili Muluzi and Vice-President Justin Malewezi, was elected because it promised change. Its promise of free primary schooling in a country where illiteracy runs upwards of 60 percent was warmly greeted by voters. It also promised to alleviate poverty and improve other services including hospitals and roads. 

Statistics recently released by government for the first time demonstrate what observers have

suspected all along: Malawi is one of the poorest countries in the world. There is also an urgent need to meet emergency food needs in this year of drought, a need which took President Muluzi on visits to food- exporting, neighbouring states within two weeks of taking office. Demonstrating an awareness of human rights issues, he also promptly closed three prisons renowned for their cruel treatment of detainees and released any political prisoners still being held by Dr. Hastings Kamuzu Banda's outgoing government. He commuted all death sentences to life imprisonment, affecting 120 people immediately and as many as 300 untried capital cases.

President Muluzi inherits a country where poverty and illiteracy are widespread, the birth rate is high, capital is scarce, and commercial agriculture, industry and trade are underdeveloped. The task of transforming the economy is a daunting one and will not be accomplished easily or quickly. It is unlikely, however, that real political reform can be accomplished without it.

It is unfortunate that following 30 years of enforced ignorance, politicians and journalists failed to sue the campaign period to analyze these issues in any detail for the electorate. Few people understand the seriousness of the situation, and therefore envision easy solutions to these difficult problems.

Expectations are high: people want change now. This disjuncture between public expectations and real possibilities is a cause for concern. It can only be combated by dissemination of accurate information to the public about the true nature of conditions in Malawi. To fail to do so will have serious political and social consequences.

Moreover, in spite of claims to the contrary, 30 years of rule by the Malawi Congress Party (MCP) did little to eliminate regionalism from politics. In fact, Dr. Banda's policies exacerbated the problem by conferring privileges on certain ethnic groups and regions while restricting those of others. This situation was exacerbated during the campaign by the failure of politicians and the media to discuss issues around which people could unite, such as differences of opinion on land reform, foreign relations, development initiatives or social policy. With little to differentiate candidates, most voters appear to have voted for presidential and parliamentary representatives according to their charismatic appeal or their tribal, linguistic or regional origins. The three major parties dominated the three regions of the

country: in the parliamentary election, 85 percent of the votes cast in the North were for the Alliance for Democracy (AFORD), 64 percent of the votes in the Central Region went to the MCP, and 76 percent of the electorate in the South voted for the UDF. Articulated class divisions that might have cut across ethnic

divisions failed to become an election issue: the legacy of years of suppression of trade unions and political activity meant that peasants and workers were unable to have their protests heard.

Strong government policies are needed to create a national consensus without heightened regionalism. This process can also be facilitated by the media if they effectively analyze and inform the public.

In order to play such a role, the media in Malawi will need to change and develop, becoming more issue-oriented, critical, analytical, and skilled. Malawian journalists and donors are drafting strategies for media reform (see below). Reforms in other areas have progressed further, beginning with the new constitutional provisions aimed at redressing the injustices and grievances of the last three decades. The task now is to implement these provisions. Conclusions

ARTICLE 19 has learned that monitoring a campaign and an election in an effort to determine whether they are free or fair is a business fraught with contradictions. In the first place, it is worth noting that power of a sort is gained by any observer group whose views are solicited, making its opinions and judgments a target of pressure from institutions determined to subvert or manipulate them. At its most crude, political parties may try to gain credibility by flooding monitors' offices with complaints. On the other hand, with utmost subtlety, diplomats from donor countries will expect observers' pronouncements to confirm the wisdom of their aid policies.

In other words, observers find themselves in the unenviable position of being expected by some to pronounce serious reservations and by others to declare elections "free and fair." For this reason, it is important that observers enter the exercise with as few predispositions as possible, that they understand what is expected of them, who might try to manipulate them, and how it might be done, They must also accept that their psychological predisposition is to insist that they understand what they see in a village, even when the circumstances are not as they appear.

We have also discovered that in order to begin to determine the fairness of a poll, monitors must at the same time try to see the broader picture. It is unlikely, except in cases of the most flagrant abuse, that observers will be able to assess accurately the fairness of an election campaign if only the last few days of it are monitored. There are many, many ways an election can be rigged, and few are noticeable by people who visit only briefly, do not understand the power relationships of the people they meet and do not know the language. At the least, monitors should arrive a few months in advance of the election, and work through local institutions, such as churches or human rights groups. Even then, observers must accept that in many cases they just will not know if intimidation has taken place, or ho much of an impact it might have on the results.

Taking these reservations into account, ARTICLE 19 nevertheless considers that the international community was right in proclaiming the elections relatively free and representative. The Electoral Commission deserves special mention for the independent and pragmatic way it performed its work. The appointment of Justice Msosa, who maintained a refreshingly straightforward approach, set the tone, Dr. Banda's acceptance of the results provided Malawi with an opportunity to move forward in peace.

Similarly, ARTICLE 19 recognizes that the MBC did make an effort to present the campaign news fairly and to broadcast civic education fully. Its coverage of the election results shows just how much is possible, if training is instituted at the MBC, if resources are made available and if it is granted editorial independence. MANA would benefit from similar assistance.

Yet Malawi still faces the hardest part of its

transition: overcoming its impoverishment, illiteracy and underdevelopment. We fear that democratic principles will fall on stony ground unless the transition includes the creation of jobs and wealth, thereby giving the fledgling democratic institutions a chance to take root. In order to achieve this goal, free and open debate of policy alternatives is essential. ARTICLE 19 remains convinced that fundamental media reform will be necessary to ensure that this transition process does not become distorted and die.

Reform is not simply a matter of creating a legal or institutional climate where journalists and broadcasters can work, but must encompass economic reform as well. An independent press, according to the Windhoek Declaration, is one that is free from government political and economic control, as well as "from (government) control of materials and infrastructure essential for the production and dissemination of newspapers, magazines and periodicals." Three years ago in Namibia, the international community was called upon to assist in the creation of a pluralistic African press by "funding support towards the development and establishment of non-governmental newspapers, magazines and periodicals that reflect the society as a whole and the different points of view within the communities that they serve." When that was written,

the political transition in Malawi had not begun: only government-controlled daily and weekly newspapers and the single government-owned radio station operated. Now, dozens of independent Malawian journalists and publishers, in the forefront of the struggle to keep democracy alive, are asking the international community to recognize that their need is the same as those African journalists who met in Windhoek three years ago.


LOAD-DATE: August 1, 1994


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


August 1, 1994 / August 14, 1994


LEFT AND RIGHT TUSSLE FOR ANC'S SOUL


LENGTH: 974 words


 

THE WEEKLY MAIL & GUARDIAN, July 15, 1994

The ANC's traditional leftwing tussles with a 'pragmatist' camp for the soul of the party. Paul Stober reports

The African National Congress' parliamentary caucus has become the front line of a battle between the organisation's "socialist" and "pragmatic" camps.

According to ANC parliamentary sources, the battle is about the future direction of the ANC. This revolves around the question as to whether the organisation and its parliamentarians will be watchdogs keeping a check on government, or whether it will become a tool of government to be used to sell state policy to ANC supporters. 

Beneath this, a subtle ideological struggle is also being waged between the ANC's traditional left, who accuse the ANC leadership in government of abandoning the organisation's commitment to far- reaching social and economic reconstruction, and some ANC members in government who want the state to follow more "pragmatic" economic and social policies.

ANC sources say the "pragmatists" are based mainly in the cabinet and are accused of sacrificing ANC interests in order to cut deals with other political parties and big business, to secure a broad- based political centre that can oversee a successful transition. They are said to include Deputy President Thabo Mbeki, Defence Minister Joe Modise, Foreign Affairs Minister Alfred Nzo, Trade and IndustryMinister Trevor Manuel and PWV Premier Tokyo Sexwale.

They are opposed in the parliamentary caucus by those who want ANC cabinet ministers to promote the organisation's policies and radically restructure government and public service. These include trade unionists put on the ANC's election list by Cosatu and by ANC political education head Raymond Suttner and SACP rising star Blade Nzimande.

Minister without portfolio Jay Naidoo, who is overseeing the Reconstruction and Development Programme from the president's office, is believed to lean towards this camp. Although Naidoo's portfolio makes him politically powerful, he is unable to make waves because many aspects of the RDP fall under the control of other ministries, which have to carry out the programme.

SACP stalwart and housing minister Joe Slovo is said to have opted to stay out of the fight. His health is poor and he wants to focus on his portfolio.

It is not clear where public service and administration minister Zola Skweyiya stands in relation to the ideological battle. What is known, however, is that Skweyiya is a powerful figure who has the ear of President Nelson Mandela. There have been a number of skirmishes between the camps over relatively minor issues in the caucus. But at the last caucus meeting the parliamentarians made a significant gain when ANC cabinet ministers agreed to form an ANC cabinet caucus to pursue the organisation's policies in government.

The ANC's national working committee and cabinet ministers met earlier this week to discuss the relationship between the ANC and government.

The battle between the two camps will most likely come to a head at the ANC's next national congress, tentatively set for December. The traditional left is pushing for a clear break between cabinet and the ANC leadership, and jockeying for positions on the organisation's national working committee has already begun.

The SACP mainstream and Cosatu appear to be lining up behind ANC secretary-general Cyril Ramaphosa, who is tipped as a strong contender for the post of ANC president when Mandela retires. Although Cosatu _ and to a lesser extent the SACP _ have been casting around for political direction since many of their leading intellectuals were elected to government, Ramaphosa still has grassroots support among ANC and Cosatu activists. He is seen as having the skill to build the ANC into a strong mass organisation which will continue to function independently of government.

The ANC also has other influential leaders outside parliament, including leading SACP intellectual Jeremy Cronin and the ANC's RDP head, Cheryl Carolus. Cosatu and SACP activists and leaders are engaged in a furious debate about how best to revive their organisations.

The battle is likely to become increasingly heated in the run-up to the congress. Both sides know there will be nothing bigger than the ANC in South African politics for the next ten years, and the future policies of the government will be decided by those who control the organisation.

Reprinted from The Weekly Mail & Guardian, July 15, 1994.

The Weekly Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media

Contact: M&G Media, 139 Smit Street, Breamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025.

Africa News


August 1, 1994 / August 14, 1994


GOVERNMENT'S FRAGILE UNITY STRETCHED


LENGTH: 880 words


 

THE WEEKLY MAIL & GUARDIAN, July 29, 1994

As MPs get ready to reconvene parliament next week, Ian Clayton analyses the tensions in the Government of National Unity

THE fragile political unity in the Government of National Unity -- with the ANC, the National Party and the Inkatha Freedom Party as unlikely bedfellows -- is coming under strain as MPs and party members become increasingly restless about the compromises necessary to make the deal work.

In the immediate post-election and post- inauguration phase, party leaders were able to preserve the image of common purpose in the interests of the broad goals of promoting democracy and reconstruction.

But that is beginning to come unstuck -- and will come under increasing pressure in the next four months as parliament gets down to the serious business of dismantling the bureaucratic apartheid empire and replacing it with democratic structures. And, as reports this week reflected, the NP could be the first to break ranks, although it will almost certainly not quit the GNU at this stage. 

NP MPs are envious that the tiny and much- scorned Democratic Party has emerged as the parliamentary opposition to the

government, and the ANC in particular.

Indeed, so jealous are they of the role played by DP acting leader Tony Leon in exposing the police and the ANC over the Shell House shootings in which eight IFP supporters were killed, that the NP's chief whip, Hennie Smit, says the party wants to play a dual role as both an opposition party and as "responsible co-governors".

The NP's real problem, though, is more

fundamental: it has lost its purpose. The party that tried to force apartheid on South Africa with missionary zeal became the party of the gravy train. It handed out jobs and high income positions to loyalists, people who served the government machine as long as they were paid. And that has all but gone.

Its one common ideological strain was an all- embracing anti- communism, but now it sits in the GNU with communists. After February 2 1990, and with the election of FW de Klerk as its leader -- remember how he just managed to defeat Barend du Plessis -- the NP did, briefly, become a party of reform, but

that ended with the April election.

With its historical baggage, the NP does not have much to contribute to the building of democracy and redressing its own wrong-doing. As it stumbles around, a process aided by De Klerk's holiday in Europe -- which has left the party rudderless for many weeks -- it's an open secret that many of its old guard, particularly former ministers and deputy ministers, are considering taking their pensions and getting out while the going is good. A number of NP MPs are expected to quit before the end of the year.

As De Klerk re-enters active politics, he may be able to use his stature and charm to stamp his authority on the NP's troubled caucus.

This week, the salt was rubbed into the NP's wound by Justice Minister Dullah Omar's statements of solidarity with Cuba. Nothing could be further from the NP's ideological soul and yet it is part of the same government as Omar.

The ANC caucus, too, has similar problems. Many ordinary MPs simply cannot handle being on the same side -- or at least being seen to be on the same side -- as the NP and particularly the IFP. And the compromises in the GNU are often painful.

The South African Communist Party's attack on President Nelson Mandela's statements about the wave of strikes must be seen in the context of the problems being faced internally by the ANC alliance about its role in government.

As parliament reconvenes next week to debate the welter of legislation facing it and the first 100 days of Mandela's government, these tensions are bound to become more obvious. But for the time being at least, the GNU is expected to survive.

Reprinted from The Weekly Mail & Guardian, July 29, 1994.

The Weekly Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media

Contact: M&G Media, 139 Smit Street, Breamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025.
