Africa News


August 1, 1994 / August 14, 1994


A JOURNALIST'S PERSONAL EXPERIENCES OF THE ARMY TAKEOVER


BYLINE: Alieu Badara Njie


LENGTH: 1627 words


 

DAILY OBSERVER, July 25, 1994

I was on my way to Brikama on that fateful Friday morning when the driver of the mini-van I was in suddenly made a sharp swerve at the intersection leading to the airport. Everybody was puzzled about this sudden move, but things started to take shape in the next few minutes, as we all began to witness a historic event unfold tight before our very eyes.

Alighting from the mini-van, I soon discovered the reason for the driver's move. A flurry of activity was in progress around the vicinity of the Yundum army barracks. Soldiers were milling about apparently attempting to commandeer passing vehicles in which they were quite successful as they soon took over a GPTC mini-van and two trucks. Momentarily the three vehicles were careening down the highway towards Banjul at breakneck speed full of heavily armed soldiers.

Murmurs from the bewildered crowd indicated that the soldiers were staging a demonstration because they had not received their salaries. Other opinions indicated that the army was on a joint military exercise with US Navy personnel who arrived the previous day aboard the naval vessel, USS La Moure County. My journalistic instinct, however, told me that this was not a mere event, and I hopped into a passing GPTC bus to further try to find out what the soldiers were up to. 

At Lamin, all traffic was brought to a halt as one of the trucks was fueling up at the Shell Petrol station. I quickly jumped out of the bus, and walked slowly towards the petrol station in the hope that I might find out the intentions of the soldiers. However, as my approach became recognized, I was angrily asked to stop in my tracks by one of the soldiers, and when I identified myself as a journalist, he retorted, "We do not have any need for journalists at this time, so turn back and go," whilst he menacingly pointed his gun at me. I needed no further warning so I returned to the bus. Soon after the soldiers departed, the traffic was reopened, and we continued our journey into the unknown.

At Kanifing, the driver announced that he was not proceeding any further. Everyone scrambled out of the bus in anticipation of picking up another transport bound for Banjul. To our dismay, however, it was learnt that all Banjul-bound traffic was being turned back at Denton Bridge. In the melee, I managed to secure a lift, but the driver told me that he was going to Bakau and can only drop me at the intersection.

I intended to walk the rest of the way, but luckily enough, I was picked up by another motorist. As we approached the bridge we saw a multitude of different transports being turned back by tow armed soldiers. I walked up to one of them and identified myself in the hope that e would let me across. I was now keenly anxious to get to Banjul because whatever was brewing at this juncture must be centered there.

The soldiers however turned down my request and asked me to turn back for my own safety.

Just that moment, I caught sight of a colleague, Momodou Musa Secka, of the "Daily Observer" who had been similarly rebuffed by the soldiers. We decided to proceed to the "Daily Observer" office in Bakau from where we could plan our next move. Moments after we arrived, we could hear the sound of gunshots emanating from the TSG headquarters.

Without hesitating we decided to go and investigate. At the Bakau Fire Station, we met a group of people who were talking among themselves in a hushed manner. We asked them what was going on inside the TSG premises, and they told us that some 20 soldiers of the Gambia National Army had raided the barracks, and were in the process of disarming and arresting the TSG and Police personnel there.

We approached the barracks carefully, and as we got closed a soldier on guard at the gate signalled us to come forward by only with our hands held up. He asked us for identification, and when I proffered my "Daily Observer" press card, he geared into action.

He began raving about journalists telling lies to the Government. "You are from the "Observer" but today we will be observing you." At gun point, we were marched into the barracks, and at the entrance, we were asked to board a truck full of captured TSG and policemen and women.

I estimated our number to range between 30 and 40 which made conditions very uncomfortable. After what seemed an eternity, the truck suddenly took off without warning making us pile on top of one another. I understood from conversations going on that we were being taken to the Army Barracks, at Yundum.

It was a most uncomfortable drive. By now people were milling on the roadside to satisfy their curiosity and to cheer the soldiers who were then the only ones using the roads.

When we arrived at the army barracks, we were herded out. One of the soldiers reported to a lieutenant that we were two journalists. The lieutenant promptly instructed him to take us to the mess room until he was ready to deal with us. We, however, ended up in another room where we were kept under guard.

By then we were getting restless because we were civilians and could not understand why we were being detained. We therefore requested to be brought before one Captain Momar Cham who was apparently in command of the camp.

Capt. Cham turned out to be a very polite officer who explained the situation to us. He said that what was happening in the country was of concern to everyone, and added that the army was trying to bring things under control. He told us to exercise patience and that if things became normal, we would be allowed to go. He gave us some cigarettes and promised to come back to us later on.

A few minutes later, however, a soldier walked into the room and asked us to follow him. We were taken to the place where the main body of detainees were held and locked in. Not long, a lieutenant walked into the room and gave a short speech in which he tried to allay our fears. "You are in safe hands," he declared, "no one here is going to be killed. We are just trying to rectify 30 years of mismanagement and corruption. Just as soon as the situation is brought under control, we will release you all."

We kept on waiting. Cigarettes were distributed and lunch was also served. After what seemed an eternity, Captain Sarr came for us and led us to the Senior Officer's mess. Along the way, he told that Mr.. Ebun Jack, the Permanent Secretary at the Ministry of Defence, and Mr. Kebba Ceesay, the Director of the National Security Service, were being held there and he would like us to have a word with them.

We were asked to be seated in the outer room.

It was another long wait until around 5pm when Captain Sheriff Sarr emerged from the inner room to inform us that we were to go with him to Radio Syd where an announcement would be made. We were joined in the vehicle by Captain Badjie and two NCOs.

When we reached Radio Syd however, the place was deserted and Captain Sarr instructed the driver to proceed to State House in Banjul. At State House we were introduced to the rest of the officer corps who successfully planned and executed the couple

Lt. Edward Singhatey, a highly composed officer, gave us a quick briefing in which he indicated that there was not a single casualty largely because the Presidential Guards decided to join them rather than offer resistance. He told us that the President together with the Vice President and the Inspector General of Police were seeking refuge in the US ship, USS La Moure County, and that the Minister of Information and Broadcasting and the Minister of Justice were being held at Marine Unit headquarters in Banjul.

After the briefing, I was provided with an escort to take me home for by then the curfew was almost two hours old...

Reprinted from the Daily Observer, July 25, 1994.

The Daily Observer is published by The Observer Company (Gambia) Ltd., New Town-Sait Matty Junction, Bakau, P.M.B. 131. Banjul, The Gambia. Telephone: (220) 496608, 496877, 496878. Fax: (220) 496878.


LOAD-DATE: August 1, 1994


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


257 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


August 1, 1994 / August 14, 1994


WHY WE TOOK OVER


BYLINE: Rodney D. Sieh & Momodou Musa Secka


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 2534 words


 

DAILY OBSERVER, July 25, 1994 In the aftermath of Friday's bloodless takeover by the Provisional Ruling Council, Observer's Rodney D. Sieh, also the BBC's Banjul Correspondent, accompanied by Momodou Musa Secka, also of the Observer, met with the head of the 4-man council at State House. In this interview, the young Lieutenant explained what led to the takeover, the forming of a new government and among other things, the fate of former government officials. This is how it went.

DAILY OBSERVER: How long was this takeover planned?

Lt. Yaya Jammeh: Well, it was planned within 24 hours, because when we came from the airport where we went to welcome the President from his annual leave, we were humiliated publicly because the politicians accused us of plotting to overthrow the government, and we were searched in public. All soldiers were searched, weapons seized. And that was the straw. I myself was disarmed even though most of time I'm armed, but on that day I was disarmed for no apparent reason. 

None of them could take action to inculcate discipline in the PPP regime and there was random plundering of the country's assets, just to benefit a few people. So we realised that even though we hated coming to power, because we were not elected by the people, we had to make sure that the people had their voice so that is why we decided to come here.

DO: What is the fate of former ministers?

Lt.J: We are not out to take revenge, okay, we do not want to go out and hunt for them, to give the public the impression that we are out to harm anybody. We are not here for that. They are Gambians, wherever they run, they will come back. I want to make sure that their conscience will prevail upon their emotions to come for accountability. No minister needs to be afraid. We are not going to set up any military tribunal to try anybody. We are going to institute a government that is composed of mostly civilians and a civilian judicial system will be put into place to try civilians, and those who will be tried will be tried publicly. We are not here to set up secret military tribunal; we are not here to set up anybody but what we want is for the nation's assets that have been plundered to be returned to the state for the benefit of all Gambians. This is why we are not hunting anybody. We want all of them to report to the nearest police station. If they fail to do so we would get them because they have their families here. They'll come back.

DO: So far, how many former ministers have you been able to capture?

Lt.J: Well it's not a question of capturing any minister. It's a question of taking them into custody. For their own protection. Because the masses of the people would lynch any minister that is seen in the street and we don't want bloodshed. We don't want to shed anybody's blood, we don't want any counter resistance, and we don't want anybody to take the law into his own hands.

DO: How soon should we expect a new government to be named?

Lt.J: A new government will be named as soon as possible. We are not naming a government now, because we need the support of the civilians, intellectuals and patriotic Gambians who are clean, who will make sure that they serve in their appointments without fear or favour.

DO: What are your plans for the establishment of democracy, which was one of your main objectives for taking over?

Lt.J: Well, as soon as a new government is instituted which is composed of mostly civilians, democracy would be in place and we will welcome all contributions from all corners of the country to make sure that everything is done in the right way and that transparency and accountability will be the order of the day. We will not tolerate any sort of corruption, we will not be secretive in anything that we do. We want the press and the international community, including Gambians, to criticise us where we go wrong. We are not here for praises, we are not here to enrich ourselves. We are here to set up a just system that is not corruptible, to make sure that the living standards of Gambians will be augmented to an acceptable standard within the limits of our resources. But we are not here to sue the limited resources of the country for our own good at the detriment of the masses.

DO: Did you encounter any resistance during the takeover?

Lt.J: We encountered a lot of resistance from the TSG, their commando unit and the Police. We came under fire. We marched from Yundum to State House, but we never returned any fire because we did not want to shed any Gambian blood. We are not here to shed innocent blood and we are even not here to shed anybody's blood. We are blood thirsty military officers. We were obliged by the urgency of the situation to step in and that is why we have warned them that we are not here for a bloodbath. We are more heavily armed than they. If we had released our heavy weapons it would have been a catastrophe; that is why we did not even release any weapon, we just kept on the advance and those of their officers who came forward we told them of our resolved to march to the State House and take it over to overthrow the government under all circumstances and at any cost, and if they continued to fire at us, we may retaliate which was not our aim.

DO: So as far as you are concerned, there was no bloodshed during the takeover?

Lt.J: We marched from Yundum to Banjul, took over the TSG headquarters State House, took forces and there was no bloodshed. No civilian was shot. Nobody was shot.

DO: What is the rapport between the army and the police now?

Lt.J: Well, you see, we are here for a common interest and the differences in uniform do not signify differences in patriotism. They have understood the situation because most of us are from the provinces, we are people who are suffering. Everybody's relatives are suffering. They know that they are suffering the same injustices. So at the end of the day we have to come together for a common cause. We are working harmoniously, we are not sidelining anybody, we are grouping together, having meetings, integrating the forces, joint patrols and there is a harmonious relationship.

D: So since Friday, the national and international telephone lines have been cut off and this has developed into the international community misinterpreting what actually took place. How soon do we expect these lines to be opened.

Lt.J: Well the reason for cutting off the international telephone lines was the fact that some of the former ministers were making calls t some people outside for what reason we don't know. it was necessary to cut off the international lines to make sure that nobody misinformed the international public as to what was going on here. That is the reason we cut off the international lines, but we have giving order for GAMTEL to re-open them.

DO: How soon will that take place?

Lt.J: Well, what happens is that those people responsible for the restoration of the lines disappeared, and we had to go in search of them until they were found. They said it would take a number of hours to restore the international lines and we hope that they will be restored soon.

DO: Do you have any intention of including any member of the PPP government in your new structure?

Lt.J: You see, we are not painting all members of the PPP government as bad or corrupt. Whoever is clean and has the interest of the country at heart rather than personal interest is welcome to be a part of the government, because we want advice, we want people who have contributed positively to the development of the country under constraints, we want them in the new government. We are not sidelining anyone who is clean. We are not out to wipe out the entire PPP. There are some good guys in the PPP and they are free to come forward and we'll sit together and work in the interest of the country.

DO: There have been conflicting reports about the situation of the former Vice President Sabally. Is it true that he has been captured?

Lt.J: Well, it is not true that the Vice President has been captured. He is in safe hands, he is with the president aboard an American vessel together with the Inspector General of Police and some officers of the presidential guard and the Police, including the ADC; they are on board the American vessel.

DO: How did they get there?

Lt.J: How they got there I am not certain, but for some reason the ship was anchored at the port waiting for the exercise that was supposed to have taken place, when we decided to put a stop to the plunder and the looting of national assets for the benefit of a very few. So, as we were advancing towards State House, knowing that all the forces they had put to counter us had failed to stop our advance, I think that's when they decided to flee into the ship.

DO: Will you make any effort to question them about the whereabouts of the government funds?

Lt.J: Well, it is up to them to come back as Gambians and account for whatever they have to account for whatever they want to account for. But as for the President, we all know that we owe it to him that the name of The Gambia has reached the international level and we respect him; but the people who were behind him misled him, were corrupt, did whatever they wanted to do because he was too lenient. We have no intention of harming him -- the former president -- or humiliating him. We want to treat him as an elderly man. He is free to come to the country as a Gambian citizen and we can provide for his security if he needs it, and from time to time we will need to consult him. We will not sideline him, we will consult him for advice. We have nothing against him, but the people behind him were doing whatever they wanted, uncontrolled.

DO: A four man council has been set up, who is in charge of this council?

Lt.J: Well I am in charge of the council, but being a four man council doesn't mean that that is where it stops. We are going to incorporate civilians, put civilians and members of the armed forces into the council to make sure that it is a broad based council to make decisions.

DO: Do you have any advice for the public or for Gambian citizens who may be panicking because they don't know what the situation is now?

Lt.J: The Gambian public have no cause to panic, because since we came in we have made sure that there was no rampage, there was no looting, there was no bloodshed and we provided patrols to make sure that Gambians are safe because we do not want anybody to take the law into his or her own hands or settle old scores. We are not here for bloodshed, we are not here to harass anybody. The masses of the Gambian people suffered under this system and they need not fear us simply because we are soldiers. We are not setting up a military dictatorship to dictate what is going to happen, we are here for the public to know that they have to contribute positively for the development of the country, everyone, irrespective of where you come from, what language you speak or what you do. This is our main objective, so we are assuring all Gambians that we are here for them, not for our own interest, but for them.

DO: So how soon, then, can the ordinary Gambian say, "I am looking forward to free and fair elections", what timetable can you give?

Lt.J: Well, we are not giving any timetable for free and fair elections. That does not mean that we are here to stay too long. We are not here for that.

DO: How long then?

Lt.J: I cannot give you a fixed timetable because we have to make sure that Gambians are aware of what their rights are, what kind of leaders they want, and what type of system they want to put into effect in this country, that's all. And we also want to make sure that the term of the presidency in this country is limited. We don't want life presidency, a president who will rule for decades, so from that you will know that we are just transitional.

DO: So what term are you suggesting for presidency in The Gambia?

Lt.J: Well, that will be up to the Gambian people. I am not here to dictate what should happen to the Gambians. We will organise a national electoral commission and a referendum as well to ask the people of The Gambia what kind of leaders they want and the term of office they want that leadership to serve. Certainly it will not be a term that will exceed then years, in fact, ten years is too much for a Third World country like The Gambia so we will make sure that there's a democratic system of government that will be elected buy the people and that can be kicked out by the people if they don't want it, peacefully, and through the ballot box, and that is all we want.

Reprinted from the Daily Observer, July 25, 1994.

The Daily Observer is published by The Observer Company (Gambia) Ltd., New Town-Sait Matty Junction, Bakau, P.M.B. 131. Banjul, The Gambia. Telephone: (220) 496608, 496877, 496878. Fax: (220) 496878.

EDUCATION/TRAVEL


LENGTH: 1267 words


 

The San Francisco State University College of Extended Learning is offering a new professional training series this fall: The International Trade program. The following courses will be offered: Export Documentation, Sept. 19-Nov. 21, 6-9pm, $375; Export/Import Letters of Credit, Sept. 22-Dec. 1, 6-9 pm, $375; Introduction to Export Marketing and Promotion, Sept. 27-Nov. 29, 6-9 pm, $375; Import Regulations and Documentations (Customs Brokerage), Sept. 28-Nov.30, 6-9 pm, $375. Contact: SFSU College of Extended Learning, SFSU Downtown Center, 425 Market. (415) 904-7700.

The Collaborative Projects Program of the National Endowment for the Humanities welcomes applications for projects of broad scholarly and public significance in the humanities that entail the collaboration of two or more scholars for periods 1-3 years. All topics in the humanities are eligible. Awards usually range from $10,000 to about $150,000. The deadline is OCTOBER 15, 1994 for projects beginning no earlier than July of the next year. For application materials and further information write or call: Collaborative, Projects/Interpretive Research, Division of Research Programs, Room 318, 1100 Pennsylvania Ave., NW, Washington, DC 20506. Tel: (202) 606-8210. 

The National Endowment for the Humanities Reference Materials Program supports projects to prepare reference works that will improve access to information and resources. Support is available for the creation of dictionaries, historical or linguistic atlases, encyclopedias, concordances, reference grammars, databases, textbooks, and other projects that will provide essential scholarly tools for the advancement of research or for general reference purposes. Support is also available for projects that address important issues related to the design or accessibility of reference works. The application deadline of 15 SEPTEMBER 1994 for projects beginning after 1 JULY 1995. For more information write to Reference Materials, Room 318, NEH, Washington, DC 20506.

Environmental Briefs Corp. is a non-profit organization that publishes a newsletter updating African environmental scientists on recent findings published in academic literature. The student intern would serve as an editorial assistant. Duties would include: reading and summarizing articles in the academic literature; going to university libraries to photocopy articles; writing letters to journal editors and article authors; and updating mailing lists. Knowledge of or familiarity with calculus, mathematical models, the earth sciences and Africa would be helpful. Computer experience (preferably in a Macintosh environment) is also a plus. While this is an unpaid internship, it will provide invaluable experience to anyone interested in a career in either international development of the environment. Please contact Catherine Camp Boyle, Environmental Briefs Corp., 22 Willowdale Road, Winchester, MA 01890.

The Population-Environment Fellows Program, sponsored by USAID and administered at the University of Michigan, sponsors fellow for two-year appointments with overseas agencies. Fellows, who must hold a graduate degree in a relevant area and demonstrated expertise a both population and environment, provide assistance and technical support for developing country institutions to foster a comprehensive approach to development. Applications are reviewed on a rolling basis, but the sooner a completed application is received, the greater the availability of sites for which it can be considered. Inquiries and application requests may be obtained by contacting: The Population-Environment Fellows Program, SPH II, Room M2240, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109-2029. Tel: (313) 747-0222. Fax: (313) 747-4947.

The University of Florida sponsors academic year abroad programs in Tanzania and Nigeria and summer programs in Uganda and Morocco. At the University of Dar es Salaam in Tanzania, students spend an academic year studying Swahili. A summer field course in tropical rain forest ecology and conservation will be offered in the Kibale Forest of Western Uganda at the Makere University Biological Field Station. A Summer Arabic Language, Conversation and Translation Program is located in Fez, Morocco. Contact: Overseas Studies, Office of International Studies and Programs, 123 Tigert Hall, University of Florida, Gainesville, FL 32611. Tel: (904) 392-5206. Fax: (904) 392-5575.

Research grants in African Rural Development Issues are offered by the Winrock International Institute for Agricultural Development. Although the fourth round of grants had a deadline of February 1, 1994, interested social scientists may contact Winrock for further information on future funding opportunities. Contact: Dirk Perthel, Winrock International, 08 B.P. 1603, Abidjan 08, Cote d'Ivoire. Phone: (225) 44-94-14. Fax: (225) 44-94-11. Their U.S. office is at 1611 N. Kent St., #600, Arlington, VA 22209. Tel: (703) 525-9430. Fax: (703) 525-1744.

University of Minnesota, Minnesota Studies in International Development (MSID) offers an academic year program of internships and field study including 5 months in Senegal or Kenya. Financial aid is available. Details are available at the Center of through: MSID, The Global Campus, University of Minnesota, 106-M Nicholson Hall, 216 Pillsbury Drive SE, Minneapolis, MN 55455-0138. Tel: (216) 625-3379.

The Center for Global Education announces a semester-long program in Namibia designed to introduce students to the central issues facing Southern Africa. Course credit may be earned. Applications and brochures are available from Center for Global Education, Augsburg College, 2211 Riverside Avenue, Minneapolis, MN 55454. Tel: (612) 330-1159.

The University of Cape Town's Centre for African Studies announces the Harry Oppenheimer Research Fellowship. Applicants are considered annually in December for the following year. The fellowship is for three to six months, depending on the recipients program. Fellows receive R7500 and are expected deliver an Africa Seminar and contribute to the cultural life of the Centre. Contact: Harry Oppenheimer Institute, UCT Private Bag, 7700 Ronderbosch, University of Cape Town, South Africa. Phone: (021) 650-3273. Fax: (021) 650-3274. email: erasmus@socsci.uct.ac.za.

EMPLOYMENT


LENGTH: 6734 words


 

World Relief seeks the following: **PROGRAM DIRECTOR, Zaire -- Will design, implement, and oversee all field level programs in Rwanguba, Zaire, to respond to the current situation in Rwanda. Programs include, but are not limited to: camp management, health. In addition to managing the implementation and execution of field programs, the director will also be responsible for representing World Relief with other "on the field" NGO's and providing, as needed, support to local national churches. Qualifications include: Fluency in French, prior overseas field experience, ability to leave immediately and serve a 6-month term with the possibility of extending for an additional 2- 6 month term. Fax resume to Jim Watters at 708-665- 4473.

**HEALTH PROGRAM COORDINATOR, Zaire -- Medical doctor will respond to the current situation in Rwanda. Position is based in Rwanguba, Zaire. Individual will be responsible for designing and implementing the medical response as well as establishing the "on the field" work site. In addition to overseeing the medical program, the Health Program Coordinator will also be responsible for negotiating agreements with the UN and other governing bodies as required. Qualifications include: fluency in French desirable, prior overseas medical experience, and a comprehensive understanding of community health concepts and practices. In addition to the base qualifications the Health Program Coordinator must be able to leave immediately and serve a 3-6 month term. Fax resume to Jim Watters at 708-665-4473. 

**LOGISTICS OFFICER, Zaire -- Medical doctor will be responsible for arranging and organizing transportation, provision of housing and needed supplies for the Program Director and the assigned medical teams. In addition to these responsibilities, the Logistics Officer will also be responsible for designing distribution systems, procuring materials, and working with all vendors in and out of country. Qualifications for this position include: prior overseas experience, preferably in Africa, French fluency, prior logistics experience desirable but not required, excellent organizational and communication skills. Logistics officer must be available to leave immediately and serve a 6 month term. Fax resume to Jim Watters at 708-665-4473.

Senior Program Manager, Strategic Business Planning & Development, sought by 'Private Initiatives for Primary Health Care' project to assist in development, implementation and testing of different models of sustainable private sector health service delivery that provide basic health care to low income, urban residents in developing countries. Responsible for business development aspects of project's activities. Areas of expertise should include: accessing start-up capital; strategic business planning and implementation; financial planning and operations; MIS; outsourcing of support; joint procurement programs; load find management; payment mechanism. Qualifications: 7+ years administration/management in financing or health care service delivery organizations; Masters degree in health care of business administration, finance or economics, Spanish fluency required; experience in Latin America and Africa; ability and willingness to travel extensively. Resumes to: INITIATIVES, JSI Research & Training Institute, 1616 N. Fort Meyer Drive, 11th Floor, Arlington, VA 22209.

The Panos Institute (Washington, DC), an international NGO working in the Americas to produce information and educational resources on sustainable development, seeks a well-organized self-starter to take charge of internal information systems, and coordinate media/press outreach here and throughout the Americas. Qualified applicants must be highly proficient in spoken/written Spanish and English, possess advanced computer skills including Internet, Dbase, and Wordperfect, and 1+ year prior paid experience in an office environment, preferably non- profit. Degree required. Position coordinates intern and support staff. Duties include: media outreach, publications dissemination, library management, computerized systems management and office administration. Salary: low $20s. Send resume, salary history and writing sample to: Diane McGlynn, Panos Institute, 1717 Massachusetts Avenue, NW, Suite 301, Washington, DC 20036.

Small consulting firm seeks bright, humanitarian assistance professional. Duties include proposal development, client relations, and office management. Background with AID, UN or PVOs beneficial. Computer and strong writing skills required. Send resumes, references, and writing samples to: KAI, 611 Pennsylvania Ave., SE, #229, Washington, DC 20003.

ICDDR,B, the world's international health and population research center, seeks a desk officer to work with a senior development officer and consultants to support and coordinate its fund-raising activities (including a new capital campaign to raise $20 million, and the placing or project proposals) in North America. Excellent written and verbal skills, some fund-raising experience, creative ideas, enthusiasm, and some independent work required. Effective results may permit the conversion of this into a full time position. Send letter of interest, salary requirements, 3 references to: Child Health Foundation, PO Box 1205, Columbia, MD 21044.

Washington-based international development firm interested in receiving resumes from experienced project management professionals. Interested individuals must have at least ten years experience working with private voluntary organizzations and/or USAID in the area of development and humanitarian assitance. They should be experienced in program evaluation, project design and implementation, and the management of USAID/PVO grant portfolios. Experience in any of the follwing very userul: samll enterprisee credit development, agriculture/farming systems, natural resources management/environmental protection, cooperative/international trade, and development education. Fax CV to Mendez England & Assoc,. 202-965-4053.

Washington-based international development firm is seeking individuals with 3+ years experience in the administration of USAID/PVO grant portfolio. Knowledge and working experience iwth proposal reviews, project monitoring and evaluation, preparation of grant documents and overall grant management and adminstration. Qualified candidates should be able to pick up on complex subject matter and procedures quickly and be able to handle routine work conscientiously. Must posses excellent writing and communications skills. Undergraduate degree required. Fax CA to Mendez England & Assoc,. 202-965-4053.

Mendez England & Associates is seeking experienced consultants in the following areas for upcoming projects: project evaluation, project design and implementation; management and technical training; small enterprise credit development; agriculture/farming systems; natural resources mangement/enviornmental protection; cooperative/international trade; development education; local government; communications; journalism; and television production. Fax CV to Mendez England & Assoc,. 202-965-4053.

DIRECTOR OF INTERNATIONAL OPERATIONS - Candidate should have strong knowledge of international development agencies and development issues related to macro-economic policies, private sector development, privatization, training and management and institutional development; familiarity with foreign direct investment and capital financing; good organizational, analytical, communication and interpersonal skills; strong knowledge of computer databases and electronic information management; working knowledge of 1+ foreign languages, preferably French or Spanish; minimum BA; MA in relevant field preferred; prior work experience in a developing country. Responsibilities: Supervise and backstop all international activities including helping set priorities, communicating these to staff, and overseeing implementation; manage all research requests for ongoing activities and marketing, including supervision of research staff; work on specific projects on an ad hoc basis and undertake assignments to prepare feasibility studies, proposals and reports; market the firm's capabilities to private corporations, government agencies, foreign governments and non-profit organizations. Fax resume to the attention of G. Walker at 703-684-9489.

The AIDS Control and Prevention (AIDSCAP) Division of Family Health International seeks a DEPUTY DIRECTOR, AFRICA to assist the Regional Director in providing technical and managerial expertise in planning, implementing and evaluating country programs and to provide direct supervision of office staff. Requires doctoral or masters level degree in social science, publich health and 7+ years of program management experience; considerable knowledge and expertise in public health, infectious disease transmission, and behaviour change related to health issues. Please state salary requirements in cover letter with resume to: Human Resources (MD/DDA), FHI, 2101 Wilson Blvd., Suite 700, Arlington, VA 22201.

Refugees International is seeking a senior advocate to become a key player in our advocacy on behalf of refugees and other humanitarian victims. The senior advocate is expected to travel on short notice to sites of humanitarian emergencies to assess needs and give early warning using written and verbal reports of governments, UN officials, the media, etc. Ideal applicant would have: excellent written and verbal advocacy skills and name recognition; extensive experience in conducting humanitarian emergency field assessments; strong background in Africa; and good working knowledge of UN humanitarian operations with relevant contacts. Send resume, salary history, and 2 writing samples to: Refugees International, 21 Dupont Cicle NW, Washington, DC 20036. Fax: 202-828-0819.

PACT, Inc. seeks outstanding, broad-gauged individaul with 3-5 years' media experience to: conceive, shape and impart the public image of PACT targets to US and overseas audiences through media, publications and videos; work with PACT overseas and US staffs and others to document program experiences, and to articulate and share lessons learned; write speeches, op-ed pieces and other PACT-focused literature including annual report; and sevre as PACT spokesperson. Send letter of interest, resume, salary history and writing samples to: Fannie Sedgwick, Executive Search, PACT, Inc., 1901 Pennsylvania Ave., NW #510, Washington, DC 20006.

Bread for the World, a nation-wide, faith-based, anti-hunger advocacy orgnaization is looking for a Human Resources Manager. The position requires a Bachelor's degree, 5 years' experience and specific training in HR policy analysis and implementation, benefits administration, volunteer and intern prgoram development, law and the workplace regulation, and online payroll systems managment. Send resume, availability, salary needs and references to: Phoebe deReynier, Vice President, BFW, 1100 Wayne Ave., Suite 1000, Silver Springs, MD 20910. No phone calls please. BFW is an equal opportunity employer.

CURRICULUM DEVELOPER/TRAINER - Develop advocacy training materials for womens' NGOs in preparation for the 1995 World Women's Conference, with a focus on Africa. Broad background in women's issues and development and proven training capabilities required. French required. Send resume to Kari Hamerschlag, InterAction, 1717 Massachusetts Avenue, NW #801, Washington, DC 20036.

OPD SUPERVISOR, Uganda. Responsibilities: train and supervise local nursing staff; set-up emergency/acute care clinic; collaborate with local health authorities, NGOs and UN agnecies; oversee patient and clinic activities and prepare monthly reports. Qualifications: RN or MD with emergency/acute care experience in developing coutnries; proven success in implementing new programs in relief situtaions; excellent communication and interpersonal skills; self-starter; training experience desirable. $1,200/month, 6 month contract. Call or send resume to American Refugees Committte, Cathy Tilsen, 2344 Nicollet Avenue, #350, Minneapolis, MN 55404. Phone: 612-872-7060. Fax: 612-872-4309.

MENTAL HEALTH COORDINATOR, Uganda. Position will work with Rwandan refugees in two camps in southern Uganda. Responsibilities: prepare and conduct needs assessment; prepare and conduct training course for Rwanda counterparts; develop, with counterparts, therapeutic activities; provide accessible mental health services to refugees in both camps. Qualifications: Masters' degree in counseling and mental health services; minimum of 2 years developing country experience; previous experience with post traumatic stress disorder, preferably among refugees; ability to work well with refugees and host country nationals in program planning and implementation. French proficiency desired. 6 month contract, $1,200/month, immediate opening. Transportation, health insurance and group housing provided. Contact American Refugees Committte, Cathy Tilsen, 2344 Nicollet Avenue, #350, Minneapolis, MN 55404. Phone: 612-872-7060. Fax: 612-872-4309.

HOME VISIT COORDINATOR, Uganda. Responsibilities: Coordinate with Ugandan Red Cross to select participants to be trained as home visitors; prepare and implement training course to enable participants to provide primary health outreach to all families in the refugee camps; supervise and support local staff in daily primary health care activities; provide continuing education to the home visitor participants; prepare and submit reports and attend meetings as needed. Qualifications: RN or MPH with minimum 2 years' experience in health prevention/promotion activities; previous developing country experience; ability to work effectively with host country nationals and refugees in program planning and implementation; and proficiency in French. 6 month contract. Immediate opening. $1,200/month. Call or send resume to American Refugees Committte, Cathy Tilsen, 2344 Nicollet Avenue, #350, Minneapolis, MN 55404. Phone: 612-872-7060. Fax: 612-872-4309.

International Rescue Committee seeks fund- raising professional to manage major gift program. Applications must possess 3 years of fund-raising experience (preferably with a non-profit major gift program), BA/BS, strong analytical and organizational skills, excellent communication skills, both verbal and written; some field experience with refugees desirable; some international travel. Must be willing team player. Position offers excellent salary/benefits and pleasant work environment. Send cover letter, salary history and resume to: Louise Shea, IRC, 122 East 42nd Street, New York, NY 10168.

DEVELOPMENT OFFICER. The International Women's Health Coalition seeks seasoned development professional to manage annual and project funddevelopment of annual fund-raising goals, design and raising. Newly-created position. Responsibilities: management of campaigns and events; writing proposals, solicitations, reports; coordination of prospect and donor research and contacts. Emphasis on expanding individual donor base. Qualifications: 5-10 years significant development experienece; strong writing and oral communication skills; computer literate. Requirements: detail-oriented, highly organized. Resume and letter of interest to: G. Angela Flemister, Director of Management and Human Resoures, International Women's Health Coalition, 24 Eaast 21st Street, New York, NY 10010. No calls please.

World Vision US seeks individuals to handle the following responsibilities in DC office: financial management of government contracts, budgeting for grant proposals, compliance reporting, and providing technical support to field offices. Must have good communication skills and the ability to manage multiple tasks under very tight deadlines. Degree in accounting or finance and at least 5 years experience required. CPA or advanced degree desired. Requires extensive international travel. Resume to World Vision US, Employment Dept., 919 W. Huntington Dr., Monrovia, CA 91016.

ACCION International seeks Program Assistant tot work with Director of US Operations in all aspects of management and development of ACCION's network of associated microenterprise organizsations throughout the US> Recommeneded qualifications invlude knowledge of community economic development (in the US and/or in the field of microenterprise development), relevant master's degree andor experience in the field, strong Spanish speaking and reading skills, and basic computer skills. Salary range: $30-34,000 polus benefits. Starts September 1. Send resume and cover letter to: Katherine Stearns, Director, US Operations, 733 15th St. NW, Stuie 700, Washington, DC 20005. Fax: 202-393-5115.

Refugees International is seeking an executive assistant for its President to: provide administrative support, liasison with staff and Board; draft correspondence, memos, faxes, reports and testimony; schedule meetings and travel arragements; contact press, politicians and government officials, and maintain and update files. The ideal candidate would have: 5 years administrative/secretarial experience in a fast-paced, quick turn-around environment; WordPerfect 5.1 proficiency; experience with e-mail and Internet; excellent oral and written communications skills; and strong organizationsal and problem-solving skills. Send resume, salary history and writing samples to: Refugees International, 21 Dupont Circle, NW, Washington, DC 20036. Fax: 202-828-0819.

Located in the Georgetown section of Washington, DC. Small, very busy, international consulting firm has an immediate need for a bright, energetic individual to handle a wide variety of office duties. Must know WordPerfect and Lotus. Database experience helpful. Salary $18,000 to $20,000. Send resume to SK, 3250 Prospect Street NW, Washington, DC 20007. Fax: 202-965-4053.

International Rescue Committee seeks individual to assist two Directors with fund-raising activities on a part-time basis. Position requires excellent organizational and communication skills, thorough knowledge of WordPerfect for Windows and Lotus, and the ability to work M-F for a total of 19 hours. Offers competitive salary/no benefits, and a pleasant work environment. Send cover letter with salary history and resume to: Lousie Shea, IRC, 122 E. 42nd St., New York, NY 10168.

InterAction seeks a part-time intern to assist the Program Officer for Foreign Disaster Response. Duties will include gathering and editing information on member agency activities in crisis areas throughout the world, reporting on meetings and briefings related to disaster assistance efforts, and liaison with member organizations, USAID's Office of Foreign Disaster Assistance, and UN agencies. The position is unpaid and requires 18 to 21 hours per week. Applicants should have strong writing and computer (Windows, Internet, etc.) skills. Overseas humanitarian experience preferred. Please fax cover letter and resume to George Devendorf at 202-667-8236.

INTERNATIONAL MEDICAL CORPS has multiple openings. Mail or fax resume or letter of interest to International Medical Corps, Dept. 93- 033, 12233 West Olympic Blvd., #280, Los Angeles, CA 90064; fax: (310) 442-6622.

IMC is seeking a DIRECTOR OF DEVELOPMENT to direct its fund-raising activities. Individual will be responsible for the implementation of a comprehensive development plan. Individual will research and write foundation proposals, develop grassroots support, act as a liaison with board members, oversee the direct mail campaigns, plan special events, supervise maintenancen of donor database, and coordinate corporate and major gifts programs. Qualifications: superior writing skills, established contacts with major donors and foundations, BA/BS degree, 5-7 years of proven fund-raising experience, excellent interpersonal skills and supervisory skills. Competitive salary and full benefits.

The following International Medical Corps positions are available in ANGOLA: **COUNTRY DIRECTOR: October 1994 start date. Prior overseas experience managing emergency/relief program with increasing levels of reponsibility required. Strong management, interpersonal and donor-relations skills required.

The following International Medical Corps positions are available in SOMALIA. **OB/GYN RN or NP for Baidoa Hosiptal to assist with the set up of the maternal/child health services, train local Somali nurses on triage of children and women, work with a local midwife in seeing ante-natal patients and teach basic classes on ante-natal care, post delivery care and basic nursing skills. ** PRIMARY HEALTH CARE (PHC) TRAINER to assist the local PHC team in implementing a community health worker and traditional birth attendant training and referesher program. Additional duties will include expanding and strengthening the local staff's health education, supervisory skills. The ideal candidtate will have clinical experience and prior experience with PHC in a rural area or developing country. **EXPANDED PROGRAM FOR IMMUNIZATION (EPI) COORDINATOR to mount mobile immunization campaigns and keep immunization records and statistics. Anticipated start date is Spetember 1994.

The following International Medical Corps positions are available in SUDAN. **EPI COORDINATOR: Requirements include: Prior overseas experience, strong teaching skills and immunization campaign implementation experience. Salary, insurance, round- trip transportation, room and board provided. **NURSE PRACTITIONER to diagnose and treat patients seeking care at Tambura Hospital. position requiresments: NP license, ability to deal with a wide variety of respiratory and tropical diseases. One year of rural or developing country expereince needed.

The INTERNATIONAL MEDICAL CORPS is seeking the following for its start-up emergency hospital program in RWANDA: **EMERGENCY ROOM NURSE - Strong trauma background, critical care casualty, emergency and triage preferred. **OUT PATIENT DEPARTMENT NURSE WITH STRONG OB/GYN EXPERIENCE-to examine pregnant women in need of ante-natal care, assess, evalutate and triage children. In addition, examine and treat male adults for a variety of tropical diseases.

The Center for International Private Enterprise (CIPE), an affiliate of the US Chamber of Commerce, seeks individual to assist with developing and implementing training/education programs focused on strengthening overseas business associations and their staffs' capabilities. Will conduct needs assessments; establish training objectives; select/develop courses; recruit instructors; and coordinate logistics. Will also assist with managing CIPE's grants programs for Africa. Requires related degree and 2 years of related training experience in an international setting; experience with Microsoft Word and Lotus; fluency in Russian; and the ability to travel, work with diverse constituencies and meet tight deadlines. Portuguese language skills preferred. Start $28K with excellent benefits. Send cover letter and benefits to: US Chamber of Commerce, Personnel Dept., 11615 H St., NW, Washington, DC 20062-2000.

Doctors of the World, a New York-based volunteer organization that provides medical and humanitarian relief to desperate populations around the world, is seeking a dynamic Executive Director to manage and develop this young and growing non-profit. As the Executive Director, you will be responsible for creating and implementing fund-raising strategies, writing proposals, and overseeing day-to-day operations including managing personnel, finances and material resources. In addition, you will recruit field staff, respond to field programs' needs and handle legal (and other) matters pertaining to overseas programs and headquarters office. Required qualifications: Master's degree in a relevant field (or equivalent work experience) and 3-5 years of solid foundation fund-raising and/or management experience. Excellent representational, public relations, communication and proposal writing skills as well as supervisory and budget monitoring experience and a commitment to the goals and development of this organization are essential. Experience working overseas, or a background in a health/medical field and a working knowledge of French and/or Spanish are desired. We offer a salary range of $50,000-$55,000 plus benefits. Qualified women and minorities are encouraged to apply. Please submit resume and cover letter to: Dr. Victoria Sharp, Executive Search Committee, DOW, 415 West 51st Street, New York, NY 10019.

InterAid International seeks a Country Director for its Kenya programs. Responsibilities include overall management and administration of country operations. individual should have international management experience preferably in East Africa; be capable of administering financial controls and budget implementation and possess excellent communication and proposal writing skills. We offer a competitive salary and benefits package. Mail or fax resume to InterAid International, 360 Mobil Avenue, Suite C210, Camarillo, CA 93010; fax 805-484-8829.

Food for the Hungry International seeks Director of Finance to be based and FHI headquarters in Scottsdale, AZ. Will be responsible for all FHI accounting functions globally. Must be a CPA with 5-10 years experience. Previous overseas experience is desired. Must have non-profit and government accounting experience. Position will be filled by July 1994. Send resume to: Scott Allen, Director of Mobilization, Food for the Hungry International, 7807 East Greenway Road, Suite 3, Scottsdale, AZ 85260; 800-248-6437. Fax: 602-951-9035.

TechnoServe Inc. seeks a Regional Director, Africa for Norfolk, CT headquarters. Regional Director will be responsible for overseeing all country programs in Africa monitoring and ensuring the quality of the programs; staff training and development; the identificationadn startup of new country programs; serve on a Program Managmeent Team to contribute to the overall management fo the Program Divisions. Required: 8+ years of management experience in international development, 5+ years overseas management experience and proven supervisory skills. Master's degree in finance, business administration, economics or related fields/experience. Excellent oral and written communication skills in English, French desirable. Willingness to travel international (25Scofield, Manager of Human Resources, TechnoServe, 30%). Send resume and salary history to: Ms. Terri Inc., 49 Day Street, Norfolk, CT 06854. fax: 203-838-6717.

International Action Against Hunger seeks Health Coordinator for oversight of Community Health Workers, Traditional Birth Attendants and MCH workers; oversight of EPI activities; participation in the design and implementation of training programs; contribute to the development of a community health education curriculum; surveys, monitoring and evaluation; and set-up and supervise the use of an HIS. Qualifications: MD or RN; MPH or equivalent degree or relevant community health experience; strong negotiation, communication and management skills; ability to work in a difficult environment; and curriculum development and/or HIS skills a plus. Send resume and cover letter including date of availability and salary requirements to: Personnel Recruiter, AICF/USA, 815-15th Street NW, Suite 832, Washington, DC 20005. fax: 202-783-5247.

International public health management firm seeks an Assistant Database Manger with an interest in international development to assist with the administration and operations of a complex database. Duties include: tracking and managing shipments of AID-donated commodities; acting as liaison between JSI staff and the shipping contractor, coordinating activities among AID, the shipping contractor and JSI staff; managing all electronic data import form the shipper, and supervising other staff. Applications should be self-directed, detail-oriented, and have strong interpersonal/communication skills. Must have 2+ years professional experience. USAID knowledge a plus. We offer a flexible working environment, excellent benefits and a salary commensurate with experience. Send resumes to Magda Ruesch, John Snow, Inc., 11th Floor, 1616 N. Fort Meyer Drive, Arlington, VA 22209. NO PHONE CALLS.

CARE seeks individual to support the development of health projects around the world. Reviews and provides technical assistance to health project. Will support development of design and evaluation criteria, handle external networking of Child Survival programs and manage the portfolio management system. Qualifications: MA in public health, nutrition or related field. Lesser-developed country experience in community-based primary health care projects (3+ years). Experience in project design, implementation and evaluation. Analytical, writing and public speaking skills. Ability to work without direct supervision. Willingness to travel (33-50%) to remote areas of developing countries. Resume: Ann Magoffin, CARE, 151 Ellis Street, Atlanta, GA 30303-2439. Fax: 404-577-9418.

CARE seeks individual to supervise and coordinate the implementation of infrastructure development projects and Urban Food for Work (UFFW) activities in Mogadishu. Will plan, administer, monitor and evaluate the Mogadishu Emergency Employment Creation (MEEC)/UFFW in accordance with the program's focus. Planning responsibilities include finalizing criteria and selection of participating communities and individual infrastructure projects. Prepare quarterly schedules; develop commodity/material distribution, monitoring and reporting system to control stocks and for the disbursement of UFFW rations; direct and supervise CARE Community Extension Workers; provide direction to various personnel' handle donor funding negotiations and project reporting. Qualifications: previous experience in a Food for Work (FFW) project, good negotiating skills, demonstrated organizational capabilities, and patience. Resume: Jeannett Nance Frett, CARE, 151 Ellis Street, Atlanta, GA 30303-2439. Fax: 404-577-9418.

CARE seeks individual to provide technical assistance to CARE's SEAD projects, focusing on the areas of institutional development, management of large credit funds, rural SEAD programming, and management information systems (computer skills). Provide and/or coordinate technical training for CARE's overseas staff or counterparts in response to SEAD Unit initiative related to specific areas mentioned above. Focus on technical assistance needs which are implementation and systems oriented. Assist in evaluation programs. Improve skills of other Regional Technical Advisors. Qualifications: Graduate degree in Business, Economics or International Development with a strong emphasis on economics preferred. 5+ years experience in Small Enterprise Development work, a portion of which must have been spend in direct program management. Fluent French or Spanish. Resume: Ann Magoffin, CARE, 151 Ellis Street, Atlanta, GA 30303-2439. Fax: 404-577-9418.

OIC International seeks individual to provide technical and training assistance in value added transformation of raw produce with the purpose of creating employment for unemployed youths and disadvantaged communities in third world countries. Will be responsible for identifying cottage industries and appropriate technologies adaptable to the client countries; develop curricula to train related entrepreneurial and technical skills to develop and manage businesses. Applicant should possess degree or have experience in development work, and working experience in Africa; first-had experience in managing a business and/or appropriate technology development. Must be fluent in written and spoken English and French, Spanish a plus. Post located in Philadelphia with extensive travel. Resume and salary requirements to: OIC International, Inc., 240 W. Tulpehocken Street, Philadelphia, PA 19144, Attn: Human Resources Administrator.

International Medical Corps seeks a dynamic Development Director to direct its fund raising activities. Individual will be responsible for the implementation of a comprehensive development plan. Individual will research and write foundation proposals, develop grassroots support, act as a liaison with board members, oversee the direct mail campaigns, plan special events, supervise maintenance of donor data base and coordinate corporate and major gifts programs. Qualifications: superior writing skills, established contacts with major donors and foundations, BA/BS degree, 5-7 years of proven fund- raising experience, excellent interpersonal skills and supervisory skills. Competitive salary and full benefits. Salary, insurance, round-trip transportation, room and board provided. Submit resume or letter of interest to: IMC, Dept. 94-017, 12233 W. Olympic Blvd., #280, Los Angeles, CA 90064. Fax: 310- 442-6622.

Africa News


September 12, 1994 / September 30, 1994


VOLUNTEER OPPORTUNITIES


LENGTH: 1280 words


 

HEALTH VOLUNTEERS OVERSEAS has the following programs and volunteer opportunities:

ANESTHESIA OVERSEAS (AO) & NURSE ANESTHESIA OVERSEAS (NAO): **ERITREA: This new program will train two groups of students: nurse anesthetists and soldiers who provided anesthesia care during the recent war. A suitable curriculum is being developed and volunteers will be needed beginning in March 1995. Anesthesiologists and nurse anesthetists with teaching backgrounds, not necessarily in an academic setting, are being solicited. Interested volunteers are required to provide a CV six months prior to their assignment. Assignments are for one month. Contact: Dr. Hugh Westgate, 612-938-1474.

**MALAWI: This program provides assistance in the training and supervision of Medical Assistants undergoing a one year training program to produce Anesthetic Clinical Officers. Volunteers are solicited for one month assignments. Contact: Dr. Howard Chait, 310-470-6291. 

**TRANSKEI: Transkei, SA is in need of program participants to teach anesthesia at Umtata General Hospital to physicians-in-training (medical students and medical officers) who will be providing anesthesia services in the outlying hospitals upon completion of their training. Volunteers will also provide direct anesthesia care. Housing on the hospital grounds is provided for the volunteer at no cost. Contact: Dr. Kevin Speight, 919-716-4498 (w), 919-454-3956 (h).

**UGANDA: Anesthesiologists and CRNA volunteers participate in the only anesthesia training program in Uganda. Most of the teaching takes place in Kampala's Mulago Hospital. Three groups of students are in need of additional training: those in the "masters" program (equivalent to our residency), anesthesia asistants who work without supervision and administer most of the anesthesia throughout Uganda, and the medical students. A guest house is available for volunteers.

Volunteers serve a minimum of one month. Contact: Dr. Harry Zutz at 908-381-4200 (w), 201-378-3323 (h) or Mattilou Catchpoe, PhD, CRNA at 217-786-7425 (w), 217-525-0183 (h).

DENTISTRY OVERSEAS (DO):

** MALAWI: The School of Health Sciences in Lilongwe is the training site for a program providing education support in the areas of diagnosing dental and oral pathoses, performing conservative dentistry, periodontics, uncomplicated dental extractions and precentive dentistry. Volunteers are solicited for two month assignments with one month assignments also considered. This program is soliciting at least three volunteers a year with a one month hiatus between volunteers. Contact Dr. Dick Nieusma 402-472-1367.

ORTHOPAEDICS OVERSEAS (OO):

**MALAWI: The Malawi Orthopaedic Project trains classes of 10 full-time students in an 18 month course. Volunteers will participate in lectures, clinics, rounds and surgery. Operative cases include polio residuals, tuberculosis, osteomyelitis, club feet and trauma. Volunteers are needed for a minimum period of one month and for additional periods in increments of one month. Volunteers will be located in Blantyre at the Queen Elizabeth Central Hospital. They will also travel to District Hospitals where they will supervise graduates of previous classes. Housing is available at a cost of $750 per month. A vehicle is furnished but volunteers pay for gas. Contact: Dr. Richard Kemme at 303-352-0250.

**TRANSKEI: Volunteers are involved in teaching and providing for orthopaedic care needs at the Umtata General Hospital and the Transkei Medical School. The students include residents and medical students as well as Orthopaedic Nurse Practitioners who complete a one-year course. Housing is provided at no cost. Accommodations for families can often be arranged. This program also seeks volunteers in physical therapy and general surgery. Contact: Dr. Robert Eaton at 704- 692-5781.

**UGANDA: This program trains Ugandan medical students and physicians to improve the treatment of amputees and disabled people injured as a result of civil strife. Orthopaedic surgeons are needed to teach orthopaedic assistants, medical students and physicians at the national teaching hospital in Kampala and its newly renovated orthopaedic operating theatre which provides orthopaedic surgical care for Uganda's 18 million people. Surgeons will also conduct orthopaedic clinics and operating sessions with Ugandan doctors in upcountry regional hospitals. Volunteers are asked to serve for a minimum of one month. For a nominal fee, housing will be provided at the newly renovated Mulago Guest House. Contact: Dr. David Denzel at 716-434-2697.

The American Medical Team for Africa (AMTA) promotes and executes educational exchange and medical training in African countries. The goal of the non-profit organization is to bring volunteer doctors, nurses and medical students together with donated supplies, and equipment to serve needs on the continent. Survey teams assess the most pressing needs in targeted countries, develop and publish training manuals in appropriate languages, hold workshops and refresher courses for doctors, nurses and specialists interested in maintenance of health care delivery systems in Africa; and distribute medical supplies and equipment donated by corporations, pharmaceutical companies, hospitals and doctors. The AMTA plans a second medical mission to Africa. For more information, contact Deman Rageh, Executive Director, The American Medical Team for Africa, 2245 Godby Road, Atlanta, GA 30349; phone (404) 766-8000; fax: (404) 767-5264.

Private Voluntary Organization in Rosslyn needs an experienced Agribusiness/Marketing Specialist to fill a 3-year Chief of Party position in Mali. The candidate must have at least 10 years of proven experience in the field of Agribusiness, Marketing, Credit and Procurement (preferably of fruits & vegetables). Must have related job experience in developing country with hands-on experience and an MBA. Strong training skills in the areas of agribusiness and marketing required. Fluency in French/English (FSI, S-3, R03) a must. Interested candidates must submit a resume, a certification of foreign language capability, and a standard AID bio-data form. Please mail original copies to: ReginaWynn, VITA, 5th floor, Arlington, VA 22209. Tel: (703) 276-1800 or fax: (703) 2143-1865.


LOAD-DATE: March 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


September 12, 1994 / September 30, 1994


AFRICAN VISITORS TO THE US


LENGTH: 3267 words


 

Compiled from the "Arrival List of International Visitors," published by the United States Information Agency.

ALGERIA

AMIR, Mohamed, Rector , University of Annaba; NEA Regional Project on University Administration; Arrives 9/26/94 for 30 days.

DJABRI, Mohieddine, Manager/Owner, Algerian International Trade Company; Project Interest: Private Sector. Arrives 8/15/94.

MAKHLOUF, Moussa, Deputy Director, Personnel, Ministry of Higher Education & Scientific Research; Arrives 9/26/94 for 30 days. 

SIDI SAID, Abdelmadjid, National Union of Algerian Workers; Project Interest: U.S. Labor. Arrives 8/15/94.

ANGOLA

NETO, Antonio Domingos Pitra C., Minister of Public Administration, Labor and Security; Project Interest: Labor, Public Administration; Arrives 9/19/94 (FTUI).

BOTSWANA

KWAPA, Mogatosi, Broadcasting Officer, Radio Botswana, Dept. of Information and Broadcasting; "Radio Broadcasting in the U.S." Arrives 8/8/94 for 35 days.

BURKINA FASO

NANA, Emmanual Tankouliga, Director of Guidance, Counseling and Scholarships, Head of Offices of Information, Guidance and Emplyment, OEDRAGO, Tanga Marc, Director for Student Services, University of Ouagadougou, Director of Studies, University of Ouagadougou, SEREME, Paco, Director of Scientific Cooperation, Researcher in Phytopathology, SISSOKO, Mamadou, Secretary General, Ministry of Secondary and Higher Education, Technical Advisor to Minister of Education, YAGO, Ahmed, Director of National Fund for Education and Research, High Commissioner of Houet Province; Burkina Faso-Only Project "Financing Higher Education in the U.s.;" Arrive 9/12/94 for 28 days.

CAMEROON

SENEGAL

DIALLO, Josephine Sarr, Chief, Police Plateau Division, Dakar; Senegal-Only Project "Human and Civil Rights in U.S. Penal System" Arrives 8/22/94.

September 12, 1994 / September 30, 1994


ANNOUNCEMENTS


SECTION: DIRECTORY


LENGTH: 294 words


 

K-Executive Club of Uganda (PO Box 3992, Kampala) promotes libraries, adult education and voluntary services. It seeks new and used books on all subjects, plus financial assitance to help with shipping costs. To support the later, contact: Mr. Cliff B. Gosney Jr., Benevolence T.E. Inc., PO Drawer 291850, Port Orange, FL 32129-1850.

Tanzania's Environmental Information Centre seeks current texts on environmental monitoring management, natural resources, G.I.S., remote sensing, biodiversity, etc. Contact Mr. Ade Towry-Coker, National Environment Management Council, PO Box 63154, Dar es Salaam.

Zanzibar Library Project seeks donations from individuals and institutions to support a new research library for scholars in the House of Wonders (Beit al- Ajaib) Museum. Priorities include scholarly materials on Africa in general and East Africa in particular. It also seeks more general material for the new National Library for the general public; and Macintosh computers and printers (Imagewriters preferred). All donations should be sent (preferably in 12x12x18 boxes) to: Zanzibar Libary Project, c/o Mr. Leo Robinson, ILWU Local 10, 400 North Point St., San Francisco, CA 94133. The longshoreman's union will ship the contributions in November 1994. The Project is endorsed by the Association of Concerned Africa Scholars. Questions should be directed to Ed Ferguson in Berkeley at 413-256-8316.
