267 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 12, 1994 / September 30, 1994


LIBRARY REVIEW


LENGTH: 587 words


 

THE MONITOR, August 05-09, 1994

NEW BOOK ON WOLE SOYINKA'S 60TH BIRTHDAY

To celebrate the 60th birthday of Wole Soyinka, Heinemann has unveiled a collection of essays which pay tribute to the Nigerian writer's many achievements.

The anthology, Wole Soyinka: An Appraisal, is prefaced by Soyinka's own Nobel speech of 1986, which voiced his overriding concern for justice and freedom- a driving force in his life as well as his literature; and the concluding contribution, an interview he gave to Boyi Bandele-Thomas some seven years on, bears witness to that unflagging concern.

Other contributors include both fellow writers and distinguished academics. Some, like Nadine Gordimer, have chosen to record their personal and professional regard for Soyinka, while others, such as Wilson Harris and Abdulrazak Burnah, adopt a more critical- though constrictive and no less appreciative stance towards Soyinka's plays, poetry or novels. 

Femi Osofisan, fellow Nigerian playwright, combines the two approaches in a personal memoir of the man and his life and interpretation of his work and a heartfelt acknowledgment of Soyinka's vital and continuing influence.

Wole Soyinka is one of the most original and multifarious writers, whose astonishing output of plays, novels, poems, autobiographies, essays and social commentaries are read and studied throughout the world.

Soyinka's reputation was established in 1966 when he won the New Statesman John Whiting Drama prize (1966-67) and flourished when, despite his imprisonment in the late 1960s, he continued to write and was awarded the New Statesmen Jock Campbell Literary Prize for his first novel, The Interpreters. Soyinka was later appointed Overseas Fellow at Churchill College, Cambridge, where he wrote the widely acclaimed Death and the King's Horseman.

The George Benson Medal of the Royal Society of Literature and the UNESCO Medal for the Arts were to follow, and this glittering array of awards culminated in 1986, when Soyinka became the first African writer to win the Nobel Prize for Literature.

For further information on these and other titles please contact your local agent or bookshop.

In case of difficulty contact: Export sales Department, Heinemann Educational, Halley Court,

Jordan Hill, Oxford OX2 8EJ, U.K. Tel: 0865-314040,

Telex: 837292 HEBOXFG Fax: 0865-310029.

Reprinted from The Monitor, August 5-9, 1994.

The Monitor is published by The Monitor Publications Ltd. (Uganda)

Contact: The Monitor, P.O. Box 12141, Kampala. Phone: 251353; fax: 251352.


LOAD-DATE: March 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


268 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 12, 1994 / September 30, 1994


100 DAYS OF DEMOCRACY VS. CENTURIES OF APARTHEID


BYLINE: Amrit Manga


LENGTH: 2480 words


 

NEW NATION, August 19,1994

If government's performance during its first hundred days of rule is to be measured in terms of what has visibly been acheived in terms of concrete delivery, there would be little to gloat about.

Except for the lone model house in a vast stretch of land somewhere in the PWV, or lenghty queues at clinics for free health care, there is little that has visibly changed.

Unemployment continues at record levels, urban and rural development has not transcended beyond being an RDP buzz word and education remains in a crisis when assesed in terms of the amount of learning that is taking place in black schools.

And except for the restitution of land to residents forcibly removed from Mogopa near Ventersdorp in the western Transvaal, the process of restoring ownership of land to those dispossessed by apartheid remains largely unaccomplished.

But should government's performance be measured on the basis of concrete delivery chalked up in 100- days? If the transition was simply transferring government from one party to another, without the need for major restructuring, such as in established democracies, it would have been appropriate to subject performance to such a 100-day test. 

In a country that has undergone a major transition from hundreds of years of white minority rule, of which 46 were devoted to statuatory apartheid, the 100-day test, linked to delivery of houses, schools, water reticulation, electricity, etc, is clearly an inappropiate one.

What needs to be assesed is the extent to which the government has suceeded in re-organizing its administrative infrastructure and tuning it into the priorities identified in the RDP.

"The RDP is about restructuring, and the government will need all of the five years it has been given by the electorate to do that," one analyst monitoring the reconstruction and the development programme says.

Acting deputy director-general in the RDP office Bernie Fanaroff agrees that the main trust of the RDP is really about changing the management programme of the government.

Minister in charge of reconstruction and development Jay Naidoo adds that changing the management programme of government really amounts to "turning the ship around". And this he says is a huge task given the fact that the ship has been sailing for around 350 years on a course determined by apartheid impertatives.

"There has had to be planning, new structure have had to be set up to work towards new priorities. We have also had to build consensus in the government of national unity in addition ot shifting the focus of the civil service and reorganizing the Budget," Naidoo added.

While the immediate task was to change course, the government has also recognized that it was important to begin implementing the reconstruction and development programme.

"We set up the R2, 5-billion RDP fund because we could not wait till the budget was re-organized in its entirety," Naidoo says.

We needed a fund to leverage changes in the budget and civil service to reflect the RDP priorities. We had to ask ourselves: 'how is the R30- billion in the education budget going ot be spent? What is the quality of expenditure?'

"In answering these questions, we agreed that the RDP fund had to be used in two ways:

To kick-start major programmes - and that is what we have been working on systematically. We have focused our energies on identifying integrated programmes that arise from what the President spelt out in his State of the Nation address in May.

The second aspect of the way we used the RDP fund was to leverage changes in how expenditure took place in various government departments."

The end result of all of this was that government has used the Presidential projects to spearhead a number of important programmes.

Among the projects mentioned by President Mandela were a free health scheme and school feeding programmes.

Fanaroff adds that in identifying projects that should be undertaken, the RDP office took into account the fact that the RDP was really about transition.

"What we have done so far is to have identified projects that will lead to this transition. These include programmes relating to human resource development, urban renewal, rural development and economic restructuring.

"At the same time, the national RDP office has taken the Presidential programmes announced earlier this year, and together with a process of consulation with various line ministries and provincial governments, begun identifying projects that will lead to a series of longer term programmes," he told New Nation.

While programmes in a number of areas have already been identified, the process of implementation has in itself initiated restructuring in key areas of government.

Most important in this regard has been the process of re-ordering government expenditure. In addition, it has also begun a process of re-ordering the way in which civil service and public sector resources are utilised.

The process has also set line ministries on a course towards developing long term visions which must find expression in their five-year development strategies and the budget expenditure.

"What these projects, identified by the RDP office, have acheived," says Fanaroff, "is that they have started driving the actual process of restructuring the way government operates.

"Through the process of budgetry allocations, we have also levered changes to the budgetry process," he adds.

Money has been levered out of departmental allocations and channelled into projects, some of which have been kick-started with finance from the R2,5-billion RDP fund.

Naidoo explains saying: " If we put money into building schools or clinics, we would then require the education and health ministers to re-organise their budgets to pay for the running of those schools and clinics."

Re-ordering of expenditure would amount to taking money away from funding huge bureaucracies created by apartheid - running empty schools, for example - to make new structures built with the RDP fund functional.

If sustained, the process could see the subsequent Budgets reflecting RDP priorities more closely. What will emerge at the end will be a programme-based budget which will make it possible for government to report on progress and assess targets set in terms of the projects undertaken.

This has clearly not been the case with the way the past government administered its budget and reflects a mojor change in style of government to one which will clearly find itself having to be more accountable and subject to monitoring.

Certainly, Fanaroff is pleased with the way in which expenditure has been re-ordered as a result of the leverage provided by the RDP fund and the Presidential projects.

Whether the leverage provided by the fund has succeeded in re-organising the civil service and public sector, however, is doubtful.

In part, government has been hamstrung by constitutional restrictions.

But a lot has been acheived in setting up an infrastructure within government to reflect the new priorities.

"Within the government, we have set up the RDP Cabinet Committee," says Naidoo. Its immediate task is to ensure that all projects undertaken by differernt line departments in government are integrated.

"Its job is to ensure that we all allocate resources from the RDP fund in suchs a way that it leads to integrated programmes." says Naidoo. In addition, this committee is also expected to monitor and evaluate the government's implementation strategy.

According to Naidoo, the finance ministry forms a key component of the RDP committee given the fact that the reconstruction and development programme is not simply about spending the R2,5-billion allocated to the RDP fund.

"It is, in reality, about how we re-organise the whole of the R135-billion in our budget so that it goes towards meeting the needs of our people." says Naidoo.

Illustrating how the RDP fund, along with the Presidential projects, have been employed in redirecting and levering funds at every level in government, Naidoo says: "If you examine the free health care project, for example-that has been linked to a programme to build clinics. At the same time we have linked that up to a campaign to fight Aids."

Naidoo goes on to add that the school feeding scheme, for example, should not been seen as simply a nutritional programme.

By implementing the feeding scheme, says Naidoo, "we are focusing our efforts on the whole campaign to get children back to school and restore the culture of learning.

"But that in itself has to be linked to a programme of building schools, repairing classrooms, furnishing them and installing electricity as well as setting up democratic school management structures.

"Rather than the Presidential projects being seen as ad hoc isolated events, we have conceptualised them into programmes which are already unfolding," he adds.

In the area of land reform, a number of pilot projects have been established which go beyond simply land restitution. It also focuses on the development of small and medium sized farming project which could have important spinoffs for the empowerment of women located in rural areas.

This process has also impacted on the area of restructuring the way government works.

In order to ensure that projects are located in a co-ordinated programme of growth through development, government has also established interdepartmental task forces to ensure that projects are integrated.

Naidoo explains that the government cannot afford to implement a housing programme without the Department of Housing liaising with the education and health ministries to decide on where schools and clinics will be located.

"Setting up these committees has taken a lot of time," says Naidoo. But this achievement has not necessarily been projected as something tangible that immediately translates into more houses, schools and clinics.

Naidoo, however, says what the government has acheived to date is the broad allocation of funds into broad programmes.

"We are now entering the next phase - the final planning and involvement of communities in an actual programme of delivery."

Asked whether this meant that the electorate could look foward to seeing concrete delivery, and tangible changes in areas such as housing, education, health care and job creation, Naidoo said: "Most certainly - with all that we have acheived, we have now reached a stage where we can begin the delivery in a systematic way."

He nevertheless cautioned that the programmes government will support will be subjected to a set of strict criteria.

One of the most important will be community support and committment. For example, while urban renewal deals with restoring services and upgrading infrastructur, "government will not be able to find sufficient money to acheive this all on its own if people don't pay for services.

"Therefore, communities in any area we target for upgrading will have to enter into a contract between themselves, the local and provincial government and ourselves."

"We won't put money into any area where such an agreement does not exist," Naidoo warned.

Reprinted from New Nation, Augfust 19, 1994.

New Nation is published by the New Nation Publishing Company, First Floor Darragh House, 13 Wanderers Street, Johannesburg. (011) 333-2711.


LOAD-DATE: March 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


September 12, 1994 / September 30, 1994


UGANDA TOPS WORLD IN PRISONER DEATHS


BYLINE: Dismas Nkunda in New York and Peter Mwesige in Kampala


LENGTH: 1267 words


 

THE MONITOR, August 26-30, 1994

Uganda has been fingered by international human rights organisations as the country wiht one of the highest prisoner death rates in the world.

A just released report by Freedom House, a US human rights organisation, attributed the high Ugandan prison deaths to harsh conditions in the cells, overcrowding, malnutrition and the spread of AIDS.

The report was presented to eight African journalists from Kenya, Tanzania, Zimbabwe, Ghana, Nigeria, Liberia, South Africa and Uganda who are on a comparison study of the USA human rights and press record at the invitation of Freedom House.

Presenting the report, Senior Scholar in International Communications at Freedom House and Adjunct Professor of Journalism and Mass Communication at New York University, Leonard Sussman said that he hoped " Uganda does not slip further into bad press when the press bill that is before parliment is passed." 

When contacted for comment, the Commissioner for Prisons, Joseph Etima, warned the press not to pick an item and "build a mountain in order to sell a paper."

He insisted the Freedom House report was based on a 1992 United States published Country Human Rights Report which only contained the statement that "Uganda prisons reportedly have one of the highest mortality rates in the world."

"That was a distortion of the facts. As for whether there are deaths in prisons, yes there are deaths, but you must take figures to isolate who leads," Etima said.

The report titled "Freedom in the World" (1993- 1994) says that equally bad in Uganda are the political rights. It says that the NRM government has persistently worked to undermine the traditional political parties, DP and UPC alleging that the two parties lead to division based on religion, ethnicity and regionalism.

The report highlights the Constitutional Commission's report and the recommendations it made and its tragic end in the death of Prof. Dan Mudhoola on February 20,1993.

If states that after the commission endorsed a five year extension of NRM, "political parties within Uganda and various exile groups immediately denounced the report as simply incorporating the NRM position." And accordingly "on 20 Feb 1993, in what was viewed as a possible vendetta by members of a political party, a hand grenade thrown into a party (bar), killed the Commission Vice Chairman Dan Mudhoola." No party is specifically named.

But not all is lost on Uganda. The report says that since 1987, with IMF suggested economic adjustments programs, Uganda has enjoyed one of the highest economic growth rates in Africa, averaging 6% annually. Sadly though the report says; "Nevertheless the country remains one of the poorest in the world, with 1 million AIDS-caused orphans and 2 million AIDS carriers."

On the human rights record, the report says that Ugandans can not yet change their government democratically. It also says that there are no meaningful balances on executive power and "Museveni enjoys a wide discretion in exercising his political power."

The judiciary's independence is also questioned. The report says that the judiciary "is circumscribed by direct executive interference in cases involving political opponents of the regime. As for the press, it is a dead end. The report says that the press in Uganda is practicing self-censorship due to the governments attempt to muzzle it.

Uganda is listed among 26 African countries with the worst press freedom record in the world.

The report does not list the prisoners whom it alleges have died in Ugandan prisons. Perhaps to confirm the message in the report, July 28 a prisoner from Masafu Prison, Wilberforce Wabwire, collapsed and died in a Magistrate's court in Busia.

According to his inmates, Bwire had been suffering abdominal pains, diarrhorea and was pissing blood the day before he appeared in court for a trial on elopment charges!

Just in June local administration police in Mukono district caused the death of an inmate after one and a half years of detention.

Fred Mukisa, who was arrested after a domestic quarrel and later a fight with his wife, had been severely tortured and detained without trial at several local administration police stations.

The police kept Mukisa for a long time to allegedly extort money from his relatives.

Danish Ambassador to Uganda, Thomas Scheerbeck, said while closing a three-day regional conference on Penal Reform Development last Wednesday that human rights situations in Uganda is much better compared to a few years back.

According to a report in Monday's New Vision, the Danish envoy is quoted to have said:

"I find this (human rights situation ) extremely important, as we all know that it has been bad a few years ago, and that it is not yet good enough, but the important thing is that it is improving."

On other issues raised in the Freedom House report, Commissioner Etima who was flanked by two Assistant Commissioners, the Director of Prison Medical Services and the PRO, also said the issue of AIDS was known to everybody.

"The prisoners we have come from the popluation which is already infected," he said.

He argued that while looking at the conditions of the prisoners, the general conditions of Ugandans should not be lost on us.

"The conditions of Ugandans generally are also harsh because of economic hardships," he said.

The director of Prisons Medical Services, Dr. D. Nyabwana, maintained that Uganda was far ahead of African countries in health care in prisons.

Reprinted from The Monitor, August 26-30, 1994. THE MONITOR is published by The Monitor Publications Ltd. (Uganda)

CONTACT: THE MONITOR, P.O. Box 12141, Kampala. Phone: 251353; fax: 251352.


LOAD-DATE: March 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


270 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 12, 1994 / September 30, 1994


GLOBAL WARMING SPAWNS


BYLINE: Vukoni Lupa-Lasaga


LENGTH: 947 words


 

THE MONITOR, August 23-26, 1994

Malaria is back with a big bang.

Our news trays are over-flowing with reports of this fresh outburst. Each of them carries grim tales.

Unconfirmed reports from Kabale put the death count at over 200. In Kapchorwa, fatalities have shot beyond 100. 

The Ministry of Health seems not to have come to terms with the unfolding tragedy. World Vision, an NGO, was the only organisation that rushed medecines to the malaria death scenes.

Officially, the Ministry of Health has breathed no word about what they are doing to cope with what looks like it is becoming an epedemic. The public is unlikely to hear from them soon since the top three officials at the ministry were not available for comment.

Health experts say decades of civil strife have taken their toll on the health infrastructure. Government, too, for quite sometime has been spending penuts on health, and a very tiny fraction of that on malaria.

"If you cause a disarray in your health service, that disarray takes much longer to rebuild. Communities suffer much longer from diseases which were previously under control." Prof. Gilbert Bukenya who heads Makerere Medical School's Institute of Public Health (IPH) points out.

According to the professor, though NRM's expenditure on health has risen from about two to ten percent of Gross National Product in the last eight years, the impact of this rise cannot compare with the 1960's.

Currently, the annual percapita budgetry expenditure on health is about Shs. 4,000. In the '60's, government also spent about ten percent of its budget on health but due to the uninterrupted build-up from colonial days, and the smaller population, the effect of this expenditure was more visible.

Now much of the money goes into the rehabilitation of the infrastructure vandalised in the wars of politicians hunting for power.

In addition, because AIDS has become the official No.1 public enemy, though it kills fewer people than malaria, it is nowadays easier to get condoms in an up-country dispensary than chloroquine tablets. Another problem. The sale of drugs on the open market by ignorant traders has encouraged self- treatment. Result? Under-doses of chloroquine, an inexpensive cure, have made malaria parasites resistant. Substitutes life Fansidar and Metakelfin cost Shs. 1,500 upwards per dose. If each member of a family succumbs to malaria every month, it becomes clear that a complete therapy is beyond the means of the average Ugandan.

Prof. Bukenya again. Malaria is a scourge with medical, social, and economic dimensions. Thus even if the health service had all the resources it needs and enough doctors to give quick diagnoses and cures, it would all be ineffective unless the social-economics of malaria and ecological factors get due attention.

Poor drainage, and the nonenforcement of laws that prohibit planting crops likely ot breed mosquitoes near homes spawn problems. According to the IPH boss a small investment in bed nets is likely to reduce the incidence of malaria by as much as 50 percent.

Malaria contributes enormously to underdevelopment because it constitutes enormously to underdevelopment because it constitutes about 40 percent of the national disease burden. World Health Organisation (WHO) estimates put malaria at the head of killer diseases in Uganda. The 1993 figures show that 25 percent of hospital out- patient attendance is malaria-related. Fourteen percent o in-patients are malaria cases and of htose who die, 10 percent are malaria fatalities. Not even AIDS beats that record!

You can blame the weather for the misfortunes of Kapchorwa and Kabale. These highland areas once had near-temperate climates which checked the spread of malaria. But due to the effects of global warming, temperatures have shot up to levels favourable for mosquitoes and malaria parasites to thrive. The low natural immunity to the disease among the Sabiny and Bakiga partly explains the unprecedented malaria deaths.

But the politicians who pull our purse strings hold the real answers to the malaria scourge. A new turn in priorities even within the limits of our budget can nip the new menace in the bud. Short of that more peasants must be prepared to die.

Reprinted from The Monitor, August 23-26, 1994.

THE MONITOR is published by The Monitor Publications Ltd. (Uganda)

CONTACT: THE MONITOR, P.O. Box 12141, Kampala. Phone: 251353; fax: 251352.


LOAD-DATE: March 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


271 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 12, 1994 / September 30, 1994


AFRICA'S 2ND BILLIONAIRE TO COME FROM UGANDA?


BYLINE: Staff Reporter.


LENGTH: 1200 words


 

THE MONITOR, August 12-16, 1994

Uganda has been mentioned as the potential breeding ground for Africa's second dollar billionaire after South Africa's Harry Oppenheimer in an otherwise bleak African economic landscape.

According to the July issue of Forbes - a leading world financial magazine - the Madhvani Group with an annual turnover of over $100 million - up from nothing in 1989, is set for an economic take off.

In June the Madhvani and NutraSweet, a division of Monsanto, began producing a blend of cane sugar and aspartame to be marketed throughout East Africa.

Forbes magazine says the Madhvani's Ugandan enterprises now employ capital of around $200 million and account for about 9 percent of the country's GNP. 

It quotes Mayur Madhvani 45, a director of the family's Ugandan interests, as saying sugar production should hit pre-Amin levels of around 70,000 tons in 1995, with volume rising to 130,000 tons by 1988. "At the rate things are going, it's a safe bet that they'll be Uganda's first dollar billionaires - as long as the government holds to its course of economic liberation."

At the time the despot Idi Amin expelled the Madhvanis and 70,000 other Asians in 1972 the Madhvanis, with assets of around $120 million, controlled more than one-third of the industrial investments in the country. The center-piece was the Kakira Sugar Works, a 22,000 acre plantation in Jinja. The family also owned a brewery, a candy factory, textile and steel mills and tea estates.

After Amin was driven from the country in 1979, the Madhvanis were among the first Asian families to return to Uganda. With help from the World Bank and other lenders, the Madhvanis undertook a $55 million rehabilitation effort. They've also begun rejuvenating their other properties.

The magazine says that when converted into dollars at prevailing exchange rates, the fortunes of Uganda's Madhvanis, India's Ruias and China's Rongs don't add up to $1 billion a piece. Yet in their respective countries they're much more powerful and may live better - than typical U.S., or European billionaires in their home countries.

This paradox results from the difference between simple exchange rate conversions and more complicated purchasing power parity, or PPP.

In developing countries, most goods and services are cheaper than in the U.S. for instance, a housekeeper in Kampala costs Shs. 15,000($15) per month, but $4.36 per hour in a typical U.S. city.

According to the Futures Group, a Glastonbury, Connecticut-based management consulting firm, using purchasing power parties, India's Lalit Mohan Thaper is worth $300 million based on the exchange rate but can buy $1.5 billion worth of Indian goods and services. China's Rongs can buy about $1.5 billion worth, and Uganda's Maldhvanis may be $1.2 billion worth.

Key elements in Uganda's rather surprising rating are the government's recovery plan: abolishing price controls, establishing a market determined exchange rate, ending currency restrictions, down sizing the army and civil service, and selling off state-owned businesses.

The results: Since 1987, when Museveni began the reforms, economic growth has averaged 5 percent and inflation has fallen from over 200 percent to less than 5 percent. Foreign investors are beginning to return.

On average however, Forebes magazine says that the prospects for the African continent are not bright. While most of the world had embraced free markets, many African countries still stagnate under corrupt governments that have stifled private enterprise and crippled economies.

In 1987 Forbes' first survey of world billionaires included only 6 Latin American billionaires, and 2 of them were cocaine lords, now dead; on this year's list are 42 Latin billionaires; by all appearances, every one is legitimate.

Excluding Japan, in 1987 Forbes reporters found only 14 Asian billionaires. This year the number is 46.

The developing countries really are emerging, and wealth is accumulating as economic liberalization sweeps the globe.

With at least 24 billionaires, Mexico ranks fourth in the world as a breeding ground for the species, after the U.S., Germany and Japan.

The most promising country right now is India, where serious liberalisation is afoot. New billionaires should also emerge in Israel, Eastern Europe as bureaucratic barriers to invest and expand are torn down.

Meanwhile, the latest issue of the London- published Africa Analysis newsletter says that Uganda could be the first African country to benefit from the large once-for-all cancellations of foreign debt. This follows an agreement between Western leaders meeting at eh recent G7 summit in Naples.

It is revealed that governments with IMF reform programmes in place and a relianle record of recent debt payments will be offered once-off cancellations of debt stock owed to the Paris Club; and the proportion written off will be raised from the present 50 percent to at least 66 percent.

Other African countries including Zimbabwe, Cote D'Ivoire and other former ' middle income' states driven by economic crisis into the 'least developed' category could follow Uganda.

Uganda is already benefitting from donor efforts to convert old loans into concessional credits. An IDA-supported buy-back has wiped out $159m in debt; and $53m in aid has been set aside this year to eliminate most remaining burdensome payment obligations. Efforts are under way to minimise loans contracted at close to market rates from the African Development Fund.

Reprinted from The Monitor, August 12-16, 1994.

THE MONITOR is published by The Monitor Publications Ltd. (Uganda)

CONTACT: THE MONITOR, P.O. Box 12141, Kampala. Phone: 251353; fax: 251352.


LOAD-DATE: March 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


272 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 12, 1994 / September 30, 1994


JOURNALISTS ADOPT CODE OF ETHICS


LENGTH: 894 words


 

THE GHANAIAN CHRONICLE, Thursday, August 4- Sunday, August 7, 1994

The 17 articles in the code provide a frame of reference to the National Executive and the Disciplinary Committee as well as members of the association when it becomes necessary to initiate disciplinary action against a member who flouts any articles of the code.

According to its preamble, the code is meant to ensure that members of GJA adhere to the highest ethical standards, professional competence and good behaviour.

The preamble states that as the fourth estate of the realm, the public expect the media to play its watchdog role, adding it should do this with a high sense of responsibility, professional integrity, plagiarism, respect for privacy and human dignity, separating comments from facts, rejoinders and headlines and sensationalism, among others.

Under people's right to true information, the code reaffirms that "the duty of every journalist is to write and report the truth bearing in mind his duty to serve the public," adding the public have the right to unbiased , accurate, balanced and comprehensive information as well as express themselves freely through the media. 

It stresses that a journalist should make adequate inquiries and cross-check his facts.

The code states under professional integrity that " a journalist should not accept bribe or any form of inducement to influence the performance of his professional duties."

It points out under "plagiarism" that a journalist should not plagiarize, because it is unethical and illegal, and advises that where there is the need to use other's material, "it is proper to credit the sources."

On respect for privacy and human dignity, the code calls on journalists to respect the right of the individual to privacy and human dignity, and emphasises that inquiries and intrusions into a person's private life can only be justified when done in public interest.

It warns journalists to guard against defamation, libel, slander and obscenity.

The code advises journalists not to originate material which encourages discrimination on grounds of ethnicity, colour, creed, gender or sexual orientation.

The code enjoins journalists to protect confidential sources of information, but advises that "under no circumstance should news or a publication be surpressed unless it borders on national security or it is in the public interest to do so."

On rejoinders, the code says an opportunity for rejoinders should be given to individuals or organisations, stressing that any report or write-up affecting the reputation of an individual or organisation without a chance of reply is unfair and must be avoided by journalists.

It said that while journalists are free to take positions on any issue they should draw a clear line between comment, conjecture and fact.

the code advises journalists to avoid identifying victims of sexual assault. They should protect the rights of minors in criminal and other cases and secure the consent of parent or guardians before interviewing or photographing them.

The code states: "newspaper headlines should be fully warranted by the contents of the articles they accompany", stressing that photographs and telecasts should give an accurate picture of an event and not highlight an incident out of context.

The National Consultative Committee (NCC) which approves national policy and programmes of the association ratified the code of ethics at its meeting which formed part of the three-day seminar organised by the association in co-operation with Freidrich Ebert Stiftung (FES) on "the state of the media".

The NCC agreed that members who flout the code of ethics should not be allowed to hold office in the association and should not be allowed to participate in the media awards competition.

About 95 per cent of paractising journalists are members of the association who are bound by the code of ethics.

Reprinted from The Ghanaian Chronicle, August 4-7, 1994.

The Ghanaian Chronicle is published at P.O. Box 16369, Airport-Accra. Tel: 22-77-89. Telex: 2694. Fax: 22-65-73.


LOAD-DATE: March 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


273 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


September 12, 1994 / September 30, 1994


SOLDIERS, COUPS AND DEMOCRACY IN AFRICA


LENGTH: 3094 words


 

DAILY OBSERVER, August 2, 1994

The overthrow of the 30- year-old People's Progressive Party government marks the end of an era in Africa's post-colonial politics. Until 22nd July 1994, Sir Dawda Jawara was the last surviving member of the dwindling group of godfathers who led Africa from the gambling house of colonialism and began the continent's long search for democracy and social justice.

Since the coup against Tafawa Balewa in the early 1960s, most West African countries have gone from one military regime to another. Nigeria, Ghana, Benin, Liberia, Sierra Leone, Guinea Conakry and Togo are all under military regimes or soldier-turned- politician regimes.

There are several reasons why soldiers intervene in politics. These include corruption, mismanagement of state resources, the dominance of state power by one ethnic group or in some cases interference by a super power. The anti-Nkrumah coup in Ghana was a combination of all these factors. The coup makers said corruption and the PPP's dictatorial character had been their motivating factor. but Ghanaians were later to learn that the US Central Intelligence Agency had plotted and financed the coup against Osagyefo Dr. Kwame Nkrumah. 

Coups in Africa or the Third World are described or classified as rhetoric, proclamations or initial actions of the coup makers. Coups are either rightwing, because they are against a progressive or radical ruler (such as the anti-Nkrumah coup in 1966), leftwing (such as that of Thomas Sankara in Burkina Faso), or simply nationalistic. The Nasser coup in Egypt, Col. Gadafi's coup in Libya, Numeri's in Sudan and Gen. Murtala in Nigeria fall under the radical mode. It should also be noted that some coups which start as radical or leftwing can become rightwing.

Why Coups Take Place

In Latin America and most Third World countries radical coups occur for several reasons, the most important being the question of political power. Lenin, the foremost theoretician on state power, once said that "the bourgeoisie maintains itself in power not only by force, but also by virtue of the lack of class consciousness and organisation, the routinism and downtrodden state of the masses."

While the often stated reasons for coups point to corruption, there are more pertinent reasons for their occurrence. The late Rith First, a former member of FRELIMO, argued that coups "occur because governments are too weak to rule but radical forces are to weak to take power. Referring to the 1951 coup against King Farouk, a social scientist observed that "when the old rulers are no longer able to hold power, the middle classes are to weak to seize, and the working class not yet matured to the task, officers fill the vacuum which has been formed."

In general, social scientists have identified several reasons or conditions for a coup: the presence of a nationalistic elite, sometimes (pro-western) unable to carry out social reforms; the inability of a government to solve social crisis or problems; dissatisfaction of the elite with an inert or archaic regime; and the inefficiency of a civilian government normally bolstered by corruption and the disappointment to the masses. Other factors include foreign interference (especially against nationalistic pan African leaders); ethnic oriented coups and coups in which imperialist conflicts are fought out by proxy.

The factors enumerated above also lead us to two main distinctions between coups of a progressive character and reactionary (pro-imperialist coups).

Progressive Coups

In terms of rhetoric, radical coups tent to promise to restructure society, are anti-imperialist and nationalistic in ideology and often tend to be against the ruling class. Radical coup makers also mobilise the oppressed and exploited segments of society in the days of the cold war, most radical coups looked to the Soviet Union for support and legitimacy. In the same way, a regimes ideological character was also gauged by its attitude towards either the Soviet Union or to the United States. The Sankara coup in Burkina Faso mobilised radical workers and peasants, was anti-imperialist, and promised to reclaim the wealth of Burkina Faso. Nasser, Numeiri and Gaddafi tried to do the same.

Gamal Abdul Masser, in his Philosophy of the Revolution, argued that his progressive coup was necessary because "the state of affairs...singled out the army as the force to do the hob...this situation demanded the existence of a force set in a cohesive framework, far removed from the conflict between individuals and classes, and drawn from the heart of the people, a with enough materials strength at its disposal to guarantee swift and decisive action. These conditions could be met only by the army."

Radical coups by their nature are carried out by a combination of soldiers and some radical groups or tend to rely on the mobilisation of the masses: workers, peasants and some sections of the middle classes. The coup of 21st October 1969 in Somalia was carried out by a alliance of soldiers and students. Such coups rely on such mobilisation to legitimize the regime and to reassure the deprived sections of the population that it can be trusted.

In essence, the democratisation of political power and the interruption of capitalist development in favour of the development of local productive forces and enabling people to participate in the decision making process is what distinguishes a progressive coup from all others. To achieve this, the coup must have a democratic and popular content. As noted by earlier theoreticians on military regimes, "the progressive orientation of a military regime depends on the development of democracy and on the broader and broader participation of the masses in economical, social and cultural reconstruction."

Reactionary Coups

In contrast, the anti-Nkrumah coup of 1966 was pro-imperialist, anti-socialist and sought to reverse the nationalistic policies of the CPP regime. The coup of Master Sergeant Doe and Captain Strasser in Sierra Leone are either nationalistic or basically rightwing and therefore could be described as reactionary in ideology. Reactionary groups tend to stray towards consolidating the power of the bureaucracy, maintaining the status quo and are generally pro- imperialist or to be more specific, pro-American. For these rulers, it is always business as usual. Not many coup makers subscribe to rightwing ideology from the day of the coup, even though their actions would tend to take that route to development.

One feature of reactionary coups is the class character of the regimes. They tend to be made up of senior army officers who dislike the old regimes precisely because it is nationalistic or simply because they have been denied a share of the national cake. A Ghanaian coup leader once said that the reason for his coup was because the army had been "denied even the most basic amenities."

Another development worth noting is the rise of young, radical and nationalistic army officers such as the late Thomas Sankara, Rawlings (in the late 1970s), Blaise Campaore and Captain Strasser. These officers tend to blame old politicians for Africa's socio- economic problems. Leaders like Thomas Sankara tended to side with radical students, youth movements, grassroots organizations for support in their quest for power. It is therefore always tempting to classify these army officers as radicals even though their actions have ultimately suggested that they were mere power seekers.

It is always tempting to take a simplistic approach in classifying to analysing military regimes in Africa. Society is complex, and there are always social or economic reasons that influence and properly coup makers. Western intellectuals and Embassy officials tend to listen to the public pronouncements of coup makers or leaders. The important thing is to look beyond what they say in public and to look at the class character of coup makers. The social forces they mobilise in the first few days, their supporters and the reaction of the public to the coup as a whole. That would explain the potential difference in pronouncements and the actions of coup makers in the history of Africa.

Contrary to popular beliefs, coups do not need lost of men to succeed. Because they happen when governments are weak because of their failure to fulfill people's ambitions, and has therefore lost popularity, they are unable to mobilise resistance. Most of the time, coup makers face apathy, curiosity or sometimes, open jubilation.

The Banjul Quintet

So what do we make of the Banjul Quintet who now constitute the Armed Forces Provisional Ruling Council? So far, the pronouncements of the AFPRC, leaders of the 22nd July coup in The Gambia, have not said much. The broadcast announcing the overthrow of the 30 year old Jawara regime promised a "new era of freedom, progress, democracy and accountability." subsequently, the coup leader new ruler of The Gambia, Lt. Yaya A.J.J. Jammeh.

Unlike other coup makers in West Africa, the new leaders have refrained from making wild statements and promises. It is difficult to say what the end result of such causation will be. However, at this stage, the ideological orientation of the coup is still not clear. That also points to the fact that in the aftermath of the cold way, coup makers (leaders) are not under pressure to woo one super power or the other to please.

However, the talk of "free market" would also suggest that the AFPRC regime does not intend to make a radical departure from the economic orientation of the PPP government and is like to please the business class and of course some western countries.

However, the issue of accountability is where the new regime can make a difference. The PPP government was caught up in its own internal contradictions and class interests. As a result, it could not and was never in a position to confront the issue of corruption in a radical or forthright manner.

The legal battles between the Assets Recovery Management Committee and some local businessmen, and the failure of the government to respond to calls for a probe into the state of affairs at the African Center for Democracy and Human Rights are just two examples of the government's weakness and inability to address the question of corruption in the Gambia society.

These issues, coupled with the rising poverty in the country, would suggest that the coup makers lived in a country that was ready for explosion. It was only a matter of time.

A Promise to Keep

The Daily Observer's editorial, "A Promise to Keep," noted quite rightly that "the military in Africa do not have a track record of fulfilling the lofty ideals for which they say they seize power. Instead, the people experience more suffering, most often far worse than before. And because the military rules with guns, the people remain helpless victims of perennial hegemony and suppression." That summarizes the relationship between the military and civil society in Africa in recent times and is based on concrete reality.

Africa's relationship with military rule always starts on a happy note and ended sourly. The recent debacle in Nigeria, Rawlings' present relationship with Ghanaians, and Eyadema's ongoing problems attests to the above statement.

One reason for this is the nature of the military. Numerous references have been made to then the colonial character of Africa's military. It has been noted that because of the ideological orientation of the military, it has no democratic content and can therefore not be expected to reinforce and promote democracy in Africa. The fallacy of this argument is that there are examples of military regimes being more democratic than their civilian counterparts.

However, it is also true that coups by their nature are conspiratorial activities, and tend to rely on a few trusted officers and men in the army to succeed. But their continued survival depends on the support of the broad masses and their initial actions. No single coup follows a particular pattern, and so it would be an exercise in folly to look for this in the events on 22nd July in the Gambia.

Either by fate of design, the only surviving multi-party democracy of the old mold has also fallen to the gun. It is a sad reflection of Africa politics that political differences have always to be resolved in the end by the gun. However, in the case, the AFPRC has avoided bloodshed, and Gambians can only hope that this becomes one of the most peaceful takeovers in African history.

Maybe, the Banjul Quintet should take a leaf from the history books and avoid the excesses of others. Most coup leaders in West Africa have fallen to the same temptations of the predecessors. In the end, military rulers always become more affluent, more corrupt, more despotic, more undemocratic than the civilians.

Examples abound in Ghana, Liberia, Sierra Leone, Togo, Nigeria, Sudan, etc., etc.

The AFPRC should perhaps rely on the creative energies of the Gambian people, listen less to foreign advisers, with a double agenda (especially those form powerful western countries), and listen more to Gambian opinion, especially the cries of the poor.

This is one area where the PPP government failed woefully. Their abiding class interest alienated that majority of ordinary Gambians. Their narrow selfish interests, narrow visions and surprising lack of creativity created a wide gulf between them and the general population. The loud talk of transforming The Gambia into a Singapore was as unrealisable dream of the most absurd proportions and lacked anything concrete to back the claim.

Above all, the PPP's failure to address the question of poverty in a concrete manner was an historical indictment. Child malnutrition, malaria, food shortage and the state of deprivation of urban Gambia should have been a source of concern to the PPP big shots. Perhaps it was, but the reality of today suggests otherwise, and we will never know, the most pressing problem of Gambians today is therefore poverty. How the AFPRC regime addresses this will distinguish it from the PPP.

There will be many sycophants and many midnight adversaries. Some of those who led the PPP government along the road to disaster, and are now hiding in the closet will soon re-emerge. There will be many businessmen working round the clock to but favours, turn their support and 'donations' from the non- existent PPP to the AFPRC. How the new rulers either succumb to these temptations or avoid them will test their commitment to democracy, transparency, accountability and their commitment to the broad masses of Gambian workers and peasants.

Will the AFPRC be different from all the others? The world is watching. The Banjul Quintet has sounded new notes in Gambia's musical chairs. Will the song be different from the one Gambians heard in the last 30 years? Will the new song be receptive to Gambian ears?

Reprinted from the Daily Observer, August 2, 1994.

The Daily Observer is published by The Observer Company (Gambia) Ltd., New Town-Sait Matty Junction, Bakau, P.M.B. 131. Banjul, The Gambia. Telephone: (220) 496608, 496877, 496878. Fax: (220) 496878.

Africa News


September 12, 1994 / September 30, 1994


NO USAID FUNDS FOR MILITARY GOVERNMENT


BYLINE: S.B. Danso


LENGTH: 534 words


 

DAILY OBSERVER, Wednesday, August 3, 1994

"None of the funds appropriated or otherwise made available pursuant to this Act shall be obligated or expended to finance directly any assistance to any country whose duly elected head of Government is deposed by military coup or decree: provided, that assistance may be resumed to such country if the President determines and reports to the Committees on Appropriations that subsequent to the termination of assistance a democratically elected government has taken office."

This citation of Section 508 of Fund Assistance Appropriations Act 1994 of Public Law 103-87 of the USA was made by Rose Marie Depp, USAID representative to The Gambia, in an interview with the Daily Observer following the military takeover of the government.

Mrs. Depp explained that it is beyond her control to persuade the US government to approve new aid obligations or commitments to the Gambia under the military regime. The above quotation, she added, is not just a policy but a law in America, and all countries small or large under military rule are regarded and treated the same way. 

She revealed that the only exemptions in this case are made for countries suffering from a natural disaster.

On the question of stopping USAID's operations in The Gambia, she aid that so far she has not received any communication from Washington to terminate any of her staff or cease operations. Mrs. Depp added that even if they were to do so, they would have to look at each component of every single project.

She revealed that since independence the USAID increased its annual development fund to The Gambia form $6 million to $10 million in 1994. The reason for the increase, she said, was due mainly to the good economic policy reform record and the democratic and human rights records in The Gambia. The USAID representative said that the Washington Office has closed 21 missions of USAID across the world, nine of which were in Africa. All these were countries which came under military rule where USAID had its operations

USAID, since 1979 when it started sending permanent representatives to the Gambia, has sent five people here: Tom Moser, Byron Bahl, Jimmie Stone, Bonnie Pounds and Rose Marie Depp.

Reprinted from the Daily Observer, August 3, 1994.

The Daily Observer is published by The Observer Company (Gambia) Ltd., New Town-Sait Matty Junction, Bakau, P.M.B. 131. Banjul, The Gambia. Telephone: (220) 496608, 496877, 496878. Fax: (220) 496878.


LOAD-DATE: March 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


September 12, 1994 / September 30, 1994


HOW SIR DAWDA ESCAPED


LENGTH: 987 words


 

WEEKEND OBSERVER, July 29-31, 1994

United States Ambassador Andrew J. Winter has been explaining how he helped President Dawda K. Jawara to leave the country on the morning of the military take-over that toppled the government of the People's Progressive Party.

Mr. Winter was asked by this newspaper how it happened that at the propitious moment when the coup d'etat was fast unfolding, he happened to be in the right place-- State House-- at the right time-- Friday morning-- to rescue the Gambian leader.

He explained that he had accompanied Reubin Bookert, the Captain of the visiting US naval vessel, Lamoure County , to pay a courtesy call on the then Permanent Secretary of the Ministry of Defense, Mr. Bun Jack. Mr. Jack's office is located on the first floor of State House, just next to the office of the Vice President, who was also Minister of Defense in the Jawara government.

"When we got to the corridor leading to the vice President's office," said the ambassador, " the door flung open and Vice President Sabally appeared and asked us in. He then told us that he had just received word that there was a problem with troops at the Yundum barracks of the Gambia National Army." 

Incidentally, a contingent of the GNA had been scheduled on Saturday, July 23, to engage in training exercises with naval officers from the ship. That is why in the early hours of the coup, many ruled out any trouble because they thought it was all part of the scheduled training exercises.

"While I and the ship captain were in the Vice President's office, Sabally excused himself to go and see the President. Ten minutes later he returned and requested that we take him and the President to the ship for safekeeping.

"The captain and I concurred and proceeded with Mr. Sabally downstairs. I then moved my car backward toward State House, and awaited the President. He, Lady Chilel, several children, grandchildren, and personal security and servants emerged from the State House. It was suggested that for security reasons, President Jawara would ride in my car. I took the front passenger seat and he took the back seat. And with security escort, we proceeded to the Port of Banjul."

The Ambassador said there were 47-49 Gambians aboard the ship, most of the family members. Finance and Economic Affairs Minister B.B. Dabo came later. He was the only cabinet minister apart from the Vice President.

Asked what happened to the President's other wife, Lady Njaimeh, Mr. Winter said she did not return with the President from London the previous day, Thursday, when he returned from a six week trip abroad.

"As we received reports that the troops were entering Banjul," the Ambassador continued, " the captain and I decided to set sail. We went to the mouth of the harbour and could still see the dock. Then we moved the ship to a position opposite the State House to see what was going on. We had no military intentions whatsoever," he assured.

He continued, "Then we got word from the Gambia National Army to please move the ship from opposite State House. So, we moved south, about two miles out, off the coast to Cape St. Mary, and sat for a long while.

" W e spent the night at that location. We didn't leave Gambian waters until around 1-2 o'clock Sunday afternoon."

Meanwhile, according to the Ambassador, four crew members of the ship had gone down to Kunkujang where a Catholic priest runs an orphanage, "and we wanted them back on the ship. They made their way to the embassy beach house in Tangie, accompanied by some embassy staff, and spent the night there. Finally, they made their way to the Ambassador's residence in Fajara on Saturday by road on the beach.

"And with the kind assistance of the GNA, we got permission to send a small boat from the ship to Banjul, which took them back to the ship." Mr. Winter went on, "We then requested permission for me to go ashore. Permission was granted. But by that time, it was 7pm, after the curfew time. And as I started out for the beach, the GNA called to say they could not guarantee my safety because they couldn't make contact with the GNA personnel patrolling on the beach.

"Therefore, on Sunday, at about 1pm, the Bolong Kanta, a patrol boat which the US government gave the Gambia government, rendezvoused with the LaMoure County and took me and two members of my staff. The GNA granted us safe conduct through Banjul to the embassy."

"That same Sunday," the Ambassador said, "the ship left for Dakar, where President Abdou Diouf granted Sir Dawda asylum.

Reprinted from the Weekend Observer, July 29-31, 1994.

The Weekend Observer is published by the Observer Company (Gambia) Ltd., New Town-Sait Matty Junction, Bakau. PMB 131, Banjul, The Gambia.


LOAD-DATE: March 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


September 12, 1994 / September 30, 1994


STALS BETS ON RANDS AND WINS


BYLINE: Duma Gqubule


LENGTH: 1560 words


 

WEEKLY MAIL & GUARDIAN, September 9, 1994

A RESERVE BANK masterplan has caused currency speculators to burn their fingers and lose billions of rands betting against the rand over the past couple of months. Governor Chris Stals this week laughed at speculators who had put wagers on the commercial rand continuing its headlong slide against the dollar as pressure mounted for the bank to scrap the financial rand dual currency system. The finrand, as it is known, protects the reserves of the country by sterilising outflows of foreign capital. Non-residents who invest in South Africa use these special rands, a pool of which has been created by foreigners disinvesting. While non-residents should find the cheaper finrand attractive, it has many disadvantages, not the least of which is that inflows of money via this route do not build up the capital in the country, but only soak up the outflow of capital. 

Stals also issued a warning to the speculators: "Nobody is going to force the bank to scrap the financial rand before the right conditions exist, especially now that our reserves are on the rise again and the market is flush with dollars. "We are making profits in our dealings in foreign exchange markets at the moment while they are losing money. The financial rand exchange rate must first come towards that of the commercial rand and not the other way round. In that way there will be less room for speculators and the pain ordinary South Africans will have to bear when the finrand goes will be reduced."

Stals said the bank had anticipated an outflow of short-term capital in the months leading up to the April election which would result in a sharp depreciation in the value of the rand against the dollar and other currencies. These outflows would stabilise after the election, resulting in the rand gaining value against the dollar. "We could have done nothing and allowed a sharp fall in the currency's value which would be followed by a sharp appreciation after the election. Instead, we decided to supply the market with dollars before the election and buy them back after the election to smooth out expected volatile fluctuations in the rand's value during the transition.

"Between end-August and May 10, the bank borrowed dollars worth R7,4-billion to prop up the rand, but the currency still depreciated sharply against the dollar. The fall would have been much sharper had the bank not intervened.

"We could have been wrong, but the plan worked out quite well because short-term capital outflows have receded and reserves are rising again.

"We are now net buyers of dollars and have repaid loans worth R4-billion. The currency has stabilised again -- around R3,56 -- R3,60 against the dollar - - over the past two months.

"Those who bought forward contracts at R3,70c have burnt their fingers. These people are the ones who are saying the bank must allow the currency to fall. But how can we do this if there are surplus dollars on the market?"

Stals said a repeat of the situation where international speculator George Soros broke the Bank of England's back and pocketed Stg 1-billion was unlikely to happen in South Africa. The difference was that in 1992, the Bank of England had decided to fix their currency against the European Exchange Rate Mechanism (ERM) and refused to budge even when all economic fundamentals said the pound could not be fixed at such a high level. Speculative pressures built up and the bubble popped in September 1992.

"The Reserve Bank does not fix the price of the rand or have targets for it. We only lean against the wind smoothing out undue fluctuations in the currency's value. If economic fundamentals are really against the rand we let it go." Stals hit back at economists who were calling for a sharp depreciation in the value of the rand to boost exports and prevent a balance of payments (BoP) crisis. Simplistically, the BoP shows how much in credit or debt the country is with the rest of the world.

"This will result in a short-term improvement in the BoP position as the value of exports increase faster than import prices are rising. But the gains for exporters will be wiped out very quickly by rising inflation.

"We estimate every 10 percent depreciation in the value of the rand will increase the inflation rate by 1,5 percent. Other knock-on effects in the domestic market, like higher wage demands, will result in a spiral of further rises in the inflation rate and inflationary expectations."

On the possibility of an interest rate hike, Stals said many economic indicators (including the rate of inflation and the rate of growth of the money supply and credit extended by the banks) were moving in the wrong direction.

"The pressure is building up, but we have not yet reached the stage where bank rate will have to increase." The bank rate, set by the Reserve Bank, is the key interest rate which determines all other short-term interest rates. The bank was watching with interest developments in money and capital markets where rates were rising.

"So far the pressure in these markets is not enough to make us increase bank rate, even though some banks are complaining that an increase is needed to improve their interest margins.

"We will look at how much they are borrowing from us. At this stage it is only R2-billion to R3- billion a day. If our rate is too low they will borrow more and only if the figure rises to about R6-billion to R8-billion will we be forced to increase bank rate."

Stals said there was no timeframe for scrapping the financial rand. The country was moving in the right direction which would make it easier for the bank to recommend a removal of the dual currency system.

* The exchange rate had stabilised

* Foreign exchange reserves were increasing

* Arrangements were being made for South Africa to receive a credit rating and borrow overseas

* Long-term interest rates had already discounted the ending of the finrand

* Short- term capital outflows were improving

* Soon long term outflows would follow suit and maybe, in 18 months, foreign direct investment would start arriving

"We are moving in the direction that the shocks to the economy (when the finrand was abolished) would be reduced."

On the country's growth prospects during the transition, Stals said he was optimistic. "This year there will be not much more than two percent growth. Hopefully, we will be able to gradually solve the structural problems in the economy and raise our medium and long term growth potential. These structural adjustments will happen over time -- some are already happening in the clothing and textiles industries -- and not in one big bang package from the IMF.

"South Africa's problems are not as great as those of countries like Argentina which had an inflation rate of 200 percent and a growth rate of -5 percent. These countries had no choice but to make their adjustments in one big bang."

Reprinted from The Weekly Mail & Guardian, September 9, 1994.

The Weekly Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media Contact: M&G Media, 139 Smit Street, Breamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025.


LOAD-DATE: March 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English
