Africa News


October 1, 1994 / October 31, 1994


LIFE AND TIMES OF WINNIE MANDELA


BYLINE: MFUNDO NDEBELE


SECTION: BOOK REVIEW


LENGTH: 1134 words


 

Winnie Mandela is without a doubt one of South Africa's world-renowned political leaders.

As a controversial figure, her role and personality mean different things to different people. One thing is clear though her marriage to the state President Nelson Mandela and her implacable hatred of white domination, place her among a special class of our distinguished contemporaries.

But, who is Winnie? Is she a heroine, a pacifist, a demagogue or an enigma? Author Emma Gilbey attempt to provide answers to these questions in her book titled "The Lady - Life and Times of Winnie Mandela". 

The book traces her rural background of Bizana in the Transkei. She is the fourth child of Columbus and Gertrude Madikizela. Her parents had three daughters already. They, together with her strong and domineering grandmother, had hoped for a boy. This attitude contributed to the shaping of her thinking and behaviour throughtout her life.

After graduating from the local primary school, her father sent her to Jan Hofmeyr School of Social Work in Johannesburg in the early '50s. The National Party (NP) had been elevated to power in 1948 and it vigourously implemented racist policies.

The oppressed blacks had rallied behind the ANC which spearheaded the struggle for liberation and equality. The ANC Youth League formed in the late '40s and led by Anton Lembede, Oliver Tambo and Nelson Mandela among other young firebrands, mapped out aggressive and co-ordinated opposition to teh apartheid regime.

After completing her studies, Winnie took up post as a social worker at the Baragwanath Hospital. She became the first black to obtain the qualification. It was while working there that she friendship with Adelaide Tshukudu who was to become the wife of Oliver Tambo.

One day while Winnie was travelling with Tambo and Adelaide to Baragwanath, on the way they met with Nelson Mandela. This led to Tambo introducing Winnie to Mandela.

After Mandela's divorce with Evelyn, a whirlwind romance ensued. In May 1958, Winnie and Mandela got married. Henceforth Winnie, on Mandela's encouragement became more entangled in political activities.

In the same year, nearly 2,000 women gathered in the centre of Johannesberg to protest against the pass law. Winnie was one of them. For her role in the demonstration, she spent a fortnight in prison. She was detained several times thereafter. On her release from detention, she was fired at Baragwanath.

The book shows clearly a lack of blissful moments in their married life. Mandela was among the 156 accused at teh Johannesburg Magistrate's Court. The trial which dragged on for months, became known as the Treason Trial.

In 1958 the couple was blessed with a daughter, Zenani.

Nineteen-sixty (1960) was a watershed in South African history.

In the same year, both the ANC and PAC were outlawed and the State of Emergency was enforced, resulting in massive arrests and bannings. Mandela went underground and Tambo fled into exile to form the ANC military wing Umkhonto weSizwe (MK). Mandela also skipped the country to campaign for MK. For 18 months he evaded a massive police hunt, earning him the nickname "The Black Pimpernell".

The Mandelas' second daughter, Zinzi, was born in 1960.

While police were looking for Mandela, Winnie and her two daughters had to content with the dreadful dawn raids. Mandela was later arrested in a roadblock near Escourt.

He was charged with nine ANC leaders in 1964 during the Rivonia Trial and sentenced to life imprisonment.

This never seriously daunted Winnie. She instead continued with the struggle. With the outbreak of the 1976 uprising, Winnie became a member of the Black Parents Association. The following year she wsa banished to a small town of Brandfort in the Orange Free State (OFS).

The book also reveals several emotional brief visits to her husband. On such such trips she used to be subjected to indignities by the prison officials.

Gilbey traces the psychological effects this had on Winnie. She argues that the growing power which Winnie felt within her made her feel she was above the law.

The author cites her formation of the Mandela Football club which conducted a reign of terror in the community. This culminated in teh death of a young activist Stompie Sepei. Many other murder cases in which Winnie was implicated were followed. In 1991 Winnie appeared in the Rand Supreme Court on four counts of abduction and four counts of violence with intent to do grievous bodily harm. She was fined R6 000 and set free.

The book also touches on her fall from grace as a result of her activities with the Mandela FC. It tells of her rejection by the Mass Democratic Movement (MDM) and the community of Soweto at large.

The book ends on a sad note with the separation of Winnie and Mandela, depriving her of a deserving wedded bliss.

"The Lady" is a well researched and compelling book. But it suffers from many digressions. At some stage one forgets that Winnie is its subject. It also reveals the author's bias against Winnie and the ANC in particular.

Reprinted from NEW NATION, September 23-29, 1994.

NEW NATION is published at Darragh House, 13 Wanders Street, Johannesburg. Tel: (011) 333-2711 or (011)333-2721/2/3/4 Telex: 482226 Fax: (011)889-0630.


LOAD-DATE: March 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


300 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 1, 1994 / October 31, 1994


TOGO: NEW GOVERNMENT FAILS TO PUT HUMAN RIGHTS ON ITS AGENDA


LENGTH: 1000 words


 

One year after presidential elections in Togo and six months on from the country's first ever multi-party elections, past human rights violations remain uninvestigated and unaccounted for and violations continue to be carried out by the Togolese security forces, according to Amnesty International.

"Since the new government came to power, insecurity in the capital, Lome, has continued despite the announcement of measures aimed at establishing the rule of law," Amnesty International said.

Recent information suggests that political activists and some returning refugees have been harassed and intimidated by members of the Togolese Armed Forces or by armed groups and individuals, some of whom may be working in collusion with the Togolese Armed Forces. A number of businessmen -- particularly financiers -- have been the target of recent assassination attempts, some of which have been successful. 

The security forces have also allegedly arbitrarily detained people on account of their political opinions. One man who was arbitrarily arrested by soldiers in July was allegedly held in a secret detention centre with 12 other detainees; he was held for 19 days and subjected to torture and ill-treatment.

The government is not known to have made any attempt to establish responsibility for any of these incidents.

"Unless the Togolese government puts the protection of human rights firmly on the political agenda, and punishes those found guilty of past and present abuses, the future safeguard of human rights in the country cannot be assured," Amnesty International said.

In a report published today, the human rights organization is calling on the new government of Togo to confirm its commitment to investigate past violations and bring cases to court.

"Although the new government itself is not responsible for human rights abuses committed in the past, it now needs to acknowledge and investigate these violations -- notably those committed by the security forces -- as a clear indication that such abuses will not be tolerated in the future," Amnesty International said today.

Scores of people were extrajudicially executed, arbitrarily arrested, tortured and harassed by the security forces during the period of political transition in Togo. This began with the National Conference in 1991 and ended with presidential and multi- party legislative elections in August 1993 and February this year.

Amnesty International's new report documents violations during the election period. These include the death in custody of at least 20 opposition supporters in August last year; the extrajudicial execution of at least 48 people by members of the Togolese Armed Forces following an alleged attack in Lome this January; the killing of a member of parliament, Gaston Aziaduvo Edeh, and two other political activists and the "disappearance" of at least four people in February this year.

The new report also calls on the government to implement urgently needed human rights reforms, including vigorous measures to eradicate torture and a review of the cases of political prisoners still held. These include prisoner of conscience Martin Dossou Gbenouga, a newspaper editor, sentenced to five years' imprisonment in May in connection with an article which criticized President Eyadema and the French Government. His conviction fits into a long-standing pattern of intimidation and harassment of independent journalists, newspaper publishers and vendors in Togo.

Amnesty International is also concerned about the continued detention without charge or trial of trade union leader Komi Dackey, arrested on 11 January this year. The government claims that Komi Dackey is among a number of individuals held on suspicion of their involvement in a violent attack on the headquarters of the Regiment interarmes togolais (RIT), Togolese Combined Regiment in Lome on 5 January, but other sources maintain that he was arrested because of his trade union activities.

Amnesty International believes that the Togolese authorities should urgently review these and other cases, with a viw to completing the judicial process fairly and speedily and releasing prisoners who are detained on account of their non-violent political views.

The organization is also urging other governments which have links with Togo to assist the Togolese authorities in improving human rights. Any government that has renewed its military assistance to Togo, in particular the French government - - who were the first to do so -- should ensure that any such assistance incorporates training in respect for human rights and is not used to facilitate human rights violations.

From: Hilary Naylor

For further information, contact the International Secretariat of Amnesty International, 1 Easton Street, London WC1X 8DJ (Tel +44-71-413-5500, Fax +44-71-956-1157) or SHARRRISO@IGC.APC.ORG


LOAD-DATE: March 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


301 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 1, 1994 / October 31, 1994


SUDAN: US JOURNALISTS CONDEMN SUDANESE GOVERNMENT'S CLOSURE OF NEWSPAPER OFFICE, DEMAND RELEASE OF IMPRISONED REPORTER


LENGTH: 814 words


 

The Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ) deplored the closure of the Sudanese office of "Al-Khartoum" newspaper. The office was raided by security forces on September 11.

"Al-Khartoum" is published in Cairo by exiled Sudanese journalists. It is distributed in Egypt, the Gulf and Europe, but is forbidden in Sudan. 

In a letter to Lt. General Omar Hassan Bashir, who came to power in a fundamentalist-backed coup in 1989, CPJ demanded the release of "Al-Khartoum" reporter Mohamed Abd al-Seed. He was arrested on June 23 and has not been heard from since. CPJ fears that he is being held in a clandestine detention center.

September 29, 1994

To: General Omar Hassan al-Bashir Head of State and Chairman of N.S.R.C.C. c/o Embassy of Sudan 2210 Massachusetts Avenue, NW Washington, DC 20008

Mr. Abd al-Aziz Shiddo Minister of Justice and Attorney-General c/o Embassy of Sudan 2210 Massachusetts Avenue, NW Washington, DC 20008

Mr. Abd al-Basit Sabdarat Minister of Culture and Information c/o Embassy of Sudan 2210 Massachusetts Avenue, NW Washington, DC 20008

Your Excellency:

The Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ) is deeply disturbed by the closure of the Khartoum office of "Al-Khartoum" newspaper. And we are extremely alarmed by the prolonged detention of one of "Al-Khartoum's" reporters, Mohamed Abd al-Seed. On September 11, members of the security forces raided and closed the Khartoum office of the independent Cairo-based newspaper "Al-Khartoum." One day earlier the office received a warning from the international section of the Ministry of Culture and Information, that the bureau would be closed, sources at the newspaper told CPJ. Officials confiscated the press cards of all five journalists who worked in the bureau: Mohamed Mahmoud Rajih, Mu'tasim Mahmoud (who had been imprisoned earlier this year), Nafisa al-Haj, Murtada al-Ghali, and Najib Nourredine.

Sudanese authorities have given no official explanation for the closure. Security officials claim that "Al-Khartoum's" office was being used to arrange clandestine opposition meetings. This has been emphatically denied by the paper.

CPJ is very concerned about the well-being of "Al-Khartoum" reporter Mohamed Abd al-Seed, a matter we have already taken up with Your Excellency in a June 24 letter. On June 23 security forces entered the offices of Al-Khartoum. After beating and kicking Mr. Abd al-Seed, the officers accused him of involvement in a plot to assassinate Hassan al-Turabi, leader of the National Islamic Front (NIF), and took him into custody.

Over three months later, Mr. Abd al-Seed's whereabouts remain unknown to his family and colleagues, his employers report. Last year, when he was Khartoum bureau chief for the Saudi-owned daily newspaper Asharq al-Awsat, he was arrested and held for nearly two months in a "ghost house." CPJ fears that he has once again been thrown into one of these clandestine detention centers where prisoners are routinely tortured.

As a nonpartisan organization of journalists dedicated to the defense of our colleagues' rights throughout the world, CPJ believes the closure of "Al-Khartoum's" office will have a chilling effect on news coverage of Sudan. We respectfully urge the government of Sudan to allow the office to reopen, return its employees' press cards and assure that they can resume their journalistic work unhindered.

Finally, CPJ denounces the incommunicado detention of Mohamed Abd al-Seed as a flagrant violation of Article 19 of the United Nations' Universal Declaration of Human Rights. We urge the government of Sudan to release him immediately and unconditionally.

Thank you for your attention. We welcome your comments.

Sincerely,

William A. Orme, Jr.

Executive Director


LOAD-DATE: March 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


302 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 1, 1994 / October 31, 1994


RWANDA: LETTER DATED 1 OCTOBER 1994 FROM THE SECRETARY-GENERAL ADDRESSED TO THE PRESIDENT OF THE SECURITY COUNCIL


LENGTH: 854 words


 

By its resolution 935 (1994) of 1 July 1994, the Security Council requested me to establish, as a matter of urgency, an impartial Commission of Experts to examine and analyse information submitted pursuant to that resolution, together with such further information as the Commission of Experts might obtain through its own investigations or the efforts of other persons or bodies, including the information made available by the Special Rapporteur of the Commission on Human Rights on Rwanda, with a view to providing me with its conclusions on the evidence of grave violations of international humanitarian law committed in the territory of Rwanda, including the evidence of possible acts of genocide.

On 26 and 29 July 1994, I informed the Security Council of the establishment of the Commission and its terms of reference and composition (S/1994/879 and S/1994/906). On that occasion, I expressed the hope that, in view of the urgency of the matter, the final report of the Commission would be submitted not later than 30 November 1994. 

The Commission began its work on 15 August 1994 and, after a series of meetings in Geneva, conducted a field mission to Rwanda and some neighbouring countries from 29 August to 17 September 1994. Pursuant to a decision taken at its first session, the Commission has transmitted to me an interim report which covers its preliminary investigations and activities prior to 30 September 1994. The Commission has taken the period 6 April 1994 to 15 July 1994 as the temporal mandate for the purpose of its interim report.

The interim report provides an account of the evidence gathered by the Commission during its field visit to Rwanda or provided by various Governments, intergovernmental institutions and non-governmental organizations. It also contains conclusions and recommendations and describes a plan of work for the remainder of its activities.

I wish to draw your attention to the conclusions reached at this stage by the Commission, namely that, in the period under consideration:

(a) Individuals from both sides to the armed conflict have perpetrated serious breaches of international humanitarian law, in particular of obligations set forth in article 3 common to the four Geneva Conventions of 12 August 1949 and in Protocol II additional to the Geneva Conventions and relating to the Protection of Victims of Non-International Armed Conflicts of 8 June 1977;

(b) Individuals from both sides to the armed conflict have perpetrated crimes against humanity in Rwanda;

(c) Acts of genocide against the Tutsi group were perpetrated by Hutu elements in a concerted, planned, systematic and methodical way. These acts of mass extermination against the Tutsi group as such constitute genocide within the meaning of article II of the Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of the Crime of Genocide. The Commission has not uncovered any evidence to indicate that Tutsi elements perpetrated acts committed with the intent to destroy the Hutu ethnic group as such.

The Commission of Experts has recommended that the Security Council take all necessary and effective action to ensure that the individuals responsible for the foregoing grave violations of human rights in Rwanda during the armed conflict are brought to justice before an independent and impartial international criminal tribunal. In order to enhance the fair and consistent interpretation, application and adjudication of international law on individual responsibility for serious human rights violations and to achieve the most efficient allocation of resources, the Commission has further recommended that the Security Council amend the Statute of the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia so that it can consider crimes under international law committed during the armed conflict in Rwanda.

In view of the importance of the contents of the interim report, in particular of its conclusions and recommendations, I am forwarding a copy to you for the information of the Council. I will, of course, bring to the attention of the Security Council the final report envisaged in paragraph 3 of resolution 935 (1994) as soon as the Commission makes it available to me.

(Signed)

Boutros BOUTROS-GHALI


LOAD-DATE: March 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


303 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 1, 1994 / October 31, 1994


LIBERIA: SECRETARY-GENERAL EXPRESSES GRAVE CONCERN OVER CONDITIONS IN LIBERIA


LENGTH: 347 words


 

October 5, 1994

The following statement was issued today by the Spokesman for

Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali:

The Secretary-General is gravely concerned over the deterioration of humanitarian conditions in Liberia resulting from factional fighting, victimization of innocent civilians and the impossibility of conducting relief operations in most parts of the country.

Since early September, intense fighting has erupted in many parts of Liberia, particularly the central region around the town of Gbarnga. Well over 100,000 people have been displaced by this latest wave of hostilities, with 55,000 new arrivals registered by the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) in Guinea and 40,000 in Cote d'Ivoire. This latest wave of refugees joins the 700,000 already exiled since the start of the Liberian civil war in 1989.

While those crossing the border will receive emergency assistance from the UNHCR and the World Food Programme (WFP), thousands of displaced and injured civilians trapped inside the country cannot be reached by humanitarian agencies. The intense fighting, willful disregard of the security of humanitarian workers and seizure of nearly all their vehicles, equipment and relief stocks have forced the suspension of humanitarian assistance outside Monrovia and its environs.

The Secretary-General deplores the wanton destruction of life and property in Liberia and calls upon the warring factions to create conditions in which humanitarian assistance can be safely delivered to all Liberians in need.


LOAD-DATE: March 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


304 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 1, 1994 / October 31, 1994


Government of National Unity of South Africa Reconstruction and Development Programme


LENGTH: 934 words


 

Excerpts: WHITE PAPER -- DISCUSSION DOCUMENT

September 1994

CONCLUSION: A NATIONAL CONSENSUS

This first White Paper on Reconstruction and Development has set out key change management strategies for transformation, particular of government at all levels. It also sets out guidelines on areas of particular importance for change. This is the first in a series. The second will be published for comment in March 1995 and will set out in more detail specific policies, together with an evaluation of process. Daunting challenges face government in implementing the programme set out in this paper. Perhaps the most crucial is the establishment of credible and effective Local Government, in both urban and rural areas. Without this, implementation of development programmes will be seriously hindered. It will require a sustained and intensive campaign which brings together Central Government, Provincial Governments, existing local authorities, civics, trade unions, business and other community organizations. Local Government development will also require a huge effort in human recourse and capacity development. Existing institutions will be challenged to provide this input in a coordinated 

The stability of Local Government services depends on the regular payment of user charges. The first step in achieving this is to make all aspects of Local Government finances completely open and transparent. This must be done also with the finances and cost structures of both municipal and national utilities.

Furt(her planning of a campaign to restore stability to local authority finances must be done together with mass organizations and especially with trade unions active in Local Government.

The campaign will only be successful if government at all levels is prepared to go out to the people, to talk, clarify and explain, and to answer questions.

The issue of affordable tariffs, targeted subsidies and targeted welfare delivery must be resolved as a matter of urgency. Communities must be prepared to commit themselves to performance contracts in terms of which they undertake to participate in the planning, management and protection of development programmes.

There is a second major challenge in implementing the Government's programme. For the RDP to be 'people-driven', there must be a vibrant civil society. However, there is a tendency at present to believe that 'the Government will deliver on its own'. This has the potential to disempower the organizations of civil society. Communities and organizations are listing projects and expecting the Government to pass over a cheque. Rather, organizations and communities should themselves set up projects and expect the Government to cooperate, not to finance. The Government must proactively assist civil society to gain access to information and to participate effectively in the consultations required for a 'people-driven' RDP(P. Equally, civil society must ensure that the resources of Local and Provincial Governments are rapidly re-organized and redirected.

The third major challenge is to ensure that the change management process in government moves sufficiently rapidly to allow significant changes in the deployment of staff and expenditure before the Budget in March 1995. This must include changes in budgeting procedures, control and management of programmes and asset policies.

The responsibility for the renewal and transformation of our nation is, however, not the responsibility only of the Government nor of particular elected officials. It is a joint responsibility of all sections of our nation, and calls on all to put their energy and creativity into finding ways of doing things better and differently. The constraints and obstacles which can prevent delivery of a better life for all of our people can be solved if those constituencies most involved in a sector apply their minds to the problem jointly.

This partnership and national consensus does not mean that different constituencies and organizations of civil society cannot or should not have their own aims and goals. It does, however, mean that they should attempt to make those aims and goals consistent with the aims of the RDP and of renewal of our society, in a conscious and honest process. It is essential that organizations of civil society do, in fact, have clear goals which reflect the real interests of their members, but they should lead their members in attempting to align those goals with the RDP.

In this way the energy of the nation can be harnessed for the good of all.


LOAD-DATE: March 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


October 1, 1994 / October 31, 1994


BOTSWANA: HUMAN RIGHTS WATCH WOMEN'S RIGHTS PROJECT


LENGTH: 1467 words


 

The Botswana government discriminates against women by denying their right to pass Botswana citizenship to their children from marriages to foreign men; by contrast, under Botswana's Citizenship Act, children born to Botswana men and foreign women automatically become Botswana nationals. In "Second Class Citizens: Discrimination Against Women Under Botswana's Citizenship Act," released on September 14, 1994, Human Rights Watch/Africa and Human Rights Watch Women's Rights Project accuse the government of undermining the rule of law and independence of the judiciary by continuing to enforce the law even though the country's highest court ruled, in 1992 landmark case "Attorney General v. Unity Dow," that section 4 of the Citizenship Act is unconstitutional because it discriminates against women.

This singularly discriminatory law also interferes with Botswana women's freedom of movement and marriage, and leads to discrimination against affected children in education and employment. Human Rights Watch urges the Botswana government to uphold the ruling of Botswana's Court of Appeal by immediately amending section and other discriminatory sections of the citizenship Act. Published by Human Rights Watch, "Second Class Citizens: Discrimination Against Women under Botswana's Citizenship Act," documents the landmark case "Attorney General v. Unity Dow" and the Botswana government's subsequent defiance of the Appeal Court's decision. According to one of the Appeal Court Justices, "the effect of section 4 of the (Citizenship) Act is to accord an advantage or a privilege to a man which is denied to a woman. A more discriminatory provision can hardly be found." Under this provision, a person born in Botswana acquires citizenship by birth and descent if "his father is a citizen of Botswana or in the case of a person born out of wedlock, his mother was a citizen of Botswana."

A Botswana woman married to a foreign male has no chance of passing Botswana citizenship to her children, regardless of whether the children were born in Botswana, have taken up residence in Botswana, or have never been outside of Botswana. Such children are treated as aliens and require residence permits to remain in Botswana. The law does not, however, apply to any child born to a Botswana father, regardless of where the child was born or even if the child has never been in Botswana.

In June 1990, Unity Dow, married to American citizen Peter Nathan Dow, commenced legal action challenging the constitutionality of sections 4 and 5 of the citizenship Act on the grounds that they discriminate by reason of sex. (The Appeal Court ruled that Dow lacked legal standing to contest section 5 which concerns children born ousted of Botswana). The couple, married in 1984, have three children. Unity's first daughter, Cheese Maitumelo Dow, was born out of wedlock before the 1984 Citizenship (Amendment) Act and was later adopted by Peter Dow. She acquired citizenship by birth in Botswana. Unity's two other children, born after her marriage to Nathan Dow, have been denied Botswana citizenship. Due to the Act they have different nationalities and rights than their siste, even though they have the same parents and reside in the same country.

HRW also charges in "Second Class Citizens" that sex discrimination under the Citizenship Act severely curtails women's and children's other fundamental freedoms. Botswana women who have married foreign men are prevented from exercising the right to travel freely in and out of the country without leaving their children who, without Botswana passports, may not be readmitted.

Moreover, the Appeal Court found that the Citizenship Act interferes with Botswana women's freedom of marriage. By forcing Botswana women to weigh the negative consequences to their children of marrying foreign men, this law may dissuade them from marrying the men of their choice. These consequences include rendering the affected children potentially stateless, if they are unable to acquire their father's nationality for any reason. If they cannot acquire any country's passport, they would not be able to travel externally. As aliens in their own country, the affected children also cannot vote or hold certain public offices. Moreover, they suffer discrimination in access to education since non-citizen children are admitted to public schools only when they do not jeopardize a citizen's chance of enrollment.

The report finds that more than two years after the Unity Dow decision, the Botswana government has yet to amend the Citizenship Act to end discrimination against women. Replying to the Unity Dow's application for passports for her two younger children, the Attorney General in July 1994 wrote that he has been "unable to see the relevance of (the Appeal Court) judgment to the question of the issue of passports. The government has also flouted the court's decision by denying passports to other children in similar situations.

Human Rights Watch is concerned that such defiance undermines the rule of law and the independence of the judiciary in Botswana. It also sets a dangerous precedent for human rights in the region more generally since Botswana is often looked to as an example of good governance and democracy in Africa.

Based on the conclusions of "Second Class Citizens," Human Rights Watch recommends that the government of Botswana urgently take the following steps:

- Immediately enforce the decision of the Unity Dow case by amending section 4 of the Citizenship Act to allow children born in Botswana to a Botswana woman a foreign male to acquire Botswana citizenship.

-Amend other discriminatory sections of the Citizenship Act, particularly sections 5,6 and 12, to conform to international human rights standards of equality and nondiscrimination.

-Consider amending the constitution expressly to include distinctions on the basis of sex in the definition of discrimination under section 15.

-Ratify the major international instruments protecting the rights of women and children, particularly the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, the Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination Against Women, and the Convention on the Rights of the Child.

"Human Rights Watch/Africa (formerly Africa Watch)".

Human Rights Watch is a non-governmental organization established in 1978 to monitor and promote the observance of internationally recognized human rights in Africa, the Americas, Asia, the Middle East and among the signatories of the Helsinki accords. It is supported by contributions from private individuals and foundations worldwide. It accepts no government funds, directly or indirectly. Its Africa division was established in 1988 to monitor and promote the observance of internationally recognized human rights in sub-Saharan Africa.

The Women Rights Project was established in 1990 to monitor violence against women and gender discrimination throughout the world.

Copies of the report are available from the Publications Department, Human Rights Watch, 485 Fifth Avenue, New York, NY 10017-6104. To order a copy, please make your check payable in U.S. dollars to Human Rights Watch in the amount of $3.60 (includes domestic shipping and handling) or $4.50 (includes international shipping and handling). For Further Information contact Abdullahi An-Na'im (202) 371-6592, Sarah Y. Lai, (202) 371-6592, Susan Osnos, (212) 972-2527


LOAD-DATE: March 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


306 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 1, 1994 / October 31, 1994


ALGERIA: Farewell Message by the Ambassador of Algeria to the United States


SECTION: DOCUMENTS


LENGTH: 1027 words


 

H.E. Nourredine Yazid Zerhouni

Washington, D.C., September, 1994

First of all, Mrs. Zerhouni and I would like to thank you all for attending our farewell party. We are particularly honored to see so many of our friends this evening.

Throughout my tenure as Ambassador of Algeria to this great and beautiful country, I have above all tried to explain the complexity of the multi-faceted crisis that my country has been going through and which excludes any hasty or manichean evaluation likely to generate negative or counterproductive signals.

Today, what is at stake in Algeria is not only an electoral issue: it is the pursuit of a genuine and irreversible democratic process based on pluralism and alternance to power with full respect of fundamental liberties. 

Concurrently, radical economic reforms were launched to insure a sustained development in a framework of free enterprise, while at the same time avoiding to generate unbearable social inequalities. In this respect, a couple of weeks ago, the International Monetary Fund issued a very positive report on the progress achieved by Algeria in the implementation of and commitment to the program of structural reforms reached earlier this year.

Thus, the pursuit of the democratic process and the implementation of radical reforms are the main objectives of the transitional period which Algeria has been going through since January of this year.

In order to take up this challenge, H.E. President Liamine Zeroual has favored a political approach based on a responsible dialogue and on the involvement of all the leaders and organizations opposed to the use of violence and committed to upholding the Constitution and its fundamental principles.

This dialogue has two primary objectives: end to violence and organization of free elections.

Ladies and gentlemen: With your help, it has been possible to promote a greater interest for what is happening in Algeria. I am convinced that this greater attention will bring about a better perception of the stakes and the challenges that are facing Algeria and the rest of our region.

At the conclusion of my mission, I am pleased to note that the United States Government, essentially supports our approach, condemns violence and avoids the dangerous mix up between Islam and extremism.

We also appreciate the interest manifested by US businesses for Algeria and their increasingly active participation in the development of a new type of partnership based on mutual interests and shared benefits and capable of taking the greatest advantage of the restructuring of our economy.

Ladies and Gentlemen, dear fellow Ambassadors and Charges d'Affaires:

Algeria does not expect her friends and partners to substitute themselves for her in facing the difficult responsibilities that are hers. While we have always refused to interfere in the internal affairs of others, we also know that the solutions to our internal problems are to be found in Algeria alone and among Algerians: this is characteristic of our culture and one of our idiosyncrasies.

However, despite the pressure exerted by the current difficulties, Algeria has not failed to her regional or international obligations. We have positively and in decisive moments contributed to the starting of the Middle East process and to its progress, as we have contributed to the resolution of conflicts taking place closer to our borders. Several among our best diplomats have actively devoted their skills and energies to such tasks.

Our interest for cooperation in the Mediterranean area and in Africa, and more particularly, with our Mahgreb and Sub-Saharan neighbors, has not lessened either.

Similarly, we continue to work for a just and real solution to the Western Sahara conflict based on as honest referendum for self-determination.

Ladies and gentlemen. before leaving this country, I would like to tell you that your availability and your friendly attention have been quite helpful in generating a better mutual understanding. I am grateful to you for that.

I would like to express my thanks and appreciation to the members of the Algerian community in the United States for their awareness, their sensitivity and interest for everything that is happening in their homeland, as well as for their efforts to better communicate with their official representation.

This evening, I would also like to congratulate my fellow diplomats at the embassy who represent their country with dignity and patriotism.

I will certainly not forget the constant devotion, commitment and efforts of the local staff of the embassy. They have continuously improved their professionalism, and have always been available when called upon.

Finally, I would like to express my gratitude and my deep appreciation to my family and more particularly to my wife Faitha for their committed support. Thanks to them, my mission was easier to accomplish.

Thank you very much.


LOAD-DATE: March 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


October 1, 1994 / October 31, 1994


SOUTH AFRICA: WOMEN WANT EQUAL RIGHTS NOW BY


LENGTH: 480 words


 

Women's rights activists resolved at a Johannesburg comference at the weekend to lobby power to ensure women's equality becomes a reality.

Delegates at the three-day conference of the Women's National Coalition (WNC) met to chart the future role of the organisation after its mandate expired with the formunlation of the Charter for Effective Equality.

"The WNC and its affiliates will now build organisations, sttructures and lobbying power to ensure that women's equality becomes a reality," said Jean Ngubane, convener of the WNC which, according to its leaders, represents more than two million women. 

She said the country was in a state of flux and that "most people are likely to relax and think that things are just going to work themselves out.

"We in the coalition feel this is actually the time we should be demanding that everything be done according to the charter or according to women's demands," she told a Press conference early this week.

The conference was also addressed by Dr. Sheila Meintjes, WNC outgoing deputy general secretary, who said the coalition would influence the composition of the Gender and Human Rights COmmissions and the Office of the Public Protector.

"These are the institutions that in a sense are going to be the most important in implemnting policy around women's issues. There is clearly a great need for us in the Women's National Coalition to interact closely with Government institutions to ensure that women are represented in the new bodies that are being structured now."

Ngubane said the confernce agreed that the working relationship with Government structures needed to be clearly worked out. The WNC would have to play a monitoring, facilitating and challenging role "but not to agree to whatever Government gender policies are."

Dr.Meintjes added: "What we should be doing is to be looking to where power is located in Government and make that our point of pressure. To ensure that women's issues are not marginalised in the development of public policy and in the development of public institutions in this transformative period of South Africa's entry into a democratic society."

Reprinted from NEW NATION June 24,1994.

NEW NATION is published at Darragh House 13 Wanders St. Johannesburg. Tel:(011)333-2711 or (011)333-2721/2/3/4 Telex:482226 Fax:(011)889-0630.


LOAD-DATE: March 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


308 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 1, 1994 / October 31, 1994


THE GAMBIA: BEIJING 1995: THE CHALLENGE FOR THE AFRICAN WOMAN


SECTION: WOMEN


LENGTH: 920 words


 

In September 1995, the fourth World Conference on Women will take place in Beijing, China. The gathering of women from the world is preceded by three world conferences in Mexico, 1975, Copenhagen, 1980 and Nairobi, 1985. The objectives are to develop strategies vital to the assessment of the situation of women around the world.

At the last conference held almost 10 years ago in Nairobi, women at the conference developed what was termed as the Nairobi Forward Looking Strategy. The idea was developed in consideration of the state of women in the world which was assessed between 1975 and 1985. 

Prior to the start of the Beijing conference, African women will be converging in Dakar in November this year for the fifth series of African regional conferences on women.

They will, as in the past, be taking stock of how far African women have progressed or retrogressed in the implementation of regional and global strategies and plans of actions adopted to advance women in the region.

This fifth regional stock-taking follows four previous regional conferences which took place in Mauritania in 1977; Zambia in 1979; Tanzania in 1984; and Nigeria in 1989.

Saffiatou Singhhateh is flying The Gambia's colours as the executive director of the African Women's Development and Communication Network.

While on a visit here recently, she explained in an interview with the "Daily Observer" the essence of the Women's World Conference and the run-up to the African Preparatory Conference due to be held in Dakar in November.

She said that despite efforts being made by governments in Africa, such as an increase in proclamations on women and a rise in the number of women in parliament, women still encounter problems with their basic survival. Some countries, she said, have set up women's bureaus. "Some have impacts while others lack substance. It has been realized that ," she added, "that some countries have focal points in women's affairs."

Yet almost two decades on, the concerns and issues which provoked those earlier regional conferences remain high on the agenda. There is much unfinished business to tackle in order to further women's advancement and to ensure their full participation in the region's developmental efforts.

"The preparatory conference in Dakar, coming as it does after the Abuja Declaration on Participatory Development, will be crucial for reviewing and matching real achievements in the region with the targets set in the Abuja Declaration, "explained Mrs. Singhateh.

Like the third African regional conference of 1984 which came up with the Arusha strategies for the advancement of women and fed into the global Nairobi Forward-looking Strategies, adopted by consensus at the third World Conference, the Dakar meeting will serve as a regional preparatory meeting to the fourth World Conference on Women. "It will review and appraise the Nairobi Forward-looking Strategies and come up with the African platform for action which will be Africa's input into the global platform for action to be adopted in 1995."

From 4 to 15 September 1995, the fourth World Conference on Women will be staged in Beijing. Running concurrently with this inter-governmental meeting will be a forum for non-governmental organizations (NGOs).

Gertrude Mongella is secretary-general of the fourth World Conference on Women. She has been a strong advocate of women's rights. At a conference for African ministers responsible for economic development and planning in Addis Ababa last May, Mrs. Mongella urged African governments to facilitate the national and regional preparations for the world conference by providing both moral and financial support to the preparations, particularly at national level.

"I believe that Africa's development, and especially women's equality and their integration into development by the year 2000 and beyond, depend critically on the kinds of policies and development frameworks that are being put into place now at national, regional and international levels," Mrs. Mongella asserted.

The road from Nairobi through Abuja to Dakar with final destination in Beijing will be challenging for the African woman and therefore requires the full involvement and participation of all. The challenge is for us and we are confident that the whole region (women and men too) will rally to the cause in the crucial journey to Beijing.

Reprinted from DAILY OBSERVER, August 9, 1994.

DAILY OBSERVER is published at P.M.B. 131 Banjul, The Gambia. Tel: (220) 496608,496877,496878 Fax: (220) 496878


LOAD-DATE: March 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


309 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 1, 1994 / October 31, 1994


SOUTH AFRICA: DREAMING OF OLYMPIC GLORY BY MANSOOR JAFFER


LENGTH: 560 words


 

South African running sensation Hezekiel Sepeng dreams of the day he stands on the winners rostrum at the Olympic Games as 800m champion of the world.

He believes that thorouogh planning and preparation contribute to the realisation of dreams.

Right now, however, Sepeng is concentrating all his efforts on striking gold in the final matric exams next month. 

The Potchefstroom Boys High pupil told ChalkLine that he was studying hard for his finals.

"I missed loads of work while I was at the Commonwealth Games in Canada. Teachers assisted me with extra lessons on my return and I have managed to catch up."

Speneg, who will only race again early next year, said: "I feel confident that I will do well in the exams."

The 20-year-old, who rose from humble and poor beginnings as the son of a farmworker to an internationally known athlete, has applied to study public relations at Potchefstroom University next year.

He has triumphed despite the severe disadvantages which go with being in a right-wing Western Transvaal town.

In recent years he had to contend with racist comments from fellow pupils at the school. "I feel hurt inside," he said.

"But I know I am not allowed to hit them." He stressed, however, that "it is getting better now." Sepeng is the third eldest in a family of four boys and two girls. Like his brothers, Sepeng has a strong passion for soccer. "But soccer and athletics do not go together," he told ChalkLine. "If you get injured in a soccer match before a big athletics meeting then you can't run," he said. "So it is best to separate the two."

A few years ago Sepeng would not have in his wildest dreams imagined visiting countries such as Canada, Italy, Spain and Russia. He wishes that his father and mother, a domestic worker, could accompany him on one of his trips. But they don't have the money.

Sepeng has a bright future in athletics. He is the current South African 800m champion and has been unbeaten in the past athletic season.

He has also won silver medals at the South African junior champinoships and at the international Stockholm athletics meeting.

His advice to young athletes: "Determination and hard work is the key. Once you have made up your mind about what you want, go for it. Plan and you cannot go wrong."

Reprinted from SOUTH, September 23, 1994.

SOUTH is published at 76 Darling Street, Cape Town 8001. Tel:021 462 2012 Fax: 021 4615407


LOAD-DATE: March 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


310 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 1, 1994 / October 31, 1994


NIGERIA: DOWN-AND-OUT ON THE COURTS


BYLINE: Kayode Olaokun


SECTION: SPORTS


LENGTH: 1187 words


 

When Chuka Momah, a sports analyst assumed the leadership of the Nigerian Lawn Tennis Association, NLTA, in May 1991, he promised that the association will lay emphasis on its junior development programme which is aimed at discovering new junior players and exposing those who had emerged. At his inaugural press conference, Momah said his board which included veteran tennis stars like Thompson Onibokun, Lawrence Awopegba and Bowo Olagbegi, will set up a tennis academy where young players will be discovered, trained and exposed.

"Our aim is to expose as many children as we possibly can to the game of tennis. We would strive to ensure that the children in at least major cities of the country have a basic tennis knowledge," he declared. 

As if to prove his sencerity, Monah and his group indeed swung into action immediately. First, it set up a three-man coaching clinic headed by David Imonite, a former tennis player. The clinic was expected to translate into an academy. They also took a historic gamble in May 1992 when they did away with the services of Nduka Odizor, Nigeria's most prominent tennis player who had represented the country since 1986, to try junior players in a Davis Sup tie against Morocco. They experimented with Sule Ladipo, Emmanuel Udozor, Kyrian Nwokedi and Yakubu Suleiman, who were all teenagers at that time. Although, the team lost to Morocco 5-0, it launced the boys to big time tennis as they started performing well in international circuits. For once, it seemed as if Nigerian tennis had come of age and that the country now had replacements for Odizor, who had dominated the tennis scene for over a decade.

The hope soon faded when Alex Akinyele, the then chairman of National Sports Commission, NSC, without any reason dissolved the Momah-led board and replaced it with a new one headed by Kofi Fidelis, a brigadier-general whose resignation as chairman in 1991 led to the inauguration of the Momah-led board. The first decision taken by the board was to discontinue Momah's experimentation with junior players as they brought Odizor back into the country's Davis Cup team. Fidelis said then that he took the decision because Odizor despite having dropped off Association of Tennis Players, ATP, singles ranking remained the best Nigerian tennis player. "It is true Odizor had lost form. He can still beat any of the Nigerian players even immediately after waking up from sleep."

He was proved wrong as the Odizor-led team crumbled 5-0 to Romania in the Euro-African Zone Two play-off in April last year. This forced Fidelis to resort to the junior team in subsequent matches. But then the damage had been done. Most of the junior players, like Mohammed and Nwokedi, who were studying abroad had lost form because they could not play in the international circuits. They only played collegiate tennis to retain their scholarship. The new NLTA which should have helped them with funds seemed to lackj interest. They even suspended the ides of the academy for lack of funds. Only Sule Landipo, the current best player in the country managed to remain afloat, thanks to Rolf Wegner, his German trainer and sponser, who took over the management of his career immediately he left high school in Nigeria. He is now ranked 254 in the world and is a member of the International Tennis Federation, ITF, world touring team. This situation is symptomatic of the inconsistent policies by different helmsmen that have bedevilled Nigerian tennis.

Even now that Momah has been brought back by Sylvanus Akinwumi, who replaced Akinyele as NSC chairman, the junior development programme still remains a step away from success. Momah himself admits this much at an interview with Newswatch. He blames the situation on lack of enthousiasm among players, indiscipline, over-ambition and inadequate funds. The first major step in having a successful youth programme, he says, "is to have the kids willing to pay the price and make the sacrafice." He adds that is after this that one can start talking about money which he admits is a crucial factor in tennis development.

Lack of money has indeed been a major factor responsible for the decline in the fortunes of tennis in Nigeria. Erstwhile ATP recognised local international championships like Ogbe Hard Court, Okada Tennis Tournament, Lord Runners Classics which used to serve as launching pads for local players have been suspemded by ITF when they failed to meet the federation's standard. One of the rules set by ITF and which Nigerian sponsers of the championships have not been able to meet lately is that prize money for such championships be deposited with Men's International Tennis Council, MITC, six months in advance. Scarcity of foreign exchange and the fluctuation in the exchange rate of the naira has made the condition practically impossible to meet by Nigerian sponsors.

For instance, Ajsomo Alabi, who is the sole financier of the $75,000 prizemoney, Lord Rumen Classic requires about N3.8 million minus operational cost, to organise the tournament.

The suspension of these championships which gave Odizor vital ATP points in his days has been a great loss to budding tennis players in Nigeria. The situation is made worse because the NLTA is unable to raise enough money to send them to international circuits. "Right now, we are looking for money to send Godwin Omuta and Emmanuel Ehirim to participate in satellite tournaments. But where do we get a sponsor who will be willing to invest between $20,000 and $30,000 on each of the players for three years before they become self-sufficient?", Momah asked.

Hauwa-Kulu Akinyemi, secretary of NLTA while echoing Momah's views said that what the board does at the moment is to send junior players to junior championships in the sub-region where they could be picked by ITF for training. Three teenagers, Osaro Amandi, Sunday Maku and Lucy Michael were picked at last year's junior lawn tennis championship in Abidjan.

Reprinted from NEWSWATCH, October 3,1994

NEWSWATCH is published at P.M.B. 21499, Ikeja, Nigeria. Tel:4960950 Fax:962887 Telex:27874.


LOAD-DATE: March 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


October 1, 1994 / October 31, 1994


ZIMBABWE/SOUTH AFRICA: TRADE PACT ON CARDS


LENGTH: 374 words


 

Weekly Mail Reporter

Zimbabwe and South Africa have established a working group of senior government officials to review the outdated 1964 trade agreement and propose amendments aimed at enhancing two-way trade between Southern Africa's two largest economies.

Officials from the two countries, who met in Pretoria recently, have started consultations to investigate aspects of the agreement which need amending, before meeting again by the end of November this year to report back on their findings. 

Businessmen in Zimbabwe are anxious that a new preferential trade pact be signed, to allow them to widen their share of the South African market.

Industry sources in Harare said South Africa should remove or reduce punitive tariffs on selected products, such as textiles and clothing, as the first step towards enhancing bilateral trade, currently amounting to over R875-million a year.

South Africa slapped high import tariffs on textile products more than two years ago, mainly to protect its own industry from cheap imports from the Far East.

The action by South Africa severely affected the Zimbabwean textile sector, which was forced to retrench more than 5,000 workers during the past 18 month.

It is against this background that Zimbabwean businessmen are urging President Robert Mugabe's government to press for an early conclusion to the talks, which were started in 1992 but suspended just before South Africa's elections.

Presidents Nelson Mandela and Mugabe have expressed their commitment to a speedy resolution, saying it would promote development in the region.


LOAD-DATE: March 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


312 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 1, 1994 / October 31, 1994


UGANDA: AMERICAN FIRM TAKES OVER TROUBLED UCB


LENGTH: 574 words


 

ITT, a private American conglomerate, has won a contract to manage debt straddled Uganda Commercial Bank (UCB), the country's largest money house, according to the latest issue of the London-pubblished Africa Analysis newsletter.

UCB's story has been a litany of mismanagement, lending malpractices and corruption. Over an eight-year period, the bank gave out loans totalling Shs. 52.3bn ($52.3m) which it has failed to recover. 

But, as in the past, Africa Analysis warns, the debt-recovery exercise may get caught up in the web of local politics: many defaulters are high-ranking members of the government who are not keen on paying up. Some want the state to write off the debts, or cut them by half. The government is unlikely to oblige, and it has accepted to set up a Non-performing Loans Recovery Trust to clear the debts.

The newsletter also says that American organisations have virtually taken control of Uganda's commercial banks in an effort to save them from collapse.

The bail-out, it says, is being spearheaded by USAID and ITT. Other American corporations are also expected to participate in the proposed restructuring of the Bank of Uganda.

ITT (whose stable includes Sheraton Corporation, Hartford Insurance and ITT Rayonier) has sent in three specialists to help manage credit control, financial services and bank inspection.

They will also advise on a planned revision of UCB's 1965 act of incorporation - seen as vital for revitalising a bank which accounts for 60 percent of all credit in Uganda.

USAID is providing a $13m loan to the Co-operative Bank to shore up its capital reserves and stem losses, which reached Shs.2bn ($3.2m) in 1993. The bank is burdened with non-performing loans - liabilities outstrip assets by U. Shs. 5.4bn.

USAID has made the help for the Co-operative Bank conditional on radical cost-cuts. Staff numbers and the vehicle fleet are being pared down. The benefits are beginning to show: operating losses are down by 93 percent. Managing director Godfrey Nsubuga hopes for a profit this year and next and has announced plans to strengthen the bank's share capital with an injection of U.Shs. 300m ($300,000) in new money.

Apart from the scandalous political loans totalling U.Shs. 52.3bn. ($52.3m) over the past three years UCB has lost $12m on a rural credit scheme, after failing to impress on farmers the need to repay loans that many thought were grants.

Reprinted from THE MONITOR Oct 10-12,1994

THE MONITOR is published at P.O. Box 12111 Kampala. Tel: 236939 Fax: 251352


LOAD-DATE: March 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English
