313 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 1, 1994 / October 31, 1994


NIGERIA/SOUTH AFRICA: PARTNERSHIP GIANTS


BYLINE: Utibe Ukim


LENGTH: 1640 words


 

Nigeria and South Africa, the two strongest economies in Africa, are coming together in new trade partnerships made possible by the recent political reforms in the former apartheid state. It is a partnership informed by economic realities in the two countries and the need for the two economies to build new trade alliances which they desperately need.

"We are the two major economies in Africa," says Stephen Akinwolere, director-general of the Nigerian-South African Chamber of Commerce, NISAC, "and we must operate together. South Africa has the most developed market in Africa. Nigeria is the most extensive."

Last week, a trade delegation from the National Association of Chambers of Commerce, Industry, Mines and Agriculture, NACCIMA, left Lagos for Johannesburg, South Africa, for an exploratory trade visit to the country. The team is expected to sign bilateral trade agreements and reach a cooperative arrangements with the Johannesburg Chamber of Commerce. 

The delegation is the second from Nigeria to South Africa in the past month. Early September, officials of the NISAC spent 10 days in South Africa on its first preliminary business visit to that country. The 23-man team, led by Olu Adegbite and Stephen Akinwolere, president and director general of NISAC, met with officials of the South African Foreign Trade Organisation, SAFTO, as well as the Johannesburg Chamber of Commerce. At the end of the visit, the team signed a six-point mutual cooperation agreement, which among others provide for the hosting of an international seminar on trade between the two countries. The seminar is planned to hold in Lagos in next March. Both sides expect that a major trade policy will emerge at the end of the seminar.

As one of the emerging markets, South Africa's economy is said to worth $100 billion, bigger than the economies of half of the continent. The capitalisation of its main stock exchange, the Johannesburg Stock Exchange is put at $150 million, according to a report by the World Economic Forum, WEF, released at its last meeting in Cape Town, South Africa in June.

This is far ahead of the capitalisation of the stock exchanges in all other African countries combined. The WEF report puts the combined capitalisation of the stock exchanges in five countries with vibrant capital markets in Africa at $12 million. The countries include Nigeria, Zimbabwe and Namibia.

South African businesses find Nigeria attractive because it is the second strongest economy in the continent and the most extensive market. They are seeking to establish close working relations with Nigerian businesses. Says Charles Kuzmanitch, former head of the Africa desk at the South African Trade Organisation, SAFTO, "Nigeria and South Africa being the two strongest economies in Africa have got to look at joint efforts in the development of their regions."

SAFTO has since 1993 organised visits by six trade delegations to Nigeria. Another visit planned for June was postponed indefinintely because of the political crisis in Nigeria and the tension it generated. "Nigeria is a very good market for us to take clients into," Kuzmanitch told "NEWSWATCH". "We have taken six groups since we started. One reason why group visits to Nigeria has been so successful is that people are concerned about doing business with Nigeria."

He said 13 of the 15 people he took to Nigeria in 1993 have "done business and a number of them are going back to do business." Most of these businesses have been in the area of marketing investments. But he said service companies are also showing remarkable interest. We have service companies looking at Nigeria. Trade mark attorneys, patent attorneys, companies involved in the service area are asking to see what they can do in Nigeria," he said.

The interest in Nigeria reflects the zeal with which South African businesses want to take on international businesses. During the days of sanctions, most South African businesses traded in extreme secrecy. There were markets that they could not attempt to enter directly. Nigeria, with its leading role in its fight against apartheid, was one such markets. Products meant for the Nigerian market were usually shipped to Cote D'Ivoire from where they were transfered into Nigeria, usually with the country of origin missing.

A report by SAFTO, for instance, showed major transit points like Namibia, Lesotho, Zaire and Mauritius and Cote D'Ivoire as South Africa's major trading partners. These countries also served as the major transit point for exports to South Africa. Take oil for instance. That country bought Nigerisn oil regularly through indirect channels, and it may be Nigeria itself," Kuzmanitch said.

In most of the front-line states Zimbabwe, Zambia, Tanzania- South Africa has remained a major trading partner for many years." In the case of Zimbabwe, South Africa has always been our major trading partner" said Godfry Gomwe, chief executive officer of Cluff Resources, Zimbabwe, which owns the largest gold mine in that country.

What is happening now, Gomwe explains is that South Africa has moved into the playing field. Since the end of trade sanctions against it, trade has become an open affair. According to SAFTO's figures, South African export to Nigeria grew from about five million South African Rands (about $1.4 million, $1 = R3.6) in 1992 to R40 million in 1993, largely because of the end of trade sanctions.

South African desperately needs Nigerian oil. This country rich in precious metals like diamond, gold, uranium, iron ore and copper, does not have crude oil. "South Africa has got almost everything it needs in the industrial side except oil," said Kuzmanitch.

In looking to Nigeria it hopes to be able to import crude and the by-produccts. But more than that it wants to develop a market here for products from its industries. South African businesses are looking forward to replacing Western suppliers for the equipment required by the oil industry. And with strong agricultural and automative sectors, they are also looking forward to exporting finished and semi-finished agricultural and automative products to Nigeria.

Nigerian businesses are alos rushing to South Africa. Shehu Malami, chairman of Asea Brown Boveri, enjoys a high profile in the business community there. Last year, ABB moved the headquarters of its sub-Saharan department from Zurich to Johannesburg. That department carters for Nigeria and all the electricity transformers that ABB has been shipping into Nigeria have been comming from Johannesburg.

Malami remains the only non-South African director of Africa Initiative, an organisation formed in Johannesburg in 1993 to promote economic and commercial initiative across the continent. "I have a lot of confidence in South Africa," he told NEWSWATCH. His hopes is that South Africans would not only see Nigeria as a good market but a place to invest in.

Kuzmanitch says heavy infrastructural investments by South Africans in Nigeria may not be immediate because "South Africa is not a rich country as we are thought to be.

"Yes, we are a strong country. Yes, we arre a wealthy country but we do not have the capacity to mobilise external funds. We have been in a recession and we are trying to pick our way out of it. South Africa does not have enough money for its own needs," he said.

What is likely to happen is that the two countries will look towards joint venture partnership. "There are some technologies we can get from Nigeria, and there are some that we can give to Nigeria. We do not think of Nigeria in terms of products. We think of Nigeria in terms of cooperative ventures, he said. Akinwolere too says NISAC is not "looking at South Africa as a distributive market centre. We want to import South Africa's technology in exchange for Nigeria's variety of products and native intelligence. We don't see them as another trading outpost but as a trading partner with good heritage from which we can draw."

Reprinted from NEWSWATCH October 17,1994

NEWSWATCH is published at P.M.B. 21499, Ikeja, Nigeria. Tel:4960950 Fax:962887 Telex:27874


LOAD-DATE: March 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


314 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 1, 1994 / October 31, 1994


CONTINENT: FASTER GROWTH BUT NO ECONOMIC TURNAROUND


BYLINE: Roy Laishley


SECTION: BUSINESS/ECONOMICS


LENGTH: 1227 words


 

Africas 20-year decline in per capita incomes is set to continue for most countries despite consensus from forecasters on faster growth this year and, says the World Bank, for the rest of the decade. The latest predictions from multilateral institutions suggest growth for 1994 of 2.0-3.4 per cent, against annual population growth of some 3 per cent. In its relatively bullish forecast, the International Monetary Fund (IMF) predicts growth rising to 4.5 per cent in 1995. All reviews, however, agree on Africa's "precarious and disturbing" economic situation, the conclusion drawn by Mr.Layashi Yaker, Executive Secretary of the UN's Economic Commission for Africa (ECA), in a 1994 review of African economies.

The higher growth projections hinge mainly on an upturn in commodity prices. But having reached their lowest levels ever in real terms in 1993, the roughly 5 per cent improvement in prices being predicted will not be sufficient to stimulate the growth needed to significantly improve living conditions for most Africans. 

"The prognosis for overall growth in (the sub-Saharan African) region is sobering... income per capita and, more important, private consumption per capita are unlikely to see much increase for a third decade in a row," says the World Bank's "Global Economic Prospects and the Developing Countries". Its prediction of average 3.9 per cent growth over the next decade is higher than earlier forecasts, but is still well short of the 5 per cent plus needed to reverse the fall in incomes. If the fate of earlier forecasts is repeated, the Bank's low-growth estimate of 2.4 per cent will prove more realistic and incomes will continue to decline.

"Growth"--Last year was another disaster for Africa, with overall growth just 1-1.5 per cent. Since 1990, African economies have grown an average 1.3 per cent which, the ECA says, means a yearly fall in per capita income of 1.7 per cent.

However, experience was diverse. Oil exporters recorded their lowest growth since 1988, reports the UN's "World Economic and Social survey 1994". Central African countries suffered most, with gross domestic product (GDP) down 4.6 per cent. East African countries fared best, though 2.6 per cent growth was still below the rate of population increase.

Encouragingly, says the ECA, 11 countries (up from seven in 1992) enjoyed growth of 5 per cent or more. This covered some 20 per cent of Africa's population. GDP failed to match population growth in 30 out of 51 countries in 1993, four less than in 1992. But countries averaging growth of 5 per cent or more since the mid-1980s cover under 3 per cent of Africa's population.

Ethiopia exemplifies how misleading the figures on Africa can be. Estimated 1993 GDP growth of 9.3 per cent says more about the economy's rebound from earlier devastation than about current living standards. This year the country is facing the worst famine since 1984.

According to the IMF'S "World Economic Outlook", North African economies should experience a stronger performance in 1994. And for South Africa, most forecasts expect progress from around 1 per cent in 1993 to some 3 per cent in 1994. Unlike the ECA, which points more cautiously to the short-term costs of the CFA franc devaluation in January, the IMF predicts a turnround in franc zone economies, with the exception of Cameroon, followed by strong growth in 1995.

"Trade"--A surge in the price of most commodities in the first half of 1994 has reinforced hopes of a general upturn in growth for Africa this year. A strong showing by oil prices in the second quarter could mean a better-than-forecast performance by oil exporters. After six years of watching prices decline ot their lowest level ever, cocoa and coffee producers could enhoy a 25 and 50 per cent increase in prices respectively between 1993 and 2000. Only copper, iron ore, oil, tea and tobacco out of Africa's manor exports face a downturn in real terms in 1994, says the World Bank. And t o date, both copper and oil are defying that trend.

With better prospects for commodities, the UN is predicting positive terms of trade for African economies in 1994, a 2.5 per cent improvement, for the first time since 1990. In 1993, Africa's terms of trade fell between 3.5 and 5.5 per cent, causing a loss of at least $3 bn, while imports rose only marginally to $75.9bn, according to the ECA.

"Finance"--Private financial flows are booming everywhere but Africa, the UN reports in its 1994 "World Economic and Social Survey". Private outflows from Africa rose to over $61e ban in 1993 from $53.5 bn in 1992 as capital flight continued and foreign investors stayed away.

Official transfers rose to close to $82 bn, up a relatively healthy 11 per cent. But there is a "considerable risk" of lower net resource flows to Africa, the World Bank warns, as donor cutbacks and competing claims dig into Africa's share of the aid pie. The UN reports that net transfers of financial resources to Africa were still negative, but at $200 mn, represented the smallest outflow since the negative trend began in 1990. For sub-Saharan Africa (excluding Nigeria and South Africa), net transfers were down, at $8.6 bn from $9.8 bn in 1992, but still positive and still up on late-1980s levels.

The ECA and the African Development bank estimate that Africa's stock of debt rose to $285.4 bn in 1993, from $278.8 bn in 1992, equivalent to almost 96 per cent of GDP. For sub-Saharran Africa, the debt burden rose to over 123 percent of GDP (113.9 per cent in 1992). Debt-service, however, declined to the equivalent of 24.4 percent of African export earnings (from 26.3 per cent in 1992). Sub-Saharan Africa's ratio fell dramatically to 13.2 per cent from 18.8 per cent, says the ECA. But this reflects a growing inability to pay rather the success of debt relief efforts, which continue to be inadequate, all reviews note.

Reprinted from AFRICA RECOVERY April-September 1994.

AFRICA RECOVERY is published in English and French by the Promotion and External Relations Division of the United Nations Department of Public Information, with support from UNDP and UNICEF. Secretariat Room 931. United Nations, New York 10017. Tel:(212) 963-6857. Fax:(212) 963-1193


LOAD-DATE: March 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


315 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 1, 1994 / October 31, 1994


NIGERIA: THE IDEAL NIGERIA BY RAY EKPU


LENGTH: 2600 words


 

In the last few years of the Ibrahim Bagangida administration, there was a growing sensitivity to th federal character question. According to an informed source, the government had perfected a strategy on the manner of release of hte names of appointees to federal positions. It was a kind of name-arranging game.

Whenever names of appointees were to be released by the government to the public through the media, the conventional formats didn't seem to matter, not alphabetical order of names or of states, not necessarily seniority of officers or sex (ladies first) of appointees. The government had noted based on observation that it was necessary to mix the order in which the names appeared, so that names of people from one ethnic group were not bunched up, rather they were all scattered throughout the list. The scattering strategy was to remove the impression of concentration and make the weight of numbers from certain ethnic groups not too massive.

But trust Nigerians. They will find out truth. They reach for their calcultors and do the numbers game: they pick out from their book shelves a book titled "How to Identify Tribes from names" And work it all out. That way they know whether their ethnic group has been short-changed or whether this time they're in or out, or in but not quite in or whether this time they have, again, been, to use a favorite buzzword, marginalised. 

This name-scattering game didn't always result in a win for the government, no matter how hard it tried. A few years ago, Babangida was severely criticised for lopsidedness in the composition of the Armed Forces Ruling Council, AFRC. His reply: "There is no north, no south. No Christianity and no Islam. Merit is the only consideration. "His words were a good political slogan, suitable for an election campaign. It was a statement on the Ideal Nigeria, the one we are yet to attain, not a statement on teh Real Nigeria, the one in which we currently live.

For a country like Nigeria with some 250 ethnic groups and 513 languages and dialects, any leader who satisfies all these interests must have to have a superhuman, legendary powers. In a heterogeneous federation, the central government must remain the glue that binds the federating states by the representativeness of its appointments and the fairness of its actions generally. It was via the view to addressing the problem of domination and its flip side, marginalisation, that the Constitution Drafting Committee, argued that "in view of Nigeria's history of inter-ethnic rivalry to secure the domination of government by one ethnic group or a combination of ethnic groups to the exclusion of others, it is essential to have some provisions to ensure that the predominance of persons from a few states or from a few ethnic or other sectional groups is avoided in the composition of government or election of persons to high offices in the state."

They were obliged. For the first time the concept of federal character was inserted in the 1979 constitution. Section 14(3) states that , "That composition of the government of the federation or any of its agencies and the conduct of its affairs shall be carried out in such a manner as to reflect the federal character of Nigeria and the need to promote national unity and also to command national lolalty, therby ensuing that there shall be no predominance of persons from a few states or from a few ethnic or other sectional groups in that government or in any of its agencies."

Has the implementation of the federal character principle promoted national unity and commanded national loyalty? It is doubtful. First, the policy is actually difficult to implement, and secondly, the implementation is done selectively. How do you reflect federal character? By numerical equality or representativeness of ethnic groups or of geographical spread or should amenities be allocated by number or by worth? At what level of appointment should quota or proportionality be applied - at the entry point or at more senior level? How do you acheive proportionality without sacraficing quality or merit or efficiency or morale within the public service?

In February, 1992, some fellows who identified themselves as "Admirers of AAA" had inserted a satirical advert in some newspapers. It was headed "Congratulations" and it ran thus: "We must heartily congratulate the Hon. Minister of Finance and Sardauna of Sokoto, Alhaji Abubakar Alhaji on his recent appointments of chief executives of the 13 federal government controlled commercial and merchant banks. The appointments are a demonstration of the indefitable minister's evenhandedness and unflinching commitment to the federal structure of Nigeria. The following breakdown proves this to the hilt: Hausa/ Fulani7; Yoruba5; Igbos1; Northern Minorities0; Southern Minorities0."

The names of the managing directors and the banks were listed. The advert was rounded off with "All Hail One Nigeria," a satirical commentary on what could be a drawback to having one united Nigeria, which has been the refrain of most, if not all Nigerian leaders.

Because of the circumstance of the marriage, a kind of shotgun marriage between the Northern and Southern Protectorates in 1914, virtually every Nigerian leader has preached the sermon of "a united Nigeria." Here were two territories similar in several but different in many respects including culture, religion and education being merged in a marriage of convenience. The overt incompatability inherent in that marriage gave birth to the expression "unity in diversity."

In apparent acknowledgement of the difficulty in welding such groups together, Nigerian leaders never failed to harp on the unity theme in their public speeches. Abubakar Tafawa Balewa, Nigeria's first prime minister and Nnamdi Azikiwe, first president, all preached from time to time the sermon of national unity. Even Chukwuma Nzeogwu, the army major whose January 1966 coup ended up disuniting the country, started off on a optimistic declaration "to establish a strong, united and prosperous nation, free from corruption and internal strife."

Quite ironically it was in the bid to establish unity that J.T.U. Aguiyi-Ironsi, the major-general who inherited the federal government from Nzeogwu that he, Ironsi, opted for a unitary system of government which was opposed by the north. While past leaders of the Nigerian federation had made declaration now and again on what ought to be the nation's guiding objectives it was not until October 1970 that the nation had a clear-cut set of objectives.

Yakubu Gowon, in launching the Second National Development Plan 1970-74, listed five national objectives: (a) A united , strong and self-reliant nation, (b) A great and dynamic economy, (c) A just and egalitarian society, (d) A free and democratic society.

The government published a booklet titled "National Guidelines for thwe Protection of Nigeria's Philosophy and Action" to explain its goals.

Some of these objectives have been given lip-service by various governments emphasised on depended on the problems it faced at the time and its visions of how to tackle them. In his inaugural address July 29, 1974 Murtala Muhammed who overthrew the Gowon government that had been accused of drifting and condoning corruption, talked of sacrafice, self-discipline and declared that his "government will not condone abuse of office." He went ahead and sanctioned 10 out of Gowon's 12 governors and purged the public service of the corrupt and indolent.

In his famous Jaji address in September 1977 Olusegun Obasanjo, who stepped in after Muhammed's assassination February 13, 1976, described the Nigeria "we are aspiring to build as a disciplined, fair, just and humane African society." Shehu Shagari who took over from Obasanjo as president in 1979 said that "our domestic policies will be geared towards making Nigeria a united, peaceful and economically self-reliant nation" at a dinner on the eve of his inauguration. His economic policies which were marred by corruption, profligacy and the large-scale of both necessaries and luxuries were not likely to lead to realisation of "an economically self-reliant nation." But his strength was his faith in the slogan "One nation, One Destiny" which he tried totranslate into reality not only by shooting his forefinger into the sky but in actually trying to extend his friendship to political foes across the land. His effort met with several road blocks: the Bendel State Government attempted to stop him from visiting the state, the Oyo State Government demolished some federal government houses in the area, for example.

The Muhammadu Buhari government faced with the political rascality of the politicisans his government had just sacked and the tottering economy they left behind gound himself in a war-mongering mood. He declared on taking over as head of state January 1,1984: "This government will not tolerate kickbacks, inflation of contracts and over-invoicing of imports nor will it condone forgery, fraud, embezzlement, misuse and abuse of office and illegal dealings in foreign exchange and smuggling."

Many people admitted that his government had instituted sanity into the chaotic life of the Nigerian and had made a bold effort to control the leakages in the economy but they objected to the government's use of the tactics of a drill sergant, the extreme step of killing trakkickers, detaining people without trial. Perhaps, the chink in his government moral armour was the 53 suitcases which passed through the airport unchecked at a time that the government had insisted everyone and every luggage must pass through the needle's eye of a rigorous search.

His successor, Ibrahim Babangida, declared on assumption of office August 27, 1985: "Let us all dedicate ourselves to the cause of building a strong, united and viable nation for the sake of our own lives and the benefit of prosperity." We probably dedicated to this cause. We embarked on political restructuring of the country through the creation of more states and local governments. We tried a restructuring of the economy through privatisation, a measure of deregulaiton, creation of new financial institutions, devaluation and debt management but lapses in policy implementation, exemptions through the back door corrupt practices and frequent policy changes have successfully stalled the growth of the economy, and stymied our hope for an early recovery. What's more, the inexplicable annulment of the June 12,1993 election has left the country weak and deeply divided and made the talk of a united nation academic. The rowdy debates at the Constitutional Conference last week, testify to this. Babangida's characterisation of the state of the nation on his assumption of office was that of "a bewildered nation." At his exit, the country could be characterised as a beleagured nation.

The two governments that have followed the Babangida government, the Ernest Shonekan government christened "a child of circumstance" and the Sani Abacha government dressed as "a child of necessity" have harped, understandably on the unity theme. Shonekan's desire was to move the country foward as a "united , indivisable nation," while Abacha seeks to "bulid a united and peaceful Nigeria." Since Babangida's exit "unity" and "peace" have been quite elusive because of the post election trauma. The search for both must obviously mean the subordination of other national objectives. However, "fairness" and "justice" have, in the past one year or so become much more than indefinable philosophical concepts. They've grown into tangible, touchable props on which the nation's present and future ride. They present themselves in various forms: June 12, Ogoni and Co, Madueke and Chris Alli, revenue alloocation, you can add to the list. But the struggle for fairness and justice is not limited by time or space. It is a universal struggle, one that transcends Nigeria and transcends Abacha's government. They're not isssues that'll go away tomorrow morning or the day after because the way the world is arranged, human beings and groups prefer to hold on to what they have, they prefer to enjoy the comforts that privileged settings offer, they prefer to be in a situation that gives them a head start all the time, they prefer if they can, to put the other guy in his place, that is below them.

Gowon's definition of our national objectives is the most comprehensive. It remains the benchmark. If we have not achieved all or even most of them it is because we have adopted, over the years, policies that are disincentive to unity, to the erection of a just and egalitarian society, in education, politics, economy, in appointments, in the provision of amenities, in the sharing of our national patrimony. We have failed to tackle decisively such monsters as corruption, proflgacy, mismanagement, ethnicity, religious and other forms of fanaticism; We have failed to cut down root and branch the evils that have haunted us for 34 years. We make beautiful constitutions but we never let them work. We formulate beautiful policies but we deface them by creating sacred cows. We are fortunate to have wealth dropped on our laps but we're so greedy we want to steal everything.

To remake Nigeria we must start afresh, keep our objectives in sight and work honestly, assiduously, selflessly towards those goals. We may not always achieve the ideal but we must be seen to be working towards it.

Reprinted from NEWSWATCH October 10,1994.

NEWSWATCH is published at P.M.B. 21499, Ikoja, Nigeria. Tel:4960950 Fax:962887 Telex:27874


LOAD-DATE: March 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


316 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 1, 1994 / October 31, 1994


SOUTH AFRICA: THE BIGGEST THREAT TO PRESS FREEDOM


SECTION: COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 720 words


 

Recent criticism by the ANC of the treatment it has received in the press has generated much concern in the media.

Many in the press community have thrown their hands up in protest against suggestions from government, and particularly the ANC, that newspapers have been unnecessarily critical of the new administration

The National Party has warned that utterances from within the ANC did not bode well for press freedom.

And others in the media world have interpreted comments by President Mandela and his deputy Thabo Mbeki as an ominous signal of dark days to come. 

We in the independent media community know better than most what the denial of press freedom means. We endured it in its most unadulterated form under the National Party government.

This newspaper was banned twice in terms of the state of emergency and numerous other times in terms of the Publications Control Act.

We should therefore have been in the forefront to lead the chorus against the threat to press freedom.

But we are concerned that those who have been most vocal in their protests have ignored the fact that the greatest threat to press freedom has been the monopolization of the mass media in the hands of a tiny white minority.

This is reflected, not only in the ownership of the media, but also in the staffing at senior levels of South Africa's major newspapers by white men.

Without any doubt press freedom in this context translates into little more than the freedom to ensure that government can be criticized-- but only to the extent that the interests of big business are protected.

Not much more can really be expected of newspapers owned by big business. Nevertheless it is their democratic right and must not be tampered with.

But it needs to be said that the role of media in general goes beyond safeguarding the interests of a fraction of a narrow constituency, despite its economic predominance in society.

There are also the interests of the vast majority, which has over centuries been disempowered economically and, until April this year, politically as well.

As a result, their aspirations and interests have hardly found adequate expression in the established mass media.

If the protests recently heard are to translate into anything meaningful, newspaper monopolies will have to begin shedding some of the control they have over the mass media.

Meaningful steps must be taken to ensure that ownership of newspapers and control begin to reflect the demographics of South African society.

It needs to be said that this empowerment we advocate must translate into genuine control and go beyond economic empowerment which only addresses monetary imbalances.

It must mean political empowerment as well, because it is only those who stand to benefit most from the new democracy that can be trusted to defend it with any genuine commitment.

Unless the media monopolies act decisively in this regard, there is the real risk that press freedom will be reduced to little more than a fetish that will not help consolidate the country's hard-earned democracy.

Reprinted from New Nation.

Published by New Nation Publishing Co., 1st Floor P.O. Box 10674, Johannesburg 2000 Darraagh House, 13 Wanderers Street, Johannesburg.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


October 1, 1994 / October 31, 1994


MUSEVENI THROWS GOVERNMENT THIEVES INTO DONORS' JAWS


BYLINE: Dismas Nkundu


LENGTH: 800 words


 

President Yoweri Museveni has okayed a deal which is very bad news for corrupt politicians, government officials and managers of state-owned companies.

Recently Museveni agreed to open up government and parastatals' books of accounts for external examination in return for a reduction of Uganda's US$2.6 bn (Ug. Shs. 2.6 trillion) debt.

The president's Press Secretary, Ms. Hope Kivengere, confirmed to The Monitor that President Museveni proposed at a reception held in his honour in London June this year that donors were free to inspect the government books since his government had nothing to hide.

According to the London-based centre for Accountability and Debt Relief, Museveni "offered a unique challenge to World Bank and IMF which hold Uganda's debt in recognition of the government's committment to keep its financial affairs fully transparent, accountable and subject to continuing audit." 

The donors are certain to find all the evidence that the NRC's Public Accounts Committee has been stumbling on the shocking cases of corruption.

An informed source told The Monitor that; "even if that was the case, an agreement could be reached to tie the reduction levels to progress on eliminating corruption and embezzlement."

If the Museveni proposal fires up, Uganda could well become the first country in the developing world to benefit from a debt reduction package agreed upon during the last conference of industrialized nations in Paris.

Museveni's ideas were warmly welcomed by the influential Centre for Accountability and Debt Relief which said that "Museveni's offer should be seen as the correct way forward for all troubled borrowers world wide."

The NRM government has been tainted by corruption, partly because of its failure to crack-down on corruption. In some instances, people linked to corruption have been promoted, giving the view that the government-at worst- has chosen to turn a blind eye.

Museveni has himself spoken in very terse terms about corruption and threatened to take drastic action, but beyond brave words, he has still shied away from the fight.

At the London meet, Museveni also pledged to bring all available resources to bear against corruption by any of his own government ministers and civil servants. This time though, the price for stemming graft is attractive and there might be some credible action.

The donor community has promised to waive off part of Uganda's debt after auditing all the other monies that have been loaned to Uganda.

Uganda's economic recovery and liberalisation has impressed the donor community (even if less so Ugandans) and was lauded at the recent consultive meeting in Paris which who gave US$820m for the budget year 1994/1995. This was more than the Uganda government had requested.

During the London meeting Museveni is reported to have said that it is not a good idea to wipe off entirely the whole debt because this might give a wrong signal, that nations can incur debts and not pay back.

If implemented Uganda will become the second country after Tanzania to open its books to external examination. In May this year the government in Dar es Salaam allowed donors working with the Auditor-General to audit ministries, parastatall and NGO's to curb misuse of donor funds.

According to a London newsletter Africa Analysis, governments which went by the IMF reform programmes and have a reliable record of debts payments would be extended the cancellation of some of their debt owed to the Paris club.

Ministry of Finance and Economic Planning officials were not available for comment.

Reprinted from THE MONITOR, September 19-21 1994.

THE MONITOR is published at P.O. Box 12141, Kampala. Tel(general):236939. Tel(editor's line):251353. Fax:251352


LOAD-DATE: March 24, 1995

Africa News


October 1, 1994 / October 31, 1994


UGANDA: NYERERE WARNS TRIBALISTS


BYLINE: Kyazze Simwogerere


LENGTH: 1187 words


 

In a brilliant soul-searching speech that will be remembered for long in the Constituent Assembly (CA), former Tanzanian President Mwalimu Julius Nyerere yesterday tackled the twin issues of tribalism and national unity.

The graying socialist, in his signature collar-less suit, was a guest speaker to the CA fourth of a six -day visit to Uganda.

Tribalism was clearly on top of Nyerere's agenda. Nyerere, who quit politics voluntarily in 1985, said he shared with the delegates his shock when he came to Uganda as a student in 1943, when he witnessed how tribalism and religious bigotry were over-played here. 

"We had more tribes in Tanzania than in Uganda and Kenya put together, but I think we succeeded in defeating tribalism," Nyerere said.

He said he had even abolished the business of asking for people's religions and tribes during the Population Census.

"We as the government do not give service to Christians as Christians, so why do we want to know how many Christians there are?" Nyerere recalled.

Nyerere remembered someone once asking him how many Catholics (like himself), were cabinet ministers.

"I thought and thought; and other than myself, there was only one other Catholic," he said.

"And he was a polygamist!" (the delegates roared with laughter). Nyerere said that he did not even know which tribe or religion his cabinet ministers belonged to , and preached the doctrine of de-emphasizing the tribe to build nations in Africa.

"African countries are new, artificial, vulnerable and the only entity that is understood and is natural is the tribe," Mwalimu said. He came even closer home, to Uganda.

"What future is there in Batooro, Banyoro?"

"There is no future there at all. It is absolutely useless; emphasizing your tribe is absurd!" Nyerere said, as the Assembly reverberated with applause. More than a few heads were bowed in despair, as the words against tribalism sunk.

Nyerere gave the example of European countries, built over hundreds of years, but which are still looking for unity up to now.

"These countries were built by Kings and Queens, supported by armies, not by political parties," he said, adding that only African countries were being built by political parties. He wanted to stop here because he thought they knew what he meant, but delegates--thirsting for more, urged him on.

He said that Western democracies, strong and united as they are, "still perceive this unity as not enough and they are looking to a higher unity."

"The Europeans are doing this so that they can face the 1 billion Chinese, the Japanese, the Americans," he said.

"We in Africa, in 1994, we are still thinking in terms of tribes. What chance can we have in the 21st century?"

In a gesture of humility, Nyerere also conceded that he, and his generation of African leaders, tried to create an East African Federation. And failed which shamed him sometimes.

"We lost; but I am saying that don't give up. Every generation achieves what it can. For us we got rid of colonialism," Nyerere said.

"Your generation should think of the future of the continent." Unknown to Nyerere of course was that many delegates he was addressing were not of this generation, and that some were actually around before his time.

And a word of counsel for African leaders.

"Africa cannot afford unprincipled leaders at all," he said. He begged the delegates to give Uganda a chance, a new lease on life.

He recalled the glorious years of Uganda, the Pearl of Africa, the place where everybody, including himself, came to study.

"You have suffered too much, you lost all those years," Nyerere said, in a halting, breaking voice.

He implored Ugandans to preach "peace and stability" and work for it too.

"Peace and stability are not like this morning's rain, which fell without you asking it!" he said comically.

"Building a country requires intelligence and hard work."

Breaking up a country does not require any intelligence at all!" he said indignantly.

He gave as example, the Russian Parliament Building in Moscow which was razed by tanks while a journalist standing nearby (CNN) described its demise.

"He said that this building took 20 years to build; now it is taking 20 minutes to destroy," Nyerere recalled.

The Mwalimu implored the delegates not to dream of the things in Europe and America, implying the luxuries of multi-parties, which he advised should be shelved.

After his beautiful 45 minute speech, Nyerere was given an unprecedented standing ovation, as well as a bouquet from CA Chairman James Wapakhabulo who called Nyerere "one of the leading sons of Africa."

Wapakhabulo remembered how many Ugandans took refuge in Nyerere's Tanzania during the bad times, "and I am sure if I asked them to stand up here, there would be a forest!" Wapa said.

Ambassador Katenta Apuuli (CP Del.) moving a vote of thanks, told the Mwalimu : "You belong to a very special group of African leaders who stepped down from power." That group includes only Nyerere and Senegal's first President Leopold Senghor, who retired in 1980, Ahmad Ahijido of Cameroon, and Siaka Stevens of Sierre Leone.

Reprinted from The Monitor Friday, September 23-26, 1994

The Monitor is published by The Monitor Publications Ltd. P.O. Box 12141, Kampala, Uganda. Tel: 236939


LOAD-DATE: March 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


October 1, 1994 / October 31, 1994


SUDAN: IGADD STAYS THE COURSE IN SPITE OF KHARTOUM'S ARROGANCE


LENGTH: 534 words


 

SUDAN DEMOCRATIC GAZETTE

Following the collapse of the Intergovernmental Authority on Drought and Development (IGADD) mediated talks on 8 September, the four heads of state of the IGADD countries resolved on 19 September, at their summit in Nairobi, to stay on course and preserve with their efforts to find a lasting peaceful solution to Sudan's conflict. In addition, they called upon the international community to support their efforts.

The four heads of state, Daniel arop Moi of Kenya, Yoweri Museveni of Uganda, Meles Zinawi of Ethiopia and Isias Afworki of Eritrea, held a one day summit in Nairobi, Kenya to reaffirm their commitment to peace, pointing out that they were not dispassionate observers to the Sudanese conflict but in fact concerned neighbors with a vested interest in bringing peace to that country. They pointed out that the waste of innocent lives and the impediment to development, which the war has brought to Sudan, has also affected their four countries. 

The Statement

Their joint statement, issued after a one day summit in Nairobi on 19 September said: "The heads of state of the IGADD Committee on the Sudanese Conflict have today decided that the IGADD initiative should continue. The talks had reached a deadlock on the vital issues of separation of state and religion and on the question of Self-determination for Southern Sudan.

"The heads of state consider the Declaration of Principles (DOP) agreed during the talks to continue. The heads of state will seek collective and appropriate means to re-inforce the on going IGADD initiative with a view to reaching a final settlement of the problem."

One of the heads of state, speaking to the Gazette after the Nairobi summit, said that some of the Sudanese parties to the conflict were labouring under the misconception that the IGADD countries would eventually lose interest in the conflict and leave the Sudanese to continue fighting amongst themselves. This is not the case. He stated that he has watch the Sudanese kill each other for too long. Originally the IGADD countries assumed that the Sudanese would be capable of resolving the conflict themselves. When, forty years on, it became apparent that they were not, the IGADD leaders were left with few options but to act positively. He hoped that the international community would give the IGADD peace effort the support it needs to succeed.

Reprinted from SUDAN DEMOCRATIC GAZETTE.

SUDAN DEMOCRATIC GAZETTE is published by Bona Malwal, P O Box 2295, London, W14 OND, UK.


LOAD-DATE: March 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


320 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 1, 1994 / October 31, 1994


OUTCRY OVER TOXIC WASTE IMPORT PLAN


LENGTH: 1147 words


 

Environmental groups have promised drastic action if Dawie de Villiers' proposal to allow the importation of toxic waste goes ahead, writes Eddie Koch TOXIC waste shipments will be allowed into the country, according to new policy devised by Environment Minister Dawie de Villiers. The move overturns a current ban on toxic waste imports and would make South Africa one of only two African countries that trades in industrial poisons.

Environmental groups promise a nationwide campaign of civil disobedience if the proposal goes ahead and say they will mobilise support from the ANC and its allied organisations, who support a total ban on all toxic imports.

A White Paper gazetted this month says the existing embargo on toxic imports into the country is not in South Africa's interests and proposes o create regions in the country where toxic material from overseas countries can be dumped. 

"A blanket ban on transboundary movement of such wastes would ... jeopardise and impact adversely on present economic and industrial activities," says the document.

The proposal flies in the face of ANC policy that states: "We will not allow our country to become a dumping ground for toxic waste."

"The only reason that other countries would pay South Africa to take their toxic waste is because contractors here are allowed to cut corners that contractors in countries such as the United States and the Netherlands would be jailed for doing," says Chris Albertyn of Earthlife Africa.

"The first costs to be cut are those of protecting the health of workers and pollution of the environment ..."

Every other government on the continent backs Organisation of African Unity resolutions which prohibit any form of toxic material being dumped here. The OAU has also adopted the Bamako Convention which bans all imports of hazardous wastes into the content.

A discussion document on foreign policy, released recently by the ANC, recommends that South Africa sign the convention. The move by De Villiers' department is thus likely to open rifts in the cabinet between the ANC and the National Party, which allowed toxic imports when it was in power.

Environmental groups reject the White Paper's claim that South Africa has the technical expertise to dispose of toxic materials in a safe way. They say recent incidents at the Thor Chemicals plant in Natal demonstrate how incompetent local authorities are in handling these imports.

A director and two senior officials from Thor, a British-owned firm with a plant at Cato Ridge near Pietermaritzburg, are currently facing culpable homicide charges after two workers died after being exposed to high levels of mercury toxins. Another worker has been in a coma for three years due to the exposure and 28 others are diagnosed as having mercury poisoning symptoms.

Thor was provided with a permit by the old government to import large amounts of toxic materials from the United States. Rivers in the region have been also been polluted by large amounts of mercury leakages from the plant. The scandal led to the current ban being slapped on all shipments of waste into the country.

Earthlife Africa says it is mobilising its branches and allied organisations in the civic and trade union movements to resist the proposal. "There will be civil disobedience on a major scale if this passes into law," warns Albertyn.

The document stipulates that a strict set of minimum standards will be developed to minimise threats from transboundary movements of toxic waste and the storage of these materials. This has been supplemented by three volumes, produced by the Department of Water Affairs, which lay down detailed guidelines for managing waste.

Officials in the Environment Department defend the paper by noting it meets requirements of the Basel Convention, an international agreement designed to ensure effective controls on transboundary movements of toxic materials.

It endorses the "polluter pays" principle which states that anyone guilty of damaging the environment by mishandling waste be forced to pay for reparations. This concedes to a demand that has long been made by the environmental movement.

The document also supports the "cradle to grave" principle, which provides for control of the entire waste cycle from the point of production to the recycling, destruction or safe disposal of these materials.

Willem Scott, deputy director in charge of pollution control at the Department of Environment Affairs, told the Weekly Mail & Guardian the proposed relaxation on toxic imports was intended "only as a last resort under special circumstances" and there was no plan for South Africa to become a major player in the trade.

He said South Africa was not snubbing the rest of Africa by allowing limited imports as many countries on the continent were party to the Basel Convention which guides the principles of the White Paper.

Human rights lawyers and green activists are worried that the proposed legislation specifically excludes organised labour from taking part in the management of toxic imports and dumping. The Thor case, they argue, shows that factory workers are frequently the first to suffer and play a vital watchdog role.

According to the department, the proposal will not become law until it has been subjected to scrutiny. "The public will be given ample opportunity to comment before it is finalised," said Scott.


LOAD-DATE: March 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


321 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 1, 1994 / October 31, 1994


INTELLIGENCE AGENTS 'SNOOPING' IN RDP BUSINESS


LENGTH: 1227 words


 

Agents of the previous government's National Intelligence Service have been displaying an unusual interest in the RDP, report Drew Forrest and Wiseman Khuzwayo

The National Intelligence Service (NIS) has taken it upon itself to police the reconstruction and development programme -- provoking an angry response from President Nelson Mandela's office and the office of RDP Minister Jay Naidoo.

The Weekly Mail & Guardian knows of two cases where NIS agents have approached individuals, claiming to be acting on behalf of the RDP. In one case, the intelligence agency interviewed a senior official of the Pretoria branch of the South African National Civics Organisation (Sanco).

NIS comprises the intelligence agents of the previous, white-dominated government. It has yet to be integrated into the new, legitimate structures of the National Intelligence Community (NIC), which will include members of the ANC's department of intelligence and security (DIS). 

Questioned this week about the NIS's role in respect of the RDP, its spokesman, Willem Theron, confirmed their interest in backing up the government policy: "The NIS and a future intelligence agency's role is to provide the government with intelligence on any matter related to security and stability."

"The successful implementation of the RDP is seen as a key element of ensuring social and political stability, and as such the NIS is instrumental in providing the government of national unity with timely intelligence on any aspect threatening the government's programmes, including the RDP." He declined to give specifics.

This has provoked an immediate response, with experts and politicians pointing out that it is the NIS's role to protect the security of the state, not to ensure the smooth-running of government policy; the NIS is charged with watching those who break the law, not those who oppose government policy.

Military consultant Jakkie Cilliers, director of the Institute for Defence Policy, expressed concern that actions taken in the name of the RDP may just be duplicating the "total onslaught strategy" of the apartheid era.

"Justifying intelligence activities in this way follows the tradition of the previous national strategy. It can easily become an excuse to justify budgetary expenses."

Approached for comment, Mandela's spokesman, Joel Netshitenzhe, said Mandela would request a report from the NIS. He added: "It is the firm view of the president that the government is totally opposed to attempts by any agency to snoop on citizens who are not involved in unconstitutional or illegal activity."

And Fred Oberholzer, spokesman for Naidoo, strongly distanced the minister from any activities undertaken by NIS in defence of the RDP. "We have never requested the NIS to collect any information on our behalf nor have we asked them to speak on our behalf," he said.

Pending legislation, the NIS has yet to be integrated into the new National Intelligence Community, which will take on more than 900 ANC intelligence agents. It and other intelligence services are unchanged since the apartheid era.

Sanco's Pretoria secretary, Jackie Masemola, said that in June, two NIS agents -- Peter Small and a Myburgh -- had approached him, saying they were co-operating with Naidoo's office on the RDP.

Masemola said the agents claimed they were interested in security matters in the townships as an aspect of RDP implementation, and wanted to have formal meetings with him. They also expressed a particular interest in the reaction of Sanco's constituency to the petrol price increase.

The request was discussed by Sanco's Pretoria executive on June 29. The minutes of the meeting note the executive agreed that "these meetings (between NIS and Masemola) should continue to ascertain their (the NIS) role in the RDP".

Masemola said this was not a green light for him to establish formal contact with the NIS agents. Sanco had approached Naidoo's office to verify the NIS claim and was still awaiting a response. In addition, the general council of Sanco had discussed the matter and had recommended caution in dealing with the NIS.

In another incident, the housing co-ordinator of the non-governmental organisation Planact, lawyer Carien Engelbrecht, said she had been interviewed by an NIS agent after giving a speech early this month at a high- level housing conference which alluded to illegal immigrants living in the Johannesburg inner city.

A member of the Planact management committee had been present at the interview.

Engelbrecht said a certain Greta Bezuidenhout, an NIS section head operating from an office in Braamfontein, had told her the intelligence agency "was investigating issues which threatened the attainment of the RDP", including illegal immigration.

Bezuidenhout had asked for the source of Planact's statistics on immigrants and had offered to share information "in the interests of the RDP". She had also implied that her information-gathering exercise had the backing of PWV Safety and Security minister Jesse Duarte.

Last week Duarte vehemently denied this, saying she would follow up the issue with the NIS.

"The questions related to existing or potential clients," Engelbrecht said. "It was very creepy and we didn't co-operate."

It has also been learnt that the secretary of Sanco's Northern Cape region has been suspended for, among other things, holding secret meetings with NIS agents on Sanco premises. The nature of these dealings could not be established.

Reprinted from The Weekly Mail & Guardian, September 30, 1994.

The Weekly Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media Contact: M&G Media, 139 Smit Street, Breamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025.


LOAD-DATE: March 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


322 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 1, 1994 / October 31, 1994


SOUTH AFRICA: BUTHELEZI'S BATTLE TO CONTROL THE MONARCHY


BYLINE: Amrit Manga


LENGTH: 2854 words


 

Buthelezi has survived many political crises in his time. Each time analysts have dared to predict the end of his political life, Buthelezi has bounced back with greater confidence and in the process has consolidated his own and his party's place in the national political equation.

In many ways, he has demonstrated the same tenacity for which National Party politicians have become so well known for over the years, surviving crises that would destroy governments in almost any democracy.

He is almost certain to survive the most recent embarrassment he caused himself at the South African Broadcasting Corporation television studio Durban last Sunday.

But what the incident has brought to the fore is a genuine frustration generated by his failure to carve a niche for himself in national government. 

The depth of his frustrations was clearly illustrated by the bitterness of his response to a cabinet decision not to give him sole control over the local government.

"I hope they exclude me for good. I am out of it. If they want to do it by themselves then they will do it by themselves then they will do it by themselves," Buthelezi was reported as saying the cabinet decision.

Frustrations generated by Buthelezi's futile attempts at making an impact in the cabinet were only made worse by rifts between himself and the Zulu monarchy.

Buthelezi and his party have in the past benefited a great deal from their association with the monarchy and the souring of relations does not help Inkatha or its leader.

How the struggle will resolve itself and whether Zwelithini will muster the resolve to break with Buthelezi at the end of the battle remains difficult to speculate on.

But analyst say the battle is not unique or new to Zulu politics. In fact, both Zwelithini and Buthelezi must feel a sense of deja vu, knowing that they have been through all of it before.

In many ways, the monarchy was faced with a similar struggle from the late sixties to the late seventies when Buthelezi and his supporters tried to pull the king into their kraal while the National Party tried to secure overall control of the Royal House to advance its own homeland policies.

Gerhart Mare of the University of Natal's sociology department says the struggle now playing itself out in the province is in some ways a replay of that tussle that went on in the sixties and seventies.

Details of these clashes have been extensively recorded by historians, among them Mzala in his book on Inkatha and Buthelezi titled "Gathsha Buthelezi - chief with a Double Agenda".

What soured relations between the King and Buthelezi then was the Inkatha leaders' insistence that the Monarch should restrict himself to a ceremonial role and stay aloof from party politics.

"The King must personify the unity of the Zulu nation; the King must be kept out of the heat and dust of politics," Buthelezi was said to have argued then.

The Inkatha leaders' view prevailed then, much against Zwelithini's wishes.

That the move to curtail tha King's powers did not gain favour in the Royal House became evident from the fact that Buthelezi was excluded from preparations for Zwelithini's coronation.

Buthelezi was also prevented from performing the role of master of ceremonies, which would have greatly enhanced the Inkatha leaders' standing in the Zulu kingdom.

Instead, the royal family appointed Prince Herbert Zulu in Buthelezi's place.

"That fight was important because it was thought by both sides that they could gain legitamacy from a relationship with the king that would benefit them," Mare says.

It was therefore not surprising when Zwelithini was made patron of two political parties, the Inala and Icilongo parties, which had been floated by the NP to thwart Buthelezi's opposition to apartheid's brand of independence for homelands.

Buthelezi, however, won that battle and defeated the NP's attempt to foist independence on kwaZulu.

Zwelithini, at the stage, was evidently willing to accept independence to advance his own vision of establishing an executive monarchy and even went to Swaziland to study that country's constitution.

Mare says current events are similar to those witnessed in the sixties and seventies in that there has been mention of a royal political party and some people involved with the king then have once come to the fore, including Prince Israel Mcwayizeni.

The similarities go furhter in that Inkatha continues as an opposition movement in the sense that it remains a minority party in national politics.

One area in which it is not easy to draw similarities is around the question of who would be steering the king's battle against Buthelezi.

In the seventies, it was evidently the NP's Bureau for State Security. But much has changed politically and it is unlikely that remnants of the NP's intelligence network could be the driving influence this time around.

Zwelithini himself has never demonstrated the capacity to independantly orchestrate any political manoeuvre.

Many have suggested that the ANC might have precipitated the rift. But even that remains unclear given the fact that not all in the Royal House are ANC supporters.

Mare says one factor that might be at play is the emergence of a new set of power players, made possible by changed political conditions.

He says that the current conflict would not have happened had Buthelezi continuted to hold the office of chief minister of kwaZulu and the ANC remained a banned organisation.

"I think there is some kind of shift within the Royal House and the confidence gained from that, which has a political link, has allowed the emergence of a different set of power players," Mare exlains.

And it is this confidence which has found expression in the form of the challenge posed to Buthelezi as a traditional prime minister.

He emphasises that while some of the new power players have ANC leanings, not all would fall into the same political camp.

Mare also rules out the possibility of Zwelithini emerging as a rival political force in the province that could challenge Inkatha for power.

"He (Zwelithini) had the crude and clear failure of patronising political parties that failed in the seventies and this would give Buthelezi great confidence that Zwelithini will not emerge as an independent political force."

A third political force led by the King would also find itself caught between two other political forces-the ANC and Inkatha-and will not survive in such a situation.

Instead, says Mare, the struggle is for control of the entire Royal package which comes with the King.

He goes on to explain that it is clear the King has been central to the legitamacy Buthelezi has gained up to now.

And around the royal tradition of the Zulu people, there is a package of institutions such as the chiefs, who have been tremendously important in Inkatha's mobilisation before and during the elections.

Therefore Buthelezi will continue to fight for control over the entire institution of royalty.

"Therefore, Buthelezi and those around him have been saying that it is not the king as a person that is important, but rather the monarchy.

"And the battle for control over that package of tradition, in which the monarchy is very important will continue for some time still, particularly for the access it offers to support on the ground."

Inkatha is, however, projecting the struggle very differently, with Buthelezi focusing his attack on Zwelithini's apparent desire for an executive monarchy.

At last weekend's King Shaka celebration, Buthelezi warned Zwelithini to stay out of politics, saying there was no room in the new South Africa for an executive monarch.

Buthelezi clearly recognized Zwelithini's past willingness to accept the National Party offer in the late seventies for an independent kwaZulu ruled by an executive king.

Inkatha secretary-general Ziba Jiyane also pointed to the possibility that attempts may be made to promote the case for an executive monarchy.

"The IFP fought hard for the creation of the constitutional monarchy, but there are those who have influence over the king who want the creation of an executive monarchy, such as exists in Swaziland," he told New Nation last week.

Other analysts share the view that if those surrounding Zwelithini succeed in serving with Inkatha, they will begin mobilising grassroots support but they do not go so far as to suggest that the king will challenge Buthelezi for power.

However, they do not rule out the possibility of conservative Afrikaners and remnant structures of the old apartheid state, who pin their hopes on a failure of the government of national unity, coming to the aid of the monarchy with the hope of advancing dated agendas.

These analysts also point to instances before the April elections when Zwelithini alluded to the possibility of establishing a soverign state.

"This was the first time that the king had publicaly defined his position outside of that had been defined for him by Buthelezi.

"This was a sign of a growing definition of his own boundries of power," one analyst says, adding that was very unnerving for Buthelezi.

However, there are doubts as to the extent to which the Royal House will be able to mobilise support purely on a traditional ticket and loyalty to the king.

"These attempts will be undermined by the fact that the monarch will not be able to deliver material benefits to his loyalists and this will effect the extent to which Zwelthini will succeed in building an independent base," one analyst says.

But the exact detail of the king's agenda will only begin to emerge more clearly once the struggle with Buthalezi reaches some finality.

Question is- how will this struggle resolve itself and what impact will it have on Inkatha support in the region.

Zwelthini has not demonstrated strong leadership in the past and has remained quiet for most of the current conflict between himself and Buthelezi. And this makes it difficult to assess the possibility of the king severing ties with Inkatha.

If, however the new power players succed in their push for a clinical break with Buthalezi, the impact it could have on Inkatha will be informed by the extent to which the IFP is dependent on the monarchy for grassroots support.

Mare says if Buthelezi and Inkatha lose control over the entire package that goes with the tradition of royalty, it could have an impact on the IFP which depends very much on its regional and traditional support base.

But he adds that is not clear at all whether the ANC would be able to step into the space created by such a development- it would however, change the balance of forces.

"A neutral king will certainly benefit the ANC," says Mare.

He also does not rule out the possibility of some people in the IFP leaving.

The ANC's Blade Nzimande, currently a member of palimrnt, also seems to suggest that a break with the Royal House will precipitate divisions within Inkatha.

"People pledging their loyalty to the king are not going to take kindly to attempts by Inkatha to substitute itself for the King," says Nzimande.

"New kinds of tensions are going to emerge that will threaten the IFP," he added.

He points out that it was significant that the Natal amakhosi have been quiet about the tensions. "This indicates that tensions in the IFP along traditional lines are already surfacing," he said.

Jiyane disagrees, saying that a split between the IFP and the king will have no effect on Inkatha.

Speaking to "NewNation" last week, Jiyane said the IFP had built the monarchy into what it was and not the other way around.

"The IFP revived and built the kingdom to respectable standards and levels of prestige over the years."

Not everyone projects as optimistic a prognosis as Jiyane does. A political scientist "NewNation" spoke to says there is little beyond the monarchy the Inkatha can use to mobilise support.

"Inkatha as a political party is weakened by the absence of a resilient organisational structure - it has become more and more a party that simply reacts to various situations," the political analyst says.

If it loses its traditional base, it may well suffer considerable damage.

One way or another, Inkatha is unlikely to forego the advantage of having the monarchy on its side, especially at this crucial stage in the preparations for local government elections.

Buthelezi knows as well as anyone else the importance of retaining power at local government level, because that is the level at which delivery of tangible change envisaged by the Reconstruction and Development Programme will take place.

And the visibility of political parties at local government level will have a crucial bearing on the outcome of the next national election.

Reprinted from NEW NATION Sept. 30, 1994.

NEW NATION is published at Darragh House 13 Wanders St. Johannesburg, Tel:(011)333-2711 or (011)333-2721/2/3/4 Telex:482226 Fax:(011)889-0630.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


October 1, 1994 / October 31, 1994


SENEGAL: FATE OF DAKAR UNIVERSITY YEAR IN BALANCE


BYLINE: Alle Badara Sheriff


LENGTH: 480 words


 

The constant struggle to meet college tuition and book fees will continue for Bakary Camara in Dakar if the decision is taken to declare this academic year invalid.

Bakary, 24, is a final year student of English and philosophy at the Cheikh Anta Diop University in Dakar. In an interview with the "Daily Observer," he said it has always been difficult for him to secure funding for his education. "I would have loved to say 'Thank God' at the end of this year, but with the current problems, the future is uncertain and I face a continuing struggle to earn a mere bachelor's degree," he complained. 

Bakary, who entered the university in 1990, has survived on petty trading at the end of each academic year. Buying inferior goods in Dakar and selling them in villages in Casamance, he used the meagre profits to meet college expenses. If this academic year is declared void, he will have to spend another two years raising more funds. "All my plans will have been destroyed," he explained.

Meanwhile, according to sources, the university authorities have set a deadline as to whether this year will be declared invalid or whether another solution can be found. The sources also intimated that lecturers are divided in support for the propose "white year".

The secretary-general of the United Democratic Union of Senegalese Teachers, Iba Ndiaye Djadji, supported the need for the 1993/94 academic year to be invalidated by pointing out certain instances which compromise its validity. He commented that the university must be a place of competence and excellence in the service of development. He called for a dialogue to prepare a new academic year for the success and development of the university.

Baboucarr Diop, secretary general of Le Federaton de l'Education et de la Recherche, said all mediation efforts have failed and therefore the same problems of the university persist. He maintained that it is necessary to find a solution and called on all to sacrifice in order to save the year.

According to "Le Soleil," a leading Senegalese newspaper, the university principal, Sulaymane Niang, has said the assembly endorses the non-validation of the academic year.

Reprinted from WEEKEND OBSERVER, August 5-7, 1994.

WEEKEND OBSERVER is published by The Observer Company (Gambia) LTD., New Town-Sait Matty Junction, Bakau. PMB 131, Banjul, The Gambia


LOAD-DATE: March 24, 1995
