Africa News


October 1, 1994 / October 31, 1994


RWANDA: "The World and Rwanda"


BYLINE: Richard Joseph


LENGTH: 1174 words


 

An estimated half-million Rwandans have died, cruelly, in the space of a few months. Was this appalling catastrophe avoidable? In "Africa Demos" of February 1992, we published a letter from Rwanda's Ambassador to the United States, the Hon. Aloys Uwimana, in which he explained the steps being taken by the government of President Juvenal Habyarimana to establish "the rules guaranteeing a more profound respect of the workings of democracy and ensuring national cohesion." A Commission to that effect, he told us, was established on Sept. 21,1990, just nine days before the invasion launched from Uganda by the Rwandan Patriotic Front (RPF).

In the following issue of August 1992, we published an extensive rejoinder by Nicola Jefferson to the Ambassador's letter titled, "Behind the Democratic Veil in Rwanda." In her article, she gave a detailed account of the tyrannical and tribalist system established by Habyarimana: grenade attacks without warning; killings, arson and vandalism 'far from the combat zone;" official encouragement and participation in "vicious attacks against members of the Tutsi minority group;" radio broadcasts of scurrilous accusations against government opponents; "beatings and disappearances" of Tutsi civilians taken into government custody, including thousands detained after the September 1990 invasion; and the persecution of "outspoken journalists" and the seizure of opposition publications. 

Everything that has happened since Habyarimana was apparently killed by his regime's hardliners in the downing of his aircraft on April 6 is an expansion of a policy of systematic repression already documented by Human Rights Watch/ Africa. The French government, which created a "safe zone" in the southwest of Rwanda when the United Nations failed to act, was deeply complicit in Habyarimana's tyranny, providing training, equipment and advisers for his armed forces. Yet, that is little different from what France has done, and continues to do, throughout Francophone Africa.

Although effective action was not taken to curb the human rights abuses and political repression in Rwanda before and after the RPF invaded in 1990, a fundamental question sill has to be answered: Why did the international community fail to act expeditiously to protect Rwandan civilians after April 6? It should be remembered that most of the U.N. troops in Rwanda were pulled out after the crisis began, and the few hundred remaining had very restricted terms of engagement. While it may be argued that the brutalities in such a small country could formerly be overlooked internationally, this excuse would not hold for anything that transpired within days of death. Rwanda quickly became a killing field in which most of the victims were civilians and most of the perpetrators government-sponsored thugs. To obtain a satisfactory account of why so little was done to protect so many citizens known to be at risk, an independent international commission of distinguished jurists, scholars and retired diplomats should be appointed.

The United States government will spend perhaps a half-billion dollars on relief operations for Rwandan refugees and displaced persons before the end of 1994 for what Defense Secretary William Perry has described as "the most logistically complex humanitarian relief operation in U.S. history." Large sums will also be expended by other countries. It is with mixed feelings that many of us read reports of these intricate logistical operations, using airports in Western Europe and Eastern Africa.

When the united Nations finally decided on June 17, after weeks of U.S. obstruction, to put together an African peacekeeping force 5,5000 for Rwanda, more weeks were spent haggling over how much the United Nations should pay the United States to lease armored personnel carriers. It is as if an individual who asked to transport a person in cardiac arrest to a hospital first insists on negotiating a fee for use of his car.

The information supplied to all western governments and major international agencies by Rwanda experts about what was happening, and how an even greater catastrophe could be avoided, was also widely circulated to the media and the U.S. foreign policy community. The necessity and feasibility of creating an international security zone in the southern half of Rwanda were clearly and convincingly argued. Regrettably, these submissions failed to sway key policymakers. The United Nations, of course, had only recently been cautioned by President Bill Clinton to learn how and when to say "no" to request for large-scale humanitarian intervention. Moreover, the opposition of the U.S. Defense Department to such an engagement proved insuperable.

In principle, issues of state terrorism and genocide should tran-scend the fluctuating agendas of particular nations. Unfortunately, without the active involvement, and even sanction of the United States, major conflicts and catastrophes cannot be satisfactorily addressed in the world today. To ensure that half-million Rwandans have not died in vain, we need new rules, institutions, and mechanisms to guarantee that the next major catastrophe will be contained in a timely manner. An independent review of this tragedy should be promptly initiated, perhaps under the auspices of organizations such as the International Commission of Jurists and the International Peace Academy, and its report and recommendations made widely available.

Rwanda is more than an African tragedy. It has brought all of us to the threshold of our own humanity. The American equivalent of Rwandan deaths is less than four months, as a proportion of the U.S. population, would be 15 million- and the numbers are still mounting. One of the charges to the group of eminent persons would be to review the profound gap between the humanity and inhumanity displayed within and outside Rwanda and to help the world community identify how in the future it could say "yes" when "no", in the words of U.N. Secretary General Boutros Boutros-, would be nothing but "a scandal".

Reprinted from "Africa Demos"

"Africa Demos" is published by The African Governance Program of the Carter Center. One Copenhill, Atlanta, GA 30307


LOAD-DATE: March 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


325 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 1, 1994 / October 31, 1994


DEMOCRACY = SUCCESS


BYLINE: Chukwuemeka Gahia


LENGTH: 1974 words


 

There has been no official response to Nigeria's application for a permanant seat in the United Nations, Un, Security Council. The council is expected to use the occasion of the 50th anniversary of the UN to consider increasing the number of its permanant members from five to 10, as part of an attempt to chart a new course for the world body in the next 50 years. But it has not taken a position on the matter and if precedence is anything to go by, such a step could remain stymied by big power intrigues and the beaurcratic inertia of the UN process.

Ibrahim Gambari, Nigeria's permanant representative to the UN, told NEWSWATCH he was sure the matter would be put on the agenda next year. He considered Nigeria's chances to be bright. "We are favoured despite what you hear from certain quarter," Gambari said, insisting that his optimism was not misplaced. 

Femi Aribisala, a senior research fellow at the Nigeria Institute of International Affairs, NIIA, does not think Nigeria has a chance. He told Newswatch there would have been no problems had the country not become what he called "a disgrace on the international level." He was referring to the bad publicity against the country following the annulment of the June 12 presidential election. Gambari is also disturbed by the develpoment. He sees it as the only obstacle to the bid for the seat and said he hoped the country would return to civil rule by October next year when the UN holds the all-important 50th anniversary session. "If we can get that - democratically elected civilian government in place, and I have no cause to believe the contrary, then we are as good as having clinched the post," he said.

Gambari is banking on the extensive role Nigeria has played in UN peace keeping operations and its pre-eminent position in the continent to tilt the balance in its favour.

Baba Gana Kingibe, external affairs minister, presented the request for the seat in an address to the 49th session of the General Assembly on September 28, saying it was in line with current discussions on equitable representation and increase in the council's membership. He called for a "fundamantal restructuring" of the UN system, arguing that the present composition and decision-making process of the council did not adequately reflect the existing international situation.

The first time Nigeria expressed interest in the seat was in 1991 when Ibrahim Bagangida, former president, addressed the 46th session of the General Assembly in his capacity as the chairman of the Organisation of African Unity, OAU. He said the limitation of the permanent membership to the present five had become both anachronistic and unrepresentative.

Ike Nwachukwa, a retired major-general and former foreign affairs minister, formally proposed Nigeria's application for the seat during his address to the 47th session of the General Assembly in October 1992. It was not taken seriously initially. Said the New York Times of the bid: "Nigeria is a nation knee-deep in garbage gunning for a permanent seat in the UN." Nwachukwa had told the assembly that "Nigeria as the most populous African nation with the largest economic potential and proven commitment to the cause of world peace and security possesses the qualification to fulfill Africa's aspirations in this regard." He also observed that the council represents only three of the world's five regions.

The criteria for membership listed by Kingibe in Nigeria's favour include population, capacity to contribute to the maintenance of international peace and security, track record in international peace-keeping and peace-making efforts, and equitable geographical representation. The permanent members meet these and other more complex criteria for big power status. Population is an advantage for Nigeria because it remains the biggest black nation in the world. One out of every five Africans is a Nigerian. But, as experts have observed, population has to be measured not just in terms of size, but also as a function of its skills, education, health and relatively youthfulness.

The size of Nigeria's exploitable territory is also an advantage, meaning that its economic base is potentially unlikely to be displaced in the early stages of any hostilities. None of the current permanent members has this disability. All of them enjoy a high and stable gross national products per capita, high productivity industrial production, and high proportion of national income available for new investment. The implication, as has been noted, is that none of the current big powers can be subdued "without a world war and without a whole combination of other power fighting against them."

A standard which the current permanent members enjoy which Nigeria also meets is the wide scale and diversity of its interests in the international system. It has interests in the West African subregion, the Africa region and in the large growing black diaspora. A third critical variable which applies in favour of the current permanent members is the recognition or acceptance of their status in the world's pecking order by other members of the international system. Other states, on a regional or global basis, defer to the wishes of the permanent members as they pursue their own interests, and this is a recognition that without the cooperation of the big five, these other nations cannot realise their goals. This is what has given the big five their status and clout and remains the biggest test Nigeria must pass.

So far, the regional rivals for the seat are South Africa and Egypt, which urged last week that the creation of any additional security council seat should be donr on a regional rather on a country-to-country basis. Amre Moussa, the Egyptian foreign minister, suggested to the UN General Assembly that regions not currently represented on the council should be allocated two seats each. The disadvantaged regions are Africa, Asia ans Latin America. Under Moussa's proposal, the rotational principle will be used to determine the choice of the states that will fill the allotted seats to each region at any given time.

Gambari said while Egypt might gain from the influence of Boutros Boutros-Ghali, UN secretary general, Nigeria as a permanent SC member will demonstrate better prospects of ensuring "a fair African representation" on the council. Aribisala said that although Egypt is in Africa, it is essentially an Arab nation. Against an African country like Nigeria, it has a slim chance," he added. Both Gambari and Aribisala failed to rate South Africa's chances high. They said it is too young and lacks both regional and interanational diplomatic experience.

The more formidable challenge to Nigeria's bid will probably come from Germany and Japan. Both countries have been mentioned consistently as potential permanent members primarily because of their big power economic status. Aribsala said they are the current favourite. "It will look funny comparing Nigeria with countries like Germany and Japan," he argued. "These countries are both economically stable and moreover they are democratic countries. This is in sharp contrast with what is happening in Nigeria today."

The major obstacle confronting their own bids is probably the lingering reservation of their having caused both the First and Second World Wars. It still raises questions about their future commitment to the maintenance of international peace and security. The UN, formed in 1945 as the World War II was about to end, is in truth as much an attempt to guarentee international peace and security, as it was in conception a mechanism aimed at containing German and Japanese militarism.

A lot has changed since then, however, and both countries, forced to follow a pacifist course as a condition for their surrender to the Allied powers, are no longer seen as posing danger to world peace. The United States which, along with the Soviet Union, played the leading role in bringing about their defeat is today actively backing their bids for permanent seats. This is, however, said to be on condition that they would not enjoy veto power.

The Japanese are pulling out all the stops in pressing their bid. Last week, their emperor, Akihito, was in Paris where President Francois Mitterand endorsed the bid. Boutros Ghali was also invited over to Tokyo last month and said at the end of the visit that the Japanese bid was a good idea.

The only country that has supported Nigeria so far is Israel. Moshe Gilboa, former Israeli ambassador to Nigeria, said it deserved the seat because of its contributions to UN peace-keeping efforts, adding that Israel supported Nigeria's candidature from the start. "Israel believes that Nigeria is a genuine representative of the African continent which it represents by virtue of its size and contributions to the UN," Gilboa said.

China, which has a soft spot for Third World causes, might have been suportive also, but Nigeria incurred its anger in 1993 when it surprisingly approved consular level diplomatic relations with Taiwan which Peking insists is part of communist China and not a separate country. It accused Nigeria of recognising "two republics in one country."

Observers think the present political crisis is capable of depriving Nigeria of British support for the bid. Britain is Nigeria's most reliable ally. That leaves Russia and France as the possible remaining permanent members of teh council which could act to save Nigeria from an embarrassing unanimous rejection by the big five. Unfortunately, France has little to gain from Nigeria's membership. It still sees Nigeria as the major threat to its long-standing interest in sustaining a regional hegemony in Africa, particularly in the West African sub-region.

Aribisala is convinced Africa will be given a seat eventually. "I cannot say exactly when but I know it is in the nearest future," he said. This will depend, according to him, on African states pursuing the quest as a common objective. "They are not always unified but when they are, they usually got their way."

Reprinted from NEWSWATCH October 17, 1994.

NEWSWATCH is published at P.M.B. 21499, Ikeja, Nigeria. Tel:4960950 Fax:962887 Telex:27874


LOAD-DATE: March 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


326 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 1, 1994 / October 31, 1994


NIGERIA: Clamour for a U-Turn


BYLINE: Mike Akpan


LENGTH: 1534 words


 

NEWSWATCH September 26, 1994

Oil producing states in Nigeria have submitted proposals designed to help the on-going Constitutional Conference arrive at an equitable and acceptable revenue allocation formula. The proposals were contained in a memorandum: "Revenue Allocation in Nigeria-An Equitable Approach," submitted on their behalf by the Southern Minorities Delegates Forum, SMDF. In the memorandum, oil producing states want a return to the formula recognized by the 1963 constitution which struck a reasonable balance between the principle of derivation and distributable pool account, DPA, popularly known as federation account. By implication, they want a return to the formula adopted between 1950 and 1966 which gave a 50:50 balance between derivation and DPA.

That formula was abandoned in 1967 when crude oil became a major revenue earner for the country. Accordingly, mining rents and royalties which hitherto were earned by states from where oil was produced went to the federation account. Such a turn around in policy, oil producing states argue, was indefensible, viewed against the background that derivation principle was given reasonable weight when national politics was dominated by the three regional governments, with each wanting to maximise the benefits from the natural resources located in its geographical area. 

In order, therefore, to arrive at an acceptable formula, the SMDF, has made six recommendations to the conference. One of the recommendations is that the conference should do away with oppressive constitutional and statutory provisions used by successive federal governments to confiscate the oil mineral wealth of the oil producing states. These include the Petroleum Act 1969, and Section 40(3) of the 1979 Constitution. The two laws, the SMDF pointed out, confiscated minerals from the mineral-producing communities. The other law is the land use decree 52 of 1993, backdated to 2975, which vests ownership of shoreline lands including those reclaimed by private capital, in the federal government.

The SMDF also wants the conference to recognise that rent and royalties from mineral oil prospecting activities are land related, arguing that royalty is payment made to a land owner for the extraction of wealth from beneath his land. For this reason, mineral producing states have intrinsic right to rents and royalties paid on all minerals extracted from their land. The SMDG wondered why this right which was recognised in the 1963 was not extended to the 1979 constitution. Apart from restoration of royalty and rent right, oil producing states want all laws relating to oil company-community relations to be up graded.

Not only that. They want the laws that apply to other minerals to also to oil minerals. Said the memorandum: "If the Oyo State government through the Igbeti Marble Industry could unilaterally exploit the mineral in its territory, so be it for oil producing states and oil." It said oil producing states don't understand why Borno State government is allowed to commission feasibility studies on the deposits of soda ash, mica, glass sands, limestone, phosphorous and gypsum on its territory when such right is denied them regarding oil. The same, it argued applies in the case of limestone whereby states are allowed to exploit the mineral to run their cement industries.

The forum also wants the federal government to grant equity participation to the states which have minerals. It cited examples within and outside Nigeria to buttress its position. The eastern region, the forum pointed out, had equity shares in the Port Harcourt refinery before the civil war. In Malaysia, it said, the state where the gas industry is located has 10 percent equity in it. "The new constitution should provide for this in respect of oil producing states," the forum recommended.

To help the conference, the SMDF has submitted two proposals which, if adopted, will allow states benefit more from minerals located in their territories. One on the proposals known as the Igbeti Marble Industry formula provides for recognition of the autonomous nationalities as the owners of the resources in their territory. Under that formula which is currently applicable in the industry, the state government, using experts, financiers, technocrats and other relevant personnel, develops the resources on behalf of the community, subject to strategic and conservatory regulations imposed by the federal government. Thereafter, the state makes percentage allocations to the federal government, the host local government, the host community and the operating industry. Argued the forum: " This approach will force every state to look inwards and halt the overdependence on the resources of other states and the federal government for funds. It should be applicable to all resources-- oil minerals, solid minerals and agricultural resources."

In the alternative, the forum has recommended that the revenue should be shared using the principle of derivation as specified in the 1963 constitution. Section 140 of that constitution, it explained, recognised oil as a mineral while sub-section 5 of the same section also recognised continental shelf of a region or state as a part of its territory. It provided that whatever derived from the territory must be shared 50 percent on the basis of derivation and 50 percent on the DPA principle.

From whatever goes to the DPA allocation, it also recommended that 30 percent of the distributable quota should go to the federal government. In addition to its share of the federation account, it said the federal government should have exclusive revenue items which include federal income taxes and dividends from federal parastatals and companies. "It should retain 50 percent of this revenue and return 50 percent to the DPA," the forum said, adding that 50 percent allocation to the DPA should be shared to the states on the basis of 60 percent on equality and 40 percent on population.

The memorandum also specified functions for the Oil Mineral Producing Areas Development Commission, OMPADEC, which it wants retained in the new arrangement. Among such responsibilities are control of coastal and marine pollution, industrial pollution, erosion and flooding, land and fishery as well as forestry resources in accordance with accepted international conventions. In addition, it wants OMPADEC to embark on long-term industrialisation plan for the oil-producing states to ensure a decent level of socio-economic life for generations of indigenes of the states even when the oil is extinct.

To ensure that OMPADEC is properly funded to carry out these responsibilities, it proposed an allocation of 15 percent to it format he 50 percent derivation fund. It also suggested that OMPADEC should be centrally managed with equitable representation of the affected states in the organisation.

Finally, the memorandum recommended a return to a true federal system which provides for a proper devolution of powers and responsibilities. Accordingly, it said the federal government should limit itself to a strict list of regulatory and common services leaving the socio-economic welfare and services of citizens, that is, education, health, housing, agriculture, commerce and tourism among others, to state and local governments. "This must of necessity increase the financial provisions to the lower tiers of government, and in no way weakens the federal government," the forum pointed out.

Reprinted from NEWSWATCH September 26, 1994.

NEWSWATCH is published by Newswatch Communications Limited, No.3 Billings Way, Oregun Industrial Estate, Oregun, P.M.B.21499 Ikeja, Lagos, Nigeria.


LOAD-DATE: March 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


327 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 1, 1994 / October 31, 1994


MOZAMBIQUE: 6.4 MILLION REGISTER


LENGTH: 2427 words


 

Nearly 6.4 million people have registered for the election. This is 81% of the eligible population of 7.9 million as estimated by the UN.

Registration opened on 1 June and was to close on 15 August. The deadline was first extended to 20 August, but Renamo argued for a further extension because brigades had started late in its areas because Renamo had failed to grant access. On 19 August registration brigades were told to stay in place and on 22 August a further registration period of 24 August - 2 September was announced. More than 850,000 people were registered during the extra periods, mainly returning refugees, demobilised soldiers, and members of the new army.

SMOOTH REGISTRATION--AWEPA observers who visited Zambezi, Tete, Manica, Sofala, Inhambane and Maputo provinces concluded that registration was smoothly and completely run everywhere they visited. The registration brigades took their jobs very seriously, worked well and, in general, knew and followed the rules. They seemed serious, well-trained, and committed to their work. AWEPA observers saw no example of improper or sloppy conduct by any registration worker. 

Registration brigades were imaginative and resourceful in setting up their posts under difficult circumstances. Many simply worked under cashew trees. Some used school classrooms. In Inhaminga the brigade worked in a destroyed railway wagon. In Luala the brigade had been forced to borrow tables and chairs from local residents each day, returning them at night.

Although some brigades were working in their home areas and members could go home at night, others were living in tents or specially constructed huts for three months. The brigades were remarkably good humoured about the difficult conditions, although we did see examples of brigades on strike in Caia and Quelimane.

Most registration posts AWEPA visited had completed their work and had few, if any, people arriving for registration by mid-August. In some instances brigades had finished their work in one or even two places and had been moved to other areas where people still had not been registered. District electoral commissions seemed flexible and well organised in terms of moving brigades.

Registration was largely completed and there was no need, in the areas visited, to extend registration beyond the initial 20 August deadline. Everyone who wanted to register was able to do so.

AWEPA observers saw and were told that it was common practice to set aside registration days for particular groups of people. Regulos or neighbourhood secretaries would then bring most of the people from their zone for registration on one or two days. This also facilitated identification, as the regulo or secretary could under the law provide testimony as to the identity of a person who had no identity document- varying from one-third to two-thirds of those being registered.

Numbered tickets (senhas) were used effectively for crowd control. Where crowds were too large and people had to be sent home and told to come back the next day, the senhas allowed people to be taken in order when they returned.

Although a few registration posts still had large queues in mid-August, there was a consensus that by moving brigades into the areas everyone would be registered by 20 August. The queues were due to late registration in cities, underestimates of population in areas of dislocated people, and returning refugees in border ones.

Concern was expressed about the difficulties of access in Muanza, Cheriingoma and Morrumbala districts, where brigades were being transported to some zones by helicopter. Remote zones of all three districts are Renamo-controlled. In Morrumbala, the (Renamo) vice-president of the district electoral commission assured AWEPA that all zones had already been reached by 20 August. In Inhaminga, the (Renamo) vice-president for Cheringoma said that only one pocket with perhaps 125 potential voters had been missed. In Muanza with a week to go they were still waiting to transport two brigades.

WE ARE LIKE GOATS--"We are like goats" said a man waiting to register in Nicoadala, as he made a motion with his hands to show how they had been sent to the registration post like a heard of goats. Most people say they are registering because they have been told they must.

When asked about the process, men often used vague phrases, saying that there would be a chance to "elect a president" or "choose our leaders"; few women would admit to knowing anything about the process. This reluctance to discuss the election is in sharp contrast both to other countries such as Malawi and Angola, and to earlier times when Mozambicans were often happy to discuss political issues.

This reluctance to talk reflects both the lack of civic education, which means most people are unsure what is to happen, and a genuine reluctance to talk about it. There is substantial fear that the election cannot bring anything good, and might serve to end the time of peace as it had in Angola. No one showed any excitement about the election.

The continued disruptions and mutinies by demobilised and about-to-be-demobalised soldiers (which also delayed AWEPA observer teams) has increased the worry and demoralisation of many ordinary people.

Civic education has been particularly weak. Before the election, there was virtually no government or elecetion commission civic education, except for that done by non-government organisations. AWEPA, for example, trained teams from the youth, women's and trade union organisations (OJM, OMM, OTM).

Each registration brigade had a civic education worker who gave short explanations to people who came to register. Some also went to villages and neighbourhoods to hold meetings to tell people they had to register, although civic education workers repeatedly stressed they could have done more if they had had bicycles.

Although campaingning is legal in the period before the official campaign (which only grants additional rights, for example to radio air time), ther is little evidence of any political activity in most parts of the country.

Two types of intimidation have been noted by registration observation brigades. It is widely reported that Renamo has told peasants in its zones that the ballot would not be secret because curandeiros (traditional healers) will know how people vote and they must vote for Renamo. In Quelimane it is reported that Frelimo has put strong pressure on government employees to join the governing party.

And there is no free campaigning in some Renamo zones.

12 PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATES--The number of presidential and parlimentary candidates submitted to the National Election Commission (CNE) exceede all expectations; 13 presidential candidates and 13 political groups presented documents. There is one new coalition, the Patriotic Alliance (AP - Alianca Patriotica), which combines MONAMO and FAP.

Each candidate must submit a series of documents including notarised copies of identity and voter registration cards proof of a clean criminal record, and a letter agreeing to stand. This is set out in the electoral law, but many parties did not notice this and complained that it was onerous to do this in a short time. Each presidential candidate also had to submit 10,000 signatures.

The start of formal campaigning wsa delayed from 12 September until 22 September as a result of the extension of the registration period.

Twelve men are fighting for the presidency of Mozambique. They are, for the two large parties: Joaquim Chissano, Frelimo; Afonso Dhlakama, Renamo. For both coalitions: Maximo Dias, AP; Wehia Riupa, UD. For five small parties: Domingos Arouca, FUMO; Ya-Qub Simbindy, PIMO; Carlos Reis, UNAMO; Casimiro Nhamithambo, SOL; Padimbe Kamati, PPPM; Vasco Campira Mamboya, Pacode; and two independents:Carlos Jeque; Mario Machel.

The election commission rejected the candidacy of Neves Serrano of PPLM because he did not submit the proper documentation. His party was also the only one not to submit any parlimentary candidates.

13 PARTIES PROPOSE CANDIDATES--Candidates were submitted by 11 parties and both coalitions. By mid-September the election commission had not yet ruled on their eligibility.

One coalition, the Alianca Patriotica, and six parties - Frelimo, Fumo, Pacode, PCN, PPPM and Renamo - handed in lists of candidates for all 11 electoral circles (provinces plus the city of Maputo), but with different numbers of candidates for each.

The greatest number of nationally and international recognised names appeared, not surprisingly, on Frelimo's list for each circle was headed by well-known and long time party stalwarts such as Foreign Minister Pascoal Mocumbi (Inhambane), Defense Minister Alberto Chipande (Cabo Delgado), Minister without portfolio Mariano Matsinhe (Tete), Labour Minister Teodato Hunguana (Maputo City) and Transport Minister and chief peace negatiator Armando Guebuza (Maputo Province).

The reappearance in first place of all the familiar names, however, disappointed many party members from the provinces, who claimed that they had proposed new blood at provincial level, only to see their own candidates seconded in favour of central party leaders.

Most of the top Frelimo names on provincial lists are people long based in Maputo. Meanwhile, some Frelimo members were surprised to see the prominence of names like Bonifacio Gruveta, Frelimo Party Secretary in Zambezi province after a reportedly poor performance. Recent opinion polls testify to teh growing popularity of Renamo in Zambezia.

In Sofala, Frelimo fielded Central Committee member Alcidio Nguenha, who springs from one of Sofala's elite families.

The Frelimo lists contained the names of several prominent media workers such as national radio director Manuel Tome (heading the list for Mancia), national TV director Botelho Moniz standing in Zambezia and radio delegate Antonio Barros also in Zambezia.

It added some novelties which surprised the business and muslim communities, including businessman and owner of the nation's one private TV station, Carlos Klint (for Zambezi) and Nazir Lunat, son of Muslim business magnate Yacob Lunat, standing in Inhambane.

Renamo's parlimentary efforts are concentrated in the centre and north. Renamo strongman and chief peace process negotiator Raul Domingos heads the list for Sofala province, where he was also sent to direct the central region election campaign. Second on the list is Renamo political delegate for the province, Manuel Pereira.

Renamo's list in Zambezia is topped by David Alone, well-known sociologist, Frelimo dissident and son of a local regulo (traditional leader). Renamo Secretary General Vicente Ululu, a Maknode from Cabo Delgado, headsd the list for that province. Leading Renamo general, Herminio Morais, fronts the Maputo City candidates. In Niassa Renamo proposed only three candidates for the 11 potential seats.

The Alianca Patriotica also appears to have concentrated considerable efforts in Zambezia Province, where the list is headed by Monamo President and AP presidential candidate, Maximo Dias, and includes other Monamo and FAP party top leaders Guilhermino Fortes (Monamo), Jose Palaco (FAP President) and Joao Ironga (FAP). FAP Secretary General Raul da Conceicao heads the list for Maputo City.

PCN's Maputo City list is headed by Lutero Simango, PCN's top dog and son of the famous Frelimo dissent Urias Simango, followed by jurist Alice Mabota. Of PCN top leaders, Inacio Chire heads the list for Zambezia.

FUMO has concentrated its top candidates in the southern provinces. PIMO has meanwhile made its major efforts in the north, while virtually missing out the centre (no candidates in Manica and only four for Sofala). PIMO president and presidential candidate Ya-Qub Sibindy heads the Nampula list.

Reprinted from "MOZAMBIQUE PEACE PROCESS BULLETIN" Sept. 1994.

"MOZAMBIQUE PEACE..." is published at 48, 1012 AC Amsterdam Tel: (31) 20-6266639 Fax: (31)20-6220130


LOAD-DATE: March 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


October 1, 1994 / October 31, 1994


WEST AFRICA: ECOWAS In Distress


BYLINE: Tunde Asaju


LENGTH: 2134 words


 

The economic community of west African States, ECOWAS, is dying. At the 17th session of the conference of heads of states and governments held in Abuja, August 4 to August 7, only seven leaders were present while others sent representatives. Although most of the delegations arrived very late, their members had to rely on the generosity of Nigeria, the host country, for transport and accommodation arrangements. 

As a result of the poor financial status of the community most of the materials meant for the summit could not be transported to the venue of the meeting on time. Speeches of key officials were not distributed immediately after presentation, so journalist covering the summit had to rely on their notes and recordings. The $27 million secretariat in Abuja is lacking in facilities. There are no photocopying machines, no computers and no typewriters in the complex. Speeches of Sani Abacha, a general and host, were only made available August 7, after most of the foreign journalists had gone back. The problem brought Adama Gaye, the community's director of information, into serious confrontation with journalists. "Newswatch" learnt that the information section has been operating without any budgetary allocation. In an interview with "Newswatch," Gaye lamented the culture of hoarding information by the policy makers of the community. Said he: "If the negative trend is not corrected, there is no need to hae an information department or to associate journalists with the activities of the community. ECOWAS needs to go through glasnost (openness) and perestroika (reforms) if it is to realise its goals of becoming a people-oriented organisation."

The problems, however, is that the community has no money to run it's affairs. Last year's budget existed largely on paper due to non-payment of contributions by member states. Its implementation stated only last July ending after Cape Verde, one of the member-countries, which raised objection, dropped it at the minister's summit.

Besides, most member-states have not met financial obligations to the organisation. Only the Republic of Benin has fully paid up its contributions to the end of July this year. Observers say this may be due to the fact that Nicephore Dieudonne Soglo, the country's leader, was the chairman of the community for the past two years. Liberia is owing over $6 million in contributions alone. It is followed by Cote d'Ivoire which owes $2.5 million. Ghana, Mauritania, and Sierre Leone are owing more than $2 million each also. Senegal, Gambia, Mali and Nigeria are in the $1 million bracket while others owe less than a million dollars each.

A source at the secretariat put the arrears of debts owed by member states at $37 million. "With such huge debts," said the source, ' the idea of a serious community with laudable programmes is not possible. We simply cannot continue to run like this." All outstanding contributions are to be paid within sixty months while capital funds still being awaited are to be remitted within thirty-six months. The community, however, lacks the clout to enforce compliance with its resolutions. One observer said that he was skeptical about the ability of the resolution to get the association out of the woods. Said he: "They have made more beautiful speeches a and resolutions than this or other summits, but once they are out of here, that is the end."

"Newswatch" also gathered that Nigeria has been bending over backwards to make the organisation which it helped to found in 1975 to remain afloat. Under normal circumstances, the Republic of Benin which headed the community for the last two years ought to have hosted the summit. But it approached Nigeria to save it that expenditure. Nigeria is also to underwrite the hotel bills of most of the visitors lodged at the prestigious Nico-Noga-Hilton Hotel, Abuja, which is one of the most expensive in the country. Expenses for most lodgers were pegged by the Nigerian government to avoid unnecessary high bills. Apart from, this, Nigeria provided the aircraft that brought most heads of states to Abuja and also took them back.

Despite its efforts to keep the community afloat, most of the Francophone countries kept away the summit. "Newswatch" learnt that they kept away in order to prevent a heated debate over the formation of parallel monetary union among themselves. In January this year, six Francophone countries founded the West African Monetary Union, UEMOA, following the devaluation of their currency, the CFA. Most English-speaking countries especially Nigeria and Ghana were afraid that the formation of UMEOA would grossly reduce commitment to ECOWAS by the countries concerned. To ensure their presence, Nigeria prevailed on ECOWAS secretariat to postpone the summit till August so as to enable Senegal, Cote d'Ivoire, two principal countries, to be represented by their leaders. The two leaders agreed to come but at the last minute sent representatives instead.

Their absence put Soglo in a tight corner. He tried to assuage hostile feelings by explaining that the monetary union was the last chance the affected countries had to survive following spiraling inflation, social disenchantment and disinvestment in Francophone countries at the time of the devaluation of the CFA. He also explained that the affected countries pit ECOWAS first by stating their genuine commitment to the body in articles one and two of their memoranda of association. With these explanations, he called for the understanding of his fellow heads of states.

Ghana's Jerry Rawlings did not completely agree with him. He said Ghana and indeed, all countries within the sub-region, have been saddled with the burden of structural adjustment in the past decade. If these countries can weather the storm without going under, there is no reason why the Francophone countries can't do the same. He warned that, "whatever manoeuvres", whatever mechanics are put in place to sustain UMEOA should not undermine the ultimate goal of a united states of West Africa." The matter was left unresolved. A diplomat told Newswatch that "the sincerity of the Francophone countries to ECOWAS would now be measured by their commitment to the unity of purpose and financial commitment to the community, especially now that the leadership has moved to the other side."

Despite the problems, the summit eventually took off, holding most of its deliberations in camera. Newswatch gathered that when the issue of observer status for the West African Journalists Association, WAJA and the democratic research group, GERDES, was mentioned, most of the delegates called for caution. It was believed that openness would not work for the good of the community "at a time like this." Rawlings, in a speech after his election, told the audience that there was need for caution in associating with organisations which called themselves democratic unions. He was applauded.

The community at its closed door sessions discussed the issue of poverty now ravaging the sub-region. Rawlings admitted that there was gloom and deterioration in living standards in the region saying the problems seemed insurmountable. He called for interstate trade as a way of ameliorating the bastardised economy of member-states and for self-sufficiency.

The meeting also provided an opportunity to review the situation in Liberia. Most of the ECOWAS countries are said to be owing huge arrears for the upkeep of their soldiers in the beleaguered nation. With a fragile peace prevailing in the country, ECOWAS leaders are afraid that except they can find needs for disarmament, rehabilitation of soldiers and the creation of means of subsistence for them the uneasy peace would not last. Soglo warned that "every minute of waiting is an encumbrance on the peace process which is bound to jeopardise the lives of millions of Liberians."

Rawlings was more apprehensive. Said he: "If ECOMOG fails, anarchists would take over." Both leaders called for foreign assistance in order to keep peace. Rawlings warned that except armed sanctions imposed on member-countries are observed and money made available, the warring factions would strike at the ECOMOG and UNOMIL troops and unleash terror on them when they are vulnerable. They, however, agreed that all efforts towards peace would succeed only when the Liberian people have resolved to make it among themselves.

One of the problems which ECOWAS has refused to tackle over the years is the incessant military intervention in the sub-region's politics. Just when the summit was being awaited, a new military junta imposed itself in The Gambia. Sana Sabally, a lieutenant and product of the Nigerian Defence Academy, NDA, is the vice-chairman of the Provincial Ruling Council of The Gambia. In defence of their action, the 21-year-old leader said they seized power "to save our country in a coup devoid of rancour and bloodshed. We have a herculean task of restoring democracy in our country." Such explanation did not move foreign observers at the summit whose governments are refusing to grant aids to countries under military rule.

Rawlings, who has gone through the metamorphosis of military to civilian president, blamed developed countries for not understanding the dynamics of the African polity. He said that through their manoevures, the industrialised nations have stopped Africans from evolving anything truly indigenous to Africa.

Instead of deliberating on military incursions into the political life of member-states, the summit decided to speak on the establishment of an ECOWAS parliament. The protocol for the establishment of the parliament has been given to member states. The final communique urged member states who are yet to sign the paper to do so with dispatch to enable the parliament to take off. Said Soglo: We can put our strength on democratic process by having a parliament. "But an observer wondered if soldiers would be sent to the parliament from states under military rule. Others believed that the issue was not with establishment of a parliament but getting funds to run it.

The meeting also refused to be drawn into the political crisis in Nigeria. The government made ECOWAS leaders believe all was well in Nigeria. Most of the visiting leaders were driven through routes where they did not see the long queues for fuel in Abuja. Schools remained open for the duration of the summit and school children were made to line up the streets at the airport to welcome the visitors, all in an attempt to give them a sense of calm and stability.

The meeting adjourned to be reconvened at the end of July 1995 in Accra, Ghana. Rawlings, who was elected chairman told Abacha that he would not hesitate to call on him if he found that he lacked the financial muscle required to host the summit in Accra.

Reprinted from Newswatch, August 22, 1994.

Newswatch is published by Newswatch Communications Limited, No. 3 Billings Way, Oregun Industrial Estate, Oregun, P.M.B. 21499, Ikeja, Lagos, Nigeria.


LOAD-DATE: March 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


329 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 1, 1994 / October 31, 1994


THE NOMA AWARD FOR PUBLISHING IN AFRICA; Malawian scholar wins 1994 Noma Award


LENGTH: 880 words


 

An outstanding new academic book is this year's winner of the Noma Award for Publishing in Africa. The jury chose Paul Tiyambe Zeleza's "A Modern Economic History of Africa. Volume 1 : The Nineteenth Century", published in 1993 by the Dakar-based Council for the Development of Social Science Research in Africa (CODESRIA), as the winner of the 1994 Noma Award, citing the book as "an ambitious, skillfully written, and exhaustively research synthesis of African economic history in the 19th century." 

The jury citation goes on to say that " the book is an exercise in historical reconstruction, and its strength and distinction lies above all in its bold and convincing challenge to hitherto accepted orthodoxies, terminologies, and interpretations, about the nature and development of African societies and economies. The book is an outstanding, pioneering work, destined to become highly influential, and providing such a wealth of information and detail as to elevate the study of African economic history to anew pedestal." The jury considered a further achievement of the book to be its "successful, continent-wide approach" and "its thorough accessibility". The very full documentary apparatus in the book, "which also makes it an extremely useful work of reference", was similarly praised by the jury. The publisher, CODESRIA, was commended for "having shown great enterprise in identifying and supporting their author and finding him the necessary resources." Over 140 titles, from 55 African publishers, in 17 countries were submitted for this year's competition. The five-member Noma Award jury, chaired by Professor Abiola Irele, met in Oxford on 10-11 September to select the 1994 winner, together with a number of titles which were singled out for 'Special Commendation' or 'Honourable Mention'. In selecting the Award-winning title each year, the jury proceeds with the help of independent opinion and assessments secured from subject specialists. The $5000 prize will be presented to Tiyambe Zeleza at a special ceremony to be held on 29 November, coinciding with the 5th National Book Festival organized by the Publishers Association of Tanzania. It is hoped that former President Mwalimu Julius Nyerere will be agreeable to make the presentation.

"Gender Profile of Tanzania," published by the Tanzanian Gender Networking Programme in 1993, was awarded 'Special Commendation' by the Noma jury. Produced by people who have been active in the women's movement in Tanzania at national and grassroots level for many years, the book was the Programme's "collective and affirmative effort taken towards women's empowerment in Tanzania", and its "novel participatory and democratic approach", employing "innovative methods of accessing information and social data gathering". The jury also singled out five further books for 'Honourable Mention'. They are (in alphabetical order by author): "Die wit vlinder" by Corlia Fourie (children's book in Afrikaans), illustrated by Alida Bothma, Cape Town: Tafelberg Publishers, 1993; "Assaulting Childhood. Children's Experiences of Migrancy and Hostel Life in South Africa" by Sean Jones, Johannesburg: Witwatersrand University Press, 1993; "Children of the Sun. Selected Writers and Themes in South Africans Children's Literature" by Elwyn Jenkins, Johannesburg: Ravan Press, 1993. "Religion, Politics and Power in Northern Nigeria" by Matthew Hassan Kukah, Ibadan: Spectrum Books Ltd., 1993; "Mamy Wata et le monstre" (Children's picture-story book) written and illustrated by Veroniqe Tadjo, Abidjan: Nouvelles Editions Ivoirennes, 1993.

Established in 1979, the Noma Award is open to African writers and scholars whose work is published in Africa. It is given annually for an outstanding new book in any of these three categories: (1) scholarly or academic, (2) books for children, (3) literature and creative writing. The Award's founder is the late Shoichi Noma, formerly President of Kodansha Ltd., the Japanese publishing giant. Mr. Noma died in 1984 after a lifetime's devotion to making books more readily available in developing countries, to actively promoting reader ship in these countries, and to bridging the gap between North and South. His ideals are shared by his daughter, Mrs. Sawako Noma, the current President of Kodansha, who has continued to support the prize generously. The Noma Award for Publishing Africa is administered by the quarterly journal "The African Book Publishing Record" published in Oxford, England, and currently celebrating its 20th year of publication.

For more information, contact Hans M. Zell or Mary Jay, "The African Publishing Record," PO Box 56, Oxford OX1 2SJ, England. Telephone: +44-(0) 865-311534 or 793298.


LOAD-DATE: March 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


330 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 1, 1994 / October 31, 1994


LET'S RE-DRAW MAP ALONG AFRICAN LINES


BYLINE: Makau was Mutua


LENGTH: 1147 words


 

Even though there is some good news out of Africa, the enduring images of the continent are grisly scenes of the dead, the dying and the desperate in Rwanda and the refugee camps in Zaire.

Perhaps a dozen other countries, from Nigeria to Angola, precariously dance on the precipice. The consequences of the failed post-colonial state are do destructive that radical solutions must now be contemplated to avert the wholesale destruction of groups of the African people.

Many (people in the West) incorrectly think that Africans are incapable of governing themselves. But the current crisis of the modern African state has its roots in European and Arab expansion, slavery, the partition of Africa at the Berlin Conference in 1885, and their distortion of the continent's political map. The trauma of that history is evident today. 

Africans had to live within the new colonial boundaries in completely alien political systems with contrived citizenry. The analogy of the colonial state as a jail is appropriate. These territorial units could not inspire loyalty because they were unnatural and forced. They dismally failed to forge new nationalistic identities. Although Africans fiercely struggled against colonialism, the post-colonial states they inherited continues to suffer from similar deficiencies. Its structures, demographic composition and boundaries are colonial.

Since citizens lack instinctual and nationalistic bond to the state, those who become rulers pillage it. They resort to massive human rights violations to hold power and keep their fellow citizens down.

Meanwhile, the single party or the impenetrable state is cast as the guarantor of national unity and development. Those who criticize are stigmatized as unpatriotic. But soon this tourist organization masquerading as the state is attacked or spins out of control because of its own paranoia. Inevitably, ethnic, social and economic cleavages burst open, pitting citizen against citizen. The alien state lacking a popular base either crumbles, or prosecutes a genocidal war, as it has done in Rwanda, Liberia and Sudan.

There is little hope for Africa unless it courageously addresses the nature of the post-colonial state and reconfigures the political landscape of the continent. Setting aside the foolish and racist talk about recolonizing Africa to save it, responsible Africans must for now discard several principles of international law better suited for Europe.

The first of these fetishes is state sovereignty, a concept that allows ridiculous colonial entities, such as The Gambia, Burundi, Liberia, Malawi, Burkina Faso and Tunisia, to claim inviolability. The second id the principle of non-interference in the internal affairs of other states. These pillars of the law of nations have allowed callous elite to swim in small ponds under the pretext of statehood.

Since these colonial creations are not viable, their permanence should be repudiated. A continental organization should be formed to re-draw the map of Africa to construct viable states. Perhaps the Organization of Africa Unity whose "raison d'etre" ended with the abolition of apartheid--could justify its continued existence by making a new map for Africa. The criteria for the creation of new states should include historical factors especially the demographic contours of Africa's pre-colonial states and political formations, ethnic similarities and alliances based on cultural homogeneity and economic viability. The new map of Africa should hold no more than 15 states as opposed to the 50 today.

Based on these criteria, my map of Africa creates new countries by abolishing some and combining others. The new Republic of Kusini (which means "south" in the Kiswahili language would take in South Africa, Namibia, Zimbabwe, Mozambique, Lesotho, Swaziland and Malawi--nations with shared historical, economic and ethnic interests.

The new Egypt would combine Egypt and northern Sudan. Nubia which would bring together Kenya, Uganda, Tanzania and southern Sudan.

Mali--named for an ancient empire would swallow up Mali, Senegal, Guinea, Sierra Leone, Liberia, The Gambia, Guinea Bissau and Cape Verde.

Somalia would be beefed up by Djibouti, the Ogaden province of Ethiopia and Kenya's northern province. Both the Ogaden and the Kenyan province are inhabited by Somali ethnic groups.

Congo would combine ethnically similar people of Zaire, Congo, Burundi, Central African Republic and Rwanda. While Ghana, another ancient kingdom, would consist of Ghana, Ivory Coast, Togo, Benin, Nigeria, Cameroon, Gabon, Equatorial Guinea, and Sao Tome, Principe.

Benin--named for a sprawling ancient kingdom--would take in Chad, Burkina Faso and Niger. Algeria and Angola remain the same, while Libya takes over Tunisia. Morocco, Western Sahara and Mauritania become Sahara.

The new state of Kisiwana which means "Island" in Kiswahili brings together Madagascar, Mauritius and the Comoros.

Few Africans owe their allegiance to the emergent state, many identify with an ethnic group--a loyalty which pre-dates colonialism--or the pan-Africanist idea of Africa as home. The colonial state and its successor have been so alienated from the people that the development of national consciousness was not possible.

Newer larger and democratic entities created by Africans for Africans stand a better chance of instilling loyalty and stoking the inherent love for the motherland. This may be the only formula that will reverse Africa's disfiguration and save it from extinction.

Makau wa Mutua is a Kenyan and currently Project Director of the Human Rights Program at Harvard University. This article was edited from a version that appeared in "The Boston Globe" as an opinion piece.

Reprinted from The Monitor, Sept. 28 - 30, 1994.


LOAD-DATE: March 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


331 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


October 1, 1994 / October 31, 1994


CONTINENT LEGAL AGREEMENT TO CURB DESERTIFICATION TO BE OPENED FOR SIGNATURE IN PARIS, 14-15 OCTOBER


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 1787 words


 

An international legal agreement to curb the degradation of arid lands worldwide will be open for signature on 14-15 October in Paris. The agreement--the United Nations Convention on Desertification--was concluded on 18 June, also in Paris, by over 100 Governments.

A number of Heads of State, including the presidents of Senegal and Cape Verde, and Ministers are expected to attend the two-day high-level meeting at the UNESCO Centre. French President Francois Mitterand will open the session. After each Government signs the agreement, it will announce plans to implement the accord.

Many countries are expected to outline concrete steps they will take immediately to tackle urgent desertification problems, especially in Africa. It is hoped that these interim measures will jump-start the Convention's implementation even though the accord is not expected to become legally binding for some two years. I will enter into force 90 days after it has been ratified by legislatures in 50 countries. 

The convention was called for at the 1992 Earth Summit in Rio de Haneiro, Brazil, to address the critical problem of the degradation of fragile drylands, which threatens the livelihoods and food security of over 900 million people in some 100 countries. Ambassador Bo Kjellen of Sweden, chairman of the negotiating committee, called the convention "an important step forward toward improving life for people in the drylands."

The convention establishes a framework for national, sub-regional and regional programs to counter the degradation of drylands, including semi-arid grasslands and well as deserts. It calls for international action, including the mobilization of "substantial financial resources," transfer of anti-desertification technologies from developed to developing countries, information exchange and research and training programs.

One innovative feature of the agreement is that is "commits countries to a bottom-up approach that involves the local populace, national aithorities and the international community," according to Hama Arba Diallo, executive secretary of the negotiating committee. While in the past, "countries often have just set up shopping lists of what they want" from donors, the new convention "initiates integrated national programs drawn up and implemented in consultation with donors and local communities."

Four annexes detail how the agreement will be implemented regionally, in Africa, Asia, Latin America and the Caribbean, and the northern Mediterranean, respectively.

The degradation of arid lands, a process known as desertification, affects some 25 per cent of the Earth's land area and seems to be occurring at an accelerated rate globally, according to the United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP). The causes include overgrazing, overcropping, poor irrigation practices and deforestation, combined with climate variations.

The situation is especially serious in Africa, where 66% of the continent is desert or dryland, and 73% of the agricultural drylands are already degraded. The Convention aims to prevent long-term consequences such as mass migration, loss of plant and animal species, climate change and the need for emergency aid to populations in crisis. Most of the world's 800 million people without adequate food live in the drylands, according the to Food and Agriculture Organization of the UN (FAO).

The issue of financial arrangements dominated the final negotiations for the Convention, held 6-17 June in Paris--the fifth session of the Intergovernmental Negotiating Committee for a Convention on Desertification (INCD).

Although donor counties did not agree to legally binding commitments to new anti-desertification funding--as many developing countries, particularly in Africa, had hoped--Mr. Diallo expressed confidence that "resources to assist implementation of the Convention will be forthcoming." Several donor countries indicated they would return to Paris for the signing of the Convention ready to announce their contributions.

Developing countries suffering from desertification pushed during negotiations for donor commitments to "new and additional financial resources," the wording agreed to under Agenda 21, the Earth Summit action program. In the end, donor countries agreed to "mobilize substantial financial resources" to combat desertification, a phrase that left open the possibility of increased funding without making hard promises.

Governments are urged to pursue the possibility of financing anti-desertification action through the Global Environment Facility (GEF), in cases where curbing desertification can be linked with the GEF's four mandated funding areas: preventing climate change and loss of species, and protecting international waterways and the ozone layer. In practice, however, GEF funding covers only "agreed incremental costs, " i.e. those parts of a project which provide global benefits, a requirement which could prove challenging for many proposals.

The GEF is the interim financing channel for the other legal agreements signed at the Earth Summit, the Convention on Biological Diversity and the Framework Convention on Climate Change. African countries in particular have long contended that the Facility should also fund anti-desertification projects. However, even the entire US $2 billion recently pledged to replenish the GEF is just a fraction of the amount needed to combat desertification worldwide. UNEP estimates that between US $10 billion and $22.4 billion would be required annually for an effective 20-year global program. This would include the cost of rehabilitating land already degraded as well as preventing further loss of fertility. Currently less than $1 billion per year is being spent, although the annual loss in agricultural income because of desertification is estimated to be some $42 billion.

To provide scientific information and advise to the Conference of Parties, a monitoring body composed of countries that have ratified the agreement, a subsidiary Committee on Science and Technology will be set up, composed of Government representatives with particular competence. The Conference of Parties will also maintain a roster of independent experts to be nominated by the Parties, from which it may appoint ad hoc panels as needed.

The Convention's "bottom-up" approach reflects a growing recognition of the importance of grassroots groups and non-governmental organizations (NGOs) in fighting desertification, because they reach the people who work the land. The Convention assigns NGOs a role in designing and implementing national programs and in overseeing national desertification funds. "Local communities will be consulted on what they believe is an appropriate course of action, especially in light of traditional knowledge and practices," Mr. Diallo said.

The bottom-up approach is also tied to efforts to improve effectiveness of funding. "Development cooperation has come to a critical point," said Ambassador Kjellen in an interview last June. "People are asking if large funding programs have lost their purpose. If our Convention can some up with a bottom-up approach which integrates physical factors with social and economic issues, perhaps donor fatigue can be turned to enthusiasm."

The Regional Implementation Annex for Africa recounts the particular conditions of the continent, including the high proportion of drylands, frequent droughts, political instability and difficult socio-economic conditions such as widespread poverty and high debt.

Unique among regional instruments, the African Annex elaborates upon the obligations and Parties in the general Convention. African countries should aim to "mobilize new and additional national financial resources" to combat desertification and to strengthen reforms toward decentralization, more democratic ownership of land, and participation of local people. In implementing the Convention, developed countries should give priority to African countries and "continue to allocate significant resources and/or increase resources" to assist them in combating desertification, as well as facilitating the transfer of appropriate technologies.

Concerning technical assistance, the African Annex refers to the need to ensure that less-costly local experts are given preference over foreign consultants, reflecting dissatisfaction with the high overhead costs of many technical projects and their failure to use and empower local expertise. To improve coordination on desertification activities, the Annex calls for consultative processes to be set up at the national, sub-regional and regional levels--including donors, national Governments, NGOs and local populations--to negotiate partnership agreements and to improve monitoring and information exchange.

For more information contact Department of Public Information, Room S-1037, United Nations, New York, NY 10017. TEL: (212) 963-4295 or 963-6870. FAX: (212) 963-1186.


LOAD-DATE: March 24, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.

CURRENCY EXCHANGE


LENGTH: 2494 words


 

The table gives selected currencies valued against the major international trading currencies. Rates quoted are the middle rates between buying and selling, but currencies are in most cases not freely traded. These rates have been compiled by Maxwell Stamp PLC for information only. Maxwell Stamp accepts no responsibility for any transaction undertaken on the basis of these figures. For further information please contact John Morgan at Maxwell Stamp's Head Office in London; phone 44-71-251-0147; telex 914569 MAXAMP G; fax 44-71-251-0140. 

*CFA Franc = Benin, Burkina Faso, Cameroon, Central African Republic, Chad, Comoros, Congo, Cote d'Ivoire, Equatorial Guinea, Gabon, Mali, Niger, Senegal, Togo.

** commercial rate

November 1, 1994 / November 30, 1994


EMPLOYMENT


LENGTH: 520 words


 

The Development Group for Alternative Policies, a non-profit working on aid and trade policy including issues related to the World Bank and structural adjustment, is hiring a Communications Coordinator to handle a variety of task related to media relations, materials production and distribution, public outreach and information systems. They are seeking a highly motivated individual an established track record in the communications field, excellent writing and editing skills, working knowledge of word-processing, electronic mail and database programs and commitment to social change. To apply send resume and three references to Communications Position, Development GAP, 927 15th Street, NW, 4th Floor, Washington, DC 20005. 

The International Medical Corps provides emergency medical relief and health care services in regions devastated by war and catastrophe. IMC has several positions available in Rwanda, including Public Health Nurses with community health training and experience in mobilization of local populations, to set up and be part of mobile clinic teams. All positions require French. Send letter of interest or resume to IMC, 12233 W. Olympic Blvd., #280, Los Angeles, CA 90064; FAX: (310) 442- 6622.

Food for the Hungry International, an organization of Christian Motivation committed to working with poor people to overcome hunger and poverty through integrated self-development and appropriate relief, has several positions available. An Agri-Enterprise Coordinator for Mozambique is need to establish and manage agricultural enterprise programs in rural communities in Sofala Province. Candidates must be in agreement with FHI's Christian philosophy and practice and have a BA or BS in Business Management or closely related field, two years of previous international experience in rural business/micro enterprise development, good working knowledge of Lotus 123 or Quattro Pro, Word Perfect and DOS; good writing skills are also required. Must be fluent in Portuguese, Spanish or French (Portuguese preferred).

A Programmes Manager is needed for Ethiopia. The manager will oversee all aspects of program implementation; programs include health, agroforestry, water animal health and emergency relief. Candidates must be in agreement with FHI's Christian philosophy and belief and must have 3-5 years experience in international relief and development program management, preferably with NGO projects in Africa. Amharic is strongly recommended. Send resumes to Scott Allen, Personnel Coordinator, FHI, 7807 East Greenway Road, Suite 3, Scottsdale, AZ 85260; TEL: (800) 248-6437; FAX: (602) 951-9035.

November 1, 1994 / November 30, 1994


RESOURCES


LENGTH: 907 words


 

The Information Bank on Africa Development Studies (IBADS) is an electronic mailing service provided by the African Technical Department at the World Bank. Its objective is to disseminate information about development studies in sub-Saharan Africa. To subscribe, write an e-mail message to listser@tome.worldbank.org and include "Subscribe IBADS (first name-space-last name). Questions go to Mehdi Ali at MALI2@worldbank.org

The U. S. Agency for International Development (USAID) will make a monthly newsletter available to readers via Internet. Persons interested in automatically receiving the "West Coast International News" at an e-mail address should contact the West Coast Outreach Office at usaid.wco@ortel.org or phone (310) 533-0770. The newsletter includes USAID world and West Coast news, a calendar of USAID WCO international events and current USAID solicitations. 

The Liberian Studies Association is now accessible by e-mail. The group seeks to facilitate educational contacts and exchange of information and ideas between Liberia and the U.S. To subscribe send an e-mail message to listserv@UGA.CC.UGA.EDU. Leave subject line blank. In the body of the message write: sub LSA-L <your first name> <your last name>; example: sub LSA-L Ann Smith.

The Stony Point Center's Southern Africa Education Program announces its 1994 Fall Consultation on December 2-3, 1994. The theme for the convocation is "South Africa's Liberation: New Prospects for Southern Africa." Keynote speakers are Frank Chikane and Carol Thompson. Advance registration deadline is November 25, 1994. For more information contact Southern Africa Education Program, Stony Point Center, 17 Crickettown Road, Stony Point, NY 10980.

TRAVELING RESPONSIBILITY: A DIRECTORY OF OPPORTUNITIES: Since 1977, TRANSITIONS ABROAD, has detailed the rewards of travel with a purpose. Each issue is a directory of information on all the ways to combine international travel with activities of special interest to the individual traveler. The November/December issue focuses on ecotourism or environmentally responsible travel. Responsible tours to chose locally owned lodging, local restaurants, and employ local counterparts to keep as much of the tourist dollar as possible in the host country. Responsible tours are in-depth learning experiences with the local hosts as teachers. Organized by region and country, the possibilities in the current directory include: village- based bicycle tours to all parts of Africa; East African Safaris focusing on marine ecology, art, beadwork, language/literature, archaeology, and wildlife conservation; living with village families in Kenya; orangutan research in Indonesia; trekking and elephant safaris in the Himalayas; and economic development in Vietnam, Laos, and Cambodia among others. Along with the directory of special interest tours, this issue contains its usual mix of columns and departments emphasizing low-cost independent alternatives to packaged tours: hiking across the Alps, overlanding through Africa, and folk dancing around the world. A one-year, six-issue subscription to the magazine costs $19.95 from: TRANSITIONS ABROAD, Dept. TRA, P.O. Box 3000, Denville, NJ 07834. New subscribers receive a free 56-page "Guide to Opportunities Overseas", a selection of the most useful features from the magazine's first 17 years of publication. A free catalogue of dozens of separately printed resource guides on work, travel, and study abroad is available from TRANSITIONS ABROAD, P.O. Box 1300, Amherst, MA 01004-1300.

MEDIAPRO, a film production agency specializing in films about Africa, has new films available for rental or purchase. MEDIAPRO's offerings include short films suitable for classroom use and feature-length films for events-related screenings. Contact Olaniyi Areke, MEDIAPRO, 6202 Springhill Drive, #302, Greenbelt, MD 20770; TEL: (301) 345-1852.

The Sudan-American Foundation for Education, Inc. seeks donations in almost any field of instruction at the University of Khartoum. For more information, including the Silver Spring, MD shipping address, contact Lee G. Burchinal, 4141 N. Henderson Rd., Suite 1216, Arlington, VA 22203-2424; phone: (703) 525-9045.

The Zanzibar Library Project needs ten thousand books and journals on Africa for shipment via San Francisco to the new Africa research library at the House of Wonders Museum in Zanzibar. Donations of one box or more are welcome as are contributions. For details contact Ed Ferguson, Associates Program, Five Colleges, Inc., PO Box 740, Amherst, MA 01004; phone: (413) 256-8316; E-mail: edfergus@smith.smith.edu

CALLS FOR PAPERS;


LENGTH: 574 words


 

February 14-18,1995 NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF AFRICA-AMERICAN STUDIES NATIONAL CONFERENCE VIRGINIA STATE UNIVERSITY PETERSBURG, VIRGINIA 23806 Fifty(50) word abstracts should be submitted on letterhead which relate to any aspect of the African-American Experience. Subjects may include, but are not limited to literature, demographics, history, politics, economics, the arts, religion, education, health care, the family, international relations, agriculture, business, the sciences, sports, computer science, women's studies, multi-culturalism, social sciences and many other areas. ABSTRACTS SHOULD BE POSTMARKED BY DECEMBER 17, 1994. Forward Abstracts to: Lemuel Berry, Jr., Executive Director, NAAAS, Virginia State University, P.O. Box 9403, Petersburg, VA 23306, TEL:(804)524-5447, 524-524-5487, FAX:(804)524-6708. April 21-22, 1995 NEW YORK STATE AFRICAN STUDIES ASSOCIATION 19TH ANNUAL CONFERENCE Scholars are invited to present papers at the 19th annual conference with the theme: "African Renaissance and Reconstruction," to be held April 21-22, 1995 at Hostos Community College, City University of New York. Papers on all topics from all disciplines will be considered; especially welcomed are those dealing with the direction for Africa as the 21st century is approached. a 600 word abstract is requested for papers. Those organizing panels should submit a 600 word abstract along with the names of the participants. THE DEADLINE IS JANUARY 15, 1994. Send proposals including home and office phone numbers as well as E-mail and fax information to: Edward S. Maynard, Program Chair, Hostos Community College, City University of New York, 500 Grand Concourse, C411, Bronx, NY 10451; TEL: (718) 518- 6715; FAX: (718) 518-6643. May 4-5, 1995 SUDAN STUDIES ASSOCIATION FOURTEENTH ANNUAL MEETING The theme for the annual meeting of the Sudan Studies Association is "Conflict and Conflict Resolution;" the meeting will be held at Villanova University. Papers are welcome from any relevant discipline and may also consider other countries in the Horn of Africa. Send paper or panel abstracts to: Ann Lewsch, Center for Arab and Islamic Studies, Villanova University, 800 Lancaster Ave., Villanova, PA 19085. TEL: (610) 519-7712. FAX: (610) 519-7249. June 21-25, 1995 NATIONAL WOMEN'S STUDIES ASSOCIATION 16TH ANNUAL CONFERENCE UNIVERSITY OF WYOMING, LARAMIE, WYOMING Conference plenaries are organized around 4 major themes: Generations of Women, Politics of Survival, Order and Chaos, and Communities and Coalitions. Proposals for presentations by activists, community and cultural workers, teachers, graduate and undergraduate students and scholars are invited. Interdisciplinary papers are welcome as are papers, panels and other forms of presentations from all fields in the humanities, the natural sciences, social sciences, creative and performing arts, as well as from health, law and medical fields. PROPOSAL DEADLINE IS NOVEMBER 8, 1994. Direct questions to NWSA '95 Conference Office, TEL: (307) 766-6872, FAX: (307) 766-3812, E-MAIL: WMST@UWYO.edu
