EDUCATION/TRAVEL


LENGTH: 1187 words


 

Teachers for Africa Program of the International Foundation for Education and Self- Help (IFESH) is accepting applications for a class to depart in September, 1995. The program is designed to allow teachers, school administrators and other professionals from the US to spend an academic year in African countries helping to improve the quality of education. For further information contact IFESH, TEL: (800) 835-3530; FAX: (602) 443-1824.

Intercultural Dimensions organizes cross-cultural travel abroad programs to Africa. "Crossing Cultures: Senegal" program will take place from December 28 to January 18, 1995. "Crossing Cultures: Burkina Faso" will be February 24 to March 12, 1995. For further information contact Intercultural Dimensions, TEL: (617) 864-8442; E-MAIL: janetid@aol.com 

The Rockefeller Foundation is accepting institutional applications to host projects from programs offering: humanistic analysis of social construction of race, gender, and ethnicity; the circulation and interpretation of cultures, including questions of pluralism and civil society; the consequences of diaspora, immigration, and new forms of citizenship; the core impact of the media in everyday life; and communal conflict and intergroup relations. The deadline for a letter of intent is required by December 1, 1994. For further information, contact Fellowship Office, Rockefeller Foundation 1133 Avenue of Americas, New York, NY 10033

The American Association of University Women Education Foundation (AAUW) is accepting applications for their 1995-96 Fellowship and Grants Program. AAUW programs support women pursuing advanced research graduate study, and community service. Last year the AAUW awarded more than $2.5 million in fellowships and grants to 269 women for community action projects, individual research, and formal academic pursuits. The programs are as follows: American Fellowships-Dissertation fellowships with a stipend of $14,500 and post doctoral fellowships with a stipend ranging from $20,000-$25,000 will be awarded for completing dissertations or conduction post- doctoral research. Summer fellowships of $5,000 are available for post doctoral research by tenured, non tenured, and adjunct women faculty at colleges and universities whose teaching loads limit active research. Applications must be US citizens or permanent residents. POSTMARK DEADLINE IS NOVEMBER 15, 1994. International Fellowships- For full-time graduate or postgraduate study or research in the US for women who are not US citizens or permanent residents. Applicants must hold the equivalent of a US bachelor's degree. Stipend is $15,065. POSTMARK DEADLINE DECEMBER 1,1994. Selected Professions Fellowships- Awards from $5,000-$9,000 for US citizens or permanent residents for assistance in their final year of graduate study in fields where participation by women has traditionally been low. Postmark deadline is December 15,1994. Career Development Grants- For women reentering the work force, changing careers, or advancing their current career. Awards range from $1,000- $5,000. Applicants must be US citizens or permanent residents. POSTMARK DEADLINE IS JANUARY 2,1995.

The Margaret McNamara Memorial Fund invites women from developing countries to apply for grants to be awarded in spring 1995. The fund was established in 1981 to honor the late Margaret McNamara and her commitment to the well-being of women children in developing countries. Grants awarded are for amounts up to $6,000 and are not renewable. US citizens and permanent residents of the US are not eligible to apply. Applicants must have been born before January 1,1970 and must meet other criteria. For more details about the award and for a list of the eligible developing countries, contact; The Margaret Mcnamara Memorial Fund 1818 H Street, NW, Room G- 1000 Washington, DC 20433.

U.S. doctoral candidates and established scholars who wish to conduct research in West Africa in any field of academic study are eligible for WARA Fellowship in West Africa for American scholars. Small grants not exceeding $4,000 are available for travel partial support. All applicants should submit in triplicate: vitae indicating language ability and institutional affiliations; university transcript if Ph.D. candidate; names of two referees; a maximum 1,500 word proposal including indication of the nature of the final product; proposed itinerary with dates; proposed budget from all sources; evidence of US citizenship. APPLICATION DEADLINE IS JANUARY 15,1995. All applicants should be sent to: Professor Joseph E. Harris Box 682 Howard University Washington DC. 20059

MAP International announces an international study-tour for nurses and nursing students, "Out of Africa: The Challenge of International Nursing, a Kenyan Perspective." The study-tour is scheduled January 19 - February 3, 1995 for those "committed to serving the less fortunate, and inspired to make a difference in the world." For more information contact Nicole Henderson, Registrar, Educational Services, MAP International, PO Box 21500, Brunswick, GA 31521-5000; TEL: (800) 225- 8550.

WorldTeach provides opportunities for graduating seniors and others to spend one year teaching English, math or science in Namibia or South Africa. For details, contact WorldTeach Inc., Harvard Institute for International Development, One Eliot Street, Cambridge, MA 02138-5705; TEL: (617) 495-5527.

The Center for Global Education at Augsburg College offers semester study programs in southern Africa. In the fall of 1995 the theme is "Southern Africa in Transition: The View from Namibia." In the spring of 1996 the theme will be "Women and Development: Southern African Perspectives." Deadlines are in April and October. Call: (800) 299-8889 for details. Wells College offers a course in Senegalese society, culture and politics in Dakar, Senegal, January 3-22, 1995. Contact: Tukumbi Lumemba-Kasongo, Wells College, Aurora, NY 13026; TEL: (315) 364-3220. DEADLINE IS NOVEMBER 28.

The Institute for Advanced Study is offering Visiting Member Awards for postdoctoral social scientists to pursue their own research at Princeton. Contact: Administrative Officer, School of Social Science, Institute for Advanced Study, Princeton, NJ 08540. DEADLINE IS DECEMBER 1, 1994.

November 1, 1994 / November 30, 1994


EXHIBITIONS/PROGRAMS


LENGTH: 667 words


 

Through April 30,1995 Richmond, VA. Virginia Museum of Fine Arts "SPIRIT OF THE MOTHERLAND" Contact: Suzanne Hall or Don Dale, Office of Public Affairs, Virginia Museum of Fine Arts, 2800 Grove Avenue, Richmond, VA. 23221, TEL: (804)367-0878 FAX:(804)367-9393.

Through March 5, 1995 New York, NY "EXHIBITION-ism: Museums and African Art" Contact: The Museum for African Art, 593 Broadway, New York, NY 10012. Tel: (212) 966-1313, Fax: (212) 966-1432. 

November 3,1994 Virginia Museum of Fine Art 2800 Grove Avenue, Richmond, VA. 23221 The special film series" a Cinematic Celebration of Africa and the African Americas" begins at 7:30 p.m. with "Daughters of the Dust" a film by Julie Dash (113 min.,1991) This contemporary classic portrays the unique culture of the Gullah people, descendants of slaves who lived in isolation on the Sea Islands of Georgia coast, and their struggle to retain the past while claiming the future .

November 16,1994 - February 26,1995 National Museum of African Art MOHAMMED OMER DHALIS, PRINTMAKER/AMIR I.M. NOUR SCULPTOR This exhibition is devoted to works by two Sudanese artists, Mohammed Omer Khalil ,printmaker and painter (b.1936) and Amir Nour (b.1939) that recall their environment and life experiences Contact: National Museum of African Art, 950 Independence Ave. S.W. Washington, D.C. 20560, TEL:202-357-4600

November 23,1994 - March 27,1995 National Museum of African Art GRACE K SCULPTURE; AN ARTIST'S BOOK BY ATTAWA KWAMI In 1993, Atta Kwami, A Ghanaian artist, created a book that explores the artwork of his mother, Grace Salome Kwami. The book itself is a work of art that consists of 48 unnumbered, folded pages that open like the legs of spider(ananse) In Ghanaian Culture, the Character Ananse is the custodian of wisdom and a symbol of ingenuity. Contact: National Museum of African Art, 950 Independence Ave. S.W., Washington, D.C. 205060, TEL: 202-357-4600

November 26, 1994, 3 p.m. National Museum of African Art Gallery Discussion "Looking, Talking and Telling: The Ingenuity of Ananse the Spider" Among the Akan people of Ghana and Cote d'Ivoire, Ananse tales recount how this mythical character interacts with mankind. Peter Pipim, education specialist, discusses Ananse in relation to the exhibition "Grace Kwami Sculpture, An Artist's Book by Atta Kwami." Contact: National Museum of African Art, 950 Independence Ave., SW, Washington, D.C. 20360, TEL: 202-357-4600

Contact: National Museum of African Art, 950 Independence Ave., SW, Washington, D.C. 20360, TEL: 202-357-4600

Peter Pipim, education specialist, discusses Ananse in relation to the exhibition "Grace Kwami Sculpture, An Artist's Book by Atta Kwami." This will be the first time an AMARC conference will be held in Africa and the decision to hold it there reflects the democratization of communication that is sweeping Africa. Details on the themes, agenda, special airfares, and cost of registration and accommodation will be posted when available to the APC conference amarc.radio and to the "Devmedia" list.

340 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 1, 1994 / November 30, 1994


THE MOON IS DEAD! GIVE US OUR MONEY! WINS THE 1994 HERSKOVITS AWARD


SECTION: BOOKS


LENGTH: 307 words


 

Portsmouth, NH- The Moon is Dead! Give Us Our Money! The Cultural Origins of an African Work Ethic, Natal, South Africa, 1843-1900 (Heinemann; January, 1994) by Keletso E. Atkins has been named winner of the African Studies Association Herskovits Award for 1994. The Moon Is Dead! Give Us Our Money! was also named a CHOICE Outstanding Academic Book. 

The Herskovits Award is presented annually to the author of the outstanding, original, scholarly work published in English on Africa. It was established in honor of Melville J. Herskovits, one of the founders of the Association and an acknowledged leader in the establishment of African studies in the United States. The Award was presented publicly on the occasion of the 1994 ASA Awards Ceremony held on November 3, 1994 in Toronto.

The Moon is Dead! Give Us Our Money! is a major contribution to the literature focusing on the formation of the South African working class, emphasizing African cultural practices and African resistance as a shaping force.

The Moon Is Dead! Give Us Our Money! is part of the Social History in Africa series, edited by Allen Isaacman and Jean Hay, published by Heinemann. The series has produced another Herskovits winner, Colonial Conscripts: The Tirailleurs Senegalais in French West Africa, 1857-1960 in 1992, and two finalists for the Award: Peasants, Traders, and Wives: Shona Women in the History of Zimbabwe, 1870- 1939 in 1993, and Women of Phokeng: Consciousness, Life Strategy, and Migrancy in South Africa, 1900-1983 in 1992.


LOAD-DATE: February 6, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


341 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 1, 1994 / November 30, 1994


SUDAN REPORT


BYLINE: Human Rights Watch


LENGTH: 1094 words


 

November 10, 1994

The government of Sudan has taken extraordinary measures to prevent the world from learning the specifics of its abysmal human rights record. According to "In the Name of God:" Repression Continues in Northern Sudan," released today by Human Rights Watch/ Africa, gross human rights violations continue in Sudan five years after a military coup ousted the elected civilian government and brought to power a military regime dominated by the National Islamic Front (NIF). Based on the human rights situation in both the north and the south, Human Rights Watch/Africa calls on the international community, through the United Nations and the European Union, to pressure Sudan for change.

As the current regime completes its fifth year in power, all forms of political opposition remain banned both legally and through systematic terror. Sudan has been profoundly altered through extensive purges of the civil service and by dismantling any element of civil society that challenges its narrow vision of an Islamic state. The whole country is politically controlled by a tiny ideological elite. 

The Sudanese government has imposed harsh punishments on dissidents and excluded or restricted independent observers, journalists, human rights monitors, and humanitarian organizations. Sudanese who attempt to speak out on human rights issues have been subjected to threats or arrest, even when seeking to meet with the UN. Human Rights Commission's Special Rapporteur on Sudan, Gaspar Biro.

Public dialogue in Sudan has been silenced, even for those who share a commitment to the implementation of shari'a law but disagree with the policies and practices of the present government. All political parties remain banned, and arrests and torture of their members continue unabated. Detentions of others believed to be or to have been political activists are designed to terrorize and intimidate through mistreatment and torture while in detention, often in unacknowledged, unofficial centers called "ghost houses." The report includes testimony of horrific torture practices over the last several years.

Armed conflict in the south of the country has provided the backdrop for particularly appalling abuse. The conflict has spread north; the peoples of Nuba Mountains of southern Kordofan have been suffering the combined effects of the cruelties of the army, government-sponsored militias, and the insurgent Sudan People's Liberation Army which the government seeks to crush.

"In the Name of God" highlights excerpts from a diary kept by a resident of Kordofan from late 1992 to April 1993, chronicling the large-scale displacement of Nubans, their forcible relocation under intolerable conditions, the abduction of children, the forced recruitment of boys as young as thirteen into military service, the destruction of churches, the abuses against women in displaced persons' camps, and the manipulation of the food supply for Islamic proselytization purposes.

Human Rights Watch/Africa documents the plight of displaced persons and squatters in urban areas of northern Sudan, including Nubians and southerners uprooted by the war. In 1992 hundreds of thousands of the displaced and squatters were summarily evicted from their homes in urban areas. Their property was destroyed under a purported urban renewal campaign which targeted the large non-Arab and non- Muslim population of the capital. This campaign continued in 1993, and an estimated 160,000 more people were similarly displaced in Khartoum in 1994.

The report also underlines the plight of displaced southern boys, many of whom have been detained in government dragnets and removed, without due process or notice to their families, to detention camps, with a view toward indoctrination and eventual incorporation into the government militia.

The NIF military government has also enacted and implemented a series of laws which place women and non-Muslims in a legally inferior relationship to men and Muslims. The death penalty and other forms of cruel and inhuman punishment are now expressly mandated for the crime of apostasy, the repudiation by a Muslim of his faith in Islam.

Human Rights Watch/Africa offers a series of detailed recommendations to improve the current situation in Sudan. Among them, Human Rights Watch/Africa:

-Calls upon the Sudanese government to halt torture, flogging, the use of shackles, the hudud punishment, and summary executions; cease imposing shari'a on non-Muslims; abolish the crime of apostasy and the death penalty; and establish equality in law of women and non-Muslims.

-Recommends that the United Nations Security Council institute an arms embargo on the warring parties in Sudan and authorize a full contingent of United Nations human rights monitors with access to all parts of the country.

-Urges the United States, United Kingdom, European Union, and other concerned governments and bodies to use their votes in international financial institutions to oppose Sudanese requests for loans or disbursements on the grounds of gross human rights abuses. Using individual testimonies gathered in the region, the forty-three page report highlights human rights abuses in northern Sudan to supplement the evidence of violations in the south detailed in "Civilian Devastation: Abuses by All Parties to the War in Southern Sudan," published by Human Rights Watch/Africa in July 1994.

Human Rights Watch/Africa, 485 Fifth Avenue, New York, NY 10017. Tel(212) 972- 8400


LOAD-DATE: February 6, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


November 1, 1994 / November 30, 1994


EQUATORIAL GUINEA: AMNESTY INTERNATIONAL RELEASES REPORT


BYLINE: Amnesty International


SECTION: DOCUMENTS


LENGTH: 294 words


 

November 1994 (updates an article printed in AFRICANEWS ONLINE 41.5-6.)

Re: Indalecio Abuy, Indalecio Eko, Tomas Nzo, Placido Mico, Victorino Bolekia Banay, Jose Mecheba Ikaka and Amancio Gabriel Nze

Following intense international pressure including that from Amnesty International, all the above named men have been released. 

Indalecio Abuy, Indalecio Eko and Tomas Nzo were released on 11 October 1994. However, for some days they were not allowed to leave Niefang, the town where they had been arrested and held. These restrictions have now been lifted. Amancio Gabriel Nze was released on 12 October, but for a few days after his release he had to go to the police station everyday.

Placido Mico, Victorino Bolekia Banay and Jose Mecheba Ikaka were released from Bata prison on 13 October.

Placido Mico and Victorino Bolekia Banay returned to Malabo, the capital of Equatorial Guinea on Bioko Island where they reside, on 16 October. However, Jose Mecheba, who was to travel to Malabo on 20 October has been prevented, on several occasions, from traveling by the airport police. No explanation has been given by the police other than they have orders from higher authorities not to let him travel.

For further information, contact the International Secretariat of Amnesty International, 1 Easton Street, London WC1X 8DJ (Tel +44-71-413-5500, Fax +44-71- 956-1157) or SHARRRISO@IGC.APC.ORG


LOAD-DATE: February 6, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


November 1, 1994 / November 30, 1994


LESOTHO WOMEN WANT TO BE FIRST CLASS CITIZENS


BYLINE: WORK FOR JUSTICE (Maseru)


SECTION: WOMEN


LENGTH: 840 words


 

October 1994

Women are handicapped because of the legal system which makes it very difficult for them to own or inherit land, to own or run businesses, to sign contracts, to buy "unnecessary goods" or to get credit. Most women can't even get passports for themselves or their children without the permission of their husbands (who may be away working in the mines, and inaccessible). If, despite their many handicaps, women do develop income generating businesses, husbands can take them over and claim the profits. Under both systems of law applied in Lesotho, married women are treated as minor children, without the right to sue or be sued. Under customary law a woman is never regarded as an adult. Under common law show can have more rights, but only when she is single or widowed. Married women are always children before the law.

Although the Lesotho constitution guarantees basic human rights to women, and equality before the law, this guarantee is taken away in Section 18! Both customary and common law still apply in relation to matters which affect women: adoption, marriage, divorce, burial and inheritance of property. Thus the constitution contradicts itself, and , in the end, leaves over 50% of the adult population with status of children! 

Women do not have control over their own reproduction. Almost 60% of women are married by the age of 19, and the first baby is usually born soon after. A 1993 study revealed that 82% of girls wanted only four children or less. But 51% of the boys wanted five or more, and it is still the men who control reproduction. Family planning services are available in Lesotho, but in many rural areas women don't even know they exist! Those who do use some form of birth control often do so surreptitiously because their husbands strongly disapprove. The older, natural method of contraception (not having intercourse during breast feeding, which usually lasted two years) is disappearing in part because the woman's in-laws, and not the woman herself, decide when she must begin weaning the child. Abortion is illegal, even for health reasons, or following rape. 282 per 100,000 women die in child birth (almost 3 out of every 1000).

Yet a woman is usually left out of the decision making process regarding her own fertility! She may find herself treated more like a little valued breeding animal than like a respected adult human being. Women are not adequately protected from male violence. Many husbands believe they are entitled, before the law, to subdue their wives and children by violent means. Alcoholism is a major problem among Basotho males, and probably contributes significantly to injuries from domestic violence against women and children. Significant female violence against males or children is much less common. Adequate studies of common phenomena like "wife beating" don't yet exist, although anecdotal evidence is overwhelming. However, at QE II Hospital in January 1993 40% of patients were treated for injuries from assaults, stab wounds, rapes, burns and gunshot wounds. Most of the injuries were caused by males attacking other males, but a third of those wounded (usually also by males) were women. There are few legal protections for women assaulted by their own husbands.

Women have considerable coping and organizing skills. Women have gathered into hundreds of little credit societies, where they pool their own meager funds to make credit available to each other. There are thousands of other little income generating organizations, through which women help each other set up brewing, catering or dressmaking enterprises. Women have organized many of the little private creches and schools springing up around the country. Many of the institutions for the disabled have been conceived and developed by women. Women's church organizations are powerful forces in Lesotho's communities. Women are active in most of the other NGOs and in many informal societies seeking to improve the lives of their families, their communities and their country.

This article is based on interviews with Debbie Gill, Editor of "Women and Children in Lesotho, l994."

Excerpted from the October, 1994 issue of "Work for Justice," a quarterly newsletter of Transformation Resource Center, PO Box 1338, Maseru 100, Lesotho; phone, 314 463.


LOAD-DATE: February 6, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


344 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 1, 1994 / November 30, 1994


UGANDA DON'T LET YOUR CHILD BE A JOURNALIST


BYLINE: Charles Onyango-Obbo, THE MONITOR (Kampala)


LENGTH: 1547 words


 

October 17, 1994

As the man on the street said, we have seen big things since "The Monitor" Editor-in-Chief Wafula Oguttu was arrested by the government in a fit of madness on October 6; and released about 24 hours later.

The charges against him, that he defamed three ministers when "The Monitor" published in a July 19, 1994 story alleging that the minister's performance had been criticized by President Yoweri Museveni at a meeting at Rwakitura, were withdrawn. That is an ugly sign, because when a government lets you off on a charge that could cost you six months in jail, it is because they might want to get you in on one that keeps you behind bars for three years.

However, one of the greatest revelations of Waf's arrest was his mother. She is a tough cookie. She arrived at Central-Police Station in the evening and declared; "I am not leaving here without Filipo." Philip was Waf's name until he ate something funny which went to his head and he dropped it. 

After she had been persuaded that the policemen would not eat her son, towards midnight she broke off her vigil.

Since Waf's release, I have learnt that to be doted on you need one of two things: either to be very powerful like President Yoweri Museveni; very rich like James Mulwana; or to be a journalist who has been jailed unjustly.

At "The Monitor" since Waf's release, all the visitors' chairs are piled outside his office. On Sunday night I left the office at 10:15 p.m., and there was still a respectable queue of sympathizers and solidarity stampers waiting to have their say. I have counted two international television interviews, and a couple of diplomatic visits.

There is a complicated process going on here. And it is the product of the peculiar politics of Uganda under NRM.

When it came to power in 1986, the NRM suspended political party activities. They argued that the country needed a breathing period to heal wounds, and that fractious party politics would make that impossible.

However, they made one important concession. These parties would be free to publish newspapers to push their political line.

The mainstream newspapers then felt flattered by the special status the government had accorded the press. They accepted the suspension of political parties for the reasons given by the NRM, and gave the government a very good press for the first time in three years. Newspapers like the pro-DP "Citizen" kept up a vicious tirade against the NRM. It wasn't long before it went into oblivion. "Citizen" made two mistakes. First, it was hysterically critical of the NRM at a time when the Movement was very popular in the market the paper circulated in. Secondly, while it campaigned for the suspension of the party activities to end, it kept alive the DP's rivalry with UPC, thus suggesting that freedom should be available to all other parties except UPC.

It stumbled into the hole most journalists and newspapers fell into when they supported the suspension of party activities. There could be no freedom for DP only; just as the press should not have been short-sighted to imagine that somehow a government could tolerate a free press, but not a free political activity. There were cautionary articles in the media on this subject, but they were largely ignored.

But this co-habitation could not go on peacefully forever. Because once there was no politics organized independent of the NRM, it was not going to be long before the press should have been to take on issues that should have been handled by opposition political parties. Soon the press was campaigning directly against human rights abuses in the north, instead of just reporting about them. It was agitating against unfairness in the distribution of public jobs an development projects-until the largely ineffective "anti-sectarian" law of 1988 was promptly passed to put an end to that.

But the pressure continued, and even for the government-owned newspaper "New Vision" to remain viable and credible, it had to reflect these concerns. At one point it was the leading outlet for the reporting official corruption, the miserable life of the people, and student and staff discontent at Makerere University.

The longer the parties remained on the shelves, the more themes which should have been the subject of political campaigns found their way into the papers. It was inevitable therefore that the NRM would begin to see newspapers and free journalism as more of a political activity than a journalistic enterprise.

So while a free press was s necessary component of the NRM strategy of muzzling the parties, it had to be controlled before it grew out of control. The result was the pattern of harassment of journalists, followed by a long break of freedom, then a return to harassment.

But if that was all, the journalists would live with it as part of their "professional hazards". However, because the absence of organized free politics made newspapering look more like political agitation than conventional journalism, the government brought the language and the weapons from political struggle to its confrontation with the media.

This language was bizarre and intimidating. The NRM has been fighting political groups which cannot oppose it in parliament or open campaigns. Therefore there has been no normal debate where opposing points of view contest for public acceptance.

In that situation, the NRM can do no better than call the parties names; "divisive," "sectarian," "authors of the bloodshed of the past," "murderous UPC," "reactionary DP" etc.

The parties reply in the same currency; "militaristic NRM," "sectarian," "sellers of the country to foreign interests," "corrupt regime." All this because there is not forum for open and honest disputation being cultivated.

Thus when a story which is critical of the government appears in the paper, the charges follow as it were part of the stale political battle. The paper will be accused of trying to "discredit the NRM government," "putting the cabinet into disrepute," "opposed to the unity of Uganda," "being used by UPC," "fighting DP's battles." When a pre-NRM journalist criticizes the government, he or she is immediately labeled a "kipinga mizi."

Therefore a wrong report in a newspaper is never treated as an error; not is any article which is critical of the government considered to have been written or published in good faith. It can only be one thing; the work of an enemy. And it cannot combated with words or presenting the facts which the government claims to be truth. The editor of the newspaper is treated like he was a fighter in a battle field-jailed. Or of not, denounced in official propaganda, at rallies or state- monopolized media.

The life of journalists in this country will only improve if there is sufficient freedom to allow groups to raise the issues of government conduct, thus removing the direct burden from the press.

As long as these wider political freedoms are not there, these issues will continue to appear in the press. And the government will continue to treat independent journalism as hostile political opposition.

Journalists will continue to be attacked by politicians at rallies instead of print, to be arbitrarily jailed, and to be heroes for the wrong reason. If you asked any journalist whether he wants to be famous for writing a great story or being jailed unfairly, he will tell you he wants to be famous for writing. I see no sign that the NRM will allow that to be.

THE MONITOR is published by The Monitor Publications Ltd. (Uganda) P.O. Box 12141, Kampala. Phone: 251353; fax: 251352.


LOAD-DATE: February 6, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


345 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 1, 1994 / November 30, 1994


DEPORTED EDITOR: 'THE PRESS IS CRITICAL TO DEMOCRACY."


BYLINE: Africa News Service


LENGTH: 1494 words


 

EXCERPTS FROM AN INTERVIEW

November 1994

Q: Tell us about your life in the past month, what you've been through.

A: We've had quite a difficult experience or series of difficult experiences, beginning first with a visit I received one Monday morning from the immigration director, summoning me to his office for some questioning.

That morning, on the front page, two MPs were challenging the military leader, Mr. Jammeh, on a particular issue. We had an editorial where, as usual, we were pressing for the military to come up with a credible timetable to democratic civilian rule. And on the back page, we had a story of a German diplomat visiting in Dakar who had said in an interview with our reporter that the military should defend, not rule. That was the particular thing that seemed to have angered the military establishment in the country. 

They kept me there for a whole day asking all kinds of questions. I had to write a statement and then I was taken to the Immigration Office where I also had to write a statement. And finally they released me at 5:30 in the evening.

I was accompanied back to my home by an Immigration agent as well as a Labor Officer. The mission was to find out all the foreigners I had working for me and what was their status.

That was followed by Immigration and Labor as well as Social Security and Customs people checking into all of my books. They were surprised to find that we had just done our audit and the audit had been conducted by a reputable accountant, Panel K. Foster, an international auditing firm that anyone who wants to cheat doesn't go to. And most of our records were in order.

We had a few refugees working with us from Liberia and also from Nigeria and Sierra Leone. Some of these were professional people. Some of them were just casual workers but we thought we were making a contribution to society by employing these refugees. They are not allowed to work under immigration law, they told me, but they never showed us the law.

Following that, the reporter who had written the story about the German diplomat was picked up by plain clothes men who did not properly identify themselves. He spent a whole day at the police station. They wanted him to name a police informer who had given him the story, and of course he refused to do it. After about 6:00 or 7:00 they released him.

The following Friday, we published a story, saying construction companies were laying off hundreds of people because there was no work, reflecting the malaise which had begun to set in following the coup. Apparently, the government didn't like that, so I was summoned and they took me far into the countryside, to an unknown destination, near the Senegalese border.

After two days. an official told me that they had instructions to take me back to my residence. The man told me, "Mr. Best, from now on you have to be very careful what you publish in your newspaper." But he didn't explain. It turned out that they had already signed my deportation order, but they rescinded it because of intense political and diplomatic pressure.

Two weeks later, on a Sunday morning, I found the same Immigration jeep at my gate. The Immigration man, with a sheepish look on his face, said to me, " I came to take you with me, I want you to go with me back to your office to find out whether you have any foreigners there. "I said, "There are no foreigners there. The office doesn't open until 10:00," but he said he wanted to make sure.

When we got in the jeep, he took me to the airport and turned me over to another officer. Fortunately for me, my sister-in-law, who works for the UN Developmental Program, had a UN jeep to take her and my wife with her to the airport, and the two of them were sitting in the car inside the airport area waiting to see what would happen to me.

I spied the jeep, waved to them and they threw kisses back. I had on only my T- shirt. But my wife, who knew what going to happen to me, brought my jacket with her. As we passed the jeep, she called out to the senior officer who was in front and said, "Could I please be allowed to give him his jacket?" and he said, "Is there any money in it?" He checked for money and there was no money in it. He took the jacket and handed it to me.

Q: And what transpired when you got to Monrovia?

A: I was surprised. The deputy foreign minister was there to greet me with a whole contingent of the press as well as a group of family members and friends. It was a rousing reception. The following morning people welcomed me on the streets and said, "We're glad you're back and now we think we can have "The Observer" again." The void "The Observer" left when we were forced to stop publishing on the 2nd July 1990 has never been filled, they told me.

Q: What has happened with "The Observer" in Gambia?

A: The chaps we left behind are courageous and determined to keep the paper going. The paper comes out everyday and it's forthright.

Q: I've heard that people weren't very encouraging when you went to Gambia to start the paper.

A: When I got there they told us that Gambians were not ready for this. They said the country was 80% illiterate, so who'd read the paper, that 10-to-20 people read (each copy) in The Gambia, so who would buy it, and that the government talks about commitment to press freedom but they don't mean it. I said to them, "Any freedom that you have and don't use, you never know if you really have it or not. You have to test it."

Q: We've seen the growth of an independent press all over Africa.

A: Yes, it is a growing phenomenon, thanks to the developing awareness of the African public to public issues and to the growth of the democracy movements. I think that what has been happening in southern Africa, particularly South Africa, in the past three years has made a tremendous impact, and the collapse of communism and the emergence of one superpower also encouraged the democratic movements throughout the continent.

People are always interested in expressing themselves. In The Gambia, people were not used to it. But "The Observer" changed all that. Suddenly everything was being discussed in the papers. That won us many friends, but also powerful enemies. You have to be socially responsible. If something would hurt the society by publishing it more than it would help it, you have to take a second look at it. In that context, we tried to put into the paper those things that would elevate the society and not things that will bring it down.

The press is a critical vehicle in the quest of greater democracy and human rights. Without it, tyrants have a field day. I think it's significant that you people have as your first amendment of your constitution the guarantee of freedom of the press. That is the saving grace of your democracy.

Q: After what you've been through, why do you persist? Why are you even thinking of re-starting your paper in Liberia?

A: I come from a journalism family. My uncle, who went to jail two or three times, started writing in his 20s, and until he died in 1986, he was still struggling to save Liberia. Our continent is in a grievous and pervasive crisis. Many people, including many Africans, have given up on Africa. But we are aware that other parts of the world went through crises, tragedy and destruction. Europe. Your own country. You had a civil war, but that wasn't the end of the world, thank God. Im an eternal optimist and I always strive towards a better future.


LOAD-DATE: February 6, 1995


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


November 1, 1994 / November 30, 1994


THE GAMBIA: OBSERVER BOSS DEPORTED


BYLINE: THE DAILY OBSERVER (Banjul)


SECTION: MEDIA


LENGTH: 1227 words


 

October 31, 1994

The managing director of the "Observer" newspaper, Kenneth Y. Best, was yesterday afternoon deported to Monrovia, Liberia, by the Gambian Immigration authorities. This newspaper is yet to be told why Mr. Best has been deported, but according to Radio Gambia, quoting a press release from the Immigration Department, Mr. Best was deported because of some taxes he (or his company) owes to the Government, among other things.

The Radio Gambia announcement also claimed that the company had been reported for employing foreigners who do not either have residential or work permits or both. And as a result of this, Mr. Best was deported having been considered "an undesirable alien". 

Retrospective -- However, it is important to state that some two months ago, Mr. Best was summoned by the Minister of Interior, Lt. Sadibou Hyadura, in connection with an article carried in the US-based "Independent" newspaper.

This writer, who was acting editor at the time, accompanied Mr. Best to the Minister to listened to what he had to say. And immediately we entered the office, this is that the Minister remarked among other things, "Mr. Best, we have got a security problem with you and, in fact, we were going to ask you to park off and leave the country, but we thought we should call you to hear your side of the story before we could take any action."

The Minister then showed Mr. Best the article which quoted him as having said, among other things, that the military in Africa do not have a track record of fulfilling their promises. "They make grandiose promises when they come to power but nothing is achieved," the "Independent" quoted Mr. Best as having said. The controversial "they", Mr. Best insisted, did not refer to the AFPRC per se.

However, it appeared that Council felt that it referred to them. In explaining his side of the story, Mr. Best told Lt. Hyadura that it was a general comment he made and that he was not referring to any particular military government. Mr. Best also told Lt. Hyadura that the American journalist who came to interview him had touched on a lot of issues. "In as much as I made some negative comments about the nature of the military in Africa, I also said some positive things about the AFPRC, but unfortunately the journalist did not use them," Mr. Best explained.

But, Mr. Best added, that it was no surprise to him because he should have known better than Western journalists since, in most cases, only look out for the negative things; they are not normally interested in the positive side.

In conclusion, Mr. Best told the Minister to tell Chairman Jammeh and Council that he had said a lot of good things about the AFPRC in the interview, which never appeared. He regretted the incident and took the opportunity to inform Lt. Hyadura that he had started writing a 250-page book on the coup. "We have gone far with the writing of the book and I can assure you that the book will take into account all the good things you have done,"

Mr. Best told the Minister. Lt. Hyadura then said he was going to convey Mr. Best's reaction to Chairman Jammeh after which a decision would be taken. Many events unfolded since that summons- arrests, detentions, visitations by Customs Officials, Immigration, Social Security and Labour officers to the "Observer" office.

We also received many calls from the authorities expressing reservations about certain stories this newspaper had carried, including a complaint about why the Chairman Jammeh's Set Setal activity in Brikama was not carried on the front page but rather on page three, at a time when we had the Chairman's picture and story on the front page as the lead story, among others.

Deportation of Mr. Best -- The last blow to this newspaper came yesterday when Mr. Best was arrested by Immigration officers, at the gate of his residence in Kanifing at around 8:30am as he had just returned from the offices of the "Daily Observer" in Bakau. He had come to the "Observer" building to open the door and was on the verge of going to church when he met with officers at his residence's gate. There how was picked up and driven to the Banjul International Airport where he was made to board on ADC carrier bound for Monrovia. He had waited for few hours at the airport before finally boarding the aircraft at a little after 2 pm. His wife, Mao Gen. Best, shocked but courageous, drove up to the Airport to give Mr. Best a jacket to put on since he had on just a casual shirt. The jacket was reportedly rejected, but was accepted after Mr. Best a jacket to put on since he had on just a casual shirt. The jacket was reportedly rejected, but was accepted after Mrs. Best had pleaded with the officers

Behind-the-scenes Maneuvers -- Meanwhile, while Mr. Best was waiting for the flight, Dr. Lenric Peters, a renowned Gambian surgeon and author, and Robert Collingwood, the European Union delegate in Banjul, had gone to see Lt. Yahya Jammeh to revoke the deportation order, but without success. It is reported that both the Head of State and his Vice Chairman said no to the men's request. Consequently, plans went as scheduled and the "Observer" boss was finally deported.

Mr. Best in Monrovia -- At around 7 pm Mr. Best called to say that he had arrived safely in Monrovia where he was shocked by the "large turn-out" that came to welcome him at the airport. As courageous as ever, Mr. Best, fondly called Bishop by the Observer staff, because of versatility in theology, sent a message to the newspaper staff that the paper was no longer his property, but instead it belongs to the people. Mr. Best left behind his wife, sisters and children and many other dependents. He came to The Gambia in 1990 and started the paper, the first ever daily newspaper in The Gambia, in May 1992. He holds a B.A. degree in English and Political Science and a Master's degree in journalism from Columbia University in the USA. He has spent over 30 years in journalism and was at one time Deputy Minister of Information in Liberia, his native country.

DAILY OBSERVER is published at P.M.B. 131 Banjul, The Gambia Tel:(220)496608 Fax:(220)496878.


LOAD-DATE: February 6, 1995


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


November 1, 1994 / November 30, 1994


TRACING THE BLUES TO TIMBUKTU


BYLINE: WEEKLY MAIL (Johannesburg)


SECTION: CULTURE & MUSIC


LENGTH: 867 words


 

November 4, 1994

An unusual collaboration between Western guitar wizard Ry Cooder and Malian bluesman Ali Farka Toure has produced one of the best-selling African albums ever, writes Fred de Vries

It's a daunting task interviewing Ali Farka Toure about the exceptional album he has recorded with Ry Cooder. The man lives in Bamako, capital of Mali, and for hours on end the telephone operator can't get through. Then, when we finally manage to make some kind of connection, it turns out that Toure doesn't speak English or much French.

So we settle for a faxed interview that goes through his record company in London, is translated into French and then into a Malian language, then back into French, back into English and finally finds its way back to Johannesburg. The process takes two days. So much for the globalisation of pop and technology. 

But it's worth the effort. Because the result of Toure's unusual collaboration with American guitar virtuoso Cooder, Talking Timbuktu, is brilliant and deservedly one of the best-selling African albums ever.

It's full of soothing, hypnotic music that goes way beyond the usual 12-bar blues format. The rhythms, lyrics and Arabic-influenced vocals are often very West African, while the unmistakably melancholic blues-feel makes it accessible to our Western ears. It's just a bit sad that, once again, it has taken an American name to sell an African record.

Fortunately, Cooder is no Paul Simon. He didn't need this album to revitalize an aching career. And consequently he didn't turn this African-American partnership into an ego trip. This is very much a Toure album, spiced up with Cooder's subtle guitar-playing and production.

Apparently great mutual respect exists between the musicians. During the sessions 55-year-old Toure referred to Cooder as "master", which had the much younger Cooder "squirming". But Toure says he used that term because Cooder is "a master of the guitar".

The two guitarists met in England, recalls Toure. "We were both in London at the same time. So I feel (the collaboration) was meant to happen. It's difficult to explain, but when we met, immediately there was something between us and we were sure something important could be achieved."

For the sake of the spoilt Western consumer, the music on Talking Timbuktu has been labeled "African blues". Toure doesn't like the label, saying it doesn't do justice to the variety and the depth of the music.

"My music is much more than what you call African blues. It is music from deep within the cultures of Mali and it is reflective of the Malian people. I would think that what you call African blues is only one millionth of my music."

Nevertheless, Toure, who has been called "Africa's John Lee Hooker", admits to being influenced by American blues, which he first heard in the late 1960s. He was immediately struck by its similarities with Malian music, often referred to as the origin of the blues.

"A student friend of mine had some records of Albert King, James Brown, John Lee Hooker, Jimmy Smith and Otis Redding. And when I heard this music I knew it had been taken from here. I liked the music but I could hear it was really Malian music with small changes -- the essence of this music is African but more specifically it is Malian."

Toure is clearly getting tired of that blues connection.

"The words in blues music don't teach us anything," he grumbles. Hence you won't find any "I woke up this morning with the mean women and sour whisky blues round my neck" lyrics on this album.

The theme is not wallowing in self-pity, but giving guidance and praise, as the old African troubadours have done for centuries.

"The words of my songs deal with things that are important," says Toure. "The need for everyone to work for the good of all, for all people to be truthful. The need to praise those who have done good works.

"These are stories with morals teaching people to move in the right direction. And those messages and themes do not change with the times."

The Weekly Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media Contact: M&G Media, 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025.


LOAD-DATE: February 6, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.
