Africa News


November 1, 1994 / November 30, 1994


CONTINENT AFRICAN LINK-UP A BOOST FOR JSE


BYLINE: WEEKLY MAIL (Johannesburg)


LENGTH: 920 words


 

November 4, 1994

The linking up of African stock exchanges should strengthen the Johannesburg Stock Exchange (JSE) as an emerging market, attracting outside investors, reports Teigue Payne

International investment houses are increasingly positive about emerging stock markets and though Africa has hardly benefited from this trend, it is likely to soon. Some foreign investors will divert funds away from equity investment in South Africa to invest in other African markets.

American investment house Morgan Stanley, which launched its Africa Fund in April 1994, is one such fund which will be diverting. Within the next two years, it will be reducing its investment in South Africa and increasing it in less developed African markets, the Africa Fund's principal and portfolio manager, Marianne Hay, told the African Stock Exchanges conference in Johannesburg last week. Morgan Stanley's Africa Fund is now one of eight funds which focus on Africa. All have been started in the past few years. 

Morgan Stanley's Africa Fund goal in allocating its assets launched was to place 50 percent in South Africa, with the rest spread between sovereign debt, investment in other African countries and investment in non-African companies which derive income from Africa.

Now Morgan Stanley has decided to reduce its investment in South Africa to 35 percent of assets because this country is a relatively developed market, and a hothouse for local equity investment because of exchange control. And South Africa is flavor of the month internationally, whereas Morgan Stanley is looking for new opportunities.

Currently, South Africa, Namibia, Botswana, Zimbabwe, Swaziland, Mauritius, Kenya, Nigeria, Ghana, Ivory Coast, Egypt, Tunisia and Morocco have established stock exchanges. Zambia, Malawi, Tanzania, Uganda and Cameroon are in the process of setting up stock exchanges.

According to the World Bank's International Finance Corporation, total capitalization of African stock exchanges is about $233-billion, but of this the Johannesburg Stock Exchange accounts for $217-billion. The next biggest stock market on the continent is Cairo, which has a capitalization of $3,8-billion. Cairo has 674 listed companies, slightly more than the JSE's 647. The capitalization of African stock exchanges is tiny compared to the total capitalization of world stock exchanges of about $16-trillion.

In 1993, the top performing African stock exchange was Zimbabwe. Its price index in US dollar terms rose 123 percent. Mauritius followed with 51 percent, Ghana with 38 percent, Ivory Coast with 34 percent and South Africa with 31 percent. Worst returns were from Botswana (-12 percent) and Nigeria (-18 percent).

At the conference, both Hay and Michael Howell, head of global strategy of British investment house Barings Securities, were highly positive about economic growth prospects in Africa.

Their optimism was primarily based on expectations that the current world commodities boom will endure. But they also pointed to encouraging developments like the lifting of exchange controls, privatization, lower inflation and stable currencies in many African countries.

Howell says Africa has received about 0,1 percent of funds flows to emerging markets in recent years. With flows to emerging markets generally expected to grow strongly, and given the brighter outlook for Africa, South Africa can expect an inflow of $1-billion to $1,25-billion a year. Collectively, other African countries can expect $250- million to $300-million a year.

Though Africa is still blighted by perceptions that it is plagued by civil war, drought and malaise, Hay warned against viewing it as homogeneous. Morgan Stanley, she said, views it as a sandwich: North Africa and Southern Africa, which had relatively sound economies, sandwiched sub-Saharan Africa, where there was perhaps most potential.

Hay says investment in African emergent markets is back to front compared with other emerging markets. Companies listed on African stock exchanges are largely in consumer goods, whereas generally this is characteristic of the last stage of development of emerging markets. In other emergent markets, telecommunications and utilities like power are at the first stage. As these are now being privatized in many African countries, this indicates major investment opportunities.

The Weekly Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media Contact: M&G Media, 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; hone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025.


LOAD-DATE: February 6, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


349 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 1, 1994 / November 30, 1994


CONTINENT PRIVATE SECTOR PARTICIPATION IN NATIONAL DEVELOPMENT


BYLINE: Alieu O. Faal, DAILY OBSERVER (Banjul)


SECTION: BUSINESS/ECONOMICS


LENGTH: 1494 words


 

November 2, 1994

It is no surprise that adequate and efficient infrastructure is the linchpin of economic and social development and the lack of it in developing countries is hampering economic growth and frustrating the reform efforts of may African governments. If we in the Gambia are to cherish our objective of promoting economic and social developments we should look to the private sector.

A growing number of countries in the region are turning to the private sector to provide efficient facilities and/or services that have traditionally been seen as natural monopolies and were heavily regulated and controlled by the state. These include: roads, transport, electricity, water, airports, and ports facilities, telecommunications, and postal services. 

If an archetypal economist was asked why, in one word, society would benefit from the privatization of state-owned enterprises, and the answer would be "efficiency". Private Enterprise -- It is widely accepted that government departments are managed to achieve a variety of national objectives intertwined in the complexities of politics, while private enterprises are largely managed to earn profits, and cost efficiency and market responsiveness are important to that pursuit. The more competitive the markets in which the private enterprise operates, the more it is compelled by its objective of profit and survival to operate efficiently.

The widely articulated rationales for the vogue for privatization in the developing countries have generally focused on perception of waste, lethargy, economic mismanagement, inefficiency, and poor quality of service in the operations of state-run enterprises, as compared to expectations of dynamism, cost- effectiveness, high quality, accountability, and creative productivity in the operation of private enterprises.

At the same time there appears to be a countervailing reluctance to spin activities out of direct public control, a reluctance linked to both the protection of status quo benefits and to concern over the ability of private enterprise to respond to and serve the interest of the public.

The Gambia Public Sector -- The public enterprise sector in The Gambia was largely inefficient, characterized by over staffing and managerial weaknesses, which gave rise to the undue pressures on government finances and to difficulties in servicing foreign loans undertaken by these enterprises.

Structural Adjustment -- One of the key components of the structural adjustment policies implemented in The Gambia since 1985/86 has been the reform of the public enterprise sector. The broad objectives of the reform program have been to reduce the involvement of the public sector in activities that could be more effectively carried out by the private sector, and to improve the efficiency and financial performance of the public enterprises that would remain for the time being in the public sector.

Against this background, the reform of the public enterprise sector was expected to do the following: strengthening the management of several key enterprises, such as the GMBO, the GUC, and the GCDB; redirecting government managerial and financial resources to priority areas identified in the adjustment program; generating cash proceeds for the government budget deficit through the sale of pubic enterprises; and creating an enabling environment for new private investment, management, and modern technology in the private sector of The Gambia, that will enhance efficiency, promote greater competition in a market-oriented environment.

Public Sector Reforms -- In designing as effective program for the pubic sector reforms there must be link between the structure of an economy (free market economy as compared to a centrally planned economy) and the ability of privatization to satisfy that country's development objectives and goals. In order to be effective, the divestiture of state owned enterprises requires a suitable set of institutions, an appropriate regulatory framework that would promote a secure environment for stakeholders through special legal prerogatives, and a market- oriented institutional framework in achieving a desirable or measurable performance.

In addition to the institutional structures just described, there is another category that is essential to the success of privatization and that drives the difference between public and regulated private enterprises -the ability of government to define its influence over privatized firms. That is, the government must commit itself to laissez-faire by maintaining an anonymous and arm's-length relationship with the private enterprises. A relationship that is critical of a market-friendly economic environment.

If the government does not have the capacity to tie its own hands and insulate the enterprises from arbitrary intervention, the expected benefits of privatization are unlikely to be realized. Political forces will influence the way the enterprises are run with little attention given profitability or cost conditions of the privatized enterprise.

For example the 'de-hiring' process going on at the Gambia Airways would not have been accomplished if the government had intervened to safeguard the burgeoning unemployment rate in the country without due regard to the company's objectives of operating profitably.

There must be proper legal framework that conforms with international commercial practices and conventions if the involvement of the private sector in national economic development is expected to grow and attract wary foreign investment capital.

Modern Concepts -- Private sector participation takes many forms including selling off existing government-owned entities, operations and maintenance contracts, build, operate (BO), build, operate, transfer (BOOT) schemes. There are volumes of articles now available on how to go about implementing concepts, but many governments are pursuing all these options, and are looking particularly to BOOS to provide financing for new investment.

BOO involves the award of a concession, or right, for a specified period of time by a government entity to a private investor to arrange financing, construct, own and operate a facility to provide a service. This approach has become increasingly popular and a particular appropriate form for privatizing electricity and water facilities.

Task Ahead -- It is clear that much remains to be done to consolidate some of the gains already made in reforms of the private sector. While we continue to address the deep-rooted developmental constraints that confront our economy, the development process will unavoidably be a protracted one.

An important head-start to this end has already been made. The gateway vision should be made a reality and it is only through the development of adequate and efficient infrastructure combined with other private sector reform measures can we achieve our economic objectives of being the gateway for the region.

As the development process continues well into the 1990s, and the country finds itself delicately balanced between political change and crucial economic reforms, the growing need for efficient infrastructure far outstrips the available funding from our traditional sources of finance. We should therefore seek improvements in operating efficiently through greater private sector participation and create new points entry for private investors.

Spurred by favorable liberalized economic policies, the spate of privatization in the developing countries are likely to continue well into the 1990s, and The Gambia should not lag behind in the race to attract foreign private investment. DAILY OBSERVER is published at P.M.B. 131 Banjul, The Gambia Tel:(220)496608 Fax:(220)496878.


LOAD-DATE: February 6, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


350 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 1, 1994 / November 30, 1994


SUDAN: NEW DRY SEASON ATROCITIES ARE INTENDED TO DESTROY THE NUBA MOUNTAINS


BYLINE: SUDAN DEMOCRATIC GAZETTE (London)


LENGTH: 1947 words


 

November 1994

Reports from the Nuba Mountains area of South Kordofan suggest that the Khartoum regime is intending to target the civilian population there once more. In the coming dry season the regime plans to gain control of the whole area and to finally push the Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA) out of the region altogether.

Large scale troop movements have been observed in and around the Nuba Mountains in preparation for the offensive. Unlike in previous years, the regime's forces do not have instructions to capture slaves, take wives and mistresses, rape the women or ethnically cleanse the area by displacing the indigenous population to refugee camps in Northern Kordofan. This time the troops have been told to shoot on sight. There will be no subtlety about the regime's genocidal policy in this campaign. In the past, displaced civilians or escaped slaves have found an eager audience for their tales of atrocities. The regime intends there to be no survivors this time around to tell any tales about what went on.

SPLA Difficulties--The SPLA forces in the Nuba Mountains have been isolated from the rest of the organization for three years, following the schism at Nasir in 1991. They have not received their usual supplies in that time. The regime believes that there is a good chance of wiping them out completely and gaining total control of the Nuba Mountains area. 

Already the regime has set about encircling the area under SPLA control by taking control of communication routes and traditional hill passes used by the Nuba tribes for centuries. The regime's troops have been instructed to identify and take control of the water points in the area. This will mean that any individual able to slip through the encirclement will then have to face dying of thirst. In addition, local people have been prevented from harvesting their crops, which will now be harvested by the regime's forces and used as their own supplies.

Water and food can be scarce commodities in the Nuba Mountains, water especially, during the dry season. This is why the regime has chosen to use them as weapons against the local population. It will be impossible for large groups of people to survive the dry season if they are denied access to water.

It is by no means certain that the regime will be able to carry out its plan in practice. The Nuba people have watched the troop movements, been unable to harvest their crops, and so are well aware of Khartoum's intentions. The Nuba tribes know the area better than any of the soldiers or religious fanatics that Khartoum has imported into the area during the past five years of occupation.

Whatever the local traitors may have told the regime's forces, there will be plenty of secret pathways and water storage points in the hills that the regime is totally unaware of, which will hopefully ensure that the rebellion will continue beyond this dry season.

Unheeded Appeals--Over the past five years the Gazette has echoed many of the appeals to the international community to come to the aid of the Nuba people. In spite of the reports of massacres and ethnic cleansing, the international community has squarely failed to respond in an effective way. There is no reason to suppose that the response will be any different this time around.

It is clear that the Khartoum regime has been emboldened by the lack of an effective response to its criminal activities. What does a condemnation of human rights abuses matter to a regime which places no value on human life?

This dry season the regime's plans have gone further than ever before to destroy the Nuba people, wipe their homelands off the map and destroy their cultures. Here is an abject crime against humanity constantly ignored by the international community. It is as if those crimes and atrocities which do not happen in the full glare of the international media are not considered to happen at all. In the words of one Southern Sudanese refugee, "Blessed are the Bosnian Moslems, the Somalis and the Rwandans who die in front of international television cameras."

News from Other Fronts--The regime's military build up in the South appears to be a cautious one. It seems as if Khartoum is not entirely sure whether the Mainstream SPLA under Colonel John Garang is preparing an offensive of its own, and so does not want to over extend its forces. There are other reasons for the cautious approach, however, not least of which is the lack of fresh military supplies from China. The Chinese have been responsible for supplying Khartoum with the latest military hardware in recent years but now the supplies have stopped because the Iranian government has stopped financing them. The regime has resorted to sending antiquated equipment to the South and this is likely to prove to be of dubious value in the war against the SPLA. Whether the lack of Chinese supplies will be of great significance remains to be seen because the SPLA itself has been without a foreign backer and supplier since the collapse of the Mengistu regime in Ethiopia in 1991.

Concentration of Troops--Based upon recent calculations the regime now has about 110,000 troops deployed in Southern Sudan. When they came to power in 1989 the figure was a mere 20,000. The logistical problems involved in supplying such a large army spread out over the South are considerable.

The regime's forces only move out of their garrisons in large armored convoys. In order to do so, they need a regular supply of fuel. This is one of the most difficult commodities to supply to the South. Even supposing that fuel supplies can be delivered by barge, rail or air to Wau and Juba, it then has to be transported by land to the garrisons, and becomes an obvious target for SPLA attack. Scenarios such as this make it unlikely that the SPLA will be defeated in this coming dry season.

Targets of the Offensive--Overall, the targets for this year remain much the same as last. The regime would dearly love to gain control of the borders with Kenya and Uganda as well as recapturing Western Equatoria from the SPLA.

Troops have been preparing for breaking out from Juba and heading to staging posts in Eastern Equatoria at Kapoeta, Torit, Yei, Morobo, Kajokeji and Juba-Nimule road. The troops dispatched to Zaire and the Central African Republic (CAR), with French connivance and assistance, are far from ready for attacking Western Equatoria. They have logistical problems of their own and cannot decide how best to re-enter Southern Sudan. Troops have been concentrated at Wau in Bahr El Ghazal and at Tarekeka to the north of Juba. These will be spearhead troops for forcing a way into Western Equatoria when that order is given.

SPLA Factions--Khartoum is now experiencing the burden of being allied to the breakaway SPLA factions. These groups have splintered and formed several breakaways of their own, with the regime largely being their only means of supply. SPLA United has more or less ceased to exist. Commander Riek Machar, one of the original leaders of the schism at Nasir in 1991, is believed to have renamed his small group of supporters as the Southern Sudan Independence Movement (SSIM). "Sim" is an Arabic word meaning poison. If true, this latest move is an indication of Commander Machar's military weakness rather than strength. It is a last ditch effort to gain support by playing upon popular sentiments.

Nyuon and Kuayin--For their parts, Commanders William Nyuon Beny and Kerubino Kuuanyin Bol, although nominally still part of Reik Machar's set up, are now part of the regime's military coalition against the Mainstream SPLA. They receive their weapons and supplies from Khartoum and have even received some reinforcements. This has constituted an additional logistical burden for the regime.

William Nyuon has moved between his three bases of Mugeri, Lopit and Torit, under the protection of Khartoum's forces. He has not staged a further attack on the SPLA, laying siege to Torit, since he was defeated in September. However, reports abound that the regime has assigned him the task of co-ordinating operations with the Ugandan "Lord's Resistance Army", a rebel group in Northern Uganda trained and supplied by Khartoum.

Meanwhile, Kerubino Kuanyin Bol is based in his native Twic Dinka country of northern Gogrial in Bahr El Ghazal. It is believed that the regime intends to supply him with reinforcements from Abyei in Southern Korodofan, as well as from Aweil. Attempts to do so have been hampered by the end of season floods.

If Kerubino survives the rest of the rainy season, the regime intends to use his forces to clear northern Gogrial district of the Mainstream SPLA and link it up with the regime's new regional headquarters at Warrap. Much of Bahr El Ghazal would then be linked up with Upper Nile, denying the Mainstream SPLA access to large parts of the South.

Lam Akol--It is not known what Dr Lam Akol plans for the future are. Since he was expelled from SPLA United by Riek Machar last February, he has returned to Southern Sudan from Kenya to rebuild his power base. Reports suggest he is living in his native Shiluk area of Tonja. Dr Lam Akol makes no pretenses whatsoever about his alignment with the Khartoum regime.

Mainstream SPLA--The greatest problem facing Colonel John Garang is one of credibility as a fighting force since all the schisms in his movement. No one denies that the Mainstream SPLA has fought a convincing defensive war for the past three years. That is above question. However, wars of liberation are never won through purely defensive actions. In the coming dry season it will not be enough for Colonel Garang's forces to merely survive. The guerrilla army needs to conclusively demonstrate that it is still an effective fighting force by going on to the offensive on at least one of the war fronts in the South.

SDG is published at P.O. Box 2295 London W14 OND, UK


LOAD-DATE: February 6, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


351 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 1, 1994 / November 30, 1994


PAYING THE COST FOR LETHAL CARGO


BYLINE: Eddie Koch, WEEKLY MAIL (Johannesburg)


LENGTH: 694 words


 

November 4, 1994

United States authorities want to slap a multimillion dollar fine on an American firm that shipped 140,000 kg of toxic mercuric waste to South Africa in defiance of US law. The lethal cargo was allowed into this country in the early 1990s by the former government -- even though the cabinet had imposed a ban on imports of toxic waste.

Environmental groups say the case highlights the dangers of allowing toxic industrial materials into the country. "This is proof that our laws are not in line with international standards and that our companies do not have the expertise to adequately handle other countries' waste," says Chris Albertyn of Earthlife Africa. 

The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), a statutory body that monitors environment abuses in the US, said in a statement it was seeking punitive action against the Borden Chemicals and Plastics Operating Company for polluting local ground water and illegally exporting toxic materials to South Africa.

The EPA said "hundreds of thousands of pounds" of extremely toxic mercury byproducts were illegally shipped to Thor Chemicals in Natal, supposedly to be recycled for industrial purposes. Once the cargo arrived, says the statement, very little raw material was extracted and most of the load was incinerated -- causing air and water contamination in Natal.

A director and two senior officials from Thor, a British-owned firm located at Cato Ridge near Pietermaritzburg, are currently facing culpable homicide charges after two workers died allegedly due to high levels of mercury exposure at the factory.

Another worker has been in a coma for three years and 28 others have been diagnosed as having mercury poisoning symptoms. It is likely that many other employees at the plant have suffered chronic damage to their nervous systems.

The US Justice Department filed an indictment against Borden Chemicals in October this year after diplomatic staff at the American embassy in Pretoria carried out an extensive inquiry into the movement of mercury waste from the US to Thor Chemicals -- and the abuse of health and safety regulations at the plant.

While US waste management regulations made the shipments illegal, the South African government allowed the waste into the country -- even though former environment minister Gert Kotze had promised he would ban all imports of industrial toxins into the country.

Kotze justified flouting his own ban by saying Thor was able to extract useful mercury catalysts from the waste.

The EPA dismisses this claim and suggests the Borden-Thor transaction was a cheap way for the American firm to bypass strict controls on the management of waste in that country.

Earthlife has launched a national petition and demonstrations in protest against a recent White Paper, issued by the Department of Environment Affairs, which proposes to lift the current ban so that a subregion can be created in the country where limited amounts of waste from neighboring states can be imported into the country.

The Weekly Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media Contact: M&G Media, 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025.


LOAD-DATE: February 6, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


352 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 1, 1994 / November 30, 1994


SOUTH AFRICA: WILL THE RDP DELIVER THE GOODS?


BYLINE: Amrit Manga, NEW NATION (Johannesburg)


LENGTH: 3134 words


 

November 4, 1994

It is now more than a month since the government released its Reconstruction and Development Program (RDP) White Paper discussion document, its blueprint for addressing the apartheid legacy.

The release of the White Paper came amid tough warnings from some of the ANC's partners outside parliament that government should be careful not to water down the RDP in its attempts to appease business interests and seek reconciliation.

Since then, submissions received by the government's RDP Standing Committee have repeated some of these concerns, with the National Institute for Economic Policy (NIEP) warning that there is a danger of the RDP Base Document, adopted by the ANC and its allies as their election platform , being reduced to a "fairly worthless" document.

The institute points to significant departures from the Base Document, as the original RDP has come to be known, and says the White Paper, in its current form, stands to become a standard to measure the progress of a "very conservative austerity program".

"This," it says "will happen by default rather than design" because of some of the deficiencies of the White Paper. 

It is against the background of similar warnings that the question must be asked - will the reconstruction and development strategy outlined in the White Paper propel South Africa onto a path of sustained economic growth or trap it in a cycle of poverty and continued underdevelopment?

The NIEP is concerned that unless the government begins to give meaningful content to President Nelson Mandela's preamble to the White Paper, it could precipitate serious problems.

Quoting the preamble, in which the President says ". our people have elected us because they want change. Change is what they will get. we must put firmly into place the concrete goals, timeframes and strategies to achieve this change", the NIEP says of the White Paper: "The document lacks a clear statement of purpose. The process would have benefited enormously through the adoption of a more consistent and rigorous structure which includes an analysis of the situation, a summary of the policy objectives, the identification of priorities, the setting of indicative targets and time-frames."

It goes on to say that besides having "significantly revised some of the major strategies and policy recommendations of the original RDP" the White Paper "in many cases provides neither concrete goals nor a time frame for the achievement of RDP objectives."

The NIEP takes issue with the way in which the White Paper addresses the question of fiscal discipline in the context of reconstruction and development.

The White Paper elaborates the second of the RDP's six basic principles saying: "All levels of government must pay attention to afford ability, given our commitment to fiscal discipline and to achievable goals."

Commenting on this elaboration, the NIEP says that while it acknowledges the necessity for fiscal prudence, it must be regarded as a means to an ultimate goal and "cannot be taken as a goal in itself".

It goes on to add that "the use of fiscal policy to mobilize funding for medium and long term objectives of the RDP has been undermined by fears of a lack of fiscal discipline.

"In this sense, the White Paper seems to reflect the preoccupation's of the old Normative Economic Model of the apartheid regime," the NIEP argues.

It also criticizes the White Paper's lack of specific policy recommendations to implement the RDP objectives. "Fears of lack of fiscal discipline, the debt trap and a rising budget deficit have meant that the potential of fiscal policy to help realize some of the medium and long term objectives of the RDP is undermined in the White Paper."

Some of the recommendations, the NIEP says, lack details, such as time frames , as well as the source and amount of funding required for implementation.

In its submission, Cosatu express a similar concern, saying "the White Paper's commitment to fiscal discipline must not be implemented in a way which undermines the RDP.

"The RDP involves a massive expansion in welfare and service delivery by government to the vast majority of South Africans.

"This may in certain instances lead to an increase in public spending and employment in certain areas, while reducing it in others."

Cosatu argues that the Finance Ministry's call for government expenditure to be cut down from 22 percent of GDP to 17 percent over the next five years is driven more by a commitment to fiscal discipline than meeting the needs of implementing the RDP.

Equally worrying for the NIEP is the changing of the "key role of government" in economic transformation.

The institute adds that while the Base Document says the government must play a leading and enabling role in guiding the economy and market towards reconstruction and development", the White Paper reduces this role to government simply managing the transformation.

The NIEP submission also comes out strongly against aspects of the White Paper's Economic Policy Framework.

It says that while the Base Document states that "the RDP links reconstruction and development in a process that will lead to growth in all parts of the economy, greater equity through redistribution and sustain ability", the White Paper omits "redistribution" from its formulation.

"The omission of redistribution is a serious oversight which will have dire consequences for growth and the economic development of the country," the NIEP says.

"We strongly believe that the need for reconciliation must not be used to undermine the need for concrete measures to ensure changes to the pattern of distribution of wealth and income in this country."

Emphasizing the importance of a coherent redistribution policy, the NIEP says redistribution is central to the "attainment of sustainable growth through stimulation of domestic demand, and social and political stability." STATUS OF THE BASE DOCUMENT

Considerable attention has also been focused on the status of the Base Document following the release of the White Paper. Fears have been expressed in some quarters that the original RDP document adopted by the ANC-led alliance is being watered down and rewritten.

RDP Minister Jay Naidoo rejected this assertion but the NIEP remains concerned at the possibility that the original RDP may still be relegated to a worthless document of intentions.

It says in its submission: "The White Paper states that the original RDP document is considered the basic starting point for the RDP White Paper. and underpins the approach to reconstruction and development of the Government of National Unity (GNU)."

But the NIEP wants government to go step further than simply stating the importance of its reconstruction and development initiatives.

It says that "it is absolutely necessary to have an RDP Act that recognizes the Base Document as the guiding document. In its present form, the White Paper diverts from the Base Document in significant ways that directly or indirectly undermine the RDP.

"It is the view of the NIEP that the proposed RDP Act should commit the government to meeting its electoral mandate and embody the basic principles of the RDP." MONETARY AND FISCAL POLICY

While the institute recognizes the White Paper's commitment to the principle of zero-based budgeting, it says government does not provide any specific time frames within which it hopes to achieve this objective.

Cosatu expresses the same concern in its submission, saying: "The proposal for zero-based budgeting , according to which (government) departments will have to justify all their programs from scratch, could be an extremely important instrument for reorienting resources to meet RDP priorities."

But the federation goes a step further than the NIEP, saying zero-based budgeting must be introduced as soon as 1995/96.

It adds that the lack of firm target dates for the NIEP, saying zero-based budgeting suggests that the "government is not confident that it can implement. zero-based budgeting."

"In particular," says Cosatu, "the continued existence of the RDP Fund over the five-year period contradicts the approach of zero-based budgeting, which should operate on the basis that the entire budget is aligned to the RDP."

Cosatu expresses concern that there is still a view in government which equates the RDP Fund with total RDP spending. "This threatens to reduce the RDP to a marginal program of government," it warns.

The NIEP also takes government to task for "drastically" deviating from the Base Document on the question of monetary policy.

"Even more disturbing, is the extent to which the White Paper's discussion of monetary and financial policy deviates from the Base Document.

"A large number of the Base Document's recommendations that should have been elaborated further in the White Paper are not incorporated in its recommendations on monetary and financial policy.

"Among these are the Base Document's recommendations on creating Housing Banks, Community Banks and introducing concrete policy measures to 'combat discrimination' in financial services to establish 'prudent and non-discriminatory lending criteria', to change the boards of the Mutual Funds and the Reserve Bank and to 'include representatives from the trade unions and civil society.'"

The NIEP adds that the "absence of these issues in constructing the new monetary and financial policy demonstrates the extent to which the RDP's principle of democratization of institutions and people-driven processes have been compromised in the case of monetary and fiscal policy."

Unless these shortcomings are addressed, the NIEP warns, it will leave the concentration of financial wealth intact in the hands of a white minority. INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC POLICY

The NIEP, while accepting that the White Paper outlines measures government will take to cushion the impact of trade liberalization, remains skeptical of the depth of commitment on the part of the authorities to such a policy.

If the White Paper accurately reflects government policy on international trade, then why is it implementing General Agreement on Trade and Tariffs (GATT) measures when "an effective industrial policy is not yet in place" the NIEP asks. It is also critical of the fact that government does not provide details and time frames for implementing the measures referred to above.

But it is not only the implementation of trade liberalization measures, as required by GATT, that concerns the NIEP in the area of international economic policy.

The institute says "the extension of the principle of national treatment to foreign investors means that the government will extend to foreign investors treatment no less favorable than it accords to its own investors."

It also expresses concern that the White Paper does not impose any performance requirements with regards to expansion, management and conduct.

"Performance requirements cover provisions such as the requirement to export at a given level, to achieve a given level of domestic content, to accord a preference to domestic goods or services, to relate to the volume or value of imports of a foreign investor, or to restrict sales of goods or services in its own territory," the NIEP points out.

It however, concedes that such provisions are also absent from the Base Document but adds that the original RDP nevertheless states that the "democratic government must develop policies to ensure that foreign investment creates as much employment, technological capacity and real knowledge transfer as possible, allowing greater participation by workers in decision-making."

The institute says the White Paper should have elaborated each one of these points.

It cites the Australian example, where government uses the leverage of its purchasing power to influence the decisions of multinationals in order to achieve national economic goals.

"In an arrangement established eight years ago, prior to the current GATT agreement, the Australian government set up a 'Partnership for Development Program.'

"Each company selling more than a defined threshold to national, state and local governments was required to enter an agreement between the Australian government and the company's international headquarters. The details were negotiated between the company and the (Australian) Department of Industry and embodied in an agreement specifying export targets and research and development expenditures, which were based on formulae relating to the company's sales revenue in Australia and its level of imports," the NIEP explains. And by the end of the agreed period, which is usually seven years, the multinational has to achieve exports to the value of 50 percent of its imports and investment in research and development to the value of five percent of its revenue.

Cosatu is less critical of the White Paper's policy in international economic relations, saying it "supports the approach to foreign investment of 'national treatment'". However, Cosatu wants government to clarify its stance on the introduction of Export Processing Zones, as well as its commitment to maintaining labor standards. LABOR POLICY

According to the NIEP, there are significant differences between the White Paper and the Base Document on key issues of labor market policy such as collective bargaining, living wage, workplace empowerment, training and retraining and the right to information.

It says, for example, that while the Base Document supports a system of collective bargaining at national, industrial and workplace level, the White Paper's support extends only as far as national and industrial bargaining.

The significance of the White Paper's lack of support for workplace bargaining undermines the importance of organized labor in designing and overseeing changes, not only at national and industry level, but also at factory, shop and mine level.

Government's commitment to a living wage to stimulate economic growth is also questioned by the NIEP, which says that the White Paper omits an important requirement of the Base Document that argues that the establishment of a living wage is a prerequisite for economic growth.

In direct contrast to the Base Document, an argument implicit in the White Paper suggests that a living wage impedes growth.

Against the background of these submissions the NIEP says that in its current form, "the White Paper does not provide an integrated implementation program that corresponds to the original objectives and strategies of the RDP.

"Furthermore, the NIEP is concerned that the RDP might become limited to belong only a social net to cushion the effect of economic, political and social transformation."

NEW NATION is published at Darragh House 13 Wanders St. Johannesburg Tel:(011)333-2711 or (011)333-2721/2/3/4 Telex: 482226 Fax:(011)889-0630


LOAD-DATE: February 6, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


353 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 1, 1994 / November 30, 1994


NIGERIA: WHERE IS THE MONEY?


BYLINE: Utibe Ukim, NEWSWATCH (Lagos)


LENGTH: 6707 words


 

October 24, 1994

Nigeria earned $12.4 billion (N272.8 billion) additional revenue from oil sales during the nine months of the Gulf crisis in 1990 up to and including June 30,1994. The money came from increases in crude oil prices in the global oil market following shortfall in supplies to the market with the absence of Iraq and Kuwait.

The earnings were more than the federal government's revenue projections and receipts for any single year between 1989 and 1993.

However, unlike other oil-producing countries like Saudi Arabia, Libya, Algeria and Venezuela which promptly declared their earnings and directed the monies into visible projects with benefits to their citizens, the Nigerian government said nothing about the windfall.

In fact, the official government account for 1990 and 1991 released by the Central Bank of Nigeria, CBN, showed the government incurred a deficit for the two years. The deficit was N21.681 billion in 1990 and N35.31 in 1991. Actual government receipts were given as $7,789 billion in 1990 and $11.348 billion in 1991. The 1991 figure showed a decline of about $500 million from the budget estimates. 

William Keeling, a freelance reporter for the "Financial Times of London", incurred the wrath of the government when he reported the windfall had been mismanaged. He was deported from Nigeria. But the curiosity of Nigerians and that of the international community had been aroused.

Last month, Pius Okigbo, an economist who headed a government panel to reorganize the CBN, said at the submission of his panel's report that the windfall amounted to $12.4 billion or N272.8 billion at the official exchange rate of $1 to N22. The panel also found that the money was not paid into the federation account as required by law but into special dedicated accounts.

Those who had knowledge of, and access to it, Okigbo said, were Ibrahim Babangida, a general and the country's ruler until August 26,1993, and Abdulkadir Ahmed, who was the governor of the CBN until September 1993. The panel found that as at June this year, only $206 million was left in the accounts. The rest, it said, had been squandered.

Said Okigbo: "They were spent on what could neither be adjudged genuine high priority nor truly regenerative investment; that neither the president nor the governor (of the CBN) accounted to anyone for these massive extra budgetary expenditures; that these disbursements were clandestinely undertaken while the country was openly reeling with crushing external debt overhang. These represent a gross abuse of public trust"

NEWSWATCH learnt that government was surprised by both the findings of the Okigbo panel and his tough speech. When he submitted a draft to the presidency for approval, the presidency was reportedly rattled. Not knowing how best to respond to it, Okigbo was asked to help in drafting government's response. Soon after he delivered his speech, security agents reportedly took away all the copies from everyone present.

Oil money seems to have been a major weakness of the Babangida administration as it has been of most governments in the country since oil production started in 1958.

The issue of transparency in the management of oil revenue has become a critical question. Many Nigerians and as well as international financial institutions like the International Monetary Fund, IMF, and the World Bank have consistently raised questions about the management of the country's oil revenue. The dedicated account is seen as one more avenue for leakage. The practice with dedicated accounts, according to an NNPC official, is that the government sets aside a certain amount of crude whose proceeds would be used to fund specific projects. Control of such accounts is vested in the government through the CBN governor who is directly answerable to the head of state. The NNPC is only required to advise crude buyers on which particular account of the CBN to make lodgments. How the money is eventually spent is not its responsibility.

This raises an ethical question which Abacha referred to in January when he inaugurated a panel headed by Emmanuel Abisoye, a retired major-general, to probe the affairs of the NNPC. "In the past decade or so," said Abacha, "there had arisen a situation whereby the average Nigerian could legitimately wonder and complain as to why his country's earnings have not been reflected adequately in the well-being of our teeming populace. In a sense, our people with some justification feel outraged and short-changed by what they regard as persistent and massive leakage of their country's external earnings."

Babangida started the dedicated accounts in 1986 with 20,000 barrels per day, bpd, to fund the Nigerian Liquefied Natural Gas, NLNG, project. Proceeds of the sales were paid into a special account with the Midland Bank of London to create independent revenue source for the project which nearly every government has seen as a priority project. In April 1988, new accounts were opened following the allocation of 50,000 barrels of crude per day for other projects by the regime.

By the time Babangida left in August 1993, there were at least six such accounts funded by the allocation of 105,000 barrels per day - about six percent of the country's daily output of 1,85 million bpd. By 1993, the Midland Bank account, for instance, had $3,343 billion. Government borrowed from the account and directed an additional 40,000 bpd to NNPC to recoup the debt. NNPC could only recoup part of it. When the cash call was made for equity contributions by NLNG partners, government was short of funds since "the proceeds of the crude dedication was used up," said government sources. This prompted the decision in May 1993 to sell five percent of the government's share in the NNPC/ Shell/ Elf/ Agip joint ventures and 11 percent of its shares in the NLNG.

Developments like this prompted greater pressure on government for openness in the administration of these accounts. In response to the pressure of the internal community, especially the IMF and the World Bank, the present government pledged to discontinue the dedication of crude but instead to fund specific projects from direct budgetary allocation. It allocated $279 million as special treasury allocation to finance certain projects. Only the allocation for the NLNG project was to continue.

Whether this has been done remains to be seen. However, what the Okigbo panel found out does not give room for cheers, The Abacha government had actually increased the amount of dedicated oil from 105,000 bpd to 150,000 bpd at the end of June. The increase is a signal that the pattern may not have changed much.

The oil industry stinks. At every stage, from production to sales administration, the oil industry in Nigeria is characterized by inefficiencies, corruption and maladministration.

Among all oil producing nations, Nigeria has the highest cost of production put at $6 per barrel. The range in most oil producing countries is $2.5 to $4.00. The cost is made up of $3.50 as technical cost and $2.5 as cost of new investments and operator's profit margin.

Oil industry sources say that fraud and corruption account for the high production cost in Nigeria. The sources say that these are what ordinary Nigerians are paying for with the recent increases in the price of petroleum products by the government. With that increase, a liter of petrol now sells for N11 or $0.50, which is higher than petrol prices in Brazil and Indonesia where a liter of the product sells for $0.15 and in Venezuela and Argentina where it sells for $0.05 and $0.1875 respectively. In fact, the realization that Nigerians may be indirectly paying for the large-scale corruption within the oil industry is said to have created some division within the government on the timing and the rate of price increase. The Aisoye panel is said to have recommended a phased increase only when a reliable and cheaper transportation system had been put in place. The National Economic Intelligence Committee, NEIC, is said to have recommended a 100 percent increase this year followed by a minor increase in 1995. The NNPC is said to have asked for N8 per liter.

According to the World Bank, oil contracts in Nigeria remain unusually high. In a publication, "Adjustments in Africa, Lessons from Country Case Studies", the bank said that the cost of constructing a new export terminal at Bonny for the new Port Harcourt refinery put at $340 million was too high and "could be cut by two- thirds." Sources say that this view of the World Bank was confirmed by the findings of the Abisoye panel which submitted its report to the government in July. Abisoye himself had told the government at the submission ceremony that NNPC was a monument of corruption. He said: "NNPC does not respect its own budgets. NNPC does not respect its own plans. NNPC does not respect constituted authorities. The unwritten code in NNPC style of management therefore would appear to be everyone to himself and God for us all; make hay while the sun shines and loot all the lootables."

There have been several cases of mismanagement of fund through questionable expenditures. Presidency sources told NEWSWATCH that the Abisoye panel discovered that N71.39 billion of oil revenue earned by the country and lodged with various NNPC accounts was misappropriated through questionable deals and fraudulent practices between 1991 and 1993. The money is made up of $3.231 billion, N329.03 million and N519.219 Dutch Mark. This amount represents about 65 percent of the federal government's budget for 1994. The money is believed to have been improperly paid out of NNPC accounts mainly on the orders of government for jobs that were either over-inflated, totally unnecessary or imposed on the corporation by top government functionaries. And in many cases, the jobs were abandoned midway. These payments excluded the Gulf War windfall. These payments helped to build up a liability of $18 billion or N400 billion which the corporation carried as at September 1993.

The Gulf War earnings remain a controversial issue. Although the Okigbo panel report said it was $12.4 billion, sources say that the Abisoye panel found far less than that in the books. An official said that between October 1990 and April 1991, the extra earnings amounted to only $2.3 billion which by January 1992 had risen to $2.4 billion as a result of interest earned on it. The earnings formed what is called the Gulf War stabilization account. Of the total sales, which should have gone directly into the federation account, a source quoted the report as saying that the $2.4 billion was not noticed. Rather, on the instruction of the president, the proceeds were paid directly to contractors handling certain projects for the government. These projects include the controversial Aluminum Smelter project at Ikot Abasi which the World Bank said was "60 percent more costly than comparable projects elsewhere in the world;" the Ajaokuta Steel and the Itakpe iron ore projects as well as the government's debt buy-back program between 1991 and 1992.

The controversy surrounding the total earnings deepens with yet another claim that the Gulf War account shows net earnings to only $119 million. Dependable NEWSWATCH sources said that the NEIC, which is said to have studied the Abisoye panel report, found certain discrepancies in it. NEIC is said to have drawn the government's attention to two figures of $2.4 billion and another $119 million in the report. The two figures could not be right, NEIC is reported to have told the government. Oil industry sources told NEWSWATCH last week that the Okigbo report approximates the truth as the earnings from the multiple dedicated oil sales do not form part of the NNPC financial records.

The Abisoye panel is said to have found a case of immediate transfer of $755 million from NNPC's dedicated account to the CBN between April and November 1992. According to NEWSWATCH sources, the panel noted that the money was later paid by the CBN to Billingfinger & Berger Bau in Germany for jobs reportedly done by Julius Berger.

Another contentious expenditure which the panel reportedly unearthed was the payment of $57,595,242.46 to Lutin Investment Limited for the hire of coastal vessels under NNPC's strategic floating reserve program. Of the amount, $41.1 million was paid to Lutin after Philip Asiodu, the secretary to petroleum resources in the transitional council, had canceled the contract. The payment led to the sacking of six key officials of the corporation, including Edmund Daukuro, its managing director at the time. The men were initially charged to court but government subsequently dropped the charges. It is believed that Lutin was a front for top people in government who influenced the corporation to make the payments even when the contracts had been canceled.

NEWSWATCH was told that the entire strategic floating vessel program is a major source for diverting fund from the corporation. NNPC relies on coastal vessels for the transportation of petroleum products from Port Harcourt and Warri to Lagos. According to Aret Adams, a former managing director of the corporation, up-till 1987, NNPC depended on major marketers for the movement of products to Lagos. The marketers used 10 vessels with average capacity of 3,000 tons but their operations were considered unreliable and inefficient. NNPC hired a consultant to review the operations of the vessels. The finding of the consultant was that the NNPC could run an effective system with only four vessels and at a cheaper cost than it was paying the oil marketers.

Based on the report, the NNPC decided to hire the vessels directly. This created another problem. Said Adams in a critique of the oil industry in April: "Unfortunately, like many well-intended programs in Nigeria's public sector, that decision turned out to be a very costly mistake because in less than two years, the vessels had been increased to about 12 and most of them were provided by or through very powerful and highly influential people in the corridors of power. Many of the vessels were imposed on NNPC by the powers that be."

Now, there are at least 22 vessels for which the corporation pays $8 million (N176 million) monthly. A recent study of the operations of the vessels called for the immediate disengagement of at least six of the vessels because they are redundant.

NEWSWATCH sources say that the Abisoye panel noted that interventions like this affect the fortunes of Nigeria's largest corporation. Although the NNPC is set up as an independent corporation which monitors government's oil interests, in practices the corporation is merely an extension of the ministry of petroleum resources. In theory, the day-to-day management of the affairs of the corporation is vested in the group managing director but in practice, the oil minister has the final say.

This stronghold of government over the organization has done so much havoc to the corporation. NEWSWATCH learnt that the panel accused the government of forcing the corporation to undertake worthless projects. A NEWSWATCH source quoted the panel as observing that with government holding tightly to its equity interests in the joint ventures, NNPC lacks the capital and revenue base to operate successfully as an integrated, international oil corporation. The report is said to be critical of government practice of imposing chartered vessels on the corporation far in excess of its operational needs, directing it to make uneconomic investments, forcing it to enter into uncommercial transactions.

An NNPC official told NEWSWATCH last week that the corporation had become the source of free fund for government. "The practice is that the ministry passes over some expenditures to the corporation to pay and debit it later. But the refund is hardly made by the ministry." He cited the case of payment of estacodes to ministry officials by the corporation. As at June, the corporation had paid N140 million to the ministry as estacode allowance. In addition, proceeds of the sales of crude oil dedicated for the purpose of solid mineral development has been diverted by the ministry to fund non-essential services. From the proceeds, the petroleum ministry bought 70 vehicles for use by its officials as well as furnish the official residences of senior ministry staff.

These were all extra budgetary expenditure for which no account has so far been rendered and there is no indication that the money would be refunded to the corporation. Said an NNPC staff last week: "The ministry has not undertaken any key activity in prospecting and developing solid minerals. The ministry uses the dedicated account to fund recurrent and capital expenditures not relevant to solid minerals since the account is within its direct control, unlike its vote which it gets from the ministry of finance."

The presidency also sources funds for many of its unbudgetted expenditure from the NNPC. In most cases, said a senior official of the NNPC, the bills are first incurred and later, the corporation is asked to pick them up with a promise for reimbursements. It never does. The panel reportedly listed one such case as the recent image polishing campaign which the federal government embarked upon in the United States. At the end of the exercise, the government is said to have asked NNPC to pick the bill.

Similarly, government has also shifted responsibility for some of the bills incurred by its participation in ECOMOG in Liberia to the NNPC. It was the corporation which the government handed a bill of $5.83 million and N71.5 million submitted to it by Unipetrol for supplies to the peace-keeping force in Liberia. A loan of N25.4 million to the ministry defense has not been repaid.

One major case of government directing the NNPC to enter into a costly agreement has to do with the construction of the Bonny export terminal to serve the new Port Harcourt refinery built initially for the export market. The $340 million contract was awarded to IPCO of Singapore last year. While negotiating for financing for the project, the NNPC had an offer from the Petroleum Financing Corporation, PFC, to fund the project with a loan repayable in 12 years, with a moratorium of 30 months. But the financing contract was rather awarded to Total on the advice of the contractor on terms which are less favorable to the corporation. Under Total's terms, it would provide an initial credit with which to open the letter of credit for IPCO. This would be repaid from the proceeds of the 20,000 bpd allocated to Total from the 300,000 bpd meant for local refining and consumption as well as 50,000 tons per month of fuel oil.

IPCO's offer was more attractive but government was said to have preferred Total whose offer would eat into the crude dedicated for local consumption and invariably lead to higher imports of refined petroleum products. The panel is said to have observed that it was inconceivable that better loan facilities offered by PFC were rejected in preference to arrangements which involved eating into the domestic dedication of 300,000 barrel per day which were inadequate for domestic needs. This, of course, would inevitably result into additional imports of petroleum products to meet resultant domestic shortages, at higher cost.

Government interference is just one problem of the oil corporation. It is when problems of the corporation include inadequate revenue and capital base for meaningful operation, operational limitations which restrict borrowing and its being limited to banking with the CBN which denies the corporation access to independent sources of fund. The inability of the government and the NNPC to meet cash-calls for operational costs is also another problem. The panel is said to have drawn government attention to some other problems such as the corporation's lack of investable funds, the tendency to fill up subsidiary boards with political appointees, unconstitutional management and mismanagement of proceeds of crude oil sales, malpractices in materials management, poor planning culture and aggressive labor unions.

NNPC has never been left well alone by government. The corporation has had eight chiefs executives since 1977. Virtually all of them were removed from office by the government on allegations of impropriety. The corporation has eight subsidiaries. Its major subsidiary, the National Petroleum Investment Management Services, NAPIMS, manages and supervises government investments in the petroleum sector. It is to statutorily protect Nigeria's interests in joint venture operations with foreign partners. According to Chamberlain Oyibo, group management director of the corporation, NNPC through NAPIMS monitors the oil companies to ensure that they do not unnecessarily inflate their costs.

This does not appear to be so in practice. The Abisoye panel reportedly found that its system of checking cash call requests by joint venture operators sometimes results in the operators getting higher amounts than they requested for. For instance, in 1992 the company approved the payment of arrears to Shell totaling $34.1 million for cash calls adjustments from 1973 to 1990, despite the fact that Shell's accounts were reconciled yearly, during that period.

The Kaduna Refining and Petrochemical Company Limited, KRPC, which the NNPC headquarters in Lagos claim it exercises little control over, is another problem area for the corporation. Said Don Etiebet, the petroleum and mineral resources minister, of the refinery in April: "The Kaduna refinery was burnt down. It was repaired. The turn around maintenance was done at the cost of over N1 million. Seven days later, it was burnt down again. Up-till now, it is still limping."

NEWSWATCH was told that a strong syndicate of mainly importers of petroleum products has been linked with the frequent fire incidents at the refinery because disruptions in normal operations at the refineries mean good business for them. Sources in the corporation said the Abisoye panel indicted the accounting system at the refinery. In 1992, the company hired a number of firms to help it to source for foreign exchange. The firms included KC Holdings Limited, owned by one King Ibe; First Abuja Finance and Investment Company; and Oney and Zainey and Company Limited. KC Holdings was paid N2.15 million based on vouchers the company presented to KRPC from a non-existent bank, New Era Bank Plc, Ebutte-Metta, Lagos. The panel is said to have described the payments as questionable and fake. King Ibe, the managing director of KC Holdings, may be in for trouble over the payments.

First Abuja Finance was paid a total of N7.3 million to source for foreign exchange while Oney and Zainey was paid $35,045, NEWSWATCH learnt. The suspicion is that some staff of the refinery might have used this avenue to defraud the company.

But one NNPC official in Lagos explained that the recourse to the use of scouts to source for foreign exchange is due to the poor finances of the corporation which forces it to look for alternative sources when it requires huge foreign exchange. He said that, for instance, the NNPC bought dollars in 1993 at an average rate of N30 to $1 against the official rate of N21.

NEWSWATCH learnt that in all the refineries owned by the NNPC, the panel made the same observations about the accounting systems which it said was poor. It is said to have noted cases of over-payments or payments for jobs not done. Another problem, sources say, is that the refineries are in the habit of ordering stocks that they do not really require. This leads to large scale wastage. For instance, the proforma invoice for the turn around maintenance of the Warri refinery showed several cases of forgery and inflation of the contract sum which were passed by the management of the Warri Refinery and Petrochemical Company, WRPC. These were initially blamed on PROMAS, the central purchasing organization for the NNPC, by the management of the refinery. But NEWSWATCH sources said the panel found that the managing director of the company was directly responsible for it. Although it was gathered that he offered to resign when the case was discovered, there were no indications by last week that he had.

At the Pipeline and Products Marketing Company, PPMC, the story is the same. Inflation of contracts is reported to be a major strategy for milking the company. For instance, two senior staff of the organization are said to have spent N5.6 million to buy a transformer that should have cost the company N2.1 million. The price intelligence unit of the PPMC at Mosimi which should look into cases of contract inflation is said to have been rendered ineffective. Staff who did not cooperate in the fraud are allegedly frustrated or forced to leave. Other cases of irregularities in NNPC and its subsidiaries said to have been established by the panel include the duplication of payment totaling $153,003.54 and 519,210.80 Dutch Mark by the Eleme Petrochemical Company Limited to a foreign firm called Credito Italianos, the payment of N2 million to Keeler Nigeria Limited, the local representative of Windmoller and Holscher of German for the supply of film manufacturing equipment which are yet to be delivered.

Similarly although the EPCL enjoyed duty exemption since 1992, its books show the payment of N19.81 million as customs duties. Also, the panel is said to have queried the disappearance of $1.563 million from the $3.2 million contributions by NNPC between September e1991 to October 1992 towards the UNIDO Plastics Technology Center. The spending spree extends to three other subsidiaries, namely Stallion Properties, the Integrated Data Services Limited, IDSL, and the Nigeria Petroleum Development Company Limited, NPDC, according to sources. A Stallion Property, controversy surrounds the payment of N 10.5 million to a lawyer named J.O. Adekunbi. The payments were allegedly made to obtain the governor's consent for its land in Lagos State.

NEWSWATCH learnt that the Abisoye panel refused to buy the story. Rather, sources say its report to government spoke of the panel's "grave concern, the circumstances in which the management possibly defrauded the company to the tune of N10.5 million and produced receipts which we believe were forged." For IDSL, NEWSWATCH was told that the panel accused its board of exceeding its limit of authority in the award of contracts. NPDC's frivolous spending manifests in the treatment of its contractors, according to the sources quoting the panel's report. It is said to have for instance, overpaid contractor, Niger Construction Limited, based on an improper claim filed by the company. It paid another contractor, Speedwell Maritime and Freight Services Limited, N4.3 million for a job that valued at N1.3 million and for which no request for variation was to be entertained. Another contractor, Nigeria Laboratory Company Limited, was paid N756,537. 54 as mobilization fee for a contract in 1992. The contract is yet to be executed and no effort has been made by the management to recover the money. it also allegedly overpaid N1.9 million as import duties for a contract handled by Stonehill Nigeria Limited. At NNPC, figures often do not add up, according to an auditor who once worked on the corporation's account. For instance, NEWSWATCH learnt that the panel pointed out the difference of 154,000 bpd between the Nigerian official export statistics and statistics by the IMF. The monetary value of this is put at $1 billion per year. The panel reportedly blamed this on unofficial shipments and other physical losses. It said that the corporation lacks, amongst others, a reliable internal auditing system. What the NNPC needed, the report is quoted as saying, was a sound corporate auditing policy that would constantly remind senior personnel and higher authorities of the legal and commercial implications of their actions.

Lack of energy policy in the country and the absence of long range planning in the NNPC have been blamed for the choice of inappropriate technology for the Warri refinery, inappropriate plant for the Kaduna refinery, the non-completion of the Pipeline and Depot Phase III project and the absence of a refinery to serve the Lagos-Ibadan axis which accounts for about 40 percent of the national demand for petroleum products, according to a source close to the panel. When he submitted the report to government, Abisoye said this much: "Because of poor planning and budgetary culture, projects get injected into NNPC at any time, depending on the status of the promoter." For the current year, NNPC has a budget of N64.6 billion. This is to be funded from sales of oil dedicated to it by the government as well as earnings from its investments. A large part of this would be required to pay for the completion of its on-going 117 projects. Some of these projects include the butanisation project phase II, the pipeline and depot phase II project, the Calabar jetty phase II and the Warri Refinery rehabilitation projectors, phases I, II, and III. Others are the KRPC phase I, the repairs of the fluid catalytic cracker unit of the Kaduna refinery, the Jos tank farm project and the completion of the NNPC head office complex along Mulliner Road, Lagos.

NEWSWATCH learnt that the Abisoye panel suggested the phasing of these projects into priority and non-priority projects. It is believed to have recommended the completion of eight top priority projects before the end of the year. This recommendation, NEWSWATCH learnt, may not suit well with the government because the projects to be completed would require at least N7 billion. NEWSWATCH gathered that the National Economic Intelligence Unit has advised government not to push the NNPC into hasty completion of the projects. It is believed that NNPC is considering a thorough re-appraisal of some of the projects. For instance, the Bonny export terminal may not be needed in a long time to come because of diversion of products from the new Port Harcourt refinery originally meant for export into local consumption. "The expansion of the Atlas Cove at the cost of $50 million and N70 million, for instance, which NNPC is undertaking to facilitate the off loading of coastal vessels is another project which may not be viable in the future. Once the pipelines and depot phase III projects are completed, the movement of products by sea will decline drastically."

NNPC's greatest need for now is to be restructured effectively in a way that will promote efficiency and growth within the oil sector. The panel is said to have noted that the corporation is overblown and has deteriorated so badly that it will take drastic surgery to cut to size and nurse it back to good health. For this hob, the panel, according to NEWSWATCH sources in the presidency, recommended its member to work full time to reshape the organization. Dependable sources say the panel wants the NNPC freed from the ministry of petroleum resources to make it a purely commercial venture. Although the Abisoye panel is said to have recommended a new structure for the organization, NEWSWATCH learnt that the government may prefer the recommendations of the Technical Committee on Privatization and Commercialization which have been under consideration for some time now.

It is believed that NEIC supports the TCPC recommendations. NEIC is said to have dismissed the Abisoye panel for failing to advance superior arguments over those of the TCPC. On the panel's alleged recommendations that it be appointed to handle the reorganization, NEIC which sources say the government referred the report to for consideration , said it was unethical and urged the government to reject it. Perhaps the most crucial decision remains the relationship between the government and a commercialized NNPC. The panel is said to have urged the government to withdraw from the industry and allow the NNPC a free hand. At the moment, the NNPC makes all the money for government but hardly has enough to meet its obligations Outstanding commitments to join venture partners has only just been reduced from $500 million to $150 million. With declining earnings from oil, experts believe that the industry must seek commercial viability.

At an interview with the "Daily Times" in April, Oyibo spoke of the need to free the corporation from government control so that it can operate profitably. Said he: "Almost all the OPEC member countries are treating their national oil companies as purely commercial enterprise. Some of them, say, pay tax only. I saw the Mexican National Oil Company president and he said that last year, they paid $18 billion tax to the government. What the government is interested in is tax. We should take commercial decisions. We would invest where we will get returns, because whatever profit we make, the government is our sole shareholder. It will go back to the government."

But Etiebet believes all is now well with the corporation. Last November, he swore he world conquer the powerful forces plundering the nation's oil industry. On October 7, he told a news conference he had kept his promise and the result was the improvement in the financial fortune of the corporation. He said its overdraft of N6 billion at the beginning of the year had wiped out. In the past nine months, it generated N40 billion, enough to clear its outstanding 1993 commitments of N11 billion, commit N20 billion to this year's operations and pay the federal government N3.6 billion for crude oil.

Etiebet said NNPC had equally met some of its pressing foreign currency commitments. It paid $766 million (N16.8 billion) into the escrow account of the Nigeria Liquefied Natural Gas Company as deposit for its shares in the firm. The payment excludes $39 million (N858 million) set aside to meet the operational requirements of the company of which it owns 49 percent equity. Etiebet said this was achieved without using the $500 million realized from the sale of Nigeria's five percent equity in Shell joint venture to Elf.

To revive Eleme Petrochemicals Projects abandoned for two years due to lack of funds, NNPC paid $230 million (N5.06 billion) to the contractors and rescheduled $1.078 billion (N23.7 billion) of the project's loan. The corporation equally repaid $136 million (N2.9 billion) of the loan taken in 1986 to build the new Port Harcourt refinery. Other financial commitments of $388 million (N.5 billion) was also paid. Despite its ability to meet the financial commitments, the corporation still has problems with its foreign accounts. Etiebet said this was because NNPC had foreign accounts commitments of $4.2 billion (N92.4 billion) at the beginning of the year of which $1.2 billion (N26.4 billion) was due for payment this year. The minister is hoping that his policies of prioritisation and scaling down of projects, stopping of wasteful spending and financial discipline would turn the accounts around before the end of the year. Reported by Ray Ekpu, Soji Akinrinade and Moffat Ekoriko

NEWSWATCH is published at P.M.B. 21499, Ikoja, Nigeria Tel: 4960950 Fax: 962887 Telex: 27874


LOAD-DATE: February 6, 1995
