Africa News


November 1, 1994 / November 30, 1994


THE WORLD REMEMBERS SARO-WIWA


BYLINE: Sam Olukoya, NEWSWATCH (Lagos)


LENGTH: 854 words


 

October 31, 1994

Not even the prison walls could stop Ken Saro-Wiwa from winning the $250,000 1994 Right Livelihood Award.

Saro-Wiwa, leader of the Movement for the Survival of Ogoni People, MOSOP, has been in detention since May 22, this year. Coming two days after marking his 53rd birthday in detention, the award might as well pass for a birthday gift. Saro-Wiwa has won a number of international awards in the past, including the Noma Award for publishing in Africa and the Commonwealth Writers prize. 

The Right Livelihood Award is considered equivalent of the Nobel Prize. The award was introduced in 1980 by Jakob Von Uexkull, a Swedish-German philatelic, who felt that the Nobel Prizes have become too narrow and specialized and ignored much work and knowledge vital for the survival of mankind.

Like the Nobel Prize, the Right Livelihood Award is presented by the Swedish parliament. It is traditionally presented on December 9, the day before the Nobel Prize is presented.

In a press statement, the Right Livelihood Award Foundation of Stockholm, Sweden, said: "The jury honors Saro-Wiwa for his exemplary and selfless courage and in striving non-violently for the civil, economic and environmental rights of his people."

Saro-Wiwa shares the award with MOSOP, a body which he uses as an instrument for civil, economic and environmental rights crusade. For both Saro-Wiwa and MOSOP, the award surely comes as a tonic in a difficult moment.

Since 1992 when the Ogoni, under MOSOP umbrella, became active in their campaign against environmental degradation, never have they faced the kind of difficulty they are facing now. A number of MOSOP members and officials have been thrown into detention while several others are declared wanted by security agencies for alleged criminal acts.

While government is yet to react to the award, reactions from other quarters tend to suggest that the award is a vindication that MOSOP and Saro-Wiwa have been pursuing a worthy cause. The Association of Nigerian Authors, ANA, observed in a press statement that the award is "a well-deserved recognition and honor for a man of letters who has refused to abandon a worthy cause in spite of draconian pressure from the minders of state."

The "Vanguard", in an editorial last Tuesday, said: "This award has also given succor and fillip to all like Ken who feel persecuted since they would now be secured in the knowledge that thousands of miles away there are people who care and understand."

MOSOP described the award as "an endorsement of the non-violent struggle of the Ogoni people through MOSOP for the preservation of their environment and for social justice in Nigeria."

It said the award was a stinging and resounding rebuke handed down by the international community to the Rivers State government and the oil company which had together misled the federal government into waging a needless war against the Ogoni people.

Saro-Wiwa was born on October 10, 1941, at Bori Rivers State. He attended the Native Authority School, Bori; Government College, Umahia, and the University of Ibadan. At 26, he was administrator for Bonny, Rivers State. Between 1968 and 1973, he was commissioner in three ministries in Rivers State.

Saro-Wiwa is an extraordinary man, an extraordinary writer. Indeed, I can think of no other writer anywhere else in the world who reproduces even half of his many facets," says William Boyd, a British writer.

The vast ecological devastation of his native Ogoni through the activities of oil companies transformed him from a writer to an environmental activist.

He certainly has paid a high prize for this. He has been detained six times since last year following his activities.

NEWSWATCH is published by NEWSWATCH Communications Limited, No.3 Billings Way, Oregun Industrial Estate, Oregun, P.M.B. 21499, Ikeja, Lagos, Nigeria.


LOAD-DATE: February 6, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


November 1, 1994 / November 30, 1994


OBASANJO: MY POLITICAL MISSION


BYLINE: Wale Oladepo, NEWSWATCH (Lagos)


LENGTH: 574 words


 

(excerpt)

NOVEMBER 14,1994

General Olusegun Obasanjo, former head of state, has set up a political association he intends to register as a political party. At an exclusive interview with associate editor, Wale Oladepo, Obasanjo speaks on his new moves.

NEWSWATCH: What exactly is the mission of the National Unity Organisation of Nigeria, NUON, which you are forming? 

OBASANJO: Well, the National Unity Organisation as its name signifies, stands for unity of Nigeria above anything else. It stands for harmony, it stands for good governance, it stands for human rights, it stands for democracy, it stands for all those things without which we cannot be seen to be making progress as a nation, either internationally or internally.

NEWSWATCH: Who are the members, Sir?

OBASANJO: The membership transcends the entire country. We have members in every state of the country. We have interim officers. Interim because until we have our formal annual convention, all our offices are interim but for now I give the leadership direction to the organisation along with the interim executive council of the organisation until we have elected our permanent officers.

NEWSWATCH: Nigerians thrive on rumours. At a time it was rumoured that you had been contacted and lobbied to head the interim government. Now, it is being rumoured that you are coming back to politics in order to be president.

OBASANJO: Well, the first one, I do not know who lobbied me, at what time and where. And to head what? That is absolutely untrue. As you said, rumours grow well in Nigeria. There was a time it was said that a helicopter stopped on my farm and bla, bla, bla. You know that is absolutely untrue. On the second point that when the ban is lifted, I am going into politics, because of what I have been saying and doing. The comments I have been passing, you cannot say that they are not in a way political. But where you will be right is that our organisation will sponsor somebody when the ban on politics is lifted. That decision we have taken. What the organisation will then do after that is entirely left to the organisation. But I will be a facilitator of that exercise. But let me say this, that is not for the purpose of going back to the state house, because to me it is absolutely objectionable that anybody should form a political party because he wants to go the government house. We believe that politics has to do with the good of the people, the good of the majority and the means by which you can exercise that is through party politics. And therefore we believe we should have an association and as an organisation, we should pave the next step and we should go when the time comes, into a political organisation which will also work with others to form probably a democratic coalition.


LOAD-DATE: February 6, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


November 1, 1994 / November 30, 1994


THE GAMBIA: AFPRC REVEALS EAGERLY-AWAITED TIMETABLE


BYLINE: Abdullah Savage, DAILY OBSERVER (Banjul)


LENGTH: 467 words


 

October 25, 1994

The Armed Forces Provisional Ruling Council (AFPRC) has announced that it will hand over power to a democratically elected civilian government in December of 1998. The Chairman of the AFPRC and Head of State, Lt. Yaya Jammeh made this important announcement yesterday at the Independence Stadium in Bakau.

Over 15,000 people of all walks of life witnessed the occasion, chaired by Attorney General and Minister of Justice, Fafa E. Mbai. Also in attendance were cabinet ministers, members of the diplomatic corps and the international community. 

Lt. Jammeh began his address by giving the "rationale" behind the military takeover of July 22. "The AFPRC seized power to respond to the early warnings of a potential political turbulence emanating form social injustice and human rights violations inflicted on the majority of Gambians for over 30 years." Lt. Jammeh said.

The Head of State stated that the AFPRC is committed to continue "economic reform and related policies and programs already underway." He went on to express his Government's intention to honor all international commitments and obligations.

Consistent with the ideals and principles of the AFPRC, Lt. Jammeh asserted, the return to a democratic constitutional rule is focused on many issues highlighted. Lt. Jammeh highlighted the first issue of a revised constitution, among others. He went on to say that the commissions of inquiry are being set up to investigate public officers, government departments, public corporations and land administration.

"Special independent audits will also be carried out with a view to improving better management of public funds," he said. On the control of crime, drugs and other social vices, Lt. Jammeh said these constitute a key objective of the AFPRC Government during the transitional period.

"The Government will introduce a of action aimed at controlling crime, drug trafficking and abuse, and other social vices," Lt. Jammeh concluded.

The "Daily Observer" is published by The Observer Company (Gambia) Ltd. New Town-Sait Matty Junction, Bakau, P.M.B., 131, Banjul, the Gambia Telephone: (220) 496608,496878 Fax: (220) 496878


LOAD-DATE: February 6, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


357 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 1, 1994 / November 30, 1994


AMNESTY INTERNATIONAL PROTESTS HARASSMENT OF LOCAL GROUPS IN NORTH AFRICA


BYLINE: AMNESTY INTERNATIONAL


LENGTH: 960 words


 

November 10, 1994

Amnesty International's Secretary-General Pierre Sane today strongly protested the escalating harassment of the human rights organization's local groups in Egypt and across the Middle East and North Africa.

"If Amnesty International members are barred from meeting to elect their own leaders, banned from carrying out their activities, and if we can't send our staff to train these members or send researchers to investigate the human rights situation, what clearer signal do we need that Amnesty International is not welcome?" Pierre Sane said.

At the end of last month, Egyptian authorities banned Amnesty International's Egyptian members from holding their annual general meeting. The government also barred the organization's international representatives from attending meetings and accused Amnesty International's organizational field worker in Egypt of carrying out "illegal activities". 

This action comes in the wake of the September publication of the Amnesty International report on Egypt, "Egypt: Human Rights Defenders Under Threat." It detailed the arbitrary arrests of human rights defenders, including at least 41 lawyers and journalists. Egyptian police have also administratively detained thousands of suspected members and sympathizers of banned Islamist militant groups, according to the report which descr

ibes systematic torture and the deaths of detainees while in police custody. In high-level talks in Cairo last year, officials at Egypt's Foreign Affairs Ministry repeated assurances first given in 1992 that local members of Amnesty International would soon have legal standing.

Yet those assurances have not produced any government action. "For years, we have asked the government to give our groups legal recognition in Egypt and instead they are taking steps to silence us," Pierre Sane said. "I find it hard to reconcile this with President Mubarak's statement to us in 1992 that Amnesty International is welcome in Egypt, providing that it does not concern itself with the internal politics of the country." Amnesty International has always operated openly and within the law, keeping authorities informed of its peaceful activities carried out in solidarity with the victims of human rights violations worldwide. Amnesty International's own procedures provide that members campaign on behalf of individual cases of human rights violations throughout the world -- but not in their own country.

The de facto banning of Amnesty International in Egypt fits a pattern of harassment that Amnesty International members, delegates and staff members face elsewhere in the region. In Tunisia, the government has harassed the Amnesty International section for over two years, blocking publications from entering the country, and so preventing its members from receiving the basic tools to carry out their normal activities. They have received no mailings of the organization's newsletter since April 1994 nor copies of the annual International Report.

The Tunisian authorities have imposed administrative impediments and restrictions on the Amnesty International section and have banned a member of the International Secretariat from visiting the country.

In Kuwait, the local Amnesty International groups applied for registration two years ago. Despite support by the parliament's Human Rights Committee, authorities continue to refuse legal registration to the groups and consequently imposes restrictions on their activity. The Kuwaiti Government has also denied entry visas to the Amnesty International membership development team for more than two years.

"This is a dangerous trend of harassment and restrictions on human rights organizations -- not just Amnesty International -- across the Middle East and North Africa," Pierre Sane said. "Authorities deliberately create a gray area by refusing legal recognition of human rights organizations, imposing restrictions on their activities and banning their meetings."

While governments in the region are pleased to proclaim the existence of Amnesty International groups and members in their countries in international human rights fora, this does not stop these same governments from targeting the organization's members, staff and delegates -- apparently in response to Amnesty International's worldwide campaigning activities against human rights abuses in these countries.

"We shall not remain silent," Pierre Sane said. "Such action against our movement simply reinforces our resolve to fight against human rights abuses and re-affirm the principle of international solidarity among defenders of human rights worldwide."

For further information, contact the International Secretariat of Amnesty International, 1 Easton Street, London WC1X 8DJ (Tel +44-71-413-5500, Fax +44-71- 956-1157) or SHARRRISO@IGC.APC.ORG


LOAD-DATE: February 6, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


358 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 1, 1994 / November 30, 1994


CONTINENT GLOBAL AID BECOMING INVESTMENT BUSINESS


BYLINE: DAILY OBSERVER (Banjul)


LENGTH: 1280 words


 

October 25,1994.

The subject was so commonplace and the details deemed so inconsequential they were awarded just one sentence near the bottom of a column of international news briefs. Under the headline "poverty trap", The Times of London reported that the World Bank could not release up to $250 million in loans to Rwanda until the Government of the devastated African country paid off $3.75 million in arrears.

To the Bank's many critics, it was yet another example of the gross inefficiency of the world's largest lending institution and its twin, the International Monetary Fund (IMF), born 50 years ago in Bretton Woods, New Hampshire. 

Opponents charge that with more than one billion people living in absolute poverty, 40 per cent of the population in developing countries lacking basic sanitation or clean water and the gap between rich and poor growing wider, the two bodies, committed to the reduction of global poverty, have proved a disaster.

"(Their) policies are failing precisely the people they are supposed to help, the poorest in the developing world", says Michael Taylor, director of Christian AID, a British NGO.

Christian Aid and a group of other Third World charities were pressing for reforms to the World Bank and IMF at the 50th annual meetings of the Washington- based institutions in Madrid, on October 4-6. Critics want the debt of developing countries substantially reduced, controversial structural adjustment programs (SAPs) altered and the two bodies democratized so that they are more accountable to taxpayers in rich countries and recipients in poor nations.

World Bank officials admit their record has not been perfect, but they insist the institution has contributed to global economic and social progress in the past half century. In developing countries, average life expectancy has increased by about 50 per cent; the proportion of children attending school has risen from less than half to more than three-quarters; and average income per person has more than doubled, they note.

Spokesperson Geoffery Lamb, said the Bank will continue to fund "free market friendly" projects because, despite the short-term negative impacts on social programs, SAPs are the best way to go about reducing poverty.

Lamb admitted that the social components including health care and education of the first generation of SAPs - large loans to continue contingent on them liberalizing their economies - had been "quite inadequate", but current policy is aimed more at softening the blow for the poorest of the poor.

"Increasingly, we will not lend in situations where we are not satisfied of the viability and proper implementation of a project," Lamb told reporters at a news conference releasing the Bank's 1994 annual report. "Which is not the same as saying we will not make any more mistakes."

No matter which side of the debate they are on, a few people dispute the fact that global aid has changed dramatically since the fall of the Berlin Wall in 1989. The former Soviet Union, once a large aid donor, has not only stopped paying out, but, along with its now-independent republics and other former Eastern bloc allies, has become a major recipient of assistance from main global lenders - the World Bank/IMF, the 22-member organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) and regional development banks.

The world's poorest countries have paid a heavy price for this shift. In its report earlier this year, the OECD noted that total assistance to developing countries in 1992 reached a record $159.1 billion, a 21 per cent increase from the previous year. But further examination of the figures for so-called development finance, shows continuation of a disturbing trend for have-not countries. Concessional money - cut-rate loans, grants and other concessions - fell 3.5 per cent between 1991 and 1992, while private flows-direct investment, international bank lending and other private money-increased by nearly 35 per cent.

Between 1984 and 1992, private flows increased from just over 39 per cent to nearly 57 per cent of OECD countries' total resources to the developing world.

Few people dispute individual business investment is needed to make the world's poorer countries more self-sufficient. "Aid should never be looked at as the solution to poverty worldwide," says Harriet Lamb, of the World Development Movement (WDM), a British NGO. "No country wants to be dependent on aid."

But as private investment figures show, that is exactly what is happening. It is typically only a select few "economically attractive" nations that get the money. According to the 1984 United Nations Human Development Report, although private flows to developing countries have increased dramatically in recent years, between 1989 and 1992, 72 per cent of the money went to just 10 countries. Sub-Saharan Africa received just a 6 per cent piece of the pie and the least developed countries only 2 per cent.

Lamb of WDM said economic adjustments are definitely needed in poor countries to reduce poverty and make them more efficient and attractive to foreign investors but the SAPs are being universally applied without taking into account differences between the nations.

Lamb added that developing nations' debt- which according to the World Bank was $156.4 billion, or nearly 54 per cent of the gross national product of sub- Saharan Africa in 1993 - must be reduced.

Most observers say aid to developing countries is a question of priorities on the part of donor nations and recipient governments. As long as richer nations put winning new markets for domestic products and securing contracts for their industries ahead of improving the lot of the poor, few see poverty being tamed.

The Human Development Report notes that only 7 per cent of the funds from bilateral donors is directed to education, primary health care, rural water supplies, nutrition programs and family planning services.

Those crucial areas be paid for by diverting small percentages of the budget developing countries devote to military spending. About 12 per cent of the $125 billion those nations put toward defense in 1992 would provide primary health care and safe drinking water for all. DAILY OBSERVER is published at P.M.B. 131 Banjul, The Gambia Tel:(220)496608 Fax:(220)496878.


LOAD-DATE: February 6, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


359 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 1, 1994 / November 30, 1994


ANGOLA: AFTER THE WAR A SHATTERED PEACE


BYLINE: Phillip van Niekerk


LENGTH: 2134 words


 

WEEKLY MAIL

November 18, 1994

While attention focused on the signing of an Angolan ceasefire in Lusaka, Phillip van Niekerk visited the scene of the battle -- and found a city that resembles Dresden in 1945

THE Angola "story" achieved some prominence again this week, in a strangely disembodied way. The rest of the world, alerted by the trigger-word "peace", finally sat up and took notice, but they had first to be reminded that an awful war was underway.

Last week I walked among the rubble of Cuito, a provincial capital east of Huambo in Angola's central highlands. A visit here is disturbed by blasts. Not artillery shells, but the sound of people treading on landmines or children picking up handgrenades. Relief workers say four or five people blow themselves up each day. 

Angolan government troops drove Unita rebels out of Cuito in July. The city of 140 000 was left with one of the highest amputee populations in the world and a skyline that resembles Dresden in 1945.

It is a pocked city littered with rubble. There is not a tree without bullet holes. The facades of the once lovely Portuguese villas look like they have been bashed by a gigantic sledgehammer. Perhaps, one might imagine, such devastation is to be expected after 20 years of war. But it has taken only two years to destroy Cuito and most medium-sized cities in Angola. It took much longer to wreak less destruction in former Yugoslavia.

What has gone missing is an understanding of what has happened here. Until the October 1992 elections, the Angolan war was fought mostly in the bush, touching a handful of urban settlements in the south-east of the country. During a brief window of peace in 1992, Angola was still intact.

When Unita leader Jonas Savimbi went back to war at the end of 1992 he seized the cities. These have become ferocious battlegrounds during the past year as the war has turned in favour of the government. Unita has been dislodged from one city after the other in struggles more reminiscent of Stalingrad than anything encountered before in Africa.

These names mean nothing in the West: N'dalatando, Milanje, Sauremo, Huambo. They were each home to hundreds of thousands of people and now they are ruins. Only Luanda, Lobito-Benguela and Lubango have survived.

For 18 months, the frontline in Cuito was Joaquim Kapango Street, the main street, named after an anti-colonial guerrilla hero. Ten metres of tar separated Unita from the MPLA.

For nine months there was no humanitarian assistance. No one will go on record but it is widely known that some people resorted to eating corpses. The same people who tell you this say the dogs were eaten. Indeed, there are no dogs left in Cuito.

The rest of the world may have been in the dark, but it was not without its contribution. At last count, 68 different kinds of explosives from 23 nations have been found in the rubble of Cuito -- even British handgrenades of early World War II vintage.

The biggest threat is to the children. A cluster bomb looks like a shiny toy. Every day those who are lucky enough to survive have limbs amputated at the Fellini Hospital -- so named by the French doctors who opened it in February on the day when the great Italian film director died.

The inhabitants of Cuito are camping in the husks of former apartment blocks, in tents and in a destroyed football stadium. Not wanting to risk more of the living by crossing minefields to bury the dead, makeshift cemetries -- little mounds with wooden crosses and flowers -- have been constructed in people's back gardens.

The government appears to have abandoned all pretence at serving its people in favour of pursuing a war that the hawks are increasingly confident they can win without having to compromise to the terms of a peace treaty. The Angolan army has been rebuilt at vast cost to the country's oil reserves and with the help of South African soldiers from Executive Outcomes, who have played a major role in turning the war around.

It has been left to the International NGOs to take over the distribution of food, medical care and the welfare of the Angolan people.

The human rights group, Africa Watch, this week charged both the MPLA government and Unita of human rights violations, including summarily executing opponents. The government's armed forces, Faa, also stands charged of indiscriminate aerial bombardment of population centres, while Unita is accused of mass abductions and starving civilians by attacking relief operations, mining agricultural fields and killing those tending their fields.

That this catastrophe has gone largely unreported is partly the fault of the competing armies, who have kept journalists away from the frontlines. It is also the fault of the news agency format that is a conduit for every piece of war propaganda uttered by the two sides. The resulting slew of contradictions are usually far too confusing for foreign editors, let alone the man in the street, many thousands of kilometres away.

Angola is bad television. It is a fertile country. If the crops are not planted, there are always roots or wild berries to eat. People are starving in Angola, but it cannot compare to the Horn of Africa, the misery of which is a familiar image in the jaded consciousness of the Western viewer.

Ten days ago I visited one of the worst sites of misery that aid workers have been able to get to. Balombo is a small town 112km west of Huambo. It has changed hands between Unita and the MPLA five times since 1975, last being recaptured by the MPLA in October 1993.

Encircled by the rebels and with a short, battered runway that prevented relief flights from getting in, it was cut off from the rest of the world until four weeks ago when government forces mended the runway.

Since January, 928 people out of a population of 17 000 have starved to death. It is a town of stick figures, of emaciated people. In a room that serves as a clinic, skeletal children and puffy "kwashie" babies cling to their mothers' breasts that have been sucked dry of milk.

Unlike what would have been the case in Sudan, the situation has improved dramatically since flights started coming in. With the rainy season weeks away, and Unita pushed out of the surrounding territory, peasants were out planting the seeds that reached them just in time.

Luanda absorbs all the shocks that strike the interior. Refugees fleeing this war of a thousand fronts are packed tightly into slums, or bairros, built on former market gardens, in factories or in city parks. One rose on what used to be Luanda's rubbish dump where the stench has never quite dissipated.

A city that was built for 600 000 people at most now holds anything up to three million -- almost a third of the Angolan population.

Luanda is a city of hard times where nothing is cheap. The minimum wage is 240 000 kwanzas a month -- about half an American dollar. It costs twice that a month to send your child to private lessons, which is the only way he or she will be educated; a quarter of your month's wage for a loaf of bread; one eighth for a bucket of clean water; one sixteenth to shit in private.

Women sell in the markets in a desperate scramble to keep up with inflation, estimated by the World Bank last year at 1 800 percent.

But what is there to sell in this city? Anything that has the slightest economic value. One family is in the toothpaste business. The children rummage through the rubbish dumps for spent toothpaste tubes that the adults scrape out until they have a full tube to sell in the market.

But Luanda is not a life. Out of the debris of ideologies that have brought destruction, the only comfort is the preaching of the evangelical pastors on Sunday. The people who cram into the bairros believe that when the war is over, they will go home, to Milanje, to Zaire province, to Bie and Lunda Sul, and to Huambo.

Those returning to the countryside have the best hope of restarting their lives. Those going back to the provincial cities will find devastation.

Cuito has been so badly damaged that some officials have suggested it be written off and a new city constructed alongside. Even while they dither, the people have themselves started rebuilding. In Cuito, the street market is bustling again. On sale were onions, car parts and, significantly, rows of nails neatly sorted into different lengths. The World Bank officials in Luanda, wary of stepping on mines, haven't even travelled to Cuito yet to revise the costs of reconstruction but the people of the city have started the enormous process of rebuilding their lives.

Among the war's greatest victims, the peasants, there is an almost mystical optimism that this time the fighting is over, contrasting with a worldy wise cynicism in Luanda. News of the peace talks travels by radio and bush telegraph. Everyone in the villages around Balombo, even those who cannot tell you their age, know the latest from Lusaka.

If they had the time, they might reflect that they are not just victims of the MPLA and Unita warmongers. One of the pities that this war has gone unreported is it lets off the hook international players who need their noses rubbed in the fly-ridden rubble of Cuito. Like the Portuguese, who created the original mess, and the Americans and the Russians who used Angolan lives as pawns in their global chess game.

Then there is the United Nations, which forged ahead with an unrealistic election date, ignoring warnings that Savimbi still had an army, because it didn't want to waste more money on an unsexy Third World country. For that mistake, at least 100 000 more Angolan civilians have died. The UN stood back feebly while Savimbi took the country back to war. The government had largely demobilised and was left without an army.

This makes the revamped Faa's offensive in recent weeks, its instinct to go for the kill rather than another treaty with a doublecrosser, its willingness to rely on its own strength rather than on international guarantees, at least understandable.

Most importantly, South Africa -- in particular the militarists of the National Party government -- have a lot to answer for. They spent millions of our tax rands to build up and defend Savimbi, providing him with the power base to hold his country to ransom and destroy it for the sake of his personal ambition.

Yes, we paid for it. We all had a role in reducing Angola to beggary. Still, the darkness permits us to ignore it. The Weekly Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media Contact: M&G Media, 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025.


LOAD-DATE: February 6, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


360 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 1, 1994 / November 30, 1994


MOZAMBIQUE: ELECTION RESULTS


BYLINE: Africa News Service


LENGTH: 134 words


 

Official results from Maputo indicate that President Joaquim Chissano received 53.3 percent of the vote in the country's first multi-party elections. Voting took place from October 27 to October 29, with 12 candidates contending for the nation's highest office. Some 7,000 United Nations peacekeepers have been in the country to oversee the process.

Afonso Dhlakama received 33.7 percent of the votes.

Chissano's Frelimo party won 129 seats in the 250-member parliament. Dhlakama's Renamo took 112 seats. The Democratic Union won the other nine parliamentary seats and is expected to form a unified opposition with Renamo.


LOAD-DATE: February 6, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


361 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


November 1, 1994 / November 30, 1994


U.S. POLICY: ANGOLA FIGHTING EVOKES BIPARTISAN REACTION IN WASHINGTON


BYLINE: Reed Kramer, Africa News Service


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 1040 words


 

Washington, D.C. -- The Angolan civil war, once one of the most divisive Cold War issues in American politics, has resurfaced on the U.S. foreign policy agenda. Now, however, there is more agreement than discord, with both the Democratic administration and the incoming Republican leadership in Congress pressing the Angolan parties to adhere to the peace accord that was signed in the Zambian capital Lusaka on November 20.

In the weeks prior to the signing ceremony, the White House and Capitol Hill Republicans appealed for cessation of the continuing carnage, which has claimed at least 100,000 lives in the past two years and has, until this point, defied diplomatic solution.

Jesse Helms, in his first foray into Africa policy since the Republican election victory that puts him in line to chair the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, issued a sharp rebuke of the recent Angolan government offensive against the rebel movement Unita. Likening recent developments to the plot of a Frederick Forsyth spy novel, the North Carolina conservative accused the Angolan army of employing South African mercenaries who once fought with Unita in an attempt to "destroy the Unita army and assassinate Jonas Savimbi," the movement's leader. 

Dan Burton, the ranking Republican on the House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on Africa, cabled Angolan President Jose Eduardo dos Santos "to deplore in the strongest possible terms" the government army's offensive. "I urge you to stop this madness and honor the cease-fire immediately," Burton said. Both Helms and Burton have corresponded with Savimbi as well.

In an earlier statement issued by the White House, the Clinton administration also criticized the government's battlefield actions for undercutting "the spirit of national reconciliation" displayed during peace negotiations in the Zambian capital Lusaka.

During heavy fighting in early November, government forces captured the central Angolan city of Huambo, where Unita has been headquartered, and also attacked Unita in several other areas, including the town of Uige.

Antagonism between Unita and dos Santo's MPLA dates from the early 1970s, during the struggle against Portuguese colonialism. Fighting between the two groups intensified following independence in 1975, fueled by superpower rivalries. The MPLA received arms and aid from the Soviet Union and troops from Cuba, while Unita allied itself with white-ruled South Africa and was funded and armed by the United States.

A 1988 regional peace accord led to the withdrawal of Cuban troops from Angola and to South Africa's pull-back from Namibia, Angola's southern neighbor. In 1991, Angola held internationally monitored elections, which dos Santos won by a narrow margin. Fighting resumed in late 1992, following Savimbi's rejection of the results.

Despite the latest set-backs, many observers believe both sides eventually will abide by the new accord, hammered out during months of negotiations in Lusaka coordinated by a United Nations representative. The Clinton administration has backed the talks, assigning veteran diplomat Paul Hare as special envoy to bring the long-feuding parties together.

Savimbi, who once was enthusiastically embraced as an anti-Communist warrior by Republicans, as well as some Democrats, lost most of his support following the 1991 election fiasco. But the latest turn of events, coinciding with the Republican ascendancy in Congress, has provided him with a public relations boost.

"Militarily, Unita is the weakest it has been since 1976," says Shawn McCormick, director of the Angola Study Group at the Center for Strategic and International Studies. "Savimbi can't afford to take a political hit as well, so he needs international condemnation of the government."

On Capitol Hill, even Democrats who have been critical of Savimbi feel the government shares the blame for the recent diplomatic stalemate. "We agree with almost all the Republicans are saying," said one Democratic Congressional aide. What Democrats don't support, the aide said, is the threat to pressure dos Santos with economic reprisals. Helm's letter, which was addressed to National Security Advisor Anthony Lake, calls on the administration to "consider oil sanctions" and to "publicly identify Angola as the pariah regime it has become."

Burton, too, pledged support for "severe financial, political and military sanctions" if the government refused to honor the cease-fire accord.

Angola produces a light crude oil that is highly desirable for making unleaded gasoline. Most of the country's output is purchased by the United States, and Chevron and several other U.S. firms have major operations there.

by their post-election reactions to the Angolan problem, Helms and Burton have signaled they will be actively monitoring the administration's Africa policy. "There is agreement among key Republicans that there needs to be a new focus on a few keys countries in Africa such as Nigeria and Zaire, where U.S. interests are at stake," says one Capital Hill source who has been involved in several foreign policy strategy discussions. The Republicans also want to reduce foreign aid overall and likely will want to reduce the aid package for South Africa, in favor of maintaining assistance to some other African countries, the source says.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


November 1, 1994 / November 30, 1994


THE JOY OF COOKING--AFRICAN STYLE!!


SECTION: ANNOUNCEMENT


LENGTH: 507 words


 

Nearly 200 African culinary masterpieces are made easy in "The Africa News Cookbook," which adapts some of Africa's best cuisines to the utensils in your kitchen and ingredients available in your local supermarket. You will learn how to produce healthy, interesting, tasty dishes ranging from spicy sauces and appetizers to aromatic breads, refreshing salads, flavorful entrees and enticing desserts and beverages.

"The Africa News Cookbook: African Cooking for Western Kitchens" was lovingly compiled and illustrated by our staff and published by Viking Penguin. It's a perfect introduction to African food and hospitality for the novice, and a welcome resource for those who already have sampled Africa's gifts. 

Read a few samples of what cooking professionals and publications have to say about the cookbook:

"This thoroughly fascinating book is as much a Third World history and geography source as an unusual cookbook. If the thought of preparing such exotic dishes seems an imposition on a hot summer day, this spiral-bound book makes for charming reading--at the beach or anywhere."--The Washington Times Magazine

"In giving us this important, joyfully serious cookbook, adapting for us succulent foods from all over the African continent, the Africa News Service also shows us an Africa that, despite its poverty, its conflicts, its diversity, has a talent for hospitality and a perdurable capacity for celebration."--Gourmet Magazine

"A smattering of anthropology, linguistics, culture, economics, mores and folkways accompanies lively and varied recipes culled from across the continent in this attractive African cookbook."--Publisher's Weekly

"Highly evocative of an Africa I know and love. The smoky smells, the amber palm oil, the heaps of exotic vegetables. It's a wonderful feast."--Judith Olney, cookbook author.

The cookbook is a 176 page paperback with perfect binding. The price is $17.00 plus $1.50 shipping and handling. Africa News Service accepts Visa and Mastercard orders. Send your order to:

Africa News Service, Post Office Box 3851, Durham, NC 27702.

Please include a daytime telephone number in case we have questions. Remember to enclose payment or credit card number and expiration date and all address information. Order several now--the books are excellent holiday gifts! Bulk orders are eligible for price discounts.

Resources


LENGTH: 2540 words


 

The "International cross-Cultural Black Women's Studies 1995 Summer Institute" will be held in Hawaii. Focus is "Pacific Women: Culture, Identity, and Self-Determination." The institute fosters cooperation to promote peace; human, national, and democratic rights; and development. It is committed to empowering women in various struggles for self-determination and autonomy and aims to develop women's leadership in international service. Prospective delegates must be at least 18; express a concern for black women of Africa, the Americas, Asia, Europe, the Middle East, and/or the Pacific; be willing to actively facilitate on-site activities of the institute; and be flexible in adapting to the circumstances of a given host nation. To apply, send a one-page statement or audio recording about your organizing activities and how your participation will help your work. Contact: Dr. Celia Alvarez, Women's Studies, Arizona State University-West, P.O. Box 37100, 4701 W. Thunderbird Road, Phoenix, AZ 85069, USA, phone 602/ 543-3311, Fax 602/ 543-3312; or Center for Women's Development (New York), phone 718/ 270-5051 or 270-5011, FAX 718/ 270-5126; or Mrs. Chenzira J. This comprehensive 90-page resource guide features new and classic works by and about Third World peoples and communities of Color, including 200 films and videos from African, Asian, Latin American, Palestinian and Native American Diaspora. Send $10 to: Third World Newsreel, 335 West 38th Street, 5th floor, New York, NY 10018.

"Africa on the Move" 55 minutes, VHS, 3 parts, 1992. Produced by Galen Films for the Hunger Project and the Soviet Peace Fund, this is an upbeat celebration of the rich potential of Africa's people and nations. Using Uganda as a case study, the filmakers show examples of Africans using their wealth of natural and human resources to design new ways to combat age-old problems of poverty, hunger and underdevelopment, all of which the United States and Russia had to face not many years ago, and in certain regions, still do. The film shows how responsibly and industriously a 35-member family farm in Uganda addresses its problems. Distributor: Bullfrog Films, P.O. Box 149, Oley, PA 19547. U.S. Rental: $50. Purchase $275.

African-Americans are making their voices heard in the Catholic Church as their understanding of Christ arises in part from their African heritage of art and worship. Maryknoll Educational Videos, Maryknoll World Productions, PO Box 308, Maryknoll, NY 10545-0308. tel: 800/227-8523; fax: 914/945-0670.

THE-AFRICA-IN-OUR-SCHOOLS-National School Program is an integrated learning program designed to help African-American school children develop attitudes and abilities conducive to learning. There is an activity or exercise for each subject including African autos and trucks, rail and air transportation, healthcare products and services, investment and banking services to name a few, that allows children to experience that particular subject from a continental African perspective. Children with no knowledge of African cities, see Africans in cities doing what they, too, want to do. A pilot program was run at Century Park Elementary School in March 1993. Endorsed by the Black Education Commission and the Los Angeles Unified School District (the second largest in the U.S.), it is seen to be relevant to the needs of African-American school children. For more information write: Africa-In-Our-Schools National School Program, 4817 S. Van Ness Avenue. Los Angeles, CA 90062. tel: 800/736-3824.

The Carter Center's African Governance Program has recently published a set of working papers from a Seminar on Democratization in Africa held at the Center, May 13-14, 1994. The volume, entitled "The Democratic Challenge in Africa" provides valuable insights into some of the pressing concerns of the democratic movement in contemporary Africa. This is the Center's fourth publication to address issues affecting governance and democratization in Africa. "Beyond Autocracy in Africa", "Perestroika Without Glasnost in Africa" and "African Governance in the 1990s" were published in 1989 and 1990. Copies of "The Democratic Challenge in Africa" can be obtained for $15 (individuals) and $24 (institutions). Make checks payable to: The Carter Center. Send orders to the Office of Public Information, One Copenhill, Atlanta, GA 30307.

"The International Free Press" (IFP) is a free service on the Internet. IFP focuses on stories, interviews and editorials that deal with Black groups and individuals on a global basis. Writers and editors are from Africa, Asia, Europe and North America. To subscribe send an e-mail message to: dhosten@freenet.scri.fsu.edu with the word SUBSCRIBE in the body of your letter.

Kwaplah International Inc. is an African-based organization interested in compiling bio-data on African and African-American Experts in different fields of study as well as subject specialists. The purpose is to help connect such individuals with international organizations that engage in development work in Africa and other developing nations. Those interested should contact: Kwaplah International Inc., Office of Procurement and International Consultant Service. E-mail : yakubut@csos.orst.edu or mahns@ucs.orst.edu

While most papers are expected to be about crop science, socioeconomic and rural development topics will also be welcomed. Africa News


December 1, 1994 / December 31, 1994


Calls for Papers


LENGTH: 1160 words


 

Hofstra Cultural Center announces a call for papers for Africa 2000, an interdisciplinary conference examining the situation of Africa in the year 2000 and the decade thereafter. Papers should focus on or emphasize the immediate future faced by the continent. Any discussion that increases an understanding of Africa's next decade and a half are welcome. Papers are invited on such diverse topics as African Americans and Africa; the African Diaspora; ethnic relations; medical geography; multinational corporations; public health; popular culture; single and multiparty states; urbanization; and women in Africa. Previously presented or published material should not be submitted. The conference will feature keynote speaker Chinua Achebe. DEADLINE: MARCH 15, 1995, for final papers (in duplicate), one-page abstract, and curriculum vitae. Contact: Athelene A. Collins, Hofstra University, Hampstead, NY 11550-1090, phone 516/ 564-4306.

"African Entrepreneurship" is the theme of The Carter Lecture Series to be held November 1-2, 1995 at the University of Florida, Gainesville. Contact Dr.Anita Spring, Department of Anthropology, University of Florida, Gainesville, FL 32611. Tel:(904) 392-4691.

Subjects may include, but are not limited to literature, demographics, history, politics, economics, the arts, religion, education, health care, the family, international relations, agriculture, business, the sciences, sports, computer science, women's studies, multi-culturalism, social sciences and many other areas. Box 9403, Petersburg, VA 23306, TEL:(804)524-5447, 524-524-5487, FAX:(804)524-6708.

April 21-22, 1995 NEW YORK STATE AFRICAN STUDIES ASSOCIATION 19TH ANNUAL CONFERENCE Scholars are invited to present papers at the 19th annual conference with the theme: "African Renaissance and Reconstruction," to be held April 21-22, 1995 at Hostos Community College, City University of New York. Papers on all topics from all disciplines will be considered; especially welcomed are those dealing with the direction for Africa as the 21st century is approached. a 600 word abstract is requested for papers. Those organizing panels should submit a 600 word abstract along with the names of the participants. THE DEADLINE IS JANUARY 15, 1994. Send proposals including home and office phone numbers as well as E-mail and fax information to: Edward S. Maynard, Program Chair, Hostos Community College, City University of New York, 500 Grand Concourse, C411, Bronx, NY 10451; TEL: (718) 518- 6715; FAX: (718) 518-6643.

Economic, Political, Cultural and Social Perspectives" is the theme of the 1995 spring conference.Send abstracts to Marianne Villanueva, Joint Center for African Studies, Littlefield Center, Room 14, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94305-5013. Tel:(415) 723-0295. DEADLINE IS FEBRUARY 1, 1995,

Papers are welcome from any relevant discipline and may also consider other countries in the Horn of Africa. Employment Opportunities


LENGTH: 760 words


 

The World Bank offers a summer employment program for those interested in working with international organizations. Applications and more information are available by contacting the program directly, Summer Employment Program, World Bank, 1818 H Street, NW, Washington, DC 20433

The International Women's Health Coalition is a nonprofit organization based in the United States that works with women and men from countries in Asia, Africa, and Latin America to secure women's reproductive and sexual health and rights. IWHC currently seeks to fill the position of Senior Program Officer: West Africa. The Program Officer undertakes both program assessment and development including grantmaking in Nigeria and Cameroon; assists in fundraising for the West Africa Program and participates in professional fora relevant to women's reproductive health and rights issues; Solicit, review, and negotiate proposals; administer grants; and maintain liaison with projects in West Africa, and Solicit, review, and negotiate proposals; administer grants; and maintain liaison with projects in West Africa among other responsibilities. The Program Officer is based in New York. Qualifications include significant professional experience and acknowledged track record; advanced training in health or social sciences or the equivalent experience with particular attention to women's reproductive health and rights; knowledge of and experience in Africa; strong analytic and writing ability; demonstrated capacity to work effectively with colleagues from diverse disciplines and perspectives. Ability to work autonomously, take initiative, manage multiple and competing priorities, and handle detail. Fluent written and oral French or willingness to achieve it. Interested candidates should send their curriculum vitae and a brief writing sample to: G. Angela Flemister, Director of Management and Human Resources, The International Women's Health Coalition, Africa Search, 24 East 21st Street, New York, NY 10010.

Inter Press Service (IPS) is seeking to place an African journalist in the IPS Washington, D.C. bureau for two years, starting mid-March 1995, to cover African -related issues and events. The job will involve reporting on the World Bank, IMF, U.S policies toward Africa and non-governmental organizations whose projects and policies affect Africa. Preference will be given to those who speak a second language, ideally French. Applicants should send a curriculum vitae, three references and eight recent articles to: Delin Cormeny/DC post. PO Box 6050. 127 Union Avenue. Harare, Zimbabwe. E-mail: ispdc@gn.apc.org or ipswaseigc.apc.org

Human Rights Watch invites applications for its fellowship program. Human Rights Watch is composed of five regional divisions: Africa, Americas, Asia, Helsinki, and the Middle East, and has projects on arms transfers, free expression, prison conditions, children's rights, and women's rights. Fellowships are intended for students in their final year or recent graduates of law schools or graduate programs in journalism, international relations and area studies. Fellows work full time for one year with one or more divisions of Human Rights Watch, based in New York or Washington. Fellows monitor human rights developments in various countries, conduct on-site investigations, draft reports on human rights conditions, and engage in advocacy efforts aimed at publicizing and curtailing human rights violations. Applicants must have exceptional analytic skills, an ability to write and speak clearly, and a commitment to work in the human rights field in the future. Proficiency in one language in addition to English is strongly recommended. Familiarity with countries or regions where serious human rights violations occur is also valued. Fellowships begin in the early fall of 1995. Submit a resume, two letters of recommendation, a law or graduate school transcript and at least one writing sample to: Marti Weithman, Human Rights Watch, 485 Fifth Avenue, New York, NY 10017

November 23,1994 - March 27,1995 National Museum of African Art GRACE K SCULPTURE; AN ARTIST'S BOOK BY ATTAWA KWAMI In 1993, Attawa Kwami, A Ghanaian artist, created a book that explores the artwork of his mother, Grace Salome Kwami. The book itself is a work of art that consists of 48 unnumbered, folded pages that open like the legs of spider(ananse) In Ghanaian Culture, the Character Ananse is the custodian of wisdom and a symbol of ingenuity. LOAD-DATE: February 6, 1995
