371 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 1, 1994 / December 31, 1994


News Group Wants Sanctions for Freedom Violators


BYLINE: Media Institute of Southern Africa (MISA)


SECTION: PRESS


LENGTH: 1454 words


 

December 1994

The Windhoek-based Media Institute of Southern Africa (MISA), whose members include independent news publications throughout the region, is demanding that sanctions be imposed on southern African governments which abuse media freedom.

In a resolution adopted at the close of the organisation's annual general meeting in Swaziland, MISA demands that members of the Southern African Development Community (SADC) sanction fellow SADC governments which do not abide by the 1991 Windhoek Declaration of Promoting a Free and Pluralistic Press in Africa.

The Windhoek Declaration, which has been adopted by SADC governments, recognises that media freedom and diversity are essential ingredients of social and economic development. In its resolutions,

MISA further calls on the international community to "pressurise" countries which continue to violate press freedom in southern Africa. Swaziland, Angola and Zambia are singled out by MISA as currently having the worst media freedom records in the region. 

The MISA annual congress -- held near the Swazi capital Mbabane and attended by more than 50 media workers from throughout the SADC region --also saw the presentation of MISA's annual Press Freedom Award, which this year went to Zimbabwean journalist Basildon Peta.

The MISA award is given in recognition of outstanding contributions made by southern African journalists to the promotion of media freedom in the region. In March this year, Peta -- a 24-year-old reporter with the Harare-based Daily Gazette newspaper -- was repeatedly detained, interrogated and finally charged by police in terms of the country's Official Secrets Act, after he exposed massive tax evasion by companies owned by the ruling ZANU-PF party.

During five days of incessant questioning, police tried to make Peta reveal who had given him information about the fraud. However, Peta remained true to his p professional ethics and refused to reveal his sources, and it was for this that he was honoured by MISA.

Presenting the award at a gala ceremony on November 22 was Kenyan journalist and human rights lawyer Gitobu Imanyara, who in recent years has been jailed and harassed by the Kenyan authorities for his ardent pro-democracy campaigning.

"Basildon Peta refused to be dictated to," Imanyara said before presenting Peta with the MISA award. "He showed no sign of fear and behaved in the best traditions of a journalist. He is a brave son of Africa."

Describing the award as the "best thing" ever to happen to him, Peta said he was not going to rest on his laurels. "This award has placed a great responsibility on me, and this responsibility is for me to persevere... I am therefore not going to reveal my sources to anyone, even if they take me to jail."

Although the Zimbabwean authorities have since dropped the case against Peta for lack of evidence, the charge could be reactivated any time during the next two years. "I will maintain my stance and I will do exactly what I have been accorded this prize for -- that is to maintain professionalism and excellence in the profession," said Peta.

MISA Trustee Justice John Manyarara, a retired Zimbabwean High Court judge, told the award ceremony that a journalist's duty was founded on "courage and commitment to the ethics of journalism". " (Excellence in journalism) finds its expression in a press that promotes justice, peace and respect for human rights and the rule of law," said Justice Manyarara.

The following resolutions were passed at the MISA annual meeting:

1. MISA, noting that all SADC governments are signatories of the 1991 Windhoek Declaration on Promoting an Independent and Pluralistic African Press, demands that they impose sanctions on member countries who do not abide by the terms of the declaration. Such sanctions can be applied in terms of Article 33 of the SADC treaty. MISA further calls on the international community to put pressure on countries which continue to violate press freedom in the region.

2. MISA is appalled that the Government of Swaziland -- a signatory of the 1991 Windhoek Declaration on Promoting an Independent and Pluralistic African Press -- does not have constitutional provisions which guarantee press freedom, and calls on the Swazi Government to introduce internationally accepted norms of media freedom. MISA, in solidarity with Swazi journalists, demands that the Swazi Government stops its harassment of media practitioners.

3. Considering the pressures on journalistic activities, and obstacles to the development of a free, independent and pluralistic media in Angola; Taking into account evidence of the reinforcement of governing-party control, censorship and manipulation of state-run media; And considering the recent appeal of the Angolan President for a pluralistic media in the context of the post-Lusaka peace agreement, MISA's annual general meeting:

a) Reiterates its deepest concern at the government and Unita's restrictions on the activities of journalists.

b) Calls on the parties in Angola to commit themselves to the 1991 Windhoek Declaration on Promoting a Free and Pluralistic African Press, and to promote a culture of peace and national reconciliation through the media.

4. This meeting condemns the on-going harassment of The Post newspaper in Zambia , and of its Managing Director Fred M'membe in particular, and further calls on the Government of Zambia to scrap those clauses in the Leadership Code of Ethics Bill that require journalists writing about political leaders to appear before a tribunal to justify stories and to disclose their sources of information. This clause undermines press freedom, gives exclusive privilege to a few individuals in society, and breaches ethical demands of the profession of journalism .

5. This annual general meeting of MISA confirms an earlier call for the ending of monopolies in the electronic media. It further calls on governments in the region to transform state-controlled media into independently controlled public service media, and to abstain from interference of any kind in these media.

6. To facilitate the free flow of information, MISA calls upon SADC member governments to scrap visa and accreditation requirements for journalists working in the region.

7. In light of continued harassment of journalists throughout the region, MISA h as decided to set up a "hotline" to advise media in the region. The hotline will l be set up in tandem with a legal trust fund, and used to defend journalists against infringements of their fundamental rights to freedom of expression. The purpose of the hotline and the fund is to assist those media practitioners who would otherwise not have access to legal advice, or to legal advisers who are familiar with media law. 8. MISA, recognising that the new South Africa has seen fit not to set up a Ministry of Information, urges all other SADC member governments to emulate this example.

For further information, contact David Lush at Media Institute of Southern Africa (MISA) Private Bag 13386, Windhoek, Namibia. E-mail: dlush@misa.alt.na / tel. 264 61 232975 / fax. 264 61 248016


LOAD-DATE: February 6, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


372 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 1, 1994 / December 31, 1994


SOUTH AFRICA: New life for old classic -- Cry, the Beloved Country


BYLINE: William Pretorius, Weekly Mail & Guardian (Johannesburg), December 9, 1994


LENGTH: 867 words


 

THERE'S a lot riding on director Darrell Roodt's film of Alan Paton's Cry, the Beloved Country, produced by Anant Singh. It's the first major post-election film production. A new beginning? Yes, thinks Roodt, when you can pin him down during reshoots in Kliptown, just outside Johannesburg.

"Things have changed. Some people argue not, but there's a cultural shift. People want to examine their history, their roots, to look at where they are now. It's very important to make films to do this." 

The set is near Freedom Square, where the Freedom Charter was signed. Two kids wrestle, oblivious of the equipment that signifies "movie being made". It's difficult to tell who lives there and who are extras. A woman with a bundle of sticks on her head sways past. "Perfect," says production designer David Barkham. She was unplanned. A mangy dog sniffs at a pair of discarded shoes. No, they're props.

Barkham tells, in a voice modulated to talking quietly after a bearded crew member calls "roll sound" and we all have to shut up, how they wanted to film in a nearby Zionist Christian Church. They were refused permission although the church was poor, and they offered a lot of money. "We would have cleaned and painted it as well," says Barkham.

Now carpenters are building a facade of the church several blocks from the set, with interiors in a studio. Barkham wonders what the parishioners will think when they see their church on screen. They really wanted to film in that church -- it used to be a movie theatre.

The Fifties props were easier: things like cars, an aeroplane -- "we found one straight out of Casablanca" -- and a train. In fact, they have two trains. One was to be filmed at Pietermaritzburg station, but wires got crossed. The station was being painted so they had to relocate to Pretoria, with a new train. This one will be painted in colours that wash off.

But it's all in a day's filming. James Earl Jones, who plays pastor Stephen Khumalo, searching for his son in crime-ridden Johannesburg, is between takes. How does he feel playing a South African? He is soft-spoken, in spite of the famous booming voice. The quality he looks for is "humility". That's not easy: "Even to wake up in the morning is an act of arrogance -- you take on life! But Khumalo's humbleness is more than social, he walks in the steps of Jesus, as best as he can."

Jones had a "vision of Khumalo" before he started filming. "His journey is from a peaceful countryside blessed by nature, to Johannesburg, a journey to Purgatory and Hell."

Jones hasn't seen as much of South Africa. "It's hotel, highway and set." He'd like to return with his family, "not as tourists, but to meet others in the same industry". The poverty in Kliptown, though, upsets him: "the quaintness wears off and rage sets in" at the way squalor wears the spirit down. He's not a critical outsider -- he feels the same about similar parts of America.

The international media have been watching filming. Newsweek, The New York Times, international television crews have all paid a visit. Locally, though, there are some rumblings about "colonialism" in the choice of novel.

"I kind of agree with that," says Roodt, "but we're now allowed to approach the book with a Nineties perspective. The original film was colonial; the characters one- dimensional, divided between good old British upper-class guys and noble peasants, a bit too rah-rah. I'm making it more human."

Confrontational protest films are over, he says: "Friends was the last nail in the coffin of that kind of cinema. Finish! Finish! Enough now."

The novel, says Roodt, "is the one definitive classic about contemporary South Africa, and still surprisingly relevant". It is much more "philosophical about the dilemma of apartheid, although it was written before apartheid was legislated. It's about forgiveness, looking forward, understanding." In other words, it's universal.

But does it matter if the novel is colonial? On set, one realises that Paton's words are getting a new, different life in that mysterious process of becoming a living, visual thing -- a film. This isn't martial arts junk for video, a sure-fire money-maker. Instead, they're thinking South Africa -- and that takes enormous courage and faith in film.

We might have a movie industry after all.


LOAD-DATE: February 6, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


373 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 1, 1994 / December 31, 1994


Africa's voice Cries Out in Germany


BYLINE: S. Beitz, The Monitor (Kampala), The Monitor (Kampala), November 21-23, 1994


LENGTH: 694 words


 

"African authors have the potential to take the world by storm. They have a fresh message that comes very close to the true nature of people. It's a message that is of intellectual significance for the whole world," Zimbabwean publisher Paul Brickhin believes. 

Actually the Germans are reading the words of more and more African authors. These writers include the Nigerian Nobel Prize winner Wole Soyinka and his countrymen Chinua Achebe, the Senegalese woman author Mariama Ba, the Kenyan Ngugiwa Thiong'o, and Chenjeri Hove, Shimmer Chinodya and Tsitsi Dangarembga of Zimbabwe.

However, now as before, it is not easy to gain a foothold in Europe with African fiction. There are plenty of good manuscripts, but the African publishing business is not sufficiently developed to assert itself and its authors on the world market.

For the voice of Africa to be heard worldwide, despite this drawback, this section of global literature needs purposeful promotion. A first important and expensive step in this direction is the translation of the original manuscripts. For this reason, the German Foreign Ministry together with the Swiss Cultural foundation PRO HELVETIA has supported the translation into German of 34 African novels alone in the last 10 years. Translating is done through the Gsellschaft zur Forderung der Literature azusAfrika, Asien and Lateinamerwika e.V., in Frankfurt/Main, which was founded especially for this purpose.

This programme, which aims at encouraging German-language publishing companies to venture into literary discoveries which can help make literature from the South better known in Germany, has promoted important African authors. They include Dambudzo Marechera of Zimbabwe, the South Africans Peter Abrahams, Richard Rive and Mongane Wally Serote, Amadou Hampate Ba of Mali, an Henri Lopes of the Congo. Some translation have in fact become commercial successes, such as the book "Die Nacht des Baobab" by the Senegalese Ken Bugul, and the works of the woman author Bessie Head, who hails from South Africa. Their books, whose hard-cover editions were co-financed by the Foreign Ministry, have also been available as paperbacks for some years.

The applications for promotional funds come from German publishers. They commit themselves to adopting one novel, from the sub-Saharan region in their programmes when they receive subsidies for translation costs. A committee in which the Federal government, the Protestant Church and institutions of foreign cultural policy cooperate decides on the commissions. The Gsellschaft zur Forderung der Literature aus Afrika, Asien und Lateinamerika e.V. has been the launching pad for this translation promotion, the like of which is to be found in no other European country, since 1984. The Foreign Ministry has made DM 100,000 available for this project in 1994.

Among the publishing houses which for some years have committed themselves to the presence of African literature on the German book market are the Peter Hammer Verlag in Wuppertal, the Verlag Oto Lembeck in Frankfurt/Main, the Lamuv Verlag in Gotingen, the Jurgen Horlemann Verlag in Bad Honef, the Deutch Tschenburch Verlag (dtv) with its series "Drei Kontinente", and the Marino Verlag (formerly Kyrill & Method), both in. Munich.

THE MONITOR is published at P.O. Box 12141 Kampala, Uganda, Tel:251353 Fax: 251352,


LOAD-DATE: February 6, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


374 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 1, 1994 / December 31, 1994


Africa on the move: Dibango Album a Crash Course in Contemporary African Music


BYLINE: Steve Gordon, Weekly Mail & Guardian (Johannesburg), Weekly Mail & Guardian (Johannesburg), December 9, 1994


SECTION: MUSIC AND BOOKS


LENGTH: 814 words


 

WAKAFRIKA is a Manu Dibango opus -- an album of African classics by one of Africa's classics. Wakafrika? Vuka Afrika! This is a collection of anthems African, Africanised and Africaine. Recorded during 1993, the album was a 60th birthday project for Dibango, a celebration and collaboration with a flock of Africa's stars. 

Wakafrika comes to us in South Africa as a call back to our continent after years in the wilderness. Sure, we've rejoined the Organisation of African Unity and the United Nations. But Dibango is the African ambassador leading us back to the music, musicians and heart of modern Africa -- with a little help from his friends: Ray Phiri, Angelique Kidjo, Salif Keita, Sinead O'Connor, Ladysmith Black Mambazo, Peter Gabriel, Youssou N'dour, and more.

The album offers a crash course in contemporary African music. It's an anthology of modern African tracks, packaged with Dibango's rich Franco-Cameroonian treatment. We know many of the songs, if not their names. Pata Pata in a pan- African style? Wimoweh? Homeless? Melodies creep up from behind, like old friends. Familiar sounds are discernible within the layers and textures of Dibango's teasing arrangements.

Soul Makossa, Dibango's inescapable classic, is served fresh as always. N'dour's distinctive staccato phrasing slips tight into the funky guitar of the makossa groove, then soars high as the Senegalese singer makes his stamp on the 1972 classic. The makossa party's happening: brass swirls and swells, rhythm cycles to a standing wave for a moment, and contortionist N'dour climbs atop the groove.

Minimalist drum and percussion set up Peter Gabriel's Biko. Horns state the mournful lines of the familiar Biko chorus; a melancholy guitar lick, then enter the choir featuring Ladysmith Black Mambazo, Geoffrey Oryema, Alex Brown, O'Connor and Gabriel. Next, another classic, Jingo, introduces King Sunny Ade, juju master of Nigeria.

Wakafrika's comprehensive sleeve notes reveal that several of the featured artists are known to South African listeners. Souleymane Doumbia and Lasine Kouyate, for example, were the percussionist and balafonist who accompanied Salif Keita on his recent South African visit.

On Pata Pata, lead vocals are sung by Kaissa Doumbe, who toured South Africa as part of Dibango's Soul Makossa Gang in 1993. Perhaps inspired by her South African visit, Doumbe sings and improvises the pata pata lines with a nouveau sweetness.

Other highlights include Amio, which features Kidjo and Papa Wemba, and an addition to the South African repertoire in the form of Wimoweh (Mbube), where Joseph Shabalala, Phiri, Dibango and friends rock gently over marimba and guitar.

In Homeless, O'Connor weaves the midnite lake alongside Zaire's Ray Lema, and South African/Malawian-born Phiri. Known to us courtesy of Hugh Masekela's early 1980s recordings and frequent on-stage renditions, Lady, a funky and sensual Afrobeat song by Nigerian Fela Kuti, is also fronted by Phiri and O'Connor.

The album concludes with the Soul Makossa Gang's live rendition of Dibango's oriental ,a Va Chouia.

Strings and brass build a menacing tension, only to be released when the bass starts running, guitars picking, horns scatting, and we're into a groove.

The performance breaks down again to the menacing tension of Andre Manga's bass, and suddenly, high above the clouds, swathed in reverb, the trumpet of David Lewis catches its shaft of light, trading with the wah-wah guitar licks which snap rattlesnake-style with the snare.

The Weekly Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media Contact: M&G Media, 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025.For e-mail subscriptions, sned enquiries to: wmail-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point your browser to: http://www.is.co.za/services/wmail.html.


LOAD-DATE: February 6, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


375 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 1, 1994 / December 31, 1994


NIGERIA: Amnesty International Press Conference with Wole Soyinka


LENGTH: 1227 words


 

Washington, DC, December 6, 1994

Wole Soyinka was introduced by James O'Dea, Washington Director, Amnesty International USA

Soyinka recounted the state of oppression in Nigeria, and ridiculed the denial by government of existence of political detainees. He reserved very harsh comments for Abacha as a "man with no mind", a brutal person, and in a comparison drawing some guffaws commended Babangida of at least being "a dictator with some civilization." He urged the international community to impose more isolating sanctions (economic, social, cultural and sports) on the Nigerian government, stating that the government had in any case already imposed sanctions on its own people.

In a Question and Answer session, he urged wide participation in the rally on the British Embassy, stating the British were dealing in arms with Nigeria, notwithstanding their claim that it was a private deal between a company named VICA (?) and the Nigerian government. 

Daniel Suleiman (Commander retired) traced the birth of NADECO, their efforts at mobilizing the pro-democracy activities in Nigeria, the draconian measures used to suppress them, the press and the oil workers, and the need for many of them to flee their country in order to avoid detention and inhuman treatment, and carry on the struggle from safer grounds. He also urged the international community to impose sanctions on Nigeria to force a change in the human rights condition.

In his Qestion and Answer session, he said he was proud of his participation as a military officer in a regime which as promised returned power to civilian rule, and all that he wanted was for his colleagues to have done the same. Several questions were asked.

Statement By Amnesty International USA: Deteriorating Human Rights Situation In Nigeria

Read by Adotei Akwei, at Wole Soyinka's Press Conference

Few countries can boast of having both a Nobel Prize winner, Wole Soyinka, and a Right Livelihood winner, Ken Saro-Wiwa. Fewer still have forced their Nobel laureate to flee the country to avoid arrest or have kept their Right Livelihood award winner in detention without charge. The fact that Nigeria has done both is indicative of its potential and the depth of the current crisis.

In the past year the regime of General Sanni Abacha has banned over 15 newspapers and journals including the Concord, Punch and Guardian groups; arresting, detaining and harassing their staffs in addition to occupying their offices.

It has arrested or detained hundreds of demonstrators including M.K.O. Abiola, the man widely believed to have won last year's June presidential election, Ken Saro-Wiwa, who is also the President of the Movement for the Survival of the Ogoni People, retired Air Commodore Dan Suleiman, acting Chairman of NADECO, leading human rights activist Gani Fawehinmi, Dr. Beko Ransome Kuti and Liddum Mitee.

Also targeted for repression were the leaders of Nigerian Labor Congress (NLC), the National Union of Petroleum and Natural Gas Workers (NUPENG) and the Petroleum and Natural Gas Senior Staff Association of Nigeria (PENGASSAN). Following strikes and demonstrations in June and July the government arrested and dissolved the leadership, and then passed backdated decrees preventing any legal challenges to its actions.

General Abacha's troops have regularly used excessive force, committed extrajudicial execution and have killed an estimated 200 protesters. No investigations have been made into the circumstances of the killings.

Building on an already formidable web of repressive legislation, General Abacha has promulgated even more repressive decrees: Decree No. 11 of 1994 allows the Chief of General Staff and the Inspector General of Police to order detention without trial up to three months of anyone considered a threat to the security of the state. The decree also eliminated habeas corpus.

Decree No. 12 1994 blocks the ability of the Nigerian judiciary to challenge the government's actions or authority, solidifying the impunity already enjoyed in practice by the security forces and members of the government. The judiciary has also been undermined by the continued use of military tribunals whose record for due process has been questionable. The regime's contempt for the rule of law was displayed when it did not even bother to inform its Attorney-General of eight new decrees passed in September.

In Rivers State in southeast Nigeria the government has escalated a campaign of repression being waged on the Ogoni people. The Ogoni have been protesting environmental damage from years of oil production as well as lack of adequate compensation, development and aid from the federal government. Between May and June of 1994 at least 50 people were extrajudicially executed, an estimated 600 people detained or arrested and over 60 villages raided.

Amnesty International USA believes that the urgent crisis in Nigeria must be addressed by the international community. Any government that does not consider itself accountable to the rule of law domestically, (made clear by the failure to inform the former Attorney General about eight new decrees being passed) or internationally, (the seizure of Dr. Soyinka's UNESCO travel documents in November was a clear violation of international law) belie any claim it can make of returning the country to democratic rule.

We call upon the United States and the international community to serve notice to the Abacha regime that merely professing a commitment to the rule of law and democracy will not suffice to return its relation with the international community to business as usual.

President Clinton must lead the international community and call for the immediate and unconditional release of all prisoners of conscience and the prompt public investigations of all persons implicated in human rights violations in Nigeria.

Contact: Amnesty International, 304 Pennsylvania Ave. SE Washington D.C. 20003 Tel:202-544-0200 Fax:202-546-7142


LOAD-DATE: February 6, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


376 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 1, 1994 / December 31, 1994


NIGERIA: Statement by Amnesty International


LENGTH: 680 words


 

December 1994

Washington, D.C. -- Amnesty International USA (AIUSA) and Nobel Laureate Wole Soyinka today called on President Clinton to denounce the deteriorating human rights situation in Nigeria and urged him to lead the international community in applying pressure on the Nigeria's military regime to respect and protect human rights.

Wole Soyinka, Nobel Laureate in Literature, 1986, was forced to flee his homeland in mid-November following rumors that he was to be arrested by Nigerian military authorities. In September, his passport had been seized and his house placed under surveillance prior to a scheduled trip to Europe. A few weeks later, his travel documents from the United Nations Educational, Social and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) for which he is a goodwill ambassador, were seized. 

"The Nigerian government's treatment of Wole Soyinka underscores the arrogance with which they view Nigerian and international laws," said Adotei Adkwei, Program Officer for Sub-Saharan Africa, AIUSA, "The United States must take preventive action now while the possibility exists to avoid a future disaster in Africa's most populace country. Given the genocide in Rwanda, the continuing disintegration of Somalia and the ongoing civil war in Liberia, the United States cannot afford to view Nigeria as solely an African issue only to be faced with containing the chaos' later."

The government has arrested and detained hundreds of pro-democracy protesters, journalists, politicians, lawyers and trade unionists. Among those currently detained are M.K.O. Abiola, the projected winner of the presidential elections; Ken Saro-Wiwa, a prominent writer, President of the Movement for the Survival of the Ogoni People (MOSOP) and recipient of the Right Livelihood Award (also known as the alternative Nobel Prize); Liddum Mittee, Vice-President of MOSOP Chief Anthony Enahoro, Vice-Chairman of Nadeco and a former minister in Nigeria's first independent government in 1960. Amnesty International considers these men to be Prisoners of Conscience, imprisoned solely for the non-violent expression of their political views and calls for their immediate and unconditional release.

In the last year the Abacha regime has banned over 15 newspapers and journals often occupying the premises of publications and arbitrarily detaining the employees.

In south east Nigeria, Oganiland, Amnesty International has documented a violent crackdown on the Ogoni people following their efforts to seek compensation for years of environmental pollution and inadequate development by the Nigerian government. The crackdown has included a pattern of extra judicial executions, arbitrary detentions and raids in over 60 villages mostly between May and June, 1994. Over the last year, the Nigerian authorities have prevented reporters or human rights organizations from visiting the area.

"Nigeria is a critical country both in practical as well as symbolic terms," said Akwei, "The United States must now call on the Nigerian government to take measures to stop gross human rights violations before the current situation confronts the international community with a disaster felt across West Africa."

Contact: Amnesty International, 304 Pennsylvania Ave. SE Washington D.C. 20003 Tel:202-544-0200 Fax:202-546-7142


LOAD-DATE: February 6, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


377 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 1, 1994 / December 31, 1994


LIBERIA: Quest For Peace- an Update


BYLINE: Ezekiel Pajibo


LENGTH: 2067 words


 

Africa Faith and Justice Network (Washington, D.C.), December 1994

The lack of peace in Liberia has nothing to do with peace conferences. There have been at least 20 of them. It does not have to do with a lack of agreements, there have been at least 10 accords. So why has peace not come to Liberia yet? Ghana is trying to answer that question or can it? Akosombo Liberian warring factions and politicians have been in Ghana since November 12, 1994 at the invitation of President Jerry Rawlings of Ghana who is the current Chairman of the Economic Community of West Africa States (ECOWAS) whose monitoring group, ECOMOG, has been in Liberia since 1990 trying to secure the peace. The meeting was adjourned on September 11, to resume on the 20 after negotiators had consulted with their followers and/or their warlord(s). 

The Ghanaians are trying to rescue an accord reached in early September by three warring factions: the National Patriotic Front of Liberia (NPFL), harbinger of the war, Armed Forces of Liberia, (AFL)- supposedly the national army - and the United Liberia Movement for Democracy (ULIMO). The Akosombo Accord, as the treaty is known, was rejected by Liberian politicians who were in attendance at the Liberian National Conference in Monrovia as well as Liberian journalists. Their opposition to Akosombo stemmed from the interpretation that the Accord was rewarding individuals who are particularly responsible for the lack of progress in the implementation of the Cotonou Accord signed in July 1993 in Benin (more about Cotonou later).

What is more, the three groups, which were party to the latest accord, have serious internal divisions impaired by wanton violence. There are two ULIMOs: one wing led by Alhadji Kromah, who was one of the signatories to Akosombo and the other wing headed by Roosevelt Johnson, who, although represented at Akosombo, did not sign on to the agreement. The territories in Liberia to which ULIMO has claim are controlled by Johnson's ULIMO while Mr. Kromah, is believed to be resident in Guinea.

Mr. Charles Taylor, head of the NPFL and another signatory to the accord, has immense problems keeping his group together. Three of his highest profiled representatives in the Liberia National Transitional Government (LNTG), which was set up as a result of the Cotonou Accord have all parted company with him. Not only have they "ousted" him from the group, they are now party to something called "the coalition forces" who are battling remnants of Taylor's NPFL soldiers for control of Gbarnga, the provisional headquarters of the NPFL. Mr. Taylor has not been able to return to Gbarnga since he went to Ghana in early September. Even though Mr. Taylor has publicly stated that he would be taking Gbarnga back "soon;" two months have gone by and Gbarnga continues to be a "no man's land." Taylor's last known destination was Burkina Faso.

The AFL has its hands full. Almost all of the warring factions, perhaps, except for the NPFL, have fighters in their ranks who are members of the AFL. On September 15, former AFL Commanding General, the notorious Charles Julu (who left Worcester, Massachusetts, USA a day earlier) attempted to overthrow the LNTG with the help of 100 members of the AFL. The attempt was foiled by ECOMOG. Julu now awaits trial for "treason" in Monrovia. Following the foiled coup, 1000 members of the AFL were disarmed by ECOMOG. A few weeks thereafter, LNTG head, David Kpomakpor, sacked Hezekiah Bowen from his position as Chief of Staff of the AFL. Bowen was the one who signed in behalf of the AFL at Akosombo. Bowen's immediate deputy was promoted to replace him. Though dismissed, Bowen continues to be considered, by ECOWAS and himself, as the head of the AFL. Bowen's invitation to Ghana and his apparent refusal to step down, exemplified the rampant confusion characterizing the current Liberia peace process. Who is who; who represents who and/or what constitute the million dollar questions, a solution to the Liberian crisis will have to address.

Akosombo Once Ghana was impressed by Liberian politicians that it would not accept Akosombo I, a high level Ghanaian delegation visited Monrovia on September 9 and held talks with members of Liberia's political class, especially those involved with the Liberia National Conference. The talks did not produce any tangible result. Liberian politicians including, former President of the Interim Government of National Unity (IGNU), Amos Sawyer, the Chairman and Chief Organizer of the Liberia National Conference, a civilian member of the LNTG as well as Taylor appointee on the LNTG were in turn invited to Accra the following week. Again, no agreement was announced.

However, following the mid September Ghana meeting, participants of the National Conference in Monrovia, tempered their opposition to the Akosombo Accord. At the conclusion of the Conference in early October, it was hinted that with some modifications, Akosombo may become acceptable to the Liberian political class. It is also not very clear who the Liberian political class really represents either. They have not created any medium through which ordinary Liberians would contribute to the peace process. Liberian refugees, who number over a million have no way of impacting the talks. Only "recognized" politicians or their groups received invitations to the Ghana talks. Certainly, the Liberia National Conference is the largest assembly of Liberians since the civil war. About 1000 Liberians reportedly participated in the Conference. Its composition nonetheless does not differ from the one which met in March-April 1991. At that time it was largely the same "recognized" groups and individuals who were invited. This time around, the number have increased, obviously in response to the increased number of warring factions - the more the warriors, the more the urban politicians. In April 1991 there were only two warring factions. Now there are seven.

It is against this background that the warring factions and politicians met in Ghana "to fine tune" the agreement according to Ghana's Foreign Minister, who is co-chairing the talks along with his Nigerian counterpart. On November 6, following a meeting with the two Foreign Ministers, the three signatories to Akosombo I: NPFL's Taylor, ULIMO's Kromah and AFL's Bowen, issued a joint statement in which they pledged allegiance to the terms of Akosombo I and called on Ghana to install within "10 days" a new transitional Government. Ghanaian authorities differ and are pressuring the Liberian political class to accept a modified version of the treaty. Ghana expresses hope that with some adjustments, Akosombo II may provide a workable framework for resolving the Liberian crisis. Liberians can only wait and hope that this becomes the case.

Revisiting Cotonou--The Cotonou Accord is the current peace treaty in force. It transpired on September 7. Cotonou had a life span of six months. During that period it should have achieved disarmament, repatriation and democratic elections. It achieved none of those. Akosombo I hoped to have had that corrected. It nevertheless underestimated or chose to ignore the prevailing circumstances (as stated above) in the country. This is especially the case because renewed fighting had engulfed central and southeastern Liberia, producing new refugees and displaced persons. 200,000 Liberian refugees are believed to have fled to Cote d'Ivoire since September. An additional 50,000 Liberians, mostly from southeastern Liberia are displaced in Buchanan during the same period according to United Nations' sources.

As a result of the fighting, all relief groups in central and southeastern Liberia have withdrawn. heir withdrawal was precipitated by the kidnapping of relief workers, the looting of relief supplies, the carjacking of relief vehicles; and the outright capriciousness shown by the warring factions. Of greater concern is the partial withdrawal by Nigeria of some of its troops in Liberia; about 4000 of them have been withdrawn "due to lack of logistics." Furthermore, the United Nations has reduced its monitors from 368 to a mere 90 . This has put into jeopardy the lives of thousands of Liberians who were dependent on these agencies for their survival. Several hundred Liberian children are now facing starvation or suffering from malnutrition. The conditions of displaced Liberians has only gotten more precarious; with a threatening cholera epidemic. All of these are the direct results of the activities of the various warlords without exception. It is with them however, that the burden of bringing peace to Liberia rests; will and can they do so on their own?

Conclusion--At a time when Liberians need the international community most, it seems to be shirking its obligation to the people of that war-scarred country. U.N. Secretary General clearly stated this view by observing that "with regard to the Trust Fund for the Implementation of the Cotonou Agreement on Liberia, as at 10 October 1994, voluntary contributions received amounted to $17.8 million..." The Trust Fund, whose target was $160 million, was launched two years ago.

Cash-strapped Nigerians have been forced to cut back their troop strength. Ugandan President Museveni has promised to keep his troops in Liberia; maybe Tanzania will do similarly. Ghana threatened to bring home its troops by December if the warring factions do not disarm by then. Ghana, which has the second largest number of troops in the country, may change their position depending on the outcome of Akosombo II. Liberia is in competition with so many other crises in Africa for international attention. With the lack of Western media attention, Liberia appears to be kept on the back burner of Western policy makers. Time could not be any bleaker for Liberia.

Liberians need the help of the international community, especially the West, to end its crisis. Preliminary steps to achieve this will have to include a ceasefire by the warring factions and guarantees for the safety of relief workers. This will enable relief workers to gain access to displaced persons. For another accord to have serious impact, it would require significant diplomatic and financial assistance from western countries particularly the United States of America. It should be stated unambiguously as a caveat, that any party which presents obstacle(s) to the implementation of the agreement will be severely censured. The time for peace in Liberia is now.

Resources Available on Liberia: 1. The Akosombo Accord; 2. U.N. Secretary General 7th Progress Report to the UN Security Council; 3. Briefing Paper - Liberia Peace Process produced by the Justice and Peace Commission, National Catholic Secretariat, Monrovia.

Please feel free to call the Africa Faith and Justice Network (202 832-3412) for information on Liberia.


LOAD-DATE: February 6, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


378 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 1, 1994 / December 31, 1994


U.S./ AFRICA: Speech by National Security Adviser Anthony Lake to the Organization for African Unity


SECTION: DOCUMENTS


LENGTH: 2534 words


 

(excerpt)

Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, December 15, 1994

Democracy is finding its root in country after country. There is concrete proof that economic discipline and modernization will yield growth. There are encouraging signs that subregional organizations--ECOWAS in Liberia, IGADD in Sudan, and SADC in Angola, Mozamibque and Lesotho-- are searching for new ways to address the calamitous conflicts in their areas. I might add that it is important that there is a longing for stability among so many-- people tired of civil wars, exhausted by disasters man-made and natural, desperate and determined to pass on a better life to their children. It is a desire that Africans share with people all over the world-- from the Middle East to Northern Ireland to Central America.

But while we recognize these signs of hope, we know--as you know-- that many Africannations are but one step away from crisis. And at such an important and potentially difficult moment, caring means not only acting, but also that it is necessary for Africa's friends to speak the truth as we see it. Not to condemn and not to distance ourselves from Africa's problems, but as part of our commitment to help resolve them. 

Despite the signs of progress, the truth in stark. African nations must reverse the economic slide of the so-called "lost decade of the 1980s" that has left their people, for the most part, poorer, less educated, less healthy and with fewer prospects for better lives than they had almost a generation ago. Even the countries that are making progress are threatened by instability in their regions. Sixteen African nations are involved in some form of civil conflict: six million refugees and 17 million displaced persons put an intolerable strain on resources.

In countries like the United States, those of us who recognize the importance of continued active engagement and support for Africa are confronting the reality of shrinking resources and an honest skepticism about the return on our investments in peacekeeping and development. The world around Africa is fast coming together, and this continent risks becoming the odd man out.

Let me illustrate what I mean.

I have come to Addis after six weeks with President Clinton that has taken us around the world. We traveled to six nations in the Middle East and witnessed the signing of a peace treaty between Israel and Jordon. In Budapest, at the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, President Clinton marked an historic occasion as three nations of the former Soviet Union agreed to dismantle their nuclear weapons. In Jakart, the President helped lead 17 Asian-Pacific governments to agreement on creating a free trade zone by the year 2020. In Miami last weekend, he led the nations of the Western Hemisphere as they agreed to create an agreement for a Free Trade of the Americas by 2005. And at home, he secured the passage by our Congress of the General of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

These are tremendous accomplishments, events that would have been unimaginable even a decade ago. I catalogue them for you because I believe that-- despite their different goals-- they all send a clear message: each of these regions is coming together politically and, especially, economically. And they are doing so in the context of the global GATT agreement. Unless African nations can resolve their internal problems so that they can come together in similar fashion. Africa could be left outside the new globla marketplace, and that would be a tragedy.

Much of this is probably due to economic and environmental mismanagement. But it is also a fact that those responsible for the murderous conflicts that plague the continent are doing more that slaughtering so many of this generation with bullets and machetes; they are also killing the hope of future generations to find a more prosperous life.

Too many African nations are caught in a vicious cycle. Bloody civil wars and deadly ethnic conflicts make political stability impossible. Without political stability there can be little economic development. And economic and environmental decay, in turn, generate the conditions for these explosive civil wars.

Breaking this cycle is no easy task. But one thing is clear: African governments and international community together must shift their focus from reacting to crises and dealing with the human consequences to their prevention.

President Clinton's Horn of Africa initiative seeks to identity and address the root causes of hunger and famine in ten nations before they can erupt.

Currently, the United States spends twice as much on disaster relief as it does on development.

We have begun talks with African governments and donors to fashion an approach that changes this trend, that goes beyond disaster relief to try to intergrate our relief and development efforts. That approach would involve regional cooperation among affected nations, improved donor collaboration, and- very important- strengthened early warning systems to account for social and political trends in addition to climatic changes. The initiative will put African governments at the center of an alliance among donor governments, private groups and the countries in the region.

The goal is to launch a three-part program. Our first focus combines traditional relief techniques and new technology to prevent immediate threats of famine by propositioning food, so that Africans and the international community can react quickly to Famine Early Warning System reports. In turn, we will work with local governments and populations to advance programs necessary for recovery from such crises: increasing agricultural production, repairing and building roads and dams, and launching projects to prevent soil erosion. And third, and this is most important, we will also address such long term challenges as overpopulation, the role of women, and environmental decay. Working with other donors and international institutions and drawing on our allocated relief resources, we hope that up to $1 billion can be identified by the international community for these vital activities, and we're going to work onthis.

Regional cooperation will help begin to break the grip of famine. It can also help African natios to solve one of the major man-made causes of these disasters: ethnic conflicts and civil wars. Controlling and preventing these outbreaks is in every African nation's self-interest. But the United States can also help support these efforts, for it is in our interest too.

In the wake of long and terrible conflicts, many countries are faced witht he dilemma of what to do with the former cobatants. Nations like Ethiopia, and others, have taken strong steps to demobilize their forces, in an effort to promote stability by helping them move smoothly and quickly into productive civilian jobs. Demobilization frees up resources better spent on schools, health clinics and development projects.

Different nations have used different techniques from cash payments for soldiers to providing funds for transport home or job training. The results have been dramatic. By next year, Uganda will have cut its 80,000-man army by half; each soldier receives $1000 for materials to build homes, purchase medical care and provide transport for himself and his family. And in Mozmbique, the combined forces of 110,000 warring armies have already been reduced to less than 15,000.

Over the past two years the United States has allocated some $40 million for dembilization this year.

The United States also supports the goal of the eentual elimination fo land mines everywhere. Towards that goal, we are supporting programs aimed at comprehensive steps to remove landmines throughout Africa. At the United Nations this year, President Clinton announced our intention to seek unprecedented controls ont he export and use of landmines. Africa is the world's most heavily mined region, with as many as 30 million mines in 18 countries-- out fo an estimated 100 million worldwide. In Angola alone, there's more than one landmine for each of its nearly 10 million citizens.

In addition to our program in Angola, this year we are supporting efforts to clear mines and train people to recognize, avoid and report landmines in Ethiopia, Eritrea, Mozambique, Namibia and Rwanda. Removing these mines is not only important for humanitarian purposes, but can be key to economic recovery in nations after long years of war and slowed agricultural production.

Finally, the United States has committed $1.5 million to support the OAU's conflict resolution program begun by Secretary Genereal Salim. We want to help you redouble your efforts to prevent conflict and enhance your peacekeeping activities, as you have done int he recent mission that sent human rights monitors to Burundi. And two weels ago we were pleased to welcome Doctor Chris Bakwesegha, chief of your conflict resolution division, when he visited the U.S. to tour a number of facilities,including the Pentagon's national military commander center. We are encouraged by his plan to create an effective operations center here in Addis.

Let me emphasize: the Clinton Administration stands with you and with everyone on the front lines of the struggle for Africa's future. But securing these resources and supporting these programs is not getting any easier. The problems are apparent: shrinking budgets that could maean stagnant levels of aid. An American people devating where and when to get involved abroad. A United Nations stretched to its capacities. We are commited to remaining engaged-- but we must recognize how hard the road ahead of all of us will be.

In the best of times, all that the outside world can offer nations in crisis is "window of opportunity" in which they can sort out their problems during a period of relative security. The international community can offer support; it cannot be a savior. Outsiders have neither the power or the right to dictate solutions for the nations of Africa or any other region.

Now, when the times are getting tougher, we face a new reality. In Africa and elsewhere, the windows of opportunity can remain open for only so long. And every time the leaders of contending factions do not seize that opportunity, do not act before the window slams shut, they will not only hurt the citizens of their countries, they may also diminish the will of the international community to offer such support elsewhere in other conflicts and crises on the continent. So it will be harder-- not impossible, but harder-- o count on the international community ot heal the wounds of these wars. The warlords -- and, tragically, their peoples-- cannot always count on an international safety net.

Ultimately Africa's leaders and it's people are responsible for their actions; they have it within their power to settle their differences. And we need look no further than southern Africa, to Mozambique, for encouraging evidence taht when leaders decide to put the future of their nations ahead of their immediate ambitions, and use democracy to settle their differences,they can rightfully claim the gratitude of their people and the applause of the world.

In recent months we have seen how in both Lesotho and Mozambique neighboring states can help prevent such conflicts. And across Africa, there is a new generation of leaders, like President Meles in Ethiopia, many of whom have come to power since the end of the Cold War. These leaders have discarded the ideological baggage of the end of the Cold War. They have gone beyond the heady era of independence and the subsequent period of blaming everything on their colonial legacies. They recognize the deadly potential of ethnic rivalries, AIDS, environmental degradation. And they are ready to measure their progress on a different scale: instituting economic policies that promote sustainable development,building responsive governments that give citizens a stake in the future, and creating civil societies in which freedom flourishes.

That is why, despite the dangers and the difficulties that I have just outlined. President Clinton and his Administration reject Afro-pessimism. But neither should any of us seek refuge in the illusions of Afro-optimism. Friends of Africa who suggest these challenges will be easily met are not doing any of us a favor.

What is needed, I think, instead is a new Afro-realism. An Afro-realism that commits us to the hard work that can strenghten the partnership between Africa and America. For without the partnership, Africa will have lost the support we wish to give and are determined to give. And America will have lost the opportunity to participate in what could be--what must be--one of the great adventures of our time: fulfilling the dreams of Africa's greatness that animated the leaders of its independence so many years ago.


LOAD-DATE: February 6, 1995

Africa News


December 1, 1994 / December 31, 1994


NIGERIA: The Women are Coming


BYLINE: Newswatch, December 5, 1994


LENGTH: 854 words


 

For the first time, Nigerian women are becoming directly involved in the formation of political associations. In the past one week, two political associations headed by women have emerged. The first one is the Republican Movement of Nigeria, RMN, which is headed by Oliviah Agbajoh, a lawyer and former member of the Federal House of Representatives in the Second Republic. She told "Newswatch" last week that when the ban on formation of political parties is finally lifted, the movement would transform into the Republican Party of Nigeria, RPN.

The party, she said, would have as its focus the liberation of all oppressed Nigerians especially women and children. She argued that although women and children constitute a greater percentage of Nigeria, successive governments have neglected them. She accused Sani Abacha, the head of state of refusing to include women in his government, adding, "it is not only people in oil producing communities who are marginalised. Many people including the poor and defenseless women and children are suffering. So our aim would be to liberate them." She explained that her role in the formation of the political association is to ensure equal participation for all Nigerians in the democratisation process. 

A second political association, the One Nigeria Forum is said to be lead by Sara Jubril, former presidential aspirant of the proscribed Social Democratic Party, SDP. Although she refused to sign the pamphlet announcing the formation of the political association, she was said to have been involved in it formation. The association which may also transform into a political party is said to be aimed at healing the wounds created by political differences which have torn the country apart in the past two years.

Already, the two groups are said to be recruiting members from all parts of the country. Said Agbajoh: "Our target is to reach everybody in this country, to spread our message of liberation, our message of national regeneration. I am sure that our messages will appeal to millions of Nigerians."

"Newswatch" learnt that these political moves by the women was encouraged by a two-day national workshop on the participation of women in politics and national development organised by the National Council of Women Societies, NCWS. At the workshop, the NCWS urged women to seek elective offices without compromising their family and societal obligations. The council also suggested that there should be no party exclusively for women or women's wings' in political parties, saying "women should be involved in the process of party formation and in the highest decision-making organs of parties." A non-partisan trust fund is to be set up to provide support for any duly nominated female candidate. This will provide female politicians strong financial base with which to fight for elective positions.

A similar workshop organised by the NCWS media forum to sensitise Nigerian journalist on the coverage of international conferences was also held in Lagos. Speakers at the workshop agreed on the need to promote women's positive contributions to society. Tom Adaba who represented Jerry Gana, minister of information, said Nigerian media women should strive to "re-affirm women's wisdom and knowledge by way of encouraging dialogue and debate."

Another speaker, Janet Badjan-Young, the director of United Nations Information Centre in Nigeria said women in the media should "promote issues like gender equality and highlight harmful cultural practices like teenage marriage, violence against women, denial of education to females and dumping of female babies in pit latrines." According to her, this could be done by providing education on health issues and career options. Badjan-Young said the media role of advocacy is equally important. Women in the media she said, "must be the voice of the voiceless, must protect women's interests, aspirations and visions by making government and international organisations responsive to women's issues and advancement."

Apart from generating a new spirit of determination and commitment to the advancement of women, the workshops were a part of preparation for the conferences on women in Dakar Senegal and Beijing China.

NEWSWATCH is published at P.M.B. 21499, Ikeja, Nigeria, Tel:4960950; Fax:962887 Telex:27874

Africa News


December 1, 1994 / December 31, 1994


SOUTH AFRICA: Women Take The FLoor


BYLINE: New Nation (Johannesburg), December 2, 1994


SECTION: WOMEN


LENGTH: 1227 words


 

South Africa's new parliament has more women than ever beforee, but as the first session drew to a close a fortnight ago, women MPs agreed it still was not a "woman-friendly" place.

For a start, when the new MPs arrived in May, they found there were hardly any women's toilets.There was a billiard room, but no childcare facilities, and the two gyms were used exclusively by men.

Parliament's walls were full of portraits of white men. The only woman sharing the place with them was Helen Suzman of the Progressive Federal Party (PFP), But some things have started to change. A creche was set up, women's toilets put in on every floor, and a gym given over to women members. 

"This is probably the first time any parliament in the world has had an ad-hoc committee dealing with children," said ANC MP Yvette Myakayaka. But ANC MP Baleka Kgositsile said: "Men have their own world and their own way of networking in parliament that is not sensitive to women. So issues affecting more than half of the population, like sexual harassment and rape, tend not become policy matters."

ANC MP Zoe Kota said it also meant: "Because a person is a woman, she has to prove herself three times in order to be seen to be doing something in parliament."

Women have also complained about the persistent jeering in sessions though by men from the former liberation movements, in which this was not common, have found it just as alienating. In addition, working hours are awkward for women with families to take care of. Senate and National Assembly sessions can go on until 8 pm, said PAC MP Patricia de Lile.

Nightmare

"My personal experience has been a nightmare," said ANC MP Baleka Kgositsile. She is a single parent with five children in Johannesburg and finds the time she has to spend in Cape Town disruptive and financially demanding. "It is even more difficult for women whose husbands have not reached a level of political maturity where they cannot accept that their wives are MPs," she said.

"They face tensions in their marriages, while at the same time trying to settle down in Cape Town and set up second homes." But despite the obstacles, there have been victories, starting with Frene Ginwala's appointment as Speaker of the National Assembly.

Women also chair committees, head study groups, are whips and play an important role in caucuses, though they are still under-represented at the highest level of government. There are 17 ministries, but only two are women and three deputy ministers.

"We need to ensure that the criteria of non-sexism is taken as seriously as the non-racist one when appointments are made, " said Kgositsile. Nevertheless, women made themselves heard on some key issues in this session. The Reconstruction and Development Programme (RDP) white paper took on board women's concerns by including free medical facilities for pregnant women and children under six, free schooling for the first 10 years and school feeding schemes, for example.

But the real test would be in its implementation, said Myakayaka. Women would have to be involved in the local government and non-governmental structures which would be responsible for delivery if they were going to benefit from the RDP.

The decision by the President's office to have a special desk to deal with women's issues was a set in the right decision, De Lille said. The passing of the Land Restitution Bill was also a victory for women, Myakayaka pointed out. A large number of rural families were headed by women, who often bore the brunt of forced removals.

Meanwhile, committees were set up to look into the questions of unequal taxation, abortion and sterilisation and the establishment of a commission on gender equality to advise the government on legislation and policy. The commission is provided for in the interim constitution but women are concerned that it should not become a ghetto on gender issues.

"Our experience of Codesa was that gender issues were put to advisory committees. That meant policy making continued while gender issues were pushed aside," explained Kota.

Organise

Women have also managed to organise themselves both within their parties and across party-political lines. A multi-party women's caucus meets weekly to try and reach consensus on issues that affect them across the board and to provide support to its members. many of whom have been in full time politics before. The organisation is still in its infancy without even an office or a co-ordinator but successfully rallied women around the issue of making International Women's Day on August 9 as a national holiday.

There have also been workshops on speech writing and delivery, for example, as well as visits overseas to give women a chance to se how other parliaments function. "We have established a good rapport and the contact between different women is very good and better than among men," Myakayaka said.

IFP MP Faith Gas agreed. "Some IFP women were a bit cautious about working with ANC women but the more they went to caucus the happier they got," she said. The challenge will be to maintain that unity when the more controversial issues like abortion and sterilisation are raised in the next session.

The caucus also needs to organise itself to screen legislation, Kota said. Most MPs do not have the support of research assistants or secretaries and individuals have not had the time to scrutinise every piece of legislation that has been through parliament for its impact on women.

In addition, the caucus needs to make contact with women's organisations outside parliament. "Until now, we have not been speaking with a mandate," explained Kota. So the issues prioritised by MPs might not be the issues that women outside parliament considered most important.

New Nation, Darraugh House, 13 Wanders Street, Johannesburg, S. A. Tel.: 333-2711 or 333-2721/2/3/4/; Fax: 889-0630

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


December 1, 1994 / December 31, 1994


FOOTBALL: The Road is Now Clear


BYLINE: Dotun Oladipo, Newswatch, November 28, 1994


SECTION: SPORTS


LENGTH: 1067 words


 

"African football has come of age," says Adegboye Onigbinde, former Super Eagles coach and Confederation of African Football, CAF, technical committee member. He was reacting to FIFA's decision to give Africa two additional slots at the 1998 World Cup. Fanny Amu, Flying Eagles coach and Joseph Ladipo, a.k.a. Jossy Lad, also a coach, expressed the same view.

Winning two more slots for Africa was a major victory for Issa Hayatou, CAF president. He convinced Joao Havalenge, FIFA president, to concede to Africa five of the 32 slots for the 1998 world cup finals in France. Hayatou had been campaigning for two additional slots for Africa since the 32 team format was proposed in 1990. "We had to fight hard to get this," Hayatoud said in New York. 

The battle was not won easily. Before the last World Cup, USA '94, in which Africa had three representatives-Nigeria, Cameroon and Morocco-the continent had two representatives. Cameroon's spectacular performance at Italy '90 changed that and FIFA decided to give Africa one more place. That extra place was taken from Europe. This time around, however, there was some politiking. Havalenge's sixth term as FIFA president was partly made possible by Hayatou's withdrawal from succession contest. CAF had put forward Hayatou mid-way into Havalenge's fifth term. A lot of work was also done by CAF to ensure the African representative's success. At a stage, Sepp Blatter, FIFA secretary-general, told the press that an African was likely to succeed Havalenge. But towards the end of Havalenge's fifth term, the Brazilian called Hayatou for a dialogue in order to win one more term. Hayatou agreed. At the FIFA congress during the USA '94 draws, Havalenge was returned unopposed.

And Africa's gain was a loss for other continents. Europe, lobbied for 15 places but was given 14. It had 13. South America for one more to make it five. Confederation of American Football, CONCACAF, also received one more place. It now has three. Asia, wanted four places but was given only one more making them three but of four team option. The continent's fourth qualifier will play a qualifying match with the winner of Oceania which has none or one option.

Blatter said, "there was no real problem. Only the Asians who would have liked four guaranteed places were a bit unhappy." Lent Johannson, Union of European Football Association, UEFA, president said that Europe's two extra slots "made a lot of sense. We could have argued for another place but we have respect for the others."

The Asians are unhappy because FIFA did not take the performance of its representatives, South Korea and Saudi Arabia, at USA '94 into consideration. Though South Korea lost out in the preliminaries, it gave a good account of the improvement that Asian football has gone through in the last four years. They drew 2-2 with Spain and 0-0 with Bolivia, only to lose in their best match of the tournament to Germany. 2-3. Saudi Arabia went as far as the second round and they lost to Sweden.

If that argument were tenable, Europe and South America might as well have taken all the world cup places available. At the last World Cup, three of the semifinalists were from Europe- Italy, Bulgaria, and Romania. The other semifinalist was Brazil from South America. South American countries Brazil, Argentina and Uruguay have won the World Cup eight times. Brazil won the Jules Rimet trophy for keeps in 1970.

However, FIFA's other consideration was the number of football associations each region has registered with it. FIFA has 178 members comprising Europe with 49, Africa 48, Asia 36, CONCACAF 27, South America 10, and Oceania 8.

With the 32 team format, the cumbersome and unjustifiable process of picking the four best third-placed teams after world cup finals preliminary match will be eliminated. Although FIFA feels it has taken a right decision, the body will wait to see the performance of each zone before it puts its seal on the format.

This perhaps, is where CAF might run into problems. Hayatou's plans is to employ FIFA's method for seeding countries based on the strength of the teams. But some African countries are already lobbying CAF to pick a team each from each of the five regions of Africa. These are West, East, South, North and Central Africa.

Segun Odegbami, former Eagles captain and head of marketing committee of the NFA was afraid this could happen. He advised that FIFA should grant only four places to Africa. Odegbami argues that "countries with weak teams show want to go to the world cup at all cost out number those with strong teams. They could take the situation out of CAF's control."

Onigbinde thinks Odegbami's fears are misplaced. He told "Newswatch" that Africa had been divided into six operational zones by CAF. There are two each in the West and North and one in the South/Central and East Africa Hayatou himself is sure the CAF will adopt a system which will guarantee that the best five teams in Africa are picked. He says he recognises that West Africa has three strong reams and that it the three qualify for the world cup, no one would query CAF's decision. "The system of the best will be used in selecting qualifiers," Hayatou said.

NEWSWATCH is published at P.M.B.21499, Ikoja, Nigeria Tel: 4960950 Fax: 962887 Telex: 27874

LANGUAGE: English
