Africa News


December 1, 1994 / December 31, 1994


TRADE: ADB Proposes A Twin-Track Route For Southern Africa


BYLINE: New Nation, November 25, 1994


LENGTH: 800 words


 

With the demise of South Africa's apartheid system, the whole Southern African region stands at the threshold of a new era promising greater economic co-operation and integration, observes the African Development Bank (ADB).

But the new opportunities for expanded trade and mutually beneficial exchanges "must be seized before the moment passes," the ADB warns in a study called "Economic Integration in Southern Africa" published in the latest edition of the United Nations' quarterly publication, African Recovery.

Surveying the likely impact of the large South African economy on the rest of Southern Africa, the study stressed that development and growth must be more balanced than in the past. 

"The clear lesson," says ADB President Babacar Ndiaye, "is that for the region's overall welfare gain to be distributed among countries more equitably than the market would by itself achieve, a regional policy will be required that would ensure that all countries register net gain as a result of co-operation and progressive integration".

Ndiaye asserts that for such an equitable economic integration to succeed, a "pre-occupation with trade liberalisation" by itself insufficient.

There must also be a corresponding "priority to investment in production to expand productive capacity in all sectors and to build the necessary infrastructure". This approach, he says, marks a "fundamental departure" from past attempts at African economic integration.

he study stresses that integration of the wider Southern region must proceed incrementally, beginning with the "core group of countries: the 10 countries of the Southern African Development Community (SADC), plus South Africa.

Improving co-ordination with Kenya, Zimbabwe or other nearby countries may be vital in certain economic sectors, but involving all 20 members of the wider Preferential Trade Area for Eastern and Southern African (TPA) at this point "would be fraught with severe practical problems".

"Bilateral"

Nevertheless, it is important to begin now to rationalise the overlapping and sometimes competing regional institutions.

Besides SADC and PTA, there are the Southern African Customs Union (Sacu), the Southern African Multilateral Monetary Area and other subsidiary bodies and bilateral agreements.

The study concludes that the basis already established by SADC for project and sector coordination should provide the "main focus" for integration efforts and that SADC should be careful not to dissipate its efforts.

SADC will have its hands full simply concentrating on the task of co-ordinating investments in key sectors and engaging South Africa in the region's development.

Meanwhile, "the PTA should continue as the agenda-setting authority on trade liberalisation and the evolution of a common market," in light of the hopes for an "eventual enlargement" of sub-regional groupings into a broader continent-wide community.

The study's institutional recommendations reflect its view t hat the route to economic integration in Southern Africa will need to proceed along two parallel and connected tracks.

The first is sector co-ordination and co-operation on project investment and policy harmonisation. Progress along this track should begin immediately, the study says, and "co-ordination in each sector should proceed as fast as circumstances within the sector allow."

The second track, market integration, will involve reducing both tariff and non-tariff barriers to intraregional trade.

New Nation, November 25, 2994

New Nation, Darraugh House, 13 Wanders Street, Johannesburg, S. A. Tel.: 333-2711 or 333-2721/2/3/4/; Fax: 889-0630


LOAD-DATE: February 6, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


383 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 1, 1994 / December 31, 1994


TRADE: GATT's Impact on Africa


LENGTH: 1334 words


 

Washington Notes on Africa

Fall 1994

African countries, whose representatives played little role in the complex and secretive negotiations, are likely to be particularly big losers. A recent OECD (Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development) study of GATT's effects predicted that by the year 2002 the rest of the world will be gaining annual benefits of $216 billion while Sub-Saharan Africa will be suffering losses of $2.6 billion a year. This loss, argued the study, could be offset by an increase in aid to the continent. But given the trend towards diminished aid, this seems unlikely. 

In theory, GATT should open up opportunities for developing countries, including Africa, to sell more to the developed world. There will likely be gains in some sectors, such as for African sugar exporters. Eventually African textile exports might benefit, although most tariff cuts for textile imports by developed countries will not fall until 2005. The negative effects will be more substantial, while Africa's leverage to gain exceptions will remain far less than that of more powerful actors in the world economy.

The most significant losses will come from erosion of quotas and preferences for Africa under the Lome agreements with Europe. The Generalized System of Preferences (GSP), a loophole allowing special treatment for developing countries, will also be more restricted under the new GATT.

Traditional African exports of tropical products will thus suffer. There will be increasing restrictions on African governments' options for subsidizing farmers and restricting food imports to achieve food security. While theoretically GATT exempts the least developed countries from having to remove their agricultural import barriers, it will intensify pressures in that direction already at work in most structural adjustment programs instituted by the World Bank and IMF.

Gains from GATT will tend to accrue to larger farmers and multinational agricultural companies already engaging in production for export. Food security, however, is better promoted through increasing and diversifying production for the domestic market and promoting regional trade between African countries. Both these goals will be more difficult to pursue under GATT guidelines.

More generally, GATT will promote deeper penetration of African economies by foreign interests. A requirement to treat foreign companies in the same way as domestic ones will override the ability of governments to have a say, for example, in requiring majority domestic ownership of joint ventures. The net effect will be to reduce the options for protecting vulnerable local markets.

The new World Trade Organization, to be set up as a result of the GATT agreement, will be a highly undemocratic body, removing decisions even further from input by grassroots interests.

GENERALIZED SYSTEM OF PREFERENCES (GSP)

A related issue which will be on the Congressional agenda is renewal of the GSP, currently the most important mechanism regulating trade between the U.S. and developing countries.

When GATT began thirty years ago, participating countries were required to implement reciprocal reductions in trade barriers, and treat all countries equally. Developing nations, however, said such requirements hindered their ability to increase export earnings and reduce their dependence on foreign aid. The requirements were then modified to exempt developing countries from the reciprocity requirement, and to allow developed countries to grant preferential treatment to developing countries. Although this mechanism has provided limited benefits to date, it provides a framework for advocating measures to increase Africa's trade earnings.

In 1974 the U.S. passed legislation implementing the GSP, with the stated goals of helping developing countries industrialize, reduce their dependence on primary commodities and increase expand manufacturing. Specifically, the GSP:

1) authorizes the President to allow eligible articles into the U.S. market duty-free;

2) forbids the President from designating certain items as eligible articles, specifically textile and apparel articles subject to textile agreements, electronic products, steel products, most leather products, glass products, and some others;

3) places limits on the amount of each article which may be imported;

4) sets criteria which countries must meet before being eligible for GSP.

With all these qualifications, according to the Environmental and Energy Study Institute, only 14 percent of all imports to the U.S. from developing countries enjoy GSP treatment. Less than one tenth of one percent of GSP benefits go to the forty least developed countries, most in Sub-Saharan Africa. GSP thus currently translates into few gains for African countries. In fact, it tends to benefit countries such as South Korea which already have manufacturing capacity.

Most of the eligible articles which enjoy GSP treatment are not agricultural products, which are generally considered sensitive to the U.S. economy. Overall, less than 10 percent of U.S. imports from least-developed African beneficiaries of GSP receive GSP treatment.

This year Congress, at the administration's request, reauthorized GSP for one year only. Next year the administration is expected to propose a ten-year renewal. The one-year renewal reduces total GSP benefits slightly, while giving the President more discretionary authority to review tariff schedules and grant GSP status to additional commodities not considered "import-sensitive," including steel, electronics and glass. Virtually no least-developed country, however, has the capacity to export these products.

Advocates of GSP reform argue that GSP unnecessarily excludes from coverage many products of export interest to Africa's least-developed countries. Their export volumes are unlikely to be large enough to have "import-sensitive" effects for U.S. producers. For this group of countries, all products should be eligible for consideration for GSP status, and the decision should be made on the basis of the potential contribution to sustainable development.

In new GSP legislation, moreover, the objectives need to be clearly focused on environmentally sustainable development and diversification of exports by developing countries.

Washington Notes on Africa, The Washington Office on Africa, 110 Maryland Ave., NE, Suite 112, Washington, DC 20002 Tel: (202) 546-7961


LOAD-DATE: February 6, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


384 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 1, 1994 / December 31, 1994


AFRICAN ECONOMIES: Still In The Woods


BYLINE: Joseph Ode, Newswatch, November 21, 1994


SECTION: BUSINESS and FINANCE


LENGTH: 1787 words


 

The year 1993, on the whole, was a difficult one for the economies of African countries. So says The World Bank Annual Report 1994. The Gross Domestic Product, GDP, for the continent, excluding South Africa, grew by just 1.4 percent. "Although this represents an improvement over 1992, it is nonetheless disappointing considering the region's high rate of population growth and the level needed for development," the report says.

As in previous years, according to the report, the countries implementing major economic reforms and, therefore, benefiting from the Special Programme of Assistance, SPA, saw their aggregate output increase by 2.1 percent, or more than the average for the region. The SPA for low-income, debt-distressed sub-Saharan African countries provides quick-disbursing balance-of-payments assistance to 29 eligible countries (as at the end of June 1994) in support of reform programmes developed in conjunction with the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, IMF. The 16 core or steady reformers did still better as their GDP rose by 2.8 percent. The countries comprising the CFA zone, however, saw their economies contract for the third consecutive year. 

A positive development in 1993, according to the World Bank, was that, on the average, the low-income countries performed better than the middle-income ones, although, neither group recorded an increase in per capita terms. Some of the highest rates were achieved by those countries such as Lesotho, Malawi, Mozambique, and Zambia that were recovering from the severe drought of 1991/92. The report attributes the "rather quick recovery" of these and other countries from the effects of the drought to "the relative resilience of their economies and to the effectiveness of collaboration among their public administrations, donors, and non-governmental organisations."

There were sharp contrasts in the performance of the economies of African countries last year, due to the contradictory forces at play not just across countries but within them and even within sectors. For instance, such countries as The Gambia, Sierra Leone, and Zimbabwe, where the implementation of reform programmes is on track, experienced low GDP growth rates due to the deterioration of their terms of trade (low prices of their exports), weather conditions, the lingering effects of the 1991-92 drought, or the disruptions caused by rebel activity and political transition. In contrast, other countries such as Equatorial Guinea and Sudan where reform programmes were lacking or off-track, registered growth of six to seven percent, made possible by oil exports or favourable agricultural conditions.

Despite these variations, the events of the past year have some common elements which, to the World Bank, "provide encouraging signs for the future." One of them is the fact that democratisation process in the continent is still moving ahead despite delays and costs in terms of lives and physical assets. The other is that reform programmes have survived in most countries and have even been strengthened in others despite economic and political hardships. "Several countries improved their performance in the course of the past year, and the members of the CFA zone have taken an historic, bold step to improve their competitiveness. While much remains to be done, more countries are embarking on reform programmes and face better prospects compared with a year ago."

Apparently in response to criticisms of economic adjustment programmes recommended and supervised by it, the World Bank, in the report, gave specific comparative instances to prove that African countries that have sustained such programmes generally have performed better than those that have not. The observation is based on a recent study by the bank staff covering 29 countries in sub-Saharan Africa for the 1981-91 period. According to their findings, the six countries with the greatest success in eliminating macro-economic imbalances enjoyed the strongest resurgence in economic performance, experiencing a median increase of almost two percent points in the growth rate of GDP per person.

The experiences of Nigeria, Kenya and Uganda were cited to demonstrate respectively, the effects on the economy of a disrupted political transition programme, disrupted by re-introduced economic reforms and a steady implementation of reforms. Nigeria went through a tumultuous period in both 1992 and 1993 with the planned democratic transition getting protracted without bringing a democratic rule into being. The process, the report said, generated considerable uncertainty, economic disruptions and social unrest. Budgetary control deteriorated, leading to fiscal deficits which exceeded 10 percent of GDP. Inflation rose to 40 percent in 1992, and 58 percent in 1993. The official exchange was pegged below market rates, with the spread reaching 100 percent by late 1993. The external balance deteriorated significantly, with reserves dwindling and arrears to external creditors rising to more than $6 billion, or one fifth of outstanding debt. These combined, made the economy to grow by 4,1 percent in 1992 and 1.9 percent in 1993, compared with an average of five percent in the preceding six years.

In Kenya, there was a sharp decline in major macro-economic performance indicators between 1990-92 following the abandonment of IMF/World Bank recommended reforms. However, in early 1993, the Kenyan authorities signaled an interest in restarting the reform process and as a result, the conditions for strong medium-term growth in Kenya, according to the report, have improved significantly. Implementation of stabilization policies and more effective enforcement of financial sector regulations, according to the report, have sharply reduced runaway inflation (falling to an annual rate of around 15 percent during the last quarter of 1993 after peaking at around 100 percent during the second quarter). "Important steps towards structural reforms particularly in the area of external trade, have begun to gradually restore domestic and international confidence in the government's commitment to reform. With the elimination of all but a short list of import licenses and the introduction of unified and stabilised market-determined exchange rate (the Kenyan Shilling became fully convertible in May 1994), the stage has been set for the private, and especially the export sector to lead the recovery."

Uganda, according to the report, has gone quite far in creating a free enterprise economy. At the same time, the government has stabilised the economy through tight fiscal and monetary policies. These have reduced inflation to around four percent in 1993, down from 45 percent in 1992 and 240 percent in 1987, the year in which the present adjustment programme was initiated. The programme covers the civil service, public enterprises, and major financial institutions and a large cut in military forces to release resources for priority spending programmes. "These reforms have had a positive effect on the economy: real GDP growth is estimated to have reached six percent in 1993, enabling per capita consumption to rise by about 2.5 percent. The lower inflation has contributed to a stable exchange rate and renewed confidence in the country's currency."

This achievement, however, pales into insignificance compared with the growth in East Asia and the Pacific which at 9.2 percent, has outpaced that in every other developing region by at least five percentage points. China remained the fastest growing economy in the region - and the world. Growth in China has averaged 13 percent in the past two years, as the government continued to implement market-based reforms and as transitional corporations corporations continued to commit record amounts of investment. Malaysia and Thailand, two other prime recipients of foreign direct investment, once again displayed outstanding performance.

Latin America and Caribbean once again experienced gains in output as reforms in many countries continued to take root and show results. The report says that growth for the region as a whole, supported by large inflows of foreign private capital flows, rose to 3.5 percent from 2.8 percent in 1992.

In South Asia, growth slowed to 3.8 percent, partly as a result of devastating floods in Pakistan towards the end of 1992 and weak industrial growth in India. The report said that countries in the region showed improvements in their external account performance with increased exports and private capital flows. The fall in world oil prices by more than 10 percent, according to the report, contributed to a market decline in growth to an estimated 1.9 percent, in the Middle-East and North Africa.

Economic activity in the industrialised countries slowed further in 1993, too, to 1.2 percent as a result of sluggish growth in Japan and recession in continental Europe. Recovery in the United States, according to the report, was well underway by the fourth quarter of 1993 when output expanded by seven percent. Canada and the United Kingdom experienced a modest recovery in 1993. The slow pace of overall growth in 1993, says the report, was associated with rising unemployment, which reached 8.2 percent in the industrial countries as a group, rising to 10 percent in the labour force in several European countries.

NEWSWATCH is published at P.M.B. 21499, Ikeja, Nigeria, tel:4960950 fax:962887 telex:27874

Africa News


December 1, 1994 / December 31, 1994


UGANDA: Politics Isn't Everything


BYLINE: The Monitor, November 18-21, 1994


LENGTH: 640 words


 

This week was remarkable. The UPC, who made their bones as republicans and abolished the kingdom and the quasi-federal Independence constitution in 1966, held a press conference to announce that now they were for federalism.

And if Buganda wanted federalism, they can have it. What is UPC up to? That it is difficult to tell. What is certain, is that UPC is playing politics, perhaps hoping to win the support of the Buganda federalists in CA and get them to vote for multi-partyism. 

Will Buganda, which has been crying that the rest of Uganda has ganged up against them and does not appreciate their need for federalism cut a deal with UPC? No, because UPC is the monster in Buganda for having scrapped kingdoms, the Baganda delegates are still suspicious of it. They want votes for federalism, but it seems not from UPC.

Then with the NRM irritated by the last week's walk out from Committee Five by multi-partists because of what they saw as the dirty tactics used to pass an amendment giving the Movement another five years, President Yoweri Museveni called CA delegates from several western districts to his Rwakitura farm. There were raised eyebrows about the unusual "regional caucus" and expectations that, because a small group of NRM stalwarts had been in Rwakitura a day earlier on Tuesday, we were going to hear of some new initiatives to bring the political temperature in the country down.

Surprise, surprise! Instead we learn that the meeting was called to discuss a matter which most Ugandans thought had died out: The restoration of Obugabeship of Ankole which, the meeting decided, should continue to be on ice.

Almost difficult to believe. These political works are not impressive. The only impression they conveyed is of the old politics of under-the-table deals being reborn, confusion, and playing the fiddle while the country is burning. It is amazing how much the political class is consumed with conspiratorial and partisan politics.

Amazing because they have an open forum - the CA - to articulate the thoughts they are putting out at press conferences and secretive palace meetings, but they are not taking advantage. Ministers have become so taken with constitution politics, either fighting for Movement, federalism, or against multi-partyists, they have forgotten they are ministers for all Ugandans.

There is more to life than back-room politics and plotting to win or cling to power. Ugandans are all too aware that periods like this with elections looming are dangerous precisely because leaders become too taken by narrow pursuits which can win them power, than broad politics.

In Uganda's case, that has almost always been disastrous. Like in 1966/67 when the 1962 constitution was scrapped, 1971 when Obote I was overthrown, and 1985 when Obote II was overthrown, 1989 when the NRM tempted fate by extending itself in power without an electoral mandate.

We hope the politicians will heed these signs from our history and bring back a degree of sobriety to the political scene.

THE MONITOR is published at P.O. Box 12141 Kampala, Uganda Tel: 251353 Fax: 251352


LOAD-DATE: February 6, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


386 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 1, 1994 / December 31, 1994


LIBYA: Humanitarian Impact Of The UN Sanctions


SECTION: COMMENTARY


LENGTH: 1600 words


 

The following is excerpted from a report to Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali by the Libyan permanent representative, Ambassador Mohamed Azwai.

A. Humanitarian consequences--The implementation of Security Council resolutions 748 (1992) and 883 (1993) has had considerable humanitarian and social repercussions on the Libyan Arab people, particularly in the health and social security sector, which has been severely affected (medical supplies, therapeutic and preventive care, international technical cooperation.) It has also had a serious impact on the functioning and maintenance of vital equipment and on all economic aspects of health and social security. These adverse consequences can be summarized as follows:

1. Impossibility of evacuating some 9,000 patients who could not be treated in Libya and should have been transported abroad by air ambulance or on board a commercial airline, in particular, where diseases were progressing or in emergency cases (including treatment of serious cardio-vascular disorders, kidney transplants, treatment of detached retinas, brain surgery and neurosurgery, spinal cord transplants, treatment of third-degree burns, cancer treatment).

2. Owing to the seriousness of their condition and the long distance over which they had to be transported, 350 of the patients who were to be transported by land to airports in neighboring countries died en route. 

3. The programme under which, inter alia, Austrian, Yugoslav, German, Swiss, French, Italian, Polish, Bulgarian professors of medicine, specialists and university and medical school lecturers had been invited to Libya could not proceed as planned. Approximately 150 professors and specialists in various medical disciplines were prevented from coming to Libya in order to treat certain difficult cases, perform delicate surgery, help administer university examinations and attend international scientific conferences and medical colloquiums which are organized in Libya from time to time.

Moreover, many Libyan doctors and professors had to abandon their plans to travel abroad in order to attend international conferences, meetings and study programmes and were thus prevented from expanding their knowledge, from participating in and benefiting from the work of these meetings and, hence, from keeping abreast of the progress achieved in today's world in various scientific fields.

4. Many foreign doctors and medical assistants had to turn down offers of employment from Libya. Thus, some 4,500 doctors and medical assistants who were to come to Libya to work had to abandon their plans. Moreover, more than 100 doctors and medical assistants resign every month; there have been a total of 2,500 resignations thus far. These staff reductions have seriously impaired the functioning of all health services in Libya.

5. Without the necessary $10 million worth of spare parts which had been ordered, medical and electromechanical devices used at Libyan health centres could not be maintained properly. What is more, the foreign experts and technicians who were supposed to maintain them were not able to come to Libya. In most Libyan hospitals and health centres, the provision of health services was seriously impaired as a result.

6. The condition of allergy patients was aggravated by the fact that certain drugs and types of equipment essential to their treatment which had to be ordered urgently from abroad did not arrive on time. These delays were responsible for the death of some 350 infants in various Libyan hospitals and more than 150 women who had given birth, particularly after hemorrhaging.

7. The programmes that were to be carried out in cooperation with the World Health Organization (WHO) could not be implemented. Most visits by international experts and working groups sent by WHO had to be postponed or cancelled. The situation has impeded the development and rehabilitation of the health sector, slowed down the implementation of primary health care programmes, compromised international cooperation activities undertaken in the field of health and prevented WHO from attaining its objectives under the strategy "Health for All by the Year 2000".

8. The shipment of medical supplies and their clearance through customs were delayed, as the shipping documents did not arrive on time. Moreover, the sanctions caused complications in the import and storage of serum, vaccines, blood products, hormones, laboratory reagents for the detection of AIDS and radioactive iodine. Because of the air embargo, these products had to be shipped by sea and stop in intermediate ports, and they deteriorated as a result. This happened, in particular, to poliomyelitis vaccines transported by ship. Many manufacturers are still obtaining information on the means by which to ship these products, which should only be shipped by air. The air embargo has not only caused the depletion of stocks but also slow deliveries which have resulted in waste, as certain products had expired by the time they arrived. The best example of this is the loss of much of the ocean cargo shipped by OANSSEM and TANSSEM, which specialize in the manufacture of analgesics, anesthetics and other medicines for hospitals and health centres.

9. One hundred fifty-six orders for medicines, medical devices, equipment and medical supplies could not be filled. The articles ordered included serums, vaccines, laboratory reagents and equipment for a total values of nearly $50 million.

10. Radioactive products for identifying certain hormones - which, as it is known, must be shipped by air directly from producer to consumer countries - could not be shipped. These products, particularly a drug called Mastin, are used in the treatment of cancer.

11. Exceptionally heavy traffic has resulted in 10,200 road accidents, including 1,622 deaths, 4,220 serious injuries or disabilities for life and 3,124 minor injuries. There are 9,200 persons who need to use a wheelchair following serious accidents.

12. The Committee established by Security Council resolution 748 (1992) has been slow to grant authorization to transport patients in need of emergency treatment to other countries by air ambulance and on several occasions (as recently as 4 May 1994) prevented the evacuation of patients, which resulted in the death of many patients or caused their condition to deteriorate. There are no medical or legal grounds for such delays and refusals; they are but a reflection of the hostile position maintained by certain members of the Committee, in utter disregard of all humanitarian concerns.

13. The following are some of the difficulties confronting companies doing business with Libya:

- In an official letter dated 27 February 1993, the Austrian company VAMED ENGINEERING of Vienna (awarded a contract for a project for the delivery of equipment to the new central hospital of Tripoli) informed the Libyan authorities that the authorities of the United States of America would not authorize it to export medical equipment to Libya. The Libyan party was therefore forced to try and make other arrange- ments, which has, to this day, delayed the opening of the new central hospital of Tripoli;

- The Canadian company which was awarded a contract for the export of radiology equipment to Libya was prevented from doing so by the authorities of the United States of America;

- The Maltese company MEDAVIA, which specializes in emergency medical assistance, informed the Libyan authorities of the numerous difficulties confronting it as a result of pressure from a number of Western countries to stop exporting vital medical equipment to Libya.

14. The health sector experienced extreme difficulty in providing emergency services and supplying the necessary medical equipment to the Libyan rescue team which made every effort to carry out its humanitarian mission when a civil aircraft from the regular Libyan domestic airline crashed in flight between Bengazi and Tripoli. This accident, which occurred on 22 December 1992, resulted in 170 casualties. The victims were of different nationalities.


LOAD-DATE: February 6, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


387 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 1, 1994 / December 31, 1994


UGANDA: Another Bull Shall Rise - M7


BYLINE: Martin Lutalo Mpungu, Monitor, November 18-21, 1994


LENGTH: 1907 words


 

A few days after his return from a Chief Executives Organisation meeting in Argentina; and stopovers in South Africa, Ghana and Libya, President Yoweri Museveni called his traditional Press Conference in Kampala, November 9. The following are excerpts from an edited version of the Conference as recorded by the Monitor's Senior Sub Editor, Martin Lutalo Mpungu.

Museveni:...I looked at it ( the CEO meeting) as a strategy session for the American business. They wanted to know how to handle the events in the world. I think they call people whom they think can help them to understand the world better.

...My interest in talking to this group is that they are investors; general managers of big American companies. I talked to them with a view of inviting them to come here. This was an opportunity I didn't want to lose. I (also) stopped in South Africa. Mr. Mandela was not in the country, but I met some other leaders as well as some business people. 

... Argentina is a very rich country with, a lot of livestock and oil. So I met the President (Menem), ministers, and Argentinean businessmen also. I invited the president and he agreed to come and visit us. So it was a very good trip for me, for business.

Then I came through Ghana, I talked to Mr. Rawlings about Liberia, then I went to North Africa, to see Mr. Qadhafi about our bilateral relations. So that was our trip. The main thing was business, to bring investors here.

Ayebale Adnia (Market Place): Foreign investors see Africa as a continent torn by political strife and civil wars. However much countries like Uganda try to sell themselves, there is little chance that multinationals will look at them as individual countries. For example they say that (Eastern) Europe has attracted US$ 50 billion (In foreign investment); Asia US$16 billion and Africa only US$ 3 billion. How do you see the situation?

Museveni: Actually that was my topic--"Does Africa Matter?" People are wondering whether Africa matters. It was my duty to tell them that it matters. There is that opinion that Africa does not matter--mainly because of mismanagement by African leaders and ideological confusion among the African leaders.

...So it's true that American companies have the idea that Africa does not matter. Secondly, when they talk of Africa these days, they now talk of South Africa. So it's our job to wake them up and tell them that they are missing money here--because we are not asking them to come here and give us charity. We are asking them to come here and make money. And we also make money.

However, we are not limiting our investment drive to only American and European companies. The Indians know the value of East Africa. Those have no difficulty in coming here. Since (my trip to India) some of them have already got licenses like the fertiliser company to be involved in Tororo. TATA is building a workshop here and (another) Indian group dealing with shoes...

So I talked to the Americans, I talk to Indians, the Japanese, I talk to all of them. I also talk to the locals here. We are going to get investments one way or the other. The other day the (Uganda) Investment Authority published something in your papers saying that since 1972 they had registered 970 new enterprises.

So we need to call many people--many will not come but some will come. This is our strategy.

Peter Mungerera - Voice of America: Is true there are mediation efforts, by Col. Qadhafi, to try and salvage the poor relations between Uganda and Sudan. Did he raise that matter when you met?

Museveni: Yes, I discussed Sudan quite a lot with Colonel Qadhafi and I informed him of the mediation work by IGADD. When I came back, I (rang) President Moi - the chairman of this IGADD committee. Our view is that everything must be done through IGADD.

Mungerera: I mean Uganda and Sudan. It's been reported that Qadhafi has been trying to arrange for meditation.

Museveni: There is no problem between Uganda and Sudan. The problem is inside Sudan.

Michael Ssentongo - The New Vision: Can we have a long lasting constitution if the constitution making process in the CA creates losers and winners?

Museveni: Now, I'm a believer in broadbased politics and I'm also a believer in participatory politics. This however does not mean that there is no direction. There must be some direction. On some crucial issues. Like for instance in driving, you either drive on the left or on the right. So if you just drive in the middle of the road then you cause accidents. So if you just drive in the middle of the road then you cause accidents. So some of the issues need to be decided on. You can't leave them in the middle. However, as usual we are always ready to involve others in governance if we have the upper hand. This however, should not mean that we shouldn't decide. Because this is the moment to decide on some of the major issues. As you can see the things being debated in the constitution are strategic matters; and positions must be taken on some of them.

Martin Lutalo Mpungu - The Monitor: You talk of crossing the bridge when you get there. Yet the new NRM structure for post-CA government has already been drawn up. Isn't this creating the assumption that we are definitely having the Movement System after CA? And if, as assumed, even the lower RC's also became part of the state, isn't this a recipe for dictatorship?

Museveni: Well, the proposals which the (NRM) Secretariat submitted ... will have to be debated by the CA. It's up to the CA to accept. So there is no prejudgement of the CA. If they do not accept it, it will be changed.

Now, the State being fused with the Movement well, how? The RC's are there and have been there all these years. But the chiefs are there. Chiefs who are not members of the RC's. The chiefs are not going to be removed. They will still be there because the RC's represent the movement side while the chiefs continue to be the case. There is no fusion.

I think the only fusion is that if a president is elected, then you also become the chairman of the Movement. That is even done in western Europe where many of you draw your models from, because normally the head of the ruling party also becomes the Prime Minister. So I don't see anything new there. There is no fusion.

White Freelance, Rambo: You came to power talking about how foreign aid is a continuation of colonialism and now Uganda is accepting a lot of aid dollars. Why have you changed your view of whether or not foreign aid is a good economic policy?

Museveni: I have not changed my opinion. My opinion is the same. That we should build an integrated, independent and self sustaining economy. And that's what we are doing. If we get aid in order to achieve that independence of the economy, then that is consistence. It is not a divergence at all.

Rambo: When you came to power, you said you were not going to accept much aid.

Museveni: I never said I would reject aid, did I? However I said that we will make it the basis of our policy and even today, it is not the basis.

If you take the budget this year, we hope to collect Shs. 500 billion by ourselves, yet the whole budget is Shs 800 billion. As I speak now, 62% of our revenue is by ourselves from our own resources. So rapidly we are moving towards eliminating dependence on foreign budgetary support.

And besides, we borrow this money and pay it back. Each year we are paying the IMF and the World Bank. Each year we pay them US$120 million. It's not a one-way traffic.

Timothy Kalyegira-Capital Radio: You implied that if you left the stage the situation will create its own leader. Is that situation chaotic or smooth?

Museveni: With this succession we can no longer allow turmoil. If I leave leadership now, I will still be a Ugandan and together with other Ugandans we shall get a new leader. The problem in the past was that the people had no power. Some of the groups had hijacked the power from the population. What we have done now is to give power back to the people. So if we want to get a new leader, we shall work for it.

I don't like this argument that if Museveni goes there will be chaos. The implication is that, that society does not have internal strength to stand up as a society. It is just depending on some single magician by the names of Museveni who using wizardry and has managed to put the people together.

I came from the people and in the same way others will come from the people - as long as the people have got the freedom to chose through elections.

You see, this is an attempt to imply that African societies are basically unstable - that once in a while you get some wizards like Museveni who manage to check these wild people and as soon as those wizards go away, those Africans will go back to their ways of wildness. This is not the case. Those people who were against Amin and Obote are there. They are the ones who produced us and they can produce other people.

THE MONITOR is published at P.O. Box 12141 Kampala, Uganda Tel: 251353 Fax: 251352


LOAD-DATE: February 6, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


388 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 1, 1994 / December 31, 1994


SOUTH AFRICA: Of Wealthy Ugandans, Rich Editors, Poor South Africans


BYLINE: James Serugo in East London, The Monitor, November 18-21, 1994


LENGTH: 1120 words


 

There is a rather shocking but fascinating story from down South.

South Africa has one of the world's widest gaps between the rich and the poor. The rich are so rich, the poor even look poorer.

Imagine this; an average director of a big company earns Shs. 1.5 million a month yet an average worker earns Shs. 320,000. 

The difference is forty fold. It means that a worker has to toil 40 years or just about his entire life, to get what the boss earns just in one year.

And that is not the worst case. Recent surveys show that some directors earn Shs. 36 million a year and have been giving themselves annual increment of double the inflation rate. (7.6 p.a. now).

Even further down the management ladder, imbalances persist. A middle rank manager earns a average salary of Shs. 40 million per year and an average worker Shs. 4 million. Ten fold difference.

Even Newspapers which have indignantly fumed about the "gravy train" (eating) since Mandela came to power in April, are not any better. There are editors who earn Shs. 12 million a month, which is allegedly more than what president Mandela gets, and Shs. 24 million a year, more than the cabinet ministers. Guess what reporters earn! A paltry Shs. 0.8 million to Shs. 1.1 million a month. Again a ten fold difference.

South Africa's rich people know how to flask their wealth. Flashy cars, ostentatious mansions and glitzy casinos. All this, is juxtaposed with 46 percent unemployment and 7 (seven) million homeless. Most of the wealthy are, of course, whites.

The skewed value system is now being passed on to the emerging black entrepreneurial class. As they break out of their apartheid ghettos, these upwardly mobile copy-cats are reaching greedily for the big houses, the BMWs and the Shs. 1.5 million suits.

By the way, Ugandans living and working in South Africa have not been outdone. There is an average of two cars to every family of Ugandans working here. They live in good homes and go to the beach over the weekends. An average Ugandan family has two kids and both husband and wife hold good jobs. They are either teachers or doctors, in a majority of cases.

There are a few lucky ones who have broken into managerial levels. One was recently a director of medical services in the Bantustan, but has just been sacked. But I am told he still holds his pay package of somewhere around Shs. 3 million a month.

Nobody seems to know how many Ugandans live and work in South Africa. One Ugandan called Frank who holds a nice job in a finance company and claims to have arrived in Johannesburg earlier than other Ugandans, put his estimate to 500 Ugandans in Johannesburg and a total of 5,000 in the whole of South Africa. But other not so conservative estimates put the number above 50,000.

It's not that these Ugandans have not suffered. Most of theme came here in phases. First a brief teaching stint in Kenya, (to earn money for a ticket) then to Zambia or Lesotho and finally South Africa.

I have visited very many of them. They are an impressive lot; nearly all of them have their hearts back home. They would want to return only if they can afford to earn a living wage in Kampala.

They constantly live with the fear of being deported and that's why a good number of them have put up houses at home. They however have a defender in the name of Vice President Thabo Mbeki who is against deporting foreigners as a government policy.

One big hospital I visited in Ciskei had a total of 30 Ugandan doctors! And nearly every school has more than one Ugandan teacher.

President Mandela recently announced a cut in the presidential and ministerial salaries. Just a symbolic gesture to stem the "gravy train", criticism. And also to encourage national austerity. It was not immediately know how much was going to be cut from how much of the president's pay.

Already several workers' unions are on strike, demanding a pay rise. By the end of this week, civil servants could be on strike, after rejecting token salary rises.

Problem is that, President Mandela and his ANC party campaigned and won the April 27 election on the ticket of good life. They promised to end suffering to the millions of apartheid afflicted blacks. Now it is the time to match promises with deeds.

Soon as he took the government, Mandela declared free education in schools and asked hospitals not to charge money for their services. He said South Africa was very rich.

By the time South Africans realise that "Ebyobwereere n'e Mulago bya ggwayo" (Even Mulago no longer gives free services) it will be too late. One doctor told me that Eastern Cape region run out of a Shs. 3 billion medical budget in 5 months. The remaining six months of the financial year might see them with a broken medical service. Before this, they used to change some money to supplement the government budget.

But people in government are determined to push through the process of integration which has so far been marred by suspicion and racial divisions.

The army itself said it laxed on discipline in order to ease the integration process. The result was a massive desertion of over 2,500 army men- with their guns. All this has caused untold insecurity and social disorder which the ANC government is groping to tame. Mandela needs a lot of luck.

The Monitor, P. O. Box 12141, Kampala, Uganda Tel.: 251353, Fax: 2551352


LOAD-DATE: February 6, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


389 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 1, 1994 / December 31, 1994


SOUTH AFRICA: Fragile, but Slovo's reaping the fruits of a lifelong fight


BYLINE: Phillip van Niekerk, Weekly Mail & Guardian (Johannesburg), December 9, 1994


LENGTH: 1654 words


 

A few weeks ago Joe Slovo's battle with cancer took on a very public dimension. A dramatic weight loss and sudden gaunt appearance, brought on by an unfavourable response to new medication, unleash-ed frenetic speculation about whether the old communist, the most senior white person in the ANC, had fought his last political and personal battle.

In an interview in his Pretoria office last week, it was hard to tell which was the more fragile, Slovo's health or his humour, as he faced the inevitable questions about his health.

"I am in a stable condition," he snapped. "I'm doing my work, as you see. You chaps go on and on about it. Like all of us, when we can't do our jobs, we'll say so." 

His sharp response was softened by a flash of old Slovo wit. "Life is a terminal illness," he added. "We'll all go."

Despite his advanced illness, Slovo is enjoying life as a cabinet minister, savouring the most "challenging, most productive period" of his life. He puffs contentedly on a cigarillo, but won't allow himself to be photographed smoking it.

Talk about Slovo's health has overshadowed his achievements as housing minister in President Nelson Mandela's government of national unity. Into his domain falls one of the most visible inheritances of apartheid: nine million homeless people packed mostly into squalid squatter camps ringing the cities.

Housing is the yardstick against which Mandela's government will be judged to have succeeded or failed in its primary task of delivering a better life to black South Africans.

But before the building can even start, a political impasse has to be broken. Law and order has collapsed in many townships, and the boycott of bond repayments, rent and service payments -- begun as resistance to the old order -- has only grown under the new government, and along with it the banks' retaliatory red-lining of black areas.

"The banks fear to tread because of the complete breakdown of civil law enforcement," said Slovo. "They have got something like 18 000 properties for which they've received judgment for eviction, and are unable to implement."

To end the stand-off, Slovo has put together the most pragmatic of compacts: coaxing the banks back into the township market by deploying state funds to underwrite mortgages, while cajoling black residents into resuming monthly payments with the carrot of community upliftment and the stick of eviction threats.

"We have spent this period charting the path ahead, ensuring that all the relevant stakeholders are with us. >From early next year the fruits of this will start to show themselves.

"This question: 'what have you delivered?' was ridiculously asked after three months. The question is: 'are the resources there? Do you have strategy in place? Has progress been made?' I am sure that is the case."

If employing private investment and individual ownership is an odd policy for an avowed communist, Slovo's plans to house the millions who can't afford mortgages are even more unorthodox: the state will provide sites with the basics of electricity, water and sewage and a slab. Apart from backup in the form of know-how and access to cheap materials, responsibility for putting a roof over the heads of South Africa's millions will depend on "mobilising the sweat equity of the people themselves".

"You cannot build an economy or a society purely on the basis of entitlement," said Slovo, who for many years admired Eastern Bloc societies where the state was meant to provide from cradle to grave.

"People have to make a contribution. They have to have a sense of ownership which they don't get from being given blocks of rented accommodation which they don't own, don't have a stake in and haven't helped to design."

Slovo still considers himself a communist. "It's not on the agenda now, it's not the issue now, but I believe with what we are doing in every sphere -- the reconstruction and development programme and so forth -- we are creating a foundation in which there will be all kinds of possibilities including a movement away from the domination of the economy by the criteria of profit."

He is, however, contrite about his lifelong support for the Soviet Union and that model of socialism. Gone is the old defensiveness. In a remarkably frank moment during the interview, he said: "I was wrong and I am ashamed of some of the traps I was led into."

He explained: "If you've ever been part of an official delegation you learn less about a country than sitting in the British museum. You don't meet the people, you don't actually see the conditions. People said there were gulags, millions of people incarcerated there. We were assured there was no such thing. We didn't have opportunities to actually check."

Slovo still points out that the Eastern Bloc was not all "tyranny and evil and murder and mayhem.

"You're talking about a world that pioneered the modern eight-hour day, women's equality and free education. Every segment of the welfare capitalist world originated in the socialist world and the battle between the two had an impact on the more tolerable conditions in the capitalist world."

He admitted that his own doubts began in the mid-1960s but he chose to remain silent because he had seen the alternative close at hand. His wife, the fiercely independent author and academic Ruth First, was, he said, sidelined by the movement. He said he had differences with her on this issue.

"The choice that you face is whether you can continue to contribute to the struggle or not. At that stage, independence was just not tolerated. It was part of the sickness we tried to get away from eventually.

"For me, the question was: do I now take a lecturer's job in London? In retrospect I would have made a big mistake if I'd allowed my doubts, which were growing and growing, to lead to a withdrawal."

It is in that context that Slovo's contribution makes sense. He is a pragmatist, prepared to compromise to achieve a larger goal: in this case, national liberation.

While pointing out that "we are still living in an apartheid state", Slovo admits to feeling "smug" about the way things have gone.

A brief few years ago he was the b_te noire of the white establishment, a target for assassination. His wife was blown up in Maputo by a parcel bomb sent by the South African security forces. Today he is one of the most respected cabinet ministers in South Africa, working from the offices of the very politicians who made him out to be the epitome of all evil.

He savours the twists of fortune that have taken him from membership of a "relatively powerless grouping" in the 1940s, through the defiance campaign, exile and armed struggle, the negotiating process, the attainment of power, to the beginnings of reconstruction. At every point Slovo was a key player.

"The last year or two have been the happiest in my life. There have been miraculous achievements in this period. It's working. We're going to have major and minor hiccups, but I'm optimistic. I think that in general we are going to achieve our targets.

"I could happily lie down and die now because what more does a person want out of life than the life I have had?"

But beneath the self-confidence, Slovo betrayed a vulnerability, as the subject he least likes to talk about resurfaced on its own. "I have cancer. What can I tell you? I also have feelings."

Phillip van Niekerk is the Southern Africa correspondent of the Observer

The Weekly Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media Contact: M&G Media, 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025.For e-mail subscriptions, sned enquiries to: wmail-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point your browser to: http://www.is.co.za/services/wmail.html.

Africa News


December 1, 1994 / December 31, 1994


SOUTH AFRICA: Zero Hour plus 235 days


BYLINE: Anton Harber, Weekly Mail & Guardian (Johannesburg), December 23, 1994


LENGTH: 2387 words


 

THERE was before the airplanes. And there was after.

Just before 1pm on Tuesday, 10 May, six South African Air Force jets swept over the Union Buildings in Pretoria, each trailing one of the six colours of the new South African flag.

They were OUR planes, from OUR air force, trailing OUR national colours, over OUR seat of government, in OUR capital city. The crowd gathered in the amphitheatre below -- most of whom would never have been allowed near the building in the past -- gasped with the realisation that the air force was saluting its new commander-in- chief, President Nelson Rolihlahla Mandela. 

It was Zero Hour in the new South Africa.

The end of the year marks Zero Hour plus 235 days -- a fitting time to make a sober assessment of the new order. It is more than twice the 100 days Mandela gave himself in his inauguration speech to show progress, and considerably longer than any reasonable honeymoon period.

Yet, the afterglow lingers.

Minister without Portfolio Jay Naidoo summoned journalists to his plush office in the Union Buildings last week to pre-empt suggestions that there had been little progress in the government of national unity's reconstruction and development programme.

He showed impressively thick business plans for major RDP projects; he outlined the elaborate processes that he had gone through to reach this stage; he spoke of the progress of proper policy formulation, full consultation and the creation of structures to ensure effective delivery; and he blamed poor goverment communication for the impression that things were moving slowly.

All of which is true and important. What he couldn't show was a house, a sewerage pipe, a borehole, a transformed township, or a new school.

But that hardly seems to matter at the moment. Despite all the pundits warning about heightened expectations at the grassroots and growing impatience among the mass of deprived people, there is little tangible evidence of it.

Mandela himself has been going out of his way to explain why reconciliation was the initial priority of his government, and how it was essential -- and not inimical -- to reconstruction. If he did not get the recalcitrant old guard behind the RDP, and undermine resistance to it, there would be precious little progress, he has quite rightly pointed out at any available occasion in the past few weeks.

He and other ANC leaders were clearly worried about the flak they might catch at last weekend's triennial national conference of the ANC, with branch representatives demanding progress on social transformation. It didn't materialise.

Why not? Partly, it is a tribute to the success of the policy of reconciliation, and the extent to which the restoration of relative peace in most of the country is - - for the time being -- enough to keep people happy. But it is also because the issue of raised expectations and grassroots impatience has been exaggerated.

Opinion polls show high approval ratings for the government. Mandela is universally loved and trusted. There is an instinctive understanding that change is difficult and will take time. How much time is altogether another question.

Clearly, the new government faces grave difficulties in delivering on its promises to build one million houses, electrify 2,5-million homes, provide 10 years of free and compulsory education for all, create masses of jobs ...

The major obstacle is the civil service -- too big, too old guard, too costly, too much apartheid duplication. And the negotiated agreement to protect all civil service jobs -- the price of reconciliation -- now looks as if it may have been a huge mistake.

Yet, the agreement is to protect jobs, not positions, and to abide by labour legislation in the event of any job terminations. They would have had to do that anyway, so it was not that much of a concession.

In fact, the problem has been the inability of the Commission for Public Administration, headed by Minister Zola Skweyiya, to rise to the challenge of transforming the civil service. He started off the crudest of ways: creating 11 000 affirmative action jobs. It was difficult to see that would transform the service into an effective and efficient one, but anyway the process ground to a halt when he was flooded with two million applications.

The second obstacle was the lack of effective local authorities. These should provide much of the engine of reconstruction at a local level, but elections are only scheduled for late next year -- leaving a huge gap in the RDP delivery machinery.

A third factor has been the chaos in some of the provincial governments. Some, notably the Orange Free State, inherited a coherent administration and relative order and were able to get down to business quickly. Others, notably the Eastern Cape and Northern Transvaal, face the nightmare of unifying three apartheid administrations. Leadership has not always been effective, and progress has been uneven.

Probably the greatest factor of all is the extent to which almost every government department has to be redirected, its resources rechannelled, its structures changed to meet the completely different tasks the new government is setting it.

The bulk of Naidoo's work, in fact, is not the showcase 22 presidential projects, but the daily grind of ensuring that departments shift their resources to meet RDP priorities. This also involves battles between departments -- over issues such as whether the navy should buy four new ships while health has to cut back.

But it is easy to see only these problems. Less easy to see is the remarkable transformation of our political discourse and almost all of our political institutions.

The ANC's greatest achievement has been to unite all sectors of South Africa's highly stratified society behind its RDP. Although the plan is being treated like Mao's Little Red Book, it does mean the debate is no longer over whether there should be a redistribution of resources, but on how to achieve this.

We are the one country in the world where all sectors have thrown their weight behind a radical social transformation. There are, of course, important differences over how this should happen -- but nobody is arguing any longer that it shouldn't happen, and that it shouldn't happen as quickly as practically possible.

Notable at the ANC's conference last week was the lack of ideological dispute, even from communist party and Cosatu stalwarts. The mood is an overwhelmingly pragmatic one: how do we deliver to our constituency effectively and timeously? The debate over privatisation, for example, has transcended the rhetorical flourishes of previous years, and is now focused on whether this policy will release assets for the RDP, and how this can be achieved without compromising the delivery of essential services.

One of the clearest signs of national unity was the fact that the new government imposed an effective wealth tax, though they called it a transition levy, placing a heavy additional burden on those with higher incomes to fund the costs of the election, peacekeeping and the integration of the armed forces. Having warned for years against the dangers of a wealth tax, business and the middle classes accepted it without much protest.

The new, radical social democratic agenda is being felt in all sectors -- education, health, welfare, housing -- but with varying degrees of progress and effectiveness in each of them. One notable areas of progress and one which will fundamentally affect social relations is the draft new labour legislation. Due for release any day now, it is designed to replace the traditionally antagonistic dichotomy of industrial relations with a tripartite partnership among organised labour, business and the state.

Some manufacturers, such as Volkswagen, have been quick to anticipate this and have already adopted groundbreaking agreements that cross the divide between owners and workers.

Most foreign investors, however, are still treating this country with circumspection, watching from a distance to see if stability and growth last beyond the honeymoon. The biggest launch in years was Pepsi's, filling Ellis Park with the music of Whitney Houston and the skies of Johannesburg with fireworks. It was the model black advancement investment, with the new wave of South African businessmen getting into the trenches with African-American investors to fight the cola wars. But the crowd of unemployed outside the new Pepsi factory was unimpressed and refused to go away. Not the kind of sight investors want to see.

The "brothers" from National Sorghum Breweries set the tone for new black-owned business with the launch of its Vivo beer. They described their rival's products as "as pale and sour as the people who made them"; in contrast, they said, "Vivo's got soul".

It's the first affirmative beer -- and the Africanism inherent in its marketing signals a clear divide in the new South Africa. Black middle class expectations of post-apartheid reward are met by near-hysteria in most of the Afrikaans media about white victims of affirmative action.

Parliament also acquired a soul, transforming within weeks from a crusty, tradition-bound home for otherwise unemployable friends of the ruling party, to a vibrant and lively institution for otherwise unemployable ex- freedom fighters. Debate in the chamber was as dull and purposeless as ever, but suddenly the previously comotose parliamentary committees, under the influence of energetic activists, sprang to life and became cabinet watchdogs and critical forums for debate and policy- making.

Parliament was the one institution that took to heart the constitution's fundamental commitment to openness and accountability. The other extreme was marked, ironically, by the Judicial Service Commission, which ignored the spirit in which it was created and chose to operate in darkness, choosing supreme court judges in secrecy and banning the broadcast media from its hearings to choose Constitutional Court judges.

Incidentally, those hearings provided an early test of civil society in the new South Africa -- and it failed. Very little was heard from any of the major interest groups -- such as women, workers, black lawyers, the broadcast industry -- which could be expected to assert themselves on issues important to them.

But these interest groups have much to trumpet about. Ironically, the ANC's firmly progressive social policies put it way ahead of its own constituency. It will be interesting to see if it can sustain its firmly anti- capital punishment, pro-abortion, pro-gender rights, sympathy-for-illegal immigrants policies in the face of growing unemployment and rising crime.

None of this will matter, however, if the government fails to show tangible evidence of delivery on housing, education, health and jobs before the extended honeymoon ends and the afterglow wears off.

Patience will be running out about a year after the inauguration, May 10 1995. It would be good to see the six air force planes repeat their salute, but if Naidoo is doing his job properly, he will probably have diverted their fuel payments to the health budget.

And everyone will celebrate (except maybe a few pilots). Zero Hour plus one year.

The Weekly Mail & Guardian is published by M&G Media Contact: M&G Media, 139 Smit Street, Braamfontein, Johannesburg, South Africa; phone:(011) 403-7111. Fax:(011) 403-1025.For e-mail subscriptions, send enquiries to: wmail-info@wmail.misanet.org. Or point a browser to: http://www.is.co.za/services/wmail.html.


LOAD-DATE: February 6, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


391 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 1, 1994 / December 31, 1994


NIGERIA: An Angry Tirade


BYLINE: Wale Oladepo, Newswatch, November 28, 1994


LENGTH: 1014 words


 

General Sani Abacha, head of state, is fast confirming that he has learnt nothing from his predecessors.When words went round that he would make an anniversary broadcast last Thursday, expectations were high that he would use the occasion to relax some of the stern measures taken by government now that it has a firm hold on to power. As a reconciliatory gesture, it was expected that he would de-proscribe the media houses shut down in the wake of the June 12 crisis, release some political detainees and put some balm on strained nerves. But Abacha's speech contained not such conciliatory moves.

In his 11-page address, Abacha once again took on the labour leaders whom he had chalked out of their posts in the wake of the protracted pro-democracy strike of July and August. He said the government was aware that some leaders of the oil workers union and their senior staff counter-parts as well as those of the Nigeria Labour Congress, NLC, "were spurred on by financial inducements" from those who were bent on making the political programme of this government unworkable. This included foreign interest. 

In a tone laced with anger, he said "these unpatriotic Nigerians embarked on a protracted and debilitating, politically motivated strike action" in the name of collective bargaining and protecting workers interest. He said it was obvious that the leadership of the NLC, NUPENG and PENGASSAN did not have the approval of the overwhelming majority of the trade union movement for their actions. As he put it, it was "criminal and grossly unpatriotic to set out deliberately to disrupt and weaken our efforts at revival" as the labour leaders did.

In the same vein, the head of state made a veiled reference to opposition politicians whose continued detention has been decried of by both local and international pressure groups. He said that despite the loud and untrue protestations of certain individuals, "none of our citizens has been penalised or taken so far by his government saying it was to calm the political atmosphere and ensure smooth take off of the foundations of a new democratic Nigeria through the constitutional conference.

General Abacha, in his review of the press situation in the country said it remained the freest in Africa adding that Nigeria is one of the few countries in the continent where private press outnumber government newspapers. But this freedom he said, was abused necessitating the closure of some media houses. He, however, stopped short of saying that the shut media houses will be de-proscribed. In his review of the relation between his government and the press, Abacha recalled that out of sheer good gestures were spurned by some sections of the press "as they relished in deliberate incitement and seditious falsehood."

The state of the economy which has proved to be the Achiles heel of previous administrations remained a sore point on which the head of state sang the same old tune. For the umpteenth time, the refrain repeated that this government, like its predecessors, is making effort to revive the nation's neglected agriculture and mining sectors. Said the head of state: "Our studies show that if we return to full production in agriculture and resume our abandoned interests in mining other than in oil, we would not only feed ourselves, our earning from those sectors would surpass that from oil exports." He, however, did not say whether the measures to be adopted in this regard will take the pattern of Operation Feed the Nation, OFN, the Green Revolution, GR, or the Directorate of Food, Road and Rural Infrastructure, DFFRI, all of which were tried by the past three administrations.

However the head of state was categorical that, the high cost of food items, among others notwithstanding, his government was not considering the options resorted to by past administrations which tried to provide the emergency relief through importation of food items. The reasons he would not do this is clear: In the past, it "led to abuse, to mismanagement and it created a crop of unpatriotic persons who took the opportunity to enrich themselves and frustrate the efforts of government. "This administration is not tempted to go down the road of emergency importations in order to create an artificial atmosphere of well being" he added.

Just as the head of state is not willing to spare his political oponents, so also is he set to make life tough for those who put spanner in the works for his fiscal policies. To that end, managers of the nation's financial institutions who have contribued to failures of the banking industry are in for a hard time. The failed Banks (Recovery of Debts) and Financial Malpractices in Banks decree has been promulgated. The decree, which empowers the National Deposit Insurance Corporation, NDIC, and the Central Bank of Nigeria, CBN, to deal more decisively with bank failures, also establishes special tribunals to try culprits who have ruined some of the financial houses. In addition, a dree to try economic offenders has also been promulgated. The National Economic Intelligence Committee, NEIC, decree as it is called, has the powers of a watch-dog which will also try offenders.

NEWSWATCH is published at P.M.B. 21499, Ikeja, Nigeria Tel:4960950 Fax:962887 Telex:27874


LOAD-DATE: February 6, 1995


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


December 1, 1994 / December 31, 1994


NIGERIA: A Change of Attitude?


BYLINE: Wale Akin-Aina, Newswatch, December 5, 1994


LENGTH: 907 words


 

The visit of the six-man team of United States congressmen last week left prodemocracy activists and groups in a sour mood and with the feeling that American support for the validation of the annulled June 12 elections last year and the installation of Moshood Abiola, believed to have won the election, as president, is fast waning. According to Harry Johnston, spokesman for the team, the visit was largely to understand the political situation" in the country and not to impose solutions. He added that in view of recent developments in the country and on the ongoing National Constitutional Conference, the United States was reviewing its past posture while hoping for better days ahead.

Last July, the US house of representatives had passed a resolution stating that continued cordial relation between the US and Nigeria depended on the restoration of democracy. Also the administration of President Bill Clinton had imposed sanctions on Nigeria which included the suspension of $450,000 military aid, expulsion of the Nigerian military attache in Washington and an embargo on visits by all senior government and military officers and their relations to the United States. 

Femi Falana, a lawyer and prodemocracy activist, said last week that the visit of the congressmen and their comments represented a shift in the US perception of the country's situation.

The congressmen arrived in the country November 17, four months after members of a similar team were allegedly refused visas. The team which also had Donald Payne, Floyd Flake, Alcee Hastings, Cynthia McTinny and William Jefferson as members discussed with Sani Abacha, a general and the head of state; met with Abiola and parleyed with the human rights community. Newswatch learnt that at meeting with Abacha, the congressmen could not get a firm commitment on the terminal date of the military government. According to sources, at the meeting held between 11 p.m. and 2 a.m., November 18, the Americans were made to understand that the military would disengage " as soon as possible". One of the congressmen was said to have noted that as soon as possible could mean next year or the year 2000.

At the meeting with the prodemocracy and civil rights groups in the residence of the American ambassador, the congressmen took part in a stormy session. Falana confirmed to Newswatch that at a point discussions degenerated into a shouting match. The congressmen explained that the United States had to review its stand as it was being isolated by other western nations. During heated debate one of the congressmen claimed that the crux of the problem was that Abiola was hand-picked by his friend, Ibrahim Babangida former president and that following a disagreement between them, Babangida annulled the elections. He observed that election results of 23 presidential aspirants were also canceled and no one complained.

Sources say that at this point, Olabiyi Durajaiye was said to have explained that he was one of the 23 aspirants and that no complaint was heard because all the aspirants agreed with the cancellation of the results. He also noted that the elections were canceled at the party primaries level.

The congressmen were also hosted by Kudirat, wife of Abiola, who asked them to declare their stand on June 12. They were said to have explained that they were the only parliament that had passed a resolution on the June 12 issue, but did not make any categorical declaration on the annulled elections this time. A source said that the farthest they went was to call for the release of Abiola who is in detention.

Payne and Jefferson, both members of the congressional black caucus were said to have seen Abiola in detention. According to sources, Abiola was said to have expressed his disappointment with the way the American government was handling the June 12 issue. He was said to have sent a strong message to the caucus through the two congressmen. At the end of their visit last week the congressmen said that Abiola's release from detention would be "a right step in the right direction." But government had earlier said that it was still holding Abiola in jail pending its appeal at the Supreme Court against an appeal court order that Abiola be released on bail. The government had filed a 10 ground appeal to the Supreme court against the order. Last week Kudirat appealed to Clinton not to abandon Nigerians in their quest for democracy. She called on the American president to impress upon the military administration the need to respect the rule of law and release Abiola from detention.

NEWSWATCH is published at P.M.B. 21499, Ikeja, Nigeria, tel:4960950 fax:962887 telex:27874


LOAD-DATE: February 6, 1995


LANGUAGE: English
