Africa News


December 1, 1994 / December 31, 1994


THE GAMBIA: World Bank Gives Nod to Timetable


BYLINE: Ebrima Ceesay, Daily Observer, November 1, 1994


LENGTH: 907 words


 

The World Bank, one of the nation's leading lenders, has given a positive response to the four year timetable to democratic constitutional rule announce by the Head of State Lt. Yahya Jammeh, last Monday.

A press release issued by the Ministry of Finance and Economic Affairs and broadcast over Radio Gambia at the weekend said the Bank had now officially lifted the temporary suspension which it had imposed on its projects in The Gambia.

The suspension followed the events of July 22, when the democratically elected government of Sir Dawda Jawarwa was toppled in a military coup.

The Bank's decision to suspend funds, according to the release, followed a fact finding mission by the Banks officials to The Gambia in September. During the visit, the mission held discussions with the Chairman and Head of State, Lt. Jammeh and all members of the Council and of the Cabinet. 

The release stated: "Subsequent to the outcome of the Mission and the fact that the AFPRC made pronouncements to adhere to all our ongoing macro-economic policies and programmes with the Bretton Woods institutions, the Bank has now officially lifted the temporary suspension, resumed disbursement for all ongoing programmes and projects and the re-establishment of normal relationship with the country."

According to the release, the Ministry of Finance "welcomed the announcement with relief" and extended appreciation to all beneficiaries "for their patience and understanding during the brief period of suspension."

Among the leading beneficiaries are Gamworks, a non-governmental organisation (NGO) which is poised to undertake an impressive and wide ranging number of development projects in the country; the National Environment Agency; the Gambia Port Authority; and the education sector, in which the World Bank and the African Development Bank are funding a US$14.6 million project.

The resumption of disbursements is bound to have a positive impact on the construction industry which in recent weeks, has been scaling down operations and laying off workers due to lack of contracts.

Many contractors are depending on Gamworks, the school projects and GPA's Phase III development programme to keep them busy for the foreseeable future.

The business community in general may also feel some sense of relief, given the diverse spin-offs from these and other projects affected.

But many businesses would be anxious to know what compromises would be made (if there are any) on the timetable that would cause the United States and the European Union to resume full measure of their aid to The Gambia.

Already, the European Union has suspended some aid to The Gambia. The United States last Friday suspended some aid to The Gambia. The United States last Friday suspended bilateral aid to The Gambia.

"The suspension conforms with section 508 of the FY 1994 Foreign Operations, Export Financing, and the related Programs Appropriations Act which (like past and subsequent annual appropriations Acts), provides that no funds appropriated or made available under the Act will be obligated or expended to finance directly any assistance to any country whose duly elected head of government is deposed by military coup'."

While the law allows some exceptions, including humanitarian aid if it is in the U.S. national interest, balance of payments support and other government-to-government aid for The Gambia has stopped and cannot resume until the president of the US determines that democratic government has been restored in The Gambia.

According to a press release from the U.S. bilateral assistance for The Gambia, including $100,000 in security assistance, amounted to about $10.9 million in FY 1994.

A U.S. State Department Official, David Johnson, said that "the US will provide no economic or security assistance to the Gambian military Government."

Humanitarian aid, however, will be continued, according to Johnson.

But Johnson said "the AFPRC's plan to delay ceding power until 1998 in wholly unreasonable. "We call upon the AFPRC to reconsider its proposed timetable and to work with the Gambian people to restore democratic civilian rule within 12 months," Johnson said in his statement.

DAILY OBSERVER is published at P.M.B. 131 Banjul, The Gambia, tel:(220)496608 fax:(220)496878.


LOAD-DATE: February 6, 1995


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1994 AllAfrica, Inc.


394 of 398 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December 1, 1994 / December 31, 1994


AFRICA: Violence in Urban Africa


BYLINE: Dotun Oladipo, Newswatch (Lagos), November 21, 1994


LENGTH: 880 words


 

African urban areas, like urban areas in other parts of the world, share a common trait of urban violence, usually accompanied by high casualty figures. This was the submission of participants at a symposium on Urban Management and Urban Violence in Africa held last week in Ibadan. Casualty figure during the Kano ethnic/religious riot of 1953 was put at 277. Of the number, 36 were killed, while 241 were treated in hospitals. Another riot in the Northern part of Nigeria in 1966 led by people protesting the legitimacy of General Aguyi Ironsi's government resulted in the death of over 300 people. At least 650 people were injured. And in 1980, the Maitatsine riot claimed the lives of over 5,000 people.

The case in South Africa is also terrible. The Soweto riots of 1976 costs 575 people their lives, while 3907 were injured. Between January and April this year, over 1,000 deaths were recorded in the Kwazulu/ Natal Province. 

The symposium was fashioned to identify the various violent behaviors in sub-Saharan Africa and the challenges they pose to urban management officials. Akin Mabogunje, former chairmen of the National Board for the Community Banks and chairman, organising committee of the symposium, identified six major causes of urban violence. These are ethnic, religious, pervasive, social, cultural, and state-sponsored violence. According to Mabogunje, by 2020 AD, about 600 million people will be living in the urban areas of Africa. "The issue before this symposium, is thus, how well would these 600 million people live; how free from fear and violence will their lives be; how well-ordered and managed would the affairs of our cities become with passing years?"

Eighty-three academicians from within and outside Nigeria presented papers on the issue. The researches of the scholars covered Zimbabwe, Cairo, Congo, Gabon, Angola, Mozambique, Ghana, Nigeria, South Africa, Uganda, Burkina Faso, Togo, Kenya, Ethiopia and Cote d'Ivoire. The speakers traced the origin of such violence to inequalities in housing, unemployment, the widening gap between the rich and the poor, inadequate health care facilities, transportation problems and the educational system.

The disparity in housing for the rich and the poor and an unplanned environment were some of the issues speakers who spoke on housing touched on. Tunde Agboola of the Centre for Urban and Regional Planning, CURP, University of Ibadan, UI, said that the country is suffering the fate of a late starter in its housing policies. He spoke on "The politics and administration of housing standards and the structure of African cities." Agboola observed that in Africa, "government and people don't value planning. Once people don't appreciate the essence of planning, there is a problem." He observed that "politics and politiking area also human elements that impede planning."

In his own paper, Ben Arimah, of CURP, IU, said that the politics involved in African housing policies has made the execution of such policies impossible. A good example he said is the land use decree. The rich, Arimah noted, have been able to make a mess of the decree. This has resulted in some parts of Nigerian cities being overcrowded while there is land available in other parts. Lagos is a good example.

Of very great interest to participants at the symposium was the paper: "The area boys of Lagos: A study of organised street violence", presented by Wuyi Omitoogun of the Centre for Trans Saharan Studies, University of Maiduguri. Omitiigun attributed the trend in unemployment among the youths who now constitute themselves into area boys. This is the trend in Dakar, Nairobi and Johannesburg. But Femi Odekunle, a professor of criminology at the Ahmadu Bello University, ABU, was quick to point out that area boys as well as motor park touts have their own functions. He observed that in South Africa, some of the street boys were those who fought for the freedom of the apartheid enclave. Same was the situation in Nigeria when the June 12, 1993 election was annulled. "Some of these so-called area boys even engage in the filling of pot holes on our roads," Odekunle said.

The symposium was jointly organised by the French Institute for the Research in Africa, IFRA, Ibandan, and the Institute for African Studies, University of Ibandan at the International Institute for Tropical Agriculture, Ibadan.

NEWSWATCH Communications Limited, No.3 Billings Way, Oregun Industrial Estate,Oregun,P.M.B. 21499, Ikeja,Lagos, Nigeria

Africa News


December 1, 1994 / December 31, 1994


MOZAMBIQUE CHISSANO INSTALLS NEW CABINET


BYLINE: Jim Cason Africa News Service


LENGTH: 654 words


 

Washington, D.C.-- Mozambican President Joaquim Chissano, the victor in internationally supervised elections earlier this year, has a new cabinet largely drawn from the top ranks of previous governments.

Chissano's Frelimo party, which has governed the country since independence from Portugal in 1975, won the late-October balloting, defeating his main rival Afonso Dhlakama. leader of Renamo, by a 53 - 34 percent margin.

No one from opposition political parties was named to the Cabinet, which was sworn in on December 23 in the capital Maputo, although the key post of minister in the presidency for defense and security remained unfilled. 

The government had asked the chairman of the National Electoral Commission, Brass Mazola, to take a cabinet position but he declined because, he said, participation might give the appearance that he had been partial in overseeing the polling.

Pascal Mocumbi, the former foreign minister, takes over as prime minister and the former health minister, Leonardo Simao, has been moved to the slot of foreign affairs. Mocumbi himself was health minister before he became foreign minister and was named prime minister in part because of his close relationship with Chissano.

President: Joaquim Chissano

Minister in the Presidency for Economic and Social Affairs - Eneas Comiche

Minister in Presidency for Parliamentary Affairs - Francisco Madeira

Minister in Presidency for Defence and Security - not named

Prime Minister - Pascoal Mocumbi

Foreign Affairs and Cooperation - Leonardo Simao

Defence - Aguiar Mazula

State Administration (in charge of civil service) - Alfredo Gamito

Justice - Jose Ibraimo Abudo

Interior - Manuel Antonio

Planning and Finance - Tomas Salomao

Education - Arnaldo Nhavoto

Health - Aurelio Zilhao

Agriculture and Fisheries - Carlos Agostiho do Rosario

Culture/Sport/Youth - Mateus Katupha

Public Works and Housing - Roberto Costley White

Transport and Communications - Paulo Muxanga

Industry/Commerce/Tourism - Oldemiro Baloi

Mineral Resources and Energy - John Kachamila

Labor - Guilherme Mavila

Environmental Coordination - Bernardo Ferraz

Social Welfare Minister Alcinda Abreu (Ms.)

AFRICA NEWS ONLINE, Vol. 41, Issue 9-10. December 1994. All rights reserved. Africa News


December 1, 1994 / December 31, 1994


ANGOLA: 'Living Again' as Peace Hopes Rise


BYLINE: Cindy Shiner, Africa News Service


LENGTH: 1040 words


 

Cunje, Angola -- There's something odd and remarkable about Tradia Milagre. She keeps smiling, flashing a toothy picket fence of cheer and domesticity while relating the story of her family's survival, the bullet that grazed her seven-year-old's head, foraging for food in a mine field.

It's only when attention is called to herself, to her strength, that this 31-year-old mother of six retreats into frowning despair, slipping into the well of grief that the survivors of Angola's 19 years of war share.

Her name, Milagre, means miracle and it fits. While tens of thousands of others perished around her in the nine-month siege on the city of Cuito, 7 kilometers south of Cunje, last year, Milagre managed to keep her family alive and intact. 

It is through this combination of strength, endurance and luck that Angolans will have to rebuild their country if the peace accord holds. Their oil-and diamond-rich nation of 10 million people is sewn with land mines, the economy is in shambles, social and industrial infrastructure has collapsed. Less than 18 percent of Angola's children complete the fourth grade, said Peter Hawkins, director of the British branch of the relief group Save the Children in the capital, Luanda. "That is the generation in 20 years time that is going to be running the country," he said, reflecting the huge leap Angolans have to make to rehabilitate themselves. "Angola is now faced with rebuilding an infrastructure which has been totally and absolutely destroyed: one, by the physical impact of the war, two, by the economic collapse as a result of the fighting, and three, by the massive displacement of populations and movement of those populations, divorcing themselves away from their traditional ways of life," said Hawkins.

Nowhere in the country is the war's destruction more apparent than in Cuito, where an estimated 30,000 people died-- at least a third of the city's population--in the battle between government and rebel forces last year. At one point, both sides occupied the city, blasting the skyline to Swiss cheese, until the government routed the rebels last July from the rubble they controlled to at least 50 kilometers beyond the city limits.

A "blitz spirit" as one aid worker put it, has gripped Cuito's residents who are eager to rebuild their community. Some schools, with the assistance of the Irish-based relief group Concern, opened last week in buildings that remained relatively intact. There's a new restaurant and even a disco. The feebly marked graves in yards have yielded to stalks of green corn.

"The city's changing very quickly," said Bruno Leger, of the Belgian branch of Doctors Without Borders, as a man filled in bullet holes on the facade of one of Cuito's hospitals. "We just arrived one month ago. There was just four or five cars in the town, now you can see many. There are many civilians working; when we arrived (there were) mostly military and disabled people. Now it seems that the city is living again."

But unseen danger still threatens to maim or kill Cuito's survivors.

"In every hedgerow, by the side of the road, inside buildings there's unexploded ordinance" creating a veritable smorgasbord of land mines, grenades and bombs," said Mike Marmol, who works for the British de-mining agency Halo Trust in Cuito. Bullets might stop flying and planes might stop bombing, but a mine stays in the ground," he said. "A miner can lay it and it can kill his grandchild."

Nearly every day produces another land mine victim or victims, aid workers say. Last week, three people pushing a loaded wheelbarrow along a path not far from the airport ran over an anti-tank mine. They were buried where they died.

Halo Trust is training 25 Angolans in Cuito how to de-mine, hoping they will spread their knowledge about mine awareness. Among the volunteers were a professional volleyball player and a teacher.

"Everybody has military experience because they've been fighting for their lives" said Marmol. Indeed, most Cuito residents own guns.

Nobody knows how many mines have been sewn throughout Angola, but relief workers say there are millions. And even if a field isn't mined, simply the fear that it might be is enough to keep people off land that they could use for farming. Often, civilians end up eating seeds provided by relief groups instead of risking the danger of planting them.

The government has not yet authorized humanitarian de-mining, saying the political and military situation is too unstable to warrant the removal of defensive mines. On the other hand, the government can also gain political leverage with each mine that explodes, pointing the finger at the rebels. And until the government and guerrillas prove to the international community that they are ready for peace, international aid to de-mining operations will likely be slow in coming. If the country is still at war, donors see little need for spending money to remove mines that might soon be replaced.

AFRICA NEWS ONLINE, Vol. 41, Issue 9-10. December 1994. All rights reserved. May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast purposes without specific authorization. AFRICA NEWS ONLINE is produced by Africa News Service, a U.S.-based non-profit news agency supplying news and feature reporting to the broadcast and print media.


LOAD-DATE: February 6, 1995


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


December 1, 1994 / December 31, 1994


U.S. POLICY: Africa Aid Cuts Planned, While Clinton Aide Promises Continued Help


BYLINE: Reed Kramer, Africa News Service


SECTION: NEWS


LENGTH: 1054 words


 

Washington, D.C. -- Although top officials in both the Clinton White House and the Republican Congressional leadership have academic backgrounds in African affairs, Africa faces a tough battle in 1995 for shrinking foreign aid resources.

Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the incoming speaker of the House of Representatives and one of the most powerful figures in Washington, wrote his doctoral dissertation on Belgium's colonial policies in what was then the Congo, now Zaire. But his political focus has been largely on domestic issues, and cutting foreign aid is on his party's agenda.

On a nine-day visit to eight African countries in December, National Security Adviser Anthony Lake, President Clinton's top foreign policy aide, tried to ease fears about American intentions. Lake, who wrote his thesis on sanctions against white-ruled Rhodesia, told African leaders that President Bill Clinton cares deeply about Africa's future. 

At the same time, Lake warned that the region "risks becoming the odd man out" in a global economy unless African nations resolve internal disputes, develop responsive governments and promote sustainable development. Levels of U.S. aid to Africa will be influenced, he said, by "shrinking budgets and honest skepticism about the return on our investment."

Key Republicans, including North Carolina Senator Jesse Helms, the new chairman the powerful Foreign Relations Committee, already have proposed substantial cuts in foreign assistance. One approach under discussion is a reduction of the three-year $600 million aid package for South Africa to allow aid levels for other African countries to be maintained without increasing the over-all appropriation for the continent.

Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, who is taking over the subcommittee overseeing foreign aid, has said he has "a hard time finding an American national interest" in Africa. He wants to eliminate the annual appropriation known as the Development Fund for Africa, which totals about $800 million this year and has helped to shield Africa's small share of the foreign aid budget from further erosion.

Funds for peacekeeping also may be cut by Republicans with Angola providing the first test of the new Congress' intentions. A vote to reduce the U.S. contribution to the United Nations expanded operation in support of the recent Angola peace accord could come in the early weeks of the 1995 session.

Any attempt to abolish the Development Fund for Africa and other forms of support for Africa will be resisted by the Congressional Black Caucus, which remains a large voting bloc in the House of Representatives. But the Republican election gains in November have reduced Caucus influence, because all but three of its 41 members are in the Democratic minority. The group's ability to shape legislation may also be affected by a Republican-engineered elimination of congressional funding for all House caucuses, which leaves interest groups scrambling for resources to pay for offices and staff.

Among the string of setbacks, however, has come a victory that Africa advocates on Capitol Hill did not anticipate. Congressional Republicans have decided to retain the House subcommittee on Africa, which had been slated for merger with another subcommittee under a restructuring plan proposed by the old Democratic leadership. In line to head the Africa group is Cuban-American Ileana Ros-Lehtinen of Florida, whose views on African issues are not yet known.

On the Senate side, the Africa subcommittee will be chaired by Nancy Landon Kassebaum of Kansas, who has a lengthy record of interest in African issues. As a member of the subcommittee, she visited Africa, championed Namibian independence, and was a proponent of increased attention to Africa during the Reagan and Bush presidencies.

According to White Hose aide Anthony Lake, the Clinton administration will seek to work with the new Congressional leadership to develop a three-point program for Africa, which will reverse the current ratio of $2 spent on disasters for every dollar spent on development.

First, Lake said, there will be a focus on crisis prevention, using a combination of "traditional relief techniques and new technology." The second emphasis will be on crisis recovery, with special attention to agriculture and to the rebuilding of roads and dams. The third priority, which Lake termed the most important, will be "such long-term challenges as overpopulation, the role of women and environmental decay."

Speaking at the headquarters of the Organization of African Unity in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, Lake said the Clinton foreign policy team rejects "Afro-pessimism," but also seeks to avoid "the illusions of Afro-optimism." Nevertheless, he pronounced himself an optimist about Africa's future, saying that the spread of democracy and a new generation of leaders offers hope for "fulfilling the dreams of Africa's greatness that animated the leaders of its independence so many years ago."

AFRICA NEWS ONLINE, Vol. 41, Issue 9-10. December 1994. All rights reserved. May not be redistributed, posted to any other location, published or used for broadcast purposes without specific authorization. AFRICA NEWS ONLINE is produced by Africa News Service, a U.S.-based non-profit news agency supplying news and feature reporting to the broadcast and print media.

December 1, 1994 / December 31, 1994


THE JOY OF COOKING--AFRICAN STYLE!!


SECTION: ANNOUNCEMENT


LENGTH: 494 words


 

Nearly 200 African culinary masterpieces are made easy in "The Africa News Cookbook," which adapts some of Africa's best cuisines to the utensils in your kitchen and ingredients available in your local supermarket. You will learn how to produce healthy, interesting, tasty dishes ranging from spicy sauces and appetizers to aromatic breads, refreshing salads, flavorful entrees and enticing desserts and beverages.

"The Africa News Cookbook: African Cooking for Western Kitchens" was lovingly compiled and illustrated by our staff and published by Viking Penguin. It's a perfect introduction to African food and hospitality for the novice, and a welcome resource for those who already have sampled Africa's gifts. 

Read a few samples of what cooking professionals and publications have to say about the cookbook:

"This thoroughly fascinating book is as much a Third World history and geography source as an unusual cookbook. If the thought of preparing such exotic dishes seems an imposition on a hot summer day, this spiral-bound book makes for charming reading--at the beach or anywhere."--The Washington Times Magazine

"In giving us this important, joyfully serious cookbook, adapting for us succulent foods from all over the African continent, the Africa News Service also shows us an Africa that, despite its poverty, its conflicts, its diversity, has a talent for hospitality and a perdurable capacity for celebration."--Gourmet Magazine

"A smattering of anthropology, linguistics, culture, economics, mores and folkways accompanies lively and varied recipes culled from across the continent in this attractive African cookbook."--Publisher's Weekly

"Highly evocative of an Africa I know and love. The smoky smells, the amber palm oil, the heaps of exotic vegetables. It's a wonderful feast."--Judith Olney, cookbook author.

The cookbook is a 176 page paperback with perfect binding. The price is $17.00 plus $1.50 shipping and handling. Africa News Service accepts Visa and Mastercard orders. Send your order to:

Africa News Service, Post Office Box 3851, Durham, NC 27702.

Please include a daytime telephone number in case we have questions. Remember to enclose payment or credit card number and expiration date and all address information. Bulk orders are eligible for price discounts.
